reviews.review: Fascinating informative tour. We really enjoyed this audio tour. You could go at your own pace and listen to additional information if you so wished. It was really informative and a very clear easy to listen to recording. You can also ask any of the stewards questions which is quite advisable as the have little gems of information to pass on.It cost £18.50 and we spent about 1.5 - 2 hours there. There was no problem with queues when we went at 10.40 in the morning.

A most enjoyable visit - didnt expect it to be as good as it was.. Spent approaching 2 hours on the visit. Security like at airport which was good to see. We didnt have a guided tour but opted for the audio tour, which I have to say was very good and wasnt disappointed. The guided tour gets the personal touch of course. The audit was very informative and had additional information you can select as you wish as you pass around the building. Building was splendid and full of so much history, many paintings, and many other points of interest, and of course for us House of Lords and Commons were great to enter and take in the atmosphere. Thankfully number of places to rest for a while too, photo opportunities were limited (wasnt allowed in many places at all - which is understandable too). We went around 3ish and was not manic, and cost was £18.50 for an adult (£16 concessions) - was in our opinion a great visit and value, and we learnt a great deal.
Amazing!!. Of course is one of the most important and beautiful building that I have ever seen!!I took lot of pictures there!
Magnificent Architecture. This was one of the best visit in our day tour. Architecture inside as well as outside is marvelous. Spent a good amount of time looking & listening history.
Iconic building . Amazing building and one of the sites of London.Great pictures can be taken from the riverside gardens past the Victoria tower.
A bit pricy but super cool!. I wasn't sure about spending almost 20£ for visiting the parliament. It is a very interesting building and they give the audioguide for free. A place to go!

Excellent Tour. Fantastic couple of hours - one of the best tours that we have taken in London. We took the guided tour rather than the self-directed tour and it was worth it. The guide was knowledgable and had lots of anecdotes to share with us.The tour takes in both the Lords and Commons chambers and lots more in between. Once inside, you have access to the restaurant and bar so you can spend more time inside if you wish. Security checks on entry are similar to those at an airport so it is advisable to plan some time for this. All in all, a really worthwhile couple of hours.

Great tour, if you can stand the queue. The tour is very good, and the houses of parliament themselves are spectacular (and unexpectedly small). For goodness sake, though, get advice on the queue to get in. I waited more than an hour on the ramp into the building, and the queue only seemed to get longer after I joined. Other reviewers may have advice on how to avoid this. First tour in the morning perhaps?

Surprisingly brilliant!. This was a great day out! We loved it and so did the kids. The kids had a different audio guide that really had them engaged. We got to stand in the House of Lords and House of Commons!This was a great family day out in London!

Great for any person interested in history. Parliament was not sittig so we spent about 2 hours touting the Palace of Westmister. It amazed us with its age, the splendor ofits interiors, especially the House of Lords chamber. A great opprtunity, which if available should not be missed. This was certainly a highlight of our visit to London.
Historical and current. A must see. History and current political issues converge in a must interesting tour. Great English guide. Be prepared to walk and stand for 90 minutes.

Way more interesting than I had anticipated. We had a lengthy, thorough, informative and entertaining tour of the Houses of Parliament. Our guide, Sue, seemed to be quite knowledgeable, and, from the snippets I heard from other groups, that appears to be the norm. We walked through the Queen's robing room, along the route she follows to the House of Lords, visited the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Parliament wasn't in session, so we got to walk into the actual parliamentary chambers, rather than up in the visitors' gallery. That's impressive because I'm American and I've never been on the floor in Congress. The tour took well over 90 minutes, but was full of interesting stories, and never got boring. That said, I don't think this tour would have been interesting for anyone under high school age. Although they will appreciate stories like why members of Parliament from opposite parties must stand at least 2.5 sword lengths apart, they have less perspective on why the monarch is not allowed on the floor of the House of Commons. But, this tour was our favorite activity of this trip.

Great guided tour. we undertook the guided tour of Westminster houses of parliament and would thoroughly recommend. A great look behind the scenes, very interesting if you like politics etc. Probably not so interested for children.

Jawdropping. If you're there on a sunny day the glitter of the windows will fascinate you. On a cloudy day it's just as lovely. One really cool way to view the Houses of Parliament is from the London Eye.

Tour decide force. I did the tour as part of a Buy A Gift package and this was the highlight for me.I would recommend the self audio tour because you can go at your own pace and the audio commentary was interesting.The House itself was more than I expected and one felt secure with all the armed Police in attendance.
Heart of London.... Iconic building that every tourist must see when visiting London. You can get amazing view of the House of Parliament from the London Eye or by taking a boat cruise.

A bit like school, just bigger assembly rooms and longer corridors!. One of the grand old men of English history, the architecture inside and out is worth a visit on its own. Certain areas are inaccessible but there is plenty to enjoy, whether on a formal tour or sitting in the gallery or private committee rooms watching our version of democracy at work. If you check out the relevant website, you can find out what is going on and where and whether it is open to the public at large.

Don't Skip Tea. Took the Parliament tour with the family in summer 2016. The tour is fascinating, and worth every penny (pound?) charged. Probably not for young kids, but ages teenage and up will enjoy it. Be prepared to stand and walk for nearly two hours. There is an option to add tea afterwards... DO NOT skip this. When you purchase tickets on-line (and you should), add the option at that time. At the end of the tour, you are escorted to a restaurant that overlooks the Themes, and served tea and appetizers. Do NOT bring your camera... if you try to use it, it will be confiscated and your tour will be over (and I saw this happen - they're not kidding).

Great tour and tea!. Our family enjoyed the 90-minute guided tour of the Palace of Westminster (its official name). Our guide explained the history of the building, the significance of the artwork, and the parliamentary system. It's very interesting, especially to compare the similarities and differences with the US Congress.We also did tea at Parliament afterwards where you sit out on the terrace on the House of Commons side with a view of the Thames. Everything was very tasty and a nice treat after a day of sightseeing.
Excellent tour. Did the audio guided tour. What a lovely place! Very interesting,very good price, well organised. Easy to book online, print tickets at home, simple!

Nice tour. This tour worths your time. Especially if you like history and politics. The tour was a nice experience as it was well organised and during the walk you are getting informed for the historical and political events that took place in UK. Very interesting.
Amazing architecture. The collection of buildings used by the parliamant is massive. Such amazing architecture. Would love to get a look inside if that is ever an option.
Worth it. This tour is so worthwhile doing and has a slightly surreal feel to it as you go through the two houses.

History - Alive and kicking in London!. Easily the most interesting and awe inspiring place you can visit in London. Excellent tour by knowledgeable guides around one of the most iconic buildings in the world. So much history in one place. Fantastic!

Fine dining in House of Lords. During the conference season the public can book a table for lunch in the Peers Dining Room at The House of Lords. The food and service are outstanding and can compete with any fine restaurant in London. The dining room and location are memorable and afterwards you can go to the gift shop to stock up.

Loved it. I like politics and history. I did the guided tour which was very good but a bit rushed as there were a lot of groups going through. I would like to do it again but I would do it with the head set so I could linger longer to view the paintings. I thought it was a terrific thing to do.

The Heart of Westminster. Located at the heart of Westminster this is what attracts millions of people across the Globe. Visible from the London Eye and pretty much the entire area. This is the house of power in London.

Tour. Having done the Tower of London tour and Buckingham palace tour, this particular tour absolutely blew my socks off. So interesting, so much history and some amazing architecture and art work. Fantastic tour guide, so knowledgable, and well organised! Am glad I saw it before the refurb :)

If in London, you have to visit. We actually went online and pre-purchased tickets for a specific time slot - highly recommend doing this. We actually purchased the audio tour which I'd recommend.You have to time, like we did when the Houses weren't in session so we saw a lot. If they are in session it is a whole different process to see the actual House of Commons and Lords. Probably still worth it

order order... we visited the houses of parliament recently, its not overly expensive but was worth it to see for yourself a piece of english history goin back to the medieval times , the entrance hall is full of history where kings and queens lay in state or where famous people met the queen, the exact spot being marked with a notice plate for each person ,nelson mandela being one. walking thru the commons chamber and the lords was very surreal after seeing it so many times on tv, it struck me at being quite small the commons anyway, it has to hold 650 mp,s, if they all turn up on the same day it wouldn't be able to accomadate them, but its a great way to spend an afternoon, seeing all that history was so cool.prices in souvenier shop and café are not to bad either , would be a good way of spending a rainy afternoon.

Houses of History. The beautiful buildings of the Houses of Parliament stand out, soaring in to the sky above London like a beacon with Big Ben as its torch. The historic decisions made in these hallowed halls have impacted on the rest of the World over the many years they have been standing and the grandeur is on display from every angle. In London the Spires of the Houses of Parliament can be seen from the River Thames and from the nearby places of interest like Big Ben, Westminster Abbey and the Tower of London - historic beauty on display.
Halls of Power. This is one of the iconic halls of power in the world that can be witnessed from the road itself. There is a tour of the place for people who are interested.

We highly recommend touring the Houses of Parliament. We were thinking this would be similar to a tour of the US House and Senate. It was so much more! The buildings are filled with stories and art from the rich history of England. Fascinating!

Visit to the House of Lords. We were very fortunate to have a guided tour of the House of Lords by a Peer. It was an eye opening experience and I would recommend to anyone that had a similar opportunity to take it.The history and splendour was amazing

A Step into History. We took the audio tour and found it fascinating and of course the building itself is beautiful. I especially loved the statues of the great men we've read about in history books and seeing where the laws are actually made.

Another Democracy on View. The UK has a royal family and a Queen who appears once a year in Parliament The discussion of how and why the queen appears, how laws are developed and passed, the balance of power between the House of Commons and House of Lords, plus views of the extraordinary beauty of the building, make this a terrific visit.
Great tour. Enjoyed a tour of the Palace of Westminster. Really good and interesting. Tiring as no real opportunities to sit down.
Guided tour. We opted fit the official parliament guided tour as opposed to the audio tour, and it was very informative and interesting.
Order in the house.. This is well worth a visit, not cheap, but London is not cheap. Tour guide very good and knows her stuff.

Beautiful Architecture . The architecture of this building is amazing. Well looked after and so clean, it's a must to see if you are visiting London, if only to marvel at the intricacies of the sculpting from the outside!

Don't miss it!. So I ended up going here on my last day in London. My fiancé and I went back and forth about whether it would be worth the money(I believe around £30/person). Turns out it was one of our favorite things that we did. The building itself is stunning. You can't really get a scope of the size until you're inside. They do a fantastic job with the guided audio tours. Quite a few points of interest along the way and you certainly leave feeling like you've learned something. Make sure to plan ahead as tickets are only available for the tour when parliament isn't in session. Sidenote: you also get a unique view of Big Ben from the courtyard that the general public doesn't.

Take the Audio Tour. A very informative and fascinating audio tour around the main working parts of Parliament. If you listen to the 'extra information' available on the tour it takes 2 hours but is fascinating. Highly recommended when you have 2 hours to spare on a day out in London. A memorable experience and I'm really looking forward to the next Prime Ministers Questions session.
beautiful building, spoiled by the contents. This is a really lovely building, it's just a shame it's used by some real dregs in society. Could be put to better use

Great Guided Tour. Very informative, and well worth the money. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable, full of historic facts and figures and kept you interested. She also answered questions, was clear and concise.

Nice to see. Well to me it's a building with power and these people inside make all the decisions. But regardless of politics it's a landmark and a beautiful building well worth a walk past and a Wee picture to be taken.

A treat. Ok I am a nerd but this was great! You have to buy the tickets over the road near the river anted then stand in a queue and go through security but it is worth it. You have to either have a guided tour or an audio tour - even if you don't want to listen to it. Personally It was extremely interesting and worth the cost.
Amazing Houses of Parliament. My visit to the Houses of Parliament was amazing. It is steeped in history and the building is really beautiful with intricate architecture and pictures.

Very informative . Great visit. We enjoyed this visit very much. We were surprised how much access you are given on the visit. You can't help but be impressed. This is worth the visit. It's not too expensive and the tour is as long as you make it. Step into the footsteps of some of the greats. Fantastic buildings. You have to visit here if you are doing the London circuits.

Enjoyed every min of it. Loved every bit of the tour. The guide issac was great, very knowledgeable.the building is stunning, but houses smaller than on telly, I would go back, loved it. Westminster hall breath taking

A must visit if you in London. Tick it off your list. Go for the guided tour as its very worth it. Great to see inside Parliament. Beautiful buildings. Just wish it included seeing base (as least ) of Big Ben

Fantastic event showcasing Birmingham St Mary's Hospice Satellite Project. Thank you so much for welcoming us to this fabulous capital building. Birmingham came to London to ask for your help and support

Brilliant Tour and Afternoon Tea. Another wonderful and enjoyable guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, followed by a lovely afternoon tea in the grandeur of the members riverside terrace overlooking the River Thames.
Treated ourselves to a glass of champagne a brilliant finish to a lovely afternoon, definitely not to be missed.

An absolute must!. Part of our tourist week in London, we booked a full guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, with a human being taking us round, not an audio guide!Quite simply, best thing we did in London all week.Not only did we cover the history of the building and of the United Kingdom, but also how the whole politcal system works in our country, in very simple terms!We got to see the House of Lords and the House of Commons.We must have spent the best part of 3 hours there.Go and see it soon, before they move out for the major refurb, which is desperately needed it seems behind the scenes, but you wouldnt know it walking round.Just a brilliant afternoon and especially when you tie it in with a Thames river cruise as well, which you get from right outside.Highly recommended.
Historic. This historic location is majestic when seeing it live. Security is extreme, but it is so massive and the architecture so brilliant, it makes for a great stop and better pictures.

Did the guided audio tour.... We decided to splurge a bit (it was pricey - over 20 pounds per person) and do the guided audio tour w/headphones. They also have English guided tours but they are slightly more expense and times didn't match up with our schedule.The House of Lords and House of Commons inside were very interesting and it was very educational learning more about the history of Britain's parliament and government. History and politics are of interest to me so it was worth the price of admission. If these topics aren't of interest, you may find the price of admission on the high side.

Lots to Learn Here!. We happened on this tour by accident, but it turned out to be one of the highlights of our trip. We used the audio tour, but asked lots of questions as we made our way. The staff was very helpful and knowledgeable. There is renovation going on, but we were still able to see everything. The story of the Queen's visit to open the session is extremely interesting.

Parliament guided tour was the way to go. We saw the Houses of Parliament through a guided tour, where the guide walked us through whitehall, house of lords and house of commons. Tour was totally worth it as she explained each chamber, how it functions, peppered with some anecdotes of these rooms steeped in history.
Awesome Architecture. A brilliant experience. There was a high police presence, which is to be expected .The Building does need to renovation but still very prominent

Excellent guided tour. Thank you Sean for a very informative tour of the Houses of Parliament on Thursday 22 Sept 2016. Quite an amazing place. The tour is approx 1.5hrs long and the inside of the building is amazing. Only downside was that there was only one opportunity to rest your legs and we rushed past a number of paintings in the corridors that may have been worthy of a look.. Maybe if we had done this tour with the headphones we could have sat down a bit more often and taken in the pictures. Having said that Sean made the tour very interesting, thank you

disappointed guided tour. I did a tour on Saturday 17th of September at 4:15 pm, and I felt that I had been fooled.The tour was in my mother language, not in English, with an insecure guide with a very poor and superficial knowledge.Better option an audio tour.
Part of the London's skyline. Another attractive landmark of London next to the towering Big Ben! Amazing buildings considering the time when they were built

GUIDED TOUR OF HOUSES OF PARLIAMENT. This was the best tour I have ever been on. This building is so amazing. From the ceiling to the floor there are pictures, statues and artefacts which completely fill the entire building. I did the guided tour and was so impressed with the history of this building. I really do recommend it.
Go inside . Many visitors must look at the outside but you can go in, free of charge. Security is tight, as you might expect, but to watch parliament in session is surreal.

A wonderful tour. We booked a guided tour and we saw and learnt so much mostly due to our very knowledgeable guide, Richard.History of the actual buildings and the development of British democracy from Norman times was covered.The workings of Parliament and the monarch's role were explained beautifully.Tour lasts two hours and was well worth the money paid.

Very interesting tour. I booked a tour with a guide. He was very knowledgeable. We visited the Houses of Commons and Lords and saw where the queen gives her annual speech. There are amazing pictures and rooms throughout.
london trip. Day trip to London and took the tour and was very nice, its well worth the money, all my group had a good time
Lovely. The Houses of Parliament are lovely architectural sites. They are very photogenic, and they are recognizable!

Get the tour!. I remember coming here in 2007 and as the youngest in the group, I got to sit in the voting chair and count everyone through. A fantastic experience and I have enjoyed coming back to visit, especially recently. Currently got scaffolding all over it though
Great. Wow what a remarkable looking building it was good to stand and see such a historic building well worth going to see

Learn all about the old customs of British democracy!. The guided tour starts in the impressive medieval Westminster Hall and leads you through the House of Lords and House of Commons. Behold the woolsack. Highly recommended and very interesting!

Tourist trap but still worth seeing. We have all seen images of the Houses of Parliament but when you are there you realise just how huge this building is. It is overrun with tourists but it's one where u have to tick the box!
Parliament grounds. Nice to walk around these grounds, beautiful area of London. Just like we've seen on television all those years
It house's parliament. If you have ever wondered what a house full of hot air looks like look no further go to the Houses of parliament

Amazing architecture and interior.. Went inside the houses of lords at a reception, what a magnificent building it is, I love architecture and interiors so wherever I go that is the first thing I see, this is one of my favourite buildings in London, and Big Ben being photographed by every turist that steps in london, is a famous landmark, so much history. I love the art inside, there is also a lovely gift shop with trinkets from london and the building.

Do the guided tour!. There is entirely too much information to not do the guided tour. JoAnn was our guide and she was so enthusiastic about the history of the Parliament, that I could have spent all day in there! She walked us through the Houses with adequate stops so we could look around and take in all the beauty.

Tour followed by lunch at House of Lords terrace. A two hour guided tour around the House of Lords and House of Commons , with our guide David , fantastic , while the house MP's were in recess / holiday , followed by lunch on the lords terrace, great food , great back drop, great staff , treated likely royalty, for normal people , excellent weather with the river view in famous settings .
Beautiful. Such beautiful buildings! Take the tour bus so you can get great pictures and information on all the sights to see!

A wonderful visit inside. After watching the Big Ben and House of Parliaments from its outside in my last visits, this time I decided to take a tour inside and I am glad I did.There are options of taking an audio or personally guided tour. Need to book in advance and option of eticketing is better as collection point is different from tour starting point. I changed mine from collection to eticket.Guides are informative. Hearing the time tell traditions, stories of monarchy versus the parliament, standing in houses of common and lords, admiring the ornate halls, voting for ayes and nays - all are an experience to be enjoyed. Pictures are allowed only inside the main hall. Tours takes a total of two hours and happen when parliament is not in session. Tours for residents can even be arranged through their MP's for free it seems and they can even view the debates.Overall an informative enjoyable visit for us outsiders.

Breathtaking. The houses of parliament have to be seen. Gold, gold, gold...and the history! There is an audio tour which is very good. But the beautiful architecture, decorative furniture and ornate walls and ceilings have to be seen. You also get a good feel for the long-standing tradition of English parliament and how It evolved through the generations of royals. We booked online, but you can get a ticket on the day. We went late afternoon and the crowds were minimal. We spent a couple of hours in this tour. Easy to get to, right near Westminster tube.

Fabulous Lunch in Peers' Dining Room. The public can book lunch in the Peers' and MPs dining rooms on a limited number of days a year, see parliaments website for dates. You must book in advance. I visited the Peers' Dining Room on 22.9.16, cost £45 3 courses includes tea/coffee. A glass of champagne was £10, a glass of port £3.50. Whoever books must take photo I'd with them (passport, driving license).The dining room is beautiful and there were many portraits of historical figures on the walls, a portrait of queen Elizabeth 1st was particularly striking. The sense of history is amazing.The food was delicious and perfectly presented. The staff were very friendly and most had been working at Westminster Palace for many years, their experience showed, we had an exceptionally high level of customer service.I took my mother as a treat. We were both thrilled to have access the the Peer's Dining Room and this was a fabulous lunch.I will definitely come again and highly recommend this event.

Must See in London - Guided Tour of the Houses of Parliament. Make plans to take the personal guided tour (as opposed to using recorded head sets) of the Houses of Parliament. Reserve tickets in advance on the internet. The tour takes about 2 hours and is all standing and walking on hard floors but worth every breathtaking minute. The gilt and majesty are eye-popping. The guides are knowledgeable and make the experience come alive. A must tour!

Mother of our Parliament. Any Australian visiting London should visit if possible (not open for tours when in session) to see how our parliamentary system came into being and to understand why it works the way it does. We enjoyed the audio tour on our own and could spend as little or as much time in each area that we wanted.Money much better spent than going on the London Eye which we did earlier.

Wonderful opportunity to Government debate.. Visited for the day to listen to the reading of the Marris Bill on Assisted Dying. Debate lasted all day; all ministers, for and against, the Bill demonstrated that they had listened carefully to their constituents views. Members spoke passionately and logically citing examples of those in support and opposition. Very interesting to observe members hard work closely. I met our local MP and his team who were very hospitable. I purchased wine for my husband in the shop, it has the House of Commons logo on it. Magnificent building, beautiful chapel. Unable to book an available tour. Will certainly return.

Another Must See when in London.. Houses of Parliament are architectural masterpieces steeped in history. As with any iconic landmark you will get more out of the experience if you take a tour. Bring your camera!

Tour of Parliament. Very interesting inside look at how the British conduct their governmental business. As you might expect there are many parallels to the USA but it was quite interesting to see the differences and get a chance to view the beautiful building with all of its history. No pictures allowed unfortunately. You can self guide with an audio headset but the personal guides allow you to ask and get answers to many more questions. The interactive nature is definitely worth the price differential. Surprisingly enough, when Parliament is in session visitors are allowed to walk up to the gate and request from the guards the opportunity to watch the members in action. If there is room in the gallery, they will let you in.
Houses of Parliament. Leave time before scheduled entry to clear security procedures with move swiftly and courteously. Fascinating to visit and definitely worth booking.
Get a tour guide. Get a tour guide and visit. Just breathe in the history. Ask lots of questions and find out why it is that the Monarch cannot enter the House of Commons!

Boring. You're rushed around, not allowed to take pictures of a box or sit down. Our tour guide was as quiet as a mouse; not good when crammed into a room with five other tour groups. I couldn't even sip water in fear of a police officer throwing me off the site.The bathroom was nice though.
Get a guide. Fascinating place. Guide was excellent, and building was amazing. It must be preserved! Still Summer recess, so unfortunately didn't see any MPs!

Outstanding Lunch at the House of Commons. I have to say, the quality of the food far outweighed any expectation I may have had. I have eaten in some truly fine places but this is right up there! Well done to all for attentive staff and fantastic food!

Truely amazing impression of democrasy. You might need an invitation by a local MP .... but if you get a chance this is a must. There is a tour through the house of parliament and you can watch a live discussion .... amazing

Fascinating tour. Really interesting visit, led by a genuine cockney Parliamentary Guide, Richard Tilling, with a great sense of humour.He was very enthusiastic and knowledgeable. Could have done with some 'free time' to look more closely at the exhibits in each location, but time was necessarily limited.Having had the official tour, I naively tried to go back in to look myself in a more leisurely fashion but, sadly, this isn't allowed.
Lots and lots of houses. This is a big strevh of london to cover if you want to see all houses.... they are all beautiful. Dont forget to put on some confortable shoes begore you head this way.

AUDIO TOUR. We did the audio tour of the HOP and found this very interesting. The place is well worth a visit and I think that the admission price is reasonable considering what there is to see. The place is stunning and heaped in history. Really enjoyed our visit..

Interested in history and politics? Go there!. We arrived around 11pm and bought an audio tour for 18p as the next guided tour would not be avaliable until 4pm on a friday which was a bit surprising... However the audio guide was easy to use and allowed you to go about in your own pace.At the time we went some restoration and reparation was going on which made the order in which you were supposed to walk in and use the audio tour a bit confused.Despite of this it was a very enjoyable and fascinating tour as the architecture of the building is phenomenal and you can really strongly feel the historic atmosphere of the place. It was particularly impressive to see the statues of former PM's, the house of commons and the house of lords in real life.

Stunning!. We've been to London a few times and past the Houses of Parliament, but this is the first time we've ventured inside. To say that the "Palace of Westminster" is impressive is a serious understatement - even for the British. The audio tour recounts the incredible history of the various rooms and chambers with all sorts of details and stories. Because parliament was not in session, we were allowed to walk on the very debate floors of both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The architecture and furnishings throughout the building are nothing short of amazing. Treat yourself and don't miss this icon of democracy

Brilliant. I visited the Grand Hall and the old chapel as part of Open House London. Both are brilliant for different reasons. The hall has a nice charm and lots of history. The renovated chapel is simply stunning. Allocate 90 minutes for a visit.
Great place to visit. Great place to visit, but you need to have an organised tour to get in and this normally means getting to know your MP or been in an organisation that can organise a tour.

Perfect for people who like history, politics or beautiful buildings. I think this is greatly underrated as a tourist destination but it is probably the best for anyone who like history or politics.We took an audio guide for £18 pp (that's the cheapest way to get inside and go around) and you are allowed to go at your own pace around the place. Very informative and hugely impressive, you just feel the history as you walk around in all of the paintings, the carvings and statues of past PMs. There's also something really charming about seeing the MPs pigeon holes, the committee lists with some names we know and, of course, seeing the boxes that so many leaders of the opposition and PMs have leaned against.I also have to say that the police and tour guides working inside were incredibly friendly and helpful. Obviously they know it's a day out for us but was really nice that they all seemed to take a genuine interest.

Interesting to see inside but need to make tour more engaging. Yes, this is a great tour around both the Houses of Parliament. Well worth while going and great value for money. The tour guide we had was very knowledgeable with historical facts and had a great speaking voice that carried to the group of about 20-25 on the tour. But I'm sorry to say it all became a bit dull. The use of stories and anecdotes could really set the magnificent history of the place alight. Also, there were too many guided groups in close proximity - often we could not physically manoeuvre around them, or concentrate on what our guide was saying as the one next to us was also speaking loudly to their group. That all said, I would recommend it.

A very informative guided tour. On a very hot September afternoon this was an oasis of fascinating history. The Commons chamber is surprisingly small, considering there are 650 MPs but the Lord's even more so as there are 810 of them!The entire building , whilst impressive, obviously needs a lot of work, which is currently under debate, some minor work is currently under way, but it will have to be closed for some time, so do visit now if you can.

Intriguing history behind the seat of British Empire. We took an audio tour of the parliament building, and it was interesting to visit the building and both chambers of the houses. The neo-gothic architecture both inside out is beautiful, and various halls and lobby are richly adored. However, I do wish the audio guide focus more on the architecture of each hall/room. The actual chambers are quite intimate in space, it's amazing this is where all the decision making process took place for the British Empire a century ago. It took us half an hour to find the ticket office which is far away from the entrance, across street, which is very confusing. There are not many people inside for the tour which was nice.
excellent. given a tour of the house of commons and of the house of lords, brilliant, worth booking in advance, even get to stand at the box of the leader of the opposition.

Must-see touristic spot . Well, there's no arguing is there? Have to see Houses of Parliament and the Big Ben. Not only one of the most influential political centres of the world, they are also beautiful!

School reunion dinner in Houses of Parliament...what a venue!. 2oo of us at a reunion dinner including excellent, knowledgeable and personable guided tour of the buildings.The overall evening was brilliant because the venue and company were excellent but very few staff were pleasant and the meal was as sparse as it could get away with...with a hefty price tag. No-one enjoyed the white wine (it was truly terrible) but the red was ok. The food was acceptable but we were all hungry again by 11 !!!I think they cash in on the beautiful surroundings and history of the venue and provide a very mediocre standard in all other areas...bar the tours...which were fantastic.

Fascinating. I took the audio guided tour and it was imformative and gave you options to learn about other things than just the main areas eg trials that have happened there. The actual building themselves are magnificent although a couple of areas were cordened off due to ongoing repairs. I thought i knew a fair bit about politics but i learnt a lot. The commentary is mostly up to date with current job holders although no mention of teresa may! A really worthwhile although pricey trip. You can get a free tour if you contact your own mp as its part of their jobs to show people around.
Beautiful. What can be said that hasn't bee said before. It is quite obvious that the House of Lords had/has more money, but the effect is stunning.

Im sure it looked better during the Great Fire of London!!. Awful!!Just don't go!!The amount of rats, pigeons, pigeon poop,and mice I have seen scuttling across the outside and the inside is diabolical!Its quite literally a health hazard!If you value your health....DONT GO!!!

Try to see it when in London.. Try to visit this when in London. But expect to wait in line for a quite long time. If you hate ques avoid this. Not suitable for kids. You need to stand in more than one que, before you are inside..

Must visit. From the outside it is a beautiful building, whose best view, however, enjoy the other side of the Thames, while the tourists flock mainly to the bridge connecting the two banks for photographing the Bin Well, that alone is worth the trip to London.

Fabulous tour. The guided tour of the Houses of Parliament is a must for a visitor of London to do, it provides an insight into the history, traditions and roles of both the Houses. The tour lasts about 1.5 hours. You can if you wish just use an audio guide
Fascinating experience. Totally lived up to expectation the only disappointing thing being that all tickets for Elizabeth Tower are sold not until it is closed for refurb

Right in the heart of London. A visit is recommended if you visit London. It's amazing to see how the House of Lords and House of Commons work hand in hand. The architecture is beautiful and there is so much to see. Sat in the gallery of both houses and observed the sessions. A great experience, one that I will cherish forever.

Historical. Wow factor. We were lucky enough to have a MP give us a tour. He met us after security and took us through Parliament. Because this was Thursday and scheduled for early session we did not have to opportunity to visit the floor of the House of Commons. We were able to visit the floor of the House of Lords. We sat in the gallery of the House of Commons and our watched the discussion. Our gracious host spoke. I can't imagine the US senators and representatives engaging is that type of discourse.The history of Westminster hall is thrilling.

Politics in a different country . This was by far one of my favorite tours. We really enjoyed learning about how government as we know it came about in England. It was so neat learning about politics in The United Kingdom and how the pomp and circumstances have not really changed over the years. It felt surreal being there. Fantastic!

Well worth the time. We visited Parliament for the first time even though we have visited London for several years. We opted for the guided tour with a human instead of the audio files. This made the tour very fun and interesting. The adages the guides can give as you walk around Westminster Palace are priceless. I recently heard the facility may be closed for a multiple year renovation. If you plan on visiting London in the near future you ought to make this a stop.

Refunds. Please be aware that if you book tickets beforehand for this tour and you have to cancel due to circumstances outwith your control, refunds are not given. I booked this tour for a party of 3 people and due to easyJet cancelling our outbound flight from Inverness, with no notice given, we could not travel. I contacted the tour organisation and I was informed the tickets are non-refundable and they are unable to change the tour date.

Beautiful architecture!. Beautiful building! Although there was some construction and maintenance going on at the time of my visit, I was still able to appreciate the marvelous architecture of this building!
Cool tour. If you love political history, this is a great tour to take. I especially love the oldest part of the building and the chambers (much smaller than they look on TV!).
Wonderful Learning Opportunity. Enjoyable tour hosted by a knowledgable, enthusiastic guide. Make sure to book prior to your arrival. The guided tour is worth it.

Think everyone should visit once in their lives. There is a que but its worth the wait. Annoyingly people looking very important start walking to the front of the que and its quite funny when some are turned back! I really like the shop its got some lovely gift ideas. I love the House of Commons mints and they are packaged beautifully
Put this on your list.. This is a wonderful place to go to. You can also have a guided tour that is great. The history of this place is wonderful.

Great. These with the Big ben form the postcard pics of the London tourism. Well maintained and an enormous structure. Great for the pics even at night. They even allow you to go inside for free at the night when the parliament debates are going on.

A thoroughly interesting insight into the working of Parliament, excellent tour.. Excellent tour of the Houses of Paliament. Gave a great insight into the workings of political life. If you visit nowhere else, visit here.

Great addition in London. I was not aware that the Houses of Parliament were open to the general public.I was generally aware of the layout, but I had no idea that the Palace of Westminster was well preserved and so magnificent.Full of British History. The complementary Audio is invalableA great visit and well worth it .I would also recommend the Imperial War Museum, which is without entry fee!

Take time to look at entire beautiful building!. You may walk, or drive past this beautiful building, but suggest you take time to really look carefully at what you see. It is also referred to as the House of Commons on one section-so much detail, so don't over look this treasure!

If you can, do.. I did not know it was possible to tour the Palace of Westminster. Such a surprise to walk past and see tickets for sale. Couldn't get my hands on one fast enough. Only available at certain times, so check. I did not think the interior could possible top the iconic exterior, but it did. What an outstandingly beautiful place. This was a real highlight for me. Security understandably very tight.
Atmospheric venue. Met an MP in the grounds of The House & were taken for tea on The Terrace. What a treat to sit where many powerful politicians have sat to discuss world affairs.

Amazing - Don't look real. The houses of Parliament are an impressive site, they look almost toy like but they are an absolute beautiful and amazing structure and well worth heading across if in South bank to the area.

Get your MP to give you a tour. This is a wonderful building to visit as it has such a long history and some of the most iconic architecture to view. You can ask your MP for a visit. I have been there for receptions and lucky enough to be invited there for lunch. Our local MP held a reception for local constituents and a tour which was super.
Excellent . This was my second time there and it still impressed me, absolutely steeped in British history as you would expect, highly recommend going.

Prime minister questions time . Our wonderful MP for Merton has provided lots of opportunity for her constitutes to tour the Houses of Parliament and to sit in on priminister questions time. View the old and historical parts and understand how your MP sends their day. My favourite is the opulent chapel with gold carvings. It's free and eventful for all ages.

Attended an afternoon meeting in a Committee Room. Shocking. Pitched up at 3.35 for a 4pm meeting and it took 45 to 50 minutes to get past security. I was 30 minutes late for the meeting. More important people kept walking past in the fast lane. Let's hope Theresa May really will stand up for the ordinary person in the future!

Limitless showcase of what the parliament offers. With great attention from the staff, once you go into parliament you see everything that is there, as well as having an explanation of what every place represents. Both houses and every highly decorated hall in between.

The heart of British democracy. The history and the stature of the Houses of Parliament are really brought into focus visiting them. They are certainly worth visiting and the impressive architecture of the time is a sight to see.

Beautiful building and it was fascinating to see how our governement works. Interesting to see behind the scenes of our government. So much of our history has happened there...and its still being made.Good audio guides both adult and children. Our teenage daughter was fascinated too. One bizarre fact from the young peoples guide ...the speaker's chair is designed with curtains...in the past if the speaker wanted to leave to house to go to the loo the proceedings had to stop ...so they would draw the curtains and make lots of noise while he ...!Few places to sit down so if that is a problem you need to be aware.Book online in advance to avoid the queues.Did you know that your MP can sometimes arrange free visits? No nor did we!! But I don't expect it will include the audio guide

Interesting Visit - worth the trip. We really enjoyed the tour here, the guide was brilliant and actually worked there too, we managed to get free tickets by contacting our local MP. Was definitely worth the trip, particularly if you like history, highly recommend it.

The interior is stunning. I signed up for the tour of the Houses of Parliament. I was not expecting the inside to be so beautiful. The tour was good. Very informative. It took almost 1 1/2 hours. I couldn't believe how grand the interior was! It is a must see. Very glad that I did. There is an audio tour that seemed to be available. It is probably cheaper and you can go at your own pace. Had I known about it, I might have chosen that.
Unique experience. Westiminster palace is an amazing sight one has to visit. I advice you book your visit because there is a big queue.

English Parliament home. The English house of parliament is so large of a structure goes beyond description. It's immensity is hard to take and close up some of the best views are on the Thames river. Where you can view how large it is from a distance.One of the absolute most important structures in London
Great. From the other side you'll have the best view! Very good time is dawn it looks perfect than! And if your hungry, a MC Donalds is right behinde your back 😉

A time in history . Our first time at Parliament was on one of the wettest and busy days ever,we queued in the rain for 60mins but it was well worth getting wet.
To see the House of Lords and House of Commons where all the lords and members of parliament sit was amazing,thanks for a wonderful visit.

Beautiful buildings. We had a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, which I loved. We were taken right into the heart of the Parliament, where we saw the Queen's Robing Room and the House of Lords. We visited the House of Commons, where we were taken right into the Chamber. We were shown the designated seats for each of the parliamentary parties, and saw the table with despatch box and microphones, where the Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition take their places. In each of the rooms, we were given interesting pieces of information by our guide, including some of the quirky customs that are still in use today. There is a tearoom, providing opportunity for refreshment at the end of the tour. I enjoyed this tour so much, I would even do it again.
Decent 2hours. Went there on audio tour and it was interesting and informative with earphones commentary. Wasn't overly busy and staff were non intrusive... worth seeing and reasonably priced

Interesting place to visit. Somewhere you see on TV and never think you'll ever get to see in real life, well I was wrong! The audio tour is very interesting and is included within a standard ticket for the visit (I think the guided tours weren't any more but you need to wait for them to join the next scheduled tour on the day). Interesting to learn about the history behind parka men and the monarchy as well as the mechanics behind the House of Lords and House of Commons!The cafe is clean and not overly priced and was a welcome place to have a drink afterwards! Well worth a visit...

Living History. My wife and I were very glad we took this tour. The palace is filled with history and continues to make history. The architecture is spectacular. We toured the rooms we have seen on tv for many years. We also learned that the House of Lords has the duty to "scrutinize" legislation. Many of these people were awarded peerage because of their outstanding accomplishments, so their talent is appreciated.After touring all the major rooms, we also went out on the balcony overlooking the Thames for an English afternoon tea. All very enjoyable and memorable.

Excellent audio tour - for both adults and kids. We decided to do this tour on a rainy Saturday. We booked online. The queue to get in moved very very slowly. When eventually in, we collected our audio guides. If you have younger children, get the kids audio guide - it is fantastic - and keeps them interested for the entire tour. It is also very interesting for adults - would highly recommend it.

Beautifully set besides the thames. Beautiful building along the Thames river adds to the mesmerizing beauty of the place. A bit far from the tube stations, but you dont mind the walk along the Thames.

Informative tour . Touring the Houses of Parliament was fascinating. Getting to actually stand where big decisions are made day in day out was incredible. The tour is well worth the fee, which was less than £20.

Well worth a visit. Took my son on a guided tour and it was excellent. Well organised and the guide Barry was very informative and helpful. As well as seeing a number of rooms we were given a really useful insight into the history of the building and heard a number of witty anecdotes which prevented the tour being too 'dry'. Tour lasted an hour and three quarters. Made use of the onsite coffee shop afterwards which had a good range of snacks and drinks at reasonable prices.

Interesting. Visiting a House of Parliament is not usually on my list of must-see attractions however there is so much history linked to this building that I just had to go. The building in itself is impressive and worth the visit.

LOVED. DEFINITELY don't miss a tour here (especially because I read they are thinking of closing it for SIX years to do major refurbishment starting in 2020). Was such an impressive audio tour and made EVEN better by high tea on the Thames right after! Book the tour + tea!!

Fantastic experience. Had a tour of the Houses of Parliament and was able to sit in on a debate and have a drink on the terrace overlooking the river. The staff we encountered were unfailingly polite and helpful, from the police officers on duty outside to the Doorkeepers in the House itself. A wonderful opportunity to experience a world famous institution, which I would highly recommend to anyone visiting the capital.
Nice building. I love building, this is the same. It's nice and it is an icon for London, than it is worth to see it. And it is close to Westminster Abbey.
Beautiful building. This is one of my favourite buildings in London. Big Ben Is attached to it! Worth the look in the day and at night as it is beautiful. Must see when in london

So Much History..!. My partner and I both visited the Houses of Parliament on a lovely Friday afternoon in September this being our first visit.We had arranged a guided tour via our local MP Boris Johnson and we were very pleased with the experience overall and are definitely looking to go again soon.Very quick and efficient airport style security checks are in place when you arrive.Our tour was booked for 4:30pm and we arrived slightly early, but there is still quite a bit to do here, we were called exactly on the dot and introduced to our expert and cockney tour guide Mick, a very pleasant, knowledgeable and funny guy, this was an excellent way to discover many behind the scene historical facts which you would never ever have likely found out otherwise.Overall a trip to be definitely recommended.

It has to be the most honorable place in UK, but it was the most terrible.. I visited on 30th June 2016, for watching Westminster Hall debates. I entered to central lobby after I waited for 20~30 minutes in St. Stephan Hall. It is required to have a green ticket(not the first one from the Cromwell entrance) that the staff managing St. Stephan Hall distributes. At that time, I didn't know that and was not given the ticket but allowed to enter to central lobby. At the next room, I got restricted to proceed even though I explained that I had waited half an hour in St. Stephan Hall. Got back to St. Stephan Hall, the staff who had told me to go to central lobby didn't say a word to explain the situation, even he pretended to not seeing me before and ignored me. The other staff from central lobby told me that I had to wait another half an hour starting from the very queue that I had just waited in. They, who work in Westminster Palace where Parliament that is the most representative of UK is situated, just insulted me. I got humiliated in that place, they just ruined the image of UK and it was very dishonorable behavior. They should be more responsible to the visitors overseas.

The Heart of the British Government. The exterior is clearly a Landmark. But, when Parliament isn't in session (summer and Saturdays the rest of the year), you can book tickets in advance for a tour. You'll get to see both Houses, as well as the remaining part of Westminster Palace. It takes about 90 minutes and shouldn't be missed.

An awesome view. Such a stunning building and you can walk so close, take pictures and find Big Ben at the end. Head to the park by the river for a view down the terrace. If your into architecture or history it is a visit you have to make and you are sure to see some famous political faces if you pick a day when houses are in session.

Worth visiting. Not with little kids, but a great insight in to the workings of government. And it's a free! Be prepared for long queues and security checks. I'd advise checking the schedule of debates first as some big issues can get very crowded.

A majestic building. Since the 11th history, when the first royal palace was built here, this location was important for the public life in Britain. It became the home of the England’s Parliament in the 16th century and the present (the New Palace) was built after the great fire destroyed the Old Palace. The Palace of Westminster, which is the official name, is a landmark of the city, an imposing sight, a Gothic building, which is best seeing from the river Thames or the Westminster bridge.

Amazing access. Tour was led by a really knowledgeable guide who clearly loved what he was doing. Was really impressed by the level of access. Tour takes you into both chambers where you can stand by the benches. Lords chamber in particular is very impressive. The whole interior is very impressive and historic. There is a well stocked gift shop and cafe at the end of the tour. Recommend.
Impressive. Very great architecture. Impressive building. Huge part of the british history and tradition. It is a must see
You can feel the history in the air. Fantastic private tour of the Houses of Parliament - highly recommend if you can book. Recommend going to the Sports Bar while it is still open!

The Houses of Parliament. One of London's many famous landmarks to have on your holiday agenda when visiting the UK. Make sure your mobile is fully charged, as you'll be taking quite a lot of video. Its not just the Parliament building that takes your breathe away, there are quite a few Iconic statues to take in too. A few hrs will be needed....Enjoy the experience.
What a piece of architecture!. It looked amazing work of architecture on a bright sunny day. A must see for anyone visiting London.

Historical, Interesting and excellent value. The Mother of all Parliaments is how it is referred to and quite rightly so. The outside of the building is well known to all no matter from what country you live in and from the number of tourists busy taking photographs you can see why the Houses of Parliament is a popular tourist attraction. A tour of the HOP is well worth doing as it reveals so much more than the outside. First book your tour. So easy to do with a very easy website and very efficient. Saves queuing. Usual security checks (airport style ) to go through but the security service are polite, helpful and of course very efficient. Once you get through the checks you enter through Westminster Hall. Here you pick up your audio guide and the rest of the tour is then done at your own pace. The audio guide is excellent. Very informative as you move your way through with extra information if you desire it. The corridors, hallways, rooms and eventually debating chambers pack a sense of history, style and an overwhelming feeling of 'wow'. The grandeur of the House of Lords, the magnificient gilded screen behind the throne is is contrast to the plainness of the House of Commons. Standing at the despatch boxes gazing at the opposing benches brings out the "politician or the comedian!" in you. ( I've had an email from Sandra in Conway who wants to know why her local buses are not running on time?) At this point I should be shouting Order, Order. The debates are televised and we are familiar with the chambers but the one thing that we don't see is how small they are. The Houses of Parliament tour is money well spent and very cheap compared to the London Eye. Well worth doing and a highlight of my visit to the Capitol.

The House of Pariament, Still a Palace. this icon is still a Palace today, it is known as the Palace of Westminster, it is still a palace because the reigning Monarch still has a room there although it is the Houses of Parliament its full title is The Palace of Westminster & The Houses of Parliament, it is a grand building which sits alongside the River Thames

Get a good guide and this is a magnificant experience. The Houses of Lords and the Parliament are open whenever these bodies are not in session. It's well worth a visit. The guides are all very experienced. No photography for unknown reasons, but this seems to be the British tradition.

Personal tour. We were lucky enough to have a friend arrange a personal tour of the Houses of Parliament. One of the highlights of our trip. I would recommend a tour and also getting tickets in the future to view the 6 questions.
So much history. The Parliament was not in session so we were able to go into the chambers. The audio tour was great.
historical. This is such a beautiful and historical building on the riverside opposite of the London Eye. definitely a must :)
Walk in the steps of prime ministers .. Well worth taking the tour to see where all the decisions are made and where the different parties battle it out!! Beautiful building and lots of history.
Decent if your bored.. Nothing really here to see but office buildings and staffers going to work. I dont think its an attraction unless you can get inside.

Fascinating. We had a tour in a group. Parliament was in the summer break so we got a great tour of the House of Commons, House of Lords and lots of other interesting and famous areas. Our guide was very knowledgable and there was certainly a lot to learn about. At times the pace was a little slow as we had to fill time because we were stuck behind another group. Overall really interesting and nothing quite like it. Would recommend it for lovers of history, culture or politics.

Tour of Houses of Parliament. The architecture is wonderful and well worth a visit just to view this. However, if you are able to book on a tour this is well worth it. Historic corridors where lives have been changed. Wonderful!

Iconic Thames view. Architecturally beautiful centre of government along the Thames. You can tour it for historic, governmental or architectural reasons. It has also been the backdrop for many movies and television series including the cult series Dr. Who.Lovely to see in person.

Impressive buildings. Lovely to see. Didn't need to go inside. It really is an incredibly beautiful row of buildings and London wouldn't look the same without them; but a few photos were enough for me.

Architecturally beautiful. The Houses of Parliament has architectural and historical significance in London, no doubt justified by the thousands of reviews, pictures and movie shoots promoting this culturally symbolic attraction. The view and photo opportunities from the outside are enough but if you can budget for a tour, then do so as if you're a first time traveler to London, this will stay with you just as much as Big Ben in the foreground of your selfies. A must see!

Educational. When you are in London looking for an educational place to visit, then the place that I am about to review is the place for you, and that place is the Houses of Parliament located at Westminster.I visited The Houses of Parliament on Saturday on my recent trip to London and it was really educational visit, after passing through airport style security you will come into Westminster Hall to meet your blue badge guide who will take you around the Houses of Parliament, where you will see the robing room, The House of Lords where the state opeining of Parliament takes place and the House of Commons, along with the aye wing.I would recommend this place

FANTASTIC. this was my first tour of Houses of Parliment, although I've been to London three times. This was fantastic and well worth it. We prebooked our tickets prior to leaving australia, so just booked them on line very quickly and easily. The tour was self guided with audio guide. It was well worth it. Dont miss it if you get to London. Its across the road from Westminster Abbey, so if you book, I suggest you book it for around 11am, go to westminter abbey first, then just alk across the road and do parliment tour. Definitely worth it.

Fascinating from outside but get your MP to get you to look inside. Simply the civilised world is built upon buildings such as these so it is a must to go inside the chambers if you can which are unparalleled with Holyrood. This is a slice of society that everyone should try to visit as some point but failing that provide a major scene by the Thames
The Mother of all parliaments.. Yes this is the venue where all the sculduggery takes place. From GuyFawkes in 1605 to the present incumbents. They all have one thing in common, themselves!

A must for those of us on the other side of the pond. Government building tours (with audio headsets) are often boring but our family of four (two adults and two teens) found this tour to be interesting, educational and fun. The audio tour was very easy to follow and most of all, great information with fascinating tidbits and details.
Houses of Parliament Westminster. Enjoyable guided tour. Excellent guide with good sense of humour. Tour took a little over an hour and finished in mediaeval great hall.
Houses of Parliament. This tour was very informative the guide was very good. The history and British political process was explained in detail. It was easy to understand and good for older children.
Fantastic view. You can get some great pictures which ever side of the parliament you are standing. Views are even better on a dry evening when it is lit up.

Superb guided tour. We have wanted to do this for quite some time and so glad we booked a guided tour. Our guide was brilliant, very knowledgeable and easy to understand. She explained a number of interesting facts about the building and political process and kept us totally engaged.It was good to see security was a very high priority and the screening process was efficient. We would have enjoyed wandering back to the House of Commons after the tour but this was not allowed. We had also pre booked afternoon tea in the pavilion overlooking the Thames - a bit expensive for what it was - but a lovely treat!

Wow. What a great tour, pay the few punds extra and go on the guided tour it is brilliant. Our guide Christine was friendly, and informative with a touch of humour. There were only around 8 people on the tour so we were able to interact with her and we were not rushed at all. Lots of info, lots to see unfortunately no photography allowed. The debating chambers are tiny, I leant so much about Britain in this tour which took about 90 minutes. The souvenir shop had friendly staff but needed a bit more variety of stock. Nearest Tube Westminster then follow the signs entrance is on the street running parallel to but not on the river. Book your tickets in advance to guarantee seeing it.

Dripping with Power. Guided tour of the Palace of Westminster which lasted about 1:45 hrs. Absolutely fascinating insight into The history, architecture, traditions and workings of this amazing place. You definitely come away with a sense of awe at the power of the whole British Establishment, built up over so many centuries, and realised in so many ways in this building. This place was built to impress, both inside and out, and you can tell by the effect on all visitors, whether British or not, that it still succeeds 150 years later in a much more cynical age. No mean feat!Would like to come back some time and do the audio tour, giving a little more time to study the artwork and the architecture and soak in the historic atmosphere.
Guided Tour was Exceptional. Bought timed ticket online. Guided tour (1.5 hours) was exceptional and highly entertaining. Not to be missed. Enjoy!

Visit to our seat of government. My wife and I booked a full guided tour of the Houses of Parliament and were very pleased with the experience overall.The obviously very necessary security checks were carried out very efficiently and quickly by pleasant operatives - so different from the same types of checks carried out at most airports.We were booked for a 2:20pm tour and we were met and started on the tour at precisely that time.Overall the tour was extremely good and our guide very knowledgeable. An excellent way to discover many behind the scene facts which are unlikely to found out otherwise.Only downside was number of tours being conducted simultaneously in each area, but this is no doubt a sign of the popularity.Overall a trip to be well recommended.
Only saw it from outside. Nice place to go and look at, near a lot of other attractions like the London Eye and London Dungeons.It's also near cafes and restaurants too if you're hungry.

Fantastic. 4 adults and a 10 year old. We took a guided tour and can't recommend this highly enough. Russell Grant was our tour guide and he conducted the tour with much humour and passion, thank you so much it was the highlight of our trip to London.
Big Ben is really that Big. . First suggestion get there early another 2 hour tour do the audio guide so that you may do it at your pace. It is beautiful and you can sell the history as you walk in.
Good photo op. If you are a political buff this would prolly be worth a visit inside. If not it's a great photo op while in the area for Big Ben and west minister abbey.

Guided tour of Houses of Parliament are very worthwhile. I was worried because I was late in arriving for my appointed time to go on the tour. Thankfully, this was not an issue. Our guide was very good and we had a school boy who wants to be Prime Minister, so he became the group mascot rather quickly. It is billed as a 1 1/2 hour tour, but our enthusiastic guide brought it to 2 hours. It is an excellent tour with walking throughout the different areas. We saw the very interesting huge entrance hall, Westminster, is an architectural masterpiece in that wooden arches hammered onto the sides of the roof provide the roof support without the need for supporting posts allowing an unobstructed view inside.The history of the building, the architectural motifs, and the history associated with the monarchy around Queen Victoria, Charles 1, Henry VIIIth, various PMs, and the political system were all presented in an engaging manner.

Interesting , informative and fascinating. We selected an audio tour and booked online.Entry was easy with impressive security.We took two hours to tour enjoyed the robing room ,the various lobbies and the Houses of Lords and Commons.We sought clarification from staff who were very helpful

Fantastic building - top tips from a local. The Houses of Parliament (as the Palace of Westminster is commonly known) is an architectural gem. It sits on the north bank of the Thames, adjacent to Parliament Square. The nearest tube is Westminster. There are plenty of pubs, restaurants and shops nearby for refreshments. Toilets are available within Westminster tube station (at a cost) or for free in the local pubs. Do at least buy a drink though.There is a lot to see with this building, so do walk the perimeter. The clock tower is known as Big Ben, although strictly speaking, Big Ben is the main bell inside. Try to get there on the hour, so as to hear it chime - it has a beautiful tone. At the opposite end of the building, the Queen's Tower soars into the sky with a Union Flag fluttering above in the wind. Adjacent to the Tower is a pleasant garden that is well worth a look.If you venture across the river over Westminster Bridge and take a right down to river level, see if you can spot the gnome carved into the embankment. Clearly the masons were having a laugh. Highly recommended.

Very Educational. We had a guided tour of Parliament which was very helpful to understand the British form of government...being from the USA we are not very knowledgeable so it was quite educational to have a detailed explanation of how the Houses of Commons and Lords 'work' and to see the location up close and personal...a real plus among our sights in London

Incredible history and Great tour. We thoroughly enjoyed our tour of the Houses of Parliament this morning. This is the origin of many historical events and traditions that influenced the history of our country (Canada), so we were keen to see the building and learn of the historical figures.Bev, our tour guide, was excellent and took us into a few nooks that people not on a tour missed out on.Best advice:- purchase your tickets on-line before you go- it appeared that morning tours were less crowded (ours was 9:20 am)- sign up for the guided tour

Extremely interesting. We had a personal tour given by a friend who is an MPs researcher, so I think we saw places off the normal public tour, which are fascinating. However, the downside to that is that we didn't feel able to read about and dwell in the public areas. Nonetheless a fascinating experience and well worth going.

A Must Do. We had such an informative guide, who kept us on track and within the formalities of the palace of Westminster. We were told of extraordinary traditions that still remain in place 300 years later. A fascinating insight to the workings of government.

Always a Great Place to Visit. I never get tired of seeing this place. Always makes me feel very proud to be British. We travel all over the world and you just cannot beet a day in London, so much going on.

Wonderful Insight into the Political Workings of England. Took the guided tour with a tour guide who explained things, answered questions, and spent about an hour and a half taking us all around the building including the actual floor of the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Very impressive and grand.I would suggest this tour if you are interested in historical as well as current English history and politics and how their system works in comparison to your own or if you just want to understand how parliament functions and who is who and who has the power. Very good tour to take young teens on for them to understand the differences in the political machines and the way they work. This was a wow.

Great to Finally do the Tour. Really is a must see, although the tour can be a bit pricey! So much history in some great buildings and a chance to see up close where our UK politicians gather to make such a mess of things!

Wonderful. I was taken around by one of our MP's staff, it's amazing, we were just in time to se the Speakers Parade and then l got a ticket to the private gallery and saw the MP's at work....(best comedy show ever)...only joking...or am l :-)...if you want to see this amazing building get on to your own PM and they can arrange it.

Where the law comes from. I'm not a history buff or really into politics however my other half is, so this was an impulse tour. Our guide gave lots of information and explained things clearly. It's not a tour to do if you cannot manage walking as it is a good walk around the building. That's once you've got out the security to get in which include having to have a photo I.d, I did find it interesting you can pay to go in during grhe summer or request to visit from you MP, otherwise it's value for money

really good experience. a great place to visit, very interesting, audio headsets supplied easy to work.not allowed in subsidised mps bars so take your own drinksarrived a little early but was let in ok, so don't hang around if early.take a letter with you as they have post office inside and your friends/family can receive a letter from you stamped at parliamentdid you know if you die while visiting you are entitled to a state funeral, just stick to the letter posting..

Tour with a difference. If you're into your historic British palaces and political history, then this is an absolute must do. Fascinating from start to finish. I even had the luxury of afternoon tea in the house if common terrace restaurant... Would definitely go back to find out more... Maybe even visit when the house is in session.

Uncle Ben :). Its not too much to say.
If you are in London - you have to go to see it and make pictures.
Building itself is beautiful (you have to pay attention on walls of building itself) and located in beautiful place.
Aware crouds of tourists arround and street performers, half of which will try to trick you for money.

Stunning sights.. Even though we didn't manage to get inside the building, the outside detail of this place looks absolutely amazing. The place costs about £20 pounds to enter which is quite a rip off but again, if you're the type of person to enjoy stunning sights, this place is for you.

Stunning. Just viewed from the outside this time but so staggeringly beautiful.
Amazing architecture and so much history.
Beautiful. Will go on a tour next time.

Great Sight. Visited a few days ago and although part of the palace of Westminster is covered in scaffolding and plastic sheeting it is still a great British Iconic landmark.
The clock tower that holds the great Big Ben remains uncovered and still a great sight.

A great place to visit. We visited the Parliament when it was not in session so we got to pay for the entrance. It was worth every penny. The audio guide was very interesting. The children's audio guide was also very good. The kids explored the place on their own and enjoyed the stories about the place. We visited both Houses.

Certainly worthwhile. It is of course special to be able to say that you were in the place where important historical decisions have been made. Apart from that, it is certainly worth a visit. It gives you a lot of history and a good understanding of how the English government system works. It is expensive, but by far not as busy as the Westminster Abbey. The ticket office is at a different place, about 10 minutes walk from the entrance,.To be sure you can go in , you can book your tickets online for a certain time slot and print them or if you don't have a printer, you can pick them up at the ticket office. Take enough extra time to pick them up! There usually is a line up and you still have to walk from the ticket office to the entrance (10 minutes).
Trip. We had an amazing time here , all the history even our 7 year old daughter enjoyed it , the guides was very helpful and informative

Still does it !. Visited today, brilliant guide ( Isobelle), very informative she managed a group of 29 aged between 8 and 80 with grace, humour and a fine grasp of her subject. The tour remains great value, well organised, security was handled with the appropriate concerns but without being intrusive.

Nice visit !!. The parliament was built for Edward the confessor, in 1050 as the Palace of Westminster. This World Heritage site has been in continues use since the 11th century, as a royal palace and now as the center of British Government. The palace was burnt down in 1834, so the Gothic architecture you see today is comparatively recent. The palace houses both of the UK's ruling bodies, the Houses of Parliament and the House of Lords. When parliament is sitting after dark, a light shines from the top of Big Ben's tower. It is possible to arrange tours, visit debates in the chamber, even climb the Big Ben's tower. Visitors can only tour during the summer with tickets purchased in advance. The tower was built to house the King's wardrobe and jewels in 1365 and today house the 'Parliament Past and Present' exhibition about the history of Parliament, (admission charge). For more information about London visit thetravelingroom.com

Memorable, informative and interesting. Simply fantastic.. I went on the audio tour of the Houses of Parliament. I was a little skeptical at first, though by the time I had finished the tour, I felt it was one of the best attractions in London. It takes you through all the different parts of the Houses of Parliament like the Commons Chamber and the voting lobbies. The audio tour allows you to get extra detail about the different parts if desired, and I walked around in awe of being in a place that is such an important part of British history and where people like Churchill and Thatcher spent so much of their time. If you are into politics, like myself, you will be interested in seeing parts like the Commons Chamber that you might have seen on television, and even if you are not into politics, you will enjoy finding out more about the huge building and how it has changed over the years. It was an experience that I will never forget.
