Fab!. This was a great place to visit, having seen it so many times on TV and in the news actually going into the House of Lords and Commons was a great experience.
The tour guide on the day was also very good and made the experience even better.
Excellent tour. We took the guided tour and found it to be interesting and very well led by our guide. The history in this wonderful place is amazing!

Nothing less than perfect. I went to this day expecting some boring rooms with no interaction or interest however it was perfect. The audio tour provided the right amount of information and as a budding politician myself I was extremely fascinated. Despite the gift shop being to small and the food being very expensive, this didn't detract from a fabulous day!

A place where the Mps hide.. The building it self is of a great historic value not only to England but to the world, had the great leader churchill do many s peaches in it. But unfortunately the only thing you will is a load of expenses fiddling Mps who are not getting the country going...

Great to see though book in advance . If you need to go here and want to go in then book way in advance.
The tour is good to see history and the amazing architecture
You can just see it from the outside though for free of course with big ben

Very informative. We had a guided tour, very informative and allowed access to some areas other visitors did not have access to. We would like to return but will view at our own pace next time with the audio guide.

Interesting and informative. We took the 90 minute guided tour. I found it interesting and insightful, but my young adults found it too long. However, it is an attraction that I consider should be seen while in London.

Amazing building with lots of history. We visited Houses of Parliament on a sunny day and as it was so hot was great to be indoors as a respite from the sun.Had to go through security which is very quick and painless. Then into the houses we went. We were given audio guides which were very informative and the map you are given is easy to navigate. Got to see the House of Lords and the House of Commons and the grand halls throughout. Lovely staff and very knowledgable. What we loved was there was no restrictions on where you could go and the fact that you are in areas where you constantly see on tv is very surreal. Had to drag my partner out as he loved it that much but everyone should go as it's such an old building and everyone should go and visit. Very small gift shop but lots of good suffragette memorabilia and a wonderful art work called tides of time dedicated to them that it above one of the halls that lights up at different tide levels.

Fascinating!. Brilliant to experience the history and atmosphere of Parliament - and to appreciate our role in democratic government. The audio guide was excellent and included in the ticket price - there was a lot of additional information that you could choose to listen to. If I was more organised, I'd like to go back during a parliamentary session and see the two houses in session!

Hidden Gem of London. How can the Houses of Parliament be a hidden gem? Because most people don't realize that when Parliament is in session you can go to the viewing area and watch the proceedings. Additionally, Parliament is open on Saturdays for tours. The tours must booked in advance. Plan ahead for the time required to make it through security. Simply beautiful!
great tour. we paid the extra for a personal tour and it was well worth it. to be able to stand in the same spot as some of our great leaders was just fantastic. fantastic
Morag C. Worth a visit, I was there for business. ..well organised, friendly staff, amazing building and surrounding areas

Fascinating history. I was part of a group with an excellent guide who made some aspects interesting for all ages. Good to see the places often shown on television and the significance of the various parts of the building.
Well worth a visit.. Very good guided tour with excellent guide. Walked through from the Lords to the Commons. Tiring as on feet for an hour and a half as not allowed to sit. Can recommend.
Fascinating!. Really historically interesting place to visit, would recommend this to everyone. We had a tour guide, which is great because you can ask questions and get answers to them immediately.

Very interesting visit . After passing through airport style security we had a guided tour of the HoP, this was a very worthwhile visit which included some interesting anecdotes of how the HoP has developed through the ages.
We were on a hosted tour which was free, but despite been a tight Yorkshireman I would have happily paid to do the tour.

Parliament is fun. History unfolds as you listen to the audio or tour guide and see the great politicians roll past your eyes - statues, plaques, stories about their influence on English history.
Learn about how the government has developed over time and how it works today.

Create tour and chance to see what you see on TV. This is a great tour allowing you to see the House of Lords and House of Parliament and historic rooms also.Security on the way in is like airport security but you are allowed to bring in water. Everything is organised well.If you are a UK citizen you can also get a free tour through your local MP by contacting and asking them. This will be taken by the MP or one of their secretaries or staff as opposed to one of the normal tour guides. I did this and the secretary that took us round was obviously trained to do the tour also as they were very informative.The tour takes about 2 hours in total from security to exit.Note there is only certain area you can use your camera. Some good opportunities in the the first main hall at the top of the steps, at the next long corridor, and also just outside the entrance to the main hall where if you angle it correctly you can also get Big Ben in the picture.Note kid focused tours are only on certain days if you are going for the normal paid tours. These are slightly shorter tours gear towards young children.

Take the guided tour. Spur of the moment decision to visit but I'm so glad that I did. Paid full price (at Portcullis House) but it was well worth it: I always take a fully Guided Tour whenever they are available bcause the Blue Badge guides simply bring the place to life. Bought the Official Guide - to study over the winter and, I will repeat the visit next time I'm in London..

Go! Don't hesitate!. I had been in London two times and never went to the House of Parliament, the third time couldn't pass it up. Great tour! Unfortunately you're not allow to take pictures inside some rooms (the best ones) but it's worth it. Use the audio tour to understand how the sessions in the Parliament work.

Great tour. . Really enjoyed a thoroughly informative and interesting tour. The guide, Liz, made it her job to inspire my 12 yr old daughter and she did a great job! A fantastic tour so you may see the world's leading debating chamber, the Lord's, the Queen's Robing Room etc. Unlocks the idiosyncrasies of the British Constitution. Just brilliant.
amazing. must see when visiting London a special icon full of Character. well looked after building. just need alot of time to walk round
Great thing to do in London!. Spectacular views outside and inside - audio guides are very good and if need be friendly staff supply additional info.

Iconic and Obligatory. Make sure to take the audio tour and see the inside of the building. The craftsmanship and statuary are unbelievable. Try to schedule afternoon tea at Parliament looking out over the Thames.
A must visit. You can only visit when the house is not sitting but it worth very penny of the entrance fee. If you can book high tea on the terrace.

Exciting absorbing and different to expectation!. This really is a very interesting couple of hours, having the freedom to roam once inside the visitor area. We found it very different to what we thought it would be, based on what TV coverage shows. It is well worth a visit.

Tour of both Houses of Parliament. We attended a tour at 3pm on Thursday 25th August. Our guide was Philip (blue badge). He was an excellent guide and we found the tour to be informative and engaging made the more so by Philip's easy going manner

Birth and development of Democracy. As you start your tour of the Parliament House, you are drawn back in time line to the age before Democracy, slowly as you advance you learn how democracy developed, a major step towards civilization, decent and humane society...
It is a must visit, that is if you are lucky, and parliament is open for visitors...

Met our MP. Took my class here. Security was quick and quite fun with a group of 10 year olds... police with fund, body searches! Met our MP on arrival who showed us round. Huge place and holds lots of history. The plaques on the floor were very informative and showed just how important the place is.Parliament was sitting which meant we couldn't take a school group into the public gallery but we got the feel of the place.Saw a few MPs... some who were to become more famous a few weeks later!!Good day and worth thr visit.

One of our highlights for this visit.. A last minute to buy a guided tour of the houses before we left Australia. Great decision this turned out to be one of the highlights. Just standing in Westminster hall, built by William the Conqueor in the 10th century was amazing. In this hall famous persons lay in state over the years. The tour and explanation of the workings and functions of the two houses was wonderful. Certainly worth signing up for.

Two day visit with my cousin from Milan . There are several landmarks around parliament square and the Houses of Parliament is one of them. This is one of the top British landmark that shouldn't be missed when in London. You can queue up to go inside.

Glad I went! . Great place to visit, we completed the audio tours and my son found the child's version really interesting and came away telling me all sorts of facts that I didn't know. Shame photos were not allowed in most area but appreciated the reasons for this. Well worth a visit....but I would arrive early as it was becoming very busy as we left at about 12ish.

Today House of Commons. Well all I can say is that I have visited london a few times from NZ and never made a point of visiting this magnificant building structure until this morning.I signed up for the guided tour at 0920 luckly we only had 12 instead of the normally 24 in the tour party which also would have been ok .Our tour guide was Harry all I can say is Harry you are a 10 out of 10 with a dry sense of humour and I also gaveyou some latitude for thinking I was and Assuie but he will not make that same mistake again will you Harry :-).All I can say to visitors to London please take the time pay the money and take the tour I am so pleased I did the highlight of our 5 week stay in London it's a 10 from me thank you so much .

A thoroughly enjoyable few hours. What an unexpected visit! Appealed to both my 13 & 16 year old. The audio guide was excellent and very easy to follow. It was great to see the House of Commons and other areas in person after seeing everything on the news! The tea room sold delicious scones and cakes! Staff were extremely friendly and accommodating in all areas. Well worth a visit and a great rainy day London activity too.

Great experience being inside temple of democracy. It's a must visit for anyone visiting London. The guided tour took us through the two chambers of parliament, the history etc in all its magnificence

Parliament. We were fortunate to get a tour of the Houses of Parliament......well worth the effort if you can get in. Absolute beautiful rooms.....but to see the House of Lords is amazing!!!! Unforgettable experience!

Fantastic!. What an amazing city! And this was my favorite part! So much history, architecture and wow in one spot! It is easy enough to walk the area and spend the day. We happened to be there the hottest day of the year, which did not bother me, I prefer it over rain any day! Highly recommend to visit by foot-to bet more of a feel of the area.

Interesting and educational. . I arranged a group visit guided tour for myself and my work colleagues, we were not disappointed! If you find politics interesting this would be for you, if not and you go with an open mind you will still have a great time. The history and architecture is fantastic and makes you proud to be British. The tour guide was informative and humours throughout, I would go again and certainly would arrange another outing to visit this place.
Well worth it.. Really good, excellent info, not at school boring for us or kids, engaging throughout, tour guide was excellent, lots of additional info because he was there to answer questions.
Gorgeous Building!!!!!!. Excellent place to visit. Make sure to have a bit more time to enjoy this gorgeous building, it worth every minute of it....

Self directed tour of the Houses of Parliament.. This tour, using headphones, gives you a good insight into the Houses of Parliament. The opulence of the House of Lords, compared to the House of Commons was striking.

Awesome architecture. Beautiful building both from outside and inside. A must visit during your stay in London. One can buy a ticket from a counter on the ground floor of a building just opposite Westminster Pier. Give yourself a good 1.5 to 2 hours to do justice to your ticket. Guided tours are available only when the parliament is not functioning. However, we were told by one of the guides that one can visit the parliament for free and also watch the parliamentary proceedings while the parliament is in session. Just check with the security and depending upon the space and the matter being discussed they will let you in.You need not be a British citizen to make use of this facility.
Simply Beautiful. Houses of Parliament is a very beautiful. If you are a photographer or love to take pictures then you must visit this place.

A Must See. Great place to visit. History exudes in every corner. If you have a British friend, have them contact their local Member of Parliament and ask them to have a staff member tour you around. It will be much better and far more exciting. They will take you place that you couldn't get into that are truly amazing. Whether you are toured of part of the masses, this is a place you must not miss. An absolute must to visit.
Interesting building. Good looking building from the outside but really interesting if you can get a look inside.I managed to get inside by visiting the visitors gallery in the Commons.

Fantastic insight into the workings of British government. I have visited many years ago. But really fancied a second trip. The management of visitors in London seems to have improved massively, maybe the London Olympics was the catalyst. You are treated warmly from the police at street side, right through the tight security, up to the moment you walk into the impressive Royal Palace where again the staff are excellent. We went on a guided tour. I haven't been on an audio tour so can't comment on the difference. As expected, the tour guide quality is excellent. Our guide was warm and greeted each of us into the tour. I wont go into the historical detail, but it was enormously interesting and a rapid trip through British royalty and governance since around Edward the Confessors reign. One last comment, the wheelchair bound guest in our group was also handled very well. Recommend you go!

Really interesting and a stunning building. Not really into history but I totally enjoyed the visit. Great audio tour with interactive element so that you can go deeper into the various historical elements if you want to. Very fascinated by the interiors and seemingly archaic way that politics are carried out. Well worth a visit.

london tour. iconic building on river thames. London is full of beautiful buildings but this one is really awesome.and best part it is just near london eye. from top you can see the beauty of this building

Amazing!. We walked around the outside of Houses of Parliament, the architecture is stunning. We enjoyed a quiet coffee break in the park next to the Housesof Parliament and then walked over the bridge to view across the Thames. Well worth seeing both close andfrom over the river.
An interesting morning. A tour of the Houses of Parliament is an excellent way to spend a morning....The guide is knowledgable and maintains interest well..... highly recommended.....

Saturday tour. My daughter and I were lucky enough to be here in London during the changing of PM's this summer. The tour takes place on Saturdays only and you get to see the most amazing parts of the Houses. Renting the taped tour guide is a must to get the information you will want. To see this ancient place where SO much history has taken place with so many amazing individuals (from Wallace to Thatcher and so many more) that have had a hand in British and World history is a definite bucket list item. You can almost smell Churchill's cigar.

Fascinating and so much smaller than I expected. Booked a guided visit through our MP. We were taken all over the building. Upper cha!mber, lower chamber, lobby, with lots of historical detail and interesting anecdotes.

I went for a Prie Minsters meeting. the building is very old with loads of history and architecture is great... thank God it wasn't blown up by Guy Fawkes that's all I can say ... They do tours and take people around when the MPS are not around... Worth a visit if you can worth to go and see and hear the stories from old.

The tour you have to take in London. In simmer open daily, but when Parliament is in session only on saturdays. anybody interested in British politics and the Palace of Westminster HAS to take this trip. Last 90 minutes, we get to be in the House of Lords and the Commons, the Queen's dressing room and other rooms chock full of history and pageantry. Probably the high point of this trip to London. Cant recommend highly enough and our guide Mark was super knowledgeable.

Worth the Visit.. The British have so many old traditions its really interesting place.Take the guided tour.Its worth it.Our guide,Nicola was very knowledgable and entertaining.For us Americans it was a nice look into British politics and tradition.

Not to be missed.. I booked online for a 10.20am Tuesday slot, Audio Tour. Security is like an airport but not as busy and not a problem. The headphones were excellent, easy to use, and you could pause whenever you wanted. You have access to most areas, and is very interesting, took us about 90 minutes, a stroll. A great way to fill in a couple of hours.

Book a guided tour and enjoy the afternoon tea. It would be great if you book a guided tour online. The guided tour can be in Chinese or some other languages. The afternoon tea is fairly good valued, after all, which is special.

Second time lucky and worth the wait.. Three of us booked online well in advance though their own website and hoped Parliament wouldn't be recalled as happened the first time.Get there about 15 minutes before your assigned time so you can get your bearings and through an efficient airport style security check.We had a tour guide rather than an audio tour and we all thought it worth the extra cost. Well organised, extremely knowledgeable and friendly.Tours are going on all at once with audio tour users doing their own thing but everything was very well organised with a good flow through the various fantastic rooms that have seen so much history. There are only limited places that you can sit to rest - certainly not in the House of Lords or the House of Commons were you stand in among the benches. The tour can last nearly 2 hours so if you are not good on your feet best to avoid it.The tourist shop is well stocked and the café is good quality but predictably expensive.Highly recommended that you do this at least once.

A must for everyone. We were a group of 4 adults ranging in ages from 30-50 and everyone of us thoroughly enjoyed this tour. It last approximately 105 minutes and was interesting from start to finish. Obviously the highlights were being in the House of Lords and the House of Commons but the architecture, paintings and wall murals, gold leafing and the feel of history were equally important.Our guide -Derek- was eloquent and clear and made sure that everyone in the group could hear him and see the exhibit. He had time for questions and even though I'm sure he does many of these tours, never once sounded or made us feel that he was just relaying a script. You were only allowed to take photos in 2 main areas and not in the 2 Houses. Once the tour was finished we went for the prebooked afternoon tea in the orangery overlooking the River Thames. The setting was picturesque, the tables were nicely placed so you didn't feel like you were sitting on top of people and the staff were attentive and didn't rush you. The food arrived on a beatiful stand and was a delight to eat. The scones were warm, fresh and when combined with the jam and clotted cream, were the best I've ever tasted. We also had a glass of the House of Commons Savignon Blanc. There was time for selfies on the outside terrace before reluctantly leaving. I prebooked the tour and the tea online and it cost about £60 per person and we all felt that this was terrified value for money.

Only good it you are British or a history buff. I love history, but I felt the 20 GBP admission was too high for the limited areas that you tour through. It's probably an excellent tour if you are British, but otherwise I would find other attractions like the Tate Modern (which is free).

Steeped in History. We visited the Westminster Houses of Parliament, also known as the Palace of Westminster, in July 2016. We were on a guided tour. Even though we have been to England a few times, this would have to be one of the most interesting and fascinating tourist attractions we have viewed. The history of the building, dating back to before King Henry VIII is amazing. You are literally walking on hallowed ground. We were also privileged to see the House of Commons and the House of Lords chambers and to have afternoon tea on the balcony overlooking the Thames River where members of the House of Commons take their breaks. A fantastic glimpse into the past history of England. Allow a few hours.

It will surprise you. I really didn't expect much, but from the first place you walk into (the oldest part of Parliament) to the House of Lords and House of Commons to the in between room where they meet before they are called to vote. The tour was great!

A great guided tour. Having previously done the Westminster Abbey Tour we wanted to do the one across the road so to speak.Thanks to some excellent pre booked rail tickets courtesy of Virgin we travelled down to London early Saturday morning at the end of July to visit the Houses of Parliament on a pre booked guided tour.Our guide was both informative and funny and we really enjoyed the experience.The tour was a little short of 2 hours and was well worth the money.We could have then gone back ourselves but opted to take a few more of the sights in including Covent Garden ,which once we actually found it...I always thought my sense of direction was good but on this occasion it wasn't until a kind Couple pointed us in the right direction...was also really enjoyable..before catching our train back home.Only disappointment is photography is restricted for most of the HoP tour but it is understandable as I guess otherwise the place would probably grind to a halt.It would have been nice to get a photo of the better half at the dispatch boxes but at least she was standing right where our new PM was if only...well one row behind but close enough!

Fascinating in its own right . The Houses of Parliament are often overlooked in favour of the more famous (and photo-op/Facebook worthy) Big Ben. However, the building is steeped in plenty of history in its own right despite being rebuilt in the Victorian era.The guided tour was a good way to get an understanding of the building and the institutions it houses. Although long, it provides plenty of information which helps you piece together the pieces of British political history you've managed to imbue. Having said that, thus does strongly depend on your tour group or guide - our guide was good but catered to the group of school children in our midst and consequently was simplifying a lot of the information that we wanted to know more about.

Amazing place to visit.. Definite for the bucket list. The history oozes from the walls but you can take in as much as you like. I would definitely suggest to take a guided tour as you get the interaction with your guide and a few more stories about the history. We had a wonderful guide but I can't remember his name. The facilities are very good with a good shop for souveniers and cafe with plenty of choice. The staff are very friendly and helpful. The security is very tight, but not intrusive so you can still enjoy your visit.
Lovely Piece of British Culture . Passing parliament whilst exploring the west end was well worth it, it's an amazing structure, intricate to every detail, and emits culture and character throughout

An Amazing Tour. I was part of a party on a guided tour which lasted about 1 hour 40 minutes. Our guide was superb and in addition to describing where we were enlivened the experience with anecdotes about day to day business conducted in the Palace of Westminster. We saw all the places we have seen many times on TV and to see the Houses of Lords and Commons for real is an exceptional experience. Even if you think you know how Parliament operates you are sure to learn something new.You are not allowed to sit in either the Lords or Commons nor in many other of the rooms so be prepared for a lot of standing. There are also a lot of steps although there are lifts. On a guided tour although so far as possible progress will be at the pace of the slowest member of the party if you can you will be encouraged to make steady progress to avoid the next tour catching up.With the exception of two areas, photography is not permitted anywhere.

Very interesting, but heavy on the legs. I took the tour of the Houses of Parliament. Interesting both for the history and for standing in the places you see on TV regularly. I enjoyed it very much. But a word of warning: the tour is about 90 minutes, and you're on your legs for the first 80 or so (sitting's nog allowed anywhere). Towards the end I felt my legs and they're pretty strong. Some older visitors clearly needed to sit near the end. So take that into account. But if you're up to it, very interesting!

Nice to look at but don't go in . I would not waste my time to go in. The outside is pretty enough. There is a nice small park for a picnic behind the houses and river which is out of the hustle and bustle and could be a great spot for an afternoon nap.

A place not to be missed. Absolutely amazing. We did a guided tour of the place that lasted 1 1/2 hour and it went flying. It is a beautiful place, full of rituals and history. Too bad it is only open for tours during the summer recess.
Pure History. A must for any tourist. Big Ben, everything just looks so English. I was lucky and had a tour of the House. Well worth it

Beautiful Building. I enjoyed the beauty of the building and the views around (Big Ben and the River Thames). The audio tour was okay so I would recommend getting a real tour guide to enhance your experience.

Very interesting visit. You can't believe you are actually in the very place seen on tv lots of times! Exciting tour of home of democracy. Lots of paintings & statues of former politicians. Not to be missed.

incredible place to visit. Organise this in advance via your MP, you will get a better tour (free as well) it is amazing to walk through the house of commons and house of lords (as seen on tv!) Well worth doing if in london

Government Building. Excellent information given by the docent. Photography only allowed in one hall. The Robing Room for the monarch is lovely; history of the traditions fascinating. There is a lot of standing; challenging terrain for mobility impaired.

Magical Building. We chose an Audio tour which was extremely interesting as we could set our own pace and spend as much time as we needed. The information, history and craftsmanship throughout the whole building is awesome.

Beautiful . So glad chose to visit this venue and a highlight for anyone's trip to London I would suggest. My daughter loved it and the young persons audio guides kept the children informed and more importantly for me and other visitors kept them quiet.Highlights were the house of Lords and commons and now as my daughter says when you see it on the TV we can say we stood there. My daughter was PM for a brief period and thankfully the country survived.
Nice for photos . If visiting London you have to stop by and take a few pictures. It's always busy but you can get some great shots. Easy to get to via tube.
Educational and fascinating. Via the guided tour, mandatory and highly recommended, I learned a lot about how the government functions as well as the history behind it, well worth the time/cost.

An M.P.'s guided topur. My daughter who is doing A.level Politics at school decided she would like to visit our seat of Government. So we contacted our M.P. who very kindly organised for us to visit this magnificent facility. We had an excellent and very knowledgeable guide ( 9 in our group)who spent almost an hour and a half showing us both houses and explaining the intricate history and tradition that we all take for granted.A thoroughly rewarding visit that we recommend I to all visitors to London. Followed up by a pleasant and reasonably priced interlude in their own Cafe
Vacation . Beautiful church didn't go this time but it is a must for first time I. London. Go early as crowds tend to be there as it gets later.

An excellent and informative tour. I learned so much! I've always wanted to just visit Westminster Hall but there is so much more to this tour. The tour guides were very knowledgeable and although the tour moved rather quickly, it delivered at every stop. The cafe at the end offered a great ending. I came out feeling more well informed and would recommend to anyone visiting London.

A lot of information. Cannot recommend this tour enough! This guided tour was well worth the amount we paid! I've actually been back with everybody that comes to visit me and always learn a new bit of information. Mu recommendation to buy tickets online for timed slots.
Nice to finally see!. My husband and I visited the house of parliament and got some great pictures. We did take the tour as not enough time, and bit expensive.

Nice guided tour. Paid for a guided tour of the Palace of Westminster (that's where Parliament is housed). There is also an cheaper self guided with audio recording tour but I felt I got much more out of the guided tour. Well worth a visit
Great Experience. The audio tour was very good. A high level summary of each room which was very interesting. Special experience.

Pre book on line.Well worth a visit with an audio guide. With an audio guide you can pace yourself.fast forward/rewind. Some /many areas are stunningly different. It's a true Victorian gothic masterpiece. It's also fascinating to see for yourself where Black Rod knocks on the door and where our leaders face each other in debates and PMQT. The explanations of the division bell with the ayes and no corridors were clear and interesting.I recommend this tour for anyone interested in politics/Victoriana.The admission ticket also covers entry to the Jewel Tower over the road, again worth a visit if you are interested in history.

A must-see for local and tourists alike - audio tour recommendation. I’ve been on a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament before, but I must say that the audio tour is much better because you can go at your own pace and the quality of the commentary is outstanding. You will need to go through security when you arrive, which is similar to the procedure you find at an airport. Once inside you can pick up your headset in the ancient Westminster Hall, which is over 900 years old and the scene of many of the most important events in British history, such as the trials of King Charles I, William Wallace and Guy Fawkes. You’ll need a couple of hours for the tour, which runs in a loop taking in the House of Commons and the House of Lords. You’ll end up back in Westminster Hall where you can choose to visit the extensive shop or the café. One of the best things about the tour is that the staff are so friendly and cheerful, even though security is tight and it’s really busy. If you are looking for a good place to have coffee or lunch I would strongly recommend you visit Wesley’s Café which is in the basement of Methodist Central Hall, just a few minutes walk from Parliament (opposite Westminster Abbey).

Take the guided tour. Tickets are not where you think. They are at the Portcullis House which across the street from Big Ben. You walk around to the side facing the Thames River and walk to the far end of building. The actual visitor entrance to Parliament is near the middle of the building basically across from Westminster Abbey. Security is airport style with metal detector. As far as tour goes in one word FANTASTIC. The tour guide took us through the Queens changing room where she gets ready to open parliament then into the House of Lords across the long hall way to the rowdy House of Commons. That was the major highlight as I watch Prime Minister questions every Wednesday. The history was amazing. Highly recommended for those who follow politics and/or history. There is a self guided tour but pay the extra for the guided one.

The Greatest City in the World. At the heart of the City is Parliament and the Palace of Westminster and these tours are worth every penny of the cost. This building is unique and instantly recognisable World over. The staff are excellent and with an enhanced Police presence you certainly feel safe. For visitors and residents this tour should be high on your list of places to see in London.

London at its best!. Been to London loads of times and decided to have a guided audio tour of the Houses of Parliament this time - brilliant! Wonderful historical buildings; interesting information given and the option for more information on specific items available. Even our family, who have had worked their on occasions, were impressed.

The place of clever quips!!!. You know how you watch the U.S. Congress and they go back and forth with one-upmanship of the SNL or Monty Python-esque variety? The kind of repartee that is so well-executed you have to chuckle because your representative is SO smart? Yeah, me neither. Well, this is the place you watch on BCC or all the foreign channels where that British wit from the Houses of Parliament indulge in keeping their peers in check. And I got to witness it in in all the green felt glory. Totally worth it. This and the statues, hallways, etc.
Wonderful buildings . The Houses of Parliament are a wonderful piece of architecture and definitely worth getting close to in order to take pictures.

Take the walking tour! Its amazing. Literally the best "paid for" thing I've done in London. Highly recommended. Educational but not to the point where you feel your being lectured. Walk round at your own pace and take it all in

WOW - LOVED IT. Everybody should visit here - I saw the oldest post-office in the world - Loved it - Police officers were very friendly and interesting as well as totally equipped - I heard it was the safest place in the UK ?

Excellent Tour. I waited along time to do this tour and it was so worth it. The inside is so beautiful and the tour so interesting. You go in The House of Lords and Commons and Westminster Hall. You can do an audio tour or guided tour we went for guided tour but cant wait to go again and do audio tour so can go at own pace to take in the surroundings more. A must do if you are in London and I have done a fair bit in London and would rate this in the top five.

Depth of history is immense. Audio tour is good - perhaps a little lengthy for my own interest - tended to listen for a bit then move on at my own pace. Great place to see and look around though. No photography allowed once through the first hall. Lovely staff throughout.
Great tour and afternoon tea. I loved the tour, it is well worth a visit, very interesting. The afternoon tea was lovely with great views over the Thames.
A Must See!. The family will always remember this place! We learned and saw so much during the tour and the walk around the area of the building. This is a must see at night as well.

Family visit with 3 kids, 7 8and 9. Just WOW!!! Everyone was amazed by the scale and history of the place. My kids loved it and the audio tour is specially adapted to keep kids entertained. I listened to some of the kids audio and it was better than the adults! Good value and a life experience......unless of course you happen to be an MP and then it may not be so attractive as a leisure time visit. Highly recommended.

Best Thing We've Done to Date in London. I highly recommend you sign up for the in-person guided tour. I can't comment on the audio-guided tours, but the in-person tour was excellent. Plus, it was very interesting to learn more about how the British government works ranging from the monarch's annual speech to the mechanics of voting in the House of Commons.Of course, if government and politics is not your thing, you will likely not find this as interesting. If you do, I think you will find this more informative than the tours given at the US Capitol.

Mother parliament . Having seen Big Ben and the Palace of Westminster many many times before, I didn't realise you could actually visit. So visit booked and with a guided tour, we took our place in the queue, airport type security to get in but wasn't too bad, downside is it's a bit pricey!!! Great tour, but you can't take photos?? Our tour guide Harri with an I was excellent Would recommend

Booked a guided tour . We booked a guided tour in English. Our guide Reg was quite good and entertaining. Loved his wit. If you want to view each piece of artwork in the Houses then get the audio tour. If you want a great perspective on history and the structure choose the guide. Really appreciated Reg D.

Guided Tour was Excellent. My mum and I did the guided tour of the House of Parliament today and loved it. The inside of the building was incredible and beautiful and the guided tour with Harri was excellent. He was a brilliant tour guide and gave us lots of fascinating stories along the way. It's made me want to go home and read all about British history. Highly recommend the tour - especially with Harri.

Lots of history! Audio tour recommended!. Lovely place to spend a few hours learning about British parliament and the history of the building. You get to walk through so many different rooms lined with paintings, historical architecture, and furniture. You enter rooms that you have seen being broadcast on television about British politics. Really cool and fascinating stuff!I got the audio guide and spent such a long time at each number point because there was so much information. If it's too much, I'd recommend just listening what you want and then moving onto the next room. There's primarily no photography in a majority of the rooms visited but that's not a problem. For me, the audio guide was enough but the guided tour did seem pretty cool and engaging as well. If you're willing to spend a little more, get the guided tour. If not, the audio guide is more than enough.
Fabulous. 2 hours of sheer delight. Our gudle, Ian ,was most informative and helpfull in any questions we asked.
Lovely view. Walking down the Thames and gazing on the Houses of Parliament was a lovely way to spend the morning.

Impressive and fascinating. We had an outstanding guide for our tour and found the whole experience excellent. There are stairs during the tour and very few times during the hour and a half to sit down. Security before the tour is like airport security. Photos are not permitted except in one or two rooms. Well worth doing! Nice little shop and cafe in the building.

Interesting insight into British politics. In 2012, as part of the UpRising Leadership Programme, I was lucky enough to go on a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament in London courtesy of Bedford and Kempston MP Richard Fuller. Security is very strict here for obvious reasons. The tour is very detailed and you get to see where Prime Ministers' Questions and Parliamentary Debates take place as well as the House of Lords. It is a very ornate building inside and out and is an iconic centrepiece of the London landscape. The souvenir shop sells quirky political-themed gifts. But the café on-site can be very expensive though.

Well worth a visit and exit through the gift shop!. Such an iconic building, definitely worth taking the guided tour which is informative and gives a real insight into the past and present. An expert 'Blue Badge' guide accompanies you throughout this 90 minute tour through the House of Lords and House of Commons.Tour highlights include:Westminster HallRoyal GalleryPrince’s ChamberLords ChamberCentral LobbyMembers’ LobbyCommons Chamber
History. It"s beautiful and full of history. The guided tour was excellent and very informative. Worth to visit to everybody
Guided tour. It is well worth paying the extra for the guided tour. Our guide was extremely informative and full of amusing anecdotes. A real insight into how parliament works.

The place where our future is decided. We used the audio tour to find our way. Unfortunately, there were no English language leaflets available when we started, although I found one on the way out, so it was less satisfactory. However, fantastic place and fascinating to actually see what we see on television, where Prime Minister's Question Time takes place and where debate occurs and decisions are made affecting every aspect of our lives. Staff friendly and knowledgeable and good souvenirs in the gift shop.

Take the guided tour!. Wow, this was quire something.We met in Westminster Hall after going through light security and in a small group were guided around Westminster. The place was surprisingly full but because we had the guided tour we went behind the scenes and through barriers for those who only had the audio-guide. Our guide was really very knowledgeable and entertaining. It helps if you have some grasp of English constitutional and political history before you go to keep up with the speed of all the information.Without doubt this is the way to visit Westminster.

2 hours in the very heart of democracy (and the heart of Victorian Gothis). It is very special to be inside the chambers of the House of Commons and the House of Lords.The tour is about 2 hours of walking with limited opportunity for sitting.

Fantastic . We Came on a coach tour and new this was something I really wanted to see, so much history and mostly hidden from our site, you see where the house if lords reside as well as the houses of commons, you are not allowed to take photos in these areas unfortunately though

Love architecture? You'll love this.. Booked ahead for free via our MP and really enjoyed the visit. Both Houses smaller than expected but really great to be allowed to sample both close up and hear of the history from Barbara our guide. Disappointed that the Elizabeth Tower was not included (with Big Ben) but the site is vast!
Weekend of history. Great tour of our seat of democracy so much history and unknown facts told by a brilliant guide well worth a visit not for very young children but maybe 10 up nice shop and cafe

A definite hightlight. We went for a tour of the Houses of Parliament, and it was a definite highlight of our stay in London. Excellent guides and such an interesting building, and also great insight into British politics. Highly recommended.

A step back in time . We booked our tickets online - a good idea, but remember to print them off and take with you. Very little waiting time at 'airport" type security, all staff most friendly and a huge security presence by armed police everywhere. Felt very safe. Keith was our guide for the 90 mins. He was fantastic, answering questions and keeping us informed and amused. If you prefer to go it alone, headsets are available.Totally recommend this venue - prepare to be taken back in time but also be right up to date.

The perfect image of London. The architecture may not be 'fit for purpose' any more but these fabulous buildings epitomise all that's best in London. Your MP can arrange group visits at no charge if you're a UK citizen.

Fantastic. Went along with family that included three children between 6_9. The children enjoyed the audio recordings which were aimed at their age groups. They walked from room to room taking in all the information. Meanwhile,the adults could enjoy their own audio knowing the children were happy. It is all very well organised and we all had a brilliant time.

Went to a conference in the house of Lords. It was quite interesting to see the architecture of the rooms and read up the history. Never seen so many police in one place before! More than at big Daves summer party that ended in a raid last year!It was summer and stifling hot in there. The chairs where old and uncomfortable, like being back at school. The gentleman giving the conference was the speech writer for Obama during his presidency campaign and was actually quite interesting. There where a couple of Etonian teens in there which made me uncomfortable. They appeared quite judgmental of the people entering the room and acted quite rudely throughout. Made me want to go Croydonian on them, but I kept I real and allowed it, particularly when I remembered I moved to croydon, I wasn't born there.In all, I can see why I'm not in politics. I don't like the place or the clueless out of touch sorts who attend this building.

Interesting but too long winded. It was an interesting tour but unfortunately so many people in our group that we struggled to hear the guide. Consequently it didn't hold everyone's interest like I had hoped.Other visitors were using the audio guides so if we were to go again, this is what I would choose to book onto.
Beautiful. Such a beautiful building and an engineering feat to add the huge clock and bells..often sit oposite it and eat my lunch among the statues
A memorable visit. Had the opportunity to visit the Houses of Parliament with a business group, a historic iconic building, not to be missed.
Wonderful. No trip to London is complete without a visit to the Houses of Parliament. These buildings are so incredibly iconic, and are worth being seen from all angles, including from the water!

See it now . We went round with a guided tour keen to see the Houses of Parliament before they are refurbished. The guide was excellent - knowledgeable and humorous. There are plenty of stairs so beware the less mobile. Photographs allowed in only 2 places. 90 minutes covers the essentials and you see all key aspects which the audio tour doesn't cover fully. Excellent opportunity and fascinating place.

Ahh, History and Tradition. Visited for an organised, accompanied visit. Our guide was excellent. Knowledgeable, friendly and most informative. The rooms are sumptuous and impressive. You get in to both the Lords and Commons, but also plenty of other rooms.
Amazing. The architecture is just stunning. Every inch of the palace is a joy to look at and when you consider the history of this building it really is quite astounding.

Lead on! Superb tour.. Fantastic tour. Audio guide highly informative. We went through at what we believed to be 'average' pace and took us 75 minutes. There is plenty to see and admire. Really good, and we were surprised, to be able to enter both chambers of the Commons and Lords. Understandably very little photo opportunity as the tour could then take hours. Buy the Guide for a fiver and you have your photos. Nice cup of tea and slice of cake in the cafe rounded the tour off and prices were surprisingly reasonable! Not such a rip-off Britain.

Democracy, British Style! Excellent.. We were walking by, asked about visiting Parliament, and next we knew we were sitting in before the amazing throne in the House of Lords and an enlightened debate on Brexit in the House of Commons!

Westminster Abbey. Holly audience one of the best Gothic church made by human kind. More than church it is an art museum with all the important person's tombs, walls and ceeling definitly worth to see...Kings and Queens and even Sir İsaac Newton rest in peace in this holly place.

Amazing piece of History. Beautiful building, was great to have the Audio tour to understand the history behind this beautiful building. This is not to be missed when in London. The only thing that ruined it for me was the awful piece of latex that hangs the whole length of the Hall, even if it is based on a study of dust. Once past this though, the rest of the building makes up for this.

Wonderful Tour. Booked the guided tour ahead of time since we had my 85 year old mother with us in a wheelchair. Thought it would be easier then the self guided tour for her and it was, she really enjoyed it. The guide was great, very engaging and accommodating. It was an enjoyable way to be able to see how the government and the monarch are run.

Don't miss this trip!. Never will you find a more interesting way to spend a couple of hours!You see everything .....House of Lords and House of Commons.Excellent would go back again.Highly recommend this tour.Unfortunately no photography allowed inside the chambers.

Tour of the Houses of Parliament. We visited the Palace of Westminster or as it is more commonly known Parliament. This is something everyone should do at least once when in London. You can buy your tickets online or in person at Portcullis House just opposite Big Ben. The ticket office is just around the corner facing the river. Lines move quickly and the staff is very helpful. It costs £25.50 (senior discount available) and is worth it and more. After going through security you will meet your guide for the tour and he or she will take you through this icon landmark with an excellent running commentary on the history of the building as well as a primer on how the British government works. Thrilling to stand in those debating room we've all seen on TV and in films for so many years. After the tour there's a good cafe for sandwiches and sound and of course cake. I had Victoria sponge and it was delicious. This stop is a must for Anglophiles.
London Vacation. If you have the time it is worth checking out the Houses of Parliament. Tour the House of Commons and House of Lords.
Beuatiful Place, Stunning Location. Britain Governs from this lux spot and located on the River Thames. Oozing with history it is just a must see and do while in London!

A landmark. Of course you have no excuse if you don't see it. To be honest, I've seen more beautiful buildings but that's not why you are there ! The big clock with the bell ( Big Ben is the bell not the clock and you only hear it, the whole hours ) is a well known site.

Okay. It was good to see. Kids enjoyed the experience.
Its history. As seen on tv. Well worth coming to see if your in the city.
Parliment. Never been inside but it is definitely something you have to see when you visit London, even if it's form the outside.
Great to see. My husband and I did the guided tour. The tour guide was excellent. It's a great lesson in British government and history even if you don't like either subject.

Excellent Visit. We booked a self guided audio tour approximately six weeks before visiting London. There are guided and self guided tours and we were pleased with our choice as we could do at our own pace. The best time to visit is of course when Parliament is not sitting hence we went during summer recess. We were very impressed that we could go right into the Commons and House of Lords areas and see upfront where they debate and lean on the boxes during question period. Lots of history and overall a very worthwhile tour would highly recommend.

Houses of Parlimenr tour. Good tour we had the audio guide ,Which we think was just as good as the guided tour only about £10 cheaper ,You are not allowed to take photos in the chambers ,Only at the beginning in the main Hall , well worth a visit ,They do a free visit for Uk personnel only ,But when we looked they start at 9 oc in the morning ,If you want a dinner time or afternoon session its one you have to pay for ,You go into the main chambers where the prime minister speaks Also the house of Lords ,Good visit .

Excellent. This was a prebooked tour and we managed to get in a little earlier. There is security to go through but it didn't take long. We did the audio tour which was extremely informative and allowed you to do the route at your own speed. There is a lot to see and it took us nearly 2hrs. Having watched a lot of the political shows and interviews on TV it was interesting to see the rooms in which the MPs spend their time. There are toilets at the start and no photos are allowed.

Successful family visit. Saturday in August. Easily booked a slot, staff were helpful and approachable. Kids ( boys aged 9 & 10) had a different audio tour to us and they both really enjoyed it. This gave us ample to time to wander listen and see. As we didn't have to pay for them I thought it was reasonably priced. A really good day out
Go!. Buy tickets on lineGo early because there are several security checks to pass throughSo glad we went, interesting for adults and kids
Parliament. Was by the houses of Parliament, A very Big building. Looks Nice in the good weather, with the flag at the tops. Lots of tourits here, so be Aware of your things.

Excellent family tour. We done the family tour today with kids (age 9,7 and 4). We had a very informative and educational guide, Diane, so engaged the kids from the beginning. There were about 4 families in our group and the tour lasted about 1 hour and we seen all the main rooms, the House of Commons and Lords, the Queens golden chair, central lobby - the lot. The kids came home talking about it in great detail, so good job Diane! Family days run in August - free for kids and £18.50 for adults.Really glad we done it!

A must see as part of Londons important buildings. It was all part of the Big Ben experience but so important to the English people and as a US citizen I was proud to say these people are our friend and allies. All the best England.

Wonderful experience. Visited with 2 teenagers, wonderful experience. You have to pre book online and then pass security.
You get audio guides for children and adults which are excellent and make the visit worthwhile. The whole visit is interesting and the parliament has so much history.
We spent close to 2 hours and enjoyed every minute.
Very much recommended.

Worth paying to do tour with a Guide. After going through tight security checks we were able to go into Westminster Hall to sit and wait for our booked tour. They actually offered us an earlier tour, which we joined. Our Blue Badge Guide was first class and had a wide knowledge, sense of humour and was so informative that our 90 minutes tour lasted for all but two hours! Definitely a great thing to do in London, especially if you are interested in the way our country is governed. Our Guide was very accommodating for children on the tour and ensured they remained interested.

Highly recommended. We did an audio tour of the Houses of Parliament on a Saturday in late June. It was fascinating and we ended up spending about 2 hours there. Great for anyone interested in parliamentary history or historical London.

Historical . This is a great historical site to visit. I did go because one of my relatives has a statue in the House of Lords. It was nice to be able to see the statue. I do wish that the staff members do a little bit more of the historical meanings within the building. But they were very nice and accommodating for me. It was nice to see some of my family history there.

Fantastic family tour. We have kids ages 23, 14, 12, & 9 and all of us loved this visit! We did the audio tours so you can go at your own pace and choose more information in certain areas. The 2 younger ones were given a kids' audio tour and they learned so many interesting tidbits that they shared with us after. I would love to go back through and listen to their version as well. Took us about 2 1/2 hours but could easily spend more time. Fascinating architecture, statues, history, personal stories, politics!

Try and visit when in London. The UK Parliament has gone out of its way in the past decade to improve its accessibility to locals and visitors, alike. It's important that this home of democracy, regardless of its grandeur, can be viewed from the inside, and so it is much less intimidating to visit these days. There are the necessary security barriers but the police do a great job of keeping the institution and those within it safe while not being overbearing. It's definitely worthwhile adding a visit to your itinerary, especially if you have children and would like to embed in them a sense of history and civic engagement and how Parliament works.

Worth the tour. I was surprised by the stunning architecture found inside the Houses. I also paid for a guided tour which I highly recommend. Our guide was quite knowledgeable and friendly, and went an extra step by engaging the little kids in the tour.
Awesome Architecture . These buildings are beautiful, amazing walk about and awesome scenery, great for a walk around and a must see in London!

Interesting family visit with lots of history. It was good to visit such a historical place. Interesting architecture and a audio tour which was very informative. Kids (12&10) enjoyed it especially my youngest who listen to a child's version of the audio tour. We spent just over 1.5 hours looking around which was about right for the kids.

London highlight . This was the highlight of our trip. The audio tour was great the access to both houses was amazing. It wasn't too rammed so you could enjoy the spaces. A real sense of history and national pride. Only available seasonally when parliament closed so do it if you hit the right time you won't regret it.

Breathtaking place!. As a person who has no idea about the British government system, I was amazed by the wealth of information and the many interesting things to see inside the building.
It was definitely worth to pay for the audio tour.
I wish they would add more languages to the audio guide.
Very informative visit. I have seen it so often on Television it is great to get there. Great history and the tour really brought this out.

Family visit.. Booked a tour for our family of 4 adults. Our tour guide Marian Bacon was excellent and very well informed. We thoroughly enjoyed the 90 min approx tour. We also had afternoon tea on the terrace which was a lovely experience.

full of history. A great visit to understand our countries history in politics. The building was beautiful inside and out. I got a buzz out of being where the likes of the queen and our primeminister past and present have stood.

Nice place. I do recommend
Historical and beautiful place and views
Does not take long but worth the visit
Dont forget to bring your camera
Excellent architecture. Perfectly located, near other landmarks such as the London Eye. Steeped in history with its friendly tour guides.

Wonderful place to visit; ful of history. My son and I visited the HoP in July and opted for the self guided audio tour. I think it cost around £18 in total. Being an avid fan of English history I was thrilled to be in the place where so much had taken happened during the reign of Elizabeth I and others. The building is beautiful and there is lots to see and read about on your way round. You can go at your own pace and staff are on hand to answer questions and keep your right about directions etc. I'm not sure why photos are not allowed in certain areas but it is interesting to see places in real life that you have only ever come across on TV. The House of Commons is so much smaller than you think. I visit the gidt shop which had a lovely selection of items to purchase. I did not visit the cafe as I was on a tight schedule. Well worth a visit

Just Top Notch!. The Palace of Westminster has a number of advantages over other major attractions - it was built as a piece and exists as its two architects designed it (give or take a bit of bomb damage), it has a logical route following its various components, it has superb, spectacular, high quality design, much of it is familiar from TV and it has a Palace-full of politicalstories to bring it to life. This is our second visit, six years apart. Both were guided in style and the security was unobtrusive. There was somewhere to wait at the start and the tour started promptly.We would urge anyone going to book the afternoon tea on the Terrace. It is £25 a head and another £9 for a glass of champagne BUT to sit on the river balcony looking the totally iconic view is worth it. The food quality lives up to the promise. Maybe I will get to be a member!

Great. The opportunity to see the place where all our laws have been hammered out over the centuries is well worth a visit with access to both chambers and the queens area it is a great place to visit

Architecturally very impressive! . I've lived in London most of my life and have seen driven past the Houses of Parliament may times. My two sons (aged 6 and 3) wanted to see the sights of London so we did a Big Bus Tour of London. The Houses of Parliament is a very impressive building, especially considering its age. The best view of it is from the south side of the river or from one of the bridges. A must do for anyone visiting London!

More Access in August and Throughout the British Summer Time. During August the commons are closed and members of parliament can take holidays. This means that tours are granted far more access and time whilst in the buildings.Houses of Parliament are a fantastic and iconic site, well worth visiting when in London.

Well worth visiting. My daughter (aged 12) and I did the audio tour (tickets must be booked/collected from a site around the corner) earlier this week. The tour is informative, not too stuffy and has lots of optional extras to listen to if you wish. Reasonably priced and well worth a visit.

The Mother of Parliaments. Another iconic building of Britain and its empirical history. You can actually enter the visitors' gallery to watch the going-ons of our lunatic politicians. A pity the building is in a bad state of repair.

Worth a look. My title is odd as I'm not sure how to sum up the visit! You can book in line for a timed slot in the audio tour or do as we did & just turn up on the day. Though probably best to call and check availability first. You can only go round when they are not in session, so check that also if unsure. Tickets are bought at Portcullis House which is across the road from Big Ben, the door is facing the river at the far end of the building. I think we were unlucky with our civil servant as he was particularly incompetent and grumpy, but we got our tickets. You then brave the crowds and traffic to walk right down the front of the Houses of Parliament to the entrance. There is tight security as you would expect, but not daunting. Much like at an airport. Once inside there is a cafe a shop & loos. (Suggest using loos as it's quite a long trip round) We then had quite a queue for our headphones, but once there they are efficient and easy to use. The commentary is a bit long winded for some but you can dip in and out of it. There is a post office inside the building so a great place to post any postcards etc. if Id have known I would have taken something in as you cannot buy anything to post (except first day covers) It is most odd wandering into the House of Lords then the House of Commons - places you think you know so well! Loads of history and lots of unexpected details also. There are few places to sit & rest and lots of stairs etc so I'm not sure it is for the less mobile. I expect that if you enquire there is an accessible route - we certainly have less physically able peers and they must get in.

A must see for any visit to London. I used to live in London for years but never managed to get to visit the Houses of Parliament. Now, two years later, I had an opportunity to visit and I absolutely loved it! I took a guided tour with friends and it was hands down, one of the best tours I've ever taken. The tour took about 2 hours and our guide was extremely informative and very engaging. She made the tour feel like it was flying by and everyone was hanging on to her every word. It was definitely a memorable experience, one which I will be sharing with friends and family for years to come. To top off our visit, we booked to have Afternoon Tea. It was such a delightful way to end a special visit to such an historic building.
Architectural masterpiece. Oh what a fabulous place London is. The houses of parliament should be on everyones hit list. You cant be disappointed with this superb building in a beautiful position.

Always Fun To See. It's all part of the scene with Big Ben, the Thames and Westminster.One never tires of seeing these together - maybe line the New York skyline, only better!!I've never been inside - too much to do in the UK and our last visit was 10 days.

Excellent tour of both Houses of Parliament . Our guide was witty, knowledgeable and kept the group enthralled for the 90 minute tour. We were shown around both Houses, the robing room, the lobby, and were given a good potted history of how the Palace of Westminster came into being. The role of the Speaker and Black Rod was explained. I was in a motorised scooter and was guided to lifts and ramps in a well organised way. A very good trip. If you have a timed ticket do give yourselves an extra 15 minutes to be able to go through the airport like screening. Very useful for 6th formers who are studying history or politics.

Audio tour of the Houses of Parliament.. I did the audio tour of the Houses of Parliament I was booked for an 11am slot and got there half an hour early as recommended at busy times but was able to straight in. Your met first with airline type security remove all metal objects and walk through the metal detectors and your wallet phone etc. go through the x-ray machine. Once inside you start off in the old Palace of Westminster hall where you pick up your headphones and are given instructions on how to use the audio device which is quite straightforward then you follow a set route and press play on your set when prompted by numbered signs. There are extra more in-depth commentaries that you get the option of listening to. You get to go at your own pace and it wasn't to crowded, you are not allowed to take photos apart from in Westminster hall and St Stevens hall which is a pity. I found this tour interesting and informative a good place to visit.

Jeff. Went to present to the House of Lords about stroke rehab and the lack of it
Had a quick bite.
Very friendly and helpful
Food fresh
Would def go back
Jeff

If you love politics.... Listen in to the Commons or Lords debate. See the the exhibition in Westminster Hall. Check online for debate times and topics. Prime Minister's questions is the best chance to see the famous pols.

Another must do.. I was lucky becuase a family member worked there so I had a back door view.
But even if I didn't this would defiant be worth the trip.
Amazing.

Absolutely brilliant . I didn't even know you could visit the Houses of Parliament we just fell across it by accident and so glad we did. It was a very interesting tour done by audio so it was very informative, if you have the chance to visit it is a must. Thereby an awful lot of history here and fantastic
Westminister. When you are in London, do what the Londoners do....please visit the area around Big Ben and West Minister.
Kid Free break. Took my breath away, the art work especailly King John signing the Magna carta ..wow...amazing how small the actual chamber is though!

Amazing & Informative!. We have always wanted to tour the Parliament Building and this time we did it. I recommend that you pay a little extra to take the guided tour rather than the self guided one with the earphones. The reason is that you not only get an in-depth talk but you also get the opportunity to ask questions. You also get to go into the different chambers where the people with the self guided tour cannot go. That was what made this tour fascinating! This is a must do tour.

Very interesting. Excellent couple of hours spent. Great Audio Tour with lots of additional material to explore. Took around an hour and half. Access to main parts including Commons and Lords. Appointments are timed so not too crowdy. Have to go thru' airport-type security to access.

Get the guided tour!. Due to Brexit and the nerdiness of my family, we decided this was the one place where we should pay the upcharge for the guided tour rather than the audio. I highly recommend you do the same! Our guide, Andrew, knew so much and patiently took all the questions that were asked. The guided tour also takes you into rooms where the audio tour is not. This is easily one of the best places to see in London!

A beautiful building and excellent audio tour. Not too busy as numbers are controlled. Be prepared for an airport style security check and armed police inside. The building is absolutely amazing, a must see.
Fantastic place. Fabulous building and great to see all the rooms you normally see on television. Takes about hour and half to see everything comfortably. Would definitely recommend a visit

Excellent tour. We were booked on the guided tour last Saturday and really enjoyed it. The guide really knew her history and was very interesting. I had been before when parliament was sitting so wanted to return to do the tour and would highly recommend it! The guide explained so many things about procedures that I vaguely knew but was able to understand properly! You won't be disappointed if you go I promise!!!!

Current affairs, history and architecture all in one place.. I took the audio tour and enjoyed the fact that I could walk around at my pace and enjoy the commentary and the surroundings, It took approx 2 hours to get around, and I listened to all of the commentary including the additional items.If you have any questions as you walk around there are plenty of support staff that you can ask.It was great to see areas that I have seen on the TV for years, and understand how it is all set out in the building.There are a number of locations where you can sit down if you need to, and take in the sites, this includes the large number of clocks that seem to be around.There are only a limited number of areas that you can take photos, but in the current day I think this helps you take more of it in, rather than viewing it all from the screens on your phones/cameras.

Make sure you have a full access tour. Before booking try to ensure Parliament is not sitting so that you get access to the Houses of Lords and Commons. Once that is confirmed this tour is worth the money. I have been to London so many times and can't believe I have not done this tour before. Make sure you do the tour with a guide. Firstly, you get a bit more access to some areas and secondly they add a more to the discussion than if you do the audio tour.
Unexpected bonus. Didn't know we could visit until we got there. Such a wonderful tour of all rooms. Even saw a wedding in a courtyard!

Take the tour. If the tour is on make sure and take it, can provide some informative insight into the different areas etc. Also please be mindful of what you bring as you will have to go through security before entering.
One of the best tours. Taking the Tour of Parliament is a must! We had a fabulous tour guide, Nicola, who brought the history of this important building and it's functions to life.

iconic London. Like other sites along the Thames this is a great photo op of iconic London. It's not a place to inside and is best viewed from the south bank of the river. They always seem to be working on the building so expect some scaffolding in you picture. Best pictures will be in the early morning or evening and also avoid the crowds.

great heritage. Access is limited due to parliamentary business, so call or check the website, but most Saturdays are available.The audio tour was organised very efficiently over the phone for £18.50 per adult. The entrance is on Cromwell Green, Abingdon Street, which is across from Westminster Abbey. Provide the order number to an assistant who will fetch the tickets. Proceed through security and on to collect the headset and audio guide. Allow 2-3 hours to complete the tour as there is a lot of detail on the guide and it was very busy.The tour is very well done and highly recommended.

Fascinating. Had a guided tour of both Houses, main lobby etc. Our guide - Richard- was very knowledgeable and interesting to listen to. That tour dispelled a lot of my prejudice and was an excellent learning experience. Value for money? £20 for nearly 2 hours of personal attention, that's what I call value! Airport type security and only offered when Parliament is in recess so look out for when available. Highly recommended and we will return to do this again. When available one can also tour using an audio guide. Consider carefully if one has mobility issues as there is a lot of standing but it is wheelchair accessible.

Bespoke tour for visitors with disabilities. My adult daughter has autism and when we rang to enquire about tours we discovered arrangements can be made by their inclusion and diversity officer. No idea this existed but our guide Tracey deserves a medal- she prepared us with emails of a virtual tour and bags of information so my daughter was fully primed for our visit. Tracey met us off the train at Westminster and we spent almost 2 hours with her. She was exceptionally knowledgeable about the place, its history and developments to the present day. She also is clearly passionate about her job and about engaging people with our democracy. We realised how much of a priority the powers that be have put on how open the place is kept to the public in these days of so much global instability. Quite uniquely so. After our trip, the whole Parliament/politicians concept seems so much less remote to us and I would strongly recommend anyone to visit. And thank you so much, Tracey, for bringing it all alive to us. We had a wonderful time.

A wonderful and informative experience. I did the family audio tour with a 7 & 8 year old. It was really interesting and informative. It took us just under 2 hours to walk the whole way round, but there were benches at some points where you could rest. The audio tour was excellent and you can ask the wardens if you want additional information. I can't recommend this highly enough.

Great tour but have to stand.. This tour takes about 2 hours. We went for the guided tour[you can ask questions] Its really interesting and our guide was very informative.The only down side was you have to stand, and photos could not be taken in the commons chamber or the house of lords. I found this strange as both are televised. However, worthwhile probably best saved for a rainy day.
Excellent tour. The inside of houses of parliament is aesthetically beautful and rich with history. The guided tour was engaging and informative. Would highly recommend to anyone young and old

Trip round Houses of Parliament. My wife booked this and I was not really bothered about going.However I am so pleased II went because it was very interesting and the guide was exltremely knowledgeable. Well worth it .
Amazing history. We are took audio guides, so you can take your time in every point where you want. It's very practical. So other tours don't distracting. Amazing history in each part!

Audio Tour. The audio tour was informative, and interesting. You cannot help being immersed in the history of this great place. The audio tour lets you set your own pace, while giving you all the information you need.

History before your yes.... Incredible, beautiful building steeped in history. Fascinating to think you are standing in a place where so many famous people have trodden. The audio tour was informative and interesting and the guides are knowledgeable and enthusiastic in answering questions. All well organised and a must do !
Well Worth A Visit. Such an interesting place full of history. Very well organised and excellent audio tour facility to find out so much interesting information.

An afternoon tea experience to never forget!. I must admit I was a little bit sceptical about going to visit the parliament. But after getting to the main hall it was worth it to see the architecture and paintings. After this visit, I want to go back again and see a debate in the house of commons. I love the afternoon tea, it was really nice and British. I love the way the audio guide was spoken. Finally, the staff were really nice and welcoming except for the security guards that were really rude and disrespectful. They treated us really rude. In general we had a great time.

A must do for all visitors. An informative, interesting and absorbing experience. Took a tour with a blue badge guide that lasted around 90 minutes. The time flew by as the Houses of Parliament came to life. The Commons, the House of Lords, Westminster Hall, St Stephens Hall and the Central Lobby featured so often on the TV News were fascinating. Our guide was extremely competent covering so much parliamentary history in so short a time. Highly recommended as a must see for all visitors to London.

The best place to see!. This is, by far, the best visit you can make in London. The audio-tours are great and you get to see the actual chambers of the House of Commons and Lords, plus some other curious places. Even though the audio-guide is good, don't hesitate to ask some of the members of staff, actually most of them are full-time workers at the Parliament and have tons of great anecdotes. Note that this is one of the few places where you actually get a ticket for a particular time of entrance, regardless of whether you're getting a live-tour or an audio-guide. We were told this is to avoid crowding. So we got our tickets at 9am and were booked for 1am.

Amazing Place! Must visit in London. The security is well managed but the place is amazing. Guided and unguided tours available. The place was open from 9am when we visited. Once inside the place you are hot by the attention to detail. Getting into the House of Commons and Lords.....awesome. Do go and see....amazing history.

Fantastic tour. Took the audio tour - very clear and informative. Easy access, plenty of room to spread out. Informative tour in a beautiful setting. Get tickets in advance to save time. Be sure to book a riverside terrace tea post-tour. Beautiful setting and a delicious gluten free tea.

GREAT EXPERIENCE. Family took the self-guided tour (they give you headphones which takes you through everything). You can take your time and spend as long as you want in each room.
