No photos permitted at all (except in the Great Hall). Fascinating for history buffs and a beautiful building. The great hall is the oldest section, scene of the trials of Charles the first, Guy Fawkes, Thomas More, and William Wallace. You go right onto the floor of the Commons, standing right next to the Prime Ministers seat (God bless you, Winston). The House of Lords is also beautiful. Statues throughout of Kings and P.M's. NOTE: PARLIAMENT CAN ONLY BE TOURED ON SATURDAYS!
Adorable. Your visit to London is not complete without a ride on the Thames and an excellent view of the House of Parliament

A Stunning Sight, Wouldn't Want the Window Cleaning Contract!. This building is stunning - very imposing and gothic in appearance it's something that you have to see if you're in London.Standing outside knowing that the people who run the country are just the other side of the wall is an inspirational thought.It's great for the kids to see where the rules that govern their lives are made.A must see!

very interesting history of houses of parliament. we went to houses of parliament on 26/07/16, myself my boys 9 and 10yrs, husband in his wheelchair. there was only one room my husband couldn't access fully he sat on top of the stairs in his wheelchair just to one side of the door and was able to listen to the audio tour and watch me and the kids looking around the room. I wouldnt really bother taking a camera as they wont allow you to take many pictures better to buy the guide book which we did was £5.00. the houses of lords and commons you cant get a wheelchair down through the centre you go in the top of both then a guide takes you around through back corridors through to the other side of the house of commons and lords then you can get right up to the centre of both houses. so you do not miss anything if anything you get a behind the scenes tour ask the guides to look at the medals cabinet and they will tell you about them. if you want to ask questions staff are in every room and go out of there way to answer questions. I asked him about suffragettes and Mrs Pankhurst, he said she locked herself in a broom cupboard during the census, and Michael Jackson wanted to buy the queens lovely throne from the house of lords and was told sorry its not for sale etc. this info was priceless thanks for that. if parliament staff read this thanks for such helpful facts and info and thanks for looking after my disabled husband they went above and beyond even the coppers were very bright and friendly and welcoming and happy in their work. arrive 30mins early to get through airport style security. our children asked questions and they worded them in a way any child could understand. if I were you book tickets online we didn't (but you cant get a carer in free only as kids and cares free just had to pay for husband) and were told only ones available are for tomorrow so we bought them and went to tower bridge and London eye instead. best photos to take are of the outside of the building statues of famous people in the park next door which we used as it has a playground for kids at the far end for them to just have some playtime after being so well behaved inside parliament. do book the audio tour as you can go round at your own pace and keeps kids entertained too. please be carefull in houses of commons a foreign toursist stepped past the ropes and get severe telling of by police with a gun so do read the signs.WARNINGone thing I'm not happy about, they had an art installation it looked like dead skin off a giant animal hanging in the entrance hall. they did have signs warning it was latex I saw it, but husband in a wheelchair didn't see it. it made his throat very itchy as he is sensitive to latex. so watch out I think it was disgusting reminded me of dead animals and should be in the tate modern not in houses of parliament. so many people are allergic to latex I think bigger signage and when you hand your tickets in the guy on the security guide could have warned us.

A must for anyone visiting London. We visited the Houses of Parliament and was very impressed with the building and it,s history, we found out so much we did not know. The staff are very polite and helpful.
Boat trip. Lovely boat trip up the river Thames to visit Houses of Parliament and surroundings. Great way to travel and wasn't disappointed. Very spectacular building and we'll worth the trip.
Stunning. Only went in the outside of the parliment and did not do the inside. Spectacular to look at and the sound of Big Ben emreasured me that I was British.
Amazing historical place. Old city with many historical buldings. Nice london! Best of the London city. You must it see. Amazing place for panoramatic photos.

Very worthwhile to visit. Best position on the Thames, wonderful buildings, fantastic inside as well as out. Watch parliament in session. Very interesting, though view is restricted. Free of charge if you don't go for a tour.

Great tour. The building, the history and the stories are brilliant. We spent about 2 hours and it was engrossing for the whole tour. We used the audio equipment and I would recommend it. We are interested in politics and history so it worked for us.

Must see - but only a drive by. You may be slightly disappointed by this landmark. You will ride by it a number of times on your ride around London. It is iconic but not accessible to the public. So ride by and photograph is the high point. I would suggest getting off at this stop as there are a number of places to see in this small area.

Fascinating. Must see this, so well worth it, do book a guided tour, so much better than the audio tour - which is pretty good as well. So much history, culture and tradition. The option of taking tea at the Houses of Parliament is expensive but fun and we enjoyed it a lot. Nice to relax with a cup of tea and splendid array of fancies after a tour.

Parliament tour is a great way to learn about the UK government. During certain times of the year (summer it seems), the inside of Parliament is open to the public for tours. I opted for an audio tour so that I could take my time walking around. The building is beautiful and full of history. I found the audio tour particularly interesting as an American because it covered quite a bit of information on the UK government, past and present, which I did not know.Free if you want to just view it from the outside, but there is a fee for tours.

home of government. the seat of govt is enthralling but is badly in need of major refurbishment. Just to walk through and around the building is awesome realising how much has happened here in a thousand years

Wonderful! Don't miss it!. I chose the guided tour and my guide, Christine, was excellent. 90 minutes of history and functioning of the parliament, besides history of the building itself and a bit of arts inside. Good chance to learn about their politics. I DO RECOMMEND IT.

Ancient semi-democracy in action. Anyone even remotely interested in history or politics should visit the so-called "strangers gallery" in both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. It's a bit of a process to get in, what with security and lines, but the officials are cheerful and efficient. When I visited it was a 35 minute wait to get into the Commons but no wait to get into the Lords. Apparently it is a mob scene once a week during Prime Ministers Question Time, when the opposition tries to tear the PM a new one, politely, of course.You will have to give up your mobile phone to get into the Lords and silence it to get into the Commons. No backpacks either. Behave yourself - they have a zero tolerance policy for taking pictures or video. I watched a security officer in the Lords strangers gallery question a woman who checked something on her phone. The woman was required to show her photo stream. No fooling about. Also, the gallery steps are *steep*, so if you have balance or stair climbing problems, see about the accessible entrance.The interiors of both chambers are magnificent, the Lords more so with the throne and such.It was interesting to hear the debate in both houses. I was there just pose Brexit and the Lords were discussing the UK's relationship to NATO post-Brexit. The Commons was discussing the Wales Bill, devolving power to the Welsh National Assembly, like Scotland. It's like watching the news happen in real time. The formalities are kind of a hoot as well.I move that my Honorable Friend from Tripadvisor visit Westminster. (Hear! Hear!)I should note that the expression "Hear! Hear!", which is short for "Hear him!", has devolved into a sound like "iya-iya-iya."

Be sure to check this out!. This is a very important thing to check out while visiting London. Although you can't go inside, you can check out the outside and learn information about the UK's government.

We did a "drive-by"!. We didn't enter the Houses of Parliament (time restraints), but we have tons of pictures of the outside of it! It's hard to miss, as it's attached to the iconic Big Ben! There was ongoing construction to the exterior at the time of our visit, so the river views of the Parliament weren't very...scenic. Still, it was very worthwhile seeing.

Guided tour is a walk through British history. Totally worth the 15£ or so to go on the guided tour. You see all the important and interesting rooms surrounding the Houses of Lords and of Commons (you of course go into these chambers as well, and can even go right up to the dispatch boxes and other places. The guide also points out many fascinating features of the internal architecture and art, especially as it pertains to British history. In this sense, the tour is a wonderful, compact journey through the political history of Britain.

Lunch with corporate guests. Hosted a table with others for a corporate summer lunch for my employer in the Winston Dining room at the house of parliament.Exellent service and very friendly staff. I also lost my phone and they could not have been more helpful to me, helping me locate it.Our guests loved the super lunch, which was beautifully presented and very tasty.I would have no hesitation in using the house of commons dining facilities for future corporate events. Thank you and well done!
Exciting. It is an exciting experience to actually walk through the spaces where the British Government exercises its power. Gorgeous and fascinating, don't miss it!

House of the Big Ben. The Parliament house is more known for the Big Ben, but the whole building is amazing. Not only that, there are also tours on the building if you book in advance which are quite nice.

Interesting tour. Had a tour of the Houses of Parliament, the lady guide was very informative and the tour of parliament very interesting especially the difference between the commons and the Lords. There is a cafe and toilets. There were a lots of tours going on at the same time which was a bit distracting.

Great History Lesson. We took the Audio tour which allowed us to move at our own pace. This is a great way to learn a wee bit about British political history and also get a look round the House of Lords and House of Commons. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was because after you get past St. Stephen's Hall you're not allowed to take any photos ... gutted!

Be a part of history. The public is allowed to sit in on Parliament and observe and I highly recommend it. The queue starts early and once they've filled the galley no more are allowed in. It's quite interesting and refreshing as an American to watch how polished and polite government can be, even in a hearty disagreement.

Best time to visit: winter - spring, fall, but NOT in summer (overcrowded!). I ravelled my first time to London and GB in 1975 when I had finished my school. Before the beginning of my studies of management and engineering at a Technical University in Germany, I travelled my first time to London and GB.I enjoyed it very much to visit many interesting places in London and I enjoyed to travel all over GB.since that first visit in 1975, I have been several times in London and in GB, and in U.K. and in USA. But I still like to remember my first visit to London.Of course, I visited the Westminster Palace. I strongly recommend you to visit it in fall, or spring, or maybe even in winter; this place is too overcrowded in summerIt is really worth a visit. You won't regret it. It is recommendable to read some information about the Westminster Palace before you visit it. However there are excellent tour guides (in English, German, French, ...etc.)
History. The Audio tour is very good, the history and knowledge right in the heart of London, well worth a visit

Well worth a tour. If you get the chance everyone should have a tour of Parliament. Really enjoyed our visit. We opted for the audio tour which was very interesting. Our tour was booked for 11am but we arrived early and went straight in.

Informative, friendly Verger Staff Tour. Although I really enjoyed the amount of time I spent on the tour, I had to leave early due to jetlag as I just flew in from the States that morning. The guide was very friendly and formative. The staff was friendly and helpful. The price was well worth it.
Awesome!. We were unable to go in as did not make prior arrangements, but just to see the size and exterior was unbelievable! The buildings are magnificent!

Guided tour on Saturdays - well worth it!. Book in advance for the guided tour on Saturdays! Well worth the money to hear about Parliament and get to go into rooms that the general public does not see. The tour takes 90 minutes and you don't get to sit down (except twice). You will go through security before the tour so leave time to do that, plus take pictures of you with Big Ben in the background! You can't take photos inside, so you should get the Office Guide book!

Fantastic to see where our country is governed from. This is such an interesting place to visit. So English, so old and history everywhere. Headset tour just right level of information and getting right into both houses and the halls and other rooms was great. Enough seats you can sit on if needs a rest and statues and other art work wonderful. A must visit.

Interesting to know . There is a short queue for security check. Parliament house is going through some kind of refurbishment. We book a tour, learn some history about London and learn quite a bit on how the parliament work.

Interesting tour. My husband and I took the guided tour on a Saturday. We had booked in advance and were very lucky to get Liz as our guide. She immediately impressed us by introducing herself individually to each of the guests, asking us where we were from and chatting for a few minutes while we waited for the tour to start. She was so well informed and really made the history of the place come to life. Much better than an impersonal audio tour.

Great photo spots. Walking around the parliament was like being in Disney world. The never ending castle-like adventure. It was monstrous and so many angles with each being more breathtaking. Amazing architecture.
Beauté fil l'odeur structure. We coulent gent in thé insidieux but We tried. Dont Knowles il thé whigs été in session or not bécasse We could not go inside

Loved it. I absolutely loved this tour you get an audio device and wander around on your own which is brilliant as you don't have to keep up with other people. It was brilliant to see the lords and the House of Commons but it looks so much larger on the TV then in real life. The cafe is lovely and so is the food I would definitely recommend to anyone interested in visiting.

An interesting visit. It was an interesting visit but nothing I would stand in a queue for, except to say I was there. First off, you don't buy your ticket there but around the corner and across the street. Look for the signs when you get off the tube or else you'll be backtracking. Also, pay attention to your ticket as there are specific times for you to enter. You get to visit both the House of Lords and House of Commons but the tour does not take you to the Elizabeth II Tower and Big Ben. I'm glad I visited it once but I don't see a reason to visit there again.
Houses of Parliament. Houses of Parliament another must seen when you got to London. It's a great area to wander around on a sunny day.
Busy location but worth it. Stunning building and located by other great attractions (Westminster abbey, Big Ben, Downing street). Great to just stand and stare!

Well organized. A visit which you should do if you are in London . Be aware that only Saturday is permit for tourist and you should plan weeks a head for online booking or per telephone , otherwise you will not get a chance to go in .

Brilliant experience. In the late afternoon after a day touring central London, we discovered the Parliament buildings were open to visitors. No queue and straight in. Audio guides for adults and children were excellent and the children were treated to access to both houses and the wonderful history, art and architecture within. Unforgettable.

25 pounds and stay on line. I don't understand the logic of visiting this building. You must pay a hefty fee and stay on line to visit an official government building, an activity that is free in just about any other place on the planet!
Impressive!. We spent time in the Parliament Square area in both daylight and dark - fascinating! History up close and personal!
Surprising interesting. Wasn't sure about this to start with but what an amazing tour. Suppassed my expectations in the end and was a very interesting and informative visit.

Great. The ticket prices weren't very pricey and it was an insightful look into England's political history and culture. However in many areas you are prohibited to photograph. Young children may become slightly restless although the rooms are very beautiful and decorated. Would highly recommend.

Beautiful building with less impressive human content. A wonderful building. Only an outside tour this time in London. Rumors has it that the audiotour is great. Remember your "Spot the politician"-app...
The summit of our visit to London. We spent an enjoyable 3 hours at this venue and the audio tour is a must. The history, the splendour, the grandeur - almost overwhelming. Priceless.

interesting visit!. For those who like that sort of things, this would be the sort of thing they like! Lots of history and interesting stories, as told by the guides. Takes a while to get in due to security etc, but worth it in the end.
Houses of parliament. Parliament is made up ofthe house of commouns and House of lords .it is responsible for making law deciding taxes and the government

Attended a function at the HoP. Visited an event I was invited to. The terraces facing the Thames are an events venue. I have never thought of going inside yet it is a stunning building. I recommend an internal visit or using it as a venue.

Getting Ready for Photos. Unbelievable! This grand monument, along with the Big Ben, seems to be posing. Always ready to put on a show and be seen. At each step Everybody stopped enchanted to him homage with looks and photos. Flashy and dazzling day and night full of lights, changes its appearance and dress adapting to the climate and the light. Never boring and always attractive.

Great experience for all Americans. I visited here the first time in 1978 with a friend or a friend who was an Member of Parliament and was able to see the House of Commons, deserted, and sit on the benches for a while. It was a treat to be long remembered. But if that doesn't quite work out for you, the next best thing is to reserve a spot on the Saturday tour through the Parliament offices on the web. Obviously, with so many foreign visitors, you must do this early - we made our reservations around February or March when we could easily pick the precise hourly time. Plan on arriving early to deal with the airport like security system. Enter from the western public entrance - many bobbies are around to help direct you correctly and join the ticketed line. You will be directed to wait in the large hall until your group is ready to leave (toilet room available). The guides are thoroughly professional and will regale you with the many details and personal stories that you would normally expect. The full experience will go for about 90 minutes with very limited seating opportunities (not possible in the H of C) and no bathroom breaks while touring. For government enthusiasts this is one of the two required visiting sites in England (and the other is the Magna Carta at Salisbury Cathedral).

Amazing and informative. We spent a super 90 minutes here - there is so much to see- paintings, sculptures and the explanation and clarificationof the old customs. We had a really good guide who went out of her way to explain, answer questions and was extremely helpful. Some of the rooms and decor is jaw-dropping - if somewhat (at times) a bit over the top. Would certainly recommend a visit here.

Political must do. If you are at all interested in politics then you must sit in the gallery at either House. It is extraordinary to be able to watch and listen to them debate. Yes, Americans can see it on C-span but so much better I. Person. The wait can be several hours. There are tours but not while in session.

Amazing!. Had a fabulous afternoon at the Houses of Parliament on a guided tour. We came away amazed at the place but equally embarrassed about our lack of knowledge around our own government. 17 yr old as enthralled as I was and although my 7 yr old didn't understand it all she was given pride of place throughout the tour and so loved it too. Thanks to Hazel our guide who was fantastic!
Good Looking Building. Its a nice looking building and along with Big Ben is worth seeing due to its importance within England.

Definitely worth a visit! Tip: book in advance (online). We took the guided tour. Good guide, interesting tour. Too bad it was ruined by a bunch of rude, uninterested Russian teenagers who claimed to speak RRRRealllly good Engllish (heavy Russian accents). It soon turned out their English was rrrreally rrreally bad and they completely disrespected the instructions of our guide and were generally just annoying. I still wonder if it was a mixture of stupidity or just plain rudeness. The guide was distracted and irritated because of this. I also did the same tour 2 years ago, in the company of genuinely interested people and it was a lot better because the guide didn't have to play policeman/schoolteacher. The guides are all skilled funny people and born story tellers. They give interesting details, show you around parliament rooms, and they answer questions. Our guide was a person that used to work in the parliament before as an administrative employee so he knew it from the inside. It's definitely worth a visit. Just run if you see they put teenage Russians in your tour group.

The ghost of Westminster. I had stopped off at Henry's Bar on the way to Westminster. It was a Friday evening. We were given a guided tour around both houses of parliament. Our guide received supplementary comments from General Richard Vickers from the Winston Churchill Memorial Trust. His view was that parliament was only created so the monarch could raise more taxes for war! I thought about his earlier words that "Africa was rotten to the core" and wondered what type of conversations were taking place inside Buckingham Palace. I slowly detached myself from the party and returned to look at the Great Hall. It was dark and empty and yet full of stories. I heard a telephone ringing. I will never forget it's constant ring that seemed to go on for an eternity. I followed the sound into the lower parts of parliament. It kept ringing, demanding my attention. I tried to determine if the ring tone was delivering good news or bad news. You do that sometimes. Then all of a sudden the telephone stopped. The stillness and deadly silence told me that the telephone should have been answered..........

Really enjoyable . I booked up as I had friends visiting the Uk and thought this would be a great place to visit. I originally purchased the tickets for the wrong date online and the team swiftly corrected my mistake- thank you! We visited on a Saturday and queues were large I believe because they had, had issues earlier but we moved through quick enough and made our way to the start of the tour where we picked up the audio visual guide. This was great! It was wonderful to see things I'd only seen on television or in books, well worth the visit. Having visited the Tower of London the day before and having such a poor visit there (see my poor review) my friend commented how this was 100 times better!

Excellent rooms and institution!. The quintessential legislative power institution is the British Parliament House, within these walls Oliver Cromwell could take down the English monarchy by the execution of a King Charles I (1650) go to all the rooms, and Houses Lords and Commons and enjoy the guide tour with the explanations of the different areas, expend at least 2:30 hours in this visit.

A visit in the uk parliament . My father and I was part of a guided tour of the parliament. The guide was excellent and has a lot of knowledge. Unfortunately the tour was not what I expected. It was mainly about the history of the building rather than the legislative process. also the bigger part of the tour focused at the House of Lords rather than the House of Common, which I found as quite strange. The tour is recommended for those the history, art and architecture of the building is their main interest. Those who mind more of what happen on a regular basis inside the place could be disappointed.

You can spend hours enjoying the immediate area.. Situated part and parcel to Big Ben, they're a must see. During our visit, restoration work (and therefore scaffolding) was ongoing on the riverfront side. This didn't diminish the nighttime photos we took however.

X-rays and machine guns. So we showed up right as they opened the doors to the houses and the security is pretty tight as you can imagine. A new prime minister was just named and things were in a state of flux... guys with machine guns are watching all of the tourist and they run your bags through the x-ray machine. The tour guide walked us through the route of the Queen when she makes her state opening and many other points of interest. She was quite informative and I would recommend this. You cannot sit in either house! But the seats look so comfy!! Just don't do it... also no pictures... they will tell you to put the phone away... May have been the highlight of our week long stay in London.
Great Place. The security to get into is a lot but the Tour inside is fantastic - note that you have to write to your local MP to get a place (or be invited by a Lord)

Lots of interesting facts . Worth the entry fee. Get the audio guide together for 18.5 pounds. Very interesting facts about history of the relationship among the monarch, houses of common and lords. The building is quite smelly inside house of common though. Damp and dirty carpets.

Fully recommend the 'full' visitors package. A most fantastic place to visit for anyone, suitable for all ages.
Can however, only take photos of certain areas of the interior but we will always have the memories

Look at Houses of Parliament as a Whole!. People always focus too much on the tower, that they forget to look at this palace as a whole. While I found the tower to be so so (I meant, it is just a gothic tower, though iconic and beautiful), the Palace of Westminster as a whole looks amazing in the night. "Book" your spot on the south end of the London Bridge for the best view (and photograph) of the Palace!If you want to see the interior, be watchful for the opening schedule in the website.

Brilliant!. If you live in the UK it's possible to arrange a free tour by getting in touch with your Member of Parliament. This is what we did. Tours are conducted early in the day, before parliamentary business starts, so you have to be there by 9.30am.We were taken to see both the House of Commons and the Lords, as well as Westminster Hall. The building is beautiful, and a warren of corridors and passageways! The Commons is much smaller than it looks on TV. Unfortunately you are not allowed to take photos in either of the Houses - there are some very zealous security guards who will tell you off if you try!We rounded off our tour with a visit to the gift shop - reasonably priced souvenirs, and by having a drink in the cafe - a bit expensive, but decent coffee and nice cake.I really recommend a visit to the HoP. Even the stroppy teens enjoyed it! To be able to see so much history and engage with our seat of democracy was a real privilege and something that none of us will forget.

Amazing. We did a group trip from our home town. It was so informative on the tour. Great to tread the steps of all our famous politicians. Nice to sit in the cafe afterwards. Small gift shop. I would love to do it all again as there is so much information to take in. Brilliant!!!!

something one cannot miss. no one will miss this icon of London if they visit London, after Buckingham Palace I guess this one tops the list of attraction in London. I did the same when I first visited London in the eighties but now I live here!

a churchillian view. a different sort of heritage visit.A world that no one knew existed durin WW2. See where tha action happened. Read abot the participants, where and how they lived. A peek into history

Well worth a visit. Our tour was organised by our MP and one of his member of staff showed us around. We were greated in Westminster Hall the oldest part of the building and an amazing building, we were then shown around the central lobby and through both chambers of the house being told a lot about the history and role of the building and the people who work there. The staff and security were very friendly and filled in a lot of info on the building, you could tell they really enjoyed working there and most have been there for a long time. We also managed to get into PMQ. I had wanted to visit for many years and this was certainly something to tick off my 'bucket' list. If you get the chance arrange a visit through your MP to get a sense of history and the power of the building.
One of my favourite London sights!. We saw the Houses of Parliament today both from the London Eye and then walked past it - beautiful architecture.

I was surprised at how much I liked this.. Originally, I thought that this would be a bore. However, there is lots to see and the audio tour had some good commentary, putting the building into historical perspective.You get to see both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Very interesting seeing the rooms in person versus from the perspective of television.

Get a tour guide! Definitely worth the cost.. We took a tour of the Houses of Parliament with one of the official tour guides. He was very knowledgeable and engaging. Definitely worth the cost! We got lucky and took our tour on the weekend just before the change in government. So a lot of activity and interest around parliament.

Wonderful tour. Interesting and informative. The booking process couldn't have been easier. Simply log on to the website and select and tour and pay. There was a bit of a wait to go inside, however the helpful staff were happy to provide umbrellas to shield us from the blistering heat. The tour takes you through the historic palace, including notable locations such as the House of Lords and Commons. The audio guide provided allows you to take the tour at your own pace and is pitched at the right level without being too heavy. Children are actively encouraged not to take the tour as it may be boring for them and unfortunately photography is prohibited for security reasons. Fascinating way to spend a Saturday afternoon!
London Parliament. Its nice being outside and taking in the building and the clock.What goes on inside, is out of my hands, although, running it for a week would change things a bit..........

A must if you want to understand UK politics. If you are a UK resident, contact your MP to see if you can get a on a tour for free. Also remember there is full airport style security to get into Westminster so arrive at the public entrance at least an hour before the time of your tour.

Fascinating tour. Audio guide is very informative with options to listen to more details if interested. Interesting to sit on the benches in the house that were so used to seeing in television. Highly recommended.

Totally disorganised and extended queuing for visitors. I had booked a guided tour over an audio tour for a specific time. Turned up 20 minutes early and there were hundreds in the queue. Sent to to the end of the queue with people who had all booked, with many missing their time slot. Eventually got placed on a guided tour where some of the party were on a coach trip which had to leave soon. We rushed around the tour with hardly any time to take a good look at the building and art works. Done in an hour. The audio tour people could take their time and look around at everything in detail at their leisure. We were herded like cattle and stood in one place in each room without being able to look around it. I queued less time on the London Eye. It is magnificent building and we saw one or two rooms audio visitors do not see. Interesting tour guide but I spent longer in the queue than on the tour. Do the audio tour if you want a good look around the building and get there at least an hour before your time slot.

Stunning architecture, Fascinating History, and Wonderful Tea when you're through!. We visited the Houses of Parliament on July 9, 2016. The tour was fascinating; we were able to enter both Chambers as well as see much of the connecting halls and large meeting rooms. The symbolism built into each room was a striking reminder of the Empire that the UK once was, and after the Brexit vote, this was made even more poignant by our guide. The tour itself is about 2 hours, which is a bit long for families with younger children, as all that history can sum up to loads of dry, boring detail if you're not really interested. However, just seeing the place makes some of the drier bits easier to take! :-) If you can manage it, register for tea ahead of time and enjoy fabulous High Tea along the Thames in the MP's tea room! And reflect upon all the decisons that have been made in this beautiful setting....

So, so cool!. We had just finished a tour of the Westminster Abbey on a Tuesday morning and there we were in front of the Houses of Parliament sensing all the excitement going on about Brexit. My husband is a history teacher and I am a political enthusiast. Our teenage boys are actively engaged in all political discussions around the house. Can you imagine my surprise when I casually asked one of the guards outside the Parliament if we could visit without any prior appointment or reservation, and he responded saying sure, why not! Ma'm, which house would you like to visit, the House of Commons or the House of Lords or both?Wow, it is was so, so, so interesting to be able to sit there watching live debates between the politicians, right in the heart of all the bustle of Brexit and just a couple of days before the PM resigned!! It was a memorable trip that left a lasting impression on all four of us! I also want to add that the staff at the Houses of Parliament was most courteous and welcoming. The only restriction was that one could not take photographs while the parliament was in session. I highly recommend this visit to all who are interested in politics and those wanting to get a glimpse of where the mighty British Parliament makes important decisions for their country, and maybe the world!!!

Really interesting . I was surprised how much I enjoyed visiting the Houses of Parliament it was much more interesting than I had expected seen as I have no interest in politics. Beautiful rooms lots to see and do once your in I would certainly recommend a visit it's not every day you can chance to wander through the chambers that until now I had only ever seen on the tv.
Members Tour. Lovely tour organised by Coombeshead Academy for the School Council of Newton Abbot.Coach trip was awesome dropped us right by HoP, thank you Abbot Coaches.

Fantastic tour, make time to do this. We recently toured the Houses of Parliament and it is a fantastic place to visit and amazing how close to the action you actually get, standing at the dispatch box that so many iconic politicians have stood. For London it is reasonably priced and children are free. Having also recently been to the Reichstag (and whilst free) saw very little by comparison it made me appreciate just how good an experience this is. Also very interesting to compare how open British Politics is compared to others.
Another photo opportunity . Another most for any London trip . Great for family photos. One you can say I was there . Plenty to see nearby as well and it is free.
Saw it from afar, but still cool. We weren't able to go into the area since we didn't want to pay anything, but it was still quite spectacular to see from afar.

Another Treasure. Stand where Winston Churchill gave his speeches and see where his signet ring marked the despatch box as he hammered home his policies. History in the making, another great treasure not to miss in Westminster.

Facinating insight but depends on guide. We visited with friends from the USA. The experience and sights of both Houses was fascinating. However our guide was a little sardonic at times, where as we noted others were much more open and enthusiastic. Also had tea in the members area which was lovely but we did have to wait a long while to get seated. However - worth the experience. The security guard at the end of the tour was very engaging and made a real effort with our friends.

Visit to the Houses of Parliament .. We were allowed into the public gallery to watch a debate in progress , very interesting for our foreign visitors to see our government in day to day business. A must visit.

An amazing slice of history. We loved our guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. There is so much history contained in this location, including the site of trials of Charles I, William Wallace (Braveheart) and Guy Fawkes. Unfortunately, we were not permitted to take photos in most section of the palace, but that is understandable given the nature of the building.The guides are usually retired employees of the Parliament and they are very knowledgeable. They explain the key historical points along with the functions of the Houses today (the role of the Speaker, how voting works, etc).If you are a UK citizen, you can get the tour for free if you contact your local MP. I heartily recommend this attraction.

Such a very interesting place!. We've been meaning to visit this attraction for years and finally got round to it this summer. What a fabulous and interesting visit we had! The audio guide gave a wealth of information and guides in each room added to this with humorous snippets of tales. The Houses are beautiful inside - and we were only a bit disappointed that we were not allowed to take photographs of most of it (this seems odd when the Houses are viewed on national TV daily!). Otherwise, a brilliant tour and highly recommended.
Beautiful and worth viewing.. This attraction is worth viewing and close by to many other attraction therefore it can be seen with other attractions in the same day.

Quick visit but so worth it. Visited the House of Lords for a special event and special it certainly was.As guests we were ushered through some inner corridors and courtyards and it was a fascinating couple of hours.The building is a thing of true beauty and the architecture is remarkable. Despite reports of the building's demise and need of repair it gives off an air of grandeur and is steeped in history.The staff, security and hosts were excellent, including the police officer who hailed us a taxi in rush hour. Brilliant visit.

A happening place with lot of views around. If you are fine in doing long walks, there are a lot of things to explore in this area. You will also enjoy a lot of beautiful scenes around the thames river. The are is very well connected with public transport, but tends to get jam packed with heavy traffic.

A great place to visit and understand how our Government is made up.. I booked my tour via my local MP so it is free. Chargeable tours are available. Had a lovely guide who provided plenty of useful information on the buildings and how the Government use the various areas. Smaller than I had expected.
Beautiful!. This area was included in our free walking tour, be sure to find one while you're visiting London! Educational

Democracy and history combined. We took the English language guided tour and it was truly excellent. With the guided tour you can go to places that are off limits if you use only the audio tour. The information provided by the guide and the answers to the questions was first class, even if, as a British citizen I found the unqualified support for the House of Lords a bit OTT! Highly recommended for all visitors, British and from overseas.

A Very Interesting Tour. We booked the first audio tour - which happened to be booked for the morning after the outcome of the EU Referendum - making it even more interesting to see what goes on in Parliament!Security were brilliant - it's a bit daunting, but a relief to see that they don't take security light-heatedly here.I would suggest taking up the audio tour as this means you can 'skip' any parts of the talks that you aren't particularly interested in, and walk at your own pace.The whole building is beautiful and impressive and I learnt alot in my 2 hours there! Reasonable prices - would definitely recommend.

Spectacular. It is the best I have known of the visit to London. Knowing inside parliament and be in the House of Lords and the House of Commons is a privilege and an unforgettable experience. The audio guide is fundamantela to understand the operation and understand what you see .

Staff training. This was my second visit to Westminster. We were there for staff training. Absolutely loved every aspect of itEnjoyed drinks in the Lords visitors' bar and dinner in the Strangers Restaurant.Attended a debate in Westminster Hall. Had a short tour not with a guide but a colleague so got to know a bit more about the building.It is spectacular

Business function with visit to functions room. Opportunity to be part of the history in open friendly business environment. Following to function social network with visits to functions rooms and history. House of common and the house of Lords. Impressive and welcoming.

Historical Beauty. Go! There's so much history here and I learned so much that I never knew before going. The architecture both internally and externally is utterly amazing. I think of all these landmarks right within this area were all built before there were cranes or bulldozers and it's amazing that they are still standing in all their glory and history through the centuries.

What a wonderful place!. We visited with a friend and joined a tour, it was so interesting. Not only is the architecture out of this world, you can just imagine if those stones could talk. Only low point is the terrifying Thatcher statue, other than that wonderful!

IMPRESSIVE!!. Wow! These beautiful buildings were built resembling the Gothic era, and they are monumental and impressive! Big Ben (or rather the tower known as Big Ben even though Big Ben is actually only the bell in the tower) was massive, and the clock & bells rang at 6:00on as we neared. It was unbelievable!

Government in action. We sat in on both the House of Lords and House of Commons during our visit. They only do tours for educational groups, not the general public, so this was the only way to see anything. No photos are allowed. We happened to be there the same day as outgoing PM David Cameron was giving his final address, but were not lucky enough to be there at that time. Government in action can be a slow, boring process ;)

Day in London . Spend the day in London very hot so very busy, our first stop Westminster, fantastic building beautiful area with plants sculptures and interesting points of history, plenty of places to eat and drink and sit, fantastic day just watching the world go by,

Impressive building. Very impressive to see - it is a true landmark and shouldn't be missed on a trip to London. Obviously it gets very busy but you can get an excellent view if you walk over Westminster bridge. Luckily we got there at midday so we got the best chimes from Big Ben which was a bonus. Don't forget to look at the shadow of the decoration on the side of the bridge which gets "very interesting" at times!

What an amazing tour. We were in London last week and hadn't even thought to check and see if you could tour Parliament. Someone mentioned it on a Tuesday morning so I pulled up the website and was booking our visit minutes later.And then the visit... AMAZING. To see the inside of Parliament and the House of Commons and House of Lords and to learn about the history of England's government was just stunning.You are only allowed to take pictures in a couple of areas - so much of the building is off limits to taking snapshots for your scrapbook but it still was a wonderful wonderful experience.I would highly recommend it. And do go online and book in advance as tickets were sold out at 9AM for the entire day when we visited. So glad we'd bought them in advance and quite surprised, to be honest, that less than a week out they were still available.

Pure History in action.. Have been there a couple of times. Its free and you can gain entry just going through security from the street. Absolutely fascinating especially as you recognise everything with it being on TV all the time. Try get on a tour. The guides are great.House of Lords is spectacular also. You see the great and the good in action. Get tea there also, it's quite reasonable. A small pot is plenty for 2 people.
Absolutely loved this place.. The history in this building is amazing, it is such a beautiful building and the whole tour was facinating with the audio. Very informative.
The national landmark. If Eiffel Tower is for Paris then the Houses of Parliament is for London (including Big Ben). It is one of the most photographed icons in England and best to see day and night.

British Government in Action. We thought that it would be more interesting to see the British Government conducting business on a week day rather than touring the building on a Saturday. It was quite easy to access and we were not the only tourists viewing government in action.The topic they were arguing was voting irregularities. I thought I was in DC for a minute.

Outstanding!!!!!. We undertook the tour of Houses of Parliament. My husband also booked us in for afternoon tea (do this before leaving home). A wonderful experience in such an historic iconic venue. Must do on a trip to London.
Day out . Kids loved the houses of parliament asking a lot of questions about the history and guy fawkes they were just in ore of it all

Interesting and informative. While in London we were lucky enough to be able to visit the Houses of Parliament as they were open to visitors on Saturday. We could not get a guided tour as they were all booked, but managed to get an audio tour. We arrived earlier than our time and was allowed to go in. We had to go through airport style security but when inside the audio tour was excellent with each part of the building explained thoroughly. The tour goes through by area numbers and ran smoothly, and was very interesting. The only down side was the no photos policy I would recommend this tour if you get the chance.

Excellent tour!. Buy your tickets in advance!Street traffic was horrid on the day we attended. Many buses were delayed. We were taking the tube and arrived early. They took us early to make space for those delayed by traffic. VERY WELL DONE!Lovely little gift shop with items you will not find elsewhere!Have a nice cup of tea and a bite in the restaurant.
fascinating. Did the tour of parliament and was very impressed. The guides was very knowledgeable and added richness to the history. Would definitely recommend, I'm still talking about it now!

Not to long ago they ruled the world. This is by far, the most amazing Parliament in the world. Not even DC's amazing House comes close. Just walk around it and think that one day, not long ago, here was where all decisions from the British Commonwealth was made. The empire where the the sun never sets.

Great view - and iconic building. The Houses of Parliament are an iconic piece of architecture that are synomnous with London.So if nothing else - make sure you get a picture of yourself with them in the background. Everyone will know where you are.
Very interesting - great access. Absolutely one of the highlights to our trip to London, staff were amazing and very accommodating. Highly recommend.
Beautiful building. Great piece of history and architecturally incredible and the décor is unbelievable the building is bigger than expected and worthy of arranging a special visit
Nice design building. Everyday thousands of tourists taking pictures of parliament the British the history for another 100 year or more ...

Historic Guided Tour. Take the guided tour rather than the self guided one. Our guide was a very chatty and entertaining Welshman who added so many tales and color to this fascinating intro to British politics and history. Should be mandatory for Americans. Buy tickets ahead of time to assure you are not disappointed.
great experience. Really enjoyed the trip to parliament. We learned a lot from the docent who was managing tickets for the visit to the house of commons.

Visit to PM Question Time. It was a fantastic experience and the building itself is breathtaking. The atmosphere is really lively and I would truly recommend a visit to this beautiful institute. The tour guides are all experienced and so knowledgeable, wear some comfy shoes, its a huge place.

Lovely afternoon tea. We were invited to the House of Lords for afternoon tea as part of the Winston Churchill Fellowship Trust. We had lovely strawberries and cream, scones, cakes and sandwiches, all in the marquee alongside the Thames. Such a lovely way to spend an afternoon.

Just after the Brexit Referendum - Tour of both Houses. Judith gave excellent information on the Houses od Parliament. I did very much enjoy the tour and her comments. Although it was a busy day I could enjoy the tour. Unfortunately I didn't book in advance, so English tours were not available.

Politics can be fun. The history of the building provided by the guide was interested but the ringside seat to the centre ring show that is the House of Commons was fascinating. The three of us (two teens and mom) were rooted to our seats by the debate on education and amused by the cutting comments of both sides. A great insight into the world.

Great tour. This building is amazing outside, but I really recommend to take the self-guided tour of the Parliament, that is open to public on saturdays and can be easily booked on line.Since entrance times are diluted, there is little line and you are given an audio guide that leads you around 20 points of interest inside the Engli Parliament.It has been really amazing seeing the Houses of Lords and of Commons, listening to the various curiosities offered by the audio guide and by the local wardens.A must-see experience, for a very reasonable price
Excellent! . Took a guided tour through the Houses or Parliament. It was wonderful! A lot of history, beautiful rooms and a real sense of majesty.
Awesome design. I always admire the beauty of this old building. It's architectural design is beyond compare. Just standing and watching it makes you wonder how clever the people who built it.
London visit. This was a great trip to do, we enjoyed it immensely. Good security before being allowed into the Houses of Parliament which is a bonus.
The Chapel was built in pagan times. If you get the opportunity to be toured around the Houses by a local MP, take it!There is so very much to learn and see.

Amamazing palace - interesting History. It was absolutely interesting to visit this site. Having a guided tour in German language brought us to a deep insight of the history of this impressive building. It was also a big pleasure to see all those Halls and rooms already known by television but seen now live and to learn how British parliament works in practice.
A cathedral like historic house of Laws. Compared to t our Capital complex this was like stepping into a Cathedral where laws of many centuries were created.
Hard to miss, they are as big as day.. You see the HP from all points in Central London. Lots of photo ops. Next time we will see to looking inside.

Interesting visit, but unpleasant experience with security.. I went with some work colleagues to meet our M.P and I was searched by a police woman in an unpleasant fashion. I walk with a stick and am 60, I was wearing a thin summer dress and a flat belt which keeps my waist warm. The officer kept patting me down and asked in a very unfriendly way why I was wearing it and passing her metal detector over me, I mentioned that I have an artificial knee (which sets off metal detectors) and she said that she "might have to take me in a back room" I felt shocked and dizzy, and humiliated as all my colleagues were waiting. Not a very positive experience.

Continues to amaze. Stayed on the south bank this time so saw the Houses of Parliament from a different angle. Wow, what an amazing sight. Didn't tour but want to visit for afternoon tea sometime soon. Beautiful British architecture at its best.

A great place you should visit. I bought my ticket on line so skipped the queue for tickets. The actual building with the tower and Big Ben is very impressive. Inside you visit the great hall and both the houses, Commons and Lords. There are statues and paintings of famous Prime Ministers in the lobby. I had visited the Parliament in Ottawa Canada and wanted to see the one in the UK. Apparently according to the audio I had they said there were not enough seats in the commons for all the MPs. I was interested to see that the PM sat on a bench in the middle of the room but there were no tables in front of anyone as there is in Canada. When the two houses get together as when the Queen opens Parliament they have to use the great hall to seat everyone. I found the visit very interesting. Outside in Parliament square I saw statues of Churchill and Mandela among others. That day there was a peaceful demonstration against Brexit so lots of people watching. Take the audio tour.
Worth a look and some pics. Looked around the outside and took some pictures. Worth a visit. Not sure if you could get in for a tour or not. Lots to see in the general area.

Symbol of The British Rule of Law. On previous visits to London, I have toured the interiors of the Houses of Parliament and many years ago have sat in the Common's Visitors Galleries during question time when that was possible. Westminster Hall the only surviving part of the original Palace of Westminster dates from 1097 and you are struck by the overwhelming sense of history when you think about the famous persons who have walked through that space. This extraordinary building rebuilt in in the Victorian Period after burning down in 1834, was designed by Sir Charles Barry and Augustus Pugin.On this trip I was walking along St. Margaret Street admiring the splendid neo-Gothic architecture when the assasination of Jo Cox,the young female Labour member of the Commons from Yorkshire, was being mourned in front of Parliament. Against the backdrop of this building the signifies the rule of law, the country was in shock amidst the rancour of the upcoming Brexit vote.

Tour. The guided tour of the Houses of Parliament is wonderful. It's not too expensive and our guide was extremely informative. I'm very interested in politics, but even for those that are not, there is a great deal to see and hear about, presented in a non-stuffy way.

The Best. This was the best visit of them all. To see the seat of English politics is to venture back through history. The House of Lords and Commons are truly wonderful aided by an excellent audio system

Great experience with the guided tour!. We booked online for the guided tour. This guided tour is available on dates the parliament recesses and in multiple languages. When you arrive, you must pass an airport-security type check and then you are directed to a lobby, where the tour groups are finally arranged. The Parliament is beautiful and full of history. The guided tour is a great experience as the guides area very knowledgeable and keep an active pace on the visit. I loved the access to some popular rooms as the Lords Chamber or the Common Chamber, where the parliament members actually seats and debate!I recommend to not bring large bags or cameras (it is forbidden to take pictures), as you will walk a lot. There is no bag storage facility.

A hall with a view . One job to sort out so I had time for a guided tour - very suprised at the size of both the Commons and the Lords - smaller than I thought - the history of the place seeps out of every inch you cover - the Strangers Bar is very reasonably priced and the views from the terrace whilst having a drink is added to by seeing well known MPs relaxing after all the excitement of the last couple of days
A Stunning building. The houses of Parliament has to rank as one of the most beautiful and intricate building not just in London but in all of Europe.

Great Visit!. There was no way I could have anticipated what I saw in the Parliament building. The architecture, interior design, and inside look at Parliament were phenomenal! The audio tour gave a great history of the building and how Parliament works. The tour only takes about an hour depending on how many of the additional audio files you listen to. That leaves lots of time to explore the area and visit Westminister Abbey, which is across the street.

Worth visiting. The interior is extremely beautiful! Also, the feeling you get when walking around in those rooms and aisles where once the greatest made their choices affecting the whole nation....unbelievable.The staff of the visitor center did a great job, the entry was smooth despite the scanning.
What a building... It is 1000 times greater than on pictures. You dont need a special tour to see it. If you happen to be in central London just have a walk around Parliament and you'll be amazed.
The sight to see. As expected, such a wonderful landmark and if you are here on the day of a tour, definiley recommend you take it.

Christmas Office Party. Had the tour of the HoP, then drinks before a fabulous meal, 10 to a table, followed by further drinks and a dance. Would highly recommend to everyone, I'd like to return to do the tour again for a more leisurely wander round.
very interesting and wellcoming .. beautifull and very very impressing visit . Very wellcoming attitude what can i say more ? I wish they will make the right dicitions for the whole world

Superb tour.. We took this tour on Saturday and it was really fantastic. Our guide was really friendly and so well informed. Up close and personal in both Houses of Common and Lords...great being in the middle of it all. Cafe is pretty reasonably priced ..great photo opportunities on way out.

The mother of all parliaments. There is so much history about the Houses of Parliament that I could hardly scratch the surface. If you are planning a trip to London this should be very high on your agenda. I have been here many times and the views from the embankment and Thames never cease to amaze me.

Wonderful architecture. We did the audio tour so that we could take our time and really take in the fabulous building.I had a tour of the houses about ten years ago but there was so much I had forgotten. We had tea and cake after our visit ,the small tea room was fine and the produce was reasonably priced.

Is Big Ben Included?. By the Thames River and the best place to view the whole building is on the bridge. Just be careful because the bridge is full of people and almost everyone stops to take photos.

Parliament Building Tour. Well worth the time to take the tour of Westminster. I booked on line and paid a few days before for the self directed audio tour. Liked that option as you can go at your own pace and spend time really looking at the architecture. The audio explanations are quite good and there were people you could ask questions to in various areas. Give yourself a half hour before to pick up tickets. You have to get them across the street at the Thames side of Portcullis House and then cross back over to the side of Westminster facing the Abbey. Signage is not great and there are crowds, so it did take us more than 15 minutes. I was surprised that there was a cost for the tour as a Canadian, since our parliament tour is free. Was also surprised that Westminster Abbey charged for entry to the church also.
Beautiful building. Big Ben and the Parliament Building is absolutely stunning. Great area to walk and explore the buildings. Across the street from Westminster Abbey.
Powerhouse of West. Definitely a must see.it was the week of Brexit so lots of security around and lots of activities around,we did not go inside.magnificent architecture.

House of Authority. We visited London 16 years ago and saw the Parliament building from the other side of the bank, but it looks just as beautiful from the street. And the wonderful thing is that walking on the street of the British Empire, you look up and look down, no matter what you do, you'll find wonders. We saw this prime meridian seal in front of the parliament building, and was amazed by its meaning.

The guided tour was very good value. We booked a guided tour on a Saturday and were really surprised at what good value it was. the tour lasted about 2 hours, with stops to sit down along the way. The guide was very knowledgable, talking about the history, architecture and modern use of all the rooms we saw (including the House of Commons and House of Lords.
Be sure to take the tour. The tour of the Houses of Parliament was one of the best tours I have ever taken of a historical site. The guides are very knowledgeable and interesting.

What a great tour. One of my favourite tours ever - we had a wonderful time. So good to see the inner workings of Parliament. The tour itself lasted 1h 30 mins and it was inthralling. I learnt so much about British politics that I didn't realise and so much also about the very buildings themselves. Worth every penny to sit in the Lords and stand near the dispatch box in the Commons. Very enjoyable.

Fascinating . We had a free tour arranged through our local MP. To see behind the scenes was fantastic and the little cafe was OK too. We want to do the tour again as we couldn't take it all in in 1 1/4 hours. We had an excellent Indian guide too who is in charge of given permits to the media when they want to enter the lobby.

Great tour. We had a great tour guide called Barry. He gave us a good sense of British government and how parliament relates to the monarchy, as well as the history of the building. I was hoping for a little more reaction re Brexit, but they seem to be keeping a stiff upper lip and carrying on. I enjoyed seeing the difference between the two houses: commons and lords. Worth the guided tour. It lasts about 1.5 hours. I recommend printing your tickets before you come. Enter directly across the street from Westminster Abbey.
Great tour. We did the official tour f Parliament, not an outside tour. The guide was very knowledgeable, the tour itself was very educational. It was a great tour and great value for the money.

Well Done. We had a fabulous tour of the Houses of Parliament. We pre-booked for the morning. Entry was easy. Our guide was knowledgeable. We learned about the history of the building and how the houses of Parliament evolved, how decisions are made, and a bit of the history of the royals.

Audioguides in all languages make it fully adorable :). The Webstminster , such a dream from the childhood to see, when I entered this monument of history and royalty I've got occupied by a mood of ages ago.It's good to plan a couple of hours for visiting it, as there is so much to experience, which is very interesting with audioguide in your native language.
Gorgeous building!. Stunning building! Just off the Thames not far from the London Eye! This huge historical building is definitely worth a visit!
Don't miss seeing. Even if you don't go inside, view this landmark from the river or nearby parks. An architectural wonder, now undergoing 3 billion pound renovation!

Beautiful!. Took the Tour, which allowed us inside access to the Houses of Parliament. While our tour ran over by about 30 minutes, we learned a lot about the history of Parliament and the building itself is just beautiful. Absolutely recommend this tour!
The MPs hiding place. Well I was invited to receive an award so got to see a fair bit. Very restrictive otherwise I imagine. Place is very interested but definatly needs some repairs & soon

Great tour if you can hear the guide. Good tour of the Palace of Westminster, interesting and worth doing. Maybe it was our guide but group too large and they'd started talking before getting everyone together and could hear her when she turned away from the group. This on top of the fact they have 5+ tours going around at the same time in the same route so in echoy halls its hard to hear anything in the mix of different tour guides. If the guides went around in slightly different orders or if the were staggered by ten minutes itd be much better

very interesting tour. we visited the houses of parlament and we lovef it, very interesting to see how things work from the inside.another of the many things that libdon has to offer and you shouldnt miss

History and nice buildings. House of parliaments - a part of history and a good one for all tourists to see. We went a day before BREXIT and it was all secured in the area. We walked along the sides of the building all through to the gardens behind. We spent some time in the garden behind on the banks of Thames. This can be a part of your one day walk tour of Thames river banks.
Private Tour a must. if you're able to get a private tour of Parliament, take advantage of that. You can only take photos in one room of the building, but that does not deter from the experience.

Got to attend Prime Minister's Question (PMQs) Time!!. I watch PMQs on a weekly basis and am a huge follower and fan of the UK political system. Had to pull some strings to get tickets to this event. I have also gone on a tour of the Palace of Westminster which was quite enjoyable. This Gothic palace is one of the birth places of democracy. I highly recommend visiting.

A must see. Had an appointment to meet my MP and, as he was running late, he sent his assistant to show me around while I waited. Amazing building. It was great to actually see central lobby and Westminster Hall. Security to enter the building is strict but understandably so. I was a bit disappointed that a security guard made me leave my demonstration sash at the entrance. He said I could collect it as I left the building but I didn't exit the same way so had to leave it behind. Great cafe and toilets.

Excellent visit with school. I went to the Palace of Westminster with my daughters school (School Council). There was a group of 20 children aged 7-8 years old. The children and adults were all intrigued. We went via the educational centre. I was told my the guide that we can visit the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben for free if write to your local MP and ask them to arrange a guided tour. I also learnt that if you have a question for your MP, and the commons is in session than your local MP will see you. If they can not be located then they will need to respond to your query with 8 days.

Every British person should visit. We try to do one specific thing when we go to London and this time we visited the seat of our Government. The audio tour was excellent as you could move at your own pace and listen to extra bits if you choose to do so.The building is stunning inside as well as out and the price isn't bad either

Confiscation upsetting. I keep my keys on a key ring with my old police whistle from the days I was a special constable. In the security area a rude attendant detached my whistle which is marked, metropolitan police. He said I couldn't take it inside parliament. I am 69 and hardly likely to blow it in the Strangers Gallery! I was given no receipt. At the end of my visit it was really difficult to get back into the security entrance area and I had to explain to several officers why I was going back. Eventually after enquiries it was rudely returned to me.I was upset. I gave over ten years voluntary service to the Special Constabulary and felt treated like dirt.

Steeped in history and beauty. An amazingly gorgeous building where history permeates the air. Well worth a visit. The pomp and circumstance of the traditions and austere dress of the civil servants are fascinating.

Well worth the visit.. We went on a private evening visit at the invitation of our MP and had a tour of the building, chambers and committee rooms. Some areas (The House of Lords) are quite spectacular, whilst others are more than a little 'tired'.

Book a tour of Parliament - its worth it!. We booked to do a tour inside parliament. We booked it through the official parliament website - if you google visiting parliament UK it will come up. Then just click on the link for guided tours. It was 25 pounds per person which is pricey, but it was worth every cent.The guide was fantastic and the tour was fascinating. It was just the right mix of info on the history of parliament and info on the current ongoings at parliament.I would recommend it for anyone aged 16 and up.

Don't miss a tour of Parliament. Our tour guide was wonderful at explaining how the British government works. The building is magnificent and jaw-droppingly beautiful. It's amazing to be able to enter the House of Lords and the House of Commons! Wow!

Iconic Buildings!. The correct name for the Houses of Parliament is the Palace of Westminster. It was built in 1040 by Edward the Confessor. Following a fire in 1834, the Palace of Westminster was rebuilt to the design of architect Charles Barry. Included in the new design is the most famous clock tower in the world - Big Ben. Westminster Hall, which survived the fire, was built in 1097 and is considered to be one of Europe's finest medieval buildings. It is the largest Gothic building in the world and was the main Royal residence until Henry VIII moved to Whitehall. And it’s full of houses: namely the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Parliament is open to all UK and overseas visitors to attend debates, watch committee hearings, or take a tour inside one of the world’s most iconic buildings.Tube Station: Westminster
By chance visit. Great to see inside and look and hear about all the differen t things that go on. The audio tour was informative and you can listen to more if you like on the different button.
A very worthwhile visit. An excellent tour guide made this visit particularly special, very informative, fun and interesting. A must when in London.

Go Early, take "inside tour". Perhaps the best historical site in London, and perhaps the UK. If you miss this you have "missed the boat." Walking tour with guide is the best. Both Houses of Parliament.
Significant. While we didn't go inside, we visited it from the outside, and the buildings are quite impressive from the outside.

A Highlight of Our Trip. We visited on a Monday evening and were able to go to the visitors gallery to view a debate in progress. I'm from Canada and was thrilled to get an opportunity to watch someone else's government in action - I was actually impressed, despite some of the headlines that I've seen. The debate was much more thoughtful and focused on group problem-solving than what I'm used to in my home country. Great context for questioning our own parliament!
Beautiful historical sight. Saw it from the Albert Embankment beautiful interesting building. Good to see from a historical buildings point of view - so intricate
Beautiful. Really beautiful place to visit. Really get a feel for history when visiting. Very interesting. Definitely worth it :-)

Interesting. Took the opportunity to take the guided tour, when the House had broken up prior to the EU Referendum vote. Must book a time slot via website and bring Photo ID. Cost £25 for the Guided Tour. A self paced audio tour is available, but does not give you access to some of the places on the guided tour. Allow 2 to 3 hours. Very informative with information aimed at Nationals and visitors. Well worth a visit to this iconic site. Photography not allowed.

Houses of Parliament. On days the parliament is in session, the gallery is free. But we booked the audio tour online. Very interesting. You get to go in the House of Commons and House of Lords, going down to the floor. A great behind the scenes look at parliament.
Great view !. The view from there is amazing, Big Ben, the London eye, the house of Parliament of course, it's a major landmark and a must see for all tourist.

Very Interesting. I'm not one that follows politics but my brother wanted to do this visit for his birthday so went along and so glad we did this.Even if you're not interested in politics the tour around really is! For those that don't have the slightest, the trip makes everything make sense! We even watched some meetings on the TV after the trip! Out tour guide was very knowledgeable, I wish I got her name! Definitely worth a visit!

Amazing Interriors. I have waited too long to visit here! We had a sensational guide, It was so interesting visiting in a time when our politics in the UK is facing a tumultuous time. The Interriors are magnificent and listening to the very well informed guide made the trip all the more enjoyable. It is a must to take a guided tour rather that a self guided tour. The guides have always good stories to tell. Our guide Mikki was great.

Do not miss a chance for this tour. We had a Saturday morning tour, which we booked online. Since Parliament was not in session, we walked the floor of both House in a relatively uncrowded hour and a half tour. The audio tour--like all we experienced in London--was excellent
Tour arranged via my local MP. Amazing visit. Great guide, really informative. The place is beautiful. Saw both House of Commons and Lords. Great if you are interested in history and/or politics.

History and Politics - heavy subjects. We did a guided tour and were pleased we did. The guide takes you to rooms that are locked to the general public and provides a wealth of information in bitesize chunks. Worth the effort to go on a tour.
Looking sad. This most iconic British building is looking very sad as many parts of it are covered in scaffolding. Well worth a visit inside, but the photo opportunity outside is not so good.
Plan ahead. The Houses of Parliament was interesting to walk through and hear about. Plan ahead as you need to purchase tickets ahead of time and there are only certain days you can go.

A piece of history. The guided tour in summer is very informative and available in different languages. Having the chance to actually see and move around spaces and rooms that you normally only see on TV is a unique experience.

A right honourable day!. I travelled down to the big smoke with some friends to take a tour of the Houses of Parliament. I have always had an interestIn houses, and felt sure one that is parliamentary in nature would be fascinating. Indeed it was!Our tour guide for the day? Non other than our local MP! As somewhat of a political glory hunter, I was happy to be wooed by my guide and found his tour to be full of facts, fun and outrageous political propaganda, all of which I loved with equal measure!The building itself is magnificent and grand, with history built in to every stone and guild. A must visit for historians! We gained unprecedented access to some areas, and were afforded plenty of time to explore at leisure, looking deeper into some of the extraordinary events that have taken place throughout history.It was a real pleasure to know that for a moment, I was standing on the same ground once trodden by legendary parliamentary figures such as Winston Churchill, Margaret Thatcher and Lembit Opik (that one who married a cheeky girl).As we left, I purchased novelty items from the reasonably priced gift shop and had a light snack and beverage from the reasonably priced cafe. On the whole, a terrific, educational and inspiring experience that left me wanting to pick a team and bally well cheer for them!Thank you Guy Fawkes for being the terrorist equivalent of Emile Heskey. If you'd have succeeded with your dastardly plot, my daughter would not have a Big Ben pen and notepad. I perish the thought.9 Big Ben dongs out of 9!

An interesting visit. I went on a tour at Houses of Parliament with a guide. It's a beautiful building, a great history and it's fascinating walking in the rooms of power - standing in House of Commons and House of Lords. Learning about the way the woting system works. I can highly recommend a tour.

Fantastic!. Visited on a Saturday morning. Very organised staff getting you in and through security - a bit like security checks at an airport! The whole tour was totally amazing and the guide was fantastic, very knowledgable and happy to answer all questions. The inside of the building is breathtaking, and you are allowed to enter the commons and lords debating rooms! Would love to do it again!

Heart of British Government-an International Icon Building. London is my hometown where I Live with my family and work. Being in London, I had many occasions to visit Westminster in London. It has become almost a compulsory trip to take all family friends and business friends to these areas every time they visit, I was invited to the Parliament building to see it from inside for the first time by one of my closest friends for a brief meeting in March 2016. I am stunned and very excited to see its architecture and beauty every time I visit. I also see that there are sight seeing trips available for all visitors during certain periods in year and tour guides are available for groups organised. We can always help those planning to visit United Kingdom and know its rich heritage and culture and see this Building also BIG BEN at the bank of river Thames in London.Worth seeing

Fascinating. we did the audio tour because my girlfriend and her son are German and they found it easier to understand in their native tongue. The history and information was fascinating. Plus you could go at your own pace a replay the audio if you missed something. If history is of interest to you then this is a must

Plan your visit. From what I recall on booking the tickets, Houses of Parliament is open certain days of the week and I think the last admission is 1530. So I recommend booking the tickets beforehand.
