One of the perks on going on a tour is you get to see the Elizabeth Tower up-close with no crowds trying to get in front of you and you see the different rooms where debates are held which were architecturally beautiful.

Truly Amazing - beautiful and very interesting!. This was by far my favorite part of a 10 days trip to London!They building is visually stunning, while also rich in history and stories. It also felt like we were learning the greater picture on the country that we were visiting.

Guided Tour-Excellent. Great experience although make sure you understand the ticket process and where to collect your tickets if you do not have them in advance. (Ticket pickup is actually around the corner and down a 1/2 block or so from Big Ben--safe yourself some extra walking and try and get your tickets in advance.) We were excited about this tour and enjoyed it even more than expected--one of the top things we did while in London. The guided tour gets you into a few areas that the self-guided option does not and it is very nice to get an overview of the way the UK government functions (for those like us who are from other countries). Strongly suggest you make a visit and opt for the guided option. (We did not do the tea afterwards.)

Nice Place and Beautiful Building. Houses of Parliement is located in the northern bank of the River Thames in Westminster, next to Westminster Abbey. It is the heart of British Politics, the meeting place of House of Commons and House of Lords, interesting architecture and beautiful building. If you are interested with detail information and history you can have a guided tour.

Open for tours on Saturdays!. Self-guided tours are available on Saturdays. Remarkable to be actually standing in the houses, walking the halls, visiting the antechambers where so much history resides.

Parliament visit. I took a group of teenagers for a visit around Parliament. I don't know who was more thrilled - probably me! I was absolutely amazed by it all, the history and stories those walls could tell. I stood at the despatch box where so many British Prime Ministers have stood. What a privilege.
The Monday after the Referendum. Very busy - not much food available as there were so many visitors. Had wraps which were not very filling and quite tasteless.

Great tour - meaningful. Signing up for the tour was one of the best choices we've made while living for 10 months in London, especially on the eve of the Brexit vote. The guide captured the building's and the nation's history well, noted the architectural and artistic highlights, and effectively explained the place and the processes as we stood in the benches of House of Lords and House of Commons. Watching the TV newspeople in the lobby and the Prime Minister's Questions period has become much more meaningful as we watch during the present time of high drama.

Very interesting. I am an attorney and thus wanted to stop in to see some debate. It was classic in the way the 2 sides jabbed at each other in the most polite of ways. Don't go necessarily for beauty, but to see discussion of world events from a different perspective.

Arrange a visit through your MP. It's worth doing. You get to see both houses plus Westminster Hall and you can go up to see Big Ben (but you need to arrange that separately.Lots of British pomp and ceremony. Especially when the speaker of the House of Commons breezes through.

Very Interesting tour.. If your interested in politics and the inner parts of our MP'S domain then this is the place to visit.Full of History and the Guides are full of information.A great way to pass a few Hours.
WI visit. Very informative guide. Sadly day after Jo Cox was killed so laid some flowers in her memory. The tours were very busy & it was hard to hear when groups overlaped.

Very interesting audio tour. We had a nice time and learned a lot about the British government thanks to this audio tour. Since we were in London during a week end we couldn't attend a regular session but in exchange we were able to wander in every chamber and rooms of the parliement.
just great,,,. One of the greatest monuments of London. Amazing architecture with its facade and the tower of Big Ben.

Interesting place to visit. We did a tour of the Houses of Parliament. We went during the summer months when government was in recess. The tour included seeing the House of Commons and the House of Lords and was very interesting and well worth the visit.
A must visit. Very interesting place, we had a guided tour which was very informative but audio ones are also available. Beautiful architectural building.
Guided tour is a must. If you are a visitor make sure you reserve the parliament guided tour in advance. Worth visiting it and value for money.

The Home of British Parliamentary Democracy. When the Houses of Parliament were rebuilt in 1949 they were rebuilt in the same Gothic style of their 19th century inception. This was pure aesthetic nostalgia and has served absolutely no practical purpose since. The Building is averse to progress of all kinds as technicians must go to excrutiating lengths to install simple modern conveniences such as wi-fi and air conditioning. The taxpayer has and continues to fund myriad "adjustments" attempting to mitigate the crippling problems inherent in the design and pull Parliament's books back into surplus. However as a piece of our collective national history and pride it is an irrevocable landmark. A symbol of unity and pride which is needed now more than ever. Also it can be an awful lot of fun watching MP's (our so-called "representatives") get into partisan shouting matches. The gift shop has some cute pieces of memorabilia and contrived souvenirs aswell.

A New Dawn. Booked tickets in advance to see the installation dedicated to suffrage called New Dawn. Wasn't disappointed at all. It was incredible. The attention to detail & research carried out made the installation both visually attractive & really interesting.The shop had a range of related merchandise & I may have made a purchase...

Beautiful building full of history. We loved the visit - there are so many histories behind each wall... We took the self guided tour and it was good, but I believe that if you have the time to get a proper guide, he will be able to tell you a lot more...

So historical. You cant help but be carried away by the feeling of ancient history here. Seeing it on TV is nothing to being there and feeling the deep deep connection to the past this place has. Sends shivers down your spine and reminds you of all the life changing things that have happened in Londons seat of Poer
Must see!!. Another thing you must see, especially if you have an interest in history. Absolutely stunning, even under renovation like it was when I was there last.

The Houses of Parliament Visit. What a lovey visit we had to the stunning Houses of Parliament you would not believe the beautiful architecture inside with paintings carvings furniture that is being lovingly restored we had a beautiful audio guide well worth a visit

Amazing History. My daughters and I took a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament and were so glad that we did. The tour guide, Owen, was extremely knowledgeable and friendly and he was extremely easy to listen to. He was also able to tell us all of the little details that we would not have known if we were walking around ourselves. I would definately recommend this tour to new visitors
Fascinating tour of the Houses of Parliament. With all going on in the UK was most interesting to tour on a Saturday. Must organize before you visit the uk online.

Most interesting and informative visit. Went on n group visit. Very busy and high security. We had a wonderfully knowledgeable guide who gave much information about the workings of Parliament. Beautiful building with frescoes and painting House of Commons smaller than looks on to. Amazing gold leaf work everywhere and history. Just too many people/groups together.

Fascinating experience. Took a guided tour, which gave us a lot of information but perhaps not the tine to slowly appreciate things so choose which you prefer. The Royal rooms and the House of Lords are amazingly decorative. Airport type security to enter, which was reassuring. Good cafe inside for light meals or snacks.
Nice Architecture. Striking Gothic architecture throughout the whole building. A great view from the bridge or across the river!

One word "WOW". We paid £18.50 each for audio tour. We have booked and printed our tickets online so no hassle at all. It's very educational. The interior and architecture is soooo amazing. It is a must see place in London.

Interesting visit . We did the guided tour which was well worth doing, our guide Karen was knowledgable and really passionate about the history that this magnificent building has and the concise explanations of the different parts of the building and the workings of parliament . The new addition of the "New Dawn" light sculpture to celebrate the women's suffrage movement 100 years ago was amazing worth spending time watching the changes as the tide of the Thames rises and falls

Must see if interested in English History. Fascinating tour into an integral part of British history! Be sure to book your tickets online ahead of the visit. Unfortunately Big Ben is not part of the tour. This can apparently only be booked through a citizen's own local MP.

Great structure . A must area to walk around when in London! Great structure and breathtaking views! Even when it's a not so sunny day! I always come by this area and the Big Ben everytime I go to London!

Amazing Interior!. We spent over 2 hours wandering around this incredible building. The architecture and interior is stunning beyond words. The audio tour was very informative without being stuffy and kept our teenagers engaged. We had the freedom to stop and start, take photos where permitted and wander around at our own pace. As the timings are staggered throughout the day, I doubt it ever gets too crowded. A fantastic experience and highly recommended - a must see for everyone!

Extremely informative. I took a guided tour. It is usually advisable to book the tour in advance, costs about £26.5 for a guided one.I think it is a very holistic tour where you understand about the history as well as the current operations of the parliament. The architecture is a viewer's delight. The guide was very knowledgable and it was an enjoyable learning experience.

Walk where they walk. This is a good attraction in the heart of Westminster. Tours are available every Saturday, with limited tours available during the week. Like everything else in London - great history and stories. An audio tour is included in admission. This is a good rainy day activity as its all indoors. Allow about 2 hours.

In awe. Booked a self guided tour online for Saturday morning at 10am. I noticed it cost less than a tour led by a guide. Security was swift & easy to maneuver through No queues upon entering. Smooth. The self guided audio tour was educational & meaningful. The lovely voice informed us of so much about British history & politics. The directions provided thru audio took you to specific areas all numbered & in order instead of just wandering around & bumping into people. Only in certain areas could photos be taken. This was one of my favorite stops whilst in London. Tube station directly across the street. Just steps from Westminster Abbey & other Landmarks. Glad we went inside for the tour. Inside just as impressive as the outside.

Great place to spend the day. The Houses of Parliament building is a superb piece of architecture. When you look at it from the South Bank – you get a true sense of how grand this building looks. Big Ben stands majestically overlooking the Houses.The nearest underground station is Westminster.It is a great place to spend the day with your family and to learn the things that take place here that govern the country. There are many interesting facts about the Houses of Parliament. There are guided tours that will give a wealth of information of this Parliament. Parliament is made up of the House of Commons, the House of Lords and the Monarchy. Members of Parliament debate and have discussions in the House of Commons and the Lords either approve or not in the House of Lords. Parliament makes and passes new laws, debates various issues concerning the country and approves Government spending in terms of the taxes and budgets. Parliament also monitors and checks the work of the Government by questioning ministers and their respective ministries.When you think of history, you will recall that Guy Fawkes tried to blow up the Houses of Parliament. He must have been crazy to carry out such a deed. Security is very tight just like how it is in airports. There are restrictions on what you can and cannot photograph. By the way, there are no cloakroom facilities.Tickets cost GBP18.50 per adult (June 2016). One child up to 16 years of age is admitted with each fee paying adult. You will need to select which timed tour you wish to go for. There is a café that serves snacks and drinks and a nice gift shop.I would highly recommend a tour of the Houses of Parliament. You will definitely like it.

Great tour. I went on the guided tour and it was both informative and interesting. I highly recommend it to anyone who has any interest in British politics or history. There's also a less expensive audio tour that looked like it would be worthwhile and allow you to go at your own pace.

Guided tour with David a must. We live in london and have always wanted to tour parliament. So glad we did as it was informative, interesting, and educational. Our tour guide David was spectacular! We loved his tour. Only go if you're going to pay for the guided tour otherwise it's hard to get the meaning of the different parts of the building.

Historical & impressive. Book your tickets online, to avoid disappointment as this is a very popular tourist attraction. Getting into the houses of parliament can take upto an hour due to the crowds & security checking. But it is totally worth it. Both the house of Commons & the House of Lords are impressive & have a lot of history associated with it

Ideally classic. Like the Big Ben, this building is unacessable but if your lucky, you might meet a parliament representative. Wear your jacket at all times because it is very cold in London in the summer.
Huge. It is back drop of big ben and an Intricate building which can be seen from the bridge also if you choose to take a cruise on Thames.

Fascinating incite into an iconic landmark. We booked a guided tour and it was very reasonably priced at £25 each but I believe you can apply to your own local MP to get a reduced rate but we didn't have time to do this.The entry was much like an airport screening with scanners for your handbags which is to be expected in this environment. and we didn't have to wait too long to get through.The guide was extremely knowledgble and answered loads of questions from several of us in the group which was a reasonable size so you could hear everything.We got to see the house of Lords & the house of commons and we had the traditions and various roles explained to us along with the history of the building.Its a beautiful building with numerous corridors and rooms and I loved the Division bell system calling the MP's to vote which is linked into several pubs in the area. We went to St Stephen's Tavern which is a lovely old school pub which is all glass & brass & always busy spilling out onto the pavement.Would recommend Houses of Parliment for a London day out - book in advance to avoid queues

An impressive building with so much history. The tours are excellent.. The Houses of Parliament are such an important part of the country and also a landmark in their own right. During the summer recess of Parliament, you can go on a tour of the building and it really is worth it. Pre-booking is essential, but worth the trouble. The tour guides are very good indeed and you get to see Westminster Hall (where Richard II was deposed), the Commons and the Lords, while learning about the history of the building and the democratic system over the centuries. Highly recommended.

It is iconic and a great place to see. Visiting London? This iconic landmark of London is worth your time to see. If you have time and some money to spare (and you are outside visitors) buying a package tour is good so the tour company will arrange the tour inside the building (I think you can read on the website and will get that insight as well). If you go to that area, you definitely seeing Big Ben, Westminster Abby and the Parliament. For picture op, take the underground to the area-get off at Westminster station and have your picture(s) taken with these three major icon and just walk around like everyone else. Just the size of seeing the Building and be among the people is worth your time and get chill feeling through your spine.
Changing Guard. The Changing of the guard was a wonderful experience. Very colorful. Children will enjoy the pomp and pageantry. A must see.
Beautiful icon. I did not go in but took th photos from a bus tour it is the building that u will get goosebumps from seeing it is the most photoed building i

Political Workings of UK. We were there at the time the Prime Minister Q&A session with Parliament was scheduled to discuss the EU membership. Unfortunately, there was great demand to get in an only UK residents had priority. We came back the following day and spent about 45 minutes in each of the Houses to hear the discussion of the Syrian refugee situation. We did not hear Jo Cox speak, but there were equally eloquent MP speakers. Wonderful oppty to see the political workings of another country
Looks impressive. But could only view it and walk past, its not like you can go in and tour it... or can you? I dont know! I wouldnt mind...

Excellent guided tour. We took the guided tour to the Parliament and it was extremely interesting. They took us to all the most important rooms and the guide was very knowledgeable.Cons: no photos and beware of taking anything sharp as security is tight.
Always so wonderful to see this iconic building day or night. Recommend walking day or night..Beautiful building and of course Big Ben chiming give you goose bumps!
Great pictures to be taken.. Enjoyed the opportunity to take lots of pictures at the Houses of Parliament.Great day & beautiful weather made this an easy spot for a morning walk.

MUST SEE. You need to plan your visit when Parliment is not in session or on a Saturday. Plan ahead to get your ticket or tour. Some are in combination with Westminster Abbey tour. You will not be disappointed since you are visiting this active, historic building. You can get audio guides which are great. You will need about 1-2 hours taking the audio tour and go through the usual airport type security. Also, there is quite a smartly dressed guard team in each room. They are all stellar. You can ask them just about anything and they are quite knowledgeable, friendly and love their jobs. How often do you get into the House of Commons, House of Lords right on the floor!!! The accompanying rooms are teaching historic, governmental museums in their own right. There is a cafe and gift shop for the House of Commons inside. Don't just pass by the building thinking what if.

Surprisingly excellent and engaging. I had no plans to visit Parliament on my most recent trip to London, somewhat misguided in believing it would just entail looking round a few rooms that I commonly see on TV. However, following the EU referendum debates I have had a renewed interest in politics so decided to spent some time in Parliament rather than just taking picture of the building. There were extensive queues to get in, around 20 minutes, understandably security needs to be tight but perhaps there could be more staff to ensure a quicker trip. I opted for the audio tour £18.50, rather than the £25.50 group tour. I fail to see how the group tour could be more informative than the audio tour. The information provided by the audio tour was very detailed and I left feeling that my knowledge of the building was greatly enhanced. I spent around an hour in the main hall, the amount of historical events that have occurred in the hall is sheet - Charles 1 trial, William Wallace's Trial, addresses by Nelson Mandela and the Queen. I then went into St Stephen's Hall which contained many exquisite mural paintings on the wall and statue of several historical politicians (all male at the moment!). Photos are permitted in the main hall and St Stephen's Hall but not thereafter. I then moved on to the central lobby, which contains statues of Churchill and Thatcher amongst others , and also a post office. It is the main lobby that leads into the Commons on one side and the Lords on the other. I then went into the House of Lords, much smaller than I thought, not allowed to sit on the seats. The Queen's throne is truly glittering and dazzling. There is then a surprising room containing paintings of monarchs past and present and paintings of the Battle of Waterloo. I then moved into the House of Commons, again quite small and was very excited to find myself in the place that so many debates and important votes took place. You are not allowed to sit on the seats but are able to freely wander between the seats and by the despatch boxes. Highly recommend this tour.
London site to see. Good photo opportunity. Very grand and historic structure that one must-see while in London. Not to be mistaken as the Westminster Abbey.

Visually spectacular. Not just because it's iconic, for me it is mainly because of the beauty and the size of the entire building coupled with Big Ben standing proud next to it. It's truly a sight to behold.
tour and tea. we went to visit the parliament and what an amazing visit it was! afterwards we had tea there (must be booked in advance). we absolutely loved it!

Really excellent tour !. I booked this as part of hubbies BD in London and it was brilliant .Excellent value 90 minute guided tour and a real insight into the history of the Houses of Parliament .Our tour guide Sarah was really good made the tour come alive.I hadn't appreciated how stunning the building was, it was beautiful .To see the House of Lords , the House of Commons , where the Queen walks , the lobby etc was great .This has to be a must do when visiting London , not sure why we left it so,long .

An interesting Visit. Spent a good two hours going round this interesting place. Security first then into Westminster hall for the map and information booklet as well as the usual gadget and headphones for your tour. You can only take photographs in the first two halls which are Westminster Hall and St Stephen's Hall before you hit the centre lobby where the House of Commons and House of Lords are on each side. Plenty of advisors nearby if you have questions. Loads of paintings and statues which you would recognise. There are stairs so accessibility to wheelchair users is by alternative routes. There is a café to enjoy coffee/tea and a snack after your tour. I would recommend this tour as I found it very interesting learning about the day to day workings of parliament.

It's what's on the tin. Strict security and a generally good tour. I was disappointed about no photography but I guess that's a given. The audio tour was pretty well done and a good learning experience to kids. The bit where it says things are usually civil in the commons is just not true though. The heckeling MPs are at it each week and it was excellent to stand near the seats of famous MPs like Dennis Skinner. Good but not amazing. Recommended though and a key pary to any London sight seeing day
my family argued more than the poloticians. great on architacture but was cold and damp. my family argued so much about the temperature that i nearly had to leave.
Wow. Well organise...well describe we tooke the guide tour and is really a good things to do it once in a while I will try next time the afternoon tea...i incrase my colection og gin and bath duck
A must in London. As well as Big Ben the Houses of Parliament is a must for a visitor in London. At the moment parts are shrouded for renovation.

Stunning piece of architecture . I guess it's very rare to see it without a part now being in scaffold as major repairs need to be done, but the place is simply stunning! No wonder it's a major draw for foreign visitors and the like. Visited two days after the horrific murder of MP Jo Cox and to see the flags flying at half mast was a touching tribute.
Nice!. This is a must if you are in London. They are a lot bigger and grander that they appear in photographs and postcards.

Historical center of London. Go see the Houses of Parliament. Big Ben and Victoria tower. There is so much history here.
I don't have to recommend this place, you were already going to visit anyway.

The audio tour was excellent. We opted for the self guided audio tour and our 8 year old found it fascinating. The guides were all helpful and knowledgeable and at no point did we feel rushed to move on.
Great audio guided tour!. We had an impressive tour through the building and enjoyed the audio tour a lot! the building is impressive, full of history and interesting facts.
Tour?. A really neat hugh building. Is the tour worth it? Depends on what you are interested in. My husband was interested, me not so much.

Parliament Tour!. What a great tour. Learned so much about the Houses of Parliament. The tour guide was great. We were the first group to tour in the morning so we had the place almost to ourselves. It was interesting to hear all of the traditions that they still have in place after hundreds of years. I would definitely recommend it!

Fascinating historical site. While I was surprised we needed to have an audio set despite our not wanting the audio tour(for security reasons), it was a nice addition. The rooms were very rich in history and artwork. The only downside to this tour was the need to purchase tickets two blocks away from the entrance. Was not well marked.

Impressive and moving. We've been twice, thanks to our MP. We've sat in the public gallery of both houses, and took a tour that allowed us to sit in the back benches of the House of Commons. We also got a (separate) tour of the Elizabeth Tower and stood by Big Ben as it chimed 12. (We had earplugs in!) Both tours were impressive.If you care about our democracy - indeed, if you cherish the fact that we HAVE one, however badly tarnished - then go. Get your MP to arrange the tour and it'll be FREE. Stand on the spot in the 900-year-old Westminster Hall where Charles I or William Wallace were put on trial, or where Winston Churchill lay in state before his funeral, look at the amazing ceiling that dates back over 600 years, and (if you're British) be thankful that you don't live in North Korea, Iran, Zimbabwe, China or a whole load of other places that don't have the democracy and freedoms we take for granted. The saying goes that 90% of politicians give the other 10% a bad name. This may be true, but at least we have some control over our politicians - as much through the embarrassment of adverse publicity as the ballot box - and it's quite humbling to stand in Westminster Hall and think of all the people - Chartists, Abolitionists, Tolpuddle Martyrs, Suffragettes, etc - who fought so hard for the freedoms we now enjoy. Go - and be moved; it's your democratic right.

Like in a Harry Potter's novel. To be inside the building is like to be inside a fairy tale or the famous Rowling's book or a textbook on English history :-)Rich decorated spaces, no photos are allowed.Audio guide tour works fine, possible to order it and pay in advance on website.90 minutes or more

Wonderful tour. We did the guided tour and thought it was just marvelous and well worth the effort to book ahead of time. I had read that the security lines were very long so we got there quite early but the attendant actually said we were there too early and could we come back a little later! Security was a breeze and the whole thing was very nicely organized. So informative and interesting.

Discover more on the history of parliamentary democracy in the UK. We took the audio guided tour and it is very detailed and entertaining. Along the path there are places where it is possible to sit down and take photos; in some of the places it is forbidden but there is a good balance.Stunning visit, especially the Royal Gallery, the Houses of Lords and Commons and Westminster Hall.

Beautiful Building Full of History. Our guided tour was very interesting. We were amazed at the beauty of the interior of the buildings. The tour was very informative and not too long at 90 minutes. You can only visit by guided tour on days when the Parliament is not in session. It is important to pre-book. This is one of those hidden gems.

Facinating for locals and visitros alike. We were very fortunate as we had a memeber of staff give us a tour of both houses. Although I get to visit for work on occasions, having time to take in the history and find out some of the unusual details was just a joy. A must for anyone visiting our great capital!

A Great Tour. We signed up for an English speaking tour of Parliament through their website for a day when the legislators were on recess. It was well organized and they even accommodated our late arrival. The tour lasted about 90 minutes and took us through all the public spaces including the House of Lords and House of Commons with time in each for detailed explanations. We learned a lot which has already faded from my mind after a month but which was very enjoyable and informative at the time! The group was about 20 with no listening devices but we were able to follow along quite well and even my 81 year old husband heard most of it.Afterward, we had also arranged for afternoon tea (through the website) on a terrace overlooking the Thames, which was a slight disappointment. The venue was not a real room but a tent like enclosure with plastic windows and a noisy floor and everyone was being served at once which made for lots of servers walking back and forth constantly. Not very relaxing but the food was good and I guess it was good value at £29 each compared to hotel teas. The view was fun.Anyway, great afternoon out in London. It had been on my list for awhile. The best part was no standing in lines.

Open to the Public. By chance, mu husband and I went to the Houses of Parliament to see if it was open to the public. It is when the Houses are in session. It was in session and we were able to go in without waiting in any line. There is much security all around but it is worth it. We entered and walked the big hall, climbed the many stairs and were allowed to view the House of Commons behind a glass wall. Afterwards, we went to the House of Lords and were thoroughly impressed as we saw the men in white wigs discussing various bills they were working on. I would highly recommend this tour as a free activity to do in London.

Loved this!. This was wonderful, educational and just down right enjoyable. any history buff would LOVE this. I really enjoyed being able to be in the House of Commons and enjoyed learning about how parliament works. Ask questions as you go along. The audio is a must or you will miss lots of information.

Do Not Miss This Spectacular History. We were lucky enough to get an inside tour by a lord of the Houses of Parliament. Seeing the outside is not enough. Buy a tour to get inside. I don't know how much one is or whose is best but just do it. I have been in US Capitol and my State Capitol (Minnesota) but neither holds a candle to this place. It is from where much of the structure of my Country (United States) came. It is full of Great Traditions.

On the bucket list. Have always wanted to have a look round parliamentHad a tour with guide, tour was about 1.5 hours and was very informativeYou can only take photos in a couple of areas - not the chambers !Well worth visiting, reasonably priced
the spot where the people speaks. A meeting with history at the emblematic center for parliaments. it is the spot where you still understand the meaning of popular representation.

Impressive. Just to let you know, there is a very strict security, you cannot wonder around, just to walk in s specific direction- no access to the river Thames unless you book afternoon teaThe staff was very politeThe building itself is amazing, just like on tv, it's great that they let tourists inFantastic art work and tourPS Also thank you to wonderful security officer, who offered me an umbrella while I was waiting outside of security area in the rain:)

Palace Tour. My MP arranged for tour tickets for myself and my niece. We were there a few hours with a tour guide who was very interesting and knowledgeable. We thorough enjoyed the tour more that we expected and it was beautiful and many works of art. We went into the houses of parliament chambers and the lords chamber. We also viewed from the visits balcony government discussing matters, it was quite unreal, but exciting too. Well worth a visit.

Anniversary weekend in london. We pre booked the audio tour. The tour was very informative and you could go round at your own pace. It took around 1 1/2 to 2 hours. The architecture, statues and art was all incredible. Seeing the inside of House of Lords and commons on tv just doesn't do it justice. Truly breathtaking. We would definitely recommend visiting.

A very interesting trip.. Really enjoyed a visit inside the Palace of Westminster and it was great to learn about the history of the place and to see inside the House of Commons. We also got to visit inside the House of Lords whilst a debate was going on which was a real insight. Would highly recommend a visit here.

Plenty to learn about. I booked a guided tour online. But you can also do a audio guided tour which you can book online or book at the ticket office near the Westminster underground station. Or else you make your way to the entrance to collect your ticket and have your bag checked. Once you enter the great hall, you either go to the digital guide counter to collect it or to the guided tour counter to inform them that you have arrived. You can collect your souvenir guide book if you have ordered one at the digital guide counter.Depending on the number of people, there may be more than one tour group. You will be escorted to the different rooms and explained about its functions and its history. Do note photo taking is not allowed. The tour takes about 2 hours.

Tour and afternoon tea. We chose the accompanied tour and we're pleased that we did. The guide, Norma, was helpful, informative and knowledgeable. The tour passes through the Queen's robing room, the House of Lords, House of Commons and many other places. There is a good explanation of the history, art and use of each room as well as the chance to stand (but not sit) in the benches where the lords and MPs sit. Booking is essentialWe followed to tour with afternoon tea under cover on the terrace, very tasty and not unreasonably priced for the location.I would highly recommend both the tour and the afternoon tea
Parliament. Very interesting place...saw this on a tour..learnt a lot about it, and how it works....lovely building

Excellent Tour. This was an excellent tour. I would definitely recommend doing the guided tour. Our tour guide was very good which made a huge difference. If you have time, take the guided tour and then go back and walk through again at your own pace to see all the things you missed the first time. One of the best tours we did all week.
Historical!. We did the audio tour which was nice because we could wander around on our own and not be stuck in a crowd.

House of Curiosities. Until last week I didn't even realise it was possible for lowly mortals to wander free inside our glorious seat of government, It came as quite a surprise, then, when I was invited to take a tour of the Palace of Westminster last week to discover that the building throbbed with school parties, and tourist groups from every corner of the world. MPs and Peers rubbed shoulders with the common herd as they went about the necessary tasks involved in running the country. Even the doors of the great debating chambers themselves are thrown open to visitors when not required for the business of the day. You can stand by the Woolsack in the Lords and see the marks on the table made by the signet ring of Winston Churchill as he hammered home his opinions. There on the doors themselves are the indentations made by Black Rod's staff of office. ( A black rod, one assumes) The decor in the Lords rivals any stately home in the land. Not so that of the Other Place, which is utilitarian and unassuming by contrast.On arrival, quite naturally, visitors are frisked comprehensively. (Don't wear oversized trousers, as you will have to relinquish your belt for the scanners.) The purified tourist is then disgorged into the echoing and ancient Westminster Hall, a marvel of pre-conquest archiecture not unlike the great dining hall at Hogwarts Castle. Brass plaques mark the spot where the great and glorious of the past were laid in state, or, in the case of the hapless Charles I, condemned to death.Arrive at the start of the day's business in the Commons, and you may observe The Speaker's procession into the house, heralded by a cry of "Hats off, strangers!" when even burly policemen hasten to doff their helmets. If men in tights are your thing, this is the moment for you. To tour the twin Houses of the British Parliament is an experience to be savoured. Souvenirs are available from the small gift shop, Lights snacks may be obtained from the cafe, but the highpoint of your visit, if the commons is in cession, will be visit the Public Gallery, the day's Order Papers in hand, and to watch for a while in reverent silence as the very wheels of government turn before your eyes down there below you, on the floor of the House.Take a conducted tour if you can, to discover the many quaint and curious facts about the place. (Did you know, for example, that it is against the law to die in this building?) Both an education and an entertainment, this is one day out every voter should experience at least once in a lifetime.

This is a Palace. Visiting Parliament in London isn't about politics or government. The British houses of Parliament are inside Westminster Palace, an actual Palace once occupied by Kings and Queens. The rooms are very grand, big with high ceilings, and opulent, decorated with details and paintings everywhere. They do show you the places where the prime minister and the MPs sit and explain how they go about their business, but that's only one part of the tour. There is security screening at the entrance, similar to airport security (you have take off anything metal and they screen your bag).

Beautiful building both inside and out. Was lucky enough to be invited in last year and really enjoyed seeing inside for the first time. So much history within the walls, would highly recommend for any tourist or local.

What an amazing Building!. The Palace of Westminster itself is the Star of this tour!.You have to book in and and be issued with ID and go through security to enter.Once inside, and on the Tour you will be taken into the Actual House of Commons and then the Lords. What amazed me was all of the anti chambers, particularly around the Lords and their level of opulence and splendor. It really is a Palace inside. The old Hall which forms the core of the Building with its high vaulted Ceiling is also a highlight.I even managed to find the pIgeon hole for my own MP! The guide also explained how the voting system worked, which is very effective in its simplicity.Finished off with Tea and Scones in the Cafe!.

What a fantastic tour. We booked to do the tour on June 11th which was the day that The Queen was celebrating her 90th birthday, so it seemed even more special. Big Ben's bells were peeling out in celebration and there was a very nice atmosphere all around. We arrived early as we did not know what the traffic and trains would be like, we had a drink and snack in the cafe, before our 1 p.m tour.We had such a nice tour leader, she was really very good explaining every room as we went along, I am disabled, and she arranged for myself and my husband to go up in a lift, this saves a lot of stairs. Once up there with the rest of our group we went from room to room, and it was amazing to see everything up close and personal, after seeing it so often on TV. She explained all the portraits to us, and also all the restoration work that is being carried out. The tour took almost 2 hours, there is a lot of walking, and only a couple of places that we were allowed to sit down for a few minutes.I booked it on line and they do afternoon tea as well, book early though as it's very popular.All in all very pleased that we did it and once again thank you very much to our very nice tour guide.
Beautiful palace. This building is a world landmark on the outside but definitely, look into the guided tours to get a detailed look at fascinating periods of English history.

Great Experience!. If you have the opportunity, see the Houses of Parliament on a Saturday. We happened to find out that it is open to the public on Saturdays. It is an experience you won't soon forget. It is a 90 minute guided tour, and worth the time. Make sure you have your tickets before going to the gate. The tickets are sold across the street from Big Ben, then you have to walk down to the entrance gate. There is a café inside where you can have a snack while waiting for your tour to begin. The historical and procedural information was excellent, especially if you get Christine as your tour guide.

Great building. The view of the Houses of Parliament from the other side of the Thames is quite stunning. To check out the House of Parliament it is best to do an audio tour as you can move around on your own time table and not be stuck in a large crowd.

Great tour. Great tour. Picked the guided tour and had a very knowledgeable guide. The place is very interesting, with a lot of history. The tour length was perfect, not too long or short. The line to get in was very reasonable. Would definitely recommend to anyone who is interested in history, royal history and government.

Interesting to see the workings of government. Getting to see the House of Lords in action so to speak. Interesting, glad I don't spend my days there, but good to visit. Buildings worth a look too, didn't get to see it all on my visit, just on own not part of a group. Told being part of a tour group would have been able to see House of Commons which was not in session.

Another must-see from Britains history. Westminster is another place with a history that deserves a bit of your time. I've walked aoround it and seen it from the ouside numberous times, but this is the first time I've been inside. The main hall alone is worth standing in as it has been the platform for many great speakers including Winston Churchill and countless royalty.We didn't do an official tour so I'm not sure the quality or value of actual tours but the building itself is worth seeing.
Can´t miss it. Take the audio tour and regulate your speed of your tour, according to your interests and time available.

Fantastic Tour. We were very lucky. Parliament was open when it was not supposed to be open so we just walked right in (after walking 2 blocks to buy the very cheap tickets). I've been to London 5 times in my life and always wanted to visit Parliament and always it was closed, so getting in on Friday May 27, 2016 was a real treat. This is an amazing building and they let you visit every room (but no Photos). One can stand (no sitting) where the Prime Minister stands and take in this room with so much history. Also you can visit the House of Lords. Trust me, if they are open this will be the highlight of your visit.
Was ok. I did a tour and this was one of the places we visited. Regularly I would just skip this or walk by out of curiosity... But it was just ok for me. Nothing to do with the location..

Historic and stunning.. After the queue and security check this place unfolds and history comes up to meet you. It is not at all stuffy but do not sit on the seats if you are a commoner! There is so much to see and the sense of past power and intrigue is tangible. The peculiar dual system of Lords and Commons plays out here and you can touch it and absorb some of the fascinating machinations of this ancient institution. Quite a wonder!I just wish as a Brit expat we could have booked to see Big Ben too.Not qualified apparently!

Put this on your "A" List and Schedule a Guided Tour. My wife and I were here at 1100 hours on Saturday May 28, 2016. I scheduled the guided tour as soon as it was available online. It is a group of 15 people. Photos are limited to certain areas. The guide brought us "behind the ropes", we sat in the House of Commons, and walked corridors not open to the public. The tour was 2 hours and is an excellent personal experience. Allow time to get through the layers of security and bag checks. Go soak up history and you will not be disappointed. Highly recommend.

Nice if you like politics. Burned town to the ground and rebuild. The palace is not that old. But the great hall is one of the few reminders of the old palace.You can visit the house of commons and the house of lords. Book the guided to to get in to the Elisabeth tower. "Big Ben".
worth seeing. great to see this well worth the effort. a pretty amazing pace. be prepared for security checks so go a few minutes past opening times and the crowds are less

Guided tour. We booked a guided tour. The queuing outside & coordination of the group in the Great Hall entrance was chaotic, however when the tour got underway it was fascinating. Our tour guide was Diane Small. She was superb & she engaged with everyone in the group. Diane is a real credit to this attraction - a wonderful lady.

nicest house of parliament in the world.. Exceeding beautiful and grand, the houses of parliament are also mysterious in their architecture and size. I would love to be able to just wander around alone! Even my kids loved it.

Disappointment. Due to a useless website and rude guard, I never made it inside. Details of how to purchase tickets are not online, or at least not easily found, so we naively thought we could find them at the door. When we arrived at the gate, the guard waved us on as if to say there is another gate further down. I am disabled and shuffled on with my walker past droves of people until I found myself at The Thames. There was no other gate. So I shuffled back, along with my niece who had a broken foot, only to be told tickets were available in an unmarked building 3/4 of a mile away. We had expended all our physical efforts by that point and got on a bus and left. All of this could have been avoided had their website been more informative, and their guard cared. It's the only London attraction where we've had a bad experience. I recommend they walk across the street to Westminster Abbey to see how it should be done.

Beautiful building!. Many people are so excited about seeing the Elizabeth Tower that they miss the beauty of the Houses of Parliament. the building is absolutely stunning. The detail in the architecture is amazing. It's worth taking a slow walk around the building and taking the time to peer through the fence to really admire the details of the building, and the statues on the building and inside the fence.

FASCINATING VISIT TO COMMONS CHAMBER. Applied to my local MP and got three free tickets for entry to watch events in the House of Commons Chamber. Very simple process and had tickets for the start of a Monday session at 2:30 p.m. Get there a bit early to watch the procession go into the chamber which is quite interesting. Obviously you don't know what will be discussed and which MP's will be in attendance but questions move on fairly quickly so during 90 minutes we saw quite a lot of debate and statements from some cabinet members. Quite a lot of claim and counter claim and arguments over figures (all frustrating for the general public. Overall though a very good insight into our parliament and views of the Great Hall and Chamber.

Good guide tour. We visited on Saturday the 4th of June and opted for the guided tour as I like to ask questions if I want to. The tour lasted 2 hours and it was great. Loads of information to take in. Tours are staggered and as the group behind us was hot on our heels we didn't have an opportunity for questions during the tour which was disappointing. I managed to ask the guide a few as we walked from room to room but felt we were rushed.
Must be seen. One of the symbols of London and the UK. Best is the view from Westminster Bridge and the park to the hospital on the other side of the river ..

House of Commons Gallery Visit. This is one visit you should not miss. There was so much history on display. We actually went up into the gallery to watch the day's debates. It was fascinating, EU issues, marriage certificate minutiae, and a lot of ups and downs voting. COOL!!!! Check out the gift shop, nice stuff there.

Stunning! . The Houses of Parliament are something else. This iconic attraction proved very popular with tourists but one you have to visit whilst in London. The place is huge. Elizabeth Tower (Big Ben) provides some great picture opportunities too and round the front you can see more of the architectural features too. The place is Police guarded and gated but if you stand back away from them you can get some great pictures yet still pick up the features of the building. A must see for everyone planning a visit to London.

Historic Parliament. Second visit to Parliament, and enjoyed it again. The first visit was with a guide, the second with an Audio Guide. Would recommend the live guide if you have a choice. Great visit either way. Book early to get the you want.

Fascinating guided toour. Book early and go for the guided tour (not the headphone one). There's a lot of walking around, and lots of steps, so not for pregnant ladies (ours fainted) or the frail. If you like history or politics, or just want to understand a little more about the history of our Parliament, this is a must-do.

Great tour, Beautiful structure. Did the audio tour of parliament, which was well worth it! A great mix of information about their government system, history, traditions, and lore, very much enjoyed the tour and getting to see and hear about the magnificent westminster palace.

Cocktail dinner for a good cause. Was invited to a cocktail dinner to raise money for a charity I support. Once time Ive been inside the Parliament, we got a free tour and was given some history. Had a nice view from the balcony and enjoyed the great views. The food and drinks was perfect.

Interesting. A spur of the moment decision, but well worth it. We happened to be in the area, and decided to go in. Beautiful building, and it's fun to have been there next time debates come on the news.

Incredible sightseeing opportunity!. Where else but Westminster can you see Big Ben, Westminster Abbey and the Houses of Parliament in one incredible view. What a photo op!!!! Then again that's the reason why they are on virtually every post card, every tour and every TV Travel Log of London!!! Definite Must See when touring London.

Iconic. Only viewed from their outside but a truely fascinating building to study in design and achitecture. Only downside was the restoration that was going on, which I understand is necessary, but the way they covered this work was not very subtle which was a slight disappointment.
Big ben - London mark. Must see! On the River Thames characteristic London Big Ben and Parliament - House of Commons and House of Lords.

A walking visit. Didn't actually go into Parliament for any tour but did spend quite a bit of time taking pictures from around the building(s) including from across the river.
Views from across the thames are in fact one of the best spots to go for pictures.

Great audio tour. We came with two boys under 8 and I can honestly say that we had a great time. We hadn't ever thought about being able to do a tour of the Houses of Parliment but are so glad we did. We collected the tickets from the box office by Portcullis House and had to go through the airport style security bt Cromwell Green entrance. We were allowed to take drinks/rucksack in but no sharp objects. We wondered round following the audio guide for just over 90min. There were places to sit and the boys loved seeing the House of Commons. There is a gift shop at the end and a cafe for a well earned cup of tea.

Such an interesting tour even if you don't like history of politics. We booked the guided tour as it goes to more parts of the Houses of Parliament than the self guided tour. The guide was very informative combining history with how modern day parliament works. She spoke very clearly and was able to convey the rigours of how politics works in a way that made it interesting and fascinating. The rooms and halls we visited had the most amazing decoration and paintings I have ever seen there was hardly a wall without something to see. As it happens I love history and for me to walk through the central lobby, in the lords chamber and to stand where the prime minister stands in the commons chamber is unbelievable, I have seen these spaces on TV and for me to be there I find incredible. Even if you don't find history and politics interesting the Houses of Parliament is still worth a visit as it is a magnificent building in its own right. The cafe and shop are reasonably priced.

Well worth the visit. A little pricey at £25 for the guided tour but much better than the self audio guide. Barbara Askwith....I think the guide was excellent and knowledgeable. No photos can be taken inside and not surprising the place is crawling with security which no doubts counts for the majority of the entrance fee. Probably more interesting for Brits but there were a fair amount of foreigners attend. Be prepared to be searched as if you are going on a plane journey but liquids were not banned. Highlight for me was the House of Commons it is a lot smaller than it seems on TV and you can only imagine how noisy it would be when full. The other rooms were very grand especially the house of lords. You also see THE thrown used by the queen and various rooms and statues of past Prime Ministers. All this was brought to life by the guide.

Get your tour ticket very early. I took the guided tour of Parliament. You can do a self-guided tour with audio but the one with an actual guide goes to places the indie visitor doesn't see. We started with the path that the Queen follows when she opens Parliament; that only goes as far as the Commons. We went on to the Lords room too.The guide was excellent. She managed to get security to let us sit down in some places; something an indie visitor could not do.Their tour capacity is very limited. Get your ticket as soon as you can. You are competing for that limited space with organized tours and school groups.Their were several people in our group who needed an elevator and this was handled quite well.
Beautiful, awe inspiring!. Gazing upon this feat of architecture is absolutely breathtaking. Must see along with the Big Ben and Westminster Abbey which are right beside it.

Audio tour. All I can say is if you are looking to visit landmarks within London then a visit to the Houses of Parliament are a must. It is amazing the history and the decor of the interior will and should take your breath away. Walking through the House of Lords Chambers then across the Central Lobby to the House of Commons, to be able to stand in these areas does put it in context when you see this on TVThe tour took about 2 hours as we did not rush and from what I saw would say choose the self audio tour rather than the guided one as you can go at your own pace.
Excellent. Fantastic trip. Really knowledgeable guide. Felt like there was the right about time in each part but could have stayed all day.
A great place to visit. Took a tour with a guide...worth every penny. She was informative, easy to listen to and lasted the right length of time.

Informative Audio Tour. Loads of information on the Audio Tour, which takes approximately 90 mins. You tour through Westminster Hall, House of Lords, House of Commons and all through the outer chambers and halls. There is so much to learn about our government and parliamentary system. A good gift shop and decent, not overly priced cafe at the end of the visit. Highly recommended.
The workings of Parliment. Very interesting learning about the workings of Parliment. The Brit's have many traditions that they love. They have 1000 years of history.
Historical. Another must see monument. Incredibly impressive and accesible under circumstances. Had a very informative and educational visit.

A fantastic tour, well worth it!. Booked this for a day during half term! May not be for younger teens but we found it fascinating and a fab insight into the going on of our Political Establishment! Our tour guide was a wealth of information and if you do the guided tour you do get to go beyond the areas others can't go! Certainly would recommend!!

900 years of history, and it shows. This is without a doubt the most elaborately decorated government building we have ever seen. Amazing to see all that pomp and circumstance. Very good audio guide. Very knowledgeable staff. Well worth seeing.
AMAZING . Amazing insight to the world of politics. Brilliant tour guide, could recommend visiting this building enough. Thank you. Brilliant visit

Highly recommend the guided tour. Despite a rough start, I would highly recommend opting for the guided tour. Unfortunately we arrived late for our tour today which we had prebooked online. Evidently they expect you to arrive 20 minutes before your tour even if you book ahead. We are usually very punctual, but didn't realise how long the Changing of the Guards took and were stuck until the police allowed us to pass. The manager at the ticket counter told us no refunds and that our options were to catch up to the tour we had already booked or pay another £51 for a different tour. We decided to try to run to catch up with the tour that was already underway. At this point, we were already a good 20-30 minutes into the 90 minute tour after having waited in line and having to run over to the actual entrance and go through security. An extremely kind usher took pity on us and wrote a note on our tickets to allow us into the next available tour. I am sooo grateful to him. Our tour guide Mike was absolutely wonderful. He was so enthusiastic and had great fun facts along the way. He did a great job getting the younger children involved and made what could have been a dry topic like how a bill becomes a law interesting and entertaining. It was quite an experience to hear the bells of Big Ben from inside the Houses of Parliament. Highly recommend you take the opportunity to explore the history and inner workings of such an iconic location!

You can't miss it. A deep tour in the politic's chambers. Don't forget to take the audioguide, it will tell you more and more informations and nice facts to know about.Be aware that in some places it's forbidden to take pictures!You can book also a partiuclar tea time at 5 o' clock in the afternoon with a special view on the Thames and London Eye!!!
WOW. Amazing to see these buildings both walking and on the River Cruise - Loved it! Well. Worth the visit.

Excellent - take the guided tour. An outstanding visit round parliament. We went for the guided tour. Our tour guide was amazing - very knowledgable and really bought things to life for us. Its quite expensive, but well worth it!

Guided Tour. We opted for a guided tour and thoroughly enjoyed it. It was really interesting to listen to the guide explain the different halls, rooms and functions of the house. The history was equally interesting. You do need to keep up with the guide and group so you do have to be reasonably mobile and fit, otherwise recommend the tour.

AN interesting behind the scenes look at London Parliment. I highly recommend doing this tour if it is running during your visit to London. Check the London Parliament website for open times, but it is normally open every Saturday when parliament is not sitting. We visited about 2 weeks before the Queen was due to open Parliament so all was busy getting things ready for Her Majesties arrival. Our guide was wonderful, she was able to provide some behind the scene facts that you don't get from the self guided audio tours. Also as we visited during the anniversary of Shakespeare's death there was a rendition of one of his plays being performed in the great hall, which was an added bonus for us. Tickets can be purchased online or from the assigned ticket office, near new parliament house. a few points to remember. You must go through screening like at the airports so be careful what you pack. There are only a few limited places you can actually take photos do to privacy laws. Finally, the tour can take 2 hours, so comfy walking shoes and be aware that you can only sit when the guide tells you. the temptation to sit on the seats in both the house of lords & commons is frowned upon and security is ALWAYS watching

Fascinating visit and great value for money.. If you are interested in the development of democracy and British politics past and present you should take the opportunity to visit which takes around 2 hours to do it justice.
Great Tour. Sign up in advance for a great tour of the Houses of Parliament. Very interesting history and a view inside of what happens in session. We enjoyed the audio tour very much.
Iconic. These are lovely and beautiful historic buildings. We walked across the Thames for a better view and were not disappointed.

A must to see if you are in London. There is so much to see and anyone with an interest in history will love this place. We started out with coffee and cake (of course) in the cafe, which was very reasonable priced and very good. We used the audio system which was very good and informative and allowed us to go at our own pace. There are guided tours too so it just a matter of choice really. We took about two hours as there are many interesting pictures etc to view. It was very crowded considering that it was half term and a weekend. Other contributors have said that they tried to purchase tickets for a weekday but I understood that it is not open when Parliament is in session so it might be wise to check this before any purchase is made.
looks nice but full of arseholls.. Beautiful architecture interesting to see where everything happens Its unfortunate that half the residents are nasty.

What's your politics?. If you are interested in history, politics, and royalty with heaps of pomp and ceremony, the Houses of Parliament are definitely worth a visit.Did you know that Westminster Hall was originally used for palace functions before it was used as a Law Court. It was last used as a royal residence by King Henry VIII who gave it over to the government. Who knew that Henry VIII ever gave anything away?The House of Lords is separate from the House of Commmons and the Houses are distinguished by red and green decor. Westminister Bridge is painted green as this is the common end of Parliament and Lambeth Bridge is painted Red as per the House of Lords. Although Parliament is a working site at the heart of the British Goverment, it is also a palace and a museum of sorts with amazing artefacts including paintings, statues and historical documents. If you are interested in cloak and dagger intrigue you can see the Visitors Book signed by Guy Fawkes.If you want to see both The House of Commons and the House of Lords you will need to book a tour with an official guide.
interesting experience. you need to go through security to visit the House Chambers, but the security people are very nice and helpful.

Great Area To Walk Around. Check to see if you hotel has cable that includes the Parliament Cable station on it. It is fascinating to watch parliament in action for a little while and then take the walk around the parliament building and Westminster.
Went to the houses of parliament. Had a brilliant day beautiful in side lots to see went into the house of commons very interesting. Well worth a visit .

Closed to visitors, web ticket purchase failed. Both of our guide books and the website indicate that visitors are allowed when Parliament is in session, but when we got there we were told the whole of Westminster Palace was closed to visitors "because the government is working." The guard said we could purchase tickets online, the next date available being the last day of our trip. I went through the whole reservation process up to submitting payment info three times and got an error message every time. So we never got to tour Westminster Palace. Very disappointing.
Truly fascinating. An amazing couple of hours with brilliant access to all you could want. Great value for money and not spoilt by big crowds pushing and shoving

Architecture. We didn't go inside the Parliament but viewed it from the inside & it looked downright regal. Beautiful architecture meets history - fascinating! hope the next time, we'll be able to take a tour.
House of Parliament. Great place to take pictures. Iconic building not to be missed attraction. Great place to spend more time

Architecture meets historical gravitas. I didn't have the chance to take the tour. I arrived too late. However, I am so glad that I took the time to peruse this building, even if only from the exterior. If you didn't know, the Palace of Westminster is where the House of Commons and the House of Lords meets. Apparently the first palace appeared on this site in the 11th century. Destroyed several times over (the last time by fire in 1834), this is the edifice that was built to replace it around 1840. The building is gorgeous, and the historical significance immeasurable.

So much history. You do not have to be a history buff to enjoy this tour however the amount of history you are bombarded with is amazing. The audio guides are a must and do get a shot of the big ben on your way in or out. There is airport style security but its very quick and ques are quite reasonable. Its a shame no photography is allowed in most of the rooms but then again, you look and listen alot more because there are no distractions! This is a MUST VISIT for anyone with some idea about british history.

Nice even in the Chilly Winter. it was down right cold when we visited, but really didn't mind the walk around the place. We didn't venture inside, not really sure you can actually. I marveled at its impressive nature. I liked the surrounding walk way by the Thames

Beautiful Architectue. We were glad to have the opportunity to enjoy the beautiful architecture of the Houses of Parliament. We walked around the side street to enjoy the wonderful design and fabulous gates in the back.Great for photos!

House of Commons impressive Q & A. Sat for over 3 hours watching and listening to House of Commons discussion and Q & A and walked away impressed by tone and substance of the inter-change. Enjoyed the experience immensely.

Houses of Parliament a very worthwhile place to visit. We booked a tour of the Houses of Parliament beforehand and also included the afternoon tea on the terrace afterwards. Get there in good time as you have to be processed through an airport style security system. Understandable.Our guide was Harry and what wealth of knowledge he was, combined with his gentle wit, as he took us on a journey "through the ages" of these wonderful buildings with their most interesting history. It takes about 1.5 hours for the tour so, if you've booked the afternoon tea you will be looking forward to it. Sadly on our day the staff in the terrace restaurant appeared poorly organized as some people had their tea some 20-25 minutes before their food arrived whilst others seemed to received everything in good time. After being seated it took 20 minutes for our order to be taken although not quite so long again for the tea and food. I hope the tea service improves for others!

Steeped in history and truly magnificent. If you're at all interested in history then you can't go past a visit to this place. I was in total awe as we walked into the Great Hall, a place where Kings and Queens as far back as the 12th century dealt with issues and people of the day. The rest of the old palace, House of Lords, House of Commons, Queen's Robing Room - all fascinating. Just loved it.
History. We have been to this landmark many times and every time we can help taking even more photos! What a building, amazingly beautiful and never get tired of seeing it.

Great Place. its a nice place to go, obviously a must see in London! if you can, go on the London-Eye to have a better view from the House of Parliment.. I would also recommend to read a bit of history before checking these historical buildings

Amazing guided tour!! . It's well worth going on a guided tour of this building especially if your interested in British history. The lords rooms are so ornate. The guides really know there stuff and it's all so interesting.

Excellent Tour And A Must If In London. The House of Parliament has fascinating history and the tour gives you an excellent insight into all the events that lead up to today. The entire building is steeped in tradition and history and the elaborate rooms and chambers makes it hard to believe that in the place of government of today. Ensure you book well ahead and do this on-line to ensure you can visit when you are in London. A Great experience.
Marvelous. Great architectural monument. While I've never been inside, nor do I know if you can take a tour, the outside is quite spectacular.

Majestic and Beautiful building!. Parliament is a "Beautiful Building!" It looks and seems like a very powerful and strong structure! Just knowing of how much history is in it and all that takes place in it, makes one want to tour it and know more about it! It is also a very beautiful back ground for pictures with incredible etched in gates surrounding all of Parliament.

Gorgeous. We admired the buildings from a river cruise. The coolest buildings in all of London. I wish we had time to go inside and do a tour, but sadly we ran out of time. Add this to your must-see list.

Don't miss it! . Definitely recommend the private tour - Victoria was our guide. She was personable & funny, and shared not only the history of Parliament but many insightful anecdotes about the debates that carry on. Both husband & son thought it was great.

Historic site!. Unfortunately, we were unable to book a tour of the inside. However, I still highly recommend walking around as much of the outside as possible, and reading the history associated with this place. Also remember that Guy Fawkes did not act alone, but was a member of a group of provincial English Catholics who planned the failed Gunpowder Plot of 1605.

Great photo ops. We didn't tour but just from the outside alone the photo opportunities abound. Do yourself a favor and take not of the detail and beauty etched in the gates surrounding Parliament. Breathtaking if viewed from the London Eye as well.

Guided Tour. We took the guided tour of the beautiful Palace of Westminster. It was a very good tour with lots of interesting information about the building and the government within. Wonderful couple of hours.
Part of the walk. It is part of the historic/scenic walk of London. The building is impressive. Right beside the river. From the other side you get a clear view of the dimensions.
Westminster Comedy theatre. Great building, sadly falling apart. Spoiled by the antics of Members of Parliament and wasted on them. See Westminster Hall, it's stunning.

A Real British Experience!. We had booked online and printed off the tickets. You have to go through an airport security to get into the building. We did the audio tour. I was with my family and there was 8 of us. The audio tour was very well thought out. It gave all the information you needed to know and there was a choice if you wanted to listen to more. The tour for our group took over an hour long. I would recommend this tour who wanted to know more how important decisions are made about our welfare.
Very historic. I loved the architecture of this building and the idea of all the laws and mandates that have been handed down over the centuries just blows my mind. Well worth the visit.

Great Tour. The perfect place for a rainy day, I prefer the morning when it is a little quieter. Can't visit London without coming here! See it on the new almost every day, spot the famous people walking by!
Great buildongs. In my opinion it's one of the greatest buildings in London. Those who have a chance should explore it.

Very interesting couple of hours. A very interesting couple of hours can be spent here, though it would be boring for most children unless they are part of a large group. Get headphones on your way in and enjoy learning. Photos are only permitted in certain areas.

The mother of all parliaments. This a MUST visit once in a lifetime sort of place. Not because it's parliament but because of what it represents.It's surprising how easy it is to visit the Houses of Parliament, once you've gone through the thorough security checks and had your bags searched. A fact of too many places of interest these days, here and worldwide. Before you know where you are you're in the oldest part of the palace, Westminster Hall, the worlds widest medieval building, and the largest surviving part of the pre 19th century building. This huge space, scene for some of the biggest events in British history, is a great place to pause. Seeing MP's ministers and other parliamentarians pass, spot who you recognise and then pass on into building proper.If you get a chance go up to see the current debate from the visitors gallery in either the commons of Lords. You'll need to ask one of the many Police or ushers for help in the central lobby.We all think we know what the place looks and feels like from seeing it so often on the TV, but trust me when I say, nothing quite prepares you for seeing the opulence and incredible over the top decorations with your own eyes.

The debates are just like on the bbc. . At the entrance tell the guard you want to attend a debate. You can attend at the house of Commons or the house of Lords or both. Awesome experience. The Parliament building is a magnificent sight to see. No Charge

Iconic buildings. Everyone has probably seen these buildings on TV, in a move or in a book. They are stately, though appear a bit covered in soot in places. We couldn't get inside. So, not much more to say.

an amazing place and superb tea. we went on the tour of the houses of parliament and learned so much history from our excellent guide - seeing both chambers was an experience to remember - we also had high tea on the terrace - the service was first class and the tea was great with good sandwiches and cakes

Incredible. We did the early tour and must immediately name check Francis our guide who was superb, friendly and knowledgeable. We were surprised to be able to enter both the commons and the House of Lords. The history is enthralling and the building very interesting. TIP: Book an early trip as entry to the commons is not possible after the MPs start.

The Pomp and History Sets This Apart. I love the U.S. Capitol - I worked on the Hill for several years and loved being there. But, the Palace of Westminster makes you realize what a young country the U.S. We were able to take a tour of the Houses of Parliament and highly recommend to any visitor to London. Emerging from the Tube at Westminster Station you're immediately struck by the majesty of the Elizabeth Tower and Big Ben. Security at Portcullis House was very efficient and we met our tour group in Westminster Hall. Seeing the plaques of the Kings and Queens and illuminates who lay in state there (Churchill) and who spoke there (Mandela) gave us chills (was also b/c it is freezing in there). Our guide was excellent, told us the history of what we were seeing and also much about the British parliamentary system. The House of Commons was smaller than it seems on television, the House of Lords was ornate and grand. I wished we had more time to stay and see the Commons in session - plan ahead to get tickets and go on a Wednesday so that you can see Prime Minister's questions (we were seeing a show so couldn't stay). This is so much more worthwhile than seeing most of the palaces and castles that tourists usually concentrate on so if time is limited this should be at the top of your list.

All that history.... An awesome place. I just wish I could have seen more of it. They show you the main famous bits with lots and lots of history but there seems to be so much more to the building.Highly recommended.

Beautiful . Wonderful old iconic building in London. Such a shame that events in the world now see this place fortified like a castle. It's a grand and lovely thing to see. Make sure you got to a range of different vantage points so you can get alternative views.

Long overdue visit. You live in or around London and see this place all the time and never bother being a tourist and having a tour. Just like me. I was Wrong. It was fantastic. See up close and personal the things seen only on telly. Walk the walk of the Queen or Black Rod. See the back corridors where politicians scurry or hang their swords.

Take the tour if you are able!. We booked online in advance of our visit. Be aware that you can exchange your online booking for actual tickets either the day of your tour or before, if you find yourself near by. The tour itself was fantastic. Our guide was very interesting. I wished we could have stayed longer on our own. Unfortunately, we had a flight to catch. They were nice to allow us to bring and leave our luggage in the entry.

Very educational . Came here for a school trip and I must say it is every interesting on how everything works and where everyone sits I just say it was much better than I thought it would be and it is also very inspiring to the future generation.
This is London. This place means LONDON, the famous big ben and houses of parliament. If you didn't visit it while being in London, it means you didn't see London..!
interesting insights in Britains politics. Great guide, learned something new about the politics in Britain as well as the role of the monarchy in these matters.
Great building. It is a beautiful architecture. You can really see the whole from the other side of the Thames, or from a cruise boat.

Seat of democracy?. Had called my local MPsoffice and managed to get a tour with his researcher. I was delighted. Opening if parliament was the following day so we could get int the chamber. Beautiful building with great history, explains why some MPs find it so hard to move with the times

Free to go in and see Parliament in session. We went on a Monday about 4:30pm. Very organized, no queue. Go in on the side facing Westminster Abbey at the Cromwell Green entrance. We went to Commons first then went straight into the House of Lords. You can go on the Parliament website to get the days and times they are in session.
