If you prefer a tour, they are only offered on Saturdays.
LOVE LOVE LOVE. One of my favorite places- where William Wilberforce changed history. . . the slave trade became no more. Be sure to attend!
Very educational. Our tour guide was very knowledge and friendly. It was very fascinating to see the inside, the tour was very helpful. Would recommend for families and tourists.
See how it works.. We were lucky enough to have a private tour of the House of Lords and sit in on a session. Nice to see how English government works.

What more could you ask for?. It's all here. History, architecture, art, lavish decoration, and a touch of politics. Actually being in the Houses of Parliament adds depth to the entire experience. The audio tour is very helpful. There is airport style security but these agents are much friendlier than those at Heathrow!
A must visit for London. We had a blue badge tour which was excellent and you do get a lot more information than on a self audio tour the venue is surprising busy so I advise advance booking.

Worth it. Although it is a little pricey it is amazing to see how Parliament works! It is definitely worth doing and my family loved seeing it! You could spend a long time here so plan your trip accordingly! Don't walk in without snapping a picture of Elizabeth Tower from inside Parliament, it is astounding!
Superb architecture. This exquisitely carved building must surely be increasing the morale of the parliamentarians working inside. Can't hope for a better looking office.

Well worth the wait and cost. Went to visit the House of Parliment to see the Palace and the workings of the various branches of the British government. The guided tour was conducted by a female docent who was very knowledgeable regarding the proceedings of the working government. A different type of self-guiding tour was also available. But, I would advise to take the guided tour. You will be taking into more off-limit nooks and crannies of the building than on the self-guided one. The "wow" factor would be the Throne Room in the House of Lords.

Learned a lot; well done. We opted for a guided tour rather than an audio tour. We saw parts of parliament that others didn't. Help us better understand the House of Lords and House of Commons, red vs. green, more history of the English parliamentary system, and how the Whips got their names. One needs to book in advance.

Fascinating traditions and history. We had a great few hours touring the Houses of Parliament. The buildings look impressive from the outside, but once you are in there the history all comes alive.Wonderful paintings, statues and seating. Although you can't go everywhere, you can see the chambers, the throne room and other rooms too. Westminster hall is huge. Well worth the trouble of setting up a visit. Go through your local MP.

Mother of parliaments. One of the most pleasurable aspects of visiting the Houses of Parliament at Westminster is the courtesy and friendliness of the doorkeepers. They have to be dutiful and formal, yet manage to somehow make you feel utterly welcome and undaunted by the magnificence of the medieval Westminster Hall, the grandeur of St Stephen's Hall, or the opulence of the octagonal Central Lobby, in all its ornate Victorian Gothic splendour. Watching the House of Commons in action from the Public Gallery is always exciting, however prosaic the actual proceedings. MPs jumping up and down, trying to catch the Speaker's attention, the formalities of address, the antiquated traditions in this 21st century is a medley of old and new. Simultaneous TV relays with subtitles ensure you know which MP is speaking and what is going on.Even the café is charming with interesting wraps and sandwiches and Twining teas. Sit by the window and watch the sun glittering on the top of Big Ben, and hear the famous chimes ring the quarter hours. Anyone can visit the Houses of Parliament. It's a fascinating place to see government in action.
nice place. good and quite place..nice view and location...I use to sit out side near river and listen songs...good for summer
Really good value for money. Really worth a visit. The audio tour was good but the guided tour seemed to go to more places. Booking over the phone was easy and reservation staff really friendly.

Fascinating visit. You need to book a time slot online before visiting. Of course, there is heavy security and a bit of a wait to enter. When you finally enter the grounds and look up at the clock uninterrupted by a ton of tourists it's wonderful. There is an excellent Audio tour. Those who love history will thoroughly enjoy the experience. Seeing the green benches and sit on them is pretty incredible.

Highlight of my trip!. I loved i there it was so interesting! I booked tickets waaaaaay in advance to ensure I got them! Was well worth the wait! So interesting and everyone there was helpful and would happily answer questions! Going through security etc was efficient and was easyOnly drawback was no pictures allowed (which I understand) but I thought they would be able to take pictures and sell them to you but nevermindWould massively recommend !

House of Commons. Was impressed with how easy it was to get in to the House of Commons without a reservation. Did have to go thru airport type security check to get in. The afternoon we were there was relatively empty with only a few opposition people arguing for labor unions.

History in the Past and Present . From the moment you enter The Great Hall you are hit by the history and how big the whole place is within.Was luck enough to eat in one of the private rooms with my MP and food excellent.On the right day waiting not to long for debating Houses in Lords and Commons and fascinating insight in to how it all works.A must for people interested in history and politics in UK
Heart of London.. This place exhibit London. Every bollywood movie is shoot here or near its surroundings. So a must, must visit.
One of the top attraction in London. This is a top pick to visit when you go first time in the city. It is in the same are with Big Ben, next to metro. Same as the London Eye
Den of Inquity. just one of those places you have to visit, Sunday so thankfully none of the inhabitants that frequent the place were working,

Make a Reservation in Advance for a Guided Tour. I was so glad I had looked this attraction up prior to going to London. It is only open for visits on Saturdays and you have to make a reservation for a guided tour which I did and it was so worth it! Our guide was knowledgeable and interesting. We learned so much and saw such beautiful things. The guided tour is 90 minutes long and is a lot of standing and walking so I wouldn't recommend it for people who would be challenged to do so. But for anyone else, I absolutely recommend it. Get there early as there is substantial security to go through prior to getting in.
Amazing. It was a great privilege to see the house of Lords. I went there from my university. It was an amazing experience.

Stunning building with so much history. It is a very special building, and a working one at that with the parliament sitting though not all the time. It's amazing to see the place where our laws have been debated for the past centuries. It's also really beautiful inside.
Just the view alone. if you want to feel small and watch the world i highly recommend a trip here its also full of history

Excellent. Had pleasure of exclusive visit and witnessed House of Lords in action. great experience. If you can go with a business group or at the invitation of an MP it will enhance your experience. I guess guided tours are well worthwhile.
Attending a session. Last year I attended a session in the House of Commons. A very good experience. You can take part every day, I think, the only thing you need to do is queue at the entrance.

A must see for locals & tourists alike. A guided tour is by far the best way to see the Houses of Parliament, tickets can be booked on line prior to your visit & cost approx £25 per person but it's well worth the price, the tour takes you through the whole building including the House of Lords & the House of Commons, visit the lovely cafe & souvenir shop when you have completed the tour

Worth a Visit. It is worth a visit to at least walk around the outside of the building if you don't want to do a tour (which I believe are only on Saturdays). It's a beautiful piece of architecture and history and goes well with your visit to Big Ben. I'd go super early in the morning or at twilight to avoid the masses of people that flock to this area.

Second Visit. This was my second visit to the Houses of Parliament. I bought tickets for my husband's Christmas present and this time I added on the afternoon tea experience. If you can do this, I would highly recommend it, it is a wonderful way to end a very interesting and informative visit.

Lovely Architecture. visited HoP after something like 30 years on a sightseeing trip with my daughters in April 2016 - i guess age and grey hair make you appreciate the architecture even more - must see for all tourists

What a place to visit. Well worth a visit to the Houses of Parliament. Rich in history and stories take a tour and spend some time soaking in the beautiful architecture and history. So close to the underground stations and within walking distance form other amazing attractions attraction.

Confusing. So Big Ben, Westminster Abbey, and the Houses of Parliament are all in the same area and can be hard to separate unless you have some background info. I might even recommend a bus tour for this one

Identity of London. You get to see the Houses of Parliament just outside the entrance of Westminister tube station. Big Ben compliments the parliament building. Houses of parliament and the Big Ben forms the prominent skyline of London

Spring evening meets history. History was made at this magnificent building ! If you are a visitor in London do make this a definite stop. Worth seeing. The size however maybe somewhat smaller than you expected!

Take a tour- guaranteed to learn so much. We reserved online for a small private guided group tour. It was worth every bit of the price charged. Having a guide added so much to experience. We received an education of what goes on here and behind the scenes information that we would not have experienced without a guide. All our questions were answered.

Well worth a visit. Our trip to the Houses of Parliament was organised as part of an event we attended so I don't know the cost etc but would say it was very interesting with a very knowledgeable guide - we will be returning with our children for a longer trip.

Great tour of the original House of Cards!. Just kidding with the title although the original house of cards television show was set here. the guided tour was outstanding. very interesting and thorough explanation of the history and operation of the House of Lords and Commons.

Nice to look at. They only give tours on Saturday so you cannot go in any other day. It makes for a nice photo from the outside and you can get a good one from the park across the street from Westminster Abbey.
Great photo opp. If you are visiting Big Ben, you will naturally visit this as well. Perfect for taking traditional Lonal photos.

Wonderful. Enjoyed a wonderful tour of Westminster Palace.
What a wonderful building, we had an exceptional
guide on our tour, very knowledgeable, I think this
should be a must for schoolchildren, they would
not be bored there is so much to see and learn.
Amazing building a must visit. What an amazing place. The building itself is so very iconic. So much detail and impressive place to have a tour, whether into politics or not.

Excellent visit. My husband and I visited here as our Christmas present to each other - it was brilliant. We did the self audio tour and wandered around at our own pace. The history is amazing and to think we sat where the PM sits - cool! Book onto the tour and enjoy.

A must to see when you come to London. If you visit here, you can get some great photo's from Lamberth bridge and also directly across the river just up from the London eye, if your lucky, there's also a small park to the side of houses of parliament, Lambeth bridge side. We hire street bike and rode over Westminster Bridge and back over Lambeth bridge, stopping along the way to take in the views and take photos, it was a fantastic afternoon out.If you found this helpful, I'd appreciate your tick, thanks and have a great trip.

'Less is more' does not apply here!. I went to the Houses of Parliament for the first time to attend in a charity event. The interior of this place is beyond anything I have ever seen and I highly recommend anyone to go there. Sadly they don't allow you to take photos inside but it wouldn't be the same as seeing it up front anyway.

Waste of a beautiful building. Visited Houses of Parliament as a family on a sight seeing trip. It's an absolutely lovely building which is a shame it's being wasted as Houses of Parliament. Lots of restoration work going on at the moment so it's marred by lots of scaffolding.
Incredible historical building. It's just a few minutes walking distance from Big Ben where it's located between the botanical gardens.

A stunning building and surroundings. I have been lucky enough to dine at the House of Lords as a guest and can confirm the building is stunning inside and out. Overlooking the river we were very well looked after and enjoyed absolutely fabulous food.
A privileged opportunity for those who are offered.

Extremely Interesting. Did a guided tour of Parliament House. Definitely recommend it. Our Guide was exceptional. We visited The House of Commons and House of Lords and various other parts of the Parliament.
Extremely interesting. our fortunate to go inside see how the parliament. We really appreciated all of the history, culture and tradition. This is so interesting place so just check it out !
Houses of Parliament. The structure of all these buildings are just awesome. So much to see and the beauty and work that went into building is just mind blowing. You will want to see.

An Opportunity that can't be missed!. I happened to find this experience by chance when I walked by a booth selling tickets. I never knew before that they let tourists go inside parliament. If you have any interest in British culture, history, tradition, or architecture, I suggest that you do not miss this attraction. I loved every moment of the experience from learning about the history to learning about modern day activities!
Impressive. Enjoyed the grand nature of this building, especially with Big Ben towering over it. Deserves more than a quick drive by to appreciate it.

Worth visiting when nearby. I visited the House of Commons while it was in session immediately following my tour of Westminster Abbey, as it's just across the street. I did so as an educational experience, as I'm from the United States and have also visited the U.S. Congress in Washington, DC while in session. At about 1:00 pm there was no line whatsoever, so doing so was very easy. I only watched the action for about 30 minutes, but enjoyed my visit, considering that it's not something one gets to do every day. The House of Lords was due to meet later in the afternoon, but I decided to move on to other things rather than wait for it to begin. I'm glad I took the time to visit the House of Commons, as the entire process only took about an hour or so.

Beautiful building. This building is even more beautiful inside then outside. Audio tour guide is included in the price and explains the history of the building and how the Parliament of the UK is built up and works.

I suggest you go for the audio tour. I had the audio tour on a Saturday morning and it was excellent value for money. I didnt know that one could go into the houses of parliament until someone told me about it. I pre booked about two weeks before. It was all very well organised the audio tour is of a very high standard with lots of interesting information and a variety of speakers. You get to see both houses and the great hall. There is also a reasonably priced cafe where we had lunch. I think we were there for about 2.5 hours - really enjoyable. All the attendants were friendly and helpful.
Access to Public. I was surprised that they offered free access to the public. GREAT, INTERESTING AND FREE . Worth the time.

Perfect way to spend a rainy morning in Westminister. I took the Audio guide which wasn't cheep but sure worth it. i took the time to see everything. it could be quite tiresome but it's magnificent and very interesting. will come again with the wife and kids.

Thoroughly good conducted tour. We joined a conducted tour rather than use the audio guide - and were glad we did so as we got access to a few places that were not available on the audio tour - plus a lot more information through the guides answers to the various questions that were asked etc
Magnificent!. As you enter the building you enter the history of England! It is extremely interesting. One gets so much important and interesting information!

Take the tour. Entrance to this wonderful home to British democracy is only available by taking the official tour. A self-guided audio tour is available but I would heartily recommend taking the guided tour as the guides offer many insights into the Palace. Best to sign up online well ahead of time to speed things up when you arrive and also to ensure that there is availability. Arrive ahead of schedule and expect a long wait to get through security even though you've pre-booked. Bad luck if it raining (not that it ever rains in England) as you will find yourself out in the elements while you wait. It took us one hour, standing in the rain, from the time we first joined the line just to get into the building for security screening. For the most part, it is organised chaos until the tour starts but it is well worth the wait. Most definitely a unique 'attraction' and one that should be high on your list of things to do in London.
Informative. Informative for all pupils and staff! They were also extremely helpful with dealing with a poorly pupil! Thank you very much

Take a tour for a comprehensive overview. Enjoyed this tour very informative., great guide. Make sure you are there around half and hour early ticket suggested 15 and the queue for security was so long I only just made it
Weekender. This place is amazing steeped in history well worh spending time here was lucky enough to get into the public gallery a great view of the chamber

Mother of Parliaments. The Palace of Westminster contains the Houses of Parliament. The Parliament in London.governs the United Kingdom. The House Commons, which is surprisingly small, is in green and the House of Lords is in red -- a colours scheme floowed throughout the Commonwealth of Nations. Gaining entry to the Parliament is possible, but unless you have some official connection, you may have a very the Parliament is sitting..
It really is a huge building. Each time I visit I continue to be amazed at its size. What a beautiful site to see. We never tire of visiting time and again.

So worthwhile !. This was our first time to tour the Houses of Parliament. Beautiful buildings (formerly a Palace) and such interesting information about the British form of government. Highly recommend signing up for the guided tour (not just the audio tour). You learn so much more, and have the ability to ask questions. They also take you in areas not accessible to the public.

Find Culture In This House. Don't worry, it's not all a history of which political party wanted what or anything like that: Parliament was definitely affected by the wars and fires that plagued many aspects of England's history. And visiting it definitely helped me orient and immerse myself in the background and culture of the area during my visit. Personally I found a tour of Parliament while the building was empty to be quite delightful and peaceful (a welcome relief given London's bustling sidewalks!). The architecture and artwork alike are stunning. The building and the massive halls inside of it are just gorgeous, and with a guided and/or audio tour you can enhance your experience even more by learning more about the history and governing process of Parliament.

The guided tour and afternoon tea. The tour was amazing.really informative. Actually able to stand in both houses of parliament. As well as seeing some of the rooms behind the scenes. A must do tour for everyone.!The afternoon tea was superb.one of the most expensive I've had but we'll worth the experience. Arrive in time to go through airport style security which causes a queueBuy the guide book..it's worth the money.We also saw prime minister question time and the budget ...you have to contact your MP to get tickets for this thoughA really good day out

Westminster Urban Jungle. Parliament Square is a lovely little area of a green among the sprawling central Westminster urban jungle. Perhaps not the healthiest, what with the heavy traffic surrounding from every angle... but lovely nonetheless. If you're lucky enough to enter the Houses of Parliament you'll get to witness some of the most important documents in British (and, indeed world) history. I must admit I haven't seen as much of the HofP as I would like to, but I did get to sit in on a House of Commons session when my A-Level Politics class made a trip there. It was surreal seeing those Gods of legislature, such as Iain Duncan Smith and Michael Portillo, a mere stone's throw away. I'd highly recommend this area to anyone with even the slightest interest in politics or British history. Intriguing.

Huge and impressive. This place (with Big Ben attached) is breathtaking. It (along with the nearby Westminster Abbey) are the most beautiful buildings in London. (Far more impressive and interesting than Buckingham Palace) It's so big I found myself walking up and down the street to check it out from multiple angles.

Interesting Insight into UK Government. This was a really interesting tour of the seat of UK Government.The building is magnificent and worthy of the history within... though possibly not the current numpties. It was really interesting to see such familiar chambers from the news in their proper context.We arrived about half an hour early for the time stated, but queued for half an hour to get through security so early arrival is recommended.Once in, we took the audio tour and wandered round at our own pace. Some of the guided tours did seem to whizz past us.Definitely recommended this as a tour.

Amazing tour. Wanted to do this for a long time, and was not disappointed. Although when you book you have to select a time, not sure why, we arrived 30 minutes early but had to queue for 30 minutes. You have to go through tight security at the start but once in you can wander around unescorted, when you go in the House of Lords and past all the artist paintings it is mind blowing, then you go to the commons again past some amazing paintings and see how small it really is and how big the to makes it look. You can go in the viewing gallery when parliament is sitting if you get your timings right, overall I was very impressed and would recommend this to everyone.

Fascinating. The building itself is very beautiful but if you want to attend a session in the House of Commons you need to arrange them in advance through your local MP (if your a British citizen). If you are from abroad, you can line up or try the British consulate in your home country.Once inside, the architecture and history are breathtaking. There are beautiful Windows, murals, plaques and paintings to look at that date back about 1000 years!
very Nice... The houses of parliament in westminster is a marvel piece of architecture with the river flowing near it.. it is easily reachable by the tube.

Brilliant Guided Tour. They offer a range of different tour options; we chose the guided tour over the audio tour as we thought it would be more personal. It was a great choice, cost £25 each, lasted 90 mins and we were able to wander around by ourselves afterwards to see things in more detail. We went into both chambers, the Inquiry room, Aye room and many others. We found out loads we didn't know both about the processes and the decor. The guide was very knowledgeable and happy to answer questions. Highly recommended, we had a fab time. TIP: starting queuing 20mins or so before your ticket time as the security is understandably quite high. You are not allowed to take photos in a lot of the rooms.
day ou†. very nice experience great guided tour good value as well, very informative and thorough tour of the house of commons and house of lords.

Fantastic!. We were are little curious about this as the prices seemed a little high, but the tour did have a 90min length.It turned out to be a very professional and in depth tour with a very good guide with a great deal of knowledge and a clear passion for what he was describing.Anybody with a slight interest in UK history or government, should do this.
Take a walk and see the Parliament. They have amazing buildings, love how they take care of them. It is a part of the city that you can see taking the way since the National Gallery to the Big Ben.

awsome. got to go inside one of the common room though security was very tight even on 11 yr olds when we went with the school but still got to actually have a meeting in one of the debate halls of course with our local conciluar

Private tour with a real MP. Through personal contacts we managed to score a private tour with a sitting member of parliament - what an absolute treat! Our "guide" was entertaining and also very informative, definitely not your average run of the mill tour!
Very beautiful. This is a very beautiful building Pictures of it are incredible but seeing in up close is inspiring. Definite must see when in London..

A majestic building steeped in history.. You don't have to be into politics to visit the Houses of Parliament. We booked online for the audio tour. There is strict security here, which is a good thing and we were pleased they were being diligent and protecting us from terrorists.  We found the tour really interesting, the art work on the walls was stunning but we were surprised how small both the House of Commons and House of Lords really are.We only went to limited parts of the building: House of Commons, House of Lords and Her Majesty the Queen’s robing room, which she only uses once a year when she opens Parliament.It is one of those places you go to in order to say you've been there. I can remember seeing a very scary statue of Margaret Thatcher with her handbag!Definitely worth a visit!

Massive Structure Parliament. I could only stand in awe for a good long time trying to take it all in. A truly magnificent, though sometimes redundant work of builders. This structure is so massive it was hard to tell where it begins and ends sometimes when you're next to it. I have no idea how far back I had to go across the bridge to capture the whole thing during sunset. So much intricate artisan work put in every inch of it's architecture.

Can't Discuss It. Hadn't been here since Harold Wilson was PM. Nowadays it's £18 for an audio tour. Ouch!The queue - even for ticket holders - was vast and static. Swarms of jobsworths - some with guns and grim faces - circled us but couldn't possibly discuss why we weren't being allowed into the place.Once past the airport-style security, more jobsworths were waiting. Herding tourists is no doubt a tedious business but was it really necessary to ban my wife from walking the two metres to join me in the Commons? Have your one-way system if you must, but please exercise some common sense or you may cause deep offence. We were there not to admire Pugin's tawdry, crumbling Victorian architecture or hark the echo of Bevan's oratory or ponder why there's an obvious dark stain on the front bench exactly where the PM parks himself, but to watch Richard II Act IV Scene 1 performed by young players from KES Stratford in Westminster Hall. Nice.

Enjoyable and fascinating. We visited the Houses of Parliament and toured round it as part of an event run by Stockport Grammar School. It was very interesting to see the seat of British Government and gain an insight into the history and how it works. Our guide was absolutely excellent!!!!
Fascinating tour. Visited with friends and given tour by a local MP.Amazing building with so many great stories would highly recommend.

Pretty! Informative!. I loved this! We took the audiotour, which takes you a good 1.5h to complete. Beautiful building and really worth the money! Make sure you book in advance and also if possible book early, less people will be there!
Historical monument. The architecture in this historic building always impresses me everytime I visit. We went on Sunday so didn't go inside although there are tours.

Great tour but apalling pre-entry organisation. This could have been a five-star review as the actual tour of the Palace of Westminster is extremely interesting. Unfortunately it was let down by the amateur organisation while trying to actually get in...as many people commented, it was as though this was the first time they'd opened the building to visitors!It's an important criticism as one of the tour options is a guided tour at set times during the day (the tours only run on Saturdays) and so anyone using this option to maximise their time in the city could face a problem. My tour was due to start at 1220 but, despite having arrived at 1145, the start time had long gone before I reached the airport-level security screening and eventually got underway almost an hour later.However, once we were on our way, this is a great way to the Mother of Parliaments. The Blue Badge Guide takes you through the fascinating history of the building itself as well as how parliament works. To actually stand in the famous chambers usually seen only on TV is a great experience although it should be noted that there is a rigidly enforced 'no photos' rule in all but two rooms (not the ones you'd like to take pictures of...) which is a bit of a shame.

Tour of Parliament. I found the tour of the houses of parliament totaly worth the trip down to london.seeing it on tv and then in the flesh totaly different.its looks so much bigger on tv, the tour guides know there stuff.there are two ways to get on a tour by ether going to the ticket office or in my case i wrote to my local MP.I say go if you get a a chance

best experience ever. Don't miss it! you'll live the past history that made London and Great Britain, while living everyday Parliament life! All is true: past and present mingle while you walk along the many rooms where the most famous British politicians have walked. Where modern Great Britain has been forged!

Take the guided tour - it's worth it . My fiancé and I had a fantastic time exploring the Palace of Westminster with an informative and entertaining guided tour. I would really recommend doing the tour this way rather than with an audio guide, as you can ask as many questions as you like about the Houses of Parliament - their history and how they work now. We debriefed over scones and tea and had a great time.

A walk through history. Booked a timed self guided audio tour. The only disappointment was the priority given to the non self guided tours awaiting security checks which delayed the self guided by half an hour. On a wet day this would be very annoying as the queue is in the open air.Once inside there is a good cafe and loos so that you can refresh yourself before commencing your tour.The audio guide is excellent and there is a fair amount of seating around so that you can listen and look around in comfort. There is no time limit to the visit and the additional information regarding the history of events taking place during the last few centuries is well worth listening toThe staff inside,outside and in the catering area are friendly,helpful and informativeHighly recommended

Parliamentry visit. We booked this online and chose to have the guided tour which I fully recommend. To start with we didn't expect to queue but we soon got over it as the weather was lovely. Once through the very strict security and into the main hall where we met our guide the adventure back in time began. This building has so much to offer it's a must do place to visit. I don't want to spoil it for anyone but you will not be disappointed. So briefly wrap up as it can get quite cold in some of the rooms. security is strict so don't take photos where it says you can't. Nice cafe inside and a well stocked gift shop. My wife is still buzzing from this visit.

History in the making!. We were allowed into the House of Lords which was very interesting. We were fortunate to be taken into the House of Commons which was closed to the public. Extremely interesting & I would recommend a visit here.
A 'must do' in London. Wonderful history and tradition, and amazing to see how their Parliament works compared with ours. Really loved this visit!

Extremely interesting. Fascinating tour with American relatives. Definitely use the audio guide which has lots of extra information. All adults should go and see where parliament sits and works, to appreciate the history behind our democracy.
Totally worth taking the guided tour. We booked a guided a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament and found our guide informative, interesting and open to questions. It was great - we learned a lot!
tHE vERY bEAUTIFUL tHAMES. so famous, so calm, so photogenic, so very British.The scenery is bucolic and the photographers are prolific.

Viewed from exterior only. When in London we made sure to walk past the Houses of Parliament which we were told were not currently open to visitors -- we were told the interior is open during the summer only when Parliament is not in session. Disappointing but an excuse to return during a different time of year.Walking around outside one finds tremendously beautiful gardens even in March, and the building itself is breathtaking. It is easy to see why Monet would paint the building more than once. I have liked Gothic architecture before I knew what the design was called so being up close and personal to this building was a real treat. The two towers are magnificent though of course everyone's favorite is probably the tower containing Big Ben. I did not know until I visited this spot part of the building survived a huge fire in the mid 1800s. Amazing to be able to incorporate the parts which survived into the present buildings.Other than up close and personal I would recommend viewing this building while walking across Westminster Bridge from the other side of the Thames. Before our trip around the building we were able to see the Houses of Parliament from the other side of the Thames as we were staying off Tower Bridge Road which gave us an opportunity to cross the Thames on more than one bridge. Absolutely stunning building.

Free on the Outside. This attraction is free to see from the outside and there are many points where you can get a spectacular view; try Westminster Bridge or the South bank for example. If you have more time and want to see the inside it will cost around £25.

Beautiful building. So much history. It looked like they were some renovations on the building. News casts were present and doing live interviews. Cool architecture and a sight to see. Any photo you take of the building is so regal it really makes the skyline special. Best time to visit is between May and September when they host both weekday and Saturday guided tours. You can go to the parliament.uk site to see the days and hours when these are available.

Wonderful tour. You need to prebook your visit go on line to find out the details. You can either take an audio tour or a guided tour. The guided tour gets you into areas of the building that are not accessible on the self guided audio tour so I would recommend it. it is a very interesting tour and I would certainly recommend the visit if you can.
House of Parliament. Great Building but very busy did not have a lot of time to ha ve a good look around will come back at a later date when i have more time

I commend you to the House. Glimpses on the tele have whetted my appetite for a tour for ages. Informative guides and close up inspection of the decor and architecture made it very worthwhile . But not an MP in sight to collar and interrogate.

House Of Parliament History Place. England is one of the seats of political history and this building has been the center of it forever. The guide was knowledgeable. I am not a fan of many political groups these days. Most do not function well and often seem mainly interested in their own welfare. Was OK, We had been previously on a visit which was provided by an aide of the sitting MP, this was much more enjoyable and relaxed, there was nothing wrong with this tour it was enjoyable, being constantly on your feet it felt a bit long, especially for older people.
One of the main tourist spot. A subject of many photography enthusiast.Near a tube stationIt gets crowded during summer months.I really appreciate the old magical architectural marvel.

Must See for History Buffs. We did a guided tour of Parliament. It takes about 90 minutes. The amount of information our tour guide gave us was amazing. She explained how the ceremonial things came to be, broke down the different houses... I seriously think she knew everything about Parliament. Do not recommend children on the tour as there were a few on our tour & it gets a bit long & boring for them.

What is the most important date in English history ?. We attended a guided tour, led by the charming Cliff Cowell, former Architect. Cliff has tremendous knowledge about the architectural style and design of Westminster Palace and is keen to share his own views and correct misperceptions - be prepared to find out the truth !The tour lasted around 90 minutes and there is a lot of standing - the walking is not taxing at all. There are many tours that are timed but ultimately you will hear shouting and noise from the other guides. Cliff shared some funny stories and told us that he asked a group of school children 'what is the most important date in English history?' The unanimous response was not 1066, rather 1966 - when England won the World Cup !I wish we had visited before - it's an experience not to be missed !

Seat of Power in UK - worth a visit at least once. Following recommendation via good friend, I decided to drag three teenagers round House Parliament, audio tour. Having seen the outside of the Elizabeth Tower for many a visit, I at least was thrilled to actually go beyond the black iron railings and into Westminister Hall. As expected you need to pass through security, but from then on once you have your audio guide you are free to wander back and forth. I was prepared for the size of Houses of Parliament, so many people in such a small space, but the bling effect of the House of Lords was a pleasant surprise, along with the closeness of the council chambers. The tour information was good and we spent 1.5 hours in the Palace of Westminster. You exit via a cafe - serving for London good value tea and coffee in old vaults - although no one was high me for arranging the trip, it has been talked about a lot since our return. Worth the effort, though on paper may seem a dull idea. Gift shop sold very expensive souvenirs.

Investment Summit House of Lords. A venue dripping with grandeur and historical significance. A must see site for all architectural buffs and those who just love seeing wonderful buildings. MIMO - Miss It Miss Out
Houses of Parliament. I visited here when I was 16 - it was cool to see the House of Commons and House of Lords - which look so much smaller in real life!
Wonderfully historic. Truly beautiful architecture, and fascinating to look around - but not fit for purpose for modern government. But well worth a look

So much History. If you get the opportunity go and visit, there is so much history, we decided to do the audio tour, so much information, and a step by step signs to make it easy to go around. From Oliver Cromwells monument outside to looking up and seeing Big Ben and that's before you even go in.

Interesting historical gem. The guided tour reveals so much info that one did not know previously. I learnt about a 3 line whip, state opening of parliament, where word parliament originates & so much more. Just wish I could have enjoyed a g&t in the members bar overlooking the Thames

Guided Tour. Was OK, We had been previously on a visit which was provided by an aide of the sitting MP, this was much more enjoyable and relaxed, there was nothing wrong with this tour it was enjoyable, being constantly on your feet it felt a bit long, especially for older people. The guide was knowledgeable, taking time to point out paintings and oddities you would have other wised missed, giving explanations of procedure and the inner workings of Government, the building and its interior is in itself worth a visit, however I wouldn't rush back.
Very interesting. We really enjoyed visiting the Houses of Parliament. Using the audio guide you get a good history of the building. Well worth visiting.

Government and History Wrapped up In One Building. I am not a fan of many political groups these days. Most do not function well and often seem mainly interested in their own welfare. But England is one of the seats of political history and this building has been the center of it forever.... Don't miss stopping in to see as much as you can.

Magnificent...... Just add this building to the list of magnificent sights in London. The architecture is fantastic but I would highly recommend that apart from viewing the outside that you actually go inside and make your way to the Public Gallery and see British politics "in action".A sight and experience not to be missed...

Excellent tour guide. Once you get over the absolute luxury the MPs work in whilst they are busy screwing the rest of us, the H of P are a fantastic visit. The tour guide was helpful, informative and happy to be asked questions. Security was very good and this was reassuring.
WE HAD A TOUR. It was a great tour - and the man was really friendly and very informative. I really enjoyed it - the inside is beautiful.

Go in to watch the house of Parliament debate. As we walked around Big Ben and Westminster Hall there were so many tourists it was overwhelming, but once we got inside it was quiet and we were able to take in all of the history of the building, and got to see both houses debate live. It was a treat. People seemed so glad to see us there and gave us all kinds of direction once inside about where to go and what to see. This building has amazing history. We felt fortunate to be inside. It seemed that most tourstis didn't know about this, or just weren't interested.

The Place of the Government. Westminster has a serious and ceremony about its churches and houses of government. The House of Lords and the House of Commons sit aside the River Thames and are overshadowed by the Big Ben.

Fun Learning. We went on an organised tour of the Houses of Parliament. The guide was excellent and she told us lots of very interesting facts. We learnt how Churchill used to bang the table and about where certain MP'S sit.
Massive buildings. Saw buildings from tour bus. Glad to see sites and understand process of political decisions. Interesting view, but did not go inside.
Amazing to see in person. We walked along the south bank of the river on our first day in London to get a get view of the Houses of Parliament. A great vantage point for taking photos.

Ghastly and overblown. I suppose sentimentality about London and Big Ben plays a lot into this, but as a centre of government this is well past its sell by date. Completed only 150 years ago it is no older than the US Capitol building, despite masquerading as being more historical. Also the design is a pseudo-mediaeval confection which was ill suited to the time it was built, pandering to Victorian beliefs about British history, and contains an inherent allusion to one of the hypocracies of the age: despite Catholic Emancipation in 1829, in the building there are no acknowledgements of the influence of Pugin, a Catholic Architect of note, who provided the character and detail to Barry's overal design. It is a now-crumbling anachronism providing no more than a theatrical backdrop. The sooner it simply becomes a museum and the UK parliament moves elsewhere the better. I think most MPs (apart from 'traditionalists' who really misunderstand 'tradition') would agree!

Fantastic opportunity to walk the corridors of power!. To find out all you need to know about this great building you need to use the headphones supplied to walk around the building at your own pace and not to miss a thing as it is explained really well by various speakers. I thoroughly enjoyed this experience and would thoroughly recommend it. I will never watch the BBC in Parliament again without thinking "I was there".

90 minutes flew by. We joined a guided 90 minute tour from Westminster Hall, the Lords to the Commons - our guide, Gabriella, was terrific imparting great information and insight. Really good value. Don't forget you will have to go through 'airport style' security before your entry.

A Great Insight to how Parliament Works. I have always wanted to visit the Houses of Parliament. This tour was first class and the tour guide was very knowledgable. Every corner you turn in the House of Lords you are met with stunning Victorian decoration. It is steeped with history throughout and a must visit if you enjoy history.

A large bit of history. An interesting morning being guided round the power base of the U.K. If visiting I would recommend the guided tour, you would be surprised as I was how small the Lords and the Commans are. If your interested in this countries history then a visit to the Houses of Parliament Is a must.

Book the tour, it is great.. Very informative tour which took approximately 11/2 hours. Amazing history lesson and the evolution of British democracy is explained in detail by guides who have amazing memories!

Tour of the Mother of Parliaments. I have visited the Houses of Parliament on numerous occasions, the first being as aschoolboy in 1956.Well worth a visit, especially as they are to be closed down for esential repairs before too long!

Very interesting guided tour. As someone who is interested in politics I found this visit very interesting. We paid in advance for a guided tour which lasted about 1.75 hours. These start at specific times and the groups are therefore limited in number to around 20. It was very busy, but Leonie kept us in strict order and gave a very clear account of what happens taking us through the Palace in a logical manner, although with limited interaction. At the end there was the customary cafe and shop and you can also go for afternoon tea if you wish for £29 per head if prebooked. On entry there is an airport style security check. There are very limited opportunities to sit down and only two, less interesting, locations where photos can be taken. These were the disappointing downsides, but overall it was an interesting and worthwhile tour.

Brilliant!. I got a place on the tour through the office of our constituency MP, and it is one of the most enlightening, informative and interesting tours I've been on. So much history and context, along with full explanations of how it relates to our modern-day parliamentary systems. A bit more explanation on the committee stages would have added to it, but that's a minor point. Really, really good.
where the powerhouse are. historic building with plenty to walk around to see and appreciate. extreme busy underground station leading to it.

Beautiful architecture. This icon of London is a must-see. It is beautifully lit of in the evenings and the view of the Houses of parliament across the Thames is stunning. Views of the Houses of Parliament are especially great from the London Eye on clear days

Beautiful Building, Good Tour. Chose the audio tour but I feel like you can't go wrong no matter how you see this place, as long as you see it! It really is a beautiful building and has a lot of history in it. Seeing where the debates go on even today was really fun, and this is a must see for politics and history buffs.

Oozing history. If you can get booked onto one of the tours here it is a fascinating glimpse into the beating heart of British Politics. The history on the walls, the floors and even in the roof is mind-blowing at times and more is made here every day.

great tour. a friend contacted a constituent and his MP hosted us. What a treat to see how the famous place we all see on TV looks in real life [just as impressive - and lots of things you will never see on TV]. Go for it!
What can I say. Its one of London's iconic landmarks. Great architecture, close to Big Ben, West Minster abbey, and London Eye. Can become very crowded, especially on weekends.
Interesting . An excellent place to visit. I was hosted by local Member of Parliament who had a great knowEdge of the history of the establishment. Excellent evening and very informative.

Fascinating tour. We contacted our local MP and were booked onto a guided tour of Parliament free of charge. This is the second time we have been but found the experience to be very different (though equally good) both times as individual tour guides add their emphasis. We were allowed in many areas of the building and were provided with an interesting and informative commentary throughout. Even with few MP's present as it was the Easter break it was still clear this was a working building, Well worth the trip!

Tradition, history and a monumental building. I was attending a function on the terrace - actually a marquee with a walkway outside, directly overlooking the Thames. Decent function canapes and good, friendly service. The treat was arriving a little early and getting to go up to the visitors' gallery and see a live debate. Democracy in action, of a sort. Building is just astonishing and it's well worth visiting to see the collected years of history here.

History lesson. I was privileged enough to be offered a tour of the Houses of Parliament by a local MP followed by a coffee and sit on the members balcony. My own MP was acting speaker, prior to the speakers re-election. Next time I visit Westminster need to spent longer there.
Stunning building. This is such an iconic building. Stunning architecture both inside and outside. Easy to get to. Highly recommend a visit!!

Great tour. Would highly recommend the guided tours. We had a great lady who was funny and very knowledgable. Really interesting one and a half hours . Not many places to sit down so you have to be prepared to walk. Well needed cup of tea at the end in the cafe. A must do!

the public galleries are a revelation. We were not able to do the full tour but were able to easily access the public galleries in both houses. The whole place is steeped in history which you cannot miss as you make your way to the galleries. Very interesting to see how the process works and it is much better than watching it on the TV. If you are in London when parliament is sitting you must go here

Westminster Palace & Big Ben. Westminster Palace is also known as the Houses of Parliament and is the meeting place for the House of Commons and House of Lords (basically Congress for Americans). The first palace was built here in the late 1400's and was subsequently destroyed several times over the centuries and rebuilt. The form that we see it today, 'new gothic' style, is from the mid-1800's. There are a very limited number of tours available when Parliament is not in session if you are lucky enough to be in London at the time- they sell out fast. Also attached to the Westminster Palace is Elizabeth's Tower with the famous Big Big clock.

A Must See. Recommend to see if you are visiting London. From a historical point of view you should include in your schedule if you can. I just learnt recently that Parliament got its name from the French word "parle" which means to speak and was founded by a man called Simon de Montford who was French. I visited with my three children on a guided tour and even my 8 year old found it very interesting. We visited the public gallery and watched for a little while the House of Commons in session. We also saw a statute that the suffragettes chained themselves to.

Highly Interesting/Informative Audio Tour. I could have spent all afternoon here, particularly in the House of Lords and Robing Room! I've been to London numerous times and never had done this tour -- I'm glad I did, and highly recommend it to anyone wanting a crash course on the building, British Parliamentary history, and parliamentory procedures. The art alone was worth seeing. Icing on the cake (no pun intended) was having Afternoon Tea along the Thames -- delightful, but way too much to eat!
Conference . Always amazing whenever I visit.. It was my second time but the building is huge and beautiful.. Just a lovely place to be in

Shame some of it was covered up.. Loved seeing the Houses of Parliament,such an iconic building,unfortunatly some of it seems to be being renovated at the minute so was covered but didn't detract from the splendour of the building itself.

A massive chunk of British history, wrapped in a delicious architectural 'bun'. Apart from the fact it MASSIVE inside a real-life tardis effect it is a genuinely handsome piece of design in beautiful stone (recently renovated and cleaned up for nice selfies (nothing sensible to do with politics if TV is anything to go by).Despite a long boring queue to get in past the sadly obligatory security inside there are a few levels and interesting things to see. Strangely though the whole "look and feel" is quite like one of our typical old boarding schools of yesteryear (and some act as if they are still at school).The outside balcony is still used and in the good weather can be seen the eccentric mamil known as the british member of parliament feasting on his much needed luncheon.Its far too big to take it all in from just one visit so I shall update after my next with some new insights and great things to do.All-in-all a lovely slice of Ye Old England's heritage - a must see!
Massive. Couldn't believe how big it is, it's a shame that you can't go inside as I bet that it is just as grand inside as outside. It really is a marvellous looking building.

Don't Hesitate!! - Book it and GO!!. We booked a guided tour and it was 1 and 3/4hours of great informative entertainment!! ... very worth while!!We saw many others walking around looking aimless with audio headsets glued on ... and I am sure that they didn't get anywhere near as good value as we didI wish we could have taken pictures in the main areas of parliament .... but it was probably for the better as I looked and listened more and even asked questions!!We arrived early for our tour and they fitted us on to the tour before the time we were booked ... a great morning out!! .... and some okay pictures of views and areas I have never seen before
Mother of all Parliament's. Undergoing restoration, beautiful as ever when passing by. It be nice if you go inside without asking your MP.
Nice Parliament. This Parliament is amazing! You can walk beside this place and see the view.If you prefer,you can take a boat and take some pictures from other sides. I LOVE IT!!!

Iconic. Another iconic place in London. We found it simple to get to and have a photo taken with. I found the best views of the Houses of Parliament came from our trip on the London Eye. You can see much more than you can at street level.
Great to See.. Take the time and go Look & Learn. While in London for a long week. Stop by and make this a location to see. Great to learn about UK Parliament and the buildings

One of the Best Tours in London. Iconic building in London, that is definitely worth the tour. I did the guided tour which was well worth it as it gave a good summary of the history of the building and also you were taken places that are out of bounds to the public.

A must visit in London city. One of the best tours you can have...Even if the tickets seem a bit expensive, it definitely worth it. You are given an audio guide (free of charge) that provides you all the useful information about the history of this impressive building. You will have the chance to wander around the parliament's halls (House of Lords and House of Commons) and see the place where all decisions for country's future are taken! Recommended!

very interesting.....security takes a long time so allow for that. one always looks at this on telly but you never go to see it...well worth it....security take less so that you pass on the line quickly. this day and age one has to allow longer times....but well worth the visit

Canapes in The Speaker's House. I went to a private function in the grand drawing rooms of the Speaker's House. The surroundings are opulent, Draped in maroon damask wallpapers with gold detailing on the columns with portraits of the current and past Speakers of the House going back to the 17th Century. The canapés were delicious and just kept coming even after the Princess Royal had come and gone. Certain to be highly recommended as a set of function rooms for that most important event.

A must visit. Audio tour is of high quality with the function to extend the summaries provided to suit your particular interests or available time. Would suggest a minimum of one and half hours for a visit. Security at entrance is high so allow additional time before your tour start time of about 15/20 minutes. Also if it is raining you have to queue in the open so be prepared

Fascinating behind the scenes tour. We visited here on a Saturday morning and opted for the audio tour. It was really interesting and informative. Be prepared to queue to get in as security is similar to an airport and take an umbrella if its raining as the queue is outside

Where history was made.. When taking the tour you have a choice between a guided tour or an audio tour. It is great to have the audio tour as you can replay the recordings to truly understand the actions that took place in history. It is amazing to believe that our history is shaped because of what actually put place in Lord and commons chambers.You can not take pictures in all areas as it is prohibited but you are welcome to take pictures in the common areas.

A fascinating insight behind the political doors. We had a tour and then afternoon tea. The guided tour was brilliant and the afternoon tea was lovely. The history around the building and the explanation of all the processes and procedures was enlightening. Getting to have tea in the rooms where the MPs and lords dine was exciting with fab views across the river.

Iconic Landmark. This is one of the must see things in London. Hugely attractive building steeped in history. Sitting right on the Thames and close to many other tourist sites its the perfect photo opportunity also

Great Evening Stroll. We purposely waited until the evening to walk by the Houses of Parliament. They are so beautiful and I think even more majestic lit up in the evening. We walked from the National Gallery, to Trafalgar Square, to Big Ben to Parliament. We walked half way across the bridge after Parliament and got some more great family shots with the building in the background, but it got too cold to continue on the bridge so we just turned around. It's free,got great photos, no lines and doesn't take a long time!

Informative and interesting. I booked online for the audio tour. Getting in was a bit chaotic - but obviously security is paramount. The audio tour is very easy to follow and to see areas so steeped in history was a joy. The commentary is informative. The only negative is that photos are not allowed which was disappointing.

A Must . Awesome historic building and incredible place on the river. It is possible to visit inside and sit in the public galleries which is recommended. Check out the Commons and Lords. Full of art and interesting history.

PMQ's. My partner had always wanted to go to PMQ's so he finally got around to asking his MP if there was any chance of obtaining tickets, it seems there was! I wasn't overly keen but I'm glad I went with him. The buildings are beautiful and everything is run with timeless precision. Lots of professional and polite staff about to answer questions and offer help. There were a few questions I'd have liked to have asked but the public are hidden safely at arms length behind huge Perspex screens under strict instructions from a chap (with a very posh belt buckle!) not to clap, shout, jeer etc.. An enjoyable couple of hours.
So worth a visit. I am not sure how popular it is ti visit the HoP but I definately recommend it to someone who is interested in the UK history. Guides available in various languages.

Very informative, well worth it. We booked a guided tour and, would definitely recommend it. The tour takes about an hour and a half and, I assume, is available in a number of languages. I certainly would choose this over the headset, do it yourself tour as the guide was happy to ask any questions and was very knowledgeable. One word of caution though, there is only one opportunity to sit down on this tour so, worth bearing that in mind if you have mobility issues

Dinner in the seat of Power. We had the pleasure of diner in the houses of parliament Take a camera and comfortable shoes as the hard stone floors can become painful in high heels take a tour of the parliament chambers revel in the majesty an history and the day to day decisions made the food was excellent pricey but well worth the decadence the staff are very helpful and photos from across the Thames and inside the venue are stunning don't forget your souvenirs pricey but unique

Saturday Tour. We had booked the recorded audio guide tour as it was a little cheaper than using the proper guided tour. We were not disappointed - the Palace of Westminster is amazing, for both it's architecture and its history. The audio guides enable you to go at your own pace, and repeat sections of particular interest. Would recommend it to anyone, and especially to those interested in history and politics.

Great to visit. We booked online to visit, a month in advance and were lucky as parliament was in recess when we were going so could choose a mid week tour. Our tour guide took us around all the main areas including the House of Commons and the House of Lords. This was the highlight for me as it was so interesting to be standing in a room you see so often on the television. Throughout the tour there were many impressive paintings and statues to see of former prime ministers of the U.K. Well worth a visit and highly recommended.

Saturday Summer Tours. For foreign visitors, you can get a tour of the houses on Saturdays during Summer. You must book ahead, and it's very popular, so make sure you reserve in advance. The tours are fun, and there's a ton to enjoy!
Lovely view. Saw it from outsid and the building has some lovely carvings. The place is well kept. Non UK citizens are not allowed inside
A fantastic building.. We only had chance to look on it from the outside. Still a fantastic experience and we took some great Photos. Next time we will try to get a closer look. A must in London.

Just incredible!. Visited with my family and we all really loved it. The place is just incredible and the history is unbelievable. The tour is brilliant and very informative. I could spend all day telling you all about it but please go and see it. When parliament is in recess you get to get in both the commons, the lords and the Queens robing room so it's best to go and see everything rather than just going in the public gallery.
Postcard. Very nice building, interesting history and facts. Also it is mandatory place for pictures or to make a selfie.

Beautiful building inside and out. A great opportunity to see how the houses of parliament work and where the mps and lords sit. Inside is really interesting with statues and paintings everywhere, depicting many old parliamentarians.

Not Bad.. Cool location - very historical.
Apart from there being lots of snakes in there, it's probably worth a visit. I'd definitely visit again, although not sure what else there is to see.
Café in there isn't too bad.

GREAT PIECE OF HISSTORY. an absolute must if one can get the chance for a guided tour; incredibly interesting, steeped in history and tradition. Best way to arrange this is through your own MP's office.

Fantastic!!!!. I took a group to the Houses of Parliament for an audio tour, this must not be missed it was fantastic, you don't have to be into politics just marvel at the fantastic architecture, décor and history. The audio Tour is informative and not boring in any way and the great part about it is you can take as long as you like to wonder around. My party really enjoyed their tour and we were all impressed with the wonderful atmosphere generated by everyone involved including the policemen outside while we were waiting for our tickets. Having been into the House of Lords The Commons and all around it puts everything you see on the news into perspective. If you are going to London DO THIS TOUR it really is well worth it. By the way there ids a great café inside to, I was amazed at the prices really cheap for lunch and superb quality!!! Normally attractions capitalise on prices, this one doesn't!!! A Fantastic trip!!

Attending a debate. This building is of architectural and historical interest. It's a fascinating place to visit. Once you are past the re-assuring security measures there are great places to explore. The catering for private functions is excellent

Visit with French friend. Anyone can visit the H-O-P; just queue up and walk in as far as the central lobby. You can book tours but just arriving (free entry) gets you into the Great Hall of Westminster; the original seat of Parliament and the spot where Charles1 was tried. the walk onwards to the central lobby is full of history. if you are well organised, write to your MP and ask to be shown around.

Visual overload. An assault on the eyes. This building(s) is full of history and custom and protocol plus amazing architecture with fantastic floor and ceiling decorations. There is SO much to take in on a one hour tour. Deffinitely worth a revisit. I arranged this via my local MP so had a personal guide for four rather than in a group of 20. Plus free. Excellent.

London trip. I arranged the full guided tour of the houses of parliament through my local MP for myself and my nine year old son as it's free.. A very informative visit by our tour guide Elizabeth . I was absolutely in awe of the beauty and history of the place .

Amazing. We booked a visit to the Houses of Parliament through our local MP. Upon arrival security was very tight (as you would expect) once inside we met our guide for the tour. His knowledge on the building and its history was fantastic. You could tell that he was proud of his job and obviously loved it. The tour itself was amazing, a beautiful building oozing with history. If your visiting London and you can arrange to visit then it's a must do. Without a doubt one of the most memorable days out I've had

Amazing Visit!!. It was a fantastic visit and it was also very informative. Me and my Grandma went on the pre-booked guided tour. Our tour guide was fantastic and very friendly. If you go you will learn a lot of new things!! Well worth the money. The café has nice food too.

It is quite a sight. Living in Rome the architecture is astonishing, there is nothing quite like it where I live and I really loved to walk around it. The nicest view is undoubfuly from the nearby bridge or from the other side of the river where you can take really awesome pictures. By night it's just a splendor, too bad we couldn't visit the insides....
Beautiful. and big, just what you imagine. The entire area is beautiful and fun to walk around. Lots to do and see and a short walk away from museums and the Buckingham Palace.

Very interesting pre-booked free tour. A group of 6 adults enjoyed a pre-booked free tour of the Houses of Parliament amongst a larger group, arranged via our MP. Our guide was well informed although, as there were a number of tours taking place, difficult to hear at times. The guide explained the traditions as well as the history of the building, answering questions too.

So many things to learn.... I love it when I visit a place and get out with this impression of having learnt something and want to share it. This is exactly what happened last Saturday after visiting the Houses of Parliament.Make sure you take the audio guide for your visit. The comments are of very good quality. I notice there are also private guided tours available.It took us about 1:15 to complete the tour and see both Chambers. More detailed visits could last longer.I will recommend this visit to anyone who wants to understand and get a good feeling of what/how is democracy in the UK.
So much history here. You need to go to the House of Parliament. There is so much history here, the only problem is they would not allow photos.
Book a guided tour!!!. Great guided tour in the houses of parliament. This is a beautiful building with a lot of history. I strongly suggest you to book a guided tour instead of an audio guide.

An historical building worthy of a visit . We came to the Houses of Parliament on a booked coach trip. Tight security before going in, fully justified but worth the wait in getting in. We had a tour guide whom was brilliant, so informative taking us to the House of Lords then to the House of Commons seeing where the Prime Minister at question time stands, the public speaker to where the Queen addresses the house and where cross benchers sit, so much more. Then finally to Westminster Hall which is the oldest part of the building back to Edward the Confessor. Our guide gave her last tour as she was now retiring. We then had afternoon tea on the terraces of the House of Lords. You must book to see this wonderful historical building so worthy of a visit.

Capitol tour. Last week end i went on the Houses of Parliament tour which was amazing. I couldn't fit in all the facts and detail that I saw and heard in that 1hr 45 min tour. It is worth pre booking because the wait for tickets could be very long indeed. My guide was a guy named Jacob who was brilliant, witty,and knowledgable but easy to listen to and was never caught out by any of the questions fired at him, I am sure the other guides are good as well.If you have any interest in history, politics or just general knowledge pay the very reasonable price and have an enjoyable day in the Houses of Parliament.
Great to go inside and see the rooms. Really great experience seeing where the debating happens. House of lords is also another nice room. Enjoy!

Lunch in the Commons Dining Room with our local MP. Fine dining with silver service in a busy and buzzing dining room. Fabulous!! We had bid £560 at a charity fundraising auction for this experience and it was worth every penny.

Fantastic tour!-- worth time and money.. We had an excellent guided tour of Parliament... Our guide was Liz Rubenstein-- a Blue Badge Tourist guide. She was passionate, knowledgeable, and witty.... made it very entertaining. She knew all her info--memorized and able to deliver with enthusiasm. Highly recommend her.
Well worth a visit. Recommend for adults and children. Beautiful building with lots of interesting information. Highlight was getting to visit The House of Commons

Fascinating . Even though this is one of the most famous buildings in the world, it seemed to be a hidden gem that nobody knew they could get into. It is an extremely fascinating palace turned debating chamber which has a lot of interesting history. We took a guided tour so we could ask questions and receive a more personal tour of it. A downside to the "attraction" is that photos could only be taken in one room. I'm not really sure why this is the case as the House of Commons and House of Lords are televised anyway. I probably wouldn't advise this to families as you need to take in a lot of information but it is ok as long as your teenager is interested in politics, modern studies or history.
Stunning architecture. They are doing some renovations on one side but you can still see and appreciate the wonderful architecture of this landmark.
london visit. London's most iconic buildings,the Palace of Westminster is the meeting place of the House of Commons and the House of Lords, the two houses of the Parliament of the United Kingdom.

Very interesting. We took a tour that last 1 hr 45 mins and it was the way to go. You have no hope of understanding how British government works without a guide. The building is fascinating and full of history.

Don't Miss Out!. This was not a planned visit but more of a what shall we do next...got off the tube at Westminster to have a look at Big Ben. Noticed the Houses of Parliament tour guide and thought why not and how fantastic it was!We went for the audio tour and with two young girls (9 and 11) we thought they "might" like it.....like it, I don't think I've ever seen my daughters so interested in history, I'm still in shock!!It was a great 2 hours spent seeing everything great about where we have come from to the present, standing in the actual house of commons was somewhat strange but great.Personally I thought fantastic value for money at £36 for a family of 4 with no time restrictions that I'm aware of.
Class visit to Parliament. I took a class of 25 French students to the Houses of Parliament last month and it was a great experience. The guide was knowledgable and good fun.

Should be on everyone's bucket list!. My friends and I booked this as a guided tour with afternoon tea. The tour was a revelation! Our guide, Victoria, absolutely made it as she was knowledgeable, friendly and humorous. I don't know why this isn't on the school curriculum, and it's a must do for anyone even remotely interested in British history, politics or even architecture as the Palace of Westminster is absolutely stunning. The afternoon tea was, without doubt, the best I've had, we ate everything! Highly recommended.

Wonderful . This tour is absolutely amazing. We booked online to secure a guided tour and were delighted that we were in a group of only 8. The history and decor are fabulous and should be up there as a top priority to see in London. Totally shocked there isn't a queue of people trying to visit , in fact I don't think the public realise the Houses of Parliament are actually accessible. This is a must see !

Beautiful..!. Situated next to Westminister Bridge, Big Ben and London Eye, you can't miss it if you visit any of these. Offers great backdrop for photographs taken on the bridge overlooking the lake and the parliament.

Tour. This tour is excellent and probably one of the best I have been on. The buildings are amazing and the audio guide provides a wonderful explanation as you walk through them. This is a must do when you come to London.

Excellent. Visited the Houses of Parliament Friday what a wonderful tour, took the audio tour which enables you to go at your own pace and take in all the wonders around you in my opinion you do not have to be politically minded to appreciate the p!ace. Everyone should do this tour, young and old alike. May I also say how very reasonable the cafe was with a very good selection of snacks available. Overall a great day out. Please go you will not be disappointed.

ok. We booked this tour before we arrived to ensure there was space. You get to walk around with your audio head set but there is so much information to take in. The rooms are beautiful but be warned, this has airport security before you enter (of course!) and I had to remove shoes, belt, watch and jewelry so make sure you leave time for this.The robing room is lovely and being in both chambers is a privilege.Great couple of hours and a lovely (if not expensive) tea room with beautiful cakes.
Great Tour. This is a great tour that you can only take on Saturdays. You need to book it advance as tickets are limited.

Excellent. Booked an audio tour with my teenage daughter. What a brilliant hour and a half, incredibly informative and interesting. The palace of westminster is beautiful inside with so much recognisable from tv. We went at our own pace, sitting down every now and then to soak up the atmosphere. Security is tight so at busy times there is a bit of a wait but nothing too long. Loved it.
Beautiful. I walk pass this everyday! such an iconic bridge and would recommend everyone to come visit! Lucky if you catch it opening!
Stunningly imposing. To imagine the effect of this building when it was constructed is to realise the power of the Empire! Awe inspiring.

Amazing architecture. The architecture of the House of Parliament is really amazing and very beautiful.I like seeing the building from the other side of the river, where you can get good photos with the building and Big Ben in the background.

Sue. I have done this before and thought the grandson would enjoy it and I was right. We did the audio tour. He had a great time and asked questions of the many attendants that are around to help. Tickets are available from opposite big Ben or online. You will go through a security check just like an airport.

Take the guided tour. A very interesting and enjoyable afternoon out.We paid the extra for the tour guide and it was well worth it. Just enough information to keep the grown ups happy but not too much to bore the kids.You get to go into both chambers of the house but unfortunately can't take photographs.Delighted to see that even in such a prestigious venue you "exit through gift shop".
Talk and hear the big bang.. We take a big talk around the parliament, and we also stay in a little "park" so we can hear the clock.

Wow!!!!. We were very fortunate to get into the Parliament Houses tour. They will only run this tour when Parliament is NOT in session (for obvious reasons). The interior is beautiful and ornate and unlike any type of government building I have ever seen. We were allowed in both the House of Lords and The House of Commons. Very knowledgeable guides take you through in small groups and discuss the history and the function of Parliament. Go if you are able. You must book admission online

Take a guided tour. This is an amazing place to visit. our guide, Jo, was absolutely fantastic, very knowledgeable - her recoil of historic dates and people was phenomenal but all told with a sense of humour and several witty asides. Would highly recommend a visit.

Go When You Can Get the Full Tour--Absolutely Phenomenal. We were visiting the Parliament during the British Elections when Parliament was not in session for over a month. We signed up for the full tour and it was absolutely incredible.Find out when you get go and get the full tour and book it.We went to the Chamber of the House of Lords, Queen and Kings special rooms when they visit, and the old halls. Not to be missed.

Tour guide is well worth the money. Despite being fairly pricey (at £25 for adults and £20 for students), the tour guide of the Houses of Parliament is well worth forking out for.
