So much history in both houses it is a must for historians, political interest etc. Extremely tight airport style security (tighter than airports) at the entrance so make sure you have no sharps (including tweezers, metal nail files)

Guided Tour. One word: Excellent ! The tour guide was great and it is a must see for anyone! takes about 1hour 30mins, a lot of walking, but I would really recommend it. Not going to give to much away of the information you find out but it is really interesting. One thing though, no pictures allowed.
Wow. This is a must for all the family. And if you can make sure you book to have tea there you will not be disappointed the staff are absolutely amazing

Guided tour of The Palace of Westminster. Really interesting to see the place where a lot of our laws are made. You can visit both chambers and also see the main lobby which is shown on most news reports. Needs to be booked in advance, but well worth the cost.
Great tour!. The guided tour of the Houses of Parliament was a fantastic experience. Lovely to see inside the iconic building which we usually only see on TV.

A must when visiting London. Our guide Russell was exceptional and held us all in thrall for nearly two hours. Visitors have excellent access to the important spaces inside the Palace of Westminster and are led through The House of Lords, The House of Commons, the Queen's robing room etc. (Having also done a tour of BBC Broadcasting House I was struck by how much MORE access visitors have to our seat of government. Both are working buildings but Houses of Parliament allow for much closer engagement with our national institutions!).History is a massive part of this tour and Russell took every opportunity to share nuggets which both fascinated and intrigued. No doubt the jokes and stories are rehearsed patter - but he delivered them with enthusiasm and passion for his subject so they did not feel stale. There is so much to savour for anyone with even a passing interest in history, architecture, politics and art. A fantastic visit!

The glory of Parliaments. A tremendous sense of history from the 11th. Century Westminster Hall - then probably the largest hall in Europe - to the Gothic grandeur of the Lords, the more functional but still splendid Commons chamber rebuilt after the WW2 bombing and the modern cutting edge of the select committees in Portcullis House and its splendid atrium. The Houses of Parliament and its wider estate has so many nooks and crannies of great interest, try to visit before the refurbishment starts in earnest.
Lovely to see. Great to see the houses of parliment, it was only around the corner from our hotel.lovely to walk all around that area & take in the sights

Such a Statement of Power. Heavily guarded and encircled by barred fences and gates one needs to get up close to really appreciate this buildings architecture, design and the craftsmanship required to build such a statement of power. A marvel when viewed from any point or location in its vicinity. Given that this building serves an active role in British Politics it is not generally open to the greater public but one can only imagine what it must feel and look like from the inside. Being in such an immaculate condition it is hard to believe that it has actually been in existence for hundreds of years. Wonderful.
Guided Tour. Excellent! A very knowledgable guide imparted information in an informative and interesting way! Will take another tour next time i'm in London!

Awesome Experience. The Houses of Parliament are a place that you really have to see when in London!At weekends and during recess you can pre-book tours online, and UK residents can request free tour tickets from their MP (but get in early - generally they book up 6mths in advance!).The tour offers an excellent look at both chambers of Parliament whilst giving an in-depth look at the work of Parliament and its history. Every tour guide we have had thus far has been extremely knowledgeable and they are happy to answer any question about the work of Parliament. Please do remember, though, that Parliament is a working palace and legislature. You will pass through airport-style security ran by the Metropolitan Police when you enter, and you will find a good number of police officers and security staff inside. You will also have to wear a visitor badge. When Parliament is in session, you will generally not be allowed outside of the 'public' areas unless escorted by a pass holder - but you can access the public galleries, Westminster Hall, the cafe, etc. even when Parliament is sitting. Outside of these times you will be able to explore the palace either with a tour guide or audio guide. If you're not happy with this then I would not recommend visiting - nor would I recommend visiting without pre-booking tickets. Also do note you will NOT be allowed to sit on the Parliamentary benches in the chambers so please don't try.The Palace is a great place to learn about democracy and its history in the UK - and it is in close proximity to other 'attractions' such as the Supreme Court and Westminster Abbey.
A 'must see' when visiting London. The most amazing building ever! both inside and out. Take the tour to see, hear & learn all about British history.
History and architecture . House of Parliament is very good design by architecture and very good history place. So many tourists visit to parliament.
Iconic. Such an iconic part of London. Make sure you cross the bridge to get some photos of the houses next to Big Ben and Westminster Abbey

Fascinating tour, cool to stand on the floor of both houses!. How cool is this!? You take the tour and get the stand on the floor of both the House of Commons AND the House of Lords! Whoa! Mind blown! And the history of the place is simply amazing. All the funky little rituals that have grown up over the years are simply amazing (I'm just gonna say: Blackstaff!). Well worth the visit. And the Great Hall is a very impressive space, the chapel is simply beautiful and the House of Lords stunning in its richness (and fascinating in its contrast to the rather sparse House of Commons).
Really interesting. The staff are really welcoming and the tour guides give you so much information. It's a bit overwhelming to be in the same places as the many leaders of this nation!

Audio-guided tour well worthwhile. For anyone interested in history, architecture or politics this is a fascinating tour. The inside of the Houses of Parliament, including the House of Lords and Commons chambers, central lobby and the Old Great Hall are as beautiful as you may imagine from viewing the outside of this magnificent building. Charles Barry's design is amazing and intricate.The self-guided audio tour gives a lot of information to increase the enjoyment the visit. There is also a guided tour at various times of the day but we enjoyed the ability to go round at our own pace. We were able to go straight in with no queues (in comparison to the nearby London Eye attraction).Definitely a must see!

The best London experience. Such a special place to visit. The guides were absolutely sensational. I could not fault this experience. We took children 5 & 9 are the guides made a special point of working with them.

Visit - you know you want to!!!. We arrived in the rain and stood waiting for security - so if wet - take a brolly as there could be some standing! Security staff very friendly and helpful - jolly and joking but very meticulous! The guided tour we booked on was very full so we opted to go on a later one. Late afternoon tours are probably less busy! 1 oclock tour was over full! Good guide - we would have liked time to look at the rooms though! It felt like we were in a rush! Cafe good and shop good too!

Historical. If you enjoy history (old and new), you need to take a tour of the Houses of Parliament. Best enjoyed with the audio headset. Best to go when they are not in session. AVOID the afternoon tea (watered down experience)

First Visit. Can't believe it's taken me so long to visit. I was mesmerised. We had a guided tour and went out onto the balcony as well as both houses. Cake, coffee and gift shop all very good to finish off a very pleasant day. We are so lucky having all this history. Security was present but it didn't feel oppressive and we saw quite a few famous people.

History and architecture - what a wonderful combination!. It was great to tour the building inside and see the magnificent architecture - especially the ceiling of Westminster Hall (the oldest part). We also found out about the UK system of government and parliament, walking into the 2 separate Chambers. A most interesting visit that should be on every visitor's itinerary!

Stunning!. I visit this building a lot throughout the year and it is simply stunning - I never tire of the architectural beauty. It can be a bit of a pain queuing to get in but security is rightly taken seriously here.Not visited - contact your local MP and ask them to book you in for a tour.

I feel like I am in the BBC news. Fabulous. Buying tickets is confusing,across the street etc. Smaller than I thought. Unbelievable tourist access. Guide was jerky and bordered on politically incorrect with Americans. Other than that an absolute must for history/politics fans...

Excellent. Had a guided tour with a friend that works in parliament. Really good experience, would suggest taking a tour (if possible) as a lot of random stuff you wouldn't find out if you just walked through by yourself.
Interesting to see the last House of Commons/Lords and where the queen gets robed when she visits.
Beautiful Architecture. This is beautiful piece of architecture to look at. Details are impeccable and this is a place to see. Cops are friendly if you want to take a picture.

Bucket List. Great site to see. House of parliament is right next to the tube entrance. People seem to overlook that Westminster Abbey is right next to this sight. To beat the crowds of people for the perfect picture, cross the road towards Westminster and you can get a great photo of Big Ben and the London eye. Great historical site. I did see long lines next to the red telephone booths, but there are red telephone booths located all over London so you don't have to wait in the long lines.
Good. A good attraction, and one you can't really miss in London. Can get very busy and tourist-y though..

Interesting insight into British politics. Had a thoroughly enjoyable visit to the Houses of Parliament, including a tour through central lobby and the chance to sit in the public gallery for the days debates. Wonderful architecture and fantastic staff who took the time to offer friendly advice, information and guidance throughout the visit. Would definitely visit again any time.

London point of interest. Great to see up close. Pictures do not do it justice.October was a good time to go. It was crowded, but not like peak times. Weather was Ok for London, not too cold or hot. Only rained a few times.
Beautiful. When in England, visit the Houses of Parliament is compulsory. It's always a pleasure to revisit it.
Icon view . Love seeing this wonderful view with so much history! Kids were so chuffed to see the clock from the telly!! Well worth a visit!
Beautiful and amazing. Right around big ben are beautiful intricate buildings and just so much to see. Great view from the Canal with lots of photo opportunities

House of Parliament. My fiance and I went to see the House of Parliament we are self did not go in we just saw it from the outside with the guards and everything very nice place next time we go we must go in to see what it looks like from the inside

The live debates there are well worth a watch. I came here to go and watch a debate at the House of Commons and as I made my ways to the gallery, that feeling of being enveloped by authentic history was overwhelming. The indoor architecture very much transports you through time and is worth a visit.The debate itself was not only free and insightful, but thoroughly entertaining - think Jerry Springer meets Downton Abbey - as the grandstanders of Britain very politely slag each other off in the most British way possible.

Well organised, fascinating. I really enjoyed wandering through this historic building. Stop for a cup of tea and a piece of cake, it's worth it. If you love history and politics, this is one not to miss.

Amazing building.. We stayed at the elegant Pooters B&B which is a short walk south of the river giving perfect views of the Houses of Parliament as you approach. Sitting on a bench on the South bank of the river contemplating the Houses of Parliament gives you the chance of enjoying this spectacular sight.
It's huge. Go and walk around appreciate that biggest monument side by side with the Thames very historical part of London
Amazing. We never went inside but from the outside, the buildings are so impressive and amazing looking, you have to go and you have to take as many photos as you can.

Overall good for not knower of British history . We've been there for a guided tour led by a native English speaker with Italian's language knowledge. The lady could speak a very good Italian and made the tour enjoyable, although if you're someone with prior knowledge of the British politics and have some insight of the houses of parliament, then you might well go unguided. Good experience overall.

Excellent, value for money tour!. I took the Houses of Parliament English guided tour, 90 minutes long costing £25. It was fascinating and our guide, Fernando, was superb and so knowledgeable. I can highly recommend this tour for an insight into English parliamentary and royal history.
House of Parliament. How lucky we were to get to tour the House of Parliament. To stand and visualize all the history was surreal.

Mother of Parliaments. An amazing tour of the Houses of Parliament. Walking back through history... clearly showed the importance of this place and how it has shaped the history of the world. Awe inspiring! If you love history this is a must!

A must do for locals as well as tourists. I was a bit sceptical before going on this tour but it was absolutely brilliant. I learned so much about where the British government came from and how it has evolved to what it is today, and the special traditions that they still follow. Our guide was full of enthusiasm, extremely knowledgeable and spoke in stories to deliver the facts is a highly entertaining and interesting way that will be remembered. Worth every penny.

Must see in London. Tours are available but we made do with a swatch from outside for free. Architecture alone is worth a look but this is a must to tick off your sight seeing list and worth the scenic walk.

Marvellous and humbling. Understandably tight security and so be prepared to queue a while. However incredibly polite staff and security personnel. The audio tour was great, permitting you to choose summary or more detail as you prefer. There were more rooms and more ornate architecture than we realised. It was humbling to stand (if not sit!) in the back benches. Will help put everything in context next time I see footage from the Lords or Commons

Amazing Historic Building. We have organised events here. Fantastic history. Every part of the building has a story connected to it. It's worth seeing inside. As a democratic country we have the right to see our laws being created

To be inside The Great Hall!. I mostly wanted to visit Parliament for the Great Hall (a history lovers dream) where the medieval and Queens and Kings ruled....where the famous trials of Thomas More, William Wallace and King Charles I was held! It was an added bonus to then go inside and see the Parliament rooms. I loved the Prince's Chamber....great art depicting history everywhere.

A walk through history. My wife and I went on a tour of the Houses of Parliament organised by my daughter's school. The guide was knowledgeable and took the time to explain everything relevant. Not surprisingly it is steeped in history and to walk through the area where Prime Minsters Question Time takes place is a real thrill. I recommend it to anyone with an interest in historywonderful
Super audio tour. Attended for the audio tour and was extremely pleased.Great narrative throughout and learnt a great deal, fabulous architecture, loads of history. Well worth a visit!

High Quality Tour - Go when Parliament is not "in session" if possible. A very high quality tour. We were lucky enough to tour when Parliament was not in session. This allowed us to actually go on the floor of both the House of Commons and the House of Lords as well as see other associated areas of Parliament normally off-limits. Our tour guide was fabulous and very well informed. Interestingly, we could not "sit" in either chamber as that was forbidden for some reason. Like seemingly everything else in London, you must pay to tour but it was well worth it.

Extremely interesting. We took a guided tour around the Houses of Parliament during a long weekend in London. It is an impressive building with a fascinating history. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and friendly answering all.questions. A must see for anyone interested in British politics
Parliament in Winter. Very cool sight, lots of good picture opportunities within a walk. The tube will take I right to it, also Westminster Abbey is nearby too! A must see while in London!

made special by a very special guide. we managed to arrange a tour through our MP . this is a fantastic place full of pomp and history and we learnt more in our 2 hour tour than in any classroom This was entirely due to our fantastic guide Chris whose day job is part of the sergeant at arms team . he told us much of the official (and unofficial ) history and gossip of the Houses along the way We got to see many of the places you see on the new channels as Parliament had gone home for the week-end including both chambers and we found out why you can't be declared dead in the palace of Westminster
Nice historical site. Its ok to be there and watch the sunset. Crowded but interesting. Definitely worth seeing and exploring.

History at its best. Amazing buildings with so much history attached, as well as being the heart of where the country is governed from. Apply in advance for tickets to the chambers and you may be able to watch a heated debate! Also, remember security is very tight.

Democracy in action. I've taken friends from overseas (USA and Australia) into Parliament when it has been sitting. They have been amazed at the access afforded. Be sure to visit the House of Lords as well as the Commons. This is British history at its finest.

So interesting!. Not many people think of visiting probably cause you have to pre-book and it's only on open on some days but it was so interesting and our guide (yes it is a guided tour) was great! His name was Tom and he even made sure to include some of that wonderful British humour in his explanations :)

Great architecture and interior design. Augustus Pugin is a genius!. It lives up to expectations. No photographs allowed inside though. A bit expensive, but worthwhile if you have extra cash to spare.
Tour. We were given a tour by our local MP Gregg Clarke with a few other constituents but a general tour with guide is available. Not to be missed.

Guided Tour. We went here on a guided tour with a Coach trip especially for this tour, from our home town The tour guide, Sarah Reynolds, was excellent - she explained everything extremely well and had a good speaking voice that one could hear very well and she included everyone into the tourThe tour itself is a great experience, learning about all of the history of the building and the everyday life of the staff working there - apparently around 10000 people a day work in this famous buildingOne of the most important buildings in the UK both for parliamentarian business and for TourismA must visit for a tour should you have the opportunityRecommended - Enjoy

Interesting trip but expensve. Very interesting visit with knowledgable guide. Your not allowed to take photos and as with most landmarks in London, it can be expensive especially if you are a family.

Houses of Parliament tour. Our group had a wonderful visit to HoP 8 February. Chris was an exemplar of what tour guide should be. Just enough information, delightful manner and lots of detail when required. We loved the architure and the ornate rooms are beyond belief. If you want a great historical experience do this tour.
Attend Prime Minister Question Time every Wednesday. Open to the public, do the tour and attend the Prime Minister Questioning to explore another democratic process in the UK for politics lovers.

Bursting with history. Visited as part of a college trip that involved a tour of parliament and to the Commons public gallery. It's worth a visit for the architecture alone, the rooms are full of brilliant paintings and statues. But you aren't allowed to take pictures inside which is a little bit annoying but makes you focus on what's being said. I would reccommend a visit to the public gallery of the Commons, even if there is no lively debate taking place it's still interesting to see how day to day parliament is run. If you visit on a Wednesday the chamber will be full and you can witness Prime Ministers Questions, although I expect it will be quite busy.
Great tour!. If you fancy a bit of extraordinary history, taking the Houses of Parliament tour is a great way to spend a few hours in London!
Fantastic insight to the world of parliment.. We did the english guide tour very good guide lasted about 1hour 45. Staff very friendly and helpful

Unexpected great afternoon . Went at lunchtime and found it a really good tour. The audio guide was a bit over informative so found there is a bit of hanging around waiting before moving to the next number. But that said it covered everything
Breathtaking. My favourite building in London simply unbelievable could spend a whole day just looking at it stunning
Pleasant surprise. Great guided tour with great guide. Fantastic in the Chambers and the history that you do not get. The size or lack of is not apparent on television.

Excellent visit. Very helpful staff helped me buy tickets on my phone and allowed my disabled husband to shelter out of the wind in their kiosk (the ticket office is opposite Big Ben - a long way away from the entrance to the H of P). Took the audio guide and the whole visit was brilliant
Interesting Tour. Definitely do the guided tour. You learn more and I believe you get to go more places than if you just took the audio tour.

Very informative visit. This was a fantastic visit to an iconic building steeped in history. I had an audio guide which I prefer to a guided tour as you can take it at your own pace and re-listen to anything. There is so much to see and admire that sometimes you stop listening! I spent 2 hours walking around and learning so much about the House of Commons and House of Lords. No queues in February, so there were no holdups anywhere. Well priced cafe to visit before leaving. Good value for money.

Mother of Parliament. Any visitor to London should arrange a tour of this amazing building, this can be done in advance through the tours office.If your a UK resident, why not inform your local M.P of your intended visit he /she might just be waiting to greet you

Educational tour. I have been here many times to visit on the outside but first time inside. Really fantastic tour and was blown away by the decorative House of Lords. The original medieval hall was the high point of the tour.

Saturday only. Completely fascinating every minute of the 90 minute tour. A lot of walking as it is a huge building dating from the 11th century. House of Lords, House of Commons, Queen's robing room, the historical corridors where some of the most important people in the history of the world have walked. Every detail is covered. Well worth the admission price. Don't miss it if you have an opportunity.

Best attraction in London. This is definetly the best place to see in whole London. History, art, architecture, everything clearly narrated by the employees as well as by audio guides in many languages. Visit the rest of London only after this.A little bit pricey, and some queue due to the security checks at the entrance, but worth a visit.
Beautiful view. One of the iconic sights of London. It has an amazing view from anywhere. It's a must see place when somebody is looking for attractions.

Great tour. Just completed the full tour here, encompassed the Queen's chamber, the house of lords, house of commons and several other rooms. It lasted around 1hr 20mins and well worth it. I didn't realise it used to be a palace, and it certainly lives up to it.There's toilets and a gift shop, as well as places to sit at several points.

Awards dinner . This was my second parliamentary dinner and much improved on last year. Beef Wellington was the main and by far the best I ve ever had cooked to perfection. The venue it's self is steeped in history and provides a prestigious setting for an awards dinner really enjoyed it looking forward to the next one

Opportunity to observe democracy at work!. Had opportunity to visit public galleries and observe debate on pending bill in House of Commons. Great hall is very impressive and reeks of England's history. Security is tight but not obtrusive.

What's not worth seeing?. It's one of the very top attractions in the heart of London and if you're lucky you might be able to get inside the Strangers' Gallery to see the action...but you might think why you bothered if most of the MPs are in Committee. Lol!. You just have to go and see the exterior.
great to inspire my sons love of politics and modern studies. its iconic and a must if you visit london, a great place to see and feel like your in the heart of the nation x

History in the making. The sheer majesty of looking arond the mother of all Parliaments is awesome. Everywhere your feet tread history exudes. There are so many nooks and crannies just waiting to be discovered. I managed to sit in the stranger's gallery in the House of Commons - wonderful. Earlier I had a tour of the House of Lords and getting so close to the 'throne' of England was almost ineffable and nearly a numinous experience. Slend visit and a must for all to see!

politics. as I watch daily politics at home this visit was a must for me, although we had not pre-booked we spoke to the guides outside and were informed that a card was necessary to get you inside, then stringent security(airport style) another form to fill in(name and address) then on to the gallery to watch our MP's in debate, even the wife enjoyed seeing parliament in live action. Lots of history, coffee shop and a nice souvenir wallet for my birthday.

Inspirational tour for all. A fantastic place to learn about European history to present day with professional tour guides explaining the facts regarding the Queen and royal family. Allow at least 2 hours to explore or buy a souvenir in the nearby shops. Churchill's war rooms are opposite near to St James' Park.

Such a huge building!. The Houses of Parliament are attached to Big Ben. Easy access from Hop on hop off buses, the tube and river cruises. It is a huge building and unfortunately we were not allowed inside but the view from the outside is just a beautiful!

Interesting architecture from the outside but more interesting from the in. Nice attraction to see as it is free and adjacent to Big Ben, and lots of other attractions nearby. Would not make the trip just for the houses of parliament, but never the less still interesting on some level.
Lovely . This is lovely to go up and see, A nice walk up to it on a nice hot day is lovely would be worth a trip up to go and see

Excellent. We booked a tour of The Houses of Parliament and our tour guide, Norma was excellent and very informative. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit hearing about the history of the building and the workings of Parliament. It is possible to tour independently using an audio guide. However, the guided tour is well worth paying for and you go into some rooms which you wouldn't see on the audio tour. Having said that we were a little disappointed that, following the tour we could not return independently to look more closely at display cases and objects. We hope to return again sometime when we will do the audio tour and view at our pace. There is an on site cafe and gift shop. As would be expected security is very tight on entry so allow time if you have a pre booked tour. The Houses of Parliament are well worth a visit but book in advance especially in Summer or if you have limited time in London.
Lot of history. If don't have much time just go and take a photo outside. Otherwise, go in an visit it. It nice and have lot of history.

Excellent tour. Did the guided tour on Saturday and it was well worth the price, the guide we had was well versed up on his history and had a great way of telling you about the history of the building.The tour lasted 1 hour 30 minutes and you see quite a lot of inside parliament more than I thought we would see, you are not allowed to take photos after you leave Westminster Hall, you certainly have to go through security like at airports at the beginning but was very fast.Merc

Grand buildings. Fabulous grand buildings along the river that are wonderful landmarks in London. Unless you book a tour to go in then you only really get a peak from the outside at the wonderful detail in the architecture. They make a fantastic photo opportunity next to Big Ben!
Beautiful Building. Just viewed from the outside very impressive Did not tour inside not sure if it available depending on when parliament is in session
Fascinating insight. Visited in group arranged by local MP. If you ever get the chance it's an amazing building. History is fascinating, architecture impressive

What a surprise!. A fascinating and gentle look inside somewhere I have only ever complained about.We took the guided tour, booked online and turned up about 20 minutes ahead of time to find that we were to go through full on security checks - on reflection I should not be surprised, but I am glad we were early. We were taken on a 90 minute expertly guided, informative and pleasant tour and had the benefit of seeing more closely, and I believe with more detail, many aspects of the place you simply don't get from a self guided tour. Worth the extra for the tour guide, and if you are in two minds as to its interest then go and be surprised, I certainly enjoyed every minute.

History and current events. I took the audio tour of Parliament and it was very interesting to hear about the history and trials as well as walk though the rooms where laws are made today. The audio guide was great.

Work visit. Stunning. For history lovers and those fascinated by politics a fantastic experience. Had the good fortune to go on a tour with someone with a true passion for the place. Well worth a visit! Great pubs around it!

Smaller than you think..... I was surprised, and dare I say a bit disappointed, by how ordinary these buildings were. From photographs and films, I was expecting something majestic and imposing, but in fact they are smaller and less impressive in reality. Big Ben isn't that big! However it was interesting to see them in the flesh so to speak, and I did take lots of pictures for posterity.
organised visit. Along with fellow travellers, went on organised visit by our local Member of Parliament. A wonderful place packed with History.

Excellent. We opted for the guided tour and found it to be very informative and interesting. Our guide was excellent, very well spoken and easy to listen to. We thoroughly enjoyed the morning and plan on returning. We will probably opt for the headsets next time to get a different perspective. Would definitely remember the guided tour for a first visit.

Fascinating visit. We took the guided tour (£25 per adult and £10 per child). The tour itself was about 1.5 hours long including visiting both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. My children found it interesting and informative. Let down by poorly maintained toilets which doesn't set a good impression for visitors.
Our Heritage. Visited on three occasions and have been stunned by the sheer magnificence of the building. Guided tours are available, something that I must organise for myself.

Brilliant interesting experience, must do!!. We had the guided tour and our guide was so knowledgable and interesting it was great to hear the history. I learnt so much I would happily do it all over again. It's really surreal to be in the rooms and see everything that has so much history behind it, it's made me want to learn so much more about my home country. Couldn't recommend more. From looking around people generally seemed to be enjoying more the guides than just the audio head set.

Beautiful. It's beautiful to see from afar, and you're just drawn to get a better look at it. In your eyesight, there's the Houses, the Square, the Abbey, and Big Ben -- you really can't find a terrible-looking building around.

Worth the visit. Booked this tour at the last minute & it was terrific. I did the audio one because the guided one was all full. I thought the audio one was excellent. I did overhear the guided one go over some other details while walking so I bet that would be good too. Similar to US Capital tour.

Still fun even though they were not in session. We had a great tour guide who explained the history as well as present day actions and politics in Parliament. A tour is a must to really understand and get the full experience.

Palais de Westminster / London. It was about 400 years the Residence of the Kings; constructed in 1065; It's not free to the public; You can see a nice horsesstatue in bronze of Richard Coeur-de-Lion.From Parlement Square you see one part of the Hall of Westminster.

Dining with the Lords.. Ooo Err . If you in or around London in April or May then it's worth prior to your visit checking out the link below.Me my wife and two friends were luck enough to secure 4 reservations (available to the public) for a 3 course fine dining (standard House of Lords fayre) in April 2015.The meal was amazing and we ordered a bottle of white wine to help wash it down, all was subsidised as is the norm in the House restaurants and bars, wine being £17 ...The meal itself was fantastic the architecture and setting mind blowing and all for £35 per person... If you get lucky and see the tickets advertised ... Get some, you won't regret it.You may even get to meet a Lord.... On the next table Keep em peeled - R

Fascinating . This is a very well organised tour. You will visit both houses (commons and Lords) and will be shown the important places in the building. A must for anyone interested in British politics.
Historical Treat. The architecture is beautiful and the building is full of history. You can sense the grandeur and the power that's resides in there. Interesting way to spend an hour or two
The Nations Finest!. It doesn't matter where you view the Houses of Parliament from, they are very impressive and a fitting location for the great British government, best selfie backdrop in London!

Pre plan. To be able to get inside you must have prior permission, but you can look around the grounds freely. Its massive and big ben is right there. You can spend an afternoon visiting many things in this area.

Houses of parliament. Incredibly interesting. It is free when parliament is sitting. You do not get a guide, but you can easily work your way around and read all the information above the various plaques and paintings. Both houses are very impressive, but particularly the house of Lords. The public also have access to a viewing gallery when the debates and prime minister question time are taking place. A 'must' if you are a visitor to London. As a resident in London this must be number one on the to do list.

Amazing to look round . I was totally stunned that you could even look around Parliament, was amazing to see the history and all the staff were amazing apart from one grumpy bald police man, everybody should come see what Parliament looks like, it's truly inspirational.

Impressive and memorable !. Our family's very first view and visit was to this famous London location and iconic site. Combined with Big Ben, it is a great place to appreciate the politics, heritage and history of Great Britain. A visit at night is also recommended.

Whatever your political preferences you can't ignore the history. We visited the Houses of Parliament and House of Commons. They work on timed tours and security is understandably high. Once inside you walk round with your recorded 'walking tour' unless you are on a guided tour. This was very informative and has options to pause and rewind etc. I was surprised at how small both Houses were in reality, but the history that has been made in those buildings made me feel quite star struck. Regardless of political preferences it is well worth a visit.
Just to see from outside. The bus tour passes by. Unless that is very important to you or you really like politics. For me, seeing it from outside was OK.
Great architecture!. I recommend you to make a walk across the bridge and enjoy the view on the beautiful architecture of this parliament.

Very proud. From policemen and women to indoor staff, what delightful, helpful and courteous people.Astounding, as a British citizen, to suddenly find yourself where events and scenes of the greatest national importance have (and continue), taken place.Sat for half an hour in the Commons gallery, listening to debate on NHS and Social Care. Not exactly riveting, but you realise that this is your life, and that of your family and friends, being decided upon. My admiration and respect for our representatives has rocketed as a result of this visit. Came away very proud of my country.Will be going back more than once.P.S. The shop has same chocolate as Westminster Abbey, but cheaper!

Really good visit. We did the Houses of Parliament tour on a Saturday morning and really enjoyed the experience. You enter via the Cromwell Road entrance and go through security. We made the mistake of having a coffee at the Cafe Nero over the road from the Houses of Parliament and it was pretty awful. We then found that they had a really good cafe actually in the Houses of Parliament so avoid the other and just use that one!The tour itself was really good. We chose the audio tour which was good and allowed us to wander around at our own speed taking it all in. The Houses of Parliament are stunning and the decor is amazing. Our highlights were the St Stephens Hall, House of Lords chamber, House of Parliament chamber, royal gallery and Princes chamber which had many great paintings.
Atmospheric. Visited here with the family for a day out, had an excellent time in such a beautiful building with many fascinating features.

Tour of Westminster Palace. We were fortunate to join a tour and were led by a very knowledgeable guide who accompanied us throughout .We were able to visit both Houses which in real life I found quite small .At the conclusion of the tour our guide advised us that if you wanted tickets for PMQs you could join a queue in the chance that persons did not take up their allocation .After 5 mins we were delighted to receive passes to the public gallery , making our visit even more memorable
Had a fantastic tour at a good price. r old son here and had a great time, its very informative and full of history; you can have a guided tour, or hire out headphones and walk yourselves around.
Amazing Houses of Parliament . Take the time to book in for this wonderful tour as we had unprecedented access to all of the areas around the Houses of Lords and Commons.

Tradition and history. Don't miss 100s of years of history in the Mother of all Parliaments. Simply queue up for a guided tour but take a passport to pass security and don't have too many bags. The House of Lords is particularly magnificent.
Definitely worth a visit. Pre-book your tickets to avoid long queues, it's definitely worth a visit as the building is beautiful.

VERY INTERESTING HISTORY LESSON. I found this really interesting, the history to it is amazing and i will be doing it again so i may take in more information to this iconic building. I contacted my MP and arranged a private visit with one of his staff ( due to hime not being there at the time otherwise he would have done the tour) and it cost me nothing
Another great visit. A friend managed to get us a seat in the PMs guest box for his Wednesdays meeting with Parliament. It was a highlight of our visit, especially for Americans visit the UK.
Not Bad. Yes, it is smaller than you think. The House of Commons is tiny, only biggered slightly by the House of Lords.

Obsessed with the architecture!. We were not able to enter the House of Parliament due to a school tour that had the location closed to the public. Big let down but we took full advantage of taking photographs of the building itself. It is a photographers dream! Loved the building and hung around to take pictures for about an hour. Great!!!

Great building the fenc can spoil the view. An iconic building which has to be on the London go and see list.I suggest walking part way across Westminster Bridge to get some of the best viewsAlso go back at night

Breathtaking. If you enjoy historical buildings, this collection of buildings is breathtaking. The design and character of the building is so impressive that many will be mesmerized and stand in awe admiring the majesty of the building. A must-see when you are in London.

A piece of history. It's been an exciting visit.Walls are full of history, you can smell it in the air visiting the main hall, the house of Commons and the house of Lords. The architecture, the past and the present, even if you don't like history you'll feel the magic of this place.The audio guide tour is a very good choice, you can take your time exploring and listening to all the information about this place.This is the first place I recommend to visit in the city!

Worth a visit..... Having been in London for 30 years we finally made it to the HoP. If your interested in history, architecture and politics then it's worth a morning of your time.Fab to go into the chambers where our country is governed from.
Great history & architecture . This is a iconic building surrounded by history the architecture is amazing the tours are expensive but it's part of history

Go for the guided tour. This was a real eye opener. As someone who has only seen the two houses on tv it was something of a surprise to find that the building is actually the Palace of Westminster and is jam packed full of history, art and some great tales of times gone by. We had Harry as our guide and he was terrific - he knew all the historical facts up to the modern day. He also gave us a lot of information about the political process some of which I didn't know. Add to that a nice sense of humour and it was 90 minutes of enjoyment. A great experience.
Great tour.. Did the guided tour. Our guide was superb, making it even more interesting and entertaining than it would have otherwise been.

Great visit. It is a little expensive (as everything in London), but absolutely worth it. The visit is nice and you visit lots of historic chambers of the Houses of Parliament. The audioguide takes you through the history of the Uk and you get to see amazing places and objects. I loved it.

Behind the scenes . Wanted to revisit the Houses of Parliament as not been since a school trip! The views and interiors are Britain at its best ! Steeped in history you can feel the walks of power in the corridors. Entrance to the House of Commons and lords is a privilege. Our history is something to be proud of! It is beautifully maintained and recommend the audio tour - so full of background information. A great visit for all ages! Only recommendation would be larger gift shop - seemed cramped and would deter some from buying gifts.
Well worth a visit. If you are interested in politics, history and England etc then this is the place to visit! Guided tours take you behind the scenes with stories about politicians past and present
just like moviez !!. i enjoyed the site through the bridge across the river , had lots of photos , very close to London aquarium and eye , must visit

Guided tour, chock full of facts and info. We chose a 2-hour guided tour (rather than the self-guided audio tour), and it was a great option. Our guide was a fully licensed Blue Badge London tour guide who was one of the most knowledgeable and professional guides we've ever had. Liz took us into rooms that were used only one day each year; rooms where the Queen herself is not allowed access; and rooms we had only seen on the telly -- all with an interesting, full explanation. The group was small (24 people, perhaps) so there was no problem hearing or following what was being said. Probably not of much interest to younger children, but the adults were awestruck and loved every minute. Highly recommended.

Go inside the House of Commons and House of Lords. Learn first hand about British Parliament. Highly recommended tour. Be sure to book your tickets ahead online and pick them up at the ticket office. Take the guided tour for more in-depth details and access to certain spots that are not available to those on the self-guided tour.

Tour of Premises and dining!. Wonderful place to drink and dine in a most convivial setting. We had arranged a tour which is a walk through British history for us all -and then a delicious mel in one of the several cafes in the House

Very impressive. From the moment you enter security to the time you leave, the whole experience was very impressive. The guide was extremely knowledgable. Standing in the house of commons and House of Lords was a surreal experience. The periphery areas also very impressive. Interesting for adults and children alike. Great, simple cafe too.

Houses of Parliament Tour. excellent tour. i would highly recommend this. Our guide was very knowledgeable. we did not feel rushed but we would go back and do an audio tour so that we can stop more often.
It made me feel proud to be a Brit and acknowledge our 1000 year history of politics.

A definite "Must Do" attraction. Booked an audio tour online 5 days earlier. Arrived 30 minutes early, and had no problems getting in early.The audio tour is with headset and 'walkman style' audio device. You press the number on the device when you get to certain parts of the building. This means you can go at your own pace, and repeat certain parts if you want to.You visit all the main areas including both the House of Lords and House of Parliament.Tour took us around 1 hour 15 minutes in all. Well worth the money and would recommend.
Gothis!. We didn't go in and just see from outside. The architecture is awesome. Absolutely love the gothic feeel to it.

Beautiful . 10/10 would recommend. Totally worth your money. Absolutely beautiful, and the history is so interesting, so rich. You get an insight into modern parliamentary procedures too. I've been to parliament houses in Singapore, Australia, South Korea, and without the mindblowing art and architecture and history, they're all so boring compared to this one.We did an audio tour - gave us all the information we needed and we could go at our own pace. The tour groups are pretty big so I'd probably miss a lot of what the guide says if I were to join one of them. Whole thing took about 1.5 hours for us, and we took our time admiring, soaking everything in.
Quick stop at night. We stopped at night and it was fabulous to see everything lit up. Since it was December there were still Christmas lights up.
Iconic known globally . Its a structure so much associated with UK and most recognisable worldwide so it feels great when you see such places in real as a traveler
So much history. We did the guided tour - highly recommend - get to go to places & learn so much about the British parliament

London's Iconic Landmark. The Eiffel Tower is to Paris and the Colosseum is to Rome, what the House of Parliaments and Big Ben is to London. The poster-child of this city is obviously a must-see for all visitors here. Tours cost 25 pounds ($38), takes about 75 minutes, and can be taken only when the Parliament is in recess during the summer. Best views for photos is across the river, so stroll across the bridge for a good pic. To get here, the nearest metro (tube) station is Westminster on the yellow, green, or gray line. If you plan on using public transportation more than twice per day, buy an Oyster Card (not a Visitor Oyster Card) for 5 pounds, then add 6.40 pounds per day since this is the daily cap for unlimited public transit use in Zones 1-2 (these zones encompass almost all tourist sights like Big Ben, Buckingham, Kensington, London Eye, etc). The 5 pound deposit is refundable if you go to a counter at any tube station before returning home (otherwise you'll have to request a refund by mail).

A must . I took guided tour to the Parliament it was very nice (and its available in many different languages) I suggest to take it after visiting Westminster Abbey where the history of the parliament started

Democracy In Action!!. Both my Wife and I decided to visit the Houses Of Parliament on our recent trip to London and we are sure glad we did!We decided to pre book our tickets in advance and it will save you time on the day of your visit as you are ushered straight into the security queue. For preparation, security is exactly the same as if you are at an airport!! The staff work hard and will get you through as soon as they can.We undertook the self guided audio tour. This was an excellent tour which started in the main hall and slowly guided you through the building passing through all the essential parts of this magnificent structure. There is too much information to describe everything, but our personal favourite was the House Of Commons!! This part of the building is where you get to realise that this is where everything that effects us as UK citizens starts in this part of the Palace Of Westminster. This was a fantastic part of the tour which throughout all the history of the building, this gives you a sense of the here and now! The next time we see it on the TV, we will see it from a different light that's for sure.From start to finish you get an understanding of politics and how processes work and how democracy started here in the UK many moons ago. A slow amble round taking in all the information will take around 2-3 hours. There is also a shop and cafe if you wish to use them and another well stocked shop on the corner opposite Big Ben.My belief is that every UK citizen if they get the chance should undertake a visit to the Palace Of Westminster! It is an absolute fascinating place and any visitor that comes to London, their monies would be well spent visiting a major part of British history and to which is still making history today........................

The mother of Parliaments. We visited just from the outside and spent a bit of time in the park beside. Despite the much needed security barriers etc the building remains an iconic Victorian masterpiece. Nice to be there on the hour in order to hear the well known chimes from Big Ben. Had we had more time I would want to see the interior and may do this on a subsequent visit.

Can't stop looking at it. Looked at it and took so many photos of it! Stunning! Can't believe they still hold office in a place this old and grand. The Big Ben is a stunner especially at night. Will definitely find myself back here, taking more photos of this grand structure!

W O W what a place. Had the privilege of being invited to visit the place. What a great experience. Tells you such a lot about the history revolving around Britain. Its a must for visitors if they really wish to know London better.
Excellent audio tour. . Spent a really enjoyable couple of hours here. The audio tour was perfect for a good level of info with options for more if wanted. Highly recommended
Great photo opportunity.... Liked the history and open rooms here, books, carpet, stories and wandering around. Would love to have been able to get through to the chambers!

London attraction must see. We went there on our trip to London and it is huge,y impressive, and would recommend this site. When we went there it was very busy and be careful not to get knocked around

Worthwhile Tour. The tour is well done and only offered on days when Parliament is not sitting. Not surprisingly, you enter through a security check similar to that at airports. The House of Lords is ornate and beautiful; the House of Commons much plainer. The most interesting part of the tour is information on the workings of Parliament...eg, how one becomes a Lord, how the House of Commons is a debate chamber, etc.
Worth a visit! . Featured on BBC parliament! Who can argue with that? fantastic place with lots of history, worth having a look at any time of the day!

WOW. I had the opportunity to visit the Houses of Parliament.
If the outside of it is incredible, the inside is just wow.
Every single penny spent on the ticket worth the beauty of the place.
The guide made the tour even more exciting giving lots of curiosity.
Great day.
Highly recommended.
great to say you have been. we were here only for a weekend so not long enough to enjoy it fully but great to see the size and architecture and big ben well worth going

Down on the Floor of the Great Houses of Parliament. Parliament is not in session on Saturdays. This is a perfect time for a tour of both Houses. It was exciting to learn more about the English form of government and to actually be down in the rooms where great political debates take place!

Great tour. We opted for the guided tour and I am glad that we did. Val was very knowledgeable and obviously loves what she does. Why wouldn't you? The tour is about 70 minutes long and went by very quickly. As you can't take photographs I would recommend the guide book for £5.

Watched proceedings in the House of Commons for over 2 hours. Called in to visit the public gallery during a birthday treat visit to London for my wife. She was so fascinated by the proceedings in the commons that we stayed for over three hours. The icing on the cake (literally) was that the café offered reasonable quality sandwiches, cakes and hot drinks at affordable prices.
Interesting. We pre booked a tour for a Saturday before Christmas. Despite having lived in London for many years we had never got round to going to the Houses of Parliament. Good to do.

Guided Tour. Booked a guided tour with the wonderful Sheila. Went around all of the Houses of Lords and of Commons, also went into some backstage areas not open to the general self-guided public. This was a very educative and enjoyable tour made all the better by our wonderful tour guide.

More history than information about the day to day operations. This tour wasn't what I expected - but then I also did not realize how much historical items and portraits were to be viewable on the tour. Our group toured on a Saturday. It would be more interesting to see things during a working day, I imagine. This is not a tour if you have difficulty standing for long periods of time. The walking is fine.... the standing, not so much

A wealth of history . I was lucky enough to be offered a tour following a meeting in the houses. What a wealth of history, the statues, paintings and the building. If you can visit I would highly recommend it

Must see in London. Remember, remember the 5th of November! You cannot be in London and not see the Houses of Parliament. It's historically interesting but also the view is so nice at night. It's a lovely walk round the area and you'll find little crowded pubs that are very nice for a few drinks and a couple of good laughs. Nice during weekdays too!

Architecture and history in abundance. It's winter now and gets dark around 4.30pm - try going around this time as it looks amazing when lit up. We then headed to the Thames where the views are even more breathtaking at night then I remember in the daytime.

More history that I realised... Took the opportunity for a tour. Was expecting the history of the chambers bit. Didn't click about the rest of the history from the court - William Wallace / Guy Fawkes / Laying in State..

Find out how MP's operate. Make use of the warm welcome of the police and security at the gates as the main entrance hall at this time of year is quite cold. Yes, you will have to endure a 'Heathrow' type security check for obvious reasons. Once you get going you can make up your own mind as to what they do. Very interesting

School party visit - recommended. Although not always easy to get a booking, I'd recommend persevering to get the opportunity to visit. A real piece of living history and always good to compare the place to how it appears on TV. You can see both houses in action. Ed centre workshops are great too!

Incredible Tour !. Just booked a Tor over ther website an is has been an incredible experience ! you will the both houses and the corresponding corridors, get an extensivie explanationa nd get some understanding on how this thing works ! very interesting, go there !!!

Not visited....You can't be serious!. We booked a guided tour [party of 4] and it was money well spent. Although a couple of the party had visited before, all enjoyed it immensely. The tour guide was excellent, setting a fast pace while imparting her profound knowledge with wit and enthusiasm. The only blip on an otherwise superb afternoon was the afternoon tea. if I said the best bit of this was the opportunity to walk some of the back corridors and peek into 1/2 rooms not on our tour, you will get the drift. So although I can say I drank tea in HoP I wish I had saved my money for the Berkeley or similar. If you haven't yet visited this is a must in London............go now!
Beautiful Structure. We did do the tour of the inside, but just seeing the outside for a few minutes and snapping a few photos lets you appreciate the awesome architecture of this building. Must Do!
Day Trip. My son was visiting form USA and I wanted to show him a bit of London history. This helped him understand the history of the city.

Day out with friends. Have always wanted to see inside and I wasnt disappointed. Seeing all the ornate rooms and where the Lords sit in the house statues of past prime ministers and where the present prime minister host question time. It is almost like going back in time you realise all the decisions that are made for the country in this one place. We had a hand held machine giving us all the information of what room we were in and any paintings on the walls and it was very easy to follow and very informative. I enjoyed it immensely and was very glad we decided to go.

Tour of Parliament. I have been to London many times but had never toured Parliament. Very glad we were able to fit it in. Our guide, Owen, was very helpful and knowledgeable. The tour was interesting and helped me, as an American, understand the British form of government a little better.

Best thing we did in London...... On the Parliament website you can book a private tour, well worth it. We learned so much more then had we just wandered through on our own. Also on the website the offer a tea service after your tour for an additional fee. I understand that's worth it if you love a good tea. It was not available the day we went, darn. How many people can say they had a private tea in Parliment. The private tour allows you side door, skip the line access as well.

Book your tour via your local MP, free of charge. We booked a tour via our local MP which is free and one of their staff shows you round both Houses, max 6 people in the group but you see things you will not see on a public tour. You can also request a seat at Prime Ministers question time from you MP, again free and well worth the visit. Not always possible to do both in one visit.

A walk through English history. The first thing I noticed is the security staff is the best dressed in the world (seriously - wearing black tie and coat tails), the second is they're ever so polite and helpful. One of the staff took the time to explain how the building was a Grade I listed building. Catering in the restaurant was amazing (I had a curry stew - everyone I spoke to was impressed) and because the building in Grade I you can just imagine MPs of today and yesteryear dining in the same room. The corridors are lined with statues and works of art as a tribute to past contributors to English history. Highlights include Black Rod's ceremonial robes. One slight disappointment was a couple of patches of the floor was being renovated (as you would expect from such and old building with such heavy use)...that said one of the members of security shows me a recently renovated patch as comparison and it was clear the money was well spent.If you get the opportunity to visit the private gardens do so - despite being in Parliament Square, it is a place of peace and calm. I could barely hear the traffic. As I left the Houses of Parliament I felt so privileged.

Take a Tour of the "Palace" Houses of Parliament. Went through by where luck with someone who worked there., after 40 years o f going to London had no idea that you could go on a tour. I would highly recommend to use one of the tour companies that you see outside the station. Its truly amazing and humbling as so much history has occurred here. I'll be going back again for another visit next time London is on the schedule.

Curious Brit!. I booked this tour for a group of friends. I was awfully excited like a little kid. I was not disappointed, thanks goes to my MP Gavin B for being such a good tour guide. Full of opulence and tremendous history. Received a thorough insight into how it all works in there. If you get an opportunity to do this tour, do it!

Good place to visit but not for all. The Houses of Parliament is a good place to visit however it is more for people who want to know the history or are genuinely interested in it.If you are looking at the Houses of Parliament just as a place to visit, rather save your money and time, YouTube it.It's more for people with a real interest.

Fascinating Place to Visit!. We had a wonderful tour of Parliament! It was fascinating to see the Parliament building and learn about all the history that has taken place there. Our tour guide was great! So informative and a wonderful story teller!
great!. one of the best things in london. go there and enjoy it, you won't regret it! make it one of your must-visit places. trust me
MOTHER OF PARLIAMENTS. You must visit and have a guided tour.The place is amazing .The building is marvellous. Its full of history. Worth the visit.
MOTHER OF PARLIAMENTS. You must visit and have a guided tour.The place is amazing .The building is marvellous. Its full of history. Worth the visit.

The houses of parliament tour is great!. One of the most iconic buildings in the world! Beautiful at night!
If you're an UK resident, you can sign up to the houses of parliament tour by contacting your MP. Our MP gave us a lively tour and it was interesting to learn about the origin of some political phrases. Highly recommend the tour!

Fun, informative and fascinating. A self guided audio tour that takes you across the floor of the House of Commons and House of Lords. The audio guide is extremely informative and fascinating.
Highly recommended!

Beautiful view; amazing photos. From the river Thames or from its banks, one can take some amazing photographs whether it is a sunny day or a rainy one. If you find the building amazing, just take a close look to its walls. It is all in the details! I bet you will find them amazing and interesting!

Democracy at its finest. Try to sit in on a debate...riviting. The traditions of Parliament exemplify civilized debate, and are very worth observing and hearing. A little pageantry comes for free as well. Stroll afterwarda along the Thames river bank, kisten tom the chimes of Big Ben, and tour Westminster Abbey,
Funny in the Underhouse.. Funny and strange for a scandinaven. Debating and jumping up and down. Good for english listening. Go for it !
The View. We did not tour the Houses, but walked around the gardens/court viewing the statues of Britain's historical leaders. The Churchill statue fixes the eye quite quickly.

Enjoyable tour!. A booking is essential to take this unique tour. It lasts about 90 minutes and you get a nice view of the history of British government as well as the related traditions. It's a little pricey but was worth doing.
brilliant. a brilliant tour and so enlightening ,great to see and much better than i thought it would be.The guide was so knowledgeable,really worth doing

Educational and entertaining. We took the guided tour as opposed to the audio guided tour, with Mark Conroy as tour guide. Wasn't cheap, but thoroughly entertaining and educational - even for someone who doesn't 'do' history or politics. Tour was around 90mins long and worth every penny. Utterly brilliant afternoon. (Booked ahead of time on their website)

Wonderful. My family really enjoyed the guided tour. We were taken through each room at a leisurely pace and the guide was wonderful. There was an exhibition of the Magna Carta while we were there and that was kind of interesting.We didn't originally plan to spend our day in the House of Parliament, but we had a great time and would do it again in a heart beat!

the heart of england. you can see this from park plaza hotel, its a must if you go to london and if you get the chance go inside or even during prime ministers question time on a wednesday, very interesting exercise

This is a grand government building rich in history and architecture. Start off your tour in a cavernous structure where tour guides begin their history lesson as they lead you up stairs to the main floor and entry into the majestic rooms and meeting halls where Great Brittan's politicians gather. Ornate windows, walls, furniture and ceilings are priceless beyond compare. Statues and busts of important historical figures adorn hallways. You will see the House of Lords and the House of Commons plus Royal greeting and waiting rooms. There is handicap access and I noticed stairs only at the beginning and end of the tour in the great hall. Ask about any special services when you make your reservations. Reservations should be made by anyone wanting to visit as group tour space is limited. You cannot wander around by yourselves and are herded around as the tour guide keeps careful count of the group for security purposes.

Very interesting. We've been 3 times. Twice in a private visit and once for a dinner and tour. It is incredible to see the history here and walk in the footsteps of the famous kings, queues, Lords, ladies and politicians. I'd always say go if you get the chance.

Free. Houses of Parliament, really nice building probably one of the finest in London, really interesting history but mainly just a house for the elite, good for a visit walking past but really no fun

Great couple of hours. Go and do this! It's so interesting and is well laid out. Get access to all the Chambers and has a helpful audio guide to assist you. Sadly was not able to stage a revolution and take power myself,perhaps next time

As a solicitor , it's a must go destination. As a Law student it was an unbelievable experience to see ''the real'' action and how the decisions are been made. Total sick how it's in there with the security.
Great history which is still in progress. Apart from great architecture, it's a good opportunity to be in the heart of political debates of an important country.

Picturesque Parliment. We could Only view outside as The General Election was taking place. What a Beautiful Building. With Big Ben as its crowning glory. Its close to the South Bank with the London Eye near by. The river cruises also start here. If nothing else its worth a Photograph!

Wonderful history and great guide. Guide was great on the tour. Having done it since the 1970's, she had great background and detail. Wonderful history and great architecture, paintings etc on display throughout. Well worth the trip

Mother of Parliaments. Notwithstanding the slightly cynical view of politics that most of us have there is no getting away from the fact that, to paraphrase Churchill, our democratic process is the best of all. The Palace of Westminster is an amazing and absolutely beautiful building and even the most cynical will be hard pressed not to find its history compelling. Absolutely stunning setting for the two houses (Commons and Lords). The scene of so much that has influenced Britain and the World. Even in these waning years of global influence this British institution demands respect. Our tour was brilliant and the guide was so knowledgeable. She looked like she was a teacher that had stepped right out of a 1950s Belles of St. Trinians movie! kept group discipline and really she knew her stuff. It was tremendous to actually be in both the Commons and Lords (can't sit) and experience the atmosphere. Many years ago I had the opportunity to sit in on both houses but to be actually 'on the floor' was powerful.If you have a couple of hours, take the tour. It will reinvigorate your democratic demeanor. I don't think that it will sit too well with children, say under 14. I was a little disappointed that photography was strictly limited.

Historical. If your visiting London for the first time there's nothing better to get a sense of England than visiting the home of its political process. We took the audio tour and it was well worth the extra price.
Beautiful. A gracious and stately building. Quite overshadowed by the other magnificent buildings in London. Don't miss this one though.

Government at work . The edifice is simply beautiful but understand that there is still plenty of function behind those wonderful doors. Laws of England are made here everyday that impact citizens of the beautiful country. On our visit, a group of protestors were standing outside opposing some changes to housing being discussed behind those imposing walls. This isn't MERELY history: people in this building MAKE history for the citizens they represent. A must see on any trip and pick up a local newspaper while you are in town. There will always be an article on something happening in Parliament.

Interesting tour. Having seen it from the outside so many times I finally decided to book a tour and visit the inside.The self guided audio-tour is good. I got to learn more about the building's history and how it functions when the parliament is at work.Although, depending on time and budget, I wouldn't consider it a must visit attraction.

Walking into in a living working historic monument. One of the most famous buildings in the world, known as the "mother of parliaments", and the beauty of its neo-gothic scale and detail by Barry and Pugin is simply breath-taking, what is equally impressive is that this is no dusty museum piece but a living and working hub of democratic government. Westminster Hall is a deeply evocative space not only because if its grandeur, but the historic atmosphere is almost tangible, the place of trials of Kings and traitors of martyrs and nobles, the audience chamber where Popes and Presidents have given addresses and where Kings Queen's and Statesmen have laid before burial. The House of Commons Chamber surprises by its intimacy but if you gain admittance during such as Prime minister's question time the atmosphere is electric, while the splendour of the House of Lords is truly regal, during a working day visits are limited but the buzz of MP's meeting constituents and frock-coated stewards bringing messages all gives a sense of living history

A highlight. I spent a lot of time visiting here. I sat in on a debate and had an interesting conversation with the guard on security who held phones etc afterwards. Amazing statues of former leaders. A great place to reflect on history
Love the look of this building. Lovely piece of history and lovely views down the river. It's right next to Big Ben. Take the tour it's well worth it would highly recommend it.

Beautiful House of Parliament. Never tire of seeing this place of interests. It remains majestic regardless of the surrounding, the politics, rain or shine. The pedestrian crossing constantly amazes me; the young & old, the different peoples & languages being spoken on the streets. The debates within may be controversial, but the architecture and its beauty always remains stunning. Here are photos taken of its exterior on a wet day with overcast

parliment. I Did not find it awfully exciting took the children for a education trip as they were working on a project for school. If you don't mind walking around looking at walls which appeared quite dull for me.on a brighter side very good place to take your children so they can understand were the governments place of work is.

Get the audio guide. this is a new attraction only available when parliament is not sitting. Fascinating, but you do need the audio guide to enjoy it properly.
Tip - book early as places are limited.

Open each Saturday for a visit to Parliament.. We caught the tube to Westminister and Parliament House is opposite the station, however you need to turn left when you alight the station and go around th corner to the ticket office to buy tickets and a guide book (extra £5) You can either join a tour or get an audio tour; we chose the audio tour so we could go at our own pace. We went on a Saturday. After passing through security, the House of Lords and Commons are both accessible to the public, but not, it appears, Big Ben, however you can take uninterrupted photos of Big Ben from the entrance to the Parliament. The audio tour was informative and gives you a glimpse of the history of the Parliament. Worth a visit which takes around an hour.

Great Visit. When my father first suggested this tour i was a bit hesitant to say the least but we went along.it was worth the money and very interesting and glad i went along.The tour is fun and very informative and was great to see inside the rooms and be shown round by a enthuisatic guide.
Take the Tour. Get tix early and be prepared for airport style security, but the tour is so worth it. We learned so much and would highly recommend it!

Time well spent. We included this on a recent visit although it was not on our original list of sites to see. We were glad we did and found it to be a good use of our somewhat limited time. The history and the insight that one gains is well worth the time, and relatively expensive entrance fees (compared to V&A and several other attractions that are free).

Working Hard. Most fascinating part of our trip was to visit the Houses of Parliament.It was free to go in but well worth the visit.The Great Hall and the history was remarkable.We waited a little while before we could go into the House of Lords but it was so interesting to see the debate in the House.Some of the old dears were asleep through it all but by and large it was a great experience to observe live what we had only seen on the tv.The sense of history was wonderful ,such a unique time and place in history.
beautiful architecture. Striking how large the building is and sits right on edge of Thames. It is lit beautifully at night next to Big Ben bell tower. A must see.

An iconic landmark always worth seeing day and night!. Hearing Big Ben and then walk past the House of Parliament is a 'must do' while in London. At night the buildings are lit and cast a yellowish hue to the skyline and Thames. By day, the gothic architecture and clock tower gongs are legendary.

Beautiful. I loved Parliament. I didn't go in but from the outside and seeing while on the Eye, it was just amazing. Architecture is out of this world and so impressive. I would certainly like to go into the building but didn't have the time nor the patience for the crowds.

Beautiful and interesting place . The audio guide program is excellent. The security guards are actually very helpful and can provide even more information to the visitors, especially from their own perspectives.
Quite impressive architecture. We just strolled around so to get some pictures and there is a lot to see and do nearby such as the abbey and London Eye. The tube station is right next to it.

Fabulous visit. We took a guided tour with four children including one under 4. We loved it - fabulous guide with knowledge and also wry humour and good access to both Houses of Parliament and the royal rooms. If anything was changed it would be good to have a but more about modern British politics and a little less royal history, given that many visitors will also go to the Abbey or the other royal palaces.

Family visit. Fab time. . We really enjoyed visiting here. Security is tight. We went in as a group arranged via a mp. We had our own guide who was lovely and very knowledgeable. It was a great experience to see both the house of commons and the House of Lords The visit gave us lots of history and engaged both our teen and our younger child. We took food to eat in the hall afterwards there was a restaurant but it was extremely busy. Toilets were in good condition. We felt very privileged to be able to visit here. Would definitely visit again in a few years time.
Sensory History Heaven. Didn't bargain for the fabulous architecture and art work along with the incredible ambience that within this building lives have changed across the country

On hidden pearl in London. Every time I have been in London I have walked past Big Ben. But it was´t until now that I actually did a tour in the Parliament. We hade a guided tour and I really recommend it! The guide was brilliant and ti was very interesting!

Interesting and Beautiful Buildings. Didn't get a chance to visit inside but certainly enjoyed the wonderfulu history and architecture. A really amazing place to wander around and enjoy the old history that such a landmark offers.

The Heart of Democracy: Where It All Began. Visited the Houses of Parliament on a beautiful summer's day in early August. The Westminster Hall (nearly 1000 years old) was the first stop on the tour before being allowed to wander further and further into the ornate hallways and chambers of intricately carved Seraphs, Bishops, Kings, Queens and Noblemen/women. Learning about the process of democracy from the time of William the Conqueror to David Cameron will not disappoint any cultured and insightful traveller. I would highly recommend booking the Afternoon Tea Special at the Terrace Pavilion to conclude your tour - the view of the Thames, the London Eye and Westminster Bridge is perfect on a clear summer's day from this Pavilion on the side of the Palace of Westminster!

Fascinating walk through British history!. The guided tour of the Houses of Parliament was strongly recommended by a friend, and it did not disappoint. The building is stunning. Most of it went up in the 1840s, and it is all very ornate and beautiful. It certainly succeeds in reminding one of the power of the British Empire. Just about all that remains of the original Palace of Westminster is Westminster Hall, which hails from the twelfth century. It's one of those places that makes me feel very keenly the presence of the innumerable figures from British history who walked its floors.
