Our tourguide was very knowledgeable about both the physical building and the business of Parliament. As we have found in many historic British attractions, there was also a very good food service in the lower level, offering a variety of sandwiches, sweets and drinks. This was a really fascinating 90 minutes, and I strongly recommend a visit.

Really interesting. We took the audio tour, which took us through all the main parts including the highlights of the House of Lords and Commons debating chambers, which you are able to wander around at your leisure. The audio description was extensive and interesting even to 15 year olds!
Iconic London. A must when in London. You van do a self guided walking tour a see all the must sees in a day. Very special.
GREAT TOUR. This is an Amazing tour! Note: you have to get your ticket to the tour across from Big Ben, and this tour is only available during the weekend

In the footsteps of so many historic figures. For UK residents, free guided tours of the Houses of Parliament, or to be more precise, the Palace of Westminster can be arranged in advance through your local M.P. or a member of the House of Lords. Not knowing who many of the Lords and Ladies are who sit in the House of Lords, we applied to our local M.P. Within a few days we received a reply confirming the date and time that we could do the tour. Non-UK residents can apply to do a similar tour for a fee and can apply for tickets online. As one might expect with a place like this, there were some security checks to go through upon arrival for the tour, akin to airport security. We were then allowed in to Westminster Hall, the oldest part of the Palace of Westminster. When it was time to begin the tour, our guide introduced herself and welcomed our group of about 25. There were a small number of rules to follow, but nothing too onerous: keep up with your guide, don't dilly-dally and most importantly, don't sit down in the Chamber of the House of Commons or the House of Lords! Only members of the Commons or Lords are allowed to take a seat in the relevant Chamber. Photographs can be taken "... for personal, non-commercial purposes" in Westminster Hall, St Stephen's Hall and New Palace Yard but not in other areas within the palace boundaries. After all, this is an important working environment. The guided part of the tour lasted about 90 minutes and ended back at Westminster Hall. We then had a look round the gift shop and had a bite to eat in the adjacent Jubilee Cafe. Given the long march of history at this location, it is an honour to follow in the footsteps of so many historic figures, and not just English or British ones. For example, there are brass plaques on the steps of Westminster Hall marking the place where some of the great figures of history have stood, such as King Charles I, Queen Elizabeth II and President Nelson Mandela. What were the highlights of the tour? Firstly, there was a close-up view of one of the finest examples of the 19th Century 'Gothic revival', the vision of Charles Barry and Augustus Welby Northmore Pugin. Secondly, there is the privilege of standing in a place that has played an important part in history and the democratic tradition. Thirdly, after visiting the Palace of Westminster, I felt I had a better understanding of how the Queen's Government works. After the visit of the Houses of Parliament there was the added bonus of a free tour on the same day of the nearby 'Jewel Tower'. All told, it had been a memorable day steeped in English and British history.

WELL ORGANISED, INTERESTING AND VERY INFORMATIVE TOUR GUIDE. this was one of a few london attractions we booked whilst on a short stay. we were very impressed with the professional tour guide - she was extremely well informed and made the whole tour very enjoyable and informative. good value for money and would highly recommend.

What a building. We didn't get inside the building but enjoyed the fine architecture from Westminster Abbey side and on the other side of the river. The best spot to admire the whole building is from the London Eye.

Well worth a visit. and far more interesting than we thought it would be. The only draw back is that you are on a timed visit and you are not allowed to dawdle at any point. My husband tried to study a couple of pictures on route and he was soon moved on.
Splendid in the eveninglights. Beatiful view from the bridge over the river Thames or even better from the London Eye or cruise :). Easily reachable by bus (cheaper than subway).
Gigantic building with Gothic look. Really magnificient building with gothic and medieval style. You can see it from far away but worth getting closeup
Inspiring and Beautiful. One of the site which you get to see when you are on hop on and hop off tour bus. The building is amazing
Must see place. Very attractive place in view of architectural design of that time. Scenic view besides the river makes it more attractive.

Beautiful and educational. We booked the audio tour and so we were able to go at our own pace. We enjoyed the history of the buildings and the enthusiasm and helpfulness if the staff. There is a lot to see but we were done in an hour and felt like we learned and saw a lot. The only downside is that you can only take pictures in the first two rooms.

Family Tour. Booked a tour for our family of four. Arrived early and were able to join the earlier tour. Lots of people, but well organized. Security is through.
Our guide was informative, cleaver and engaging.
Lots is history to hear about--time well spent.

Beautiful and inspiring. This building is amazing. The way the staircases wind throughout the whole structure - creating maze after maze with every wall and landing decorated with historical busts of previous Prime Ministers and paintings of various Lord this or Duke that. The feel of it is best described as - more Hogwarts than Hogwarts itself. I half expected Wormtail to scurry past my feet at any given point but luckily this did not happen.The traditions that have existed within the walls that wrap around the outside of the Houses of Parliament have been there for many hundreds of years and although parts of the building does look slightly haggard; I believe this dated and dilapidated look alongside the seasoned traditions adds to the charm and character of the place.The fact that the plumbing is so dated and slightly dysfunctional also probably is quite apt as I imagine some of the regular visitors mirror the problems with the plumbing and the building in their own decrepit bodies. Bless them though as they still go in and scream "hear hear". Not because they are agreeing with something mind you but because they probably want to let every one there know that they have indeed been able to make the journey from their second home successfully and are indeed present.

Nice Place to visit!!. Nice and beautiful place around river Thames. Its very easily accessible through underground train and get exit at Westminster station. You can see Big Ben, London eye just near to the Westminster parliament houses. Nice area to walk around.

Fabulous and educational. Loved this tour! Great audio program really helps people understand the history and importance You have to go through security to get in, so get rid of water bottles, but there is a nice cafe right inside.
Visit. excellent tour taken of this fine building with a tour rep included plus seeing the History of the best prime minsters we ever hadMaggie and Winston.

History, History and History.... Westminster is so full of history and to be at the heart of the U.K. government is an experience. You have to include the time it takes to get through security when you visit but inside there is a modern cafe and some great tours. If you want to go up the Elizabeth Tower to Big Ben write to your MP to arrange a visit...
Imponent building (outside perspective). Very beautiful and imponet next to the Thames and to Big Ben. Nice area to walk around and visit important monuments

An interesting visit. Although, there was a bit of waiting around and confusion about who was on which tour, our guide was charismatic and informative. Well worth a visit to see how Parliament works and understand the various traditions and etiquette.

Interesting Tour of the Parliament. Beautiful building inside and out. Photos are not allowed which was disappointing. Tour guide was informative but that's about it. Glad we were able to see where the politicians of the UK seat, discuss and argue various matters.

Wonderful!. -The visit was great! We recommend to take the guided tour or the audio one. There's so much to see and learn! It's full of history -We booked our tour a few days in advance. All online. It's easy. -There's a coffee shop inside and also a shop, also toilets. -It is not allowed to take pictures inside the building -Be ready for a security check as done in airports

Worth going in. Been into both chambers and worth it
Very small and worth a look
Nice area around there as well and very touristy
Worth a shirt wait but would queue for hours

Amazing place.. Didn't expect to enjoy visiting the HoP as much as I did. The history of Britain laid out before you, all in one place. Probably one of the best public buildings I have ever visited, including all the Royal Palaces. The audio tour was excellent and allows you to stroll round at your own pace, re-visiting particular areas of interest if you wish. Just a pity that photography is not permitted in either chamber and the lobbies.Added bonus was having afternoon tea in the Terrace restaurant, overlooking the Thames, after the tour. Not quite up to the overall standard of The Savoy, but perfectly adequate for the price.

Excellent piece of history in a super location. My partner and I managed to get booked onto a tour by our local MP. The venue is absurdly amazing and beautiful. The guides who volunteer know everything there is to know about the great hall, House of Commons and House of Lords. It's a very enjoyable tour which lasts around two hours. There's a lot of walking but you don't really notice it as there so much to do and see. We were even shown around the Queens robing room where I proposed (The answer was yes thankfully). There's a great gift shop where you can buy items with the House of Lords & House of Commons creat in which looks great. The restaurant is very nice although the menu is basic. There's no phone reception there either. All in all a great day out and highly recommended, email your MP now.

Plan and Book Early. The Houses of Parliament are open to tour only by obtaining tickets in advance, on days when tours are offered. Not quite like the US Congress - one can't just walk in. The effort is worthwhile. The walking tour is led by a highly knowledgeable guide, and visits a fine selection of locations in both the Lords and Commons. Standing on the floor of both Houses - please, no sitting down! - is a truly remarkable experience.
House of Parliment. Great experience and would recommmend to anyone in the London area. Lovely background for pictures. Careful of the people on the bridge. Dont accept anything from them.

Was there for evening dinner and reception. Absolutely amazing reinforces that no other country in the world can compete with the pageantry and splendour of the Palace of Westminster. The staff were great and the food was in the words of the late great Michael Winer "Historic" well done o you all

Do the 90 minute guided tour. What an amazing experience. Follow in the footsteps of the Queen on the day she opens parliament. Learn about the history of the British Parliament - the Monarchy, the Lords and the Commons and visit the debating chambers. The tour grants you access to areas you would not normally be able to access and the guides stories bring the place to life. We went when Parliament was in recess which allows greater access to part of the building. Be warned the tour is 90 minutes on your feet with very little opportunity to sit.

Even from across the river, Parliament is an impressive sight. I had the pleasure of seeing the Houses of Parliament during two different trips to London. Even seeing it from across the River Thames brings emotions to one's heart. It is an impressive view, along with Big Ben and many other UK enjoyments.
Houses of Parliament. If you can afford the tour, then do it, as it's well worth it. If not, then a stroll along the opposite side of the Thames provides a good view of the architecture.
Such a beauty!. We got here by big bus tour. Though its quite crowded, the place is still magnificent. The building is intricately built with every detail. A must visit in London.

Fantastic. Went on a school trip both occasions and both times it was fantastic both times going. The tour guides where very informative and it was nice to learn about what has gone on in Parliement and what is going on in Parliement

Family from USA visit . Perfect visit and tour, everyone from the minute we arrived to the moment we left could not have been nicer , gorgeous place too cannot believe I've not been in side before its breath taking .
Tricia

Inside Tour of Parliament. Enjoy gorgeous architecture as well as gain insight into the inner workings of the British government. Purchasing the guided tour is definitely worth the additional fee in order to see all that Parliament has to offer.

Watch Policy In Action. Watch policy in action....Or at least watch the debate process. When we attended the majority of the members were absent. However, it was quite impressive to actually be able to go through the Houses of Parliament, sit and listen to those that were there debating issues, to see the process in action. My one suggestion would be to try to determine ahead of a visit if there is going to be any "high level" discussion going on, I think it would be a lot more exciting. It is something not to be missed if you have a chance though
Super excellent . Great visit. Very knowledgeable guide. Full of history. You will enjoy it at its best if you have previously read Jeffrey Archer's four among equal novel.

Enjoyed the guided tour . The guide for my group is very well versed in the history of uk political studies and she conducted the 90 min session in a very interesting and light hearted manner. I learned so much during this tour. Very beautiful architecture, definitely worth the visit.
Great landmark to visit when in London. Although it was wet and cold on the day we visited, it was a great landmark to see and visit whilst in London.

Excellent!. Great views from the bridge and an iconic landmark. The Big Ben is definitely the highlight of the area, but the Parliament architecture is quite distinctive. I would recommend reading up a little on the history prior, unless you are covering this as part of a walking tour.

Brilliant. I did the houses of parliament tour back in the summer and I cant recommend it enough. The architecture outside is fabulous and the decor inside is brilliant. The whole place drips in history and every artefact has a story.Was great to go into both chambers of the house and breathe in the history.

PMs Questions. Had an excellent day in Westminster buildings, after contacting my local MP I was lucky enough to be allocated a ticket to attend the day's proceedings, very enlightening, also gave me a chance to look and admire the architecture of the building,
Impressive. Great visit , Big ben is the focal point tho but was brilliant to see parliment and so interesting!!

Do the audio tour. I've done a few tours of Parliament, the guided tours they used to do a few years ago during the Summer opening were good, but you had to move at the same pace as the guide. They now do audio tours, which gives you more time to see things.

Beautiful building . What a fantastic and iconic building in London. Great to see on a summer afternoon from across the river . Lucky enough to have gone on a tour before and say in the observer box during a House of Commons vote.

The symbol of an entire nation. Westminster Palace is undoubtedly one of the undisputed symbols of the city. Located in the heart of London. This beautiful building overlooking the banks of the Thames includes the English Parliament and the Big Ben clock tower. Needless to say, a picture with this in the background is a must.

Everyone should go. We had our visit on Saturday 19th Dec; everyone we met along the way was polite, friendly and professional and our guide was superb (David, if you are lucky enough to get him!). Seeing history alive is part of a visit to London, and this is living history. I am keen to return when Parliament is in session to get a better feel for it all. A morning very well spent.

Best to view at night!!. I make a pint to walk around this area a couple of times during my London visits. It's so beautiful when views at night. During my last visit there was a sit in as group was protesting as a result of parliament voting on a key measure. A green light near the top of Big Ben means parliament is in session.

Fantastic tour with oodles of detail. Awesome! The full tour from the ancient to the lobby and houses of lords and commons encompass many of the facilities. Exceptional and of interest to anyone with a vague interest history. Far too good for the "work force".
Interesting !. you can walk through the street to have a look at the in famous Big Ben and pass through the St. James Park before getting there.

Beautiful buildings along the Thames. This is a UNESCO world heritage site. Fantastic architecture of the buildings along the Thames river brings about a view worth seeing. Free guided tours of the Palace are held throughout the parliamentary session for UK residents, who can apply through their MP or a member of the House of Lords. The tours last about 75 minutes.

Beautiful piece of history. This is a beautiful structure with a lot of history. It is a must see for a first trip to London. The area is quite crowded. It may be best to see it in early morning or early evening. You do not want to drive there!

Guided Tour Excellent. Arranged this trip six months previously and it was well worth the wait. The guide was very knowlegeable and humourous (Terry) and we were allowed to stand in front of those famous green benches in the Houses of Lords & Commons. Afterwards we sat in on the days business in the Public Gallery. Everyone should experience this at least once in their lifetime.
Awesome view!. Fantastic architecture, in a perfect location next to the river, available for photographs and observation from any angles you can think of, definitely must see when in London.

Worth a visit. I definitely recommend making time to stop here when you're in London. I had a guided tour which was great, but you can opt for a self-guided audio tour as well. Our guide was knowledgeable but not all that interesting. If you can get past that, you'll enjoy the t our. Visits to the House of Commons and the House of Lords were particularly fascinating, and the stories of how business is done here are entertaining.Don't pass up the chance to have tea here on Saturday afternoons. Sittings are at 2 and 3:30 (I believe) and are pretty good with great views. Worth the money.
Stunning piece of architecture!. Incredible building along side the Thames! The building is even better when viewed all lit up at night! A must-see when visiting London!
A great sight. A must to see when in London. Big, imposing and very aesthetically pleasing to look at. You haven`t seen London until you`ve seen the Houses of Parliament

Utterly fascinating. We opted for the guided tour and were really pleased that we did. Not only was it the best way to ensure my mother was able to have wheelchair access but the guide was knowledgable, had a good sense of humour and was a terrific story teller from a historical and contemporary perspective. The building is beautiful and gives a huge insight into the history over time. I am not sure the building lends itself to comfortable workings by politicians but there you go. This tour is absolutely worth it and was a fantastic experience. The cafe here is also quite reasonable for a light snack. The tour people advise be 20 mins early I would say make it 30 mins as security whilst smooth and effective can have a bit of a que. Also be really careful not to loose your security pass like I did as you have to go back to security for a new one.
Iconic. Forget about google pictures and everything someone has show you before. It much nicer live. Especially at dusk. No filters necessary :)
beautiful monument. although i just saw it from outside, is just a great monument, with a lot of history...close to other places to visit.....
The Parliament of UK. One of the oldest building of London. Centrally located next to the Thames river it is a must visit for tourists across the world.

Democracy in action. We had a free tour of the Houses of Parliament courtesy of our MP, and it was an inspiring visit. Not only is this a wonderful building, with a colourful history, but it is the home of modern democracy. Walking through the halls where our history has been made was a wonderful experience, and with a very knowledgeable tour guide, this was a brilliant visit. Also a very good gift shop! .
Must see. Had a great experience visiting the Houses of Parliament. the decorations, ambiance reflects the monarchy.

One of the best places to visit in london. This is one of the best attractions in London, I've just done a second tour of the Houses of Parliament and would thoroughly recommend the guided tour which is timed and can be booked online. Security is tight as you would expect but reassuring. The tour is very informative and interesting and gives you a great insight into past history and present day politics. You get to visit the House of Commons and House of Lords and if you can stretch to it I would thoroughly recommend booking the lovely afternoon tea package.
Cool. Cool touristy place to visit in London. The parliament buildings and big ben make a lovely photograph :)

Excellent tour. It is worth the modest effort to book the tour of the Houses of Parliament on their website in advance of visiting London. It is a fabulous building and the tour guides (ours was Vicky) are very knowledgeable. You should plan on arriving at least a half hour before your scheduled tour in order to go through the screening process. Security is not a lot different from what you experience at major international airports. While the tours have scheduled start times, we found that if one is there early and an earlier tour has space available they will add you on.
historic location and buildings. provides an excellent historic insight into the buildings supporting the British political system today and in the past

Just an interesting historic tour. Today I went on an organised tour of the Houses of Parliament. Whether you are interested in history or not this trip would appeal to everyone. It provides an understanding of the iconic way that the British Parliament operates. In addition to experiencing the majesty and splendour of British Victorian Renaissance architecture. The tour guide was very knowledgable and made the whole experience very interesting. Having the privilege of standing in the lords and the commons chambers was awesome and standing there realising the number of debates that have taken place and laws that have been created over the centuries was truly inspiring. A great trip and will defiantly do this again.

So much to see. We booked a guided tour rather than an audio guide, which I would highly recommend as the guiding was excellent, the only drawback being you had to move along pretty rapidly, where there were so many areas it would have been good to get a longer and closer look at - painting, statues etc. I would like to go back and spend a little longer looking around. Would recommend booking in advance, then you just collect your tickets around 20 minutes before the tour to allow for the security check. Well worth visiting and price not unreasonable

Great look at the interior & history. Note that tours are only available on Saturdays or when Parliament is in recess. We stood in a short, but slow moving queue at a building across the street from Big Ben (Portcullis House) on a whim when we discovered that tours were available. You can also book tickets online or by telephone. We had the time for the 90 minute guided tour, but considered the 60 minute audio/self-guided tour. During the tour, we found that the guided tour goes some places the self-guided tours do not. Do allow at least 5-10 minutes before your tour time to go through security and find the correct meeting location of the tour (the tour meeting area was a bit disorganized). About 25 people compose each tour group.The tour started by following the path the Queen would take when she arrives to open Parliament. Our guide did a good job explaining the history and the structure of the buildings and the government. She added info on current activities, and little tidbits along the way (e.g., the uniform for the Doorkeepers in the House of Commons includes a badge that is considered part of the Crown Jewels). Overall, I felt the tour was definitely worth the price and time. Pictures are not allowed in most of the tour, which is a bit disappointing, but understandable.

House of Commons surprise. I was amazed to discover that you can turn up outside the Houses of Parliament and get access to the House of commons to hear a debate in the Public Gallery without any booking. Security is obviously rigorous but very pleasant and courteous. It was superb to be able to walk through Westminster Hall and then sit in the public gallery and listen to a debate. Half an hour is enough for anybody because it does get a bit boring but a great experience that I would recommend to anyone. This freedom of democracy is what we need to celebrate.
Reallyenjoyable. Went to a uni reception there no did the tour. GraT to see it like and to stand in the centre where they all dash through when the Division Bell sounds

Surpriingly informative and interesting. We opted for the guided tour and I'm so glad we did; it was spot on. If you do the same, the ticket office is across the road (not Parliament building itself) and then allow time to get through the security checks. For me, the guided tour put everything in context in terms of parliament's history, the main players in its foundation over the centuries, exactly how it all works and why - I thought I knew a fair bit but it seems not. I didn't appreciate that most of it was rebuilt, and to look old, in Victoria's reign, or that MPs had to ballot for a seat to sit on ('cos it's not as big as it appears on TV), and so may other things. Our guide was exceptionally knowledgeable in its history and its complex machinations.There's no photography throughout, although I can't fathom why; it's not like they sell their own photos or anything. But there is a good cafe on the way out which isn't in any way expensive - £7 for 2 coffees, a sandwich and a cookie. I'd recommend this tour.

Great tour even if uninterested in Politics. Bought for husbands 60th birthday as he enjoys Political issues, I dont, but found the tour so interesting and informative. wonderful to see history of our nation depicted on walls, photos and statues. well worth the guide price.
Westminster. Very nice this ! Home of the queen and à lot too see , easy to reach by train and 3 hour visit is enough time to see everything Aldi inside is Beautiful !

Dinner with Trollopes!. The final event of this special celebratory year for the 200th anniversary of Anthony Trollope was held in the Cholmondley room within the House of Lords. It was enjoyable, entertaining & with excellent company. I would particularly highlight the lovely Dean & Nadir who looked after us very well indeed. The meal was fine, the drink flowed... the speeches were interesting & a good time was had by all once more. Personally I prefer the Dining Room as a location though!
So much history. We only walked around the outside, but well worth a visit, if you have the time to get inside. Lots of people and it was very buzy

Well Worth Seeing!!!. Exited Westminster Station viewed The Eye, and Big Ben and walked around the grounds of Parliament. I spoke to a gentleman at one of the entrances to Parliament and he asked me if I would like to visit. Naturally, I said yes. It is simply a wonderful experience! Upon entering you start out in common areas where you can take photos, purchase gifts, and grab a bite to eat. Next stop for me was the House of Commons which I enjoyed watching a session for 20 minutes. Next stop was the House of Lords where watched a session for about 15 minutes. The sessions during my visit were not monumental on a international scale. It was simply amazing to visit and see Parliament, which is steeped in so much history! If you get the opportunity to visit the House of Parliament, you should!!!
The best building in the UK. Amazing building, spectacular history, would recommend the last tour on a Sat as quiet and really nice to see the building lit up.
The home of modern democracy. 1st visit here and would come again get your MP to organise the trip you get in for free you be back hopefully for a PMQ
Breathtaking. Every time I visit London, I always go to look at the Houses of Parliament, the building isbreathtaking, and make some wonderful Photographs.
Interesting tour. Great place to visit. First time in 60 years should have gone there earlier in my life. You get to see all the main features of Parliament.

Awesome guided tour. The Houses of Parliament and Big Ben are the iconic images of London we've all seen on television, in photos or from the sidewalk as tourists. They are even more stunning on the inside with a guided tour that brings to life the history, art, architecture and politics of the place.Avoid the long queues for tickets at Portcullis House by booking online or by telephone. You have a choice between a self-guided audio tour and a live guided tour. The guided tours get into places the self-guided tours don't, are more personal and offer the chance to ask questions.Mary Parker, who looks a bit like Dame Judi Dench, was our wonderful guide. She was expert, as you would expect, at bringing the history of the palace to life. But she also incorporated current activities into her commentary, making it clear this is still the working seat of UK government where momentous decisions are debated and decided (the contentious vote on British bombing of ISIS had just concluded a couple days before our tour). She wove her wonderful understated sense of humor throughout her talk. This was no dry historical lecture. The tours are only available on Saturdays, or when Parliament is in recess. If you are in London when the tours are being conducted, make the time to take one.

Not to be missed. We took the audio tour which we enjoyed. You were able to take the tour at your own pace. There were a few places you could sit and listen and take in the atmosphere. I have to say I thought the whole tour was very well organised. The building is beautiful. I did not expect to be able to actually stand in the House of Lords and commons.You are only able to take photos in certain areas which was a shame but I can understand the logic behind the ban. You have to book in advance. Well worth the money.

Focus on legislative work. The houses of parliament are located within the palace of Westminster. The latter was built by Edward the Confessor in the eleventh century and served as a royal residence until 1512. Afterwards it became the permanent home of the English parliament and the seat of the Royal Courts of Justice.The houses of parliament were gutted by fire in 1834 and subsequently reconstructed in neo gothic style by architect Charles Barry and decorator August Pugin. The houses of parliament can only be visited on certain days and tickets come with a timeframe. Therefore I recommend ordering your tickets online in advance.In most areas photography is prohibited.Visitors can discover the houses of parliament either with the help of an audio guide or by enlisting for a guided tour. The rating reflects my relative disappointment in the visit. I was keen on learning about the medieval royal palace and hoped to visualize its former splendor via reconstruction drawings and scale models. I had also hoped to obtain detailed information about the beautiful neo gothic interior and facades. Who did the many statues represent ? What topics were chosen for the paintings and reliefs and why ? What scandals and dramas had occurred within these walls ?However, explanations focus on the legislative work of the houses of parliament. Information about their composition, daily work and voting methods alternate with audio comments of deputies. I guess this is mostly appealing to British visitors.In retrospect I would not book a tour of the houses of parliament again and I encourage you to rather spend your time in London wandering the various districts with the help of a good travel guide.

Houses of British Decisions Makers. British Houses of Parliament is among most powerful Parliaments of the World. As United Kingdom is one of the most powerful country of the World and its decisions effect international community accordingly. it is located adjacent to river tames and Big Ben is major Land Mark of Houses of Parliament and can be seen from for away. Very Impressive and very powerful parliament of the world.

The heart of our nation steeped in history. We were invited here by our local MP who personally gave us and other invitees a guided tour of the house of commons and halls. The history and very interesting facts of our government through made for a vrry educational visit. There was a session going on in the House of Lords so we did not manage to see that at the time but we will be looking to get back at some time to take that in and visit big Ben. Politics may be boring but the Houses of Parliament are far from it.
Very informative guide. A little expensive but worth it. You also get to know some of the inner workings of British politics

Fascinating Tour. We did the Saturday audio guide tour. The audio guide is really well done and informative without being boring. Getting to see both houses and learn about the history and process of the place was really interesting. It was great to actually get to walk through on the floor where everything happens.

History in Architecture . The intricacies of the building are stunning and it is well worth studying the structure. There are great perspectives of the building from Westminster Bridge and from the south side of the river. If you can get on to a tour it is more than well worth it.

Worth A Visit!. We took a guided tour (recommend you book in advance) which was really worthwhile, the guide made the tour both interesting & entertaining.....lots of little anecdotes! There's lots to see and even more to take in, you can really feel the history of the Palace. As you'd expect there's quite a bit of walking and not that many places where you can rest your feet for a few minutes so just be wary of that. Overall a very enjoyable couple of hours.......nice coffee shop at the end of the tour as well!
Oh Lord! . Had the opportunity to be hosted for dinner in the House of Lords. Wild experience...so much history and protocol. Beautiful and ornate.

Very Interesting. Booked in advance via our Local MP. Wasn't too sure what to expect but was not disappointed. Met in the Visitors area inside and were shown around by a female guide, we had a party of 1 10 with us. Fortunately on this day we were allowed inside the House of Commons and House of Lords, this is not always possible. It was great to inside what we normally see on the TV, but we could not sit down on any of the seats.We went through the areas where the Queen gets ready for her one visit and saw the area where Queen Victoria sat. Steeped on history but worth going just to get a feel of what exactly happens.

a Trip around History. I was not sure if I would find this trip interesting enought, but I needn't have worried. Our Guide was knowledgable, and he told us al sorts of facts and history that had happened in this great building. To actually see areas, that I have seen on the tv news, was quite a surprise, it was a lot smaller than I thought it would be. The tour took approx 1hour 40minutes and the time flew past. Amazing building. a must see if you are in london. You are not allowed to take photos after you leave the great hall and enter parliament.

Only on Saturdays is this tour available to the public.. We very much enjoyed seeing Parliament and all the stories that go along with the tour. Make sure you have a guide as I think this makes the tour more enjoyable.

A Walk Through History. I feel very privileged to have visited this wonderful place. My visit was a special one after I asked my local MP if it was possible she could arrange a visit in particular also attend PMQ's. At this time I was unaware that there were public tours allowed. Fortunately I received a reply and given a date.We arrived at Portcullis House on the due day and after going through severe security checks was met by my MP's PA. She explained that my MP was busy and that she (the PA) will give us a personal tour.We started off in Westminster Hall the oldest building on the Westminster Estate, 900 years old. The Hall was built in 1097 under William II (Rufus), the son of William the Conqueror. Many Historic characters were put on trial here.At the end of Westminster Hall is St Stephen's Hall which stands on the site of the royal Chapel of St Stephen's, where the House of Commons sat until the Chapel was destroyed by the fire of 1834. We did not go into the House of Commons as members were sitting but we did visit the House of Lords and saw the Woolsack, the Queens Throne for the opening of Parliament, and of course the Red benches. From here we were walked through the library then on to The Reading Room, The Central Lobby the MP's Restaurant and were allowed a quick peek onto the Terrace over looking the River Thames. At this point my MP arrived and escorted us around the portrait paintings that are displayed in Portcullis House.Finally we were escorted to the Visitors Gallery where we stayed for that Wednesdays PMQ's.This visit was very very special in terms of curiosity, history, architecturally. I am not sure how a public visit varies from our own but the PA did say we have seen some parts of Westminster that the public organised tours do not see.I would thoroughly recommend this it has so much history much more than I can quote here, it would be very educational for anyone including children.

Brilliant Tour!. I had always wanted to visit Parliament as I've a keen interest in politics & I wasn't disappointed. We did the guided tour which cost £20 & it was money well spent. The tour lasted just over 2 hours & the guide was terrific, she really knew her stuff! The tour takes in the Lords & The Commons & to stand in these rooms is pretty amazing!!! If you love politics this is a must visit place but I would recommend a tour even to those who find politics annoying as the building itself is quite remarkable!

Houses of Parliament. The palace of Westminster is a really architectural treat. To see where our elected government hold office and to see democracy in action was refreshing. The Thames side restaurant has great views even if the food is not of the highest quality.

Full Guided Tour for UK Civil Servants. I was looking for a team day out and wrote to my MP asking for passes to see the Houses of Parliament. They came through and we got a free version of the regular guided tour. It was important to have a guide as there is SO much history and things to see - I was particularly taken with the royal toilet in the House of Lords!Anyone can goto the ticket office and queue - on the day we were there it took longer to arrange our free passes than for others to buy them so don't be put off by the queue.It is a truly inspiring place and it is the beating heart of London so please do try and go!
Wow!!! Wonder view.. We walk around and saw Big Ben as well. Must see and plenty of great photo opportunity. It was close so we could not go in.

Well worth the visit. Although the lineups can be a bit long during the summer, it is well worth the experience to go through the historic House of Lords and the House of Parliament. You will enter through the oldest part of Westminster Palace. Have a look at the wood structure roof dating back to the 11th century

Beautiful building with superb views. It was just magnificent to see the building. It was majestic and just a beauty to marvel at the wonder design and the architecture of the buildingThis is a must when u visit london
Worth seeing. The buildings are worth seeing for their history and architecture, however be prepared for the crowds of people taking photos and stopping to see them.

Fantastic. Must See. Did a guided tour on a Saturday morning. Cost £25.The tour took a few hours and was brilliant. We covered both the House of Lords and House of Commons and the guide went into great detail about each, explaining the statues, pictures etc.., and the processes involved in both houses was just fascinating.By being on an early tour (9.20am), the crowds hadn't arrived yet and it was easy to get around. By about 11am, it filled up pretty quick. One of the best attractions in London. Make sure you visit.

wondrful views and pictures. this place is very beautiful, open spaced, perfect for pictures for good memories. the view from the bridge to the west minister palace and bigben, london eye, and st james hospital is all great. you will not want to leave. the historical building of houses of parliament are amazing from closer looks and is more huge than I thought. If you visit london, you will not want to miss this place certainly.
seat of power. Walked past the houses of parliament whilst walking through London. Iconic building dominated by Big Ben. Very very busy area
Amazijg to see. This is a must see in London, the Big Ben is so large and the houses of Parliament look so amazingly detailed, and easy to reach by tube, very good!
It has to be done. While it London you have to go and see the houses of parliament if up that way while exploring they aren't hard to miss .. Go and see and be a part of it

Great place to take school groups. Classes will be in awe of this fantastic building and the tour is excellent! The staff are friendly and informative and the workshops are interactive to suit all ages.
recommend. Visited here and was well impressed with the building and the information whether you are interested in politics or not

Member's tour. Went on a member's tour (free for UK citizens - must book months ahead through your MP). Cracking tour. Imagine walking the chambers and corridors as the MPs: and there they were, going about their business. Tour guide was entertaining and informative. Tour visited the chambers of the House of Lords, House of Commons, the lobbies: what you see on the news, and there we were. Great experience. Any interest in parliament or politics and you must go.Restrictions: no photos except in Westminster Hall (where the tour starts), no food or drink on the tours, and definitely NO telephones.
Suprisingly good. Its a long walk, but really enjoyable and a great insight into our parliament. Very informal, relaxed and enjoyable, even the cafe was a surprise.

Definitely worth a visit. Visited with family including a teenager interested in politics. The tour was well worth it. The guides were very entertaining and knowledgeable. Learned lots of things we didn't know. The buildings are beautiful, steeped in history and thoroughly recommended.

A demystifying experience. Some places are described as "humbling", I would describe visiting the Houses of Parliament as the exact opposite. To see that the place where national decisions are made is about the size of an ordinary auditorium makes the whole process feel less distant and out-of-touch.

Unmissable. This often overlooked beautiful iconic building is well worth the visit & for me one of the greatest attractions in London. Without saying too much the building is stunningly awesome - inside especially. It's the nerve point & hub of past present & future British history - to be there is wonderful truly memorable & thought provoking! Great for all ages from 8 to 80. HoP guided tours are a tad expensive but still a must to fully appreciate the experience. £25 for adults, £20 for OAP's & students & £10 age 5-15
Well worth the wait.. There is a lengthy process to get in but the history waiting for you when you arrive is fabulous. It is a part of democracy in action.

A must do tour of the houses of parliament. We went on a guided tour of the houses of parliaments, this is a must do if you love London or history of the city or even politics. This tour shows you around quite a lot of different sections of the two houses, the lords and commons and also the queen rooms in-between. The tour guide really new his stuff and any questions he knew the answers to. The tour lasted about 90 minutes and really is interesting even if you aren't interested in current affairs there is something for everyone from the Tudors and the Stewarts to the Windsors. The age of the buildings and content is amazing and I'm glad that i took time out and broke away from the crowded streets of London to experience this tour.

Amazed. You won't believe until you see it with your own eyes. This is a must see place to everyone! And the best of it is you can do it for free! Just pop in for one the sessions and you'll be able to walk the same corridors as politicians do!

THE BEAUTIFUL FACE OF LONDON. This beautiful building lends itself to so many photo opportunities from every angle. Having been privileged to be invited on a tour of parliament I have to say it is just as lovely inside.

London trip. Amazing building with all its different sections and the statues outside. Busy when we visited, but it was the day of the Syria debate, so loads if Press and Police. Great views along the Thames and across to Lambeth.

Great tour. We went on a tour during the summer recess, and what a treat it was. The guide was very informative, it's such a stunning building, and the chambers are really much smaller than they appear on television - no wonder members often have to stand!I cannot recommend it enough, especially if you have an interest in politics or British history.

Center of the world for parliamentary systems!. Get a tour of the Parliament. No trip to London is complete without one. In addition to this being Parliament, the location itself is steeped in history.

beautiful view!. went there the past 2 weeks in winter with husband and 2 kids, beautiful building, just walking distance from london eye, buckingham palace just beside river Thames, a must visit in London!

Informative and interesting tour.. I travelled recently as part of a group of 24 to the Houses of Parliament.The guide we had made it very interesting ( which always makes such a difference if the guide delivers it well)It was fascinating to hear all about the history of our system and see the actual rooms for myself.We at extremely lucky to have such wonderful traditions in our country.

Nice surprise: Watch the discussion from the Galleries!. At first we were disappointed we could not tour the Houses of Parliament because Parliament was in session. But we learned we could still enter, walk through the imposing entry hall, and go to the galleries of either the House of Lords or the House of Commons. The day we went the House of Commons was debating a 3rd runway at Heathrow, and representatives from London to Scotland voiced their opinions for or against. It was easy to follow, and engaging. The House of Lords has a more impressive room with a gold screen. If you toured the Tower of London and noticed two maces were missing and "in use", they were in each House of Parliament. Not suggested for children. Best surprise of our week!

Visited Historic "Houses of Parliament" London August 2015. I along with my wife visited UK for few days and during our London's visit we have the honor to visit world’s most iconic buildings Houses of Parliament OR Palace of Westminster" It is also known as House of Commons and House of Lords as well. It was my desire to visit this charismatic building physically during my visit to UK. Big Ban, River Thames, Buckingham Palace, 10 downing Street, Trafalgar Square and London Eye etc all famous monuments are on walking distance from here. I will strongly recommend visitors of London to must visit this historic building.

Interesting buildings. We were lucky enough to be there on a Saturday which is the only day these are open otherwise when parliament is not sitting. Tickets need to be purchased prior to attending which is at the front of Portcullis House on Victoria Embankment. Get there early to book a guided tour otherwise you will need to battle the self guided tour which can be annoying after a while, we listened into a few tours walking around which make it that more interesting. Buildings are amazing and great to see in real life.

Very interesting experienx. I took one of the guided tours and found it to be excellent. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and the use of time very efficient. This was one of the best things I did in London.
A piece our heritage. We were lucky enough to get a private tour of both houses, so much history and so beautiful and majestic. Fabulous.

Public Gallery anyone?. It is well known that you can enjoy guided tours of the Houses of Parliament.But did you know that subject to certain conditions you may spend some time in the Public Gallery either in stead of or as well as?Both Police Officers and uniformed Palace staff will advise you first whether a Session is available and members are debating and then help you through the security checks etc.I would like to thank both Police and staff for the warm welcome they gave my wife and teenage grandson when we arrived 'on spec'. They could not have been more helpful and we shown into the Looby to watch the official opening proceedings at 2.30p.m. when The Speaker and The Mace proceed through to the House for Prayers prior to the start of Business.You are given an Order paper for that day's business, just before you are escorted through to the public viewing gallery. When you have seen enough, you may leave when you wish - most take 30 to 45 minutes to take it all in although this will need the co-operation of those sitting alongside you to do so as the upholstered benches are quite close together. The steps leading down to the seating are very steep but the grandly uniformed attendants will assist those with mobility problems.Well done House of Commons - an excellent experience made all the richer for the very warm and helpful welcome from all those involved in allowing you to enjoy this.

Very interesting, write to your MP to request a visit.. This was the main focus of short break. What a fascinating building etc. Guide (Helen McGivern(?)) was extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic, she made the tour even more enjoyable. Not many things are free, this is a must.

Listending to debates and seeing personalities in real life. Yet architecture stays the same but the content of the debate and the contributors differ every day.You can make up your mind about their contributions much more easily than having journalists edit them.

About time I did this!. I am surprised that so mamy people, om hearing of my visit, have also not explred inside! From the great hall dating back to 1099 through interesting stories of its history through to current restoration of clay floor tiles and nosy peeking through curtains, I thoroughly enjoyed my tour with headphones and recorded guide. They say it takes and hour and a half but I listened to all the interesting extras and we were over two hours. The cafe was not appropriate for lunch unless you like bread products!

Great Tour. A really interesting and informative tour, if you have a spare couple of hours on a Saturday it's well worth it. Amazing architecture and interiors, and very informative guides. Apparently the afternoon tea is very good, however I didn't try it.

British political history alive. Artistically, the inside looks even more stunning than the outside, and so much to see and learn about key historical and political figures. The portraits and the House of Lords are particularly impressive. I took only the audio guide, which was very informative, but probably would be more amusing with a real guided tour.

An eye-opening experience!. I was fortunate enough to get a guided tour from a friend of mine who works there. I must say I did not expect the splendour of the place to be of such magnitude.This is one of those places that one must visit a few times to really appreciate the different aspects.
Guided tour. Excellent guided tour of the House of Parliament. Our guide, Mary Cook, was very infomative. A good 2 hour tour

A must see tourist attraction. Visited as a must see with children,they are having some work done on them at the moment but you can still see what an impressive building it is,great places to grab photos all around.

Admired from outside, Big Ben is beautiful in sight and sound. Walked across Westminster bridge which offers amazing views of this monument by day or night, hearing the chimes up close and personal is a great experience, wouldn't appeal to children.
Make sure you do the tour. The tour was amazing and gave so many details that allowed you to really get a feel for how the government is run. The place is beautiful as well!
Interesting visit.. Be prepared for all the security and yet it is worth a look.We sat in on one sitting and found it interesting to listen to.The heated concrete waiting seats are a good idea.

'Must do' tour whilst in London. An informative and most enjoyable 2 hour tour. The opulence of the House of Lords is particularly stunning and our guide Anne brought the political history of the U.K. to life in an understandable way with some added amusing anecdotes. Highly recommended.
must-do list!. A part of history still in full working use today-an amazing experience, and well organised tour with really helpful staff.

Brilliant day out! . We took our three young children to the Houses of Parliament and had a great family day out!
The kids had the children's audio guides which are brilliantly tailored to make it interesting and informative for them.
always takes my breath away. wonderful place to visit and it is so beautiful. The history oozes out of the place. the security is as u would expected but the staff are so nice and helpful

Outstanding guided tour. We were booked onto the 9.20am tour but because security was so swift and efficient, we were put on the earlier one to save us waiting.Expect airport style security that is taken very seriously. Do what you're told and you'll be through in no time. We were greeted by our guide, Mary, who asked us all where we were from so she could personalise the tour. She was an outstanding guide giving us insights from the art, to parliamentary protocols, to anecdotes from days gone by - all peppered with humorous tales of misbehaving MPs. She was enthusiastic and friendly and answered any questions.The tour takes you through all the places you want to see and then some! Incredibly well-organised and efficient.The tour took around 2 hours and was arranged very well - there were several other tours going round but it didn't feel crowded or that we were fighting for space.Would highly recommend. And each tour guide had their own tales to tell so you could easily go more than once.The best place I've visited in London.
Go See. If Parliament is in Session you can watch the debates on the floor of the House of Commons and House of Lords. Our kids did not want to leave!

Fabulous Building, but tour - too much information. The Building is wonderful, so enjoyed seeing inside this very British Goverment Building. Arranged my free visit through my MP available to all British citizens. So much to take in with the guide got lost a few times as very centred on the past. Cannot sit on the seats, why...thought that a load of tosh personally. As when I went long time ago with my small kids I am sure I sat on the speakers chair. It was so warm in the House of Lords no wonder they all snooze in there. Lovely paintings and just looked round in awe at it all.
Really interesting . Visted here with a group of school children and had a really good interesting tour around the houses of parliament. Seeped in history and heritage I would really recommend this

Fascinating glimpse of the home of Govt. Visited the House of Commons and House of Lords - highly recommend the visit as an insight into how things are done. Fascinating history, quirky details and lots of bling as well!

Take the Saturday Guided Tour. Absolutely loved the live person guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. I'm sure the audio tape one is good but if possible take the guided tour! I had been in London for a week and had become intrigued with the politics covered on tv and the newspapers. However had a lot of questions on how it all worked. Got my answers and some wonderful history! And a walk through a stunningly beautiful building! I do suggest that you buy and PRINT your tickets on line...will save you time! Be prepared to pass through airport like security.

Democracy in Action. We visited here to see PMQ's & found the whole visit to be fascinating. With an informative guided tour of both the Commons & the Lords, we then sat in the public gallery to see the debating, together with the Chancellor's delivery of the Autumn statement. Whilst I'd be the first to admit some of our MP's leave something to be desired it is still to be applauded that in an essentially free country we can see an elected chamber in session debating the issues of the day. Far better than the stark alternative offered by those who would seek to undermine our democracy & way of life via the gun & suicide vest.

Beautiful.. Even with all the pomp and ceremony, the HOP is very much worth a visit. The sense of how old the building is, is very powerful, and most people are willing to fill you in with the history. Makes you want to be a MP just so you can sit on those green leather benches.

mother of all parliament's. The palace of Westminster is only open to the public on Saturdays and is by advance ticket purchase.Strict airport style security is required to gain access to the building so recommend you arrive 20 to 30 mins before your reservation time. The day we visited queues were long and we just made it in time to join our allocated guided tour. The guide was extremely knowledgeable of the history, treasures, pageantry and unusual customs of parliament.Once inside the ancient Westminster Hall you instantly feel the historical and cultural significance of this amazing building and the part it has played in our nation's history. For any Brit visiting the capital go see your parliament the place where decisions are made on your behalf its an absolutely fascinating building. It is truly the mother of all parliament's.
Excellent Tour. Had a tour of the houses of parliament, and our guide Ralph Spencer made it very interesting about all the rooms visited and he knew his history very well. Very educational

Unmissable!. We took the audio guide tour, which had a good level of detail. The interior is fantastic and you get to see inside both the houses of commons and lords. Very enjoyable, would thoroughly recommend.

Great buildings and fascinating history. Houses of Parliament is worth av visit. It is only open for visitors at Saturdays. You have to buy tickets in advance (the day before or early in the morning) at the ticket office on the opposite side of the Parliament. We used audio guides and it was perfect, interesting and great to be there.

the mother of all parliaments. The Houses of parliament are open during the summer recess, in August, and the visit takes you through both the House of Commons and house of Lords. I have been twice as I wanted my children, when they reached their teenage years, to understand what democracy was about. It is an excellent trip, with the guides being very knowledgable about the traditions and process of government in the UK. No matter what your politics this is a must see, even if you are only interested in the architecture and Pugins work.

In the Temple of Democracy. I recently had the chance to be taken through the HoP by Lord Levy.It is a truly inspiring place.You feel the weight of history.The terrace on the Thames offers one of the most exquisite view of London.A mind blowing experience.

House of Parliement worth a look. The Houses of Parliament are worth a walk or drive by. The best thing is it is right there with parliament and Westminster Abbey so you can take the tube there and just wander. The Westminster tube station is very close and an easy ride. You can walk along the street and take pictures.
Mlord. Great sight to see and so beer to many other attractions The center of London has to offer. There are you've stations nearby, plenty pubs and restaurants.

Long lines, watch your time! . Recommended if you have enough time to tour around. Great architecture & view.Transportation is near and go if you don't mind having a lot of people walking around. Be careful with the gamblers on the bridge in front.

Very interesting tour. You need to book well in advance for a guided tour which we weren't able to do, so we did the audio tour instead which was still great. Even if you do the audio tour you need to book a time slot at the ticket office down the street. The tour itself was excellent and a lot of the artwork is more interesting than a lot of stuff you'll find in museums. My wife isn't interested in politics and she still enjoyed the tour. Highly recommended.

Palace of Westminster, Houses of Parliament - Commons & Lords. Elizabeth Tower, known also as Big Ben, is part of Houses of Parliament. It is the Palace of Westminster. It is located across from Westminster Abbey built at the end of the 11th century. We went about 2:30 and were able to see both houses in session.
Everything London. It was THE iconic place to go and soak up some culture and history! Great for pictures any time. Wish we went inside to see more.
Great. One of the most iconic symbols of London. You simply can't miss to see this architectural symbol of the city.

A pleasant and interesting few hours. Not being a fan of horror whilst the rest of my party went to the London Dungeon I took the opportunity to visit Parliament, something I'd been meaning to do for some 30 years and never got round to.Booking the ticket visit the website was easy and straightforward as was clearing security having followed the instructions and not having things like a penknife in ones pocket!I elected to do a self guided audio tour which was informative and interesting but in such an impressive and historic place left me wanting more so I will definitely be revisiting and doing a guided tour. The thing that surprised me most was how small the chambers were - they look huge on TV!One point of particular note was the Houses of Parliament Post Office. I bought a HoP envelope and posted it there to my niece as a surprise when she got home as a momento of her visit. The chap behind the counter was really helpful and friendly to us 'mere tourists' who must be a nightmare for them!

Lording it up at the House of Lorder. you have to experience this excursion. probably one of the most memorable trips I have taken. you don't have to be into politics to take this trip, the architecture alone will grab your attention, but most of all is the history. excellent trip

Best of British. Well worth the visit. So much to see and take in. Tour guide was informative and interesting, To visit the Chambers of the Lords and Commons gave a fantastic insight into the operation of the politics of this country. Something to be very proud of. The building itself it amazing and must be preserved at all costs.The best of British.
Andrew d. Very interesting place to visit, we used the commentary earpiece to guide us around, great to see for ourselves where television takes us on the news.

House of Lords & commons tour. Visit this for a unique piece of history It fantastic to be in the very room where MPs debate and our lords sit stunning pugian design the guides are also greatHear about Charles the King the door where black rod hits
Steeped in history. Go on the guided tour well worth the money. Lots to see and loads of stories. You cannot take pictures but that does not matter.

Amazing. it is a great place to visit especially if you can go inside the sessions in the afternoon. You can go there for free, I highly recomend it for families with teenagers as well. Acros the river you can go the Eye London and also you can go up the street to the Tower of London and The Tower Bridge. You will need an antire day to do this itinerary though
History doesnt get better than this!. So much history!! So many fantastic stories!! I cant recommend enough! Visit the Great Hall where Henry VIII played tennis indoors. I think that says it all!

Iconic London. When you come out of Westminster tube station this landmark is very dominating, with Big Ben directly over you. For the best view and photo opportunities it is worth starting to walk along the bridge or admiring it from the other side of the river where you can see the entirety of the iconic Westminster and Big Ben looming beside it.It is a short walk from here to St James Park, Buckingham place, The Mall, Downing street, Trafalgar square and Westminster Abbey. If you are visiting all of the iconic London landmarks then make sure you stop off here and tick this one off your list.

A Fantastic Experience . The Houses of Parliament Tour is a must do when in LondonTotally recommended 9/10The good- our blue jacket tour guide was fantastic- the building is steeped in history and is exceptionally ornate- great value for moneyThe bad- nothingRecommendations - book on line in advance- also book the afternoon tea which although not cheap is fantastic quality

Great tour. You can see the entire parliament including House of Lords and House of Commons. Audio tour is excellent. The live tours are lively and well conducted and see a few extra rooms. No line in mid November.

"An amazing Tour". Originally a royal residence and officially still a royal palace (Palace of Westminster), it houses both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The 1 1/4 hour tour is well worth the money. Our guide, a lady with 15 years experience showed us so many places and rooms including the Norman Porch, the Queen's Robing Room, Royal Gallery, Prince's Chambers, Lord's Chamber Peer's Lobby and a number of others areas and room. This is a "MUST VISIT" in London.

So interesting, but so tiring.. These days, security is extremely tight, to access this attraction, so be warned, do not take anything that is vaguely offensive in with you, it will be removed. [ I had a very tiny nail scissors taken out of my handbag. ] This is airport style security!There is so much to see, almost too much.You have the option of headsets, to go at your own pace, [certainly useful for non English speakers, ] or guided tours, with very knowledgeable staff.The biggest problem, is that you're not allowed to "sit down" on any of the chairs in the main chambers, so a guided tour of almost two hours, was seriously tiring, with several people fainting, [ and it wasn't a hot sunny day, but a very cold and wet November one. ] You do get a couple of minutes to sit in one side room, but then you don't want to get up! Plus you're not allowed to take in food / drink, to refresh yourself.The whole place is so full of history, so awe inspiring, it is really worthwhile doing. Just make sure you wear comfortable shoes, go to the toilet first and can take off your top coat, so you don't get too hot.
Great place to visit. Great visit and free too! Just a couple of Tube stops away so it is easy to get too. Just a couple of tube stops away.
a breathtaking building. This is a must see when you visit London, the architecture and the history is just unbelievable. A wonderfull experience

Parliament is in session. Really beautiful building from the outside, right next door to Westminster abbey, they only give tours on Saturdays but you can enter any day and go up to the gallery to see the house of commons or the house of lords in session. Very interesting!

Got to see this on a trip to London. We didn't go in, hence the Average mark, but the buildings and Big Ben make for good photos. Met Paddy Ashdown exiting the gate. You can get into the public gallery and get bored by British politics at certain times of the day.
Gorgeous!. Stunning, absolutely stunned even a month after that I was next to the Houses of Parliament. It was amazing and I would go again 100%
Always loved visiting. Have been many times over the years and particularly enjoyed the visit up the tower. Its a stunning building with amazing history.
Nice. Just took a few photos it's absolutely amazing really enjoyed my birthday weekend in London and can't wait to return.It rained all day but didn't dampen our spirit .
No guide. We just looked onto the grounds and it was an incredible sight - once we got through the panhandlers. But nevertheless an amazing and well kept sight.
Been here on business a few times. . Been here on business a few times. Lots of bars and lots to see and do as you would imagine. What else can you say really. Nice polite police officers and staff.

Wonderful outside, wonderful inside.. As we were staying a short walk away from The Palace of Westminster, my partner and I decided to visit the "Strangers gallery". Admission was free and after going through the stringent security checks we entered the Great Hall. As the name suggests it was "Great", a very large area that is used on various state occasions. Very helpful and knowledgeable staff were around to give directions and information. It was interesting being able to see the debate in the chamber although the view of the chamber is restricted due to the gallery extending over half of the chamber. Nevertheless, a very worthwhile place to visit.
Popped in for a meeting. Had a meeting at this amazing place . Wow is what I would say the architecture was the best ever . Highly recommend a visit

The art of governance. The House of Commons is not big. It can't hold all the Members of Parliament at once. It is also quite drab. Visitors have to line p for a long time to gain access to the public gallery. The House of Lords is far more ornate. The standard of debate in the Commons.is said to be far superior to that of Commonwealth countries such as Australia.

A must go when in London for photos!. Was in London on a visit and didn't have any particular desire to visit for a tour or anything (if that's even available) but it's a must photo opportunity when in London. Busy area though so watch yourself.

An interesting tour. We arranged a guided tour via our local MP, which was straightforward to do. Our guide was excellent and gave some very interesting detail about the history of the old palace and the workings of the present day parliament. It was fascinating to see the rooms where Parliament meets and some of the other rooms and chambers. The tour lasted about 75 minutes which was about right. The only "issue" was that there were several tours all at the same time so it was at times difficult to hear everything. We did not do it but you can also go into the visitors galleries without queuing when the Houses are sitting. There can be long queues at times

A must visit when in London. The House of Parliament is a must visit when in London. It is famous for many reasons and it worth visiting. The building is associated with so many events throughout the British & world history.

A must do,. We took the escorted tour around the building. We were particularly lucky as our guide had worked there as a civil servant. He took great pains to find out where people were from and he then used that on the tour to talk about their MP or the parliament in their home country. The tour lasted about 1 hour 50 minutes. The only thing I need to point out is that you aren't allowed to sit down at all apart from 3 short stops on the tour. It makes it hard on your back for certain people but it was worth putting up with a creaky back the next day as it was so interesting.

History. The guided tours are fascinating (with a good guide) but the queues are usually long and the bag and body searches somewhat trying.If you are lucky enough to get an invitation to a Terrace function this is great.

Audio tour. Great opportunity to visit the Houses of Lords and Commons and learn about the history of the Palace of Westminster. Reasonable price at £18 per head. Visit takes about 1 and a half hours.

Amazing. i was fortunate to visit the houses of Parliament, what grace, class and history. i felt i was so small compared to the legacy this place holds. its one of these places that you must see to believe during your lifetime.
Amazing views. We had the chance to swing by Parliament. It is very close to the underground and we were able to just walk around right out of the tube.

Reception at the House of Lords followed by a tour.. Wonderful experience. Very priveleged to have been invited to the reception to celebrate 50 years of Aston University. Thoroughly enjoyed the reception and the guided tour was amazing. So interesting and so much history.

Lobby of Parliament . Incredible history and architecture and a must attraction to visit whilst in the city. Try and meet your MP and sample the delights of the terrace bar with its breathtaking views of the London Eye and River Thames.

Iconic picture of London. how could you visit London as a tourist and not take in this fantastic historic building. Great view from the front and even better from across the river. Look out for the Saturday tours inside the building - we have done this and it is well worth it - but you will have to book ahead (they also do them in the week during recess)
Must do!. Wonderful experience did the inside tour and saw the MPs and Queens seats, an architects dream, so amazing
Must see in London. Just need to walk past and soak up the views and atmosphere. Very close to Westminster tube stop, and Westminster Abbey.

A must for London . Going to the Palace of Westminster is the right of any British Citizen and free of charge. It is a place steeped in history and to get the most out of the visit it is worth a pre-booked tour guide. You could spend the day seeing the political machinery in action which is a completely different experience to watching on TV.

Interesting. I,have been to London countless time but never been in. It is interesting to visit somewhere that you have seen so often on the news. The commentary does go on a bit in places. The staff is a little officious and you can only get photos in a couple of areas which isn't we'll sign posted. Also there are a lot of areas where you can't sit which is rather annoying as again this isn't made obvious. The gift shop is poor especially the lack of postcards which should be better especially due to the fact you can't take photos.
On a rainy day in London.... Not that rain is a surprise! But step off the train and see buildings you've only seen on tv. Old and impressive. Make sure to keep an umbrella close

Free tour. Free guided tour(75mins). Booked via our local MP. Very interesting to see such a building and hear the history of the houses of parliament. It felt it belonged to the people and we were welcome there.
Excellent Tour. The tour guide was highly engaging. This was a definite highlight of our stay in London. Recommend making time for this stop.
Really interesting tour.. The tour was very in-depth and definitely gave a greater understanding on how everything is set up at the Houses of Parliament.
Overlooked experience. The guided tour of the Houses of Parliament was fascinating. Only downer was not being able to take photos.

Christmas gift. Part of a special day with my wife prior to theatre and dinner tonight.Opted for the audio tour where you can take your time and take in the history of the place you can go into sub menus for even more info should you wish or just do the normal tour.Very interesting.
Parli. Loved seeing the culture of London! It is old and historic, everything we see in history books, facinating.
Gorgeous buildings.. Is there much more to say than ironically gorgeous buildings that are recognized worldwide. Stick around and hear big ben chime.
fascinating insight into where those political idiots work. worth planning in advance and queuing to get past security, good guide and well paced tour. try to avoid tourist peak periods.

Amazing place. The Houses of Parliament are breathtaking. We had a brilliant tour guide and we were shown round in a very logical way. Starting with where the Queen arrives to open Parliament where she robes up etc. Then the Lords and then the commons chambers. It's easy to see how our MPs get overawed with their surroundings and all want to fiddle their expenses!We paid for the tour but we are thinking of contacting our own MP and asking him for an opportunity to visit Parliament again.Our tour lasted nearly two hours and has given us a memory we will have for the rest of our lives

Exceptional . The history and pomp and glorious architecture is not comparable with anything in any other countryEngland and London are truly amazingly special places and the culture and history of the Houses of Parliament are second to none
Great tour, however. It's great to see inside this place, however, contact your local MP, they will arrange to show you around and you also won't have to pay. Obviously need to book well in advance.

one of the highlights of London. My husband suggested that my daughter and I visit h of p when we were in London for a few days I have to say I'm glad he did because it was something we hadn't thought of doing and we really enjoyed it . We booked a guided tour and the lady who took us round was really good. Well worth booking to go

A hidden treasure.... I have only been the once but (assuming it is still) for a free admission its the best value historical London experience you will find. The architecture inside the building is stunning and you really get a sense of the history of the place of government. Must go again sometime.

A must-see on the tourist itinerary. Had a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to be taken on a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament one evening, followed by a drinks reception. It was an amazing experience to soak up the history and ceremony of the place, in the knowledge that this is the seat of power for the UK and has so much history behind it. Surprisingly the Commons Chamber and the Lords Chamber looked smaller than I expected but still impressive. The guide was very knowledgeable and could answer all questions asked of him - probably through years of experience.
