The tour took about an hour and a half, and covered everything from the thousand year-old Westminster Hall at the start of the tour all the way through the various parts of the House - the Norman Porch, Queen’s Robing Room, Royal Gallery, Prince’s Chamber, Lords Chamber, Moses Room Central Lobby, Members’ Lobby Aye Lobby, Commons Chamber St Stephen’s Hall....too much to take in, and fantastic history, architecture and ceremony. A word of caution - there is a fair amount of walking and standing involved although there are some areas to sit. Security (as you would expect) is tight and ID is required, with Airport-style security scanning (although much stricter than some airports I have encountered!)
Nice & ok.. Was interesting to see this famous building. While it wasn't anything spectacular i thought it was ok and still a recommended place to see.
lovely buildings. First time in London and loved to see all the things that I usually only get to see on TV. Would recommend adding this on your list if you go sightseeing in London.

Fantastic Cityscape at Sunset. These iconic buildings are a 'must see' when you're in London and if you want to visit Big Ben, just spend the extra few minutes soaking up the architecture of the Houses of Parliament. If you want a really great view, wait for sunset and hop across the river (just down from the London Eye), and you'll get a beautiful silhouette of this part of the city.

Impressive Day or Night.. A wonderful panorama and set against the Thames River, Westminster Bridge and many notable attractions. A very impressive building and a real spectacle. A stand out visit even if you do not go inside for a tour.
Tour of Parliament. When Parliament is not in session it is possible to take a guided tour. Guide was excellent and it was fascinating to see the rooms where Parliament meets.

Mother of Parliaments. This is a mindblowingly interesting tour when you can see the two houses and immerse yourself in British historyWe taught the world about democracy following on from the Grecian beginningsHard fought for principles are on show hereA wonderful educational attraction

Held the attention of my seven year old. Even excitement in the history to capture a seven year old's attention for the entire audio tour, beheading and dynamite helped. Then there is the Speaker of the common's toiler chair! My seven year old loved it enough to wrote about it into his journal. Well worth the time. (need to order tickets ahead.)
Takes forever to get in through security. I was late for a prearranged meeting. Security won't give preference even when you can show you are not just a casual visitor

Impressive - and hopefully here to stay. We visited the Palace of Westminster through an annua Reading University Alumni arrangement (Lord Carrington is former Vice-Chancellor of the university). There was a reception which allowed access to the River Terrace - brilliant views on a clear night, and then a guided tour of both Houses of Parliament, the lobbies and Westminster Hall (one of the largest surviving pillar-free medieval halls in Europe). Simply amazing, and the guides invited our questions and tried to answer them as best as they could. Our visit came an especially apt time as the Lords had just blocked a central piece of government legislation earlier the same week. Barry and Pugin really did do a brilliant job, but now the building is in need of a £5 billion restoration which poses major challenges to the nation. Still, it is surely a major highlight of any tourist's London itinerary, and should remain so, including of course the National Gallery which houses Turner's sketches of its predecessor burning down in 1834 (the resulting 2 oil canvases are sadly in Philadelphia and Cleveland).
Well Worth It. We took the audio device guided tour with was well done. Parliament reeks of history and the great political battles that took place there. A must see while in London.
Cultural experience I really enjoyed. Went for a charity event and a group visit at the building and learn about the history of the building and the England, which I love.

Afternoon in the Visitors' Gallery. We just happened upon this attraction and the Parliament was actually sitting. So we attended in the visitors' gallery and found it very interesting and entertaining.

Nice old entrance hall. It's good to see these famous buildings from the inside. I had expected a little more old history - although the old entrance hall is quite magnificent by itself. Picture taking must have been prohibited, since I didn't take any.
April 2014. Beautiful view from the London Eye. Other than that, we did not get the change to enter. Although we were very close to view, we never got to the buildings.

New leader of the house . Think it was May when new leader was installed. Visited London with caravan staying at Crystal Palace site. Walking past Houses of Parliament asked if any tours told we could go and sit in Strangers Galary. The experience was wonderful. Beautiful building so interesting to see our leaders at work. One of the highlights of the holiday.
Working visit. I recently went there for work, however it was the buildings which caught my attention, and have had an amazing effect on me. The history of these grand old buildings is amazing.

awesome to see such a grand place - shame about the occupants !!. when worth a visit most of the bus tours pass right past it with good commentary -
right next to big ben and downing street as well as a bonus !

The tour is interesting. Visited the Houses of Parliament and we had booked a tour. This was good as you got to see the House of Lords and the House of Commons plus many other areas of the Houses of Parliament. Good for a perspective and appreciation of how we have moved through history to present day.

Houses of Parliament. What a wonderful building absolutely spectacular with so much architecture to enjoy fabulous to be in the Commons and Lords and get a feel for goes on there a real treat for s day out x

The most beautiful architecture!. It is so hard to imagine what an undertaking it was to build this spectacular building...there is so much detail in this building you can hardly take it all in...a MUST SEE!

A guided tour. We took a 'paid for' guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, this was an excellent tour.
Our guide was very informative and knowledgeable and we got great pleasure from the way Philip Wigan delivered his narrative and guided us around.

history but alive. Each time I go, I am in awe. just walking along the sorridors where so many famous feet have trodden is enough. Whatever your political views are, this (and the other place) are a must see.

Go and see debates. Having worked here, I've learned more of Parliament than the average member of the public and the place is steeped in fascinating historical stories, even for non-historians like me. I can thoroughly recommend the tours or sitting in on an actual debate. Parts of the estate are a thousand years old. Other parts, you can see bomb and shrapnel damage (honourable scars) from. There's almost always some sort of political/rights related protest going on which is worth seeing.

Visiting Palace of Westminster. This is a great experience & takes about 90 mins min enjoyed Westminster hall where monarchs lie in state & enjoyed seeing where prime ministers questions takes place - booked online before going

Do visit. The architecture impresses as soon as you see it, well worth a visit.Plenty of areas outside to walk and marvel.The green where media interviews are done is easily accessible and in the past we have done the tours of both houses and also had tea on the terrace, both great experiences

we really enjoyed the impressive Houses of Parliament. all the area is beautiful to walk around this area in London my family and I love to walk in this are is a fantastic place and lovely see all this monuments around

The audit tour . The tour start at 9:20, very user friendly, all the staffs are helpful and make sure you wouldn't get lost. However, the coffee shop opens at 10 am I was so desperately needed a drink of water...I will go back again for the guided tour for sure. This is a place everyone should visit at least once! I have been there before during the open house 2015, fantastic.

impressive building, great walking area. We are walkers, and we really enjoyed the impressive Houses of Parliament, as well as the general Thames area. We were able to overhear some of the political deal-making, and it was clear that many of the break-takers were involved in government positions. At this time the war memorials were being observed, with public lawns filled with crosses with the names of fallen soldiers.
Audio tour is great!. Loved the Houses of Parliament. It was very easy to use the audio tour. Audio tour was clear and informative. We enjoyed going at our own pace.

A unique glimpse into the political process. During an excellent tour, we walked through the very rooms where the UK's MPs debate and propose laws. A spirit of order pervades this place, as well as openness - the debates are recorded and televised. A sad contrast to other countries, where politicians more often than not have a hostile attitude to the public peering into their activities.

A London Icon. The houses of parliament are one of the most iconic places in London. They are a great place to go and visit. You can combine it with a boat ride on the Thames - where you get to see them from all angles or the open top buses if you don't fancy walking!

Very interesting history and pegeantry. We had the luck of having one of the peers in the House of Lords as a friend. He took us around and we even managed to get to rooms that are normally not open to the public. The robing room where the Queen prepares herself before addressing Parliament was particularly interesting because of what goes on there. The throne dates back to Queen Victoria's days and one can imagine her size given the throne's size. This is one place not to be missed in London.

An experience you must have. I went there last week as one of my friends who lives in London for about 40 years now, had an invitation to visit Houses of Parliament. I am not sure how it works with school excursions, but as I understood you actually must have an invitation from one of the members in order to visit House of Parliament. We also saw house of lords, which was great.
A unique insight into the workings of British politics.. Amazing to visit this beautiful and historical site and to sit in the public gallery and observe democracy working before your eyes.
Very Impressive. Booked the audio tour and was not disappointed. Able to walk through the Lords and the commons at your own pace. Stacked with history and helpful staff are on hand for any questions.

Fantastic Visit. Very much enjoyed the tour of parliament, very informative and easy to book on. Would highly recommend to book in advance for Saturdays. Ask for Liz, a very helpful and delightful person

Caravan club award ceremony. We attended an awards ceremony at the houses of parliament and were then taken on a tour of the whole place by one of the mps. It is an amazing building with fantastic detailing where ever you look. Well worth spending a few hours to explore.
Excellent - very interesting!. Booked ahead for a guided tour - well worth it. Building and history very interesting, guide, Sarah, was very knowledgeable. The whole family really enjoyed our visit.

If you can book it - take your business function there and WOW your contacts and yourself. My firm was 100 years old in 2015 - none of us were there for its birth I hasten to add. We managed to book the space on the river front at the House of Commons for a party (capacity 200) and we invited 500 as obviously 2/3rds either never reply or are unavailable - within ten days we were overbooked WHOOPS. We managed to book 7 days later same time same place and we ran two back to back centenary parties. The building is impressive, the views to die for, the food fine, the drinks decent and the price is probably cheaper than a similar space commercially nearby.If you can get it - go for it. (But be a bit discerning in dispatching invitations as take up will be above your normal expectations, if our experience is anything to go by.)

An excellent day spent there!. The cafeteria is amazing u must stay for coffee n a desert. the visit was very informative and as usual bot only to you get guided through the palace on how it was built and decorated but actually how it is used and by whom exactly which was extremely informative!

Absolutely fascinating and informative tour not to be missed!. One of our favorite tours in London, the Parliament buildings are filled with history and fascinating. Our guide was excellent, well informed and paced the group well so we could always hear and ask any questions it is a tour that we would do again – it is impossible to absorb all the history!

Interesting Experience. My husband and I lived in London in the early 1990s, and we'd never visited the Houses of Parliament while Parliament was in session until this past June. Very interesting experience that shows politics are quite the same everywhere!
Great Historical Tour. We had a great tour of the houses of parliament - well worth while as the guides are so knowledgeable and so much history has taken place in the houses.
Awesome view. I always dreamed to see this place and seasoned it with chillsand drink coffee and enjoy the landscape of good vibrations. You have to see this place!!!

Oh England, How Do I Love Thee?. A long time ago as a child, I saw the Houses of Parliament sculptured out of sugar. The white sugar structure was magical. Years later at a store, I saw a 3D puzzle of the Houses of Parliament constructed from pieces of transparent plastic. It seemed complicated.Today, I see the Houses of Parliament made of brick and mortar. It looks unreal with every inch cut, crafted, chiseled, and etched as it stands majestically on the Thames River. What a sight to behold. Unsurpassed beauty. Exquisite.I slowly walk around the entire perimeter soaking and savoring every detail of the House. I spend hours committing to memory the wondrous beauty. I feel utterly privileged. I do not want to forget this moment. It will comfort me when I am old and no longer mobile. My eyes see. My hands touch. My mind absorbs. Yet, it all seems imaginary. How can man create something this beautiful? How can a nation capable of such a spectacular and glorious imagination lose her empire?

A must see while in LOndon. The Houses of Parliament are also in the same area as Big Ben and the London Eye. If you are going to see one, you are going to see all of them and I suggest you do! They do offer a tour and I would suggest taking it. To see old London up close and personnel in side is a win win.

Well worth the time to take the Guided Tour!. Based on a friend's recommendation, we signed up for the fully guided tour (versus just doing the audio tour). Turned out to be one of the highlights of our visit to London! It's so nice to get insider information and be able to ask questions about anything you see. The interactive aspect of the guided tour is so much better than just the audio tour, plus you can always go back inside and linger over areas that you may not have been able to linger over in order to keep up with the tour.
Heritage. I suppose that everyone should visit this institution once in their lifetime and watch the wheels of democracy turning (grindingly slowly at times!).

London weekend. The Houses of Parliament & Big Ben are a must if you visit London. You must also try to get on the London Eye! If you can get there early enough you can get a cheaper deal and come back for another ride when the lights are on and the sun has gone down. The city looks amazing at night. It all seems to come to life.
Just stunning. Took a guided tour and learned so much. Just amazing to be so close up to where our laws are made. The buildings are just wonderful
Really? How could this be bad?. The place is shockingly beautiful and the tour is fascinating. You will come out with at least a half dozen great stories.

Stunning building. Worth viewing up close with a walk around the outside, if you lucky enough to get the opportunity go inside. Also go to the other side of the Thames to get a better view, even better at night all lit up

Interesting. My husband is the history buff in the family but I went along anyway- however I found the Audio Tour quite fascinating and to stand in the House of Commons where laws are passed was pretty cool!
beautiful. we didn't go in for a tour but even from the outside it was impressive and beautiful. The amount of work to create this building is phenominal!

Very well presented tour of a very historical place. There's a lot to see and choosing between a live tour & an audio guide when you book on line is difficult. All we can say is that our observation was that the live tour takes you through pretty rapidly but on the snipets we heard, gives you a bit more of a colourful commentary than does the audio guide. We actually paused our informative audio guide to listen to whatever live tour was in the room when we arrived there, then resumed the audio guide to see things in more detail. This worked well and gave us something of both commentaries. Note that the signs at the very beginning of the tour (before & after security) saying photos are prohibited are actually misleading, as photos ARE permitted inside Westminster Hall, and the ban only starts when you leave the hall.Book online well ahead as tours occur only each Saturday and they fill up as a consequence.

A really interesting and awe inspiring trip. We managed to get last minute tickets for a guided tour, a truly interesting and awe inspiring visit from seeing both the the House of Commons and House of Lords to the beautiful exhibition of the suffragettes. The staff are very knowledgeable and quite happy to answer questions and also expand on the standard tour patter. We were amazed by the tiny post office and the beauty of the building. A trip worth making !
Organise through your MP for free. Don't pay for a tour, instead contact your local MP for a free personal guided tour. It's a fascinating place to visit.

Disappointing customer service. If you're I'll try and be ill with 24hrs notice. I booked a special Sufragette tour for myself and my partner and her mother. The tour was expensive at £25 each but was going to be the highlight of my mother in law's visit from New Zealand. Unfortunately on the day of the morning of the tour she had to be taken into hospital. While my partner went with her I rang the Visit Parliament centre - with 3 hrs notice - in the hope that they might be able to re-use the tickets and perhaps allow us the opportunity to reschedule. At first the indications were positive - a possible refund - circumstances beyond our control - or a possible credit/rebook. But - a week later and after having to chase up on promises of a response never received - I'm told 'there's nothing we can do'. No good will, not even a partial credit for another standard cheaper tour. Shame on you Visit Parliament.

Expensive Small Cream tea. Booked a cream tea at the houses of Parliament. It was a nice day and the location was good. You have tea in the large gazebo next to the river. The views are great but that's where it ends. They have a strange way of taking you to the tea area which means all dinners leave in a large party and are seated at once - a recipe for disaster! This means the waiting staff have a very large number to serve during the hour slot you have booked. The cream tea was very nicely presented and looked great but the portions are VERY small to say the least. You do NOT get your tea refilled and they use TEA BAGS !!! and have limited choice of teas. We have done many cream teas in London and this was both VERY expensive and disappoint especially the use of tea bags at this level of cost. Service was POOR as we were one of the last to be seated and therefore the last to be served. Most people spent less than 30 mins in the tea room which reflect the quality of the offering :-(I would recommend you enjoyed a trip around the House to see the history but go elsewhere for a cream tea.

Witnessing history first hand touring the Houses of Parliament. Sometimes it pays to be lucky and on this occasion this was our lot as we were given an opportunity to witness democracy in action. We undertook an escorted tour of the Houses of Parliament and it was most impressive. Our guide was personable and exhibited a fine sense of humor as we trekked through the buildings and listened to accounts of the historical significance of so many of the features that we were seeing first hand. The buildings are historic and most impressive with their stunning stained-glass windows, wood-paneled meeting rooms and vaulted ceilings. Highly recommended.

Brilliant. We took our two grand children, 9 and 8, on an audio tour and were very pleased we did. Firstly they were given a children's audio commentary and secondly it was well done and interesting. We hadn't expected to be allowed such access. To be in the actual chambers of the Lords and the Commons was amazing and our 8 year old grandson was 'blown away' by the gold throne! No minuses just pluses a tour that everyone should do.

Excellent. Must book on Internet prior to your visit it saves waiting in a long queue. Well organised and staff very helpful. Easy to follow Audio guide. Interesting to see the Lords Chamber and Commons Chamber.
Fascinating visit. Not something we would normally choose to do, but we thoroughly enjoyed our visit. It was very informative and fascinating to see and learn all about the way Parliament works.
weekend in the smoke. did not realise how close all these historic buildings are together you can walk from one to another in a matter of minutes
Great Visit. Was well worth the stop, seeing the history and architecture. Was a little disappointed we couldn't take photos.

Fascinating 75 minute tour. Were shown round in a group of 10 which was ideal as we could all ask questions. Guide was very knowledgeable and involved the children (all of whom has special needs) in the tour. Would love the tour to be longer as the place has a fascinating history. Met local MP in entrance hall as he had arranged tour. It's free if your MP arranges it.. Leave 15 minutes to get through security before the actual start time of your tour, although even though we were 5 minutes late, they still let us do the tour.
Beautiful walk. We visited the Houses of Parliament while we were walking around. We did not go inside but it was a great walking trip.

House of Lords. Last Wednesday we were part of a group that was entertained to a drinks reception in the River Room and guided on a walking tour of parts of the Houses of Parliament open to the public. The building is fascinating and the guides seem to know the history; but, sadly, somewhat cynically. After the tour we sat in the Strangers Gallery of the House of Lords and listened to part of the debate on English Votes for English Laws. Most of the speakers were Scottish Lords! This is certainly a place to be visited sooner in one's life rather than later.

Even more interesting than I expected!. As a politics graduate it took me over 15 years of living in London to get round to the Houses of Parliament. I visited during the anniversary of Magna Carta so there was even more historical significance than usual. I took my mother on a standard tour of both Houses and for tea. We both learnt a lot and found a few lesser known facts too.Next I plan to make it to Prime Minsters question time to see politics in action!!!
Lesson in Politics, walk in history... Enjoyable visit, security lines move quickly. Read up before you visit so you know what you are seeing. Great to see interaction of politicians.

What an amazing building. We were lucky enough to get an escorted tour of the HoP and it was fantastic. The building is stunning with a wealth of architectural features, works of art and history. The House of Commons itself seemed too small to swallow 650 MPs but it works. similarly the House of Lords seemed small too. A great mix of modern technology, opulence and tradition. Well worth a visit if you get the chance. An opportunity to see democracy at work.

as i think. nice experience ..
very beautiful and historic building ,,,it is near Victoria station
and Thames River
take the walk. the best thing to do is to take the walk and see everything that comes in the way.i really am glad that i walked at my own pace and saw evrything

At the heart of democracy. Surveyed the home of democracy and which turned out to be a busy day for important events . Managed to get pictures of the houses of parliament ,Big Ben ,Parliament square and travelled up parliament street including outside downing street .

Can't miss it!. Don't bother making a special trip... you'll pass the Houses of Parliament on almost every tour you take of London. Hop on a city bus for a self-guided tour and pass by for some great photo-ops.

Tour of the Houses of Parliament. To have this tour you need to book in advance (easy steps on their website). I wish I had done this tour when I was a teenager instead of as a pensioner. I found it totally educational and informative. I now view the TV coverage of any events in any of the Chambers in quite a different way than ever before.

Worth a Visit. I took the audio tour as I went in the summer recess so this was the only tour available. It was really interesting to see inside, and how small the House of Commons actually is. You can only take photos of the Westminster Hall inside. There is a shop and café. They advertised WiFi in the café but it didn't work, due to the thickness of the walls. The café didn't open till about 10.
Pure Hisdtory. I went to a travel dinner in one of the rooms past speakers cornerhas cocktails over looking the Thames fantastic.

Prime Ministers Questions. Very very interesting, you watch the speaker go into the House in small procession and then see all the MP's in action. David Cameron and Jeremy Corbin were both there when we visited and it was fascinating.
An Interesting Afternoon.. Had a guided tour around parliament, really informative and interesting and gave a real insight into how parliament works. Would highly recommend a visit!!

Great tour. Visited today thanks to our MP. A very informative and fun tour of one of the country's most iconic buildings. My son and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Shame you cannot take photographs but I can see why.
Stunning. It's surreal every time I see it in person! A beautiful sight and a free photo op! Be sure to get a picture from the opposite side of the Thames!
Watch parliament debates and see the house that an Empire built. We were there while parliament was in session and were able to visit the various rooms and hall ways.

The best guided tour I have been on. We paid for the guided tour rather than the audio guide and our guide, Justin, was a very personable and humorous guide who not only knew his history but added some context for the modern parliament including for the foreign visitors amongst us. Aside from the guide, this is a stupendous and fabulous building which is beautiful and ornate and yet still the home of the mother of all parliaments. Also a nice insight for a brit into the working life of our elected disrepresentatives
Iconic. Iconic and absolutely beautiful building. This is a must when in London to see were the UK has been governed for hundreds of years.

Dauntingly historic. The history of this place is obvious from all sides and you get the acute sense of being in an historic and important place. The palace is fantastically grand and yet has the feel of a working place. Worth a visit and definitely worth going to see a debate in the commons chamber. It is wonderful to witness the democratic process in action!

Very cool. I opted for the audio tour and am glad I did so. It allowed me to go at my own pace and listen to more info as I wanted to. Plus when I stood next to guided tour groups sometimes I just turned off my audio and listed to what they had - so I got the best of both worlds. Good history info and it's cool to go into the chambers and stand in spots you've seen on TV for years.

Take the Guided Tour. Took the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. It was a great experience. The guide was great and provided background on the building and on how Parliament functions. It was very informative and enjoyable. I highly recommend it.

An incredible iconic historical experience. The tour guide was very informative and had lots of interesting stories. The beauty of the architecture and detail was breathtaking. It's amazing how well it's been kept, you wouldn't believe the age. It was very interesting sitting in on a session in the House of Commons. Overall an incredible experience. I recommend as one of your must see items on your London itinerary.

One of the greatest sights to see in London. The home of democracy, one cannot be not inspired by this great place, I have visited the Palace of Westminster numerous time, and am in continuous awe of this great place to visit, I would recommend to any one who visits, to get s guided tour, I cannot recommend this place enough.
One of the must-sees in London. Westminister is one of the most beautiful places in London. It's an architectural masterpiece. Wear comfortable shoes :)
GREAT VIEWS. Being in London and seeing all the diffrent places is worth viewing i loved just seeing and being outside the place love to visit it again

Fantastic self-guided tour. Easy to book online and when I arrived for the tour the staff printed off my ticket for me. You have the option of a guided tour or a self-guided tour with headphones. I would say this is the best option as you can go at your own pace and choose which language. The building is incredible with stunning stained-glass windows, wood-panelled lobbies and vaulted ceilings. In addition to the famous House of Commons and the House of Lords, there are many other areas to explore. Westminster Hall makes for an impressive start to the tour. St Stephen's Hall, where the Commons uses to meet and where William Wilberforce pleaded for the abolition of the slave trade, is ornate and beautiful. The octagonal Central Lobby is exquisite and there is even a small post office inside.The tour is available on Saturdays throughout the year and on recess. I would certainly recommend it.

Visit to Houses of Parliament. I had an audio tour of the Houses of Parliament with friends. I found the tour interesting and informative. The audio tour provide me with all the details of history of the building along with adequate information about the style and decor of the various rooms. I did find meeting groups with the tour guides off putting as frequently met groups who just surged through and on two occasions almost knocked myself and a friend down. They guided tour groups appear to feel they have total right to surge forward at will. This aside I did enjoy the visit. Afterwards we visited the coffee shop - the queue was quite long and the wait for coffees was quite long. I think this was due to a limited space as it may be better to serve the coffees in a different place rather than at the till. Choice of food was adequate and the price was ok too. The gift shop was very limited - certainly I was not encouraged to buy anything but this may depend on the "tourist"

One of the most important buildings in Britain. The Houses of Parliament are a must see in London. They are the origin of the Westminster system of government that is used across the world.I thoroughly recommend the guided tour - we had a lovely lady called Vannine who knew everything about the place and presented it in the most engaging and enthusiastic manner. They limit the size of the tour groups as well which makes it easier to enjoy the experience.Every room is full of history. Budget for around three hours - don't miss this place.

The great image of London . This is great to see with your own eyes. The outside of the building is such a terrific sight alongside the river. Even if you are not interested in politics- you will be able to appreciate the marvellous building and the view.

AWESOME Tour. We booked the first guided tour on a Saturday morning, had a fantastic, well informed guide that not only shared much of the history but also how parliament works. We were able to ask questions and overall would highly recommend a guided tour over an audio self paced tour, it is just not the same. This tour starts with getting through security that is efficient and friendly. You're provided a guest pass and make your way in. Our guide met us and at first it seemed like we were just moving too fast but he did tell us we would return through the same areas but we were literally the first group in. There is amazing history and information about the architecture while sharing how Parliament works. I highly recommend this tour for those that enjoy history, government, architecture and want to experience British political culture as well as those that enjoy just learning something they may not otherwise know. At the end there is a café, gift shop, toilets and upon exit you return your pass. Overall a great tour, we booked ahead online as we wanted to ensure we took a guided tour, it is well worth booking in advance and paying a bit more.

Grand. Looking up at the houses of parliament you can see how important the building is. It is so big, so grand and majestic. The best views of the houses of parliament are from the London Eye, however if you cross the river you can get stunning photos from the riverbank.

Take the guided tour. You have 2 options for the Houses of Parliament tour, you can go with a human guide or an audio guide. I would 100% recommend the human guide. Our guide gave us great insights and answered any questions we had.
Great to see. This is a great way to see where our government works. You need to get your MP or a member of the House of Lords to give you a tour unless you go when they are in recess.

A hitch hikers guide to British democracy.. An absolute must, but make sure you go via your MP or you will have to pay quite a lot. You can only go when it is in recess or on a Saturday if during session.

Full of history!. We managed to get in to this place for free. If the MP's are having a debate during the week, you are able to see the inside- free. The building has full of history but some part of the building requires renovation.The most beautiful part I saw is the house of the lords. It was a magnificent design. House of parliament is ok. Its is covered by glass for MP's protection. Mobile or cameras are strictly prohibited.I really would like to see this place again.Thank you.

Worth booking the tour guide. We're both interested in politics, but still learned huge amounts on this great tour of the Houses during the recess. The architecture is truly incredible, and it's a privilege to have seen it up close personal, especially at a time when the future of the building is uncertain and up for discussion. The guide was fantastic in accounting for varying knowledge of parliamentary history, and pacing the tour. All in all, a valuable few hours.

A must!. We scheduled out your before we flew to London. We wanted to visit since we are American and wanted to see where our idea of congress came from. I know, a bit nerdy, but hey!It was a great tour, not only is be building beautifully decorated but it was a great tour. We opted for the self guided tour with audio and it had a good amount of detail. I believe we did the tour of the wing in about 3 hours. But we would def come back to do it again.
Iconic. One of London's symbolic architectural gems, the building is spectacular inside and out. Incredible historic events have transpired here, a must-see in London.

Best part of a 2-week trip. The tour (only Sat. and Sundays) was fabulous; I got the ticket months in advance. I learned so much about the parliamentary form of government and how the chambers evolved over time. The Victorian buildings are gorgeous, especially House of Lords (of course). Tour guide was excellent. Plan for this.

Fantastic!. From the moment we arrived to the moment we left we were enthralled. The functions carried out here and it's history are amazing and made me proud to be . Our tour was superb and extremely informative. Our guide was very knowledgeable and humorous with it.We stayed in the Palace of Westminster after our tour and observed both the House of Commons and the House of Lords from the public gallery.If you are a UK citizen and you are planning this trip in advance you can email your local Member of Parliament and ask them to organise a tour for you.

You could feel the history oozing out of it. We visited to see our MP and the whole experience was a delight. The halls and corridors are filled with art and sculpture of its history. All the staff were polite and professional. The Westminster Hall is full of history and is older than many countries. We sat through Prime Ministers questions which was busy and fun, Mr Cameron was on top form.

Wow!. These buildings are amazing. So beautiful. I only saw them from the outside, but it was still great. There are the typical guards on horses outside and you caboose for a photo next to them. While we were there we saw some sort of changing of the guards(I think). Really cool Place.

Watching law and history in the making. As a disclaimer, even though politicians will be the death of us, law/government is a passion of mine. Free to go in and watch and there's a post office where you can mail something from "The House of Parliament". You go in, check everything at the entrance point (cell phone, keys, purse, etc) and go and sit quietly to observe. I didn't get any pictures of the actual parliament but a few on the way in.
Get the private tour!. It was a very informative, interesting tour of Parliament. Everyone should take a moment to see this!

One of the best tours we did in London. Visiting Westminster was a fascinating experience. It's incredible how much access you get to such world-famous rooms. You can literally stand in the same spot as the Prime Minister in the House of Commons, and you can explore the backbencher in that chamber as well as the Lords. It's kind of silly that they don't allow photography (so that means discretion is in order!).

Just Beautiful. Wee visited the Houses of Parliament on a weekend visit to London , I didn't realise what a Beautiful building it is as seeing it on tv doesn't show the full beauty of the building .i would love to visit again .
Kind of disappointed. We tried a few times to get in and finally did and it was quite a disappointment. I wouldn't spend the time unless you are also going into the debating rooms.

Best seen from the London Eye. Did not take a tour into the houses of Parliament - not sure there is such a thing but the view of it in its entirety is spectacular from the London Eye. I took multitude of pictures from the Eye and each one looked picture perfect!

Exquisite experience, the guided tour is a must. The building itself is absolutely a piece of gem! And the guided tour where you would learn so much about how the parliament works made the whole tour much more fun and knowledgeable. Don't miss it.
Unexpectedly great visit. I passed by the palace of Westminster 100's of times; now was the time to visit and I was amazed. Great guides give excellent explanations about function and history.

parliament tip. We sat in on parliament. the days they are in debate you cannot tour the house of parliament. as a tip go to the visitor entrance and ask to it in. they will escort you to a viewing area. you can see a little bit inside and witness real parliament in action!

Majestic and Palatial. A visit is a must, simply stunning building and décor!! so much to see and find out about this Palace.It was a lot larger than I imagined lots of walking involved but worth every minute, TV coverage misses out so much from paintings to statues, We had champagne afternoon tea overlooking the Thames it was a beautiful day, would definitely recommend this day out. Suitable for everyone ,im sure all will enjoy.

Sightseeing. When in London, you must visit the Iconic Houses of Parliament and get a photograph in front of this British Landmark. Its always very busy with tourists in this area as there is a lot of Landmarks close to one another.
Grab a chance. Grab a chance when you are in london. Love every single serenity. The building was gorgeous. Worth to visit anyway

An interesting visit. We popped in here on spec just to see what it was like. There was a "health questions" session on in the House Of Commons which we caught some of. It is actually quite interesting to see how it all goes on, and how patronising our MP's really are to each other !
Dont miss it!. Its so magnificent. The building is so huge and beautiful. It might be packed in the weekend but its still worth the time.

Great visit.. Loved every minute of my tour. Chose the audio tour, could stop and start it at any time and more importantly stop for a breather from time to time. The audio guide is very good and gives you more than enough information. The tour is numbered in a set sequence, so you can't go wrong. And you are given a paper guide too, which tells you where you can sit down etc. The tour takes a good 1.5 hours with a few sit downs along the way. When I went, it was quiet and there was no queue or waiting time or queue at security. I had prepaid for my tickets online, which is advisable, printed off at home and turned up. You pick the time you want. This means you can go straight to the entrance and you are guaranteed entry. I also went when parliament was in recess, this is the best time to go, as you can see everything including the lords and commons chambers, you won't be able to go into these if the house is sitting of if you get a tour through your MP. Only negative £18 a bit steep for audio tour, £25 for tour with tour guide. I have been to a few other parliaments in Europe and it cost me nothing.

Brilliant and educational!. We went on the Audio Guided tour and found the whole tour from the start to the finish fascinating. While I love seeing places like this that you always see on TV, it was great to learn more about the history of the building and all the amazing things that have happened there. Great value for money!

Geat tour!. I've been to London over a dozen times but never visited the Houses of Parliament and it was well worth the visit. There's great historical value but also provides a view into the UK government today. Very interesting and highly recommended.

Lots history!. I did the audio tour, it let me go at my own pace and linger a little longer at different places and there is always someone around to answer any question. It was really interesting and enlightening. We all have seen the House of Commons and the House of Lords on TV but being there was really fun and actually walk on those hall, great!
Another classic. Beautiful, iconic public building. A must see. Displays UK once amazing wealth.It is a shame that so many tories reside inside.

Magnificent Looking. We went around the area many times but never went inside (it was never really in our plans because we have a baby with us). It really looks magnificent from the outlook and we learnt a little about the building during our river cruise tour. Go ahead for the tour and take a look inside. Any weekday should be good except on weekend or holiday peak period(s). The area was swamped over the weekend and we can only imagine how the crowd must have been on the inside.

Fascinating for all ages - do not miss!. We visited twice- once with a guide (in English) and once with the audio-guide and two kids. Both visits were delightful and enlightening. We were all fascinated by the history of the Palace and the various aspects of the British Parliament. Amazingly, seeing 'the seats', 'left' and 'right' and two 'houses' made the abstract ideas much more accessible to our kids and allowed for an interesting discussion on various forms of government (we're not British). We also used YouTube videos to show them the Houses in action.So make your reservations in advance, allow for 1-2 hours, depending on the type of visit you chose and ENJOY.I highly recommend combining the visit with a walk up Whitehall St., through 10 Downing St., the pubs etc. up to Buckingham Palace. I think it allows for a deeper experience of the British government.

Great tour!. Seeing all the rooms inside was interesting, but the history and tradition is what makes the tour most fascinating. Recommended both for visitors and even locals - my boyfriend is English and has lived in London for a decade but never been. We went with my parents visiting from Canada, and we all loved it.

Superb! By far the best attraction in London! . Free! Easy to arrange through your MP (although allow plenty of time to do it)
Fascinating insight into the history of the U.K. Parliament, the history and traditions behind it, but also how it works now and fits into modern society.
A must for anyone with even the smallest interest in politics.

Awesome experience of the wheels turning in the heart of our democratic country. Like many people we have seen images of the House of Commons on TV and in pictures but we had a strange desire to see it for real. Our local MP Ann Milton was contacted about a visit to the public gallery of the House of Commons and a guided tour of the whole Palace of Westminster. Through her office we arranged a morning to view the action in the House and a full personal tour of the Houses of Parliament in the afternoon.Although the subject of debate was not over exciting watching the process was. The polite terms of address - The Honourable Member - and the ordered process of speaking was strangely pleasant. The casual seating positions, and the apparent slumping to one side as if asleep but was to help the slightly hard of hearing put their ear nearer to the installed small speakers in the seats, gave the impression of relaxed attention to the processes. However it was clear that there was full attention to the procedure when an MP (no names) sought permission to speak and express a very firm opinion to what had been previously said. I would urge you to make the effort to experience this especially with children and young people to experience the democratic process first hand

Terrific Tour. We had the most fantastic tour of the Houses of Parliament which lasted 90 minutes. Our tour guide was knowledgeable and quirky with a great sense of humour. I would thoroughly recommend this tour to anyone as it is an eccentric piece of British history. We had a lovely tea at the cafe located near the exit. Enjoy your visit!!!

Nice and historic. Tour guide was very knowledgeable and passionate about the history of the building. Got to see Caroline Lucas. Would go again, but not on a Wednesday due to the prime minister question time - we had to leave early.

A bug history in unvail. I always saw the Big Ben Pictures in Movie and then the Prime Minister's Speech in TV. Seeing all the thing with your own eyes and then feeling like yes, this is what happens on a daily course, its a awesome feeling. The chair where Queen sits and the entire medieval architecture and the rich history is overwhelming. One should visit once and don't forget to get the audio guided tour. It talks a lot.They won't allow you to take pictures at the most crucial portions but its ok. You will have a memory of a lifetime don't worry.Happy Experiencing Life...!!!

Great tour. This is something I always wanted to do in London after being in the city for almost 10 years. When I finally did it I was really pleased. The tour guides are very knowledgeable and explain really well both the historic details of the venue as well as some political "behind the scenes" stories. It is a fun and interesting experiences.Truly recommended.

London Week-end. I had already booked a tour of the Houses of Parliament before our trip which was very easy. we did the 1/12hour guided tour and the knowledge of our guide was excellent you get an opportunity to visit places you would not see on your own, very interesting this is something everyone should do. The café although small was very good and good value for London. After the tour I had booked afternoon tea in the Members Pavilion over looking the Thames such a lovely experience, add this to your itinerary.

Like being on a movie set. A great way to bring history to life without the kids realising it! Suitable for teens and adults the visit explains the history and workings of the House of Commons and the House of Lords. A truly remarkable building and you'll recognise from from movies such as Sherlock Holmes to Made in Dagenham - and many in between.

Goverment at Work. As a polical junkie this is a must tour. Historical building with implications impacting today's world. Defiantly sign up for the guide tour that last for only 1 1/2 hours. You can but on line.
Excellent. Great couple of hours spent here with really interesting tour guide. Lots of history, great art and politics. Definitely worth a visit. Timed tickets mean you don't have to queue
Tour with tea with our MP. Excellent tour given by Bob who supports our MP. Very informative, and quite a comprehensive tour, finished up with tea with Stephen Metcalfe

A lot to take in. We had the guided tour and it was well worth the money. The tour lasted about two and a half hours and was full of information. I think you need to have a little information about the monarchy, parliament and kings and queens of England to get the most out of this tour. The rooms are very ornate. I think you would get the most out of this tour if you know your history.
full of history. most visit. full of history and culture. The tour guides are great and really get the kids involved. well worth the visit.
Must Visit. A first trip to London requires a visit to the major sites. This building is amazing. Definitely worth strolling along the river to have a look.

Great place to keep an eye on tourist activity. Furiously snapping pictures enviously of our democratic institutions. For those who wish to do so, this is the centre of huge history with big ben, Westminster cathedral, and Buckingham Palace, the river and much more all very close.
A day out with friends. We wrote to our MP and organised a tour we had a great day the tour is well worth while the history we had a lovely guide we would visit again we enjoyed the day

An evening tour is best. We toured the Houses of Parliament at night and were glad we made the effort. There is more to see in the evening and the atmosphere is better because of the effect of the lighting. Our package included drinks and elegant eats in the Terrace Lounge with outdoor tables overlooking the Thames - amazing!

A place of historic importance. Guided tours include the route taken by the Queen at State Opening of Parliament; from the Queen’s Robing Room, through the Royal Gallery and into the majestic Lords Chamber.There are tours that move on through Central Lobby, Members Lobby and one of the voting lobbies before entering the Commons Chamber, scene of many lively debates. The Commons Chamber is lot smaller than you think!Passing through St Stephen’s Hall, tours end in 900 year old Westminster Hall where Guy Fawkes was tried and where Nelson Mandela addressed Parliament in more recent years.Tours are available in many languages.

A must see. I have seen this building both from the outside and the inside. I went there in 2013 as a tourist and got some love photos of this and big Ben. Then in October 2015 I went there for a showcase of a program I had. been working on. For any tourist or resident of the UK this is a must see on your way around London.

Must visit!. We took a guided tour and our guide was very enthusiastic, showed as both Houses and explained everything in detail. It was a very uplifting and inspiring to walk through the corridors which hold so much history!Westminster parliament is open for pubic on Saturdays and during the year when the the parliament is on Holiday. You can take audio guide or a guided tour, which is available in many languages. Must book in advance online.
Visit if you get a chance. We were able to visit as parliament was not in session. Did the audio tour and it was very educational
fun. It is is monument a landmark and worth a visit a many who visit uk do. I didn venture inside but even from out it is beautiful

Unique building. We had a guided tour, led by one of London's very experienced Blue Badge Guides. The tour covers Westminster Hall, part of the original building, and the newer House of Lords and House of Commons. So interesting to see places that look so familiar yet have only previously been seen on television news programmes. The tour lasted approximately 1hour 45minutes and the time went so quickly as we were totally absorbed in learning about the processes and protocols of Parliament. We finished our tour with a pre-booked afternoon tea on The Terrace, an event well worth setting aside time for. Delicious sandwiches, scones and cakes all beautifully presented.
House of Lords is the stand out. I have seen so much of the lower house in news stories and was completely gob smacked by the beauty of the upper house.

Absolutely fascinating. We wrote to our MP and organised a tour of the Palace of Westminster. So worth while, if you are interested in history, even if you are not interested in politics, it make a fascinating trip, we even listened to a debate in the House of Commons.
Really interesting tour. A really interesting tour, the guide was knowledgable and there was so much to see.Lovely paintings and sculptures.
Can only visit the Public Gallery. As we are not UK residents, we were not able to take a tour of the House of Parliament, though were permitted to go into the Public Gallery

Very Majestic. We did an audio tour through the Houses of Parliament on a Saturday and were truly amazed. So much history to see and hear about. We were able to walk through both houses in our own time. We booked on line.

A must see!!! Houses of Parliament, Big Ben & West Minister Abbey all together!. Plan a day to go to visit Houses of Parliament, Big Ben, West Minister Abbey & the London Eye as they are all in the same area of London. Guided tours are available at the Houses of Parliament. Make sure you walk onto Westminister Bridge to take some fabulous pics of Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament!

What an experience!!!. Visited with teenage daughters and went for the audio tour. Didn't know what to expect and wondered if it would be too high brow for us but OMG, it was brilliant! Really interesting and was awesome to be inside the House of Commons standing next to Cam the Man's seat. Dead cheap to do this tour and wouldn't hesitate to recommend - everybody should do this at some point in their life.

Good to see. We passed here and seen the guards outside which wad really nice, the police at the gates of bleb gates was funny
Nothing to go mad about
Great. Awesome historical location in London. Great spot close to other attractions. Very busy location, go early or later on in the day.
Very Interesting. We chose the audio tour rather than guided and found this great because you can do it at your own pace.

Wow, Wow. My view of this great building was from the ground and i was impressed, but later saw it from the Thames and i was even more impressed. A great building that is recognised all over the world. I was blessed to see it in real life.

Guided tour is invaluable. Pre-booked on line, this tour was worth every £. The guide was knowledgeable, and brought life to each of the halls of the Palace of Westminster. Her snippets of history added lots of colour to the tour. The group was sensibly small, so there was no problem hearing the commentary. Further, the 'no photos' policy made sense and ensured the group concentrated on the guides tales.
Never bores me. I love the Houses of Parliament. If you're coming to London for the first or 50th time, you have to visit the Houses of Parliament!
Beautiful building. Beautiful and impressive buildings. Looks great, and it must surely be the most beautiful parliament building in the world

What a fascinating place!. My Mum and I took a coach trip to visit the Houses Of Parliament. You know the sort of thing: guided tour and a cream tea on the terrace. It's a brilliant place to visit. The tour, conducted by a lady who not only knew her stuff, but was hugely enthusiastic about it, too, was excellent. This has got to be one of the most interesting places to visit in London.Although there is some very obvious security on entry, the security people were helpful and polite. Every single member of staff in the houses of parliament was kind and helpful, knowledgeable about the place, and really enthusiastic about working there.The cream tea was beautiful, served on a terrace overlooking the river.I can thoroughly recommend a visit, even if you don't have tea there.

The guided tour is the best use of your time and money. The guided tour, by far, exceeded my expectations. In addition to the stunning architecture and symbolic furnishings I learned a lot from the guide, about the history and future of the UK parliament.

The best building ever. This is the best bulding I have ever seen. It is so beautiful and so very, very huge. When the flag is flying it looks so small, it is the size of a tennis court - which gives you some idea of the scale of the place.
Wonderful place. Very interesting tour around this wonderful place, had a great morning and stood where the Ministers stand or sit, makes you proud to be British

Looks just like the postcards!. We didn't do any tours because I didn't know you could! We just walked around the general area with our tourist hats on :) If i return again definitely want to do the guided tour!
Want to go again!. Had a really interesting tour. Took us round the house of commons and lords really good and will be revisiting!
A Guided Tour of Parliament. We went on the guided tour through the Parliament building. We learned so much about the history of the building and the protocol of the working of the building.

Great guide and tour. We had a lovely guide, who made the whole experience engaging and interesting. I didnt think we would enjoy it as much as we did, but really did.
Would recommend if you are interested in a bit of history and love old architecture.

Amazing Tour - Real History. Get a personal tour guide, their extra knowledge, insights and stories add a real personal level to the tour. Walking the same route and centuries or monarchs and politicians, understanding the system makes this one of the best tours in London

A fantastic experience - whether you're political or not!. I absolutely loved this guided tour. We used the audio tour and found it both informative and still very authentic. The building itself oozes history and I was in awe. The tour takes you right through the Palace, beginning at Westminster Hall. Whether or not you like politics, it is a fantastic visit and something that is a MUST when in London.

You must do this tour!. Having enjoyed looking at the outside of this building for many years we finally got round to doing the tour of the inside. One of the best things we have done in London! We did the guided tour which at £25 each seemed a little pricey but I have to say well worth the money. Our group at first seemed a little large but actually it was fine. Our excellent guide, Pauline, kept us together well and kept up a very informative talk all the way round. Friendly staff, nice gift shop, cafe and facilities. Fascinating.
Got to be seen. We didn't stop in to do any sort of tour, but just walked around the outside of the building. It was still amazing to see and be around.
Impressive!. Impressive, of course! The size and the lights at night looks amazing!!!! Easy to get to by the public transport.

For Lovers of History. The easiest way to see the Houses of Parliament is to book your guided tour online at Parliament's website. Then you can pass through security at your appointed time with no hassle. As a fan of the State Opening of Parliament ad Prime Minister's Questions on PBS, it was thrilling standing in the benches in the Commons and the House of Lords. A must-see if you're visiting London.
You pay for the place. The Strangers restaurant in the HoC is a great place to eat to impress. the food is fine but in this instance is all about the place.
Day out. A place I found to be very drull and full off poo.Would not go again as the entertainment was bad and over rated

History and Democracy. Good value, not too much waiting and knowledgeable guide. Takes you to the Commons and Lords Chambers. Couldn't quite believe the access we got. Rewarded them by spending a lot in the shop and cafe!
Historic. Beautiful and I loved hearing the lovely history, but was impressed that it is where current action occurs!!!

educational trip. can be a bit boring at times and you are not allowed to take photos. the tour can be quite lengthy but overall it is very educational. one to put in your 'places to visit' list when coming to London. not good for the little kids and please don't bring your screaming babies here women.

A storehouse of knowledge. On our first visit to the Houses of Parliament, we took a guided tour. This 90 minute tour is given by an expert guide who is an absolute wealth of information. Besides covering the history, role of royalty, and the functioning of the parliament, the guide also gave lots of little fun tidbits about the place. Do note that there is a security check and usually a long queue outside, so it would be wise to prepare for a delay of about 15-20 minutes outside. Highly recommended!
Visit. Very good to see but I think it's hit and miss with your tour guide. Mine was rather distracted and seemed uninterested. He also didn't engage with his group and wax goo hard to hear.

Excellent tour. We booked our tour last minute and thoroughly enjoyed it. I'd advise the guided tour rather than the audio tour. You get to go to more places than on the audio tour and our guide, Harry, was excellent. Really informative and made the whole tour insightful and enjoyable. I'd recommend this to everyone.

Stunning building.. Four of us visited with an invite from our MP. The only difference was we didn't have to pay.Entry point is about central to the front elevation and this was all very easy. Staff guided us through the entrance route to the security points (like an airport). You report to a tours desk in the enormous Westminster Hall and there is the cafe and souvenir shop to one side off the Hall. The tour guides take you on a standard route that they can't adjust. You'll get to all the main spaces, Commons, Lords and Royal chambers but none of the back room areas. There is a Post Office counter in the central lobby (a surprise). Everyone on our tour thought the Commons and the Lords chambers were smaller than they imagined.Wheelchair users were able to be taken round (four on our tour) but they often had to be taken to private area lifts and then rejoining the tour.The lavish details are so impressive.

Palace of Westminster . Had a tour round the houses of parliament starting in the great hall thanks to our local MP. This was a fantastic tour see all the place that you see on tv and much more.
We had a guide provided who was very knowledgeable about all of the building and enjoyed see history at its best.
A must see. The pure grandeur is breathtaking and was one of the highlights of visiting London. Highly recommend.

Wonderful tour. We were in London at a service in Westminster Abbey and found out that we could tour Parliament. There were two tours available, Audio and Guided. We decided to go for the Guided tour and were asked what time we wanted to start. Tours were timed at 20 minute intervals. After buying the tickets, the ticket office is across the road from Parliament, we made our way to the visitor entrance. We then went down to be screened, X-ray and metal detector, just like airport screening, and were ushered into Westminster hall to start our tour. Our guide was very knowledgable and took us to the furthest point of the building and guiding us back. The tour covers the areas used by the Queen at state opening, the chamber of the Lords, central lobby and commons chamber, as well as other areas. The tour lasted around 90 minutes and was very informative. We ended back at Westminster hall and a well stocked gift shop. This tour is wonderful and very worthwhile. The tour cost £25 per adult but was well worth it. The guide book was also good value at £5. I would recommend to anyone.
Very impressive . It was during one of walks when walked by these majestic iconic buildings. Definitely worth a visit when you are in London.

Amazing place. Booked in advance for the audio tour. This was really informative and allowed you to do the tour at your own pace. You really feel like you are walking through history. It was so interesting seeing the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

Houses of parliament. A well constructed visit,with an excellent guide.As parliament was in recess we were allowed into both chambers.Booking in advance via your Member of Parliament is advised as it is timed and avoids the queues.

A truly amazing British institution- don't miss it!. Excellent place to visit. The history of this building is amazing. You can book a tour on a Saturday with very knowledgable staff or contact your local MP for a free guided tour during the week. If you want to go up Elizabeth tower to see the Big Ben bell then book this at least 6 months in advance as it's always fully booked.
Attached to Big Ben. Great area to visit with all the key London skyline features in one spot- including the houses, Big Ben, Westminster Abbey around the corner and the Thames at the door step.

London icon. An exciting part of London with a large number of tourist icons nearby. The building is a marvel and well worth the time to wander the outside, however if you want a really clear view, be early.

Worth a visit. Just amazingly beautiful. Great architecture. Worth a visit. Sitting on the Thames river with Big Ben beside it. This is where everything in the UK gets done and to think of all the years the politicians have been sitting here.

Best Tour in London!. This is a wonderful two hour tour packed full of history of Britain and you have the opportunity to see so many interesting locations. The tour leaders are excellent and keep you amused.However for US visitors there is limited opportunity since the tours cannot be held when Parliament is in session, so you have most Saturdays year round and during the summer recess, check those dates as they change each year.Don't miss this tour!
Worth the look. Couldn't go inside (since we are not UK citizens), but this is impressive to walk around. Lots of construction in the area made it difficult though.

Outstanding history lesson, live. It was very impressive to me to walk on all these rooms and corridors full of history. It was very educative since the audioguide let us enough time to delight with with the views during the time when audio stories flow out.You have to buy an official catalog to be able to remember what we're the main things you visited. They are so many, and you are not allowed to take any pictures when passing into the "parliamentary" area.Take at least 2 hours to complete the tour, to really be able to have all the info and delight with all.Do note the tickets are not available in the palace premises!!, and you have to go back the street on the other side of the main road with Big Ben, just near the Tube station, on the bridge ends area.Enjoy!
Didn't Do Indoor Tour!. Did not tour inside, but everyone should see & walk around it! It is probably the prettiest architecture in London as far as I am concerned!
Absolutely wonderful!. We happened to stop by when the Prime Minister was being questioned about Syrian refugees, very interesting.

The Mother of Parliaments - just wonderful. Went on a Constituents' Tour (ie arranged by my constituency MP). The tour was wonderful. We are both keen on Politics and watch BBC Parliament as a default TV option. Our guide was Kevin (apologies for not remembering his surname), and he was just super. Good knowledge of history and full of charm and very amusing. There is the history of our laws: the Palace of Westminster is a beautiful building and it was great to see it in real life, so to speak. Very grateful to my MP for organising it, and to the Tour organisers. You have to queue for a bit to get to security and then you are fairly swiftly through the airport security (I was frisked, and my partner was told off for going through the metal detector too soon afer me. Security could be a bit more polite, we are not trying to be difficult!). Then we spent some time in the cafe, saw the little shop, toilets are in this area, and then into the vast Westminster Hall to gather for the tour. We loved it once we'd got through security (and we do understand the need for excellent security). A super tour, thank you.

Guided tour with afternoon tea. We had a guided tour through the Houses of Parliament with a guide who was very knowledgeable and kept us interested. The architecture and history of the Palace is absolutely spellbinding. After our tour we then had afternoon tea in the Member's Dining Room. That was an experience in itself. Such opulence and splendor, not to mention the quality and presentation of the food. It was definitely a worthwhile experience

One of the world's most impressive looking public buildings. We’ve stood gazing at the Houses of Parliament about a half-dozen times while trying to decide whether to take a guided tour of this wonderful public building. And just that many times we’ve elected to tour something else – most recently Westminster Abbey. Shame on us. This is most assuredly one of the best looking, most impressive public buildings in the world, and we have yet to set foot in it. Next time for sure, I promise.

Well worth visiting at least once. I'd strongly advise you to book in advance for this excursion. I booked online and it was easy-we opted for the guided tour and it was great! It is definitely worth a visit but you are standing a lot and walking and the tour takes around 1.5hrs. If you do need to sit then the guide will advise where you can sit.
Marvelous H Of P.. This house of Parliament is some of the best House of Parliament building, look wise, architecturally, color, combinations etc
Our Guide was the Star. Sept. 29, 2015 guided tour with Victoria Wood. Knowledgeable and funny and kept us interested. She's a pro who made seeing Parliament awesome!
England at its finest. Loved the architecture and so happy that I finally got to see one of England's most well known attractions

Cracking tour of Parliament, but don't bother with the afternoon tea. We had a most excellent 2 hour tour of the Houses of Parliament with Fernando and I would give this 5 stars and thoroughly recommend it.Our experience was rather devalued by the afternoon tea, of which we had high expectations. Everyone who had booked the afternoon tea was taken to the dining room together at the same time and then everyone was served (kind of) simultaneously. And this clearly presents catering with a challenge, so everything is prepared well in advance. As a result our sandwiches were cardboard-dry as they had been standing out waiting for our arrival for far too long (the waiter explained this to us when we made a comment).Significantly the portions were super-tiny (three tiny, tiny, tiny sandwiches, one small scone and two other tiny desserts each - the desserts were delicious, but the sandwiches were tasteless as well as dry). And rather strangely the waiting staff gathered in the menus before we'd been able to select another pot of tea because clearly none of the diners could be trusted! I confess it did make me feel like I wanted to be mischievous.I could go on, but suffice to say at £27.50 per person (in addition to £25pp for the guided tour) it was all about the location rather than the tea so I would recommend you go to on the tour and give the tea a miss.

Tour of houses of parliament. Had a great tour of H of P today with colleagues from work. This was arranged through our local MP, Tom Pursglove. Many thanks to yourself and Zara for talking the time to meet us and show us round.Took about 90 minutes showing us both the commons and Lords chambers. Well woth it

Overwhelming impression. Extremely interesting and well presented by our guide Owen whose every word was to the point and entertaining. The guided tour lasted 90 minutes and took us to the House of Lords and to the House of Commons and some parts in between. The building is overwhelming in its size and beauty.
Great guide . I actually just mistakenly wrote this review in Buckingham. Oops. The oak ceiling from 1399 was incredible. The guide knew all the coolest stories. A must see.
A must see!. I would recommend booking a package, as we did. Beautiful old architecture. Big Ben took my breath away. Recommended for all ages. And, the tour guide was fantastic.

Beautiful Building. We saw the Houses of Parliament from a tour bus, hop-on hop-off bus, and the London Eye while visiting London in September 2015. We did not go inside. A beautiful building from the outside.

Very interesting visit!. I booked the audio guide tour on internet with 3 weeks in advance. You gotta pass through security check before you can enter it, but it is quite fast. Then you get your audio guide (they even have it in Portuguese!!) and start roaming the place. It takes a while to listen to everything and see all the areas but it is very interesting and informative. You learn how the Parliament works, the tradition, some curiosities. The only pity is that one is not allowed to take pictures, only on the main hall and first corridor. So, book the tour in advance and enjoy!

Westminster palace. It is best to make a reservation and take a guided tour in the language of your choice. The visit lasts about two hours and is worth wile. Very disapointing because you can not take pictures only in one place.

Amazing Place to Visit. Would definetly visit again - is worth every penny! Amazing place and to actually be able to go into the Houses of Commons and Lords was great. Audio tour for visitors really informative and you're able to wander round at your own pace. Am booking for another visit!

Worthwhile. Amazing tour with audio guide. You learn about the parliamentary system and the history of the building and British Government. Interior very interesting. Security is quite tight but not a problem. Recommend you get tickets on line.

The Palace of Westminster - so much history. A wonderful building , steeped in history. Westminster hall has so much history with so many world changing events being hosted in it. You really can feel the atmosphere of 'what has gone before'. Inside both the commons and Lords it is possible to view debates and see politics in action. I would recommend a visit here

Don't miss Parliament. If you have a chance don't miss Parliament. The buildings are gorgeous and the artwork is lovely. The guided tours last an hour and a half and the guides are incredibly educated and can answer any question. They take you through Parliament's history and British history in a very easy and understandable way. It was very enjoyable
Old but gold. Full of historical buildings. Very iconic, and it also oversees Thames River. Quite lively due to huge number of tourist around. Must come if you are at London!
Attractive Gothic style building. A must visit when in London. Big Ben (Elizabeth tower) chime on the hour. On the banks of the Thames and close to a few bridges to get you to both ends

The famous Big Ben. The Big Ben is the most famous attraction among the House of Parliament. By enjoying the whole view of the House of Parliament, I recommend to visit the London Eye for an overall view of the Parliament or even can cross over the bridges and enjoy it from far away.
Just a walk by. Didn't get to go in. Not sure if I even can. Walking by was just amazing for me. I really like to see it lit up at night that's my favorite.

One of the Best Tours in London. This is a really cool tour when open to the public...its loaded with history, information and splendor. Only drawback no photos inside...though you can get some great shots of the exterior (inside the fence).

Fascinating. We thoroughly enjoyed a fascinating tour of both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The history , the architecture, the sumptuous colours, paintings, statues and traditions are stunning . Whatever one's views of many MPs, this national treasure of a building must be preserved. I did not know that I would feel so strongly about this until I spent some hours there. I strongly recommend that all British citizens do so before forming an opinion on whether the Palace of Westminster is worth saving or should be demolished.

Informative and interesting. A present from the father in law who spent some years as a London tour guide and thought we would enjoy it.Allow 20 minutes before the start time to get through security (airport style) and then find the tour man/woman if you have a guided tour. I recommend a guided tour as they tell you all about the palace, its history and you learn so much more than just walking around with an audio set as you can ask questions as you go. The tour takes an hour and a half or so and you get to see the house of Lords, Commons and other areas.Well worth it if you can get in on a small group of 12 like we had but apparently they can have up to 30 on a tour so may make it a little less personal. Luck of the draw I guess. Don't expect to take lots of photos as there is no photography allowed inside.

Signature site of London...Iconic & moving!. The Houses of Parliament & The Elizabeth Tower which is attached (not Big Ben...Big Ben is the large bell inside the Elizabeth Tower) is the most recognizable landmark that people associate with London. When I fist laid eyes on this beautiful structure I got a warm feeling all over my body. It is stunningly beautiful and I knew I was in London when I saw this iconic masterpiece. Seeing it in person for the first time will overwhelm you and put a great big smile on your face. This is the signature of London. Enjoy the view.

View it from far! . Make sure you see it from far away (from the other margin). The building is gorgeous and huge. And the best view is really not close to it. From the other margin you can see the entire complex!

Parliament. good view of the building on the day that i visited unfortunately you cannot enter the building unless you are a pm or mp to my knowledge its a good building to look at through as well as next to big ben and lots of other places
Great. A must see when you visit London. Amazing how many security there is and what they did to provide any attack. But don't pay to many attention of that and enjoy the english traditions.
