Ayes to the right. This visit gets my vote.. Prior to entering the building you will pass through the. equivalent of airport security with the usual restrictions on what you may not carry. The audio tour controllers are easy to use and in addition to the 20 way points extra information is available by typing in additional codes. The extra information includes the trials of Guy Fawkes, Thomas More and Charles 1st. The commentary is a good balance between history and current running of parliament and covers several key aspects of our developing democracy like the Civil War, the role of the monarchy and the fight for women's suffrage. Friendly, well informed staff are on hand to answer any questions.Booking for a mid morning tour reduces your risk of congestion in the main building or the pleasant cafe and shop. Our visit lasted two hours.
Parliament is part of that Must See Group. Like Tower, Tower Bridge, Big Ben and such, House of Parliament is a must see for the novice London visitor.

One of my favourite buildings in the whole world. I adore this building and go to several events here every year. There are few places that compare. I have been on a tour here, world here, visited for events and conducted tours. The history is just awesome. Nothing quite takes your breath away like walking for the first time into the House of Lords, with all the gold. You can visit a debate for free in either the Lords or Commons by queuing outside. Parliament has done a lot of work in recent years making the building more accessible to the public, and have a cafe for visitors at the Cromwell Green entrance. They do weddings, and afternoon tea. You can book a tour of the building, climb up the Elizabeth Tower with a guid, and even lobby your MP. The architecture is just awesome. There is a gift shop which sells everything from watches to wine either Lords or Commons branded. UK Parliament is so unique and will never disappoint a visitor, every British citizen should visit at least once. Even with a wheel chair it is possible to see round the building, disabled visitor will see things from a slightly different angle because wheel chairs weren't top priority when the building was built, but it is possible to visit for those less mobile.

Brother's birthday. Absolutely divine! Food and service were amazing. I would not hesitate to recommend this to anyone who enjoys great food and polite service. We felt like lords at the house of lords :-)

Fabulous school trip!. We had a fantastic educational visit. The guide was excellent and I would highly recommend any school taking their children. We also had a workshop after the tour which again was excellent. I cannot fault the visit at all. Thank you for a brilliant experience, the children and staff really enjoyed it and learned a great deal.

Love English history? This is for you!. Take the guided tour. Our guide made this lovely building (worthy of a visit just to see the rooms) a living piece of history. One of the best 1.5 hours I've spent on six continents!
Must visit. Amazing style .. and history .. must visit ... a bike tour is highly recommended .... and vist to buchimghmapalace

Part of our Herritage. Lovely piece of Historic Archetecture a must se whe visiting London You can go in certain times not that i have ever done this if Your intersted in politicle History this is a must
Loverly day out with the grand children. Beautiful building London is a beautiful city and the Houses of Parliament have to be seen close up to see the whole beauty of the building .

Questions to government. This is a beautiful way to see politics "live". Probably a place to bring the kids too, first because they will understand where decisions are being made, second because it is the heart of the British democracy (and a beautiful architectural place to visit), last but not least because questions to government are "lively". Every one stands up and sits down to ask authorisation to speak, they call each other "my honourable friend" and spill venom right afterwards, it is a very nice experience.

excellent. excellent views and friendly staff cant recommend them enough, they were very helpful, we had attended a wedding there,and all the satff were pleasent, polite, even the security check in was smooth
awesome experince ... we had really good time there..it looked amazing..the building is so old and built gothic style. it looks surrial..we had a really good time ..

A Surprise Highlight of Our Trip. I am so glad that we took the offical tour of the parliment buildings. I had no idea that this place was so large, so grand and so beautiful. I was really struck by the plaques in the floor of the big hall which marked the exact spot of important moments in history. I highly recommend this tour for adults, as it is facinating. I don't think that it would be good tour for children.

Stunning building for odd people. Really interesting and full of tradition. Would love to see the cellars where Guy Fawkes hid the explosives. Good to have a guide to explain where some of the seemingly odd traditions come from.

For Students of the British Parliamentary System and Historians. This is the home of the House of Commons (elected Members of Parliament) and the House of Lords many of whom hold hereditary titles. It contains the famous Westminster Hall dating from the 11th century. It would be worth doing some advance checking to see if and when you might visit.

And why haven't I been before?!!. I booked the audio tour as a surprise for a visit to London with a friend, and we both loved it! We had both wanted to go for some time, and were lucky enough to visit when no MP's etc were around, so got to see everything. The interior is so beautiful and it really brought all those history lessons to life. The Houses were much smaller than I had expected, but it was all so interesting. It was a fantastic experience - I now want to return to hear the guided tour, which seemed to give different information when I managed to overhear.The cafe was a bit pricey - I know it's London, but maybe that's why it was empty! We were both really impressed by the Police Officers on duty at the entrance, and the security staff inside - all so pleasant and friendly. The security checks here were handled with far less drama than those at the Sky Garden!

Interesting and informative. free pre booked tickets through tour MP. Guides are generally in the mornings our slot was 11:00am. We was searched on the way in just like at the airport and handed a visitor badge. Our tour group was a good size (not too many) and our guide was very informative and knowledgable. As parliament had not resumed we got to see all of the House of Lords and commons. You get to see it all and stand in the same room and spots as he queen and the PM. I don't have a massive interest in politics but I loved the tour. The rooms are amazing and the design and attention to detail is amazing. Photos are only allowed in certain areas but you get some fab up close pictures of Big Ben from inside the grounds.

Wow!. Staying nearby the House of Parliament during our trip to London it is not hard to see why London is such a spectacular city.The architecture of the building situated right on the Themes River is stunning and is hard to believe you are there seeing it in all it's glory.

Audio Tour. Went round the Houses of Parliament on Saturday last, was very interesting. I preferred the audio tour as the group for the guided tour was large and I didn't think I would hear everything. Would recommend the Audio tour as you could stop and start when you wanted and you could click on extra information as and when. All very good.

Glad to have finally visited!. i took the audio tour although there are guided ones as well. Tickets are available around the side of the building next to Westminster Underground. Open Saturdays for the most part as far as I know. Definitely a must see for history and politics buffs. The architecture is stunning. Not to mention the fact that I was just thrilled to finally be inside The House of Commons and The House of Lords. The Elizabeth Tower which houses Big Ben is only open to residents of the UK. But as it's several hundred steps to the to, no complaints here. Be prepared for a real security check much like the airport. Highly recommend.

Great value for money, and lots to see.. Great value for money. Visited with my daughter, who was free of charge. So we only paid £18 for a self-guided audio tour for the two of us. For me, this was the best value venue on our visit to London. The audio tour was great quality, and the buildings themselves have a lot of interesting history. The ability to walk around the House of Commons and House of Lords chambers was a definite bonus. Very worthwhile, and I would visit again.

Really Great. Have always seen pictures of this building but standing in front of it and being able to go inside was awesome. I couldn't believe how much of the inside we were able to see with our guide. I could feel a sense of grandeur and reverence as we walked through this stately building. My wife loved the architecture.

WOW. Awesome to see this part of British history. the architecture is definitely WOW to the max. it is so iconic that when u get there you just stand and stare and think how amazing this building thru the century.

Beautiful buildings and views. A perfect photo-opportunity walk down Westminster Bridge and take pictures with this as a backdrop. See Nelson Mandela's statue in the green and then walk down to the Westminster Abbey gift shop for souvenirs.

Saw Prime Minister address House of Commons. Walked right in and saw the Prime Minister speak - wow !! It was amazing. We could not get tickets from the U.S. because Parliament was not supposed to be in session. However, the Syrian refugee crisis intervened and they were in session. Please give it a try if you are at all interested. It was a life changing experience.

Great for photos, not so overwhelming. A beautiful builiding. It is very nice during the day and during the night (It is lighten up very nicely during the night). But when you get there, you can not get into it unless it is pre booked long in advance. There is nothing to do there apart from taking photos along with many tourists on a busy road. It is a famous attraction you should probably see if you're in London for the first time but it is not very interesting. Do not expect too much. Enjoy your stay!

Wow, the highlight of London attractions. The home of democracy was without doubt the highlight of our tour of London. Fascinating history and amazing to see the inside of both chambers. The audio tour is brilliant and at just the right level for everyone from the specially designed audio for younger visitors to the main audio which was just right for teenagers and adults alike. Forget the expensive tourist attractions such as London Dungeon and visit Parliament and the real London instead, much better value and much more interesting.

Great architecture, enjoyed learning the history on the tour.. Visited this magnificent building with my politics class. Always loved seeing it as I drove past and really enjoyed seeing the artwork and learning about events that had taken place over the century's.You do not have to book a tour to visit and anyone can request to lobby their MP and therefor see the inner sanctum of parliament but the tour was very enjoyable.
Must see!. Beautiful and huge building you have to see and, if possible, visit / do a tour!!! Worth taking pictures by day and by night!!!

Beautiful and very interesting tour of the building. Visited the House of Parliament in Sept 2015. We did the audio tour which was very interesting and also had the afternoon tea which was lovely and with a great view being based by the river.

Very interesting visit!!. We had a great time hear and would recommend it even if you live in the UK!! Lot of history with in the building . My partner uses a wheel chair and neede parking so they were able to give use parking on site which was great!! The disabled access is good but you do have to be taken a different way but we did not mines as we were able to see things that other could not!! Would go again.

Interesting. On my first trip to London, with a school group, we were able to sit quietly in the gallery and observe some members of Parliament engaged in debate. I found the experience to be eye-opening and interesting.

The View of the building. Enjoyed the history and the building as it was the center of a world Empire at one time and that they were able to shift out of the empire stage to a common wealth connection of free nations with links to one another.

Brilliant . Wow it is a great place to visit the guide showing us round was very good and knowledgeable. You can go into both the commons and lords on the tour also Westminster hall and the room where the queen gets ready for the state opening. Great way to spend a morning
Green seats, red seats. A very interesting tour, especially if you are interested in politics. The tour leader certainly knew his subject well and was able to answer various types of questions.
Great photos at sunset!. Take the best pictures of Big Ben and Parliament via a hop/on bus as the sun is setting.... amazing!
brillant. only got to see it from the outside. next time will go inside. very limited time in the city. must return.

An inside view . The building is even more beautiful on the inside than it is on the outside...We booked a guided tour online and enjoyed every minute of it! I think the extra 4 pounds you pay are well worth it as you will hear an interesting story and gain access to some additional rooms compared to the audio guide - the tour takes about 1,5 hours.This is an amazing building and i particularly liked the two chambers (lords and commons) and the contrast between them.

Great place to visit. Big ben and the parliament houses stand magnificent and grand as soon as u walk out of the tube station with a view of the london eye and thames on one side. Dont forget to take a walk around the block.

brilliant tour. Well worth the effort of booking in advance. This is a must see destination for anyone going to London. It will blow your mind not just the history and the fact you are walking where legends have been but the actual house is so much smaller and intimate than it looks on the tv.
Family trip to London. What can you say. One of the most iconic spots in London. A must for all visitors. Stand on Westminster bridge at midday and get the perfect shot

An interior even more ornate than its exterior. Booked a guided tour, which was excellent, she was very knowledgeable. History of the Palace (which it was originally built as), beautiful interior. Well worth a visit or even two!

A little dull. We took the 90 min guided tour. Parliament was not in session so we could see more areas. The guide covered the British Parliament history and process. I thought the presentation was very dry. I much preferred the tour of Westminster Abbey or any or the royal residences. If you have an interest in the British law making process, then this might be the tour for you.

Wonderful Tour which gives 'heaps' of of really interesting information!!. Our tour was led by a highly knowledgeable gentleman who made the information he imparted, fascinating (but not at all boring).The tour, which included visits to The House of Lords, The House of Commons and Westminster Hall (to name a few) spanned approximately 90 minutes and every minute was 'time well spent).British citizens can (through their local MP's secretary) request a tour invitation and assuming their MP has available invites, the tour costs nothing (these tours are limited to only certain days). Alternatively, there are 'pay-for' tours for visitors.I can only HIGHLY recommend a visit to the Houses of Parliament - Enjoy!!
Westminster and more. Interesting view, and right next to Westminster Abbey. This area is a Tourist mecca, and will be for a long time.

Great day out. I really enjoyed my visit to The Houses of Parliament,security was airport style which was reassuring and went very smoothly.I have resided in London for 25 years now and it was great to go behind the scenes of a building which you would normally only see on TV during heated debates.I took the audio tour which was very informative and you could take at your own pace.We finished off with a lovely cup of tea and super fresh sandwiches in the cafe,I recommend the chicken and chorizo.We would liked to have come again for afternoon tea on the terrace but from what I can see it can only be booked in conjunction with the tour,never mind the cafe was lovely.
The centre of democracy. Historic building of the Houses of Parliament...the Commons and the Lords..wonderful view down the river Thames
Lords and Commons!. Only got to see the monument from the outside, it looks really majestic. Wish could go in and witness the proceedings, alas!

Great tour experience of the Houses of Parliament.. This was a great experience and we would heartily recommend taking a guided tour through the Houses and chambers during your visit to get a better understanding about the history and protocols that are followed. Very informative.

The Mother of a tour. I was lucky enough to be given a special out of hours tour by an MP. I even sat in the House of Lords. Not sure if this was strictly allowed but it was a fantastic experience. This is the Mother of all parliaments for good reason. It is so full of history. Stand where Charles the 1st stood at his trail. See where Guy Fawkes tried to blow the place up. Have a drink on the terrace and just absorb the atmosphere.

A history of democracy. We booked a guided tour as opposed to wandering round with the headphones on. It was superb. Our guide, Colin, who happened to be from our constituency, was very knowledgeable on the history of the Palace of Westminster and very entertaining. He regaled us with lots of stories and funny anecdotes. You can't fail to be impressed by the grandeur and sense of history hanging over the place. It's a must-see, no question!

Parliament. To be honest the building is amazing the historical side of it walked past it alot when stayed in london i had so much todo and so little time thats only teason why i didnt go in if i had more time it be defo but all in all brilliant will call in next time its in the top 5 sites to see in london big ben right there too so you get 1 stone two birds london eye is only over the bridge too
Nice building. Very nice Parliament building and really in main tourist route. Interesting read about history and system inside,must see!

Beauty and knowledge. I took a tour at the Parliament. It was fantastic. It gave me the possibility of seing things that I would have not access to and to learn a lot about political British history. And the place is majestic. Strongly recommended.

Government machinery. Finally went to the Houses of Parliament having worked in London for over 40 years. Thoroughly worth the visit with a guide and gives an insight of the daily ministrations of government
A must do. Just beautiful! So much history to learn in this building. The tour is an individual audio tour so you can go at your own pace which was really nice. A must do in London.
Historical building. This is just opposite to Big Ben and always included in the all the London tours. It is one of the icons of London.

This gets my vote.. This must rate as one of the most enjoyable visits so far,everything was spot on & amazing.I had watched the fairly recent documentary on the BBC,and this gave such a behind the scenes eye opener about this ancient political building.We booked our tickets on line,and just printed things off before we made our maiden visit.After checking in at the gate you go through to the security area,this takes just a few minutes & then you are on your way for your tour.You can take photo's in the great hall,but after that sadly you are not permitted to take any more.I say sadly because it is just so special when you are walking through the various rooms that you have previously only seen on tv.There is just so much political history to step back in amazement and enjoy,to think that you are actually walking just a few feet away from where Mr David Cameron, our current prime minister deliver all of those witty lines.!Of course we may like some of the members more than others,but at least we get the chance to vote them in & out when our chance comes.The house of Lords is just as impressive,as you get to see the leather benches where one or two peers have a been caught having a mini nap on tv.Loads of statues for you see & wonder which name is going to appear under it to reveal that illusive former prime ministers name.Summing up,a brilliant place to visit at the very centre of British politics.The entrance fee for two seniors was £31.00,so at £15.50 this represented great value for the entertainment value alone.Would we come again,without a doubt,this was so very,very good.Thank you to all of the helpful staff on duty.

Thinkers are Doers. I enjoyed my tour of this historic place. Went to both chambers, the Green and Red. You need to be on a guided tour to better appreciate the rich story behind every façade. Do you know that This used to be a trading market place? To know more, book your place now.

Audio tour fantastic. Brilliant to see inside and audio tour is informative. Book ahead online so you can walk right up to the gate to collect tickets. Highly recommend. It is apparently free to sit in the public gallery while parliament is sitting. Not sure how you'd go about arranging this but would be great to see.

Beautiful Architecture. The government buildings were beautiful and the place was a bit crowded. I would visit this place if travelling through London. The guards were friendly and there was high security for the times we are in.

Great tour - recommend the Educational tour. Visited the House of Lords and House of Commons with a group of 15 children, We were 90 minutes late due to a motorway incident. The tour was rearranged and tailored to the reduced time we had available. It was informative, interesting and engaging.The children (and adults) were enthralled.We had time to see the parliament film, both houses, voting lobbies, entrance to the House of Commons and a couple of other areas.Only disappointment was the restrictions on raking photographs inside the houses.

Iconic. Probably 1 of the most famous landmarks in the world. 1 of the must visits in London. I did a tour through Parliament where you can go in the chambers for the house of lords and house of commons which is very cool. Alas you can't take pictures but well worth visiting if you have time.

History so much. Apparently the old thing is falling into disrepair, not that you'd notice from outside. What a building and so much history. I have never done a tour inside but I could walk past every day and never cease to be amazed
Amazing building . If you wanna visit London, don't miss it. The parliament is a huge architectural piece, that you must run by.

A Marvellous Introduction to the British Political System and History. I visited the HOP for the very first time despite living here, with my 12 year old daughter, and was not disappointed. We chose the audio self tour instead of a guided tour, but having seen the guided tour would also highly recommend it. With plenty of time to wander round and with an excellent array of historical background to listen to in addition to the guide, this was a history diploma in the making, for me anyway...!! My daughter was, to coin an american phrase 'just blown away' by being at the heart of the british political system, something I think we take for granted seeing it on TV etc.It was awesome and something I want to do again as soon as possible. The highlights for me were St Stephens Hall, House of Lords, and House of Commons. St Stephens Hall because of its rich history dating back to the first Commons Chamber which once stood on this site, which is why the present hall is lined with 12 marble statues of famous Members of Parliament facing each other, as in debate. The House of Lords and House of Commons also intriguing and surprising, given that they both are much smaller than they appear on television....!!Overall, an excellent visit and even though you have to go through stringent security for good reason, this is done so efficiently and courteously that you hardly notice..!!So Highly recommended if you are at all interested in politics, history or political history ..!

Home of Parliament. Another of those iconic buiding's in London, a must visit, sited next to Big Ben and across the street from Westminster Abbey, this is a MUST on anyone's trip to London for sightseeing

Amazing history around each corner!. I was here on business however managed to also see the magnificence of this wonderful palace. Stood where Mandela had stood and walked the floors that Prime Ministers had walked. Loved it! Had afternoon tea on the Terrace - with wonderful views of the Thames

Stunning inside and out!. We chose to take the guided tour, and for the most part we were glad we did. Although our guide talked longer than we cared for about certain parts of the building, being on a guided tour allowed us to see some things other visitors do not see. All in all, we had a wonderful time.

Well worth taking a guided tour. As a member of IOD, Kent, I was delighted to take a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament followed by Christmas lunch. The experience was excellent and very educational. The House of Commons is a 'must do' and afterwards we made our own way to the House of Lords where we sat next to Floella Benjamin and listened to one of the bills being discussed. The whole day was fascinating and I would strongly recommend it to anyone that likes politics or history.

proud of our history. My husband and I did the tour of the houses of parliament and absolutely loved it. Our tourguide Louise was excellent and had an impressive knowledge of the building. She spoke clearly and happily answered all questions. We will definitely be returning as we would like to spend more time exploring the location.

An historical wonder. Last Saturday my wife and I were very fortunate to be part of a group to be invited to tea at the House of Commons followed by a guided tour. The tea was in the members tea room and overlooked the river Thames. The tea was delicious and the service was what you would expect in such an auspicious location. During our tour we were able to enter both the House of Lords and House of Commons and walk amongst the member benches. My wife is English and I am American and we both truly appreciated the history of the surroundings and the events that have taken place there.If you can arrange a tour even without the tea, please do not fail to do so. British subjects may request a tour from their MP, I have never searched for commercial offerings of a tour but I suspect it can be arranged..

Grand!. Talk of GRAND locations like really grand places around the globe venue of the famous big Ben which itself is grand, it's an amazing place to visit. You can't miss the famous (London police men) in their grand uniforms as well, phew, I'm not going to bore you with my grand story just hop on a flight and see it all for yourself LOL.

Amazing. I went on the advice of friends and am so glad I did.the tour was amazing, and the guide very informative. I want to go back with the audio guide to fill in the gaps.So much to see, and spine tingling to be where so much history has been made
So impressed by the architecture.. This is a sight that I never tire of seeing the style and shere size can't fail to impress.A must see when visiting London .
Wonderful tour guides. Fascinating and fun, not much new to add but it's definitely worth the time and effort to get tickets and do the proper tour.

The Palace of Westminster. This is one of the go to places in central London. The Houses of Parliament are only viewable from the outside however certain sections are open to the public when there is the OpenHouse event. I have seen certain sections from the inside as well as the outside. One of the striking features from the inside is how colourful the stained glass windows look. This building is also known as the Palace of Westminster because before Buckingham Palace the previous kings and queens resided here. There are statues, carvings and giant wall murals inside. It is definitely worth going to see the building and if you are fortunate to also take a step inside
Impressive.. Awesome view from the other side of the river. Big Ben was very impressive and made me feel quite patriotic when it chimed, It was a good area to visit.

Visiting the Parliament. Passed by Houses of Parliament on a cloudy day and a awe inspiring sight nevertheless. It was a shame i couldn't enter the place due to time constraints but grateful I got to see it with Big Ben.
Great building but you can only see outside .. Stunning building but not much of a tourist attraction as very difficult to see the interior , shame .

Politics with London Flare.... It's a good thing to go to see this if you are at all a history buff with politics, after all Canadians owe how our government runs because of the British system. Also just how grand and old the building is and how it still functions today. Big Ben was also a great part of this beautiful landmark. A must see while in London there are also daily tours, inside the Parliament building.

Another true icon . Fantastic building English architecture at its best. These new age designers take note. Will yours be standing after hundreds of years ?. If it is then will it be a true icon like this amazing historic building

Loved it!. Wow well I loved this! Absolutely super. I took part in the audio tour and have to say I loved every minute of this tour. So impressive and so well organised. Unfortunately I was attending with a group who walked round a bit quickly when I could of spent ages here, so will definitely be going on my own in the near future! I would like to add I am by no means a history lover but I really enjoyed this tour I think that it has something for everyone. Don’t be put off by thinking you’re not into history! I would also say the tour is really managed, all areas flowed well and nowhere seemed over crowded. Very well managed, very well priced and a super tour.

Have you seen it on TV? See it for yourself!. We have visited this place recently. It is interesting to learn more about the history of the parliament! We used audio tour and it was good enough :)You can visit both house of lords and house of commons in the visit. Funnily enough: You are not a Lord, you don't sit on House of Lords Hallway seats, as a common person however you are a common person you can sit on the same seats in the house of commons! So so English huh? :D

Houses of Parliament from the outside. Big ben seems to reach for the sky as you stand by it, what a sight. achitecturally a wonder incorporating that magnificant clock. i walked around the corner by the bridge and passed the members car park entrance immediately remembering Mr Nieve M.P who died so tragically at this spot. i walked further around and came to the public entrance where i was met by met police,and there started part two of the inspection.
Bunch of old buildings!. For some perhaps will love it. London is great but another old building! Go anyway because it's historical.

Iconic, impressive and interesting.. This is something we have wanted to do for some time. Well worth the wait! Fantastic guide - we would definitely recommend this personnel touch rather than the audio version. One and a half hour tour which went so quick and was never boring.
Amazing piece of London's city. These buildings are a great addition to any visit to London and are great for photos, even though people can get in the way.

The Seat of Power. No one could fail to be impressed with a visit to this most historical of all institutions. From the great halls to the debating chambers to the MP's tea rooms you just get an incredible feel for the history of the place and its continued importance in our democratic way of life.
1000 years of history. Excellent 1.5 hour tour. Knowledgeable, engaging guide. Try the last tour of the day apparently. There are less people.

Pretty good!. Pretty good, what you'd expect. Nothing awful as a surprise. Bit of a wait to get in. Easy access to ladies. Having said all this I got in as a journalist, as a member of the public, I have no idea.

A historical place. Wow.. It is a historical place to those interested in seeing historical places. You will be lucky if the Queen is visiting it, you will see one of the very interesting shows you can imagine.

Beyond Awesome. I was looking forward to visiting the Houses of Parliament and expected the history of it all to be interesting however I can't describe how incredible this visit was! Beyond awesome! Everyone should have this on their list of things to visit. We took the audio tour so were able to stroll around at our own pace (will take between 60 - 90 minutes). It made us proud to be British.
London has been cleaned up!. All the historical buildings in London appear to have been cleaned up since I last visited London (1977) - good to see.

iconic london place. Amazing building to see the outside of! hard to take pictures of the whole thing as people get in the way, and it is absolutely massive! Close to many other major attractions, very easy to get to.

Impressive. Took an audio tour of The Houses Of Parliament. After going through security one was free to wander and listen to the commentary at one's own pace. It was very informative without overloading one with too much information. It is a magnificent building with an intriguing history and we'll worth a visit. I would suggest going along when Parliament is in recess during the summer.....you get to see more. It is also well worth booking tickets in advance to save queuing.

Beautiful parliament. Wow this is one of the most beautiful parliament. its very beautiful if you seen at night time. full of light and full security. we can take snaps. I recommend everyone who visit in London must visit this place also.
Where politics ticks. It's amazing to go and see the insides of one of the oldest parliments. The Tour was very interesting. Lots of traditions and tales.
House of Parliament with Big Ben. Great view and architecture along with Big Ben. A Must see in London . It along with big ben makes a great wall paper. great views.

This Has to Be Seen. The Houses of parliament and the House of Lords are known throughout the world, ones always seeing it on the news the shouting in the chamber and hearing order order order now be part of it. We booked on line for the tour very easily to do and your given a time and you turn up at that it easy. Once inside you start in the great hall you can take photos in there only. Then into the house of Lords so very grand no its fantastic then into the house of commons again fantastic your going through history. After there is a great little gift shop and not expensive. Check it out as i believe its only open for tours in the summer but check it out and go go go.

Must See in London. This was a great tour. So interesting. I recommend doing the tour with the live guide---we did that instead of the audio guided one so I cannot compare that but the guide was excellent. Lots of historical information was presented and it was just the right length. Really enjoyed it.
Cool. Very impressive building looks bigger on tv. But worth a look at. Book a trip it's worth it. Plenty of history and things to look ata

A Real Treat.. We visited The Houses Of Parliament in August..and were escorted by a friend, what a wonderful place it was too full of history, tunnels secret passages an amazing place that really should be visited. To see The House of Commons and The House Of Lords where debates are heard and argued and history is made, things I've only seen on TV in the past, we were able to stand out on the terrace by the Thames the views are spectacular, thank you for our tour.

A WOW!!. Utterly stunned at how big and opulent it is. So many are unworthy to run our country, and walk these floors that are steeped in history.However, A well run audio tour throughout. The Parliament staff, and security staff are very friendly. Everyone is made to feel welcome. A great 2 hours. And A MUST DO!

First trip to Houses of Parliament . I am not particularly interested in politics but found a trip around the Houses of Parliament was extremely interesting and highly entertaining. Well worth the visit especially if you go on a guided tour
Great visit. It`s a great place to visit, the home of every world´s Parliaments. A must-do visit, with a lot of history inside.
Sight seeing. We as a family just went for a walk around and took some photo's. It was nice to see the sights of London and everything is within easy reach by walking or tube.

A Must See in London!. When visiting London, this is a must! We took the self-guided tour with the audio. It was very informative, and the Houses of Parliament are beautiful.There is a lot of security throughout the facility which was comforting. We learned much and certainly would highly recommend visiting this site.

Tour excellent, afternoon tea terrible. Really interesting. Everyone should go. We saw a lot of both the Lords and the Commons. Only let down was the afternoon tea, which was overpriced and awful. Visit the HoP, then go across the river to the City Hall Library, which has good views and serves a very good tea!
Westminster. the westminster palace qw nice architecture structure is a visit you can't miss if you are in London for visiting it
Iconic British Landmark. Great place to walk past and look at Big Ben and to see the bobbies. Especially impressive at night.
Fantastic London landmark. excellent landmark to enjoy, particularly from the river boat cruise, and also great when you hear the "gongs" of the big ben clock to add to the atmosphere
Overly priced. Architecture is good but is overly priced. Also, no photography is allowed at most of the places. One time visit.

Excellent view. This is one of the photographs you will see whenever you think of London.Very large structure and gives a very good photogenic look because of the river.Must visit place, you can see this gigantic structure from the London eye as well!
Take great photos here. Again, must seen atraction. You can't go inside, it's not for public but definetely worth to see. Nearby are London Eye, Downing Street, Westminster Abbey, St James Park...

Much more impressive in person. It is a London iconic postcard, and we've seen it thousands of times in books. However, when you get off the Westminster tube station and see that huge building in front of you, makes you speechless. It is breathtaking. If you have a chance, walk towards the bridge for a different view, or just sit at the park across the street, and enjoy the view.

Tour of Parliament.. My wife and I won a visit to Parliament at a charity ball, including taking tea with a local MP. We did the tour first, which was most enjoyable - the guide was very knowledgeable, and very humorous - made it entertaining and educational. Coffee and cake in the public café was good, and when we returned in the afternoon, we had a very pleasant meeting with the MP, with tea provided. We managed also to get a place in the public gallery of the Commons late in the afternoon to listen to a debate - interesting, but confirmed my view that they are a' childish' bunch. Overall a good day!

Very pricey. I was surprised at the cost. I paid £18 for a non-guided tour I.e. just entry to the Houses of Parliament. However this does include an audio tour. A visit here is a must on your trip to London as there is so much history preserved in this building. If you haven't been before I would recommend a guided tour although I don't know how much that costs.
Enjoyable visit.. Enjoyable visit to the Houses of Parliament. Interesting to see places you've seen on the TV. Good audio presentation.

Take a photo from the London Eye. .You can't go inside. Unless you are a Member of Parliament!You can't even get near, because it is surrounded with protective iron barricades against a terrorist attack. :-(The best place to see it and take a photo is from the London Eye. When you go into the cabin, try and stand at the back on the felt hand side, to get the best view. And the best photo.Done that, been there, ticked off . . ..

Highlight of a lifetime. Wow, wow, wow. This is a bucket list must do. I booked this tour through my local MP Oliver Colvile. We went through security in Portcllis House and we were met by my MPs PA Stuart. He escorted us to Westminster Hall from there Mick the tour guide took us through the House of Commons, House of Lords and the lobby. This is one of the most interesting and intriguing things my wife and I have ever done. Stuart took us to watch PMQs and we visited our MPs office. Thank you so much for making this visit so special. This is a visit that money cannot buy. Thank you Mick, thank you Oliver and thank you Stuart.
Grand. Very grand. British Architecture at its best. Centrally located.hence getting a public transport is very easy. Worth a visit.

Must visit! Impressive, iconic, historic.. Such an historic and impressive building. I have been on a tour through local MP and for a work event. Both times were great and the tour guides are really knowledgeable. A must visit if you can to see where our laws are made.

Really interesting guided tour. A very interesting tour. Our guide, Andy, obviously enjoys doing the tours and was very entertaining and informative.The tour takes about 90 minutes, with little opportunity to sit down, so bear that in mind if it's likely you to cause any problems

Finally!. It took 8 trips to London to finally work in a tour of the Houses of Parliament! They have a limited schedule for touring so be sure to check the website and definitely pre-purchase tickets if you want to visit. We did the guided tour and I was glad we chose that over the audio tour since our guide was so knowledgable. He answered our questions without ever making us feel uninformed. Be prepared for a security scan and for about 2 hours of walking with very little sitting. Definitely worth every pound!
Very Interesting. Really interesting guided tour,very knowledgeable guide.Interesting to see parliament in person rather than just on Tv

Good visit. A good few hours entertainment. We paid for the tour which I think was well worth it to have the history explained. Very interesting to see where the politicians go and the different nuances.

All the power you can muster, just don't take a seat!. Fantastic building, rich in history and bursting with the origins of many English sayings. Once you've been through airport style security you enter the main hall, where you're met by your guide. This is a fascinating tour, make sure you wear very comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk/stand for up to two hours. The guides are generally excellent and will share vast amounts of key historical facts and figures. Some have a delightful sense of humour. You're taken through the main hall and reception areas, where history and architecture are explained. Then in to the Lords and Commons - but don't sit on the benches!!!!!! Only the elected (or privileged) can do that. Your guide will explain why monarchs can't enter certain rooms, where decisions are made, where plotting took place, and you'll even file through as if taking a vote (eys to right, no's to the left), passing age-old Hansards on the way. You will generally get a sense of how the house works, given an ancient system in a modern world. Assuming parliament is not in recess then you'll probably see some of your representatives rushing about. If it were my decision I'd ensure every UK citizen got to visit here at least once, it's not only politically and historically fascinating, it's also architecturally fab. There's a small retail area on the way out, but no catering facilities, but plenty outside.

Looks great, make sure they are open before you go.. We could only look from the outside because they are CLOSED when parliament is in session! If you are used to being able to see the US Capitol when they are in session, you'll be disappointed. You can walk around and see the beautiful building no matter what.

Icon of English/ World history. So much of my colonial past resonates with images of these buildings along with the Big Ben tower and clock. Blew me away when I came upon part of my old English film memories.

Honoured!. With our friends coming over from America on the 4th of July, celebrating Michele's 50th birthday, we were honoured to have a guided tour around our seat of Government by our own MP, the Right Honourable Andrew Griffiths. Andrew was generous with his time and was clearly well versed in the incredible history of the place as we toured both chambers, the room where the Queen gets changed prior to opening Parliament and even the chapel where Andrew himself got married. The history of the place is fantastic and well recommended. I have been to London many times but this was a real first!

Houses of Parliament... Must do in London. If you London, you must take the time to tour the Houses of Parliament. To do so, visit their website and select a date and time in advance. You'll see both houses (Lords and Commons) and walk the halls where so many have before

Well worth a visit.. We visit Parliament on the day David Cameron spoke to the house about the taking out of terrorists in Syria. His 2 speeches and rebuttal to the Opposition was something to hear. It was a great thrill to be in gallery of the House of Commons and watch the proceedings of the House.

A grand day out!. We had booked the audio tour as we wanted to go round at our own pace. The audio was really informative and gave you the option to listen to further detail on different topics if you wanted to. It was really interesting to learn of the different traditions that are used.I would recommend going on this tour and the price is worth it.

Nice to see where your vote goes to work.. Booked a visit through my local MP and was going to be shown around by him. Unfortunately he was called away and we ended up with his Chief of Staff. I believe that we had good luck that day as the CoS was fantastic, his knowledge about the buildings and rooms was second to none. Parliament was in session so we also went up to the viewing gallery. If you wait till the summer break then I believe you can go into the main room and sit on the front and back benches.
Great photo opportunity. You can visit London without coming here. The buildings are spectacular. Worth a trip to see. Kids love it too.

Must See. Very cool experience to go to the house of Parliament. It is as large as it seems in photos and really is at the center of everything in London. Almost on top of Westminster abbey, right next to Whitehall and a stone's throw from the London eye.
WOW. Beautiful Architecture!!!!! Full of history and interesting to children. We only visited from the outside but lots and lots to see.WOW
The famous view of London. It represent one of the most famous place of London and it's really wonderful. The bridge, the Big Ben and the parliament, I really love it.

The Government Seat. It's huge, first of all. And seriously guarded. Security is paramount. The history of the place is gives one pause. And for extra fun, on the day of our visit, there was a protest happening across the street, "Save the Badgers!" "Kill the Cull". Apparently an over run of sick badgers are infecting cattle, and the government is ordering that the population of badgers be culled to control the disease.

Typical London landscape. The typical London view. It's worth going to the opposite side of the river Thames as the view is complete and you can take amazing pictures. If you are lucky with the sun you might be able to take a picture with the reflect in the river

Don't miss this tour. Tour booked online, £25 per person, lasts about 1.5 hrs. Guided tour included the Commons and the Lords (but the website sells tickets for separate tours so make sure you don't book both I nearly did & it would have been a waste). We were a group of 5 & everyone was surprised at how interesting it was , it exceeded expectations.

Of course, it's a must see.. I've been back on many occasions over the last 27 years to visit the Houses of Parliament. Beautiful and conveniently located near many must-see London attractions, there are plenty of great photo opportunities and great sights to be taken advantage of. The bridge going across the river near the London Eye offers a nice, distant view for those looking for a different angle.
Worth the trip. Most interesting to ge to places you never usually see. Guide was excellent - funny and knowledgeable.

Great place to visit. We didnt plan to go to this attraction but when we saw it was open we brought tickets. It was very cheap as we did not have to pay for our children as they go free.We did the audio self tour and gave you the information through headphones. The building is amazing and to get to see the houses of lords and commons was great as you normally only see them on TV.Definatly worth a visit.

Brilliant. Fabulous building outside and equally inspiring inside. We took the audio tour, booked at 11:40 on the Saturday when Jez Corbyn was elected - so it was fairly active in Parliament Square which added to the atmosphere - democracy in action !It took 15 mins to get through the various layers of security until we arrived in Westminster Hall where the tour starts.Once equipped with our audio device and maps etc we set off - listening to all the 'add on' commentaries that are available. Through the House of Lords in all its grandeur - (recalling associated recent scandals) - and on to the various interconnecting rooms that lead to the House of Commons. The comparison between Lords and Commons is dramatic - reflecting their titles.Standing where PMs have addressed the packed room and glancing up at the speakers chair - it was a good moment.This testimony to British democracy is something of which we can be proud.
magnificent.. We had a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, well recommended, the place is a lot smaller than you see on t v, but worth a visit.

Entertaining guide. We enjoyed, our guide, Christine's commentary. It would have been good if we had known that there was only one gift shop, to the side of Westminster Hall. It was too late for us to purchase the gift we wanted for our grandchildren. It is not possible to go back to the shop as you need another ticket to get into the Westminster Hall building.
Wedding venue. My Nephew got married in the Jubilee Room in May 2015. Lovely setting for a non church ceremony and a fantastic day in all
Tour. Make sure to book your tour in advance. A very nice building. You hear not only about its use today but the history of the building.

Great History Over the Pond. A great history lesson on how there government works to make decisions for the people over the pond. The buildings themselves are historical old but nicely kept and well preserved.

Fascinating visit!. Again, England does a marvelous job with Audio phones that work-- and I hate the things as a rule! Great explanations of the Palace of Westminster--and how amazing to be where William Wallace (Braveheart) and Charles I were tried & sentenced to death!  The House of Lords & House of Commons chambers are so filled with history--and amazing to visit where The Queen sits for the Opening of Parliament.
A 'must' visit. Marvellous tour - excellent guide - fascinating to visit such an iconic and historic building. Very worthwhile.

Fun for the Adults, Totally Lost on the Kids. My husband and I, along with our seven year old daughter, toured the Houses of Parliament while visiting London. My husband and I LOVE politics and found the House of Commons to be the highlight of the tour. Our daughter whined the entire time. The guide was excellent and provided a ton of great information during the 1.5 hour tour. Although she did editorialize a bit when we came to Margaret Thatcher's statue. There were only a very few opportunities to sit down during the tour, so if you're feeble and cannot stay on your feet for long, I'd skip it. There's seating everywhere, however they strictly prohibit you from sitting on it. This site is well worth a visit to catch a glimpse into how the UK government works and where the big decisions are made. If at all possible, go without kids and you'll have a much more enjoyable time. No photography is allowed beyond the initial entrance.

full of hot air signifying nothing. as a tourist attraction its worth a look if inly to see the excesses of empire - as a political debating chamber its really far too old school and probably should be replaced with something more suited to purpose ... in birmingham. recommended

A must. Make sure you go at a time where there is no construction work going on cause it kills the photos.
A must to see in London.
Nice Police officers. We visited the gates and the police men were so polite, not like some of the ones here in US. Great tourist attraction

A must see in London. The area Waterloo is a very interesting and cool area. Lots of history and a pretty walk along the river and the bridges. I recommend that you do not take the London eye thought. Just taking a stroll in the area is a much better use of your time.

Blue Guide Tour £20 - Worth every penny. Don't know why it has taken so many years before we visited this historic building. Our guide, Christine was brilliant and so informative. Quite a long queue to get in. Probably need to allow 30 minutes when it is busy. The only slight disadvantage is that you can't go at your own pace but a guide makes the whole place come alive. We may return some time and take the audio tour so we can take everything in. Also we had a number of people tag along so our group increased from 23 to 33. This was irritating as they hadn't paid for the tour. The organisers need to have some system eg stickers or bands so the guide can keep a check on who should be in their group.

A must visit spot in London. It is next to the Big Ben and London Eye, really a good place for taking nice photos because it has extraordinary facade! A must visit spot in London. It was pity that we couldn't have enough time and budget to join tour for introducing inside the House of Parliament. We definitely will do it next time when we are back!!

It's worth it. This is one of the most famous building in the world and it's an honour to be able to go inside. Being from the states, going into government buildings can be quite difficult if not near impossible. We went online, saw that tickets were available and purchased them. It was that easy! Walking into the Houses of Parliament you can feel the excitement build up. You can't believe you're going in. Once inside you find yourself getting lost in the history. Whether it is reading the plaques on the floor or admiring the paintings and statues you feel like you could spend a lifetime in here and still not see everything. This is a must do!

Audio tour of the Houses of Parliament. Houses of Parliament is a fascinating tour and by using the audio guide, you can visit at your own pace. Photography is only allowed in the Westminster Hall and St Stephen's Hall, however. This tour gives you the inside view of how the English conduct their legislature. Beautiful building!

Second hottest day ever in the House of Lords (not involving Cromwell). I had the pleasure this past summer to enter on the House of Lords side on second hottest day ever recorded in London. It was an interesting debate on transportation policy and high tea on the veranda just adjacent to the Thames. The heat was overwhelming--no A/C here--but a great experience even with the Westminster underground station closed that afternoon.

A must See in London. You must visit the House of Parliament if you can while in London. It was probably the most interesting place of all that we saw in London. Well worth the $15 pounds each, we saw the House of Commons and the House of Lords up close

Exceeded my expectations, worth going as a tourist or seasoned Londoner.. I always meant to go but somehow never got round to it. I went with couple of visiting tourist friends and we all enjoyed it a lot. We went for the audio tour and it was great, you could walk at your own pace and focus on your favorite bits. Worth going to.

London Magesty.. A must see, Big Ben and the house Of Parliament are together.
Big Beb is the actual name of the bell inside the hu Ztower.

Book in advance for Fabulous guided tour. We booked a guided tour which you must do in advance. I believe you can do an audio tour without advance booking but we had such an excellent guide I dont think an audio tour could possibly equal the experience. Liz (Rosenbloom?) explained with great wit and verve the workings of the British parliamentary system. I consider myself informed and educated (not to mention experienced and mature- which is a nice way to say "old" ) but there was so much I did not understand about British form of government. Did you know for example that campaigning is limited to 30 days and there is a spending limit? We Americans could take a lesson from that! Don't want to reveal much more...do not fail to visit this venerable institution in its magnificent setting. Truly awe-inspiring

A special and historical place.. Lucky enough to be invited to visit by our local MP. Had a meeting in one of the Committee rooms prior to a tour, by an official guide, of the houses of Lords and Commons, along with the various ante-rooms and lobbies and the oldest part, the 11th Century Westminster Hall. Truly an amazing building, such ornate and spectacular decoration, paintings and statues. An admission charge is payable by visitors, unless invited, when there was no fee. The organised tours are of a specific time and only in certain areas, and no-one is allowed to roam freely. Security is very important and all entrances policed.

Very Beautiful Building Inside and Out. We walked by the Houses of Parliament and thought it was a cool building not knowing what is was. Once we figured it out we had to go inside. It was amazing! Be sure to get the audio tour it takes about an 1.5 hours or less.

Polite Poitics at Parliament. August is the only time that non-UK citizens can tour Parliament, which is also Westminster Palace. Make your reservation ahead of time. It's a fascinating mix of history and current events.
A highlight. The guided tour was outstanding. The guide was extremely good, with a wealth information. Plenty of photographs to be taken here. It was so interesting. Well worth the money

Lives up to its name as the 'Palace of Westminster'. Beautiful building that will take your breath away throughout your visit. Did not take a guided tour - took the option of the self tour with headphones and found this was great. This allowed me to take the tour at my pace. So much to see there and adequate places to sit down during the tour. Well worth a visit.

Fascinating representation of past and present history in the making. Had it not been for my visiting teenage niece and her best friend, I would never have given over my precious free time to visit The Houses of Parliament, or to give it its proper name, The Palace of Westminster. Our guided tour was very affordable, well structured and very informative. The guide began with the narrative of the opening of Parliament and thus begun our journey into the history of the building, the architect and artisans whose imagination created this marvellous building as well as the people whose influence still affects our daily lives. Then we learnt about The House of Lords through to the devolution of powers from the Monarchy to the representatives of the people in The Commons. Walking through both Houses which I have seen on TV many times, I couldn't believe how small and intimate both chambers were. This 1:45-2:00+ hour tour is tiring on the legs especially since visitors can only sit in allocated places which is torture when stood amongst the leather benches in both Houses! The 200 year old interior decor with its dark frescos, portraits, sculptures and paintings suspend your disbelief that this is still the most important working building in 21st Century United Kingdom! This tour is designed to keep old and young interested while you learn about how our emancipation has come about and why the continuation of antiquated rituals is so important to both Houses, even if they have little relevance to those outside of Parliament. Then take a boat trip from Westminster Pier (minutes away) to Greenwich Pier to see the fast vanishing Thames river history before this too vanishes under the modern glass edifices of £million offices and apartments. Highly recommended, no matter what the weather!

Historical and Interesting.. Very interesting and historical. It is a beautiful building and there is a lot of history in this building. If one is into history certainly a building that one should not miss.

Audio tour of Palace of Westminster. This was a good place to visit with my teenager who went for free with my ticket (£18). I booked the tour on line on the same day and although we arrived early was allowed to start the tour straight away. It was good to see where the MPs meet and also the Lords and to walk round at our own pace while hearing about the history. It took about 90 minutes to see it all.

A must see. What a wonderful building. We booked the visit on-line which was easy enough. You go through an airport-style security, which was fast enough and there were no queues as you get a time to visit. We took the audio tour rather than a guided tour, which was excellent as we could take our time to wander around on our own, although you are guided by roped off areas on how you proceed around the building. You can take pictures in Westminster Hall and St Stephen's Hall, but not in other areas. Well worth a visit, the décor in the House of Lords was very opulent and was lovely to see. The House of Commons room was quite small, it seems bigger when you see it on the TV screen. There were plenty of staff to assist, should you need to ask questions.

A Must-See. You absolutely cannot come to London for the first time and not see the Houses of Parliament. We saw the view from the London Eye at sunset, and it was quite possibly one of my favorite memories of London.

More than you expect. I hope our MPs stop occasionally and turn their minds to the building and its significance. They are privileged. It's a wonderful place. I once gave a short talk there in one of the back rooms using handheld notes on little cards. I don't normally do that but I was nervous as I was very conscious of where I was and some of the great speeches that had been made there. Nothing, however, had prepared me for how impressive the buildings are inside. You could describe it but it takes a better pen than mine to convey the feel of the place. Pay your money and take a guided tour. First class. The best place to see the House from is from the south side of the river in front of St Thomas' Hospital. Take some time to look at Big Ben too (see review).

Guided Tour of the Palace of Westminster. Although this is a bit pricey, we decided to do a guided tour of the Palace of Westminster. Our tour guide was not only informative but also very funny and made the history of the building come alive. I thought it was fun to be able to see both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. I enjoyed being able to walk where the Queen walks when she opens parliament. It was well worth the money for the guided tour. We showed up a bit early for our tour, and they had a few openings in the tour scheduled before us. They had us join that tour instead of waiting another 20 minutes. This was my husbands favorite sight was saw in London.

Houses of Parliament Tour. We thought this tour was great! Been to London many times, but never knew this was available. Only 90 minutes, a small group (we had 8) with a Blue Badge guide (they are tops). Thoroughly enjoyable and informative. Highly recommended.

Amazing. Wonderful history and great to see the difference between the House of Commons and the House of Lords. We booked by emailing our MP so got in for free which a lot of people don't know about but was well worth it even if we had paid.

Must see. Even better than expected. Extremely interesting and the Tour Guide (Andrew I think) was exceptional. The ex Civil Servant's knowledge and presentation was first class and his narrative full of humour.It is difficult to choose what was best and least liked. The time flew in and that is always a good way to judge an attraction.
Well worth it. We thoroughly enjoyed the guided tour. The guide was interesting and informative and allowed us plenty of time to look around as we went through the rooms.

A place all UK Citizens should visit.... It's a little known piece of information but every UK Voter has the right to ask his/her MP for a visit to the Houses of Parliament. To see where your local MP works is a great experience, one not to be missed if ever you are in London!!

Mother of Democracy. It does what is says on the ti. Many travellers have seen the iconic Elizabeth Tower with the bell, Big Ben in on television. Why not go and see the inside of this amazing building for your selves. The art, the architecture the over the top Victorian designs are stunning. If your lucky, go into the visitors gallery of the Commons and watch and listen to democracy at work.
Photo stop. A lovely view. Def worth a visit especially on a nice day. The walk over the bridge facing is a great way to see it.

Wonderful Historic Building. This is very interesting, well worth the visit and the entrance fee. Audio tour is very good and gave us so much history. After seeing this building all my life it was amazing to go inside and hear so much of the past and interesting history that has happened here. The architecture of the building is worth the visit also.
Good. It was good 2 see it up front it looks ao different in front rather on tv xxvery enjoyable xx it was a mice day out x

BEST SEEN FROM THE SOUTH BANK. Wilst you're busy looking at Big Ben, don't forget it's just the bell tower for the Houses of Parliament. Not nearly as ancient as they look, though part of the building originated in Norman Times, it's still a major attraction.

Must see!. Beautiful architecture! Breathtaking!
If you have time, definitely take a tour inside.
It's right next to Big Ben.
Another famous landmark in London. check out both day time and night time. Very different feel.

Worth the visit, specially the inside. Everybody knows this place, specially the outside. But did you know it can be visit in the inside? And let me tell you, it's worth the visit.Either with a guided tour or on your own you can see all the places you usually see on the telly. From the magnificent of the chamber of Lords to the tiny chamber of Commons and all the aisles the Queen uses annually in the opening ceremony.Really, give it a go, you won't be disappointed.
Nice biulding in a nice area. This is a nice biulding in a nice area, tourist wise I mean. It is close to Big Ben and quite fascinating to stroll around in. Sometimnes a lot of people.

Impressive place. I've been lucky enough to visit and work at both ends of the house on several occasions.It works surprisingly well as place of work and isn't anywhere as badly laidout as you might imagine.I happen to think we've got quite a good system of government and whilst there is undoubtedly the odd plonker that gets to work here most I've met work hard against all odds.The Palace itself oozes the gravitas you would expect from a place that's played such an important part in the dignification of humankind. That's not to say that there's still a long way to go, but this place, or at least parts of it have played an important part in that process for at least a 1000 years. Definitely a place you should visit. If your visiting London from overseas then I'd recommend your visit be part of a day of reflection, the other thing you should do that day is visit The British Library and have a look at the Magna Carta.
Majestic doesn't begin to describe it. Spectacular historical buildings and beautiful grounds (not to mention Big Ben!) I must see if you are in London.

Excellent guided tour!. We booked our tickets well in advance and chose the 'personal guide' option rather than the audio speaker only...we are so glad we did as there were plenty of questions to be asked and the Mother of Parliaments just wouldn't have seemed the same.Our tour guide, Tony, was engaging and professional as well as being an excellent ambassador for the historic parliament. He was amusing and knowledgeable and encouraged questions from we visitors. He was made even the youngest to the oldest of us feel like we were on our own private tour, even though there were 25 of us.We started in the great Westminster Hall where monarchs and world leaders have made historic speeches under the huge hammer beam roof which has stood since 1399...through fires, terrorist plots and two cataclysmic world wars. Kings and Queens and great men have laid in sate there as well as others being tried and heard their death sentences. You really feel you are standing in a huge room that has seen history unfold since the 11th century and continues to do so.We were then taken to the Robing room and the magnificent House of Lords...a wonderful testament to Pugin who oversaw so much guilding (23.5 c!) and colour that it makes the viewer stand in awe.The House of Commons was next and then the rooms where the respective MPs go to indicate how they are voting. I have lived in London most of my life and at last understand totally our voting system thanks to Tony our tour guide.The building is full of paintings of pivotal moments in the history of Great Britain stunning statues and busts of it's leaders everywhere you look. The 90 minute tour was over in a flash was so much of interest.There is a lovely café and afternoon tea is available in the restaurant facing the river.You really are in for a wonderful and memorable experience. I can't recommend in enough.

1,000 years of British History. I'm biased - I used to work at Westminster - but this has to be one of my favourite places in London. You are surrounded by history at every turn and even if I had spent 30 years there, I am sure there would have been something new to learn. The tours with blue badge guides are highly recommended - entertaining and informative, they are a highlight in any visit to London.
Well worth a visit. Great tour at a reasonable price. Our guide was excellent and made the experience very enjoyable. Nice coffee shop to relax in with cakes afterwards.

High tea in Parliament is the best!. One of the highlights of my London trip! Took the guided tour through House of Lords and the House of Commons, followed by an outstanding afternoon tea on the atrium terrace along the Thames--superb!

weekend break in London. Very interesting. It was good to see the inside of what people see on the tv. We had a good speaker taking us around and made the tour fascinating. Would recommend this visit.
Westmınster. It's a very nıce place! And even ıf you travel alone you can meet dıfferent people from dıfferent countrıes and have a good tıme! I do recommend!

A 'must see' in London. Excellent experience. Highly recommended when visiting London. One can visit either with an Audio handset or with the Guides. The visit was with children of 8 and 11 years and they followed nicely whithout getting bored.

A must do visit in London. This visit was excellent. I booked my ticket online with an audio tour (18£) and I arrived directly to the Parliament (the entrance is on the street between Houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey). There is a security screening (not so bad) prior to entering the building itself. As soon as you arrive there's the table with the audio guides, select your language and you will receive a map of the building. The audio guide is very good, has so many details, and there are a few places where you can seat, listen and admire the building. Is very well organized, it's not a long tour (1-1.30hrs) but it's excellent. It doesn't matter if you know about England history and politics or not you will definitely enjoy it. The visit to the Lords Chamber and the Commons Chamber was the best part for me, but there are plenty of highlights such as the Royal Gallery and Westminster Hall. The dates and times for visiting are very specific so make sure to check their website to see available dates.
Oozing history (but you knew that) :-). It's an amazing building - although sadly it's crumbling to pieces - and with the right guide, it really comes to life. Definitely worth a visit.
a landmark. It is of course a landmark in London, and you can't miss it if you go to the city center. The building is beautiful with all the history.
Visit to parliament.. Wonderful experience.attended a meeting in one of the rooms. Very helpful staff as my mother is in a wheelchair

Beautiful building.. Was walking by on my way to a meeting sun was shining and was just admiring what is undoubtably a lovely building it is just a shame over the last 20 odd years it's been populated by a bunch of self loathing privately educated middle class muppets not a patch on the politicians of the past but still grin and bear it suck it up and admire the beautiful architecture of a by gone age.

Eye opener. Allow time for the queueing prior to your timed visit and security checks. However, we had a brilliant tour guide who made the tour so interesting. Tour takes about one and a half hours without many places to sit and rest so unsuitable for those with walking difficulties. There was quite a lot of noise in some areas as the floor was being renovated so we had to wear headphones. Interesting to see Parliament and learn about its workings. allowed to go into all the Commons and Lords. All was very interesting and not at all boring which was what some of us had feared.

Discover Interesting History and Traditions. We had a private guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, our guide was actually a key player, specifically of interest was his role in the "Black Rod" Tradition, therefore extremely knowledgeable, articulate, well versed in an incredible amount of interesting facts surrounding Parliament's current role in society and the importance of the roles within it along with traditions passed down and still in practice today. For example by tradition, the British Sovereign does not enter the Chamber of the House of Commons. The last King to enter was in 1642 so when you visit you have access to an area where even the queen can not go!!

Home to the 'Mother of Parliaments'.. Since my last, detailed review I have been past these wonderful buildings several times and after a private visit to Portcullis House (reviewed separately) we were taken through the passageway under the road, walked past the base of Elizabeth Tower (known by most as 'Big Ben') and went into Westminster Hall where we were given champagne and a great illustrated lecture in a side room.This should really be known as the Palace of Westminster. The two Houses of Parliament sit here in their respective chambers.The exterior of these beautiful buildings is one of the most recognisable sights in the world.

Westminster Palace. Having visited London a number of time before this was a must see for this trip and didn't disappoint. This was one of the highlights of our London trip that I would recommend to anyone who has an interest in history, architecture and/or politics. The audio tour was very informative and conducted by a knowledgeable guide. Each participant had their own headset and the guide a microphone so was easily heard as we traveled through the Palace. A fascinating tour where we learnt a great deal about the evolution of the Palace's from Westminster Hall to what it is today. All perfectly finished off with Afternoon Tea (extra price & ticket booking required 27.50 pounds + extra for champagne) served on the Terraces. Best Afternoon Tea we had this visit, magic!

Should Have Done The Audio Guided Tour. Was really interesting. Sadly our tour guide was not very good. She might have been under instructions to hurry us up all the time but also could not answer all the questions people had either becsause not enought time or she didnt know the answer and said she really should check. Well not much cop to us as we arent going back to see if she found answers out. I would reccomend people took the audio guides. Enough negatives a most beautiful building that you just dont apreciate just from looking on from the outside. A must for all all visitors to and from London.
Amazing view. Cannot visit London without stopping over, I have attended various free seminars here which have been of great insight,

Guided tour is worth it!. I was so glad we did a guided tour instead of just the audio tour. Andrew was our guide. We learned so much about the history and traditions of this building and operation. Having someone available to answer questions and share some backstory to some of the unusual seeming traditions was so interesting. I doubt you'd have the same experience without having a guide.

Centuries of History.. This was an amazing visit, so interesting, and helped by a very knowledgeable guide.Best to book in advance on the internet, one is then given a time slot, as they are very busy. Also best to go when parliament is not siting, so that one can go into the two chambers.

Great picture spot. A must-not-lose spot of London. Too many tourists around, too many commerce in the streets (watch out - souvenirs here are more expensive than in Oxfort St, for example). The scene including Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament and the red buses on the street is magic to see, like it has left the postcard and come to real life. Pictures are great at any time.

Incredible architecture. Having visited the Houses of Parliament numerous times both on business and for leisure it never ceases to evoke strong feelings about history and governance.Much to many's surprise the building is not as old as most would think, yet the gothic design is an incredible testament to all those involved in its design and construction.Having visited a number of other parliament / government buildings throughout Europe visitors are for obvious reason more constrained in their ability to take photographs and even sit down during the tour. It is hard to understand why photographs cannot be permitted in at least some parts and the latter can be a challenge for older or less ambulant visitors. Tour guides are knowledgeable and very helpful but move at a pace that sometimes prevents visitors from simply standing a while to enjoy or examine architecture, statues, paintings etc in more detail.
great fotos. what can one say, if you go to LONDON you have to take a few fotos of this stunning view , great pics with BIG bem.
Majestic. All the secrets of the British parliament in one place. You'll find everything you want, with tranquility and serenity. You will also be guided by a guide if you want, or you can go alone.
