Fantastic tour. We had a great guide. Very knowledgeable and articulate. Gave us a lot of history, and finally we got to see a Lord there.

lovely. Lovely place to visit - definitely somewhere to visit due to its history. However very crowded and our tour guide was talking too quiet - I noticed a few people complaining to each other that they couldn't hear what she was saying but from the few parts i managed to hear, she was very informative.
Very Interesting Inside. A great place to visit and worth every penny. It is a guided tour but unlike some this is not boring, it was very interesting for adults and my teenagers.

A must, but take the audio tour. Took a guided tour that lasted exactly the promised 90 minutes (but didn't start on time because they wanted to add more people? Bit strange as you book for a set timeslot). But it was nicely done. The usual anecdotes and everything. I would have like to spend more time in certain areas though so I recommend the audio tour. I have a feeling you might miss out on a few stories but the information you get is no doubt more detailed and you can pick and choose where to spend more time. On the whole: well worth the visit. Great to see all those places you know quite well from TV!

The best staff in Britain (on recess days). The experienced, courteous, helpful staff started at the entrance outside, through security, throughout the whole audio tour and cream tea, when five of us visited. I pushed my mother in a wheelchair for her 103rd birthday outing and extra courtesy was shown when we had to divert with the help of escorts for wheelchair access. It was a wonderful experience, wholly due to the staff. They all deserve an award. A place to sit now and then during the tour would have been welcome whilst pushing the wheelchair, but thankfully I was wearing flat, comfortable shoes. It's a pity we weren't allowed to take more photographs except when eating our cream tea. Once again, congratulations on the courteousness of the staff throughout.

Make sure you get tickets in advance. We approached the visitors entrance only to be told that the ticket office was in the "black building" near the Westminster Underground stop. the wait for tickets was quite long so it might be worthwhile to try and use the internet in advance.There are guided tours (sold out for us - another reason to use the internet) and a self guides tour which was really quite good. Standing the Houses of Parliament was really quite amazing. Note photos are not allowed past the main entrance hall.
Wonderful architecture.. Did not visit the inside. Just looked outside the Westminster Palace. So I am not able to comment. Will go inside in future.

The View of a Commoner. For the second time in just under two years I had the honor of beinginvited to the House of Commons as a guest of one of the Membersof Parliament, who like me had attended the London School of Economicsand Political Science. The purpose of the visit was to attend a Gala Dinnerto be held in the Members Dining Room on Saturday, 11th.July, 18.30pm. I journeyed by rail from Northampton's new railway station, which is now very modern, and purchased, a first-class ticket to Euston station on Friday 11th. July, 2015, using London Midland, as I had booked a room at the London Holiday Inn, Mayfair. On the day of the Gala Dinner, I hired a taxi from the hotel to the Houses of Parliament andfound the taxi fares had again increased, so it is an expensive means of travel. A London red bus would have been too difficult given the route.The Houses of Parliament are a wonderful monument to the democracy of the country, but now face a huge cost for having the buildings refurbished and broughtinto the 21st.century for internal use of telecommunications and all the relatedfacilities for running a government. On arrival I found security to be extremely highand after a thorough search we were allowed in suing the Black Rod entrance.Guests were treated top a lovely chilled glass of champagne or an orangejuice as an option. The ambience of the building is unique and before the Galadinner we were treated to a guided tour of the premises. On my visit in 2014 I hadnot en joyed that privelege. The tour was most enlightening and I was surprisedby just how small the Chamber for Members of Parliament is, as the opposition andthose holding power by general election face each other during specific times.Like school they have terms, and when not in the Houses of Parliament they attendtheir local political functions and deal directly with members of the public, such asa Commoner, like me. After the tour we again had drinks prior to being seated inthe Members Dining Room which was a splendid room sited close to the RiverThames and adjoining balcony. An evening to remember as for the first time Ihad sat on a seat for both the Opposition and the Party in power, the Conservatives run by the Hon. David Cameron PM, PM. The Mp who had invited me and othersfor the Gala Dinner was Stephen Pound Mp to whom I and others of the day areeternally grateful for being able to attend such a wonderful venue. Maybe as a Commoner I will receive another invitation? Who knows?Geoffrey E. Dixon-Hamilton, editor@nordic-times.co.uk. (Sat. 11th. July, 2015). Sun. 6th.September, 2015. 11.13am gmt

Beautiful but crowded. We didn't go inside, but be warned that the area is extremely busy and crowded in the summer, which makes it hard to stop, take pictures, and appreciate the beauty of the buildings. I would avoid going midday if possible. A tad bit disappointed that parts of the external building were undergoing construction/renovation during one of the busiest times of the year. Nonetheless a beautiful, iconic piece of architecture that can't be missed when in London.

Buidlings dating to as early as the 15th century. A large group of government buildings dating from as early as the 15th century. Historically important sand on of the most famous sights in London. The clock tower known a Big Ben and adjacent to Westminster Abey. Get a good look fro the eye located across the rivwer

The Seat of Government. You don't need a tourist guide to know which building is which, London and in particular The House of Parliament has featured in so many films and TV shows that we all know London. It us an impressive building and stands out even though it is near lots of other interesting buildings. Last year on a flight from Dublin to London I was amazed how easy It was to see The a House of Parliament as we decended to land at Heathrow.This area of London is popular for spotting exotic cars with Arabic plates.
To Understand the Government Process. Out of the traditional, for understanding the style of living, the government ruling and some of the political structure of the United Kingdom.

Great insight into the running of the country.. Bought tickets and guide book online. Very easy process. Very impressed with the quality of the guide book at just £5. Went as a family with two older teenage sons. They thouroughly enjoyed the whole experience. The audio tour is well done with lots of extra bits of information. Guided tours available but preferred the audio as you can then go at your own pace. Would highly recomend this as a must see attraction.
Good experience to learn about the England Politics. 建議參加有專人導覽的參觀，可以充分了解英國國會的運作，同時可以在一般遊客不能進入的區域聽講解。裡面不能拍照。The guided tour is really good. No photo allowed inside.

Hey look kids, there's Big Ben, and there's Parliament.... This was a good landmark to visit and I would highly recommend a guided tour so you get better context for what you're seeing. Security getting in was a bit more aggressive than it needed to be but after that, the experience was great. I was surprised at how much smaller both the House of Commons and House of Lords chambers were than they appear on TV. You can buy tickets ahead of time through their website/Ticketmaster but we had our hotel concierge do it right before we left the hotel and had no problems.

Fantastic Tour & PMQ's. My wife arranged a tour of Portcullis House and the Houses of Parliament with a sit in at the public gallery for PM Q's. A fantastic day and, as you can expect, history overload. Highly recommended.

Magical History Tour. The audio tour lasts around 90 minutes. At a cost of £45 we also pre booked an Afternoon Tea. You will need to go through security so you do need to allow enough time especially weekends & holidays.The audio is incredibly informative and steeped in the Kings & Queens of England history taking you through to modern day politics. Most of the tour doesn't allow you to take pictures which is completely understandable given that most of the year our most prominent people come together. The architecture is stunning, with iconic paintings of the battle of Waterloo through to statues of Maggie Thatcher & Sir Winston ChurchillAfternoon Tea is served overlooking the Thames. It isn't neccessarily a large portion but just enough for lunch with the opportunity to venture out into the balcony and take some amazing photosIf you are a history buff who love architecture this is for you. Even if you don't want Afternoon Tea there is a cafe available. A must see even if you are a Londoner

a living palace. you can feel life inside Westminster and so much history in it. There s so much to learn about how the UK government works and I d be thrilled to participate to the debates when they take place
Amazing Hitory. Beautiful and historic Palace of Westminster has very limited visiting hours and must be booked in advance.Can be combined with afternoon tea.

UK History. Thus venue is not open to large groups all year round - just at certain times of the year in the summer. Don't be put off by politics. This is an iconic building and full of history. It is an awesome place to visit. Security is obviously tight - expect airport scanners. Groups are taken round by friendly and informative guides. I'm really glad I visited - it inspired me learn more about how our government works.

Well worth a visit. Somewhere I have always wanted to visit. You walked through both chambers , the commons and the House of Lords but you were not allowed to sit down - that would have been an experience ! Great visit and very interesting.

3 day tour in London and this was the best part. Booked last minute and thoroughly enjoyed it. Make sure you do the guided tour, not only was the guide (Russell) entertaining but was full of knowledge which made the visit so much more enjoyable.

Great building history learnt. Wow what a building. No queues when we visited. The audio tour is very info marine. Great to see parliament in real life. Took us about 80 mins to get round. One thing when you come out of tube turn left then left to buy tickets

Great... wonderful building and great audioguide. We stayed several days in London and this visit was not planned beforehand. Just as well we made it. The kids were happy with the audioguides.Wonderful place and not overcrowded as so many attractions in London.The Parliament is definitely worth a visit and such a great value. For me and my husband it was the highlight of our visit to London this year.

Sore legs. Prime Minister Question Time is a the best thing to do here!!! If you are travelling around London for a few days make sure you plan this on a day you wont be walking around much on! This is because you are not allowed to sit in any seats!!! You will definitely do a lot of standing, especially if you get the same boring guide that we did.
British Architecture at its Best. I recently visited the The House of Lords for an event. The architecture is brilliant. If you get time, it's recommend to go for the tours they conduct.
A highlight. The Houses of Parliament guided tour was outstanding. The guide was entertaining and extremeley knowledgeable. A higlight of my trip to London.

Absolutely fascinating. We paid for the guided tour. The guide was extremely good, with a wealth of information. Well worth the extra few pounds over the audio guide. Never realised how much art there is in Parliament.

One of the Best. We took the self-guided tour with our two grandchildren (age 15) and easily spent almost two hours. These are spectacularly beautiful rooms, the history is fascinating, and we loved going at our own pace, lingering when and where we chose. This is an absolute must-see.

Great Value & most interesting. My wife & I did the guided tour. It lasts 90 minutes. The guide was excellent. The guide gave lots of information and answered all the questions without any notes. You get the explanation of the Kings & Queens (esp Henry VIII) for overseas visitors but not too much. You see the House of Lords & the Commons but not Big Ben, which has a separate tour.

A must visit if you're interested in British politics.. If you're interested in British politics and history, go on a guided tour to the two Houses of Parliament. The tour will be led by a knowledgeable guide who will share interest bits of history and facts about the palace and the institution. If you wish to tour the palace leisurely, go on a self guided audio tour as the guided tour can be quite rushed.

Definitely should go. This is a serious place with serious history! Our visit was interesting and educational. Perhaps not so suitable for very young children, but this place definitely deserves a visit when in London. Highly recommended!

Wonderful Tour of Parliament and Cream Tea - some minor glitches. I visited the House of Parliament with a friend in late August 2015. We had the English speaking Guided tour (i.e. with an actual person guiding us, rather than a go-at-your-own-pace machine) followed by a Cream Tea on the Terrace overlooking the River Thames. The Tour started on time. You have to go through airport security at the start (remove belts, walk through a scanner, etc). We then gathered in Westminster Hall. The Tour doesn't spend very long in Westminster Hall - but you *can* take photos there, which is not true of most of the rest of the tour. Allow yourself some time to complete doing the hall by yourself on the way back out. It was a hot day outside (getting on for 30 degrees) and the House of Parliament had varying degrees of air-con: the House of Commons was cool, the House of Lords was OK, but some places were a bit stuffy. There were some places to sit down, but you are NOT allowed to sit in the Commons or the Lords - supposedly in case we damaged the seating and because the Commons/Lords don't like it. Hmm. Not impressed: any damage could easily have been repaired for a lot less money than they make from the tours, and we are the people who Parliament is supposed to serve, so not letting us sit on their seats was a bit hoity toity of them.Our guide had a microphone and we had heaphones so that she could speak in a normal speaking tone and we could all hear her. However, her microphone wasn't working properly, so her voice kept dropping out, and at other times there were loud pops and crackles. It was easier for most of the time just to remove the headsets and listen to her natural speaking voice. I thought this was pretty poor.The guide was friendly and knowledgeable, talking about the history of the palace and of parliament. I know a fait bit about this topic already and didn't spot any errors. The tour in front of us was behind time, which made our guide rather agitated, and the tour ended 15 minute late. Overall the tour was thoroughly enjoyable and informative, but let down by the audio equipment.We then went on to our cream tea (booked in advance) which was eye wateringly expensive, BUT we loved it. The service was excellent: efficient but friendly. We were in a kind of marquee set up on the terrace of the House of Parliament overlooking the Thames. We had timed ticket and expected to be move on after about 45 minutes, but we were there for an hour and a half. The tent wasn't too hot, and we got refills of tea. Towards the end we got to move out of the tent and onto the terrace proper. We could take photos. The food was nice (if a bit noveau cuisine with the least messy Eton mess I have ever had - meringue, cream and fruit all in separate layers).Overall, for the tour and the tea: pricey but worth it, with some minor annoyances on our tour.
Magnificent History of Legislative Stronghold. Magnificent tour of both houses of Parliament with very gracious guides. Always schedule afternoon tea as a highlight to the visit.

Fascinating Tour Of "The Mother Of Parilaments"!. We did an audio tour. This was packed with fascinating information! You could do the basic tour or choose options for more details if you preferred. It was fascinating to learn about the history of this British iconic institution. Having seen it so many times on television it was great to walk through the House Of Commons and House Of Lords and see were all theses debates take place.The architecture close up is amazing.This is a must see once in a live time as a tourist or a local!
A Must See. If viewing from the river or street take a look at this iconic building, the place that Guy Fawkes tried to destroy & where Churchill made those important decisions.

spectacular and interesting a must see. absolutely awesome visit , this is a must see and do for anyone . nothing can quite prepare you for this fantastic tour . you do not need to be interested in politics as the history , the architecture , decoration will take your breath away . tours need to be booked in advance online and the tour guides are incredibly knowledgeable and enthusiastic . also a top tip at the end of the tour I advise visiting the cafe before leaving as the prices are very reasonable and you can say that you drank tea and ate cake at the houses of parliment .... brilliant !!!

What a surprise. What a surprise, very interesting, loved every minute of it, really a must for the London experience. The statues, the paintings, use the audio tour, gives you a lot of information, even if you are not interested in modern government, the history of the Gun Powder Plot, the trials and the executions, great value for money, never thought I would say that
Great tour. Great tour with my son - open in the summer and really cool to tour through House of Lords and Commons with all the history!
Parliament. Interesting place to visit hope you dont mind crowds. best bet is to buy a ticket on some of the bus tours around the city
Great Icon and Landmark - this IS London. This staely "Icon" on London cannot be missed - great structure and a truly visual landmark that means no pinching - it's not a dream you ARE in London
Highly recommend. This tour is very interesting - inside is simply beautiful - if you love history and art - this is great , so glad I have been.

the powerhouse of all that is british. this place just has to be seen.the houses of parliament are set on the backdrop of the thames river.you can get great views from either the river or the bridge, some great photos to be had. be ware of the street traders and pick pockets

Iconic. This should be everyone's first stop in London, I think. My partner, who used to live in London wasn't interested in coming, so I took a long and leisurely tour and learned quite a bit about this historic site.
A Great Day. A BRILLIANT official tour, access all areas and very informative.Will definitely visit again next time.
great tour. good tour of parliament and some interesting factstour group was small enough for guide to talk everyone

It might be falling down but it still has it.... It might be falling down but it still has it on so many levels - It is on nearly every tour for obvious reasons and as a Londoner I have to recomend it!
Trip round parliament. Had a tour around the houses of parliament. Well worth booking and doing as you learn so much. Plus the guides are both entertaining & informative.

Really enjoyed the tour.. Excellent tour guide, Vicky, she answered all the questions & gave us a really informative, enjoyable tour. Beautiful building full of history. Afternoon tea in the terrace pavilion restaurant was a bit of a let down, we left hungry, next time we'd use the regular cafe which appeared a lot better value for money.
Business. What an amazing place. Had a business meeting here and was lucky to get a tour of the layout. Just a wonder of London.

Iconic!. Ever since I was a small child I have seen pictures of thes iconic parliament. So beautiful, and the power of Big Ben, to know that it has tolled for so many people for so many years! I lived in London for a great number of years and I always loved to see these buildings on travellings around this amazing city.
Fascinating and informative tour. Highly recommend paying for the guided tour rather than the audio tour. An absolutely fascinating look into the history of parliament and how it functions.
thames. lovely place very clean and very nice view and a walk by the river will be verry relaxing.specialy in evening.

Lots of information around , including Parliament Square. . Lots to see around here. Parliament Square has a great deal of history in famous statues. All of great likeness. Was amazing to see the amount of space around here. I always has the impression that it was a really busy place , although there were quite a few of large groups of guides filling the tourists with information, which I found rather interesting to learn , while standing nearby. Plenty of photographs to be taken here.

Fantastic interesting place to visit. we booked a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament and i must say it was one of the most amazing places we visited while in London the History and decor of this place is mind blowing i would highly reccommend paying this place a vist and taking the guided tour which was well worth the money.

Excellent guided tour . Found this to be an excellent tour and well worth the £20 we paid for the guide tour. We had good weather so walking around the Houses of Parliament was really fantastic. Glad to have visited
Great Architecture. I love the architecture, Big Ben is part of this and the Westminster Abbey is right next door. Hit all 3 sites in one go.

A lovely surprise and a real highlight. We took the tour in the morning for the Houses of Parliament. It was a small tour group and we had a great lady as our guide. She was older and had a passion for politics. This made the tour very interesting. I am from England but learned a lot about the system of politics that I didn't know. Don't think this tour is dry by any means. It was very interesting. We saw art and architecture as well as the two houses (Lords and Commons) and learned about the traditions and how the Queen fits into it all. Our son is 11 and he loved the tour too. The tour has a lot of information and it a long one so younger kids might not like it. All in all a real gem and a highlight on our trip.

Superb Tour. Organised by our local MP Stuart Andrew North West Leeds. The trip was free and covered both houses with his personal assistant on hand to offer interesting guidance and information which we all found fascinating.
Mp for the day 😊. Well worth a visit..look behind the scenes, imagine your seat in parliament or just take in the surroundings. Recommended. Very interesting trip.

Magnificent . Having travelled around quite a lot whenever I return to London the majesty of this building always surprises me. Despite seeing it on TV on a daily basis the intricacies are truly beautiful and really believe that this outshines the vast majority of buildings anywhere else in the world.
Must Do. Stunning, Must do views are amazing from all angles. Short walk to the London eye, another must do......
Stunning Historical Landmark. After walking past this many times in the place I was absolutely delighted to do the audio tour. It was so interesting. Well worth the money.
Only toured the outside. We only walked on the outside, but out tour guide gave us a lot of information about the on goings inside!
Selfie Stick Highway. Trying to walk past this is like walking down a selfie stick highway! But still worth the trek! Very busy but amazing to see.
Very interesting. Great value for money. Plenty to see and the audio guides were excellent. My teenage sons found it very interesting. Also a reasonably priced coffee shop on site.

Must see. Excellent explanation, I came here with friends 2 years ago without booking a guided tour. At entrance they advised all english tours were gone but they still have availability for the spanish ones so we went for it. Was fab, the Spanish guide was very explicative and gave us a glimpse of the history. We really enjoyed it. We all liked it!
You have to live it to believe it!. You have to live it to believe it! It is a great feeling of everything, I am sorry I am unable to express how wonderful is just being there.

Beautiful and proud testament to British architecture and design!. Went as staff on school trip. Amazing opportunity to see such a beautiful and historic landmark. tour guide was great and whole event was well organised and fun for adults and children alike. Only wish I'd had more time to stand and gawp at the amount of glorious detail!
Amazing experience. Our visit was extra special because we had a friend that works in parliament so granted us access to some places others can go, but even without that was a great visit.

A Must-See. A trip to London is not complete without a visit to the Houses of Parliament. They are visible from the banks and worth a trip. We did the audio tour, and not the guided tour, which I understand is much better.

Iconic landmark. Well worth a look if you are visiting London. Take photos from across the river to get the best view. Westminster Cathedral, Downing Street, London Eye and Embankment close by too. Easy access to Tube station.

Most beautiful Parliament !!!!. I think I can try to run for elections just to be party or people who gets regular access to this place !!!! Both house of common and house of Lords area is beautiful done !!! The common gallery is studded with sculptures of former great Britain prime ministers !!! There are some amazing century old traditions to be seen !! The door of house of common had a mark of regular beating of rod on it !!! Make sure you go inside the Parliament add must people just admire the beauty of the place from outside but real traditions are hidden inside !!!

AMAZING - Once in a lifetime experience. Myself and a friend arranged through an MP that we could climb to the top of Big Ben. Guided tours are arranged my the house of commons and have to be booked via and MP or member of the house of lords. Tour groups and met in Portvullis House and screened by security, they are then met by a tour guide. The tour itself is brilliant, its a really fascinating few hours. one word of warning you need to be fit, the tour is long and consosts of climbing hundreds of small steps to the top of the tower with only a couple of breaks. howver if you can manage the climb, it is we worth it. its a really special experience, and the view from the top of the tower is really amazing. this is definately one of the best experience ive jad while living in london
Tea at Parliament. We did the afternoon tea at Parliament. Nice ambiance for a British tea. You can watch the boats on the River Thames while having tea.

Britain at its best. An amazing enlightening fact packed tour that should be taken by every true blue Brit. There were so many amazing facts and anecdotes that we have not stopped quoting since our trip - Highly recommended, please don't miss out on not doing this tour

Great to see. We had a private guided tour by a member of staff that we know. Topped off with lunch on the parliamentary terrace and a mooch around the shop! Very interesting and great how it has so many areas open to the public. I think this is a great historical tour and part of our British history.

Well worth a visit. Book a guided tour. This was very interesting tour with lots of information on the history of how our democracy developed. The building itself is arctectually interesting. Well worth the cost. There is also a audio tour available which may be more suitable to those who which to amble round.
Great place in London. Great place in London ti visit - best view of the houses parliament is across the river.. a short walk ..

Brilliant Tour. We had an organised tour which was excellent, I learnt so much on the tour, it was a shame that there was a lot of building work going on and scaffolding but you can't take photos anyway. The House of Commons room was amazing. We then had tea on the terrace which was a bit of a rip off for £27.50 each!

Part of a group tour. Was part of a group tour earlier this year and was very impressed with the tour. We toured Parliament before seeing inside both Houses (Lord's and Commons) before watching a debate in the latter. Well worth a visit and very educational for younger people.
Must visit place in london. Wow, Its always nice to see the English parliament and its fascinating architecture. Very busy place be prepared for hussle and bustle.

Learn how it works. Very interesting guided tour and tea on the terrace over looking the river.So much history in the building and the guide, Val, did a great job with lots of facts and a few interesting stories.If you like old historical buildings this is a must.
MOTHER OF PARLIAMENTS.. Makes a great backdrop for photo's. Has scaffolding erected ATM. Not sure if you can get inside these days. Certainly has a great many people swarming around it.

Highlight of our City Break. This was the highlight of our short break. We had a guided tour for two hours. It was so interesting and even the café was nice and reasonably priced. My 13 year old son really enjoyed it too. Recommend you book in advance and go.

Interesting. Had the guided tour on a Saturday in the lead up to the general election so it was quiet. You get to see slightly more than the audio tour. Very interesting with lots to see. Fairly expensive but it's pretty much the only way to see inside.
10-day Holiday in London. The houses of parliament, even though everyone has seen them from the outside, are even more impressive from the inside. A definitive to see

Stunning London landmark, steeped in history, an attraction definitely worth a visit. Absolutely stunning building which is steeped in history, it is a must see attraction when in London. There is a choice you can either have a guided tour, or an audio tour which you conduct yourself, the audio is in different languages, the information is informative, knowledgeable and the speed is just right, you will get a really good insight into what goes on in there. The security is tight and the building is being renovated in certain areas, you will see how magnificent this building is and the history it contains, The tour is available most weekdays during Parliamentary recesses it will take about 60-75mins. The interior is stunning and carefully preserved with a lot of lovely stunning art works and decorations. The 2 chambers: The House of Lords and House of Commons are fascinating to see, I definitely recommend this tour.

Would fully recommend the guided tour. When buying tickets you can opt for either an audio guide or an actual guide. We had a real life guide and it was great! We got to go to places that we wouldn't have gone otherwise and the guide was extremely knowledgable. This is a very interesting and unique experience - would fully recommend.

Great learning experience!. We learned so much visiting here! We would definitely recommend making time to visit. We booked an audio tour and were very pleased. There was a wait to get in, but mostly due to security checks. The audio tour was very informative! Lots of places to sit and rest as we were listening to the audio tour which was really great after walking around all morning visiting tourist sites. It was really an awe-struck moment to visit the Lords Chamber and the Commons chamber. Lots of history...great visit!
Building was gorgeous. Myself and my husband enjoyed going here although more him than me, visually a lovely building.My husband was happy to see a famous MP.

Impressive landmark - best photos from bank opposite or Westminster bridge. A stunning, impressive building rich in history and well worth seeing as a landmark along with Big Ben. the best photos are definitely from the bank opposite or the bridge. would love to return at some point and tour inside at leisure (without the kids!)

Full of clowns to make you laugh. GREAT BUILDING WITH A CIRCUS ACT INSIDE WELL WORTH A VISIT Love this place so much every time i'm up to London i come here to have a Laugh and admire the architecture trully amazing place.

Parliament. Excellent value and fascinating experince. Much smaller than it appears on Tv.Only downside some of the foreign tour guides not as informative as they should be. Thoroughly reccommend for everyone.

An attraction that can not be missed. The Houses of Parliament are the best sample of British gothic architecture. Located on the banks of river Thames, it is an attraction that can not be missed when travelling to London.

A great look inside English politics. This is such an interesting site. Self directed tours with audio guide cost 18 Pounds. Tickets can be purchased online or in person (in advance, or on the day), from the Ticket Office located at the front of Portcullis House on Victoria Embankment- a 10 min walk from the Parliament entrance. Tours are available to visitors from the UK and overseas on Saturdays throughout the year, and on most weekdays during Parliamentary recesses. The tours are very popular in Summer. We were just lucky enough to get the last tickets at 2.30pm for the 4.30pm tour (last for the day) on a Sat in July. The tour takes about 60-75mins. The interior is beautiful with a lot of lovely art works and decorations. The 2 chambers: The House of Lords and House of Commons are fascinating to see-a bit smaller than I would have expected, and a lot of microphones hanging from the ceilings! The audio guide is very informative. No photos allowed. I highly recommend this tour.

Busy but Beautiful. Fantastic building and a must see when in London. The guided tour is a little expensive but the Guide was very knowledgeable and witty and gave us a really good insight into what goes on in there. Arrive early, security is tight and school holidays are very busy. The building is under constant renovation and when you see how magnificent it is, you'll realise what the £25 entrance fee is being spent on!
great. great place to see with big ben being the main thing to look at, tacky little stands along the way selling everything with I love london on, but then that may be your thing.

Another tick in the box. We arrived half an hour early for our planned visit but were allowed to enter early. I booked the audio tour which was very informative and interesting. If you are interested in the history of England this is definitely worth a visit. The facilities at the end of the tour are reasonably priced (don't let the government know or they'll hike the prices!) and the toilets were very clean and serviced

Very good explanation. It was great to visit the Houses of Parliament, such a great monument showing the long history of Britain, the guided tour was very informative and the tour was a great opportunity to touch base with UK history

Amazing history, special place.. We had an amazing visit to the houses of parliament, it was unreal. We booked our tickets on the day £18 for audio tour, one child free with a paying adult.Was greeted at entrance by friendly staff, went to a security check then onward to the second security check (like airport security).You arrive at the entrance to Westminster hall, spectacular entrance, oozing history. Pick up your audio here and relax and enjoy the breathtaking tour. The tour will take you 1 and 1/2 hrs approx. Take your time and soak up the history. Kids loved it, they had the kids audio and loved the facts and questions!Enjoy the queens robing room, the royal gallery, the prince's chamber, the lord's chamber, central lobby, members lobby, voting lobby, commons chamber......spectacular!Its so unbelievable to think of all the historic icons that walked through these buildings.We didn't visit the coffee shop but we did pop into the gift shop , it wasn't very big, we bought a small fridge magnet as a souvenir of our visit. The toilets are very grand and clean.The entry and exit grounds are an amazing place for pictures with big ben and London eye in background!We had an amazing visit. Be prepared for renovations if you visit, there was work being done in various places in the building. This doesn't take away from the tour or the visit itself though.Enjoy, enjoy, enjoy.......

Where the laws are made. There are 2 houses inside. One House of Parliament, another House of Lords. We thought they will be in full costume in House of Lords, but they weren't. Entrance is free. You can roam around. Just go up the stairs quietly and observed how laws are debated. Security screening.
Beautiful . Even with the pouring rain we did not regret our visit at all. We were astonished by the beautiful details of Houses of Parliament and Big Ben.

As Good as I'd Imagined. This is the must-see landmark in London if you visit and don't have time to see anything else. It is best viewed from the opposite bank of the Thames on a sunny morning. I sat there on my last morning in London watching streams of Londoners hurrying to work and not even looking up at this marvelous architectural treasure in their midst. Worth going out of your way to see.
Really interesting!. Houses of Parliament in London were excellent! Beautiful building and audio tour was really interesting. Worth every penny to visit. Would thoroughly recommend!

Guided Tour. Very interesting. Guide knowledgable but her voice didn't carry very well so it was difficult to hear and I felt they were too many people in the group. Wish I had just done the audio tour.

Excellent! Impressive!. to his colorful stories and background information. The size of the place is impressive and dwarfs the US Congress. We had an afternoon tea which was a nice addition to our visit and made us feel like aristocrats.
Historical site. This is one of the most historical sites in London. I was invited to a function there when I had the opportunity to visit.

Top Notch Tour Guides. The guided tour of Parliament offered great historical information and our guide was quite generous in responding to our questions. Our group experience 2 different guides and had the same reaction to the quality of the guide's delivery.

You're in London - you have to see it.... Don't just look at it on the outside.It's more than just a clock tower - it's a democratic institution that had been copied across the globe.Take the tour and, if Parliament is in session, stop and listen to the debates in both the House of Commons and the Lords.It's an world famous view of London but it's so much more than that.

London in dream. Looking at the House of Parliament from the other side of the bank would present you with the best photo opportunity of the trip. Wait for a cruise to cross and take the best picture for your album!!! :) :)

Historic place. Big Ben and Houses of Parliament is a must see location for those visiting London. Great architecture, one can keep looking at its beauty for hours. Must visit with children for its educational value.
really good. Brought my 12 year old here thinking he might find it boring however he really enjoyed the debates well worth the visit

A must-do. We've always wanted to go into the Houses of Parliament but it never occurred to us that we might be able to until last week. I believe UK citizens can arrange a free tour through their MP but we booked it last minute on the internet the night before our day trip to London - you can do a guided tour but we opted for the self-guided audio tour which cost £18 each.If you book online you can either print your ticket at home or collect on the day. We don't have a printer so opted to collect at the ticket office - for info, when you get there there isn't really any signage that tells you where to go except a sign saying "visitors entrance". You just walk along with the Houses to your left until you come to a big barrier with police. We said we were collecting tickets and they let you into the other side of the barrier, tell you where to wait, then someone comes out, takes your details, and goes and gets your tickets for you. Once you have your tickets, you go through security, which is straightforward - bags through the scanner, you go through the metal detector, they give you a visitor pass, job done. You can take liquids through - they asked me to show them my aerosol (deodorant!) but I was allowed to keep it. For info, we were booked onto an audio tour at 11:40, we picked up our tickets around 11:10, we spent about 5-10 minutes at security, then we were in. That was a Saturday in August. You pick up your audio guide in the Westminster Hall and that's it, you're away. Photography is allowed in Westminster Hall & St Stephen's Hall but everywhere else it's strictly prohibited and you will get told off if you are caught but that's all - my husband got a ticking-off but he wasn't made to delete anything or show anyone his camera.Anyway, the tour: it takes you through from Westminster Hall, through to the Central Lobby, House of Lords, House of Commons, and back again. The whole building is absolutely gorgeous and the sense of history is overwhelming - the audio guide takes you through some of the things that have happened within those walls - not to mention that you are walking in places where world leaders and monarchs have trod and where they continue to tread today! The audio itself is very good, although I tended to drift off after a while. You hear from current and former members of parliament, and get a thorough history of the place. But you go at your own pace so you can listen to it as much as you like or as little. The only downside really is that being such an old building, it is constantly under repair. On our trip the tiles in the middle of the Central Lobby were being replaced so there was a mini scaffold in the middle of the floor. But you just have to get on with it. At the end of the tour, there is a cafe and gift shop. We didn't find anything interesting in the gift shop but had tea and cake in the cafe and found it reasonably-priced - pot of tea for one: £1.95, huge slice of cake: £3 or thereabouts. There is a good selection of cakes and, well, everything really. The cafe is clean and the crockery is from Stoke! Overall this was a brilliant trip and an absolute must-do whether you're a native or a visitor - we are British and for us it was incredible to be at the seat of power and also to be somewhere that has so much history but which is still very much an active hub in today's Britain.By the way, I believe you can get tickets on the day - we saw a policewoman directing someone and she was waving them over in the direction of Big Ben so I guess the ticket office might be over there?!

group visit. Nothing to dislike at all except perhaps lack of places to sit. Guided tour as we were a large group by a Blue Badge Guide. She knew her Stuff, a potting history of the Kings and Queens of England plus an overview of how government works. The building itself is pretty impressive too.

Worth a visit. Went on a guided tour with Tim Hudson at 5pm on Monday 24th August 2015. The tour was extremely interesting and the guide was very knowledgeable with a good sense of humour. He made the visit well worth it but would advice that you to go earlier in the day as we didn't have time to go back and enjoy another look. We felt hurried by the security to leave straight after the tour and the shop and cafe had closed before the tour had finished. Overall we had a great time but would have liked some time to look around more.
Because Parliament was not in session, we were able to tour both chambers.. We took the guided tour and loved it--learned so much about the building and British government both present and past.
Best view from the Thames. The house of parliament is best viewed from the river. Get a day ticket on the commuter riverboats - hop in and hop off to see most sights of London.
Beautiful. This was beautiful. We didn't go inside but viewed from outside. It was gorgeous. With Big Ben close by it offered great photo ops.

Truly a "Gothic" Experience!. What magnificent architecture at the Houses of Parliament! This was well worth the visit. We did the audio tour and had a truly enjoyable experience. You first enter Westminster Hall with it's huge oak beamed ceiling and you know you're in for a treat. This Hall is so impressive and massive, you start to realize how vast the British empire was at one time. I was surprised by how many rooms they allowed us to visit. House of Commons, House of Lords, Lords Chamber with the Queen's highly ornate gold throne, Central Lobby with beautiful mosaics representing England, Scotland, Ireland, and Wales. Definitely take time to listen to the explanation of each mosaic on the audio. It's fascinating. The audio tour also explains how traditions are handed down over the centuries and to this day the House of Commons slams the door in Black Rod's face and he must knock 3 times to enter. You then see the indentation in the huge wooden door from centuries of knocks. Isn't that great! If you love architecture and love history, this is a must see!

Beautiful, but don't do a tour. Really great and beautiful to look at, but I wouldn't recommend a tour inside it - it's interesting to begin with, but then just drags, and there's not a whole lot to see inside to be honest.

Houses of Parliment. Having worked in London for 35 years, retirement offers the ideal opportunity to be a London tourist. We took the audio tour (£18pp) and it is the best way to visit. Having passed through airport standard security (and rightly so) you proceed into Westminster Hall to collect your audio headphones and controls, and off you go! The Hall is the oldest building on the Parliamentary Estate and has evolved over 900 hundred years! Not only does it have an amazing roof, but it represents 900 years of constitutional British History. Anyway I am in danger of replicating the tour here so I suggest a visit to London and a guided tour around this amazing historical building! Highly recommended.
Photogenic. Worth checking out if just to experience the amazing history. Just be prepared for tons of tourits milling around.
A privilege to visit. If you have the opportunity to is it don't hesitate, a privilege to visit and the ex servicemen guides are extremely knowledgeable and often full of amusing anecdotes.

Worth a visit. Took the audio tour this time. Found it much better than guided tour as can have problems hearing and taking everything in with these. You still follow the same route see all the same things, but at your pace. Fascinating insight into the history of parliament.

Not what I expected. Amazing building from outside but was disapointed by the interior. Lot of refurb work going on so scaffolding and plastic everywhere and much smaller on inside than it looks from outside!!!
Enjoyed. The children enjoyed all the information provided by the tour guide. Had reservations whether to visit but glad we did.
Just from the outside. We had such a short time to visit we just explored the outside. It was a wet day and we were on a time shedule

Tour through tradition and elegance . Bought a ticket to the audio guided tour, in the building with black roof near the Westminster tube station (the booth is not inside the parliament) and spent almost 2 hours in the tour. I absolutely loved it! The historical building is marvelous and the intricacies of the British politics is delightful.
Dont miss a view inside. When the doors open to visit the inside, dont miss the opportunity to see where the Lords have been debating since time immemorial. The architecture is splendid

Fantastic place . Beautiful and fantastic place in the centre of. London hearth - love to
Go the and enjoy my walks with friends over the - the building is
Stunning and amazing !

An Absolute Must. Spectacular.. The architecture is spectacular and the tour of the the Houses are well worth it. Plenty of history, pride of place, and visual interest. If you don't plan on visiting, check out the views from the south bank, a river cruise or even The Eye. Picture postcard views everywhere.
Big Ben. In 1963, I traveled to London with The Salem College Choral Ensemble. I saw the Parliament and BIG BEN at night. VERY memorable.

House of Parliament. We took the audio guide (18pounds), well explained, led us through the different hauls and confernce rooms.
Note: during Aug pick the "2 get 1 offer" (you gwt ut when you buy a weekly travel card) is not applicable

Well worth a visit. Visited recently, well worth it. Interesting historical and political venue. Audio tour was very good, but guided tours available too. You can't take photos everywhere inside which is a shame but i suppose for security reasons necessary. Amazing to see where the debates happen in House of Commons and you can visulalise the politicians being there for prime members question time. Enjoyed.

Well worth £25. Very interesting tour of the Houses of Parliament, we even got to see inside the Commons. Lovely tea room and gift shop at the end of the tour with reasonably priced gifts and refreshments.

Increadibly impressive inside and out. It seems that people do not realise that when Parliament is not in session (especially during the summer) it is possible to do a tour inside the Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament). I have lived in London for over 40 years and have been meaning to go for ages. Having seen both the Lords and Commons chambers on television I was expecting to be impressed but I was absolutely stunned by the architecture, heraldry, art and the sheer majesty of the place. I booked tickets the day before and it seems tickets can even be bought on the day. There was no queue to enter via the now obligatory airport style security even though it was the height of the tourist season. Do people not realise they can go round the inside of Parliament? We did the self-guided audio tour which is really well organised in a loop around the interior taking about 90 minutes. Obviously you can take longer (or less time) if you wish. The commentary was just right. There is a small shop and café. It is also possible to book afternoon tea on the river terrace but we gave that a miss – entry to the Houses of Parliament for a family of 5 (with concessions for age and student status) was £80 and tea on top of that at £27.50 a person would have meant a total bill of over £200 – we had wraps, sandwiches and drinks just down the road past Westminster Abbey for £20 instead!!! All in all an absolutely brilliant couple of hours seeing where the UK is governed from. It made me understand even more what a sheltered and cloistered life many of our Members of Parliament lead.
Eat on the Southbank!. Looks amazing from the Southbank....brilliant to bring visitors to who are visiting the U.K.....Big Ben is always a winner!
Visit and tour of The Houses of Parliament . The Tour is well worth a visit and a must do when in London. Very informative and interesting plus see things that you might never see.

Weekend Trip to the Capital. Visited on Saturday morning 22nd August 2015 on a guided tour, which was spectacular, went into the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The building is magnificent and well worth seeing, full of history.
A big thanks to Barbara the tour guide who was extremely knowledgeable, and all the staff who looked after us.

Great Tour. Big highlight of our trip to London. We opted for the guide as opposed to the audio tour and really enjoyed it. Loved that it wasn't too busy so you didn't have to fight the crowd while moving around and didn't feel rushed from room to room as we were being guided around. Tour was informative and not too long (90 mins) with a few moments for sit down should you need it!

Extraordinary!. Tops on our "better than expected" list, the Houses of Parliament is a must-see for people who want to see where history was and is made. Though we didn't stay long, seeing the House of Commons in action was a treat. And because we got very, very lucky, we met a member of the House of Lords who showed us that chamber as well. I can compare visiting the Houses of Parliament to visiting the U.S. Capital Building, and as an American I must admit that there really is no comparison; the Houses of Parliament is just far, far better. Better access (less restrictive), better history, better decor, and no way, nohow is a U.S. Senator going to take time out to show a few random foreigners around!

Fabulous. Apparently this is a bit of a secret because there weren't that many people there. We did the self-guided tour and it was very good. We enjoyed seeing the Great Hall and both houses of Parliament. There are statues of many of the great prime ministers including Pitt, Churchill, and Thatcher. It was well worth fighting through the crowds outside to get to the visitor's center for the tickets!
Proud of our heritage . Amazing, enjoyed the view from the Thames. Had a great time viewing these impressive buildings. Would recommend a visit. The earlier in the day the better.

Great photo opportunity. Such an amazing sight to see. Best viewed from the riverside. If you have a decent DSLR as I do I would recommend on a sunny day pitching with a tri pod and waiting for the sun to set behind this as it sets bang on behind sunset route west ;)

Awesome tour guide. I'd highly recommend doing the guided tour - its a little pricey but well worth it. Our guide Liz was excellent - interesting, informative, engaging, funny and kept up the energy level the entire time. There was never a boring moment. Such a shame you can't take photos inside though.

60+ years since my last tour!. If you haven't toured the Mother of Parliaments then make sure you do it one day. I was taken round by our MP when I was still at primary school and it had always been my intention to go back. My wife and I attended a few debates when Parliament used to sit during the evenings but you need to see all round the Palace to appreciate the full greatness of the place. We couldn't get on the guided tour but the audio commentary was excellent and we could go at our own pace. Westminster Hal is such a wonderful piece of our history.

I wish I knew more about British politics. We signed up well in advance to do the guided walking tour of Parliament. As an American traveling in Europe, it opened my eyes to how little I know of British politics. I had little to no idea of what I was looking at and since the majority of my tour group was British, the tour guide did not spend the time to give us a civics lesson on how British politics work. Lots of comments like, "I'm sure this looked bigger on TV" or "You're already aware of how this works..." And here I am thinking, "I've never seen this on TV" and "No, I am not." The tour guide was a little dry, but not terrible. Lots of walking and very few places to sit. I would compare it to touring Congress in the U.S., which is very interesting, unless you don't have any idea of how Congress works... If I had to go back, I probably wouldn't have sprung for the paid walking tour and would have spent my time elsewhere. But if you're well-versed in British politics, this will probably be very interesting to you.

Take your children - unmissable tour. I can't rate this guided tour highly enough; it captivated two adults, one nine year old and one thirteen year old for 100 minutes. An excellent mix of accessible history, current affairs and trivia, all in stunning surroundings. If everyone could visit the Palace of Westminster, there would be no debate on the value of restoring the building. Our tour guide was perfectly pitched, very charismatic. The whisper headphones made her so easy to listen to, a fabulous idea. The only downside is that you have to stand for almost the entire time, which was a bit of a trial but totally, one hundred per cent worth it. Go, go now.
The power of English traditions. Here you can feel the power of English traditions! House of Lords, House of Commons, Queens' rooms - this is a heart of English democracy. Very recommended for visit.

Houses of Parliament (Big Ben and Westminster). Just walk along side the thames from the big ben and you would reach this place. Do not forget to click the photo which would be memory for your life time. Visit that in the day light and you would be mesmerised by the beauty of this place.... nice place for visitors
A must visit when in London. Must be on a to do list when in LondonBest visited here either in sunshine (for better photos) or at night time for the same effect.Great British iconic building.Superb

An informative tour of wonderful buildings. We visited the Houses of Parliament for the first time on a very hot Saturday in August. We had booked an English tour on-line which was very straight forward. The security check was quick and you wait in the impressive Westminster hall for the tour to start. Our guide was Owen and he was very informative and amusing. It's a shame that you are only allowed to take photos in Westminster Hall and St Stephen's Hall. The guide takes you to the end of the buildings and then you make your way through the robing room, Royal Gallery, Lord's chamber, Central Lobby, Member's lobby and Common's chamber learning all the history as you go. It's amazing to see the rooms that you normally just see on television and it does make you feel proud to be British. The tour takes almost 2 hours and is well worth the money. We would recommend doing the tour with a guide rather than the audio-tour. The café had some nice food but the queue for the Ladies toilet was ridiculous. We would recommend doing the tour of the Houses of Parliament whether you are a tourist or British.

A really wonderful tour. In my working life I had to visit the Parliament building a number of times, so on a recent visit to the UK my wife and I visited, we had a guided tour which we enjoyed very much.What can you say about the Palace of Westminster, well it's a fascinating building seeped in history and such a wonderful place to visit.The security procedure was super efficient and friendly, and without the long queues we'd endured at Buckingham Palace the previous day.Our guide was knowledgeable and friendly and was more than willing and able to answer the numerous questions put to her.We ended our day with afternoon tea overlooking the veranda, not cheap but a wonderful experience and certainly one I would recommend.All the staff we dealt with were first class, from the police officers, guides, the door keepers and our waiter.All in all a wonderful tour and one I would highly recommend, especially with the addition of afternoon tea.

A must see!. Absolutely stunning inside. Not too crowded. Helpful staff. Got through security quite quickly. There was quite a lot of building work going on when I visited but it didn't spoil my visit!
Houses of Parliament - Wonderful Guided Tour. I took a wonderful guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. Well worth the time. The history, architecture, and art is a must to see.

Nice walk through history. Our audio tour was excellent and it was also nice and cool inside compared to the 30c outside. Security was nice and quick and easy. We would recommend the houses of parliament tour for all visitors to London.
you must visit. if you dont visit that place, you are not in london... the parliament view from the other side of the river is more than wonderful

Fascinating tour. This was our 1st visit to the Houses of Parliament despite having lived in near London for a few years now. I pre booked for a guided tour on their website and it was very straightforward.Well worth the entrance fee. There are airport style security checks to go through as you might expect, but all was done smoothly with hardly any waiting time. We were staying at the Westminster Plaza just over the bridge so didn't bring anything with us except for the pre printed tickets.The tour was led by a very knowledgable lady (I think her name was Vina) who kept us all fascinated for nearly 2 hours while we walked around the rooms we normally only see on the news. She included information about the history as well as how Parliament and the House of Lords operates in this day and age.We both found it fascinating, and would happily go again next time we visit London.
A must place to visit. when you are in London, you cannot skip this place to visit. This is nice place where you will see everything.

Interesting to see where the big wigs roam. Visited the houses of parliament a while back. Its always interesting to see and walk the corridors that the big wigs walked like churchill etc. Got to see the room the queens throne is in and absorb some of the history.

Primo!. The highlight of our most recent trip to this wonderfully rich and vibrant city! A superbly done and most impressive (audio) tour. We were never lost our out of synch. A truly wonderful experience. Allow 1/2 day.

walk from big Ben to other end..... beautiful. I didn't get a grasp of how large parliament was.... until I walked it. The building changes as you walk from section to section. The queen Victoria tower is amazing close up. Take the extra 10 mins and look at it. Architecture is...... beautiful. Can't tour it, but walking is amazing

Walk through history. Booked guided tour on line very easy to do. Everyone from the policeman on the gates, security, etc. were very pleasant and chatty. Tour was on time, great tour guide Victoria, gave us interesting facts along the way, as well as knowing answers toquestions and tip bits of information. Didn't feel rushed. Wonderful history, felt veryproud to be British. Gift shop and cafe also nice to pop into.

Very Special Indeed. My little eight year old grandson and I have been to London together on several occasions and seen the exterior of the Palace of Westminster many times, but each time he has remarked how much he would like to see inside. I was sceptical, thinking that he would be bored out of his mind, but no, he wanted to go, despite my protestations! So we did.The online booking facility was not working on the day I made our reservation about six weeks back, so I actually spoke to a person on the other end of a reservations telephone service! She was very helpful indeed and guided me to the junior audio tour rather than a full guided tour as this gave some rather more humourous facts and anecdotes for younger minds. I opted for the adult audio tour and booked a souvenir book plus tea on the terrace for us both after the tour.The audio tour tape was of exceptionally good sound quality and gave some fascinating information at every stop along the way. My grandson and I would stop before moving on to the next numbered venue and compare notes (as our audio tapes were different) - he had picked up such large chunks of information and retained them - fantastic!I had never seen inside either Chamber (except on TV) and was stunned at the sheer beauty of the decor and the intimate nature of the place, as it's all much more compact than it appears. We were both fascinated at being able to see things at such close quarters and imagined which famous posteriors had been sat on each of the various seats and benches!When it came to tea, we were instructed to wait for the Sergeant at Arms to escort us to the Terrace, where we were duly shown to our very beautifully set table and became immediately aware of the stunning view directly across the Thames to the old GLC building, the Eye and St. Thomas's Hospital.The food offering was good, although not exceptional for the (not insubstantial) price! Frankly, they were a little mean with their portions, but a certain little lad thoroughly enjoyed every mouthful of the cakes and scones, so why worry!Ever since our visit, my small companion has talked of nothing else - so I figure it must have all been worth it!

School Trip. I went in 2003 but trip advisor didn't exist then lolzz but I just wanted to say this place is wicked I liked it (but I am a history geek) we saw the house of commons and Lords but not the rest of parliament as it's so big, the architecture is world class and I have so much respect for the people that constructed this place, we also saw Henry the VIII chambers etc was really good, not sure how much it is I went with school, I would recommend this to people who already know the basic history to appreciate it to the full, although tour guides will educate you further, there are also paintings inside of wars etc really good, some people will like it some people won't but I'd recommend to do this place at least once :)
Beautiful. My favorite place in the city.....I been here many times and always I have the feeling I need to take a new picture...I don't know how many do I have....
Historical building. I was given a special tour and it was fascinating - the House of Lords, the history - it is an impressive building and there is lots to find out.

It's just a posh building unless you go inside. Had no idea you could book to go into the Houses of Parliament! Saw many posters when we walked down there from Covent Gardens. To be fair, not really very much to see just looking at the outside, think everyone mainly goes for Big Ben... Had we have known we would probably have gone inside, just to be nosy! ;)
World class. Love H o P, great venue, view, fabulous gothic architecture, doesnt everyone want a selfie with this in the background?
well worth visiting. Visited courtesy of our local mp and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Well worth a visit if you are in London. Wonderful history behind the place.

A walk through history.. Along with all the history surrounding this building the visit to the House of Commons and the House of Lords was the highlight. We stood where Churchill and other Prime Ministers and Royalty have stood--very cool.

Best of London. I have to admit, although i lived in London for 6 years and almost walked past the parliament buildings once or twice a week, I only came to realise the beauty and the architectural marvel after I left the big city. A wonderful place to be if you visit London and not to be missed and cant be missed.

Book in advance!. The tour of the Houses of Parliament is excellent- book well in advance and if you're a UK citizen, book the Public Gallery tickets with your local MP and you can see PMQ's at the end of the tour- the tour itself is very good, and will take you through the Commons and the Lords- go on the first tour of the day- I've been half a dozen times and there's always something new to learn. But book as early as you can- a couple of months, preferably! And while you're doing, pre-book Big Ben tour- which is just next door (and free!).

take pics-but good luck getting it all in the frame :). The size alone of the buildings are mesmerizing & the history is amazing. To just walk around and see the differences between England and America, our politics and the respect showed in these establishments is worth the stroll around the area.
mar 15. Thoroughly enjoyed visit. Impressive buildings and surroundings. Easily accessed from hop on hop off tour buses.

Guided tour is outstanding, other tips. Yes, it is a pricey day out. The guided tour at the HP was worth every penny. We are a family of four, our teens are 14 and 16, and my husband is British. Our guide was Joanne, and she was so knowledgeable and passionate about the subject. I highly recommend her. Even though the Victorian side of,the building is beautiful to look at, and our guide imparted wonderful details that you can't get from the audio guide, the truly interesting part of the tour is when you head over to the House of Commons. She did a brilliant job of making parliamentary procedure and politics come alive. My husband learned lots he didn't know before, and both my kids agreed that it was very interesting and worth doing. We did the last tour of the day, and I recommend that too. It meant that we had much of the place to ourselves and we weren't distracted by other tourists. It is best to get these tickets in advance. We bought ours the day before, and were lucky. But we also tried to get tickets back in late June and had no luck. This tour was by far the most interesting tour I have done in England, and I lived there for 20 years. Not to be missed.By the way, there is a lot of standing and listening, for 90 minutes. I would probably not recommend this tour for,those who can't stand for long, and I do not recommend this for kids under the age of 12, unless they happen to be very interested in government and politics.
Rich history !!. Stunning views of southbank and river Thames and Houses of Parliament . Really nice to walk around and you always kno the time !!

Interesting and worth a visit!. We booked the audio tour. Upon arrival, we passed though security and got our audio headsets. The tour was extremely interesting and you get to see parts of parliament that you would normally only see on TV. The whole experience was well organised. Would definitely recommend!
Really interesting look into British politics. A really interesting tour through the centre of British Government. The building is beautiful and amazing that it is still a fully functioning facility.

Don't bother with the cream tea. Parliament itself fascinatiing and well worth a visit. Guide, Tim, excellent. However, the tea on the terrace thing is a total rip off. Very little food available and theonly refill was for the tea. Nicely presented with linen napkins etc but the small amount of food provided for £27.50 spoils the experience.

amazing architecture. great architecture and history of this place. best attraction is the Big Ben.
Ain't happy when the road in front of it is closed due to security reasons most often which makes one take a long detour.
Architectural celebration.. Neo-Gothic complex of building is an iconic structure and offers one of the most interesting tourist and political experience.
Great to visit with your local MP. I have visited the place with my local MP on several occasions and as she is a great guide I have enjoyed every single visit.

Interesting archectural landmark. A nice acommodation for its time in history. I must congratulate Barkley's Bank for making sure the veneer of democracy is maintained to obscure their class dictatorship.over the UK and a chunk of the Third Woorld.

A Must to Visit. Visted the Houses of Parliament this afternoon. I had pre booked a guided tour at 2.00pm and it proved even better than expected. We were taken to all the important parts with an interesting and informative narrative from our guide. We got to stand in the House of Lords and then stand behind the front benches of the House of Commons. Both much smaller than imagined after seeing them on TV. It was busy but we never felt crowded. We followed the tour with a visit to the cafe and shop both very pleasant. Like I said about Buckingham Palace this should be on your list of places to visit before you die.

Informative and entertaining. I went with my friend who was visiting to have the audio tour and I really loved it. It is great to see that so many traditions are still kept in the building and the decoration and History of the place is totally remarkable. It took us around 1 hour and 30 minutes to complete the visit and really liked the fact that you could extend the comments on certain aspects if you wanted to, I like Medieval History a lot and to learn about specific trials or anecdotes was a good experience. Very interesting.

Tea on the Terrace. Having Christmas afternoon tea on the House of Lords Terrace, is an occasion I can heartily recommend if it is your good fortune to receive an invitation. With great company, good food and great service, what more could one expect. This included a brief visit by a Minister who uncomfortable at being questioned by the knowledgeable guests present, made a rapid departure. A good start to Christmas.

Great audio tour experience.... Took my two children (8 & 10 years old) here for the audio tour & we all thoroughly enjoyed the whole thing, you a given plenty of information & detail...the children had the kids audio tour sets. I thought the whole thing was just the right length of time, none of us got bored or wanted to skip any of the audio (like we have at other places!). The building is so beautiful & it was quite something going in to the House of Commons & House of Lords, loved the stationery box!I would definitely recommend a visit here, such a lovely part of our history.Carole : )
Worth investing time for a tour.. Worth seeing the building and the furnishings within. The guide was really knowledgeable and I am now so much more informed about how our parliamentary system works.

Something you have to do.... Excellent guided tour - but I think I would have preferred the audioguide to go at my own pace. Allow plenty of time for security checks before your tour starts. Fantastic to see both houses.

Houses of Parliament & Big Ben. Maybe the most spectacular building along the Thames.The architecture is so famous with it's neo-gothic style building. The clock tower 'Big Ben' is even more famous. Most people know the melody that counts the hours....
Architecturally Impressive. I simply enjoyed the architectural asthetics of this building and it is quite impressive. A must visit when touring London.
Amazing. not interested one bit about politics! ... But got to admit this building is stunning ...... It's a must go see close up when in London

Highlight of a visit to London. Having seen the stunning neo gothic exterior of this building many times it was a exciting to go on a guided tour of the seat of our government you do get to see both the House of commons and the House of Lords but for me the most interesting part is Westminster Hall one of the surviving medieval parts and the sheer amount of the nations history this hall has seen since it was built in 1097 by the son of William the Conqueror is breathtaking

The Houses of Parliament Tour. Our Tour guide Andrew was absolutely brilliant we all throughly enjoyed the experience he made it fun as well as informative definitely recommend this if you are going to the Houses of Parliament make sure you have the tour rather than going round yourself it made a difference.

Worth a tour to both. Wonderful tour with guide, lovely palatial surroundings, worth a visit, was quite surprised at interior. Also did portcullis house, which is the modern building nearby - that was good as well.

The best visitor attraction in London. This tour is the best visitor experience in London. Arrange one via the HP itself or your local MP. The tour is fascinating and free of charge. If you have any interest in British history and politics, this is a must.

A historic location that is a must see!. We pre booked an independent audio tour. Picking up the tickets was quick and easy as was the inevitable and understandable security screening. The audio guide is interesting and informative, simple to use and allows you to progress at your own pace. Being able to visit such an iconic and historical site was a pleasure and a privelege.

Absolutely fascinating. Booked a guided tour (for the second time) and loved it. It's so interesting to see where history was and is being made. I was disappointed not to be able to revisit rooms once the tour had finished as we moved through fairly quickly. I think for my third visit I'll book an audio guide so I can move at my own pace. The guides are knowledgeable and make it fun. I'd recommend this unreservedly. Up there with the Tower of London. Fantastic.

Brilliant absolutely brilliant ☆☆☆. This was an amazing experience of the highest level to stand in the house of Lords and then walk through to the house of commons and stand next to the prime ministers seat is really quite something the guide who took us around was very knowledgeable and a joy to listen to. The tour was about 90 minutes long. there's a shop and café at the end . A brilliant day out.

Amazing - a must on a trip to London. We visited courtesy of our MP and we were entranced from the moment we got in. The tour was over an hour long with an incredibly knowledgeable tour guide. It was fascinating actually being IN the House of Commons AND the House Of Lords. We even had a coffee in the coffee shop overlooked by Big Ben afterwards (great cake). Cannot recommend this highly enough.
Great. Just kick the politicians out and it would be a better place - well worth a visit when your in London.

Politics at its best. The House of parliament is located at the river Thames and near Big Ben, very beautiful architectural, looks even more beautiful in the night and specially if you look from boat . Westminster Hall was one of the major interesting place to see within the building.

Very interesting and worth the admission price.. I have wanted to visit our Parliament for a number of years.So I booked a guided tour on the 15th Aug.After passing through airport style security we were met by our guid Leonie.The tour passes through both debating chambers as well as the various lobby halls and committee rooms.This fantastic tour ends in the wondrous Westminster Hall with its exhibits,gift shop and cafe.Overall a fantastic couple of hours which I can highly recommend.

Day out to Parliament. I booked tickets online for the wrong day and the staff in the sales office were great help, refunding the tickets over the phone allowing me rebook the correct day.The tour is great, (once through the airport style security which was well staffed) there is an audio tour. It takes about 90 minutes and but you could stay longer and listen to all the extras on the recording. The two chambers were the highlight, it was great to get inside such an iconic London landmark

You can't visit London without seeing Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. I was on a whirlwind tour of London. I only saw the outside and wish I returned in the evening for more photo opportunities. What a breathtaking building. Unfortunately some of it was under repair.

Well worth a visit. There are 2 ways to get a tour of the Houses of Parliament; you can contact your M.P who can arrange a visit for you or you can book a guided tour yourself. We weren't organised enough to contact our M.P so took the guided tour. It cost £25 and for that we were taken round the House of Lords and the commons by a guide who was very interesting (Godfrey)You can only take photos in a few places; neither house and it is quite a long walk.You are not allowed to sit on any of the seats in the Lords or the Commons, so fear not Dennis Skinner, your seat's safe. You can only take photos in a few places; neither house After the tour there is a cafe and a souvenir shop.

Fascinating Tour. It took four trips to London, but we finally coordinated a tour of the Houses of Parliament. The tour was fascinating and the building beautiful. We also got tickets for the afternoon tea served on the patio overlooking the Thames. A unique experience that I highly recommend.

A must do, in London. If you travel to see other cultures and love history, this tour is a must see for the whole family.
