You get to see how their government operates, you get to learn about the history of the place, which is extensive (and part of it dates back over a thousand years) and you get fun little tidbits of info along the way.
Impressive. This building is one of the most impressive of the many other impressive tourist attractions in London and is not to be missed.

some hot spots in a messy and not very beautiful city. Beautiful, i saw only outside but i was impressed ... it s the best monument in London that is a messy architectural city.. a bit disapointing in general

interesting and informative. I visited the Houses of Parliament with my Mum on the 4/8/15. We took the audio tour which was very informative. It was quite an experience to be able to go into the House of Commons and the Lords. We decided against the afternoon tea as it would not have been able to be taken outside as there were events on.

Very much worth the time and money. Took the guided tour with my husband. At 25£ per person our expectations were high and luckily the tour was worth every penny. If you're interested in architecture, history, politics - or if you just want to be able to brag that you've been inside - this is the tour for you. Thoroughly enjoyed it. Note that there are not many opportunities to sit down during the tour.
Guy Fawkes, Thank Goodness it is still Standing.... The history and architecture...must see, Big Ben is a must see, Westminster, a short tube ride from Angel to Westminster station via Kings Cross...

Steeped with tradition. Not really strong into politics but I really enjoyed. Looking forward to seeing debates on TV and the opening of state parliament now - will see it in a different light. A fascinating insight.

Best Tour in London. I am biased as I have and continue to study politics so to walk through the building and see the Houses of Commons and Lords was a treat. The opulence of the House of Lords is only matched by the humble decor of the Commons. The history in the building is unmatched in London and the throne in the House of Lords is overwhelming to see. If I were to revisit one attraction or tour I would visit this again.

A few comments on a place I visit, professionally. I am not a member of either House, or a lobbyist, but do have cause to visit the place from time to time, to inform in relation to matters proceeding towards legislative status. I therefore see parts which the public sees, and some parts which they do not.The place is a busy legislature, and I confess to a greater interest in some of its work rather than its design and decoration (which I confess I find somewhat "over the top" to a great extent). The staff are invariably helpful; and I confess that taking tea and muffins (real ones, not what the Americans call "English muffins") is enjoyable and, like many parts of the edifice, in a place which offers plenty of opportunity for quiet conversation and small meetings.There are gift shops - and I understand that the passport covers.from the shop in the Lords, made to fit the passports issued before the EU standard document, go down very well at overseas border control points!It is years since I have been there as a tourist; but it is well worth a visit
Great seat of power. we never expected it to be so attractive. every power houses was there. and the most exciting thing there was MAHATMA GANDHI among other Great people of world.
Beautiful Architecture. This building is amazing. You need quite awhile to visit and see it all. The rooms are beautiful and ornate.

Tour of Parliament was the highlight of trip to the UK!. After a 15 year absence I had the chance this summer to return to London. The city was even more crazy and alluring than it had been at the millennium. On my last full day in London I took guided a tour of Parliament, and it was the pinnacle of an awesome visit to the capital. The tour guide Janice knew the building and its history extremely well and her explanations were informative and entertaining. The Lords chamber was amazing, but the Commons took my breath away. It meant a great deal to me to be in the room where so many heroes (and charlatans) had plied their trade. No photos were allowed, but that's OK - I will never forget what I saw. If you have any interest in history or politics, book a tour and go - you won't regret it!

Very informative , well done. Buy entrance tx across the street . Entrance times are pre- determined depending on volume of people with escorted tours and self audio tours available. Once inside the tours are informative and well planned , you leave with a great sense and understanding of how Parliment works and process that it follows. Tours are only available when they are not in session .

One hour with history and insights. Been to London many times and never been here. I should have come earlier. It is amazing that you are allowed to walk around the actual chambers, top that off with all the history. This is truly worth a visit. The audio guided tour is shorter with plenty of in depth of you want to know more. The guided tour is richer and takes you the way the guide thinks you should see it. Come here if you want to either learn about the history of parliament in England, learn about how England is governed today, learn about the buildings and the art. Do not come here if you want to have action, it is more intake of info them touching, playing around etc.
Parliament. We always try to visit the seat of government when traveling to foreign countries as well as different states. We had a fairly good tour guide and the building was terrific to see.

50th Birthday Present. Took my Sister-in-Law on a tour for her birthday. It was a lovely day out, the tour guide was really knowledgeable and was ever so friendly answering all our questions. It is really worth doing the tour. A fascinating insight into the machinations of British Politics.

Highly Recommended. A 'must see' for British and foreign visitors. Apart from being the centre of government for the UK, one should not forget that this is the Palace of Westminster and has the accompanying beauty of architecture and design. So steeped in fascinating history and tradition, it cannot fail to interest. It is best to obtain tickets as early as possible in the day as tours sell out early. Guided tours were sold out by 11am when I visited. You can buy tickets at the ticket office hours before and so there is no need to queue at Parliament itself. Check beforehand if you wish to enter the Houses of Commons and/or Lords to make sure they will not be in session and, therefore, not open for viewing.

Interesting. When we first arrived at the tour we had to wait around for a bit, not the fault of the staff, just due to our earliness. However our tour was booked for 15:00, but when we seen a tour queueing at 14:55 we asked whether it was the 15:00 tour just getting ready, but they said that it wasn't and that it was the 14:30 tour, so when we asked if they were running late they replied with "no, you're just early". But we were asked if we wanted to join that tour as there was room, so we did and I think it was actually a good choice as our tour guide (Brian/Bryan) was very funny and tried to make the tour more entertaining as we had a 10 year old and a 7 year old with us.The only problem on the actual tour was the seating; we understand that we can't sit in certain places, but there could be temporary seating in place for tours. The only other problem was that sometimes the tour behind us caught up with us or we caught up with the tour in front of us and our groups would get mixed up and we would end up briefly losing the rest of our group.
poor!. not very much to do or see, overall a very pointless trip to london for nothing so we were quite dissapointed.

A worthwhile hour or two. We took the tour based on a family recommendation. We opted for the audio guide based tour rather than a tour guide and felt this was a good option. We learned about the history of the palace of Westminster as well as the customs of both houses. The chambers themselves are way smaller than they look on TV!

A great monument to a great British institution.. Great institution that represents all that is British and good about this country. Democracy may not be perfect (it isn't) but the two houses are a great institution and something to be proud of.

Very interesting to see inside!. We used the self guided audio tour for our family of two adults and two teenagers to explore the Houses of Parliament. It was very interesting to see where it all happens. Worth a visit.
.. Worth a look quite a cool building to go and see easy to get to by tube and bus quite a busy part of London great bars and food places around and not far from the London Eye which u must book

Put it on your list to do in London. Having seen so many House of Commons and House of Lords sessions on TV to go inside and experience was everything I'd hoped for. For £18 it's great value and the audio guide they provide is really excellent. Take your time and take and breathe it in. My advice is go early. I was first in at 9am (you have to pre-book) and by the time I came out at 11am there was a crowd to get in. Spent 10 minutes on my own in The House of Commons and the political history of the place makes it a wonderful couple of hours spent.
Why does this interesting place generate so much hot air. Fascinating insight into the history and scenario of how our country is and has been governed. Pity they have a problem with the structure.

I still get a buzz. We recently visted the Houses of Parliament with my American cousins and we all thoroughly enjoyed it. Whilst it was not my first trip both Houses give an intersting insight into the way our traditional government is run - whetehr one likes it or not!The old Westminster Hall has been the site of so many events from history is well worth a visit on its own.Also try to ensure you can visit the beautiful

Interesting Historical tour. I was part of a group tour and must say the lady who showed us around was incredible - obviously highly educated regarding the property, giving facts in an interesting and engaging way whilst answering the many questions of the group.I would not hesitate to encourage others to go for a tour guide trip.

Do the tour!. I did a tour of the Houses of Parliament and loved it! Brilliant to see the the original bits and to see where all the action is. I wanted to shout ORDER in front of the speakers chair! Really good tour to do. I will go again.

One of the highlights of London. We came right before they were closing for the day, but still had enough time to appreciate the artwork all around us. It was amazing to see where the Queen comes in to meet with the Prime Minister and where the MPs sit. I did not have a chance to watch the actual Questions with the Prime Minister, but now I am inspired to come back just to see that. It is an amazing bit of history and I hope they do not change to a more modern building.

Fascinating. We purchased tickets for the longer, guided tour of Great Britain's Parliament. Our tour guide was excellent and we thoroughly enjoyed the tour. We have toured the U.S. Capitol, and Parliament buildings in Ottawa, Vienna, The Hague and Budapest. This may be the most thorough tour we've had. We have not been disappointed about the time commitment or tour price.I should add, you must be comfortable standing for long periods of time. Restroom stops are limited and you may purchase food at the end of the tour. Food, beverage and photography are STRICTLY prohibited.

An unexpected gem-Houses of Parliament Tour London. After a boat ride on the Thymes, we ended up with a few hours of touring time left and saw a sign for Houses of Parliament Tours. We were fortunate and bought two guided tickets for the last tour of the day. We walked a little way to the entry and after a security check entered and waited for our tour. **TIP** Tours last about 45 minutes but the last tour of the day can run longer if the guide and tour click. You might get a much more in depth tour than "normal".The tour was amazing. Unfortunately you can't take pictures, but you get to see everything. As we were walking down a long hall, Big Ben tolled the top of the hour and it ran a few chills down my spine thinking about where I was and what I was hearing. This was truly the "unexpected surprise" of our visit to London, and even if you are not that interested in the British Government, the rooms are quite impressive.

Really Interesting. After seeing the inside of the Houses of Parliament on tv for years it was really cool to be able to walk through the rooms...included in the tour is the commons and lords chambers...Just a tip...we booked our tickets online and were able to go straight to the tour entrance where they print the tickets for you...if you queue at the ticket office the wait was 2 hours long.

Stunning!. Although, I didn't take a tour inside, the building is simply stunning. I will definitely add it to my next trip to London. The architecture is brilliant and the building is so well kept. A must see, even if you're just passing by!!!

A great insight in to British politics. I visited here with my mother last week. An informative audio tour. Truly a great experience. We learnt so much about British politics. I would thoroughly recommend this tour for young and old.
fascinating. We took the audio tour which took approx 70 minutes, it was very informative and interesting with access to the House of Commons and House of Lords, all in all very good.
Wonderful! Go for the guided tour!. the guided tour could not have been better. So much history! Such a beautiful building. It was the highlight of my trip to London.

A must see!. An excellent experience to have taken the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. Not only informative - the guide had a very good knowledge of the historical facts of the two Houses but also to see with one's own eyes the seats of government of the country. There is a lot to take in and this is one of the rare places I think I'll visit again.

Investegate ahead when the whole building is open to the public. Look ahead on the internet and find the days that the whole building is open to the public. Be prepared for queues and mass crowds but it it worth it.

Fascinating insight into the workings of the UK. First, the best part of this attraction is that it is free to simply enter and have a look around. However, be aware that guided tours do attract a charge and need to be booked i advance, also that there may be large queues at busy times - Summer especially. Plenty to see inside, and some fascinating information as to the establishment of Parliament and how it has fared over the past several hundred years. The air of tradition from the paintings and sculptures, through to the doorkeepers and their traditional outfits is great. Finally, always remember that this is a working building, even when Parliament is not sitting there is still plenty going on so you may be instructed to behave by the officials on duty!

The true Mother of Parliaments. This is always a very special visit for me because I have spent nearly 15 years of my life working an an MP there. It is a wonderful place as the Mother of Parliaments for anyone to visit. You need to get your organising precisely right to get into the building at the right time, so go through the right channels, and the security is very tough these days. But it is all worth it to see where so many truly historic moments of our history have happened. At the right time you can visit the Chambers of the Commons and the Lords, and also see the lobbies just outside where the Members meet and discuss what they will do in the various votes. You can see the bronze statue of Winston Churchill outside the Commons chamber with one shoe polished bright from Members touching it for good luck before making a speech in the Chamber. The whole of both Houses are full of tradition and wonderful architecture and historic paintings and pictures. See the Royal Gallery in the Lords through which the monarch processes to open Parliament. And make sure you do not miss the most historic part of all, Westminster Hall, which has stood there for 1000 years since Norman kings built it, and it has witnessed great trials.speeches, and laying in state of deceased monarchs down the ages. All together a truly magical place of history not to be missed
Worth a visit........ ....... if in London. A lot of history to take in and mega security check obviously. Try to visit when parliament is in session / sitting..... can be fun. A must do.

A great see for those who like history and architecture. Visiting the HoP is a fantastic view and great for pictures but is extremely busy with tourists and traffic in the surrounding roads. I have been lucky enough to have a tour which i highly recommend. The place is a maze inside and you can really feel and smell the history. It's like stepping back in time. The House of Commons is probably the most surprising as it's much smaller than it looks on TV.

One of the best attractions in London. I've been to London probably a dozen times and never visited the Houses of Parliament. I've Got to say this is one of the best places I've visited in London. Our guide (think his name was Sean) was absolutely brilliant. His knowledge and delivery were superb for all ages. I was amazed at how much info my two boys took on board. Would recommend the guided tour which takes around 1.5-2hrs. Obviously can't comment on the audio tour.

A visit to the home of democracy. The security if obvious, but necessary, the guides are excellent and can answer any questions. If you go you will find out how large the building really is we were told three football pitches in length. And you will see the most photograph pillar box in England

well organised. We went for the guided tour in August. It was really well organised - we were able to join an earlier group as some people didn't arrive - and we had head phones so we could hear the guide even if I was busy or he went on ahead. I have done tours before with school groups but still learned and saw new things. It did feel a little rushed - w had1.5 hours just because there is so much to see. It was quite expensive so you might want to give it a miss if you are on a budget but if you are interested in politics it is definitely worth it.

Live Guided Tour. We booked ahead for a live guided tour. These tours are offered when Parliament is not in session. We greatly enjoyed seeing the rooms and our guide was excellent. I would not recommend this for young children, but our teen enjoyed it. We had some locals on our tour and they seemed to enjoy it, too! I enjoyed having the commentary of a live person, but with the self-guided audio tour you can take your time in the rooms. With the live-guided tour you move along at a quick pace. The guide said we got to go into places the self guided tour didn't go, but I'm not sure which areas that included.

Really interesting visit. We booked to visit the Houses of Parliament because my mum at 84 wanted to have a look at them and I went along as company. However, I found the visit really interesting, we both did. I had made a mistake when pre-booking as we had intended to do the guded tour, but booked the audit tour instead but it worked out really well. There is quite a bit of walking so it was nice to be able to sit down and rest for a while between different areas, which we could not have done on the guided tour. The checking in took a while as you have to go through security, but not too bad. The audio tour provided just enough information with our overloading you, but you could press the button for more in-depth info' if you wanted to. It was really amazing to be stood where William Wallace and other historical figures had stood. Lastly do go into the cafe, we had the best lemon drizzle cake we had ever tasted....shame you can't get into the cafe without paying again to go into Parliament...

Very impressive buildings but be prepared to wait to enter chambers. House of Commons and House of Lords are the Houses of Parliament in the Palace of Westminster. Buildings are very impressive. When Parliament is in session, you are allowed to enter during specified times. When we were there, the wait was close to 2 hours to enter. We chose not to - but it was still great to see the buildings and Big Ben.
Superb !! Houses of Parlaiment. A superb experience not to be missed. The hundred of years of history combined with modern day politics...Worth seeing !!

Really informative . Our local MP arranged for a tour of the Houses of Parliament for local constituents. It was a real eye opener to see the place in person and hear of its history and traditions. I would highly recommend this trip.

Get blown away by the fantastic decor. I've done this tour several times and have never been disappointed. Personally I think that this should be a compulsory tour for all school children so that they understand how the 'rules' are made
iconic. its a must see when in town. one of the iconic sights of London. see it on the thames river tour along with the other nearby sights.
Fantastic Tour. Our tour guide was Barry. He did an excellent job of showing us around Houses of Parliament and letting us know what goes on. Well worth a visit.

British Pride. The houses of Parliament, houses the chamber of Lords and the chamber of Commons. It is beautiful, it is well built with a magnificent stones covering the facades.The building is located at the margins of the Thames river, Its towers, including the clock tower ( Big Ben ) are tall and I don't have and more words to describe how beautifull it is. Inside, one can watch the works of the politicians amd see how the democracy works at its best. Tradition, art, and example to the world. If you are in London, you gotta go there............

Interesting and informative, pretty crowded. We booked some months ahead and we're still too late to get a guided tour but maybe this was because it was a mid-summer Saturday. Very helpful people and smiley policemen, all good going in through airport style screening and then the tour began. Guided tour takes about 90 minutes and takes in the House of Lords and the House of Commons as well as the central lobby. Westminster Hall etc. tour was good value. British subjects can actually get a free visit on weekdays I believe, but everyone has to pay at weekends. We also opted for the £25 cream tea after the tour and whilst it was lovely to visit the Thames-side terrace to eat, the food served was poor value for the money. It was pretty busy throughout but nevertheless I saw what I wanted and I recommend it. Some further explanation might be needed for kids or for non-Brits - this is a peculiar and very British institution.
London . It was nice to visit the Houses of Parliament. Taking few pics It wasn't the best visit but was ok Nothing much to say about it

Better than expected - go for the audio tour. We went for the audio tour option. This was excellent, and contained quite a bit of optional extra material if you were interested.There isn't much walking required, but it was great to see the impressive architecture, and to walk the hallowed grounds of what was once the legislature of a global superpower. Being able to walk through the House of Lords and the House of Commons was a real experience.My 12 and 15 year olds went as well, and they also enjoyed it - quite an achievement in today's age!Highly recommended.

Worth the time!. Our family chose the audio tour (there is also a guided tour) an enjoyed it very much. We pre-booked tickets online at the visit.parliament.uk website and were very glad we did as we got the 9:20 am tour but folks showing up at that time without tickets were getting 3:30 entry times. The site is amazing. The amount of history, changes, architecture etc. is amazing. The tour is well done with lots of extra options on various topics if you want to learn more. Without extras the audio tour takes about 1 hour 15 minutes. The architecture and gilding in the House of Lords is stunning. And it is so fun to walk down the "No" division hallway or along the way the Queen walks as she dresses in her royal garb to open Parliament each year. We thought it was an excellent tour.Notes: Book in advance especially during the summer. This is a VERY busy tourist site and often closed so be sure to check in advance if you haven't pre-booked tickets. For example it was only open for tours on Saturdays in the month of July 2015. For the audio tour adults are £18 (US $27), students are £15.50 (US $23), one child (ages 5-15) free with each paid adult but above that children are £7.20 (US $11). Unless the child has a big attention span, it may be too much for them. There are pictures allowed in couple of areas but in most of the Parliament pictures are not allowed for security reasons.

Great self-guided tour. Parliament was in recess so was open for tours. Booked the audio tour online which was very easy. The entrance for tours is not very easy to find on website. The audio tour is fantastic which you can complete at your own pace with lots of extra info on the guide. You get a fantastic insight into the history of Parliament, the Buildings and indeed Democracy. Access to all the main areas is available including the two debating chambers. At the end of the tour you can visit the shop and there is also a cafe. You get a real sense of history coming to life during the tour and in my view a must for those with an interest in this.

Unexpectedly amazed. I'm not one for history or for politics, howeevr I did the tour to please by very cultured father! We took a guided tour, and the guide was absoluteley fantastic (Tim), he made the information factually correct but also made it relevant and interesting for those who are clueless such as me. He also added in a few stories from the last decade to keep the younger ones of the audience some familiarity. If you're visiting London on a Saturday, this is a must-do. Definitely recommend the guided tour opposed to the audio tour, especially considering the price isn't too dissimilar.

Houses Of Parliament Guided Tour. A 90 minute walking tour of the Houses of Parliament. Visit includes going into the House of Lords and House of Commons. Rob, our tour guide was excellent. He was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic, and readily answered questions. Photography was not allowed. Thoroughly recommended for anyone with and an interest in History and/or politics Be careful what you take as there is an airport style security check, and I would recommend buying your ticket in advance

Impressive view. Fantastic and unforgettable view! We see the magnificent Big Ben as soon as we leave the underground station. I had not the opportunity to see it inside, but the building is really beautiful! Listen to the sound of Big Ben bell is an indescribable emotion!

A must do!. Was blown away by the tour of the Houses of Parliament. The tour was so interesting and informative and the architecture of the buildings was amazing. Would highly highly recommend to anyone visiting London!

Another iconic part of London. We did a full day of touring that included Westminster Abbey and the Houses of Parliament. While we did not do the tour inside as we were pressed for time, we spent a good amount of time outside and walking around the building. It is very impressive and if you have the time, definitely do the tour.

Great morning out. My son asked to go as part of a week in London. He is 18, and absolutely loved it. We opted for the guided tour which was fascinating and we'll delivered. The tour lasted 90 minutes and was the perfect length. Highly recommended. We want to go back for the audio tour, which we think covered other things.

Superb tour of beautiful building. We had a guided tour by Lorraine who was excellent. There was history, politics, architecture and humour in a very interesting hour and a half tour of this beautiful building.

Houses of parliament and palace of Westminster. It was really good, the English tour guide gave loades of information and the architecture was amazing, it is a place worth going to. Also the house of commons is very good as well. If your into art then the art work in the whole building is unbelievable.

Amazing access to history. Fascinating visit to such an historic place. We started our audio tour at 11am and there were relatively few delays in passing through the security process. Picking up the headset was also quite painless.The tour itself took in all the main highlights i.e. both houses, the various lobbies and the great hall. It was simply incredible to be able to stand in the Commons at the despatch box which I have seen many times in TV.Highly recommended and not overpriced. All staff were very pleasant and helpful. Tour was well thought out and straight forward.

Beautiful Building. Enjoyed this tour of the Houses of Parliament for both the history and the beautiful architecture of the majestic old building. The tour itself was informative however a little expensive but glad I went.

A great place to see English History. I throughly enjoyed my time there. You need to spend a day. It opens at 9am most days and you need to get there early because of the queue to get in. If you want to see the crown jewels you also need to queue.

Photo opts. You must get photo's of the Houses of Parliament when in London and visiting Westminster Abbey and big Ben. They all shout out, take my picture. It is also an awesome view of Parliament from the London Eye.

Still impresses with repeat visits. Been again and do have to say how much this continues to impress me, dragged the wife along to our fourth visit and still took loads of pictures - its an awesome building (but so much better in good weather - so wish you well)Its not tired, its not cliched - its London as its been for years and years. Well worth planning before visiting.
tourist trail. Nice to see these beautiful buildings up close instead of on tv, even though the streets around here are VERY VERY busy.

Better experiences to be had for tourists. Politics aside, the tourist experience of this place isn't that overwhelming. They display history pieces of well known revolutionaries and activists (E.G. The todpuddle martyrs) that I actually find quite patronizing. It basically implies that laws and rights were given to the people by parliament. That is false. Rights and laws were fought by ordinary people who died, were imprisoned and injured for their efforts. Once you pass the patronizing statements, the actual building itself isn't at all that interesting. You pretty much get a 2 hour tour of explanations about the architecture of the building (while builders are trying to fix parts of it all around you). If the tour was cheaper and less exclusive, then it would be more reasonable to argue that the tour is worth it. If you can get it for free, it's worth the one visit just for experience.
British Empire at its Best. The houses of parliament where we'll worth visiting. The architecture of these buildings is amazing.This is a must see for any tourist visiting London.
Beautiful. How could you miss this? I was lucky enough to se the change of guards, which was exciting. You cant go to London and miss this, and also the gardens near are very beautiful.

Take the Guided Tour!. Not cheap, but worth it. Very popular tourist destination, so pretty busy. But tour well organised and nicely conducted.Lasts about 90 minutes. Most of it standing with little opportunity to sit down and rest your legs.Unforgettably grand & historic buildings, let down only by the visual contribution supplied courtesy of the Metropolitan Police.......scruffy, overweight and looking as if they'd rather be somewhere else on a Saturday morning. Surely we can protect national treasures like this with a police force that looks the part......smart, engaged and physically able, unlike the present bunch.
Houses of Parliament. Great walking tour with of houses of Parliament, booking office opposite big Ben round the back, well worth a visit good value
Tour is great . Informative and interesting tour, I would recommend to anyone interested in history or politics. Also a chance to see one of the few proper thrones in the world

An awe inspiring place. Totally awe inspiring! Beautiful building steeped in history. Blows your mind to think of some of the great leaders who have been there. Central Lobby is particularly inspiring.
Don't try to take pics in there, security will not be impressed, and be prepared for a wait to get in at busy times, best to book tours in advance.

Only on Saturdays.... During the year, you can book a dedicated visit ( guided tour or excellent audioguide) for every Saturday, in August/Sept also on other days. Booking place is right around Westminster tube station, follow the signs. We felt very special, only few people manage to get in ! The Parliament breathes history in every corner - not just the famous green leather chairs in the House of Commons, but also the other pompous gathering rooms, which you never see on TV. You can also go and follow an actual session in the afternoon : political theatre, and often not crowded at all...Certainly a highlight of a London visit !

Take the Guided Tour. Though most will settle for the great view of the buildings exterior, take the time to visit the interior. Though pricey, the guided tour is worth the money as you get to see areas of the building that other tours would not. The guide was very good.
Impressive. We didn't make it inside as we were running out of time, but we were truly amazed at the outside. Big Ben is so impressive! Can't wait to go back!

Easy to get in.. We thought that we would see if we could get in on the off chance and had no problem on a Tuesday afternoon in August. There were very strict searches but no more than I would have expected.The price was very good value more money at £18 for an adult.We spent a good hour and a half walking round with a recorded commentary, which was very good. It was great to see inside where the Lords and politicians meet and was a lot smaller than I expected. Guides were on hand for any questions and for a few pounds more you could have a guided tour.Overall well worth a visit to see where all our countries decisions are made! There was a good shop and café there too.

Book through your MP. Write or e-mail your MP to book. We secured a visit within a month of contacting him.Interesting guided tour of the Great Hall, the Commons (Lords were sitting on our visit) and explanations of parliamentary procedures and history. Strangely not allowed to sit on the seats in the Commons! Maybe off to the Tower if you do!An OK couple of hours with a bored tour guide who was going through the motions but more people should take the opportunity to see the institution.Can't speak for the visitors who are not UK voters but I understand you can pay to get an audio or guided tour on payment.
My dream visit fulfilled.. Loved the visit and walking through the corridors of power and history. Well worth the time to see. It was truly awesome.
Must see!. This historic building is a must see when visiting London. Photographs do not do its grandeur justice.

In the Heart of England. This is a fantastic place where you can listen to debates... You go upstairs (no elevator) rather high. Enjoy beautiful pictures and engravings along the walls, they show England's history scenes. Stay on the top of the mother of all the Parliaments as long as you wish. Be ready though to pass through very severe security check.

A must see. This is definitely a must-see site on the London itinerary. You know what the outside looks like, now take a tour of the inside.
Take a few hours and listen to the audio tour as you stroll through the exquisite halls of British Government.
one of the great buildings of london. if your visiting london the houses of parliament is one of the buildings you must visit, its full of crooked mps but its a must see as a tourist
Stunning. We didn't go inside because there was a weekend when we were there but the outside is absolutely stunning, far better than all the photos you've ever seen.

Impressive building. These are very impressive buildings from every perspective: the waterfront perspective as well as the other side closed to Westminster Cathedral. Unfortunately, the entrance fee was ca. 25 Pound and we were 5 persons - that seemed too much for us and thus we didn`t go in.

Wonderful visit. What a great visit this is! The audio tour is first class, giving enough information without going on and on. It was so interesting to see it all and actually go in to the floor of both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The whole place is so interesting and should be on the must see list for every visitor to London.

Excellent tour. We did a guided tour that was a group of 20. I believe this is a better way to enjoy Parliament to get a better understanding of the old vs the new aspects of the government.There is a LOT of walking on this tour and minimal chances to sit down. We had a 75 year old with us who struggled at times. Also, in some rooms it was difficult to hear the tour guide because there were 2 other groups in the same space.
History First Hand. We had a great guide and the time on the tour flew by.Great to be in the house of lords and house of commons.Entertaining history at its best

Amazing history, amazing place. It is in short the most amazing building I have ever been to. The history of our country is inspiring and fascinating. We did the Audio tour, which was perfect, your pretty much left to get on with it. The audio tour is simple use, with the use of numbers located in each area of interest, it guides you through both houses, simple to use. The other good thing is that you listen to what you want, not stuck with endless audio, you can listen to what ever extras you want. They're understandably sensitive about where you go, and although pictures are not allowed, they seem to turn a blind eye, as long as your not too obvious. The architecture, history that you can see and feel around you, make it an unmissable tour. I would recommend to any visitor to London.
Family vacation. Nice to see from the outside, but that's about it. You can't go inside when we went in July, but I don't think you can go in at any time.

As inspiring in person as you would think. Definitely worth the visit, as it is amazing to see something that not only has the age and heritage, but also the the eminence of sitting right on the river's edge overlooking he rest of the city.

Last minute decision, well worth it.. We were in Westminster and remembered that last time we saw a shop opposite Big Ben selling tour tickets, for the Houses of Parliament.We bought a couple of tickets from the outlet, you have to follow the signs to find it!We then crossed the road, round the corner and found the visitor's entrance.As expected there was airport style security, but having been round Buckingham Palace in the morning with no problems, the system picked up metal rivets on my jeans, so a lot more sensitive!Guided tours or self tour via audio device were available. We chose the audio tour.Photography is limited to areas before entering the central lobby. It was very interesting to visit the Houses of Lords and Commons, as well as the adjacent areas.The commentary was good along with optional additional information if you wanted more details on artwork etc.There were the usual shop, cafe and toilet facilities available near the entrance.A good 90 minutes entertainment. Obviously we were lucky that MP's were on holiday!
Must see!. Exactly what I expected, my first time in London and this is a must see tourist attraction! very picturesque.

Guided visit. I was with a party of 25 where we had a guided tour of the houses of parliament. Very well organised no hassle and our guide Lorraine was very well versed and made the visit fun along with lots of information about the corridors of Westminster so worth a visit.

British history at it's best. Brilliant! If you like your history this is the place to visit. The electronic tour guide thingy' was excellent very informative and well worth the money. This is a must do tour when visiting London.
Interesting morning for family with teenagers. Family trip including two teenagers. All found it interesting and informative. Busy but well organised, with sufficient time to ask any questions

Houses of Parliment is an iconic London must see. Yes of course there is Big Ben (not the clock but the bell in the tower) but it also a functioning political building still today. It of course is also the office of M in the James Bond movies (although MI6 is NOT really located there). See inside for the ornate décor and possibly a session in progress. Walk across Westminster bridge over the River Thames to take in the majesty of Parliament and also see Whitehall, the Strand, South Bank and the London Eye.
A very good time was had as the guide was great. I went with my ladies group and our guide was most interesting We had to wait awhile outside as it was very busy. We were happy about this.

Worth every penny...!!!. Yes!! Worth every penny...do the guided tour with an excellent Blue Badge guide.. 90 minutes of illuminating information and facts...much wiser as to the ins and outs as to how our government works.... easily booked on line at the Houses of Parliament official site....be prepared for airport style security, but well organised visiting all of the main areas of both Houses...give it a go well worth it....multilingual tours available.

Brilliant Experience using a Tour Guide. Firstly wear a comfy pair of shoes your going to do a lot of walking and if you use a walking stick do bring it because you will be doing a lot of standing and not much sitting. Do book online it is so much easier but you can write to your MP and try to get a freebie.We had a brilliant afternoon being shown around this very beautiful building. it is so steeped in British history that as I enter the Main Lobby which has a history of over a thousand years and I stood where Thomas Moor and Will Wallace had stood for their trials a thrill went through my body and I was well and truly hooked from that moment on. You will experience 'airport security' but everyone from the Greeters at the gates to the Police and security staff are so welcoming and efficient that that all passes in the twinkling of an eye. The toilets and shop are to your right on entering the Main Lobby but do take time to look and marvel at the original vaulted roof the minor repairs because of Death Watch Beetle are undetectable and then down to look at the bronze plaques - see if you get that thrill as I did. Present your booking form at the desk and you will be asked to join a group no more than 25 - handed an earphone set ( so you can hear your guide clearly) be warned there is static initially but as you progress on it lessens , although my husband said he could hear perfectly well without them. Our tour guide Derek was simply the best we have ever had in and outside the UK . He had humour , diplomacy and was very, very knowledgeable . I genuinely think he reached all levels of interest from those like me who are nuts about history to those who have a passing interest. He clearly enjoyed his worked and his one aim was to help us appreciate this wonderful experience in its many forms.it is an outstanding building , beautifully preserved , a real jewel in our crown and is well worth seeing just for the architecture alone. I'm not going to spoil it for you by detailing 'stuff' but its nice to see where the wheels of politics which governs our lives takes place. You can only take photos in the Main Lobby and in St Stephens Room so it is up to you but they are really strict about no photos anywhere else - You have been warned!!This tour in my humble opinion isn't for tiny children there is no hands on experiences and even as adults we were expected to behave !! You will be made aware where and when you can take a quick rest and strictly no chewing gum but you can take a bottle of water with you - however there is a café outside or if you really want to push the boat out book an afternoon tea and continue to enjoy your experience . Book at same time as booking your tour.We did this, and as we had about 15minutes to kill before our slot became available it was an opportune moment for a toilet break and quick nose around the tiny shop ( some nice bits and pieces ) - once back in the main Lobby just ask a member of staff who will directed you where to go either the Terrace or as it wasn't available on the day we went the Members Dining Room which suited me a treat as after watching House of Cards I could imagine all those Machiavellian plots taking place over Shepherds Pie and a nice red. Once again you will be guided to the Restaurant from your waiting area , all done with a lovely smile and you will be made to feel very welcome. Our waiters and waitresses ( we had two or was it three ) went out of their way to make our experience as perfect as possible . The food was fresh and extremely delicious - a very inventive selection of cakes and savouries including a Salmon and Lemon Curd Roll ! but it worked perfectly and the delightfully tiny chocolate tart was manna from heaven. A variety of teas were available as well as coffee but the coffee doesn't appear on the menu so be prepared to ask . Do have a glass of champagne it's very moreish and befits the moment (£50.00 a bottle or £9.00 a glass) be warned they don't take cards but I think they must have a cash machine there as someone was taken off - for beheading !! no just to get some cash . All in all an absolutely first class experience, but don't even think of snaffling a memento such as the menu as they do come and remove them towards the end of your tea experience - do as I did and take a photo - trust me you will never remember the designer savoury and sweet names after leaving. Hope you enjoy it as much as we did. Downside only the state of the toilets surprisingly lots of used toilet paper covering the floor and receptacle but I think this was caused by confusion from visitors not understanding that toilet paper can be flushed away - having been to remoter parts of Europe where it is frowned on to flush anything other than the usual away. It was embarrassing to see a foreign visitor look at the Check List Chart for cleaning and shake her head. Apart from this one small point it was a fabulous Afternoon out.
Fascinating and intriguing!. Brilliant 90 minutes enjoyed seeing and learning the history of Westminster. Worth every penny and suitable for older children too.
When in London.... Simply the main postcard. Historical, iconic and very beautiful building. They even have visiting tours.

Great Day Out. This was a nice and interesting day out (for the adults anyhow) as it is quite a long tour as the Houses are quite big. Therefore this meant the kids got a bit bored half way round. i think the tour overall came to around 3 hours, just a bit over which i think is a bit much no matter how interesting it is. Still a good day out, no matter whether you live in England or a tourist! Learn a bit about your Parliament guys!

I'm now a member of Parliament...almost. A guided tour of the Houses of Parliament was way beyond expectation, our guide was both very knowledgable but very easy to listen to and hear, parliament and question time will definetly have a new meaning after seeing how it all takes place....we all should have that traditional experience .

Great visit but we never got in the chambers. went here with 60 year 6 school kids.......the overall experience is fab and the education staff are first rate. the kids got a really good idea about democracy, the history of parliament but sadly we didnt get in teh chambers as it was "voting in new Mps day".However, we did get photos with Mr Milliband, bumped into Lord Prescott, more photos, had a Q&A session with charlotte Leslie. I spoke to marie the new Scottish Mp and Alex Salmond.Well worth a visit

Fabulous to be able to see where giver the countries government happens. Beautiful old building, steeped in history & full of tradition. I took along 2 teenagers, just fresh from a Palace tour, which they loved, this unfortunately, via the audio tour was poor at holding their, or my ,attention for long. Which was such a shame as such important things happen here. I would recommend an update of the audio tour. My friend would recommend a guided tour. There is a nice cafe, decently priced for London , inside & decent loos thankyou for the experience.

The WOW factor. This was certainly a not to miss site in London, in the evening the lights are somewhat "romantic". We took the "HOP on HOP off tour to see the "sites" while in LOndon, sure made this a lot easier.
Houses of Parliament visit. Beautiful architechture. Plenty of photo opportunities and historical facts to learn. Hearing Big Ben chime on the hour makes for a great time too.

Essential London. Over the years I have visited both houses a number of times including dining and private tour of the Lords. Whatever access you can get is worth doing to this great cradle of democracy. Wonderful architecture and library

Beautiful building. As Londoners we seldom go but we were lucky enough to get inside as part of a group who lobbies MPs. The outside is awesome and the inside palatial too. They do guided tours which we'll certainly do one of these days. Well worth a visit

Stunning architecture. So fabulous to be allowed inside this historic and beautiful building. Amazing that the architecture still works for our Parliament today. The Red, Green and Blue coding to the interiors is beautiful. I highly recommend the guided tour - you will learn a lot about our history and the history of our democracy. Put on your walking shoes though 'cos you will cover lots of distance!

Very Enjoyable Visit to the Heart of Our Democracy... Order!!!. This 'attraction' is suitable for solo, couples or teen families. I would say that small children would be bored out of their loverly little minds!! This is my second visit.We were on a day trip to London with a 14 year old nephew and this was one of the attractions we had planned for the day. We grinningly wanted to go up the Queen Elizabeth Tower (Big Ben), but for this you need to be sponsored by your local MP and you must also be a British citizen. Every MP gets a limited number of tickets for Big Ben and most will put your name in a lottery. I guess every MP will do things differently, but this is certainly how our MP does it (Alistair Burt - Bedfordshire). Firstly, the entrance price is reasonable for London and one child goes free with one adult. There is an airport style security check when entering (opposite Westminster Abbey) but you should expect that (why am I always subjected to a pat down?!). Once through, you make your way to Westminster Great Hall. There you show your tickets and either meet your tour group or pick up your audio guides. On my first visit we had a tour guide and she was informative and you could ask additional questions. But it was a bit of a conveyor belt experience. This time we went for the audio guides and I thought they were excellent. Very clear and they were able to bring in current members of parliarment and they also gave sounds of the working building. The position points (about 20 from memory) were clearly indicated and the route was easy to follow. Once the audio piece had finished for a particular point, you had the option of keying in additional codes to get extra filler info which added depth to the experience - this was excellent and appreciated. One perk of joining the guided tour is that they get to go in through the government side of the commons and they could therefore stand at the dispatch box where the PM stands. The audio tour had to be content with being part of Her Majesty's opposition! This was the only thing that really irritated me as this was (for me) the main part of the tour. I have to admit I waited for the security person to get involved with someone else and then I stepped over the roped barrier and stood where I wanted to go! I don't recommend this and I was asked politely to go back, but I got the experience I had paid my money for. This needs to be changed as I really don't think it is fair to offer this only to the tour guide parties. If we can't challenge unfairness in the House of Commons, then where can we?! :o) I also has a sneaky quick sit down on the benches although this is not allowed - my taxes pay for them and I'm as honourable as those who do sit there (or perhaps more so in some cases!)... I really enjoyed this tour and would recommend to others. It is worth mentioning that you have the right to go to the visitors gallery in the Lords and Commons for FREE when the house is sitting and your MP will often give you a free tour too if you ask. Our tour started at 11:20 and we were out by 1pm. If you are out on a bit of a budget, there is a TESCO Express (or compress - the narrowest Tesco in the UK!) opposite Big Ben side of Parliament. You can buy sandwiches etc there and then cross Westminster Bridge and exit at the London Eye. You then cross under the bridge and walk alone the Embankment. Just a bit along there are park benches with great views of Parliament. You can eat your family lunch there. After watching Mission Impossible today, there is a scene shot on the very bench where we sat yesterday!! Spooky!Enjoy your visit...
Beautiful and interesting. The rooms are amazing and go on and on and on. Learned lots about politics in England. It's a 'must-see'.

A must see. We had an interesting day ...and I'm proud that visitors from all over the world can enjoy this unique experience.However ... Our tour was, I have to say, if you are British, a bit of a 'ladybird book' experience .... Stating the obvious at times.I wish we had ' done our own thing' ,rather than be rushed through by a lady who was keen to get the whole thing completed as quickly as possible !
Houses of Parliament. Parliament building has a lot of history inside and a guided tour is a must. Fascinating place with lots to see
Not to be missed!. So interesting. We had a great guide and the tour took about one hour and a half. I highly recommend it to everyone, including children.
Interesting visit. A most interesting visit as you can obtain access and actually see the MP,s discussing various topics.

An impressive building. Beautiful from the outside and a real icon of London. Despite growing up here I never set foot inside until this year. If you have the opportunity then do it, very atmospheric inside too!
Houses of parliament - the beauty of the city. Wonderful view from the opposite embankment, from Victorian gardens. And do not forget to look at it from the back side.

Really beautiful when the sun is shinning. I must confess that I go there very often when I am in London. hey are just beautiful when there is a bit of sun because of their golden decorations. It is one of the ex-libris of London. his, you shouldn't miss it. Close to the Big Ben and Westminster. Very nice walk, if you leave from Trafalgar Square.
Interesting to see. It's interesting to see the Houses of Parliament and it's always busy around there. I've never seen anybody famous though
Definetly a site to take in.. A site to definitely take in while you are in London. The building are majestic especially the contrast on the river.
Beautiful Vista. Looking at the Houses of Parliament from the other side of the river is such a great experience. You get the full sweep including Big Ben and can enjoy the river too.
Fascinating. I highly recommend booking a houses of parliament tour(the guided ones) the guides are really good and well informed.
The mother of all Parliaments!!. Informative , terrific guided tour, well worth a visit. Book an early morning tour to beat the crowds
Icon of London. One of the must see places in London! Sometimes a bit overcrowded but always interesting and beautiful!

If not, WHY NOT. The 90 min long guided tour was fantastic Walked through both the Lords and the Commons and the voting corridors and Committee rooms and the various "Royal" areas as well as those original parts of the building from just short of 1,000 years agoOur guide ( Andrew) was an ex civil servant who worked in the House of Commons for many yearsThese is part palace part current history and the £25 was great value for me and anyone with even a slight interest in history

Learned A Great Deal About London's Government. We took a guided tour. The guide was excellent. She taught us so much about the way the government is run and the history of the building. The tour lasts about 90 minutes. Well worth the money and time..

The ayes have it. Thoroughly enjoyed our tour of the Houses of Parliament. Couldn't get on a tour with a guide but found the audio-guide an excellent substitute. Very informative, interesting and well-paced. So much to take in, and to be enthralled by. Was surprised at the relative smallness of the House of Commons - how to manage to squeeze 600+ members in there?
Everyone should visit. What a wonderful experience. I loved every minute and it was amazing to see so many familiar faces dashing about.

The history and reconstruction of this iconic place is awe inspiring. Fantastic place to visit on a members tour. Just ask your local mp to organise it for you.Stunning architecture, fascinating behind the scenes tour with a really knowledgable guide in a very small group.A brilliant way to see art treasures not easily available to the public.

Really worthwhile visit, be aware that the ticket office is on the river (far away from the entrance!). Beautiful building, lots of history, and very educational with the excellent self-guided audio tour. It was fascinating seeing the difference between the opulent House of Lords and the much more down-to-earth House of Commons. My wife and I with our 3 sons (11, 13, and 15) really enjoyed this, and we spent a bit less than 90 minutes going through it listening to all stops on the audio tour. Perhaps this was our favorite visit in London. Note that the ticket office is in a building right on the Thames at Westminster Bridge, which is quite a hike from the entrance to the Houses, so plan your route accordingly if you want to visit here!

Well worth the cost and time. During sitting times tours are available on weekends, booking online. Once we had passed through some airport-style security we entered the Palace of Westminster via the historic Westminster Hall, where photography is permitted. We found the audioguide to be adequate, although guided tours are offered. We proceeded via St Stephen's Hall to the Central Lobby, where we turned left towards the House of Lords Chamber and Royal Gallery. What opulence! We returned to the Central Lobby and this time kept going straight ahead to the House of Commons Chamber. What relative plainness! It was a most informative time, and we learned a lot about the procedures, history and traditions of this iconic part of the London scene. Highly recommended.

Beautiful building, great information from the audio tour. We purchased tickets online, with a timed entry on a Saturday morning, first entry. We had our audio guides and really learned a lot from them. The interiors are very interesting, so much to learn. It was lovely to be inside the building when Big Ben sounded. Of course, this is a working building, and seeing things like the MPs message boxes, etc. brought home the fact that this is not just a museum, it is an active building. I would loved to see a session in process. There is also a terrific gift shop. Definitely worth the time and the money to see the Houses of Parliament.

A Trip to Parliament. Me and my family decided to visit the parliament as we were on a weekend trip to London. I myself follow politics regularly, so you can imagine my excitement at visiting this iconic location. We visited on the 27th July and we were on an audio guide tour. The staff were not very friendly, and came accross as rude and slightly scornful. In the house of commons chamber, there was one particular tour guide who was with a group and me and my Mum were accidentally stood near the benches on the government side. There is no clear signs or notices telling you to not stand in certain areas. The guide turned to a security guide and said " please will you move these people out of the way immediatley" and gave us a threatening look. We complied with this command and carried on feeling targeted and angry. Also there are not many places you can see, and photography is not allowed. We understand this is for security reasns, but added to our disapointment. The history of the building is interesting and unique. The audio toir is good and the upkeep of the building is good too. It was fascinating to see familiar sights in person and was worth the price.However I left the Parliament dissapointed by the lack of respect from staff of all kinds in the parliament and also dissapointed as you cannot see a lot of the building. All in all I enjoyed some aspects of the visit, but would only go back if I were to be elected as an MP or appointed a Lord. I feel that there is too many rules to follow and that the staff, wether they are tour guides or security guards lack respect and training.

Easy free access to Parliament - House of Commons. So worth stopping in to see a debate. On the Westminster side of Parliament, there is easy free access if you mention that you are here to see the debate in the House of Commons. They will issue your passes after passing thru security and escort you to a soundproof viewing room. They were debating national security. It was great!

Suggested to everyone interested in politics and history. We booked the Italian guided tour and the people were very nice to us. We were late and they escorted us to the group very efficiently. The guide was very good and the tour very interesting.

Best tour of 9 days trip! Would go again!. Excellent guided tour (we paid extra for personal guide, not audio tour.) Fascinating and wonderful to be in the same rooms we see on PMQ (Prime Minister's Questions.)

Lovely historic architecture, Keep the tour. Parliament was a great disappointment. Although the structure is grand and the history important, the manner in which the tours are conducted are much to desire. Be prepared for a cattle call. The appointment is booked and you arrive at a time. Women must open purses and one feels as if you are entering into an airport security line. This is understandable, yet, NEVER A SMILE OR COURTEOUS GESTURE IS FOUND. If you become tired of the tour, you are NOT allowed to leave ahead of time. On the positive side, there is much to appreciate if like myself you do some reading and reviewing prior to attending. The guides really need to speak up and consider the number of individuals in the area.

A must see if you are in London. This is quite a spectacular building and a must see. We went on Saturday and did the audio tour. We booked the day before by phone or you can do it online. If you do it this way there was no queue. We simply went to the Cromwell Green entrance opposite Westminster Abbey gave them the order number they handed over tickets and we were straight in and had to go through security. The ticket office across the road had huge lines.

Wow - beautiful Parliament - worth the visit!. When we made the reservations the guided tours were sold out so ended up doing the audio tour. The audio tour is as good as the guided tour - quite detailed. Amazing building with paintings, statues, wood work, etc. lot of history as expected. Spend your time - don't rush. The tours are only on Saturdays and you need to book way in advance especially during summer.

A excellent visit. We had a guided tour costing just over £20 a head that lasted over 90 minutes.The excellent, well informed guide took us through the Palace of Westminister to the House of Lords and then on to the House of Commons giving us an insight to the workings of Parliament and an lesson in the history that underpins our country.The security, as you would expect, is tight so expect airport type scanners and searches. The staff were all very pleasant, welcoming and helpful. The cafe off Westminister Hall was moderately cheap serving a good cup of coffee and a variety of fresh cakes and sandwich type food.A visit that I would gladly make again.

The Place and the History . The Palace is the center of old and new London. Most historical places and buildings are close. Great architecture is still new and modern after years. Outside is enough to spend some time and take lots of photos.
Lords and Commoners all. A must visit in London. We spent 3 hours absorbing history, gaining insight into the Parliament of Parliaments. Excellent guided tour.
London Trip. very interesting, nice to have a look around and very good tourist attraction, very local to bars, cafes and other tourist attractions.

Beautiful Buildings, Wonderful River Side Setting. World famous UNESCO Heritage Site. Great photo opportunities here. It's a pity you can't go inside but it is a working institution so that's understandable. If you only come to London once you have to take a stroll by here.

Super tour . Loved this. Tickets available across the street towards the bridge and not available at the entrance. Tour was very informative and the tour guide interesting and knowledgable. The sheer size of the building is impressive and pretty cool to be able to stroll around inside what you see on TV. Tour brings the history of the state from the beginning up to the present with famous figures, such as Guy Fawkes, Henry VIII, Churchill etc making plenty of appearances! Highly recommend.

Wit and Wisdom sums up our guide Chris. A fantastic visit. Our guide Chris was extremely knowledgable and witty. Both adults and children learnt lots. If you are interested in history and politics then well worth a visit.
Parliament. was an easy walking distance just to visit sites were awesome on our walk to get at the site. Just beautiful construction of the buildings
houses of parliament charlie lord. great taste of where our country makes its prime decisions. lovely place to visit, lovely place for a political mind it britan
Crumbling Palace. Palace of Westminster is desperate need of repair, not many visitors to this "political haven" where some terrible decisions have been made over the years

Wow, Wow and Wow.. It is an amazing building, from the moment you walk in through the security, you feel that you are in a very influential place. Going into the Commons and the House of Lords was amazing, it is great to see in person the place that you see, oh, so, often on TV, in person. When I was there I was lucky enough to see the Speaker's Procession though the main lobby. It is just amazing and I highly recommend it to anyone that has enough time in London!

interesting, if you like old buildings!. Interesting to see from the outside. Would have loved to to go inside. Unfortunately, we couldn't arrange it. Still, a beautiful, if crumbling building, which was interesting just to walk around.

Iconic. A lovely photo excursion and a walk-by...the many important policies that have been passed in these premises that have changed the course of world history for all time to come. An iconic structure

Excellent experience and value for money.. We did a tour followed by afternoon tea. Excellent experience and value for money. Lots of time is allowed, especially for the afternoon tea, which we throughly enjoyed.

A Must See in Londo. Well worth a stroll by. Come close to the hour and you will hear the Big Ben Bell ring. Not far, just over the bridge is the London eye, hold on to your vaulet while walking over the bridge, the pick pocket scene there is quite big.

Great experience. A magnificent building both inside and out. We opted for a guided tour which was fantastic our tour guide was great at his job. There were many opportunities to see many parts including the small throne room and both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Not to be missed!

Parliamentary Perfection!. While we’ve been to London many times, neither my husband nor I has ever visited Parliament even though our daughter worked for a member of the House of Lords several summers ago. We remedied that on Tuesday and had the time of our lives. Booking a “blue badge” tour in advance (they even have a very reasonable senior rate), we arrived slightly early and were taken with that earlier tour group. Our guide, Reginald Denny (not the poor man from Los Angeles) was both entertaining and extremely knowledgeable, giving all 15 of us a true sense of the history and grandeur within those walls. The tour was a little over 90 minutes long but we could have gone for twice that. Tube access from the Westminster station is very easy. This is a must-see site!

An "once in a lifetime" event. I visited both houses when I worked as an interpreter for a group of foreign politicians. We had a very informed guide who told us interesting facts and stories connected to this majestic landmark of London life. Fascinating glimpse into the history, architecture, present traditions and major events in the year s calendar, such as the Queen's speech. I had the privilege of taking tea on the balcony, seeing a side of the Thames not normally seen and we even had lunch in the restaurant. An overall memorable experience.

Amazing things have happened here. Walk in the footsteps of those who have governed England for centuries. It is really a lovely visit once you get over the entry hurdles: tickets, lines, security, etc. But once "in" it is SO worth it, as is the self guided recording. Whether your imagination conjures up historical characters or contemporary, it is an amazing journey through this castle.
Nice. A nice place to visit when you are in London. The night lights gives it a good and nice view. And by the Thames that is nice

Where it all happens. Amazing trip and very informative. Friends and I had booked the tour which is well worth it. We had the most fabulous lady showing us around. Unfortunately they were booked up for the following afternoon tea.
Quite Impressive. We viewed from the outside and were very impresssed for the granduer of the building and the history that it represents.
Interesting points. Walk around and the area will shows you lots of interesting buildings, art, architecture and historical.

Historic tour. Great opportunity to visit this historic building. We opted for the guided tour, which I think was better than audio option. Tour lasted 1 1/2 hours and went into the House of Lords and the commons as parliament was in recess.

What can you say!. I am not sure that the Houses of Parliament need to be rated on Trip Advisor! Will they close if they get a bad review! This place is the heart of London and is I don't knowhow many centuaries old. Anyone who goes to London should at least walk by this place and look in wonder at Englands seat of power.
Interesting and eye opening. My Husband loved it. It was ok for me too :)Beautiful architecture, powerful atmosphere and very informative.  Highly recommended!
Great experience. Had a wonderful experience. We were able to go into the "Strangers" area in the balcony and watch a debate. A must see.

Like being on a Movie Set. You cannot visit London without visiting the Houses of Parliament. Stunning to look at and you can imagine all the incredible events that have happened here over the centuries. Almost like being on a movie set...
History!. The public tours on Saturdays are excellent. Check out the cafe before you leave. Check out the statues in the gardens. They are amazing!

Great Experience!. I had my college trip in Parliament and I must say it was absolutely amazing to be perceived to the traditional and old environment of such historical place. In restaurants they are still using old cutleries and plates, which must be around 600 years old. Majority of rooms still has that old sense of history in the environment. Further, it is connected to the Westminster Abbey and other buildings around it with underground tunnel. I would highly recommend this place.

A Must Do. We booked ahead and received our time slot and tickets. Upon arrival, tours started on time. We did a self guided audio tour and found it very interesting and informative. You can almost feel the energy of the debates these great halls have seen. Plan 1-2 hours and immerse yourself in Britains history.

We were blown away by parliament. We took the audio tour of Parliament, it was fantastic experience visiting places we had only previously seen on television. The audio tour was very informative and left us with more knowledge of this iconic place. The history of the attraction is huge and it was incredible to be where the major decisions of the country are taken

Very interesting. A well organised audio tour. Really informative and thoroughly enjoyable. The interior of the building is amazing, the architecture is breathtaking. I enjoyed learning about the workings of parliament and the role of the monarchy. A fascinating insight.
Parliament to visit. It is situated on the bank of Thames river and very near to clock tower. From there you can easily see tower bridge. Very good location form london eye also,
Big Ben. Always lovely to be here and see the history. Love the buildings. love the river. Easy to get to by tube and is great to walk the entire area.
Fantastic. A great place to visit with such interesting history. It is a Must to visit to understand how today's Britain is shaped by its past, present and future.
Incredible. An extensive tour with an EXCELLENT guide. The guided tour was well worth the extra $$$. Historic and beautiful.

C-SPAN comes to life!. I've only seen the British parliament at work on C-SPAN. so it was great to see in person. I believe it's only open on the weekends for tours, so book accordingly. The buildings and rooms are really lovely. I had originally wanted a live tour guide, but as it was booked, we had to settle with the audio guide. It worked out fine though.

Afternoon Tea a Big Hit with Family. The tour itself was a bit too long at 1 1/2 hrs - would have prefferred an overview, a brief description of British govt followed by tea. entrance is cumbersome; print tickets in advance! Tea was lovely as was the tour guide's hospitality. Interesting afternoon.

Truly Amazing. I have visited so many amazing palaces I thought I could not be surprised. Wow this place is just steeped in History and is the most amazing place I have visited. We had the guide of Westminster palace, the lords and Commons our guide was full of information. Loved every second of it.
beautiful building. it is a beautiful and attractive building right on the river. it gives the place a good reason to be photographed and captured.

Visually stunning, emotionally engaging.. For those visitors with a sense of history, this tour offers an experience second to none in aligning them with the past.In spite of the necessarily high levels of security, access, once inside, is wonderfully generous. More or less unlimited freedom of movement in both chambers and, in spite of the large numbers of visitors, the opportunity to quietly reflect on the many momentous historical moments which took place there, is available to you. I was particularly moved to be freely walking around the front and back benches in the Commons. I am not usually prone to mawkish sentiment, but seeing this place did stir a sense of pride and gratitude for our democracy.The audio guide is marvellous (and an additional benefit is that you are insulated from the cacophony), criticism, if any, is that I wanted more.I am sure that I will return.
Good experience.. nice to see inside the seat of government! Good audio guide allowing you to visit at your own pace. Very interesting tour.

Visit to Houses of Parliament with my elderly mother in a wheelchair. I telephoned and booked a ticket with the Houses of Parliament prior to my visit as I was taking my elderly mother who needed to use a wheelchair. At first I was disappointed when I was told that all of the tours were booked for the day that I was wanting to go and we could only have a virtual tour. I booked the ticket for £15 and as my mum was in a wheelchair I was entitled to a free ticket as her carer. We arrived 15 minutes early and were directed through security to the Great Hall where we were given our audio head sets. I wasn't sure if my mum would manage at 93 but there was no problem she heard every word and staff were extremely friendly and helpful. The tour took about 1-1 and a half hours and was very interesting and informative. Afterwards we had a look around the gift shop and a lovely lunch in the cafe. We woud definitely recommend a visit.

Very interesting. I was invited for a tour and thoroughly enjoyed it. It did open my eyes to how my upbringing must have indeed been very privileged and my education a little beyond the ordinary. I suppose one does not know what others do not know about until you are in their company and their ignorance surfaces. Being from a political family but having no personal interest in politics it was wonderful to see the house from the inside...and seeing all the business which makes this country tick.

Flooded, we'll be back on a dry day 😀. What I wish I'd known before hand is that the Café is available to use before your timed ticket as we struggled with crowds outside to get a coffee. Older and wiser, now .Eric Miller was an excellent and humorous guide and the Palace of Westminster is such an impressive place can't fail to be a great place to visit. Sadly, The House of Commons was flooded so was not able to be accessed, another visit is required and requested!

A fantastic combination of history and beauty. If you are interested in British politics and history, this is one you should not miss. The buildings are more beautiful than I ever imagined, and the history and traditions are fascinating. The fact that it is a functioning building makes it even more interesting. We get to see the postage pigeonholes of people we see on TV every day and it makes the whole experience so real. A thoroughly undersold British attraction.

Spectacularly magnificent!. A tour of the Houses of Parliament is a spectacular event that will give you a unique insight into the rather peculiar constitutional framework that is the basis for democracy in the UK. And some of the many behind-the-scenes stories told by the guides are really entertaining.
Houses of Parliament. We booked this on a Friday and visited the following day. A really interesting attraction to visit. We did the audio tour which was very informative. A must see.
What a superb building. We didn't go inside as we hadn't got time and hadn't booked or paid in advance but it is a super building steeped in history.

How do you say "boring" without it sounding bad?. I guess I'm just not a big fan of large, ornate buildings. Maybe you shouldn't listen to me, but I find this stuff kinda boring! I'd much rather wander around some "off the beaten path" area, or sit and watch people while enjoying a frosty cold beverage. We were in The Louvre for about 40 minutes this trip as well, so that ought to tell you something! If you like large, ornate buildings, this one is fine.
