Big Ben and Westminster Abbey are also close by, so if you put you "foot into it" as they say in the USA, you can crank out the whole area in about 40 minutes!
parliament. amazing buildings, great for photos. Didn't go inside, too many tourist around, so watch your pockets for pick pockets

Exciting to be at the seat of government. If you've ever wached Prime Minister's Questions on the BBC channel, you see the back and forth among the political parties posing questions to the Prime Minister. On this tour, assuming Parliament is not in session, you get to walk right through the House of Commons! In addition, you walk through a number of other historic rooms including Westminster Hall, the oldest part of the complex where Sir Thomas More was tried in the 16th Century. One of the best sights to visit in London.

Very informative. This was a great guided tour (see your local MP to arrange) and I found out a lot about the history of the buildings and how they are laid out. I really enjoyed it but the kids were bored.

Interesting insight into the workings of Parliament. We did the guided tour and I'm not sure if we made the right choice. The guide was obviously very knowlidaible but was more interested in telling us how parliament worked (which was very interesting) rather than the history of the building etc. She was a bit "bossy" and definitely very short with an American in the group who dared to question the point of the "House of Lords". (I think she was Anne Widecombe's sister but that's pure conjecture!)There is also an audio tour where you go round at your own pace which may have been a better option.Having said all of the above it's definitely worthwhile going and you do have access to all of the areas you would expect (We went on a Saturday), be aware it is a big building we were in there almost two hours
Guided tour. Excellent with a very knowledgeable guide, good value for 1 1/2 hour tour.The lady was very friendly and was able to answer all questions she received.

Best school trip!. I normally don't enjoy school trips however I had to make an exception when coming here.My class and I got to see the House of Lords and House of Commons which were both stunning rooms, however it was incredibly difficult not to be able to sit on the extremely comfortable chairs.I would love to come back soon.

Slightly dissapointed. I have done this tour a few years ago and it was incredible. The tour guide back then was very knowledgable and it was a great day. Because of this, we applied for tickets again as family wanted to do it.Unfortunately, the houses of lords were sitting and so there was a large portion of the tour that was not possible. This was very clear to us and the guide was struggling to fill the time.It doesnt take away the fact that the building is still stunning and its exciting to get to stand inside the house of commons and the members lobby etc.We went and sat for a short period in the house of lords and watched a small amount of the debate.

Great Visit, wonderful surprising building. Absolutely beautiful building, Architecture,frescos and statues. You can take some photos in some parts of Parliament buildings. Good security, visit to open parliamentary debate. It was the last day for free entry on my visit (on the last day)
A visit well worth making.. A great visit with good audio tour. Understand why photos not allowed in Commons and Lords but should be allowed in other areas.

Day-trip to Houses of Parliament. Is a great architectural attraction. Awe-inspiring!
The fact that security is not hugely invasive allows you to get really close to the building

House of Lords and House of Commons. I had the privilege of being invited for lunch at the House of Lords, dined at the Attlee Suite and had access to the terrace with the wonderful view of London.
Lovely meal, nice wine, great company of some esteemed Lords and once in a life time experience.

Fascinating Historical Tour. Our MP's very kind PA got us on one of the guided tours as I realised at the last minute that as parliament was still sitting you couldn't get in during the week other than on these tours which are apparently booked up months in advance (thank you Elaine Wylie). You just drop your MP an email and they took it from there & got us slots on a cancellation. We didn't pay anything by having our MP sponsor us for the visit, not sure if this is the norm.The tour itself was extremely interesting. Our guide was one of the doorkeepers who was very knowledgable and amusing to boot & we had a good banter re the current SNP situation at the Houses of Parliament, which of course went over the other tourists heads as they were all non UK.I learnt lots of interesting facts & the buildings themselves are just beautiful. Be prepared for a bit of walking. We had our teenage kids with us who loved it, but I think under 10s would be bored. You don't get to sit down at all - execution was threatened if we sat on any of the MPs seats, haha! One foreigner of course sat down.....off with her head!
A lot of history. very interesting place with lots of history. Took a couple of hours to see everything. Tour guides were very knowledgeable, making it a worthwhile visit.
Visit with 2 children ages 7 & 10. Very interesting but would suggest audio tour rather than guided as lengthy talks were not child orientated.
Fantastic way to relive the history of many countries. Enjoyed the way each section featured aspects of history from different countries and cultures. No two rooms were the same

Beautiful buildings. One cannot go to London and not see the Houses of Parliament. Looking up at The Big Ben is London on a postcard - just in real life. We were lucky enough to watch runners dressed up in all sorts of different costumes completing a road race right in front of the Houses of Parliament.
nice buildings. I had a guided tour of London and she told us about the building and its history. Very nice architecture. A must see.

Impressivee building. The tours a well worth taking for all the interesting history of the Parliament House. Groups were large but could hear the presentation ok. There is a lot of area to cover so a lot of walking.

Guided tour of the Lords and Commons. Great visit, the history and tradition is amazing, you need a guide to show you the true historical impact it has on the laws. The Queens dressing room, the tradition of Opening Parliament and how laws are passed from the Commons to the Lords is well worth listening to. Really enjoyed the whole tour, we went with a Canadian visitor and she loved it too!
panoramic. The sight from every movie or tv show that is ever based in London, it's an incredibly impressive sight from across the river and up close.

Beautiful, ornate building with fascinating tour. The tours are only offered on Saturdays during the summer and lasts about 90 minutes. It was great to learn more about the English Parliamentary system and see the chambers where the House of Lords and House of Commons meet. Not recommended for younger visitors as they will likely be bored.

Fabulous. My husband contacted our MP and we were granted a tour of the Houses of Parliament. Our MP and Sam his secretary, gave us a guided tour of the building. We were lucky enough to hear a debate and were also served drinks on the terrace. A fabulous afternoon and very educational. a huge thank you to Mr Owens and Sam.

Plan into your day out. Lunch in Tower bridge, get some bicycles and cycle to covent garden via Westminster. Stop at the houses of parliament and just enjoy. Give your body a rest and soak up the beauty in every detail of the buildings.

Best tour ever. This was what my grandson had on the top of his list plus I had never been before either. We had pre-arranged our visit and this helped but there was very little waiting, to get inside the first hall was amazing and as you looked at the plaques in the floor history started right there. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and answered all the many questions also keeping the four children that were there entertained. To be able to be in all the chambers and places that you see on the television was inspiring and to stand were our country is controlled from plus actions and decisions made for around the world was a privilege. The tour was about 75 minutes but it did not feel like that because you see so much it went very quickly.
I saw better places. Big building on empty area. Nothing special:) I saw much more lovely places in London. Go and see Big Ben or lovely parks, to Tissaud, or The London Eye,

Clearly one of the "must dos" in London. We visited the Parliament to hear the debate (I was living in London at the time). You don't have to queue/line up if you were a resident and planning on only watching the debate. It was a great experience which I would definitely recommend. I have also done a tour and it is definitely a great way to experience London/UK and history.

Impressive. Today I eventually had a guided tour around our Houses of Parliament. I arranged it several months ago by contacting my MP and asking for a ticket. You need to get there earlier than your tour time as there is airport style security and you then meet your guide in Westminster Hall.There were around 18 in our group and they leave every 5 minutes so there are a lot of people milling around waiting for their group to be called.Our guide was Vanessa and she had actually worked there before becoming a tour guide. Mobile phones must be switched off and no photography is allowed once the tour starts.It's incredibly interesting and even without a knowledge of English history it would be enjoyable. Our group were lucky enough to enter both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. You are not allowed to sit in either of the Houses although we did get to stand to get an idea of how it feels.The tour lasts around and hour and fifteen minutes but it is all walking and standing so not for the less able.A thoroughly enjoyable and educational visit.

Impressive row of building by the Thames!. Easily located block of buildings beside the Thames; right by the Westminster Cathedral. Great background for photos as the British flag is flying high above the buildings. Right beside the Big Ben.
Don't miss!. Buy tickets in advance!! This tour is very popular during summer months. We did the audio tour and it was wonderful!!

Interesting History and a lovely afternoon tea. We did the tour with a very knowledgeable Blue Badge guide. It was interesting to see the various rooms, including the House of Lords and the House of Commons, the interesting art work and the statues.
Afternoon tea overlooking the Thames at the end of our tour was traditional - sandwiches, scones, pastries and cakes - and good.

A definite bucket list tour. This was a really interesting tour. From the moment you walk into Westminster Hall and take in its amazing size through to St Stephens Chapel, its an amazing experience throughout. Takes around 90 minutes and the audio guide is extremely informative. Its great to be able to soak up the history that has occured in this building. Just a pity no photography is allowed

Great place with such a wealth of history and stories. Great place and attraction. Getting through security didn't take take long considering the importance of it. The venue has plenty of facilities (shop, toilets, cafe, etc) considering it wasn't built for public access. Get a guided tour as you will miss so much history and stories without one. My only criticism is that photography is not allowed in most areas which is for both security (but why when the place is so well documented and streams live TV broadcasts) and because they want to preserve photography for commercial reasons - this is publicly funded building - why can't amateurs take photos?

Self guided audio tour . I enjoyed it here much more than I thought I would. We picked up some of the self guided audio tours, I really like these as they let you go at your own pace and can stop and look more at things when you want to. Impressive old building, lots of good facts about the parliament and done great pictures of big Ben from inside the grounds. Highly recommended
try it. Visit worth it and very interesting. The commons is a lot smaller than it looks on tv. We had an audio tour which was very informative

A must see in London. This area is a must see while visiting London. The Parlament and Big Ben are amazing to see and make for great photo shoot. I did not know that you can tour Parlament on certain days & times so next time I'd like to try it.

Visit with young teenagers to a great London sight!. Although done a few years ago, with my young teenage daughter and her friend and mum, it was very memorable. To see history almost in the making, to get an opportunity to see what we see on TV so often, for the girls to stand in a hall more than 1,000 years old where kings were crowned, it was amazing for them and still remembered with some of the facts, years later. The guides were very knowledgeable and worth chatting to!
Hurry it may not be there forever. Hurry before it falls down! It is an amazing place to see Gothic Rival the scenes of Knights of the Round Table and the Victorian's view of a stylised world.
Parliment square. great to see the victorian style buildings, statues of great world leaders. Westminister Abey was also close by.

A privileged experience.. I have had the pleasure of dining at the House of Lords twice recently with Lord Astor of Hever and on both occasions I have thoroughly enjoyed the experience, ambiance and the majesty of the building. The food and wine were also totally enjoyable. The statues throughout and the tapestries in the gallery on route to the Peers dining room are awesome. It was certainly interesting to learn that the French Foreign Service requested that the tapestries depicting Napoleon's defeat at Waterloo be covered during Charles de Gaulle's visit in 1960 to address the Lords.Needless to say without Churchill's approval... they weren't! A fine experience, good food and wine and great company.

Amazing architecture!. It's beautiful! It's of such a grand scale that the only way to fit it all into one picture frame is to cross the river. Truly amazing.The security there is quite impressive: The whole building is surrounded by a steel barrier, sufficient to prevent vehicles from crashing through. And there are numerous military-like patrolmen with automatic weapons sentinelling. They really don't detract from the beauty, their presence kind of reiterates how precious the landmark is.Go see it!

our quick 30 minutes in westminster. only saw it from the outside very busy. did not go into st pauls as it was £15pp saw big ben and heard it at 12 noon, It was mental there every nationality you could think of was there.too busy went back on the boat to Greenwich
historic place. Its top tourist spot. So must visit place for touristers. If you got time , then choose audio guide.

A great tour for a government nerd like myself. I went on this tour in September 2014 and it was amazing. You get a very up close and personal tour of the UK government for a reasonable price. Two caveats, you must book ahead and no pictures are allowed on most of the tour.

great place!. All the staff are really lovely and welcoming. upon entry you go through security that is similar to airport security and you are asked to not take any electronics into the houses of pariament, they provide 'cages' to keep your belongings safe untill you exit. The toilets are amazing, they are very clean and opulant. There are a lot of stairs and you will be standing though most of the tour so wear comfortable shoes. Also if you are disabled I would suggest you ring ahead regarding access. it is a very interesting place and i would recommend it to everyone.

Historical Excellence.. The houses of Parliament in London are a very unique place to visit. Had the privilege to take a tour there recently. The architecture is magnificient and the place is so steeped in history you can almost feel it. Upon entering the security is necessary of course and essential. Was wonderful sitting is the public gallery listening to the various members speaking in the chamber below. Was well worth joing the long queue to gain entry. For anyone interesed in politics in general this place is well worth visiting.

Insider's View of British Parliament. If you like history or are interested in political processes you will like this tour. Actually being able to enter the houses of Parliament and see the ornate furnishes is also interesting.We bought our tickets ahead of time on line. It took us about 15 minutes to find the right entrance and even though we had tickets we still had to wait about 30 minutes in line. Once inside, we received an audio box and headphones describing what we saw. Photography is allowed in the main Hall which is the oldest part of the complex and fairly sparse. The next room is St. Stephens Hall and the last room where we were allowed to take photos. This room has statues to famous statesmen. I was a bit jet lagged so I didn't get all the details that we heard about each of the rooms and the parliamentary process that seemed to be complicated. There is a central lobby between the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Both the houses have fewer seats than members so many stand. The House of Lords has an ornate red and gold throne for the monarch. The monarchy is not allowed in the House of Commons due to an incident that occurred with King Charles I in the 1600's.

Limited times for tours.. Be careful to research this one if you want to go on a tour as they are only offered during certain days of the week. You can, however, ask to go inside and see Parliament anytime that it is in session which is interesting in and of itself. You cannot go into Big Ben's tower.
One of the main attraction of London. We went on a tour inside of the building. Wasn't going too deep and not much information given but nice to know some story behind this spectacular building.

Tour and afternoon tea. Visited this attraction on a day trip to London on the 11th July, We pre booked the tickets some months before hand, and would recommend this. Access was easy, we booked a guided tour, their is a option of a audio tour. You are not allowed to take pictures, tour includes both the house of lords and commons. My wife had also booked afternoon tea as part of the package, this was overlooking the thames, not cheap but was a great experience. A memorable day.

Free tour of the palace or westminster. Excellent tour of the Houses of Parliament including the robing room and the houses of commons and lords. The tour was organised by my local MP and it was a very good educational tour extremely proffessionalism by the tour guide Camilla. Camilla was very knowledgable and gave a great amount of information in a clear and concise way, answering question posed and showed great understanding to everyone on the tour. Highly recommended.

Cool. We went and took pictures of the buildings. If you look around you can find a red telephone booth and take pictures with Big Ben in the background. There was a protest going on outside when we were there against some new Fox Hunting ruling which was just the cherry on top of our visit. Westminster Abbey is next door.

The heart of London. I have been there twice. Each time it is a revelation. This place is visitor friendly and I love walking through the Westminster area. This part of London looks the same as it was twenty years ago.
houses of parliament. Amazing building first time visit you need plenty of time but is worth the money plenty of photo opportunitys
Good to visit. Plenty of history and power here. An architectural delight and always of interest in history and politics.
big ben. couldn't come to london without seeing big ben and houses of parliament. lovely looking building, pity about the occupants.

Gothic and chance to touch history. Very beautiful inside, gold and Gothic style. And its really interesting to see where all politics are made now, house of lords and ect. where all debates are heldUnfortunately taking pics are not aloud(((

Indepth tour of an iconic building. We visited last summer having pre-booked our tour online. We were sorry that we could not also visit the Elizabeth Tower as it transpired there is a convoluted procedure of applying through your MP and we were informed you need to apply months in advance. However, parliament wasn't in session when we did visit so we were allowed access to the House of Lords, House of Commons and Westminster Hall. There are few opportunities to sit on the tour so be prepared for a lot of walking and standing, but it was well worth the visit.

Try and get a tour. If I was a tourist in London, with teenage kids or older, this is one of the most brilliant places you can visit as a tour. Unfortuantely, you have to prebook, but if you do and parliament is not sitting, you can get into the house of commons, stand at the speakers table etc. Best tour in London period

Wonderful History. This is a beautiful building rich in history. You are taken through the areas by a guide who gives you an overview of the construction of the building and the workings of Parliment. Very interesting.
Get a good picture. Myfamily and I traveled to London in summer of 2014. We had a great time and seeing this classic building was a treat.

A Must See. Twice before we have been to London and twice before we have not been able to visit the Houses of Parliament. This is because it is only open on Saturdays when Parliament is not sitting. I recommend pre booking through their website www.parliment.uk before you leave. You just walk straight in and don't have to queue. Highly worth the visit too. The architecture is amazing and the history very interesting. There is also an audi tour specifically for children which I think was probably more interesting than the adult version. My kids kept telling me various interesting facts throughout the tour!
Fantastic. Thoroughly absorbing visit for Al the family, a thoughtful two hour tour through the whole palace and brought to life by great guides

Private tour of the Crips.. The building is beautiful and the two Houses are very impressive. The House of Lords and the House of Commons. We especially enjoyed our private tour of the Crips below and our lunch in the MP dinning hall.
Really enjoyed the visit.. Great experience, educational for kids. Though you do need to link in with your local MP to access the live commons debates. We enjoyed it.

Houses of Parliament. The Houses of Parliament are amazing, I went with my College in 2006 (although I can't select that date hence why it says August 2014!) we had a tour round. It's massive and very impressive on the inside the history, the art is fascinating. We were taken into the main part where debates are held. It's very impressive. If your interested in history and politics then it's for you.

Iconic building in London. i was not able to get inside the houses of parliament, so I can only say that visiting and taking pictures of this iconic building is worth it.take pictures from any of the available river cruises or from the London eye and the photograph oportunities are endless. I knew a little bit of the house of parliament beforehand so, if this is not your case you can always get a tour inside.
A Wonderful Tourists Attraction. History & Architecture combined in one location. A great location to have some unforgettable photos.I really enjoyed the location and having some nice photos
excellent tour. We took a tour of the Houses of Parliament and quite enjoyed it. We recommend taking the audio tour to learn history and details of every room.

Great tour of the seat of government. My college age daughter and I took the guided tour on a Saturday in June 2015. Since Parliament was in session this month you could only visit on the weekend. The tour gives access to a couple of places you can't go on the self-guided tour, and it was probably worth the extra cost. The building itself is gorgeous, especially the House of Lords. Due to weekend construction our Underground stop was closed so we had to scramble for transport and consequently missed our scheduled tour. The staff were very kind and moved us to the next tour, which was only a half hour later (10 am I think). The crowds were not extensive at that time. You can only take pictures where the tour starts, in Westminster Hall. The exterior is very beautiful though, so do bring some kind of camera.

A really interesting tour. I booked the tour after reading other reviews and have to say I really enjoyed it. My guide was a world if knowledge and it was amazing to see inside the building
. you are nor allowed to take pictures which was a bit of a disappointment but then security does come first.

Worth a visit. Fantastic tour and very informative. Pre booking is essential as the tours are normally fully booked. Very busy with lots of different tours taking place within minutes of each other. Our tour guide was great and full of interesting facts. Definitely worth a visit of such a wonderful building

Fascinating. Well worth a visit. Very interesting to see all the history and day to day business that takes place in the great buildings here. Only downside is that to go up the tower housing big ben needs permission from your MP in advance - that's not the easiest thing to get if you're not booking a long way ahead and does pose another issue if your MP is at odds with your own politics as once you contact them they bombard you with mailings assuming you're on their side!

Watched the MP's in action. It was fun to watch the members of parliament in action debating in the House of Commons. It's open to the public, but check the schedule to make sure they are in session. We went around 6pm and were able to walk right in, but I know there are lines at other times. No need to stay long--after about 30 minutes you get a good flavor of how the system works.

Simply amazing . By far the best tour that I have done. The building is purely fascinating and I found myself stopping on the tour in awe of the design and grand nature that this building provides. You need to pre-book tickets beforehand, it's not simply walk in. You can buy tickets on the day but it will be for a tour later in the day. Upon entry you get close up views of Big Ben from inside the grounds of parliament, away from the hustle of the street crowds. The tour takes you through all the major halls, and into both the Commons and House of Lords, as well as a number of the Queen's rooms. Definitely recommend for anyone travelling to London to pay the extra and go inside.

Lesson in history and democracy. We took the audio guide and did the tour on our own, which lasts about 1 hour. You can also walk around with a group guide. In both cases, you get a great lesson in history and democracy.

Great afternoon. We spent a really interesting and enjoyable afternoon at the Houses of Parliament in February ths year; we booked a guided tour that I would thoroughly recommend. The guide was excellent, the traditions and workings of the House were explained interspersed with amusing stories, it was an extremely worthwhile visit (I did also book afternoon tea on the terrace, but was disappointed, it was overpriced and bland and I wouldn't bother!!)
Stunning!. The architect is just absolutely stunning and such a treat to see such a great building as the U.S. has nothing like this.
Home tourist. it is a must to see this great building! Get there early as it flies get very busy! Worth the trip. There are many area of interest to visit in the area!
Beautiful architecture. I didn't both going inside as I was not too interested in the tour or paying the price. Outside view of the amazing architecture was enough.

Visit to House of Commons and the Old Bailey. Our wait time for both was only a few minutes. When you enter the gallery, you must remain there for a minimum of 30 minutes to prevent disruption to the proceedings.In the House of Commons, we were treated to having the treasury secretary (Exchequer) being quizzed by the members about the financial situation in Greece (how British citizens visiting Greece will be protected financially, etc.). It was a very spirited discussion. In the Old Bailey, we watched an assault case in progress....a police officer was being cross-examined regarding the interpretation of the CCTV visualization of the fight. I had a grandson with me, who is interested in studying law so these visits were very informative.

Wow. We were on a guided tour of the houses of parliament organised via an MP's office. The tour lasted an hour and a quarter and covered Westminster Hall,St Stephens Hall,The Houses of Lords and Commons as well as the robing room.Our tour Dawn was incredibly knowledgeable and gave insights into both the proceedings and background to what goes on within Parliament as well as relaying some of her own experiences in various roles.This was both informative and enjoyable and well worth a visit.

A unique experience. I had the privilege to be invited to the House of Lords Terrace for a tea and my experience was unique. Just getting into Cholmondeley Room among armed policemen and crossing the courtyard was great, and sipping tea on the terrace with a view of the Thames just in front of me is unforgettable, not to mention the brief private tour that we were given at the end.

Great tour. . Your was very good. Even though the guided tours and the self audio tours got mixed in together and crowded, the tour guide was pleasant and very informational. It's amazing how the parliament building is almost similar to the U.S. Capitol but much older with much more history. Must book in advance and make sure it's on a Saturday unless it's on parliament recess.
Just marvelous!. Went there the 3rd times, but still breathtaking! The sight it's just marvelous!Planning to visit London again! Within these few years! See you soon Big Ben!
Not boring. We did an audio tour of the Westminster Palace and very much enjoyed it - the tour was neither short nor long. In addition, we paid for an afternoon tea in the palace, and it was OK.
Amazing. Amazing building, architecture is incredible. Definitely worth seeing!! Didn't do a tour as I was short of time but it's something I definitely want to do.

Incredible architecture. The Houses of Parliament are located very centrally and are known among tourists to be a vital attraction to visit on any trip to London. The building is unbelievably beautiful and the architecture is very aesthetically pleasing. It is well worth a visit if you are in the area even just for a quick photograph, trust me, you wont regret it!
Beautiful sigt. Had a lovely visit to the Houses of Parliament, first from the ground and the. From the River Thames. Always a spectacular landmark of London, England.

Book the tour and tea in the House of Commons dining gallery.. Our tour guide, Andrew, had worked on the floor of the House of Commons. He had a detailed knowledge of how the British government works and made the tour very interesting. It was much better than going with the audio guide. The tea was delicious and the view from the terrance was fantastic.

Book the tour and tea in the House of Commons dining gallery.. Our tour guide, Andrew, had worked on the floor of the House of Commons. He had a detailed knowledge of how the British government works and made the tour very interesting. It was much better than going with the audio guide. The tea was delicious and the view from the terrance was fantastic.

A bit disappointing. There are fences, trees, and security devices, making it hard to see the Houses of Parliament. And of what you can see some is covered in scaffolding. Now is not the best time to pay it a visit. If you are up that way, then take a photograph of it, but don't go out of your way to see it.
Beautiful Gothic architecture. We spent a glorious afternoon just strolling around this area and taking it all in. The best city walk ever.

Iconic - can't miss. . You can't miss the chance to walk past this place. To think of the time that would have gone in to building this so many years ago is amazing. Such a beautiful structure!Would like to have done a tour to learn more about it - will save that for next time. Now when we watch movies of London, which of course always flash a shot of this icon, it will be in perspective!

Pay for the tour guide. The tour guide was well worthwhile. She was interesting and knowledgeable. Some parts of the building are interesting because this is where parliament meets, and some parts are interesting because they feed into terms in the english language - a lobbyist waits in the lobby for their MP, to "lobby" them on an issue. The designs of the different parts of the building (commons is less ornate, for commoners) is also interesting.
Must see. Amazing experience, fast security. Its history speaks for itself. Amazing canapés with good service.

Worth a visit. An excellent place to visit. I could not book a guided tour for the time available so I booked an audio tour. The audio tour was very good and very easy to operate. A very interesting tour, also knowing it is used on a daily basis added to the interest. Would recommend a visit.
Awesome. Amazing place to visit, extremely informative and interesting. I would highly reccomend and would suggest everyone who visits London to go here.

Have to visit these classic icons. The unique architecture of these buildings just beckons. Lovely backdrop as they sit on the rivers edge. Interior is full of history and interesting images. Take a tour.
Focal point of London. The trick is to get a photo of Big Ben, a London Double Decker Bus & a Red Phone box all in the one photo. Hint go to the north side

Amazing building!. If our great architects of today could still come up with this type of buildings, our cities would be incredible! The craftsmanship and expertise of the old masters still keep us in awe!

Beautiful building of Gothic Art.. This buildinfg is very old and amazing. Very big and long
If you like gothic Art,, like me, this an old building extremelu beautiful

Seeing the home of modern democracy. Well worth a visit - lots to see - very very historic - a bit like hogwarts! You can view both Parliament and House of Lords - well organised and fun to watch for a little while esp the House of Lords who were having a good old argument. Be patient and allow time for security
Cool building. Did not get a chance to go into the Parliament, but the outside is simply amazing to look at. With the Abbey, and Big Ben so close by you have to see it if visiting London.

Not to be missed. Primary residence of the Kings of England, after it was abandoned by Henry VIII this magnificent building has been home to the two seats of Parliament - the Commons and the Lords -. More famous landmarks in its vicinity: Big Ben and Westminster Abbey - not to be missed either.

well worth a visit. I dont think many people know that you can visit such an important part of our heritage. It nice to be able to see such familiar places that we often see on tv. Security is tight and rightly so, be prepared for a bit of a wait. The gift shop have many unique items for sale.

Falling down but still quaint. Its going to cost a gazillion pounds to keep them in good condition. Maybe they will just let them retire gracefully and save the gazillion pounds. They still look great from the outside.
Dinner at the House of Lords. What a fab building and just brimming with history. Very interesting tour of the two rooms, Commons and Lords too. Must see

An Experience!. I had a private tour where you went into the house of parliament and of lords and of commons. It was very interesting and is worth a visit if your up to it and near the area. The outside has very good architectural engineering and is a pretty building from the outside. You also on the tour see the room where queen victorias throne is and where the queen gets ready before the procession and also you find out about some secret passages in the building.

What a great experience. I've been lucky enough to be invited to a few dinners at The Houses Of Parliament and it really is an experience of a life time. It's so interesting to see what Parliament looks like on the inside, it's like entering the set of a film that you have seen so many times. We were shown round and it's fascinating even more so when you go in to the whisperer's gallery to watch the MP's and co in action.

Rich Piece and Class of the English History. One of the best places to learn about the English political history and understand their view and expectations of their parliament.The building is just amazing but the most fascinating thing was our guide, she was very knowledgeable and answering every question with a smile.Make sure you book on-line in advance to avoid the very long line on site, they called for my tour timing and I jumped around 50 people who didn't book the tickets.

The best canape's ever!. We have been to Parliament twice. One occasion was a trip arranged by our MP. To stand at the despatch box in the Commons was one of life's great tingle moments. The other was a reception on the Terrace of the House of Lords. Wonderful view of London from an unusual angle. The canape's were the best we have had anywhere in the world!

'The Mother of all Parliaments'. Although this expression by the Victorian politician is often misapplied to the physical building (Palace of Westminster - the home of the Houses of Commons and Lords), every time time I go to Parliament I am bowled over by its sheer splendor and majesty, and agree that the building deserves this accolade.It was built in a gothic style to impress and simply both externally and internally it does just this. Everytime I have to go to Parliement for a meeting I consider it a great privilege for where else can one simply bump into senior politicians and political commentators simply going about their day to day jobs in such apparent opulence. Of course the reality is different from the initial veneer, and if one allows ones eyes to truly scrutinize things, it is apparent why this amazing building which was completed a little under 150 years ago is in desperate need of more than a paint job.For all this, this is a must for any visitor to London, although to be fair I have no idea how one the queues take, and especially when Parliament is in session.

See and Smell History. Several types of tours are organized for visits to the UK Parliament in London. I booked an audio guided tour. Price is 18 Pounds. Tours should be booked in advance. You get to the entrance and get a badge and an audio guide device. Follow the number signs and listen as you go through halls and corridors. The parliament is all open to you. You will be able to see what you watch on TV. But most parts are not permitted for photos and touching equipment and art are forbidden. Take your time to enjoy the place and imagine historic events that took place here through history. The tour is normally around 90 minutes but you can stay more. Take a rest on chairs where permitted and watch the art on the walls.There is a good cafeteria at the entrance where you can sip some coffee and eat a snack. Don't miss it. Book your ticket here: http://www.parliament.uk/visiting/
Disappointed. Be sure to check for access availability. When we visited, Parliament was in session and access was limited to tours offered on Saturday mornings.
Must see. Beautiful building, full of history and architecture. I went with some friends during open house, a must see

Mother of all Parliaments. I have been fortunate enough to visit the Palace of Westminster twice. The history speaks for itself but one is struck by how small both houses are, not as you see on TV. The guides are both informative and entertaining. Whilst the Greeks may well be responsible for our democratic system, our parliament stands as the oldest democracy in the modern world. Watching the sometimes buffoonery behaviour of members during PMQs one might wonder about the maturity of some members. An absolute must see.

A piece of history. Not much to do except look at these fantastic old buildings but as it is next door to Big Ben, Westminster abbey, London eye and the aquarium you can't really not visit if you come to London. Nice view up and down the Thames too.

Wow the home of parliament. We first did this trip with our extended family and learn't so much and enjoyed the trip to the point that we returned again to savour the spectacle again. Highly informative guides on both occasions and the building is simply magnificent.

Very impressive and the Tour in side the building was very interesting. I highly recommend a visit to Houses of Parliament, the guided tour is very interesting, recommend comfortable shoes there is a lot of walking and no where to sit,

The House of Commons. We were extremely fortunate to gain admission to the Public gallery of the House of Commons and witnessed a debate. The architecture of the building was extremely impressive and as it is steeped I so much history it was a highlight of our trip.
Perfect view of Thames & House of Parliament. Its a nice picturesque place if you fond of clicking photos. view of London Eye and house of parliament is great. One can also take ferry

Interesting tour. I booked in for my daughter and myself to do a self guided audio tour of the parliament. I was very informative however if we had more time I think a guided tour may have been better. Well worth doing.

Must See. Thankfully went with a councillor friend and got a more private tour, saw the terrace and the floors of the commons and Lords. Beautiful buildings throughout, such history and grandeur. Definitely a must for all visiting London.

Spectacular architecture and well lit up at night.. This is a great building to visit. Outside you admire the beauty of the architecture both stunning by day and by night. Inside there re some wonderful tapestries and furniture to admire aswell as the art works and the significance of the place.You cannot your when parliament is sitting and the are stringent security measures(rightly so).Very interesting. Ha and just like the government...this sight is not free!!

Excellent Tour. This tour was so interesting, all the way through. We had the best guide (Michael), who really made it fun.He was so genuinely passionate about the building and his job there which really added to the experience for our group.

Making history. Get in the line early for a wonderful look at a different style of government at work. The buildings are worth the tour but some of the fun is watching members of parliament yell at each other!
Royal. You see this place up and close and you will understand why England and Britishers are so royal. Such buildings will be never made.
A Sight To Behold. This building will definitely catch your breath! Anybody would be mesmerised by the history and magnificent architecture of this iconic structure!

Majestic views. This place located on river bank has its own old charm.We saw this place from outside during our city tour of london.An importent land mark,good views and historical place and a must see on london tour.
Looks great - Cannot get in!. We would have liked a tour of the building, but as Parliament was sitting these are not available because of security. Pity.

Must visit. The Houses of Parliament exudes a grand historical vibe. Visited in early June, with wonderful weather, the visit has left a deep impression and would love to return again on my next trip to London.

Admire the architecture !. This beauty of a building on the bank of the Thames was built in 1840 after a fire. The Palace of Westminster includes the House of Commons, the House of Lords and the famous landmark known as Big Ben. A definite must see while visiting London!
Very interesting to a Yank. Even not being from the country I was very impressed with the tour and learning how the parliamentary system works here.

A audio tour I will never forget . I must when you visit London, only £18, and well worth the money. I had to prebooked my tickets online, and had to choose a time of visit, I was a little early but this wasn't a problem and was allowed to start early. It gets busy quick so be warned. Also, you have to go through airport style security, so I advise don't take large bags etc. The tour lasted about 2 hours, and I missed reading some placards.
Glad We Went By. It was easy to include Parliament in our walking tour which included Buckingham Palace and Big Ben. It's a must see and a great way to start your visit to London.
Interesting. Got a tour in here well worth the money very interesting - they bring you into the chamber where the debates take place

Fantastically informative with excellent character guides. We were invited by our local MP and had a really great day out and would definitely recommend this day out especially if you love history and kings and queens.

Palace of Westminster. What an experience, I thoroughly enjoyed our tour of the Palace of Westminster. It was very informative and the buildings on the inside are just splendid. Words alone simply cannot describe it and you are not allowed to take pictures! I would highly recommend a visit to anyone visiting London.

Worth a visit!. You can apply for tickets for the tour free of charge through your MP which it what we did. It is amazing seeing the chamber but i loved seeing the small details. Everything is so intricate! Definitely worth seeing!

Glad we saw this. With so many other sites and attractions it would have been easy to miss this. So glad my wife made the plans ... we were both impressed with the tour -- audio guide is a must. Allow at 2 hours.

Very informative audio tour. The audio tour takes about an hour and a half. You need to watch the schedule as tours can be limited when parliament is in session. The tour will take you into each chamber where you can walk but not sit where members of the House of Lords and House of Commons sit and debate. The differences in each house are explained along with a description of how voting takes place. Very informative and worth the trip. Additionally, the architecture, the statues of Thatcher and Churchill are pretty neat.Tip: order tickets in advance or you will be shut out.Tip:you can get great photo families with Big Ben in the background right after you have gone through security but before you enter into the Tour.

Stunning!. The buildings architectural design is amazing and in very good condition. It is very clean and a must go when you are in London. I did not get a dance to go inside as it's closed on Sundays.

Excellent Tour. Stayed in London for 4 days and saw most of the major attractions. One of the days included a Saturday where US residents can take a tour of Houses of Parliament, and I thought this was the best attraction in all of London. Tour guide was very knowledgeable and gave a great history lesson of London. Price of the tour was about $75 USD for 2 people but it was worth every penny.

Majestic ☆ overlooking Thames ~. Super Huge and Looks Truly Majestic from a Distance or from an Aerial View . It is One of the Oldest Parliaments of the world.... and the Iconic Big Ben Alongside The Palace lends it a Royal Expression befitting a Grandeur piece of British Architecture. Leaves you Enchanted. A Must visit for Tourist.

Outstanding. Best tourist attraction in London. Visited the Houses of Parliament/Palace of Westminster in June with my wife while visiting London for 2 days. This was our first real tourist trip to the capital, despite visiting friends in London before, and we had a lot of things that we really wanted to pack in to our 2 day trip. We organised the tour of parliament through our MP (which costs nothing if you are a resident of the UK. You email your MP in advance and it can be arranged in advance). This was the first place we visited in London and it didn't get any better. We entered through the tourist gates with our pass, waited in Westminster Hall for the tour guide, and were then shown round the Houses over a 2 hour period. The tour guide was excellent, very well informed, and answered every question put to him by the group. The tour started in Westminster Hall, passed through the Royal entrance where the Queen arrives to open Parliament, on to the House of Lords with its magnificent royal throne, then on to the House of Commons, where the first Prime Minister's Question session of the new parliament was due to take place (we seen quite a few MPs jostling for seats before the session began, which only added to the tour).Overall I couldn't recommend this tour enough. The whole building is truly spectacular, and often whilst inside I had the feeling that the building was almost too grand to be a place of work. Whatever you think of the people who work inside it, the tour is well worth a visit. For the architecture, splendour, artwork and history, it really is breathtaking. A 10/10 from me
great place to go and see. i really enjoyed it seeing house of lords too i liked everything but its no go if you're in a wheelchair

House Of Great Expense. Watch the freeloaders tell everyone else to suffer austerity. Visit Portcullis House across the road and see the subsidized restaurants being used for hours by those who cut the benefits of the sick and poor whilst they sit in tax payer funded splendor. Gawp at the ' Inside' trees and wonder how they get away with it.
Beautiful Building. Beautiful building with exquisite architectural designs. It is amazing how well they take care of their historic buildings. The city in general is very well maintained.
Worth it. This was an excellent tour with an excellent guide. We were able to into both houses. We bought our tickets ahead of time and were assigned a time to show up.
Beautiful !. "Big Ben" is one of my favorite things to see in the UK. The bells are something that can be heard all over. Beautiful!

Great architecture. Liked the ambience and liked mahatma Gandhi's statue nearby.
And lots of other tourists attractions like westminister abbey,trafalgar square and the imposing Big Ben.
Wonderful to see in action!. We actually got to sit in and it was really great! We have a senior in High School son in speech and debate and he suggested it! He loved it

be quick. even that the buildings were almost totally rebuilt after 2nd world war(apart from Westminster hall)it is still fascinating to see the debating chamber;the poor relative of the lords chamber.it is recommended to book in advance.

We couldn't get inside so it's not actually a visit. We couldn't get inside since it was not during weekend and parliament at work.So yes the building is amazing , yes powerful, yes great history ... but unfortunately we couldn't see it from inside.

As Dickens said - the best club in London. The security is tight, as you would expect. It can take some time to get into Parliament, but it is worth it. Your MP can help you to get a ticket for PMQs, or to view Big Ben - and even to take a guided tour. Once in, there is quite a lot to look at - and if the house is not sitting, it's possible the guide will let you stand in the commons chamber or the Lords - but only MPs are allowed to sit on the green benches and Lords on the red benches. As a local politician, I attend meetings in the commons and the Lords from time to time and see the Palace in its form as a place of work. But, there are some rather good facilities!
Tour of the Houses of Parliament. Unbelievable architecture and great tour. The tour guide was extremely knowlegible. I would recommend signing up for a tour over listening using a headset.

Hate politics but interesting visit!. Went on an unexpected visit here through a friend of my daughter who works there. Have to say had no idea what to expect but was very pleasantly surprised! Wonderful architecture and interesting to see the places we only see on TV and to learn a bit of the history

Another Important historic location. This is a beautiful building in a central location surrounded by many other historic sites. While we were there parts of the building were closed for an upcoming funeral for a MP.This is another place where you could take lots of time to see all the venue.Definitely one of the MUST SEE places in London.

British history. Just love visiting the seat of government. The buildings are still being repaired, so not all the building is visible, but the architecture is quite stunning. The walls have all been restored and the windows look fantastic. Walk around to the rear of the buildings and there is so much more to see. There are some restrictions because of security, but do visit them. There are always crowds, so be prepared for queues. Coffee shops are very expensive, but walk a few yards away and they become much more reasonable.

One of the best free attractions in London. I was surprised to find no queue when I turned up at about 11 am on July 2nd. The staff were very courteous and helpful. There is obviously security checks, restricted items and when entering the visitors galleries you have to leave all items including bags in secure left luggage. I went into the visitors gallery of the commons and then the Lords. It was fascinating. The programme for debates in on the website. The architecture of Westminster Hall is stunning.
MPs. I have been a few times and it has been wonderful to see the architecture inside and out, and to learn the history behind it. You should see it before they start works on it.

Living history!. Part of the British heritage, a magnificent building with history at every step. You look around and then realise this is where Elizabeth the first stood...You are restricted as to which areas you can visit and please don't make the mistake of taking photos inside!
Love the architecture. I didn't go inside but love the architecture and it's located right next to Big Ben and Westminster Abbey.. I will probably tour it next time I'm in London.

Nice tour of seat of British democracy. We took a tour of Parliment and enjoyed it thoughly. After a little security screening, understandable these days, you enter the great old hall. This is were Thomas More was sentenced to death and numerous notables layer in state before burial. Pictures are only allowed here and in the next hall, so buy the guide book for photo memories. The tour includes the House of Lords and House of Commons. The rooms are beautiful and the history made in them is mind blowing. The audio tour guide lets you enjoy the building at your own pace, pause and contemplate or fast forward if in a rush.

"The most recognized building in the World" sitting next to the Clock Tower or Big Ben. We had a wonderful tour of the Houses of Parliament. The Royal Gallery have records on display from both houses. The Chapel St. Mary Undercroft with Roman Catholic mass and communion. The Pipe organ is spectular. The chapel is a very Victorian design and is located in the Royal Palace. There is a lot of walking we took time out for lunch in the cafateria. You can tell what house you are in by the decor color. The House of Commons has a green color while the House of Lords have a red decor. We walked for 4 hrs plus and worth every step.

Get your camera ready for this most famous area. This was the area that I spent most of my time of my stay, because I like outdoor. I actually circled around it. I got off the underground and had a long walk before I saw this huge building from far distance. It is next to the Thames River. The front is facing the city and the back is the river with two bridges at each end. You will get your camera very busy walking around it for sure.

Fewer guided tours of parliament. I tried to book a tour of parliament with a human guide, but all the tours were fully booked and only audio-guides were available. I understand that fewer guided tours are now being offered. This is a terrible shame because human guides are so much better than a recorded commentary. I suggest that the number of guided tours are restored to the previous level. The three stars represent the reduced quality of the tours.

Interesting Tour. My wife & I spent a couple of hours touring Westminster Palace (Parliament) in May 2015. Very interesting combination of British history & British politics. We used the free self-guided audio tour players, letting us move at our own pace. Crowds weren't too bad on a weekday afternoon, but be prepared for an airport-style security entrance (take off your belt, send your bag through scanners, etc). Also photography is prohibited (unfortunately) inside much of the building, although a few "sneak shots" are possible.

A must-see. We benefited from an organized tour, led by a retired member of Black Rod's staff, so received a comprehensive insight to the operations of the UK parliament. The interiors are impressive and incredibly ornate in places. You'll be surprised at how relatively small the House of Commons chamber is.It is possible to queue and gain entry to the public galleries. We were given the tip to ask for access to the public gallery of the House of Lords - the queues for that chamber are apparently always much smaller. However, once you are inside the Houses of Parliament, you can then move to the Commons easily.You will, of course, need to pass through security checks but it is well worth the hassle. Another tip is to ask your MP to gain access.
The seats of Power. No visit would be complete unless you experienced the great British parliament in all its glory. Get the full tour and see why so many other nations follow our lead in government

Houses of Parliament. My wife and I enjoyed a day out last December with a morning visit to Big Ben, then after lunch we had a tour of The Palace of Westminster.
These are two separate tours, which are free to anyone who is registered to vote.
Just get in touch with your local M.P. And they will do the rest.

Visitors Gallery House of Commons. email your MP in good time to request tickets to sit in the Visitors Gallery in the Commons on a future date (Wednesday is PM questions) it's free and it is fascinating!
A fine visit indeed. Took my wife to the commons for a tour, and my word what a place so much history and beautiful architecture it was a real buzz from start to finish.

Well worth a visit. This your is well worth making. Our tour guide was extremely knowledgable and interesting to listen to. It was great seeing such a familiar building in reality and it didn't disappoint.

funny little man in lords. Visted house of parliament only went into lords chamber gallery. Had to climb up a few stairs but when we got to the baggage area was greated buy a strange camp man who looked as if he could be living on the streets but dont let 1st impressions fool you this man is a born entertainer his story's and knowledge of the buildings made our day .the chamber itself is beautiful the debate was ok but would recommend just for the little camp man himself

Piece of British history. I had a really good tour guide, he really knew his history and trivia. Showed my friends and I some really unexpected quirks of the building. The building itself is amazing to look at, especially the hidden chapel underneath the lobby. Enjoyed myself.

Houses of Parliament, Westminster. . Located beside the Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament is worth a visit should you be interested in the political or legal history of the UK. An audio guide is extremely recommended and worth the £3 for the extensive information and additional tidbits of history. Witness where legal history was and is currently still being made. Also has a very decent cafe and shop that can be accessed at the start or end of tour. Tickets should be purchased online and printed out before going. Strict rules on photography throughout.

Somewhere every British Citizen should visit.. Booked tickets in advance as we knew we were spending some time in London. Opted for the audio tour rather than the guided tour. Equipment excellent, easy to use and very informative. Very busy on a Saturday and yet did not feel rushed or crowded during the visit. Refreshment facilities were adequate.
Interesting tour. A very good guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, covers all of the areas that you would want to see, Lords and Commons and Westminster Hall, with very knowledgeable tour guides.
Steeped in history. Always a favourite place for tourists and locals alike. Always busy with amateur and professional photographers alike.
Soak up the feeling. Didn't take a tour. Just walked around and enjoyed the look of the building and its situation on the Thames ... spectacular building, bot not bombastic.

Another Don't Miss while in London; if you're into history & architecture!. I wouldn't bring the little ones; but this was terrific for pre-teens plus anyone else interested in the government here and Parliament itself. Extremely educational for all!
Massive. In pictures it doesn't look as big but it's pretty awe inspiring when your up close and personal. Close to Westminster Abbey .

Good building. The place is great, the building is beautiful, but, unfortunately is full of very pendant people who think they have the right to do whatever they want just because they are MP's. Good place, bad vibes.

Attractions list number 1 ticked. Brilliant highlight, screening of the bags so don't take anything bad in!
fabulous place a must do, saw so many old and interesting areas

can say you been to london without big ben pics. beautiful place to visit if you love history like I do. However this is a popular tourist attraction, so plan when to go.
Big Ben is awesome

History and politics combine. Excellent place to soak up history and politics. The heart of the british political establishment resides here and you can witness the parry and thrust of daily debate first hand. Wonderful building.
Major London tourist site. Very historical. The British congress. Expect large crowds around the area since many major tourist sites are located nearby.

Book ahead for special tour.. The history verges on overwhelming. And there are so many interesting surprises - from events that took place there, to documents, to just how tiny the actual Houses of Government are. Go no matter what, reserve a tour before you go to the UK for the best experience.

Saturday morning tours available but must be booked well ahead of time. We were only able to visit the outside of the building because we were unaware of the Saturday tours and how soon they were booked. So plan ahead if you want to see inside parliament. It is heavily guarded and when we were there we were prevented from traveling on much of the street that it is on.
first visit. The chambers of commons and lords were smaller than I imagined but full of history. The tour with the recorded commentry was very informative and enjoyable.

Magnificent building with lots of history. Just to be able to see the Houses of Parliament up close was a treat, along with the sight of the iconic Big Ben. If you're in London, this is a must see sight, even if you aren't doing the tour.

Fun and educational experiance. Fun and educational experience.
Visited the House of Parliament when in London. You need to book a visit at least one day in advance.
The guided tour is very impressive and you get to see when the Lord actually sit and where the queen sits when she comes over.
Yeah. Typical London selfie place! Beautiful, it is what it is, a very iconic London landmark! If visiting London, it's a must see place, but a bit boring for kids!

Surprisingly Interesting...Must See!. So interesting! We visited London right before the House of Lords went on their summer break. Definitely research this before your trip...tours are only available during most of the year on Saturdays unless you are from the UK in which case I believe there is a way to arrange for weekday tours. (Tours of Big Ben are only available for UK residents.) The only time you can tour throughout the week is when Parliament is on a recess. Both visitors from the UK and oversees are able to watch both the House of Lords and House of Commons in action while they are in session. We were able to watch the House of Lords on their last day of the session and then come back for the full tour the next day. When you watch one of the Houses from the viewing gallery, you are able to enter the building and see many parts of it, but it is not at all the same as going on the tour. Both my 13 year old daughter and I enjoyed both visits (watching a session and also the tour). If I were going again, I would definitely schedule time to do both if Parliament was in session during the trip. My 13 year old found this very interesting when she studied American History and how our (the US) government was put together/established and why. It gave her an interesting perspective. I was also very impressed with the way she compared both governments (US and UK) after her 8th grade trip to Washington DC. I'm not sure an elementary school age child would find it as interesting, but I would highly recommend visiting Parliament for teens and adults. It was a highlight of our trip. I have to say the beauty alone of the building makes it worth visiting. I know this may sound silly, but on our first day out in London...when the building first came into view...I'm embarrassed to say my heart jumped in my chest. It was THAT beautiful. Don't miss seeing it!

Interesting and spectacular. We took an audio tour which I feel is better than the more expensive guided tour, because we could go at our own pace, there were further options to choose for more information at each stopping point. The whole place is steeped in tradition and history and some of the rooms are jaw dropping in the amount of detail of decoration. It was a really good visit I would thoroughly recommend it , it was good to think when I saw the House of Commons on the TV the following week that I had actually stood in that room. Can't praise it enough, the best thing we have visited for a long time.the only slight niggle was that there is no storage area for backpacks etc, which I was very surprised at given the amount of tourists who visit. I was annoying to have to carry my backpack around .

Visit this gem if you are in London. If you want to visit the House of Parliament you need to book a guided tour. The guides are excelent, some of them have blue badget. the visit is very interesting,m you will know a lot of things about their legislation, the sessions, how it works. The rooms are impressive !

See my review of Westminster.... I'll just add here that the tour of Westminster palace takes you into both the House of commons and the House of Lords. It's great to stand at the dispatch box where many great leaders have stood.
Fantastic insight. Everyone coming to London and living in the UK should take this tour so they can understand how the country works.

Fabulous insight into history and tradition. We booked a tour on a Tuesday morning which is not a busy time in the Houses. It felt like such a privilege to walk around and see and hear the history of these this iconic building. It was good to understand the reasons behind some of the traditions that we see on tv which seem so outdated nowadays. So interesting, I cannot recommend it enough. Our guild was so full of information and made it fun for the children in the party too. I don't recommend it for the really young ones though as it takes about 90 mins for the tour and there is definitely no running around! Best day out in years.

Had lunch at House of Lords, it was great. Went there on an invitation for lunch and a trip around the Lords and Commons. The food was excelent. The trip around the Palace was memorable. If you get the chance don't turn it down. You will not be disappointed.

London's #1 must see. "Hey look kids, there's Big Ben, and there's Parliament". Both very impressive structures that you must see and send time admiring. But since they are both so centrally located, you will feel like you are in that European Vacation movie, as you will spend a good chunk of your time in view of those two beautiful buildings.

Memorable experience. Not too great for disabled lots of steps to certain areas with no other access, interesting areas in Parliament. Nice to request to meet your MP and to be shown around free of charge. Cannot take photos inside but can go out on to the terraces with great views of the Thames and London Eye

A Tour Around Britain's Past and Present. We took the audio tour, this gives you the chance to go at your own speed, and the audio guide is superb. It was exciting to see all the places mentioned in history and those shown on TV news. Recommend calling in the cafe to fuel up first.
Incredible to see. Stunning building with superb décor. Historically so interesting tour was excellent. Ask your MP to arrange and it is free. Go into the public gallery and watch MP's working!

A tour well worth spending time. We especially liked the 1000 years old hall. Westminster Palace was the one I always wanted to visit. Really impressed with the central hall, where they have the 4 patron saints of England, Scotland, Wales, and Ireland. It was a great experience to go through one of the oldest democratic institutions of the world, if not the oldest. Too bad they did not allow photography inside.
London, UK. A nice gothic style, an imposing structure near by Thames, Westminster Abbey, Big Ben and London Eye.

Best tour ever. We thought it would be a good tour to take to understand the inner workings of the Houses of Parliament, especially having visited Holyrood in Edinburgh earlier this year. We took a guided tour to get the additional bits of interest you don't often get on an audio tour. This very quickly turned in to one of the very best tours we have ever been on - informative, humorous and well worth the 2 hours it took us to get round. Would 100% recommend this.
history. Always good to see the seat of power in London, magnificent building, ata present it is having some restoration work carried out but still good to see

Very pretty gothic structure. One cant see it from inside. But even from outside its very picturesque. Just next to Big Ben the structure is great. Its a great place for clicking photos. Fro London Eye also the structure looks fabulous.

Great British landmark. It's worth coming to see if you are visiting London, even if it's just to stand outside for a photo.To get inside, usually you need either to know someone who works there or get permission from your Member of Parliament, but if you can it's worth it - to see the inner workings of government - the Lords and the Commons, and the corridors of power in between.
Really interesting history.. So cool to learn about the government and all the history. Seeing Parliament really helped to better my understanding of the UK government.
Unique. It's a unique building and impressive building . One of the best attractions and worth seeing but should go down and enter with a tour guide.
Beautiful architecture. Seeing Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament in person was very cool. London is a beautiful city with great architecture. We enjoyed walking around the area.

This is England!. Summary: The Houses of Parliament are one of the iconic sights of London. Without them, London wouldn't be the same. The architecture is amazing and different times of the day yield different colors. If you like taking photographs, try doing it from different angles and from different areas on both side do the river. A beautiful and timeless place.

UK Government visited. Visited the Houses of Parliament with wife and 12 year old son. We took we took the audio tour option as the guided one was very expensive. Had a very enjoyable trip. The price for the trip is expensive but we really enjoyed the visit and it's amazing how close you get to where the country is governed. I stood right next to where David Cameron conducts question time and in particular the robing room was really interesting. My son was however rather bored but would recommend the trip. It was very busy but not over crowded.
The arguments are priceless. Make certain to get there to see the HOP where some of the best arguments for and against along with heckling take place.the Doctor

Extremely good tour!. I was prepared to be bored. My son was the one who had interest in this.It was perfect!. Our tour guide provided the right amount of history plus architecture plus current events, all given with British candor and humor!It's on my recommendation list to others if you're there for more than a day.
interesting. When we decided to take the tour around Parliament, i did not expect this tour to allow you in to so many areas, so well worth the money

A truly wonderful building - let down by the guide. Went as part of a group outing for disabled people. Our guide was far too quietly spoken for many of us to hear closely. He also spent most of the actual tour attempting to herd us to specific spots, rather than actually talking about where we were. This was a pity, as the Houses of Parliament are fantastic pieces of architecture; with the "newer" Victorian part indistinguishable from the old medieval part. Overall, well worth it: the guides need to be selected more carefully, though.

Well worth a visit. A very interesting tour, however allow time for an airport style security check when you arrive. There are several different tour options; we went for the self-guided audio, so being delayed was not a problem. If you are on an escorted tour, it might be. Keep your tickets handy until you are actually in Westminster Hall, as you have to show them a few times. The tour can take 2+ hours, and the only toilet facilities are in the café before the start and at the end of the tour. There are also only a few places to sit down, our Lords, Ladies and masters do not want us sitting on their benches. The staff, even on security, are friendly and helpful and it is a very enjoyable outing. Its interesting seeing places that appear on the TV news most nights The café is fine with plenty of seating. The gift shop well stocked and seriously over-priced, but then the majority of visitors seemed to be from overseas.

Views of Parliament. My first real visit to Westminster. Unfortunately due to time limits I did not get the chance to tour Parliament from within. However from the outside the buildings are a spectacular sight and the whole area is a photographer's paradise. From Big Ben to Westminster Abbey it is a wonderful place to visit and should be high on any tourist's list of 'sights to see' especially the views from the opposite side of the River Thames!

Quite a piece of architecture . I've heard about it for years and seen tons of pictures but none of that compares to seeing it in person it was very majestic one of the first things you should see visiting London and very easy to get to through the metro

It gets my vote!. A really interesting and informative tour of the heart of government in the UK. Our tour guide Geoffrey struck the right balance between humour and facts. The tour itself lasted about 90 minutes and covered all of the key areas within the Palace of Westminster. Certainly well worth the money as far as I am concerned.
Really a Must See. We had an excellent tour guide who made Parliament and its history come alive. Highly recommend Parliament for anyone with an interest in British history or politics.

historical place. The House of Parliament is located right next to the Big Ben and the London Eye and various other tourist attractions in London so you cannot miss this wonderful site!This structure is so massive,It was a great experience and I highly recommend it.

Go watch the questions or debates, not tour. We went to see the question time in the House of Lords. Be prepared for several waiting periods, and they will eventually make you give over your bags (way after you initially get searched.) The discussions are lively and not very civil. It made for an interesting afternoon!

Excellent tour. After having grown up in the London area, visiting the Houses of Parliament was something I've always wanted to do but only now, visitng London with my family from America, did I get an opportunity...and it was great! It was really something to stand at the exact spot in the House of Commons as does the Prime Minister and the grand spectacle of Westminister hall was amazing. The audio tour is excellent as it points out various obvious, and less obvious points of interest (like the mark on the wooden door that "Black Rod' has made over hte years as he knocks to request entry for the monarch). The only small disappointment is the limitation on taking photographs, restricted to just two areas. This seems to be a growing and unwelcomed trend among the major sights in London.

excellent tour. tour entry is timed so be prompt. were able to see the house of commons and house of lords chambers. tour guide was knowledgeable. had plenty of time afterwards to walk around westminster hall.

First thing in London we visited was the House of Commons. Walked up to the guards, found that there was a meeting of HoC within the hour, came back 20 min. later & went thru security (note to US TSA - these folks are kind & efficient ... Frisked me twice in 1/20the time I'm usually frisked at the airports due to metal implants setting off the alarm). Watched the procession into the chambers then up to watch from the visitor gallery. Very cool to see UK gov. in action. Closed circuit TV & a guide to business of the day helped too. Inside of building very impressive. Didn't do a tour...I'd probably forget all the facts presented...enjoyed just having the experience.

a true sense of history. apart from waiting to go through security which you have to expect the place has a huge sense of history, power and respectyou walk through the buildings in a kind of awe thinking about all the conversations and decisions that have been made throughout the last year and years of Governmentthe building is tired and needs work which we know will cost but it is we should keep it it is hugely impressive

Must see but don't do the guided tour. My advice: don't do the personal tour - just use the audio guide. The personal tour is too long, only available to US citizens on Saturdays, not interesting enough, and you can't go at your own pace (obviously). Also, it costs too much, is not worth it, and lasts 1.5 hrs. I found the guides were informational but boring. If you do a tour, print your tickets at home or else you have to stand in an additional line. Parliament itself is full of history to learn about and beautiful artwork and architecture so I definitely recommend going but think twice about a guided tour! Heads up that U.S. Citizens cannot tour the Elizabeth Tower.

Very interesting. Worth the visit if you can. We scheduled an English tour and we're delighted with personal stories from one of their professional tour guides. You can also purchase an audio tour but many times we found people taking their headsets off so as to hear our guide. The key is booking ahead and go early.

We tried multiple days to get in but could not. I had bad information on how to visit the House of Parliament. The guide book I used said you could go in when Parliament was in session without a tour. I went back twice while in London and was told by the guards only tours could go in and there were no tours available.
