Fantastic Trip around an amazing Building. Been all over London but by winning a charity auction for a Trip to the Houses of Parliament and having the guided tour and chat with our Local MP there I would probably vote this as the best experience / day out in London we have had.

Did a walk by, float by and a drive by. We did both a walking tour and a bus tour and the Themes river tour all who mentioned these buildings. Very expansive and large as government buildings generally are. The history though is still interesting.
This is where history is still being made .... ... and it feels like a real privilege just to be allowed to wander through these hallowed halls. Remember to book on-line well in advance.

Fantastic experience - well run. Something I had wanted to do for years - and it did not disappoint. Tickets were reasonably priced and the walking tour was the perfect length - enough information to keep you interested but not so much that it was overwhelming. Only slight disappointment was the cake at the cafe - a little dry! Definitely recommend a visit for all - tourists but also locals!

Well worth a visit - and it's free!!. Our guide Chris was excellent and made the 1.5 hr tour flow smoothly. He had just the right amount of humour and new his stuff. The history of the building is incredible and the internal rooms a pure spectacle. To see the "Power house", the Commons and Lords chambers, was simply amazing. Go now before they close it for refurbishment.
Old and decaying. it is an impressive building but it is a very busy area of london and the building looks tired and falling apart
Great for history buffs. Was able to get into house of commons and house of lords for the debates. A must see on your tourist list. Both halls are amazing and much better to see in person than c span

If you can get a tour of Parliament, take it!!. So much history - Parliament is not to be missed! The interplay between the monarchy and the government is so interesting to hear about, both in modern times and in England's rich (and sometimes sordid) history.

A real treat!. Very interesting, I think every teenager should go on a school trip. I came away understanding the british political system a bit more and finding it interesting.
The afternoon tea on the House of Commons Terrace is not to be missed, with a great view of the river and good food and great House of Commons Champers!

One stop ou have to make. This place is so historical that it would be a shame if you go to London and you don't visit it. The architecture is stunning. The tour is excellent, you will learn a lot! Excellent for classic photography. It is very centrally located, close to many other London attractions, so you must really put it in your itinerary, you won't regret it.
audio tour is woth the money. You should take an audio tour, which was around 20 Pounds. The hisory of this building started in the 11th century. That is 1.000 years ago. Unbelievable.

Weekend in London. What a great way to spend a couple of hours. The guided tours were all fully booked so we did the audio tour costing £18 per person. I was amazed at the access we got to many of the rooms throughout this beautiful building, some that you see so regularly on the news its odd seeing them in real life (so much smaller but grander than you expect). Really interesting and informative commentary - I'm glad we did this.I would also recommend the cafe for a lovely cake!

History and splendour. This is one of the best 2 hours I have spent for a long time. The tour and guide were simply amazing. You get to see both houses and a number of other rooms and areas which are simply full of history and of course history is still being made there. Our guise was a retired civil servant who had worked in the Houses of Parliament for over 30 years. She was able to very eloquently bring the building to life. If you are a UK resident to can get in for free. Simply write to your MP and request a tour. If you are non UK resident you can book and pay for the tour. Well worth it. You also get time at the end of the tour to explore Westminster hall and have a bit to eat at the cafe. The catering is excellent. Well MPs are well fed aren't they?

HOUSE OF POWER. The parliament has house of lords and common. The lords lives upto the name. The building has victorian gothic style which was not uncommon to indians since the same styled buildings are back home too. nevertheless the architecture and the maintenance of these buildings with its decorations, paintings etc are worth a visit.The guided tour was very informative.

Every tourist needs to add this to their portfolio . If you are a tourist in London, sure this must be on your list of things to see. Whilst walking around Parliament Square will give you all the angles and a chance to see the entrance used by staff, I recommend also walking onto Westminster Bridge. From the bridge you have a chance to see the full length of this building and really appreciate the craftsmanship that went into the build. From this position you can photograph the building without the incumbrance of other people in the foreground

Excellent audio tour. Well-constructed, informative and interesting audio tour - it took us just over an hour, but we could have stayed longer if we listened to more of the optional additional commentary.
Fascinating building, with fascinating history - well worth a visit for adults; not so sure kids could be kept amused throughout.

Excellent visit . Went on a tour here on Saturday. Had an excellent tour guide named Sean. He was very knowledgeable and made the whole experience a pleasure with his enthusiasm and humour. The Palace of Westminster, as it is known, is a must for anyone who loves history and architecture as it has it all in abundance! I've seen the Commons and Lords on tv many a time but there's nothing like actually being there. The breathtaking gold canopy that the Queen sits under at the state opening of Parliament is a must to see. We finished off our tour with afternoon tea on the Members terrace overlooking the Thames. An unusual selection of sandwiches and some delicious sweet treats. Staff throughout were very helpful. There is also a cafe on site as you enter. Good selection of cakes etc and lovely coffee,a bit pricey but you are in London! Be prepared to go through airport type security,it didn't take long though.

Historical. Very unique buildings along the banks of the Thames River. Very high security at all access points with police and hardened bollards to prevent vehicle access. Of course, the tower housing Big Ben alongside the Westminster Bridge.
A must see. Check when the tour is available. It is fascinating to see how Parliament works. The Lords is very extravagant while Commons is very plain. Very worthwhile

Tour with afternoon tea. Took the guided tour, they gave you comprehensive information about the building and election system in Britain. Afterwards, you got the chance to enter the restaurant at the house of commons. The quality of food was impressive. Enjoy your afternoon tea while overlooking the River Thames.

Gloriously over the top!!. We went here as part of a coach trip to London and we were not disappointed. We had a guided tour followed by afternoon tea. Whilst the whole trip was wonderful, the biggest revelation for me was the Westminster Hall. I had not realised that there was a part of the Houses of Parliament that was so old. It dates from 1099 and was actually originally part of the Palace of Westminster, used by the kings and queens of England until the Tudors, when Hampton Court became the major royal place. I actually became quite overcome by the history of this hall when looking at the plaques on the floor commemorating momentous moments in history. A must see, as is a visit to the whole of the houses of parliament. The Victorian gothic part of the building was jaw dropping including the architecture, the decoration, the gold, the tradition, and the paintings Our guide was so informative and I learnt so much about the history of politics and parliament in Great Britain. Also as part of the package we had afternoon tea near the house of commons in a building beside the river. The food was delicious and the service excellent, attentive and courteous, but not over stuffy or over the top. I would definitely recommend a visit to the houses of parliament. You will learn and see so much.
Nice building. Stunning architecture lovely building would make lovely apartments (joking) nice to actually see in person not just on TV
Beautiful. Beautiful Victorian age landscape maybe the most popular in today's culture. Never get enough of looking as this majestic skyline.

Such a wonderful place. Excellent!!. Was on holiday in London with the wife and we wanted something to do and got talking to a very friendly policeman who told us that the houses of parliament were open for visiting and it was free to enter so we thanked him and carried on our way and went in and had a lovely look around (the security was impeccable..as it should be in such an important place) the architecture was incredible and it was really rather interesting to sit in on both the houses. would certainly do it again.

beautiful building. We visited as part of an award ceremony for our daughter, we had the tour first followed by afternoon tea, our tour guide was great and very informative, my only complaint is that I could of spent hours walking around just looking at the ceilings and paintings so I will definitely visit again and do the audio tour, This really is a must do ,it's such a beautiful building inside and out. After our tour we had afternoon tea during the award ceremony which was lovely with great service and great views over the Thames, we will definitely visit again when next in London

An essential part of any trip to London. I had been to the HoP before but wanted to go with my partner who is from Brazil. We chose the audio tour option and the whole thing takes just over an hour to do at a reasonably languid pace.We were slotted in for 11.40, but were able to enter a little earlier which was really helpful. The reception and security staff were all very cheerful and it didn't feel too intimidating going through the various stages of security.The audio guide is great and gives detailed explanations of each stop on the tour with options to hear more about different parts of the history of the building and of the UK. It was great to be in the chambers and see where all the action happens as well as getting a sense of how the building works.Fantastic morning.

Houses of Parliament Tour and afternoon tea. We went last Saturday, not realising there was a march planned! I purchased the tickets as a birthday gift for my mother, who has always wanted to visit. The tour itself is outstanding - I had opted for an audio tour, rather than a guide, as it would mean we could walk the route at our own pace and only move on when ready to do so. I would very highly recommend it. I had, however, also booked afternoon tea as an add-on. What an incredible disappointment that was. We arrived at the appointed place about ten minutes before our booked time (3.45pm) and took a seat, as requested. We were then informed that they were 'just setting up' and would be with us shortly. In reality, they had a huge group of 51, all also taking tea at 3.45pm. This group were prioritised ahead of us individual bookers - they arrived after us but were taken down to the tea room first and given all the window seats (overlooking the terrace)available. We had to wait a good fifteen minutes before being escorted down and (finally) seated. The HoP staff seemed to be incredibly arrogant in their attitude to us, the leader of the huge group constantly walked up and down the room to ensure her 'guests' were comfortable, which was very intrusive, and the whole experience was most unpleasant. The tea, when it arrived, was absolutely tiny - three little sandwiches each, one scone apiece and two tiny dessert type items. I understand that you pay an inflated price for the surroundings, but there was no offer of more of anything, even tea!! I also understand that groups are an important source of revenue, but to be treated so obviously as 'second class' and to have to put up with an over-bumptious tour group leader, who took over the room, was awful. Why not insist that such large groups book the entire tea sitting so individual guests aren't treated so shabbily? We did not leave a tip. I would absolutely dissuade anyone from booking this! Take tea at Fortnums of Harrods instead!
Westminster. Grand old buildings, great architecture, unless you are interested in British politics you will walk by take a few shots and move on..
Amazing!. Just walked past. It's an awesome building. It's one of the buildings you have to see if you're in London. The architecture is beautiful.
Absolutely fabulous. A fabulous journey that never ends.... history in every corner, every hall and every room. A must see in London.

Very good and informative but also left disappointed. This place is amazing inside and definitely worth a visit. My partner and I went on a tour that we pre booked a few days before. The tour was great, informative and you are taken into a couple of rooms that normal visitors do not get to go in. The paintings and history of the place makes this a must see place to go. The only thing I found disappointing is after the tour (which lasts about 90 mins ) you are not able to look round again on your own.We were not told this and started to walk back into the main building again just to look into some of the rooms. As we were not wearing the audio headwear we stood out and got ask by security for a look at our tickets, we told them we had been on the tour and we were told we could not look round on our own and we must go back to the main hall.After a brilliant tour, I left feeling disappointed. Some of the rooms and paintings were really interesting and full of history and we just wanted to have a proper look at them.If you do the audio tour, you can walk round at your own pace and can easily stay for more then two hours.Just bear this in mind when booking as it does cost £25 for the tour and the audio is cheaper.

Great Tour of the Center of UK Government. We had a private tour with our business group and every minute was worth it. Absolutely amazing building showing the Kingdom's long history and the people who contributed to it and to the world. A do not miss spot.

Fascinating insights to the workings of UK government. After seeing these spaces on TV and in movies for so many years it was wonderful to see them first hand. The excellent audio tour provides a lot of information (or as little as you want) and allows you to move at your own pace. I am sorry I waited until my 20th visit to London to take this tour. It's generally only available on Sat. and I would encourage you to book on line.
Very much part of UK history. Such a wonderful old building. Think you have to go on a guided tour but is well worth it as the guides are very knowledgeable.

Very Interesting. Wonderful to see! As an American who is enthralled with English history this was an absolute must. It was incredible to be able to see this and learn more about the history of Parliament. There was so much to learn about the machinations of British government and this attraction is sure to not disappoint. I loved seeing the House of Lords and the House of Commons and learning about the way the meetings are broadcast to the public.

Wonderful. Had the opportunity to be shown all around Houses of Parliament even places where public cannot go. had the opportunity at the time to speak to and be taken around by Bob marshall-andrews MP. the date I went was about nearly 8 years ago but it was an experience that will always be remembered.

Book the 9am Tour. The Best attraction in London!! Book the 9am tour you beat the crowds inside. You cannot take photos in most stops. Tragic. It's so brilliant with paintings & carvings & statues. Every room in the Lords is chok full up. You get to go into each of the Lords & the Commons debating Chambers but you cannot sit down in those. But you can sit elsewhere in designated seats when the guide says so. We did the guided tour. Our guide was fabulous & she saved a seat for me on a sitting portion as I have a stick. It's a 90 min tour with 3 possible sits. Super interesting & the only stairs are at the beginning & end from Westminster Hall. It's a full airline security check to get inside.

Hey look, kids, it's Big Ben!. I'm sure they're tired of that joke haha, but seriously--it's attached to Big Ben. Take the tour if you're from a place like the United States that does not have a parliamentary structure. It's a very interesting government scheme they have going on there but it seems to be working for them. We saw the houses of parliament on a private tour as part of a private event but WOW. I really enjoyed the tour. And the architecture, like much of it in London, is amazing.

watched debates. we loved visitng the house of parliament! we waited on a very short line, and once we were inside we were allowed to watch a debate going on. it was extremely interesting to sit and watch from the viewing gallery and we absolutely loved it! definitely recommend going to watch some debates.

Great experience. We went round this building as part of a guided tour with a coach party, the guide was extremely informative and made the whole experience very enjoyable and brought history alive. The building itself is a fantastic sight to see and to experience the House of Commons (even though you are NOT allowed to sit down on any of the seats) even if you are not interested in politics is well worth the visit. We find it has also made watching the news more enjoyable as you are able to picture where it is they are referring to and recognise where they are reporting from. We are very glad we took the time to visit this very historic building as we enjoyed every minute of our time there. There are public toilet facilities and a cafe on site too.
Top place to dine. You need an invite but so much history to admire. Try your local MP as they are keen to have you look behind the screen , but with possible plans to renovate HP get in eraly.

A walk down the memory lane. An Amazing place to visit. The Parliament on London is an amazing tour with up and close view of the parliament. This is relatively a quick tour although the lines can be very long.

spectacular. We did the Italian tour. The guide was very good and I liked a lot. It is very interesting and walk inside the House is exciting! Externally the Palace and big ben are majestic. At dusk when the lights come on, I'm always watching enchanted

So much to see. There is so much to see in this amazing building - there is a wealth of history in the building with stunning pictures, statues and objects. There is the opportunity to go on guided tours and so much pomp and ceremony that we Brits do so well.Loved listening to the debates and questions.

Excellent informative tour. Visited on a Saturday afternoon and really enjoyed the audio tour. The tour was excellent and guided us through the Westminster Hall, St Stephen's Hall, Central Lobby, Lord's Chamber (with adjoining Prince's Chamber, Royal Gallery and Robing Room) and Common's Chamber Member's Lobby. It was really access all areas and provided a great insight to the building's history and current use.Even if you do not have an interest in the political process you will find this tour worthwhile. I plan to revisit with my parents.

Where history happened. If you do nothing other than stand in the awesome space of Westminster Hall which has existed in this space since the 11th century, this is well worth a visit. To visit Commons and the House of Lords is also incredibly impressive.

Fabulous in more ways than one. I actually was fortunate enough to go into the Houses of Parliament on a tour. I was impressed with the great hall and all the history that it hold. Wonderful architecture. a good visit, or admire from the outside

The laws of the land. Although you can arrange a visit without cost via your MP, it really is worth paying to do a tour of the building while Parliament isn't sitting. We went on a Saturday morning, the security process was quick, efficient and friendly.Once in the Palace, we claimed our audio guides and set forth to explore. The audio guide was clear, succinct and very understandable. There are some restrictions on where you can and can't take photos.The tour takes you around the building in a logical way and you get to see things such as the Queen's robing room, walk through the Lords and the Commons chambers and some fascinating art work and statues.Having watched the BBC's documentary on Parliment in 2014, this made it an even more fascinating experience. Allow a good couple of hours for your visit.

Worth the effort to get tickets!. The Parliament tour is only available on Saturdays, so you need to book ahead of time. I missed it last time I was in London and am thrilled I was able to tour this trip. To be in the halls of so much history is an incredible experience. The audio tour was fantastic at explaining what you were seeing. We were able to walk right through the houses. Did not expect to get that close. Very worthwhile! Don't miss it.
An entertaining experience. Worth arranging visit. The guide we had, Mike, was very knowledgeable and entertaining. The restoration and maintenance of the palace are outstanding.

So much more than expected!. We went on a guided tour at the houses of Parliament and it was well worth it. The guide knew all about everything and every questions was answered with loads of detail. We got to see both houses, the robing room and so much more.Interesting, enjoyable and fantastic!!Also popped into the Jubilee cafe for some tea and cake, also lush!
Ayes to the left. You cannot visit the parliament building where we come from so this was very interesting for us and the kids. Good afternoon tea too.
Majestic. Located on bank of Thames River, it is one of the most beautiful monument to see. If you are lucky you may be allowed to watch the house proceedings from visitor's gallery.
Worth to visit. Worth to see and walk around and see rich details of this beauty palace.It is also place when you should take a photo to check-in your London visit:)

So interesting. Well anyone who visits the Houses of Parliament will find this so interesting. We had a guide that explained what each room was used for and where the TV presenters stand when recording the news. You can almost hear the discussions and the voice of Order Order! These places in London are so educational as well so yes I would highly recommend a visit
Nice building. The building looks nice but there's not a lot to do in the area. Shoot it to have it in your photo book and move on.

What you saw in the picture is not as good as you see through your real eyes. I never interested in much architectural things and have seen this place on the pictures and magazines many times and was thinking that it's just a simple one. But when I saw the real one through my eyes and know the history of it, I feel I'm lucky to be here. It's really beautiful at all day and night time. This is the most beautiful landmark in London.

Tribute to Margaret Thatcher in the Commons. Loved it.It was shortly after she had died and it was lovely to see how her old colleagues, some friends, some foe, saying and remembering prominent moments during her career.

History, History, History. The Houses of Parliament tour is all about history and how the British do showmanship and politics at their best. The tour begins with a high level of security and then the towering sense of those who have walked the corridors begins to dawn on you. A great couple of hours. I need to do this again.
London symbol. it's always good to see Big Ben and all this building, as it'a an icon from London and it's very safe, as there are always lots of policeman.

Where decisions are made. The house of parliament themselves look just great. If you get to go inside do so. It would be a shame to miss this. The entire UK government operate in this wider area. Downing Street is near by and the entire area is made up of different aspects of UK Government. Some of the finest buildings in London can be found in this area. Take an hour or two and enjoy.
Beautiful and Interesting tour. Was lucky to have tea with Lord Bassam. Security guards are very moody, even with the registered tour guides.
Fascinating. Really interesting tour. Lasted 2 hours. Not recommended for those who cannot stand for 2 hours as only 2 places where public may sit during the guided tour

Quick walk around did not disappoint. Only having 6 hours to tour the City due to work is not necessarily the best way to see this gem but it is worth the walk from the London Eye to see the splendor of the building. I enjoyed the park just outside with the statues of Winston Churchill and other great leaders. If you have only a few hours it is worth the time

Seat of power. British heritage site that just keeps getting better every time I visit. The buildings are constantly being renovated, so some part is always covered over. Access to the area is good and there are always large crowds. From the bridge, you can see the MPs and their guests at the bar and the Thames is always nice to as well. The walk around the buildings always seems to throw up something I have not noticed before. Makes you feel proud to be British
Neat tourist attraction. This is a must to see. It is definitely packed with tourist. Be sure to see the British guards outside.

Very tall cock!. I am not into politics so I did not go inside, but I did walk around and take photos of the outside. I wanted to see Big Ben since it is so famous and in several movies. It was cool to finally see it.
Much more than expected. I had no idea about the history of Westminster Palace, a really worthwhile tour that left me with a real sense of pride in our history and traditions.

House of Commons, the day The speaker was elected. An English friend & I had a "special tour" of the Houses of Parliament on the day the speaker was elected.After the security requirements were dispensed with we made our way through the many corridors to the public gallery and had a great view of the House of Commons happenings.The history of the building, the plaques, the paintings and the banners in the Great Hall were most interesting. Each large banner gave an Act of Parliament, the date with reasons and detail on the Act passed.The gift shop had a diverse range of items for purchase and the prices were reasonable.

Parley!. I never tire of visiting the Houses of Parliament and that area of Westminster; simply stunning! We even were able to see the Queen and her family after she opened Parliament, and her carriage came right by us on Whitehall. I could never have planned that; just in the right place at the right time! GOBSMACKED!
A must for all to visit. This is a great place to book a tour. Helpful and knowledgable guides bring the history to life. Be prepared for some queuing and security checks. Very worthwhile.
WOW. Tour of Parliament arranged by our MP's staff Alice & Laura were brilliant Laura took us around which was brilliant fit was an awesome experience

Fun to see.. Fun to walk around, great architecture. Lots of tourist shops around the area to buy those required trinkets for those at home. Very crowded area though with many people standing around looking lost.

The Houses of Parliament. What a spectacular building, for the architecture alone it is worth seeing. To be able to walk through the building that is so steeped in history and so symbolic of the laws made to date is amazing. The tour guides were fabulous and answered many questions with knowledge and enthusiasm. Make sure you allow plenty of time as there is so much to see.
Our Countries leaders at work.. Very impressive building and a great part of our heritage.Good to see our Lords and MPs at work and watch a debate.
Good value . Excellent visit by self with audio sufficient plenty of time to look around best to book in advance and no waiting

Brilliant tour of the Houses of Parliament. Well worth a visit. We did the self guided tour with the voice guides. Staff at entrance were excellent - humorous in checking tickets and scanning bags - a welcome change. So pleased to see the House of Commons and House of Lords.
historic. a great atmosphere history in the here and now, the place was buzzing so nice to be in the middle of it all with the rest of united nations.

Just wow!. Visited the houses on a recommendation from friends. Never thought about it before, but so glad we did. The house is amazing and so much history is stored within these walls.
Got to walk through the house of lords as well as the commons.
Amazing, I would recommend this tour to all.

British Government 101. We took a 90 minute guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. I suggest that you book in advance because spots are very limited and on the guided tour you are aloud places those not on the tour can not access. Our tour guide was very well educated and engaging. Extraordinary interiors. The tour is also offered in a variety of languages. A must see for all travelers and those interested in democracy.

Beautiful building. Enjoyed my audio tour with my boys aged 11 and 13. The 11 year old was bored and in hindsight I should have got him the childs audio talk, the 13 year old thought it was very good and enjoyed listening to all the information as he said hed covered some of it at school. All in all we enjoyed it and it made up part of a good day out in London as its so close to the Southbank.
Guest at Lords. Just a once in a lifetime opportunity to visit the Lords Felt very honoured to be shown around and enjoy an afternoon in the debating chamber. Fantastic

Great experience! Must see in London . Took guided tour and it was a blast. If you think the outside with Big Ben was great the inside is informative and an eye opener!Guided tour lasted about an hour. No picture allowed inside, take it away in your memory and you will treasure it for life!Enjoy and listen to the guide as they were informative and interesting as well don't forget the gift shop and book for afternoon tea. Don't miss it!! Also while you were there enjoy the local entertainers on the bridge and watch out for pick pockets and con artist. Good luck and enjoy London!

Iconic Building in London a Must See. Every visit to London should include this stop. It's so scenic and Big Ben and the Thames is right there so it's an efficient stop where you can see so much. The tube gets you right there from Paddington Station if you are flying in. This was the first visit for my daughter and I was so happy that she got to see it. Since it is a major attraction there are always pan handlers about the place so be careful and pay attention to your valuables when you walk the streets and ride the Underground train. It's an awesome location and you will be glad you stopped by to see it. Having read Sir Winston's famous speeches there makes it even more interesting. Here is the place where British politicians haggled out the workings of the British Empire.

Seen from the outside only, a magnificent London monument. Go at dusk..the fading light does wonderful things to this beautiful building. I took some of the best shots I have ever ever taken, from here.

Good old fashioned proper dining. The food was very tasty and locally sourced, you are not given a choice it's generally a set meal but the preparation and presentation is perfect. The setting off course makes the experience very enjoyable,where else can you eat after listening to an interesting debate

We went after the recent election -. even got to see the mail slots with all the names of the folks who wouldn't be returning removed. Our guide was excellent (booked the tour online and ran in towards the end of the day), giving us bits of today's new, a trace of gossip and a big dose of history.
Tour was perfect, about 90 minutes, very memorable!

What a day!. There was nothing I dis liked about this trip. We went as a school. It was fascinating, history was amazing. The tour guide was knowledgable, helpful and patient. We saw so much history. It's an incredible building. I would go again in a heart beat. Was not too busy. Art work is stunning. Highly recommend a tour
Amazing building . We only went to look at the outside but what a building! Really nice too see it in real life there's so much too look at. I would do the tour next time.

Excellent place to visit. Lot of history and see how they political system operate. The line was quite big and when we reached to enter we found out that we have to buy ticket from another place. It would be helpful if their staff notified us when we were in the line.

Great place to go if you get the chance. Incredible security, there is a good reason, but I had more contact with the hands of the security guard than the average sports massage! I can say very thorough! The Great Hall is absolutely steeped in history, gave me goose pimples to be standing where Charles the First was indited and later sentenced to death.Food was not great and some of the wine awful. Staff are used to elbowing past the great and the good, but they are fine really! I actually check out the gift shop and bought a memento, bit kitsch but hey.

Mind-Blowing. We went to the security gate and asked the officer on duty there if we could visit inside. She asked us which house we wanted to visit, to which we replied the House of Commons. We were given a green ticket and were led inside, where after a security check. we entered a room above the House of Commons, with a glass partition through which the whole house was visible. There were LCD screens and speakers all around, through which we could see and hear the MP's as well. We could see the whole House, and heard the MP's debating. You can sit there for as long as you want; we sat for 1 hour. Across the House of Parliament is the Supreme Court, which is also free to visit. Both of these gave a great outlook in the Political and Judicial system of UK, and were my favorite part of my recent trip to London. I would highly recommend visiting The House Of Parliament.

All the best and worst of British tradition: yes, it's Parliament!. Roaring past parliament on a big red bus is one of 'life in London's daily pleasures when you're an expat - but to truly spoil yourself, go get tickets to Prime Minister's question time, on Wednesdays from noon (30 minutes). In the good old days you could request these through the Australian embassy: these days, foreigners need to either befriend a local and have them request tix from their MP, or be prepared for that other legendary English institution, the queue... Worth it, however, for the genuinely witty banter thrown about the chamber. If only they were real live standup comedians, rather than t also trying to govern the country in there... ;-)
Together with big ben. Wow this is fantastic we loved it to see it it was very close together.So we were there in a jiffie haha London is great

House of Parliament. We took the "tube" and exited right outside of the Westminster station. Staring us in the face was the House of Parliament. We found the size and architecture of the building amazing and it was great to finally see a landmark which I've only seen in pictures.

An excellent tour!. Have had two privately-organised guided tours (which I believe are the same as the public ones). It is an amazing building and seeing the two Houses up close and personal is a wonderful experience. The contrast between the opulence of the Lords and the rather more basic Commons is quite remarkable.

School visit as accompanying adult. Wow, what a privilege it was to be shown around such an historic and iconic building. The guide was very informative, we learnt about the statue which got damaged when a suffragette chained herself to it. Saw the Great Hall where Henry VIII had given counsel, beheadings had taken place and Harry Potter scenes had been filmed! A wonderful experience for all.

Interesting. My A-Level Politics group visited after we wrote to our local MP, and it was brilliant. There is such a vast difference between what you see on TV, and what is actually there. The tour guides all seem very interested in the buildings, and have a vast amount of knowledge. I have since made other visits to Parliament for various events, and feel that i have a much greater understanding of the buildings i am surrounded by. If you aren't much interested in architecture, history or politics, then it probably isn't the best way to spend your day, but for me, it was fascinating.

great place. This is a very nice tour although pretty crowded......... House of Parliment is an incredible place with extremely interesting history. Would love if they would allow photos to be taken ....recommend...
Worth a visit . Lo dons rich with culture and this place is no different.Stunning building and in a great location to many other sights Go have a gander

Great Guide and a fascinating group of buildings with tremendous history.. Went today, having booked a free tour via our MP. Mike, our Guide for the tour, was excellent on both facts and anecdotes. As we had a 'gas emergency' mid tour and the whole building went into lock-down, he also had to improvise while we waited in a Lobby and then had to leave and re-enter Westminster Hall. He found us a 'Door-Keeper' while we waited and we were entertained with more background and stories.A very worthwhile visit - don't miss it.

Lovely!. These buildings are amazing! They are pictured on the front of most books about the city. But they are even prettier when you see them than when you look at pictures in books. Stroll down the pretty street and enjoy?

So interesting. Who would have thought how beautiful parts of this building are. I enjoyed seeing it from the inside. The audio tour was great and makes sure you don't miss all those bits of history. Great idea, one of the best surprises.

My Architectural Highlight. I love architecture, whether is gothic or modern glass structures.The Houses of Parliament are without doubt my favourite structure in the world, close up it is without doubt a masterpiece and definitely should not be missed.
nothing like it. if you contact them early enough you can sit in on a session of parliament and be a part of british history in the making well worth the trip to see

A British Landmark of History and Democracy. The official tours of Westminster are very much worth attending. The tour guides have an excellent knowledge of parliamentary history and current practice making for a very engaging tour. The building itself is full of history and architectural charm. A must see when visiting London!
parliament. we had good walk in parliament sq is absolutely wonderful building and we had nice day out in london before we go to gatwick airport.

A Must visit when in London. Regularly visit the House of commons for functions held by a trade body and never fail to have excitement when I walk through the great hall and also the corridors with the statues and just the grandeur of the House.The tour is very worthwhile and good for those interested in the history of our country.A very interesting fact: There is a statue of Cromwell outside the House opposite the back of Westminster Abbey, a grand one it is but opposite across the road is a small church and there is a bust facing Cromwell can you guess who it is?

Kept my interest!. Really excellent tour. Lasted about 1 hour and 40 mins. Our tour guide Leonie was great - informative, humorous and sensitive to individual guests needs (disabled, hard of hearing). Would absolutely recommend!
brilliant. Really interesting and shop reasonably priced you go at your own pace once your passed security would recommend this to anybody

Too hard to see anything. Very difficult to get access. Better spend your time with something more accessible. We tried first day Parliament convened. Could not even get a good glimpse from outside. Security is very tight as will all other cites.
Guided tour was brilliant. Two happy tourists here. Amazing behind the scenes tour of both houses of Parliament and their other chambers. Best thing we did in London so far

Amazing! Must See Inside!. Every Saturday they open the Parliament to allow the public to have a tour. We did the audio tour and it was great. It was easy to follow and the information was so interesting. I did not do the guided tour but it looks just as informative but I don't like to travel in a pack and I like to go at my own pace. And it saved a few dollars doing the audio tour. I always try and do these types of tours as early as possible b/c the later you go the crazier the line is just to get in b/c of security checks. Also definitely get tixs online and in advance. This is one tour you need to get advanced tixs. This was the highlight of our stay in London. Definitely worth going.

One Of My Favorite Things We Saw In London. We had just left Westminster Abbey and inquired about a visit at the gate. Since Parliament was in session, full tours were not available, but if we were interested, we could sit in the gallery and watch a Parliamentary debate. Security is tight, but worth it. Very enlightening to watch the MP's debate. You probably need to be there an hour before the debates begin or you'll wait. The gallery is pretty small and they let viewers in as others leave.

Incredible History. I did a fairly short personal tour on a Friday around both Houses and the infrastructure and sights in between. Fascinating history, literally the tour could be one hour or most of the day, depending on your attention span. For me it was a couple of hours and I saw and heard probably less than 20% of what is potentially here. From the history to the art, architecture to the stories and memorabilia, there is so much to see and hear about. Awesome visit, really didnt understand just how interesting this attraction could be until I went and experienced it.
I would have liked to have had more time. more time here would have been great but it was nice to see in person this beautiful area. Great pictures are available. Definitely worth the effort.

Awesome experience - but ticket booking was a pain. After reaching the place, you're told tickets are available half a mile away. Don't know how I missed reading up that part - so for people who are reaching by the Westminister tube, first buy the tickets along the side of the river and then go to the Houses of Parliament.But once you're inside, it's great ! and the audio guides are awesome - very clear and good briefing - every family member can go along at his or her own pace. Good to understand so much history - now just wish we could see the State Opening of Parliament one day !

Lobbying parliament!!. This has to be one of the most beautiful pieces of architecture in London, it's detail is quite something I could look at it for hours. If however you'd like to see inside, join the queue and come lobby. It's amazing inside and depending on which topic you'd like to hear discussed, it's a vibrant (in the rooms) and yet sombre environment. Wonderful
Great. It was Brillant. We got in free as we asked our local MP. The tour is guided and you can't go around on your own. You visit both chambers and detailed tour guides

Houses of parliament. One of the best places to visit so much to see and history to learn,to see parliament on TV is one thing but to be in there for real is something else,would recommend for all ages

Got to see the Queen. We visited this area the day the Queen was addressing Parliament. What a grea way t to watch the pomp and circumstance of the Queen in her horse drawn carriage come down the street. All under the watchful eye of Big Ben . This is right at the Tube exit & entrance...so easy to visit. It's also right across the street f r on the hop on hop off boats.
Must see. Great to see up close my son only saw this on TV and was fascinated another great thing to see why done the open top bus tour hop on and hop off great

"Exhilarating Experience!". I have visited the H of P on four occasions, over 15 years, both as a tourist and as a personal guest of a Member of Parliament.Despite the necessary (but unobstrusive) security surrounding such an iconic venue and establishment, the visitor is afforded every possible courtesy by an extremely well-informed and friendly staff.As with every "guided tour" of anywhere, there is never enough time to cater for every individual's personal interests. Such is life!That said, there is so much to absorb; the inexpensive tea-rooms and well-stocked souvenir shops, provide a welcome respite from the somewhat "Magical Mystery Tour" of Britain's history, dating back to the 17th century and beyond.Everything from priceless Art & Treasures to an authentic hand-written letter from Guy Fawkes, are in full view to the public, including life-size bronze statues of historic Prime Ministers and monarchs.  Access to both the House of Commons, where monumental decisions have altered the course of history were made, and the House of Lords, "The Upper House", provide anyone, with even the remotest interest in politics, art, history and religion, with an invaluable insight and unforgettable experience.Having been FOUR times, I admit to having only "scratched the surface" of this unique Palace of Westminster.An "Absolute Must" for any tourist...whatever nationality.Personally, as a Brit, I would put such a visit on the National High School Curriculum!I cannot recommend it highly enough.

I'm glad I found my way in to watch the debates. Parliament is imposing, and surrounded by an imposing array of barriers, fences and police armed to the teeth. However, if you ask one of those police, he will direct you to an unmarked visitor entrance where they'll give you a pass to watch the debates in the House of Commons. It's not a tour (that's emphasized up front) but you get to walk through various elegant and ornate halls and corridors until you find yourself, minus cellphone and camera, in the public gallery overlooking the MPs at work. The discussion I saw was definitely political, but conducted with an eloquence and demeanour that was very impressive. You can stay as long as you want.

Great views. It is tourist central but It is one of those places you will never forget - snapshot memory. On a good clear sunny day it is amazing and you cannot miss the place if you are looking for it. Some great photos. Plenty of people are around snapping selfies with it.Iconic. Brilliant
Outstanding history!. Take a guided tour as well worth it, the guides are so knowledgable and bring humour to the tour! Great insight into the origin of actual layout of the commons/Lords.

Excellent experience. On chance went to view and was allowed in to view a session of House of Commons. Vote an gay rights was being discussed and eventually the actual vote. Excellent experience seeing it in action live. Security was very tight. Saw lots of famous people and also went in to House of Lords.

Worth a repeat visit!. I've done the standard tour of the building itself (when Parliament isn't in session) which is great - you get the full history on the functioning of both chambers, voting, the history behind the Gunpowder plot and the building itself etc, and I've also gotten a pass to sit in the visitor's gallery during a session - which was FANTASTIC!! For that you see a different section of the building and of course security is a bit tighter, but it's worth the advance preparation to try to do that if you can!

Houses of Parliament-Worth the Effort. We ordered tickets online and did the tour the same day we arrived. It was very interesting and informative. No photos allowed once inside, which was a little disappointing. The tour guide was very good. It was great seeing such a historically important place.

Definitely a must do !. A little overpriced at £25 for a guided tour but if you are a British Citizen you can apply for free tickets from your local MP. (See they are good for something).What is it like ? To quote 'Raiders of the Lost Ark' "Dr Jones, you and I are passing through history. This is history !" Just about sums it up really. You've heard the names Churchill, Thatcher, King Charles 1st, Thomas Moore, Obama etc now get to see where it happened. This really brings it to life, you are standing where these things actually, yes really, happened.The guides are great and you will have a much better understanding of the weird way in which the UK is governed after the tour. (This should be an obligatory school tour ! Sorry Kids !).Security is tight as you would imagine, so prepare for delays, but good natured. (Even when my partner forgot to inform them about her Swiss army knife she always carries). Exit through the gift shop as usual. The House of Common's mint cream chocolates are highly recommended.My lasting impression was it was so much smaller than it looked on the TV

The seat of History and Democracy. This is a must visit when in London, subject to it being an open day. Tickets can be bought just across the road from the building. The guided tours are very informative and it really is more magnificent than any television or photos can explain. There is an awful lot to be learnt about the history of the UK system and also about the building itself. The guides answer any questions you may have (subject of course to security). There is also a very good gift shop where unusual and stylish gifts can be purchased. Approximately 1-2 hours should be allowed. Was this review helpful? Yes

London trip to visit family and friends. our good friends took my husband and I and our son and his partner on a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. It was incredible, the guide was very informative and had a wry sense of humour, which really made the day. You think you know everything there is to know about the Houses of Patliament, but you don't. The 11/2 hour tour whizzed by and I am so glad I went.

Didn't Go Inside. We did not visit inside the Parliament, but it is neat to see in person (and neat to see from the London Eye!). You almost can't miss it if you're walking around near the city center and the Eye.
Weekend in london. Fantastic architecture and felt proud to be British while looking at this great building ,wish I could have seen a famous politician when we were there

The heart of London. The Palace of Westminster is the headquarter of the two houses of the United Kingdom Parliament, the House of Commons and the House of Lords.Beautiful view from Westminster Bridge.Tube stop: Westminster

Excellent visit. I had a free tour, courtesy of my Member of Parliament. The guide was out of the top drawer - hugely knowledgeable and affable. To walk through the various chambers, to have the rituals and traditions explained, to see the Speaker's procession and finally to be in the Public Gallery for Prime Minister's Questions has to be one of the best experiences available in London.

Highly Recommended. I have to admit I wasn't that enthusiastic when my partner suggested we do a tour of the House of Parliament. I kept saying "yes, yes - I'll look into it". Anyway, eventually I did look into it and went along - and Oh! My! God! I'm glad I did.If you are a UK citizen, your contact your local MP who will arrange tours for (and in my case, with) you. My MP Is Jim Fitzpatrick, and although we were only in the HoP for about 80-90 mins, we covered a huge amount of ground, both physically, historically and anecdotally. I was hugely impressed and loved every moment.I can't vouch for the quality of the general tour guides, but the collective buildings are stunning and speak for themselves. It's a shame no photos are allowed inside, but understandable.Highly recommended.

Fascinating place. Visiting Westminster after Hampton Court gave us a great perspective on the political process in England. The tour guide was knowledgeable and interesting and gave a human note to the tour.
Awesome building. We didn't go inside, but the building is huge and appealing to look at from the outside. Took a lot of pictures of it.

Impressive arcitecture. Beautiful building, stop and really look at the workmanship.....impressive indeed. Great view from the Thames if you take a river cruise. Just across from the houses is a grassy area where all the newscasts are done from so you may get your 5mins of fame!

Devote a Saturday To See Parliament. This is Saturday only event and is well worth the time. We spent several hours touring the two Houses of Parliament. To walk past the seat where Don Cameron seats and debates for the issues and to learn of the many historical stories of members that shaped British history. If time allows, return on Monday or some other day and queue up to sit in the gallery to view the debates.

An excellent enjoyable visit. Myself and my mum prebooked onto an audio tour which I had booked online. We queued for only 10/15 minutes before we entered the main Westminster Hall. It was an excellent audio tour. It was advised this would take an hour but we were there for over 2 hours as there was a lot to see and some extras on the guide we could choose. A fascinating place and will definitely be back as I am sure I missed parts as there was so much to take in.

You can organise a visit of the Parliament in different languages. Visit with a tour guide as you will learn about the many traditions involved in the working of Parliament. What's astonishing about these traditions is that they are hundreds of years old but they are still in use today. A lot to discover.

The seat of democracy. I've had the pleasure of visiting The Houses of Parliament several times, and what a pleasure it is. Security's tight, but not overly intrusive, just make sure you allow plenty of time to go through the procedures. Then marvel at the architecture, the sense of history and political purpose, and even do a bit of discrete celebrity spotting - from MPs to petitioners and even the occasional famous personality. The guided tours are well organised and the guides are well informed and passionate about their jobs. If you can, book afternoon tea. What could be better than a cuppa in the seat of democracy, followed by a comfort break in the most democratic of public conveniences!

Unbelievable must visit. . Spent 10 days in London and this was the tour and place I enjoy the most. I'm not into politics and you don't have to be too enjoy this tour Just the history and architecture inside and out is well worth the 25 pounds you pay for a guided tour. Over one thousand years of history and stories to be told during|your one and a half hours. Photos are only permitted in a few rooms but the memories will last a lifetime.

Tour of Parliament.. There were some very interesting facts - we found the plaque placed by Tony Benn in memory of Emily Davison to be the most moving, and it's a damned shame that historical cupboard is stacked up with outdated, abandoned old PC hard drives. Delightful to be shown the perpetual Commons seat used by Dennis Skinner, he appears to be quite a character! It was fascinating to see all the Victorian Bible verse references inbuilt in Commons floor tiles and wall panelling, it's a pity the incumbents don't appear to much adhere to the words of Holy advice surrounding them. We found the House of Lords to be too heavily-gilt, and subsequently it's a vulgarly overly-opulent gaff. On a bright note, the espresso and carrot cake in the cafe were fantastic lol.A really good experience.

A Must-Do Tour. This is just one of those things you really should do in London. The tour guides are highly qualified and Martin, our guide, was no exception. There's just so much history here, but they don't make it stuffy or pushy. Be prepared to do some walking!

a journey back in time. absolutely fabulousIt takes a long wait before you can actually enter the parliament but it is worth it.Everybody should visit this historical place. You can even book it with an afternoon tea.So British.We enjoyed it

Democracy at work. Had the opportunity to visit. Bought the tour online and went through the security when I was there - pretty standard. Cameras are allowed in the great hall, which is where many notable leaders have said their speeches and where some monarch and some members of the royal family were laid in state. Photography was not allowed in other parts of the Palace of Westminister but it was great to see the bits where you would see on the TV.

Gothic-styled Architectural Palace Turned Parliament House. Location: Next to River Thames.Train: Westminster Station.I did not go into the building. After reading so much about it on TripAdvisor, I think it is good to be able to book a tour and go visit inside. However, by looking from outside is already worth the visit. The Gothic-designed building is very matching with Westminster Abbey, which is just across St. Margaret Street. One end of the palace is Big Ben, the other end is Victoria Tower. This historical building is an icon for London. Great view from across River Thames.

Lessons in British History. We thoroughly enjoyed our recent tour of the Houses of Parliament. Although we have visited London several times, this had not made our list of activities. It is a beautiful building rich with British history and tradition. The Elizabeth Tower (Big Ben) is one of the focal points of London and the sound of the bells is part of the London experience.

Brilliant and historically significant. Visit it and make up your own mind..... exhibits and history abound and recognising that a number of significant life decision like taking countries into war were made there makes you appreciate the place.

grand. It was formerly a palace which has been converted to the parliament house. Both the house of commons and house of Lords are inside this majestic building. It is rich in history and the architecture inside is unbelievable. You can see wall paintings of historical events, statues of important person's who had something to do in the history of the United Kingdom. The art work inside the house of Lords is fabulous. It is a must see place for all tourists and for every one in the United Kingdom.

Has to be Worth a Visit. Did the full tour of the Palace of Westminster and its got to be one place everyone should visit. If you have a knowledgable guide with a few humourous anecdotes like ours you will have a great day out and leave packed with knowledge.well worth the money and even though Parliment is in recess when the visits take place you never quite know who you may bump intoConsidering a return visit and like any tour these days you finish in the shop situated in the Great Hall of Westminster

Fascinating. Visiting the Houses of Parliament is exremly interesting. You can go to all the vital parts and see such snipets as where Black Rod strikes the door of the chamber. All places you've seen countless of times on the TV. well worth a visit. there is a small gift shop and a nice CafeThe security is airport standard as you would expect and all the staff were pleasent and helpfull with one notable exception An older woman i think police security officer was very rude to a group of foreign students and adults for no reason. They were standing in a group chatting when she, in a rage shouted at them to move. Just a mention would have done the job. What a pity as the last thing we want is to portray that sort of attitude to overseas visitors.Otherwise a lovely visit i would thoroughly recommend.

Fascinating and beautiful buildings. I visited the Houses of Parliament in the middle of May on a Saturday. I booked tickets for the audio tour for me and a friend in advance. However there weren't that many people visiting first thing in the morning so we could probably have just bought tickets on the day. It did seem much busier later on.We went through some airport style security checks and then picked up our audio guides and a map of the tour. When I first got the map it didn't seem very impressive but there is so much to see even in the relatively few rooms you get to visit. Plus the scale and grandeur of the rooms is impressive in a couple of cases.Some of the rooms are shown on tv on the news or political programmes but you can not beat seeing them in person - they are so ornate (apart from the House of Commons) and seeped in history.I'm really glad I went to see the Houses of Parliament - well worth the price of the admission - beautiful and awe inspiring.
Rodin in the yard. There is a Rodin sculpture just behind the Parliament House, in a nice garden. It really worth a visit.
Parliament. One of a kind... Jaw dropping. This is a must see!! The detail on the building is amazing. You must see this when visiting London

Worth a visit. The audio tour was very good and very informative and more flexible than the guided tours. The staff were lovely, with the exception of a very abrupt lady giving out the audio equipment, very unapproachable.

One of the Highlights of my visit. Arrived in London Early Saturday morning and headed to ticket office right away. The ticket office is near the Westminster train station by the Thames across from Big Ben, not at the House. When I arrived at 10:30 the only option left to purchase was a 1:30 audio tour. So get there early. Security is pretty quick. You have full access to both Houses and the audio tour is very informative. Spoke at length to a docent at the House of Commons. Very historic site in a grand city. Look around to see the family crest of Parliament members who died while fighting for their country in the World Wars.

Sessions is Open. Like Ben, I didn't stop into Parliament to scope out the potential, but it was impressive from the outside. Fantastic photo op, in the hub of Westminster, and right next to the tube. Give it a flyby!
Superb. This has to be one of the best tours we have done, next time we are in London we will go back and take afternoon tea on the terrace looking forward to all ready.

So this is where it all happens.. Another must see attraction. You will need to book ahead for tickets as you cannot just walk in. Commentary excellent with guides that have a wonderful sense of humour. A lot to take in and very enjoyable.

Great fully guided tour to visit the U.K Parliament. We took a guided tour to visit the Houses of Parliament.our guide was very professional,During our 90 minute tour we had the chance to learn about the history of both Chambers(Lords and Commons),how they function,to see from inside one of the most famous buildings in the world including stunning art and architecture.I'm fully recommend to take this tour
Depends on your taste. I liked a lot of the art and architecture we were shown when we had a little tour, but I think a lot of people might find it not quite worth the queuing time.

Better than I thought. My niece wanted to go here for the tour, I didn't even realise they did tours! We were really glad we went. I thought it would be boring and a long slow drag of an outing but couldn't be more wrong. The tour guide was knowledgeable without feeling like it was a never ending lecture. She made it fun and interesting and kindly was extra good to my niece who being very small might have missed a lot but the guide made sure she was always at the front so she could see, little things like that make a big difference. Even if you don't think it's the thing for you, you might be pleasantly surprised (and learn something too!)

A place to see ! ( from a true Londoner ). This is great with a guide , I was lucky to get a special small group of 9 . So the guide gave us plenty of info. The decor is superb and the history of this building is very interesting and not Long and boring . I recommend this !

Amazing Experience. I bid at a charity auction for a trip round the Houses of Parliament as a guest of a sitting MP and it was an experience that will stay with me forever. Just the architecture was so incredible and steeped in history. We began in Westminster Hall and then went into the building from there. The tour included both the MP's chamber and of course the Lords Chamber. Absolutely fascinating !We also had a little tour with the MP of some of the other areas including the bars and restaurants and of course the veranda where anyone can sit outside and have tea on a nice day overlooking the river. Wonderful ! The great thing about this place is the sense of history and the insight into the day to day business of being a member of Parliament or a Lord. There is nowhere else you can go to savour the atmosphere of this unique building and I would really recommend to anyone that they visit the Houses of Parliament should they get the opportunity. I have no idea what it would normally cost , probably far less than I donated to the charity but it was worth every penny for the experience and the memory.
Beautiful from the outside. We did not pay to enter. If Parliament had been in session it would have been free. Right on the water near Westminster Abbey and the London Eye.

The opening of parliament by the Queen. WonderfullWe were invited to attend by an MP friend and found all the pomp and ceremony quite wonderfull and extraordinary.Obviously most people cannot do this BUT anybody by contacting their local MP can ask to have a guided tour of the Commons and their MP will organise it and it is free and the infomation and the history you get make it a top historical attraction

see how the powers that be behave. I went to the Houses of Parliament earlier in the year-toured the building and went to the gallery to observe prime minister's question time. The building is amazing beautiful architecture and a feeling of history; it's been many years since my previous visit. Question time was very interesting, not sure that I "approve" of the way our ministers behave; I know it is history but as a teacher I would be chastising my students if they were to be so rude.

Tour and Tea!. Recently had a tour with amazing tour guide called Victoria WoodShe made an interesting tour fabulous with her knowledge and enthusiasm.Then afternoon tea on the terraceCream tea, cakes and sandwiches.First class

So Much History in So Much of a Magnificant Building. I watch the TV programs in the US during the Prime Minister's audience with the members of Parliament. It was great to see the building that has so much history.
Palace of westminster. We look an audio guide. I had not realised that the public are allowed into both chambers and the division lobbies. An excellent experience
GO!!. If you get a chance to go inside, I would 100% recommend it. Brilliant!!! The guided tours inside of the building are worthwhile and the terrace bar has fantastic views!
omg!!!. Amazing! Must see. The guided tour is fantastic! Guides really know their history and you leave with memories (and pictures!!)

School Visit. We took 48 children and6 staff to HoP. We had an amazing tour. House of Commons, House of Lords, Westminster Hall.. Fantastic. If you can book an education tour through your school then you must... It was well worth it. We could see the MP's Pigeon Holes ( for messages ) and seeing it was just after the general election, many had been removed for new names. Historical - yes!Exciting - yes!Wow factor - yes,Just brilliant.

A walk through the history of social law. When Americans want to make the world believe they created equal law and democracy, the English have them dead beat at every turn with their own history of legal struggles, outlawing slavery before any other country in the American continent (including the Latin American countries that had a vested interest in outlawing slavery due to the contribution of slaves to their respective independences). The home country of the Suffragettes, with its own piece of history in the Protestant Reformation, the creators of many of the world's legal institutions, and the keepers of volumes of legal and political tradition, the Parliament is in many ways a great example of all things English.Take the time to read the semblance of English legal history in the boards at the entrance of the Old Parliament Hall, and then, spend the extra quid for the audio guides - both are absolutely worth it!

Worthwhile. The self- guided audio tour is excellent. Our 11 year old listened to the adult audio tour and really enjoyed it, but they also have a kids version. Get tickets in advance and earlier is less crowded. This was our favorite tour of the whole trip.
Beautiful. Absolutely loved London and was so excited to see all of the sites. We went early in the morning which seemed to save us from the hoards of travellers and tourists.

Impressive environs; debate a bit disappointing. It's some time since I visited Parliament (with a friend); I had tried once before, but there was a huge queue that time and I cried off. This time, there were fewer visitors being let in by the policemen on duty in the street outside. Up several flights of stairs, to what reminded me of the stage-door office of a theatre. There there was a security-check (phew! We passed!), more stairs and suddenly, slightly vertiginously, we were in the Visitors' Gallery high above the House of Commons. There had been a slightly faded, tatty air about the staircases; the rows of benches in the gallery were comparably spartan; but it seemed strange to be watching from the side opposite the Speaker's chair, and above, a debate such as one had previously often witnessed from one of two fixed viewpoints facing the rows of MPs, on television. On this occasion (mid-afternoon, I think?), the Chamber was sparsely occupied - maybe a dozen MPs, and a somnolent atmosphere. The debate, too, was on a not totally-engrossing topic, dry, factual, desultory; a bit disappointing. So after a decent period, we quietly made our way out and downstairs to the entrance-lobby. Much livelier and more interesting, with all manner of folk coming and going the entire time, and the decorative architecture very striking and ceremonial: THIS was how Parliament should be! The opportunity was offered at this point for us to visit the House of Lords. We were tempted; but the experience at the Commons had put us off, so instead we made our way round to the HIGHLIGHT of our visit: Westminster Hall. A HUGE open space with venerable stone-slab flooring, and, as I understand it, the oldest part of the Houses of Parliament, where the original King's Councils took place, it was easy to imagine this vast, grey-floored, high-walled, stained-glass-windowed SPACE, topped by dark wooden carved angels peering in from the eaves, as a location where, filled with robed nobles, great decisions were made. Almost empty, but for a modest stage-like stairs at the far end, and an exhibition of very useful pamphlets along one wall, it stirred the theatre in one's soul. You could have raced around it on roller-skates (and probably got sent to the Tower) or launched into a speech from Henry V: such a venue was it....! In the event, we peered at the very-interesting and -informative pamphlets. selecting the most-interesting to take home, and left by the side-door at the far end, feeling thoroughly part of History. (In fact, our visit was earlier than August 2014, but (a) no facility for giving this information (b) not sure exactly when, anyway.....

Parliament a fine state of affairs. Unfortuately our visit was somewhat limited to to the opening of the state parliament the following week.You visit Westminster Hall, St Stephens Hall (photo allowed), Central Lobby & House of Commons. a few rules and regulations to adhere to (no hats, or sitting unless told too). Not sure on the value. Get your MP to arrange a free tour if possible.
Alright. Been to this looks great but that's about it really. It is a must have thing to do for first time visitors to the capital but I wouldn't rush to go.
beautiful. Nice and beautiful for tourists. It was easy to find in the city and you can read a lot about it on the internet, toy can come close to it.
Better than expected. Booked to go here for something to do. Would throughly recommend it. The head sets are really imformative and easy to follow. I would recommend this.

Oh me Lord!. The guided tour to the Houses of Parliament was amazing experience - it brings you through the entire process, starting at the beginning through the house of lords then the house of commons. It's around an hour and doesn't leave you feeling too tired or bored.
No public access. Couldn't get near enough - no signs telling you we walked round and round to visitors entrance but it turned out to be official visitors entrance rather than public entrance

Excellent audio tour . I was surprised by how much I enjoyed our visit to the Houses of Parliament. We opted for the audio tour which took us on a 90 minute journey through the two houses. I was captivated not only by the beauty of the building's interior but also by the audio tour's background information on the houses themselves. Absolutely fascinating. We popped into the Cafe after the tour was complete and had scones and tea. Delicious!

Look Kids, Big Ben - Parliment. This is a great classic London spot. Here you will find the great clock and the houses of parliment where laws are made and awesome debates. I hesr that many MPs drink before seasons begin which makes for livelier than usual debate.

Free tour steeped in history. Fascinating place full of history. I went on an informative tour organised via my local MP. If you are elderly or disabled note that there aren't many places where you are allowed to sit down. You aren't permitted to sit in MPs seats...

audio tour. Audio tour booking via the internet. entry was efficient and picking up the headset fast. The audio equipment was easy to use and the quality of the information excellent. Staff inside were also knowledgeable and helpful. Well worthwhile.
Great tour. The audiotour absolutely worth its money. Historical place of world-wide significance. Definitely worth it.
Tour Houses of Parliament. Booked ahead on the internet, excellent and informative tour, lots of walking and standing so go prepared, approx. 90 minutes long, be on time!

Do the audio tour it's so beautiful!. As we were on our honeymoon I was pretty reluctant to go on an audio tour of the House of Parliament but I am so glad we did. It was absolutely beautiful inside! I didn't imagine the inside could be so elegant and grand. It's a shame you can't take photos but I would definitely recommend this tour!
To political fans. The history behind is very interesting... The place inside is amazing, but for who loves politics it is the right place to go.
A beautiful place. In the middle of london...where you will witness past meeting present...one of a kind...be sure not to miss this place

A Must. It is an amazing building . Incredible location. You get a sense of timelessness, tradition and history. I sat there and looked at the building and soaked in the atmosphere. Totally stunning...

Fantastic tour. Went with my daughter and grandchildren aged 6 & 7 it went a little over their heads but me and my daughter thought it was fascinating and the children were well behaved. The afternoon tea on the terrace after the tour icing on the cake.
Best Guided Tour Ever. For just a few pounds extra take the guided tour. You will learn so much about the "Mother of Parliaments".
amazing architecture. Gorgeous buildings with such beautiful architecture. And we love the cobblestone streets all over London. So different from home in 'new' San Diego, Ca

Take 20 mins to read about it before you go!. So it's an amazing building, lots of character and a mix of security arrangements from the futuristic to the medieval. But I suggest that if you go without a bit of preparation that is all you will take in because it is an overwhelming amount of history you are seeing there in a short space of time. If you take a while to read about the highlights before hand and focus on the key parts I reckon you will get a lot more from it and really appreciate the 1000 years of history you are being bombarded with when entering. Have a great visit it's one of my favorite place to see.

Informative, a little dry. These tours are unsurprising. A beautiful building, some British history from about Tudor times and explanations of some of the quirky customs of the British parliament.They should remind everyone to be 25 minutes early to clear security. Tickets on-line.

The Seat of Power . You can't help but be impressed After visiting here and seeing the impressive stonework which makes up this Gothic masterpiece both inside and out! To think it almost got destroyed in the Gunpowder Plot ! You can get on a tour and be guided around the chambers which we see on tv most days and learn more of the history of the place , which is the best way of visiting here.look out for the flashing taxi lamp which means an M.P. Needs a taxi quick !! You may spot a famous face getting in!
The History. London is steep in history and i really enjoy seeing the sites and sounds. although Houses of Parliament line moves slow, its worth the wait

History has been made here - and still is!. My friend and I used audioguides for this fascinating tour. Behind the scenes of what we see on the News every day! The House of Lords' chamber was beyond magnificent. I had visited as a dinner guest of an MP several times before, but this was a fascinating link with the history and traditions.

A great and down to earth view of the house of government. Its an amazing building and everywhere you hear people saying "I saw that on TV" or "that's where they they take their seats". The guides really make the history and splendor of the building come to life, together with the ways of parliament now.
Really worth a visit.

Victorian architecture and historical buildings. I usually cannot help but admire the Victorian architecture and the historical aspects of these buildings. It must be on the list of places to see when in London

Private tour. One of the most beautiful buildings in London/this country. Paintings/artworks are outstanding. Very interesting place whether you are interested in politics or not. The House of Lords - is a particular highlight! Good shop with very reasonably priced 'tour book' only £5 which contains all the photos you would like - as you can't take your own. Fab!

houses of parliament experience!. having been invited by our local MP to take a tour of this magnificent building, it was an opportunity not to be missed!
wonderful history, beautiful chapel, lose yourself in history and British tradition....don't forget to touch Sir Winston Churchill's foot on his stunning statue..for good luck!
An absolute must..at least once in a lifetime!!!!
Good to see. For your first time in UK, is good to see and take lots of beautiful pictures. Take your time to walk around the area. Will be good to do some reading before the visit.

Fascinating. Have a guided visit to make the most of your visit and to hear all the inside information. It's a marvellous place for its history but also for its modern function. It looks much smaller than on TV

Must visit. Always been my dream to visit this great building and was not disappointed.What a great sight and to find out more about the history and the actual workings of parliament was superb, also had a wonderful guide to show us around.
