The only disappointment was that you could not sit down on thee benches of the commons and lords,also no photography.

THE WORLD HOME OF FAIR GOVERNMENT. The business of Parliament takes place in two places, the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Parliament exists to challenge the work of government, approve new laws and debate government policy and current issues.Westminster Hall is a striking building and is officially a royal palace. Standing on the banks of the river Thames the Parliamentary buildings hold many important historical stories, most famously Guy Fawkes.UK residents can attend debates, watch committees, take a tour of Parliament and climb the Clock TowerOverseas visitors can attend debates and watch committees when Parliament is in session, and can tour Parliament every Saturday and during the Summer OpeningThere are tours available on a regular basis - they include access to some of the most important areas of the Palace in which Parliament meets, and explains what Parliament is and does, what it has meant to different people at different times, and how it came to be what it is today.Most of the buildings seen on the tour were built in the mid 19th Century following a devastating fire, but the route also incorporates some of the earlier buildings, such as Westminster Hall, begun in 1097 by William Rufus, son of William the Conqueror.You cannot miss BIG BEN the clock tower which has an imposing look and a chime that rang out on radio during WW2. The Shop is also has a great range of interesting stuff. The experience was all in all fascinating and impressive and makes you feel you are in a place that oodles with true history and for the good of mankind.
Great History. Well worth the tour to see up close a great building with great history. We booked before leaving Australia, suggest this is a good option.
Charity launch. A great evening on the terrace...plenty of food and drink. Security was straight forward and easy directions.
tour it!!. make sure to book your guided or audio tour in advance it is definitely worth it. loved seeing where thequeensits during a session.
great view of a night when lit up. great place to see day or night but better of a night when all lit up it looks great and a great view from other side of the river
fab. I never tire of the pomp & circumstance of these buildings and what they represent in our past as a country, it doesn't matter about the politics

Inside Parliament. A great visit, with a chance to see a lot of the general working areas. Unfortunately not enough of them, or information on its daily usage.Perhaps if a daily opportunity for small numbers of people to be able to visit by booking and paying in advance,being given the chance to see the place actually working in progress, it may be more of a genuine fantastic addition to Tourists for this attraction. We need some of the rules and regs to be a little more friendlier , this could be achieved with advanced booking and people would pay well for this.
Must see. You can't visit London without seeing the Houses of Parliament, even if it from a double decker. Parliament Square outside is a great place for photos. Also statues of great leaders.

History to see and understand. Great tour around HOP with superb insight into meanings of the traditions observed, where actions in history took place, who was involved with high level of local awareness. Luckily we were invited to climb the stairs to see Big Ben and stand behind the famous clock face what a memory. I understand you can book this extra in advance, well worth the effort.

amazing site. beautiful sight over tamisa river. it just gives you energy. it is very close to other atractions like the London Eye, or the London Sea Life Aquarium. there are also near places to take a boat trip on Tamisa and view all the bridges and the diferences between the old London city on one side and the new London city on the other side. if you go to London this atraction really is a "have to see" oportunity.
palace of Westminster. This is a very interesting and historical place visiting both the house of Lords and the commons the guides are very informative and helpful answering any questions

Great tour but Afternoon Tea was disappointing. After a very interesting guided tour of the Houses of parliament, we had booked in for Afternoon Tea to round off our visit. The setting was impressive - marquee on the terrace overlooking the Thames. Waiting staff were very friendly and professional but the food which arrived, although looking very nice, was disappointing. The sandwich bread seems a little dry and the scones and other individual desserts that were served with them had a decidedly 'artificial' flavour - maybe they had stood for a while before serving but didn't really live up to our expectations.Would recommend for the experience and the history of the place, but the food was nothing to rave about.
Both houses. Worth the wait, such history and great to be reminded of more Kings than Henry VIII !It's a contrast to see both Houses, and where the Rod is struck

Majestic. Going thru the outskirts of the parliament buildings and seeing the architecture is quite majestic! One must also take a tour inside which I didn't do that would have increased my rating here.It is easy to access by the Westminster tube station or by bus or walking. By car it's just tough to find parking.Westminster abbey is close by as well as the eye of London so you can hit all three off your list if you allot two or three hours.

Guided Tour of the Houses of Parliament Tour and Guide Book. I purchased on-line in advance for a guided tour at 1 pm on a Monday. I got there 45 minutes early in case of a line-up for going through security. Line was short and I was allowed to go on an earlier scheduled tour since there was room for me. There were about twelve people in the tour group. The tour lasted about 90 minutes.The tour guide was knowledgeable and friendly. The tour was very informative. The only negative was that photography was only limited to Westminster Hall and St. Stephen’s Hall. I did pre-order the Official Guide Book for £5 when I purchased my ticket which I picked up after the tour. The 98-page Guide Book is quite informative and has plenty of photos and illustrations. The Guide Book was worth the money.

Visit around Houses of Parliament london. Well worth a visit. There were 80 in our party and we were not herded like sheep and were left to enjoy the building at our own pace. We had the audio your and it was very informative. It was great to see the House of Lords with the red wool sack the green leather of the House of Commons and the throne the queen sits on when opening parliament. Having only ever seen Al this on films and television it was a wonderful experience too actually see this for real. Truly recommend a visit here
Excellent visit. Excellent visit. Very interesting and informative. Well worth the money. We had access to every area - I didn't realise it was so big inside!!

Great audio tour. Booked the audio tour - £25 for me and 2 boys on Saturday good value. Audio tour consists of approx 18 sections, with each clearly signposted as you move around. Each one is very informative and yet a good concise length (approx 3 minutes) so teenagers are interested without getting bored. There are optional further audio sections if you want more detail on certain topics. Total tour took exactly 1 hour but we could have spent longer if we wanted to. Nice balance of history and information on the current workings of parliament. Great access to benches of both chambers.
Great audio visit, a must go. I went there with a non english speaker so we took the audio guide. It is very nicely done and useful. We loved it. I would recommend everyone visiting London to visit.

Beautiful on the Outside, Amazing on the Inside. Buy your tickets in advance and schedule your tour. Security is tight, but efficient. The audio tour is fantastic and in depth, combining history, political evolution from monarchy to representative democracy (thank you England), art and culture. Go early and plan on a couple of hours.

A little long and no photographs is disappoining. I was disappointed that no photographs were allowed. When you have to pay to enter a public building, a rule against photographs seems a bit inappropriate. I had a guided tour and the guide was very knowlegable albeit far too long winded. There was no reason to take as long to explain the details over and over as he did.

Absolutely amazing. We were able to take an audio tour. Great stories full of history and conflict. An amazing time. We learned a lot about British history. It has inspired me to read more about the various key events.
Impressive. Lovely building , looks great from the London eye , worth a visit .steeped in history, stunning building

Atrocious wi-fi. I am no stranger to the reputation of this establishment so to say it was merely one disappointment would be an understatement, rather a series of mounting disappointments under which I was slowly over- (and seemingly under-) whelmed. Wi-fi absolutely unusable, waiting staff cold and unhelpful, seating non-existant.
Parliament tour. We learned a lot about how Parliament worked. Seeing the inside of Parliament was very interesting. Great guides.
Impressive. One of the most stunning buildings I have seen! Beautiful, impressive, easy to walk to, by Danube, great photo target
Nice atmosphere. Iconic building. The building looks great from a distance. It is in an lovely location with so much historic locations around. Awesome feeling to be there.

Fascinating guided tour. Did the tour with a live tour guide (instead of the recording). Really interesting and educational. However be prepared to walk and stand on hard floors for most of the two hours. The walking and standing actually was difficult for us near the end and we're fit and healthy. Wouldn't recommend it for older folks or those who aren't fit.

Fantastic. Visited as part of Dinner in the Lords (which was superb!) The tour round the HoP beforehand was great - knowledgeable (German!) guide who covered just enough to keep you interested without losing you in too much detail. The various rooms and halls are fantastic and the whole tour is a MUST for anyone in London.

Outstanding tour of the Houses of Parliament. This tour is outstanding - Westminster Hall, the House of Lords and the House of Commons all wrapped into the one session. You actually step onto the floor of the Lords and the Commons - inspiring stuff. You need to book ahead and there is a fairly tight security regime in place so allow plenty of time. Also, you will need to check ahead on available dates. Days when the Parliament is sitting are not available. Sadly there are no photos allowed but that is probably a great opportunity to just enjoy the fabulous surrounds. The only suggestion is that the tour can do with some proper audio devices for visitors. The non-amplified commentary can be very hard to hear at times due to the echo effect in the various parts of the tour and of course the noise from other tour groups
great tour. this is well worth the effort if you get the chance. A great insight into the history of the place and you get a bit if a behind the scenes look. Visually a stunning tour.

Simply astounding. One of those places you have seen on TV countless times, but in person it is just unbelievable. The architecture is so intricate and the area is just great for walking around. You can see some photos from my trip here: http://peak-exposure.com/adventures/2013/8/20/england
Must visit while in london. You cant come to London and not see the houses of Parliament .Amazing building ,even children will enjoy it, So much history such an interesting place for all to enjoy
if you are "DEMOCRAT". At the heart of the democratic parliamentary process. Take the guided tour - our guide was delightful and informative.

A must see for London. Even if you don't go inside the building, just walking past is great as you get to see the Parliament building and the Elizabeth Tower. I was lucky enough to go inside on a tour and it is so interesting to see how much tradition is in the building.
Political History at it's best. Great tour of the Houses of Parliament that left you wanting more time to just wander around this magnificent building. One of London's better must see tours.

A must see in London. The history and architecture of this place is amazing. It is only open to the public on Saturdays so be sure to check the schedule. This tour provides a synopsis of the UK government with the House of Lords and the House of Commons. We booked tickets on line, and you have to pick up the tickets at the ticket office. We did the audio tour which was sufficient and you can walk at your own pace.

A must-visit for any tourist AND Londoner !. It was my second visit there with friends 2 days ago and it was even better than the first one. The audio guides make the whole experience even better than a real guide as you can properly hear what is explained to you, and at your own pace. The building and everything about it is amazing and so full of history ! You are also explained a lot about the British political system and history, and get to be in the actual House of Commons and House of Lords. If I have to go there with other friends for their first visit, it will be a real pleasure and privilege to visit this amazing place once again.

Of all the amazing things we saw in London, this was my favorite. We decided to get tickets to tour Parliament at the last minute and were SO glad we did- and that we could still get tickets! The tour was really interesting and may have been our favorite thing all week. The tour was extremely interesting and we learned so much. We loved learning about the history of Parliament but really liked how they tied the tour into current events. It was relatively easy since elections were coming up so the guide could talk about all that was getting ready to happen, but I think it would be fascinating any time.What I didn't expect was all the art and beautiful paintings, sculptures, etc. It is obviously not on the same scale as a museum, but just as beautiful.I would strongly recommend anyone visiting London definitely take the tour of Parliament.

Fascinating weekend to visit. Couldn't believe I could book this amazing tour at such short notice - only a day after historic General Election! Arrived well early (1130 for a 1220 tour) to allow for security queues. Told to come back at 1210. No problem - bought a reasonably priced coffee from outlet near entrance to Westminster Abbey across the road.Came back at noon and told to join queue.Airport style security - as expected - but friendly and efficient process.Let into Westminster Hall and directed to where my tour leader was waiting.Our group was meant to be 26 but left on time with a few missing.Glad I opted for guided tour rather than headphone self-guided tour,Had professional blue badge guide called Robina - who really knew her stuff!Slightly bemused that we seemed to join the wedding procession of a bride getting married in such prestigious surroundings!Knew that we'd get to see House of Commons and Lords on this tour. Oh Wow - I thought it would be a case being taken up to rope barrier and told to have a look and then move on.Oh No! You get to visit both iconic chambers. No photos - no sitting on the seats!Initially baulked at £25 cost. Hmm - one of the best tours I have ever done - especially if you get a guide as good as I did!Bought an official guidebook in the shop - very reasonable I thought for £5 I thought. Contains the photos that I wasn't allowed to take for myself! Very friendly girl on the till too.Didn't use the cafe as I was in a rush but prices looked very reasonable.In summary was an amazing visit on an historic weekend - new government just elected and tickets for concert for 70th anniversary of VE day to go to later. Being a tourist in central London doesn't get better than this!

Highlight of the trip. As someone who has watched Prime Minister's question time on CSPAN for years, it was incredible to be able to stand in the House of Commons just near where the Prime Minister sits. They wouldn't let us sit in the seats, nor would they let us take any photos, but nonetheless, just being able to come here was the highlight of my trip to London.

Great Historical Building. The House's of Parliament otherwise known as the Palace of Westminster are well worth visiting, such a sense of history (Shame about the twits that work there), joking aside, there is so much history attached to this building, the original building was built by William 11 between 1097 and 1099, it was the largest hall in England at that time.  The Building that sits on the banks of the River Thames is the new Palace, built between 1840 and 1870, within its walls (or Westminster Hall) is all that remains of the medieval old Palace, so many Historical events are linked to these buildings, just one well known event to mention is the Gunpowder Plot, where Guy Fawkes and his Conspirators planed to blow up the Houses of Parliament, he was tried and executed in 1606, the event is remembered every year in Great Britain on November the 5th, and fireworks are let off and models of Guy Fawkes are burned on bonfires. Charles 1, while still King, was tried and condemned as a tyrant, traitor and murderer there in 1649-even though no court had any legal authority over him. The Law Courts only moved out of the House's of Parliament in the 1800's.  Long unfit for purpose, the chance came to create a new palace, when in 1834, a fire destroyed most of the old structure. Sir Charles Barry and Augustus Pugin worked to create todays Perpendicular Gothic Building, containing 1,000 rooms and two courtyards, it covers 8 acres with an impressive 266m river coverage. Standing proud of the main building is the clock tower, home of the bell, affectionately known as Big Ben, quite sadly neither Barry or Pugin lived to see the New Building Completed
Nice Site.. London citizens were voting the next day when I was there, so everything was being set-up for the election. The new Royal Baby was also born while i was there and everyone was very happy.
Crumbling Building. Totally spoilt by the "people" inside. The only good thing about the building is that you get an excellent photo of Big Ben outside of the place.

Most Impressive. I called my representative's office a few months before our visit to get passes. This was probably the best move Ive ever made as a tourist. Watching the politicians go at it in person was something I will never forget!

Amazing Building . This is probably the first and only place in the world where you could visit the Houses of Parliament, the seat of Government (PM office & Downing Street), Supreme Court offices and Westminster Abbey all at a go. London is unique for having all 4 in 1 place.As a building, the Houses of Parliament is relatively new. It was actually burnt down in the 1850's and had to be rebuilt. I must say it's restoration is amazing. You won't be disappointed making a visit here. You can feel London has a rich sense of history when visiting all these buildings.

Birthplace of Democracy. We did a guided tour and this is a memorable experience. The tour guide was very good - clear diction, interesting stories and could not be faulted. Having spent all my life observing events here on TV it is a great to experience the place a first hand. No photography except in Westminster Hall and St Stephens Hall.

Wonderful sense of history. This was my first visit to the House of Parliament and the sense of history was just stunning. When you think of all that has gone before in these halls, it really does take your breath away.
Just amazing!. What can you not like about this place, except the queues at the entrance..Make sure you arrive early.

Date with a Lord!. Jumped at the chance to goon a tour of the House of Lords with a member. It was so interesting. After lunch we also visited The House of Commons and sat in on part of a debate. we saw our Member of Parliament going through to vote. Especially interesting to visit if you are a UK citizen. Going round like this was free but if you just turn up there is a charge.

Very interesting!!. We had a private party tour of the H of P but I think you can book individual tours. The security is very tight!!I'm sure how to recommend a tour should take but we had 1 hour which was a bit rushed, the guide was very knowledgeable!In particular it's very interesting to see the difference between the House of Lords and the Commons.Lots of history here of course!!

wow a great experience. We opted for the guided tour and Norma was very knowledgeable whilst also providing interesting additons. This buidling is stunning, and we were in awe being inside. Well worth the 50

Amazing Architecture and Historical Content. Amazing Houses of Parliament. The outside is pretty impressive, the interior is incredible and full of with tradition. The buildings are spectacular on the inside and the guide gives you so much information about the rooms and traditions of the houses. I liked every bit of it and have absolutely no regrets at having done it

Historical. Friends advised us to do the guidedtour of the Palace of Westminster. It was great. Our guide obviously loved the place and all the history and stories about the politicians and royals who had been there over the centuries. The tour takes about 90 minutes and there is time to spend in both the House of Lords and House of Commons. No sitting in their seats however !! A great tour. Highly recommended.

Regret not doing this years ago. We loved this tour! The buildings are spectacular on the inside and the guide gives you so much information about the rooms and traditions of the houses etc. We loved every bit of it and came away with absolutely no regrets at having done it. If you have an interest in any of history, architecture or politics, this tour is for you. 90 minutes and £25 well spent. You can also choose to do an audio tour for £16.

Fascinating journey through democracy and time. More sandwiches for afternoon tea please!. My second trip to the seat of democracy yet still so fascinating and so much to take in. Guides were excellent and well informed. Two things would have improved our visit - have more seats available as disabled visitors in our group struggled and were initially told they shouldn't sit down - and more sandwiches for the afternoon tea please. The afternoon tea venue staff were excellent and very friendly but there was just not enough food for us Northerners. Claridges afternoon tea filled us for the day but after this one we went out for dinner!

Immensely enjoyable. Apart from the purchasing of tickets this was an a slick tourist experience. At the entrance we were directed to a building around the corner & over the road where we had to wait outside in the cold to buy tickets. Many staff in the office but only one serving - slow line. More waiting outside in the rain at the entrance. However once through security and after collecting the audio we were all enthralled. Our teenage girls loved it & even listened to all the optional commentaries. The audio & rooms are so impressive. One child free with each adult - fantastic.

Enquire about tours inside, it's stunning. Amazing does not describe the Houses of Parliament. The outside is pretty impressive, the interior is incredible and packed with tradition and treasures. Enquire with parliament via the web page how to do this, you can't just turn up and expect to be admitted

Magnificent!. I was on a specially arranged private tour, so I can't say what the public tours are like, but I got to see all of the spaces and it was very interesting to learn more about the British government and see where it all happens!
Amazing place. I had a privileged look behind the scenes... And it was amazing. Having walked where previous kings and queens have walked. Visited the library...awesome and amazing.

beautiful. better than I expected. I couldn't believe how decorative the inside was, and the tour guide was very informative. Felt quite to stand in the house of Commons front of the TV cameras. A must for history lovers.

Amazing. One of the best attractions in London. You can walk through of some of the chambers of the Parliament, see and have a feel of the home to the British government, something unforgettable. You also have an audio guide, which is quite detailed.Worth the money !

New Audio Tour is Amazing. Great value for money for a tour that is so so rich in British history. The new audio tour make the whole experience a lot more interesting and i would recommend it to Londoners as well as tourists to take in the tour.
Lovely Architecture. I was impressed by the houses of parliament more than the iconic Big Ben. They show impressive architecture. Not to be missed.

The MOST AMAZING experience. Wasn't sure if I might be a little bored with the history around the H of P. However, this could not have been further from my experience. The place is magnificent and the guides bring it to life. I would do the tour again tomorrow. A MUST DO for anyone having a day out in London.Leave time for the security clearance to get in and make time for the superb coffee shop at the end!
Very Very impressive. just go and see it and be amazed.... The history and the architecture absolutely fabulous. A brilliant day out
Always visit.. A landmark that I never tire of. Been to London four times and always visit this site. So much to see on one corner of the city.

Amazing history.. The amount of history held withing the houses of parliament is simply fascinating and its amazing how long the building has stood. Also i must say our tour guide, Mr James Wharton the Stockton south MP was simply amazing, as i am sure the others also are. however i don't recommend this for younger children as it would simply bore them.
Worth a visit. An interesting visit, matches with what you see on the tv! You are not allowed to take phones, cameras etc, so go light, though these are looked after for you in a security box.

Ayes Right. Very easy to book online, but obviously cannot visit when parliament is sitting. Went for an early Saturday morning booking and arrived early to avoid crowds at security.Guide was very informative. Tour included robing room, Houses of Lords, House of Commons and Westminster Hall.Good value
Not a Family Place. Best to go solo. I went with my kids and they got bored really easily. the food was okay. If you book a tour it might be more intresting.

Historic tour . Fantastic place to visit with an amazing history.Take a tour if you can as you get more idea of the history of parliament and England.It's also a beautifully designed historic building and a must when in London.

Guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, London. We were booked in for the 1.00pm tour which cost £20. After clearing airport type security we were ushered to the Westminster Hall to wait for our tour guide. This magnificent room took my breathe away, I knew this tour was going to be something really special. We were greeted by our guide, Barbara, who explained the rules for the tour, one being no photography past the hall, which was disappointing. The tour took 2 hours and Barbara explained the history of the buildings, development of the Westminster parliamentary system, the daily operations of the parliament and other staff working there. She told us about various works of art and restoration of same. We were taken into the Houses of Lords and Common. She was well informed about all aspects of the complex and its operations and obviously very proud and passionate of her role as a guide. At the finish of our tour we visited the cafe for tea & scones looking out to Big Ben. We purchased a copy of the guide book as a momento of this delightful and educational experience. Highly recommend you add it to your London itinerary. You need to book well in advance and it is worth every penny of the admission price, which I initially thought was pretty steep.
Marvelous!. A must to see. Took the guided tour, beautifully done. An amazing look into the mother of Parliaments, even if the 19th century version.

Excellent place to understand how parliament works!. We found this tour one of the most interesting of our stay in London and were lucky to be able to see all the areas of Parliament House as the houses weren't sitting.
The audio visual guide which they give you is a must and very informative.
Getting into the House of Lords and the Commons was amazing.
Wonderful attraction

The children loved it!. Book a tour, then you get to go inside the roped off areas and you get answers to your questions!We went as a family with a 14 and 10 year old and they loved it. Not normally so interested in history, there wasn't a peep out if them as we went from the Queens door through the House if Lords ending in The House of Commons.It is absolutely fascinating and I could believe we hadn't done it before.Lots of armed police added to the appeal for the children, police very happy to pose for photos.Smashing gift shop too!

Fascinating to visit. We took the audio rather than the guided tour as there is a child's version which turned out to be perfect for our 10 year old, it also meant that we could explore at our own pace rather than that of one of the guides. Having said that I would like to visit again and do the guided tour as the snippets we heard as we were walking round did seem to be very interesting offering a little more than is possible with the audio tour.Being inside the building that we've seen so much on television and learning some of the detail, history, traditions and workings of both the building and parliament itself was fascinating.I'd thoroughly recommend a visit.

A Must Do in London. Went for a guided tour & tea and was thoroughly impressed by the setting, organisation and food. After getting thorough security (airport type, 30 mins) we had afternoon tea on the balcony overlooking the Thames. Fortunately it was a sunny day so we able to stand outside, admire the scenery and take pictures. The tea itself was quite good - decent sandwiches & cakes and selection of teas. Doesn't quite match some of the bigger hotels but still very good quality. We then joined our tour which was a small group (15 people) led by a great guide called Rob who provided lots of interesting background, history and anecdotes. Got to see all the main rooms and sights. Visitors do have the option of an audio guide but i would recommend the guided tour because you get a much better feel of the history and characters. If you are in London then this is a must do.

A must do in London. Took escorted guided tour. Pre booked on line & collected tickets on day. Was running a little late due to volume of people, but a very helpful person radioed through to ask our tour to wait. Very grateful to this person. You are able to book on day & do your own audio tour. This looked very busy & to guarantee entrance I would suggest book online. Glad I opted for guided tour as much more personal with lots of inside knowledge and able to ask questions along the way. Throughly enjoyed the whole tour. A magnificent building oozing culture & history. Used all other facilities - toilets, cafe & gift shop, all well above average. A must do thing in London in my opinion, loved it!
I know what its like. A family member of mine works their (very well paid)its not a very exciting place but it is rick in history and elegance it also has lots of foliage around the building

A Fantastic Experience. I go to London on a regular basis and I am always looking for something different to do. I booked this guided tour for £25 and it was worth every penny. The tour takes you right through the building starting at the Norman Porch and our guide was interesting, knowledgeable and informative. I thought the building was impressive from the outside but this indie is even better. The tour last about 90 minutes but felt like 10 as it passed by so quickly. I would definitely recommend and I look forward to visiting again

Amazing, brilliant, awe inspiring.. This was certainly the highlight of our long weekend in London. The audio tour is informative and interesting, and the route is well laid out. To be inside such an historical building, with full knowledge of the role it has played in the moulding of the UK, and with such important figures having passed through its' portals - magical.Can't recommend enough.

Simply spectacular . Having seen an advert for a visit to the Houses of Parliament I thought why not. I was not disappointed and in fact it was an amazing spectacle! We decided to have the guided tour and this by far was the best way of doing it. Nigel our guide had so much knowledge about the whole building it was interesting and fascinating and just wanted to know more. We also got to go into the areas where people with the headsets did not go so you get to see more. I think the whole visit has been made even more special due to the election coming up so Nigel related all of the areas to what is going to happen. I know that it's sad, but I'm now looking forward to watching the opening of Parliament with the Queen getting involved! Great stuff and well worth the visit.

A HIGHLIGHT OF OUR TRIP. This is a must!!!!! England is full of rich history and tradition and a visit to the Parliament will give you a wonderful sense of all of this.I strongly urge you to sign up for a guided tour--not the audio guide, but an actual person. The building, inside and out is magnificent and with a guide you hear all of the history of the government, the traditions that have been in place for hundreds of years. You actually get to be in the House of Commons room, see the House of Lords, hear what happens when the queen comes to parliament . You are standing in history and it is amazing-- not enough words to describe it. Having a guide gives you a chance to hear some marvelous stories, get info that is not on the audio guide and to ask questions. This tour was one of the best things we did in London . You can sign up on line, which will save you time in case lines are long. Guided tours are offered many times throughout the day. DON'T MISS THIS

A BRILLIANT EXPERIENCE. I finally made it. After many decades of living in the UK I went to visit the Houses of Parliament. It is amazing, quite takes your breath away. The self-guided tour is very good and doesn't overload you with information. There are frequently offered options to get a more in-depth description offered on your guide programme. The opulence of the chambers on view, the wonderful paintings and the superb busts and statues of all the former Prime Ministers are really worth seeing. Of course it's the history that really hits you. So many great men and women have walked those hallowed halls. The Jubilee Shop offers some nice but quite expensive souvenirs of your visit but the Cafe has an excellent range of food and at extremely competitive prices. All in all a great place to visit. Two things to remember. Pre-book and get there at least 15 minutes before your tour time. There is are airport style security searches in place.

Interesting - and free. Contrary to what some people seem to think, you don't need tickets to see a debate: just check online to see when they're on, then turn up within a few hours of the start time and confidently walk up to the guard and say you're there to watch a debate - the guard seemed to be turning away tourists who said they wanted to take a look around, but he let me in. Then you have to go though a security check, do some paperwork, cloak you bags, and wait to be admitted to the chamber (which didn't take long).I saw the House of Lords debate because it's in a fancier room, it was mildly interesting but I couldn't follow it all - not sure if this was because of the acoustics or because of the accents (many of the Lords are appointed rather than hereditary so they don't all sound like Benedict Cumberbatch unfortunately!).

The birthplace of good government!. Even if you aren't able to fit in a tour of the INSIDE, simply wandering around and soaking up the history of the Houses ofParliament is worth the time and effort (and great photo opportunities). It's difficult to go to London and not SEE Parliament Square, of course!

Houses of Parliament Tour. If you ever get a chance to do a tour its well worth it. The grandeur of the Lords against the dull green of the Commons..A very difference and unique experience.. go up Big Ben as well.
A must see. Such a beautiful place - full of history and mystery. Plenty of places nearby (Big Ben etc).An amazing place which must be seen.

Another don't miss this one - in the top 3 visits for London. A fantastic tour guided again / a guide who explained parliament the rooms/ the paintings - with great enthusiasm / expertise / in a lighthearted fascinating manner - if only history was taught in this way - fantastic !! Don't miss this extravagant gothic palace - worth every minute - toilets are available in the attached cafe / good to know before the tour !

Very impressive. We went and viewed the building only which was very beautiful. I would recommend trying to get tickets to see a debate though as judging from the television would be interesting as everyone yells and insults each other.
Amazing first view . First trip to London and this was our first view after leaving hotel simply wow factor. Very busy as expected as royals were around for anzac day but enjoyed nevertheless.

Scintillating and Educational Experience. I've lived in London for years, and have seen the Houses of Parliament from the river umpteen times but never knew that they conduct tours of the building (not did I bothered to check). It was only fairly recently that I went for the guided tour (there are two types of tour - guided and audio), and I thoroughly enjoyed myself. It is an impressive building brimming with pageantry and ceremonial details that are both amusing and venerated. Being a bit of a history buff I had a fantastic time, and our guide was engaging and knowledgeable. The rooms were gorgeous to behold, especially the Lord's Chamber and the Queen's seat within it. The ticket was a bit pricey but well worth it. Attractions in London are notoriously expensive, and I found this to be a more immersive and memorable experience than other famous spots like St Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey (which are wonderful in their own righ, but pales in comparison methinks). So if money is not a huge issue, don't just take photos of the building from the outside, sign up for the guided tour and enjoy an educational trip down the hallowed halls of British history!

A must see. A bit pricey, but well worth the visit. A touch expensive, but it was informative, interesting and definately a nice break from the zoo outside. It's easy to spend a couple hours here at least. You need to go to the ticket office first. It's facing the Thames in the building across the street. If you come out of Westminster stations, turn left and left again and it's along the side of the building where the station is. There's no ticket sales at the actual entrance/airport security.  Also, best view of Big Ben humanly possible and not swarming with tourists.

Historical happiness. We took tour round the famous buildings. Lots of history here with people on hand to help. We took audio tour which was good as long as you keep up with the numbers situated throughout. Access to many parts, Westminster hall, House of lords and parliament. You must see this if travelling to London.

A must visit. Integral part of the history,heart of mother of all parliament,lots of pop and ceremony ,so much to learn and view,makes you feel to be proud that you are part of it.Particularly for tourist a london trip is incomplete without a visit to the parliament.

Audio Tour. Pre-booked audio tour so had an allocated time-slot. Be aware of airport style security when you enter. Allow 1.5hrs for visit. Bit of a shame you can only take photos in 2 of the halls. Was thrilled by the sparkling ceilings & stunning architecture. Very impressed by Westminster Hall where you enter - real sense of occasion when you look at the plaques on the floor marking where the Queen & other dignitaries have given speeches. A definite "must do visit" when in London.

Much fancier than Canada's Parliament Buildings. Well worth seeing, particularly as a resident of Ottawa, Canada, where I daily look out at the Parliament Buildings from my office. The architecture and sheer size of Westminster is stunning. As I'm sure nearly everyone would say, its well worth a visit. One of our friends on our trip also had time to do a tour, and she said that it was a very worthwhile experience. Next time.

A Pantheon of history and governance. The Barry and Pugin realisation of the 'modern' Palace of Westminster, which is home to the House of Parliament, is a Gothic Revivalist's feast. This amazing riverside edifice, which has been the home of Kings and Queens, the Parliament of England and the Royal Courts of Justice, replaced the medieval building which was destroyed by fire. In turn, the new palace is a survivor of repeated bombing during the WW2 Blitz and, later still, of small but significant attacks by terrorists, protesters and assorted nutters.Yet despite all these changes of bricks and mortar, governance of Britons - wise and foolish, hasty and considered - has emanated from this place since the thirteenth century; almost 1000 years.I have been lucky enough to have had private tours on my several trips to the Houses of Parliament but the website gives very helpful information for new visitors. The Guides all have different interests which translate to delightfully idiosyncratic tours - do try to book onto a tour and be sure to read some background in advance and ask lots of questions.My highlights: Central Lobby mosiacs which depict the patron saints of the British Isles - Ireland being represented by two: Patrick and Brigid; House of Lords Royal Gallery with the sumptious panels by Maclise of the Battle of Waterloo and the death of Nelson at the battle of Trafalgar; the box of sands collected from each of the Normandy D-Day landing beaches in the same room; The Lords Chamber, where you can see the dents from Churchill's signet ring in the Table of the House, made whilst the chamber was used as the temporary Commons Chamber when the 'other place' was damaged by bombing during WW2; House of Commons Members Lobby, where the plain arch into the Commons Chamber is a symbol of the ravages of warfare; Westminster Hall where dozens of heads of state (including Winston Churchill) have lain in state before burial; The Chapel of St Mary's Undercroft, where Emily Wilding Davison hid during the 1911 census to enable her registration address as 'House of Commons', thus making a claim to political rights similar to those of men. [She later died by apparently throwing herself under the King's horse, Anmer, at the 1913 Derby. Five years later (in 1918), nearly 8.5 million women became eligible to vote.]It is possible that more overseas visitors, than citizens of the UK, have visited this ravishing place - you should and must go.

Great audio tour!! . As I was looking up things to do in London on tripadvisor I came across this gem! If you are interested in UK history and government or just seeing the inside of this magnificent building this is the place to visit. I did not prebook I just walked up to the ticket office and paid for the audio tour. The trick is to make sure you go to the ticket office first to get your tickets if you have your back to Big Ben and are facing the metro station, follow the building the metro station is in around the right side and the ticket office is located in there. Houses of parliament does not allow for pictures other than the hall when you first walk in. Be prepare to even have to shut your phone off. The audio tour is great and explains how the government works. Would definitely recommend it!!

Awesome piece of History. I took the self-guided audio tour of the House of Parliament which I think was the right choice. This allowed me to walk at my own pace and spend time looking at what I wanted to look at. The audio was very interesting and had a great deal of information. In comparison I saw the guided tours often with 20+ hurrying around the Houses. The staff were very helpful as I often had a few questioned not addressed in the audio. You also get to see heaps of rooms in the Palace including the two Houses. Well worth the price!

Heart of the House.. We had a wonderful tour of the Houses of Parliament. Our guide was full of fascinating facts,pointed out things to look for and answered our questions. To stand inside the House of Lords and the Commons felt very surreal. The interior decoration is superb.So much history it's awe inspiring. Within walking distance there is Westminster Abbey and Horse Guards Parade A fantastic day trip.

A little of a hassle to get tickets but worth the effort. You need tickets for the audio tour and it's about a block away in very heavy pedestrian traffic -- so plan ahead so you won't have to backtrack. You also have to go through a not unexpected security check, etc. Once in, the audio tour is excellent and every student of democracy needs to tour this place.
Amazing to see. Absolutely fantastic viewing. Amazing architecture. I have always wanted to visit here and I am glad I have. Visited twice during my stay

In the footsteps of Giants. One of the best places to visit on a trip to London. It's really quite awe inspiring to think one's feet are stepping on the same floors as such parliamentary giants as Winston Churchill, Aneurin Bevan, Margaret Thatcher and other former statesmen. The interior is magnificent... you could wander around just taking in the splendour of the gothic archetecture, We were enthralled by the commentary of the guides and learned soooooo much about British Politics. Would I recommend a visit Yes Absolutely, especially if you are keen on British Political History! There's so much to see and do; time flies from the moment you join the tour until you find yourself at the end of it. There are lots of historic paintings to see - a real treat for anyone who likes art. All in all I think it's a great way to spend an hour or two. And then you can spend at least another hour marvelling at the outside of the palace of Westminster and Big Ben!!!.

Grand. You are of course surrounded by history. The whole place buzzes and you are enveloped in the daily business of this unique Palace of Westminster. The Chamber seems much smaller than it appears on TV. Loved it.

Seat of Democracy. We visited the Houses of Parliament about nine years ago during the summer recess. This was a memorable visit, the architecture is stunning and it is great to see where all the decisions are made that form the laws of our country. This is not to be missed.

Amazing!. Got a lucky invite via a business contact for a private dinner here with a Lord! And we got a full guided tour - it was awesome! Not sure how this compares to standard tour but we got to see both Houses and a whole load of amazing British history. Seen through the eyes of a real Lord it was even more amazing.

fantastic tour. Visited the Houses of Parliament early morning of Saturday 14th March.Took the audio tour and thoroughly enjoyed the experience.Well worth taking the tour.Security is very tight so expect delays when entering.Photo opportunities are limited.
British Icon. Loved it...You come to London you have to visit...great historical buildings, stunning architecture, event he police guarding were friendly. And topping it off is the awesome Big Ben!!!

Houses of Parliament London. I have had opportunity to take my gusts from Overseas on number of occasions and every time I take them there is always something new that I learn. Every Londoner should make a trip to House of Commons & House of Lords. Very educational and breathtaking architecture. Great day out for a family as well. Book through your Local MP's.trip of a life time. Why do they have 3 different colored carpets? Is Monarch allowed into House of Commons? Some questions you might want to raise.

Worth a visit. I took the audio tour and really enjoyed my visit. As a Londoner I'm ashamed to say it was my first visit inside the building. Great to actually see the rooms that I've seen so often on TV.

Interesting and enjoyable. I am really positive about this attraction. I booked the audio tour which was great. The information is not too difficult to understand and not over detailed. You often have the opportunity to listen to more in-depth story's by pressing a specific combination of numbers on your audio device. So if you would like to hear more details about an area, that is possible.The palace itself is beautifully decorated and a joy to watch.

Gotta see it to appreciate it!. Located in the central Westminster tube precinct right along side Westminster Abbey.This is a world renown building. Amazing in its size, design and sheer presence. You've seen the photos all your life, now be prepared to be astounded by being ther in person.Tours are limited based on Parliament schedules. I didn't get in.Plan on doing the Westminster Abbey and Westminster Parliament Palace on one day.It's right by the Thames, so easy access to cross to the Southwalk too or the nearby London Eye.

Splendour. Although I am a Londoner and see this amazing building all the time I had never thought to do a tour of the interior. I booked the Royalty and Splendour tour and it was fantastic. The guide was great and he led us around telling stories with humour and answering any questions. I recommend this tour - we did the evening one. It finishes with a glass of champagne although we would have preferred a cup of tea......speaking of tea there is a nice little café and a bookshop that you come to after going through security. It is worth getting there a little early if you can as the tea and scones are some of the best we have tasted.

Stunning. I did the guided tour. Absolutely stunning building and I found out a lot i didn't know. I've been meaning to do this for years. Some of the info was a little over my head which shows how complicated our political system can be. My only slight niggle is that it was pouring down with rain and my tour was the first tour. They didn't even attempt to let us in a little earlier to save people getting drenched. There was plenty of space once inside so it wasn't a space issue. I was soaking by the time I got in and hadn't arrived too early.

A must for students of government & history. We took the audio tour -- very well done, with a variety of voices and interviews of some of the parliamentary officers. Wish more of the spaces allowed photography -- only the first two -- but quite a tour of English history, from statues or paintings of all their sovereigns (and their consorts -- see Henry VIII lined up with all six!) to famous MPs to bomb damage deliberately left unrestored on Churchill's suggestion. Really brings home the quirky nature of British democracy and its similarities and many differences with the American legislative system.

This is where all the important decisions are made in the United Kingdom.. Yet again visited the Houses of Parliament, from the outside only I might add, as I have never been inside. I enjoy the hustle bustle of people busying themselves on foot, by car, taxi , bicycle , or any other mode of transport getting to and fro from these fantastic buildings, and to watch people stop to hear Big Ben is special. Don't miss a wander down this end of town, when in London, it is truly special, and visitors from all over the world come to see the sights which are quite fantastic. With the statue of Winston Churchill looking over everything and everyone as he did during those bleak war years, while he led our country to victory.

Tour of Westminster Palace. We were taken around by a guide i recommend booking a guide as you see more of this beautiful building which took around 90 minutes the guide also answered any questions we asked. We only got our tickets on the morning of the tour but still managed to get on the first tour

Just visiting. Have visiting the houses of parliament a few times for work, sadly never for pleasure, I've yet to do the full guided tour. The thing to remember is that no sharps are allowed, so if you carry a pen knife or have something similar on your key chain, its best to leave it at home, or ask for it to be kept in a locker until your return. Security is very good, so expect it to take a while and arrive early to allow for it. So much history is connected to this building, it is certainly worth seeing inside, just remember to book tickets in advance for Saturday, or a long time in advance if you write to your MP, MP arranged tours are generally fully booked six months in advance, but these are only available for those resident in the United Kingdom.

what a place!. if you are interested in history, art or great buildings, this is the place to spend 1 - 2 hours! You get an audio guide and can walk around in your own pace and choose how much you want to learn

Awesome building. We have enjoyed many of the sights of London and as we have not visited the Houses of Parliament booked a trip here on our last city break after Easter. The House of Lords and Royal areas are truly magnificient. The architecture and history most interesting. We booked a Guided Tour but as there were more than one operating at the same time and some guides had louder voices than others it was distracting and made it difficult to hear it all. Maybe the audio tour is better. We followed the Tour with afternoon tea. At a cost of £27.50 we anticipated something nice.We have had many afternoon teas across the Capital and this ranked with the worst. We expected English afternoon tea. The tea was made with teabags!! not as we expected. Then the sandwiches were a smoked salmon and lemon dressing on a small slice of ciabatta, a smoked chicken on a brioche bun and a tomato and mozarella on a small piece of rye bread anything but traditionally British. A small poorly made little to no fruit type scone with a minute amount of jam and clotted cream and then a chocolate and orange tart and a small glass with a type of Eton mess in it and one other cake - I can't even remember it. This was served on a stand with dark little shelves on it not a 3 tier British cake stand. In our opinion this is a British Institution and visitors from far and wide would appreciate a more quintessential English traditional Afternoon Tea. We left very disappointed on many counts and £150 poorer for 3 afternoon teas and 2 oap guided tours and one adult tour. Happy to pay but expect some value for money
Old but nice. Looks old but still looks nice.looks great with the river view.would recommend for everyone who wishes to see where British policy is made.
Fascinating. We recommend to audio tour. Went with kids as well and all enjoyed the tour and the accessibility to all the areas of Parliament.

Highlight of our Trip. We've been to London several times, but have never been able to work in a tour of the Houses of Parliament until our most recent trip. We opted for guided tour rather than the audio guide and it was completely worth it. Our tour guide was brilliant and was both informative, warm, energetic, and just a pleasure to talk to. It was such an experience being present in the areas where the work of the British gov't takes place and to learn more about the pageantry and ritual involved. While this would have been enough, the various rooms we went to were often gorgeous and filled with lovely paintings and decorations. I'm so glad we were finally able to fit this tour in and only wish we had done it sooner.

Living history as well as stunning works of art. I would emphasize to all visitors to England, but especially those from former colonies or Commonwealth countries, to not miss this! A place which is so meaningful politically to our lives and our own history but also a place which is chock full of stunning artworks, stained glass and other historical treasures. The best part about it for me was the entrance hall, preserved from the original building, originally a banqueting hall in the 1000's, later the chamber where Thomas More and others were tried. Do not miss seeing the Palace of Westminster on your trip to London!

Wonderful and insightful experience. Wasn't expecting to enjoy as much as I did! So much history to take in - but the audio tour did this in a really engaging way. Just wish we could have taken photos to really remember it. Would visit again.

Fantastic. I am sure there is no other Parliament building in the world that you can visit like this.This is the second time I have visited, a fantastic experience and well worth any UK citizen or tourist doing. The tour by a very informative guide lasts around 1 1/2 hours.This is the mother of all parliaments and to hear the history of how we ended up with our system of government is truly wonderful and was quite emotional.The surroundings are ornate and very well explained as you go round, you can't take pictures on the tour.To be able to stand (not sit) on the benches of the Lords and Commons is worth the entrance fee alone.The entrance Westminster Hall's roof is over 600 years old and absolutely remarkable.A worth while and important tour to do while in London.

Very interesting tour. What an historic and beautiful building inside and out, great to see inside all of those famous areas that we see so much on the news, quite a long tour and not too many options for a seat during the tour, so be prepared.Enjoyment could be slightly affected by the guide you are allocated, some would appear to be better than others ours was a bit retentive! Its potluck which one you get though.

Arrogance & Disappointment. Having seen the mass marketing around London to visit the Houses of Parliament, I booked this guided tour expecting an enjoyable afternoon. However, right from the start, the tour guide was extremely arrogant emphasising what a true "privilege" it is to have access to the heart of UK politics-very overzealous indeed. We visited each of the chambers/rooms/cabinets in both the House of Lords and Commons, yet the only real insight we got was of how spectacular the art is; yet this was great to see, as now we can see what the government spends with our tax on....Funding gold furniture. However, I would recommend this tour to any tourists, who want a first glimpse of what the Houses of Parliament are like. If you understand politics and don't want a beginners lesson of how many constituencies there are and who the PM is then I strongly advise you to stay away; especially for the over expensive £25 you have to pay for the tour. The tour duration is around 90 minutes.

Awesome Architecture!. If you're visiting London this attraction has to be one of your stopping off points. It's splendour and history is there to behold and it's location on Parliament Square links with so much culture and other popular attractions: Big Ben, Westminster Abbey, Westminster Bridge, boat trips on the Thames, Tate Britain Art Gallery & many beautiful walks on London's Southbank. An absolute must see!
good history. we took a guided tour which was very informative and interesting. Actually got into the House of Lords and the House of Commons.
Audio Tour. This was a really great visit and so glad I booked it. Great to see the different rooms and the audio guide was very useful.

Amazing architecture. Only wandered the outside but well worth the stroll. The building is radiant even on a dreary day, and the fine detail of the building really amazed me. Would have loved to have done a tour.

A Must. I wasn't sure what to expect but being so close to my hotel I thought I'd give a visit.
What an amazing piece of architecture and history. There's no point in me writing on what to expect as it's been done many times before...I'll just say go there. You won't be disappointed.

Thouroughly interesting, educational, and truly spectacular. Family trip to Houses of parliament - took 5y and 8y daughters. Audio tour - family options. Thoroughly enjoyed by all. Children too. Lords chamber spectacular and a superb feeling to be standing in the commons chamber - much history. Audio guides were excellent and kept both children enthused throughout the 4 hour visit.
Such history. The gold colour of the building makes it almost unreal. Not. As big as I though it would be but close to the abbey so it was a lovely walk around to see everything

A Must see place for a British Voter or Tourist. It is a must see place as 1st it is a magnificent building. With many interesting halls, statues and paintings. For a British Voter it is worthwhile seeing as this is where all the British Laws are made and Passed. You can also arrange to meet your MP there to discuss a political matter and they are often pleased to show you around, time permitting.It is a must place to see for any Tourist to London. Unfortunately, due to Terrorists, the security is much stricter and time consuming, than it used to be in the 1960's

Excellent guided tour. Took the booked guided tour. Very well worth the money - a knowledgeable and engaging guide. I thought I knew quite a lot about our Houses of Parliament but learnt a lot more. Only disappointing bit was the shop which I felt could have had a better range of goods on sale.

One of the best tours on our trip. During our visit, we took the guided tour of Parliament instead of the audio tour. The guided tour was fantastic! Not being from England, it was interesting to learn not only about the Parliament building, but also about how the two houses function.
A must see in London, obviously. Pretty pretty and pretty again :) impressive and with all the policemen arround.. typically British. absolute must.

Be sure to Visit. I thought I'd be bored seeing the Parliament...was I ever wrong. It was very interesting and the audio narrative gives you a lot of information. Parliament had the same architect as at Highclere Castle (Downton Abby). I'm glad I didn't miss this great place.

One thing to do before you die!. We went with a blue badge guide who conducted the tour with humour and a sense of occasion. It really is the most amazing place, the paintings alone are awesome. You think you know about the Houses of Parliament but the tour will show you that there is a lot more to know. From the start, (where only in England), a friendly policeman at the gate asks you if you have any "weapons" to declare before going through security to the end of the tour was a wonderful experience. Definitely worth the money.
Fantastic architecture. This is a must if you haven't been. The architecture is amazing. Hard to get it all when taking a photo.

Wonderful. We took the guided tour rather than the audio tour which gets you access to more areas. Very informative and interesting. Stunning architecture and decoration. Not to be missed. Would have loved to have afternoon tea too but we didn't book far enough in advance.

Great experience.. If you do this tour pay for a guide it’s worth the additional cost for a once in a lifetime visit. Also, if you can, plan your visit during a recess as you will see the two main chambers. If you are a UK citizen, you can arrange a visit through your MP.

Amazing. Love London!
Love the architecture and the Houses of Parliament are magnificent
They stand so proud and the photo opportunities are superb
Lots of tourists and expect a billion selfie sticks in your face
Well worth a visit

Tour of The Houses of Parliment. Absolutely wonderful experience enhanced by the fact that we had an extremely knowledgeable friendly & humorous guideExcellent value for money & I would recommend it to anyone who has any interest in history and/or politics

Incredible architecture in the centre of Government. We bought our tickets online (a must) and were ushered in on time. After security checks we passed through the main doors and were given our headsets for our audio guide.Allow 90 - 120 minutes for the tour - anything less would be a waste of time.Photography is allowed in some of the rooms (all noted on the map handed out when collecting audio guides). Mobile phones are not allowed - mine went off and I was extremely embarrassed as a security guard reprimanded me !! This is an incredibly beautiful building with an intricate interior - attention to detail is superb.Can't add anything which might make your visit more enjoyable - they seem to be well organised and the audio guide is a good one with options to learn more on certain topics by following the instructions.

Impressive!. This is a magnificent and impressive building. I took a guided tour, which is only slightly more expensive than the audio tour -- and well worth it I think. Our tour guide was knowledgeable and entertaining as well as easy to follow and thoughtful. I learned a lot of British history and so enjoyed the stories of the use of the rooms throughout the years, the myths and the reasons behind some of the traditions. The senior discount applies not just to British citizens -- and I used the savings to buy the wonderful Guide Book. It has many color photos, history and timelines -- good "post trip" reading. You do have to purchase tickets at an office a couple blocks away from the entrance -- and you need a ticket to enter, so best to be prepared. On a Tuesday, however, there were no long lines or waits.

Calling all Poli-Sci majors. Went into this tour with low expectations but left afterwards with a new found appreciation for the British parliamentarian system, it's intricacies and the unique relationship between the House of Lords, the House of Commons and the monarchy. Our tour guide was incredibly knowledgeable and gave our group many wonderful tidbits of info as well as pointing out all the interesting paintings and sites within the Houses of Parliament. It was a great tour and not one that would have been on my radar had our visiting friend not booked it well in advance.It's certainly suitable for families but probably not for youngsters under the age of 10.

So much to see, so little time. We paid for the guided, blue badge tour. We took one of the later tours of the day (around 430pm) which was well worth it as we had a very small group (about 6 of us, including our three) and there weren't many others inside. The only issue was that there is so much to take in in the time you have allowed. It would be nice to head back afterwards on your own and have a look at the artworks.... One of the setbacks of choosing the last tour for the day though I guess!

Impressive, but monotonous. Good for taking selfies in front of (try out on the bridge for a good view) but the building's size and repetition make it boring after about 5 minutes. And does anyone really know who all those busts of old guys actually are that are scattered all over the surface? A bit too self referential.

London's Finest Landmark. I never tire of this building no matter how many times I visit, it is just magnificent, up close you just marvel at the details and wonder how it was possible to achieve such grandeur with a hammer and chisel! The best way to view is across the river where you get the best vantage point to see this beautiful old building.

Great place to visit. We really enjoyed the Houses of Parliament. We got the audio tour, which I highly recommend. It was very interesting to hear about the history of the Parliament, and how their political system works. I liked the breakdown of the history of all of the rooms, and what takes place in each of them. The inside of the building is beautiful and well kept, while the outside is iconic and speaks for itself. Expect to be here for a couple of hours. Westminster Abbey is right across the street as well, so you could definitely make a half day out of visiting here. I'd definitely come back when I visit London again.

Tour was great. We had a free tour organised by our MP (just write to your MP to get one!) and it was very informative and interesting. The building is fascinating and you get to see The House of Commons and where all the decisions take place!
Impressive. Very impressive buildings - great to introduce the children to where most of the Country's decisions are made.

Amazing!!. I went here on a class trip and it was a brilliant experience! We got the chance to go into the House of Lords and commons which was amazing to see! We fortunately got to meet our local MP - Ed Vasey! We had a tour of the parliament and we were amazed by the interesting features of the building!

Take a tour. The tour was both informative and entertaining and well worth the money. We had afternoon tea on the terrace afterwards. The view was probably better than the food, but an interesting and unique experience.

Surprisingly good sightseeing destination. Surely every tourist will pass by the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben during a visit to London, but just how many ever pause to visit within? Well, we did this time and it was surprisingly good for the whole family (young teenage kids too). Absolutely need to book, but easy to do on line and we took Audio option which was very clear and presented in a light way. You see both Houses and can take your time in the visit. This is a well worth while visit (1-2 hours), and will give new and real perspective next time you see the politicians performing in the Commons.
intersting tour. Managed to book a guided tour of House of Commons/Lords during a short break to London. Well worth the money and very informative and interesting.

Wonderful to see and great commentary. I booked the audio tour for myself and my parents, and after we had had a very reasonably priced,and very nice coffee in the Houses of Parliament coffee shop we went through to collect our audio guides. These were clear, easy to use,and the information was such that we received the highlights but then could listen to extra information if we wished. Absolutely excellent
Book in advance!. Tours are only offered one weekly, so be sure to plan carefully. Definitely worth the effort. They show both houses, many halls. The tour guide was terrific, extensive knowledge.

A fascinating tour.. This is a most worthwhile experience for anyone with even a passing interest in the history of the UK. We took the guided tour, preferring to have a knowledgeable member of staff on hand to answer any questions, but it is also possible to take a 'self guided' one, with commentary provided through headphones.We topped our visit off with a splendid 'afternoon tea' (must be pre-booked) in the House of Commons restaurant right next to the Thames. Unforgettable.
Great visit. Have been to London lots of times but never did this. We did the audio tour. It was very good and the Palace of Westminster is lovely. Good cake in the cafe too.

Great guided tour shame we couldn't wanderround again by ourselves afterwards.. I have been to Prime Minister's Questions a few times, and wanted to see more of this impressive building. We decided on a guided tour, which was a good decision as our guide was knowledgeable and informative. Seeing the Lords and Commons close up, as well as the other magnificent parts of the building, the frescos, murals, sculpture etc. made it worth every penny. Only disappointment was that we were not allowed to wander round again afterwards, a puzzling and frustrating decision by them as we would have liked more time to soak up the atmosphere and look around. It was not busy, so we would not have inconvenienced anyone!

So much history. A friend and I went on an organised tour. I am disabled and we used a wheelchair. First all the staff were lovely nothing was too much trouble. Being their was just wonderful and as the house is resting we could go everywhere (well almost). The guide was very imformative without going on and on. Just so much to see and take in. We both felt it had been a truly great visit and would go again. We then had Afternoon Tea in the Terrace restaurant very good value for the money and after spent a few minutes on the Terrace itself taking in all the views. Couldn't fault the day.

Fascinating tour in a great building. Took the guided tour and found it fascinating. The guide was very pleasant and informative. Obviously it would depend when you go but we were in both chambers and various lobbies and got a good explanation of how everything happens plus the chance to see these iconic rooms.

Gorgeous building. Scaffolding on the building ruined it a little bit but still a beautiful building with lots of history. It was super busy as it was the easter holidays so walking around was a bit of a hassle.

A great tour!. If you get the chance to sign-up for a tour of Parliament, do it! The tour is amazing, the guides are excellent, and the opportunity to stand in the various chambers is once-in-a-lifetime.

I was treated like a VIP. Not sure I should offer my personal experience as a review because my tour of the Palace of Westminster, to give the place its proper title, was not as a tourist or part of any official visitor group.Long story, short version, I am a writer and some of the things I have written are murder mystery type thrillers. One of my stories involved the Prime Minister elect, being murdered on the eve of election victory. Hopefully not a prophesy of things to come next month ! Anyway, at the time what I knew about party politics and Parliamentary procedure you could have written on a fly's butt with a paint brush. Who better to ask than your friendly local Member of Parliament, who through his staff offered to meet me in his office in London. Being somewhat naive I asked for directions, and was told use the London underground service to Westminster, its the big building in front of you DUH !! Upon my arrival my treat started immediately, I had an appointment so I was fast tracked passed the queue of sightseers all the way to main security and once past there I was in, standing mouth open in Westminster Hall, which is the oldest part of the entire palace. The hall is 240 feet long, 68 feet wide and a staggering 92 feet high. There is a large number of magnificent oak beams, spanning the hall with a carved angels looking down upon those below. It is this very hall, that has played such a central role in over 900 years of British history, and where the likes of Sir Thomas Moore, Guy Fawkes and King Charles I were tried and condemned to death.  Of course this is only the way in, and one must climb the stone stairs and turn left and then all of a sudden déjà vu struck me as I entered the Central Lobby, although I had never been there before, everything looked so familiar to me. Not surprising of course, I have seen countless historical TV documentaries about the place, and seen it on the news but nothing, and I really mean nothing prepares you for that moment when you enter here for the first time. The Central Lobby is where people, like me, come to meet their MPs and where visitors come to attend meetings with MPs and Members of the Lords. It is a large octagonal hall and is the central point between the House of Commons and the House of Lords Chambers. A sort of grand crossroads between the Houses of Parliament.On one side there is a statue of Winston Churchill who appears to be the guardian of the entrance to the Commons Chamber. Look at the left foot of the statue and you will see that it is polished. Members of Parliament touch it on the way into the chamber for luck.I will say no more, if you are planning to go and see for yourselves, I would hate to spoil the experience. If you cannot visit in person there is a virtual web tour.  Members' tours are available to UK residents free of charge and must be sponsored by a Member of Parliament (MP) or a Member of the House of Lords. The tours are led by trained guides.Tours are available to visitors from the UK and overseas on Saturdays throughout the year and on most weekdays during Parliamentary recesses including Easter, Summer and Christmas.Also there is this link http://www.parliament.uk/visiting/visiting-and-tours/tours-of-parliament/guided-tours-of-parliament/

Felt in the center of everything. To be there meant a lot to me. As so many important decisions came straight from there and where the center of the world used to be for a long time. Garda changing is fascinating but you have to be there early to get a nice room. Don't forget to bring water (but don't drink too much otherwise you'll have to leave to go to the toilet and your spot will be gone ;-) ), some fruit and enjoy it!

HOUSES FULL OF HISTORY. History is everywhere around you when you stroll through these historic buildings. Be sure to get an interactive audio head set as the pre-recording will help you understand what has gone on over the centuries in the Houses of Parliament.
Interesting tour. An interesting tour with a really competent guide. We also had a very nice Afternoon Tea with a stunning setting.
Regal. Literally and figuratively. It is a jewel on london's crown. A must visit for children and adults alike.
Good views. Awesome architecture. If you are a history buff like me, you would love this place. Spectacular buildings and the Big BEN!!!

Gaze in wounded at this power house. Every time I walk past the Houses of Parliament I cannot help but stop and gaze at its magnificent architecture, speculate at what's occurring inside and breath in such history, wonderful.
Very good experience. We were given a "blue Badge" tour of the Palace of Westminster as a present. This was a very informative experience,well explained and informative.

For your bucket list!. This guided tour of the British Houses of Parliament was way better than expected – really worth the cost of £15 per adult, £10 child 5-15 – probably one of the best tours I’ve ever taken. It should be on any London vistor’s bucket list - easy to book online! It was more than an hour and a half of excellent, fact-filled commentary slanted towards the interests and national background of our group from a guide who really knew his stuff. (We took the francophone tour – expecting it would be a smaller – it was, there were only four of us! - so there were lots of allusions and comparisons with the French system of government, plus important historical figures, like Napoleon. Guided tours also available in: German, Italian, Spanish, Russian and Mandarin). Historical and political gems included the fact that Winston Churchill, First Lord of the Admiralty during the early stages of WWI, assumed responsibility for the debacle at Gallipoli, quit the government, and went to fight as an officer on the Western Front. Don't think you'd find that level of personal accountability in the ministerial ranks of most western government’s today.

Excellent way to spend a couple of hours or more. Beautiful building and so full of history. Excellent audio tour with extra stories if you wanted. I was recommended this tour by my sister and neice and wasn't disappointed. You see all the rooms, where the Queen sits when she opens Parliament and the Black Rod bangs on the door. Just great to see inside such a famous building with so much history. Nice little cafe also to finish the trip with a light bite.

Visit and Afternoon Tea at the Houses of Parliament.
