Taking my 9 year old granddaughter to visit the Houses of Parliament followed by afternoon tea on the Terrace there ,was a very interesting and enjoyable afternoon. I managed to get us booked in with a guide as opposed to having audio. This is a tour well worth taking as both my granddaughter and myself came away knowing a lot more of what actually does take place in this beautiful building.

Way better than I expected. . Booked this as my six year old was asking about Big Ben and as someone who takes an interest in politics thought it would be good to explain and show my kids where decisions about the country were made. We booked an audio tour and I expected to be bored rotten to be honest. Well was I wrong, not only was the audio tour really interesting it explained the history of each room you visit and some facts you would never have thought of happening in a place like this. There are very few restrictions on movement around the building. You can enter both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. You can stand where the party leaders do during PMqs and you really get a feeling for how things work. The staff, from the ladies who gave us our headsets to the security guard who spent a good 5 minutes explaining all about some of the voting systems within the house were outstanding. There is an opportunity to send mail from the post office at the House, it will be stamped the House of Commons which makes an unique gift for £2.43. Much better than I expected and a very rewarding excursion. Will do again for sure.
Cradle of Democracy. If one is lucky to get tickets to the Prime Minister's question time, it makes it a truly memorable visit. The building is perhaps the most beautiful parliament in the world.
Well worth a visit. You need to book a tour first at Portculis House, long tour but first class guide, was surprised at the opulence, it looks grand on TV but it's even grander in the flesh!
Footsteps of Giants!. Very historical visit to the UK Parliament. You really are stepping back hundreds of years in British History.

Visit to House. Lovelyl evening attended a reception. Hospitality was fab everyone was so polite and helpful. Fab architecture. Amazing to se so many well known faces busling about the corridors on the way to one meeting or the other.

Really interesting. The audio tour information was good with the option of getting further information on particular aspects - this was good if you had a key interest in something.Staff around the Parliament were very helpful and knowledgeable.There is a lack of good signage to tell you where to buy tickets - a two minute walk away, across the road and in Portcullis House. This was not obvious and it took a while to get the attention of staff at the gates to the Parliament itself to find this out which was frustrating

Lunch in the House of Commons. My partner and I were lucky to get a table to eat in the members' dining room and weren't disappointed. Food was delicious and our waiter was very knowledgeable about the building; we even got a sneaky peak at the room where they MPs have their afternoon tea. We sat in the 'labour' end for lunch which amused us no end.

SO RICH IN HISTORY. This was an amazing experience. This is what Great Britain is all about - a beautiful historical building steeped in history and fantastic stories and facts. Westminster Hall - Wow! You need to stand in it and just look up and turn around slowly. The colours the architecture - fabulous. So worth a visit.

great audio tour. I decided to take this tour to make my husband happy- and happily I found it quite interesting. The audio tour is extremely pleasant, easy to follow and understand. We have been to London quite a few times and never took this took. My husband is a British history buff and was SOOO excited to actually stand on the floors of BOTH the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Very nice tour and worth the price of admission

Excellent experience. I went with a school trip which was organised by the education department. It was excellent and the students learnt a lot as did I as the teacher. It was an interesting place and you really feel like you are part of history.
Great experience. Had a great time, we had prebooked the visit, very little queing time even though it was very busy, the tour was very interesting, staff very helpful and freindly.
Interesting visit. Very enjoyable visit. We had a guide who gave lots of information and were able to see both the house of commons and house of lords.

Amazing tour. You have two options here. You can book a guided tour in advance or you can take a self-guided tour. The guided tour is far superior. We had a three-generation group of seven and had our own group (they can be as large as 25). We went into all of the main rooms we wanted to see (including the debating rooms of both Houses and the royal rooms. Lots of fun stories and a highlight of our trip to London.
Wonderful building. Great building to look at, simply stunning, walk over bridge and get good photos, walk round towards Westminster Abbey and get more great photos

Great must do visit. Booked and ticket online. Just turned up ten minutes before and with a quick security check we were in Westminster Hall and given the audio. Left to wander round where we wanted to, it was an eye opener. Great architecture, being right at the centre of the Lords and the Commons. You can stand right at the dispatch box and get the real feel of the place. Plenty of people to help and ask about things. Worth every penny!

Fantastic!. I cannot recommend this enough!The tour is very interesting and steeped in history.Stepping through the halls where you know Prime Ministers have walked was very exciting. Seeing the House of Commons and the scene of PMQs was a high point.I would particularly like to recommend the audio guide. Informative, it also lets you complete the visit at your own pace. No one there rushes you. I definitely recommend!
Breathtaking. From photos to seeing it with my own eyes, the Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament is really a beautiful building of art and architecture.

A must see. We paid £18 each for the audio tour. We had to enter through airport style security, but was quite quick. The audio commentary was very informative and it was great to walk through such a place of history. Being able to go into the Commons Chamber was brilliant.The ban on photos in some areas was a little unecessary. Perhaps they could have allowed photography of a few spots, rather than a blanket ban.

Good value for money. There's a choice of doing an audio tour or a guided tour. The audio tour comes with a chiice of kanguage options. I chose to do the guided tour which takes 1 and a half hours.The tour guide was very informative and it was very interesting to see the Houses of Parliament from the inside.The only down side is that due to accoustics it can be difficult to hear the tour guide in a couple of places.

A MUST when in London. I had always wanted to visit the Palace of Westminster and Westminster Hall and now I've done it. It exceeded my expectations by far.The tour started in Westminster Hall. Built in 1099 over 900 years ago, its fabulous hammer beam roof completed in 1399. Through St Stephens Chapel to the Robing room and the Lords. Such rich decor and of course red benches. Then to the more soberly decor of the Commons with green benches.I took the audio guide which was very good and meant you could go at your own pace. Important tip: the stewards are very friendly and helpful and by chatting to them you get some nice little stories which you may otherwise miss. For Example: the Government and opposition benches have red lines in front of them which are two and a half sword lengths apart and if a Member steps on or over the line they are told by the Speaker to 'Toe the line'!!There is just so much wonderful tradition there which some want to modernise. I sincerely hope that NEVER happens.Photography is allowed in the Hall and St Stephens Chapel but nowhere else.

Excellent opportunity to see Parliament at work!. My husband and I visited London and taking Rick Steve's advice, went to see the House of Commons in action. We went at the end of our day as the House of Commons and House of Lords convene into the evening. We were able to see the great entry hall and the "lobby" while making our way to the viewing gallery. It was quite interesting to see and hear the interactions between the parties. If you are not able to take the formal tour of Parliament, this is a wonderful opportunity to get a sneak peak.

Iconic and not to be missed. House of parliament is one of the most visited sites and also most photographed too. The beauty of the place is such that it does attract every eye. No trip to London is complete without a visit to the parliament building but it will be a great idea to probably go along with a tour guide so that you not only get to enjoy the sights but as well as learn all the relevant history to it.

Amazing building, a tourist must see!. The kids absolutely loved seeing the Houses of Parliament, the security around it obviously limits how close you can get but they still enjoyed looking at all the different aspects and asking what happens in there. It is a very impressive structure and a lot bigger than you imagine. The architecture is well worth a look.

Awesome building. Top attraction in the UK, Elizabeth tower is the most photographed building in the world, more so than the Eiffel tower and even the statue of libertyTake time to look at the architecture and the buildings around that area.Roma gangs operate on Westminster bridge, watch you wallets and bags.I saw 5 gangs doing the "Find the pea" con, people are so thick to join in and lose their money IT IS A CON, YOU CAN NEVER WINThe Major of London is failing his duties by failing to address this major problem.
Very recommendable. We did a guided tour in Spanish which was really interesting. The guide told us about the building's history as well as how the British parliament works

Amazing tour!. Great tour around the Houses of Parlament. Very interesting with a brief but very insightful explanation on how legislation in the UK works. You can do it on your own (self guided audio tour) or be shown around (guided tour). Reasonable price. Too bad you can only take photos in selected areas! However, you are allowed to go into certain areas that not even the Queen is allowed to!

Fantastic, a must visit site. We took the tour last year and it is by far one of the best things that I have ever done in London. The buildings are so impressive and it is brilliant to stand in the chambers and in the lobbying hall. The guides are really knowledgeable and the history is just incredible. Highly recommended

My fave London attraction. You can't beat a day at the Houses of Parliament. The history, the scale, the grandeur. It is worth queuing for. Even better, contact your local MP and arrange a guided tour.

Wonderful & SOO worth it!!!!. I am a student who went with friends to do the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, and it was SOO worth it!! Our guide was so amazing! He not only was interesting and had a wealth of knowledge, he connected various sites around London back to things and people that have been or occurred in the Houses of Parliament. After this tour I feel like I know London more than I know my own hometown!

Amazing!. I booked a guided tour of The Houses of Parliament as a treat - he says the experience is "up there with the best". He doesn't praise lightly so it must be true!I highly recommend the human guided tour rather than the audio tour as you get taken to see rooms & areas you wouldn't otherwise go. If you like history and/or politics then this is the tour for you. The surroundings are palatial in places and the whole building, old or 'new' is very well cared for.
good and hystorical place. You must to visit it. it is impressive and interesting place. The Westmeinster bridge was full of people playing stupid games. Where is the police?
Charismatic Structre. We had a chance to tour inside the Palace of Westminster. It is really a breathtaking experience specially when we walked in the house of lords meeting room.

A Wonderful Outing. This was my fourth visit to London and I had never been inside the Houses of Parliament. My family and I took the audio guided tour. The audio guide is engaging and detailed. We found that unlike the guided tours around us, the audio guide allowed us to linger and marvel at the interior. A nice touch was that there was designated seating for those who needed it, in select rooms. The gift shop was small but had several nice items to pick up as souvenirs. Furthermore, the washrooms at the beginning/end of the tour were very clean and accessible. The only drawback was that the ticket entrance for audio tours and large tour groups appeared to be part of the same line. This caused confusion in the line up, as the tour groups blocked the entrance and the audio guide tourists thought they had to wait in line behind them. The security was very kind and indicated that audio guide tourists could skip the line as long as they had a timed ticket.

Great Tour. We went for a tour of he Houses of Parliament. I can thoroughly recommend a tour with an actual tour guide. Our tour was very informative and interesting. It wasn't too long and have lots of useful and interesting information. A great thing to do for UK residents and foreign tourists!
Amazing history. Free conducted tour was excellent, the guides really knew their stuff, Westminster Hall is incredible, testament to the medieval builders
Interesting and educating. The guided tour is very good. The tour take about 1.5 hour, and you get much more then just listening for the audio automatic guide.
strangely obscure. I liked everything inside and outside was there for a meeting very cultural historical and truly amazing arcitechure

Excellent Guided Tour. When we went for our guided tour, we saw some people showing up at the entrance and inquiring about purchasing tickets. Note that tickets are sold at the Ticket Office located at the front of Portcullis House on Victoria Embankment, not at the entrance to the Houses of Parliament.We visited on 1 April. Our guide was Diane. She was extremely informative. She also spoke with great clarity. It was very interesting for us to find out more about the two Houses, how the Parliament works, the architecture, paintings and stories behind some statues. We had coffee and cake after our guided tour in the casual Jubilee Cafe, had a look in the gift shop and bought a book. We had a wonderful afternoon visiting the Houses of Parliament.
Amazing Building. Its iconic, such a pleasure to see. We simply don't make buildings like this anymore which is a shame as its a gem.

Magestic. No matter how many times I saw the building, every time it amazes me. I especially find it beautiful when the sun shines, and the gold parts reflect the light. My dream is to see it from inside as well.
Very interesting. Absolutely fascinating place to visit,and to think so many famous and notable people have graced these halls of majesty is incredible.A must do for the visitor to London.
Something you should really see at some point. A quiet pretty building, it is a site you should 100% visit when in London and there are tours available.

Great Insight Into The UK Government. You will learn so much about how the UK Government works if you visit the Houses of Parliament. You need to book this highly recommended tour in advance and you can do so online. Don't miss this the next time you are in London.

Awesome!. Didn't really know what to expect with an audio tour - it was well organised - we bought our tickets on line and went into the houses of p really smoothly. Was amazing to see everything so close up the commentary was very informative and the children were focused for the whole trip

Inside the Houses stuff of history ... but be ready for a run. Organized a trip to the Houses of Parliament via my local MP (which makes it a free entrance).Entrance was very well indicated ... went through airport security and had to have a nice picture (not) of myself made into a pass.The tour was really comprehensive .... from the Old Hall (where the Kings use to play 'real Tennis' in .... and now where foreign dignitaries address MPs) .. to the House of Commons and Lords. Really, really interesting from the art to the stories that where related.The only problem is the speed of the tour (and quite a lot of steps) ... many of the older members of the tour seemed to be lagging behind ... and you wish that you linger just a little more. I suppose there is a tight time turnover .... oddly enough meet the guide in the men's toilet just after the tour ... maybe that was the other reason for the speed.

Timeless. Visited with our local MP and a group of friends. It is like being in a Time Machine knowing that you are walking in the footsteps of so many people who have shaped history and admiring the architecture and statues. History brought to life

brilliant audio tour. A really fantastic tour of the Houses of Parliament, giving a history of buildings and Government since 13th Century and earlier. You can wander around both chambers and learn about the procedures and history of Parliament. Go early it starts getting very crowded.
A great visit. I was lucky enough to be asked to dinner here, had a great tour then dinner in a private room hosted by a MP fantastic night.

Who knew you could visit?. Being quite apolitical I had never thought of visiting but thoroughly enjoyed the day. We were shown around by a wonderful guide who delivered interesting facts for the 10 / 11 year olds we had with us.
Brilliant tour. This is a great tour and an insight into the chambers of those who should have our interests looked after.Some lovely touches around the venue and really knowledgeable staff.

Get your tour tickets in advance. We did a 9:30 am tour and loved it. I definitely recommend a tour with a guide vs the audio tour from a human perspective. You need to book your tickets in advance because they sell out. Seeing where British politics take place was enlightening.

Guided tour was absolutely incredible. I took a guided tour from a lady called Liz, who was absolutely incredible. Her knowledge of the history of the building, the Westminster system and the UK really brought the building to life. I hope she continues these tours because she is a credit to the Parliament. I highly recommend paying the extra money for the guided tour as you get much more out of your visit.

Amazing tour of a majestic complex!. Do the guided tour. You get to see more of the building. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and educated us on the British style of governance (we are from the US). Every room is more amazing than the next. Don't forget to look up in each room to see the beautiful artwork and detail. One of the best parts of our visit.
a bit of waiting but worth it. Very interesting. Especially the occasion of witnessing actual debates in the parliament. Give a good and accurate sense of British spirit.

Surprising. Loved the House of Lords and the Commons. The guided tour was the best and learnt a lot. I didn't know how biased the house of lords was and that half the government isn't elected by the people ( sound a bit sus really). Fantastic decor and history.

Stunning with a sense of wonder in the establishment of Democracy. I've been to parliament on a number of occasions, but only the Terrace. This time I took the tour and I was in AWE of the sense of history and the birthplace of what I'd call modern democracy. From the Great Hall to the debating chamber, this does not disappoint to provide the sense of history and power of politics and our wonderful country. I don't know if there's amfee as I was an invited guest. But I would go again.

Here's the place from which the Empire was run.. Didn't go inside, and not sure it would be allowed, but a walk-around the outside will show you outstanding architectural features, and a gilded equestrian statue of Richard the Lion Heart, England's most revered King (although he spent a total of only 10 months in England between campaigns, and he spoke French). Make this part of a walking tour of this area,.
Many restrictions. Photographs are not allowed in the best places inside the monument and so it does not worth the price.

Great example of British architecture. Great example of historical architecture. Visit is by tour only and tickets can be purchases from a ticket office a short distance away. Security is understanably high but not intrusive. Surround yourself with the great era of the Westminister political system

Unexpectedly, maybe our favorite tour!. If you're a fan of the spattering of history-based movies and television shows about the British monarchy, you'll appreciate the tour of the Houses of Parliament. Right across the street from Westminster Abbey, and heavily-guarded, as you'd expect (though I found that aspect reassuring in this day and age). You must arrange your tickets on-line in advance, and I believe we may have been required to produce I.D. Small inconveniences for the pay-off. Very knowledgeable tour guides take you through the former castle and modern-day government building. (This tour was offered in at least 4 languages during our visit.) Favorite parts included the long hall with all the large paintings of the monarchs (and the anecdotes about many our guide peppered into his narrative----- King George of Hanover never even bothered to learn English!). Lots and lots of walking on hard floors, so come prepared for that. Very nice little cafe on your way out. Stop in for tea and cake and ask your kids what they liked the best!
Can't get in but loved the infrastructure. Didn't go in as foreign tourists are not allowed... However, loved the infrastructure and the location of it. Beautiful place to see.

Beautiful interior and understand the parliament system. First challenge is to get the tickets for guided tour. Went to the visitor entrance and was directed to elsewhere, it's not a easy job to walk against the crowd. By the time we were there, English guided tour was sold out for the day and we had to make do with audio guides. The moment you enter the building, you will be fascinated by the hall of palace of Westminster, now full of plaques on historical moments. The audio guides allow a understanding of the house of commons and the house of lords, though I think the guided tour will be more ideal in explanation. especially for this anniversay year, the understanding of what happened during the time for magna carta and why there are certain practice for house of Commons come out real strong. Love it.

Worth a visit by all. The nearest subway station is Westminster, the best way came by yellow lane , or you could use the bus . if you will taxi , some times you will suffer from the jam in the London roads.i went there when i was in london in 14-march-2015. you must book your tour early because could be full booked or parliament members busy.it nice tour & worth visit
Nice building. Nothing much to do there, just to take picture outside this historical/famous in the world buidling.It is near the Westminster, Big Ben, u'd come across it anyway.
Worth the Wait.. The Prime Minister happened to be there, so it was a good showcase for his political skills. Good sparring, although not so nasty as our Congress.

Free tour through your MP. I e-mailed my MP six months ago to arrange a free tour of the Houses of Parliament. It was worth the forward planning. After passing through security we went to Westminster Hall from there there is access to a cafe, a shop and toilets. We then met up with our tour guide. There were 8 of us on our tour, which lasted 75 minutes. We saw the Royal Chambers, House of Lords and House of Commons before arriving back in Westminster Hall. We had a very informative tour guide and it was great seeing this seat of power. Really recommend it.
Worth a visit by all.. Liked everything. It is superb. Learnt a great deal from our guide and enjoyed the additional information that you would not get from any guidebook.

Recommend all should visit. Pre booked through my MP's local office. Timed arrival then taken on a very good guided tour by a guide who was knowledgeable and interesting.Quite a lot to see - tour takes about 1.30mins. and on the MP Educational tour you get to see most places. There are limited places for these tours so contact your MP and find out when the next available tour is (No cost).This is something everyone should see as is genuinely interesting and we all pay for it. You can also book through commercial companies at a fee (not sure how much).For obvious reasons security is high and expect to go through a similar security routine to that at an airport. Recommended.

A Must See. Turned up on speck. Granted entry. Got there at 1400hrs, in time to see the Speakers procession. Went to the visitors gallery. Spent two hours listening to topical debate and statement from both main party leaders. Particularly liked the live TV streaming, with subtitles, and a note of the name and constituency of the speaker. This in particular, added to the experience.
Amazing Views. What a walk through history. Knowing what goes on here is just amazing. The views of the house of parliament were just amazing.

Wonderful experience. Pre booked this visit which meant very short waiting time before the tour began. It was a really interesting tour and quite awesome to be in such an iconic and historical building.

Really worthwhile. Took the kids for the audio tour on Saturday. We pre-booked online and were impressed that the entry and security process was pretty quick and smooth. There was a bit of a queue for the audio sets but staff walked up and down the line explaining the reason for the delay and offering anyone who didn't want to wait the chance to go around with a tour guide instead. We were impressed with how much you are able to see and the House of Lords is breathtaking. It is very exciting to be able to stand in the House of Commons. Even the teenagers enjoyed it. It's really very well priced for the experience.
You need to see it!. known from the postcards, you need to make sure you make it to see that view live! Big Ben, London Eye, all a walking distance from there!

Perfect. We, with the help of an MP, launched our company in the House of Parliament.
It was an amazing experience and I would love to go back.
We walked round and had a little look at thing - must see
Inspiring. Like most of London, the architecture of these buildings is quite beautiful. It can get quite crowded around this area - I think morning visits are best.

A Short History Lesson. A brilliant guided tour by the knowledgeable Sarah. We decided on the guided tour in preference to the audio tour as we thought it would suit us better and how right we were. The tour is scheduled for about an hour but we were still touring nearing two hours. Well worth a visit and good value.
very informative. Excellent tour and worth every penny to hear the history of England/UK. This gives an insight to how we ended up with the constitional system we have, I can't recommend high enough.

Something you should not miss. The tours of the Houses of Parliament in London, in English and in Spanish, are a must. You see the incredible chambers and you learn about History, politics and architecture.

Amazing, interesting visit, but ripoff afternoon tea! . This was such a great place to visit. We had an audio tour, which was great as we could go at our own pace. It was very informative and interesting, and we learnt a lot. My husband had also booked afternoon tea, which we were both looking forward to. What a disappointment, 2 x 1 inch square "sandwiches", plus the same size roll, each, one scone each, again about 1 inch, a delicious chocolate tart and a shot glass of Eton mess. It was all delicious but for £27 each, not worth it at all. Such a shame. We weren't even offered more tea, or water for the pot. We will not be recommending this part of the tour. This would have got a 5 star , but tea let it and us down.

Big Ben and Westminster...great photo opportunity!. Okay for all you tourists out there...like myself you have to swing by these landmarks just for the pics, these places are even grand in person. I will advise however, that the Parliament only will allow you inside on Saturdays, for a walking tour of the premises. Otherwise, you have to settle for an outside photo only!!

Facinating. Don't let the tour price dissuade you, this is a must-see. It is easily the most obvious hidden gem in this city. One of the most recognized buildings in the world, but surprising how few people realize it is open for tours any time that Parliament is not in session, including every Saturday. You get thorough tour of both houses and their 800 year history. Excellent.

Book through your mp for a free tour. If you email your mp in advance saying when you'll be in London they'll arrange for you to go on a free group guided tour. Well worth a visit, so much history & the buildings are amazing. Guides are v knowledgeable.
Nothing beats the architecture. I was sight seeing ad must say the architecture here is amazeball. I loved it lots. It was coldwhen i went so walking around wascool, literally lol

Private tour by local MP. Loved - Got to see the secret chapel - absolutely amazing place hidden away. Small but fantastic. Sitting in on the Commons and Lords questions, afternoon tea in the Pugin room, standing on the terrace overlooking the thames. Disliked - not being able to see more

Houses Of Parliament. We had the most amazing experience of seeing the Houses of Parliament on the Original Bus Tour and by taking the riverboat cruise. Such a relaxing way to visit places of interest.

sightseeing. What an awesome sight looks better close up. Didn't, go inside. No need the sights outside are all we needed. There were thousands of people's about of all denominations. With the Thames so close it is t he capital to visit.

Amazing insight into the history of British politics.. I would strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance either online or at the Ticket Office by Westminster Bridge, as you cannot purchase tickets at the entrance gate.The stewards at the entrance gates would benefit from some training as to the facilities inside. We were told there were no public toilets inside and the nearest were at the Railway Station by Westminster Bridge. After going through Airport type security, we entered Westminster Hall and saw toilets near the gift shop!We did the audio tour which was excellent, easy to follow with lots of detail and lots of extra information. The number signs along the tour which linked to the different parts of the commentary were not always clearly visible. Some of the staff were very abrupt when ushering tourists around. The architecture in this historic building is breathtaking and a real national treasure. You get a real insight into the workings of The Houses of Commons and Lords. The audio tour takes about 90 minutes, but it is really not suitable for young children.
Architecture. The architecture of this place is amazing and really makes you smile. I love london and love looking at the Houses of Parliament along with Big Ben.
Informative and inspiring. It was an extremely informative tour of a beautiful, historical building. Truly worth a visit. Not sure how suitable for young children.

One of My Favorite Things to See in London!!. This was one of my favorite things to see while in London. We arranged and paid for a small group guided tour. Our guide took us to various parts of Parliament. It wasn't in session, but we were allowed to go on the floor of the House of Lords and House of Commons. This was so impressive to see it live. When you are on the floor, you can actually picture in your mind the workings of Parliament. Our guide was very knowledgeable about the current topics being debated and the history. You need to book this before arriving in London. They have guided tours on certain days depending on the language you speak.
very impressive. Amazing architecture and very impressive workmanship.not my usual hangout but really would recommend as tour of this place as it is unique and amazing
Pmq. a great occasion to watch. You need to contact your local MP to request tickets to PMQ. Sometimes it is a few months wait.

Impressive visit. We went as a group of 8 with our local MP who had arranged a tour of both houses, an hour listening to Ministers question time, then lunch in the Strangers dining room. The tour was excellent and it was fascinating to get a glimpse if the workings of Parliament.
Great, for history buffs. Good for the whole group, but perfect for history buffs and anglophiles. The Saturday tour takes you right through the House of Lords and the House of Commons.

If you like British History, well worth a visit.. I went with a group of friends, on a day out in London. We were fortunate to secure the services of one of several tour guides, a very amusing Cockney, with lots of stories to tell, and with a fund of knowledge about the Houses of Parliament and British history. It was a great learning experience as well as a fun afternoon.

A "Must See". If you're visiting London you must go see the House of Parliament. I have seen many pictures prior to the trip like most, but to see it in person really is amazing. Beautiful architecture and busy streets add to the experience. Make sure to cross the bridge and take pictures from the other side of the Thames in order to get the full experience.
Amazing!. The architecture is stunning!The tour is quite interesting too but maybe not for children as it might become a bit boring for them.
Wonderful sight. if you are into architecture then this is one of the places to go - plenty to see around here - the statues in parliament Square as well - lots of history

The Mother of All Visits!. I've visited the Houses of Parliament numerous times: on my own, with family and also with organised groups. I visited St Stephen's Tower, seen the clock workings within it; stood next to Big Ben as it struck (it wasn't terribly loud...just vibrated a lot), and had tea on the Member's Terrace, courtesy of my MP. I've had an official guided tour, which is worth undertaking, as there is a great deal of history attached to the buildings.The shops within are a must for that special souvenir!!

A guided tour of The Houses of Parliament. I only recently became aware it was possible to take a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament and after an internet check of the options, I chose to take a guided tour as opposed to an audio tour since I thought that this would provide more information and give the opportunity to ask questions. A tour can only be made when parliament is in recess and at this time of year, Saturdays only, but I was able to easily book a week in advance of my visit.I arrived about half an hour in advance of my allotted time at the Cromwell Green visitor entrance and after the security check the group of around 20 met in Westminster Hall with our excellent guide, Richard. The tour effectively follows the route the Queen takes for the State opening of Parliament starting in the Robing Room, through the Royal Gallery, House of Lords, Central Lobby, Members Lobby and the House of Commons Chamber. The highlights for me were the Houses of Lords and Commons and whilst we were not allowed to sit, we were pemitted to walk up the galleries and stand in front of the benches while Richard gave very interesting information about tradition and history. In the Commons it was possible to stand in front of the Despatch Box and just for a few moments look up at the galleries and think of the statesmen who have stood there over the years making important speeches. It was also possible to stand alongside the Speaker's chair and imagine putting the MP's in their places, (or trying!).The tour in total took and hour and forty five minutes and I loved every one of those minutes. I would like to return but next time, through my MP, seeing PMQ's.

Highlight of any London trip!. Managed to secure a private visit via parent's MP - his Parliamentary Assistant gave a wonderful 2-hour tour starting from the Portcullis Building across the street. Granted this would not be a typical experience but probably did 80+% of what occurs on a paid tour.I never really realised what opulence lies within those walls! Was able to see both the Commons and Lords plus other "working areas". We were there late-morning on a Monday and seemed to be a lot of school groups with attendant noise & distraction but not enough to make things a hassle.Allow two hours. Nice little gift shop and cafe on the way out.
much more than expected. Tour well worth it for adults / teenagers, not good for small children. Large range of languages covered, a big plus in the UK !

Great and Big ben was Lovely. Has a lovely day around Westminster visiting Houses of Parliament and looking at all the surrounding land marks, took a lovely walk along the Thames and over Westminster Bridge, lots to see and lots of seats to sit and watch the world and people go by, would recommend a visit

Interesting Tour. This was an interesting guided tour of the Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament) lasting around 90 minutes. The tour was taken by a guide who obviously was very knowledgeable about the building and its workings. We were taken into the house of lords and the house of commons, as well as many other interesting rooms.
must see. great tour. so much history and impressive access to the building. spent hours here and recommend it as a must see in London
Trationational Horse Parade in parliament house. Wow wow great and nice to see Horse and soldiers parade in front of Parliament house ,early morning is nice show to see in London.

Breath taking. Simply a slice of history with a current affair twist. Allow time to get through the security and submerge yourself in British splendour. Hard at times to hear our guide above the voice of other guides but amazing to walk around something to stir emotion in us all.

A highlight of our trip. We pre booked an English tour on Saturday at 10:40. There were only 2 English speaking tours available. Go to the Cromwell green entrance and show them your voucher. There is security there so don't bring large bags. You will receive a security tag necklace to be worn at all times. Go to the main hall and check in. Isabel was our tour guide and she gave us a wealth of information about Parliament and the workings of the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The two rooms are so different with the 800 member House of lords having quite ornate and beautiful surroundings as compared to the very basic House of Commons. There are no photographs allowed except in the first two rooms. It was interesting to see where Churchill and the Queen Mother laid in state. I bought a very good pictorial book on Parliament in the bookstore for just 5 pounds. We thought this tour was fantastic! The actual tour lasted a little over an hour.

A Little bit of history. Well worth paying for a guided tour which lasts about 90minutes.Having lived in London for many years thus was my first visit. I certainly got to learn much that I did not know before!Why is it called house of commons? Where did "lobbying" come from?Get the answers and many others as well
Wow and wow. This was one of my london stop and see places. After seeing it on the news for so many years i had ro go and see the real thing.

a must to do !. well organize, you go at your own peace, better on a week day! maybe you can see a debate! time slot do not work exactly by the hour, so if you go like 1/2 hour early you will have more that the predicted! enjoy it!
No Doubt It's Fascinating. I'm really amazed of how England preserved the richness of its culture and heritage. . Every places and buildings are truly an amazing scenery.

Worth a second visit. I took the tour on my 2013 holiday, and it was so good that when I returned in 2014, had to do it again. For an American visiting and not knowing that much about British history and politics, it was a fascinating introduction.

If you see only one thing - see this!. This is quintessential London. The architecture is phenomenal and quite impressive to see in person. The tour of the inside also sheds some real light into the inner workings of British government.

Great efficient customer service and a breathtaking building. Security clearance was fast, all staff very friendly and helpful, smiling and courteous. Too much to see and if interested in how laws are made sitting in the gallery at the House of Lords was most informative.

Weekend Break. I can't believe all the times I've visited London and never made a visit. We did the audio tour which was very easy straight forward.
I liked how the made the tour very interesting from start to finish.
After the tour I felt very proud to be British.

Last minute tour. Excellent! Took the audio tour as a last minute tour on saturday am.
Very informative, kids loved it.
Was easy to follow and took just over an hour.
Would recommend.

amazing place to work. Went to Parliament for a launch event - and got sucked into the tourist thing of taking photos etc. What a place. Imbued with history. Amazing things to do. Must take a tour next time I'm down there.

Well worth a tour. great history very interesting tour, lots to see
Cheap bar if you are invited in by a MP great wine and fabulous view cross the Thames
understanding of the countries politics

Must See. Any introduction needed? Likely the best known building in the World! Big Ben, Parliament and Westminster Abbey. Any more history needed? Want to breath the air of world political power? That's the place to be..

Iconic stunning architecture!. As with Big Ben, who lives at the corner, the Houses of Parliament are a must see when visiting London. The architecture itself is mesmerizing and amazingly beautiful. And just opposite is Westminster Abbey. This corner alone is worth an entire day!

interesting and very much a working place - great visit. History and day to day running of the country - children interested in all the action - loved the great hall where Charles 1 spoke, then a few years later I think Obama??

Well worth a visit to enjoy our heritage. Having been here a couple of times for work based functions it was nice to be given a guided tour and enjoy looking at our heritage. There is so much history in the place and sitting waitching debates in both Houses was enlightening with there different atmospheres. If you can get yourself on a tour you should do it it makes you realise how important places such as this are in shaping our daily life.

The architecture and oppulance takes your breath away. i have often seen inside on the tv, and to see it in real life is amazing. I could have looked around all day, there is so much to see, and to read about. My son who is 6 enjoyed it too, and its great there is an audio tour made for him. Would recommend this place, although it is pricey if you are a group of adults.. kids go free.
Watched Parliament. Really enjoyed hearing the debates in House of Commons. Able to be part of an historic event without the admission fees.

Meet an MP. Met an MP known to the family and enjoyed coffee in the Members area. The architecture of this very old building is superb, A visitor can access the H of P either by arrangement through their MP or by paying for a guided tour. See the beautiful House of Lords and witness a debate in the House of Commons (for which you need to book tickets). Witness the Speaker Procession before Parliament is formally in session!

Great self guided tour. Wow, what a place. I did not expect they would let us walk through the house of lords and the chamber of commons too. The audio guide is extremely well made and makes this a memorable experience. I am glad i came early on a saturday morning. Not to be missed.
Private tour. Stacked full of history. A must if you get chance.Like: historyDisliked: having to leave and expected level of security....

So interesting. Visited on a school politics trip and it was amazing to actually be inside the Houses of Parliament. We got to see the debate on air strikes in September 2014 and even got a glimpse of David Cameron and Nick Clegg. Really worth the time.

A must se!!. When travelling to London you are very spoiled for choice of things to see and do. One of my top picks while staying in London is a visit and tour of the Houses of Parliament. The first time i went I was on a coach tour that was part of a London city tour which I highly recommend. When part of a coach tour you have a guide who is giving you all the real information you want, as well as we did not have to wait in line at any of our stops The Houses of Parliament are rich in history but also absolutely gorgeous

Historical views. Nothing I can say will match viewing the fine building yourself, although very busy everyone seemed to be there for the same reason (sight seeing as an example) and as such there was much courtesy in place which made it absolutely fine good picture taking opportunities to boot!!
Beautiful. I have not much more to say than: I am not sure why this building isn't one of the wonders of the world. It is mesmerising.

Quite a sight. It is marvelous to take it all in... in all its grandeur. I'm not a history, political, or architectural buff so I don't think I appreciated it as much as my counterparts would. It's definitely worth standing in front of and contemplating the time and effort it took to make such structure!
High tea in high chembers. A comprehensive tour of Parliament with tea and wine at the end. Well worth the time, the money and the effort.

Degree Student visit. Although I am not into politics, as part of my degree there was a planned visit. I found the houses of parliament a very interesting place and if you are interested in British history then this is a place for you!
great. great sight. walked around, lots of people but not too many. amazing history and lots of photo opportunities.

Pretty interesting. I went on a trip with friends and we got a very friendly tour guide. We learnt a lot about the history of the building and what all the rooms were used for. The architecture is amazing!

Be Sure to Take the Tour. You'll quickly learn that regardless of your country, politicians love to hear themselves talk. The tour is done only on Saturdays most of the year, and is very informative and well worth taking. You'll learn about the history of Parliament and how the UK government functions. You'll also get some fun "gossip" about some of the things which have happened in the past within the chambers.

Amazing History and Beautiful Architecture. What an interesting place this is! You've seen it on the outside, but the inside is even more intriguing and beautiful. The audio tour took about 90-120 minutes (depending upon how in-depth you go), and I learned a lot about UK government in addition to the history and importance of the building.This is a great option for individuals or families, and reasonably priced for what you see.
Interesting and informative personal tour. Booked through my MP so it was free. Went in some rooms that the regular tours don't go in. We had a personal tour! The best apple cake ever in the cafe.

Lunch in the Lords. Special treatment! In the company of 2 Lords; 5 MP's;Delightful lunch overlooking the Thames. Brief guided tour and access to the public gallery in the Commons.A wonderful place to visit and proud to be British.
Excellent!. Visited twice, House of Lords in session and a complete tour.Enjoyed the history and the grandeur of the mother of all parliaments.
Full of History. The architecture is amazing and full of history. I would recommend this a place to put of your visiting list of London.

well worth a visit. Great way to learn about how this became the seat of power and to walk through the iconic rooms! We booked the guided tour and it was worth having someone explain and describe as you went from place to place.

It's full of wonderful things . Wanted to stay longer to soak everything in. Very informative tour with each room as fascinating and awe inspiring as the next. Wish it was possible to stay longer in each room/hall/corridor to really see it all properly..would go back tomorrow

Should have booked a real guide. Audio was good but we got a bit overwhelmed by all of the information. Being from the US, it was not just a lot of history, art and architecture, but also trying to grasp an entirely u familiar governmental structure. Tours are only open on Saturdays. Need to figure out when they are in session so you can go and watch them in action during the week.
Nice. I went here last month as part of my holiday trip, just one of my to do list options, the parliament is something which you just really have to come and see for yourself, i had a great time.
Houses of Parliament. Very interesting tour of the Houses of Parliament. Rich in history and one of the most interesting places I have ever visited... and I'm NOT into politics! Worth a visit!

Great tour. In the summer of 2014, I took some of my work colleagues from overseas on a tour of Parliament. Got tickets via ticketmaster. People were just in awe and still talk about it. The guides were very informative and entertaining. Great value.

Impressive. Just a beautiful, old building with a fabulous history that belies the farcical carries on behind the facade. There are trips round - ask your local MP before travelling!! Hard to believe that they have been lost if Guy Fawkes had got his way!!

Fascinating and Excellent Visit. Absolutely terrific visit with surprisingly thorough access to both Houses. You can either book a blue badge guide or opt for a less expensive self audio guide. Our guide was very knowledgeable and full of funny anecdotes. The only minor complaint was the noise of the visitor hosting and security staff chatting away in the background which was somewhat distracting.

I loved this so much I wanted go back and do it again!. Ok so I will start by saying I am a politics geek, and as I am from New Zealand (our political system is largely based on the Westminster system) I loved seeing where it all happened. So with that in mind you may understand why I had so much fun here. I booked online a few months before to do the guided tour - you need to choose a day and time. Once through security the tour starts in the beautiful Westminster Hall (where you can take photos of yourself standing where William Wallace, Queen Elizabeth, Nelson Mandela and Obama have all stood. The tour winds through St Stephens Hall and to the Lobby (where I found out why lobbyists have that name). We walked to the Southern most buildings where the Queen enters when she visits Parliament - just the wall paintings and ceiling of the Robing Room alone have a thousand stories to tell of the history of the historical relationship between the Crown and Parliament. Back through the red House of Lords (which has the throne where the Queen opens Parliament each year) through to the green House of Commons. As I stood in the House of Commons (which physically does not have enough space for all the Members of Parliament) I thought about how much the buildings had shaped political practice here, and in some ways had limited the ability of Parliament to change with the times. At the end of the tour I wanted to go back through and wander about like those who had opted for the audio-tour, but they told me I couldn't go back. This was disappointing - next time perhaps I will do the audio-tour so I can take my time. The guided tour does take you to rooms that are off limits to the audio-tour, so both options have their benefits. The buildings are beautiful and the history so rich that I imagine that people who are not politics geeks will enjoy it.
Palace of Westminster. The buildings, paintings, statues are all stunning and as good as you will find in any major city in Europe.

An eye opener. Booked this for a rainy day treat for my husband and it did not disappoint.The security is very tight but all done very efficiently. We booked the audio guide so we could do it all at our leisure. It is amazing to see the places we normally see on the tv but we were surprised at how small it all looks. Interesting to hear all the commentary and being sable to walk where the Queen walks when she makes her big speeches and where dignitaries are received and manke their speeches. Despite the recent reports of it all crumbling down, we remarked on how spotlessly clean it was everywhere - not a spot of dust to be seen. We will go back but but a live guide so we can ask questions!

Most recognizable Gothic structure on earth. Looks exactly like the pictures, and easy to photograph from many angles. For the best shot, though, you have to go across the river and get a down-river angle. Sunrise or mid-morning allow better contrast.

London at it's best. A truly remarkable place, full of history and a privilege to visit the seat of Democracy.Words do not do justice to simply describe the architecture and the essence what this institution represents. You must simply go and see it for your self.
parliament. well worth a visit,the guide made it very interesting you found out things you wouldn't know. It is nice to see were the lords sit and the Queen sits for the opening of Parliament.

A visit to the Commons and Lords. What was not to like? Steeped in British history, superb architecture and guided by a knowledgeable chap, we first visited the Common before we were booted out for Prime Ministers Questions. The Lords was surreal. After seeing these places on TV, you sort of expect them to massive, but in reality, they were quite compact. It would have been nice to be able to sit down in both of the houses and also to be able to snap the odd souvenir photo. The airport style security is unfortunately a necessity, but the staff were very friendly. Overall a superb visit

Interesting to the two Chambers. Good to visit the heart of UK Parliamentary democracy and see the two Chambers, the Woolsack in the Lords, the bars and restaurants available to MPs/Lords . The Westminster Hall is very impressive.

Very impressive, need to take the tour to take it al in. I went there walking, and by doing that, you'll get impressed by the rich history of Westminster. However, if you take a tour you'll learn more and you are able to see more details. My tour was one which covered only a small piece of the Westminster environment so I missed a lot (I think). Next time I will take the organized tour at the house of Parliament.

inside the parliament. I did the guided tour in English and totally recommend it. You learn about the history of Parliament and the way British democracy works, plus some interesting traditions and ceremonies that take place in Parliament. I feel very proud of having been able to visit it!
Very interesting. Á very good view of political history, audio guide is good, very interesting. Need to be booked. Open on saturdays

Home of Her Majesty's Government.. Book tickets in advance and be prepared for a long wait to get in due to the intrusive but necessary security checks. Once all this hassle is over you should have a great tour of these iconic buildings.I have done this twice now and would recommend anyone with an interest in history or the workings of Government to go.This place is not called 'Houses of Parliament' but it seems almost everyone uses that title nowadays. It is the 'Palace of Westminster'. The 2 Houses, Lords and Commons, debate and vote here in their respective chambers and this is the face of Parliament most people will recognise from media reporting and television pictures. Most work is done in the committee rooms, a side of government less well-known to many.The public may attend debates and committees but it is best to get there early to queue for the weekly 'Questions to the Prime Minister', which can often seem like theatre rather than government.It is best to check in advance when tours are available or what debates/committees are on.Only UK citizens may ascend Elizabeth Tower (formerly known as The Clock Tower or wrongly as Big Ben) and this must be arranged months in advance through the local Member of Parliament.

Very interesting. Myself and 6 friends booked a guided tour as part of our Christmas present to each other . I was not sure what to expect . Our guide was Suzanne Whitting - what a wealth of knowledge - she really engaged with the group - I was worried my mind might wander but she did not just waffle on as if reading from a text - she knew her stuff and put it over in a way all could understand . Our tour was followed by afternoon tea in the terrace area - this was a little disappointing - not dreadfully good value for money but was part of the day out and the views are spectacular - almost as if you were on a boat on the Thames ! I would take the tour again as there was lots to take in but would not partake in the tea agaiThe gift shop had some fab items and was reasonably priced . Overall a great outing

PMQ's. An interesting observation on our glorious leaders and decision makers...Whilst they are always going to be divisive characters it's nice to experience the tradition that underpins this place.Well worth a visit...
Beautiful from the outside!. Wish we could have been allowed in! What a wonderful piece of architecture! Such history. We saw this on our tour with Adrian!

Even better with a guide. We were honoured to be shown round by a political adviser to our local MP so we saw the lot and, obviously, heard a fair bit of "off the record" comments.The décor inside is every bit as stunning as the architecture and to be in the actual chambers - to see where the queen is robed before the state opening - even to see the hundreds of pigeon holes for post. It was a thrilling visit.
houses of parliament. Very interesting and well worth visit.Tour guide very good and well knowledgeable.Nothing to dislike.

Quite an Education. We were privileged to have a private tour. Nothing prepared me for the education I acquired this day and joys of democracy on "the other side of the big pond." A must must tour! Allow yourself plenty of time. I'll await opening of Parliament with baited breath now...visualizing where the Queen robes and walks to and how the entire process works. Being on a private tour..we were also able to go out where Parliament members may tea. As everywhere else..the stories behind the protocol was so much fun to hear about. Also an incredible view of London from here. We didn't climb Big Ben....but being that close was impressive!

Quite an experience. I had the pleasure of dining here during an Alumni event and I was thoroughly impressed both by the standard of the food and by the lovely architecture and decoration. Truly an outstanding experience. The outside facade is well-worth seeing as well, with its famous Perpendicular Gothic design.

Excellent. One of the best visits I've done. The history and splendour of this magnificent building is shown very well in this visit. The guides were most knowledgeable. I would rate this as one of the "must do" tours of London.

What an experience! Take the tour its amazing. attended a conference here and was lucky enough to take the guided tour at the end of our day. For those who like history and/or politics I can't recommend this tour highly enough, the Palace of westminster and house of commons is very impressive and the house of lords is simply stunning. Our guide was so enthusiastic and the history of this place is just amazing. One of the bucket list items ticked
Tea on the Terrace at Houses of Parliament.. I won this trip in a raffle to have a tour of the HoP and tea on the terrace with our local MP. The tour was great loved it.
beautiful. Did the audio tour very interesting and informative. The building is stunning .reasonably priced as child goes free with paying adult.A very enjoyable few hours out of the rain

Great tour. Had a great afternoon at the Houses of Parliment, a real insight to the mechanics of how and why parliterians do what they do, a short history trip also and astounding facts - it's a good job we're British !

When can I go to PMQs...?. We went for the self guided audio tour on a beautiful afternoon at the beginning of March and I was overwhelmed by the beauty and grandeur of the surroundings. Added to the aesthetic of the buildings is the very real sense that you are truly standing in a place that has been and continues to be an important part of our history. Standing on the spot where Charles I was sentenced, passing under the gilt mosaics of the Central Lobby and into the Robing Room, you feel as if you're walking in the footsteps of greatness, sometimes madness, majesty and power. The audio tour was fascinating - informative and interesting without being dry, and with input from experts who work in the the Houses - from the clockmaker responsible for the chimes of Big Ben to the Speaker of the House of Lords. Great way to spend an afternoon.

This truly does have it all.. Architecture... Probably one of the most famous political powerhouses in the world. Easily identified by it's glorious stonework; that clock (it still tingles my spine whenever it chimes), History.... Not just the politicians who have walked these hallowed halls. (Churchill has to be top of the list, hotly followed by Thatcher) but how the building came into being and how the Lords and the Commons evolved. Royalty... her Majesty walks here, dons attire here, sits here, speaks here. (It's almost reverential). The list is endless. A magnificent building, superb guides to escort around and answer EVERY questions we could put to her. You have to go! I shall certainly go again. One visit really isn't enough. Splendid. Thank you.

Wonderful trip. This is a must do! We spend a couple of hours in the Palace of Westminster, including House of Lords and House of Commons. You get an audio guide to wear as you go around so you get all the facts while visiting at your own pace.

A Must!. I went inside as part of uni trip and it's so historical, fancy, very impressive. You feel inside an old royals movie. It's worth taking notes and mental pictures since unfortunately they are prohibited inside.

OMG! What an experience! A trip through the history and politics of Great Britain!. I signed up for the self guided tour with an audio commentary! It takes about 75 minutes and is overwhelming! The first parts permits photos [Westminster Hall and St. Stephen's Hall]. The remainder doesn't permit photography, however, you just feel the majesty and spirit of the United Kingdom. The House of Lords is composed of gold gilt walls and trim and red leather seats! The House of Commons is decorated in green leather and magnificent wood carvings! The Central Lobby has stunning mosaics of the four areas of the United Kingdom. Great value. I stayed around for High Tea in the Terrace Pavilion Restaurant along the Thames River! WOW!

great. My girls were 13 and 11. If you have kids you know how they can be at this age, Even they liked it. It was very well done, by far the best tour i've been on. I have heard people complain about the cost. I have a tip for them. You don't go to London to save money. The whole place is a money draining machine. If you are getting you wallet cleaned out in London, this is a great place to visit.

Fantastic. I recently contacted our local MP as I read that they will give short guided tours to constituents, well I'm glad I did because a planned one hour stay turned into 3 and half hours!Access was quite easy with usual security checks and we were met 9am prompt in the central lobby, from there we had the grand tour with a personal commentary on the history, pageant and workings of parliament from an MPs point of view.The highlights were obviously the 2 houses but also going behind the scenes and onto the terrace.It was a Wednesday so PMs QT day which we were told was full, however as we were watching the speaker enter the house, our MP came looking for us and I managed to get tickets for us, this was tremendous to watch, not just because of the 2 leaders battling it out but also seeing what's going on with the backbenches as well.There is a nice coffee shop and shop off Westminister Hall which we used after our tour ended and before the start of house business.Many thanks to David Hanson for his time and effort in making it a fantastic experience.

Beautiful row of buildinggs. Iconic and great for that must have London photo. Parliament has much more history behind that wonderful architecture. Have an outside tour guide give you a lesson. You'll appreciate it more.
Amazing masonry. Stop and look in detail at the stonework, we will probably never build anything this intricate in the future. Thousands of man days and such a skilled workforce. Well worth a visit.

Excellent. A facinating insight into the workings of government. The tour was both interesting & informative. Our tour guide(Victoria) was very knowlegable and able and willing to answer questions. I would do this tour again.
Definitely worth the effort. Excellent tour. It was very interesting and I found it a bonus that you actually got in to the House of Commons and Lords.

A must do, when visiting London. We recently did a guided tour of the houses of parliament, and are so glad we did, it was fascinating! Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and was so interesting, that unfortunately the 90 minutes flew by, we would happily have listened on a lot longer. You can do an audio tour but I'm glad we didnt, as out guide was so good. We visisted the house of Lords and Commons, but lots of other areas too, that were absolutely beautiful and full of history. I agree this tour would not be suitable for young children, but for anyone with any interest in politics or not , I think this visit is a definite must.We had lunch in the coffee shop there too, which was surprisingly inexpensive.This was definitely a highlight of our trip!

Houses of Parliament tour a highlight!. We booked our tickets on-line and had a wonderful guided tour by Reginald. What a font of knowledge and good humour this man was. I recommend this tour to anyone interested in British history, art and of course politics - fascinating to be in the House of Commons and House of Lords. There is so much more though to see - just do it - not with children though the one and a half hour will be too long for them.

Free for all citizens. Many people do not realise that, as electors, they have every right to visit Parliament (when in session) and ask to lobby their MP. No fee need be paid and you don't need anybody's permission - simply turn up and head for the Central Lobby.

Houses of Parliament. Took this tour with a GUIDE very informative and good to see where it all goes on. HISTORY!!!! But I didn't find the free snuff that was shown on a recent TV programme on the workings of Parliament

Fantastic visit. Not only because the building itself is historical and amazing (AKA, the Palace of Westminster) but also due to the role of the parliament in history being so significant, this visit is a must do when you visit London. You can visit both Houses (Lords and Commons).

History Comes To Life. Well everything has been written in all the many many reviews for The Houses Of Parliament. I just want to add that I felt privileged to be taking this tour & walking in the footsteps of so many famous royals & politicians. As a tip to anyone reading my review, you can get to join a tour of The Houses of Parliament free of charge. Just write a letter to your local MP & they will arrange. Also remember Parliament is a working office so parts of it may be closed when you visit.

You too can take on the role of Prime Minister!. Whether it's role-paying as the PM when standing by the despatch box in the House of Commons; sitting (where it's allowed) in the opulent House of Lords; admiring the view of the Thames, the London Eye and being looked down on by the ever-watchful (or clockful I suppose that should be!) eye of Big Ben when standing on the Terrace; exploring the incredibly beautiful Victorian-restored 'hidden' chapel below the Great Westminster Hall; or - if you are fortunate enough to be part of a tour conducted by your very own proud and clearly dedicated MP (whose initials just happen to coincide with those of his chosen profession!) - simply absorbing all the fascinating facts being enthused upon you, then you can't help but be impressed by this magnificent colossus of buildings, the history that they hold and the significance of both the tradition they have stood for in the past and the importance of what they still all stand for.today. Brilliant - well done to all involved in making this a truly spectacular evening for all our group and enabling us to be able to put a tick against one more of those places on our 'wish list' to visit.

Wonderful experience - absolutely loved it!. Full of history, tradition, pomp and ceremony. Disliked nothing. Had the good fortune to sit in the visitors area of the House of Lords to witness Question Time.

Really interesting!. I came here a while back now, had a really brilliant day, we had a tour guide and it was totally fantastic. We sat in the public gallery and watched a debate and we were shown the House of Lords which was spectacular, overall worth a visit.

Cannot believe I have never visited before.. Security is tight but going through the security checks does not take too long.I opted for an audio-guide to enhance my visit and I would recommend this to get the full experience.The Houses of Parliament is one of my favourite buildings in London and the interior is just as breathtaking.The rooms are steeped in history and to be within the walls that make such huge decisions that affect us all is very humbling.It was quite busy on the day that I visited but it was not overcrowded and I thoroughly enjoy my visit and learned so much about the politics of the UK. To walk through both the Houses of Commons and Lords was surreal having seen them on television so many times.

Unmissable. A guided tour of the Palace of Westminster is an incredible experience. You retrace the route taken by Her Majesty the Queen when she visits to for the State Opening of Parliament through lavishly decorated lobbies and corridors before entering the spectacular House of Lords Chamber. It is so beautiful it is hard to know where to look! Central Lobby and the House of Commons follow. I strongly suggest hanging back from the rest of your group when you leave the Commons and standing at the Prime Minister's Dispatch Box for a few seconds - I did and it was an awesome feeling to stand where so many great (and some not so great) leaders have stood, albeit for 10 seconds. St Stephen's Hall and Westminster Hall are a grand conclusion to the tour - but come rugged up if you visit in winter because it is FREEZING in this part of the building! If I could suggest one improvement to the tour it would be to spend more time looking at and explaining the various large paintings and statues scattered in the building. This would allow Britons and foreigners alike to better understand the history which abounds in the walls of this unique building.

very good, worth visiting. I have been here a few times on business and it is well worth seeing the mother of parliaments, Westminster includes good catering and shop facilities and clean toilets. Its a working palace so has a real feel of bustle whilst you are there.Allow 10 minutes for security checks to get inside.

Democracy at work. This is an excellent window of democracy in action. We went on a Friday morning, not much business being discussed but we did see the speakers procession, which was great to see. David Davis was on good form though.If you need sustenance there is the Strangers Bar... Lots of places nearby too.
Spectacular. Very interesting tour with excellent guide who was very knowledgeable. Great to see how our government operates. The places you would never see on TV were breathtaking.

A genuine piece of history. A guided tour of the Houses of Parliament gives you the chance to hear all of the history behind not only the English Parliament but also the buildings themselves. Alan,our tour guide,had an impressive manner of delivering this as he had actually worked there so knew all of the goings on. It is a truly beautiful building both inside and out. A British cream tea in the riverside terrace restaurant is a must after the tour - a touch of decadence to end an inspiring afternoon.

Weekend Break Away. We were in London for the weekend with friends and decided last minute to do the houses of Parliament tour, we had to do the 'audio tour' as the escorted one was fully booked, so we booked on line and went along, the security was excellent, we were all thoroughly searched, which does give one confidence. The audio tour is an excellent way to do the tour as you are able to go around at your own pace without the feeling of being rushed. Would recommend anyone to do the tour, very informative in a possitive way
Fantastic. Wonderful experience, don't know why i haven't done it before. Guided tour very informative- just at the right level for the group. Mix of tourists and Londoners.

Beautiful building. A must see when visiting London. A very impressive and beautiful building. Obviously a big tourist attraction so very busy. Also it's opposite Westminster Abbey another gorgeous and impressive building and of course Big Ben.
Amazing and beautiful scene. Beutiful scene of the houses of parliment, near the Thames, amazing to take pictures by this world-famous attraction. One of the must-dos of London!

Magic. The view is simply majestic when you arrive at this place!
Try to visit at night when the city is glowing with lights! It makes this breathtaking to look at!
It's not only a historic icon, but a timeless piece of architecture for you to look at endlessly!

Mother may be sagging but she's still worth a look. It seems the Palace is held together with string and needs a major overhaul, but it is a rather beautiful building full of fascinating detail. The website is clear and very useful to check before visiting.
They generally do security very well - polite and efficient but they are very serious about what they are protecting, I'm glad to say.

must see!. This place was beautiful! I loved all the architecture and the atmosphere of the area...there is plenty to do and see and some tours are available for non-UK residents but you need to check their website. Check out more info on Parliament and London at my blog:http://thewannabegypsy.blogspot.com/ I have pics posted and notes and tips from our personal experience there that will certainly help you!Happy travels!

You can take a paid tour or better still, approach your MP for a private tour.. Our MP does regular private tours of the Houses of Parliament for his constituents. Due to the imminent election, many more are offering this opportunity. We were told about the building itself and the workings of the system of government. We also were allowed to visit the chapel and the terrace which is not allowed on the regular public tour. The chapel is medieval but restored by Victorians and is stunningly beautiful. For many years it was used as a stable. The terrace gives great views of London. We were also allowed to visit the broom cupboard where a suffragette spent the night. You get perspective on size. Westminster Hall is massive, but the House of Commons and House of Lords are tiny in comparison. The Lords is far more opulent than the Commons. We were fortunate to have a guide who knew a lot about the building and the working of Parliament and gave us a fascinating glimpse into it.

amazing building. We visited in February. If you pre-book check you are in the right queue my son booked us in on his iphone so the policeman had to take his phone off him to go to the booking office to get our tickets, Be prepared to be searched you have to put your bag, watch, and outer coat through a scanner, but it is well worth it,we did the audio tour which is easy to follow and you can take your time, you actually get to go into the house of lords as well, the guided tour was more expensive but you get to see a little more behind the scenes. The information on the audio is really good we loved the visit, give yourselves a good couple of hours to do it we had a drink in the cafe and used the toilets which were immaculately clean. the gift shop is very small and expensive

Great photo !!!. This make a great photo oppertunity and if you stand in the garden opposite you will get a stunning picture of the whole area...if you walk over westminister bridge you can get another view of the most amazing building that is soul of london...its a very easy walk to Picaddily circus and oxford street from there..a must to see when in London...
Commons and Lords. A must see to be able to sit in the Commons and watch a live session of the MP's in action. Really enjoyed watching some interesting topics being debated.

British Politics in Action. Be sure to get gallery tickets to watch the MP's in action.
A formidable building.
After 2001, the visitor areas are restricted. You can no longer go on the roof next to the Big Ben but it is worth a visit all the same. So, queue up early.

Parliamentary Review!. Visited Pariament at the invite of my local MP and it was a golden opportunity to see the 'mother of all Parliaments.I was surprised at the hustle and bustle of the place and also that we were allowed to see the majority of the building, including both Houses (Lords and Commons)Plenty of time to sit in the Great Hall and this was the only place we were allowed to take photographs, if only just to prove we were there!A fantastic experience for this with an interest in such things.Highly recommended

A must visit in London. While staying in London I made sure to visit the Houses of Parliament. I am currently enrolled in a British Politics course at University so to see this in person was truly an experience. The detail in every inch of this building is incredible and the chance to stand where the PM does during question time is awesome. The history in the building is not missed as it is everywhere. We just did the audio guide and that was more than enough information. A highlight of the trip.
Freedom. We visited the sight of modern day freedom whilst in Westminster. The impact of decision made in this building were felt across the world. Definitely worth a visit even for a photograph.

Amazing Experience !. I booked a timeslot online, walked past Big Ben and up to the entrance. After an airline-type security check-in I found myself inside the 'corridors of power'. I thought perhaps there would be a few displays and videos to look at - and so I was genuinely surprised by the freedom to walk around at my own pace, right through the Houses of Commons and the House of Lord's chambers m- To stand at the Despatch Box and imagine being Prime Minister / Leader of Opposition - to walk among the green benches and follow in the footsteps of Her Majesty the Queen. I can only say it made a huge impression on me and I highly recommend booking yourself in if you have the opportunity !
