Fascinating to visit!. Such a familiar building to us all from television yet breathtaking in reality. The guided tour is to be recommended as it gives you a better insight into the workings of parliament .

Houses of Parliament. We visited the Houses of Parliament last Saturday for a guided tour. It was very interesting, made all the more so by the in-depth knowledge of the gentleman who took us on the tour, which lasted just over one and a half hours. Although it was quite busy, we managed to hear and follow the guide easily.It was interesting to hear the historical details regarding the rituals that have carried on for hundreds of years! I would definitely recommend this attraction. The cafe was inexpensive, which was a pleasant surprise.

Interesting Process. On Wednesday you can go in and watch and see how the British government really works it was a bit boring as I don't like politics but it was also fascinating at times to witness how they came to terms with what they will do.
A must do. You can and should visit this place. It's wonderful. A great piece of architecture full of history. Maybe a bit pricy but definitely worth the outlay.

An Informative Tour Of An Amazing Building!. If you have the option do go for the guided tour. Our guide was brilliant and took us places that were not available with the audio guide. The tour takes about an hour and a half and takes you to both houses,all the hallways as well as the divison corridor and some of the meeting rooms. The art work and statues are superb and you almost have to pinch yourself to believe you are walking down the same corridor as the Queen, The Lords, the Prime minister and all the MPs.Really well worth a visit to this amazing building containing the corridors of power.

What a Treat!!. I bought my tickets online before I left the states. There is security to go through, just like the airport. Once inside the tour was informative and interesting. It is without a doubt one of the most beautiful buildings I have ever been in! Love the stories about the Queen and her annual entrance and visit. Great coffee shop (some of the best coffee I had in London!!)

An amazing structure. The best view of the Houses of Parliament is from across the river and the nearest Underground station is Westminster.Located right on the River Thames, a magnificent Neo-Gothic building dating from the 1840s, it is most recognizable from the clock tower at one end known as Big Ben. (In fact, Big Ben is actually the bell inside the tower.)The Parliament is made up of two houses, - the House of Commons and the House of Lords and both have their meeting chambers here. It is possible to take a tour of the building or watch a debate or question time. Once a year, usually around May, the Queen visits and from her throne in the House of Lords officially opens the new session of Parliament. Tours through both the Lords and the Commons run on most Saturdays year round and on weekdays during holiday periods including Easter, Whitsun, the summer and Christmas/New Year. Admission for this tour runs between 14 -16.50 UK pounds.

Sunday morning stroll.. Viewed from the outside only. Looks mighty impressive. Took a couple of photos inc statue of Oliver Cromwell, which I deleted later. Good restaurant opposite Westminster Abbey, a Methodist church, underground which was very keenly priced, for London.

Houses of Parliament. We recently went on a visit to the Houses of Parliament, which was organised by our local MP,(don't let that put you off!). The trip was arranged during half term week for 6.00pm at the Houses of Parliament, the tour lasted for over 3 hours which was split 60mins on general history of the building, 45 mins on the Commons, 45mins on the Lords, the remainder on discussion over wine & cheese . The building was virtually deserted as, however this meant that we did not have to contend with hordes of people around the building and allowed for a more relaxed tour. The general history & the Commons aspect of the tour was presented by Ben Gummer MP, the Lords part was presented by Charlie. Both Bens & Charlies knowledge of the history and the working of Parliament was extensive and interesting and the time flew by. At no time were we subjected to party politics. This type of trip is a regular occurence and would advise anyone who has even a small interest in history or the working of Paliament to take this tour.

terrible audio guide. Arrived very early, had to hang around, then security tests. Entered the big state hall but no-one said where to get audio tour sets from, had to ask. Was expecting History of paintings, building, relicts, who painted, sculpted what BUT we seemed to get a lecture on English politics.. Great if you are a foreign tourist but I'm British. We walked past many magnificent paintings, sculptures but not a word about them.And was there a mention about black rods marking on the door(which door?) No.hiMind you glad we didnt have a guide after eavesdropping on their dialogue; child's stuff.The building was massive and impressive, very small gift shop, with over priced irrelevant gifts.Online booking said you could take tea on the river side WHERE? We found an over priced cafe, def not near a river
Great part of history and today. A parliament tour was a great historical experience in real life. If you have the chance then make sure you see and experience it.

Fantastic. Well worth the entry fee for the audio guide. Normally I don't like these machines as the headphones slip or they are clumsy but here it was easy to use and perfect. A really interesting visit you couldn't help but be impressed. A must do.

Tale of two. Different buildings.Just back from a stay in the build right opposite SW1A OAA,have to say that early morning and late at night it is splendid....what a shame that Guy's house a lot og good hard working folk while this place not so much!!.If in the city it is well worth a visit though.

Great way to spend a couple of hours. We would definitely recommend you visit the houses of parliament. We took the guided tour which in our opinion was worth the extra couple of pound, our guide was very informative and through the tour we got to see a couple of rooms that the ordinary entrance would not get to. The tour took about an hour and a half' there is airport security which does take time to get through so of you take the tour get there in good time.
Just spectacular. . Loved loved loved this area, the buildings are beautiful and Big Ben is a spectacular sight in the nights sky, you need to see this ;)

Awesome. Simply awesome. A unique and amazing place steeped in history. What grand and intricate architecture, amazing. This is the home of democracy and where the world has been shaped. I urge anyone to put it top of their list when visiting our capital city!

Very interesting. Loved this tour! We did the audio version so we could progress at our own speed. This isn't our normal cup of tea, but was so informative and such a beautiful and iconic building, U couldn't help but enjoy it. I wouldn't recommend this for primary school age kids thought as nothing to touch etc . To purchase a ticket, u need to do so at the ticket office which is round the corner( it's on the Thames bank facing the boat tours ) so make sure u do or the walk there and back is a bit annoying :-)

Brilliant - just brilliant!!. We were actually on our way to Westminster Abbey when a lady stood on the corner of Westminster Bridge thrust a leaflet in my hand and asked if we wanted to go on a tour around Parliament. This was something that all of the family have always wanted to do, but we weren't aware that they were in recess, so we jumped at the chance.Tickets need to be bought from Portcullis House on the Embankment and we went for the audio tour - costing £50 for two adults, a senior concession and a child.Once inside, you just stand in awe. This is seriously where it all happens and where it has done for hundreds of years.If you get chance, it is a must!!

Audio Tour. We spent an hour wandering around The Houses of Common's and Lords listening to an informative audio tour. Just long enough for the teenagers to bear and interesting for us adults too. Great access to some very famous places like the Central Lobby and robing rooms. Great value for £18 each (one adult and one child)

Fantastic guided tour. We booked our guided tour of the Houses of Parliament directly on the Parliament website. Our guide, Suzanne, was fantastic and brought the building to life. The tour was absolutely brilliant and it was amazing being in the same place you see on the TV so many times and learning about what goes on behind the doors. The guided tour was also great as you get access to some rooms which are not available on the audio tour. Would definitely recommend!

Stunning. Fantastic place to visit don't just look at it from the outside get involved and on a tour! The inside is breathtaking and the tour guide was very knowledgeable and made it more interesting. Would highly recommend.
Fantastic opportunity. What a great part of history and every day parliament which was great to experience in real life. If you have the chance then make sure you see and experience it.
Order Order. This is where it really happens. Much smaller than you might expect, but fascinating all the same. Essential to book in advance
Great British History. Fantastic opportunity to learn about the history of our vote. Brilliant tour guide, super value and would like to go again, very interesting

Breathtaking!. On Friday last week (while the MPs were in recess!) we opted for the guided tour of the two parliaments in the Palace of Westminster. Our guide Helen took us from the incredible 13th century Westminster Hall along the length of the Palace of Westminster to the House of Lords and we then worked our way along the building visiting key rooms as we went. We started in the Queens robing room and from there made our way through the Royal Gallery to the House of Lords. Be prepared to be blown away...the amount of bling in the House of Lords was incredible. We then travelled through the central lobby through to the "Ayes to the right" division room and from there into the House of Commons. Helen was very good and gave us lots of historical information about the building, the origins of our democracy and some fun facts to be going on with. Although expensive (at £25 per head) the tour lasted for nearly 2 hours and really isn't to be missed. Try to do this when the MPs and Lords are out on holiday so as to see everything unhindered.

A Well-formed Audio Tour. We decided to take the audio tour around the Houses of Parliament — a decision we didn't regret. The route covered all of the key areas of the Houses of Parliament, and we were fortunate enough to be able to enter both chambers, since neither the Commons nor the Lords were sitting that day.On the whole, the tour was interesting without being too long. Visitors who wanted to listen to extra information on particular subjects could press a button on their handsets, but those who did not could simply move on: an additional feature that I found particularly useful.Plus, as I understand it, there was a different audio tour available that was tailored for younger children that could be completed alongside their parents.I ought to point out that photography and video recording is not permitted anywhere on the tour. Pre-booking is advised, especially during busy periods.

2 hours very well spent. Did the guided tour (with a lady called Christine - she was very good) on Saturday. It lasts for nearly 2 hours. If you have any appreciation of British history, I would say its an excellent thing to do. Not cheap but I guess better than the audio tour as you get to ask any questions you may have on the way round. The Commons chamber is fascinating - you can visualise all the PM's and other big names through recent times standing just in front of you. The Lords chamber is far more ornate and you can just pick up the faint sounds of snoring through the ages while in there ....... A great tour and recommended.

Not to be missed.. I can thoroughly recommend a guided tour of the houses of Parliament. Tickets are quite expensive, but worth every penny. The building itself is a wonder, from the ornate gold decor of the royal chambers to the Gothic fan vaulted ceilings. All day could be spent just examining the historic paintings. I got a thrill from standing in both chambers of Parliament. You literately see where history is made. The main pleasure of the tour for me was the stories told by the guide. It seems incredible that such archaic rules and procedures are still in force! Do allow a fair amount of time to pass through the ‘airport’ security before your tour.

Interesting and fascinating. We decided to visit with another couple while visiting London. We booked for a certain time online but the time apparently doesn't matter too much as we were very early and went in anyway. We had audio guides. Loved the visit, the comments and the Authenticity of it. Definitely recommend it.

Tour by Nathan 19/02/15. We had this trip organised by work so all I had to do was turn up. On arrival we were met by our guide and given a very informative brief and then we set off. I could go into detail about everything he told us but then there would be no point in you going?If you get the chance you must go! If you can, get on an organised tour as the experience will be so much better.This is probably up there with one of the best tours I have been on. The best bit is when you get to walk the same route the The Queen takes when she visits. And you get to see Black Rods mark on the door.Excellent.

Awesome. This is an excellent place to visit. We took the audio tour which was excellent and allows you to go around at your own pace. The building is more ornate than you can imagine and the sense of history is everywhere.  I would thoroughly recommend this.

A fascinating visit. Having pre booked we were quickly through security and were met by our guide, a very smart gentlemen. He gave us a very knowledgeable tour which was both fascinating and humorous and was an excellent guided tour lasting nearly two hours. Well worth the money or free if you contact your local MP.

Informative Tour of an Historic London Landmark. My husband and I visited this historic venue yesterday. We were not disappointed. Our visit was enhanced by our knowledgeable and informative guide - Howard.I would recommend booking a tour guide rather than using the audio option. The personalised experience enabled us to ask specific questions. Overall this was a great experience which we topped off with tea.
Interesting to see!. Interesting to see, however you need to book tickets in advance in order to avoid the long queues that usually form at the London Museums.

beautiful place. We saw Edwin black here, talking about how our government sends money to Palestine, knowing full well some of it funds terrorism. Lots of history here. Just to see the inside was fantastic, walking in the steps of many .
Usual high standard. If you visit do so with your MP to get the best out of your visit, after all they are supposed to represent and in my case our MP does and works very hard

Really enjoyed our visit. We prebooked our visit to the Houses of Parliament so admission process was really easy. We had an excellent and very knowledgeable guide. The visit included time in the both the House of Lords and House of Commons. The architecture within the palace is stunning. The whole tour was extremely interesting and would highly recommend.

The corridors of power!. Tickets were booked online with no problems. There was an airport-style security search on the way in but we experienced only a short delay. We took the family audio tour, with two kids aged 5 and 10. They had the special children's commentary which they seemed to enjoy - even the 5 year old was telling us about what he had learned, mainly about fires and people having their heads chopped off, but then I suppose that is more interesting to a five-year-old than Prime Ministers Questions! The adult commentary was also interesting and it was fascinating to be in the places you normally only see on telly. I suspect though that you would learn more about the workings of Parliament on a guided tour - we listened in to a couple of groups for a short while and they seemed to get more about the human side of it, whereas the audio tour tended to focus more on the architecture and decoration. On the whole though it was well worth the time and money spent.

The hub of political business with many busy bees buzzing around. The Strangers' Gallery is something else. To listen to debates is. without question, one of the best things I have even witnessed,To walk through the main vestibule and to espy a famous face whisking through is quite exhilarating.All in all, a very illuminating insight into what goes on in the seat of power in Britain.

The Inside View. The Houses of Parliament are very old and very inappropriate for the seat of British Government, originally being built as a Palace for the then Royal seat of Power. The Palace is vast inside, with impractical long and wide passages, dozens of pointless telephone booths (MP's have mobiles and office landlines) and ancient fixtures and fittings.Government should move elsewhere and the Palace should be open to the Public in it's entirity, instead of tantilising sections. Buckingham, Kew and Hampton-Court Palaces are fully open and blend well with London tourist Venues.The Houses are well worth a look anyway on ones way past.

Red or green?. Did an audio tour of The Houses of Parliament and enjoyed it immensely. It really is a palace and some areas were stunning and befitting of royalty. The Commons were OK. I wished there was a way to have gone inside the Big Ben. It was certainly worth going there and I hope to go there soon to listen to a live debate as it is open to the public at certain times. Recommended for sure.

As expected. We booked a tour of the Palace of Westminster after watching the inside the commons programme in the television. It cost approx £50 for the two of us. We turned up early as we had been warned out the airport style security to get in. We collected out tickets from portcullis house, and did not experience the best customer service. Firstly we were asked quite rudely to wait outside until a counter became available, then were had to wait whilst the lady behind the counter hand wrote our tickets. Everyone else was given printed tickets, it was not explained why ours were hand written or guarantee given that they would be valid. We were not given directions to the entrance either (across the road and down a bit). However once inside, our tour guide was great. I didn't catch her name but she has pink hair! The tour ran over by 25 mins but no one seemed to care as she was knowledgable and willing to answer all our questions. We were slightly disappointed that we did not necessarily learn anything new that we had not heard on the programme or already knew. We were also hoping to see some of the behind the scenes bars and tea rooms however the 2hrs 10 mins were packed with information and history. We are stilling giving this 4 stars as the guide was excellent and gave us plenty of time, however the customer service of the ticket office need some work.

Interesting tour. We found the tour fascinating.The architecture of the place is stunning and the history within is mind blowing. We had seen the documentary on the tv about the workings of the Houses of Parliament which whet our appetite and spurred us to book this tour. It can only be done when parliament is on recess so bear this in mind. Well worth a visit.

The Seat of Power!. it was a very exciting experience to be standing in what I can only call this great hall of power, parts of it are so old I could imagine the Tudor kings holding court.I went as part of a group, 25 middle aged surveyors! So I guess you could say we had a special interest in buildings. The scale was not what I expected, some parts quite modest and others very grand and ornate. In all a fascinating place.The only blot was the most awful guide we had, I can only assume that she was once a school teacher as she spent the tour scolding us, like a teenage class, berating one of our group for a 'silly question that surely they must have learnt in school' I am afraid she really ruined the place for us, really could not cope with being asked questions and kept making her own political view quite clear. Shame I can't imagine we were a difficult crowd, interested, inquisitive, a touch challenging perhaps when one or two of the group gave an answer with sources for a question another of the group asked.To credit the organises they have offered us another tour.Suitability, well I guess my kids would be bored rigid as would many younger people, however if you have a sense of history, or time and place, or romance ( not in a lovey dovey way) you may just love it

Houses of Parliament tour. We learned a lot of history and some inside information about how Parliament works. Getting our tickets was very difficult and disorganized. They need to do a better job of signing where to go if you have paid on line for your tickets.

so much history proud to be british. Fantastic one of the best london attractions.our guide had an amazing knowledge the history was fascinating would say 14 years plus if taking children so they appreciate it

A working museum piece. Created less than 200 years ago, but always intended to look like a medieval palace, the standard tour is pretty interesting - particularly when you stop to appreciate that the entire country's legislation takes place in this antiquated museum. Full of quaint and absurd customs, and people dressed up in ancient clothing intended to try to make them look dignified, but actually makes them absurd. BUT one very large room is certainly worth looking at in depth : you will enter first the Great Hall, there for over a thousand years, but now effectively just a vast passageway ; look around it certainly, but most of all look up at its quite astonishing ceiling.

Very interesting, informative guide, good value.. Visited during half term with 4 children aged 9-12years. Booked guided tour. The guide was very informative. The children were given lots of educational literature appropriate for their age. It took just under 2 hours. We will definitely go back and maybe next time sit in the public galleries. Well worth a visit!

So much history!!. A visit to Parliament is yet another Must SEE attraction whilst visiting London. You'll likely be amazed at how small it really is. The benches, not seats, are close together and members sit 'cheek to jowl' as they say. This is where the many taxes were passed that led to the American Revolution in protest. Americans felt that they were British citizens, but weren't being treated as such -- among other complaints. Drop by Churchill's WWII Bunker just across the street as well to make your day complete.

Beautiful. When you step out of Westminster Station you are greeted with this amazing building and of course Big BenWalking across the Bridge towards the London Eye and looking back towards the Houses of Parliment made me proud to be a Londoner

Well worth booking a tour. What history, what a building . If you can get in while parliament is in session do it if not next best thing book a tour . The guides are informative the groups not to big . You have to queue a bit to get in but with a timed ticket it is not to bad . Well worth the time and money !
tour of parliament. absolutely terrific tour, on par with Buckingham Palace, so many treasures to see and the history is outstanding, there is a café on site for refreshments

A fantastic way to learn some history. I went on the guided tour via my friend's MP. Wasn't sure what to expect, but was totally gripped by the experience. Phrases that are common parlance were brought to life. The rooms were all interesting, often stunningly beautiful. The tour was a reasonable length in my view, about an hour and a quarter, but I would have been happy had it taken longer. The only slight downside was the inevitable but necessary security checks on entry, but well worth it.
Victorian gothic grandeur. Great experience - recommend you tie you visit to a meeting a lot of NGOs and lobby groups hold meetings and tickets can be obtained.

Excellant tour if you like history or politics. Took the guided Parliament Tour, which was outstanding. Great venue, excellant guide. There are audio guide tours available as well, I think, but the interaction with the excellant guide made it a much better experience for me.
Contact your MP. This visit is only worthwhile if you can go into the Houses of Parliament. The easiest way is via your local MP. The guides are most helpful and are mines of information.

Guided Tour of Parliament. Security is taken very seriously....was like going through airport security. Cafe inside where MPs and other politicians sat. We recognised a few faces!The tour guide was very well informed and had a friendly mannerism. Lots of history and culture. We saw MPs debating on Health issues in the House of Commons. Walked through the Red House of Lords but not allowed to sit!!! My children and I enjoyed it- would recommend it to all. So much to take in and learn from,Were allowed to take one photograph on the steps before entering the main building, so able to keep as a souvenir. Price seemed reasonable to be honest when you think that this is one of Britain's top attractions, as well as a real life part of British history.We thoroughly enjoyed our day put at Westminster.

History in the making. Security on entering was very tight but only to be expected considering you were being allowed to enter the very heart of British democracy.A most enjoyable tour through both the Hose of Commons and House of Lords. We were not rushed at all and were able to ask the very knowledgeable guide as many questions as we wanted.It was fascinating from start to finish and being there in person made all the many pictures previously seen come to life before my own eyes. If you are a lover of gigantic oil paintings then you will not be disappointed as the corridor walls between the two houses are hung all the way along.Many of the quaint customs of the workings of Parliament were explained to us and helped to make the visit a memorable one.

So interesting.... We did a guided tour, following by tea on the terrace. Be prepared for airport security, belts off , metal detectors, but it's understandable, so fine.Our guide, Victoria, certainly knew her stuff, and made it i fascinating, the 2 hours just flew by. It's hard to take in the world changing stuff that has gone on in there. Seeing the throne, House of Commons, House of Lords etc, listening to the history, I could have stayed all day. All the stuff you had to learn at school , just comes alive here.Tea on the terrace. What can I say. Not cheap, but a once in a life time thing to do. You are met by a Queens Messager and escorted to the members terrace. Amazing views of the Thames. The little cakes and nibbles were gorgeous, endless cups of tea.A fantastic experience all round. There is so much I didn't know about how my country is run.
The mother of parliament. Have visited a couple of times, once with my local WI when we had a guide. It was incredibly interesting and you could feel the power of the place.

Iconic London Landmark backbone of our nation. Just love it - proud to be British but almost too many tour groups hogging every area round it - we are independent travellers who like to do our own thing

Memorable Experience. Had the joy of visiting the Houses of Parliament and was taken in by its grandeur.Young children and history buffs will really like the experience of visiting the Houses of Parliament.

Expensive and not very nice. Overpriced - understandably given the fact you are a fairly captive audience when inside without booking out and then having to go through security again if you want to get back in. Poor choice of food, Lack lustre surrounding especially given the place is surrounded by historic architecture. Service was grumpy. Worst coffee in years too,
Prime Ministers Question Time. Although this has ti=o be organised through an MP it is worth the experience. Well worth a visit. Would go again

WHY ISN'T EVERY SCHOOLCHILD & ADULT GIVEN THE OPPORTUNITY TO VISIT. You learn so much about the history of your country and the building and art are so impressive. It was all over far too quickly for me and I would like to visit again as there was so much on offer I couldn't take it all in I was so much in awe. Saw a few cabinet ministers on the way around although the house wasn't sitting when I visited.

Worth a visit. I'm in my forties and visited for the first time a couple of months ago. It's great to get the historical tour and stand where all those people we love to hate thrash it out on a daily basis. Great to see the side rooms and all the eccentric and archaic parliamentary paraphernalia.
Visit to Houses of Parliament. I was very impressed by my visit and tour. It is remarkable how much heritage we have, I was amazed and felt very proud after.

you can't come to London without seeing the houses of parliament. You can't go in but you have to see outside. Get there early in the day to get your photo without another million tourists getting in the way.

Fascinating. I paid for a guided tour and it was worth the money. Our tour guide was very enthusiastic and quite entertaining. Tour parliament at the half term while the MPs are away so you can see more. The tour took us through the debating halls, the Moses room, the royal robing room and others. The guide explained how the two houses and the monarchy interact to pass (or block) legislature. This was definitely a highlight of my visit to London.

Great Architecture - amazing historical place. Expensive - but very well worth the visit to take in the architecture and history. Get to see more than we had expected. But it is a really out-dated place for Modern 21st Century Politics. Perhaps that is its charm?

Well worth a visit. My time was limited so I opted for a visit to the Commons Public Gallery rather than the extended guided tour. I was more interested in how debates are conducted than in the architecture or the celebrities. I stayed for more than 90 minutes and heard an excellent, reasoned, informed debate on cancer prevention. Political point-scoring was minimal, the standard of delivery was admirable. Clearly, some Members were speaking to their own constituencies or reflecting the interests of some of the many NGOs active in this area. That said, following a good debate, the Government Minister, in responding, picked up on and responded positively to the central points made. I left that place with a lighter heart than when I arrived. Some of that may be due to the 90 minute rest that I had sitting on the public benches. But I think that it was in no small measure optimism that in the corridors of power this plague is being debated constructively.Entrance was non-fussy, well signposted. Ask any policeman if the Commons is sitting and if so where to seek entrance.

Guided tour. Given this tour as a present. Security was like being at the airport and advised it could take upto 45 minutes.Guide was very knowledgeable and made the tour "come to life". Interesting to see places only previously seen on TV. Tour lasted just over 1.5 hours which I felt could be made longer and take in more history.Had afternoon tea afterwards and at £27.50 I felt it was overpriced especially as the tea was only teabags not proper tea leaves. Beautiful setting overlooking the Thames.

Excellent piece of British history. Every room of this amazing building is packed with so much history. Very impressive architecture as well as a very interesting tour of it. Definitely worth the effort, and a must if you're in London.What really caught my eye was the gigantic paintings. They each detailed some important piece of British history, and I could go back again just to see them again.
Excellent personal tour arranged by my MP. I was surprised by how beautiful the House of Lords is. Many interesting Historical, Architectural and Parliamentary points.

Well worth the time. We booked a guided tour as they had been recommended. We were not disappointed! Our guide Liz explained the different part of the building as well as how parliament worked and what we see on the TV. An excellent 2 hour tour.

Must visit sighseeing. I walked around this beautiful building so many times and finally got in...To pass by the security took a time, but then everything was organised very well and we got our guide quite shortly.Lady told us loads about history and was happy to answer any questions. Very interesting was to find out that queen actually can not go everywhere and we (visitors) could visit more than she is allowed to.In the end of there is a small shop with souvenirs.The only minus is that Big Ben is not a part of this tour.

visit to houses of Parliament. If you get an opportunity please visit the houses of ParliamentLovely ArchitectureIf you are lucky you may be able to see a celebrity Politician!Guided tours are very good!

Very interesting and good value.. We took the audio tour and it was excellent. The commentary was easy to follow and were were able to travel at our own pace. Lots to see including walking through both Houses with places to rest all along the route. Great atmosphere, impressive building.

Houses of Parliament tour and afternoon tea. Can't believe I enjoyed it so much. Really great informative tour of the spectacular building. Afternoon tea was glorious, siting beside the river having afternoon tea(coffee in my case) was the perfect way to end the tour.Thoroughly recommended

Great guided tour. Great guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. Really fascinating and informative visit, with lots of interesting historic context. Veena the tour guide was a real star and very knowledgeable. Great value. Would recommend.
Houses of Commons. Amazing had private tour of inside outside is mad with visitors and so hectic with lots of traffic but worth it.

An Amazing Experience. A tour of the seat of our democracy is something everyone should experience. I've done it twice, once with a class of children, once with the family both times it was brilliant.There are two ways of organising the tour (assuming you're a UK resident). One is to book an organised tour for which you have to pay; alternatively ask your MP's office to organise it, then its free although you din't get so much flexibility of time and must book 3 months in advance.Nonetheless to walk round such a magnificent building, steeped in history is amazing. In particular Westminster Hall, where you can see where Charles I stood to be condemned, where Churchill lay in state and where Henry VIII played tennis!
fabulous. central london must go place history of england politics whery nice place to go and see bryliant piece of london
Great visit. This is a very good tour. You are taken all around the building and told lots about the building, it's use and the process in Government

Politics, History and Architecture. A must for anyone interested in Politics and it's history. The guided tours are great, good to see the House of commons. Make sure you check when parliament is sitting as it is not open to the public then. A truly beautiful and iconic building inside and out.

Impressive Buildings so Steeped in History. The architecture and position of these buildings is so daunting and impressive. The history that surrounds these buildings is vital to the development and achievement of modern democracy -"the Westminster Model". Coming from Australia it is so impressive to view in person so much you have learned at school during you youth.

Houses of Parliament tour and afternoon tea. For Valentine's Day i took my husband to the tour and tea. I was all set to be bored by the tour but I found the audio really interesting and we moved along fast. It was fascinating seeing the Houses of Commons and Lords and beautiful ornate architecture. Not sure why we were allowed to take pics in some parts and not in others but I guess they have their reasons. Onto the tea, firstly I somehow booked the tour and tea for different days by mistake. Don't know how this happened but they were very accomodating about it and managed to fit us in. That's a big positive. The food was very nice but there really wasn't enough of it. 3 small sandwiches, one small scone and 2 small desserts each. We go for teas often and this really was the most stingy offering we've experienced, especially for the amount charged. But my real issue was it said on the ticket tea would be served in the grandeur of the Pugin Room. Unless I'm mistaken we couldn't have been in this room as it had no grandeur and looked more like a marquee, but there was no mention so that was rather strange. My advise to others visiting for tea, is eat before you go...

Awesome building. This building is a lot bigger than I thought. The pictures you see really do not do it justice. The building is truly more magnificent than any pictures out there. The architecture, location and just the overall atmosphere make this a place worth visiting.

Educational Experience. My husband and I did a guided tour. As a Canadian it was great to learn more about the British Parliamentary system. Our guide was very knowledgeable. I would suggest this tour for older children and adults. Will be dull for those uninterested in politics/history.

Wonderful visit. Had a wonderful tour of the Palace of Westminster which is better known as the Houses of Parliament. Would recommend to everyone. Really great to see the House of Commons and Lords. When you see debates on T.V. in either chamber you never really see the full setting in which they take place. Also the wooden roof in Westminster Hall is amazing. There is plenty to learn about British History and hearing about it in this great setting makes it more alive.
Parliament ����. I visited the Houses of Parliament in 2014 and it was absolutely fantastic anyone who is interested in historical government buildings this is the one for you

Take the guided tour. We visited last Saturday morning having booked the guided tour option rather than the self guided one wearing headphones. It was money well spent and we both thoroughly enjoyed our tour which lasted a fair bit longer than the advertised one and a half hours. Our tour guide (lady with the pink hair) certainly went the extra mile with information , stories and answering our questions.It was amazing to be able to visit such an old historical working building and to walk through all the chambers etc that we see on our televisions every single day. So interesting.Make sure you arrive in plenty of time as you have to pass through airport style security before you enter the premises. Once there you are not permitted to eat , drink or sit on the chairs!I would highly recommend this attraction, open at weekends.
Historical Brilliance. Loved loved loved this tour! brilliant history sculptures and art work! Intend to do another tour in the summer!

Democracy & Monarchy. Love the feel to explore the old architectural masterpiece who must have witnessed several ups & downs of super power nation UNITED KINGDOM. Some how was not happy with the dampness! smelly at some places !

Seat of power. This is an excellent tour if you can get on it. I managed to get a private tour courtesy of Lord Ashdown. My party got into the Lords and Commons and an audience with Black Rod. We were hosted superbly and there is so much to see there. The splendour of it all takes your breath away. A very highly recommended tour if you can get on it.

Very interesting tour. We very lucky to visit in November and be able to witness the committee hearings. It was fascinating to listen to the debates that are probably very familiar to the UK citizens, but not to foreign tourists. I have seen the debates on TV in the past and it was so much fun to see them with my own eyes. Needless to say that the exterior of Houses of Parliament and the iconic Big Ben are spectacular as always (not our first visit to London). It was a memorable visit and very interesting history lesson as well.

Amazing History. the Iconic Houses of Parliament and Big Ben are recognised all over the world. An amazing place to visit with parts being a thousand years old, interesting tour with more facts and figures than you can remember.  You can't climb the bell tower to see Big Ben as you have to be invited by an MP, so ask if you have one it's well worth it.

very interesting. We just happen to ask how to get a tour.. a helpful policeman standing at the gates pointed us in the right direction, we even managed to go into the public gallery and see some of the well-known faces of politics. Stayed several hours, amazing and we will go back

Fascinating tour for all ages. I took my daughter (8) and my parents (quite a bit older!) and we all thoroughly enjoyed the tour. Our guide was entertaining and informative. It really brought politics and history alive.

Fantastic experience that everyone should share. I'd never been to the Houses of Parliament and was beginning to feel rather embarrassed about it. So when our nephew came to London it seemed like an ideal opportunity to see what all the fuss was about. It was great. A brilliant guide. An insightful tour (with slightly eccentric details) and amazing interiors. It's brisk and there's quite a lot of walking but in the end it's really very important that we experience this amazing place ourselves. Very understanding security too, who even gave my partner her Swiss army knife back at the end of the tour.

A remarkable piece of London History. Such a landmark location and true symbol of London. When one thinks of London the immediate visual is of the Big Ben and houses of parliament. Definitely worth a visit to realize why it is such an awestriking monument. The most intricately designed building which has stood the test of weather and time. Also seeing the Big Ben from its ground is a must to appreciate its grandeur. One can easily appreciate most of the facets externally but if one has some time on hand and is keen on history/politics then a guided tour of the houses of parliament can be a valuable history lesson behind the closed doors of English politics.
Awesome structure for photography and viewing. A cool place to take photographs. Represents heritage of British and houses the law makers of UK. The closest station is westminster

It maybe the Seat of Government, but you don't sit down much.. The Houses of Parliament are must for locals and visitors alike. Anyone can visit the Place where the UK Government sit and you will really enjoy it, but here are a few pointers.Depending on time of day and year, getting in is simple if at times a rather long wait. Get there early or lunchtime when everyone is eating. You will have to go through security much like any airport, but once in that's it. Eat before you go in for the restaurant in the HOP are expensive so a cuppa yes, but food will cost you. If you don't like steps or find standing for some time tiring don't go as there are lots of steps and even more standing on the tours. All I would say is if reasonably fit you will have a great visit and come away a little wiser and can look at Big Ben in a new light when you see it when you get home.

insightful, amazing and informative tour. I went on a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament and it was a great experience! The tour guide was full of interesting information, and knew how to tell a story. The architecture and art alone make this a worthwhile tour.

Best History Lesson Ever. I learned more about British History in my visit to the Houses of Parliament than I ever did at school. I found it a fascinating place bought to life by our guide - well worth paying for one as they know so much - well this one did. We went during the Summer when parliament was closed but the building, the artwork and the history were all superb. Will definitely go again and thoroughly recommend it.

The place to understand and appreciate British history. We took the audio guide tour on week-end. The guide is the best I have ever had. The advantage of going there on the we is that there is no session, so you can enter all halls and rooms. History is just around you. Definitely worth every penny of the fare.

you dont see everything..... this is an ok tour - you cant take any pictures and you only get to see a very small amount of the parliaments also the audio guide is very boring and hard to concentrate as they give a bit too much history/hearsay and not enough fact!

Put this your list. We live 30 miles from London, have done for forty years, yet we had never visited The Houses of Parliament before. What an excellent experience, the tour guide was very good indeed. A word of warning though, it is quite tiring for anyone who finds standing still a problem. I had a total knee replacement 18 months ago and felt uncomfortable at times, as there is very little opportunity to sit during the tour. Highly recommend though.

Oh Lordy. We were not sure we would be able to enter the House without any appointment, but on arrival and asking staff were advised that if there was a debate taking place, anyone could enter. We were lucky that there was a debate taking place in the House of Lords. Obviously there was a lot of security in place, but on going inside, the place was amazing. The architecture was stunning, portraits hanging from the walls. The Strangers Gallery was a good place to view proceedings.
What a view. Walked all 334 steps to the belfry and 65 steps to the Ayrton light. Big Ben and the Elizabeth Tower well worth a visit.

Great tour. We booked in advance and did an audio tour. Very informative and impressive, we thoroughly enjoyed it. No queuing, although I imagine in summer the queues would be quite horrendous.Highly recommend.
The heart of British democracy. Entry closes at 4:30 pm. The audioguide visit (about 1 hour) is really interesting and the place itself fantastic.And of course we can also learn some more.

Fantastic!!!. Had a wonderful time at the Houses of Parliament over the weekend learning about this great institution. You pay a bit of extra money for a guided tour but believe me when I say that it is worth every penny. You get access to certain areas of both chambers and you certainly learn a lot more about both the Houses of Parliament and its history from a more personal perspective. Certainly not to be missed.

Recommend reservations in advance. Overall, this was an interesting tour. You get to sit in the House of Commons which is quite small. Fairly limited access (as you would imagine). You'll want to schedule during the time Parliament is out of session. If you have visited the Capitol in Washington, DC you may be disapppointed in the interior of the Houses of Parliament. The exterior is much more impressive.

What a wonderful Experience. Our guide was so informative and made our visit really interesting. I didn't think I would ever be able to walk through the house of commons chamber and I am determined to visit again when the house is sitting and watch from the gallery.
Excellent..... What Else. Most important building in the area which is historical and inspirational indeed what else can I say .
special to look inside. book tickets in advance. off course strict safety rules. Nice to see the inside of such a building and witness a meeting there.

TESTAMENT OF WORLDS MOTHER OF DEMOCRACY. take official conducted TOUR - or can wait in pubLIC Q ( FREE ENTRY) - HISTORIC westminster palace building -beautiful wonderful outside inside - artisans masterarts ceiling paintings - breath taking architecture - you can arrange special entry passes via your member of parliament or member of house of lords - WHEN IN SESSION -prime ministers question time 12pm -12.30pm wednesdays -- live committees sittings -see real democractic processes at work - get permission to LORDS sessions visitors gallery - if self constructing tour -write to MASTER SERGEANT OF ARMS office for infos - houses of parliament - westminster LONDON SW1A -UK .. ( for foreign or uk students groups via colleges ) .. momentos- pics -postcards -choclates - etc with official emblems .. as speaker says -ORDER ORDER .

The tour was excellent. Afternoon tea was cold, shambolic and short on measures. The tour was excellent - our tour guide Derek was very engaging and informative.Afternoon tea was however was cold, shambolic and short on measures. I'd very much recommend doing the tour but as far as afternoon tea goes, I'd recommend going elsewhere.
Parliament. Very similar to that one in Budapest,together with Big Ben forming an impressive scenery,great view from Westminster Bridge

Every taxpayer should visit. Went on the official tour on a Saturday morning, pre booked online. Our guide, Janet, was excellent as she confidently, and with great charm, explained the mechanics of the House of Commons and Lords with obvious enthusiasm. It was very interesting to see the Queen's dress room, walk through both the Houses, visit a Committee room and Westminster Hall. The security checks were stringent akin to the same as an airport but fairly swift. We learnt an awful lot and appreciated our privilege of living in a democracy even more.We also visited the previous Wednesday for Prime Minister's Questions after obtaining passes from our local MP. Again, great to see democracy in progress. I intend to visit PMQ's again sometime as it was fascinating.
Iconic and Inspirational. Beautiful buildings and such a vast history. Definitely worth a visit for local Londoners and tourists alike.
Historic. I just love to visit the Houses of Parliament at night, they're all light up and it just looks so beautiful. The pictures I've got are stunning.
Pretty building. Very pretty building and cool to walk a long. Remember to order ticket, if you want more than see from outside.

A great tour plus tea!. We chose the guided tour (a guide not a machine!) and had a fascinating one hour tour, which took us to parts of the Houses of Parliament which were not open to non-guided tours. I learnt an amazing amount of information about how parliament which I should have known having lived in London all my life but had no idea about. This was finished off with a cream tea overlooking the Thames - delicious sandwiches and cakes and great service.
Great experience. I had a wonderful experience the tour guide was interesting and knowledgable. Also had the opportunity to witness a debate which was incredibly interesting
Quick look. Wanted the guided tour myself but was outvoted by the rest of the party and had to settle for a view from the London eye, will plan a trip again no children !
Take the tour. We took the tour and it was a great way to see the inside working of the England government and some history as well. Too bad you cannot see Big Ben unless you are a UK citizen

Parliament Saturday English Tour. A low profile gem of a tour. The guide Brian was excellent and added to the experience he made the tour interesting, fun and answered every question put to him. At £10 per person it's got to be one of the best value tourist experiences in the capital. Oozing history, interest and learnt so much. Impressed.
Beautiful. We had a great afternoon at the Parliament, we really enjoyed our time there and we will definitely come back!!!

The centre of decision making. It was interesting to see where all the Parliamentarians meet to discuss much and achieve less all at our expense. The history oozed out of every precipice but we were moved on promptly by armed bobbies cautious of colonial interlopers (Australia).

EXCELLENT. A Great day out , long day though , go by train , see downing street , trafalgar square first , then have lunch , then do the houses of parliament tour , make sure it is the guided tour , one of the best tours i have ben on . in the afternoon , visit churchills war rooms , and then see outside of buckingham palace , all can be done , in a day ....
Wonderfull place. Beautiful building, nice place to take beautiful pictures. Very near to other important touristic points.
Must see!. We only visited these buildings from the outside. They are very well worth a wonder past as they are beautiful and impressively detailed.

Awesome location. This is an architectural magnificence and the ancient and traditional seat of our democracy. However arrogant are today's politicians, they cannot fail to be awestruck by this place that has been the place of work of our greatest leaders. As you would expect, everything is spick and span. You must come here!

Expensive but worth it.. I've ranked this as 4 star rather than 5 stars due to the price: £25 per adult for 1.5 hour guided tour (£20 for concessions). Having said that it is led by a Blue Badge guide...ours was very professional and knowledgeable. It was great to see the splendour of the Lords and the parts of the House of Commons that are commonly seen on TV! I also learnt quite a lot about the process of politics in this country, not all good! I would go for the guided tour over the audio guide tour I think - not much more expensive but much more interactive!

Annual awards. With 120 present in the Cholmondeley Terrace Room of the House of Lords for luncheon the atmosphere was buzzing. Food albeit very expensive was excellent and served promptly & efficiently.Our awards ceremony went very smoothly just unfortunate that not much time afterwards for networking as another function was due at 3pm
Great experience. Very, very knowledgeable tour guide. Go on a saturday and you get into the House of Lords and House of Commons. Find out where the terms "red tape" and "lobbying" are from.

great place to visit. we didn't go into the houses of parliament as it works out quite expensive for a couple but did walk around the outside taking pictures etc. the area outside was extremely busy. if you get off the tube at Westminster the abbey, houses of parliament etc are there as soon as you come out of the station.
excellent - but it depends on your tour guide. we had a tour by our MP and it was thoroughly excellent and very very intresting. highly recommended if you can get a good guide.

Wonderful tour. We did the guided tour. Cost a little more than the audio tour but well worth it for the insights and explanations our guide provided. We were traveling with our son, who is politics student. Did the tour primarily for him but was amazed by how interesting and informative it was. As we are Australian we were familiar with the Westminster system of parliament , but this tour is so rich in history that you cannot help but be fascinated. Absolutely beautiful inside; the architecture, furnishings, statues, paintings and history was fantastic. Having the guided tour gives you access to some of the roped off areas, such as the Queen's dressing room. Even the toilets are interesting - beautiful stained glass windows and stonework as they have been built into the original architecture.Visited at Christmas so no issue with availability of tours/queues.

A visit taking in PMQ's. Attended a visit to Westminster with my Son & 2 of his School mates. Arranged through our local MP. Absolutely marvellous guided tour of the Palace visiting the inside of the House of Lords, Westminster Hall & the Central lobby. Our tour guide was absolutely brilliant, telling us all about the history of the Palace while keeping it light hearted with funny stories & a few jokes. Also afforded us every opportunity to ask questions & have a good look around each part before moving on. None of the hustle & rush you get with a lot of guided tours. The guide made sure that we were in the Central lobby in plenty of time to see the Mace procession into the House of Commons. Prime Ministers questions was exactly as I expected. The School children I was in charge of were better behaved than the so called leaders of the Country. Absolute nonsense, they ought to be ashamed of themselves. After PMQ's the House emptied like a fire bell had gone off. Honest, the MP's were out of the House BEFORE the people watching from the public gallery. Overall thoroughly enjoyed the visit simply because of the tour guide, he was brilliant. Wish I could remember his name so I could thank him personally. Well worth a visit & you have plenty of time left to visit the other attractions nearby if you wish to do so.

Take a good tour. Security has improved very much over the years. This is an incredible tour, especially if you are fortunate enough to be able to see lots in both Houses. Every time I have managed a tour I have generally learnt something new. I remember being told the meaning once of being called to the Bar when I went on a tour.

Absolute must-do item for a London visit. Fascinating insights into one of the world's oldest sites of democracy. The buildings are fabulous, the history fascinating and the guided tours are excellent.

Not to be missed. I was recently on business, due to have lunch at the House of Lords, and got the chance to take a tour of both Houses in the morning. The tour started in Westminster Hall and we were very fortunate to have a very knowledgeable lady from Hansard as our Guide. We were all totally enthralled by the sheer history of the place. We stood amidst the benches in both Houses (seating by the public is prohibited) and were able to capture some of the atmosphere of the debating chambers. I loved the Division lobbies and the full explanation of the voting process. We should be thankful Tony Blair was outvoted in his attempt to introduce electronic voting! We were still at lunch when the daily Speakers' Procession took place at 2.30pm. This was such an enjoyable occasion we've resolved to return: do the tour again; sit in the public gallery and watch a debate. Word to the wise: there are some opportunities to sit during the tour but there's a lot of walking, so be sure to wear sensible shoes.

Anyone welcome. I was fortunate to sit through a parliament session. If you arrive by 1:30pm, they give you access to the gallery and tell you how the parliament works - for free! If you just want a tour of the building you have to pay. There is a security check line, but otherwise it is very easy to get in.

Recommended for Everyone. We were able to visit recently and what a good experience. The history, architecture and surroundings very impressive. Not really that politically minded but found the background and procedures interesting. Had opportunity to visit both Houses of Lords & Commons and slightly disappointed at the speakers who were very verbose and long winded and some training needed for a lot of them. If you are going to fall a sleep in the commons which is not surprising ! why be there in the first place. Certainly worthy of a visit if going to London.

Take the Tour. We had a great insiders' look at history. Our tour guide was delightful and knowledgable. The only thing better would be to be permitted into the gallery when the House of Commons is in session.

Audio tour. Would definitely recommend this tour. Thoroughly enjoyable. Security was thorough on entering, quite rightly, but the whole place was wonderful and the audio tour gave lots of details about everything. Would go again.
Geordie Gastronomes. Very impressive, iconic building. A must for all lovers of democracy! Lots to do and see in the surrounding area.

Let Down. Unable to grasp why the area is Dirty, given the fact this is the capitol of England and is visited by every nationality under the sun, why is no care and attention taken for infrastructure and general maintenance. Unbelievable.

Best view from south bank (day and night). Having always only seen the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben from up close as we walked the sights, on this visit we happened upon the iconic view as we did the BrakeAway Bike Tour - which took us on the south side of the river. So I realise to get this view you need to gather your energy and walk away from Big Ben across the Westminster Bridge and along the riverbank. Then you get the view you see on the TV ! We also got another brilliant view by chance when we got the evening red public bus from the Imperial War Museum to Trafalgar Square, as this bus goes from the south bank over Westminster Bridge and we saw the House of P and BB all lit up in the dark, for less than a 2pound busride.

Amazing!. Parliament was not in session in the summer of 2014 and we were able to secure a tour of the interior of the building, both the Houses of Lords and of Commons. It was a personal tour through English history and culture. I don't know when or if Parliament will next be out of session and/or if tours will be available. But, please, if visiting London and this is of interest, TRY! It was a marvelous tour and an amazing time machine. HIGHLY recommended!
A must-seen place if possible. Everything was fine, organisation, amount of people, audio-guided tickets with slotted visit time.Book it in advance. Maybe a bit pricey overall to say something.

better at night !. One of the best building in the world. Huge and beautiful, for the best view better to go there at night. Unfortunatelly there is too much people.. and it's really hard to take a good pic.

Booked tour. The website was not accurate about picking tickets up on the day - you do not have to go to the Booking Office. If you have not printed the ticket out make sure you have the reference number handy. The tour guide was excellent, very knowledgeable. A pity we could not go into some rooms as they were still dismantling scaffolding, The guide managed to adjust her tour.

Do the tour!. The building its self is of course beautiful and is in one of the best areas for tourists in London. But, if you have time I would definitely recommend doing the guided tour around it as it is really interesting and you get to see the House of Lords and the House of Commons too!

definitely worth the guided tour. obviously it is a beautiful building in a great touristy part of london, but i would definitely recommend doing a proper guided tour around it. you're taken in to the house of lords and the house of commons and the tour as a whole is really interesting.

Amain. The architecture of this place is amazing. And the fact that the public is allowed in is a testament to the freedom of the country itself. Although its a shame that you cant take photos for most of the tour for security reasons, it is well worth the time and cost to see the magnificence of the building and its history.
Normal tourist. I didn't go in, just did the casual walk by. It is a lovely building, they were under construction/renevation on my vist

Wonderful place. We really were fascinated with that visit. The place is wonderful and full of history, we enjoyed every minute we spent there. This is "must see" in London. Would recommend audio tour!

Public gallery visit. How amazing that a foreign tourist can visit the House of Commons and sit in the Public Gallery and watch the pollies live in action. We sat in on a debate about Energy pricing and found the process very interesting. After security checks you walk yourself up to the common area and into the viewing gallery. The interior is quite old and to see people going about the business of government is a nice change from the outside of buildings. Well worth an hour or two of your time.

Must be seen. Great Gothic architecture built to match Westminster Abbey's very old building. It's iconic for London, you can't miss it and it represents London itself. You also must hear the story about Guy Fawkes as it is linked to the building.
Beautiful Building. Lovely building that is full of history. Would love to go to work there everyday! Worth watching a debate in the Commons - lively and interesting.

January 2015. I had wanted to visit the Houses Of Parliament for some time. I booked the audio tour. This lasted for about an hour, and it was fascinating. I would recommend this tour for anyone want to learn more. Well worth the money !

Interesting. London is a great place for history and tours, this was like many others, informative, interesting and entertaining, London is actually not a huge place and if you set out early, it is easy to get all the sites in on the one day.
A brill look behind the scenes. Obviously high security, but the tour was amazing, full access to commons and lords with a guide who certainly knew his stuff.
Great photo stop!. Go early in the morning, when you want to take pictures without other people in the frame. Beware of the people on the road, betting on fancy tricks.

Wish we had toured. It is a fantastic site. You can't believe you are actually there! I think my whole trip was like that. You start to realize how old and historical all these places are and it is amazing. We didn't have time to tour inside, but walked around the outside. Lots of security.

As an architectural cream cake!. Perhaps one of the most famous government buildings. Perhaps also the building that most people recognize in appearance ... We made ourselves a little mistake and went here that intend to come in and look at the inside of the building. The problem was the date: September 11 ... and the building was more or less completely closed to visitors. But we will try again at the next London visit! Either way, the building is in itself a major attraction and occupies several blocks in size. You can never watch enough of the details. The style is Gothic Revival and execution almost a bit like from a fairytale ... My thoughts go to both Sherlock Holmes and Guy Fawkes. One wonders how many millions of photographs taken at this building every year. One of London's 'must see'!
Iconic. To think this is where decisions are made (and the golf course) What a national treasure. Its got scaffolding over parts at the moment but we need to care for it as we are just custodians.
The Mother of all Parliaments. What did I like? Everything!What didn't I like? Nothing!As a Londoner, I am always amazed and overawed by the massive presence of the Houses of Parliament!

Excellent value. We had access to the Visitors' Gallery in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords, All the Police and Palace Guards were all helpful and knowledgeable. Great to see the process of Government in action.

Amazing to walk in the path of so many historic events. We booked a guided tour. We were very lucky to have chosen this day as the following day parliament was unexpectedly recalled and so we would have been unable to visit! That made it feel even more special. Our guide was very informative. Everything she said was fascinating. We went into the houses of commons and Lords and we saw where the Queen opens parliament and so much more. We saw how the voting works with the ayes and the nays physically registering their vote and segregating and the lobby where the word "lobbying" originated. I would recommend the guided tour rather than the audio.It brought parliament to life and it wasn't much more expensive. A wonderful piece of living history. We took our 2 daughters who are 19 and 21 and they throughly enjoyed it too.

The British seat of power.. I would suggest that anyone considering this tour take the trouble to book places in advance to avoid disappointment. The tour basically follows the route the monarch takes during the state opening of Parliament. The commentary is both informative and filled with the usual mix of British humour, well worth the ticket price.

Should these people run the country?. Took a trip up to the Houses of Parliament with our local Chamber of Commerce. The tour was guided thankfully because I am sure I would have got lost in this magnificent building. Well worth a visit to the Commons, the Lords and definitely the Queens robing room, you may even get a peek at the 'Royal Throne'.Did spend a bit of time in the public gallery until I started to lose the will to live!. Should these people run the country? The MPs I saw just seemed intent on squabbling with the opposition and just trying to get the last word - not too sure what some of these people are paid for.The building itself and it's history is a must if you are having a break in London.Has a small cafe area which seemed to very busy.

A Must!. I highly recommend the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. Jan, the tour guide on Saturday 17 January, was outstanding in all regards. The tour also provides insight into how Parliament works.

Must do Tour. We were in London for the weekend and it was amazing. Parliament is a must do. You get to walk throughout the entire place and visit the house of lords and house of commons. You also get a great tutorial on the history. I would do it again.

A Must. Took a guided tour around the Houses of Parliament with a fantastic guide who was so knowledgeable and made the tour very interesting.On the tour we visited the House of Lords and Commons, we saw the robing room that the Queen uses when she opens Parliament and may other areas. There is so much history within the walls of the Palace of Westminster and I suppose we do forget that it did started out as a palace. There is also amazing art work such as portraits of Henry the VIII and his wives, Queen Victoria and Nelson just to name a few. Another area we visited had statues and busts of past prime ministers, Churchill, Margaret Thatcher and many more.There are guidelines to be observed when visiting, you can't sit in certain areas but this was pointed out to us by our guide, I wish I could remember his name because he was a brilliant guide. Hats have to be removed before the tour starts and our guide was also asked to mention to someone within the party to remove the chewing gum they were chewing. I think it makes a pleasant change that there is a certain etiquette to follow on this tour and at the end of the day this is what makes places like this somewhere special to visit. I highly recommend the escorted tour!
Impressive Buildings. It just gives you a feeling of being a part of very old History. The architecture was quite intricate! Pity I was there in winter on a very cold day!
fantastic. the tour we went on was very good. the guide was very informative and helpful. You could visit most of the place, did not see any mp,s unfortunately.

Splendid and Historic. During trip to London, could take time out to visit the Houses of Parliament and really glad I did it by matching timing suiting to the tour timings. The guided tour is worth every penny. Though the entrance ticket might seem a bit high, but upon completion of the tour it would really not matter much. Walking thru the seats where the likes of Margaret Tatcher / Tony Blair etc. sat and debated would give a different feeling. So also the historic details of the Parliament and all the factes involved like the attendance area , private locker facilities for the members. The voting area wherein members need to pass thru an earmarked area was quite informative and interesting. The guide did a splendid job with all details from ancient history related to the Parliament and British monarchy. The customs involved were also explained and made us spell bound with vivid imaginations. In the end one gets to buy some gifts related to the Houses of Parliament. The place is a must see especially for History loving people...

Exciting to visit - A feeling of something special. Worth a visit anytime you can get in - just for the experience of the witnessing the affairs of state LIVE. If you can get in to a "Prime Minister's Questions " session, then you have hit the jackpot ... fabulous "warfare-type goings on" between the PM and the leader of the opposition ... can sometimes go close to "crossing the line" in terms of insults going back and forward ... which all adds so much to the experience - GREAT FUN !

WHERE THE ACTION IS!. Our local MP (Alok Sharma) arranged for some members of the ENRYCH organisation to visit.We had an excellent time.The building, history and guides were excellent.Our guide worked in the Houses of Parliament so had a very good understanding of what went on. Some of her asides were very entertaining!Everyone should have the opportunity to look round the seta of our government.
Great experience. Loved the personal tour by an MP who is a friend of a friend. Sitting in on a debate in the House of Lords was educational.
A little bit of History. Want to go again, so much to take in, an hour is not enough. Was lucky to have tea in the House of commons - FABULOUS !

Superior Service!. We didn't do the tour, but got to see the House of Commons in session (FREE). We went on a Friday amd there was no wait. No lone The staff were incredible, especially the guy who took our coats - as we were walking out he chased after us and offered to show us the House of Lords. Even though it was his lunch break and not his chamber he took time to show us everything. It was especially nice to see his intreactions with the security guards. I would love to go back on a Wednesday for Question Time.

Iconic LAndmark. Been several times for PMQs and the tour - really interesting place, good tour, great architecture and knowledgable staff.The new gift shop is great - I recommend the House of Commons Claret !

Much better than I expected . We pre booked the guided tour option which takes you to places where normal ticket holders can't go. Our guide was very knowledgeable and answered all our questions. Shame you can't take photos.

Fascinating historical experience. A visit to the Houses of Parliament is a must. To hear a debate take place is a really interesting event to observe, especially if you have visited other governmental seats in different countries. Parliament is centrally located next to Westminster and just around the corner from the London Eye. The statue of Cromwell in front of Parliament is just as divisive as it ever was. This is one of the London sights you won't want to miss.

amazing. It was amazing, not to miss out...visited the viewing gallery a few debates going on it was very interesting staff very friendly. a lovely building steeped in history a visit not to be missed .

Fantasic Access. I had the chance to tour my home countries parliament (Canada) a few years back, and was surprised at how much more access they allowed in the UK. I did the audio tour and found it to be pretty good. You are allowed to explore all of the major rooms and even walk up the aisles of benches in both the house of lords and parliament. Very happy with my historical tour of such a world famous place.

Amazing way to spend a couple of hours. My wife and l were given a tour of parliament organised through our sitting member of parliament. You turn up at portcullis house and are vetted through airport style security, given visitor passes and off you go. Our guide was the very lovely Katherine Toone who made our visit a memorable one indeed. From the house of commons and the upper house of lords, the fabulous paintings, the magnificent chapel and the overall feeling of being part of history was an amazing way to spend a couple of hours. The cafe and gift shop served delicious sandwiches and cake and quite possibly the nicest tea I've had in a long time, when in London make the effort to take this tour its very special indeed.

Houses of Parliament Is A Must See. Took a tour on Saturday and for the one and half hour really got a great perspective on the history and work of the Parliament. Visiting the House of Commons and House of Lords was fabulous even after seeing them televised. Many interesting pieces of artwork and knowing how the Queen delivers the speech and the way the House of Commons is summoned to the House of Lords to hear the speech is very interesting. Recommend to get a ticket for the tour online, but understand that on weekdays it is open to public and you can go and visit the public gallery. Seeing the statues of the great English parliamentarians is a real lesson in history. Very good shop in the Parliament as well as the Jubilee coffee shop. Very glad I visited the Parliament and learned its history.
Amazing.... It was amazing, not to miss out... Note that it has very limited visiting hour, so check in advance.
Good looking Building. not much to say really, didn't hang about for too long as it was raining however pleased I have been and seen it, fantastic building, loved Big Ben.

Majestic if nothing else.. The tours are fab but no often enough, the terrace bar is not really open to us mere visitors/voters, so Order! Order! Pugin's gothic style, gorgeous and grand, bear in mind there is no photography allowed inside so don't try it, they guards are eagle eyed, do not sit on the benches in either the House of Commons of the House of Lords, or stand at the despatch box, these things are not done so don't get yourself into any trouble, and what ever happens, dear readers, don't try to sit in the Queens seat, strict protocol for visitors and rightly so. The gift shop is very good and cheaper than I thought it would be, whiskey from there is poor though mind you, brought a bottle for someone and they said so and they know better than I. Unless its the guided tour you go on, don't bother, you will miss everything. The Great Hall where William Wallace was found guilty of treason and where the kings' of old had their coronation, though big and grand, was empty and disappointing. Tickets were £26.00 each if I remember correctly, too high a price for a place already funded by tax payers, and no, there are no discounts for voters, however you may vote!
Visit. Very interesting place ,we went there during the winter months i would recommend ,best time would be summer ,getting to read about the history,it was a get away for me and my Fiance

Pop for a Guide, not the Audio Tour. I took the tour with my sons (16 and 20). We've been to London several times, but this was the first time we toured Parliament. You can book tickets online well ahead of time, so you don't have to wait as you do at most London attractions. We were there during a busy holiday week, so it was good that we booked in advance, but I think if you're in London at slower times, you can find a tour time pretty easily at the last minute. The groups are small, 10 people or less, so you aren't jostling with crowds. They offer an audio tour, but I can't imagine why you'd do that. Our guide was an older woman, charming, knowledgeable and really seemed to like showing us around. You see pretty much everything you'd want, including getting to stand in the actual house chambers. Great combination of history and current political interest. You have to go through security. It's pretty quick and efficient, but make sure you allow time for that. Although it didn't seem like they were too rigid regarding tour times.

Worthwhile guided tour.. As a foreign traveler, the House of Parliament is no doubt one of the best places to start my exploration of the U.K.'s history and tradition. Here you will witness the long history and cultures of the U.K.'s political regime and mechanism, and get in touch with some exciting British political conventions through the masterpieces on the wall or the layouts in the Commons Chamber and Lords Chamber. The guide was comprehensive enough for me to look deeper behind the corridors, chairs and paintings in the building.
