Definitely recommended for anyone who would visit London, especially those from foreign countries interested in British political traditions.

Not quite united kingdom. I've been to the Scottish parliament in Edinburgh it was free, I've been to the Welsh Assembly in Cardiff it was free I come to London, Houses of Parliament and the audio guide (although good) cost £17.50 and a tour was £25. I did the audio guide at my own pace. It was very interesting to see the house of lords and house of commons in the flesh, seen it enough times on TV, and learn about some of the history; how it was not that long ago when women could not vote and only the privileged men could vote. The other issue I have is over photography, considering there is so much TV coverage and high definition TV's why can't visitors take pictures except in the first two halls? With the exception of those two negatives it was enjoyable and educational.
wow wow wow. thank you to our fabulous enthusiastic roger king , what a fabulous insight , really was 10 out of 10

Go inside! not just take photos outside. Wow, learnt so much by taking a tour inside. Definitely things that everyone should learn/know about. Pretty for photos outside but it makes such a difference to actually visit and learn

Busy but just about manageable.. We had left Essex early to avoid the traffic. It was still busy but our coach driver got us to our destination in good time.We queued for a very short time and were then allocated our guide, a lovely Swedish lady.The crowds were managed around the buildings quite well but unfortunately a couple of the male guides were speaking at the top of their voices with no regard to the other groups and guides. This was the only criticism.The airport style check in was managed with efficiency and good humour.It was possible to take photo's in certain parts and of course outside. I wished I had brought my SLR instead of a tiny borrowed camera. As their was no clear and up to date information about photography on the website, I assumed it wasn't allowed.Our guide had a wealth of knowledge and made our visit very interesting.

An organised Christmas present. My other half knows I love history so organised a visit for me - it was great! We turned up and after initial security checks we went to the cafe and had a brew before the tour. The tour itself was amazing I didn't think it would be as good as it was. It was really interesting as well - we had a proper know it all on the tour who kept interrupting the tour guide but she managed them well and kept smiling thru it all - i damn sure I couldn't have! Overall I would definitely recommend it to all!
Awesome Sunset Location. Was here in the spring and the sunsets from across the Thames looking at the parliament is stunning, Amazing silhouettes and views, definitely a must see.

Informative Experience. My husband and I enjoyed a very informative tour of the Houses of Parliament and were not disappointed. The tour did consist of mainly standing for the couple of hours which was OK with us but maybe difficult for others.

AS great insight. I took my family on a special Saturday morning guided tour - a wonderful experience taking in history and famous events! the guide was brilliant and so engaged! we all had a great time and then had a lovely lunch in the café facility. totally recommend!

Very interesting tour followed by afternoon tea on the terrace. My wife and I spent a very interesting and entertaining couple of hours in the company of a knowledgeable tour guide. The tour - comprising 21 people - took us through both The House of Commons and The House of Lords in all its splendour, plus other areas. The guide was very happy to answer any questions in detail that anybody might have. Following the tour we had a very nice afternoon tea on the terrace at The House of Commons which we had booked separately. All in all a very interesting and pleasant way to spend several hours

Impressive!. The houses of parliament also known as the Palace of Westminster was incredible. We went there after visiting the Westminster abbey which is right next to it. Just make sure you cross to the other side of the Westminster bridge to get the best view!!!

A MUST. Was not sure what to expect, so glad we went. Very informative guide, interesting facts, presented with humour.To stand in the House of Lords, then the House of Commons and committee rooms where all our laws are discussed and made was quite impressive. Definitely an hour and half well spent.

Fascinating tour of the Houses of Parliament.. Loved this wonderfully educational and interesting tour. I loved visiting Westminster Hall and both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. I wish the US Congress were more like the British, who seem, at times, even to LISTEN to one another.

Excellent Audio Tour - Amazing Building. Visited here with wife and 2 young children (7 and 4). Booked the audio tour because the kids were free and didn't think we would get the most out of a guided tour with them in tow! The audio tour is excellent and as you wlak around the building and are prompted to key in the next number on the guide you are also given the option to listen to additional commentaries on different subjects. The guide covers the building, the parliamentray system and also its history. There is even a special childrens audio guide which my son enjoyed. There was alot of security at the entrance but everyone was very friendly. There were also staff around the building who were answering questions.

Exceptional Audio Tour Which Exceeded Expectations. I visited the House of Parliament (the Palace of Westminster) with my wife on a cold afternoon in late December 2014. The tour looked interesting from the description on the website, but based on how restrictive tours of the U.S. Capitol building have become, I was not expecting more than a cursory view of the building and rooms. I was exceptionally surprised at both how accessible the audio tour was, and the excellent information provided through the audio recording. The security staff were very polite and welcoming. The ability to walk through so much of the building, including right onto the floors of both the House of Lords and the House of Commons was amazing. There were no crowds at all. If you are in anyway a student of history or political science, I highly recommend the tour. It was well worth the time and was very interesting. To those who have visited the U.S. Capitol in the past 10 years (I work in D.C.), this tour is much more welcoming, enjoyable, informative, and you are not made to feel like a security threat in visiting. Unlike the U.S. Capitol tour, this one I highly recommend.
Excellent Historical Tour. If you are history and politics buff like myself, touring parliament in a must. I had low expectations and left pleasantly surprised.

Wow! Absolutely Impressive!. We booked a tour of the Houses of Parliament and am I glad we did! This is a must-see on your trip to London. The history in those buildings is incredible and the facts and trivia that our tour guide supplied were fantastic. Make sure you book the tour, it's well worth the 2 hours in London. Make sure you give yourselves lots of time to get to the Ticket Office(a block away) and back before your tour time starts.
Must See. Right in the Westminster area it is a great thing to see close to Big Ben and Westminster Abby. You have to see it while visiting London.
fantastic building. The guided tour was wonderful and the building itself was spellbinding., we even got into see the members of parliament having a discusson

Historic & Famous. We really enjoyed this visit, it is so interesting to see the inside of these historic and famous rooms that you only see glimpses of on TV. We chose the audio visit that was excellent and very informative. We like to do visits at our own pace, as some guided tours can be a bit boring having to stand round listening to bits you are not interested in. But I did noticed on these guided tours that they seemed to use seating areas to give out information, which is much better for older peoples legs. You were only allowed to take photos in 2 rooms, which was a bit disappointing but maybe its a security issue?

Loved it. I booked tickets online. They just don't remind you of the time of your tour in the confirmation email which has your ticket so take a note of that - better customer service would be better in this regard. I was unable to print my ticket but this was not a problem - just take note of your booking number. The tour guide was very knowledgeable, clear and interesting. I would have liked to hear more about Margaret Thatcher. I also think the guide should have given more information about how to watch parliament when sitting ( how do you book etc.). If you have an interest in politics this is a must.

Well organised tour of the two houses. We wrote to our MP and got on a tour of the Two Houses of Parliament. The tour was well organised, insightful and interesting. Absolutely amazing to actually go into the House of Commons and the House of Lords, the grandeur and history of these buildings is stunning. You should go if you get an opportunity, it is amazing to stand in the place where the country is run.

Fabulous Stephen! . We enjoyed a wonderful guided tour on Friday 9th January at 4pm with a gentleman called Stephen. A consummate professional with humour, immense knowledge, absolutely one of the best experiences in London ever. The beauty and great history of this wonderful building is overwhelming, it really should be a must visit for everyone. The tour managed to evoke feelings of immense pride for being British and a greater understanding of our history and democratic system. Stephen engaged the group - it was relaxed, interesting, entertaining...just wonderful. Thank you so much, all of our group of 6 were so impressed with this visit. Do come, visit & say hello to Stephen! Sharon Earp

The Seat of Legistation!. I was in London while Parliament was out of session, so I was able to take the full tour. The most impressive event was to stand behind the Prime Minister's seat knowing the people who had held that position. The tour goes thru the Robing Room and you get the walk the actual path the Soverign takes for the annual speech. Quit an experience - especially if you've ever watched Question to the Prime Minister and the Annual Opening of Parliament.

Escorted tour. Probably my favorite of all the sites we saw in London. We did the escorted tour and had the best tour guide! She was so lovely and knowledgeable. We were not allowed to take pictures inside Parliament but it was beautiful. Would definitely recommend this tour. They offer an audio tour also but with the guide you get to go places which are roped off. The ticket office to purchase tickets is across the street from Big Ben.
Must see in london. Very well organised. We opted for the audio guide tour and found it very thorough.Be prepared for a very strict security check at the entrance.

Got the chance to see the "back stage" of Parliament. What a unique experience to see the session of the Parliament and the rooms where the MPs work. Ate with them and enjoyed the real taste of British Democracy, something to export all over the world!! The Canteen has a great view on the river. Some of the watercolors inside are really nice.

Interesting. Watched the debate on anti-terrorism bill. Fascinating to see democracy in action. Ironic to see democracy debate the battle with terrorists dedicated to bringing democracy down and how the debate insures that rights and freedoms are protected.

An architectural marvel. I adore the grandeur of this building. So gothic. Such an icon in an iconic city. A great way to view the scale of this building is via the London Eye, but also from across the Thames on the South Bank. It looks especially beautiful at night.

Breathtaking . Didn't go inside. Just walked around. I have been to quite a few large cities aroundthe world and seen some wonderful buildings... Sagreda Famille...places in Rome. . Anker Wat...Siem Riep. ..but there's no place like home... Houses of parliament are the most beautiful architectural buildings I have ever seen. You must go... say no more! Xx
Beautifil. This place is simply amazing. It's a very long walk so take some comfort shoes. But it is just beautiful lots of friendly people. To chat to along the way
Great. magnificent! loves seeing the houses of parliament, and west Minister was a little disappointed that you had to pay to get in to west minister cathedral!

Everyone should visit this great hall of history. It is impossible not be in awe of this outstanding monument to democracy, even if some of the politicians who work there don't seem to give it that level of respect. For all its grandeur it is a surprisingly humble monument to the service of a nation, and the silence and echos within its hallways are testament to the dedication that thousands have given over the years to trying to improve the world we live in. It is worth a visit just to experience the sense of history which is inescapable as you stare up at the ancient murals, mosaics, paintings, sculptures and carvings. This is a must see for anyone who appreciates both the influence of the past as well as the importance of the future.

Interesting visit. We went on a guided tour of The Houses of Parliament and found the visit very insightful and interesting. Our guide was pleasant and informative, offering a good insight into the way parliament operates on a daily basis as well as imparting historical information.
A great experience. I very much liked the tour which on a Monday included the House of Lords as well as the Commons. You go into both chambers and see quite a few other rooms.

Guided Tour. Top Experience.. Top experience, worth every penny. This tour was purchased for us as a Christmas gift and what a fantastic present. The Palace itself is amazing. Steeped in history, ornate architecture, customs and tradition. To stand in such an important historical site is a true privilege. The building was brought to life by our guide Diane who was highly knowledgable and clearly thoroughly enjoyed her subject.  Every bit lived up to our high expectations. A word or warning - if you visit in the winter it is very cold even inside. Wrap up as for the outdoors. The only other piece of feedback for the venue is that the shop appeared to be a complete rip off e.g. Small portcullis magnet £8.95. Everything we picked up seemed ridiculously over priced.
Sighteseeing. London has so much to offer in terms of monuments and architecture.. This is one of them ... It is a must to see when coming to London ... The architecture is beautiful

Magnificent, feeling very proud of our heritage. Went to meet my MP and was warned to get there at least 45 mins beforehand to get through security. Security is very tight with airport type scanners and Police with machine guns. Having said that, once through there the security was very discrete and non threatening. Police were helpful and had a sense of humour.Once inside, the splendour of the Houses of Parliment was stunning. Hard to describe but the word awesome would be appropriate, probably on a par with the Vatican. I went to one of the committee rooms and we had afternoon tea - small cakes and sandwiches which were all lovely.I can only suggest you go - you won't be disappointed!

Worth a quick tour. in the past I've been put off these type of attractions as they get a bit too heavy/worthy for a holiday bit of fun. Give this a yo - with the audio tours you can go at your own pace - skip though or get more detail as you wish. It gives a great insight into a great British institution.

Tour of Parliament. This was our fourth family trip to London, but we had never toured Parliament. So glad that we did because this ended up being one of our best travel experiences in the city and its environs. Our tour guide was wonderful and it was a thrill to visit the seat of British government. Her commentary helped us to understand Parliament's traditions, history, as well as its built environment. Well worth the time and expense.
A good aftrernoon tour. We did the guided tour which also allowed a tour of the house of commons.The afternoon tea on the terrace was lovely.I reccomend all of this trip.

Very impressive and interesting. We took the audio tour through and were impressed with the beautiful building and interesting rooms. It was fun to see the place where so much history was decided. The audio tour was commprehensive and not too long. It took us about 1 hour an 15 minutes.

Houses of Parliament Tour. A truly excellent insight into the surroundings, history and heritage of the "mother" of all parliaments. The tour takes you through both houses, Westminster Hall and several other chambers and covers in detail what actually happens in each house when parliament is in session, the overall process of parliament along with the traditions, pageantry and state occasions. Each separate narrative is filled with fascinating facts (such as the words and phrases that have found their way into everyday vocabulary eg. Crossing the line, three line whip,etc) and to see close up such things as Black Rod's indentations on the doors the House of Commons and the marks made by a nervous young Queen Victoria before state openings, amongst other things, is very cool.I would recommend this tour to anyone, reasonably priced and well managed; not to be missed, but book in advance!
Parliament. Such a gorgeous building right beside Big Ben and The London Eye. Def worth a visit, not that you need long to stare. Perfect spot for pictures with your travel companions.

Amazing place don't miss it. We went to visit in December 2014, it was a busy time and we thought we would have to wait for a while to enter but it wasn't too bad. You need to go through a security check but that's understandable given such a significant building. We purchased tickets across the road you have the option to purchase a ticket with an audio tour which is well worth doing and very informative. You can select a short version of information but if you want to hear more in certain rooms you can access more details. You can book tour guides and as we were wandering around we came across a few groups. The ticket price is good value there are a number of rooms to visit. We would recommend a visit.

Excelent trip - take the guided tour not audio tour. This was brilliant. The tour is great. our guide was well informed and humorous. Its a pricey enough trip but thought this one was well worth the money. I guess its more interesting if you are British due to a feeling of it being your routes but definitely recommend this

FABULOUS. We took a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament while they were on break over the holiday. Our group included families from Scotland, Australia, and the Netherlands. Our guide found a way to compare their governments to that of the UK. She showed us the path the queen takes when she opens parliament every year. We were able to go into rooms that the tourists with regular audio guides could not. HIGHLY recommend!

Incredible experience - well worth a visit. Steeped in history, this is a great visit. Well worth paying the extra for the informative audio tour, the tour includes walking around both chambers of the house. Incredibly, you can walk between the benches and stand at the dispatch boxes. A great visitor experience.

Very interesting and highly recommended. We took the audio tour and found it exceptionally good. This is an amazing place with palpable history.The building itself is spectacular and it is great to see the rooms that one is so familiar with from the television.The history adds so much more to it.The audio tour is long enough to be interesting and not too long to overpower you.This is definitely somewhere to see.
topper. You've must have seen this while visiting London for the first time. We walked from Big Ben to the Tower Bridge near the river Thames. Some artists were performing. Surprenant !

Guided tour is excellent. We booked online for a scheduled guided tour a few days in advance during the busy holiday season. All went well (pick up tickets at the Cromwell Green entrance), there was no line-up and going through security was quick and painless. The only tour that was available was fairly early for us (9:30am) but this turned out to be good because the crowds were not out in full force yet— I'd recommend booking an early time during busy holidays. We had a terrific guide (Shellah) who walked us through the gigantic structure following the course that the Queen takes for the opening of parliament. The tour doesn't just cover England's parliamentary system but also gives a great perspective on the history, art and architecture of the building. We found it interesting and really informative. It's a fairly lengthy tour of about 1.5 hours, so I wouldn't recommend it for young kids. My 17 year old son is studying law and politics in high school and quite enjoyed the tour. In terms of value for money I found this tour superior to the Tower of London tour, which was very good, but uncomfortably crowded (though in fairness we probably hit Tower of London at its peak of busyness).

Simply amazing view!. It's been my dream to take picture of Big Ben and House of Parliament at sunset at the opposite side of River Thames. Everytime I visit London always for a very short business trip.This time I did it !! Luckily the weather was perfect for taking a nice photograph. The evening scenery of Big Ben is simply stunning!

Very very special. The guided tour was marvelous even though there was such a gold mine of history there (if time allowed the tour to last a year or two...!). Afternoon tea overlooking the Thames was nice even if in a marquee [spelling ??] of sorts. I thoroughly recommend a visit to the Houses'.

Visiting the place you spend your whole life seeing on TV!. Me and my brother visited in January 2014 because we were in London and fancied doing some touristy things.It made clear when we booked online that the security was like airport security - and that's very much the case - expect to empty your pockets, go through a metal detector, have bags go through the x-ray scanner and possibly be patted down by a guard. Be sure to check the website thoroughly and ensure you're not carrying any prohibited items.Even when we got through security there's still armed police hanging about, and the tour guide told us that we must keep our passes visible at all times, that we weren't allowed to take photographs, nor were we under any circumstances allowed to stray from our allocated tour group. He didn't exactly say what would happen if we did, but I got the impression you'd likely be met with some degree of hostility!Arrived in Westminster Hall to wait for the tour to start - this is where they've got plenty of leaflets and a well-stocked gift shop.When the tour started it was immediately obvious to me why the security is so overbearing, every single room of this building is a national treasure! The attention to detail is absolutely staggering - there isn't a wall or ceiling in the whole building that hasn't got some magnificent painting, wonderful stained-glass window, or sculpture made of gold or something - even without the history being a factor, this place is worth a visit purely on the basis of it being such a glorious architectural spectacle.We visited on a Saturday and so parliament wasn't in session - this suited us perfectly because it meant we got to go in the house of commons and house of lords chambers. I had always thought the public weren't ever allowed in there but it turns out I was wrong - and I found it to be a magical experience - unexpectedly walking past the dispatch box where the PM stands, I don't know how I can emphasise how magical I found it - you know when you're having problems with a significant other, and everything sort of seems irrelevant compared to love - well I think this is the kind of place that was epic enough to have distracted me (Tower of London earlier that day didn't manage it!).Also must mention the tour guide - he was brilliant - very friendly and knowledgeable. The tone of his tour was quite refreshing too, I thought it'd be quite formal and stuffy but he didn't mind having a laugh about things and making jokes about the popularity (or lack thereof) of certain politicians.Definitely recommend. If you live in the UK and watch the news occasionally then you need to come here once in your life.Top tips1.) VISIT ON A WEEKEND OR WHEN PARLIAMENT NOT IN SESSION SO YOU CAN GO IN CHAMBERS2.) No photos allowed3.) Check security guidance before visiting, many items prohibited4.) Don't get too hung up on looking at what the guide is saying, take time to take in your surroundings

Up close and inspiring. We did the audio tour with our 12 year old son, we found it probably one of the best value for money tours we have done in London. We were surprised at how many rooms of great importance you could walk around at your own pace with the audio tour. We booked on-line with a time slot which means you don't have to queue and the price much cheaper.

Fascinating visit to the home of democracy. I went on a special Member's tour, arranged through the MP of a friend. It seems that groups of up to about 20 can arrange this fairly easily, first thing in the morning before the Houses sit and with advance notice (we wrote in 2-3 months ahead). As such we had fuller access to the many parts of the building including both Chambers, than in the more limited public tours. It is a very impressive building even though the magnificent Westminster Hall is the only really historic part, and much bigger than it looks from the outside. There are innumerable attractive artworks and artifacts of interest, although necessarily heavy on Victoriana, given that so much of the earlier stuff must have been destroyed in the 1834 fire. The Guides are really knowledgeable but ours seemed to stick to a prepared script. Given the composition of our particular group, he underestimated our level of knowledge of both the political process and history, so it was mostly through questions that we learned anything new. We did feel rather hassled to move on, as a result of all our questions. Having said that, it was thoroughly worthwhile and we felt very privileged to walk on such hallowed ground.DO follow the instructions to arrive early, the security process is very lengthy indeed, airport-plus.There is quite a nice cafe to sit in afterwards and digest all you have seen.I was in a wheelchair after knee surgery and was easily accommodated, indeed I saw even more of the corridors of power than my friends, including the famous turntable in the inner courtyard for turning round Royal Mail vans..

The greatest tour you will ever do....... This is without doubt the best tour you will ever do anywhere. The history, the traditions, everything about it is fantastic. You get access to all the ares you would want, from the Commons to the Lords. The only problem are the long wait to enter and no photos allowed. Worth every penny.

Very interesting and informative. The visit was very informative and interesting. I was amazed that we could see so much and indeed could see so much that is familiar from television. The audio commentary is helpful.
Fantastic. Although these buildings are a London landmark a visit inside brings it all to life. We took the audio guide and this was more than satisfactory. Highly recommended.

Visit with friends from california. Last time I went here I was 12 years old on a school trip. Now somewhere in my 50's went again and was able to really take in first of the splenda of the building truly fantastic. Then listening to the audio tapes as you go from room to room and hall to hall you really get the feel and understanding of what goes on there. So worth a visit. I will be going back at some point.

Interesting trip. Very interesting to see and learn about an establishment which features in every ones lives. Able to follow the history and find out how the house's and the monarchy interact. The audio guide is all that is required
Iconic London. This is one of the most famous London sights! Great architecture and really impressive! A must see in London!

Worth a visit. We booked a guided tour and this turned out to be a very efficient way of viewing the buildings and learning about the function and history of parliament. My high school son who is very interested and politics and government really liked this tour as did I.

A spectacular visit. A friend and I took the headset tour. Westminster Palace is a piece of history that all can enjoy. The fact that the former royal palace is also home to the Houses of Parliament make it all the more interesting. Historical artwork, tapestries and sculptures are everywhere and the architecture is just spectacular. Why don't we build buildings like this anymore?

Houses of Parliament Tour. Brilliant tour through the Houses of Parliament. Our guide Derek was funny, knowledgeable, passionate and provided an interesting tour with both historical and current information about the working of the English Parliament.Well worth a visit.

PM question time on wednesday at 12 noon is fun. If you live here you can get tickets to PM question time and see the MPs behave like children for 35 mins...If you dont live here and in a large group you can write to the culture secretary and request tickets for PM question time...there is now a glass barrier between you and the chamber as in 2003 someone in the gallery threw blue powder at the then PM...and spoit it for everyone...If you are lucky hang around the foyer by the gift shop and you see David Cameron, Nic Clegg and Ed the horse Miliband waking past...you can even stop them and chat to them...but make it light and unconfrontational..go for tea/sandwich in one of the cafes-quite cheap.

Thoroughly enjoyable - audio worked for us. We really engaged with this experience, the gentleman on the Big Ben stand was charming, the information on the audio was excellent. My mum at 75 could have done with more seats to sit on but all in all excellent, informative, interesting and a good cup of tea at the end.

The best tour. This tour was by far the best that we've seen in London. You do need to purchase tickets, however there are discounts through the website. The guided tour is well worth the price. The tours are led by blue badged guides, ours was Jackie, who was outstanding. She explained everything with such interesting detail, we were fascinated with the history and ceremonies of Parliament. Our family including young teens who bore easily, thoroughly enjoyed this tour. Do not miss this treasure in London!

Iconic. Walking around this truly iconic and historic building is awe inspiring. The architecture is a sign of the great things we used to build but sadly rarely seem to anymore. Big Ben chiming adds to the occasion and the many statues of people in the sq nearby

Great place to visit. A great morning out to visit the Houses of Parliament. Also has a very reasonably priced cafe with fresh food. It is a great tour of the House of Commons and the House of Lords taken around by a very knowledgeable guide.

Inspiring couple of hours. We went to the Houses of Parliament as a way to kill a couple of hours before a dinner in London, and were blown away with the history and the architecture, and that we could, quite literally, stand in the Chamber at the Dispatch Box.The staff go out of their way to bring it to life for you too.

Come on down, the Price is Right!. Very interesting! Staff was nice, good historical displays in main hall. Really fun to sit in on Houses. Well worth it. No wait of any kind on any line for anything.
Nice people. I had to make a visit for work purposes to the houses of parliament and the people there where very helpful and friendly.

Cool from the outside. The Houses of Parliament are pretty cool just from the outside. We didn't go in, but walked along the Thames from Embankment to the clock tower and parliament. Take a few minutes to walk over the bridge to the south bank, down a bit towards the aquarium and the London Eye for great views of the Houses of Parliament from across the river. Then walk back towards the clock tower on the left side of the bridge for close up photos of the site. Pretty cool!

A fantastic audio tour.. What a wonderful tour of the House of Lords, the star chamber otherwise known as the central lobby & best of all the House of Commons. Anyone interested in British politics or the history of parliament will not be disappointed.The guides were always on hand to answer any questions & I was amazed to be standing on the benches where PMQ's are played out every Wednesday...audio device was excellent, cafe also very good & reasonably priced.Probably the best day out I have ever had in London, thoroughly recommended.

An iconic building.. The impressive Parliament building is even more impressive when you enter it.Make sure to take a tour inside, as it would provide you with very interesting information about the UK democracy and parliamentarism.Highly recommended!
best views. this iconic and tradional buidling is my favorite in London. the architecture and the night view is spectacular,I really recommend that you spend sometime here.

Glad done once. Went in middle of December. Booked on Audio tour. Have to go through Airport security so allow plenty of time. Audio tour good with good commentary. Each area has a number so just press relevant number when at different sections. Get to go inside MP debating chamber and House of Lords. Didn't realise so many chambers/rooms. Plenty of history. Booked afternoon tea. Not many sandwiches and only one scone each although unlimited tea. In a marquee next to River Thames. Nice view just cheap seats/tables and location. Wouldn't book afternoon tea in hindsight. Enjoyed the tour though

More police than you could shake a stick at. Everywhere you look, there is a policeman, try to get in through the scanners, airport style. There are more police than ever. Understandable why, given sensitivities.

Here here. Well worth the money to do the audio tour of this very ornate and impressive building. To see the houses of commons and the house of lords for real instead of on the TV put a lot of things into perspective.
The home of democracy. Visit the Palace of Westminster if you get a chance. It's a gem. The Strangers Bar is a lot of fun but you'll need an MP to take you there.

Take the tour. Westminster Palace (a.k.a the Houses of Parliment) are impressive from the outside,but even more so from the inside. Take the tour for a look at the interior and to learn a little about English law and the traditions associated with it.
a must to see. interested in politics, history, the latest legislation etc. the place is for you to see... beautiful rooms inside, visit House of Lords and Commons

Must do list in London. If you come to visit London, around Parliamnet Square is must visited place in your list. Big Ben, South Bank are all within same area and got wonderful feel about London. The best to see the building from other side of Thames River opposite House of Parliament.

Historic buildings. You can explore the exterior and admire the architecture and read about the history. There is a tour but unfortunately I did not have time to go on it. Pro tip - it is a secure area, be prepared for security.
Very enjoyable. If you have a good tour guide the anecdotes are better than the history of the building. Expensive to get in but glad I have been and would highly recommend.

Great if you love history . Such a cool place to walk around. And our tour was very engaging and informative. Shame that photography is not allowed, but I guess that's to be expected.
Note that if you buy your tickets in advance online, the box office to pick them up has limited hours.

Best guided tour ever!. This was my first time visiting parliament after over 20 visits to London. This was by far the best tour with the best ever guide. The information was relevant and interesting, delivered in a professional and witty manner. My 8-year old son was mesmerized. I was surprised that he was focussed and captivated despite it being such a long tour. I have two teenagers who also found it an exceptional experience to be physically present in such a historically and politically important building. This tour is special and different from the rest.

Brilliant tour.. We had a very informative and interesting tour from someone who works at our MP's office in the Houses of Parliament including all areas you can do on the audio tour but as the Houses were not meeting in late December when we visited we were able to see the House of Commons and walk through it and learn a lot you don't get from books or watching it on TV. The House of Lords was having work done to the room but we looked through windows inside and it was incredibly ornate looking from where we were standing. We saw how and where MPs vote and loads more as well, including the chapel under Westminster Hall, although this is rarely open. Westminster Hall was fascinating and is the first point you enter after the long security check (taking off bags and outer clothing to go through a scanner as at airports and some people get searched although you can take your bag and coat around everywhere with you (possibly not to watch debates though )). We learnt so much and were so grateful to the gentleman who took us around for much more than an hour and will definitely be back to do the audio tour in the future, although it is expensive, because my brain isn't able to retain a lot, but the huge amount of info we were given couldn't have been better presented and again we are really grateful for a brilliant tour.
Part of the history of London. A great place to take photos of this old building, especially as it is situated next to Big Ben, a must view for all visitors to London

Great London Experience. Would recommend this to everyone - tourists and all UK residents. Took my grandson after visiting the Abbey and the Supreme Court. We were welcomed and after security we were able to visit the Commons Chamber where a debate was in progress. An armed police officer engaged my grandson in a discussion about the arms he was carrying. Grandson delighted!

TOUR OF HOUSES OF PARLIMENT. I was fortunate enough to be taken here for a tour and then a cocktail and speeches venue afterwards in their large function room. Security was tight and brilliant and the whole tour was of great interest also very accommodating as I was disabled and arranged for me to use a lift instead of the large stairway.
informative. I did the 90 minute guided tour. Well worth the money. Obviously a hugely significant building, then coupled with an interesting tour guide. One of the best things to do in London.
Great tour. Very good tour guide who was able answer all the questions that were asked.See part of British history and walking the halls that are at the center of modern British politics.
Mother of Parliaments. You should see at least once, the real mother..Both Room of Commons as Room of Lords is very worthwhile

Beautiful Site. The week we went to tour, parliament announced it would be closed to foreign visitors. Talk about a bummer! We were so excited to actually go inside but we had to settle with taking pictures from the outside like the thousands of others. We did get some amazing shots and it truly is a beautiful building. You can't visit London without catching a glimpse of this beauty as it is not only a central location but it is surrounded by many other attractions!

Absolute must for a visit to London. This is a must for a visit to London - cannot be done on the spur of the moment & needs some planning - usually for the weekends when its quiet - Requires online booking - Worth every penny.For such a visit to the seat of a democratic company, it is both humbling and interesting to see the British Parliament - especially this coming from a Scotsman.It is difficult to put into words the actual visit - but the architectural features - fitting details - historic stories - viewing the Commons and Lords as seen so much on the TV just mind blowing.

Very pretty_better from a distance. Wonderful civic neo-gothic building. The effect is stronger in the distance with the reflection of lights on the water. The closer you get to it you realize it's a lot smaller than expected. Beautiful stone work, detailing and perspective gimmick. Absolute must if visiting UK

Good Intro to UK Politics. Took a visiting American friend here back in May. It takes about 20mins to get past security, but when you're in you can go see whatever they're debating in the Commons, talking about in the Lords and just wander around the building. Felt like a great way to introduce Britain.

fantastic building. Wonderful - like stepping back in time. We did the audio tour and would highly recommend it - you can look around at your own pace and select additional information if you want to know more.
Trip with my students.. It was a history visit with my students I enjoyed it, l took them there for a history lessons on English history and they loved it.

Fantastic enjoyed it much more than I though i would. We did the guided tour and the group size was about 20. The guide was very knowledgeable and interesting. Lots of people at the end said how much they have enjoyed it, I would definitely recommend paying that little bit extra for the guide, ours was so well worth it.
So huge and detailed. Everyone knows it's image but it and the Big Ben tower are far more impressive 'in person'. Next to Its Abbey of course
A must when you visit London. It is simply one of the most exceptional buildings in the world. The architecture and feel of the place cannot be missed.

great and cheap. well ,our likes every think,we asked our local MP for a permit to veiw parliament and big ben all free if you go throught your MP , mind you it was a few years ago as for the date above could not go back 4 years it must be the best tour i been on in london
no entry. when we walked out of the tube entrance the House of Parliament was across the street so was Big Ben. I was disappointed the we couldn't tour the inside
Wet & Windy. Nice building the weather was not so good, cannot get too close because lots of police. The walk along the bridge was nice.

It's got the WOW factor!. I was not prepared to so enjoy this tour. It started off with a long queue for security, as like at the airport but my word it was worth the effort. Eric our magnificent guide was amazing & it felt that this was a one to one guide. What insight & knowledge he possessed. Be prepared to be engrossed in the history & culture for 70 mins. Well worth it!
Just like the pictures. Was part of an overall impression left with me forever. London in Christmas Splendour. Sunny clear skys happy people
Must see. Liked: inside and outside.Disliked: ticket office far from entrance. Recommended to have tickets prior to arrival there (online or at ticket office close to Westminster tube station)
Awesome. well you cant just enter the Parliament house but it is so very beautiful from Outside. Lovely it is

Amazing!. Wow! My family and I visited the Houses of Parliament and were shown around by a Tour Guide for 70 minutes. The experience was amazing and our Tour Guide was so informative bringing to life the past and present history. To see the inside of both The House of Lords and House of Commons was fascinating. If you are a resident of the UK you can book a tour via your local MP for free which I did although I had to wait about 6 months. However, it was well worth the wait because their were 5 members of my family on the tour so we did save money. Even if you're not very political I would still advise this tour because the Houses of Parliament is such a beautiful building steeped in history it was just a pleasure to visit.
We loved this part of London. Take the day so much to do in this location , Big Ben, Westmenster Abby , take your time soak in all they have to offer so very much history ,

UNIQUE AMBIENCE. The Palace of Westminster (its alternative name being the Houses of Parliament) is the meeting place of the House of Commons and the House of Lords; the two houses of the Parliament of the UK. It’s a truly iconic building, right in central Westminster and very near the London eye. Do not miss visiting the mother of parliaments, a gothic masterpiece, with a unique ambience and amazing surrounding off the Thames.

Interesting audio tour. I've always wanted to experience the Houses of Parliament, and the audio tour was very interesting. It's just amazing the history that has gone on within those walls! The tour is well directed and there is ample information given on the tour (with the options to hear more about various topics). It's a little underwhelming inside the chambers - without all the fiery politicians! An interesting tour that I would recomment to visitors to London.

A Guided tour is essential. Possibly England most famous landmark, the houses of parliament/palace of Westminster is a building that is certainly worth visiting. During the year this normally only occurs in Saturdays, although there are also timeslots available on most weekdays during Parliamentary recesses such as 19 December 2014 – 2 January 2015 (except 24-26th December, 1st January), 13-20 February 2015, 31st March – 6 May 2015 (except 3, 6 30 April 2015). English guided tours start every 15 to 20 minutes during the day and there are also three times daily visits for French, German, Italian, Spanish, Russian, and Mandarin visitors (be careful not to get on the wrong tour). The cost is 25 pounds and the tour last 100 minutes. Tickets are best purchased online viahttps://visit.parliament.uk/HouseofParliament/shop/ViewItems.aspx?CG=TOUR&C=HOPATThe tour is fantastic and takes you through all the major segments of the palace of Westminster including the Westminster hall, house of commons, house of lords, Queens robbing room, royal gallery, etc. Even to a non UK citizen the internal elements of this building is well worth seeing and the tour adds in essential context and history that you would otherwise not understand. I would certainly recommend it to others. Of course, the self guided audio tour is an option, but I believe the guided tour is worth the money.Be sure to arrive 20 minutes before the tour is to commence as you have to go through a fairly extensive security check, which often has a queue.
Awesome day in an awesome place. The building as a beautiful historic building in a great location on the river. You could cross the bridge and get awesome pictures.

Sounds boring. Dont let the politicians put you off. This is a lovely building and Westminster Abbey, Downing Street etc and the river so close by there is plenty to see. This Houses of Parliament building took my breath away, it is like an abbey !

Excellent couple of hours. This is something everyone should do. We often forget how much we have to be proud of in this country and the home of parliamentary democracy is certainly something of which we should be very proud. Some of our MPs might come across as idiots, but the building itself is extraordinarily beautiful and the history of our nation's development is well represented throughout the tour. The guide was absolutely outstanding. She had a huge knowledge of the building and told its story with a delightful touch of humour. The two hours flew by and I could have listened to her for a lot longer. The rooms are breathtaking and to stand in them is jaw dropping. Surely this is the best excursion you can make in London?
Superb!. Brilliant. Liked it a lot. Best to visit the area around thames in the evening.. and from near London eye!
A MUST. Go you learn so much. So much smaller than I realised. Gives you a different view of the place when you see IT on the TV

Educational and Interesting. Amazing to see all the info everywhere! To think you are standing in the same places as some of the most influential people in the world present and past, great for all ages!

Well worth a visit. Visited back in November. We were on a guided tour which I would thoroughly recommend. Wonderful architecture and art. Good to see the Houses of Commons and Lords and learn a bit about the history of the Houses of Parliament and how Parliament came to be.The café served good food at reasonable prices.

What a great tour!. I did the guided tour inside the Parliament. What a great choice! Although a bit expensive (25 pounds) and only available on Saturdays, if you are going, try to take it. Our guide told us a lot of histories and it's better than any history/political class.

Worth every penny. Hi,Last week during a one-week trip to pre-Christmas London, I had booked a visit to the Houses of Parliament and I was indeed impressed.First do nto book the audio tour as it does nto allow access to the chamber of the Lords and the Commons. Take the guided tour which is the same price (16 pounds).The quality of such tours often depends on the qualities of teh guide and I had real luck 0 but I feel the overall calibre of the guides in Parliament is very very high.Did you know the Queen of England is not allowed into the House of Commons. I didn't but if you take the tour you will find out why.By the way after the tour you can have access to the tea room for afternoon tea if you have pre-booked. Do not do it. It costs 24 pounds per person and the cafeteria for the mere mortals is fine.
Well worth a trip. Book a tour via your MP. They have to be of some value after all. Excellent tour and great to see inside. Fantastic works of art and lots of history.

Charity reception and tour of the Houses of Parliament. I joined a group of supporters of the charity "Contact the Elderly" which encourages inter-generational links and is dedicated to tackling loneliness and social isolation by organising local tea parties. As a personal volunteer, and also a corporate sponsor, I was invited to a drinks reception followed by a tour, led by Finchley MP Mike Freer. Security was relatively straightforward - much as you might find in any airport nowadays - and then we found ourselves in Westminster Hall, the oldest existing part of the Palace of Westminster, which was erected in 1097! For the most part, this is a very large, but empty (and cold!) space, but the ceiling is impressive and the history vast.Guided down corridors of statues and paintings, we arrive in Central lobby, and you begin to see the sort of impressive detail that makes the Palace of Westminster such a special place. From this point, the House of Commons is in one direction and, directly opposite sit the House of Lords. We were lucky enough to visit both.From the outside, this is a mightily impressive building - the detail is astonishing. However, even that did not prepare me for the House of Lords, which was simply breathtaking. Our guide recounted some interesting anecdotes whilst we admired the quality, the cleanliness and the tradition. A hugely enjoyable experience, and a tourist must (though I cannot vouch for the quality of any other tours).

A very good tour. I hadn't realised that the Houses of Parliament were open to the general public on Saturdays until we saw the leaflet in the hotel. We booked online and collected our tickets. Obviously much security round the place and on entry but nothing onerous. We had the audio tour and it was fascinating. Supposed to take 70 or so minutes but took us two hours, but it wasn't very busy so didn't feel that we should rush. The only thing that could be improved is the shop; it is only small and doesn't have as much variety of souvenirs as I expected, but overall a great visit.

Beautiful building and architecture. The houses of parliament are just off the square of Westminster Abbey and across the bridge from the London Eye. The buildings architecture is something else, so intricate and detailed. Most people probably just march past it but take your time to admire it! Worth seeing with some decent photo opportunities available too.

Beautiful architecture. One of the most beautiful buildings in Europe - finally we got in. The guided tour is really very informative, a great summary of history, politics, tradition and funny stories. The architecture is so nice, it's not easy to digest everything you see - the only negative is that you cannot take photos - but there's a nice book at the store for a couple of pounds so no big deal. It's a 90 minutes tour you'll never forget.

History and Tradition Up Close and Personal. The guided tour of Houses of Parliament is a wonderful way to learn about the UK political process and British history. The art work and tapestries on such a grand scale and traditions that have survived centuries are awe inspiring. Tea shop and gift center are convenient at the end of the tour. Book online ahead of time to ensure your desired timeslot. Allow 15 minutes for security screening in order to arrive at the starting point if tour in good time for your scheduled tour. You will not be sorry you included this wonderful tour in your itinerary.

As a history buff, I was very disappointed. I teach the English Civil War as part of one of my classes. This tour was all about the Queen's one visit each year. Much on the House of Lords. Almost nothing on the politics of bygone eras. Nothing about the very different operations of the House of Commons, or the military coup that ended in the beheading of Charles II. (I can understand why they steer clear of current issues, but there was virtually no historical coverage. The Parliament building from the 17th century no longer stands, but the present building is on the same site.I was so bored! The queen walks on a blue carpet when she visits. The painter of the House of Lords frescos was Irish, (Daniel Maclise was a great painter, but that wasn't mentioned, just his nationality.)And uncomfortable--a two hour tour where we had to stand, except for a five minute break. The tour guide for some reason started to remind me of Hyacinth Bucket on the old Britcom "Keeping Up Appearances" and the tour went downhill for me after that.Not to be wholly negative, the final coverage of the historical functions of Westminster Hall was moving.

See where your MP works.. This is a part of our history. To enjoy it best contact your MP and ask if he can arrange a visit for you. These are restricted in number as he must attend with you. Well worth the effort as it gives a special insight into the House.

War Cabinet Rooms a Must-See. if you time it right you can queue up to visit a session of the British House of Commons, which is sure to give you a laugh or two. If you time it wrong, be sure to ask an attendant what would be the best time to return. For me the highlight is the WWII cabinet war rooms, well worth the cost of entry. Imagine yourself as Winston Churchill as you take your mind back to the early 1940's.

Fascinating piece of history. Having friends in high places certainly helps enjoy the tour of the HoP a bit more. Can't say too much, but suffice to say the intrigues of history resonate within the halls so much, you can't help but be transported to a time when government actually had power. The main hall is a stunning example of medieval architecture, and the chapel off to the side of it is one of the most amazing rooms I have ever walked through.

Amazing Tour. Had a wonderful tour of the House of Lords and House of Commons.The House of Lords is unbelievable,it is so beautiful especially the ceilings and the grandeur of the place is overpowering.The House of Commons is completely different and looks sparse compared to the Lords.It is interesting to see all the statues of past prime ministers.it really is an incredible place.

A very special visit, thanks to Peer of the Realm, Lord Errol.... Some weeks ago, I visited the House of Lords with colleagues. It was a special treat organised as a thank you to keynote speaker, Patricia Fripp. The visit was all the more delightful as our personal tour guide was Lord Errol; nothing like a hereditary peer of the realm sharing his view of history. He gave us a fascinating step into his ancestry. His intriguing anecdotes were enlightening as well as entertaining. His insights into leadership made compelling listening.Did you know that Big Ben was built as a chimney and that three idioms in common parlance originate in Parliament; according to the Earl of Erroll, although as is typical of 'The House', these points could be debatable! In the House of Commons, check-out:In the bag... motions that will be put to members.Toeing the line... designates how close opposite parties stand - two sword lengths apart.Approach the bar... references a metal gate in the House of Commons. Strongly suggest you visit the Houses of Parliament, then you can write up your own story....

Entertaining on a good day. Most people never get beyond the front door - Cromwell Green entrance to plebs like us - but if you book well in advance (tours are generally fully booked six months in advance) you can get a guided tour with even tea on the terrace thrown in for around £27.50p. Security is tight, as you would expect, but to get an understanding of how one of the world's oldest democracies operates the minor inconvenience is worth it. Members' tours are also available to UK residents free of charge and must be sponsored by a Member of Parliament (MP) or a Member of the House of Lords. The tours are led by trained guides. It is possible to attend debates in the public gallery but again unless you have a free ticket access will not be given unless you're prepared to risk it and queue but ticket-holders are given priority. But it is worth it especially when rumbunctious MPs like the Labour Party's Dennis Skinner take to the floor. Known colloquially as the Beast of Bolsover, he was checked by The Speaker just a few days ago for declaring that half the members of the opposition are crooks. The House of Commons Speaker gave the request: "Please retract". And quick as a flash Skinner replied: "OK. Half the members of the opposition are not crooks". Wit and wisdom are not always guaranteed but, being a frequent visitor, I can not imagine anyone leaving disappointed ... as a tourist that is!

A MAZING. Not many people know this but you can Book a visit to the Houses of Parliamnet Via your own MP. I Did ..and had an amazing tour of the inside of the Houses of Parliament. The tour is about 75mins in all. Steeped in history..Tour guide is brimming over with information ..LIttle Tea shop plus Gift shop.. Not that expensive in comparision to other Gift shops.. Go ahead contact your MP.. Could take a few months to organise via the MP.

Astonishing luxury for Parliament. Parliament is open for visits on Saturdays. I reserved a time, and got an audio tour which was very well done. There were talks by the Speak the House and Black Rod and everything was explained in detail. The House of Lords is covered in gold - stunning. One can have tea and cakes in a cafe on the way out, or the same food for much more in a room on the river if you book in advance. Photos are not allowed inside at all.
Nice view. We saw the parliament while we heard about the Guy Fawkes Plot. Nothing better than history to understand the place.

Must do visit. The Houses of Parliament are one of the World’s most photographed and iconic buildings. I expect very few of visitors to London ever go inside. To get a tour it is necessary to book well in advance. For foreign visitors it costs £25 which is considerably more than other London sights and is only available on Saturdays and certain other days. Have a look at the website. UK residents can get a free tour by writing to their MP at least 6 months ahead. This is what we did. Even then be careful to pick a good day when the Chambers are not in use. You can get into the Westminster Hall part easily though and can also see debates. There is always a queue and the best way again is to write to your MP, especially for Prime Ministers Questions. Out tour guide was really knowledgeable about the building etc It was really interesting to see the emphasis in the pictures etc of Britain’s greatness in the world no wonder our leaders think they can sit at the top table as of right. What a confidence booster. Bearing in mind that it was built mid 1800s (apart from Westminster Hall) not as old as one would think. For anyone interested in their country this is a must do visit.

Rich in History & Spendour. We booked our tickets online at £17.50 each to view the houses of parliament. We had no means of printing them off so joined the queue to pick up tickets on the day and allocated time of our visit. After a short period of waiting we went through the main gates and security and easily enough found ourselves in Westminster Hall. After picking up our audio tour headsets we were free to guide ourselves through the halls, houses and corridors of power at our own leisurely pace. The halls and houses of parliament were some of the most ornately beautiful and historically rich buildings I have ever visited. The audio guides are superb with offshoots into more detail if you wish to listen at various points along the route. There are some seating along parts of the tour which is handy to stop, sit and listen and just take in all that you can see.Overall we spent 2hrs touring Parliament and it was worth every penny and minute of our time.
B. I do love these buildings such an iconic set , right in central London great photo opportunities near Big Ben and the London eye

if you get the chance visit. I was lucky enough to have an invite to the house of lords for a discssion from my ex university. This included a guided tour of both houses. Fascinating to see the mix of history and modern trying to live side by side.

The Mother of Parliaments. This is a great place to visit; where history was made and is still being made today. Get yourself an Audio Tour to hear accompany your walk. On the banks of the Thames, this can be combined with other attractions to make a great day out.
Must see along with London Eye. Very near to London eye. A must watch. Easy to reach using tube. Well managed and very well built and maintained. A great Landmark

This Is Where It Begins. Besides wanting to see a fantastic landmark, we wanted to feel the place where the concept of parliament more or less began 700 over years ago. We could not book a tour in time. But had a quick walk around the place. It was so gorgeous. We note that back then it started off like a King's Council. Presumably if Parliament is to act in the name of and interests for the people, the representatives alone should not just be the ones to enjoy the splendour and glory of the infrastructure.

Take a breath as you step into history. Just an honour to be able to walk through this incredible historical place.If you are lucky you will have a tour with explanations for the paintings, the art work and the history.A must see for any visitor to London. If you are ultra lucky, you might be invited to the bar on the terrace, that is the piece de resistance.The gift shop has exquisite items in it I strongly recommend the House of Lords wine, as an exclusive christmas gift.

Makes you appreciate our history but question its relevance today?. This is unquestionably one of our great landmarks and resonates with its rich history prompting you to remember your history lessons. It made me proud to be British and that such an institution has had so much international influence and how it draws so many tourists. I then watched a couple of geriatric Lords shuffle by and listened to Prime Ministers' questions and wondered does all this anachronistic political tradition relate to the modern world? Amazing place though !

Must see.. The heart of democracy is alive and well. 2015 is the 800th year anniversary of the Magna Carta. Much is being done to spiff up all parts of the structures, so it is restored to its glory. See it all by taking some time to see it in action. A must see; great brochures to explain and understand a parliamentary form of governing. a must do while here, great for kids too. nice gift shops for delightful keepsakes.

It's worth it. Though they only let you see just a small section of this grand august building, it's well worth the experience. The best time to visit is obviously the summer months and if possible visit the side next to the Thames to enjoy the fabulous views from the balcony.

thrilling historical tour. the guides showing you around are full of excellent stories - old and new - of how the rooms were used and when they were built and why etc - really intriguing - in some chambers, you were not meant to treat the furniture or fittings as 'your own' - they were the nations. the huge hall near the end of the tour is historically one of the most important places in UK history - truly interesting and impressive way to spend a few hours also .. highly recommend

a real fantastic place to be in. This sight makes you wonder the might of the British Empire in the years gone by. The construction quality makes you feel like you are one of the higher classes in UK.
History past and present. From the hall where Kings were tried to the heart of the Politics of Great Britain, it is all here. Not to be missed
Excellent service. Good location excellent service on reception and in the restaurant wide choice of breakfast 1st class
Cool. All is nice and tidy, it's a place of historical importance, many decisions have been taken in this place.

Tea at the Lords - with Lord Dearing. A brilliant, golden October afternoon when London is at its best,,I had been invited to take tea at the House of Lords. After verifying my identity with the burly policeman guarding the main door my host, Lord Dearing, with whom I had spent a year in mid career on the Sloan FellowshipProgramme at the London Business School (equiivalent to an MBA) , led me out to the terrace. The Thames moved past at a rapid rate as the tide was coming int. Lord Dearing, a senior civil servant and past Chairman of the Post Office, ordered the full afternoon tea - which included some strawberry tarts I have never tasted before or, alas, since. If you want to have afternoon tea with one of the best views in the world and with a highly educated and witty host (Lord Dearing, sadly,pased away recently after re-organising the nation's educatiional system) the House of Lordsterrace on a golden October afternoon has it all.

It's not all politics!. Aside from the obvious history of the Houses of Parliament, just entering the doors is an experience, especially for a Canadian whose roots both politically and culturally stem from England. It was a sobering experience, but quite funny too watching all the rapid to and fro-ing going on. Everyone in such a hurry and so serious looking! The guide however was informative and clever and stuck to the history including some very juicy scandalous stories of Lords and Ladies. It's an impressive building though so many areas are off limits that just begged to be explored! Maybe next trip.........
Wow factor. A great place to visit to see the ornate rooms and paintings in the lords the commons is not so ornate but still interesting. A little pricey but if you get a good guide it's worth it.

Not to be missed. Down side the queue for tickets, security was reassuring, recommend the guide book, and the audio guide enabled you to do the tour at your own pace.The vaulted cafe is a must. Loved the gift shop, something for everyone.You got a great sense of occasion, after seeing so many views on TV, it was great to stand in the central lobby and at the dispatch boxes. Quite poignant to see Churchills statue and the damage which was left to show damage from WW11. Totally awesome and a hugh sense of history and pride.

Steeped in history and mystery. A visit to the houses of parliament opens the door to hundreds of years of history and mystery . What is the difference between the Lords and the Commons,Who is black rod? Why did Henry VIII order the chapel be turned into stables . There is so much history in thus one place it would take forever to find it all.

History right in front of your eyes!. Huge, gorgeous buildings where so much history has unfolded! We heard a rumour that the parliament may be moving to a modern building in the future. What a shame that would be!

Worth a visit. A beautiful building..the heart of our country..you need most of the day to my mind to take in the whole feel of the place..Very, very impressive..unfortunately, unlike its occupants, for whom we pay inordinate sums of money, for little practical return!

Houses of Parliament 2014. My Husband and I went by train to Houses of Parliament this year with a group of friends. We met together in main hall then had a good Guide to show us around which was very interesting he had a lot of knowledge. Would recommend this tour if you have opportunity. Great day out
A great attraction if you like great looking buildings.. Westminister is a great area with a lot of history, from the houses of parliament to Westminister Abby church.

Do the tour - just amazing. The walking tour takes you threw both the commons and lords and behind the scenes. The building is ornate and majestic in ways you couldn't imagine. Such history and honour. A really enjoyable tour even if politics and history is not you're thing. A family (and teen) friendly experience!
Amazing Architecture. Great place to visit for the architecture and history. Loads of walking and waiting but well worth it.

every one should visit. We booked online for the guided tour followed by afternoon tea. The total costs was £105 not exactly cheap but well worth the visit. There are cheaper audio tours or one could simple arrange a visit through one's MP.Tickets were published online and collected from a well signed ticket office in Portcillis House. The tour guide was a very pleasant lady who knew her facts about the history of the building and main details. The total tour was about 2 hours in length and there are few times when a seat is possible. Some people with functional mobility problems will find the tour too tiring. Both the Houses of Lords and Commons were included in the tour. Having visited both Houses in the past in an official capacity one would recommend this tour to UK and Overseas visitors for the accuracy of the information provided as well as the welcomming approach of the guide. The afternoon tea on the Commons Terrace was very well presented, delicious and in a reasonable proportion. Recommended for all ages except the very young children and those with walking difficulties. There are the now standard security searches and no photographs are permitted. Visitors on a weekend day are unlikely to catch a glimps of MPs or Life Peers.
Had to see. We had to see this right? Liked it. It is good to say that I have been there. Nice buildings with lot of history in the walls.

House of Parliament. I took a tour of Parliament with a group I belong to. We booked it through our local MP and were provided with a tour guide who was very knowledgeable and made it very interesting. The tour took about 1.30 hours. If you book through your local MP the tour is free as opposed to going on-line and paying for a tour which is not cheap.I would thoroughly recommend this as an interesting trip.

Very interesting. You have to prior book. Security arrangements. Be careful what you have in your bag...I had a small pair of scissors. Had to hand them in. Guided tour very interesting and informative.

Company Tour. I was taken round on a tour with the company I worked for. It was absolutely fantastic and made me feel very proud of our history. The guide was incredibly passionate and knowledgeable and must love his job. I'm definitely going again and want to sit in on Priministers questions next time!
Amazing. great to be able to visit House of Parlement. Expect long ques but if you visit away from peak times its not too bad.
A good trip through the UK History. A must see if in London, whether from the UK or not, spend the time in awe of the building and its contents.
eating with MP. Had dinner with MPO and a group of business people. meal was fine, much drinking, MP left twice to vote!!

Historic and atmospheric. What can I really say about this place? It is built from history and the atmosphere generated by the building and people here is incredible. The architecture has something of interest everywhere you look.

Visit to the Big House. I was very fortunate to have been successful in applying for a permit to allow me to join a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. This was a truly memorable and interesting experience. Our guide David was excellent and very knowledgeable taking us into the House of Commons and the House of Lords. If you are visiting London, even on business and have a couple of hours to spare, this is a must. You may even be lucky enough to attend Prime Ministers questions I couldn't due to time but on a busy day in the House of Commons it would be something to see.
Beautiful Walk from Victoria Station. Walked from Victoria Station straight down to Parliament Houses and Big Ben. Great Tuesday. Walked over 7 miles.

No reservation but got in any way!. We did not have a reservation for the tour but were offered a pass to the House of Commons if we wanted to listen to the MP's debate. It was awesome. We got to walk through the beautiful rooms that you go through on the tour - we just had no guide. Once inside we received a pamphlet that explained the rooms anyway. While watching the MP's in the House of Commons the PM David Cameroon came in and spoke. This was the best visit we had.

Delightful (for legal nerds only, perhaps?). The building itself was under construction in the lobby itself, but we were able to sit in on a House of Lords debate (on the role of religion in society) and as a legal nerd and someone with a mild interest in British politics, it was heaven! I could have sat for hours but left to accommodate some school children. A really fascinating experience, especially if you can see a debate. Plus very informative brochures to help you along if you know nothing about British politics whatsoever, with details down to the seats of each party, monitors to view speakers closely, and a well-positioned visitor's gallery with a great view of almost all of the members' seats. Also, the NICEST staff ever (but know that you will be subject to search and have to hand over your phone, purse, jacket, etc. if you go into an actual debate).

Get a personal tour. The history comes alive with a guided tour and you get let through the ropes that those with the headphone tour cant. The blue badge guide was so knowledgable and witty - a mine of information and we could have listened to her for hours. A must see for locals and tourists and a great tea room and gift shop at the end, heaven!!

Good tour. I was recently able to arrange a private tour of the parliament buildings through my local MP. I contacted my local MP prior to my visit to London and was told that a visit would be fine. Since I was there in the summer time large queues had formed for guided tours, this was no problem as we were permitted to skip these and go straight to the security checks. My MPs secretary was able to show us round, I must add that a paid guided tour would provide much greater depth on some aspects of the building, but this was good way to save money and still get a great experience.

Very Informative. Great visit, really informed tour guide. The only downside was having to meet with the horrendous soulless ghoul that is my local MP. All in all will probably make another visit soon as I did enjoy the trip.

A pillar of excellence, a beautiful building with unprecidented levels amazing detailed design. beautiful artwork, amazing building, full of detailed design.visitors are allowed into many areas and as a visitor you feel like have been allowed privileged access.down sights are very poor disabled access, many stairs, stressful security staff who rush you, I do not recommend disabled people visit parliament, its impossible to navigate. I guess the building is too old to make accessible.
Great. Loved seeing the history of London, definitely a place to take your family while in London. Fantastic photo opportunities
Excellent tour. A great opportunity to get very very close to power in london. Well paced tour...not too serious. Lots of interesting anecdotes.
Lovely Building. such a lovely building the workmanship that went into it was awesome next time we must try for a visit inside.The area around it is fantastic, a must for anyone that likes history
A Private tour. What can you say! A stunning building steeped in history and atmosphere. Few other guests when I was taken around the Palace of Westminster.

A must see!. I've been there last week and I'm willing to come again. I loved the place, the architecture and its history. The staff is very helpful.
We went for the audio guide which for us was the best option. We have our time to stop and observe without any rush!
Palace of Westminster. Very inspiring and a great place to visit. Lots of history, I really enjoyed getting away from the hustle outside.

Very fascinated tour. The tour of London Parliament, also called Westminster Palace, is very interesting with historical views as well as an explanation of the political system in UK. The guide, Christine, was excellent and she followed in a very ordered way the tour with full explanations of what we see and why it looks like that.

Excellent tour and guide. We booked a guided tour of Westminster Palace. Our tour guide was Hilary. The tour started on time and lasted for around one and a half hours and took us inside the House of Lords and House of Commons as well as several other areas within the building. Our tour guide was interesting and informative and we all agreed that this was the highlight of our weekend in London. Highly recommended.

An amazing and informative tour!. We visited on a Saturday morning and opted not for the audio tour, but for the guided tour. We did not regret this decision! Our tour guide, Karen, was very knowledgeable and gave us a wonderful history of the buildings and their contents. We were also able to understand more about the traditions e.g. Black Rod. It was a truly enjoyable tour and we were able to ask many questions of our guide. Too soon our time came to an end, but we left full of history and a renewed understanding of our democracy.

History live. Super place to visit. There are adio and guided tours. Both are good. Everyone should make this visit sometime. You get to see the magnificence of the Lords, where laws are made, as well as have the whole process of Parliament and how we achieved democracy. Great. Food good in the cafe too. One thing to be aware of - you cannot sit down anywhere in the Lords part. You alo cannot sit in the House of Commons though you can do so in the no lobby.

Amazing place - how so much power can be wielded in two chambers. Went here with my brother and the tour also included a climb inside Big Ben. Westminster Hall is amazing where life and death were decided. The House of Commons is quite a revelation - but according to our guide can get very noisy when in session. A must see.
