Amazing place - how so much power can be wielded in two chambers. Went here with my brother and the tour also included a climb inside Big Ben. Westminster Hall is amazing where life and death were decided. The House of Commons is quite a revelation - but according to our guide can get very noisy when in session. A must see.
beatiful. this historic building is great it has a traditional clock at the top of the sky sraping tower.there is alot of tourists around so always look around for nasty thieves

take a private tour. as in places that have so much history, ( like the ruins of Rome etc) if you take a private tour, even a two hour tour, you get to hear all the things you would have never known otherwise, the insights and the gossip.its like Segway tours. In every major city I'll do at least one and if I can combine the two ( if kids are old enough) I always feel I have learnt so much more from the insiders who know the gory details and the alleys to walk through ! We had a terrific time but by ourselves I'm not sure we would have enjoyed it as much
Just have been outside. Great place to take pic. Take a trip there when its ligth and one trip when its nigth. Manye people aroud there.

Go see the debates in the Chambers. It is free to go into the House of commons or the Lords and when they are sitting watch the debates. The Lords is usually rather sedate but worth a walk up to the Strangers Gallery to see the room.The Commons generally will have more debates and it is a different style of debate from the US Houses.

Parliament Tour Incredible. I highly recommend booking on line a Parliament Tour (Saturday's Only). I did the audio tour and was quite impressed. They actually allow you to walk thru both Chambers. This is a must see if visiting London.
A visit to London must include here.. Well worth seeing and taking time to visit inside.Set alongside the River Thames.Don't forget to ask about Guy Fawkes !

One of Our Favorite Experiences in London. Wife and I thoroughly enjoyed this informative tour. They only give it on Saturdays, but it was well-worth it. Though it included a hefty fee, it was an excellent visit. If you're into civics and history, this would be a must-see in London. You could really soak up the history and feel the import of the establishment. Absolutely loved it.
Private tour by our MP. If you ever get invited to the houses of Parliament by your MP GO! we had a great day loved the tour and all the history. Cafe inside pretty good to for a soup and sandwich.

Guided tour of the interior was a bit boring. History can be very exciting and a shame that it is not during guided tours. Something was missing, and the interiors are not as exciting as it promises an interesting building from the outside.

A great place to visit but hard to get in. The problem with visiting the House of Commons is getting through security. Personally I find it offensive that our representatives are difficult to access behind this level of security.Secondly, if we had identity cards then one could separate UK citizens from general tourists and provide a fast track accessCurrently one spends up to 30 minutes or more lining up to go through security exposed to the weather while after security the walkway is covered. A canopy over the access queue is an urgent necessityThe reward is to access the House through the magnificent St Stephens Hall, one of the wonders of the Middle Ages. After that one is in the midst of high Victorian Gothic looking a little tired at times but one has t realise that this is a working place. Maybe it should become a Museum or for state showpiece events and the Parliament reconstructed and moved to Manchester

Write To Your MP To Get A Free Tour And An Insight To The Working Of Parliament. To get a free trip around both the House of Commons and The House of Lords write to your MP and it can be arranged. We did this and in addition to the tour saw PMQ's on Wednesday Lunchtime. From the outside you can marvel at the beautiful building and listen to the chimes of Big Ben.
Great British Architecture. A stunning piece of British Architecture sure to impress with it's great location on The Thames. Look out for Big Ben and hear the chimes.

Day out in London. Travelled to London to see the poppies at the Tower of London, very emotional and overwhelming experience. Afterwards my friend suggested we go to the Houses of Parliament, as we were so close by and it is free to go in, a bonus. Had to queue for a short while to go into the House of Commons public gallery, watched a few debates, then went into the House of Lords strangers gallery to watch a few more debates. A really lovely old building, beautiful stained glass windows. Well worth a visit.
One of the must see attractions. Allthough have a bit if a wait to get in its very worth the wait plenty to see steeped in so much history maybe more than one visit to take it all in

So much history..... One of the many reasons I love London is that it is steeped in such rich and ancient history. The Houses of Parliament are no exception, part of it dating back to the 1000s! We had the best experience when we had a guided tour in the summer through our local mp. Seeing both commons and lords was amazing and all the history that goes along with it. This was the absolute highlight of our trip!

One of coolest things I have ever done in London was . . .. spending time in the gallery overlooking the House of Commons at work. Truly extraordinary. Was happy to wait in line to gain entrance. We were escorted through the majestic halls of several parts of this enormous, ancient palace on our way up a narrow staircase where we waited yet again until there was room. I spent 3 hours watching the workings of this august body. Liked it so much I went back the next day. Still have the photo id they took while we were all carefully vetted through security. Wish I had a photo of it but they made sure we left our cameras and phones at a counter just outside the entrance to the gallery.

Definitely not to be missed . If you come to London your trip would not be complete without visiting Big Ben and the houses of Parliament.Try to come before the hour so you can hear the iconic big Ben play his hourly chime.Do yourself a favor and check this out
Must see!. I liked that no matter how many times you see it in pictures, to be there in person is a completely different experience! It is beautiful, and totally worth a stop over.

Nice views from across the River. So much grander than you realise, good to have a walk along the other side of the river to fully appreciate it before you get up close and personal.Stunning as the sun sets in the evening. Good selfies as you cross the bridgeDidn't get to go inside

A must visit place for all who travel to London. this historic building is a must for all who visit this incredible city, young or old locals or vistors we can all gain a huge wealth of knowledge from visiting this historically important site.take a guided tour and absorb the history that has touched and influenced the western world, with good prep landing you can visit the actual working parliament and sit in the visitors gallery and witness the house in session, for the really fortunate you can sometimes get into the House of Lords all of it is awe inspiring and well worth a visit, allow time for queueing and recognise that security is inevitable .....

Worth a visit, interesting tour, knowledgeable guide. We booked a tour through our MP which we're all entitled to do in UK. Our guide was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic about her role. It's fantastic that we can undertake a tour of both The House of Lords and The House of Commons. There was a few primary school children doing a tour at the same time as us and it was great to see them being encouraged to act out Prime Ministers Questions. This tour is worth doing.

Fascinating. Got tickets for a guided tour and PMQs through our MP. They are good for something! Hugely interesting tour lasting some hour and a quarter, time for a coffee and snack in the cafeteria and then the live show watching the leader of the opposition getting monstered by the PM! The visit helps the layperson understand more clearly the strange place that is our parliament with its traditions and quirks. Highly recommended.
Seen from all over the city. We couldn't take enough picture of the House of Parliament. Up close, from the bridges and even from the London Eye. It's fabulous to see in person.

Politics and cream tea. We arranged a guided tour followed by a cream tea. The tour guide was very knowledgeable if a bit authoritarian but it was a great insight into the history, the queens role in the opening of parliament and differences between the Lords and Commons. We were at the front of the queue for the cream tea so had lovely window seats but these are allocated on a first come first served basis. Also if you have a glass of bubbly, beware the bottle is more expensive than individual glasses. The tea was very pleasant although don't compareit with somewhere like Langhams, as it is much lower key and there are no refills of sandwiches. However the view is lovely and it finishes the tour off in style.

Very interesting - excellent tour. I grew up in England but had never been so when I went back recently a booked a tour. Very glad I did - the guide was excellent, very knowledgeable & informative and the tour was interesting & well worth doing. Highly recomended

Guided tour of Houses of Parliament. Loved every minute of this tour. Our guide (Harri) was fabulous. The tour was very interesting & the Palace & Houses of Westminster are not to be missed. Just a shame I couldn't take photos of such a beautiful place. Definitely recommend.

Fantastic. If you're visiting London you're likely going to see Parliament, you may just not know it. Parliament is housed in Westminster Palace, also home to Big Ben. The Palace is really cool and I recommend walking on all sides if you have time. Pay close attention to the architecture and especially the detail on the massive doors. During our trip we sat and ate lunch to the South in the little park. It was less crowded than Parliament Square on the West side.

Unique, of course,. This was interesting in terms of the history and governing. The building has many beautiful touches, though its somewhat drab architecture becomes monotonous. Key for us was having a very engaged, slightly irreverent guide (Godfrey) who brought the rooms and history alive.

Great architecture and history. The houses of Parliament at Westminster are among the top sightseeings in London. They have great architecture. The impressive Big Ben is just next to the Houses of Parliaments. The guards around the premises in their elegant uniform tempt so many visitors to take photos with the guards beside the Parliaments. They are close to the Westminster underground station and they just by the side of river Thames. The view of the Houses of Parliament is fabulous whether one looks by walking around the premises or from the London eye or from the boat on river Thames.

Living history. This is really worth a visit, to see this ancient and important building. I don't think you appreciate the scale and historical significance of the place until you have been up close and viewed it. Would recommend to visitors and locals alike

History Close up. Took a tour around the Houses of Parliament fascinating to see where we are governed from. Intersting to see statues of previous Prime Ministers and to get a feel of the size of the two Houses. The House of Lords is very opulent with gold leaf covering most surfaces. The Queen's Throne is fantastic with so much decoration, the whole tour was very interesting and informative.

I found one of the imperfect tiles in central lobby, can you?. Having lived in London for 14 years I finally made it to the houses of parliament (and even managed to get lunch there!). As part of our day we had a guided tour included and I cannot recommend this more. The guide was a member of the house so had intimate knowledge of the processes involved in Parliament as well as a rich historical knowledge.If you get chance go, I don't think you could regret this fascinating building full of history. Look out for one, or if you're lucky two, tiles in the central lobby which have purposely placed imperfections. I found one of them. Can

Members Dining Room. This was the first time the Members Dining Room had been open to the public; I hope it won't be the last, as we would love to go again. £30 for a 3 course superb meal and £14 for a bottle of Merlot is not bad anyway. But, with such super and attentive staff, and such a good meal in such beautiful surroundings, it becomes even better. Please, please open again - but only tell me, and no one else, otherwise I might not get in!!

Loads to see and do. Had a fab tour by our MPs parliamentary secretary, met our MP and sat in the viewing gallery of the House of Commons watching our politicians at work! Also visited the chapel which is gorgeous. Well worth arranging to visit.

most interesting!. We had a private tour and really enjoyed seeing this. It was fun to see the old character buildings and the new buildings that have been recently added on. The gift shop has some treasures that you will enjoy too. We purchased some coffee mugs which make excellent conversation pieces.

Great tour. We visited on a Saturday and took the self guided tour. Well worth the price and we loved the experience of being able to pace ourselves. We learned all about the workings of the Houses of Parliament and enjoyed being in such a beautiful place.

Excellent value for money. This is the first time we have actually been inside the building despite visiting London many times and don't know why we left it so long! The only downside is the booking office and ticket collection office is over the opposite side of the road by the river and you have to battle through the crowds to get to the entrance so don't cut it fine if you have booked a specific slot to go round like we did! The entrance is very grand and you can take photos which is nice but further in the building photography is not allowed. We had an audio tour which was very informative. You will end up with a cricked neck from looking up at the beautiful ceilings! It was quite surreal that we were actually standing in areas which we had seen on television numerous times. Overall the tour took us around an hour and a half and we were thoroughly impressed. An absolutely stunning building. Would definitely recommend.

Wonderful guided tour!. We went on a private guided tour in September 2014 and found the whole experience so interesting. Our guide was most informative and happy to answer any questions. We were able to have drinks on the private balcony overlooking the Thames with canapés which were absolutely delicious! I would definitely recommend this tour it was fabulous!

Beautiful buildings and intriguing old governm . The first time I saw this I was across the river and thought it looked really cool but once a close you realize the detail is amazing. The tower is one of my favorite parts and of course Big Ben is a great place to take a selfie :-)

an absolute must see. if you love the luxurious palaces of Italy, do not miss this stunner. It used to be the royal palace and is sensational. The guided tour is amazing. The stories are incredibly interesting.

Essential British Institution. Given the centality of Westminster Palace to the nation, a visit to the Houses of Parliament are a 'must see' attraction. The Palace of Westminster with its world famous Big Ben is magnificent from the exterior. No matter how many times I see it it never fails to impress with its grandeur and wonderful architecture. I would strongly advise making time to tour the inside. The first time I saw the House of commons and House of Lords I was struck by their small size yet fascinating architecture and atmospheres.The historic collections in Westminster Palace are extremely interesting. Overall this is a marvellous place to gain insight into the cultural and political history of Britain within the home of its present day democracy. As other reviewers have pointed out, security for visitors is rightly strict so allow plenty of time for entry.

Agree, the Guided tour is worth the extra money... Despite London being my home town I had never been inside the Palace of Westminster (to give this wonderful building is proper name), but that was something I rectified on Saturday and even with my London biased hat on, this is a truly wonderful piece of history to visit.£25 per person may sound a lot, but the guided tour is well worth the extra money.Firstly the guides are very knowledgeable and extremely informative and, although I am sure the audio guides are very well done as well, you cannot ask questions of an audio guide.And secondly you get taken behind the ropes into some of the rooms and into the seating area of both the ‘Houses’, which gets you away from the crowds that this location attracts.As others have mentioned, if you have a ticket for a timed tour, get there about half an hour earlier, as you need to get through the airport style security, which is taken very seriously here, for obvious reasons..

Architecture, History and Government. A visit to the Houses of Parliament gives the opportunity to marvel at the architecture, to learn more about this seat of Government and to watch the operation of the House of Commons and the House of Lords. There are guided tours with an appropriate charge but if you wish to listen to debates in either House, provided there is room in the spectators galleries and the Houses are in session, this is free and can be fascinating. Security is strict for obvious reasons but all staff members were friendly and helpful.

Very Good Audio Tour - Inefficient Management. The audio guides for this tour worked well and handled our movement through parliament in a very nice way. We thoroughly enjoyed the tour and felt we learned a lot about both the history of parliament and its workings today. However, the operations involved in entry into parliament were as inefficient as any we've ever experienced. We had prebooked tickets, but had not printed them out, and we expected to just appear at a will-call window to receive them. That didn't happen. Rather, young people kept running back and forth between our line and some office with hand written notes of information on people who were wanting to pick up their tickets. If it had been raining (thankfully it wasn't) we would have been furious. When we finally got our tickets and were being escorted through the entrance, I commented on the inefficiency to the young woman doing this chore and she just rolled her eyes and agreed that the process was terrible.

Very interesting. I came here on the day that that Parliament sat to discuss the decision for the UK to go get involved in the airstrikes over Syria, so it was a particularly interesting day to drop by for a visit. Once through security, you get a chance to have a look around Westminster Hall before going through to wait to be called up to the public gallery. after passing through further security, you are shown to the seats of the public gallery where you can see all the action down below in the House of Commons.There are screens showing who is talking at any one point along with a screen of bbc Parliament so you can also see what is being broadcast on tv whilst you are there. I found the tv screen showing who each politicians were to be very helpful. It was very interesting to actually be there so close to the action of people deciding on the future of the county and seeing everything unfold down below you. A very worthwhile and engaging day out. You must visit.
wow. It was a pleasure to see this very famous and monumental building. I am happy to see the telephone boxes around it.

Very good. This is very good place . I also have visited it there I saw houses of parliament has a very good sight because cool vibes blow there. which cool down your tension and stress and you should really get to know about your politics as well as take advantage of its view..

U3A Trip to the Houses of Parliament. For those who have never been do try and go for it is an experience I shall never forget.Our guide, David, was absolutely brilliant, very knowledgeable and made the guided tour so enjoyable. From the moment we stepped into Westminster Hall I knew this place was going to leave a lasting impression on me. To actually step into the House of Commons Chamber and the House of Lords Chamber felt such a great occasion to me. After the tour the Jubilee Cafe offered a very nice cup of coffee.I managed to obtain a copy of The Palace of Westminster Official Guide on line from their Bookshop, very well worth £5, post free. In the future I wish to return, for you simply cannot take it all in solely on one visit.

Exceptional Architecture. We took the double decker bus tour and one of our favorite landmarks was the Houses of Parliament. The view from the bridge is incredible. The architecture and detail of the building is stunning. It is quintessential London.

Be sure to do a guided tour. I thought I was fairly knowledgeable... but a guided tour showed me how much I didn't know... and what a great way to find out all the wonderful little details. The tour is through both Houses, anterooms, ceremonial rooms, and halls between. So much to see-- and everything with a story. I may do it again just because I'm sure I missed some of it-- there was so much! Allow extra time for security at the entrance.

Once we got in. Got to the Houses of Parliament at about 4 pm on a Saturday. We could not find any directions as to where to buy tickets and had to ask a visitor coming out where to go.Once we had the tickets ( £17.50 each for the audio tour) we had a hard job finding the way in but once through security every thing was sign posted.The audio guide was very informative and well set out. It was interesting to see the Lords and Commons chambers and the area where the newsreaders stand, it all seemed a lot smaller than on the TVS.Definitely well worth a visit and good value, once you got in.

Tour of the Houses of Parliament. What an experience this is, specially if you get an interesting guide.as we did, lots of historical knowledge and funny facts, I'm not a history bough but really thought tis interesting. Seeing the actual debating rooms and the wonderful history of the building was fantastic. We wrote to our local MP and asked for tickets, so it cost us nothing, or you can buy tickets for about £18 so you can then choose the date you want to go. This can also be don to take a tour of Big Ben free again if you write to your local MP well well well worth doing specially if you can get the 10.30am tour you then hear the bells strike 11 great...
Beautiful. It is one of the most beautiful buildings I've ever seen. I believe it's much better in real life than on any pictures.
History !. You have to visit the historic Westminster Hall, the Queen's entrance and dressing room, House of Commons, House of Lords, the galleries.History !

Beautiful architecture and a place of history. I was lucky enough to have a tour of the inside, getting to see the House of commons and House of Lords, makes you think of the histoy that went on there. The architecture is truly fascinating and getting to see all the secret tunnels on the inside was really interesting and something worth a visit.

Houses of Parliament. Went there with friends and we had a private tour round with my friends son who was working there. It was so interesting, we all enjoyed it. There is an underground tunnel that leads to the building opposite that we didnt know about. It was a very interesting and historical tour.

Houses of Parliament. I was at the houses of Parliament in June this year. The experience of meeting the work and pensions Minister Ian Duncan Smith on some other business and then seeing the historical building was a great experience. A great insight into the concept of democracy as was perceived in the early days when the introduction of one man one vote idea of governance was brought to the forefront for running the governmental affairs.

History 1st hand. We booked a guided tour with our local MP Andrew Rosindell who's knowledge of the house was outstanding - we went everywhere & everything was explained in great detail. If you live in London see if your MP does a tour or just book in the normal way- you won't regret it.

A wonderful private tour. I was invited for a private lunch and informal to the House of Lords I couldn't believe that once though the very courteous but efficient and thorough security one could wander round and see in real life people one only saw on the television taking decisions on our behalf .The buildings are magnificent and awe inspiring You need to go and take your your growing up children , it might inspire some to try for politics

Not to be missed. Went on a guided tour,through a group booking,organized by a social club I belong to.The correct name is the Palace of Westminster,which is a 19th century rebuild of the original palace,which was destroyed by fire.After going through an airport style security check,we gathered in the great hall,to wait for our guide.There is so much to see,paintings statues which the guide explained and answered questions,as well as the house of commons and the house of Lords.and Westminster Hall*Queen’s Robing RoomRoyal GalleryPrince’s ChamberLords ChamberMoses Room*Central Lobby*Members’ LobbyAye Lobby*Commons ChamberSt Stephen’s Hall*The tour lasts 2hours and is well worth the visit,only disappointment no photo taking allowed There is a cafe for light refreshments and a gift shop.The tour is not suitable for young children,due to the amount of walking involved.It is best to visit this by public transport.
This is good! Go for the Strangers Gallery,. don't waste time looking around at pictures and statues. It is worth waiting to Democracy in actiongo when Partiment is sitting.

Excellent tour that gives you an insight into history. My wife and I did the tour (self-guided) and found it excellent. To get to see inside the two houses (Commons and Lords) where so much history has happened was eye-opening. The audio commentary was clear and well sign posted and you had the option of hearing more about a number of topics if you wanted. You can certainly get the impression of all the meetings that happen in the corridors and the only thing that could improve the tour would be to get an insight into the offices. I would even consider a revisit! However - we also booked an afternoon tea and this was disappointing (I didn't include this in the review rating as it was booked separately). We were served in the Marquee overlooking the Thames but the food was minimal and the tent unatmospheric. There are a lot better places (such as the Ritz or the Athenaeum) in London for a higher quality tea.

Houses of Parliament, Westminster, London. This is such a historically and architecturally interesting tour, as well as featuring much first class art work concerning the history of the English governmental system, it is visually stunning. Gilbert Scott designed the buildings in the Victorian new Gothic style and the situation beside the Thames makes them unique. The tours are presented by informed and helpful guides who take care of visitor flow to ensure that they can be heard and that it is possible to both listen and gain a good vantage point on the rooms as the tour progresses, The tours offer good value for money, although they do get very booked especially in the tourist season when it is possible to visit, so planning is advisable.

An excellent audio tour. You have to book a time to visit which is so good as the number of visitors at one time is controlled. We chose the audio tour and it was excellent. We certainly learned exactly how the British parliament works. The tour takes you through Westminster Hall with all of its history and both chambers. We were very impressed and would certainly advise it to anyone visiting London

Stunning. This really is a MUST SEE. The history, the buildings are quite breathtaking. I could quite happily have sat there all day absorbing the atmosphere and the many facts we were told e.g. The Dispatches Box has a Bible inside ? The seats in the House of Commons have little speakers.

TRADITION. Go and see the inside of this wonderful building, great pomp and ceremony. The architecture and murals are something to admire. Great day out. This visit is arranged via your local MP. What is great you have a guide who is very knowledgeable. Security is very strict, so it should be.

History and tradition. My husband and I booked a guided tour and afternoon tea at the Houses of Parliament, we are very glad that we did.Tours (guided or self guided audio tours) are only available when Parliament is not sitting and are very popular, so plan in advance and book early. There are discounts for Military personnel.The guided tours include access to some areas which aren't on the audio tours and so we are particularly glad that we spent the few pounds extra and got to see the Queen's Tower and were permitted inside the robing room as well as having someone available to answer any questions that we had.Afternoon tea on the Commons Terrace was delicious and of course meant that we had a view of the Thames that few others get to see.

Visit to fully understand how Parliament works. Book a guided tour with one of the excellent official guides - we had Brian. Allow a long time to see everything. Also allow plenty of time before the start of your tour as you must collect tickets and go through scanners and checks. The official guided tour is well worth the effort as he/she gives extra little anecdotes which makes it all more worth while. With an official guide you do get to go places ordinary self-guided tourists don't get to go. The debating chambers are smaller than they appear on TV but very impressive and imposing. There are gorgeous paintings, murals, carpets, chairs etc. The division lobbies are fascinating and many of the processes are quite old fashioned but work well nonetheless. The is a nice cafe and gift shop where for a change prices are reasonable. Loos are good too.

Well Worth the Wait. I've visited London many times but never yet got to see the Houses of Parliament, though my main interest was seeing the old Westminster Palace Hall with its famous wooden ceiling. I contacted my local MP to book a tour as all UK citizens are entitled to free entry in to Parliament, I also learned through our guide, that we didn't have to book, UK citizens can turn up and ask to enter to see an MP or listen to a debate, it's our right.The tour was fantastic and our guide excellent, I was amazed by the gothic architecture, it really is a fabulous place and I was ashamed to say I'd left it so long to visit.The old Westminster Hall is breathtaking, and such a shame the rest of the Palace was destroyed by fire, this hall had held banquets after the coronations of many great kings and queens including Henry VIII and Elizabeth I, and more recently for Nelson Mandella. So glad I finally got to see part of our historical heritage

Audio tour - Loved it!. We visited on a Saturday with our two girls aged 13 and 11. The audio tour was really good and we got to see a lot more than I expected. It took us through Westminster hall, Central lobby and both chambers. Along the way we learnt a huge amount about the history of the place as well as how government works. We probably spent nearly 3 hours altogether including the visit to the tea shop (nice cake!). I was particularly pleased that my two girls really enjoyed it as well and we are all much more knowledgeable as a result. It was definitely one of the highlights of our trip.
Monumental. Beautiful building and the tour explains some of the history and it is interesting and informative without being tiring. The halls are impressive.
Spectacular . Another of London's buildings that is well worth a visit . Stunning inside and out, and just full of history !! Also the cafe did the best cappuccino I had during my stay ☺

Well worth a visit. We have just taken the afternoon guided tour of the Palace of Westminster or Houses of Parliament and I must say that it was truly a well worth couple of hours. The buildings are beautiful so gothic so like a cathedral, the works of art throughout the tour we saw were impressive, great to say that you were there when it comes on the TV! However I cannot recommend the afternoon tea on the Terrace, poor slow service, food that was so-so but not of the quantity or quality that it could have been.

Great Tour - so interesting and informative. We have just returned from London, and on our last day we took in this tour, and it was simply fantastic. The tour guide was so full of knowledge, and what she told us was fascinating. The tour lasted nearly 2 hours, and the building is beautiful. I am interested in politics, so I was engrossed in what she was saying. We went on a Wednesday morning, and it was really busy as it was PMs Question Time. We saw many famous politicians and the atmosphere was brilliant. I would definitely recommend this tour

Amazing Experience!. Houses of Parliament was an amazing experience whilst apart of my study. Learnt the most interesting facts and even got to visit very important people in central Government. Recommend those who wants the chance to talk to MP's to visit on a Wednesday as these are debate days and is very busy.Would recommend it to anyone who are interested in this particular subject! What's to loose? Its free!Advantages:1). Chance to see debates and sit in public room2). Free Access3). Secured place which is cornered off with fire arm police officers Disadvantages:1). No Technology allowed 2). Waiting can take time (Book before)

Inspiring. Spent an amazing 2 hours on a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. Our guide first walked us at speed to the far end of the building then began the tour using the state opening of parliament as the script. We walked in the footsteps of the Queen, being given comprehensive information about every aspect of both the Lords and the Commons. Our guide was incredibly knowledgeable and presented in a manner that was appealing to both adults and children.I cannot recommend this visit highly enough.

Excellent way to spend a Saturday afternoon. We went here last Saturday. Have been to London many times and often stood outside but never actually been inside. We booked an audio tour online and were not disappointed. It really is a magnificent building. My one surprise was that I was amazed at how small both the Lords and the Commons actually are as they look so big on TV. well worth a visit!

Group Visit from MDDCA. In February we was invited to visit the Houses of Parliament and to see Big Ben. I have been to Parliament a number of times but walking up the spiral staircase to see Big Ben was fantastic also to be there when it rang was even better. The view from that hight was overwhelming and to walk behind the clock faces and read the storys and see the works you could not asks for anything better.If you get the change you must go it wrll worth it.

A Must See While in London. I have been to London several times, and this trip we made it a point to do things that we hadn't done before. I highly recommend a tour of Parliament! We booked our audio tour online the night before and it was great. But I would suggest booking a guided tour with some advanced planning. In general, tour guides are such great story tellers, and I can only imagine the extra information that you would get from a guided tour. We booked our audio tour for 11:00 and had to pick our tickets up. It was a good thing that we got there early because the ticket office is across the street from Parliament and there was a line. The inside of Parliament is incredibly beautiful. I loved learning about the history and all of the traditions that are still in place today. I admit to watching all of the British documentaries on TV that I can here in the states, and to see all of this in person was surreal! The audio tour of Parliament was one of my favorite highlights of my entire trip to England.

houses of parliament. fantastic visit and really interesting. It takes you back to your history lessons at school. the guide was very informative, she was interesting and humorous.
Worth every penny and I highly recommend this.

If you thought Buckingham Palace was OTT wait till you see the House of Lords. We booked for a visit online and decided to do afternoon tea on the terrace too. Annoyingly you have to book your tour before you can proceed to book tea (why aren't they bundled?) so you can print your tour tickets at home but you have to pick your tea tickets up at Portcullis House on the day. I had allowed for a long queue for ticket pickup but it was surprisingly fast consequently we had plenty of time to have a drink in the nearby St Stephen's Tavern prior to joining the security line up. Westminster Hall where you muster for tours is full of history: it should be after nearly 900 years of usage: so make sure you have sufficient time to take it in either before or after your tour. I found our tour guide very knowledgeable about Parliamentary History and Procedures and she very competently gave us a very good tour. I found she was a little lacking in contextual history outside of Parliament but that's me being picky.Nothing can prepare you adequately for the sheer impressiveness of the House of Lords. There is so much history imbedded in the adornment of that Chamber you just come away in awe. The commons though far more impressive than its equivalents in Canada and Australia just pales into the background when compared to the Lords.Tea was an experience' , price is about what the hotels charge for similar fare: if its just food you want you can do so for far less in many places I suspect most folks just want to soak in the atmosphere though.All the staff at ticket offices, security, guiding, marshalling and serving were extremely polite and friendly a true credit to Britain.Whether a native or a foreign tourist this is a must see if you are in London when Parliament is open for tours.

Great History. We had such a great time touring the Houses of Parliament! Being from the US it was interesting to see how the Parliament is run. I love all the tradition. The building is gorgeous and loved going into the chambers. The audio tour was very informative and I would highly suggest this tour; although if time permits you may wish to have the guided tour (we should have done that...oh well).

One for the books. So I'm not really into Politics but I purchased 2 Houses of Parliament tickets for my partner and I, as a birthday present.  We aren't from London, however once we arrived we were well guided to H.O.P. Upon arrival, we were searched, given clear instructions as to the do's and don'ts and taken to the main foyer to wait for our tour guide. The tour lasted around 1 hour and 40 minutes, we were taken throughout all the various rooms within the building. We went in April, so I can't really remember many names of the rooms, but the House of Commons and House of Lords are definitely worth a visit. The lady who was our guide, was extremely knowledgeable and precise. she answered any questions we had and explained in detail certain aspects of the tour. The way a guide should be.I was taken back by the upkeep of each room and well preserved statues, books and furniture were. The history of the Houses of Parliaments is fascinating. All staff are very friendly and on site to help at any point.The tour guide also advised us that we could take a tour of Big Ben and explained the full process of how to go about requesting a tour. Which we have recently booked and will be attending in November. But without her assistance, we wouldn't have known about how to request the tour. Contact your local MP on the 1st of the month and request to be put down for the Big Ben tour. This is for UK citizens only and it can take up to 6 months to be put on the waiting list. but your local MP will try and get this sorted for you.

Best place in London!. By my reckoning the most wonderful place in London. It's absolutely worth to pay a visit to get into the English democracy and the history of the kingdom and its lawmakers. Stunning building enlarged century by century plenty of wonderdul decoration, statues, amazing stories... and the jaw-dropping Lords Chamber is unforgettable. The cream of the crop of the worlwide politics have been inside these walls (Mandela, Churchill, Thatcher, Cromwell...) If you're in London it's paramount to come here.

Must see attraction!. This is a must see attraction. We visited as part of a group and we only had an audio guide but would have preferred real Guide. Nevertheless,we really enjoyed seeing all that can be seen on TV plus other places like the lobby's and voting booths.No photography is allowed inside the Chambers but it is an attraction not to be missed with a real guide.

Superb to see. Loved all the paintings and the history was extraordinary! Worth the visit of a London landmark whether you are into politics or not. The buildings are stunning - but the paintings did it me!

Parliament. This attraction should be seen in combination with a visit to Westminster Abbey, Big Ben & Buckingham Palace (which is a nice 10 minute stroll away). The Houses of Parliament are in attractive buildings and provide a beautiful backdrop for lovely photos. Highly recommended.

Viewed from the river. We went on a river tour and were fortunate to see the Houses of Parliament twice - going as well as coming back! Really spectacular view from water level. A cruise is very worthwhile to see this and many other interesting sites.

Another great attraction. I was lucky enough to see inside with a trip in the girl guides. Very posh and worth taking a camera! It's in a main road so hard to get a decent photo and also always busy with traffic and other tourists.

A wonderful Place to Visit. I was invited on a tour here, by my local MP, and brought along two great friends. We were shown around by a lovely lady, who was very knowledgable, very genuine, and not too tour guide-ish. She answered all of our questions with great aplomb, and allowed us to stop and stare as we wished. Sadly no photos allowed, but a huge honour to be able to walk around and see such an historic and important building. Great to see schools visiting as well, and asking questions of their local MPs. This should be a must for any young person, as its a great way to really understand the whole process of voting and decision making in Britain.

Superb guide; A brilliant hour and 40 minutes' tour. Rich in history and art, the Houses of Parliament in London is a 'must see' attraction. The guides are brilliant - incredibly well informed. They tell you not only about the various halls, palaces and rooms but also how the British parliament works. The tour lasts an hour and 40 minutes and takes in Westminster Hall, St. Stephen's Hall, the House of Lords and the HOuse of Commons. There is an good café there and toilet facilities are excellent. Photography is allowed only in Westminster Hall and St. Stephen's Hall. There is seating at some of the stops, but you are frequently not allowed to sit on the seats used by MPs and Lords. You need to have photographic identification and you have to go through an airport style security section to enter the buildings. It's not that much of a problem, though, although on occasions you may have to wait 20 minutes or so. You can take in cameras and small bags, but there is no storage space for bags - and large bags are not allowed.
Wow..... This place is beautiful. You need to check out this place and spend some time admiring the exterior of the building. We loved it!

Absolutely Brilliant Visit. The buildings are full of history. We bought tickets at the ticket office and were starting our tour 10 minutes later. The auto guide headset was excellent, the commentary very informative and the musical introductions spectacular. We stood on the spot where William Wallace and later Charles the First were tried for treason. We got right up close and personal with the House of Lords and Commons. We stood right at the places where so many dramatic debates have taken place. Some of the rooms within the House of Lords areas were wonderfully lavish and a treat to behold.

One of the best views in the world. You can't deny how beautiful and impressive the houses of parliament are, especially when Big Ben chimes the hour. Definitely worth seeing, especially as there are many other attractions nearby.

You can feel the history in this building. I booked a guided tour via Ticketbastard (I mean Ticketmaster) for Tuesday late morning. Note, you should arrive at least 20 minutes early because you have to go through airport type security. Once you enter the building, you need to wait for the tour to begin in Westminster Hall, which is a very large space. Note, you cannot take pictures inside the Palace of Westminster except in Westminster Hall which makes the experience a bit disappointing.The guided tour was very good. The tour guide was a bit hard to hear at times, mostly because of the presence of other tour groups in our vicinity. I believe a guided tour does give you access to a room used for conferences (that would not be available with the audio tour) and perhaps gives you a chance to stand for extended periods in the House of Commons and House of Lords chambers at the seating areas. I believe you may not be able to do a few things if you took the regular audio tour. The tour guide provided a fascinating history of the building, the politicians who legislated in the Parliament, the differences between the two chambers, why the queen cannot enter the House of Commons, how the royals fit in, where the queen sits in the House of Lords, and more! There is also plenty of art and statues that litter the buildings. You could definitely feel the building ooze history. It was well worth the high cost of the tickets.There is a cafe but we did not eat at the cafe.Note, we also ordered the afternoon tea with the tour. You can only order the combination afternoon tea and guided tour over the telephone. Unfortunately, Ticketmaster (who took our phone call) mistakenly sold tickets for the tour and afternoon tea to take place on a Tuesday. We would only learn later - the night before the tour via a phone call by Ticketmaster who then left a voicemail - that the afternoon tea was canceled! I was naturally furious why Ticketmaster decided to give us such short notice of the cancellation. I talked with the folks at the Parliament and they told us that Ticketmaster erroneously offered Tuesday afternoon teas! The Palace of Westminster supposedly does not offer afternoon tea on Tuesdays. But for some reason (I guess this is the way Ticketmaster operates), Ticketmaster did not mention their mistakes. I was naturally outraged at the way Ticketmaster handled this situation and did not own up to the fact that they made a mistake. The afternoon tea was to be one of the highlights of my trip. I was finally able to reach a Ticketmaster manager who eventually took care of the situation and was able to find me an opening for afternoon tea two days later. But this was only after I got upset and just told her I would accept nothing but a new reservation for afternoon tea. Lesson of this story - be aware of Ticketmaster!Anyway, the afternoon tea itself at the Palace at Westminster was a bit disappointing. The tea is offered in an area at river level right next to the Thames. You have an excellent view of the river. The dining area is nicely appointed and clean. We were promptly seated, but it did take quite a while for us to receive the food. The afternoon tea items were very limited (small portions). Menu items included a small roll with roast chicken/pepper/avocado guacamole, smoked salmon with cream cheese on ciabatta, tomatoes/mozarella/pesto with pine kernels on rye bread. Sweets included scones with strawberry jam/clotted cream, chocolate tart, and lychee/strawberry Eton mess shot. You also have a choice of various teas (including coffee). You can also pay extra for wine. The food was average - not spectacular at all, although the teas were good. The presentation of the food was nice. However, the service was very poor. The manager was very hospitable, but the waiters were very impatient, did not describe the food at all - the waiter just dumped the food on our table and then just walked away. It seemed like the waiters were in a constant rush throughout the meal and were not very attentive. I thought it would be a highlight of my trip but the experience was underwhelming. I would rate the afternoon tea separately at 2 out of 5 stars.
Amazing . I always visit this awesome court as it seems the heart of LondonThe river look , Big ben and further are all in a few steps walk

Must see - the seat of Govenment.. Fabulous to be able to visit the Palace of Westminster - Houses of Parliament.The 900 year old Westminster Hall is a wonderful historic space. Enjoyed the Commons and Lords Chambers and all the statutory/bust of past Prime Ministers from the 20th century. Thatcher, Churchill, Major and others. But where was Blair and Brown?We were very surprised just how small the Commons is!The cafe was very reasonably priced, and the 'portaloo' temporary toilets, whilst not ideal were top of the range affairs.

Fascinating. The audio tour of the Houses of Parliament is as fascinating as Parliament itself.The many traditions and rituals is a little alien from the POV of an American, which makes it all the more fascinating to listen to. Learned a great deal about England's government and it was well worth the time and expense.

Interesting audio tour. We did the audio tour and it was very pleasant. Of course the advantage of the audio tour is that you can take of the headphones when no longer interested, but no real need here. Was a very interesting tour, beautiful building to visit.

History and traditions. This place is something really very special. Definitely must see for anyone who loves and values the history and traditions. Over a course you'll see houses of lords and commons; halls where law decisions are being made and learn when Royals are there and when they aren't. You'll learn about who can speak and vote, and who can't. You'll see galleries and lobby room, meet Margaret Thatcher and Sir Winston Churchill. I'd recommend this tour for everyone just to understand what does Britain means for British people and why. In this place one can feel how past centuries and meantime connected to each other. Some notes for a first-time visitors. Photography is only allowed in Westminster hall. In the rest of Parliament neither photography nor video recording are allowed. On entrance, be ready and prepared for extensive airport-like checking, so perhaps avoid taking large bags, bottles or excessive iron things. Take a guided tour in your language to get the most of this place.
Excelent!. Honestly? No words to express how wonderful it is... It's breath taking. Definitely a must see! Absolutely mandatory!
Historical and interesting . I would recommend anyone on a first time visit to London doing the touristy things visits it's quite interesting and is inexpensive too

Brilliant. Having lived in London and visiting the city many times I'm embarrassed to say I had never visited here before, when I walked in and took in the history of the place I wondered why it had taken me so long for visit. If you are visiting London this is a must see, so much history under one roof and the staff are all very helpful.

If it is your first time in London!!!. If it is your first time in London I think you should visit the Parliment. It is very traditional and historical place to go. I always recommend people who travel the first time to a place to take a look at touristy places. It is nice!!!

Incredibly Interesting. This is one of the most interesting tours I have ever done. We booked online some weeks before and this is clearly advisable since there was no availability for a tour on the day of our visit. You can book a fully guided tour or an audio tour which costs slightly less. Our preference was for the audio tour which is available in several languages and gives you the flexibility of walking around at your own pace and revisiting areas should you wish to do so. The commentary was clear and very interesting. Highlights for me were visits to the House of Lords and the House of Commons but the entire building is steeped in history and there is much to see and learn. If you have even the slightest interest in politics, this tour is a must and you should allow a minimum of 90 minutes to get around. Sadly, we weren't able to use our cameras as photography is forbidden in most areas. There is a small gift shop alongside the Jubilee Café which serves tea, coffee, sandwiches etc and has glass doors leading to an outdoor block of Portaloos which as far as I could tell, were the only conveniences available. If you're visiting London, you should definitely consider this tour. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

Great audio guided tour on divento.com. I spent a dew days in London visiting major attractions, and would definitely recommend the Houses of Parliament. Got a really good deal for an audio guided tour -definitely a good idea: you get a pretty thorough background, interesting information and visit all key areas.

a must see. one of thebest guided tours i have ever been on-the buildings themselves and the richness of the history of government was fascinating-enjoyed it far more than Buckingham Palace-nice cafeteria-not overpriced by london standards

Essential tourist Destination. I treated my father to a guided tour for his birthday in June. We all really enjoyed it and learnt a lot. I recommend paying extra for a tour guide. We had a lovely Scottish lady who definitely knew her stuff. There is an amazing amount of things to see and the tour guide takes you through showing you the key details. Without the guide you could literally spend hours. I wasn't expecting to see half as much as we did. You literally see everything this beautiful building has to offer. This is an essential tourist destination for anyone visiting London as it gives an insight into our whole legal system and history throughout hundreds of years.

A walk through history. The guided tour was one of the best I've experienced. One tip - book your tickets online to be sure you can get in when you want. English language tours sell out. I got in only because of the kindness of the ticket center staff.
A good walk. A lot to see when you walk around the Houses of Parliament; plenty of food places and London Eye is there also.

Fascinating, A Must Do. We loved the tour of the Houses of Parliament - probably one of the most interesting things I have done in a long time. The tour took an hour and forty minutes and our guide had us enthralled throughout. She was informed and informative and brought all the history to life. We saw so much - from the stairs the Queen uses to enter at the State Opening of Parliament, the Lords and Commons debating chambers (amazing) and the central lobby. No photos allowed unfortunately. A must do - do not miss if you are in London.

A “must see” – it’s part of our National Heritage. In London with an organised group to see Houses of Parliament and Buckingham Palace (see separate review). Being mildly interested in UK politics, and frequently watching PMQ’s on TV whilst we lunch, we were keen to see the actuality of the chambers of the Commons and the Lords.We had the use of a tour guide (which I would recommend over an audio tour). Our guide was both knowledgeable, witty and entertaining and made the whole experience very interesting, with a very good balance between aspects historical and political. After passing through the usual security search our tour started in Westminster Hall, a stunning huge building with the most impressive oak hammerbeam roof. The history of this building started with William Rufus in 1099 (see – we were paying attention). With all the visitors milling around, some of the majesty and mystery of this building is lost, but it is nevertheless a most impressive start to the tour, and this is about the only part of the old Palace of Westminster which survived the 1834 fire. The building which we now commonly call the Houses of Parliament was completed 1847/1850 and the architecture and decoration is stunning – a magnificent example of Victorian wealth and aspiration. We were stunned by the wealth of frescos and paintings everywhere and the copious amount of gold leaf decoration.There are a few stairs at the start of the tour, but after this progress is at a modest pace and we were allowed to sit occasionally to rest (though NOT in the Commons or the Lords!). After the tour we didn’t bother with the gift shop or café, though the toilets (in temporary modules) were clean and presentable.Regardless of what you might think of politicians, the sheer history of this building makes it a “must see” at least once in your lifetime.

Probably the best historical tour I've done in London.. Those who have seen my other reviews will have noted that I live in London and have done a whole bunch of things in this city -not all of which have even made it to Tripadvisor it must be said, but of all of them, I think this i probably the best I have done.I am interested in British politics and no doubt, I think you have to be to enjoy this. If you're not interested or don't already have a grasp of how the British governmental system works, it might be advisable to skip this. If you do, read on...The building itself is magnificent. The huge win for me was the tour. Our tour guide was exceptionally knowledgeable about how government works, the history of UK government, the history of the building and the history of the relationship between monarchy and the UK government. Fascinating!As an Englishman, the chance to see the inside of the house of lords and the house of commons -two rooms, which every single English person will certainly recognise, was a real win for me. As you're talked through how debates and things work at this level and how the modern day has collided and blended (sometime awkwardly) with centuries old traditions, the amazement just keeps growing!Entry is not expensive and well worth it. Kids will find this very boring. Also, one of our party was in a wheelchair and I can say that access here and there was a little difficult in a couple of areas, but the staff helped to overcome this easily.I am very critical usually of gift shops and cafes at attractions like this. In this case, I have to be same... Everything in the gift shop is tat and nonsense. Nothing useful or a unique reminder of the experience available for you. The cafe food is actually delicious. The cost however, is exorbitant which on it's own is OK IF the quality is high also. In this case, you're paying very high cost for very mediocre quality product. People often say "yeah, well, you expect that at tourist attractions though, don't you"... In my view, that's not a good excuse... if you charge your patrons a lot of money, then you are obliged to supply a high quality product. This is my own negative point.HIGHLY recommend this, though I repeat; personally, I think it is absolutely necessary that you're interested not only in the architecture (which debatibly is worth the visit on its own), but also in the governmental process of the UK and it's history.

I learned so much!. I loved this tour. It was the best tour my husband and I did while we were in London. It was amazing getting to walk up the stairs the Queen uses to go into "her" room of the Houses of Parliament and the history behind each room and how it intertwined but remained separate from the next. I would recommend this to everyone visiting London. In my opinion, it was better than the tour of the US Capitol Building.

Fantastic history. Well worth a visit, guided tour gives you lots of interesting history about this fantastic buidling and some of the historic events to have taken place their, had a good couple of hours wandering around.
Just Gorgeous!. My husband and I checked this out on our day in London, and were so impressed at the beautiful architecture. It didn't disappoint.

I loved this visit. Very interesting couple of hours sat in the press gallery, I was invited, to witness PMQ's. Reminded me of schools boys in the end of year drama! Well worth a visit the interior is as stunning at the outside.

Amazing experience. What can I say it was an amazing experience to see this fascinating building from inside. It was so interesting to find out about the history of the building and what the parliament does today. Our tour guide was brilliant. The tickets were 25 pounds, but it was well worth to see this fascinating building. You will be guided through the house of lords, house and commons, westminster hall, st Stephen's Hall and Central Lobby.
Houses of Parliament. If you can fit it in your trip to London, I found the Houses of Parliament surprisingly interestingly and well worth the visit.

Not as amazing as expected. I recently booked a tour of the Houses of Parliament in London, on a Saturday. While many people have quite enjoyed the tours I actually found them very long and boring. While the building itself is amazing to see from the outside, and the inside, the tour itself felt very long winded. Unless you really have a keen interest in the history of UK Politics, you will likely find the tour quite boring. This is because a lot of the focus on the tour is on the politics that have happened in the building, rather than the building itself. Instead you could do the audio tour and probably be just as happy, and have it take a lot less time. Additionally, I found that the tour didn’t really give you a complete view of the building. Instead you see a few of the common rooms, but nothing “special” like the bar (yes - there is a bar in there), the offices of the politicains.Overall it is something to experience!

Wow!. My husband and I were granted a permit from our pm for a visit of the Palaces of Westminster and Parliament. Wow wow wowThe buildings and architecture is beyond words - it's absolutely stunning inside and out. The history is amazing and no matter what you think about political parties or politics in general this visit is a must. We were there on Friday and as parliament had been recalled that day due to political issues there were no public tours as such but as I said earlier we had been granted a permit to attend although security was extremely tight but I'd rather it was that way than the other! We were also allowed into the debating chamber and as the debate was the reason for the recall the majority of mps were in the chambers. It was totally thrilling to sit and listen to the debates. We were very very lucky. If you have the opportunity to go then I would say don't miss it!
Stunning. full of history and beauty. Great tour . Highlights are the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Audio tour is very good

Well worth the visit. This was an excellent visit - the tour lasts 90 minutes but with a knowledgeable and clear tour guide it seemed to pass very quickly. The tour ran with military precision - inevitable with the number of visitors they are dealing with every day. The tour encompasses all the major areas of the building, and our guide provided a very comprehensive explanation of how constitutional democracy works in this country. I knew quite a lot of this, but learnt some new snippets of information. Fascinating for anyone with an interest in architecture and history. I have scored this as "4" rather than "5" due to the very poor shop - just the usual hideous tourist tat - an opportunity missed to sell some more interesting items. I have since been told that there is another Houses of Parliament shop off site - will need to visit this next time.

Great experience. Highly recommend this tour. I learned so much about the British political system that I did not know before. To visit the very rooms that one has viewed on TV is an amazing experience. We were told that Parliament has 1100 rooms and 100 staircases within its' walls. Our guide was very knowledgeable and made the tour very interesting. Allow time to clear security. You can take pictures in the great hall, but once you leave the first area, no photography is permitted. Although we did see a few people snapping photos with their cell phones. I guess the rules only apply to the rest of us and not to them. Hoped they would be caught in the act, but that did not happen.

Most Interesting Experience. Recently visited the Houses of Parliament where a small group of us were shown round by a very informative and interesting guide. I am not particularly interested in politics but I found this experience so very interesting. It was amazing to stand in the House of Commons and the House of Lords having seen it so often on television. The guide made the whole experience so interesting and I would recommend this to anyone visiting London although of course you can only see it when Parliament are not sitting.

Tour of Parliament. During a recent trip to London we went on a guided tour of the Houses of Parlament. The tour cost£20.00 each and it was money well spent. Our guide knew everything about the place,dates of events in history and all that happens in the houses, the tour lasted two and a half hours. Our guide told us about the past and current events in both houses and I must say the time passed very quickly. This is a must visit when in London.

Great Experience. Brilliant....excellent guide who answered all questions with great knowledge....I certainly learnt something about our wonderful history and how parliament conducts itself currently.
Great!. Great tour. Would heartily recommend this to anyone with an interest in history, architecture, or politics.

Excellent visit. Booked via Ticketmaster and printed off our timed tickets. Small queue to enter but actually inside the building by the time allocated where we collected an audio tour guide (included in the ticket price). We were able to walk around at leisure listening to facts about Parliament, the building and the history of the place. It took us about two hours to see everything but the time went quickly. Unfortunately one cannot take photographs inside the building but there is plenty of scope outside on the green. Expensive gift shop but excellent cafe for a sit down and coffee after the tour. Well worth the trip!

A Return Visit, 40 years on!. I was on a tour of the Houses of Parliament as part of a school trip back in 1975. We were shown around by our local "new boy" MP Sir George Young (London Ealing Acton). Good to see he is still around, and still an MP, he normally sits close to David Cameron on the front benches these days. Yesterday, i made my re visit, on a guided tour (Saturday 27th September 2014). All amazing stuff, and the Commons is so tiny when you get in there! The cafe at the end was very good, and very reasonable prices. Probably the best 2 hour visit one can make, on a short trip to London. 5 star tourist attraction.

Who lives in a house like this?!. Power, scandal, history, you can feel it, see it, smell it. The mother of all parliaments and you can clearly see why. Tours are available, you can observe how it all works from the public gallery, otherwise pester your MP, you might get lucky and get asked round for tea!
Where it Begins. Its a must see sight, needs a little time to take it all in. Take a camera with you.- you never know who you will see.

Must see!. This was one of my favorite places to visit in London. Book ahead, and spend a little extra for the guided tour instead of the audio tour. Our guide, Phillip, was excellent and the tour was worth it! Make sure to show up early to get through security and the cafe at the end was excellent if you need a bite to eat afterwards.

Very interesting. I liked looking and walking all around at the years of history and walking where famous politicians past and present have walked. The statues and paintings are beautiful and so much history over the hundreds of years. You also go and see the place for parliaments question time and you sit in the gallery listening to whatever might be the subject of the day. Unfortunately when we went in it was some white paper on a boring subject with only a handful of politicians in. It is so fascinating to see and recognise on TV when the reporters are there, I highly recommend a visit it is well worth it.

Iconic!. You really cannot miss the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben. Seeing this picture so many times and then seeing it in real life was an unforgettable experience. Such a beautiful place and in the borough of Westminster. I could see the Houses of Parliament from my study abroad dorm room and it was one of my favourite sites to wake up to in the morning. I will be returning.

Worth a stop by . The buildings cannot be denied their historical and political significance. It was easy to stay and wonder at all the inspiration they've had in entertainment but the palace wasn't near as impressive as the media portrays.

A real Education. This tour will give you the inner workings of the British political system. The sights to see were excellent and the explanation as to how the government works an eye opener for an American. Well worth the time.

Houses of Parliament Tour. On a recent visit to London, we took the audio tour of the Houses of Parliament. Great to be in the Houses of Lords and Commons as seen on TV! There is so much interesting history and pretty inexpensive. The audio tour equipment is very user friendly and you can stop or start it as you like. Well worth a visit!!

Houses of Parliament with cream tea on the terrace. The queue to get through security moved very quickly, as we entered Westminster Palace free audio guides were available I took one and it was extremely informative and bought the history of the building to life. The House of Lords was spectacular and the Great Hall as you enter the building is amazing. Cream tea was served on the terrace. We were escorted to the terrace and waiting staff were all excellent. Champers was available at an extra cost. I bought a glass to treat myself and it perfectly complimented the tea. The cream tea was beautifully laid out. I can thoroughly recommend a visit to the Houses of Parliament to both UK residents and visiting tourists.

Take the tour for a little more, you will not regret it.. Our favorite of all the London sights and experiences. For a few dollars less you can do the audio tour. Do yourself a favor and take the 100 minute guided tour. Our guide was outstanding. Reserve your preferred time in advance. Note the purchasing of tickets is not on site, but about a block away. There is a special entrance for the tour. Arrive 20 minutes earlier than your designated tour time. Paid 25 BP each. Definitely recommend.

A real piece of history.. Seeing Big Ben after it had just been cleaned with all its trim shining was great. Especially on a bright sunny day. I was surprised at how close you could get to the building given the security in the area. Photos were also easy to get even through the border fence.It is worth walking over the bridge to get a photo from the other side. In fact the walk over the bridge and along the walkway to Lambeth Bridge and then through the park was a really nice loop to complete too.

Open House 2014. Westminster Hall, St Stephen's Hall and the Central Lobby was open on Sunday during Open House 2014 so I decided to go along at roughly 12.30pm. The queue was minimal (about 20 minutes) and we went through strict security checks and were given visitor badges.The place is absolutely breathtaking and I went onto a short tour of Westminster Hall, and I also visited the Chapel of St Mary (the crypts) and felt very humbled that this was the place that Margaret Thatcher was laid to rest in state. Got plenty of pictures of Westminster Hall, St Stephen's Hall and the Central Lobby and of course photography was forbidden in the crypts.I spent about over 4 hours in this building alone, just sitting and admiring the magnificent westminster hall and appreciating the paintings and statues in St Stephen's Hall and the Central Lobby. I will definitely recommend visiting this place. I would like to do House of Commons and the House of Lords at some point. I missed the talk about big ben as well which I will try and attend if there is another opportunity next year during Open House.Oh I also visited the jubilee room upstairs!

Don't think of going unless it's as the guest of an MP!. I've always loved visiting the Houses of Parliament but don't think of going on a tourists' guided tour....the only way to visit is as the guest of an MP, with tea or drinks on the Terrace, overlooking the Thames, or an excellent lunch as an MP's guest in the heavily subsidised dining room - ideally preceded by several heavily subsidised G&Ts in one of the heavily subsidised Commons bars!

Excellent tour. The narrative of the tour was full of humour & the guides knowledge was phenominal, how one person remembers the dates & details that were explained to our group was quite outstanding!
Well worth visiting. Organised tour is very informative and excellent value. You get to go inside the Houses of Commons and Lords.

A majestic building. Best if you accompany a tour guide as the detail and information relating to this wonderful building and its history is unfolded as you enter the different areas of Parliament Building. The guides will point out areas of particular interest and tell you when and where you're allowed to sit. Where comfortable shoes as you will spend a long time on your feet and go to the loo before the tour as there are no public facilities inside the building and only limited portaloos at the exit so expect queues. Very interesting and well worth the effort. Security is tight.

An unique opportunity. It's unique opportunity and you must take advantage of it if you can visit The Houses of Parliament. There's a narrow time frame when you can visit, due to the Parliament sessions.It's a splendid buiding, great architecture and you will have the chance to visit both Chambers and see places where historical decisions were taken for the UK (and sometimes for the whole world).

Visit part of Open House weekend. I've always wanted to visit the Houses of Parliament but have never found the time so when I saw that Westminster Hall was going to be open to the public free of charge as part of the Open House weekend in London it was an opportunity too good to miss. We had to go through security scanning which I imagine if you're on the usual tour of Parliament and once through I thought we would only be able to go into Westminster Hall. However to our surprise we were allowed as far as the Central Lobby which was lovely to see; the decor of the place took my breath away and it was lovely to be stood there after seeing it on TV so many times. Westminster Hall was breathtaking simply because of it's size, the fact that it's the oldest part of Parliament and so much history has been played out in there. We were about an hour and that was only seeing to two areas so I'd be keen to go back and have a full tour of Parliament and go up the Elizabeth tower.
Guided tour well worth doing. Fascinating tour by knowledgeable guide. Great being able to go into the rooms we are so familiar with through seeing on TV news and prime minister question time.

Fantastic. Wow, what an experience, such a wonderful building. The guide is so knowledgeable and can really draw you in with tales of past governments and how they operate today. It helps to book ahead to avoid queues and wheelchairs are available if requested at time of booking. It is a long time standing up as no chairs can be sat on but the tour is well worth any inconvenience. It is also nice to view the Houses of Parliament from the water as it looks spectacular and puts it all into perspective. The security is similar to the airport but that is understandable. Well worth the visit.
Private tour. We had a private tour of the Houses of Parliament ..  When the government are on recess . The building is open to the tourists To have guided tours

Houses of Parliament. Recently visited the Houses of Parliament on an organised coach trip and enjoyed the tour immensely. The security at the entrance is very similar to an airport, with bags being scanned and the metal frame you have to walk through. No fluids or sharp objects are allowed and no photographs when you are on the tour, which was a little disappointing, but understandable.There are 2 types of tours, one with a guide and one you can do on your own with headphones and a recorder, which uses numbers at various points on the tour and can be done at your own leisure.The gift shop is reasonable as is the cafe.The price was very reasonable at £13, but assume this price may have been as an organised group.
Must visit in London. These are a must visit in London the buildings are stunning and give you a true feeling of history. They look better then they do on tv.

Plan ahead for a tour!. Non-UK citizens can have a guided tour of this beautiful, historic, fascinating place only on Saturdays and sometimes when Parliament is not in session, but even at those times there is *plenty* to see and learn about and if you can possibly fit this into your London schedule, you will be very glad you did. The guides give you all kinds of interesting details & are very knowledgeable, will answer all questions. (Audioguide also available but I haven't tried it.) Book ahead of time! Especially if you want to add Afternoon Tea overlooking the Thames. The building is right next to Westminster Abbey--but allow plenty of time if you go to Abbey first, because it's easy to spend "extra" time there and your Parliament tour will start on time.
Exciting experience. The queue was long and the security a little exaggerated. I enjoyed the gallery and being able to watch parliament take place. It's worth going on a Wednesday when pm is there.

Amazing!. A great experience we had with our tour guide. We saw more than we expected! Really interesting traditions that are still kept to after centuries! Could do with some seating areas for people that struggle with standing for a long time.

Cholmomondeley Room dining,House of Lords.. Drinks on the terrace overlooking the Thames first.Structured three course Society paid for luncheon 'hosted' by a sponsoring Peer.Superb presentation from an obviously skilled kitchen brigade.Attractive cold vegetable starter with stuffed tomato as the centre piece.Medallion of beef and pulled shin (?) compote as a main,followed by an exquisite fruit tartlet dessert.If you ever get invited to a similar 'do',welcome the opportunity as for many reasons,not least the terrace overlooking the Thames, it is a memorable experience.Only problem is that you are not permitted to 'cross over' to the "lower house".To get to the House of Commons you have to go out and back through the security procedures.

Great building, tour provides a lot of history if you want it.
