I pre-booked an audio tour, no problems except that the ticket directed me to the wrong entrance (entry at St Stephen's(?), exit at Cromwell Gardens entrance). Audio goes on and on about parliamentary history and process, so you can skip it if you already know it and just gaze at the building. Security is remarkably friendly.

STAND IN LINE TO GET INSIDE!. After having just arrived in London me and a friend were walking around the side entrance and noticed a line of people. I asked a guard what was going on and he told me that the line was for people who wanted to watch a Parliament session. We stood in line for about half an hour, and then went through security, had to take off my baseball cap, but soon we were above the floor watching the whole thing- just amazing! Free, and something to always remember.
Amazing architecture. Amazing architecture here - bit of gothic with gargoyles etc. You can't get inside but the view outside is pretty good. Easy to access too. Great photos off the Big Bus.

Stunning outside, wished I could have toured it.... We stayed near Parliament on a recent trip to London. I didn't plan well ahead of time and we couldn't manage to get a tour inside. Still, I was able to walk around and see it/photograph it. What a beautiful, iconic building...such a great place to see. I recommend walking through Victoria Tower Gardens, located at the south end adjacent to Victoria Tower. Very peaceful and beautiful. Parliament Square (right across the street from the building) is a good place to photograph, especially from the northeast side where the Churchill statue is.A quick word on terminology/naming - The official name of the Houses of Parliament is "the Palace of Westminster"...and the big clock everyone recognizes? Yeah, that's actually called "Elizabeth Tower" (in honor of the Queen's jubilee). "Big Ben" is the large bell inside the tower that rings on the hour.I would have given this a higher rating if we'd been able to tour inside, as I understand it's beautiful.

Book through your MP for a free tour. Great couple of hours spent here. Took my mum who thoroughly enjoyed the experience and learning about it's history.Contact your MP if you live in the UK (6 month in advance if poss- although we only gave 2 weeks notice as we weren't aware of the free tour beforehand and thought we didn't have anything to lose by asking, and they managed to get us in)

STUNNING BUILDING BUT NO ACCESS. You can book to see Prime Ministers' quesiton time but if you are going to just look and see the Hosue of Parliament then prepare yourself for a disappointment! The pavement area alongside especially opposite Westminster tube station is crowded and cramped and then you cross over it;s the same. You cannot go into the building or grounds. You can get a photo of Big Ben for sure..but there's nowhere to sit or eat. Try and see Westminster Abbey opposite where Lady Diana married. You can go inside there. The whole area for me is spoilt by the incredible amount of traffic, cars,lorries,taxis and buses that speed around the square. Be VERY CAREFUL when crossing! There have been lots of accidents especially involving tourists looking the wrong way when they cross the road!!

Awesome. We booked a guided tour through our MP, you need to do this well in advance as the tours are very popular. Our guide Patrick was employed at the House and conducted tours in his spare time. He was very knowledgeable and made the tour very interesting. The House of Lords was stunning, the House of Commons much smaller than expected. This was the highlight of our visit to London.

Seat of power?. Very interesting. I was on a Crown and Commons weekend on a coach trip and was very interested in this seat of power, you were shown the house of commons and the house of lords in this guided tour. I have been twice and am thinking of going again next year. Worth a visit if your interested in this sort of thing. Pity they did not show you the canopied area next to the Thames.PS no cameras allowed to take pictures.

Knowledgeable Tour Guide. We took a guided tour and I am glad we did. The Blue Badge guide was very knowledgeable and interesting to listen to. The building interior is lovely and worth seeing itself. Security getting inside was understandably tight but we expected that.
Great. The main monument in London, visiting it you can understand the majesty of this city and its history.

Simply stunning both inside and out. Having lived all my life in London I had never visited the Houses of Parliament. It was an amazing visit - it's simply stunning and so exciting to see where the country is governed from. We then took afternoon on the terrace ( pre booked) which made for a complete afternoon. Afternoon tea was pleasant and good value by London standards but not a patch on the hotel ones.

Very educational. To attend the parliament buildings you prebook tickets and select a time convenient for you. They were about $25.00. Some times you can book a guided tour, but they were not available when we went on 06/15/ 2014. At first it was a little confusing getting our bearings, but once we got pointed in the right direction we were fine. We missed getting a map when we entered. Be sure to get one. The duty guards were not tour guides, but they were very knowledgeable and willing to talk to you on a one on one basis. At times you can visit when they are in session which would have been fun. Obviously you are driven by the Parliament's schedule as to what you will experience. A little aside..Big Ben can only be toured by British Passport Holders. We had hoped to go in it, but..oh well.

THIS IS LONDON !!!!. In the summer of 1967 I came to London to study. This is the first time I have returned to visit the Houses of Parliament and I am still in awe of their beauty. I am so glad that we took the time and effort to visit. The entry personnel were so kind to my husband (bad knee) - they got a chair for him and I ran and purchased the tickets. We used the audio tour - which was REALLY good. All of the guides were helpful and even shared stories with us. Two young women listened to my story about sitting in one of the galleries and even let us look into one of the rooms. Very nice!!Don't miss this wonderful experience....

Beautiful building!. We stayed close by, so walked past this building every day, and had a great view of it from our balcony! It really is beautiful. Would like to do a tour of it on our next trip to London.

House of Parliament, What Is London Without Visiting. I have traveled to London over 25 times and each time I have taken the time to visit this area and always glad I did. We were walking along the river and walked around the building admiring the structure. Unfortunately we didn't have the booking for a tour on this trip as we have gone in on an earlier visit.I particularly liked the David C review.

Tour. Tour with Colin as our guide was a highlight of our week in London. I highly recommend booking afternoon tea after your tour (see:http://www.parliament.uk/visiting/visiting-and-tours/tours-of-parliament/tours-teas-of-parliament/views re awesome, great photo opp, and very good tea

FASCINATING PLACE WITH STUNNING ARCHITECTURE. A superb place to visit for many reasons including the unbelievable architecture, visiting the public gallery (we were lucky to see a live House of Commons session), history, seeing MPs dashing about the place and having meetings, the 'How to make laws' workshop with the very entertaining workshop leader Sam, meeting and questioning our local MP and the friendly and knowledgeable educational guide (Andrea). The only downside was that the House of Lords hadn't returned from holiday. A GOOD TOUR FOR CHILDREN AND ADULTS ALIKE.
Wonderful building. I am sorry to say I didn't go into the Houses of Parliament but walked around the outside (it was closed). What a wonderful building to view and a great part of history to see!!

Housesof Parliament. Was taken on a very interesting tour of the above, the last timeI went was when I was at school,Not allowed to sit on the hallowed seats, but fortunately there were chairs in other rooms.Would not have missed it, but Oh my feet ached.
A must visit while in London. Had a very nice visit thanks to great weather and not that long a queue. However I will probably not visit it again as once was enough.

The source of our democratic process. We were fortunate to access the gallery of the House of Commons on opening week and observed an interesting debate concerning power compaies and their environmental responsibilities. House of Lords was not available unfortunately.
Houses of Parliament. This fabulous building makes me proud to be British and is a really interesting way to spend a few hours

Great tour, disappointing afternoon tea. We decided to go for the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament and we weren't disappointed. The building is beautifully ornate and the guide (Eileen) was excellent. She kept us all in order with humour and lots of interesting information not only about the history of the building but also about the British political system. Afterwards we went for afternoon tea on the terraces. Although it was nice, it was tiny for £25 and you couldn't tell you were still in the Houses of Parliament. So I would agree with a previous review - go for the tour but have your tea elsewhere.
Book online. The House of Parliament?! A place to go! Book online and enjoy the visit without much queue! Very british, unique atmosphere! Are you a Lord?!

The most beautiful building in the world. Really no need to review this building anymore. It's impressive from any point of view and by any weather, by day and by night. If you come to London by plane from Europe, try to take a right window seat, you will have the best view of the city, Houses of Parliament including.
Such a massive majestic building. A very impressive building, one marvels at the size of it, wonderful to walk along the Thames and enjoy the wonderful architecture.

Exellent. We wanted to visit the Abbey with my 13years old daughter,but the long queue and almost closing time,turn us back. Then we deside to check how we can enter the Houses of Parliament instead. End we had a short,but really interesting walk inside,plus possibility to watch debates and we was so impress,so couldn't leave the place......Really a good expirience.

Visit the chambers, skip the tea. As an American, who could resist visiting the "mother of Parliaments"? We opted for a guided tour followed by tea on the terrace overlooking the Thames.We met in Westminster Hall, an enormous relic that dates back to the early days after the Norman takeover. our tour guide was a little lady with a little voice. Given the size of the group, we had a lot of difficulty hearing her. The House of Lords is opulent, as one would expect, I guess. The House of Commons is a lot more understated, but if you know enough about Parliamentary history to fill in the blanks left by the guide, the tour is very good. I'm sure everyone would agree that the process where the Queen address "her" parliament is well worth seeing.We have had tea at some very nice places in a London, Parliament is not one of them. The service was slow, the sandwiches, scones, and sweets were average. Even the tented terrace along the Thames was a little boring. Don't bother with it, go to one of the better hotels instead.

Amazing . You could seriously spend all day there looking around there is so much to see! Thames River is full of boat tours and food isn't a issue as there are plenty of shops nearby, also the nearest tube station is almost next to parliament itself! Just a short walk across the bridge and you have the London dungeons, Mcdonald and of course the London Eye. If your planning on doing any of these activities though make sure you book on advance it's incredibly busy. Fantastic place and full of history

Guided Tour. So I went on the guided tour around Parliament with my boyfriend expecting it to be dull. It was a lot better than I could have ever imagined! The tour itself was over an hour long and our guide was brilliant. Some of the architecture we got to see was amazing. I personally think it was well worth the £50 or so this came to for both of us.

You will see the outside of THIS. Unfortunately, I can only speak of the OUTSIDE of this wonderful piece of architecture - probably one of the most imaged icons in London - can you do a selfie TOO?Getting an inside tour takes some trouble and NOT when the British Parliament is sitting apparently - visitor's gallery maybe.However sad it is that 'we' (not the Royal "We") did not get to sit through a large number of 'gentlemen' going on and on about UK issues, we were lucky enough to see the structure on several different occasions from plenty of different angles or locations.Try to spend the expensive amount of money it costs to go up in the London Eye at night for a truly spectacular view of the Parliament area.Big Ben is the bell housed in "Elizabeth Tower" at north end of the Houses of Parliament and even during the day it can look amazing. When the bell sounds - everyone looks that way (watch-out for the questionable street performers - some who "photo-bomb" your image and then very rudely demand money for the privilege!!! Call a 'bobbie' over if you have problems).Enjoy the view from down on the Thames River (oh, opt for a boat ride to do this), take images from the bridge and go up in the London Eye (day and night) for a very memorable vantage point.

Thank God Guy Fawkes failed!. It goes without saying this historical building is London at it's best! take a trip along the Thames afterwards and visit the local pub St Stephens Tavern and have a beer while looking up at Big Ben!
A Must See!. This is a must see. The Houses of Parliament is very beautiful. I went on an self guided audio tour which was very informative.

Packed with history, art, gold, glamour oh yes and politics... What could be better than a place full of history with amazing art, hidden facts and details in a place that is jaw-droppingly beautiful! I contacted my MP and arranged to have a tour on a Monday when there is a bit more time. I can't begin to explain everything but wiki does a very good job showing what is there and explaining the history. I hadn't realised that Westminster Hall, coffee shop and souvenir shop was available to the public without doing the tour. Bought the guide book and it's very helpful and a wonderful reminder of a fabulous day. Highly recommended.

Mr. Cameron is eloquent. As U.S. citizens, we were directed to the visitors gallery where we saw the MPs during question time. Then Prime minister Cameron took the floor to outline security measures and other foreign policy issues. He spoke directly and concisely on each issue. It was a rare opportunity to see a foreign leader speak in person. For those persons for whom walking up/down stairs is difficult, there is a lift available, but you have to ask for it.

Beautiful building. The tour was great and there is so much history tied into the actual build. The portion of the visit where you can observe the parliamentary system at work was not asuch to my liking. I would have much rather continued to look at the architecture.

Democracy, sort of. The building itself is stunningly beautiful.On the other hand getting in is a bit crazy. There aren't really any signs and once you work it out there are several layers of security to bypass including leaving behind all of your belongings. Just so you can sit behind some thick glass and watch the goings on from a distance. I must say parliament is fairly boring and the few mps attending looked bored too. The amount of umming and ahhing and lack of charisma and succinctness was concerning. I have seen high school public speaking a hundred times better. Also the rows in the viewing gallery are so close together I couldn't even fit in.I think it would be nice to have maybe gone on one of the tours, if we had of had any idea when or where they might be?

No brainer - go visit. Sure, there is a fee around almost 30 pounds for this, but it is worth it. To have the opportunity to visit something with such historical significance and see it with your own eyes...definitely worth a trio. You can choose between an audio guide tour or an actual tour (it costs a bit more). Even though there were heaps of people, it was very organized and you didn't get the feeling it was over-crowded.

The Corridors of Power. I absolutely loved this tour. I'm not 'that' into politics, but I found this tour fascinating. There is so much history in this building that you cannot fail to be impressed by it. We had a great tour guide who explained all the rooms as we went around. It was a shame there were lots of building works going on - but they explained that the summer was the best time to complete such works during holiday time.The building is full of impressive art and carvings and statues. Unfortunately you cannot take cameras inside. I saw the House of Lords and where the Queen sits etc. I also managed to get into the public gallery in the House of Commons and sat here for 30 minutes, listening to George Osborn and Teresa May give speeches. There is a gift shop and a cafe - where we stopped for a coffee and cake. This tour is well worth doing, to get a sneak peak inside the House of Parliament was both fascinating and a privilege.
British heritage at its best. Excellent value for moneyGet to visit all the rooms in the palace where the action is and that are regularly seen on the news etc.Excellent audio tourHistory at its best

History and Democracy. I spent many years in parliament, not as a politician or a civil servant but a father seeking justice for a terrible tragedy that ended with the death of my 19 year old son in a alcohol fuelled police chase. I worked with many politicians, MPs, Lords, civil servants and ministers to lobby parliament to have a law changed that enabled families and victims of 'Drink Drive' related deaths to receive justice for their loved ones.'Duggan's Law' was enacted in the 'House of Commons' in October 2002 This was a case that showed parliament listened to the common man and acted accordingly to right a terrible wrong. Democracy worked for my family and parliament showed it cared.I highly recommend a visit and take in a tour, History and Democracy does work !Declan Duggan

Tour of English Parliament. The English Parliament is the 'mother' of all parliaments and exudes a sense of history and gravitas. The Guides are excellent in their explanations and descriptions, so do ask them lots of questions, they are very knowledgable. the tour in not suitable for little children (boring) and difficult for the elderly or infirm as there is a fair amount of walking and standing. If you wear a hearing aid make sure you have it with you.
Out of world experience. This is one of my favourite places rich in culture and corridors of power along with a lovely restaurant
Ding Dong. great piece of architecture, lots to see in the area great pics from the river boats looks good at night

The Mother of all Parliaments...(and visits?). I visited here in late August mainly at the request of my history geek girlfriend (mwah x) and hadn't done a lot of homework beforehand. But as a British citizen and as a reasonably well traveled trip advisor I was really stunned at the history, architecture and the sense of privilege to be in the hallowed halls where so much history has happened. You can choose between guided and audio tours (cheaper option). We chose the guided tour because it was more personal and I believe accesses slightly more of the building. It lasted around 1 hour 45 minutes which was just about long enough. The guide was really entertaining and added another dimension to the experience. This is a working building and so one has to bear in mind that refurbishment and the business of parliament may affect access and the route of the tour. This is where the guided tour is better at adjusting for this. There is a strange juxtaposition of slow moving audio tour people engrossed in their tour, oblivious to others, and the guided walking tour weaving in between these zombie people - quite comical at times!My children (8 and 6) accompanied us because this was part of a big day out in London. I wouldn't recommend it for children of 6, however my 8 year old got a lot more out of it and even asked a question in parliament (and didn't have to pay cash for it - UK joke!).We didn't try the restaurant so you'll have to read other reviews for that aspect. I did try the gift shop which was well stocked with some interesting goods. It's a little small and was quite crowded. I really liked:- the amazing buiding, architecture and aesthetics of the place- the incredible history brought to life by the guide - the guide for his wit and clear sense of pride in his job - the sense of place and privilege - the value for money!I didn't like:There really wasn't much not to like...- having got through security and on arrival in the great hall there was a lack of a sense of arrival and welcome (minor);- I found the rule about not sitting down a little irritating at times. Partly when we were stood in the narrow benches of both houses. Mainly probably because as a UK tax payer I have bought at least one sit on the benches ;0).Overall:I loved the history, I was stunned by the opulence and beauty of the interior, the guide was really entertaining, the value for money and just the sense of having witnessed something very special.I really enjoyed the whole experience and will probably go again - highly recommended!

Fantastic Tour!. My family and I have been to London many times and the HoP was recommended by a friend - we are so glad that we took her advice and booked the guided tour (free if booked via your local MP!), it was a fascinating place to visit. The House of Commons and House of Lords looked much smaller in real life than on the TV! Our tour guide was very informative and certainly knew her stuff, this is one place that you must visit!

Well worth a visit. I didn't know what to expect and was pleasantly surprised. I loved the architecture of the building and rooms and seeing the House of Lords and Commons. Going to try and arrange a visit up the Elizabeth tower to see Big Ben.

A proud moment. We visited parliament with a party at 9.30 on a Monday in August. An excellent tour guide explained everything about governing this country and Her Majesty's part in the ceremonial. The carving and masonry are wonderful and it makes you very proud to be British with all our history.The restrooms, shop and restaurant were very good.
Very special. Really enjoyed our visit, a very impressive place to visit. Our guide was very informative, but do wish she had less hobby horses

Just fascinating. So the thing about Parliament is theres a reason it fits on a sauce bottle its really very very small other than Westminster Hall which is huge. The history of the place is amazing and just realising how compact the whole thing is compared to watching PMQ on the telly make sit really worthwhile. Definitely something for a repeat visit.

Put on your 'must do' list!. Having been to London umpteenth times in my life, I had never visited HoP. Its really fascinating to think on Monday morning this will all be hustle and bustle. And the history seeps from every wall and floor, it really is fascinating even if politics isn't your bag.I was amazed at how small the House of Lords and Commons rooms were - no wonder they look a little snug on tv!

Another London must-see. This was the highlight of my weekend. As a lawyer it has often occurred to me how important this institution is to our country and even the world. To finally get to walk around it and learn about some of its vast history was a real pleasure. Our guide was Barry Walsh (http://www.britainsbestguides.org/guides/1882/barry+walsh/), who gave tremendous insight into the storied past of the Houses of Parliament. If you are able to request him or book him for your group then I urge you to do so. He deserved a five-star rating of his own. As with Buckingham Palace, there is a limited opportunity for photography as it is restricted in many areas for security reasons.

5 for tour, 3 for afternoon tea!. Visited with a couple of friends and we all loved the guided tour. Tour guide was first class and most informative. Afterwards went for afternoon tea which was £27.50 each. Whilst the food was tasty we were shocked at the meagre sized portions - reminded us of nouvelle cuisine! We managed to get a refill of the teapot but nothing else. Given we have previously been to other venues where afternoon tea is topped up we were surprised this was not the case here. We were in and out of the restaurant in less than 30 minutes! So in conclusion, definitely do the Parliament tour but suggest you give the afternoon tea a miss!

Excellent guided tour. Security was tight, but once we got in the tour was very informative. We had the guided tour, our guide was well informed and entertaining. Loads of information, great seeing both houses and hearing some background information

Wonderful and very informative. I booked a guided tour for my 10 year old granddaughter and myself. I was apprehensive that she might find it too long, as the tour lasted nearly 2 hours, but there was so much to see, from awe inspiring architecture to amazing art. We both found the tour fascinating, covering as it does 1,000 years of history, that covered not only the history of the buildings but the evolution of the present parliamentary system. It is a place of interest that words really cannot do justice too and gets my vote as one of those places you must visit before you die. Booking online was very easy, with tickets sent by post. When we visited there was no queuing, just the few minutes it takes to go through security, as all tickets have a timed slot. You need to be aware that sitting is strictly forbidden in most places on the tour, except in two or three places, even on steps!, so after your tour, head to the cafe, situated in one corner of Westminster Hall, to refresh aching bodies and tired feet.
stunning. its massive and stunning. amazing architecture. and tells the history about the government. lovely place to visit

A Very British Experience.. History totally imortalised here. The granduer inside and outside is just magnificent. Felt privileged to go to a building where so much history has been made. The architecture has to be seen to be believed.

Very revealing tour. Enjoyed the audio tour which is well thought out and informative.Surprised in many ways that one can wander around the Houses as freely as one wishes.Would appeal to those of a political/historical bent.Very reasonably priced

Amazing place and a great afternoon tea . If you go to the ticket booth now in portcullis house opposite Big Ben you can't book afternoon tea To do both tour and afternoon tea you have to use ticket master I couldn't get it to do both do had to ring and comain and ticket master customer service sorted it out. I probably would have given up if it wasn't for a special occasion Security us tight as you would expect and us airport style so leave time Two types of tours audio do it yourself or guided The extra for the guide is well worth it Almost two hours of wonderful history and in one if the most over the top buildings ever You see both the Lords and the commons debating chambers. Sadly you can't take photos except in a couple of places and they aren't the debating chambers. Given it's on TV and photographed by the press I'm not sure why you can't take photos whilst it's not in sessionGood gift shop and cafe but we went for Afternoon Tea which was lovely and us in a Marque on the Terrace beside the Thames Nice sandwiches scones and clotted cream and cakes with good service and it really made for a memorable visit Desire living in London for years I had never been and it will certainly be a memory for the rest of my life and I can't recommend it enough

Interesting things to see. Good place to visit. We liked the music and culture section which might not be real museum stuff but the posters and costumes can bring a lot of memories back - well worth an hour or so of wandering round. By the way we thought the food in restaurant was pretty good too.

Fantastic Visit Dreadful Advance Ticketing System. This actual tour is deserving of a 5-Star rating without doubt. Such history stretching back far beyond the 19th Century period of the current Palace of Westminster. The building is a quite magnificent defiance made even more appealing by the fact that it is a true working environment and not just show.The Guide we had was of quite outstanding quality - deeply knowledgeable, irreverent and philosophical in respect of the political systems past and present!Now for the advance ticketing system. We booked our guided tour well in advance with no problems other than the total lack of instruction or direction about where to collect the tickets from or how to enter the Palace. I researched via the internet a found a few pointers from other disgruntled advance bookers. This didn't help and it was only helpful policemen who put us right!Even when we joined the entrance queue, having finally picked up the tickets,m&e almost missed our allotted tour time as there was no pointer to the fact that the queue contained many who had later tours. We barged to the front and were promptly told that we were late! Hopeless - the staff seeing us in agreed.Fantastic place to visit but the advance ticketing is unbelievably badly organised!

Best tour in London. First of all, our guide Fernando was great. Our family of four, including two teens, felt it was the most interesting site and tour guide in London. It's just really interesting to see and learn about the place where politics happens - even if it's not your own country.

Loved it!!. I dont know why I thought you could only visit when Parliament was sitting & through your MP. I think its probably better to go while its in recess as you can take your time looking around & go into both the Commons & Lords chambers. We did the self guided audio tour & took it at our own pace- listening -to all the bonus extras took a total of 2 hours. I think you could do it in just over an hour if you got on with it & didnt keep sitting down to gaze at the ceilings!Our 2 teenage children liked it as well though maybe they would have preferred the 1 hour version. I would highly recommend though maybe not suitable for younger children although I believe they have a youngsters audio guide available

Superb . Irrespective of what anyone thinks of today's politicians, this is a superb tour through the history of the palace. Steeped in history, stories, and procedures. Found it fascinating - superb. Tour guide very knowledgeable and enthusiastic.

Interesting Tour. Impressive from the outside, it's well worth taking a tour of the inside during recess.To arrange a tour when you're in the area, from the Houses of Parliament walk over the bridge, turn right and the office is just across the road. We took an audio tour - the equipment was easy to use and the commentary is very informative. It was fascinating to see inside, particularly the House of Commons. Because of timed entrances for tours it was uncrowded inside and the tour can be taken at your own pace.

our Heritage. You don't have to be political to visit, these building are being cared for our kids and generations to come. The House of Commons and Lords look bigger on the TVBut other parts are outstanding great .However was disappointed one could not book tea on the terrace at the ticket office when told we could, we had tried on line,lack of communication /training there, also quite expensive(£25)considering we pay for it. And you are not allowed to take pictures.

Excellent tour. Great audio tour. My suggestion would be to buy the tickets in advance online. We bought the tickets the day of, and had to go across the street to a different building to buy the tickets. It was kind of a pain to fight all the London tour groups to get to the other building. The ticket sales office staff were not exactly the nicest people.

The annals of history. Being interested in history and politics, and the Westminster system, I was quite excited to take this tour. It's quite easy to book your tour via the Parliament website.I took the guided tour, which was very informative and somewhat entertaining. I found it enthralling to be in the House of Commons and House of Lords chambers, which I have seen before on videos on the Internet. The interiors are also obviously ornately decorated and well preserved. Of course, your enjoyment depends on your interest.Other things I found interesting were the old and rather quirky traditions still observed by both chambers.

The mother of all democracy. Come and visit it's the seat of your government after all, and visited by less than 1 percent of the population probably. The tour is timed unless doing the self guided one which is at your own pleasure. The guide was very knowledgeable, and answered questions as the group went along. The tea on the terrace and tour is quite pricey but you have to think of where you are! Just turn up, lobby your MP, see democracy in action. Entry is fee but there is a charge for a guided tour. Other tours are available via your MP.

Cream Tea and Tour. Wife suggested this and I was a bit meh... Well I really enjoyed it and the history and self guided tour was great. If you want to understand the mother of all parliaments then do the self guided tour.

See What You're MP is Up To Every Day!. Everyone should visit this once in their lifetime. It's what your country is all about. It's where your future is decided. And it's where the people you elect make the decisions that affect your life. No wonder foreigners flock there to see it all in all ind glory and splendour. Arguably the most impressive building in Britain.
Stunning to See. The architecture in these buildings is so amazing. Of course people have seen these buildings on television shows and movies but to see it in person is quite a treat.

Fantastic to visit with a guided tour.. It's possible to visit the Houses of Parliament if you contact your local MP and complete a form online. We did this and had an enjoyable and interesting visit. The guide gives anecdotal tales about Winston Churchill, and some contemporaries, and brings to life a behind the scenes view of some of the goings on! We visited Kate in the day and the shop had closed when we got to it so, if you want a souvenir, book for an earlier tour.

Don't miss this attraction.. You are offered two options with this attraction. The audio or the guided tour. The latter is the one I'd recommend. The tour lasts about 100 mins and is packed with fascinating insights into the Uk's seats of power. You are guided thru' rooms and halls adorned with paintings and marble figures. The House of Lords is spectacular and then off to the House of Commons! Fascinating facts are everywhere. Everything is expertly and entertainingly communicated. Questions are fully answered and at the end of the tour I could have ' gone round again!'Highly recommended. Thank you Victoria' you were really special.(Our guide)

BEAUTIFUL BUILDING. Great history surrounding this building which hosts the active Parliament of the Government. It's very hard to miss when you are walking along the river and quite overwhelming. Its another must see when you are in London.

A must see in London. The audio tour of the Houses of Parliament is great fun and great learning. This fantastic building includes so many stories, so much history and yet so much present that it all makes it a great experience. Learning about how this build has been used by the parliament in the past as well as today is great fun and great learning.The afternoon tea is also worth spending some pounds on.

Wonderful Palace to visit.. This was a real eye-opener to the real power base of our country.We did not expect to be so completely enthralled by the history and sheer magnificence of this incredible building.We kept getting surprise after surprise by our fantastic guide,who told us some great stories.Well worth visiting this world famous building.We won't forget our visit in a hurry.Highly recommended.
Beautiful Building. Not sure if you are able to go inside. We saw heavy security all around but the building used to be the Westminster Castle and is a great building to see and take some photos of.

Good but not great. we took the guided tour. our guide was not very organised and kept going from one thing to another and wasn't the funniest woman on earth..it's nice that you get to know a little how it works but also disappointing that they don't let you sit anywhere but they tempt you all the time, so it's a little disturbinganyway, maybe with some wikipedia its enough..

Execellent Audio Tour. We were in London on the weekend, and noticed you could do a tour of the Houses of Parliament. To my suprise while the regular tours were fully booked (This was mid July!), the audio-tour was wide open, so we were able to book the tour that day.I think they only do the tours at the weekend, when they are in session, so its always worth checking the website. The tour was excellent, you had multiple levels to it, where if there was a particular bit you wanted more info for, you could get extended versions of the tour.What is suprising is that most of the building is really not that old (with the exception being Westmister Hall). In fact bits were bombed during the war, but there is still great bits of history there. Definately worth a trip.

Interesting. We visited here last weekend and thought it was interesting and informative and completely amazing to stand beside the seat occupied by the PM. Strange how we weren't allowed to sit at various places though. The history of the building is fascinating and it was great to see the places where so many important decisions have been made. I would recommend this attraction.

Very enjoyable and interesting. Has a lot of great things going for it. An amazing iconic building, both inside and out. Fantastic stories and history just oozes out of the place. The audio guide was really good and make doing a self guided tour easy.One tip - research where the ticket office is and where the visitor entrance is before you arrive to save time (it's not entirely logical as the ticket office is off-site).

Living History.. I would strongly encourage anyone with an interest in the country’s history and heritage to visit the Houses of Parliament. It is a wondrous building from the outside, and just as impressive inside.As you stand in Westminster Hall, which dates back to the 11th century, and which contains various plaques where monarchs and world leaders have stood and delivered addresses, or have been laid to rest, you can sense the history. The same apllies as you move through the chambers, halls and corridors.Stunning architecture, real historical interest – a great experience.

Tour of Parliament. very well informed guide gave loads of historical tales and facts plenty of items to see and take in, interesting building features, design and splendour of the place to absorb and some suprising facts.

AWESOME!. I have done a guided tour and I highly recommend that! My tour guide was Helen. She was so lovely and she explained everything so well to us! If you are interested in history and if you wanna go the same way like the queen does that once a year, you really have to join a tour through the houses of parliament. You get the chance to enter rooms, which you would never be able to enter without a guide.You can book the tour in different languages and you can get the tickets directly at the houses of parliament or online.

A great experience. Being inside the HoP was really fascinating and very exciting. We booked two days beforehand and could not get onto the tour + tea experience, so book well ahead if you want to do this. There were no queues and the whole feel was pretty relaxed. The guided tour was lengthy - nearly two hours - with not much chance to sit down (if you need to). However, it is extremely interesting - the only negative was that the tour was 75% in the House of Lords and elsewhere and only 25% in the House of Commons; personally, I would rather have heard much more about the latter and much less about the tiles/paintings/carvings and gilding in the former. Will definitely return in a few years - and use the audio guide!

worth the wait.. This was a very nice audio guided tour. Be advised that you need to purchase tickets for the tour across the street from Parliament before lining up to get in. It's worth the long lines and the rather lengthy security check.
Magical. It was a very magical moment to be at the heart of Brit politics.. You should take a tour at Westminster and see the atmosphere!

Well worth a visit. We visited yesterday and booked the audio tour via the website linked to Ticketmaster. Kids under 16 go free with an adult. Much cheaper admission that the nearby Westminster Abbey and no queues either. Photos aren't allowed in anything other than Westminster hall and I was itching to take photos in every room. Tour takes you into the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Guided tours offered but a bit more expensive. Older children will enjoy this more than younger ones.
impressive. Very accessible for anyone to see. On the Thames it looks stunning and is great if you approach it from the river.

Fantastic. Had a great time here - also my 8 year old son was fascinated with the whole tour. No queues, a little bit of security to go through at the entrance and after picking up your audio tours you were let alone. Great... 100% recommended.
Eye opener. Not what i expected at all. Well worth going though. Feel like you are surrounded by history. Enjoyable visit.

DO THE TOUR!!!!!!. Maybe from the outside is very beautiful and the architecture is gorgeous, but the interior is absolutely fabulous. I was impressed to tears, I can't describe the beauty of the interior. seriously, if you visit london for the first time then you need to do the parliament tour. you can buy the tickets near the westminster way out from underground.

Disappointed. My husband and I booked a guided tour starting at 2.30pm. We arrived early but found the queue very long, as apparently there had been a hold up in security, so we had to wait at least half an hour. Our alloted guide was an interesting lady who obviously knew her history but she could not compete with the vocal volume of her colleague in the adjacent group (an actor by profession), and also the noise from the building work. We heard only a fraction of her commentary, which I am sure was edited because of her time constraint. We were rushed through each room ending in almost a run through the chambers, side stepping severel other language groups and also individuals doing the audio tour. The whole place seemed chaotic. My advice would be to book out of the main holiday season, probably the first or last group of the day or do the audio tour so you can spend longer admiring the superb interiors of the rooms. We were left feeling short changed and very disappointed.
Houses of Parliament. This was a real gem. Amazing audio tour. Well worth the time and money. The building inside is amazing. History clearly explained

Worth Seeing for Sure. We liked Buckingham palace tour and Westminster Abbey tours more but this was worth going. It always bums me out that these places don't allow any photography but of all the places we have been, they were the loosest in enforcing this rule here. We loved some of the ceilings and the history of westminster hall (where William Wallace was condemned to death, amongst others).

Very interesting. Our trip to Houses of Parliament was very interesting. It was wonderful to see how Parliament works and the two chambers- House of Commons and House of Lords. In the Central Lobby, you see many statues of famous politicians. Also in other parts of the Palace of Westminster, there are busts and statues of more recent Prime Ministers.We also had had tea on the terrace which was very nice.

Absolutly stunning. We had a guided tour and found the history so intriguing and if only the walls could talk with all the past history what a tale they would tell. A must to visit when your next in London but arrange before you go as security is very strict
Impressive grand building. Great photo opportunities. Especially near Big Ben Try and take a bus ride or Thames cruise also to get a better insight.
site-seeing. Very fascinating to hear of their system of government and understand all the history of the english system.

Interesting for the adults. We timed it right, because both houses were in session late one night, so we went around 5 pm with no line. It was interesting to see the differences in the houses, and try to figure out what they were debating since we walked in in the middle of it. It became apparent that politics aren't so different than in the US. Even my 14 year old found it interesting, and my 11 year old took a short nap. The staff was very helpful and full of interesting anecdotes when we talked to them. Pretty cool!
Beautiful. This is the greatest and the most iconic view of London. The best time to go is in the night. Its amazing..
Informative and enjoyable. The debating chamber is smaller than you'd think. Book ahead and there's lots to see - especially the great hall. Recommended.

Interesting and very educational. I visited the Parliament in August 2014 and opted for a guided tour as I was certain a human guide was worth the few extra pounds (compared to the price of an audio guide tour) - and I was absolutely right. The guide I had was brilliant, knew everything about the building and the way the Parliament works and he made sure everyone understood what he said. Plus, we were able to go into several rooms which those with an audio guide could only view from the doorstep. The groups are quite small - around 25 people - so there's no pushing to the front rows. Everyone can hear the guide clearly - that is, unless (which was the case during my visit) some parts of the building are under maintenance, which means you occasionally have to ignore the sound of drills.As for the tour itself, it lasts for about 100 minutes and is quite interesting. We went into both the Lords and the Commons Chamber (which, for me, were the highlights of the tour), as well as many other chambers and rooms. The guide explained how the Parliament works, how laws are made, and gave as a mental image of what it's like to be a Member of Parliament. As someone who lives outside the UK and isn't completely familiar with British titles and legal terms, I had some trouble understanding certain things the guide said, but it wasn't a huge problem. By the end of the tour, I understood completely how the Parliament functions. My advice is, don't bring children with you. There were three girls in our group, two of them around 10 years old and one no older than four, who seemed to be quite bored (to be honest, no 10-year-old would like to listen about ministers, bills and voting). However, if you do decide to bring your child along, you are allowed to push them around in a buggy.Be prepared for a 1h 40min walk. There are no toilets and refreshment stops during the tour, only after you've finished it. You are also not allowed to sit in most of the benches and chairs in the building (though they are quite tempting). Come to the tour 20 minutes early, as you will have to go through an airport-like security check, for which you'll have to queue for 10ish minutes. Lastly, photography is forbidden everywhere except for the first hall you step into, so don't bother bringing one of those bigger cameras with you.

Beautiful. The buiding is really nice and the Big Ben is good to see it because is one the identities from London. You have a square with the statues of important people for British history like Churchill and also Mandela.
Just another tourist attraction. Theres not much there to do ie get a few photos to say look iv been to the houses of parliament its not the best place to go in London but thats your choice

More interesting than you may think.. We booked online, as a last minute decision, very straight forward, as was the collection of the tickets. We had a very good guide, Sheila Urbani, who made the tour extremely interesting. It was great to see the places you have only ever seen on the TV. A fabulous building, so much history. Amazing to think we have been to London so many times, but had never done this. Think it is more for adults than children, but would be great for students of any age, interested in our Constitution.

Just do it!. Wow, one of the best tours I have ever been on! Learned so much and my children too.Lovely tour guide, fantastic tour guide book!Always wanted to do this tour but never quite had the time.

Informative and Fun. We went in August so things were a little slow. Still, the tour was informative and the history behind Parliament is amazing. This is a must-do during a visit to London, particularly if you have an interest in politics.
great visit. This is the best of what London offers. History, architecture and power in the same place. Just magnificent

Major tourist attraction. I think it's among the must see in london and with the audio tour you can walk at your own, as fast or slow you want. There is history hidden in every corner of the Parliament.
Majestic. Everything you would expect the United Kingdom to have for their parliamentarians. Grand and full of gravitas.

Free tour through your MP. Highly recommend a tour. Go online and find your local MP and they will sponsor a tour for you for free. I took my 10 year old who was a little bored but I loved it. Start off in Westminster hall after going through all security, you have a tour guide in a group of 15 of so. Not allowed to take photos. You get to see House of Lords, House of Commons, robeing chamber, st Stephens hall etc. can be very busy and noisy as tours are every 10 minutes so you have to struggle to listen to your guide. They have a gift shop, cafe and toilets in Westminster hall where you finish the tour. Tour last approx 70 minutes.

Visit to Houses of Parliament. Went with a group of 14 people on a pre arranged tour via our local MP. The tour was excellent showing the Great Hall, Parliament and the House of Lords. The guide was very informative.

Just excellent!. Booked tickets through our MP (how did we get to 50 years of age and not realise this was possible) and had the best time. So much history and loads of info (our guide, Luke, was great). Fantastic to see House of Lords and Commons which we've seen so often on TV. Will now try and come back for Prime Minister's Question Time.
Excellent. Enjoyed it thoroughly, very informative and educational, lovely coffee shop too! Very historical so take your time and enjoy the atmosphere

living history. You are walking through a building that is living history. I decided to pay for the tour guide, which was both informative and lively, and unlike the audio tour, participants could ask questions. The architecture and interior are simply beautiful - design and craftsmanship at it's very best.

Unexpected discovery. We were trying to photograph my husband by the King Richard I statue. The policeman told us the the House of Lords was in session & that we ought to go through security & see it. We are so glad that we took him up on the suggestion.
Photo Ops. We took photos with the guards at the gates to parliament. It turned out to be a very nice day and the guards were very nice to indulge us with photos.
Big Ben, Parliament.... It was amazing to see in person. Lots of history and one of those iconic places in the world. Good way to spend a morning.

A Real Trip Through History. My wife and I took the guided tour and found it to be a great experience. We learned a great deal of history about the Houses of Lords and Commons. I can't wait to watch some sessions on the tube, knowing that I have been in the actual room!

Interesting and informative tour. Booked tour of the Houses of Parliament for myself and my husband, really good guide, with lads of interesting facts. A good way to spend a couple of hours. Would have liked to have actually sat on the seats on the House of Commons this would have been a bonus.
Massive stonework. Awesome building detail and size jaw dropping see what our taxes have been spent on and where all good and bad policy's are made
Great place. I enjoyed my time there. The atmosphere is great and the staff high standard. Location is perfect and we will get our friends there.

Obligatory. We did the walk by of this iconic landmark as it is somewhat obligatory while in London. It did not disappoint. It is historic, grand, and impressive and gives one much to absorb. A must see. Would I feel the need to go back? Perhaps not.

Imposing and magnificent. Every visitor to London needs to see the buildings in which our government operate, a system copied the world over. The buildings are magnificent. I haven't done the tour yet but will eventually.
impressive building. a vey large and ornately decorated building. big ben was the best bit. over the years this place has controlled a huge part of the world but it doesn't look like it
History. Historical lesson. Very friendly and relaxed environment. First visit to this historical place. Would highly recommend

Uber-toured. Well, I monitored parliament's homepage as there are tours that are run only a couple of dates and this year they were announced pretty late, but nevertheless, I did the general tour on the Houses of Parliament which was a mass event (groups of up to 25 being channeled through) and is worth the effort to get an overview. But the uber-tour was the "royalty and splendour in the House of Lords tour". We were two people. Simply incredible when you see the queues at the sights around. This was more specific and in-depth than the general tour and thanks to the number a really private and memorable affair. Should you decide to bike to the venue, bear in mind that Abingdon Green bike stand tends to be full and the alternative at St John Smith's Square is really none, if you have not tried Storey's Gate in the first place and were successful, you may end up down Millbank close to the Tate Britain and have another ten minutes to walk.

architectural magnificence. This is a must see in London. The building and it's history speak for itself. To think about Churchill to Henry the 8th and the decisions that were made in this historic landmark are fascinating and a must see.

Houses of Parliament Tour. We booked a guided tour through our local MP. The tour was very well presented and extremely interesting. There was a clear account of the history and of the business that is carried on in the House of Commons and House of Lords. There was so much to see, and so much to take in and the tour was over far too soon. It is a very special place.

Overwhelming history. Good tour, amazing buildings, with such a history! Guide was a little too much on the official history line and didn't seem to have read around the subject, i.e. she still thought that Guy Fawkes genuinely wanted to blow up the king. Westminster Hall was my favourite, to think who had stood there over the years...
History is History. The Parliament signified the long history about the development of Great Britain's government/regime.

Guided tour with secretary to our local MP. This was a prearranged visit conducted by the secretary of one of our local MPs. and covered the whole of complex including the both houses and the lobbys. The tour included a well presented account of the history of the building and the current protocol of the way business of parliament is conducted both in the Commons and `That other place` the House of Lords.It is well worth a visit.
grand. Very grand and only wish the MPs had been at work while we were there. We would have loved being able to go up in the Elizabeth Tower, but understand the security concerns, sigh.

Great insight and stunning architecture. We managed to book the tour through our local MP and following the security check which took about 10 minutes were met by his representative, it was very interesting to get an insight as to how the Houses run and visit the Commons & Lords you see on television, unfortunately when we visited Parliament was in recess and there was some building work being carried out, but the tour was fascinating nonetheless. The buildings are of great historical significance and there are some great sights to see.

Poor. We arrived half an hour early as instructed to collect our tickets and go through security. Having waited until already past our tour time we were then told we weren't able to go in the group that we had booked to go in and had to wait for the next tour. We found this appalling seen as we were early for our slot and were there ready to go when a huge school group came in and was sent through in our slot before us. We were not allowed to join this as it was 'too full'. Surely this is factored in when booking?!We'd paid good money for the particular slot that we'd chosen and had other things to do that afternoon so we didn't appreciate not being allowed to go with our requested time slot for the tour.In the slot that we finally were placed into, they were putting people in the following group that were there early into ours, holding up our tour even further. It was also extremely disorganised and very busy whilst going around the tour. We kept having to move out the way, get hurried along by the following tour group etc. It was very cramped.The tour itself was very good and i'm glad we finally got to see it, I loved getting the opportunity to see around the building but the whole experience was actually really poor and I wish we hadn't paid £50 in total for it. Definitely not worth that amount of money for two tickets.

Historic but too much standing. Very interesting tour but hard to hear and it was walking and standing almost all of the time. I recommend that you have sensible shoes and be in good condition. And make sure you don't carry any scissors or pocket knife!

Houses of Parliament. A very interesting talk and tour provided by Susan Price.Great insight into the workings of Parliament from House of Lords to House of Commons. Fascinating information regarding the Queens speech at the State opening of Parliament. Cannot take photos in most areas which is a shame and we are not allowed to sit for most of the 2 hour tour which can be quite strenuous. A very good tour however and highly recommended

Grand. Loved the architecture and the history of the building. You step into a different world and very briefly I imagined what it must be like to work in such an impressive building as well as the wondering the types of conversations that must go on
Great. Took a tour with a guide named Sheila in early August. She was informative and funny. Would recommend people purchase their tickets in advance though.
Brilliant. More insight to what our MP's and Lords get up to. The guided tour was very interesting. It's our heritage and should be made compulsory to visit

An architecturing excellence. My husband is a retired architect, so visiting the House of Parliament was a must. We went there with the Little London Art School, who organized a Fairy Treasure Hunt for our grand kids.
This building is majestic, and we even learnt a few very interesting facts about the tower and the clock. It's a must see.

How to pick. Look. Plan 2 or 3 . 5 star home run places a day and you'll still have some left on the list after a week.. Planning is key to London.. Such an awesome city..Guided tours a must... The down side, a bit sry are the Brits.. But chin up and learn some real history..Ask what a tally stick is !

Very good tour but could do better. The tour actually last 1 hour and 40 minutes and there's very little sitting allowed. However even before the tour starts you have to pass through security, which adds another 20 minutes. As Parliament was in recess, the builders are in and the place seems a bit of mess outside, as did Westminster Hall.Our tour guide, Janet, was excellent and I could not remember any mistakes. The tour concentrates on the history of the building rather than what happens inside. Ideally I would like to have seen the restaurant and bar, the MP offices, the press gallery and how the building actually works. At £25 it's not cheap, and you cannot take photos other than in two parts. As mentioned above no sitting on the benches in either the Lords or Commons, although you can sit down in the committee rooms and the voting lobby. As tours run every 20 minutes, both in English and various other languages, plus the numerous audio tours the place seemed very crowded, even though parliament was in recess.Overall I got the impression that we were being tolerated, and if every tour sells out that's nearly £80,000 per day from these tours. Someone is making some serious money from this. Came away thinking it was nice, but it would better to see the place in "action".
Take the guided tour. Very interesting. With the guided tour it is more friendly and you enter in some area reserved to the guide. You can also ask questions to the guide to have more informations
Interesting. Everthing was very informatived and orgaized plus the employed people were very knowledge about everyhing there
Excellent. Had a brilliant tour around the Houses of Parliament - was very informative. It was great to see such an old historic place in the flesh.
very insightful. Loved the guided tour... loved the experience. really a lot to learn and keep increasing our knowledge. Mum and Dad loved it too!!!
You have to go! Inside that is.. This is the best of what London offers. History, imposing architecture and power in the same place. Just magnificent.

London's ex-libris!. When you think London, you think Houses Of Parliament and Big Ben!It's great to see the architectural structure of it all and to synchronize your watch on the most accurate watch of them all, right?Take a pick at this magnificent piece of History through, as a suggestion, the Westminster Bridge AND (most important) before V blows them up! ;-)

Well worth the money for the tour. The tour of HP lasted approximately 1 1/2 hours and was worth the money. You see so much and it is explained to you along with a lot of history. Unfortunately our guide had a weak voice (it was nearing the end of the day too) and we struggled to get as close to her as we could in our crowd of tourists since we really wanted to hear the full narration. A tip to HP would be to have some kind of microphone for the guides who cannot speak very loud in order that everyone is able to enjoy the tour. The guide book that comes with your paid ticket is a great souvenir and full of information.

Went into the House of Commons. Interesting and an opportunity of a lifetime. Very easy to gain access. Do not be bashful and be sure to ask security any questions and they will give you great guidance and advice.

Interesting. We did the self guided tour and got to see both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Really interesting from a historical perspective. Nice architecture, sculptures and paintings. Most of all it felt a bit dated and strange on how things work in England. Having religious leaders who participate there seems so strange to an American where we have separation of church and state. The seats they use all seemed uncomfortable. I was shocked that there are not enough seats for all the members of the House of Commons. How odd.

Worth getting the guided tour!. I really enjoyed the tour of the Houses of Parliament. It was worth getting the Guided Tour because it was full of interesting information, we were able to access all areas on the tour and the tour guide clearly took pride in showing people around. If I were to go again I would take more time to look at the art around the building, as it was not easy to take it all in when rushing through the corridors. The building itself is impressive and full of fascinating history. I thought that the ticket price was fair for the experience. We did not book our tour in advance, but bought tickets at the door after queueing for about 10 minutes (this was on a Thursday during the school holidays).
Lovely looking buildings. we are so lucky with the wonderful architecture of our buildings in London and the houses od parliament are no exception. They are beautiful and historic.

Interesting tour. We had a guided tour which was very interesting but there are very few places on the tour to sit down. The tour takes about 90 minutes and only 3 places to sit so can be a bit trying. If I did it again I would do it under my own steam and go at my own pace.

Fascinating and historic. What a beautiful, historic structure. We did not have to wait in line very long. The audio tour a must. The staff were most helpful to me being a college government teacher. I asked many questions and the staff could answer all my questions. Loved it!

Great tour. I think it's ESSENTIAL to book early and get a guided tour of this place, it brings it alive and gets you into 2 or 3 areas you can't get into on the audio tour. You see everything you'd expect to see and more, with the history of the building and the british political system thrown in. Loved this.
Afrternoon tea on the terrace. Very enjoyable and good value as afternoon teas go in London.But well worth it for the experience of eating on the House of Commons terrace.

Walk by the river. The parliament buildings are not open to the public but they are a beautiful sight and very photogenic. The few remaining red telephone boxes are on parliament square on the side which is exit 6 from the underground. Then you can cross over to the centre and take more photos there.
great. fantastic - the seat of our government in the greatest city in the world. a must to visit if you go to london

Interesting visit. We took advantage of this visit as parliament was on summer break. We chose the headset trip as opposed to the guide tour, This meant we could take our time and the commentary was very interesting. The history of the place is fascinating and it had a slightly surreal feel being there with no politicians! There are lots of quiet places to sit and take in the atmosphere, it felt very calm and tranquil away from the hustle and bustle of Westminster bridge.there is also a super cafe to finish the visit with tea and cakes!
House of lords. We had chance to attend the debate in house of lords. The building is impressive. And a good experience.

Wonderful Tour. A wonderful visit to one of the most famous and instantly recognisable buildings in the world. It was slightly strange to see the empty and quiet benches in the House of Commons and Lords instead of the normal busy and rowdy atmosphere we have got use to on the TV. Our guide was very knowledgeable and informative.Regardless of your interest in politics, this is a must visit attraction for its historical importance and the amazing Architecture.

Great visit. This is worth a visit, the place is amazing! The architectural structure of this building both inside and outside is phenomenal.I recommend visiting on a sunny day, the stained glass windows are beautiful and with natural light they look stunning.

Wow an amazing building and an informative tour. Took my 14 yr old son and we both enjoyed it . About 1Hr 20 mins but wear comfy shoes as no sitting allowed !! The tour was very informative and interesting so much info and history. The interior is stunning as amazing as Buckingham palace. Hidden gem. Well worth a visit . We did the guided tour not the audio.

Immense. Easy to get wrapped up in the atmosphere. So busy. Beautiful surroundings. Easy to find due to Big Ben! Tour buses passes all the time. Next to Westminster Abbey so plenty of sightseeing in a short distance. River cruises will give a different view. Flat for walking. Lots of photo opportunities
Great tour. We did the tour of both houses in a group and then had lunch in the house of Lords restaurant. If you love history you will love the tour.

so much history. I was lucky to visit the house of Lords 3 times due to events I had from work and was even luckier to have a full tour through the commons as well. You can breathe history here. the building is amazing! in summer the terrace with the views are incredible.
House of Commons. We were able to attend a session of the House of Commons. Very interesting. They really cheer or jeer the speaker.

Tour of the Houses of Parliament. I have visited London many times and this year decided it was a must do my friend & I stood in the queue for our tickets & times we were allotted to tour it was really worth doing we visited the hall where kings & queens through out years layered in State then through St Stephens hall ,into the lobbies House of Lords & House of Commons lot of statues of previous MP's oil paintings of our Monarchs throughout the ages if your going to our Capitol city then it's a must you will certainly enjoy it

Great tour, shame a jobsworth security guard spoiled it. Tour took close to 2 hours with a friendly and very knowledgeable tour guide who brought the stories to life. Towards the end of the tour the guide invited us to sit down on some benches behind the Commons' chamber and a couple of people were still standing so she suggested we sit at a nearby table in green chairs. After a few moments a security guard (the chief judging by his badge) stormed in to our area and shouted at us to get out of the chairs in an aggressive and wholly unprofessional manner. He shouted across the guide and came across to check we hadn't damaged the chairs. He was so rude it was unbelievable and totally humiliating for the tour guide.As a public servant he could do with going on a customer service course and stop being such a jobsworth. Let's face it, the sort of people prepared to spend £25 each on a tour are hardly likely to be people who will damage this property. If I could have caught his name I would be making a formal complaint as this isn't the type of person I want acting as an ambassador for my country to foreign visitors attending my Parliamnat.
Just a look and a few photos. You will see it anyway, it is beside Westminster Abby and Big Ben, Just a beautiful building. Also, few steps away from river cruise boats.
Behind the scenes. Fabulous day to tour behind the scenes and watch the action from the balcony. We watched the Commons and the House of the Lords. Architecture is amazing.

Great tour, impressive place!. Did a guided tour of the place twice and really enjoyed it. There is something about this place with its charm and little stories of British political history, also it's simply a gorgeous building worth a visit in itself.

Amazing Building and Tour - A Must Do!. My husband and I booked a Saturday Afternoon guided tour of Parliament that was combined with afternoon tea in the Terrace Pavilion overlooking the River Thames. This experience was worth every penny (And trust me, it cost quite a few!), but we would do it again in a heartbeat. Pros:- The guided tour lets guest enter more rooms than the audio tour alone. Not to mention you get to talk to a real live person who can answer any questions you have. - Our guide was very knowledgeable, pleasant, and able to handle our group and our questions quite well. - The tea service was absolutely superb, and the few of the River Thames and London Eye could not be beat.- There are unicorns all over Parliament. I think this is my favorite realization of the day.Cons:- You can't take picture through most of the tour and are not allowed to sit down in many of the rooms. I truly didn't mind either of these issues, but if you are older, this might make the tour hard to endure. Although, we had a few people with canes that put the rest of us young ones to shame with all of the stairs and walking!Tips:- Arrive at least 30-45 minutes early to go through a security screening much like an airport. - Much to our surprise, they did not require an ID, just our already purchased tickets.- Once the tour is over, you are not allowed to re-enter any of the areas outside the main hub, we learned this the hard way (Meaning we received stern looks and were asked to wait in the hub for our afternoon tea).- Guided tours will provide more information and let you see more of the building.- Afternoon tea is worth it. It was vegetarian friendly as well! This must be stated when booking.

Great educational experience.. The Houses of Parliament is a must-see while in London. The entire experience is extraordinary and very educational. The audio-guide is very informative and easy to follow and the staff is very friendly and helpful. The tour allows you to walk around a majority of the area and see areas such as the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Small children may not find this interesting, though. The café at the exit is very nice and they have great selection of coffee and snacks. The souvenir book is very nice and definitely worth the £5. TIP: You cannot buy the tickets at the entrance, you must buy them across the street. Also, we went at 3:00 pm and it was not crowded at all.

An excellent tour arranged in advance with an MP.. If you have friends English friends then ask them to request a tour of the interior of the building via their local Member of Parliament. This one needs to be planned well in advance but it's worth the effort. I was spellbound throughout.

Very very impressive. Walking around with a guide left us with an admiring impression.The guide's stories were fascinating. Looking at Prime minister's Churchill's shining foot, was interesting. This is from so many people's touch. The green leather chairs in the hall are beautiful. This is the cradle of democracy. So many parliaments are built according to this place.We had a superb visit. .

A real treat to visit.. It was our 40th wedding anniversary and where did my husband want to visit? Not very romantic but we both really enjoyed our tour sponsored by our local MP so it was free. To be where history has and is still being made is awe inspiring and our guide had just the right amount of fact and humour to make it very interesting. We were lucky to be in a small group so do try to visit early. Makes you proud to be English!
A national Landmark. The magnitude of the building is impressive, the architecture even more so. I spent a lot of time there, it is a must see if you travel to England to take on the sights.

Marvellous !!. The only thing i would say to any visitor to this wonderful building is'' if you love old buildings and history it is '' A MUST SEE '' it was so interesting and eye opening i could not believe it ,such a brilliant experience i will not forget !'' i take my hat off to all the tour guides they really know their stuff !............ Ellen from Belfast ,N.I

One of the best monuments to democracy anywhere. The Houses of Parliament are sadly becoming a problem for Britain as they age and require ever more maintenance. You are likely to confront scaffolding or plastic sheeting on a visit. But go anyway. The buildings are beautiful, with a sense of drama - not least contemplating the route taken by the Queen from the House of Lords to the Commons. Perhaps the most meaningful thing is simply to stand in the Commons (or view its proceedings from the balcony) and consider how small and intimate it is.

EXTREMELY INTERESTING. I have toured round the Houses of Parliament twice because it is so interesting. The guides are extremely knowledgeable and keen. The whole tour is fascinating. You can't really take in all the facts the first time. It is a well organised tour and I would definitely recommend going.
Home of democracy. This place tells the history of modern democracy as we know it. Well worth a visit. The audio tour is fabulous.
Brilliant. Have been to this master piece.Have enjoyed the design and the thought process in terms of need of the members and public.

A fascinating tour. We booked a tour on 31 July on the internet and were unable to print off tickets so arranged to collect them. On the morning of the tour we found that the box office had moved and that we needed to collect our tickets from the entrance. A very confusing and frustrating situation!However, We arrived just in time for our tour and Eileen, our excellent and very informative tour guide, led us through the many fascinating rooms in the Houses of Parliament.A brilliant tour and if you have time, a visit to their excellent café is definitely recommended.
Surreal. very nice to go by this place, Iconic place in London. Tip: Go early morning to avoid crowd and it faces the sun for excellent pictures of it.
Beautifil on the outside. This is a classic London attraction sadly you can't go inside during the summer, so, the neo-gothic is really amazing and beautiful, but is a short quick view
Beautiful and historical. This architecture in all of London is breath taking. You don't know where to look next. If you can go inside well worth the visut, Tons if photo opportunities

Loved it. I enjoyed a super tour of the Houses of Parliament earlier this year. It was great to see so many other groups enjoying tours too which reinforced how important it is to plan ahead and organise a visit.Tours run on Saturdays throughout the year and weekdays during Parliamentary recesses during summer, Christmas and Easter. The website has details of times and dates for tours in French, German, Italian, Spanish, Russian and Mandarin.
Parliament Tours. Took the guided tour Saturday morning. Informative and very interesting not to mention the magnificence of the building itself. Tour guide was knowledgeable and pleasant.

Houses of Parliament. This is the first time I've been in London when this was available. I did the guided tour and pre-booked which I recommend. Come at the time on the ticket; you don't go early. Seeing behind the scenes was fun. On my next trip I'll plan to do the self-guided one in order to have more time to 'read' the material. (The self-guided does not go everywhere the guided tour goes.)

All things English. One of the most famous and instantly recognisable buildings in the world. Truly stunning Gothic architecture. As expected you go through security ready for your tour. Westminster Hall is huge and has the most amazing beamed ceiling and is the oldest part of the Palace at almost 1,000 years old. Walking through the corridors we passed members of parliament and saw other famous faces. The House of Commons with row upon row of empty seats was eerily quiet - not the normal rowdy room of barracking back bench politicians - the Speakers Chair is a little grander than the others but given the tough job he has, he deserves it. The House of Lords stately and grand in its red livery was also devoid of our landed gentry and token Lords. The Queens robing room etc depicted beautiful pageantry. Whether you are a History buff or Politics fan or both you will enjoy this. The guides are very informative - it is a must to see and experience. Guy Fawkes wasn't a fan and his failed attempt to blow it up and his, to be expected execution, are all mentioned. Centuries of Royalty, Politics, Wars etc, it's all here.
