Nice Historic Place. It is architecturally beautiful. The place has its own historic importance. Should be in your list for places to visit

Fascinating tour. Saturday morning guided tour of the Houses of Parliament provided plenty of information on how things work in the United Kingdom and the ability to see some amazing architecture. Group we were with was a bit lame (it's not that long a tour- stand up!!). Guide was very British- with that dry wit where you're not sure what's a joke and what isn't.

Very Interesting morning. Honestly, didn't think this would be as good as it was. Be sure to plan early & get tickets online. As a non-Brit, the tour is only available on Saturdays so plan & book early. Arrive ontime & they wisk you thru to a meet with your guide. Very imformative, the rooms eek with history & some with pageantry. I was glad to have taken the tour & it's well worth the time on your schedule.
Stunning. Just beautiful. Love the area. The architecture is pure stunning. Walk down Whitehall too to see past Downing Street too. Lots of lovely buildings around the area.
House of Lords live debate. This was fantastic. We were shown up to the strangers gallery and sat and listened to the live debate.
Great place . The Houses of Parliament has some great building features right by the Thames in the centre of town. There is so much history behind it all, it's worth a visit.

Amazing architecture. The enormity and ornateness of these buildings is incredible. Definitely worth a visit and look around, centrally located so easy to get to. You need about an hour to have a decent look.
Amasing scuplitures. Brilliand nice to show grandchildren some of our roots. The sculptures on the buildings were amazing

I felt like a tourist.. This isn't cheap, but when you see the security it's no wonder.We did the audio tour, you have to do that or go with a guide, there is so much you will miss otherwise. The audio option couldn't be bettered, you are often given the choice of delving deeper on certain subjects. I think it must be me, despite my audio quoting "Members" etc. as saying that it was a ' living ' and 'working ' place, and lots of impassioned speeches, it was like wandering around a museum. I could see no sign of the juxtaposition of this palace and today's government. If you go into any ordinary office on the weekend you can see it's being used.The fact that the only people I saw were like me , or security , only added to the strange impression. But do go, l hope your imagination is better than mine.Make sure you look up, these woodworkings and ceilings are simply wonderful, and then, the replacement floor tiles have a short film of today's mastercraftsmen replacing damaged ones, so good that we still enabeling this talent. How could it be better ? Well, it would have been nice to be guided around the exterior as well, and have that explained to us.To have the workman's huts and fences not obliterating obvious photo choices. And my one : 'Wish I knew "......Go to the toilet before !

Political history. What can one say about these hallowed halls of power. Some sections are mundane and basic other sections are overtly opulent. Fascinating to visit and an outright privilege to tour around. The oldest club in the land.
Political junkies will love Parliament. Loved seeing the history and listening to a guide who loved her work. Her knowledge was impressive and actually put a little fun into history.

Great for history of Britain. Apart from being one of the most beautiful and iconic buildings in Britain, and the world, from the Outside, The inside has also so much to offer. You have to pre-book tickets online, for timed visits, as visitor numbers are restricted. You also have to go through stringent security check upon entry.But it is worth it when you get in. You can choose from a self guided audio tour, which we did, or to join a tour. From the lobby areas, the actual house of lords and commons, you get to see all the main areasUnfortunately, you cant take photos one passed the main entrance hall. The audio guide is very detailed and you cant do the tour with out itNice little cafe at end of tour as well

Excellent visit - great Blue badge guide. Visited the Houses of Parliament yesterday - really enjoyed it. Learnt so much about our system of govt that I never knew - it was really brought to life by our brilliant Blue Badge guide. Well done Isabel Moore - you are a star and throughly deserved the spontaneous round of applause at the end of the tour. Why would anyone want to listen to an audio tour when you can enjoy someone as engaging as this lovely lady - if she were a teacher I would want to be in her class!
Incredible. This tour was the favorite London activity without question for my 17 year old daughter and I. Incredible history and continued significance in shaping governments around the world.

Not to be missed for the history. If one appreciates the Anglo Saxon Rule of Law and history, this is certainly one place that is not to be missed. A beautiful building where the Brits let each other have it in debates before the House of Commons.

Just go if you're a tourist.. Tourists should see this part of London. As a Dutch expat I take my visiting friends here all the time. Great place to walk around, see Bi Ben, Thames, Westminster Abbey and a famous politician. Worth a short visit.

Amazing learning opportunity. If you're interested in the history of the Houses of Parliament or simply visiting London on vacation this is an incredible tour through one of the most iconic buildings in the world! Book tickets through ticketmaster! This is a must in London, and is something most people don't necessarily know about, so make sure you do it!!

Absolutely wonderful tour.. Our guide was fascinating And incredibly knowledgable.
We booked high tea, which we felt was a bit lacking and rushed.
The mother of parliaments. Very interesting tour with a very knowledgeable guide who was happy to answer all of our questions and not trying to rush through the tour.
Pretty but that is it.. It nice to see and walk around but it is not a big attraction that you will spend many hours. A quick visit is more than enough.

No debates but still awesome. Easy to get timed tickets either by website or phone. Harder to find the place to pick them up (across the road). Did the audio tour. Guided tours all sold out. Audio is self-paced so I like it better. Can't think of anything I didn't enjoy.
HIstoric. Very informative guide who put a completely different slant on the visit. Gave lots of information about the history of the buildings and the way the system works.

interesting visit with surprises. We got a visit through or local MP (ask in advance). A friend used to work as a researcher there so we knew a few interesting secrets before going. Saw the hidden tables outside the lords, went inside Emily Davison's cupboard and had a nice tea on the terrace. Lovely visit, like the post office

Superb visit. I arranged a trip to Westminster via my local MP, it was all very easy to do and the various members of staff I encountered via email were all very pleasant and helpful. The tour itself was excellent, our guide was very informative and helpful, the visit took just under 2 Hours and we covered a lot of ground. It was thoroughly enjoyed by all. So much history that can be enjoyed by all ages. Make this a must do on your visit to London.

Just don't miss it.... It was one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen in terms of architecture, both from outside and inside. I took the audio guided tour (available only on Saturdays) and I will say it was really worth the price. The commentary was very detailed and descriptive, the staff well versed and rooms just splendid. The palace looks superb from the outside and at night with its lights on along with the Big Ben, it is a sight to behold for sure in London.

Very interesting. I went on a tour of the Houses of Parliament on a school trip. The tour guide was very good, telling us lots about each room of Parliament. It is a beautiful building, definitely worth having a tour of.

Audio tour. Excellent was impressed with all the rooms and a great commentary. We collected our tickets early and went back but if you don't choose to do this get there 30 minutes earlier to allow for collection and airport security. Not crowded

Mother of All Parliaments. Been before, both professionally and as a tourist. Very interesting location and I'd strongly recommend it - if you can get in. The size of the debating chambers (Commons / Lords) are surprising, and the Terrace is impressive too.

Wonderful diner at the lords. It was a special invitation by Baroness Sue Garden to dine at the Lords Chamber Restaurant and if you get at least a tour to the building it will be one of the greatest experiences you can have in London! Let alone having a wonderful diner in those chambers! It was an evening to remember to the end of my life!
not so badd. im not really interested in politics but this old building is really good to look at and can by informative to the right people
Looks nice, hard to miss.... You will see it easily, it makes for a good picture. You can go inside some buildings and look around as well.
Must See. This is one of the most famous land marks in England and if you don't see it then your either blind or stupid. Please go to this the architecture is just awesome.

Best kept secret. Did you know you could tour the entire Parliament, including the Lords and Commons, and all the cool areas that you've seen on TV dozens of times? What a thrill! The audio tour is very clear and thorough and the worker bees are very helpful. You might even be lucky enough to see an MP wandering around.

A must-see. You have to put this on your list while in London. If you have a group you can book a tour guide. This tour is very informative and if House of Commons is not in session you can see it and the House of Lords. Highly recommended even if you are not into politics.

A gem of tour ...tell everyone ..its our parliament ..its our right to visit. You get to walk all the corridors of power that you see and make such a difference to our lives. The guides have the right balance of information, anecdotes and humour. the only down side is the hyperness they have in you sitting on any leather or touching the tables .....do so just to send them over the edge nad to remind them it is our place ...well if you are a UK tax payer ...otherwise hands off !!

Worth a visit. Worth stopping by even if you do not go inside just to admire the magnificent building and take some pictures. If you go onto Westminster Bridge and look back you can get the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben in the one picture. A piece of England's history.

Great tour Very disappointing afternoon tea. We would have liked to review these two parts separately as the tour with Robina was excellent. She had the right amount of history , humour and time to look around. It was a brilliant tour and we all (ages 14-75) learnt a lot. We would strongly recommend booking a tour.The afternoon tea in the Terrace was very disappointing. The staff were friendly and the venue by the Thames should have been perfect but it was extremely hot in the Marque with fans that did nothing. We thought we would feel indulged and spoilt but just felt hot and fed up. The tea was teabags and we had to share one pot, so those of us having the same type of tea had to pass the pot from one end of a table of 10 to the other! The bread on the sandwiches was dry and there was not a lot on offer. At £27.50 per person we have had much better quality and value at other venues. We would suggest you go elsewhere for tea but make sure you do the tour.
Stop on route.... ...to grab a photo outside! Only UK residents can actually go inside by contacting their MP. Def worth a photo op though as you head somewhere else!
VERY INTERESTING!!. Cultural moment of our trip..Very interesting, allows you to understand HOW England works!!!!Impressed

Great tour. I highly recommend touring the Houses of Parliament when visiting London. Be aware, though, that if you're not a citizen of the UK, you can visit only on Saturdays (though I believe there are additional days later in the summer). I took the self-guided tour, using an audio guide. If you're doing the self-guided tour, the audio guide is essential. There is a pre-set route, and the commentary on the audio guide is very helpful in understanding the significance and history of each room/hall of the Palace of Westminster. I am a political science professor and history buff, so this place was right up my alley. Visitors are given ample time to tour the building, though security guards make sure that folks stick to the route. The rooms on the House of Lords side are more ornate, in particular the Lords chamber itself, which is very familiar to those who've watched the Queen deliver the Government's speech each year opening the new session of Parliament. While the House of Commons is more simply decorated, that body is very fascinating to this student of government. The chamber was badly damaged during the Blitz of WWII, and PM Churchill was responsible for its rebuilding. A large statue of Churchill stands outside the Commons chamber, along with busts and statues of other British PMs. Pay attention to the door to the chamber, which bears the scuff marks caused by Black Rod's annual knock at the door (followed by its slamming in his face).Lots of history here and worth visit of several hours. Be prepared to go through security (about 20 minutes or so) prior to your tour time.
Gorgeous Architecture. This was my first trip to London. Pictures do not do this justice. I was in awe of the the architecture. Loved it

Extraordinary . My favourite building in the world from the outside and it doesn't let you didn't inside either. Very ornate and fascinating. You can have private tours but you can also wander around on your own. If you're visiting London visiting parliament is essential. If you visit while the houses of commons or lords are in session you can watch a debate. You can also watch select committees in action. And pick up some souvenirs in the shop!
look kids, parliament. Really neat architecture and knowledgeable staff. We were able to schedule a brief tour and got a great history lesson. Beautiful at night.

Superb tour. Highly recommend. Tour guide and length was perfect. It was one of the best tours I've been on. The guide was very conscious of the international makeup of the tour group and did an excellent job providing information as to the history of Parliament and how it is different from other legislative bodies. Great surveyor shop as well. Unique in London.

Symbol Of oldest democracy. I liked the parliament square ,the house and the Big Ben .the prime minister is very near at 10 Downing Street ,indicating how the parliament supervise the executive branch

Absolutely Not to be Missed under any Circumstance. The Houses of Parliament were just breath taking. The architectural features, stained glass, and paintings were just amazing. It was also very special to be in a place that has changed the course of history. The tour group that I was on was magnificent. The guide was a wealth of information but not boring. He knew what to say and when to stop. If you can only see one sight in London, it should most certainly be this. It is an amazing experience and the building is absolutely breathtaking. If you go in the summertime, beware tours are only offered on saturdays and you should plan your trip accordingly.
History of Democracy. I enjoyed the whole experience. We had a very knowledgeable guide who literally made the experience come alive for us.

Interesting, informative visit. My daughter and I met our MP for a quick tour of the House of Commons before joining an official tour he had arranged for us. Because the Commons was sitting this was a tour of the House of Lords and took us through all the pomp, circumstance and history of the State Opening of Parliament. It was interesting to see where all the decisions of our country are made and to hear the history of this impressive building.

Impressive and awesome. Truly impressive tour of the Parliament Houses.You need not take the guided tour - the audio tour is good enough. Be prepared to climb-up and down the stairs. The tour does a fantastic job of explaining the history, evolution and importance of the Parliament as also the pomp & circumstance that defines it.The "tea at the Parliament" is also very much worth the while (add another couple of hours for this leisurely experience). Though expensive, the Tea is hosted on the Thames waterfront - an absolutely beautiful view. The service is little slow but stately and grand. Quite an experience.

What a Place to work :). A took a BigBus tour and crossing in front of House of Parliament was in the map, somehow due to some Gaza protest the road was closed. So I walked down that road. The building is amazing, looks beautiful from outside. Weren't allowed to take a tour.

A must see. The houses of parliament, Big Ben and Westminster next-door are must sees if you are on your first (or second or third) trip to London. The architecture is so magnificent and imposing. If you can see only one sight in London this is it.

If you are in London-You must see it!. This is one of the quintessential sites of London. The area is full of wonderful sites that cannot be missed-Big Ben and the London Eye are also within steps of Parliament. Completely grand and amazing!

Excellent experience. Like the friendly insults.. We spent a couple of hours at the Houses of Parliament, both Commons and Lords. Especially liked the House of Commons. Debate was insulting in a friendly way. We especially like that members are actually present on the floor (unlike the U.S. Congress). An educational and entertaining experience.
Great tour for those who like history. Amazing historical tour. Beautiful old paintings of the monarchy and facts about the political history of England.

A top trip. We visited the Houses of Parliament as my husband wanted to go. I wasnt that bothered but it was fantastic. You don't have to be interested in politics to enjoy this attraction. It is steeped in history and is fascinating to see the House of Commons and Lords. It really is just like you see on the television in the live debates. The picking up of tickets was really disorganised. We were told to go to a place next to the Jubilee tower so we queued there to be told that our tickets would be over the road outside the entrance to Parliament so we had to queue again. Then we had to queue AGAIN to get into the H of P when it was our time to visit. Surely they could organise a better system?

In the heart of government. Whilst visiting London we took the opportunity to look round the Houses of Parliament and it was a fantastic experience. As we only decided a few days before hand, all the organised tours were fully booked, but we used the audio guides, which were only introduced earlier this year, and they were brilliant and very easy to operate. We had a timed slot, but once inside you could take as long as you like, and the information/music on the audio guide was first class, with more information on certain subjects available if you wanted. It was fascinating to go into both the House of Lords and Commons, as well as the magnificent Westminster Hall. Although we were too late to book 'tea on the terrace' we finished off our visit with an excellent cream tea in the Jubilee cafe.

Very Interesting. Booked as a treat while in London. Very informative trip around the House of Parliament. We done the Audio Tour, and this is on a push a you go personal control. So you are able to walk around at leisure.
Just walking around the outside is really cool!. We didn't have that much time, so we opted to just walk around admiring the architecture of the building which is really neat!

Fabulous attraction. Took the audio tour which was informative and well spoken.you don't get a few of the rooms that are included in te guided tour but it is wonderful all the same. A really brilliant experience and would highly recommend.Only downside is that they don't seem to have the queuing system for tickets very well organised. We booked by telephone and were told to collect tickets 30 mins prior to our tour. The office is across from the entrance and down the road. When we arrived there was a huge queue to buy tickets and another queue if you were collecting tickets or paying cash for tickets. Unfortunately his combination meant that we had to wait 25 minutes to collect our tickets which took minutes as there were groups of people trying to negotiate purchasing tickets. It would have been much easier if there was a designated collection queue / window. It is also not very well signposted where you go after you get your tickets.
Just like in pictures. Hard to miss. Big Ben. Spend the time taking photos from all angles and walk around. Enjoy the history. Best view from London Eye

A definite do for anybody interested in political process. Went today and sat in on debate in both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. As with most upper houses of Parliament the House of Lords isn't exactly the most robust and action packed place but it is worth going just to see Her Majesty's Golden Throne.I was lucky today with the House of Commons (I use the term loosely as my luck came from a tragedy) and got to watch MPs question the Prime Minister following a statement he made on MH17 and Gaza. Seeing the Prime Minister answer questions on a Monday is rare but it was fascinating to watch over two very clearly sensitive topics. I really enjoyed it but I am a political tragic. If you have considered going then you probably are too. In that case I strongly recommend.

An interesting Dinner!. We considered ourselves lucky enough to be part of a party that were invited by an MP. The MP looked after us impeccably allowing us access to areas outside the usual tourist path. We sat in the visitors gallery at the Commons and The Lords!Dinner as had in a dining room on the Thames side of the building and was excellent quality. Our host entertained us throughout with history of the building and insights into current poilical issues.
Great experience. We only went to visit the House of Lords but wished to have had more time to see more... If you're interested in history and politics, it's the place to go!

Incredibly Interesting!. The Houses of Parliament are definitely must-sees. This incredible building sits right by Westminster Abbey on one side and the River Thames on the other. Non-UK visitors are allowed to visit certain days, so be sure to pre-book your tour. It's easy to do and you pick up the tickets right across the street. The history of this place is amazing and the tour guides are very knowledgeable and quite interesting. The House of Lords is quite a contrast to the House of Commons, but both are accessible on the tour. Even if you aren't obsessed with politics, it is still a great experience.

WORTH THE SECURITY CHECKS. I had always wanted to visit the Houses of Parliament and we did it during our recent trip. Full security check before going in, however, it was worth the effort to sit in the House of Commons and watch the British Parliament in action. The walk through thre building was priceless and it costs nothing to visit. Great tearooms to top off the visit

Fantastic and awesome. Shame about the toilet facilities.. We went on a coach trip to london which included a guided tour of the houses of parliament. The tour guide was brilliantly entertaining and knowledgeable and made for a very interesting time. As we had a long coach trip home after the tour we thought it best to go to the loos which were outside the café area. When we got there all of the loos were out of order. When we tried to go back into the building to use the loos we were told that we couldn't. The security guard was rude and aggressive and not what I would expect after paying a great deal for the tour. He told us that if we wanted to go to the loo we would need to go to the nearest pub!!!!!!!

EXCELLENT TOUR. I wish we had longer inside. The time passed so quickly. The guides are well informed and I sensed they were flu of information which I wished I could hear more about! Highly recommend. There is security-just like the airport

Should be free to enter!. Excellent for the history. Only wish you could click your fingers and transport back in time.
Drinks on the terrace is overated.
Nice!. It is a beautiful building near Big Ben and London Eye. We walked around and took some pictures. It is too bad that we are not allowed to go inside.
Impressive!. A very impressive sight, right by the river. Really a must-see destination if you are traveling through London.

Prime Minister's Question Time. On Wednesdays when the House is sitting, the PM fields questions from the MPs at noon. Highly entertaining to watch (some really excellent verbal sparring coupled with plenty of rabble from the MPs filling both sides of the house) and also v. educational - you get a nice summary of the issues over which the MPs are currently at odds. Free - I believe UK citizens can call their MPs to arrange admission for the public gallery. As a US citizen, I called the London Embassy about six weeks in advance to ask for "Cards of Introduction", which allow admission to the public gallery. They don't guarantee admission at the start of Question Time, however - we arrived an hour early and only barely got in as QT began. If you really want to see this, I'd suggest getting there even earlier.
GO in - it's worth it. saw a debate -fantastic to see our government in action -and wonderful rooms inside. Exercise your right as a citizen and pay it a visit

Always Impressive. Tour was interesting and just the right amount of information so as not to overwhelm. The interior is beautiful and rich in architectural detail. Enjoyed the tour best in the off season because of fewer people and less hurry to move along.
Impressive . I loved the architecture of the entire complex. It is pretty nice and the area is also enjoyable. If you are in London do visit this. Highly recommended
lovely to see. Gorgeous sunny day was great to see this great building. Loved the architecture and history of this building.

Fascinating place if Parliament is in session. I have been a few times and after queuing for a short time you can enter the chamber of the House of Commons and see the debate. I found that especially interesting as one can relate to what is shown on TV. I have not managed a 12.00 lunch time Wednesday visit (Prime Minister Question Time) as the queues are much longer...but some day I want to do this! After the visit if you cross the road there is a patch of grass and this is where the TV crews interview minters and MP's...live coverage for the national networks.
Must See for Every Political Nut!. As a slight political junkie, I absolutely loved the organised tour. Such culture and rich with English and European history, I loved every second!

Houses of Parliment. From the outside the buildings, statues and lawns are impressive.
Unfortunately we have never been inside. Having to book in advance has put us off but one day will do it.
Security in and around the site is very visible and extensive.
Unfortunately it is a reflection of the world we now live in.
Kayjohn
Classy classic. This classic architecture is iconic and tourists should be charged a fee for not seeing it. Simply astounding.

Highly recommended. . Enjoy the magnificent view of the river Thames, Big Ben, London Eye, The parliament. As a whole, this place is a joyous place and has a positive atmosphere. Photographers, Keep you cameras ready.

Highly recommended insight. The House of Parliament are a great attraction for British and international tourists and Londoners. Also great even if you aren't in to politics, A fantastic piece of architecture and history. If you get given the chance via your MP or School or College take it and allow quite a bit of time. I have been here a couple of times now. Well worth a good, planned visit.
Lovely view from Thames. The best is to see it from the river on a nice day. Evenings are also great as they illuminate the building and Big Ben. New Year's fireworks are a must if you are in London

Very educational. We were shown around by a guide who explained everything in great detail. Disappointed didn't do Big Ben . Bought prepaid tickets which is advisable as long queues if not but certainly well worth a visit both for educational and architectural purposes.
just OKAY. it was amazing to see, but that is really all you can do. just look at it. along with about a million other people who are just looking at it.

A bit disorganised. I wish there was a 'good' rating, but I had to choose between 'average' which is a bit harsh, and 'very good' which is a bit generous.We visited the HOP on a booked tour. The security was tight, but friendly and we were okay with it. We then went through to the hall, where everyone booked on a tour was milling around with no idea what was going on. I had borrowed a HOP wheelchair, and there was considerable confusion about whether the disabled tour route was available, and whether more than one wheelchair would be allowed per tour party. Well, they changed their minds at least half a dozen times, so the tour times and groups were totally tossed out the window. A simple booking system and a public address system to call people for their tour would be easy to implement and would eliminate so much hassle.The tour itself was fine, and the building spectacular. Now I know that they have to cater to all sorts of people of all education levels, interest in history, ability in English, but it really was a bit dumbed down. The history was not hugely accurate, and the comments on architecture and politics patronising. I am assuming the guides were volunteers?All in all, worth seeing, but don't ask them to organise an event in a brewery!

Wonderful experience. Thoroughly recommend this visit and if you can get onto the tour that takes you to the public gallery you will be in for a real treat . One of the must do things in London I guess and did not disappoint

Beautiful site. We were lucky that our hotel had a view to this beautiful site. wonderfully designed buildings. you will have the feeling to be next to the buildings where most important decisions that influenced the history were taken. A must see.

Worth the hassle. Visiting London in summer is always going to be stressful. You are always one of the many crowding the city out. Best advice is be there early. Beat the tourist bus loads. Organise some of the sight seeing and then be prepared for the unexpected bureaucratic hurdles. So, armed with our pre-bought entry to the Westminster Palace we found ourselves standing in queues and having to ask; so, how does this work? The English seem not to like having signs to organise people. Very odd considering the numbers they have visit. We managed to negotiate exchanging our print out for a 'real ticket', which was individually addressed and personally handed to us. Sounds good but really the time wasted sorting this out was tiresome. Then to the queue to get through security and then to the Westminster Hall to be collected into a 9.20 tour group (time of our particular tour). However, after that it was a really great experience and the guide we had was excellent. She had a terrific knowledge of the Parliament, the Westminster Palace and the history of both. The self supporting old wooden ceiling of the Westminster Hall simply awesome. So, in spite of the volume of people it was a great experience. Just need to fix up some very silly and time consuming bureaucratic processes.

Amazing. Just breathtaking to be in such an historic place. If you are going to London speak to your MP's office and get a tour. Our guide Philip was so engaging and knowledgeable he just made it so interesting. Only point of note, you can take a tour up Big Ben but that is a separate tour. Both can be done by speaking to your MP.
Go there. The very landmark of England, and right in the heart of the city. Houses of Parliament is worth a look from the outside to appreciate the architecture.

Interesting and Informative. We have just done the audio tour of the Houses of Parliament. We booked the tour on line and collected the tickets at the gate. All very efficient. The staff were all friendly and efficient and after going through security, we were given our headphones and then could take as long as we liked walking through the House of Lords and the House of commons as well as the various halls and lobbies. The audio tour was informative without too much information although you could key in for more information if you wanted it at various locations. It was interesting to see what I had only previously seen on television. The architecture and decoration was amazing. The tour took us just over an hour and was well worth the price. The only thing that could be improved would be the toilet facilities which were poor.

Pretty to look at. These buildings are all very pretty to walk around and look at. Must be neat to see from a river cruise as well. We walked around them and also saw them from the London Eye, which gives you a really neat view which changes as you go upwards.

A tour of the Houses of Parliament:8th July 2014.. The tour guide:The female tour guide was very good. Gives you a history of each you area of the Houses of Parliament.Friendly.The tour areas:House of commons.Stopping in the lobby on route ( The area seen on the tv reports).House of Lords.In both the above you must not sit in the seats or touch anything.The tour starts & ends in Westminster hall.The tour was very good.Plus a small group of eight,the guide said the groups can be up 25.To do a tour contact your local MP.
Always worth the visit. Amazing architecture and of course the great history of British democracy and relic of a great empire!

Nice to see. It was nice to see it, but not something I would go out of my way to visit a second time around. It's a beautiful building and indeed quite famous, but it's really just that. Not disappointed by it at all, but it's more of a photo stop, than an attraction in my opinion.

Beautiful Buildings. These buildings are quite beautiful in themselves but they are in a wonderful setting close to the Thames, which renders them even more majestic. Come here when you go to Westminster abbey and other sights on this part of town.
Saturday Parliament Tour. Highly recommend Parliament tour. We booked tickets online prior to our visit. The inside of the Palace at Westminster is very beautiful, ornate and seeped in rich history.

What you would expect. Afternoon tea was good and previous meals better than Park Lane mass events. The location makes the event and the wine is always better than the plonk served at most events, love the history and never left hungry.

Iconic building. As a Londoner who lives in a south London suburb, whenever it get to walk or drive past the Houses of Parliament I am proud of the architecture of years gone by. It is unique and a must see for any visitor to London

Beautiful & Historic. A beautiful building. We walked around where we could, would have loved ton see the inside. It is situated on the river where there are a few cafes etc. It is close to Big Ben & Westminster Abby

nice to see. it was nice to see from outside, cant go in unless your from uk and advance tickets via your local elected officalof course youll pass by and see it, and big ben but not too much time to spend there
Really enjoyed the visit. Bit expensive to get in but really enjoyed this visit. We missed the tour, would recommend you book on a tour as it would make so much more of the visit.

Did it at our own pace .. LIke all those burnt out retired teachers , after 35 years of captive audiences I don't want to listen much now . So we booked a tour ,with Ticketmaster under the Audio heading . Great , we went at our own pace switching on and off when we liked . Good control and a great afternoon .
Worth a visit. Unfortunately, not open for tours most days - check schedule ahead of time. It would be nice if at least a part of it was open for daily visits.
Here! Here!. beautiful building, the architecture is outstanding! and many people do not realise king Henry the 8th lived there also. you may even see some one famous!

You must see this!. Arranged a free tour via my MP and despite a mix up in the morning managed to get back to see it in the afternoon. What an amazing place. Beautiful architecture and history. Had the privilege of going in the chapel, the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Sat behind a screen and watched the government in front of us hold a debate chaired by Theresa May. What an amazing experience. If you get the chance, email your MP and request a free tour when you are in London, it made my trip.

Impressive First Sight of London After Exiting the Tube. Such an iconic sight in London. The first time I took my wife to London we took the tube to Westminster Station and I had her shut her eyes until we were outside and had her look up. The look of delight/wonder in her eyes was fantastic as she looked up to view St. Stephens Tower/Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. That being said...as a person of Irish heritage, I make it a point to have a picture taken of me making secretive lewd gestures at the statue of noted Irish oppressor, Oliver Cromwell. If you're around the statue on September 15th you might catch me in the act.
A must see!. If your coming to London as a tourist, this is most certainly a must see. A historic building with lots of character!

Even better than expected!!. I had long wanted to visit the HP but the experience proved better than I could have imagined. It really takes you back in time to enjoy some of the most important moments of British and World history. The halls, chambers and the house of Lords are especially fascinating. The staff were very helpful. Definitely one of the highlights of our London trip.

Detailed, Descriptive Tour . The Houses of Parliament Tour was absolutely excellent! My tour guide was very knowledgable and the tour was very detailed and descriptive. I would definitely recommend a trip there. Make sure to book online, as the tour is in very high demand.

Beautiful architecture, a great site to see. Once you see the House of Parliament, your eyes are glued to it, it's a beautiful looking building, it's right next to the River Thames so it's a perfect site to look at while you site back and relax by the river, watching all the happy nice tourists take their photos.

Impressive Area As Usual. After the Changing of the Guard, this was the first place we took our grand-kids to see. The area never fails to impress, and this day there were some activists, making it even more interesting. A self-guided walking tour of this area is a great way for new-comers to get a taste of British culture.
Great Architecture. We loved walking around the Houses of parliament and ending up at Westminster Abbey. There were lots of statues and history abound. The park next to the houses are very serene.
Great Tour!. Got to see where & how the British government is run. Also learned about the history of their system. Highly suggest, even for kids 10 and older.

our historic Parliament. We did the audio tour- it was excellent and up to date and could take our time. It still was under 2 hours so not exhausting. Well worth doing if you cannot organise a free one with your MP or if you are from abroad- many languages available.
Only saw the outside. Having only seen the outside of it, I found it to be the most beautiful building in london. If I had taken the tour, maybe this would be a 5 star review
Viewed from outside. The Parliament, the history before your eyes. Great experience with lots of history. The history, the architectural designs were very impressive.

Great. It's really a must-see building in London. Loved to be there. It's worth to walkthrough the bridge, it has a nice view of the city, but be aware it's really windy on the bridge. I have been there twice, but would go over and over again :)

Excellent. My husband and I visited a couple of days a go. We are from the UK but never been before. It was very interesting. Our guide was really knowledgeable and entertaining (David). We went in the robing room, Houses of Commons and Lords as well as the different lobbies. It took about 1 hour and 40 minutes. Two things to be mindful of: there are no toilets on the way around so go before the tour starts and you sit down on 2 occasions on the way round so you are on your feet a lot. We both really enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone.

Impressive Historic Icon. I was lucky enough to have a tour of the Houses of Parliament organised by my MP so I did not pay however i do believe that you need to pay for a normal tour. It was the highlight of my visit to London. The buildings are stunning and to see inside of a place you have seen numerous times on television was brilliant. There is sooo much history in every inch of the building from who has been there, the art on the walls, the events that have happened there. After I had toured the building we took tea on the commons terrace the view across the thames was brilliant. Finally I went to the gallery to watch that days debate in the commons and to see the political process close up was fantastic. A must visit for anyone!

Beautiful and Impressive. We took the audio tour of the Houses of Parliament. When we visited, the Westminster Hall was under construction so we couldn't see the statues that line the walls. You cannot take pictures inside. The whole audio tour is very interesting and takes quite a bit of time. We would have preferred a tour guide. Would probably rate this five stars if not under construction and had a real person as a tour guide. It really is a must see if you are touring London.

Iconic in London, there's no way of missing. The parliament and the beautiful Big Ben are points of interest that are so representative of London and England itself that I don't see a way of missing a visit to them. And a good hint is that is only some hundreds meters from London Eye and it's beside Westminster Abbey, so you can program these visits all together.The big clock tower, the Big Ben, is really beautiful. It worths the visit.

Very Impressive Building. Big Ben and the Palace of Westminster were very impressive. We were taken on a tour of the Houses of Parliament where we learnt a great deal about British Parliament . This building was my favourite in all of London. So much history abounds within these walls.

Seriously interesting visit. Took a group to visit and had a guide called Helen who was brilliant. She was interesting and knowledgeable and spoke at the right level for 9-11 age group. she looked after us very well and made sure we got to see the Speaker process with the Mace. Our local MP was there and was going to meet with us had we not had to leave for another visit. A visit every British citizen should make at least once. It is ours and we should know how it works and it is very beautiful.

Exceptional!. I visited with my Family and our age range was 16-65 at the time. All of us found it fascinating with the audio tour being among the best we have ever listened to. Upon arrival there was a airport style security check hence arriving 20 minutes early but all members of staff were absolutely great. Photographs are not allowed but to tell you the truth we were all so glued to our audio guide that taking snaps was the last thing on our minds! We would definitely visit again.

House of commons eatery. I was a guest of an MP. We both ordered the lasagna. It was cooked to order which took a while but the meal was a business affair so that was ok. My friend paid the bill but it was inexpensive. It was excellent. The place is all chrome and glass and obviously a working persons restaurant. I'm not sure if its open to the general public. We entered by an underground passage from the Parliament building to Portcullis House east of Big Ben but i left by a street entrance just at the corner of Whitehall.

Houses of Parliament.. We took a nice cruise on the River Thames from Tower Bridge to Westminster Bridge, and then toured Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament, and Westminster Abbey. What great views! And we were lucky to have great weather!

Tour excellent - Afternoon Tea disapointing. Four friends visited London on 28 June. We found the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament excellent. The guide was well informed and answered all our questions. The guide book was an added bonus. Unfortunately the afternoon tea was disappointing. We had quite a long wait before being directed to the garden terrace and then another long wait to be seated. The garden terrace was lovely with a wonderful view. The table setting was lovely. We had to wait 50 mins before being asked if we wanted tea, coffee or an alcoholic drink. After the tea and coffee arrived we waited another 15 mins before our afternoon tea arrived. The sandwiches were OK - two cheese one chicken. One person does not eat cheese but we were not told of the choices. The scone was very good but the small amount of jam and cream was barely enough for two never mind four. The cakes were nice but disappointing - nothing really special. After waiting such a long time our tea got cold. The waiters did not seem to have a system and strolled up and down the room with no urgency or efficiency. On our way out we asked if the delays were due to there being a wedding party but we were informed that there were weddings every week. Our advice is do the excellent tour but go elsewhere for afternoon tea/food.

Houses of parliament - definitely worth a visit!. We booked an audio tour to enable us to move around at our own pace. The machine was easy to control and the content very informative. The signage around the building was also helpful to keep you in sync with the audio. The building is impressive and so are the contents - Both the Houses and the many statues of our politicians / statesmen - the only down side is the fact you are not allowed to touch anything - and the warnings to the public are many and strong. The building is after all a `working office` a little more consideration to the visitors would be welcome - Although the staff were pleasant enough.All that said a good afternoon out.
Booked a tour. Brilliant tour with informative guide, who follows the route of the state opening of parliament.It is an awesome building and well worth a visit

see how the country is run. Did not have the full tour as this is only possible on a Saturday or when parliament is in recessionHowever it is still possible to visit the viewing gallery above the house of commons for free to watch the days prceedings.We came upon this by accident on overhearing a conversation with a police officer.If you proceed along the front of the houses of parliament towards big ben you will see a tent like structure.This is where the queue starts,we were lucky as there was none so got straight in at 1430 hours.You are given a security pass which you take into the building,you then go through security similar to the airports whereby everything metal has to be removed and scanned.You then follow the corridors as instructed climbing a few flights of stairs before being lead to the viewing gallery.You can stay here for as long as you want or until the session has finishedIan Duncan Smith was the main speaker on the day in question but the house was very sparsly occupied with about 20 MP,s on each side.We were informed that the longest queue's are on a Tuesday for priminister,s questions so it would be best to arrive early if you want to whitness theseYou also have the chance as you leave of seeing other parts of the building and statue's of former statesmen.

Worth a visit. We booked the audio tour, it was comprehensive and very interesting, it gave a very good insight of how parliament actually works and how the members have to conform to certain rules and regulations to make it all work and come into place. The building is beautiful inside, the many guides around were very helpful, and doing the audio tour meant we could pause and take as long as we needed to take in the atmosphere and have a good look around. We really enjoyed it. Tickets are purchased in a building over the road from Parliament, we went when they opened and had no trouble at getting in. Despite the huge queues, having a ticket meant it moved along quite reasonably. Wouldn't like to guess what it would be like in the height of summer though, I would imagine it is very popular. At the moment, to book online is through ticketmaster, these are expensive and we were told there was a plan to move away from them as they are not really geared up for the House of Parliament, so if you can get to the ticket office on the day when they open, it is better.
Look but do not enter.. Its a beautiful castle but its closed to the public unless you book a tour which is usually months in advance. Disappointing but it a great photo.

Must. This is a amazing visit, you must to see a live work day of the parlament, the lords one makes you feel in a time machine, has a lot to tell about the modern history. Pay attention to atraction agenda, is not open all the time.

You can't come to London & not see the Houses of Parliament. Standing on Westminster Bridge, take a photo of the Houses of Parliament, while you are on the London Eye side of the bridge. Wait for a London bus and even a black London cab to pass to get these two other icons in your photo as well.Tip: Be patient as traffic flow will cause a break in traffic for you to take a clear shot or one with the desired vehicles.Have fun! You are in LONDON! :)

VISIT TO THE PALACES OF WESMINISTER. I was lucky that I was able to visit the Palaces of Westminster (Houses of Parliament). I have fortunate enough to sit in at the House of Commons, although the Lady speaking could have said everything in 15 minutes not more. I had coffee in an open area and saw one or two famous people. Had dinner in a dining room next door to the Members dining room. The only downside I got stuck in the toilet. So much history (which I love).Felicity

Fascinating Tour. Really enjoyed the tour of the Houses of Parliament. Even as a Brit I learned a lot about how the 2 houses work and some of the political processes. And loved standing in the Commons! Very good guide who answered questions from all nationalities on the visit and the group size was just right.
Well worth visiting the House of Commons. Beautiful building on the Thames. Wanted to see the Commons in session. Entrance was free, security high, but well worth the wait and the visit.

Rude Bobby put us off visiting altogether. We were about to approach a bobby standing at an entrance when another couple in front of us were given very rude and sarcastic responses to their questions."Do you really think I'd let you just walk through?"When the question was quite simple "can we enter through here?"Totally changed our view of the London police force and soured our desires to enter this building!

History comes alive. We had the privilege of a private tour of the Houses of Parliament. The history is intact, despite the significant rebuilding after the war. We should be so advanced to adapt an open question period for our elected officials.

Outside visit. W e actually just walked around outside and took pictures. It is an incredible group of buildings with Big Ben on the end. Our hotel was not far so we saw it several times along with Westminster Abbey nearby. Fantastic area to be in.
Part of Big Ben. You can't go to London without seeing Big Ben and it is part of parliment. Be prepaird to see protesters acroos the street.

London Houses of Parliament. Marvellous from outside. Hard-to-judge from inside as not accessible for non-UK subjects. At least we did not find any opportunity to get inside as we were few years back.
Houses of Parliament. Who visits London and DOES NOT visit the Houses of Parliament? Wonderful area for walking and taking picturesque photos.

A Must See. A great tour of a magnificent building. Tour guide was fantastic and so well versed in Parliament's history and traditions. My only complaint is that we couldn't take photos inside but with today's security concerns this is a minor point. We pre-booked while in the states so no delays upon our arrival.

Whoa!. Impressive, impressive, impressive. Coming out of the Tube station directly under the Elizabeth Tower, then walking across the bridge to be able to see the entirety of the building is an experience. It was my first "view" of London and I'm glad to have that memory. Walking around the building is easy and the edifice itself is worth looking at. We did not go inside.

Watched from the balcony. I had the opportunity to watch from the balcony above what I have only seen on TV before.Very impressive to see politics at work this close. Saw many familiar faces on the benches. What a shame that these people were all politicians...............:-)

Watched from the balcony. I had the opportunity to watch from the balcony above what I have only seen on TV before.
Very impressive to see politics at work this close. Saw many familiar faces on the benches. What a shame that these people were all politicians...............:-)

Expensive History Lesson. Wow! There is so much beauty within these halls, and history, too. When you visit, (if you have lots of pennies to pay the admission), be sure to spend a little time in every room with your face pointed upward. The ceilings are positively magnificent!Taking a proper tour with a guide will gain you access to perhaps 3 rooms that the general population who visit don't get to enter (but you do see them from behind a barrier). However, I rather wished we had spent the extra $ and joined one of the guided groups, just to get as much of the history as possible.Still, as a self-guided tour with those head-set things, it is pretty darn good. There are many interesting little-known facts here, and you will be a trivia star by the time you leave.Plan to spend about 1 1/2 hours here. And BOOK AHEAD! Also, be sure not to bring in even the most inocuous little pen knife or poky thing. It WILL be taken from you, although unlike airport security, if it isn't a threat to national security it will be returned to you at the end of your visit. Ask me how I know. If I had to choose between here and Westminster Abbey, I would definitely come here. But that's just my personal opinion. Happy travels!
Interesting. We did this tour on Saturday. We had a very good guide (Joanne), although it's expensive we all enjoyed it even 2 hard to please teenagers.

Disappointing. Following excellent tour of Houses of Parliament we were to have Afternoon Tea at 3.15. We queued for about 40 minutes, served beverages at first and finally the sandwiches etc were brought to our table at 4.10pm Very disappointing, we were never given a menu, there was a great shortage of staff who didn't seem in any hurry to serve the full capacity restaurant. There was no apology/explanation for the delay or poor service. As we were only in London for the day, we feel we wasted almost an hour in just waiting to be served. Doubtful we would recommend this to fellow travellers.Jenny s

A very informative tour. If you get a chance, please go inside the Houses of Parliament. It is fascinating to see the insides of this magnificent building, and to get to see with your own eyes what you only have seen on TV before. The audio tours are very good, and worked better for me than a group tour with a guide. But you need to pre-book if you are on a tight schedule.
Great Insight. Great fascinating insight in the political London political world. Must be pre booked, Saturdays only.

worth a visit!. Even if you don't go inside it's worth just popping by to look! The buildings are so beautiful and provide great photo opportunities. Do pop in if you have the time; it's very interesting!

An Interesting Experience. Our local MP gave us complimentary tickets to visit, the tours are led by a well versed guide with a tremendous amount of knowledge and we found it very interesting and can highly recommend it!
Best place in London. By far the most interesting up close place to visit in London. The tour groups are small and you get to walk through we're everything has happened for centuries.

Amazing experience. The best thing about visiting is you actually stand in the Lord's and the Common's. No virtual experience or video tour, this is REAL! The best value tour in London. Any tourist should not miss this, you will talk about it for years, I live in London and I still enthuse about it.
Best of the trip. This was the best place to visit on our whole trip to London. The history and beauty are amazing. If you get the chance, go when the House of Commons is in session. Good fun.

Formal but well worth a visit. I attended a lunchtime work function in the restaurant in the Palace of Westminster. Food was traditional and served very formally (no surprise there). Top tip is to buy some House of Lords Whisky from the souvenir shop, it’s a great bargain.

We saw the house of the people. We saw the house of the people
great to see this site which is one of three in Westminster
the palace , Big Ben and House of Parliament
the sites attracted us for it is nice looking view over the Thames River
we did not book a tour because of the kids wants only takes pictures

Loved it. We visited the Houses of Parliament and loved it. The building was incredible and we enjoyed seeing all the formality of the beautiful rooms. We booked the audio tour before we left home and had no problem or lines except through security. There is high security. I highly recommend the audio tour because you can take your time in each room and the tour is actually longer than a guided tour. The only negative is that you cannot take any pictures. If you are at all interested in politics or history or both--this is a must see.
Westminster. Very interesting even if you have to que many times You can see both the House of Lords and House of Commons
Big Ben. An excellent attraction for everyone visitting London. This building never stops to amaze me - also, short walk to London Eye and Buckingham Palace

a historical monument. they are again a symbol of london .it is the seat of the 2 parliamentary houses of the united kingdom-the house of lords n the house of commons.also known as the palace of westminster,it lies on the banks of the river thames in the city of westminster in central london.the best view of this structure can be seen from the london eye or on a cruise on the river thames.though i prefer the view from the london eye.the complex houses the clock tower,the victoria tower,house of lords,house of commons,westminster hall and the lobbies,of which the clock tower-the big ben is very famous and again an iconic symbol of london.
ineresting repeat visit. Rebecca was a great guide who gave us an insight into the rebuilding of Palace of Westminster and Queen Victoria's influences. Great enthusiasm

History and Beauty. After living in London for six months, this was by far one of my favorite places to visit. The area surrounding the houses of parliament are beautifully constructed, the garden areas are well-kept, and the views are incredible. You can fit a lot into one day by visiting the houses of parliament. My only warning is to beware of the street "performers" / people who are dressed up who will approach you unexpectedly and try to get scam you. All in all, well worth the visit. However I would suggest trying to eat in a different location. Food is fairly pricey here.

Quite interesting. yeah was quite interesting, if you have a good guide, our was very good and made the slightly boring areas not so, and the interesting bits more so.. as you can only do so much in this venue. was quite busy as its very popular, defo better to book in advance so you can get a decent time and the correct language speaker for the tour..

Fascinating tour of an iconic building. We had a guided tour of the beautiful and historic Houses of Parliament, followed by afternoon tea on the Terrace. It is such a fascinating place and the tour was interesting and educational with light-hearted moments. We had some time to wander around by ourselves and the had a lovely tea on the Terrace, on the bank of the Thames. It was so interesting to be at the place that is the centre of government and that we all see on our TV's all the time - a brilliant day out!

House of Lords visit. Made friends with an English bobbie at the gate and he got us in to a visit within Parliament to the House of Lords. They were debating, of all things, the use of plastic bags! We had already seen that some grocery stores were charging for plastic bags so it made for an interesting afternoon.
A Must see... Go inside the Houses of Parliament and see what keeps Big Ben running ! One of those not to miss tourist sights

Houses of Parliament. We are Group of U3A members invited by our Local MP Alun Cairns to visit on the 9th June. Due to problems with our original coach company letting us down on the day, the replacement company did marvelously to get us there just 2 1/2 hours later than planned. We were met by Alun and his Parliamentary secretary Katherine Pearce in the lobby. Aware of our transport problems they had managed to persuade two tour guides to stay on late to give us an abreviated tour which was absolutely fascinating. We obviously did not manage to see everything, but what we did see left us all feeling that we would love to do it all again to see absolutely everything next time. Our thanks go to the staff, security personnell etc who were extremely courteous and helpful at every stage.

Excellent tour but don't bother with afternoon tea on the Terrace. Our guide on this 2 hour tour was excellent and would recommend it to everyone visiting. However, I would not bother with the afternoon tea on the terrace. At £27.50 each I thought this was far too expensive for the food we had.

Gorgeous. This is a must see if you are in town when it is open! Security is tight to get in but well worth it! There is so much history inside these walls and it was fascinating to learn so much. The inside is gorgeous and it wasincredible to see the House of the Lords.

Beauty. Architectural marvel while passing through river Thames side. Can have nice phtographs with parliament and bigben in background. London Eye is across bridge, at nearly 10 minute walking distance.Did not go inside.Will be passing through this section in any of the london tours.Can walk by the side of river Thames as well.

Amazing and beautiful historic buildings. This wonderful building which houses the mother of parliaments is must do for anyone with an interest in modern democracy and the essential elements of it which were established by some of the iconic leaders remembered in statues in this building. The statue of Oliver Cromwell, the father of modern western democracy although outside is my all time favourite in London
Only open to visitors on Saturdays. We were a little disappointed to find that this place was not open to visitors, but after all it is a place of business for the British Government.

GREAT HISTORY VISIT. Did the Parliament and House of Lords tour..Also we were able to Book the Big Ben Tour 6 months in advance. Fascinating tour of History of the UK.. The walk up Big Ben is 13 storieson stairs No lift... Learn where the terms :" tied up in Red Tape" and" its in the Bag" originated from... This was one of the high lightsof London Trip.

Worth a trip. If you want to learn about British history then this is the place to visit.
The guides have brilliant knowledge and you get to see so much.
If you are not interested in British history then don't bother but if you are then you have hit the jackpot !!!

an English seat of power. This is a very impressive building incorporating the famous ‘Big Ben’ clock tower, close to Westminster AbbeyWhilst walking around you cannot fail to be impressed by the architecture and workmanship with the best unobstructed views from the river Thames, so maybe take a boat ride there are plenty to choose fromHome of the House of Commons (British Parliament) this is one of the most impressive seats of power I have ever seen, a very iconic building

Fun at the Home of Democracy. I took a guided tour around the Palace of Westminster. My first time in the building but what a fantastic experience. I recommend it to all. The tour guide was very knowledgeable, totally engaging, delightfully humorous and extremely patient. An afternoon well spent.

aka Palace of Westminster. Famously known as Houses of Parliament. You can join official tours to go inside if a you are a visitor to London. The place oozes history. It is made up of 2 chambers, the House of Commons and the House of Lords. It is here where laws of the UK are enacted and every year the Queen has the official opening of parliament.The Palace is one of the centres of political life in the United Kingdom. It is commonly known as 'Westminster'.It is an iconic landmark of London and the UK in general, one of the most popular tourist attractions in the city and an emblem of parliamentary democracy. The Palace of Westminster has been a Grade I listed building since 1970 and part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1987.Again well worth a visit.
Lovely place to visit.. Very nice and impressive building. Lovely to wander past on a pleasant day. Nice area with lots around to visit.

Great tour guide. Very interesting tour, Guide answered all questions thrown at her. Really worth a visit if you're in London. Stunning building with so much history. Don't miss it. You have to contact your local MP to get tickets. Lovely little café on site.
A must see. We went in the morning and walked around on our own with audioguides. These gave us great information. The abbey was already quite crowded at around 10 am. Well worth a visit!

Seat of Government. Having passed through security I entered Westminster Hall, thought of the great icons of British history who have laid in State there - Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, Sir Winston Churchill to name but two! Upon leaving the Hall photography is forbidden, ascend the staircase, hand in cameras etc before taking a seat in the Stranger`s Gallery to listen and watch debates in the House of Commons albeit behind a huge glass screen with the sound coming via television sets showing the Sky Parliament channel. Really this defeats the sense of being present as you may as well be in your living room at home. I finally walked around the corridors where the tv interviews are usually broadcast from, but overall I felt stifled and let down by the need for intense security - if politicians feel they are so popular why do they operate within a fortress?

Houses of Parliament. Big, beautiful and steeped in Historical importance. The architecture is awe-full (I was full of awe for it) and it was very easy to imagine people like Churchill, Michael Collins or Lord Wilberforce or Lord Denning just strolling around there organising their countries predicaments and chatting away to each other in the corridors as friends.An amazing experience for a cheap price, thoroughly enjoyed the experience.

Get a tour. Got a 'private' tour with one of the MP's secretary on 7th May and it's fab. The House of Commons is usually closed for PM questions on a Wednesday but they managed to let us through quickly. Starting of in Westminster Hall then through the Commons and onto the plusher House of Lords finishing in the Hall. A quick look into the Queens robing room (what a treat). It's all free too but you have to pre-arrange with your MP or book a tour months in advance. So full of history, definitely worth a visit, Westminster tube station just across the road.

I will return.... Went to listen to the commons - just like the telly but much better. The building, pomp and ceremony are all delightfully British and make you want to learn more. History is very palpable here

Oozing history...so interesting!. We booked, 5 days in advance online, a guided tour for last Saturday for our family of 4 (children ages 14 and 12). There is airport style security, as you would expect, at the entrance. The place is dripping in history and the architecture is absolutely beautiful and I was totally wowed!The guided tour lasts 90 minutes and allows you access to chambers of both houses of lords and commons. It was fantastic. I am glad I chose a guided tour for my first visit but I would love to return to also do the audio tour as there is so much more to learn about. Don't miss this, you will love it.
Tradition. I was lucky enough to access the House of Lords for a ceremony and it was fantastic. British traditions at their best

Fantastic, informative and worth the time.. I am a Londoner and I had always wanted to visit the Palace of Westminster. For 14 pounds it is a bargain, however do note that if you are a UK citizen (like me) it is free to tour Parliament through an MP - although you must wait longer. Our tour guide was fantastic, very informative and I even learnt a few things myself. You are taken to every chamber, The House of Lords and The Commons, as well as Victoria Tower to see the Queen's robing room. Others have mentioned there was no mention of Cromwell, out tour guide mentioned the brief republic and its murderous and tyrannical history, which I think some people forget! You also learn a bit of Royal History, for example the robing process and the state opening. The palace is beautifully decorated and houses fantastic royal portraits. The house of Lords is beautiful. My only criticism is that you cannot take any pictures! It annoys me that in all these beautiful buildings, including Westminster Abbey you cannot take your own snaps without flash! Consider supervised photography parliament or introduce a photo permit for the die hard photographers!
Nice building but can't see the inside. It was constantly closed during the 8 days we were there. looks good from the outside but no idea what the inside is.

Great for those interested in British history and politics. Thoroughly enjoyed the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament we had. Overall the tour was very engaging with our wonderful guide Liz making even the boring aspects of Parliament interesting. It was good to be able to see a Parliamentary building and system from another country and make comparisons.

A must visit - and great value. You feel like you are being shown round living history. Our guide was excellent, fascinating tour and a must do that you won't regret. Forget about Madamme Tussauds and see womething meaningful!

Interesting to see inside. It was really interesting to see inside the Houses of Parliament, the tour guide was interesting and factual and gave us some of the more intersting facts about the building!! We went in february and it was very cold inside some parts of the building, but it was very good none the less! We also went to the viewing gallery over the house of commons which was interesting to see.

incredible !!. The building itself is so beautiful. But the history and all that has transpired there is beyond ones imagination.Knowing that you are walking on the same floors as Winston Churchill and all those who came before and after is quite an experience.Definitely worth the wait to get inside to see where so much history has been made.

Gorgeous historical monument of democracy. It is beautiful in real life than in photos. One of the must places to visit when in London. When you reach this area other interesting places are just walk away.

Pomp and Circumstance. The heart of our political democracy - history and tradition wrapped up in a fantastic building/ institution. Whatever the reason for the visit this is an absolute must for the capital of GB. History oozes out of every stone.
huge. Lovely building to look at worth going to see. Didn't think it was so big until you see it in full view.

What a building.... This was on my husband's list. We'd taken photos on the outside,but he wanted in. I went online about 2 weeks before our trip. I'm not sure if I waited too long, but I couldn't schedule the guided tour for the day and time we wanted. I could and did book tickets for the audio tour. I printed the tix before we left and we made sure to show up promptly at the designated entrance - it's easy to find. Once through security we were given our audio guides and off we went. The tour is quite thorough, but be sure to ask the staff (of whom there are many) and further questions. They all seem happy to share their knowledge. There is a nice gift shop, coffee/tea shop and fancy portable W.C.s outside.
breathtaking. good photo opportunity and definitely a place to see while in London - unfortunately we could not go inside.

Interesting History. Having done the tour of the houses of parliament I found it to be fascinating. It was interesting to hear the history of parliament, what each room was used for and the monarchy's involvement with parliament over the years. They did tours in different languages which I thought was very considerate of them. The only thing that would put me off doing it again is the security, although I understand it is necessary. I come from quite a small town in north east England and the police parading up and down the queue with the guns did slightly freak me out. It got worse when I got dragged away from my mam after I got searched because they thought my miniature deodorant in my handbag was something sinister. Very scary if you are as pathetic as myself but definitely well worth a visit.

Great visit. I have not visited the Palace of Westminster since a school trip many, many years ago. It was a good trip and we had a quick tour around which we really enjoyed. A great experience and we also sat through Prime Ministers Questions which was interesting, They could improve signage, I overheard several people asking directions once inside, I appreciate that it is a working place but a few simple signs would help the experience of visitors.
Symbolic with London. Was great to get close to such an historic and wonderful building that is the heart and soul of England. The photos were fantastic.
Iconic View. You will never say no this impressive and huge tower, a walk is equivalent to a history lesson, magnificent and beautiful along river Thames, a truly amazing experience .

Very interesting. We visited during the week when the Houses were in session. Bad news is that the tours didn't run that day, so we missed out on the background and stories. Good news, we got to view the Houses debating an issue (whether to allow Pfizer to buy a local company -forgot the name) my sister, the lawyer, was so enthrall end, she visited the House of Lords, too. I found it interesting, but not enough to spend another hour or so.You have to walk through Westminster Hall, which is different from the Abbey. They are refurbishing it, so it wasn't as cool as I expected. Good visit overall.

The best bit about London. I have been fortunate to visit the Houses of Parliament a lot, and it is a terrific historical and awe inspiring site. If you are a visitor to London, then you need to do a tour. There is nothing like it. If you a Londoner, then you need to get there and pretend you are a tourist for the day. The building is beautiful inside and out.

Very nice!. Stopping by the Houses of Parliament is a must while in London. While seeing pictures of the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben makes it seem impressive, it is even more so in person. Pictures truly do not do it justice. As other reviewers have noted the London Eye is Close by and you can get great pictures of the Houses of Parliament from there. Even if you do not go inside, definitely stop by and take a look from the outside, you will be happy you did!

BIG BEN AND HOUSES OF PARLIAMENT ARE THE MUST TO BE SEEN IN LONDON.. During a 5 days stay in London, we visited and saw a lot of buildings, attractions and shows, but the best ones are definitively Big Ben and Houses of Parliament ! I will soon add some photos for you to see and understand wha we are talking about.I was there already in 1985, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1989 and nothing changed !
Very impressive building. Worth to see this impressive building with Big Ben, which is alone very impressive and huge tower. It is situated close to London Eye.
Great day out. Nice summers day spent checking out the big ben and other Westmister sites geat a good camera as theres loads of nice places to go and take a great picture

Incredible history!. To walk through the halls of Parliament is equivalent to a history lesson. The number of historic events that have taken place there is staggering. We were also fortunate enough to sit in on a session of the House of Commons. Certainly a highlight of our visit...

Parliament. Magnificent and that is just the outside and the bells of Big Ben.Inside is magnificent........from the paintings on the walls to the statues to both houses, it is worth the visit. Only allowed to sit in certain areas. You must book in advance via your local mp, although we were lucky we got in after a call to our local mp office at Westminster on the morning of visit.Tour we got was just over an hour in time.

Magnificent. Magnificent is all you can say.The building inside and out is a jewel .The line up can be long but worth it .Not a place to take 2 year old toddlers .Older will be interested .It helps to read a little about it before you go.A must see.

Attend parliament. While the building is magnificent and the clock tower with Big Ben (the bell) are beautiful, be aware that you can also attend the gathering of the House of Lords or House of Commons. There is sometimes a line, but the visitors line moves quickly in through either a café or directly into the immense main hall. And what hall! There has been so many historic events. After you have lingered for a while, you move yourself on up a few steps to the hallway lined by murals. From there, you ushered to the stairs leading to the visitors loft to observe. (Elevator available).

State Opening of Parliament - what a show!. Sitting in the Royal Gallery for the State opening of Parliament is something I'll not forget in a hurry. Walking through Westminster Hall; a functioning building 800+ years old is mind blowing. British pomp and ceremony in magnificent surroundings.....

Even to pass by on the Thames commands respect. It's like seeing Washington DC Congress, The White House and House of Reps all at once. This is where British law is created, debated, passed and enacted.Our tour didn't take us into Parliament, but our tour guide gave us a good overview and when we passed it on the Thames River cruise, the grand view we've seen so many times made you step back and say, wow! It's right there in front of us.Very grand, very British.

Guided Tour Outstanding. We took guided tour on a rainy Saturday morning. Tour lasted 90-100 minutes and was very informative .Worth the little extra vs a self guided tour. You get a lot of the history of the building as well as the history of the British government.
