Guided Tour Well Worth It. Before we left the U.S. we had arranged to take the guided tour of the House of Parliament and it was very much worth it. No queues to get tickets just walk up at your allotted time. We also received a very nice guide book as a souvenir. Our guide, Robina Brown, was very knowledgeable and funny but did get a little snippy when questions were asked. Still she was a very good tour guide. Tour took us behind the scenes to the main rooms of the House of Lords and House of Commons, the special voting rooms etc. We did not get to see the Queens Changing Room since they were getting it ready for her actual opening of Parliament in two weeks. Overall an excellent tour that you will remember. They also had a nice gift shop.

You can not visit London without visiting Parliament. It was an awful day weather wise when I walked down past Downing Street to take a look at the home of our Government. It is such a magnificent building steeped in so much history and it is just awesome to just stand at look at it. One day I will take a guided tour but if like me you have time only just to take a look you must do just that
Classic Britain. I never am bored just walking by the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben. Day or night it is spectacular.
Big Ben is the attraction.. Must visit when in London. The Big Ben is a great attraction. The architecture is great. One can spend lots of time strolling around and admiring history

Great group visit. We had to divide ourselves into two groups but our students still really enjoyed their visit. I have been to london many times but this was my first visit inside parliament, it certainly did not disappoint. Just goes to show that it's so much more than just Big Ben!
Historical. Such amazing architecture. Step back in time. A must see while in London Town. The stain glass and Rose windows were just spectacular.
Mother of Parliaments. Excellent tour now that they have introduced the self guided audio tour. Some serious history in the Palace to a walk through both the Lord's and Commons

A "Must see" highlight of a London visit.. Another highlight and a "must see" while in London. Pre-booking is certainly recommended (It also avoid the worse of the queues). The tour was excellent. The guide was extremely good and provided a very good balance between history and information etc all presented in an easy going and humorous way. My words cannot do the place justice.
Amazing Structure. The House of Parliament is a beautiful structure in a beautiful setting. If you haven't seen it, you've got to make the trip. It's such a romantic city.

Beautiful architecture. One of the sights you must see when visiting London. If you love architecture or all building that this will be for you. I was amazed by its beauty during the day and when the lights are lit up at night.

Great experience. This guided tour took about two hours. It was both interesting and highly informative. Our guide was Andrew and he was excellent, engaging, interesting and relaxed. I was initially worried that two hours would be too much but the time flew by. Highly recommend.
Houses of Parliament. I saw it when I first came to London and have seen it so many times since then, but it still amazes me!

Interesting to see how Parliament functions. I was able to attended the House of Commons later in the day. I was a little disappointed to see that not many MPs were left from the day but still glad I got to see the British Government at work.
Must be Seen for London Visitors. The pulsating heart of London, which reflects the political and democratic life in Europe as well as London.

A must see!. You can't go to London and not see the houses of parliament! While studying abroad there I was able to actually tour the houses and it was incredible. If you have a visa, you are able to go in for free! Give it a go if you have the chance!

Pretty impenetrable unless invited but great to look at.. The Houses of Parliament , including the tower containing Big Ben, is one of the iconic sights in the world. You can get right up to the security barriers, but access is restricted obviously. If you are an UK national, you can obtain an invitation to visit. It is a fantastic photo opportunity.

A must see if visiting London. We have walked by Westminster several times on previous visits to London but had never been inside. This time we booked a tour which was the highlight of our recent trip to the UK. Westminster is one of those places you have seen and heard of all of your life but its another thing to walk through it and have its history thoroughly and clearly explained by our excellent guide. The buildings are impressive enough, especially the huge ancient main hall, but its what went on inside over the years that has led to our present way of life where we are not only allowed to visit but also can question the decisions that our lawakers make. You feel like you are reliving parts of history as you go through the various chambers. Don't miss it if you have the chance and book early.as it is very popular.

Parliament Visit. I had an audio tour of the Houses of Parliament which was quite excellent. I booked a ticket on line and picked this up half an hour before the tour. The audio was superb and easy to operate. It cost 15 pounds which included a discount as a senior citizen. For anyone wanting a taste of where the heart of British Government sits and operates then take this tour you will not be disappointed.

Visit. I went with my partner on a tour, it was the most amazing experience and the building and sense of history is mind blowing. If you are ever in London and get a chance to visit this will be the highlight of your visit. I can't explain all what you will see but this has to be among the top attractions to visit in London.

Unbelievable Architectural Details on this Massive Building. The massive size alone is enough to impress, but the architectural details make it an amazing site. Located adjacent to Westminster and Big Ben, it's a tri-feta!

Houses of Parliament. Whether you are British or overseas visitor to London, a visit to the Houses of Parliament is a must. There is much to learn about the history and architecture is just beautiful. The house is within easy access of public transport and the Houses have catered for all tourist. If you want to attend the Parliament in session, you will need to queue, no charge but it would be worth experiencing British politics in action. Try and book book a tour in advance so that you cover both the houses and do not miss anything. The surrounding area is beautiful and romantic.
Interesting visit. Always wanted to go here and not disappointed. So much history and a beautiful building. Surprised how small the Houses are!

Houses of Parliament. Incredible place to visit, saturated with historical events. The architecture alone is well worth viewing. End up having a drink on the terrace overlooking the Thames.Very romantic!Always best to book a tour in advance.
Very Informative. Excellent audio tour.TipBook in advance or online. The Ticket line is ridiculously long and they are very slow.

Great View. we went on an organised tour,it doesn't cost a lot and considering the security aspect it is value for money.the building is really fantastic and a homage to the past but still working to the future.london is full of histotical buildings but this should be top of the list.

more history. You see it on tv, going there is so interesting, learning about kings, queens and politicians. So much history, it is a wonderful building and the guides so knowledgeable. From the lords to the commons, learn how it works, how votes are carried out and where history is made, where the queen gets dressed to where and how Britain functions.
I'd love to be an MP. Best club in London to be a member of!Be enthraled by the history and grandeur of the place not to mention the history. Best value tour in town.

Visit to Houses of parliament. Great experience to tour around one of London's most famous buildings. To see where and how our government makes important decisions that affect every day life. To see busts of many previous past prime ministers and you must take the tour as it gives you a brilliant insight to fascinating facts of historical information.

The Iconic view. It is the view. When you come up out of the tube station and you cross the bridge, turn around and there's Big Ben and The Houses of Parliament. That familiar architecture. As many times as I have seen it, that is always the moment when I really know and feel on my skin that I am in London.

Tea and Politics. Marvellous mix in the seat of power. Great place to visit and the great Westminster Hall with the beautiful hammer beam roof, so steeped in history.Had tea in a small dining room overlooking the river and had a great time and good tea.

Impressive, informative and not one to miss. We arranged a tour of Parliament through our local MP. These are free and in high demand, so try and arrange well in advance. Once you pass airport style security you go through Westminster Hall, which is a magnificent place. The roof alone is stunning, massive wooden structure carried by 13 angels. The tour was on time and our tour guide was very knowledgeable...quite funny too. The tour lasted about 75 min. To actually walk through the corridors, stand in central lobby, house of commons was something quite spectacular. Got to stand on the exact spot where the PM stands when he addresses parliement, in the most important room in the country. The building inside is magnificent. The art work is very impressive indeed. We found the whole tour very enjoyable, very informative and would highly recomment it. We will try and get a tour of Big Ben next.

Wet Weather Programme when in London. During wet weather it is a great venue to visit and feel the atmosphere of one of the oldest British institutions, You get to come close up to the statues of past Prime Ministers Tapestries and of course see the debating chambers where the Members of Parliament sit and debate the best policies for the countrySee and hear the history of the Houses of Parliament the meeting rooms,chapels, corridors etc, When in London do not miss this chance to view the architecture and hear all about our past history.

fun to go to. Its a must see, the tour is great and the guides are very knowledgeable. My daughter and I had a great time seeing how Parliament worked and hearing the history. I wouldn't take small children in, they wouldn't enjoy it.

A controlled gallop .. What a fascinating place the Houses of Parliament are . The doughty lady who took us round , at the gallop , certainly knew her stuff and was not taking any prisoners . She gave us the history , brooked no nonsense and whoa betide anyone who dared to even look as though they were about to droop onto one of The Lords' benches . We were kept on a tight rein , but had a fascinating time . We agreed we would all go again as it all seemed a tiny bit unreal . To be standing in those corridors of power where so much was decided by so few ! Contact your M.P. to organize a trip .

Must see this Iconic building.. Did the audio tour, very enjoyable tour.Steeped in history this has to be in the top five historic buildings to visit while in london. In the right hand corner of the Queens Throne there is a statue of "the Marshal" also know as "the best knight that ever lived. saviour of the British monarchy who was born in 1147. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Marshal,_1st_Earl_of_PembrokePut it in perspective to relate a person to this amazing history of briton.
VIP treatment.. We were invited down for prime ministers Question Time.and were treated like VIPs with coffee on the MPs terrace after it was over.
day out. loved my visit to the Houses of Parliament the guide was excellent and found it really interesting would recommend

historic. it was a cold wet day in November when i visited the Houses of Parliament. I was looking forward to getting inside. Security checks done, and some pics taken with armed police.Great visit and learnt things i never knew. Our guide was very attentive to us, although i felt a bit rushed. I do like to take it in and absorb the moment.Basically the building it beautiful, such craftsmanship, the pomp of government well that just put me in mind of.... 'that's how it must be in Eaton/Cambridge. Worth a visit, it wont disappoint especially if you love architecture

Amzing piece of history!. Loved our visit! Definitely worth the money to spend on the ticket.Security is like airport security with bags getting scanned etc, so make sure you do not take anything weird with you which is classified as dangerous.We had the guided tour and it was fantastic to see some parts of the building. Impressive how small some rooms are as they always look very big on TV. :-)I would not recommend to go with little kids as there is a bit of walking and they might be bored by the history bits. There is a café as well.

A worthwhile visit. We were invited to visit the Houses of Parliament by our local politican.
The tour was brilliant there was so much knowledge and history to pass on the statues of past Prime Ministors are wonderful if you are offered to visit by your local politican grab the offer with two hands

Magnificent Building. Approached this building from all sides and found it fascinating.
Certainly a magnificent build of the period.
Just worth the view. We passed on the open top bus, sadly in the rain but what a building, area!!! Grand & defo worth a visit.

Wonderful Tour of Parliament. Even though I am an American Expat in London, I really enjoyed touring the Houses of Parliament. It is a shame that I could not go up the towers, but I really enjoyed the rest. I did not have much knowledge of British History prior to the tour, but I became so interested in it, I went home and read the "Becoming a UK Resident" book to learn more. I highly recommend the tour to anyone who can find a timeslot!
Must visit. Nice when the weather is lovely, take a picnic and let the kids enjoy! Nice for anyone whether you have young children or just a day out with the elders.

Stunning Architecture. Had numerous visits here when involved with my companies social policy programme.One never tires of the sheer magnificence of the setting and indeed makes one proud to be British.Refreshments in the locality could be better but such that nobody would let that spoil their visit.
Must Visit if you in London. must visit when you are in London. It is simply a place to see once. Especially Evening time when it glitters.. breath taking.

House of Commons/House of Lords. Am so lucky to have been invited to functions both of these and have stood under the green awning (house of commons) and red awning (house of lords). You can just FEEL the history in your bones. Haven't been up Big Ben (or whatever it's called - it's got another proper name) but one of these days I'll get tickets and have a go
An outstanding visit to a historic place. Had a behind the scenes your with the opportunity to dine in the strangers bar. A breathtaking building with bags of history; a must see
Total impressive. I think the houses of parliament standing on the bank of the river Thames is amazing and cannot fail to impress

Breathtaking Architecture. This is where the laws were passed and so is the fate of the colonial countries it had controlled during the days. Was a stone's throw away from St Paul's Cathedral and the Big Ben could be viewed afar. For photography tips, try go to the park right across the road at the rear side of the building and you can have an enlarge view of the subject as background as well as the person in it.

Great Iconic Architecture. been there few times. always enjoy the view let it be summer winter or spring. also in a prime location of London. have lots of shops around. the outside of the building definitely prettier than inside. If you are in London this place is must be in your to do list. otherwise no one will believe u been in London.

Always Busy But A Beautiful place. Our Second chance to visit London, always visit this monumental place, good for picture taking, facing the London Eye and the short walk to Westminster Abby. Very close to Station Westminster - Piccadilly line.

Fabulous Building. I was thoroughly impressed with this building. I've seen a number of legislatures around the world and this one is magnificent. It is a pain to get a tour though, especially if you're not a UK resident. Except for the summer months, it's only open for tours on Saturday. You don't get to see Big Ben. It is also painful to try to find. The ticket office is hidden away down the street and across the road. Google this before showing up there as it is a HUGE building to walk around. Also, don't be shy about asking folks. We got there about noon and the £25 guided tours were all sold out. The audio tour is decent though and takes less than hour once you start. There is full airport style security here. On the Saturday we were here, the whole area was Times Square-like crowded.

watch government in action, in lovely surroundings. i've gone twice now and felt it was fully worth the lines and waiting both times. watching 'prime minister's questions' on tv is one thing, but watching the sharp exchanges between members of opposing parties, as well as sitting through boring procedural work, is better. that's in the house of commons. i find a house of lords prettier, of course, but also a relative snooze in comparison.

Iconic London. The exterior is everything we think of when we think of London. Stunning architecture, impressive size, and surrounded by other icons such as Big Ben, the London Eye, red phone booths and double decker buses. I got some of my best photos here! Ran out of time so i never got in.....guess I will just have to go back!

Every British citizen should visit this!. Incredible - I could not have been more surprised at how I felt after visiting this historic building - I am not particularly patriotic but I came out feeling proud to be a British citizen and quite emotional. Not just the superb building and architecture but the excellent guided tour. The information was given in a lively and interesting way by a young lady who seemed to genuinely enjoy her job. The stories and anecdotes were wonderful and her response to questioning was first rate. The House of Commons, Lords and other rooms and corridors were endlessly fascinating. The tour was free, arranged by contacting our local MP which made it a real bonus. There is a good cafe/ restaurant which was a bonus where you can sit and watch people coming and going. Good idea to combine this with a Big Ben tour - hotels over the bridge - Park Plaza and Premier Inn.

An awesome experience. Nothing could have prepared me for the sights at this awesome tour of the Houses of Parliament. It was absolutely mind-boggling and it was a visual treat. The House of Lords in particular was spectacular and the guided tour was very informative and enlightening. Words cannot describe the grandeur of the place and it has to be seen and experienced. The tour last one hour and thirty minutes.
Amazing!. It's no coincidence that most of my pictures from London are from this place. For some reason the house of parliament, and big ben really impress everyone and you surely have to visit.
Every visit it makes you smile.. I love the house of Parliament. The best is the view from accross the river where it is also quite and you can enjoy the life around you.
Incredible experience. This is one spot that you shouldn't miss. History and architectural beauty. Incredibly beautiful. Highly recommended

Amazing building with Big ben. Very nice building with Big Ben. During city tour whether by road or cruise everyone waits to see Big Ben and houses of Parliament. Its located near westminister abbey and has a good view of london eye as well. Even if you dont go inside, its worth a see and photo.

How can you miss the Big B. The beautiful building and seeing the Big Ben in real is indeed a dream come true. The walk on the Thames path. This place has a lot to offer. The ferry cruise from the Westminister pier, London eye, Westminister Abbey the list can go on...
Icon of London. A must for photoaholics you can stand on both sides of the building and take photos of this impressive building there are tours which you can pick up some of the history
Stunning!. Not sure if you can go in as we just viewed from different angles from outside but such a stunning building. You should not miss this one!

Not as Old as it Looks. One of the world's great temples of democracy, the Houses of Parliament look a lot older than they are - part of the British sense of history and sense of humour, I think. But what takes place is, with all of its problems, one of the great showcases of what democracy can be. The highlight, if you can get tickets for it, is Prime Minister's Question Time, when the prime minister, on a weekly basis, takes questions from members of the House of Commons. With all of the hooting, laughter, and gamesmanship, it is the theatre of democracy at its pinnacle.

Interesting piece of history. A guided tour was very helpful, however there are hand held devices that talk as you move through. I believe the tour was a better choice as you could ask questions. It was fascinating to see and hear how the Houses of Parliament work, even if you're no a big history fanatic. Well worth the visit.
Day out. Very good and worthwhile. As a wheelchair user I got to see some parts the public don't see because we had to go up in the lift whilst everyone else went up the great stairs.Worth a visit

Amazing Experience. Had the opportunity to enter the houses of parliament for dinner as our conference dinner was held there. The interiors are just as grand as the outside. Picture taking at night is simply a must.
Must see in London. Most beautiful structure in London!!!! Best view for a great picture is from the bridge near the building.

Iconic Building. No matter how many times we see the Houses of Parliament, we are always impressed by its magnificence. Viewed from any angle, including from across the river on the South Bank, this has to be a must see when visiting London. We tried via our MP to get a tour, but found out that whilst we asked about a month before, you need to plan months in advance and you need to take this into account if you decide to do this

Fascinating. The Palace is a working building as well as a famous historical landmark, so you never know who you will see when you are doing the tour. It is a fascinating place, do go and see it if you are ever in London.

Uncommonly awe inspiring. This new building is the seat of gov't on the Thames. Compared to its venerable neighbor, Westminster Abbey, it is a piker, but iconic and fascinating. Remember, if you want to hear the PM's question session, contact your MP well in advance to get on the list! We Americans don't stand a chance without diplomatic maneuvering.

A London must-do. I booked the guided tour for myself, my 14 year old son & our host mother & 13 year old son, friends who live outside London. We were all very impressed with the tour & learned so much. The inside of the palace is as breathtaking as the outside & chock full of beauty & history. The guide was really good, informative & entertaining and I would highly recommend booking the guided tour versus just the audio tour. Allow a bit more time than noted in the website info in case you're needing to be done by a particular time to get to another event, at least 30 minutes extra. Photos only allowed in the first place you enter, Westminster Hall. A small shop in that hall, but a much larger shop across the street, which we missed, so plan on extra time to stop there after if you wish to really shop. Nice little cafe for lunch & they do have scones & tea if you don't want to book the official tea offered on the booking site. Will do again in future with the rest of the family.

Mother of Parliament. My. Mate booked this tour , it was the best tour I've had, free book too, saw nearly everywhere u c on TV, only think was had to stand on labour benches lol best part was too c Sir Winston and Lady T statutes.

Worth a visit. Most people do not know that you can visit and watch when house is in session. You will have to go through security if you wish to visit inside. Photography is not allowed. Unlike the USA, a house could be in session late into the night. Pictures look best taken outside from the Thames.

A feast for your eyes. It is worthwhile a visit to the Houses of Parliament. You can admire the Gothic style in all its splendour. The throne is really impressive. You have to be lucky and travel when the houses are in recess but you can find it out in the Houses of Parliament website. Besides, there is a tea room to eat delicious pastries, gateaux and cakes. I strongly recommend this sightseeing.

Selected memory!. Having visited the Houses of Parliament several times in a professional capacity I booked a tour for my husbands birthday. What a farce. No mention of Oliver Cromwell. Henry the eighth was forced by parliament to marry Ann Boleyn! Couldn't remember Ben's first name - this was Tony Benn! And so it went on.......I couldn't believe how bad the guide was. Foreign visitors hear this?

History Comes Alive. As an American, it was fascinating to see how differently Parliament works from our system. A guided tour is a must- they do a wonderful job explaining all the twists and turns of government.

Such a dazzling complex of the buildings of British history. To be in this area of Westminster district in London, to see and visit tremendous Westminster Abbey and miss the long range of magnificent historical institutions of Great Britain that along the left shore of the River Thames, was quite impossible. A day or two after viewing the Westminster Abbey, I went to see the enchanting Westminster Palace. This incredible Palace spans throughout the history over thousands years, from the Anglo-Saxons to the present times. All started with King Edward the Confessor when he moved his court to the Palace of Westminster.After this beginning came in 1265 year, the division of the Palace on two houses, i.e. the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The House of Lords met always at the Palace of Westminster while the House of Commons did not have a permanent location. The Westminster is now, the central seat of government, uniting these two Houses at the location, near the shore of Thames. Why this name of Westminster? That was given after the Saxons came on the Britain island from the City of Munster in Germany and mixed with the hosts, the Angles. So, how they headed to the west,the name was simply derived from this fact. However, what we see on this spot, is the splendid kind of gothic architecture, with towers, the high windows, the gates, the frontons, the pinacles, the buttresses walls, the spires, the clocks,the vitrages and beautiful lawns in front of the buildings with the two equestrian monuments of the two greats from the proud Albion history, that are, the Richard the First, the Lion Heart and Sir Olver Cromwell from the reign of the King Charles I. These statues are my favorites among such others You can see within the complex.Unforgettable experience, indeed.

Audio Tour. This was real value for money. Book the tour in advance and arrive 20 minutes before your allocated time. This allows you to get through security. The Audio Tour allows you to go at your own pace, and also access extra elements of the historical events that you are listening to. Excellent value for money and the tour will take you about an hour.

1000 years of history surrounds you. Took my two teens here during the recent easter recess and had a fantastic time, the great hall was amazing, and the chambers wonderful. We had the audio guides which I really recommend as all three of us listened to every word,The tea shop was good and for London well priced, no photos inside but to see the history and seat of government was incredible. To stand where guy Fawkes was tried, winston Churchill laid in state and James 1st was condemned was awe inspiring

Amazing buildings. Houses of Parliament are wonderful! The architecture is amazing. Big Ben looks wonderful, so light and unbelievable that is made of stone, as well as the rest of the building. You can order and excursion inside the buildings and it would be a nice experience to listen to the session and see some history of the UK. Recommend to visit

A great evening at the Houses of Parliament. Very interesting venue with a well organised tour. The young lad who showed us round was excellent. I felt as though we saw it all and could really sense the history of the place and Great Britain.

Excellent. Was not sure what to expect on the trip to Houses of Parliament but boy what a fantastic day we had. We were shown around the whole building by our local MP and his knowledge was amazing. The House of Commons smaller than expected but seeing it was brilliant. The House of Lords again was better than expected and with the history being explained by our MP you stand in awe at seeing and feeling the lush decor and our Queens throne. The busts, figures and paintings are fantastic all around are fantastic. Recommend without hesitation, brilliant

Only had to wait a few minutes to get in for Cabinet Question Time. Totally worth the wait! The House of Commons chamber is much more intimate that what we are used to in the US. A great free thing to do in London for politics buffs-- and being a non-UK citizen was not a barrier to entry.

Super interesting. I never got English obsession with their royalty. I mean, I get the gossip part, but they seem to care a lot about what happens to the Royal family. After visiting the House of Parliament, I got it: English history is so tied to Royal history that it s impossible to separate one from the other. Everything that has happened in England has to do with a king's or queen's decision. And even today you can see how the political decisions are made precisely to avoid the queen to have the last word. I learned about the bill of rights, the commons and parliament, and it was actually a lot of fun to watch. If you're in a time or pound constrain, get the audio tour and you can go as quick as you want, but if you can splurge it, the guided tours looked really goo and the guides had a lot of knowledge and personality. Regardless, ask questions to the staff and they'll share a story or two. It was surprisingly, a lot of fun!

Where it's all supposed to happen.. Made an appointment to meet our MP & thus avoided queues etc.Got there at lunch time & saw the Lord Chamberlain in his finer leading the Lords into the House.Was amazed to see how old some of the Lords were close up. Well worth a trip round combined with The yte which is a few minutes walk away.
The less noisy House. Not much to see, but the information given by the conductor says a lot of the activities inside. a photo shoot is a must for the spelndour of the building.

A touch of history. A must to see! Lots of information and simply breathtaking! Take a guided tour. Very worthwhile. It takes a couple of hours to go through. Take lots of pictures outside. No photos inside of course!

A touch of history. A must to see! Lots of information and simply breathtaking! Take a guided tour. Very worthwhile. It takes a couple of hours to go through. Take lots of pictures outside. No photos inside of course!

Great way to uncover the history of the British Parliament system. If you can head to the houses of Parliament on a Saturday when it is open to the public take the time to do either an audio tour or guided tour. I did the audio tour and loved it. if was full of great graphical information in an easy to listen and follow manner that gave a great insight into how the British Parliament system works and the incredible history behind it with unrivalled access. Be aware that before you enter you need to go through security which can take up to 30min.

Great Experience! Especially if you like history/government!. I did a tour of Parliament and am so happy I did! My tour guide gave us a great explanation for everything and made sure not to forget about the little things. He gave us information about the history of Parliament and how it currently is and was extremely knowledgeable. Would defiantly recommend others to do a tour!
H.P. Magestic. This is a must see, elegant and powerful on the banks of the thames. For the best view go to the London eye for your photos
Amazing and beautiful building. the architecture that fills every spot on this building so intricate you will get a beautiful picture at every angle

a place were world politics were determined. Although it is a place well known for politic debates, in fact it is a marvellous historical monument definately worth to see. Fantastic interiors combined with feeling of daily work of UK constituancy made on us a great impression. ALthough thetickets are 17.50 GBP I do not regret to pay it for such a historical and political gem.

Fantastic historical tour. We took the audio tour and so glad we did. Fascinating, informative a great way to find out all about the Houses of Parliament and its history. The tour is very well sign posted very easy to follow and you can go at your own pace. One of the best audio tours we have ever been on, highly recommended.

Worth a visit. Booked the tickets before we left the US and were able to pick them up in minutes. The audio guide was informative. We were very impressed with the great Hall and surprised at how small both chambers were

England at its best.. The tour of the Houses of Parliment maks you feel proud to be English. Aside from the fantastic historical building, the smooth running organisation, the fantastic witty and knowledgeable guides make this tour a must do while in London.

Beautiful. The British power seats, a few centuries old- a London must visit. Beautiful architecture and a landmark of the city Conveniently got here in the bus. Don't miss out on the tour, its better than going around yourself.

A look on the inside. Although I have visited London before, I never got to tour the houses of parliament at Westminster, and have only seen them from outside. This time I decided to take a tour and see how do they look from the inside. There are two types of tours. An audio tour, which is cheaper. You get a device with a tape and headphones and walk there on your own. The second type is the guided tour, which I picked. Our guide was fluent and experienced, and led us through the different parts of Westminster Palace (the actual name of the houses of parliament). The tour lasted about 1.5 hours.I found two cons in this tour. The first is that after the tour is over, you are not allowed to go back and wander the area on your own (like the people on the audio tour), so if you prefer to go at your own pace and linger more you may want to take the audio tour.The second con is the price of the tour, 25 pounds, which I find to be very dear. I have been to other parliaments in the world, and the tour was usually free. In London, they decided to make money out of it, which is a pity.A third con is that if you are not British, you cannot visit the clock tower (big ben). I hope that they will allow foreigners to visit it in the future.
Iconic Building. No visit to London is complete without a visit to this seat of power with its fantastic architecture and history

Do not miss it. Forgetting about all the clearances to actually get in, being in the middle of a debate at the Commons or Lords is simply unforgettable for any human being interested in institutions that have worked normally for quite a few centuries. Do not miss it. But keep silent once you arrive to the public gallery. And you will learn a lot.
Interesting tour. We booked the guided tour which took two hours and was very informative. Beautiful building and able to go into House of Lords and House of Commons.
Amazing. Besides there isn't much to be seen, it's very elegant and beautiful for typical London pictures and you can still walk around and see many other things in a walk distance.

Very interesting tour. If you are interested in the British political process, and the cradle of democracy, then it is well worth a visit for an official tour. I believe tours are only conducted when Parliament is in recess, so this is usually only over the summer holidays. There is stunning architecture, amazing craftmanship on show within the Palace. Further they give a very quick and easy to understand overview of how the various Parliamentary processes and ceremonies work.

a must!!. we wanted to do something different so booked a trip to the house of parliament. we booked direct through their website.it cost just under £20 each but was well worth it.we booked a tour which included an audio tape so we could go round at our own pace. the tape gave us ample information. i did notice people who had paid a little more for a guided tour did get to see a few other things but seemed rushed at times!security was tight and we were told to arrive 20 minutes before our tour. some people arrived earlier and were told to go away and come back. we booked the 10.40am tour on the saturday and it wasnt that busy.we thoroughly enjoyed it and thought the cafe and gift shop were good value.would highly recommend this tour.

Houses of Parliament. This is a must when you're planning a trip to London. As beautiful as this building is during the day, you should also take the time to view it at night. We found the best view is from the east side of the River Thames.

perfect. We did the Rick Steve's self guided walking tour....we started at Big Ben and ended at Trafalgar Square....BEST way too see this amazing area if you have the Rick Steve's app and a great pair of headphones (oh and walking shoes). We had 3 days planned in London and a very busy schedule...oh trip got cut short by a day so I combined everything and this option was fabulous.....and FREE! You see and gear about all things along the way. This "tour" is great because you can pause it as you like for photos of lunch!

Guided Tour. Great tour, guide was very informative. Got tickets from Ticketmaster. Lots of standing. Arrive early(ish) to allow enough time to go through security. Would recommend. You do not need to know much about politics to enjoy.

Iconic Landmark. Never fails to give the wow factor, awesome building and surroundings, with Westminster Abbey across the way, and Big Ben towering above. My kids loved it here, but it is very busy, so get there early to miss the crowds. It is a nice stroll after down the embankment of the Thames, or take a boat across to South Bank and it's attractions further down.

You Must Visit!. I visited the Houses of Parliament the first summer they were opened for public tours and have gone back twice since. These majestic building embody British and World History and the future as well. Plan ahead since tours can sell out.

Audio Tour. We took the audio tour when we visited. The ticket office is across the street from the entrance so you'll have to be on the look out for it. There is a great view of Big Ben from within Parliament as well as a very informational and easy to follow audio tour provided with entrance fee.

Houses of Parliament. Really great day had at houses of parliament. My husband is rally interested in politics and was amazed that as the houses were not sitting due to an easter break we could access all areas to see into the actual houses themselves. Staff were professional and courteous, audio tour easy and pleasant way to visit. Worth the cost to get the experience. Well worth a visit.

A Must See. A treasure trove of British history. There is nothing quite like standing in the House of Commons in front of the green leather benches at the government and opposition dispatch boxes. Audio tour was excellent, informative and not too terribly long.

Very interesting.. The guided tour is what made it. The wealth of information from our guide was a bit confusing for the pre-teens, but is what made it great for the parents. No photos, but everything inside very interesting. Tip: Have the teenagers watch PM's question time on CSpan before the trip so they can appreciate being in that room.

Can't leave London without seeing Big Ben. You just can't visit London without taking a stroll past the Houses of Parliament and its famous clock tower, Big Ben. The London Eye, the London Aquarium and other attractions are a stone's throw away, and St. James's Park and Buckingham Palace are also within walking distance.
Architecture and History. The architecture is a piece of art and if you can take the tour inside, it will light up some dark corners of history in your mind.

Well worth seeing. I am not a history buff but this was an amazing place to visit. Very god value for money. We did our own audio tour which was great as you could go at your own speed, and go back to things if needed. Staff very helpful, cafe quite expensive, but free tap water provided- it was horrible- nothing like devon water!! There were a few places to sit down & rest if needed.

excellent tour. A fabulous tour of house of parliament made absolutely superb by the knowledgeable and the very witty Liz. We thoroughly enjoyed her immense knowledge of the buildings and history. Definetly book a guided tour not the audio - you get to see and go places the audio tour does not take you. Well worth the money. would highly recommend. The guide book is fabulous and an added bonus and keepsake of the tour. Five stars plus - well done - the dennison family Northern Ireland.

One of our favorite things we've done in London. If you have the chance, take a tour of Parliament. My husband and I have lived in England for a year and have done many things in London, but this is our favorite along with the tour of Buckingham Palace we took in August. It is beautiful and the tours are very interesting. I saw they were going to audio guides for some of the tours. If you can, get a live guide. It makes it so much more fun. I didn't know that Parliament used to be a palace. http://www.parliament.uk/visiting/visiting-and-tours/tours-of-parliament/ Note: Anyone can take a tour of the Parliament building, whether you are a citizen or not. If you want to climb up Elizabeth Tower and see Big Ben, you have to be a citizen and arrange that through your MP.

Amazing history - a must do. This is such an interesting place to visit. To hear and see all of the history this building has to offer will leave you spellbound. A must do for all history buffs you seriously will enjoy your visit

Loved it!. While my sister and I did not pay for a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, we enjoyed our visit nonetheless. Seeing such an iconic landmark like Big Ben was one of the highlights of our trip. The London Eye is within walking distance as well. Will definitely have to book a tour on my next trip to London.

Good tour and very interesting. We took the audio tour and it was very easy to follow. Our teenage children enjoyed the whole experience. The House of Commons and the Queens robing room were very good- commentary via audio tour made it v interesting. We went during Easter break and we would like to go when parliament is session.
Parliment. lots of History on this guided tour, had to pay as it was the weekend but you do get a free book. quite expensive but worth the money

Nice guided tour!. I had a great guided tour at the Houses of Parliament. Knew a lot from before, but it was interesting to walk through the rooms, see the layout of the buildings, and try to get a grip of the atmosphere. Knowledgable guide.

Houses of Parliament. Disappointing as you cannot go inside the chamber (commons or lords) unless you are a UK Citizen & make arrangements to be shown around by a MP or Lord. Also Big Ben is difficult to get access too.

Fascinating. We took a guided tour to explore this magnificent building. It was very interesting to hear about the history and the goverment system in the UK. Altough in the internet site it was mentioned that you can pay a visit to the galleries free of charge, there was no other possibility to enter the house except for the tour.

Unique and very interesting. Booked a guided tour through ticketmaster which was excellent. Our guide Adrienne was very knowledgable and presented the information very well. She was able to answer questions from the audience. Fascinating hour and a half tour of historic and current facts in a unique setting. There was no queue to enter and were free to soak up the atmosphere in Westminster hall before and after the tour.

Amazing!!. Wow. We had a fantastic tour led by Ros the week before Easter when nothing was in session. We got to go into all the hidden away spaces and felt like we really got to know a lot about the rooms, the people and the politics of the UK. Our guide was incredibly knowledgeable. I've been to London many times but have never done this tour before - I very highly recommend!

Interesting tour. Booked a tour online, had to pick up tickets from the nearby ticket office, which is a bit hard to find, just ask a policeman but its basically across the road behind Westminster Abbey. Security was pretty quick. The tour itself was interesting and gave a good mix of information about the history of the building itself, and the functioning of the political system it houses. Book your tour a few days beforehand, some timeslots had started to sell out. I think all citizens of Britain and the British Commonwealth have an obligation to understand how the system works, but thats because I'm a legal studies teacher.

Beautiful inside and outside. The House of Parliament is not only beautiful to see and photograph the outside. A guided tour takes you to the house of lords and common. UK residents and overseas visitors can book tickets for a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament on Saturdays throughout the year and on selected weekdays During Parliamentary recesses. Find out what happens at Parliament, how your MP Represents you and how Parliament checks up on the work of Government. You can also see lots of pictures and a beautiful art collection. Check out

Interesting. Been to London lots of times but this is the first time we have been inside the houses of parliament.I would recommend it to all, even those without any political interest. We were able to watch a live debate, although its easy to be distracted by the architecture, it great.An interesting afternoon.
Perfect. First time to gallery and it was everything I expected. I was able to see my favorite Monet painting and the Sunflowers exhibit was wonderful.

Long wait to get in. We went to a reception. It took nearly an hour to get through the gross under resourced security, which does not reflect well on the Mother of Parliaments. The police were friendly but overwhelmed by the numbers of visitors. The moral of the tale is allow plenty of time to get through security.
Worth a trip. Arranged though my local MP and it was a very interesting tour. We worth the time and effort to get a little of the history of this building.
Great. booked through our MP, great free tour, very knowledgeable tour guide. Fascinating to see where it all happens. Highly recommend.

Houses of Parliament are quite unique. An absolute must to visit - it is a place with a lot of history and tradition where truly democratic processes take place. Probably not suitable for small children.

Must See!. We visited a couple of months ago and didn't get around to posting on TripAdvisor.I'd always thought you had to arrange a special invitation by an MP so hadn't bothered to really consider a visit then discovered that tickets can be purchased on Ticketmaster!We absolutely loved this tour. It was great value - around £15 each - and so interesting. The buildings and history are truly amazing and this is one of the best things I have ever done in London. Can't recommend it enough. If you are thinking of booking a visit, get on with it! You won't be disappointed.

worth the walk by. amazing architecture from every vantage point, and interesting to see at different times of the day. Big Ben is great. When parliament is in session you can see them coming in and out in their limos.

Unexpected treat!. A police officer suggested we tour Parliament, as they were currently out of session. We were so glad that we did! The audio tour was very complete and informative. The history of the building was awe-inspiring. If you have a chance to tour this building, take advantage of it--it's rare to be able to get inside.

Interesting, If you are into politics.. Very unique and Interesting experience, given of course you have some interest in politics.
The space allocated to us is a bit small but due to security reasons it's understandable and forgivable.
Although I couldn't hear them very well, the view of the "action" was second to none!

ok. Average - Go here to see where all the big legal jargon is made. It has educational value but at the cost of lengthy queue usually in the freezing cold with airport style security. Young people, teens and children will find this boring
Nice view. I wasn't able to go inside or tour this place except for on the outside. Impressive view. Need to see this place on any trip to London.

A must do. This is the heart of Western democracy and a wondeful building with lots of adjacent and nearby attractions to wander around at the smae time eg Westminister Abbey.Try and get inside and look at the building, architecture and artwork inside. Great history. You can stand in line to watch a debate in th public gallery. I did this and fiund it verey fascinating.

Houses of Parliament. This was so interesting. Wonderful to actually be there in such an historic and famous place! The audio tour is excellent and gives an opportunity to hear more about various topics if you wish. It was good to be able to go at our own pace walking where so many famous (and infamous?) feet have trodden before! Well worth a visit.

This is more than politics. Our recent visit to Westminster palace gave us an experience that was totally enthralling. Jenny (our tour guide) held our interest throughout the whole walk round. This place is a must for anyone who has any interest in how we became the country we are today with a parliament system which has been a model for many other countries.My only criticism is that the toilets need to be improved upon.

Best place to Hangout in Leisure. I think, in a span of 2 months, I would visit this place atleast 9-10 times even in Rain. This place is awesome for all sorts of Photography and catched my eyes. Nice place for Friendly hangout and the the most used backdrop in most Brisith video productions.I would visit London probably again to enjoy the scenetic view of the place.Nearby attractions are London Eye and Westminister Abbey.
fab day. just try and go we really enjoyed well worth it weather was great too to really see the place from where our country is run from.

Amazing. I had the pleasure and privilege to have visited House of Lords, the House of Commons and even the Speakers residence. In all occasions they were invitation only reception. The architecture, the history, tradition and the culture of what is Britain in personified in every stone. I have included some pictures which say more than I can describe.
Bit of history. Good to say you have been, seen and learnt a bit of British history. Great views too - your bags will be checked quickly and professionally. Been a few times now.
House of commons tour. This was brilliant. book it ahead on line with a tour guide. Only fourteen in our group. We were the only Brits. Tour lasted nearly two hours .
Very Photogenic. This is great place you must see and you can get better photos taken if you go on a tour bus as it takes you the full 360' degrees

Living History. The House of Lords, House of Commons and Big Ben are such iconic buildings to the history of England. Having a guided tour and learning so much about what has taken place in this Palace of Westminster is a must for anyone interested in British history.

Make sure you go inside and do the tour!. ... its not how you would think it to be, it used to be a Palace and the inside of the Houses of Parliament and just magnificent! I was in shock and then in awe because I wasnt expecting it, each room is more beautiful than the next!

Henry and the Houses of Parliament. If you reside in the UK you may be lucky and have a guided tour by your local MP. If not you would need to book. The houses are steeped in history with something interesting around every corner. You will learn about both the Commons and the Lords and the involvement of the crown. See where history has left its mark and the designs when it had to be rebuilt. How insurgents were handled both in history and now. Who sits where and why. Well worth a visit.
Excellent !!!!. Well worth a view, guided tours (I love them when done right!) a great insight into a great place, if only they could put in Downing Street as well !

A must for the History. The whole place is steeped with gems. To actually go and stand in the commons was great. Not allowed to sit or take pictures. But I can now say I have been and stood where the PM stands

Houses of Parliament. Wasn't too sure about going on this trip but was really impressed. The buildings are amazing inside & out. Went in the House of Commons and sat on the benches. The area was a lot smaller than it looks on TV but the history of the place is incredible. Go see if you are into your history.

The most remarkable sightseeing in London. The Big Ben is just so monumental and majestic... I absolutely adore it! It's my favourite landmark in this magical city! And the Houses of the a parliament are as majestic and beautiful! It doesn't matter if it's winter or summer, the place is always stunning! Perfect for pictures and to see people from all over the world - it's always busy over there!

Well Worth a Visit. Although I was in a privileged position and had a dedicated small group guide it is well worth visiting to see, to sit, to listen and visit the House of Lords. The refreshments were paid for so I cannot comment on that aspect, If you are interested in World History and the British Empire from Cromwell onwards you should see the birthplace of democracy etc.

Inspiring and humbling. We had a tour of the Palace of Westminster recently, and it was both inspiring and humbling in equal measure.Westminster Hall is a great building and being over 900 years old it has no doubt witnessed a few comings and goings in its lifetime. The sheer size and scale of the Hall is impressive and the roof is worth getting neck ache for as you stand and gaze at it seeing different things all the time.The House of Lords is rather opulent and richly decorated, as you might expect and the corridors around it are equally furnished. The red leather benches look quite comfortable, although you are not allowed to try them out!The House of Commons by contrast is perhaps sombre and less vibrant, the benches being green leather. The chambers of both Houses are in fact much smaller than when we see them on TV. This is a great place, and very much worth a visit. Full of stories of national and global importance through the years. It is of great historic significance.Go and see it for yourself.
good visit. This is a great place to go see were all the big decisions are made however it is fairly long and the younger people made find it a bit boring towards the end

Got there too late to tour inside, but it's iconic on the outside with Big Ben. Even though I was too late to get to the tour, it was nice to walk around the outside and take photos, Big Ben, the London Eye. Good place to walk around and take in the feel of the city.
Famous landmark and free. This is one of the best places in my opinion of the capital, brilliant for photo opportunities and so much to see in the surrounding area.

Brilliant guided tour. Visited yesterday with my daughter and sister (who is visiting from the USA). Our guide, Diana, was excellent-very engaging and knowledgeable. Seeing the Lord's and Common's 'in person' rather than on the TV was great, as well as all the other areas on the tour and hearing all the history.

British Parliament. Heritage Building once upon a time ruling over the world. This is surrounded by Big Ben GMT, Westminster Station, Tower Bridge, High Court and many more. Worth spending time in this area.

Free. Worth every penny.. Security & welcome staff were brilliant. Fell victim to an (utterly terrible) prank by the police with their metal detector. Amazing views inside and deffo well worth the visit. Debate over tax headway reductions was quite dull except for the labour MP leading the debate struggling to get any response from the government bench.Quite pleased though that all MPs, (including Mr. Reece-Smog) remained awake for the duration of our visit.
Beautiful. I've seen pictures of Parliament for years.But pictures do not do it justice. We only visited the outside of the building. I would like to plan a tour in the future.
fascinating. We went for coffee in the cafe off the great hall, which was lovely, and then had a wander. Question Period was truly interesting.
Everyone should visit at some point!. Went as a family and did the audio tour, we all learned loads that we didn't know and all found different bits that we liked best.
Worth a visit. We didn't have the time to go inside, maybe next time. But from the outside it was amazing. it is even mora impressive than you imagine.

brilliant. really hadnt expected to enjoy this guided tour so much.It was incredibly interesting, so much history in gorgeous surroundings, the staff were all so friendly and helpful and even the cafe was fab.I had 2 teenage girls with me who were not particularily enthusiastic about going, but they loved it too!

Very interesting and lovely for adults and older kids. It was a real treat to be able to enter both the House of Lords and the House of Commons and be in the actual room where the Queen prepares for her annual address. As Americans, we have become accustomed to a lack of access in our own country. We visited the U.S. Capital and weren't allowed in either chamber of Congress, despite it being a weekend when it wasn't in session.Here we actually went right down on the floor and walked in the rows where members of Parliament sit, where they have their spirited and entertaining debates! My 13 year old and 10 year old were not terribly engaged, but our 14 year old son thought it was very interesting, so if you have a tween or teen interested in history, they might really enjoy this.No photos allowed beyond the first entry hall, so be mindful. Book in advance on Ticketmaster and you can select a time of day. This is open Saturdays only, and you cannot climb up the tower where Big Ben is unless you are an EU citizen (bummer). I loved that this was a little of the beaten track of some of the wildly popular attactions like the Eye or Buckingham Palace and seemed filled with people who really have a love of history and government.

Audio Tour is brilliant. Booked the Audio tour rather than the guided tour and we were so glad we did. By doing this you can study what you want whilst taking in the detail around you - the guided tour means being stuck in a group and concentrating on the guide when he/she is speaking. If you havent been round the houses of parliament it is well worth doing.

Interesting Tour. I arranged a tour through my local MP. This has to be done months in advance, however it was worth the effort! Security check was quick and efficient. We met in the Great Westminster Hall with Jyoti Bhutani who was an excellent guide. We were shown the House of Lords which is stunning and opulent compared to the House of Commons! We saw the Queen's entrance and the room where she gets her robes and crown on, it was lovely! The trip tells you the history of the Houses of Parliament and when it was rebuilt after the great fire. Well worth a vist, has a very nice coffee shop too!

Go for it. The visit is really interesting and you will learn a lot about how the Parliament is working in the UK. The buildings are beautiful from the outside and amazing in the inside. You need to buy your tickets in advance and withdraw it when you arrive. The tour guide is a certified guide who will walk you through the buildings and centuries with pleasure. You can choose the language of your visit.

A Palace. The first shock is how big the Houses of Parliament are, second how badly bombed they were during the Blitz, and third how much history oozes out of the place. Best combined with visit to PMs question period on Wednesdays. Google to find out how.

Plan Ahead. The new arrangements for touring Parliament increases the accessibility, but be sure to buy your tickets in advance and plan ahead. Ordered online, you can pick up your tickets the day of your tour, but to make security clearance it's important to arrive at least 20 minutes early. Once inside you'll wait in Westminster Hall until your Blue Badge guide rounds everyone up and gets started. We saw more of the building than with the private Black Rod tours we got years ago, but as there are also individual audio guides going on at the same time, it can be a little crowded and hectic. Still worth every minute.

Go for it, if you can get in!. Most of the year, the only way to get in is by invitation from your MP and the it is free. (That's the radio button I checked below: without that invitation it is reasonably pricy, but fair value. Security is extensive. But the interiors are extraordinary. Putin was mad, mad I tell you. And, when I went, the coffee in the cafeteria was very good.

houses of parliement. went to london to go on the london eye after that went across westminster bridge to see big ben and the houses of parliment . my mum as never seen them before so took her round to view were all the big decisions are made . it was well timed got there at mid day and big ben gave its all i must say that i didn't realize all the work that went in to that clock the architect was amazing and had a great vision .

A 'must see' attraction. We visited on a Saturday and were shown round in groups of about twenty. The guide was very knowledgeable and entertaining, and kept us all interested and well informed. Westminster is magnificent, outside and in, and is well worth a visit by all who come to London.

Well worth it. We were on a short visit to London and decided to go to see Westminster abbey, when we arrived at Westminster tube station we saw an advert for the houses of parliament, who knew that it was open for visits? We found the ticket booth across the road about 100m away and managed to buy tickets for later that day. The cost is about £16 ea. And is well worth it. After passing through security, similar to airport security, we were introduced to our guide who was knowledgeable and informative. But the killer thing about the visit was the building itself. Living history ! The whole place exudes an aura that is impossible to define and when you think of the famous and infamous people that have been there it blows the mind. I would recommend this visit to everyone. Only one negative, I wasn't able to claim back the money on expenses unlike our members of parliament.
Wonderful!. It's simply wonderful: a must for everyone who goes to London. Easy place to take nice pictures and to learn a little more about the UK.

Friendly guards, fascinating building and government. I was intimidated to walk up to the very official entrance by the Cromwell statue but in response to my question, the guard was quick to let me in. My bag and I went through airport like security and I was issued a pass on a necklace before being let off on my own to navigate the Westminster building which is as huge as it looks on the outside. The guards were happy to let me see both House of Commons and House of Lords which were both worth the visit. Once you're in the viewing gallery, you can stay as long as you like (or as long as it's in session) and watch the process of government in action. The House of Lords and the halls leading to it are much more posh than the House of Commons but it's great to see the contrast between the two.Make sure to check the website for the times that the chambers are in session because those are the times when you're allowed in. Both UK and non-UK people are allowed in, as well.

A memorable visit to The Mother of Parliaments.. This was some time ago. Organised by my local political party, Our M.P. met us there, even showed us to a few parts not normally open to the general public,the chapel in the crypt(in which she had had a marriage blessing ) a particular 'gem' plus the broom cupboard that the brave suffragette hid in overnight in order to be in the Houses of Parliament on the occasion of the National Census. thus striking a blow for women's suffragette.  It was a great day for lots of reasons. .
Looks good. Unfortunately the day we went there, they dint have a visit entry but its looks good from outside. Lot of people suggested me to visit after sunset.
government in action. Very short wait on rainy day to attend a session of parliament and listen to debate. Chose the House of Lords and you will get to see the Queen's gold throne in the chamber.
history. wonderful historic buildings, the seat of parliament, well worth a look. surprising how small the commons and lords are, as they look quite big on television

House of Parliament Tour and Big Ben. Recommend, definitely. Contact your MP and ask him to arrange the tours and they will be f.o.c. otherwise it is something like £14 pp. for both visits. The guides are very knowledgeable and "nice". We were standing alongside the Big Ben Bell when it struck 12 noon and then walked behind the 4 clock faces. Wonderful! Just a tip. Booking for Big Ben was 3 months in advance when we booked.

a worthy attraction. Despite a lengthy queue for tickets this was well worth the wait and great value for money. The guided tours are really good and thoroughly informative and all done with professionalism and wit. The history is fascinating and the interiors were absolutely stunning with such beautiful architecture. The two houses, Commons and Lords were treasures to behold. This should be part of any trip to London
Incredibly interesting. Lots of British history. Tours are excellent and very informal.Also ideal if you love to get into the places you see on TV.

Guided tour is great. The 100-minute guided tour was not cheap, but it's value for money. We paid about 22 pounds for each person. The guide was friendly and knew all the things that he needed to present. He talked about the in-depth history, not just the superficial information. Highly recommended.

Charity Event. We went here for a charity event, we had a tour which was very informative and very well conducted, then we went to the reception which was held in the green and red marquees the food was modern and tasty, most of the waiters were friendly but a couple seamed a bit stuffy, one of the nicer ones was very helpful in letting us use the mp bar to get a cup of tea :)

A fascinating tour. We booked the tour on the same day and got four tickets for the audio tour. The personal guided tours were all booked. However we found the audio tour to be excellent and it gave us time to meander slowly through magnificent halls and both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. To be standing on the very flags where monarchs and mighty men of history stood gave a sense of awe. You can buy tickets at the booking office in the back of the white house across the road from Westminster. It was not easy to find and badly signposted. Book online with ticket master for a quick and easy process for both accompanied and audio tours. Not to be missed.

Must do trip. We booked a guided tour and am glad we did. Our guide was very informative and able to explain the workings of parliament to both the non UK residents on the tour as well as to those of us from the UK. We were guided around some of the rooms used by MPs & Peers as well as both the House of Commons and Lords and heard about the rules, traditions and history of the room, the art and the people who use the room.The whole tour was fascinating and brought the rooms we see on TV to life. The tour was approx. 2 hours and there are very few places you are allowed to sit. We were booked on the 4pm tour so had been walking around London all day and were quite tired by the time we arrived for the tour.

Amazing history. As a Londoner originally, we often overlook what in in our own back garden - so to speak. My husband booked this trip for us over Christmas and I have to say it was the highlight of our trips out over the Christmas period. The history is amazing, the guide was extremely knowledgeable and the buildings spectacularly beautiful.It gets very busy over Christmas so perhaps visit another time of year if you can. Expect a lot of security and set aside a couple of hours for your visit. Book in advance if you can.

Beautiful Westminster Palace. Couldn't go in, but the outside was lovely. Walked around the outside and took lots of pictures. There was some construction going on but it didn't take away from the beauty.

Fascinating!. We had a full tour of the House of Commons and the House of Lords and then went to the public gallery to watch a debate. Excellent way to spend a day and you will learn a lot about how it all works.

Taking the tour on Saturdays is an absolute must. I am a New York City tour guide on vacation in London. If you are in London on a Saturday then go see Westminster Palace. The Circle Line (yellow), District Line (green), and Jubillee Line (grey) stop at Westminster. You will come out by Elizabeth Tower and Big Ben. Walk away from Westminster Bridge past Elizabeth Tower and make a left on Abingdon Street. Walk the length of Houses of Parliament. Just west of Westminster Abbey you will see a small three story white building with an address plaque that says Old Palace Yard. There is a locked gate on the left side. The gate will be opened at 8:45 AM. Be there. Walk around the back of the house to one of the three ticket windows and buy your entrance ticket for £16.50. Usually, the guided tours are sold out online in advance. If you have the hard copy confirmation an employee with envelopes will start passing out the prebooked tickets. I didn't prebook the guided tour so I ended up with an audio tour which is quite good. Walk back across Abingdon Street to the big white tent to go through security and enter. Once inside Westminster Hall an audio guide will be issued to you. The Palace of Westminster is jaw dropping. Under the great oak ceiling at Westminster Hall the trials of William Wallace, Thomas More, and Charles l were held. The St Stephen Hall was rebuilt after the fire in the style of the original. The stained glass work is of singular quality. The lobby may be the most beautiful in the world. If the Royal Gallery had existed at the time then Americans would have reconsidered the revolution. The Queen's Robing Room is decorated with friezes of Arthurian legend. The knights of the Round Table on their knees swear oaths to recover the Holy Grail. I stood in the House of Commons on Saturday right where the Prime Minister stands during questions and answers on Wednesday. This was the best two hours ever spent in London. If you visit London then Parliament is open for a tour on Saturdays. Get up early and be there by 8:45 AM. The crowds build quickly. I spent two hours and I could have spent more there was so much to examine.

Beautiful architecture, fascinating history. This really is a fascinating place to visit. It has a long and illustrious history - dating back almost 1,000 years in the case of Westminster Hall. We were lucky to be invited to dinner in one if the function rooms, and the building is quite stunning inside, and it is fascinating to see the different parts of the palace. The Houses of Parliament, or Palace of Westminster, may be overlooked by some of the more famous/popular attractions but I can highly recommend a visit.
Houses of Parliament. Very informative and interesting tour, seeing the place where it all happens - followed up by a grand tea in the Pugin Room.

Really interesting, worth a visit!. The Houses of Parliament guided tour was fantastic-our guide was very knowledgeable and made every minute interesting. The building was great and the history is fascinating-well worth a visit even for those not so keen on politics. There is a lot of standing up as the tour takes 1.5hrs, but I recommend having the afternoon tea afterwards-you really appreciate it! A must visit!

HOUSES OF PARLIAMENT (INSIDE PALACE OF WESTMINISTER). If you love history, government, politics and beautiful Gothic architecture, add this walking tour to your list. It is located inside the Palace of Westminister which is also the home of the famous clock – “Big Ben” (FYI: please note this is a 75 minute walking tour with minimal opportunities to sit down).There is something special about walking through the actual halls of a leading world power government where charismatic and powerful people have walked, sat, debated and forged laws and policies that have impacted millions and millions of people all over our globe.Yes, you’ll see where the famous Prime Ministers have stated their positions and fought for their ideals and what they felt was in the best interest for their country. You’ll learn the history of parliament from your knowledgeable guide as you move through both houses of parliament.Be prepared to have you possessions searched and don’t bring any weapons. Not even a small Swiss army knife (my bad) as it will be detained for you to claim at the end of your tour. Not a major problem, but time consuming. Also FYI, no photos allowed inside parliament, but you might get a photo op of “Big Ben” just after the tour (See my night photo of Big Ben exiting the parliament tour). Hope this was helpful.

Incredibly beautiful and informative. We had booked the guided tour in advance and it was well worth the visit. The rooms are very beautiful and history connected to them is very interesting. I would love to go back again. Must visit when you're in London. I would highly recommend booking the tour.

Very interesting tour. Actual building and historical facts. The enthusiasm of our guides. Our main guide, James, made the tour interesting, gave us many historical facts. Wonderful art work and architecture. It is a huge building. You get a real feel of the place. Statues of past prime ministers - interesting.

Beyond belief. We had a tour around the House of Lords and House of Commons prior to a dinner there and it was one of the most amazing few hours I've ever spent.From the working nature of the Commons to the majesty of the Lords, this was a superb tour delivered by an excellent guide.

Would thoroughly recommend. We are a family of 4 and we would all highly recommend the audio tour. We visited early on a Saturday in March, booked in advance and had no queues or waiting time. It was equally quiet inside so we enjoyed the full audio tour, read everything we could find and asked a few questions of the helpful staff on the way round. My 12 year old pretending to be the prime minister in the House of Commons gave us all a special memory!
Impressive. Take a tour through the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben. Make sure you do it at night to experience the true beauty.

Outstanding. Joining a guided tour is a must, especially if interested in politics. The architecture is magnificent as is the decor. It is hard to imagine that so many historical figures have walked through these rooms. It is really fascinating to see the 'House of Commons' and the 'House of Lords', even without the parliamentary debates that we see on television. Very professionally carried out and well worth the visit.

Superb Tour. We, or should I say I, decided that as part of our 10th Wedding Anniversary London trip, we would take the opportunity to look around the Houses of Parliament. We are both really glad that we did, the whole process, from start to finish, was interesting, enjoyable, educational and enlightening. Even the metal detector and frisk search adds to the whole experince and makes you feel that you are being allowed access to something very special and almost secretive. Security procedures over we made our way to the only remaining part of the original Palace of Westminster, namely Westminster Hall. This dates from the 1100's and the thought that you could be walking where kings and queens from the last 900 years may have walked is very sobering, thought provoking awe inspiring. I won't go into detail about the history of the building or describe the sights too vividly as that would spoil it. What I will say is that the whole tour was superb with our guide being incredibly knowledgeable about the subject and very affable. The history is fascinating and we came away educated, entertained and enlightened. For £16-50 each this must be one of the bargain attractions in London. Money very definitely well spent. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster incidentally. Not like the old days when you had to petition your local MP to organise a trip. My only disappointment was not being allowed to sit on the seats in either the House of Lords or the House of Commons. Members only apparently. Don't worry you do get a few chances to sit during the 90 minute tour in the lobbies and some committee rooms. The oppulence, sometimes seemingly out of place, will sometimes take your breath away. Just note how much plainer and less ostentatious the Commons areas are, it tells you everything you need to know about the 'them and us' culture that has dogged our country throughout history.

Government in action. We had a tour of Parliament this week. We arranged the trip by writing to our Local MP who arranged for one of his staff to meet us and show us round personally. As we had arrived early we missed most of the crowds that were visiting in groups later that day. We were lucky enough to see more areas of the building than the tourists and even managed to go on to the famous terrace overlooking the Thames. Our guide Rory was an excellent host and very knowledgable . Other reviews describe the the awesome sights you can view throughout the building. Following a coffee we took our seats in the public gallery to watch the day's business. We were given a schedule of questions that would be discussed and s timetable of the days agenda. It was fascinating listening to the quick fire but orderly debate. Mr Speaker only had to shout order once. I was amazed to see members of the house bobbing up and down trying to attract the speakers gaze.this signifies they wish to speak.We did not watch the whole days events and were free to leave when we wished.A thoroughly wonderful day and even better it was completely free. We used our bus passes to travel around London and there is no charge made when an MP arranges a visit for you.Not sure about disabled facilities and buggy parking so I would ask before the visit if you require these facilities.
