Great experience. Very interesting tour so glad we did it. Good value for money. Very British though ( which was bril) Italian & yank queue jumpers were put well in their place in a good but firm manner, when in Rome!!!!!!!

Houses of Parliament. Every time I visit London I have to visit the Parliament buildings to learn more about the glorious history of the United Kingdom. And I can't help admiring the sight of the tower that houses "Big Ben."

Drove by it everyday during my London journey. Never gets old, it looks impressive from South bank and looks fantastic and well looked after you drive by it from behind. Such a shame I never got to go inside. Would love to see how it looks from the inside.
Great!. Great place! The exterior is diferent from any other places but the interior is even beter!It is one of the things you should see once in your life! I enjoyed it very much!

History at its best. saw the insides of the asset - had a fantastic time with the family. try to take pictures inside although they say it is not allowed.Try to get there early to get away from the numbers in waiting.Check out the treasury house after that it gives a great history point of vies.

Amazing building. Was awesome to see this building, even if full of politicians! After seeing it on TV a lot, it was nice to go inside.You an also get a sense of it from the outside, so if you want to save money, you don't have to go in. Big Ben from the streets stunning. But good experience all round and if we went back to London we would consider going back. And FYI, a good rainy day activity.

Excellent. This tour is an absolute must. Wasn't expecting too much but the tour takes you to all the interesting parts and the audio comentary is excellent.It was busy but never felt crowded, great history lesson.

Well worth seeing!. We were boooked on an Audio Tour which in hindsight I think is better then the visit with a guide. The recording can be paused or replayed as required and you can look at items and displays at your own pace, and it is chaper! (Guided tours wereovertaking us.) There are Stewards in each room, gallery or lobby to answer any questions and we found they were able to answer everything we asked. We were surprised to be able to actually enter and walk through both Houses. We took 2 hours on our visit. The prices for coffee, cream teas etc. were no dearer than other establishments.
Book on line. I'd recommend going at the weekend as you see more and book on line if you can or you may not get a tour for some time after you arrive.

Fascinating. Although our guide was very 'efficient' rather than welcoming, we really enjoyed the tour, walking through something that is so historic yet so current. Very busy, even in January so get there extra early to allow for the queue for security checking.

A pleasant and educational experience. At the end of a long day, we were in the vicinity of the Parliament and decided on a whim to check the inside. Much to our surprise, the answer was: "there are debates inside and, therefore, you can have access to the public gallery". It must have been close to 7 pm and we were surprised that it appeared to be easier to get in when the politicians were there, than otherwise. That looked to us as a wonderful proof of real democracy in action. Politicians debate - voters have the right to watch. I should add that we're not even British, but Canadians! We went inside and were able to get access to viewing galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. We could watch the debates. Very civilized. Impressive. Uplifting. This impromptu visit and the treatment received made us proud of this Mother of all Parliaments.

If you like history or architecture this is a must see.. It was a very powerful afternoon, learning about the history of the building and looking at one of the most beautiful and amazing buildings in the world! We also sat in on a parliamentary debate, interesting but I enjoyed the buildings.The parliamentary debates are free and you can only go into part of the building these start at 3 pm. There is a fee for the guided tours.

This visit is a privilege and worth every penny and then some. While on our recent visit to London we read in the newspaper that the Houses of Parliament were open for guided tours. Telephone, Ticketmaster, Credit Card and we had obtained the tour tickets. We were advised to be 30 minutes early to get our tickets at the counter and clear security. This security check is like an airport; remove coat, belt, watch etc. the whole rigmarole. However, as long as there are people out there whose goal it is to destroy lives and cultural heritage indiscriminately, I cheerfully went through the check point. After clearing the security check we were led to St. Mary's Chapel. Groups with the different time stamps were formed in this chapel, the only building which survived the fire in 1834. Unfortunately, cameras (and chewing gum) were relegated to the inside pockets, so I can't illustrate my experience with pictures. We had the good fortune to make the tour with an excellent tour guide, by the name of Shaun if I remember correctly; this guide spoke "the Queens English" so even as non-native speaker I could understand every word. He was witty and very well informed, so his explanations were very pleasant and instructive and enhanced the tour considerably. We visited the Queen's Robing Room, the House of Lords and the House of Commons. It is really thrilling to be in these places, chock full of tradition. For instance the door between the House of Lords and the House of Commons, which is slammed in the face of the emissary of the House of Lords, when his task is inviting the Commons to the House of Lords for the Queen's Speech, and the indent in the door where he knocks on the door with his baton. Every year the same ritual! One small point of criticism: The groups are a bit close together in the time frame, so overlap can occur when one group is a bit slower than the next group. TripAdvisor friends, I hope I have made you enthusiastic for this tour. If you have the opportunity to obtain tickets, don't miss the occasion. It is worth every penny and then some. At the end of the tour there is a restaurant, where you can get refreshments.

The best attraction in London. To be allowed to visit a place like the Houses of Parliament in London is absolutely fantastic. The tours are on Saturdays when the houses are devoid of politicians. Professional guides take you through the buildings including the House of Lords, and the House of commons. You really feel that you are in a place that has formed, and is forming the history of England and the UK. You need to book the tour in advance.

Very informative. I used the audio tour and found the whole visit very informative.I checked out the location the day prior to my visit and was informed to arrive 1hr earlier than the ticket stated to allow for security. When we arrived the next morning we were too early! told to come back exactly 20mins before our time. No photographs allowed inside the parliament but you can take photographs of the great hall. It took us approx 1hr to go through it all.Nice cafe inside and also good souvenirs shop

Awestruck. Accessibility is great, truly a hall mark of a confident nation. Both it's security and pride in history. Comparable structures in other countries are almost out of view but the Parliament with the light contingent of armed guards is a sign of a vibrant democracy confident in providing security to the citizens and access to MPs.

Fantastic experience. We really enjoyed our visit to the HOP. The tour guides are very well informed and entertaining and manage the needs of all their visitors including those in wheelchairs. Book in advance to avoid the queues.
Interesting visit. The audio tour was informative and lasted just about the right amount of time without you wanting to press the fast forward button. Definitely worth a visit.

Tea at the House of Commons. Loved the venue overlooking the Thames. Quite private and not a huge venue. Felt quite special and was not in a hurry to leave. Th e House of Commons and Lords was also worth a visit.
Interesting Tour. We thoroughly enjoyed the Houses Of Parliament tour. No queuing and a good audio guide. Gift shop a bit expensive.

Not To Be Misses. Very much into the past. History interests me a lot. A pleasure at last to visit inside the Houses of Parliament. At last to stand where Churchill stood & orated & also to stand in footsteps of Kings & Queens of the past 15 & 16 Century. A fascinating & beautiful building. Every citizen should see inside, we payed for it & it is where Our I lives are ruled from. Lots of historical items to see. We were lucky we did not have a guide & could enter each room at our leisure it was like a private viewing. I enjoyed standing in the commons where the the heads of state make their weekly Prime Questions Time & all parties sit, since several hundred years ago. I loved sitting in the House of Lords & actually sat in the Queens chair! An honor! Will not forget this historic visit. If you love history, visit Houses of Parliament, you can not get much nearer to history than this.

A little rushed but well worth it!!. The tour felt very rushed as Parliament was sitting in the afternoon, but what we got to see was very cool, very interesting. I would love to go again with more time to take it all in.
Amazing. So much history , great tour and even got to watch a debate in the chamber! Can't recommend this highly enough

Overrated. We arrived here last month from Brooklyn, NY. Passed by this place while on our two-day trip and thought we'd take a look. What a disappointment! Shoddy exterior design, muddy interior decoration, and no apparent purpose. Totally unfriendly staff carrying guns, what's going on with this place? The Queen live here or something? Would not recommend.

If you love history - go. We went to Houses of Parliament, booked day before travel! Really interesting, much better than we ever expected. Very well organised but can be a bit rushed. We would have liked to look at paintings etc, but you're rushed on which was a shame.Would we go back, yes, one day!
a great visit. a very impressive buildinga great guided tour in French very facts about the two Houses.beautiful roomsa must-do visit
Worth seeing. Its very well organised as you get your time slot and after that it runs smoothly. Unfortunately they dont allow you to sit on the seats and this is a turn off.
You love architecture? Go there. Real history, many architectural Details, a lot to find out if you love architecture, take binoculars are a camera with a 10X zoom.And take your time
Great experience. The building looks great! We where there in great weather and got a lot of great pic😃 we also saw a bride on the bridge😊 absolute got'todo thing!
Houses interesting. We just enjoyed the Houses of Parliament from the perimeter, but it's a lovely collection of buildings.

Better than a history O level. What a great and informative way to spend a few hours. We booked in advance for the £14.00 guided tour. I learnt more about British history in a couple of hours than I did at school. Our guide was so enthusiastic and knowledgeable. We had lunch in the cafe, they do a meal deal for £7.00, a bargain for Central London. A good tip is to use their very clean toilets before you leave, that alone saves you 50p!

Brilliant Tour. Must see tour around the Houses of Parliament but make sure you book in advance. You go thro the Royal rooms, Lords and Commons and Westminster Hall. Tour guides are very knowledgable. Takes about 1.5 hours.Fascinating stuff and great value.A must do!

Lunch on the terraces overlooking the Thames. We did the tour of the House of Lords and the House of Commons. This is a great experience and would recommend to anyone who gets the chance to do it. We finished it off with lunch on the terraces with Lord Graham.

August visit. Really interesting visit to houses of parliament. So much history in one place and really well organised for both British people and tourists who didn't speak English. A day to remember for the rest of your life
Houses of Parliament. Trip around parliament by our MP's secretary was excellent. He showed us the Houses of Commons and Lords. We would recommend a trip to anyone visiting London.
London trip. The age of the entire building and the history it holds. It was as if time had stood still. I love how London's buildings are kept in such grand condition.

Excellent tour !!!!!. What a great tour this is especially for people from this country, to see the actual place where all our political bills & laws are debated. The building itself, is just " Fantastic " and we had a very good guide called Brit, she was very pleasant & knowledgeable, and made the tour very interesting. If you haven't been, it's a " MUST DO ", you won't reget it.
An Excellent Tour. Aside from enjoying the obvious beauty and over-the-top opulence of the building, you will undoubtedly find a tour informative and well worth the price of admission.
Beautiful. By far my favorite building in the world, it's beautiful to look at, fascinating to learn about and interesting when you get to visit.

Pretty cool place, a MUST visit if its your first time in London.. By far, the most iconic part of London, and very interesting place to see on how the government of the UK works. I really find this place historical and very cool, Its understandable that its a guided tour and it can be quite a bit of a wait, yet, the tour guides in the UK are SOOOO entertaining and very witty, I just luv em! Also, its at the heart of where Big Ben is. Another iconic part of London. Overall, LOTS of history and lots of amazing value learned. I had a lot of good memories there.

Wow!. Although the queue was chronic the wait ( about an hour) was worth it, we see just a small part on TV, the splendour of the place is something to behold. The only disappointment was not being allowed to sit on the benches, which as a life long British taxpayer felt a tad unjust, lol! Our tour guide, Alan, was excellent. This was definitely one of the best tours we've done.
Worth it. The tours are timed, well-organized and very interesting. In spite of the numbers of people, the guide was able to give all the details needed. I thoroughly recommend it.

Westminster Palace Mother of Parliament. A tour of the Palace of Westminster is something everybody should do at least once in their life, to walk in the footsteps of the Leaders of our Country. The tour which takes about two hours (and our Guide told us was about a two mile walk) takes in both the Commons and Lords. The wonderful Statues and Paintings and the great stories brings history to life. One thing you are NOT allowed to take photos, and even your phones must be switched off (one of our party even got told off for eating sweets!). It is not the eating it is because sticky hands can mark, plus you are not allowed to sit down, so if you have a problems walking, do not go. The security is very tight, so it takes a bit of time to get in, but all this is worth it just to see this Mother of all Parliament's.

Very informative visit. Visited during the February half-term holiday and it was well worth the £16.50 we paid for a 90 minute tour. You are advised to arrive about 20 minutes before your tour to get through security and,once done, we started bang on time. Our tour guide was really informative witty and knowledgeable. He gave us a great insight into both the history and working of the building which is quite magnificent. The art works are something else. Your local MP can arrange a free visit for you but it is necessary to book well in advance and select a time when parliament is not in recess - difficult as MPs seem to have more holidays than teachers!

Really Excellent. We thoroughly enjoyed this visit . It went to all the parts of the Houses which you see on TV, and the guide was very informative and reallybrought it alive . Thoroughly recommend a visit,you can book via Ticketmaster.Tip - you will be allocated a time for a tour , be early as the quequing to get in is a bit slow, we missed our slot , but they were relaxed about us going on a later tour

Behind the scenes of power. If planning a trip to London, check online to see if the Houses of Parliament will be open to the public during your visit and, if so, book tickets in advance for this terrific tour. The guides are excellent, offering a bounty of historical information and insight into the traditions, rules and rituals of the two houses of Parliament -- the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The interiors are beautiful and evocative, and history comes to life inside. You will definitely understand much more about how Parliament functions after this experience and will have "insider information" in the future when watching news clips of Parliament in session. Make sure to bring a warm coat during cool months because the wait in the entrance hall can be chilly. Remember to leave anything sharp (pen knife, etc.) at the hotel, since you must pass through security before entering.
Very informative. Superb tour conducted by a very good blue badge guide, who explained all of the workings of the building.

a great insight to how parliament works. We picked a rather crowded Saturday to go to visit but it was worth all the queues to see the inside of the Lords and follow the processional route through to the Commons. The history was amazing the paintings and statues brought it all to life. Must go again as there was so much to see and hear that it was sometimes difficult to take it all in

Parliment. Ok it is where the government runs business. The guide's presentation made the experience. Telling the procedures andhow the voting and legislation is presented was interesting. Different than in U.S.

Impressive. When in London last weekend, Parliament was closed to the public, but it's still an impressive view from the outside! Be sure to walk across the bridge and get the Thames in the foreground. Look for the "secret" steps from Parliament down to the water for boat access. If you pay to get on the London Eye, you'll get even more fantastic views of Parliament and all the historic buildings nearby. Be sure to zoom your cameras in for a close-up shot of Big Ben's face. The details are amazing.If you're unable to tour Parliament, you'll only need 15-45 minutes to view the outside from all sides, depending on how long you want to feast your eyes.

Done it at last!. Should have visited the Houses of Parliament years ago. Very interesting indeed. Book the tour, you won't regret it! Well worth the money and the Guide was extremely knowledgeable. You can also get our MP to take you round if you get it organised (but will he know so much?)

Learned a lot!. I learned more about the British government and the history of the UK during the two hour tour than in two semesters of History of Western Civilization! Definitely worth the price of admission!

Best part of our trip. Wonderful experience. Our tour guide was extremely knowledgeable and didn't come across as boring as some guides do. In fact we had a giggle at times and looked to be the only group that was really enjoying the experience. One poor group had an american guide and theirs faces said it all. The building itself is also very beautiful and grand and it would be a real shame to visit London and see inside the Houses.

A London Must. This is definitely well worth a visit .Indeed I think it is suitable for anyone aged 7+. Book in advance and arrive about 20-30 mins before tour as there is a queue for security. It's great to see where it all happens!Very impressive,wish we could have wandered around on our own!

Fab site. There is no need to enter this if you don't wish to as the building itself is wonderful to view. On grass site opposite Westminster is the Nelson Mandella statue wish is also nice to view and remember such a great man. All I would say is I know people of London must get fed up of tourist while trying to get to work but please be patient and try to be little more helpful if you can. You have wonderful city let all enjoy.

Brilliant. Westminster Hall is impressive however once you walk into the Monarch's Robing Room on reflection it seems some what plain. The interiors of the House of Lords are incredible and the Commons debating chamber is fascinating. It took a while to get through security but once inside the wait was more than worth it.

Worth a visit. very enjoyanble learning experience.With all of this type of attraction it is so much better when you have a good guide, and ours was brilliant. She knew all of her history about the buildings, past and present, as well as the main historical characters. It made a change to see behind the scenes of those areas we all see on TV, and to learn how the place works. Tours lasts up to 1.5 hours, just about right.
Fanstastic experience. Very Informative Tour of the House of Commons and was sowelcoming the Tour Guides were amazing and so friendly.Lots to see and do there

How the other half lives!!. I was not fully up for a trip to see we're our "Lords and Masters" rule the roost; being somewhat cynical after the expenses scandal. However once you enter St. George's Chapel where the tour starts, a sense of history takes over and the cynicism goes out of the window.The debating chamber is an eye-opener, as it is really quite a small place. The division lobby's and general precincts of the Houses are very interesting. However, the quality of the Tour Guide was superb and he made the whole trip that much better.

Fantastic experience. Informative walk through the Palace of Westminster - House of Lords, House of Parliament, Great Hall, Robing room, Lobbys and the voting rooms. Guided tour - small numbers - book in advance. Security - airplane style at entrance. Great cafe and toilets inside.

Very enjoyable and interesting. Like most people I have seen the Houses of Parliament on TV, and during prime ministers questions. To see it as first hand was fantastic. We were shown around by a very interesting guide, and I would strongly recommend a visit.

A great trip into the heart of the british politics. A bit of a job just getting in, with thorough safety checks, but that's just how it needs to bee, I guess. Tickets must be purchased in advance.Once inside, we met our most excellent guide Richard which made our tour the mest memorable we have ever had anywhere. He led us trough the most important rooms of the parliament, including the house of commons and house of lords, explaining both the current and historical political systems, making it even more interesting with stories and anecdotes along the way.All in all, this is the best attraction I've been to in London and can highly recommend it.

Very well organised and great guide providing wonderful insight to the goings on in parliament!!. There was quite a lengthy queue however given the numbers visiting quite understandable. We found the guide courteous, informative and very engaging. I would recommend a visit to all!!

Not to be missed. I thought I was a sceptic. After this tour, I will give much more consideration before coming to conclusions.The tour, the building & the statues/pictures etc. were very very impressive.All Brits should definitely do this - & other, I'm sure would find it very interesting.

Well worth a visit. This is a great tour to do for all ages. the building is steeped in history and the guides are really knowledgeable. I have done the tour several time and each time hear something new - you may even get a glimpse of one of the MP's too. Nice facilities and souvenir shop.

A great insight. If you have the time on your trip a tour round the Houses of Parliament is worthwhile. It is very elegant inside and the tour is very educational. It is interesting to see inside the rooms you see regularly on your TV screen.

A must do. This has to be a must do when visiting London. Bought tickets via Ticketmaster and printed them at home. Airport style security to enter, as expected, but this is handled very quickly and very professionally with hardly any queuing time.The guides are excellent, informative and always willing to answer questions. The history of the buildings is as amazing as the beauty of the buildings themselves.Quite surreal standing in the chambers and understanding who does what and when during sessions. We would highly recommend a visit. Wouldn't mind having this location as my place of work! :-)

Spectacular rooms interesting politics. Get your tickets a day or two ahead as this is very popular. Security check is a long line & no nonsense. You wait in another line as you are divided into groups that are manageable with a very interesting guide. Beautiful works of art, sculpture and little known facts make up this MOST interesting of tours. House of Lords & commons are rich in color and history. Interesting facts about the speaker and the queens visits. A most beautiful of places with stunning architecture. LOVED this!
Beautiful and mandatory.. It's impossible to spend any time in London as a tourist without going to see the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben.. Worth taking a look at after dark too!

A Must Visit. We went as part of my study abroad group. The building a beautiful and just screams "history is made here!" You get to see everything that you'd want to see in the building (unlike other tours of government buildings) and don't feel like you've missed out on anything.The guide we had was spectacular and they definitely tailor the tour based on how much or little you know about UK politics and history.

A great thrill. The guide was very knowledgable and the tour was fascinating and a great experience. We couldn't see the House of Lords as that was in session which was a pity but seeing the House of Commons was terrific.
must see. Fantastic architecture didn't realise how big it was. Shame couldn't go inside but still the views especially at night were lovely.

Really interesting visit.. This was a free visit, organised by contacting your MP and essentially getting them to invite you along. We did, however, have a couple of Austrian visitors on our tour, so there are other ways of doing it. There were about 10 people on our tour, with a knowledgeable, if slightly biased, guide. We saw the Queen's throning room, several meeting rooms and the chambers of the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The tour lasted about an hour and a half. You do not get to see Big Ben, if that is interesting to you. I think it is an essential visit if you are in London. Our trip was in school half term, meaning that the Houses were not in session. This has a downside that you do not see any famour people, but on the other hand, you do get to see both Houses from the inside.

public gallery. Went to the House of Parliament to observe a public session. Very interesting. But the Lord's House is more interesting then the Commons! More nice for the eyes. This visit is for free while guided tours trough the magnific building demand tickets (16£)

Amazing!. If you just spend your time crossing Westminster bridge and walking between Embankment, Westminster and Waterloo tube station, you'd spend some really good time. The area is live and the architecture and buildings are amazing. Beware of the people inviting you to play "where is the ball" game on the Westminster bridge :) I don't play such games, but I got astonished of those being fooled.

Great experience. Did guided tour of House of Lords and Commons. I really enjoyed experience and the guide Colin was very good. Amazing to see inside and well worth doing Great value for money as tour lasts 90 mins. Would highly recommend.

Fascinating. I so enjoyed seeing behind the scenes. A shame that the visit didn't allow longer for us to look at some areas but it was an absolutely unmissable experience that we will remember for a very long time.

One of the first images that springs to mind when you think of London. Often one of the first images that springs to mind when you think of London, the House of Parliament which rests upon the banks of the River Thames in Westminster. Also referred to as the Palace of Westminster, this is an incredibly popular attraction alongside the Elizabeth Tower and the historic and important Westminster Abbey found just behind the Palace. The House of Parliament was built between 1840-1870 after its predecessor was destroyed by fire in 1834. It is a lovely building, with an elaborate Gothic style exterior and it is a beautiful building to see up close. However, for better pictures, it is best to put a bit of distance between yourself and the Palace. We particularly enjoy views from across the River Thames where you can see the Palace building clearly with the river in the foreground. At dusk, the House of Parliament is lit by floodlights, allowing it to radiate against the skyline. This continues through the night and views of the building are from across the river as well as the entire walk towards across Westminster Bridge as you approach the Palace building. Obviously, views from the London Eye capsules are quite impressive as well. Visits to the Parliament Building can be arranged for overseas visitors on Saturdays and weekdays when Parliament isn't in session. Refer to the Parliament website for details. When visiting, its also worth your time to make a quick visit to Parliament Square, which boasts many statues and monuments to important historic figures. You will also want to visit the impressive Westminster Abbey as well. Collectively, this makes a great way to spend 2-3 hours in London before moving onto other areas.

Absolutely amazing. If you don't do anything else when you go to London a must do is a visit to he Houses of Parliament . The best £16.50 that you will spend. Granted that the security takes time so if you have a three thirty tour like us get there at least half an hour before. Access is available to all and tour guides in various languages. This iconic building is steeped in history and stories dating back a thousand years. The 75 minute tour, taken by an excellent guide, starts in the 900 year old Westminster hall and along the route taken by the queen on the opening of parliament. Go through the royal gallery , view the portrates and statues of past monarchs and prime ministers etc as you wind your way into the central and members lobby. See where all the action and debates take place between politicians and the lords chambers. The tours run throughout the day and if you are going book online it's a lot easy. As stated earlier This tour offers a unique look into 1,000 years of history and is a must.

Fascinating building and beautiful artwork, etc.. I have taken students form school on educational tours several times now. The building is amazing, the artwork and sculptures, etc. are endless and I the knowledgeable tour guides are happy to answer questions, etc. Highly recommended... everyone should visit (especially the Brits). School's visits are free but need to be booked well in advance through the education service. Public tours available from Westminster Hall.

Great visit. Everyone must visit the Houses of Parliament when ever in London, to see where the decisions in Government are made.Great tours explaining everything...the gift shop is small and so is the cafe.But well worth a visit.
History. Everyone should have to visit this wonderful place. What secrets it could tell . Whether we would be pleased with the information is anybody's guess but what a place !

What a fantastic building.. Went on a guided tour price was £16.50, I gave been to London many times and have walked around the outside of the building many times as well, but this year I decided it was time to go inside and view the interior. The building is simply superb, so hard to believe that most of it only dates from the mid 19th century and the House of Commons itself from the mud 20th century, although of course the original Palace was there much earlier. The guide did seem to be knowledgeable but spent a lot of time explaining how parliament works, which if you are an informed UK citizen you should know already. However I appreciate that the tour has to be pitched at a wide audience some of whom are overseas visitors. Not enough time to look at all of huge artworks, the walls are adorned with so much symbolism. I will definitely be booking again for the tour of the art of the House of Lords. The tour did feel a little rushed to be quite honest. Did catch your guide telling the group that Charles I was beheaded at the Tower of London! I knew this to be untrue and shook my head at him and caught his eye and mouthed "Whitehall, Banqueting House" and he quickly corrected himself. Makes me wonder what else he may have said that was incorrect! My husband and I had afternoon tea in the Pugin Room after our your and this was a lovely way to finish off our visit and fave us time to appreciate a little more of this wonderful building. I would recommend that people visit thus wonderful building as what you see on TV does not do it justice.
What a historic and magnificent building!. The guided tour is excellent! I was able to attend a public hearing questioning session, each romos and hall have a secret history.

Well worth a visit to this iconic building. We had pre booked a tour for Saturday afternoon, and arrived 15 mins before our allotted slot as instructed, but we then had to queue for a further 35 mins to go through security because the rain meant visitors had more coats and brollies to scan!!Despite this annoying start our guide was superb. She explained the history with real enthusiasm and brought the whole pagent alive.Following the foot steps of the queen into the House of Lords and then continuing on into the House of Commons where the queen is not allowed was intriguing.We were told only elected MP's can sit on the Green Benches, so resisted the temptation to break the rules!After seeing both Houses on television it was great to actually be walking along the passages in this truly iconic building.
Listen toParliamentary Debates in Action. What a magnificent building. Imposing, moving and full of history.A great life experience. ...Plus an excellent Cafe off the magnificent ancient Great Hall.

front seat view!!. try lining up for free entry, we were only in the queue for a short while, then ushered in to the peoples' gallery. What a thrill, to be watching British parliament as it happened, and taking in the surroundings, a rare privilege, and so well organised.

Visit to the seat of power in the UK. This facinating building was brought to life by our guide who normally worked as a Hansard Reporter. Just the fact that you were able to be in the Lords Chamber and the Commons brought to life all those news reports from the seat of government in the United Kingdom. Every citizen should approach their MP and get a sponsored visit to the entire Palace of Westminster at least once in their life. This is an awe inspiring building with its vast history and every day use. Truly a jewel in the UK crown.
Impressive. We loved our visit here and the story of this place full of great history, told by the guide. Would visit again, it is a must!

An interesting visit. We had an excellent tour of this great establishment, our guide was very informative and the security staff were very pleasant, treating us as friends, not suspects, though security was very tight it was a very pleasant tour, thank you.

Very rude and condescending tour guide. The inside of the houses of parliament are spectacular as is the information about this beautiful old building. However, here is what happened the day we went.... We arrived promptly, twenty minutes before our allotted time at 2.15pm as requested. We stood out in the cold miserable weather as the searches were conducted and then were shepherded into the main hall, where we had to wait a further half an hour before the tour started. This already was a problem as we had already been standing motionless for nearly an hour with yet another hour and half tour to come! The second aspect, was, after watching other tour guides, I found our particular tour guide very rude. She talked down to us, we felt like naughty school children, her facial expressions told the story that it was all just too much trouble for her and we were a major inconvenience. Everyone was totally silent on the tour, never daring to ask a question and she even told some people off as they 'stood' in the wrong place! I was so busy trying to follow her barked orders that I didn't concentrate as I should have. I was worried, should my husband fall behind a little, not walking quickly, he would be the next one in the firing line. Having paid an admission fee, I did not expect this sort of behaviour and to be quite honest, it would deter me from recommending the tour in case anyone got this lady. Sad really!
Expensive but worth every penny.. The security is extremely tight, but that is completely understandable. Our guide was clear and thorough. Every room that we saw was an eye dazzler.

A great icon. The Houses of Parliament stand proud along the bank of the Thames, along wide Big Ben, a great sight, especially when on a sunny day. I particularly like seeing them lit-up in the evening, along with the clock faces of Big Ben.

Public Gallery. Good experience listening to a debate. Try to catch the Speaker entering with his entourage! Jubilee Cafe serves excellent food at reasonable prices. Gift shop selling interesting items.
Where It All happens. A well guided tour around the most important rooms. A superb guide and a logical tour route. An opportunity to go in the Chambers was welcome.
Bury South MP Visit. Excellent security and excellent treatment once inside.Staff are courteous and attentive, atmosphere and ambience first class as well as the company

Wow!. We combined a visit to Big Ben with the Houses of Parliament what a great experience it certainly had the WOW factor! You need to be fit to climb all the steps inside Big Ben but the guide does stop at intervals to give you a breather and some history. To walk around the inside face and watch the bell chime was amazing. The lords and Parliament were spectacular. Why wasn't history as interesting as this at school. The guides were truly first class. We had a truly memorable experience!

A must to appreciate how great England is. Our trip was organised by our friend's MP and walking through all the various rooms including the House of Lords, the House of Commons, the Robing Room and other rooms we really appreciated what a special and awe inspiring building this was. The architecture, art, statues and furniture were fabulous, especially the beautiful encaustic tile flooring and all this was bought alive by our wonderful guide, Cliff, who was so full of knowledge it left us all in total wonderment of him. It was definitely too much to take in on one visit so we will definitely go again. It made us very proud to be British.

A great experience. After all these years of seeing the houses of parliament on the TV, and when you walk around London we finally booked a tour which is on a Saturday as the house is not sitting. We wish we had done it years ago, obviously the security checks are strict to get you in just like traveling on an aeroplane if not more thorough. It puts into perspective all those little pieces you see on the TV. Our guide (Tim) was extremely knowledgeable; it took just over an hour and a half so you need good shoes as sitting is very limited. The tour starts and ends in the great hall where the Queen Mother laid in state. You go into the House of Lords and House of Commons, the pictures and architecture are splendid and the grandeur of the monarch's seat in the House of Lords is breath-taking. Overall a true reflection of countries great political heritage and democratic process. We wish we had booked afternoon tea just to round it off and would do so next time, however we visited the coffee shop and had a small coffee latte for two pounds each and did not think that was too bad, water is available free of charge as are the toilets. Also if you have children you can buy a pencil for 60p so should not break the bank. To ascend the tower where big ben is housed you need to make a prior request to your MP, which we intend to do.
Historic. We were shown round by generous MP an we learnt so much. Spectacular. Just and earful experience. Bit chilly. Wear a coat.

Seriously it should be a compulsory visit for everyone!!. Well what is not to like? It's fabulous history,amazing architecture,inspirational art and very educational. We've been 3 times - different guests! I learn more every time and am not yet tired of seeing it all and listening to the marvellously knowledgable guides.
historic. we contacted our MP who arranged for us to actually go around inside both houses and other rooms pictures and statues and friezes were fascinating a great history lesson
historical. it is a lovely place espesially for tourists who are visiting London it is lovely place and people love it because the story of Guyfakes and other lovely accations that have happend there

A lot of history. I went to the house of parliament for a Camber of Commerce reception, but while I was there I couldn't resist a small tour of the place. The houses of parliament are very large and well kept. There is a lot of history and interesting facts about the Houses of Parliament I would love to mention, but I don't have the space here.I would recommend you take a visit - but expect airport style security and armed guards around.

Outstanding on every level.. Few buildings in the world come anywhere near to the wow factor of this one. Steeped in history, this is a must do for anyone with an interest in politics, history or democracy. For me, there were two points etched in memory - the central lobby still shows the evidence of bomb damage from a Luftwaffe air raid which Churchill forbid the restorations from: he wanted all future generations like me and you to see how near democacy came to being usurped by fascism. Second, see the despatch table still showing the signs of damage from Churchill's signet ring as his fist hit the table during his speeches in Britain's darkest hours.This outstanding must-see attraction is free, but you must arrange visits through your local MP and you'll need to plan well in advance, but I promise that you'll never forget the time you spent here.

Very interesting. The tour can be taken in several languages (English of course, German, Italian, Spanish...I don't remember what else...). It takes about 90 minutes. I'd recommend to arrive some 30 minutes ahead of your scheduled time - the security there is, I guess, stricter than at an airport. You are taken to both House of Lords and House of Commons and are explained in detail their work, habits and cooperation. I am not greatly interested in politics however our tour guide gripped my full attention and I found the tour highly interesting. As the group size is strictly limited to 20 people, there are no problems with seeing and hearing everything well and ask the guide as much as you need :)No photo taking allowed inside.

Terrace treats. As long as you wangle an invitation from an MP, you can wine and dine on the Terrace - one of the best views from any London bar. Don't be afraid of asking - after all, it's your taxes which subsidise the food and drink. Also fun to watch them at "work" from the public gallery.

Highly recommend this tour. I would arrive at least 35 minutes before the tour commences as it takes some time to get through security. There are a number of tours occurring at this time so it's a bit hectic. We had a wonderful lady guide who informed us all there is to know in 1.5 hrs. We could not believe we got to visit both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Well worth a visit the next time you are in London.

Knowledgeable guides make this a Must Do!. After several trip to London, I was finally there on a Saturday and was able to take the tour of the Houses of Parliament. There are tours offered in several languages as well as English and the staff does a great job of moving the groups in and out of a limited space efficiently.The guides are obviously top notch. They know their material, give a well-paced and interesting tour that leaves you satisfied. The tour is a good length -- 75 minutes, not too long and not too short. You won't be bored.I second previous reviewers suggestions to buy tickets online ahead of time and leave a good 20+ minutes to get through security.
Excellent value for money. Could not fault the visit. Extremely informative, excellent guide and well worth the money. Would certainly recommend.

Saturday Tours for non-UK nationals. You can book a tour for GBP 16.50 at the website shown above. Tours for non-UK nationals are only on Saturdays, and leave every 15 minutes. You begin the tour at the entrance which is closest to Westminster Abbey. Note that you must have a physical ticket printed out in order to get into the security line for a TSA-type check. (if you only have the reservation on your phone, you must go back across the street to get your physical ticket).Tours are like a well-oiled machine, and are conducted in many languages. Photographs are only allowed in the first, entrance hall. Tours are about 90 minutes (but also allow time for the security check before your tour ticket time). A cannot recommend this tour enough. You truly feel as if you are in the heart of the British nation. The interiors, particularly those in/around the House of Commons, are a gothic extravaganza.  I took a tour near the end of the day in late January, and would perhaps recommend a tour earlier in the day when there is more light. There are so many details to see, and in the winter's gloom, it's a bit hard to pick as many things out as you might like.At the end of the tour there's a bit of a gift shop where you can get amusing coffee mugs, and also a tea room: tea and a scone for 5 pounds.

Not to miss. This station list a few site that is worth a visit.House of Parliament, London Eye, Big Ben & the Westminster bridge are all situated quite close to each other. Light up at night are charming.

Fantastic access all areas tour. Could not believe that we got to go into the actual chambers and even stand by the dispatch box used by the PM! Really recommend this tour to all. And a very informative and friendly guide too.

First class tour.. Avoid the q's by buying entrance tickets in advance. Security is similar to airport security so be prepared and allow time for this. A stimulating visit accompanied by an excellent guide. Fascinating historical insights incorporating the Commons, the Lords, the Queens robing rooms, throne, and Westminster Hall. Highly recommend the visit which is well worth the 13 pound fee.

A fantastic history tour. We booked this trip through our local MP so it was free. After going through the airport-like security check-in and being given our passes we arrived at Westminster Hall (incidently it is very cold in the waiting area). Worked was being carried out in the meeting place so there was scaffolding about but it is still an interesting area with a cafe and toilets and gift shop. Our tour guide was very informative. I learnt more in the hour and half about the history of our country and parliament than I ever did in history lessons at school. The tour takes you to the House of Commons, The House of Lords and the Queens dressing room.The thing that amazed us most was how small the House of Commons is. It really is a fascinating place. We saw quite a few MP's and Peers and if you are in the building at around 11.27am you get to see the procession into the House of Commons when the Mace is taken in. The Speaker of the House is in the procession. If you wish to go on this tour for free you need to book months in advance with your local MP or a member of the Lords. (Check Houses of Parliament tour website for all the details and how to find who is your MP)

Great tour. Very informative and interesting. I learned a lot about the British system of government as well as the history and traditions, and the guide made everything so entertaining! Definitely recommended. Book online ahead of time!

Steeped in History. Decided to go on this tour on the off chance, so could not get a slot till 3.30 in the afternoon. So booking in advance is strongly recommended. You are also advised to turn up 20 minutes before your entry time as there is a Airport style search of bags and possessions. Once in side you are greeted in the large Westminster Hall, which has a cafe, toilets and a small gift shop. You are then directed into your slot for your tour. Around 20 people where in our group but the guide was clear and we could always hear his commentary. I will not go on as the place has to be seen to believed but suffice to say ,i do not think anyone will be disappointed with the tour and the palace.Questions are encouraged as well. Only downside as always with these attractions was the entry price. Still highly recommended.

A definite must for every London visitor. I've been here at least 4 times now over the last few years and it will always get my vote as the most entertaining day out ever. Every time I've been time has been a new experience and I've learnt something new on each occasion. From the reason we have a man dressed in tights to knock on the door each time parliament is opened, to the commemorative plaque that Tony Benn placed in a broom cupboard so many questions are answered about British individuality that I go away with even more questions to bring back! Love it

Accessible Real entertainment. Parliament in the UK is run different from Congress in the United States. Most of the time there is active give and take and it is very entertaining and informative to watch the process. There is an upstairs visitor's gallery, screened off by glass but nonetheless very close to the action. In low tourist season there are no lines and you can come and go as you please - just no pictures or cell phones in the gallery.

have a look at Pariament. On a recent visit to London we looked to see if we could go on a tour of the Houses of Parliament, yes you can and if the house is sitting you can go in for free. You can have a look at both the House of Lords and the House of Commons and sit and watch the debates, it is very interesting. Security is very strict and thorough but get through that and have a look round. Not sure how much it is for a tour or what you get to see, but well worth a visit.

If you can, sit in on a session of Parliament. Even when tours are not available, if Parliament is sitting (at least the House of Commons, not sure about the Lords), you can get access to the interior of the building and be fascinated by the debate of the day. A high point of our trip to London and it was free! Note that security is vert strict so be prepared for a pat down and plan some time to get through.

Amazing historic building. I have been here on business on a few occasions now and never seem to be amazed by this historic building. It is stunning from the inside and outside and full of history. Some of the best views are from the river. An amazing must see attraction

Wonderful guide. Had bought tickets online in advance and did not have to pick up tickets in the ticket box. The security check is however tougher than at any airport, so arrive early to avoid beeing late for your slot time. The building is wonderful, and we had an amazing guide - knowledgable and with a great sense of humor. 75 well spent minutes in London!

Really loved this!. The tour is excellent but it is also very quick paced. Wear your walking shoes. We had some people that were having trouble keeping up. It's quite cool because you get to sit in the seats of the MP's and see a lot of behind the scenes type of locations. It's a beautiful building.

Even great just to admire from outside... First time in London, time was limited so I had to plan carefully. I understand seeing is different than experiencing and that was ok. On this occasion I chose to rather see than experience. Myself and my wife are not too particular with tours, and with limited time I knew we could not fit it into our already busy itinerary. If you are similar, don't fret, just being here and admiring the Houses of Parliament is a delight. Yes you've seen it many times on TV, and now you can soak it in that you are actually standing in front of it. Take lots of photos. You are now in London! It's a nice walk to see the architecture, and people watch, and you are close to a lot of other attractions. Take the tube, experience London that way at least. If you have time, and maybe if I ever get to visit again, I'll consider a tour. This is a must if it's your first time in London, and usually you won't miss it because Big Ben and other attractions are around the corner.

Guided Tour. Highly recommended. The tour guide was extremely knowledgable and the hour and a quarter absolutely flew by. I would have loved to have been able to spend more time in each room and would be happy to go on the tour again.

A London must see!. The guided tour is a fantastic experience, in which one can get to learn about the history of the UK and its politics. Our guide was very gentle and helpful. We got to visit all the main sites of the building, followed by the interesting explanations by the guide. Would surely recommend it for everybody visiting London.

A superb guided tour. I booked us onto a guided tour of Westminster encompassing the House of Lords and the Houses of Parliament. As a regular visitor to London, we have exhausted all the usual museums and tourist attractions and I was looking for something different. I cannot recommend this tour enough. It was absolutely superb. It is breathtakingly beautiful inside and I spent much of the tour open mouthed at the sheer beauty and history of the place. It made me feel incredibly proud to be British. The tour guide pitched everything perfectly - informative and interesting yet accessible and humorous. I am so pleased I booked this tour. To find yourself stood where the great and the good (and the not so good) have stood is awe inspiring. Worth every penny for the opportunity to visit this iconic building.

Within the sound of Big Ben. In 2013 I attended a re-union dinner in the Members' Dining
Room, but that was eclipsed by the entire ambience of the various corridors and rooms of political power acquired from centuries
of briallian political minds of the day. "Cometh the hour comeht
the man". Be prepared to wait for a good half hour due to security checks.

Houses of Information. We booked the tour following recommendations on Tripadvisor and were not disappointed. It had never really appealed to me as I don't know a great deal about history or politics. However, this is a very interesting tour that doesn't require any prior knowledge. Our tour guide, William, was enthusiastic, knowledgeable and informative, which really made it an enjoyable experience! I'm not sure that this is a good tour for children as it lasts about 80 minutes and there is a lot of standing and listening with very strict rules about not touching. Well worth the cost for adults though. Do get there early as security checks took about 15 minutes to get through - the most friendly yet efficient team I have come across though!
I am a fan of politics and history.. ive always loved learning about the history and politics of our country. great place to take the children to teach them a few things.

Informative guide and a good value tour. This visit was a bit of a last minute idea, but we're glad we did it. The guide was informative and friendly, and the tour itself took in all the main areas. The tour involves a fair bit of walking and standing, but nothing excessive. Worth a visit if you're in the area.

An unexpected gem!. I booked this tour more out of curiosity. I really didn't know what to expect but was delightfully surprised. What a beautiful and historic building complex. It was quite magical to walk around those halls, imagining the people and decisions that had been made in history. For the small admission price, this is a must see attraction.
Always great to see... It is a busy corner, at the houses of Parliament, and much security (well warranted), but nice to visit and take pictures.

Nice!. Nice short tour, it was very helpful to finally get a logical explanation of how the houses work, our guide Nigel was wonderful. The gift shop could be better, the ticket pick up is kind of messy, and security is VERY tight.

Very worth doing. As a UK resident we've been passed this building many times in our times in London - so glad we did the tour. The guide made it so interesting, she was lovely. Learned a lot of things I didn't know about what goes on in that lovely old building too.

Worth a visit if you can get in. I arranged a visit through a British MP and took a school group. I understand that you can join a tour through an office near Westminster Abbey. The tour takes in the House of Lords and the House of Common and variety of galleries. It starts in the Great Hall (which is amazing in its own right). Last time I was there, there was a gift kiosk near the Great Hall and there is a shop over the road near Westminster tube station.

A glimpse into Parliament. We have all maybe looked at the building from the outside lots of times but what is it really like on the inside. Well this tour lasting 75mins and available on a Saturday gives a great insight into the building and to see the stunning interiors in all their glory. Truly memorable and for a reasonable cost. The route through the buildings follow the route the Queen takes when Parliament is opened. What did strike me was the size of the debating chambers. They seem so much smaller than when they are viewed at home on T.V. AuroraUK

Best trip in London. Having been brought up in London but moved away I hadn't realised you could visit this attraction but wow this is one of the best. We had a fantastic guide Tony who brought the seat of Parliament to life...a great trip and we'll be doing it again.

Brilliant experience. Lucky enough to have a friend who works in parliament so got to see the politicians in action whilst they were live on TV. I believe 'normal folk' can only get tours on the weekends, but it is definitely worth a visit.
fascinating tour. We had a private tour of the Houses of Parliament (arranged through our MP). That was most informative. The meal was fine, value for money but nothing special.

Amazing...so different from American system.. Get tickets ahead...Question timen ot in session over this visit but we did go last time, few years ago, and it was amazing. British political system so different from American and those wigs....

Tour really interesting. A lot of standing, and it takes a while but some of the detail inside is excellent. I loved it, and all the history...wow. REALLY tight security on going in, like going on a plane. Carry so much as a pen knife and you will be arrested....Our guide (Colin I think) was amazing...AND he was so good it made me think one not so good could spoil it......maybe.

Tour guide made this tour very enjoyable. Like most of London this area was very crowded for an early morning but the tour guide was very adept at giving history and information with enthusiasm. This tour offered both historical and current information. I would definitely recommend this tour.

Visiting here was a great thrill. It was not surprising that you have to go through pretty stiff security to visit, but once inside you know it's worth it. The building is beautiful, and though the speeches we observed were the usual stuff, the subjects discussed gave us more insight into current issues in the UK, very interesting. We were also intrigued about the similarities and differences between the way the US and the UK make laws these days. Highly educational and entertaining experience for any history or political science enthusiast.

Houses of History. If the tour is organised by your M.P. it is free (always a bonus) but worth the entrance fee regardless. Strict security is comforting rather than daunting. The tour guides are extremely knowledgeable, full of great, true stories and are open to being quizzed. They aim their commentary at all age groups so good for families, groups or couples. The place itself is awe inspiring and full of British history and heritage. The house of commons is smaller than appears on tv. The house of lords is bigger and more sumptuously decorated. The tour finishes where it started in Westminster hall, the only area cameras are allowed and where our Queen will lie in state. There is also a souvenir shop in here (a bit pricey) but all profits go towards the busts and statues on display of the great and good and also free toilet facilities.
A wonderful sight how ever many times you might see it.. Incredible and beautiful architecture, fabulous history, what's not to love ? The police guarding the place are friendly and helpful.

Historically awesome!. My 16 year old son and I were walking past the houses of parliament and he suggested we went in, I did'nt think we could but we walked straight in, no queue and sat in the visitors gallery of both houses, the Commons and the Lords. amazing to be there where so many great me and women spoke and made history changing decisions, really a great moment for me. having said that I thought the Lords have a nicer place, better class of decoration! A bishop was speaking in his clerical robes, all done as it aught to be! we spoke with a man at the information desk about a realtion from the past who was an MP and he was very helpful and friendly. The great hall had plaques hwere the royalty had been laid out after they died and where Mandela spoke etc. well worth a visit for history buffs.

Corner stone of our nations history. Went on a tour of the whole grounds through the Houses of Commons and the Houses of Lords and the select committee chambers and it was all very inspiring and engaging. It brings 400 years of British History to life

A Must see, quite beautiful. Living in England and getting to see a great deal of what the country has to offer, this ranks right up there with the best. Physically seeing the history and where they make their governmental decisions is even cooler than going to Congress in America. Smaller yes, but so much more history and depth. Don't pass it up.

Excellent guided tour. I last visited the Palace of Westminster over 50 years ago when, after waiting in a long queue, one only obtained a seat in the public gallery. What an improvement now! With timed tickets booked online, we were admitted directly to historic Westminster Hall, from which our guided tour set off without delay.The tour was very comprehensive indeed, and since Parliament was not in session, it included entry to both the Lords and Commons Chambers. Our guide was most knowledgeable and gave us an interesting and entertaining account of the history of the building and the workings of the UK political system.

Informative and engaging. Great tour guides that talk with good knowledge & interest. You get to go into both the House of Lords and Commons, and see many interesting areas of this impressive historical building. Surprising just how small the House of Commons is! Tour doesn't feel rushed, and certainly worth the money.

Much better than expected. The Houses of Parliament tour far exceeded my expectations. Apparently 10,000 pass through the HOP on a typical Saturday, and I can see why. I would highly recommend this to anybody with even a vague interest in Parliament - and I would imagine children (from about 10) would enjoy it too. As you might expect there is quite extensive security, so get there before your tour time to allow for this. The tour passes through the Crown room, and both chambers (we hadn't expected to see the House of Lords from the description, we expected just to see the Commons). Photos are not allowed except for in Westminster Hall (which some visitors might remember from the Queens Jubilee banquet that was on TV). Tour lasts about an hour and 10 mins, and you will be standing most of that time. The shop doesn't sell anything remarkable, and the cafe is no more expensive that you might expect from a visitor attraction in central London.

Highlight of Our London Trip. When I booked the guided tour online, I wasn't sure if my 11-year-old daughter and 17-year-old son would like it. It turned out that it was 2 of the highlights of our 1-week-stay in London. Nigel, our tour guide was very knowledgable and enthusiastic about the politics, history and the tour itself. Thanks to him, we all found the tour very interesting, informative and comprehensive, can't imagine anyone could do a better job than him!
Couldn't get inside. Beautiful on the outside, we weren't able to get inside when we were there. It is a remarkable piece of architecture and a memorable attraction. Pictures do not do it justice.

Really interesting. Very interesting and well organised guided tour, well worth the visit.I would have liked to have more time on my own at certain spots along the way but security is EXTREME so you're simply not allowed to fall behind, go ahead or touch anything...or photograph anything for that matter which was a real shame. Still recommended.

Nice to update your info about political British style. Was a nice tour through which I've got to know more about making laws and kings' mistresses from our lovely guide! No pictures allowed through entire visit.
Guided Tours -. In you are in London during the summer, book tickets in advanced for the guided tours.It is a must go for those who like history and enoy going beyond the plain sightseeing.
Informative. As a history and social studies buff I really enjoyed this attraction. The tour was a great way to learn about government in the United Kingdom and the parliament buildings themselves.

Interesting. Booked the tour online during visit to london over the New Year holidays. Parliament was in recess so managed to see many interesting areas. Security extremely strict, which is understandable. You cannot take photos and not allowed to sit within lords or commons areas. Our time slot was last of the day and did feel we were being rushed through, considering we paid same price as everyone else, I was not too happy.
must see. What a wonderful opportunity to visit the heart of rule for the British isles. If you enjoy history, politics, and world events, then this is a must see during your time in London.
Historical walks. Classic London attraction, full of history and legend. A must see, best time at noon, so one can listen to the Big Ben chime as well!

One of the best tours all week!. Our college aged kids were not too excited about this tour but it ended up being one of our favorite things of the week. Our tour guide was excellent. We did this tour on our last day and she really pulled together all the little bits of history we had been experiencing all week. Seeing the Queen's chambers, and the Houses of Lords and Commons was fascinating. There is significant but not overwhelming security. Be prepared to have your photo taken and airport like security screening. All moved efficiently. Tours available in many languages. Best tip... eat in the little cafe in the basement. The area around Big Ben and Parliament was teeming with people and hard to get in any where to eat so this little cafe was a calm oasis.
Great to see. These are some wonderful buildings in central London. They will leave you wondering what happens behind the walls and what history they have seen. Great for photo opportunities.
Seeing a Bit of History. This is a "must see" in London, even if you just get to walk up and see it close. The view of "Big Ben" in the evening is breathtaking.

Great insight into the workings of our parliament. When I told our kids we were going on this tour, they were not pleased, would rather shop. But afterwards, they all said they were glad they had done it. We all found it really interesting and it was great standing in the rooms we see so often on the news on the telly. If you are in London on a Saturday or when they are doing this tour in the holidays, I would recommend trying to book it.
excellent. This is a tourist dream.The design of the building inside and out is worth the visit. If you get a chance--visit.

Most interesting. If you have any interest in history, this is a must! Seeing the chambers of the House of Commons and the House of Lords, while listening to stories of important deliberations is fascinating.

Houses of Parliament. I find every time I visit London, I love to go here. Even for someone who visits London regularly, it is a great place to visit, and take pictures, tourists, from UK and abroad should definitely have this on their to-do list of things to see.
Excellent experience. Very interesting tour - well worth doing. It lasted about 75 minutes. We were in a group of 15 people and the guide was excellent.

The seat of Government. It is a tour like no other and made me rather envious of those that work there. A cliche though this is you can smell the history as you walk through the rooms, which envelopes you and is truly wonderful. The guide was an expert and told you all you need to know .. We saw a debate in the Commons which was very interesting. The shop wasn't that exciting but hey that's no problem, although a tourist from say the U.S.A might like to take home a mug, one person's ordinary gift is another's memory of a great place to go. Go!!

Gorgeous Exterior. This is one of the best known facades in Europe. It does not disappoint. We did not go inside as the Parliament was shut down for most of our visit for the Christmas holidays. Make sure that you go during the day and during the night to see both sides of the building. We got the best pictures from the across the river near the London Eye.
Amazing. This is a tourist dream.The houses of parliament was stunning. I enjoyed it tremendously and will definitely recommend to all try to go early as it does become busy later in the day.

I liked it!. The building itself is impressive - and touring it is well worth the money! The only thing is, you have to buy your tickets from a ticket office located in another building nearby. And then, you have to queue and pass an airport-style screening... tours (you must choose one, preferably in your language) begin at Westminster Hall, the oldest part of the palace; make sure you get there at least 20 minutes earlier.This said, our Italian-language guide (Max) was very knowledgeable and seeing the lavish interiors of the palace (among them the House of Lords and the House of Commons) was a great experience. Pity you can't visit the Big Ben, though!

An absolute must!. I am interested in the goings on in parliament, but have never visited until this week. We had booked on line and arrived at our designated time slot, and passed quickly through security and into Westminster Hall, where our guide greeted us and explained the format for the visit. She was very informative and interesting, and certainly kept everyone (about twenty in our group) fully engaged. The tour takes you through the state rooms and into both the Lords and Commons chambers (no sitting on the benches or banging the despatch box though!!), palces I had only seen on TV before.This was a fascinating and worthwhile visit, very informative, and good value. The guided part of the tour lasts about 75 minutes.
Houses of Parliament. You see the London's houses of Parliament in pictures all the time, but in person they are amazing! The size and detail is extraordinary!

Peak into GB's history. Had to go through security and about 30 minutes in the line to get into the Parliament House, once there everything has to be done with a tour guide and no photograph was allowed once inside, so not much freedom to browse around or to go at my own pace.The parliament house offered a great opportunity to peak into the history of democracy and Britain's history, the tour guide was very helpful and well resourced to explain the history and significance of the place to the crowd, it was a shame that no photo was allowed inside. The admission was a little overpriced for the short amount of time and the tour was a little rushed.

Historic Tour of UK Government. Well worth the wait and money--to see how parliament works and the insight from the good tour guides, was a hight point of our London Trip. The design of the building inside and out is worth the visit. If you get a chance--visit.

A highlight of our trip. We booked tickets online which was easy. You print them out and bring them w/ you. The building is remarkable. Our tour guide did a great job of explaining the architecture and great insights into the House of Lords and House of Commons. I only wish they allowed pictures to be taken!

Worth Doing. I have been here a number of times on work business, but wanted to do the real tour with my mother. It is absolutely fascinating, and just so great to be inside this awesome building. Definitely a highlight for me on what to see and do in London.
Impressive. Not enough spots to get good pics from outside west minister. With the houses in session, was not allowed in. But well, worth a looks for a few minutes

Terrific!. This was the highlight of our trip to London - a beautiful historic building (where history continues to be made!) It was brought to life by our tour guide, who did a terrific job providing background and history for a multi-national crowd and who was terrific with the well-behaved 4 year old on the tour.There's so much to see and do in London that this might not come to mind - if you find yourself in London on a Saturday, highly recommend that you take this tour. You can buy tix ahead of time online or get while there (that's what we did - we lucked out as lines weren't long and we got into tour with only a 30 minute wait.)

Went via local MP. Sent an email to my local MP hoping to see PMs Question Time... alas there is a very long queue for that, so just went on the regular tour. The history and sense of place is mind-blowing, highly recommended.

A great couple of hours. The houses of Parliament are spectacular, and this tour really is worth the money. The building is really a spectacular place for the practice of democracy. While the gift shop is a little over priced, I can recommend the cream tea from the tearoom.

Very interesting. Brilliantly knowledgeable guides and a lovely building, nice art work and the cheapest cup of coffee I have ever had in London. Visit Westminster Abbey whilst there and other attractions in the area if you have time

Incredible tour with knowledgable guides. An amazing tour of the path the Queen takes when she opens Parliament every year. You will see some wonderful rooms but the highlight was the knowledgeable and personable guide who did not stop for one moment wowing us with facts and stories. The entire tour takes about an hour and a half. No photography is allowed at any time-- and they mean it. This is a chance to take in the sights.Do it. You won't be disappointed.

Very impressive building. I didn't take any tour due to time but the exterior is lovely, full of photo opportunities. Next to Big Ben, across the river from the London Eye and within walking distance of Buckingham Palace and Trafalgar Square.

Pretend you are an MP. Enjoyed the visit and saw the history please remember not to take a padlock with youThis is free if you contact your local MPWe opted for the afternoon tea which was disappointing

Breathtaking.... It's one of the most recognizable marks in London.
Located near the River Thames, the Houses are the place where all British laws are born.
I'd say the history itself starts from here. :)
Definitely a must.
Must do in London. Had VIP access overlooking the house of commons in action. Very interesting building with a lot of history.

The most beautiful building in the world. I have been inside both houses of Parliament at least 50 times as my job entails supporting Ministers through Parliamentary processes. I have therefore been into no access areas also and I have to say that the building is simply stunning, especially the drawing rooms and the paintings of the House of Lords. I have also dined with Ministers in restaurants reserved only for them and other Parliamentarians and the food is splendid. Put simply, there is no other building quite like the Houses of Parliament. It is quintessentially and uniquely British with a profound history spanning century upon century.

good all rounder. did not see it all as we went in the winter and parliament was in session but met our mp in her office and had a photo session also some of the house of commons with a member of her staff which was great.
Amazing.. A visit to Parliament is well worth it. It is a beautiful building, and rich with history. every visitor to London should make the effort to stop and take it all in.

Take the Tour. Book the tour it's well worth it, our guide was excellent and very knowledgeable as well as pleasant. The history and atmosphere are palpable brilliant to see and feel up close. The cafeteria is little expensive but not any different to other attractions in London. Tour visitors don't get subsidised meals like the other longer term visitors to the commons. Go armed with questions you want answered and you'll find you'll get more from the guides. Well worth it, book a tour and enjoy.

Beautiful view. My family went to the place during Christmas Day. The place is stunning and absolutely worth it to see. The only thing about this is that there are limited number of bathrooms. I just don't understand that tourists pay so much to see and the city don't even offer the essential services.

Pilgrimage. I teach United States and Virginia government, so it was a profound experience to observe Parliament in session. Also, to be in Westminster Hall, where so much history occurred (such as the trial of Charles I) was a great honor.

Brilliant visit with school group. Went to help a group of young school children and found the tour fascinating and absorbing. Children were able to ask many questions and to wander around state rooms, Commons and Lords (see the Royal Throne) was very interesting. We also had lunch in a committee room (by arrangement) in Portcullis House.Lots of history and atmosphere. Kids loved the hitec taps in the washrooms!

A must visit. A look into our countries political history with a guided tour of no more than 8 people. We got a pass from our local member and enjoyed a very informative morning. Got to see the commons and lords houses, very interesting even for our boys. This is a must visit for all uk residents

Guy Fawkes had the right idea!!. Only joking...This is after all 'The Mother of Parliaments'. If you can get inside and get a real tour then do so, there are some wonderful bits of 'world' history here which explain a lot of laws in other lands.....Across the Thames is the world famous St. Thomas' hospital
Very interesting. tour takes about 75 minutes.You get to visit both houses and walk amongst the seats.A guide is included who is very knowledgable.Good value and well worth a visit.
