House of Parliament. This is a very beautiful building. It's a must see for everyone who visits London. Its next to the Thames River and to Westminster Abby. Across the river from the London Eye too.
as grand in real life. Great architecture, very British!!! Enjoyed walking and taking in the view. It was very impressive and made you feel a bit patriotic!
Must See. The architecture of the building in amazing. Right on the river, it will take your breath away. I could sit and stare for hours. The entire city is that way. the history is amazing.

fascinating building with lots of stories. If you have any interest in the long fascinating history of the British government you won't want to miss a tour of the Houses of Parliament. The building itself is impressive to look at, but the tour will really give you a good overview of the parliamentary history. Definitely fascinating!

The Sights of London. We had booked a tour through National Holidays and were dropped off in London on 3 seperate visits over three days - it was great.On day 1 we visited Winter Wonderland in Hyde Park - day 2 we had 7 hours in London and did all the sights including The Houses of Parliament, Buckingham Palace, Westminster Abbey, a visit to the London Eye etc., etc., etc., day three we visited Covent Garden and St. Paul's Cathedral .All in all it was a fabulous oppertunity to see the sights and enjoy ourselves without spending too much money. The only drawback was that the hotel we stayed at was in Canary Wharf a 25 minute journey from central London, or so the maps say, but it took us from one to one and a half hours each way for each journey - so if you plan of visiting London to see the sights book a hotel located centrally if possible.

Rhubarb, rhubarb, rhubarb!. The title of this review refers to what goes on inside this historic building, rather than the place itself. Onlookers are frequently baffled by debates and procedures that sometimes seem to pay little heed to what really goes on outside. The balance between political posturing and the public good is certainly a very fine one here!That said, the seat of British government is nothing if not impressive. The gothic building oozes history, there are statues of famous statesmen, fine stained glass and, of course, the debating chamber itself, with its green leather and wood panelling. The Lords sit to the right of the complex, and everything here is adorned in opulent red.Members of the public can queue up to gain entry, but in my experience the wait can be inordinate and there is no guarantee you will get in to the spectators' gallery. If you want to go, it's probably better to contact your local MP.It is worth the effort, if you can get there.

What a great tour. Book it when you can.. The guides are very knowledgeable and love to share British history. I learned a lot in our tour, which lasted a good 90 minutes. Just make sure you use the loo before the tour.
Visit. what a great historic building , it was a must see if you are in London and I found it so interesting
Beautiful place to visit!. You should go early because after 11:00 a.m it´s crowded, which makes difficult to take a good picture!

History of the country. My tour was arranged through my local MPs office so was free. Do this and save over £16 in costs. Entry for visitors involves airport type security sad but that is the times we live in. Our guide met us in the great hall and then led us through both the Commons and the Lords with little fascinating fact along the way. The royal robing room tales and the annual taking of a hostage being a couple . Tip the shop does not do mail order and if like me you want to but whisky as a souvenir but won't be allowed in your hand luggage. But it take it to the post office in the Commons Lobby and they will be very helpful in packaging and sending it. I bought it on Friday posted it second class and it was safely delivered on Monday well done Royal Mail. You should allow about 2 hours for the tour and a bit for the security checks.
Superb Views. A must see spot in London , You can travel by tube and get off at Westminster Station.Most of the other attractions are very close by from here.

Fascinating and Free. Visited both houses of Parliament and watched government in action. Impressed by the Great Hall, and the visitors galleries. A must for those interested in politics. Does take a little time to get through security. No crowds, a wonderful experience.
Go if your in London!. Best tourists attraction I have been too, tour guide was funny and informative and the tour was great (is included with your ticket)

Would definitely recommend. This was an interesting tour and we really liked our tour guide Harry who was very knowledgeable - absolutely stunning architecture inside must be great to be a MP and see it all the time

Secret surprise. Book a ticket online for 16.50 to get a great insight into pArliament. The chance to see inside with a great insight into history.A great addition to any trip to london.Tip go for early morning visits

Nice to walk by. We visited the House of Parliament but did not do the tour as it was quite expensive and we were limited for time. We walked past it many times and couldn't help but stop, admire and take photographs everytime.
Iconic. Good to see such an iconic viewFamiliar to us all but more amazing in the flesh as it were. Very busy.

Not to be missed!. Booked to do the tour of the Houses of Parliament. Great value for money and our blue badge tour guide Simon took us around and made the tour one of the best I have been on. Very informative and with a touch of quirkiness to keep some of tour guests interested. When you arrive you have to go through strict security checks and at the beginning of the tour you are made aware of a few do's and don'ts. With this over it is on with the tour. What an experience a well spent 75 minutes full of the history of the building and how our politics works. Would recommend for all ages but not for the very young children.

Living Historical Back Bench Tour. Actually visited September 2012; Parliament NOT in session, so visit to Chambers possible. Tours highly regimented, guides well versed and definitely in charge. Not cheap, but worth the toll. A vibrant and working museum.

walk by and wave :P. we didnt get the tour but walking around the building was nice
we paced by it a few times while walking around london and each time we took a few min to admire the place
a must see sight
maybe next time well take the tour

Definitely not a boring Parliament building!. I was really quite amazed that I found this tour so interesting and enjoyable. Given that the Houses of Parliament used to be the Palace of Westminster, it has all the treasures, art and grandeur that Palaces/ former Palaces have. As well as the history and the splendour, you are there in working, functioning Houses of Parliament. Parliament was in recess at the time of our tour so we were allowed to go into the House itself. Our blue badge tour guide was extremely good.Remember: Before you enter, you have to pass strict security as if you were going to board a plane. Cameras aren't allowed to be used on the tour. The tour starts and finishes in Westminster Hall. This is a brilliant place and cameras may be used here. All staff were extremely helpful and friendly. We booked our tickets online and had no hassle getting in at the appointed time.
Must See!. An interesting tour led by well informed guides. Definitely worth working into your schedule. Tours are offered on Saturdays.

dont miss out. if you visit London on a sightseeing trip and don't visit the Houses of Parliament then you're missing out. If you have no interest in politics or history, the building still has to be admired for its architectural magnificence. Stick around long enough to hear the familiar chimes of Big Ben and you will feel the sense of importance and history. The close proximity to other sites such as the London Eye, Westminster Abbey, Downing Street and Horseguards Parade (all within seconds on foot) all add to it and the view from Westminster bridge cant be ignored either. The only downside is the slightly grubby feel to the surrounding footways. I understand how busy it gets and the reasons for the lack of waste bins, but in these modern times I'm sure there is a solution to this
Just Beautiful. You have to see these from the top of the London Eye ----- what a great view and so full of history.
Very good tour. Hi been going for like 2 years always good Tours always good we what in to hourse of lords and houses of commenes it great we saw steps queen takes
Fun to see. We were walking around in the summer and it was perfect. All the buildings were old but not outdated looking, very historical and gorgeous to look at. If you're in town check it out!

HISTORY AND SPLENDOUR. Wow!. This tour has everything. History and splendour explained simply and professionally. Leone was our guide and she was great. There are rules and quite strict security to get in, which you would expect at this spectacular place, but it is no worse than at an airport and took only about 5 minutes. All the staff were helpful.You start off in the hall and then proceed on the route taken by the Queen on The State Opening of Parliament to The House of Lords, which is gold and red. Very opulent! Lastly through the central lobby and into The House of Commons. You stand, but not sit in both chambers and everyone wants to. You get taken into a voting chamber and also the robing room. It is a totally fascinating tour and well worth the money. There is a very small shop, prices vary, but you can find something for every pocket from pencils to bone china. There is a tea shop/café which is good.I would recommend to anyone who is fit. (standing/walking for 65 minutes is not easy) and there are a few stairs to master at the beginning.. The tour is done at pace as there are several groups being shown round at the same time and there is obviously a tight time schedule. Tours are available in all languages by what I heard and there were groups of differing sizes. It would suit a teenager studying History or someone studying Politics, or just anybody who has seen it on the TV and just wants to visit it to see what it is really like.

Don't miss out. For overseas visitors to England, the only viable means in Autumn 2013 of seeing the interior of the Houses of Parliament was by booking a weekend tour. We'd recommend online booking as soon as possible: in late October there were few vacancies the day before our intended tour. The day we booked there were apparently problems with security systems and we waited well over an hour in the queue until we reached security screening. Security staff were friendly, though, and other staff, equally agreeable, were totally flexible in putting us on the first available tour. The tour itself was fast-paced but excellent. Using only professional guides and having guides develop their own commentary and tailor their talks to their group members certainly paid dividends for me. While my main interest was the extraordinary over-the-top Victorian decoration of most of the rooms that we were led though, I found the guide's commentary was both entertaining and intelligent. While the cost of the tour is quite expensive, I felt that this was money well spent.
An historical gem. Fantastic architecture & art work, o say nothing off the ancient roof! Even if you don't like politics, this building SO worth a visit.
Amazing!!. Had never been inside the parliament, but this time I did. Absolutely mesmerizing. A Must! I got more of the history I didn t know and the guide was excellent

Want to go again and get another tour guide to learn even more. Well worth the visit, fantastic to see the grandeur and learn about the history of the site and the building and how the ceremonies and procedures have evolved as a result of history. If you have never been then this is a must, far more interesting than I thought it would be, far grander and visually impressive inside than I thought it would be as well. What really makes this tour worth doing is the informative tour guides, who from the snippets I heard from other tours as they went round all have slightly different ways of telling their stories and different stories to tell. As we were waiting in Westminster Hall to start the tour, it was very telling to note that every tour that finished was met with a loud round of applause by the group that had just been round. My only regret is that I didn't know about afternoon tea, as we got back to the central lobby, half our group disappeared off to the Pugin room for afternoon tea. Would have booked if I'd known it was an option.
Great experience. The architecture is the primarily attraction but we enjoyed sitting in on both houses and listening to the speeches.

Well run tour. This was a very worthwhile tour which was run extremely well. You are advised to arrive 20 min early to get through security. This was fast efficient and friendly unlike our airports! Tours leave at 15 min intervals and were in reasonable sized groups. Our blue badge guide was friendly fun and knowledgeable and told us just the right amount of history and facts. It took just over an hour and I think it was very good value. I was very glad that I had at last managed to see inside this iconic building and left with a much better understanding of how our parliament works.

Travel back in time!. Our tour guide was Richard, absolutely lived and acted his job in the most professional manner and made the tour a fantastic experience! if history was boring at school it certainly is not if you are fortunate to travel 'Back in time' on this fantastic tour - it is the best £14:50 ever spent!

Nighttime sessions!. Both the House of Commons and the House of Lords work evenings during most of the year, especially on Mondays and Tuesdays until 10:00 pm. If you go in the evening, there are no lines, and you can watch a debate in the sumptuous halls for as long as you'd like! Note: this is not a tour, but you get to walk at your leisure through the historic and glorious building on the way to and from the galleries. Highly recommended for fans of politics, history and government!

Go inside if you can. After seeing Buckingham palace, it's hard to tell the difference. Unnecessarily huge, fancy building, expensive art inside, royal people do things in here. haha kidding (a little), it actually is a pretty cool tour. As a law student, it was neat to go inside and get the full tour, hearing about all the history of the building. They also have a gift shop inside, and a cafe. wait, so does Buckingham Palace. But if you have to choose one of the two, do this tour.
No entrance allowed, view exterior only.. Parliament buildings are a few blocks from the busy Westminster Bridge, and very close- walking distance - to Westminster.
Politics live!. Go and see the political system in person. It's free, its a beautiful building and you get to watch the government in action. I stayed for about a half hour and enjoyed it.
Everyone Should Go!. It is an incredible venture through history. Physically, where does the term lobbyist come from? Each time that I have gone, I have been more interested.
Great to see on a nice day. Fantastic architecture. Great. Stood where all the TV crew stand on the lawn. Tourist attraction. Didn't see anyone I recognised though - Will you?
Genial. Visit the Parliament only Saturdays. VERY INTERESTING. There are guide tours, expensive but are worthy

Beautiful building. I just viewed the facility from across the river and also riding the London Eye. I believe you can take a tour and sit in the balcony and listen to some of their parliament working. The building is beautiful and large. It is worth seeing if you are in London.

Fantastic. OK, so my wife wanted to go and see the Houses of Parliament. We stand outside the barriers and a police woman asks if we are going in (we had forgotten the public gallery) and reminds us that not only is it our right to go in but its also our duty. So, suitably admonished and with renewed interest, we went in (after airport style security checks and getting a policeman's hands closer than my doctors have ever been !). The inside of Westminster Hall is stunning (its nearly 1000 years old) but just wait till you get as far as Central Lobby - the floors, walls, and ceilings are so impressive.From here we went up to the public gallery to watch the MP's in debate - you are not able to throw anything at them any more or probably even be heard through the thick security glass (which is no bad thing) but to watch and hear your MP in action is fascinating.Moved on to the Lords (strangers gallery) where there is no security glass (maybe the lords are less of a target or maybe less of a loss if targeted!) but the chamber is absolutely spectacular.Anyone with a love of history or politics should visit, it is an experience that I thoroughly recommend, but make an effort to speak to the Doormen (the guys dressed in 'tails'). These are not your average comissionaires (no offence if you are one), but were historically responsible for providing the door security to the king when his parliament travelled. They will provide a lot of info and history that you wont get elsewhere.All in all, a very worth while visit.
Iconic. This is a must see on any itinerary. Always lots of people around and that adds to the feeling and occasion.

Worth a view. We stopped off on the tube so my 9 year old could view the houses of parliament for real. He loved the vast size and view of the premises from the bridge.A sight to see and with the London Eye opposite, a worthwhile stop.

British at it's best.. An exciting, educational and quite humorous tour of the Houses of Parliament. The guide is sure to point out who got beheaded when, why the Eurostar no longer arrives at Waterloo. And of course how the British Parliament 'works'.

Stunningly beautiful. It is imopossible to describe the Houses of Parliament - they are the very height of Victorian extravagance with every inch, floors, walls and ceilings designed by a single mind and no expense spared. This may be the experience that stays with you longest.

A real piece of history. The architecture of this building is amazing. We had a really informative guide and she brought the building to life for us. It was so interesting and with so much history - well worth a visit. I intend to go again as there is just so much to see and take in.

Nice building inside and out. Thought the tour was great well worth the price and you get a full guide that will answer any questions you have and the building inside is just impressive as outside really injoy it

Well, so this is what happens in the Houses of Parliement. I liked it all. To think this where our futures are voted upon and decided. I liked the difference between the Lords and Commons. The "haves" and "have nots" Obviously designed when there was a huge difference between hereditary Lords and us commoners. The guides are essential to understand what you are seeing. Well worth the visit.

Beautiful--take the tour!. Amazing site to see! I suggest taking the tour. It's around 75 minutes, I got the prices with a student discount so I can't confirm on pricing. Our guide was extremely helpful and knowledgeable. Though it is a long tour, it is definitely worth the visit!
Very interesting trip. Organised via our MP so it was free. Very interesting tour, lovely guide, lasted about 75 minutes. Very educational!

Incredible. I was lucky enough to have a tour with an MP so got to see some things that aren't on the usual tour. What an incredible place, just awesome and to see the ceremony where the speaker is called to lead members into the house is fantastic

A strolling history of British democracy. We had been advised to go on a Saturday, you have access to parts of the building which are off limits when Parliament is sitting. The professional guides take you through at a reasonable pace which allows you to absorb the atmosphere of the place and they explain the history of the place. Definitely worth booking a trip - do it quite a while in advance in order to not be disappointed.
I like a bit of history. This is a great day out for anyone like myself who is interested in history , there are some wonderful paintings and a great feel of the past

Interesting Behind the scenes visit. We have done this tour of the Houses of Parliament twice now and found different, but informative information both times. The guides seem to know the information well to pass it along, even if you have questions to ask. Interesting to have the chance to be there without parliament in session and know how it all takes place.

Really enjoyable visit. Organised this through our MP at no cost. Small tour group of 10 people and we were led by a very knowledgeable guide. Was a great insight into the Parliament buildings and the function of Parliament. The Commons were in session on our visit, but we were able to view the debate from the visitors' gallery. Great cafe as well!As part of our visit we were also able to visit the Jewel Tower, part of the original Palace of Westminster.A visit everyone should make in their lifetime.

Tour of parliament and tea in the Lords. An excellent tour with polite and helpful staff. The guide not only takes you through the building but also through history to illustrate the creation and evolution of Parliament from Edward I right up to today. We followed our tour with afternoon tea in The Pugin Room which is part of the Lords. A delightful experience - not cheap at £25 but well worth it in our opinion. Tickets bought in advance for full tours (there is a cost - full £16.50) come through the post, free entrance is only to the visitors' gallery or for MP sponsored tours.

Parliament, Politics and Protocol.. Free Entrance. The staff make you very welcome and as long as you are prepared to be searched and scanned and photographed and hand over phones etc (you get them back) you will thoroughly enjoy seeing the Common's and the Lords debating the latest legislation. If nothing else it will let you see that it takes them hours to talk about issues that both sides agree on and could be dealt with a show of hands in a matter of minutes. They certainly like to talk!!! Finding the correct entrance is not easy, it is best to ask the first available policeman, there are plenty of them. Do not take pictures in any part of the building as they don't allow it. There is a Cafe selling light snacks, cakes coffee etc and the toilets are of a high standard, as would be expected. Nearest Subway is Westminster.

Excellent Tour on Saturdays. The tours take advantage that Parliament is normally closed on Saturdays. Therefore, visitors are allowed to stand right in the middle of both houses of Parliament (exactly where the debates occurs and laws are passed).Excellent history lesson.One item not explained well. Tickets purchased online have to be picked up at a white building across the street. Allow yourself an extra 10-15 minutes.
Beautiful buildings. passed by the houses of parliament while walking around London. Beautiful architecture. Well worth a visit.

Fantastic experience!. Visited the Houses of Parliament during a recent stay in London. What an experience. We have walked in the footsteps of government, stood in the House of Lords and the House of Commons benches. Seen the beautiful 'robing room' that the Queen uses once a year and generally discovered a real gem. This is an unusual experience. You are searched quite comprehensibly by the huge police presence before you enter (and quite right too!), meet a wonderful tour guide, who gives you a very comprehensive tour of the public and private spaces in this fascinating building and are left with the impression that we are very lucky to have such a building in this country for us to see. WE LOVED IT!

Well worth the visit. Organised this through our MP at no cost. Small tour group of 12 people and we were led by a very knowledgeable lady who had worked in Westminster for 25 years. Took about an hour and was a great insight into the function of Parliament. Best bit was standing behind the Leader of the Oppositions seat in the Commons. Television shots make the chamber look much bigger. Great cafe as well!

Great experience. It was very impressive that you can come in and see real parliament.My friend was making a sketch and security stopped him and took to a special room for questioning.Apparently,its not allowed

Don't miss it. Very knowledgeable guide with the right balance of historical facts, anecdotes and information about the way Parliament works. Very beautiful building. There are 4 tours scheduled at the same time but the groups sizes are reasonable (our guide made sure kids and shorter people could stand in the front for an unobstructed view), the guides speak just loud enough and everything runs smoothly.I advise booking your ticket online in advance and getting there at least 30 minutes before your tour is scheduled to avoid stress. As a foreigner, I couldn't print my ticket from home and had to pick it up at the box office. But my ticket was nowhere to be found there and after searching through a big pile of tickets, it had to be reprinted. Then there was a long line for the security check. All in all, my tour had left by the time I made it inside the main hall. Luckily, the guards were very understanding and one of them accompanied me inside, made sure I found my friends and introduced me to the guide. Also, travel light. My purse felt like a ton after a while. There's only one flight of stairs, a lot of standing and very few occasions for sitting (our guide made sure seniors got the seats when available). Store small but some fun gifts. Free leaflets for those who want further historical of political info.

Tour - made great by a very good tour guide. My wife and I booked this tour via ticketmaster and the only concern was were the ticket office was... its mentioned in the email you get not on the web site and is opposite the building behind and to the sid eof the Abbey - near the tour buses --The tickets were on hand and a voucher for the guide i had reserved. The security takes 10 - 15 mins even with a small queue and we were worried about being late.. Late or ealry they line you up so do not fret if you are a little late.The tour is 75 great mionutes, facinating facts, jokes and good humour, but most of all entertaining. Out guide was a small (very words, Middle aged black haired lady (jewish I would guess) and was exceptional. Her timing care of attention and timing all excellent -- you can see she enjoys and takes her work very professionally and it shows through. Excellent -After 75 minutes we were delighted -- well done

Highly Recommended. Along with a group of friends, I took the tour of the Palace of Westminster yesterday. We were the last tour of the day, in fact Big Ben was sounding six o'clock as we left the Palace, but we were never rushed. The entire operation is exceptionally well organised, and please don't be put off by the airport like security, because it is well worth the trouble.Our guide, a great lady called Sheila, was patient, knowledgeable and extremely professional.Please check when these tours are available, and make the effort... history, architecture, splendour, it has it all.
Part of history. This is just one of those places everyone should visit as so much history, UK and world, ha happened here. Just an unbelievable place.
Beautiful building!!!. I went with a New Europe tour and the guy told us the story about everything. It was interesting when we could actually see the building before our eyes.

A great tour not to be missed. The Houses of Parliament can be visited on Saturdays and this is a tour not to be missed if you visit London. You enter by the old Westminster Hall which dates from 1100's and for it alone the tour is well worth doing. From then on your visit traces the route taken by the Queen when she visites at the annual opening of Parliament. The decor, fixtures and fittings need to be seen to be believed. The price ( at around £17 ) is worth every penny.

Order, order.... We got in late in the afternoon, (you have to queue for quite a while as it's one out, one in) and sat watching a debate from the public gallery. I was awestruck that you can go in for free and sit right smack bang in the middle of the seat of power of one of the world's greatest nations and watch democracy being played out in front of your very eyes.A memorable, one-off experience which made me proud (for once) to be British.
Nice building. Nice building. Just a shame it houses some of the greatest tossers this country has ever produced. Wibble.

Wait for the bells. We weren't permitted to tour the building but it was a beautiful sight nonetheless. Evidently, they do allow for tours on certain days so be sure to plan ahead if that is what you want. It was particularly beautiful at night when it was lit up and I recommend waiting to hear the bells chime. It is located near many other sites such as the London Eye.

british grandeur. these are majestic buildings that must be seen.Adajacent to The Thames River and newly cleaned the buildings are an architectural treasure and include the famous Big Ben Tower.adjacent To Westminster Abbey and Whitehall there's lots more to see in this area
History galore and stunning. Great tour and worth the time and money even though it is on the steep side. It is entertaining and enlightening at the same time!

SUPERB. British history at its best …………..I went on a wednesday with a pre arranged group which turned out to be a shame as wednesday is Prime Ministers Questions so you can't get into the commons ………the rest of the tour was excellent going all through the house of Lords just amazing FAB I would return

Highly Recommended. British citizens can visit when Parliament is in session. To arrange a visit you apply via your MP [ name and e-mail address of MP can be found online ] and the visit is free of charge. The tour is great and I think that it would make an excellent starting point for a political history project for children of 10+.

Best history lesson I ever had. Wecwentvas a large group. It was busy but we were never really held up. Airport type security at gate as you would expect. Guides truly knowledgeable, ours must have been actor as he relished and indulged us in every snippet of English history that had taken place in this amazing living museum. Well worthy of a visit much better than I expected. Great little cafe in the entrance tonwestminster too.

Stunning. Stunning building, plenty to see and take photos.
Park next to it too to have a snack.
Not many rubbish bins thou

Very extensive tour of parliament- go or the tour. I enjoyed the tour of parliament. Though it was pricey at almst 17 pounds, it was worth every pence. The tour was 1.5 hours long and we were brought in to the two houses, the hals and the galleries. The tour was very thorough and covered every aspect. Questions asked were promptly answered. The highlight was being inside the house of common a d stroking the seat where the British PM sits on. Go for the tour, it s worth it.

A must for anyone interested in politics and / or royalty. After a few near misses, it was great to finally get the chance to do this tour.The £16 entry fee represents good value for money, with a knowledgable tour guide showing us around.Ali aspects of Westminster are seen and discussed. It's such an ornate building, and the history and rituals of parliament and it's interaction with royalty were expertly detailed.Walking through the House of Commons Itself was a great experience. A must-do tour.

The tour of Parliament is a Must! Only Saturdays. I loved the tour! It was a complete tour of the Houses contained in Parliament. This building has such vast, rich history. The tour guide was knowedgable about much of the history.

After many visits to london, first visit to paliament. . Just do it, very nice building and good tour guide through this historical place. We reserved tickets for around 10 AM and there were no huge crowds or waiting times.

Culturally significant. My husband and I pre-booked a tour of the Parliament in London. We booked it on line. The tour was so informative. We were able to see the House of Commons and the House of Lords. It was really fun to be able to see the actual seat the Queen sits in; is very intricate. Learning about the history of this cultural site, as well as how their parliamentary system works was great fun. The tour was very well done, and lasted about one and one half hours. Well worth it. Seeing Big Ben was great, also.

Very informative visit. WE booked the visit via our MP< easy to do, so no need to wait in line. Our guide was very informative, and we thoroughly enjoyed the tour. I had booked for a Wednesday, hoping that my mp would have also been able to get tickets for PMQ, but no joy. So we could not go to House of Commons...bear this in mind, maybe book another day/timeslot if you just want the tour. Highly recommended.

A splendid experience. We were invited to attend a Reception on the Terrace as guests of an alumni of the University of Sussex. We arrived in good time at Black Rod's Garden Entrance where we queued for 30 minutes to reach the security check point. We were then whisked to the Terrace for drinks and canapés.Included with the invitation was a tour of the House of Lords and to this end we joined a party with an excellent guide (Frank from Shoreham-on-Sea). This tour was billed to last 30 minutes but as the House of Commons was not sitting and with Frank providing an engaging commentary, 90 minutes passed in a flash. We stood on the Floor of both houses and were struck by the grandeur of the Lords and by the more prosaic Commons. Both chambers are smaller than we envisaged. To stand at both despatch boxes in the Commons as history is succinctly explained is quite something. We finished by passing through the ancient and impressive Westminster Hall This is a must do tour which should not be missed if the opportunity presents itself.

A Truly Fascinating Tour. If you get the chance to do the Houses of Parliament tour then you really should! There is a bit of a wait while you have to queue for your time slot then go through security but once through you head in to the awe inspiring Westminster Hall meet your allocated Tour Guide. We were met by Vicky who really enhanced the tour for us with her enthusiasm and knowledge. You see the route the Queen takes for the State Opening of Parliament, the House of Lords and the House of Commons whilst admiring the fabulous collections of historical portraiture and frescos along the way. Highly recommended!! Foreign language tour guides are also available.

Breathtaking architecture, easy access. We went on a whim in a two hour window and were thrilled, partly to not wait in a long line, partly to see the interior we Americans had never expected, partly to be able to stroll (after a few benign checkpoints) right to the gallery of the House of Commons. That, we knew about, from movies and TV. While it was not exactly 'Question Time' with opposition MPs yelling hard Questions like Chris Matthews in a bad mood, it was trulyt exciting to see this in the flesh (and oak, and glass). If you are in this area you absolutely should not miss this! All the guards, police, and guides were professional and polite, friendly and informative in a far more human way than their American counterparts. Not to be missed

One of the most popular tourist spots in the world. there is the Big Ben, the most famous clock tower, which is actually the name of the bell, not the clock itself, take the best photos of London There, many spots, your trip will be remarkable there.

well worth the trip. We did the tour and honestly I can't remember when it was. Excellent short visit with a great guide. a rare glimpse into the inner workings of such a historical and important place. you can't help but feel a sense of privilege at being able to peek in!

Interesting day out. We booked a trip here a few months ago and despite the wait, thoroughly enjoyed the visit.The tour took you into both the House of Commons and House of Lords as well as Westminster Hall.We were also lucky enough to see a debate from the public gallery which is very interesting, especially when the two main parties lock horns!Definitely worth a visit

Interesting. No advanced booking needed when we went in Sept. Bought the timed ticket at the booth and were admitted twenty minutes later. Guided tour included in the price and ours was with a very knowledgeable person. A must tour for anyone with even the slightest interest in politics or Parliament.

London on a Budget. We visited the houses of parliament as part of a pre organised tour which was simple to organise but had to be undertaken in advance. If you are on the electoral roll a request can be sent to your local MP asking for tickets to join a tour of the hall and building. The process is quite easy but obviously must be undertaken a few weeks in advance of a trip. However, it does mean that your visit is free and you are guaranteed entry at the time on the tickets. I would thoroughly recommend a visit as the tour guide was very informative, witty and friendly; he really brought the whole historical element to life. If you are able to plan such a tour in your itinery I wouldn't hesitate to do so.
A must do. We did the Saturday tour and really enjoyed the experience. Colin,our guide was very good in his descriptions of the rooms and the events that had occurred in them.

Interesting & educational. An excellent visit - just 1 1/2 hours but crammed full of information. Best to book in advance - only criticism was that we arrived early & were told we could not go in until 15 minutes before our booked time - when we returned, we had to queue for 1/2 hour which was a bit annoying. So much history is learnt during the tour together with information on how parliament works today. Very good tour.

The building is worth the price of admission. It's free. Unfortunately, if you're not a resident of the UK, all you are allowed to do is listen to the debates and not take the tour. But it's an interesting thing to do even if you have no idea what it is they are debating. We actually contacted the US embassy to get letters of introduction which are supposed to get us to the front of the line. When we got there, no one was waiting, so our letters were unnecessary. So here's a tip - the House of Commons works late on Mondays. We were there about 4 and entry was very quick. I'm sure that it's like that all the way until 10pm when they close down.

A classic must visit.. I was lucky that queues were short and I managed to watch debates at the Commons and the Lords. The latter was particularly good due to the large attendance on the floor of the house and because the public gallery was not encased in glass.

witness a Parlement session for free. You can attend - for free - Parliament sessions. Great experience to hear and see the members of the House of Commons and House of Lords talk for 4 minutes in a polite way (at least when we were there), beautiful rethoric. And it's free. To reach the 2 Houses you walk through the huge hall, that alone is worth a visit. If you do not go for the guided tour, you can still see this hall when you go to the Parliament anyway. We were lucky to assist to the debate early september 2013 about attacking Syria or not, which afterwards seemed to influence Mr Obama; we feel now that we witnessed of a small historical event. I highly recommend to attend a session, it was a highlight of our trip to London.

Instead of an expensive tour.... If you want to avoid the expensive tour, but still want to go into the buildings, you can sign up for a free political sponsored event as a participant and enter the buildings. There are events everyday with think tanks and political organisations - you just have to have a little search online.Once signed up for a free event and in the buildigns, you don't get a tour obviously, but you get to explore the buildings to an extent, try the interior coffee shop and gift shop (more info: http://www.parliament.uk/visiting/access/events/).

Guided trip through history. One the highlights of our 10 days in London. The tour guide was very informative and entertaining. The history of the palace is fascinating even for non-political buffs. The rooms visited during the tour must be seen to be believed. Would love to have listened to a live sitting of Parliament, but then we would not have been able to do the tour. I was particularly interested in the various characters - kings and PMs who have had such an impact on world history. Accept the need to book in advance, the security checks, the rushed pace of the tour and the difficulty hearing the guide in some rooms (all problems arising from the popularity of this tour) - this is a must see experience!

House of Parliament. I would recommend listening to one of the debates while sitting in the gallery. We didn't go on a tour, but after reading some other reviews, I would go on a tour the next time we visit.
Great for political buffs!. My husband and I love politics and this was a true highlight for us. I highly recommend sitting in on a session and getting a real feel for political life in London.

difficult review. An awesome specticle to look at and a great photo opportunity from as far away and high up as the London Eye, across Westminster bridge, to the base of the Clock Tower. But it's an important working building. I believe the public can get in but not sure how.Great to see it though
See it after sunset. Offers a breathtaking view after sunset with its reflection in the thames. The best view can be obtained while walking on the bridge form London Eye to Big ben

Unbelieveble experience. I guess we were spoilt as we had a personal tour with a friend who works there, but from the walk from Portcullis House under the Thames to a door which opens into the central hall, then to stand at the Commons and Lords despatch boxes, the whole trip was mind blowing. I'm not into politics at all, but you can't fail to be amazed at the History that surrounds you all the way round the place. Our friend explained things brilliantly so I can imagine the professional guides would do it even more so. It should be compulsory for every British citizen to do a tour at least once in their lifetime just to see what this country is all about.

Inside View. We got an inside view of this and did a tour. It was amazing. This was one of the most beautiful buildings I have ever been in. I recommend getting the tour with it so you get the full in depth history of the place. WORTH IT.

Well worth the effort. Booked on line in advance and the wait was worth it. The tour is well organised and you get to see the best bits! Plenty of explanation clearly given. And the rooms are truly spectacular. A must for every Britishcitizen.

Just cross the bridge. After crossing the bridge and you are facing the gigantic Big Ben then turn your head back to watch the beautiful London Eye then walk and cross the street to Westminster Abbey facing now the entrance of The Parliament and in your right hand side the stunning church of WA, just stop in the corner and cherish the moment, you are in a perfect place that you could see the 3 iconic places of London, I took a picture of my 3 most loved ( my wife and my 2 big boys) here with the 3 great loved places in the background... I love it...!

Do the tour!. Definitely worth booking tickets to do a tour of parliament. The interior is extremely lavish and there are many cool rooms to see and they all aren't the same. The tour guides are very knowledgeable and provide cool facts ranging from the significance of the colors of the furniture to secret passageways used by the queen. You get to walk through the chambers where the members of parliament actually debate and vote

Highly Underrated. One of my favorite things that I did in London. You have to buy your tickets in advance and it was well worth every penny. Great history. I am surprised that it is not listed in more tour guides.
Worth a look!. just visited outside since we didn't have time to walk in but it was great to see! Lots of other stuff around it too so worth going!
Very interesting. I took a tour in Italian with my husband and we loved it. The tour was informative but not boring. Loved it!
Fantastic place to visit.. We had a great visit to both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. We watched the Commons in action with some well known politicians speaking.

great viewing. Our kids were very excited to see Big Ben, they were a bit disappointed when they found out it was the actual Bell not the clock, until they heard the bell ringing. A must see for a visit to London. For all ages.

Truly unique. Worth the trip; there's nothing else like it! Recommend speaking to your MP and sitting in on Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesdays - great theatre! If you can also wangle an invite to lunch, the food is excellent and coffee on the Terrace afterwards!

Well worth a visit and its FREE. Unable to access westminster abbey due to high entrance fees, we walked next door to the Houses of Parliment, after Speaking to one of the Police officers on duty there who was most helpful, advised us that you can go in and view the house of commons & Lords which is what we did, straight in via security.We observed the house of Lords first for approx 40 mins what an experience and fantastic building, then on to the house of commons for another 40mins, not quite so grand but so interesting. There is no time limit you can listen to the debates and observe for as long as you want. The staff are delightful and very willing to advise and help.A very unexpected but plesant suprise visit which I would highly reccomend and its all free.Brilliant.

Looks bigger on the telly. Thank you to Harlow MP Robert Halfon for a wonderful visit to the Houses of Parliament. The Commons was fascinating, green and really quite compact while the Lords was very red and gold and opulent. Thanks also to Aaron for a very informative tour of a building so Important to British democracy. The government building in Budapest is modelled on the British Houses of Parliament and it was eerie to see them lit up just like the H of P as we glided past on an evening river boat cruise. Imitation is the most sincere form of flattery.
Second best attraction. The tour was excellent and very interesting. You won't be disappointed. Well done presentation. Worth the entry price.

See it. The tours are good. If unavailable, have a seat in the gallery and watch democracy in action, then go through to the lords. Amazing building, history at it's best. Well worth a visit. You can arrange to meet your M.P. if you're that much of a masochist!
What a building. When you first see it, you think the building is part of royalty. It's just a very impressive building which is right in London.

Houses of Parliament interesting history tour. Great history and access to somewhere you wouldn't likely be allowed to go. House of Lords and House of Commons just like you see on TV. Great guide, who had lots of stories to complement the history.
Huge Historic Structures -Awesome. Though only an outside view of the Buildings, Awesome Architecture of the ages Old Monumental Structures is quite a pleasant feast to Eyes.
Beautiful!. Amazing view of parliament buildings and Big Ben from the bridge. Every time we drove by it takes your breath away.

Amazing Building. For free you can visit Westminster Hall. That alone is fantastic, the largest medieval hall in Europe. The timber beams are impressive and a must see.For a fee you can also take the guided tour of the whole palace. This tour was a huge let down and the reason I only gave 4 stars, not 5 which the building really deserves. The tour was mainly a lesson on British political history, all good and well but I wanted to hear about the palace and what I was looking at in far more detail. Many things were stated but not explained, such as a MPs calling each other Right Honourable and the mace. The constant use of the phrase "those of you who are British will probably know this..." was annoying, as most on the tour were British either that bit of trivia could be skipped and was further proof that the tour attempted to cover more bases than were really possible.Splitting the tours into a British political history tour and a history of the building tour would have been far more enjoyable.But that aside, do at least visit the Hall, a fantastic sight.

Guided tour is outstanding.. An amazing experience I would like to repeat. The Guide, Philip Grady, was very knowledgable and an excellent ambassador. The place oozes history and is just fascinating. Well worth a visit.

Interesting to see the interior. You have to book a tour through your MP -this is free but has to be done in advance. Our tour was excellent and the guide very informative about the history and the inner workings of parliament as she had spent 25 years there as a Parliamentary Private Secretary. I would recommend this to anyone who wonders here their MP spends his/her working time and what the Houses of Parliament look like from the inside.

A fantastic historic building. I went on a guided tour of the building - which was easy to book off the Parliament website. It was relatively easy to get through security and the tour started and finished on time. The building is fantastic - it's amazing to think about all the history that has taken place in that building. The only thing that is slightly difficult is that it can be hard to hear, because the building is so busy with other tours. Our tour guide was great and had some great stories about each of the rooms.
Never fails to make me stare. A trip to london wouldn't seem the same if I hadn't heard the sound of Big Ben and been passed the houses of parliament

what a surprise. This was like sneaking a look through the headmasters window, We were going to Westminster Abbey but were waylaid by a friendly guard who said "try here its free!" . After a hoot having a security picture taken we trotted off to see what this very familiar yet oddly removed building had to offer. It was a fascinating, as you saw the wonder of great architecture and the workings of state mingled together. The Lords wins on splendor and surprisingly the debate was better there too as members of the House of Commons appear to pay more attention to their ipads. It is worth a look and, again, it is free!

Take a look where it all happens. Impressive central hall. It's a good place to sit if you're waiting to exercise your right to lobby the local member of parliament. The decor alone can grab your interest.
Architectural genius.. Breathtaking in every sense. A must-see in any London visit. We saw it on a sunny Sunday as the light caught the building. Totally worth the trip.
great place to visit. What interesting place to visit with lots of surprises. well worth the money I will never watch prime minsters question time the same

Enjoyable and informative. Tour is excellent, just under 2 hours, so interesting to see the Commons, etc, and the other parts of the building that you see constantly on television. Lots of good information throughout and numerous interesting little titbits of information as well.I must say, though, probably too many people in each group, and tours far too close together.Three groups in the Commons at once when we were there.In spite of that, very enjoyable and not to be missed if you get the chance.

Great historical tour. My tour was arranged through my MP, hence I didn't have to pay the entry fee. The tour guide was very knowledgeable, as you would expect. The Houses are steeped in history, which can be seen through the various paintings through out. We were able to stand (not sit) in the Commons where we so often see our parliament carrying out the business of the country. I now know what is meant by the term 'the Ayes to the right' as we passed through the division halls.Well worth the visit and completed nicely by lunch in the Jubilee Cafeteria.

private tour via MPS. Was really interested in doing a tour of Parliament when my girlfriend and I were down in London. Looked up how to go about doing the tour and noticed you had to contact your local MP if you are a British Citizen. Having left it a little late all the official tours were full. However my local MP organised for her assistant to give us a private tour. Definitely recommend doing this as it was very good indeed. Very insightful into what goes on and really interesting seeing round Parliament. The tour lasted an hour and saw everything I wanted to and more. Even bumped into a few well known politicians when we were being shown round.
Lords and Commons. so much history and worthwhile if the weather is poor . not too long to wait for a guide and good souvenirs
Excellent tour. Excellent tour, Efficiently run and very informative. The buildings have loads of history with stunning interior with magnificient art. Well worth doing if you can.
Great morning out. Very good tour, had,nt realised how small it was Tour was well organised and the guide went out of his way to explain the workings of the lords and parliment

Must see attraction in London. Great place to visit ,have to. It tickets in advance .well worth the time .tour takes about 1.5 hours .we travelled in from Heathrow on a 1day tube pass which worked out well
Security!. Only saw it from the outside but were impressed by the scale and beauty of the building! The most stunning thing about it, however, is the amount of security around it! Police everwhere!

Beautiful building !!!. I had never been inside the Houses of Parliament before & didn't realise it used to be a palace. The rooms are stunning & full of history & the actual areas used for parliament, the House of Lords & House of Commons are very interesting. The guided tour was well worth the money, very interesting place to visit !!!
Learn about English government. Our guide was a proper English gentleman who clearly explained English government to a group of international guests. Well worth taking the tour.

Fascinating insight into British history. Arranged and purchase tickets in advance before leaving home, so glad we did - made access to a very popular attraction much easier.
Our guide Richard, an elderly gentleman was very, very interesting and researched on the history. He was patient and controlled in his description of the Houses.
Highly recommended.

Got to go if in London. You can not visit London with out going to see Parliment. it is just a must to see.
great landmark. great view from the Thames River

Extremely Interesting. I've wanted to do this tour for years and finally had the opportunity, as I am a bit of a history buff. The guide was very informative and the architecture and artworks that abound is amazing. Love It
Spectacular. Everything about this was great. Both young and old foreign or not. Everything including our tour guide was great

Nice place to work!. You can tour either the House of Lords or the House of Commons. Both are interesting in their own right but it is the history that you can learn about the government and the building that is very worth while. Maybe you'll want to do both tours. Take the time to learn and enjoy the historic surroundings.

Wonderful to see the action inside. Last visit to London we only marvelled at the outside of the building. This time it was great to be able to go inside and see the House of Commons in action. There are lots of stairs and security but that wasn't a problem for our party. The stairs might be an issue for some visitors though. Well worth the effort to go inside these amazing buildings.
Beautiful Building. If you go to London, You must go to the Parliament building, it's a very beautiful place with lot of history around the place.

Fantastic Tour of Parliament. Getting in here has been on my Bucket List ever since I started going to London 30 years ago. For so many years it was impossible. So I was overjoyed to find out that tours are now open to everyone. We booked months in advance to be sure we'd have a spot. I was not disappointed. The tour is very fast paced and extremely choreographed to get all the tours moved around the building. That didn't detract at all. The building is gloriously decorated, as my husband said - more of a church than a government building. But here the artwork is of historical figures rather than saints. It was a treat to be in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Now when we see it on TV, we have a better understanding of what is going on. As with Buckingham Palace, this is definitely something visitors to London should see if there when the building is open.

Fascinating Tour. Booked a tour through our MP and have to say it was a fantastic and most interesting experience. Took our 2 children in August and from start to finish most enjoyable from the banter with the police (my son was wearing his Man Utd shirt) through the House of Lords and into the House of commons.Would definitely recommend this attraction and the fact that it doesn't cost UK citizens a penny means it shouldn't be missed.

So interesting!. While on the London Eye another traveler recommended to us touring Parliament. He said it was one of his family's highlights. We intended to do it the next day, but it was closed for their vote regarding Syria (late August 2013). We were fortunate enough that they were open the next day and we took the tour. You go through security of course, and there are no photos allowed. The pomp and circumstance of it all, the old buildings, hearing the stories, seeing the interior, the architecture, the art, hearing about the process and the history was SO interesting (I am an American). It was highly worthwhile, I recommend it - but be prepared for discipline! No sitting on the politician's seats, and no eating (one visitor started to pop a hard candy in her mouth and was mildly scolded by the tour guide!)
FSB Visit.. Cannot fault it. Saw the Houses of Commons, House of Lords, Speakers Chair, Dispatch Box. Then dinner in the Members Room. Absolutely brilliant!

Debating at its best. Question Period is at 2 pm when the Commons are sitting. Generally the Prime Minister is in the House on Wednesday. Get tickets through your High Commission or Embassy, security is tight. If you are interested in government it is worth a visit.

very informative. the tour is really good .the guide was really good and i learned a lot, the rooms are a lot smaller than they appear on television. only down side is you cant take photographs inside but apart from that very worthwhile

Houses of Parliament - a must see. The Houses of Parliament are not open for tours all the time due to them being in session (check online to see when this is). This past trip we were finally able to get in and it was totally worth it. We toured both houses (Lords and Commons) and several other areas. The guide we had (Tony) was great and gave us a good sense of what goes on in Parliament as well as the history. The tour lasted about an hour and a half. No photography is allowed past the area of Westminster Hall (the gathering area) I would certainly do this again! We bought our tickets via Ticketmaster and printed the receipts. We arrived and they scanned them and had no problem getting it. At the end of the tour, we had lunch in the cafe. They have a modest menu, the prices are pretty modest.

Really enjoyed this tour.. This was a very organized tour of a beautiful building with some very interesting history (and this is from one that is not a lover of history). I would highly recommend taking the time, and paying the price to go inside this historic building!

Commons and Lords visit. Free to visit, just turn up and make request. We did not have to Queue. Very historic decor, art work, etc.. See Parliament working in the flesh.There was nothing I disliked about the visit.
Beautiful. You have to go here! Amazing architecture and just beautiful! Great view from the eye and beautiful pictures from the bridges near by with the water and Big Ben.

The greatest visit and one of the best guide. The Houses of Parliament are a beautiful place to go, to know about the London history; best if you have a blue badge guide, who tells you everything about the place, it's history and make some fun.
Photo-Op Must. I spent a bit of time just people watching here and taking photos of the architecture. It really is a grand thing to see something that you've seen photos of for a lifetime.
A lot of history. I loved the architecture and grandeur of the place. The people were nice and very friendly. I would love to go back.

Excellent tour. Tour of Parliament should definitely not be missed by anyone visiting London, especially if from the US. Our guide was outstanding, providing, not only a great tour, but also a lot of personality along the way, just to make it enjoyable. Emphasis not just on the mechanics of making laws in the UK, but also on the history of how it got that way. Great tour.

Fantastic Exterior. This is a great site to visit. Close to several major attractions I can't see why one would not stop for a photo. The exterior was added to the building after its original construction but the exterior makes the whole thing. Big Ben named for the bell inside can hardly be missed. What ever they call the tower now it is still Big Ben to the world. Westminster Abby is next door and is a must see on the inside if you are at all familiar with the kings and queens or the HBO series Henry the VIII.

great experience. considering how badly our government is performing going to visit Parliament in session is a real treat.there is honest discourse of different viewpoints.the chamber is beautiful .be prepared to go through a tight security check, but a trip is well worth your time and effort.

Grand!. Such an impressive and iconic building- its a must visit place.If you love history you are in it! If not its still amazing to see the house of commons you see on t.v( which is a lot smaller than expected), and the house of lords which is much grander obviously, with the throne at one end.The Great Hall is so atmospheric, just imagine all the monarchs that have been here.
View. Building architecture was amazing and it's situation on the banks of the Thames very impressive just loved everything about it

Not to be missed if in London. Living in London all my life I thought why not a visit to the Houses of Parliament with my familyan enjoyable day out finding out all the facts with a guided tour, the guide was very funny and knowledgable in the history of the parliament. Quite interesting overall and a good day out, just a shame could see inside more of the rooms or Big Ben really.Wouldn't recommend if bringing small children

Okay. Went with my university. When we got there we joined a que where we had to go through security. I understand that the job they do is very important but a smile wouldn't hurt. Me and my university friends paid nothing for the very informative tour of the historic building. It was beautiful. However people just weren't very friendly.

An unexpectedly beautiful place!. My friend and I visited Parliament, (the Palace of Westminster), late September 2013 with a guided tour we booked on line. (Really - would never have guessed that touring Parliament would involve Ticketmaster…!) Was absolutely stunned – from Westminster Hall with the largest, (and undoubtedly highest), hammer-beam roof in the world, to the jaw-dropping ceiling of the Central Lobby – it’s a beautiful place! Regrettably, Parliament is also a very, very popular place. Most of the rooms we were in had multiple tours taking place at the same time – it’s quite difficult to hear your guide, when there are four other guides in the very same room speaking as well. Still & all – I highly recommend visiting!

Historically Impressive. So much history has been written inside this building that we just had to come and see it.We were not disappointed. Unfortunately we did not spend enough time to really appreciate it.I recommend to visit this place with enough time, it is definitely a learning experience.

All that gold!. It really is worth visiting not only for the history which is fascinating, but to see the pomp and majesty of the House of Lords. It will make you gasp! It's all British Heritage and somewhere we should all visit!
Nice to see. We didn't go inside but we went and walked around it. It was one of those places you have to go and just see.

Utterly Fascinating!. I can't believe it took me years to finally walk through the gates of this historic landmark! Take it from me-put this at the top of your list! It's a must-see attraction with wonderful guides offering tantalizing tidbits of history and political machinations. The chambers, robing room, and halls are utterly gorgeous and brimming with living history. It was a fast tour and I would have loved to have spent more time here, but would definitely visit again. Give it a try...you won't be disappointed!

Popped in for a spot of tea. Had a nice afternoon sanding around and then a glass of bubble on the terrace pavilion over looking the Thames. Very interesting building with so much history. Looking forward to a return visit.
Fantastic. Went with my daughter on a women in business trip and we had lunch on the terrace , brilliant. It is amazing the stories they tell you

Fascinating. We have been twice,once on the paid for tour and another time through our local MP. The tour was excellent,very informative and enjoyable but it was taken during the summer recess so not much happening in the building. The second time we got in touch with our local MP and he arranged for five of us to do a tour with his researcher. This was brilliant, we spent nearly two hours and we could ask all the questions we wanted. We went into the public gallery after watching the speaker enter the commons and start the session, and this too was fascinating. Anyone who lives in the uk can request a tour from their MP, you just have to write or email them and they will do the rest. Best of all it's free.

House of Parliament. This was one of the highlights of our trip to London. It was great! The history was fascinating; the guide was very interesting with many historical facts. We loved the Robing Room and the large lobby with the mailboxes but especially loved standing right in both houses of Parliament. It's only open to the public on Saturdays so make sure you plan accordingly.

Yes, you can go in!. Book a visit online and go during recess. You can walk through the palace of Westminster, where plaques on the floor tell you who was here when- Charles 1 being sentenced to death...Edward iv lying in state, Churchill, Thatcher even Nelson Mandela. A whistle stop of British history! Then wander into both chambers (only in recess) and imagine you're a Lord or an MP...fascinating, with excellent guides.

Facinating and not to be missed! Stand in the House of Commons by the green leather benches where they debate!. This tour is such a great value and so interesting. The tour moves along qiuickly too. You won't have time to get bored if that's at all a concern. Our guide had been doing mutiple tours everyday for the past 9 years and yet, you could tell she loves the place, its rich history and fun traditions. I'd do this or some other version of Parliment again. Do not, miss it! Buy tickets at least a day ahead though.

Houses of Parliament. Most remarkable building I have ever seen. This time I just observed from outside, but have previously done tour. Tour only available on Saturdays and I would suggest book well in advance. Built at height of Victorian Empire, iconic and impressive, can never tire of the view.

Great Experience. You see it on telly, you hear it on the radio, but being there is so much better! We're not very political, but the sheer history and atmosphere of the place is electric! We loved the 'Robing Room', and were fascinated by the stories the very professional guides tell. Who'd have thought that 'toe the line' was related to the House of Commons. Go visit and find out more!

History. The steps in are not easy to get up with bad legs,(these are inside) but once you get past these the tour in the hands of our fantastic guide was full of facts and history, this was in recess last year (July/Aug) we where taken through both chambers, and Mum, (pre chair) was allowed to sit down in both, no photos are allowed but the guards were fantastic, the history of the place dating back century's was explained in a warm interesting way, highly recommend, Don't be put off by the security checks on the way in,(like airports) the staff have humour.

A must see. This is the mother of all Parliaments and at its best it truly is, at its worst it just sucks. The trips are free, but you have to book online and pay a booking fee (truly a politicians version of free). The guides vary between brilliant and on my goodness why do they bother, so hopefully you will get one of the former ones. You will be shown the main entrance where the Queen arrives to open Parliament, the house of Lords and the house of Commons, the lobbies and adjoining areas.It really is worth a visit and they will guide you in the language of your choice so you can still see this magnificent place and listen to English as well as many other tongues. Arrive early, if you miss your slot you will be turned away. You will go through security so don't take large bags with you.

EXCELLENT. I loved the tour of the Houses of Parliament, our guide was very informative and interesting with a bit of English humour thrown in. The history of the palace was amazing. Only problem is there is so much to see in such a short space of time.Maybe they could do a couple of tours, one based on the history and procedures of Parliament another based on the monachy and Parliament and maybe another just for history of the Art within the palace as it all can't be done in the time frame given.Brilliant, well worth the time and money.
fantastic. IT took a long time with security to check in but the tour we were given was fantastic. It was so interesting and we really enjoyed the whole experience

Britain's symbol. If nothing else do not miss just a simple walk around it and take quite a mandatory photo from the Westminster Bridge. Every time you'll look at it you'll hear God save the Queen. I promise.

Everyone ought to visit sometime. An informative visit to a truly historic monument, amazing the number of people employed within this building in addition to the MP's and Lords, if you have the chance go for afternoon tea, amazing who you will see there

Don't miss!. If you have time go and see it. The tours are held by very professional guides that explain you a lot about the parliament and the history of Great Britain.
Book in advance!

One of the Most beautiful buildings in London.... I work opposite this iconic building and it's pure beauty never fails to grab me every time I see it. A must see for any visitor to London. If you just want to see the outside I would recommend seeing in the evening or night time as just as beautiful as day as less busy ( day times get very packed around Westminster) .

What an honor. I was invited to visit this with friends at the last minute. I was in total awe to see so many politicians going about their work day as if we visitors did not exist. The tour guide was extremely informative, & was quick to answer any questions. Every room, wall & corridor seemed to be loaded with history. We saw the room where the Queen is dressed to open parliament, the door that Blackrod knocks on. The green room for commons, the red room for the Lords. Just trying to take in a quarter of what our private tour guide was telling us was mind boggling. This is something anyone who is interest in both politics & history should put on their list of things not to miss in London. Make sure you try & reserve a visit before you leave home, getting in once you get to London is not always possible especially if your own schedule is tight.
Houses of Parliament. Really interesting and a very good guide who explained everything and answered questions. Lots of people there and lots of tours but very well organisaed

A must to visit. Strict security, efficient time-tables,interesting information given by the guide, tour of the many rooms, walking along the corridors passing members of the House going about their daily business. A tour to remember without a doubt.

Thoroughly enjoyed this tour.. I was not that keen to do the tour of the Houses of Parliament but was taken by surprise by how interesting it was. Quite a mission to get through security but once in well worth it.

Something special and worth a visit if you have time. This is something a package tour cannot give you.A chance for you to listen/ see live parliament session. But be prepared for the Q and the strict security check.

Houses of Parliament. This is one of the most iconic places in London have been past it many times on trips, love hearing big bens chimes, is lovely at night all lit up as is the embankment well worth a visit, I took photos in sept of last year me and a friend did a sightseeing tour of London we started right next to big ben at 12.00 and ended up back there at 20.00 that evening we had a fab day out.

Chaine Visits Parliament. This is a very special guided tour that took us through both houses. It is to be seen to be believed - plus there is an aire of calm, dignity and history that just can't be described. You would have to be without a soul not to feel in awe. There is so much to see and take in, but the tours are well structured and our guide was just amazing - knowledgeable, patient and most interesting. Just to touch the door, on the spot where centuries of "Black Rods" have knocked was very special.We were priviledged to be entertained for lunch on the Thamesside Terrace after our tour and Tim Lamming and Stephane Portes laid on a truely exquisite luncheon.I you enjoy great food and wine in iconic locations around the World, join us in the Chaine

really enjoyed tour. I would definitely recommend this tour of the houses of parliament. Took my grandson and we had a great time. The guides are funny and make the tour a memorable and interesting experience I take my grandson to London quite often and asked him which attraction he has liked the best so far and his answer was The Houses of Parliament, so that is a good recommendation from an 11 year old. Can I give the guides a pat on the back as it is them that make the experience as good as what it is.

Fascinating. Limited access to the public on a Saturday. Not only part of our history, but also fascinating architecture and artwork throughout. We saw House of Lords and House of Commons, both look so much smaller in real life than they do on TV.

Super Visit to heart of British Politics. This was an unexpected highlight trip of our visit to London ( we also visited Buckingham Palace & Westminster Abbey over 3 days )Our tour was courtesy of our local MP ( see Houses of Parliament website for more details ) & was arranged by him during Parliaments holiday recessOur tour guide was a large jovial man who made our visit extremely interestingHis knowledge of the history of past politicians & also Kings & Queens was excellent & the way he put it over to us made it even more enjoyableThe different "houses" in all there splendour was fascinating as where lots of other roomsDefinitely rate this "as a must see experience" of British at its best

Fantastic experience.. This tour was a brilliant experience. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and made parliament very interesting. Parts of the building are absolutely splendid. Very cheerful and helpful staff made us feel very welcome. Thanks to all involved.

A Great Experience. A great tour partially due to a good tour guide maybe.Starting in the old hall area then visiting the parts previously occupied by Victoria, then through to "the corridors of power".Swamped with information, all of great interest and visually very impressive.Looking to return again in near future, enjoyed it so much.

Proved better than expected. Finally got to go on this tour and it turned out to be a real treat. Got the chance to learn more about the history and politics of Britain with explanations as to why they are governed the way they are. The guide was friendly and allowed as many questions as one liked to ask. There is a cafe you can grab a quick bite in located there. You can also arrange to have afternoon tea in the Pugin Room, which we did. The afternoon tea was rather disappointing for me as the food was just so-so and the room is rather small. The service was very attentive and good but I wouldn't not care to do it again. There are much better places to have afternoon tea that are better and in the same price range of around £25 per person.

Have to see before coming home. Have to see. Unquestionable to think whether visit. It should be the most attractive point to see. If you are lucky, it will not rain and you can walk through the bridge and enjoy.

You will not regret seeing the inside of this fabulous, historical building.. Most London visitors see Big Ben and the outside of the Houses of Parliament. In fact, the first time I visited London, I was told you could not go inside. The official tours last only for a short time each year, but are very well done and educational. The tour guides are informative and entertaining, showing you the Houses of Lords and Commons, as well as the Queen's Robing Room. I learned about the history and functioning of Parliament as well as it's structure. For about $25 US, this 90 minutes is well worth your time. As you are not allowed to sit, you must be able to stand/walk for the full time. I would not recommend this tour for small children.

World class location. This is an absolutely world class place to visit!!!!!Packed with 1000 years of history, the buildings are covered with stunning decoration on every inch of floor wall and ceiling. Just an amazing place to visit and recommended without any reservation whatsoever. Do try to look up, down and sideways all the time or you will miss something wonderful!Our guide, Doris, was knowledgeable friendly and helpful, delivering a fascinating series of chats on the history of the building, English history, and even more so on the workings of parliament today and the English constitution. This tour is phenomenal value for money and easily the best building in the world that I have ever visited. Only the Hermitage in St Petersburg comes close. If you are visiting London then it is an ABSOLUTE must see.DO, I repeat DO. book and PAY for tickets on line. Fore reasons belowNow, the downsides. Be prepared for a full airport security screening. It is not intrusive but it is there.And a word to the "organisers". This is a classic case of how the British do NOT know how to market a world class product. There is no indication of where to buy tickets, a chance encounter pointed to "behind that white house over there". I queued for over an hour in not a long queue so why does it take 10 minutes to sell some tickets in this day and age?? Service was stone age. Whoever is responsible for this needs to get in the 21st century.PLEASE to not be put off by this, just find a way around it.
