This is an amazing experience and I know awesome is an over used word but this really is an absolutely stunning place to visit in every way.It makes me proud to be English !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Best London attraction. I've lived in London for 25 years and have only just done the Houses of Parliament tour. It's definitely the best 'tourist' thing I've done in London - or anywhere for that matter. Yes, it's expensive and you aren't allowed to explore for yourself but our guide was charming and full of fascinating facts. The building is beautiful and awe inspiring. Now I get why MPs love their job! It takes about 1 hour and a quarter and there's a fair bit of walking (with no sitting allowed!). Definitely not for younger children (although of course somebody did bring their young daughters - poor things were bored and exhausted). We also splashed out £25 per person for tea in the Pugin room which was a wonderful experience. Not the best afternoon tea in the world but not bad and the service was good. It's a small room and even though it's quite a touristy thing to do it in no way feels tacky or touristy. There is also a café if you don't want to splash out on the special afternoon tea (which has to be pre-booked - usually a few weeks in advance I think)
a must. if you´re looking for opinions as you haven´t decided yet, go ahead don´t miss it. we were very lucky to meet Adelaida, the tour guide, she was just PERFECT.
Brilliant!. A fantastic and informative tour. Caroline our fabulous tour guide was better than any history lesson I have had! It was great to see inside parliament - lots of 'wow' factor!

Totally amazing.. This was the best 1:15 minutes of our trip to England.
I was so surprised by how small the chambers were. Our guide was a savant. In a short time we learned the political history of England.
These are only on Saturdays and you should buy tickets online far ahead.

elaborate and interesting. we enjoyed a guided tour of this wonderful building, rich with history and amazing architecture. learned alot about how parliment works and the customs
an enjoyable place to visit

In our humble opinion: a must!. We have a habit to make a visit to a parliament, each time we are in a capital city. Our guide was very informative and clear. Unlike other visits to parliaments, where you watch the place through glass or from a gallery, on this one we walked INSIDE the House of Commons and the House of Lords (no sitting though). We even visited the room were the queen is getting ready for ceremony.Luckily, non of us were UK citizens, so our guide adapted the tour to his audience and assumed we no nothing about British politics.Three minuses:1. The tour is not free and not cheap. It is the first time we pay for a parliament tour.2. You are not allowed to take photos during the tour.3. As said above - no sitting. The tour can be difficult for old people who cannot walk/stand for an hour and a half.

Worth the Visit. This was one of the top things to do on my London to do list. The inside of the building is absolutely gorgeous, I'd post a few pictures but like just about every other leading attraction in London, no inside photography allowed. Before you visit make sure you check out the Parliament website, because there is only a short window of time when you can visit on weekdays. A bummer for non UK citizens, you can't go into the tower which houses Big Ben :(

Walk through history. Historical, interesting, incredible and the architecture is amazing. Walking through the halls where the likes of Margaret Thatcher and Winston Churchill walked, not to mention kings and queens, is quite a thrill.

Everyone should do this tour!. I visited the Palace of Westminster last week and was amazed at how much I enjoyed the tour. I came away thinking that every British schoolchild should experience this. The building is incredible and you can feel the history as you walk through the rooms. Our guide was a true English gent and was very informative and patient with a pretty large group of varying degrees of mobility and attentiveness. My only gripe of the whole tour is that there was lots of other tours going on and it was really busy so sometimes difficult to hear our guide. If I could suggest an improvement it would be to introduce a microphone and earpiece device that is available on many tours I've been on in the USA. I'd highly recommend this tour to anyone who is even remotely interested in British history.

What an Aura!. The feeling we got when being conducted around the House of Parliament was electrical, particularly when we saw some Ministers and MPs we usually see on TV. Prime Minister's Question Time was the highlight. The atmosphere at that time was fantastic.

One of the best things about our visit. Even though Parliament is in session, we were able to get tickets for the tour. 14GBP for seniors so make sure you ask for your discount if you're over 60. This takes 75 min, and we not only saw the Queen's dressing rooms, but the area the House of Lords use, the central area and House of Common. We got to stand in the ranks of both houses, heard stories about them as well as a great discription of how they work, why they do it that way and their additudes towards each other and the Queen. Our lady guide had a good sense of humor and excellent working knowledge of their entire system and this wonderful building. It's a must go, worth every minute and penny you'll spend. On days when tours are run, it's 8;30-4:30, check on line and this is not, as many other things aren't, handicap accessible.
Fantastic and memorable. The most beautiful building and the history was great - just the right amount of info. The guide was extremely good.

In depth tour. The tour through Parliment was impressive. There were so many grand rooms, each one more spectacular than the last. Our tour guide was very informative and in depth. The tour did last over an hour and we were walking and standing for most of it. We learned history on the building, the architects, the political history, and current government proceedings. No pictures were allowed inside the building.

Do Not Miss. My husband and I and 2 kids ages 11 and 14 did this hour plus tour. First off the building is totally gorgeous and worth the tour just to see the building. Tour is extremely interesting. It is living history. We almost skipped this as we were all feeling toured out, but my friends who lives in London insisted we do it and so glad we did. There is nice cafe there your can rest in before or after the tour.
Order, order. Very interesting, great history, totally worth doing, Tour guide was excellent and certainly knew her stuff

Great Tour. Took some guests of ours on this a few weeks ago and I was really surprised how good it was. The guide we had was great - very enthusiastic and full of little anecdotes. I wasn't sure how much I would enjoy the tour (I do have an interest in history but wouldn't say it is a huge interest) but believe it was well worth spending the time and money to do this.

A Shear waste of time for the Overseas guests. ,,,,,,,yes you read it right, after what I read on this site I was hoping to have an experience of the lifetime. Alas,,, it was not only the waste of time but the huge entry fees too, Sorry but neither I am an English nor am I a student of history, yes I was interested in clicking the photographs of this beautiful structure but guess what, you're not even allowed to click the photographs inside, what was I doing there then,,,,, actually cursing myself for why I paid so much for a lousy tour.The guide was a nice lady though, so added one star for her.Forgot to mention, you have to cross a heavy security zone too.

Walk through history at Parliament. The tour of Parliament is guided by knowledgable guides who share with you the history and grandeur of both the physical plant and the history that has been made within these walls. A worthwhile hour if you have any interest in English history.

Well worth the time and money. For 1 1/4 hours this tour is well worth your time and money. Very informative, but not overwhelming. It's amazing to get inside this gorgeous structure and learn about its history and a little bit about how the political system works today. You queue for normal security but it goes rather quickly and you can mull around and enjoy Westminster Hall after the tour is complete. The cafe is a great place to stop afterwards for a drink and a snack.

Touring Parliament. We were lucky to be in London during their summer recess and used Ticketmaster to pre-order tickets. Tickets bought this way are retrieved behind a white building across the street from the main tourist entrance. Give yourself plenty of time...it's a busy place. It is well worth it.

Parliament guided tour.. The Houses of Parliament are impressive from the outside, but are even more awesome (awful word I know) inside.BB and I were booked on the 11:00AM tour last Tuesday.It didn't start too well.... Our Chinese friends from over the water were trying to go through the solo turnstiles and revolving doors two at a time at the Cromwell Green entrance to the HP, and got stuck/hurt in the process! Much to the annoyance of some of the persons in our queue, BB and I found it rather amusing. Crazy stuff.The tour itself started and finished in the impressive Westminster Hall which is among the older parts of the building. Our tour guide (a mature, slim, blonde lady) was very informative and pleasant. At times we could hardly hear her (she was quite softly spoken) due to the noise from other tour parties in the background. That is not a crticism of our guide though.The tour itself was marvellous and we were lucky enough to get into the Commons and Lords chambers which weren't in use at that time.We were also shown round many other corridors, chambers and lobbys, all of which contained many great works of art.I'd recommend the tour to anyone who likes history and art.

Well worth a visit. This was the second time we had toured the Houses of Parliament and it was just as good as the first time. The tour is well organised from buying and collecting your tickets through to security in and out.Starting in the great hall the guide was extremely knowledgeable and gave us just the right amount of interesting information.Seeing all the main areas really brought home to me how Parliament works including some very weird and ancient customs (ask about Black Rod!).After the tour we had booked afternoon tea in the Pugin room which was a lovely add-on. The food was well presented and the service excellent. To be fair it was not the best afternoon tea we have had but a fantastic location.
History of London. we visited in September a great time to travel, lovely buildings and lots to see and do allow plenty of time.

See them from Outside!. The best photos and view of these historical buildings is from the Thames river cruise! We saw them from the street and the park, but the best is taking the river cruise at sunset in the fall!

Excellent tour. I was very upset when I realized Parliament would not be in session. However, If they had, I would not have been able to enjoy this wonderful tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable, very witty, and very easy to understand. There were several tours going on and we never felt rushed or neglected.

Parliament. I thoroughly enjoyed the House of Parliament tour. The grandeur of the houses was spectacular. I was disappointed that our guide didn't often ask for questions and I had a million burning ones, that were mostly forgotten by the end of the tour and question time. I also felt a little rushed, but overall the tour guide was very informative and I left with much more knowledge than I came with.

This tour was a highlight of our trip.. You can tour the Houses of Parliament on most Saturdays. Tickets sell out quickly, so get yours as soon as you can. The tour guides are quite knowledgable and you get to see the both Houses and walk in the footsteps of those who make the laws of the land. Make sure and read all of the plaques on the floor in the room where your tour begins and ends. It is the oldest room in the whole place and many important things happened in this room throughout history. This ended up being one of our favorite tours on our vacation.

Fantastic. This was not on Rick Steve guide book, but the guided tour is a must do. You'll be going from the house of lords to the house of commons, and into the royal chamber the queen uses when she opens parliament once a year. lots of history, do not miss this tour.

Take time to do this!. We spent several hours on a Saturday doing a guided tour around Parliament! It was one of my favorite things of our 9 day trip. We had a great guide who was very knowledgeable about the history of Parliament, as well as their processes and interactions with the monarchy! It was fascinating to see both the House of Commons and the House of Lords and see where things actually take place. It is a stunning building, rich with history and a definite must when visiting London for any period of time. We booked our trip through the Parliament website--which shot us over to UK Ticketmaster. It was reasonably priced and without a doubt one of the best things we did during our time there.

Fascinating insight into how government works!. We went as part of a group & it was a guided tour. Photos not allowed, only in the entrance hall & outside. Airport security as expected. The opulence of the House of Lords compares starkly with the comparative poverty of the House of Commons, the latter having been rebuilt in the 1950s after bomb damage in WWII. Many terms explained (wool sack, lobby, lobbyists etc) & we loved the tennis ball story told to us by our guide! Good tea room - an essential after the long tour!!!

Historical Houses of Parliment.. This is an excellent tour and well worth the money. I only wish it could have been longer. There is so much to see that it would be nice to wander around at your leisure. Of course, for security reasons, this is not possible. There is a lot of security on arrival, then you are put into groups of 25 to begin the tour. My only criticism is that you can hear the other tour guides speaking as there are about three groups in each place at once. However the guide was most informative and you could ask as many questions as you wanted. The building is so impressive you don't know where to look first and it is steeped in history. The tour includes both Houses of Parliament, Queens robing room, Royal gallery, Central lobby and St Stephens porch and hall. The only place you can sit down is in the NO lobby next to the House of Commons so you are standing for over an hour. I would really recommend this as it is an excellent day out.
Are you curious about the "House of Lords"?. If you like history or simply want to know more about British system of government you should take a guided tour inside the Parliament.It's worthwhile!

What an experience.. We were able to just about walk up and get tickets to hear a debate in the House of Commons. It was quite an experience. There was security but not nearly as much as I expected there to be. The debate was cordial between those involved but it was interesting to see how the members reacted vocally about what was going on. Sitting in the chambers probably was about the highlight of our trip

Do a tour!. I am lucky enough to have friends who work at Parliament so I got a behind-the-scenes tour, and I loved it. If you know someone who works there, obviously do this!! But, they also do public tours, which I was told are just as good, so I'd highly recommend it! The tour guides are very knowledgable, and you get to hear of interesting stories and tidbits. You can't take pictures inside but you can get some pictures outside of Big Ben and the exterior, which is neat.

Wonderful History Lesson. The tour is well worth the price. The guide really knew her British hsitory and made the tour fun, as we traced the steps of the Queen each May. I still cannot believe that it takes over 1400 representatives to make the laws for a country of 63 million. I thought the 540 representing the US population of 314 million was too many. Unfortunately we did not see Harry. He was there that day for his cousin's wedding.

Could have been so so so much better!. I am so annoyed at our wooden, quick tempered tour guide! She managed to make Miss Jean Brodie appear nice and fluffy! The tour could have easily been 30 minutes longer, we practically jogged round! The building is amazing and it is hard not to be impressed, enthralled and interested. Other tour guides we overheard appeared warm, engaging and peppered their talks with anecdotes and quips. I guess we were just unlucky! A visitors centre could very much enhance the tour, with architectural displays and some parliamentary books, notes etc. I would like to go back and have another guide!

A Must Do Tour. I booked the tickets and paid for the guidebook on line as it gave a discount. When we arrived we went through airport style security and were then able to sit in the Great Hall until our tour time was ready. Richard our guide was truly excellent and had so much information and dates to tell. The Gothic style building is awe inspiring with so many paintings, frescoes and statues. The tour includes both Houses of Parliament, Queens robing room, Royal gallery, Central lobby and St Stephens porch and hall. The only place you can sit down is in the NO lobby next to the House of Commons so you are standing/ambling for over an hour. I last came here 50 years ago and my dad got into trouble then for sitting on a seat and nothing has changed.The guide book is exceptional value and a really good memento as you cannot take photographs.If you visit London you must see the Palace of Westminster - the home of Parliaments.
Walk by.. Worth a glance. Near the river and the eye ride. Get a picture of the clock. A bit cramped across the street.
Truly Inspiring. What a wonderful opportunity to visit the heart of rule for the British isles. If you enjoy history, politics, and world events, then this is a must see during your time in London.
Toured both houses. Beautiful old Tudor castle now used for Parliament. Don't miss if they are open. Learned a bit about UK government and about the building itself. Great guide, very knowledgeable.

excellent architecture. super like. UNESCO World Heritage Site.The stonework of the building was originally Anstone, a sand-coloured magnesian limestone.The Elizabeth Tower's fame has surpassed that of the Palace itself.

A spectacular 1,000 year old building - a must see!. All that remains of the original Whitehall Palace, this vast, imposing space, is almost 1,000 years old and is one of the largest Medieval buildings in Europe.It used to be much more difficult to visit. Now it is easy.Go to see where Winston Churchill and the Queen Mother lay in State. Where visiting heads of state, including Barack Obama, have addressed both Houses of Parliament.This was my third visit over the years - it still has the power to awe.
Amazing. So much history, knowledgable guides and you get to see everything you could want to see... A perfect and fascinating experience
Order, Order. we had a great time, guide was brill, was shown the main parts of the building and had High Tea in the Putin Room

Didn't intend to go in but turned out great!. I was just strolling around, when I saw people in line going in the building.It wasn't after I got in that I knew this was the House of Parliament!But I was lucky to be able to watch the two parties debating over something, and I just sat there are watched them talking... It didn't matter I couldn't really hear what they were talking about, but just the fact that I'm there when they are perhaps debating over some important issue made me.... hmmm... feel good.I has become one of my most lasting memories from London.I guess that's the charm of solo idle traveling.

Didnt realise parts of this place were so beautiful. What ever your views on parliament, visiting this place purely for the architectural delights on offer is well worth doing. Very entertaining blue badge guided tour with lots of interesting information and stories.

Parliament. I give this a top rating for a number of reasons. It is the mother of parliaments, it is housed in magnificent architecture, the tour guides are excellent, and it can be experienced in about seventy-five minutes. It would be a shame to visit London and miss this.

Very insightful and. Being a political junkie, I was really excited to learn more about the Houses of Parliament and how they operated. It's one thing to see the massive historical building from the outside in all of its glory but to walk the halls inside was breathtaking. Once through security, we met in Westminster Hall, the oldest part of the Palace of Westminster, and set off for over an hour learning more in each chamber along the way. Our guide was extremely well versed in his delivery of facts and figures and his delivery was never boring. He explained the difference between the House of Lords and the House of Commons, how bills are presented, voted upon and become laws. The art on the walls, statues, carvings and stained glass windows are simply stunning. Being present in areas where some of the greatest figures throughout history walked was amazing, but to have some of the stories laid out along the way made this particular tour so much richer. If you are someone who has a keen interest in history or how government works, whether you are from Great Britain or anywhere else, this highly informative tour should not be missed.

Best Kept Secret In London. WOW, We were walking past and noticed they had tours, didn’t’ think much and I decided to take my 9 & 10 year old girls. We were all impressed and cannot believe we were going to walk past. Best kept secret in London this tour. A MUST SEE. Westminister Parliament, the original building is about 900 years old; the building is magnificent inside, it was a wonderful insight into English history and every tour is with a guide.

Regal and full of history. My 16 yr old and I toured Houses of Parliament today and really enjoyed it.We booked online and arrived a few minutes early to look at this amazing building.You get broken up into small group and each has an experienced guide.Our guide Richard a part time actor enhanced his monologue with drama.Lovely history and building.Only complaint is they in there very English way would not allow you to sit anywhere!!!Really ridiculous as there are seats everywhere but not for commoners bums!!!!Still very worthwhile visiting!!!

Must to go for a tour!. Great tour, make sure to check the schedule and book in advance. It's very interesting and you can follow historical corridors which are still in use with the how history background.

Totally fascinating. To my shame, despite having lived in England all my life, I learnt a huge amount about the Houses of Parliament and the machinery of government from this tour, and realised how ignorant I had been before. Our guide was excellent, very informative and also INTERESTING, which is where many guides fall down. She even endeared herself to my wife by mentioning Colin Firth twice (in the context of King George VI)! The building, the chambers and the rooms are amazing, especially the House of Lords, and their history is fascinating. It really made it all come alive to be there. Strongly recommended!Also there must have been thousands doing the tour through the day and it was to the organisers' credit that everything happened so efficiently. We found the on-site cafe was an excellent place to eat and (for London) quite reasonably priced too.

Truly excellent tour. I had been concerned about this since I hate crowds. I needn't have worried, once through security (they could do with air-conditioning if only for the staff!) which did not take long we were out in a spacious environment. We were put into groups of 25 for the guided tour which lasted about 1.25 hours. It was SO interesting. Such good value for money, one of the best tours I have been on. The only little niggle was occasionally 2 groups would be in close proximity and some guides had very loud voices so it was difficult to listen to your own.
Walk along the Thames. Just a walk that ended with the Westminister part. quite a nice area and we got there just on noon. So we heard Big Ben do his noon thing

Interesting and busy. A lot is packed into this tour. It's well organised. They do prewarn you about the minimal access to seating and this is true. Some found it hard to hear everything when there were 2 or more tour groups nearby. There's a cafe and small gift shop. Understandable there's no photography permitted once you're past the hall (the start and end point of the tour). Is worth going and was very easy to book.
Tour of Parliamnet. The tour was very informative and very well organized. You show up at your specified time and within a few minutes we were allowed in. I would definitely recommend this tour.

Excellent Tour. We were extremely pleased with our tour guide for Parliament. He not only covered the rooms and building history; he also included a very informative overview of how the government works and what happens within the walls of Parliament. He made it so interesting, kept us on schedule and we learned allot!

the center of power. the guided tour to the houses of parliament is a must in London. The building is wonderful and the histories the guides tell are very interesting and help understand the particularities of the English history
sightseeing. good to see the london sights and see these places in the flesh as it were not just on TV. you dont relise how big the place actual is.

Superb !. Made me proud to be British. Have admired the architecture from outside many, many times. However to step inside The palace and see the fantastic Pugin decoration was amazing. We arranged this tour with the help of our local MP. You need to email or write to him/her and request a free tour of the Palace with dates that you are able to make. They recommend giving four months notice. You can visit in Summer I believe and pay £16.50 which would be something I would be prepared to do in future. Until you see inside you can not believe how wonderful it is. The tour starts in Westminster Hall the largest hammer beam hall in Europe. Lasts approx. 75 minutes. Treat as going through airport security and you will be fine. So do not take your Swiss Army knife etc.. Want to go again and again as it goes so quick. Small café once inside with regular London prices. Enjoy.

Excellent.. This is one place I have wanted to visit to tick off my to do list, I was not disappointed, the tour guide was friendly and really knew her stuff. I didn't know much about the history of the buildings. I do now. Walking through the Lords and commons to see in person what you see on the tv was really interesting. Great way to spend a couple of hours.
Fab!. This entire area is loaded with lots to do and see! Never a dull moment! Make sure you're there by dusk when the lights go on the HoP is really much more devastatingly beautiful.

Worth the time. Purchased tickets online before our tour. Guide was wonderful and the tour really shows off most of the rooms of the parliament. Really enjoyed seeing the rooms and paintings we see on tv. Security just like everywhere but handle quickly and efficiently.

An experience to remember!. I got bored one day in London so I thought I would nip along to the Houses Of Parliament and watch the House Of Commons "In-session". Its quite interesting to walk around and see inside. What was really good on the day was being in the gallery and watching one of the most famous moments unfurl in front of my eyes. George Galloway being "named" and removed from parliament. That made it worthwhile.
Seeing is beliving. To stand in front of these magnificent buildings blows me away every time.They are not real until you actually see them

Excellent Tour. This tour is an hour long and very informative and interesting. The building is beautiful on the outside as well as on the inside, however, you cannot take photos during your tour. I feel like we have learned a lot and we have enjoyed this tour very much. I booked this tour through Tickemaster.uk for 16.50 pounds per person.

History and life. As a UK citizen have always wanted to visit but never found the time. Part two of a day trip to London (Part one- St Pauls Cathedral) . Visited at 16.00 on a booked tour. As no session sitting relatively quick to book on the spot no waiting. Well worth a visit. Tour guide (Linda) very knowledgeable, eager to answer queries, brought history and current politics into alignment with ease. I now understand the history lessons I failed to be interested in when younger Ha Ha. Amazing architecture, fantastic sculpture/busts, paintings, political changes, royal lineage brought to life. Acknowledging our eminent guide ability this is a very interesting visit which can be topped off by a visit to the attached cafe (not too expensive) or be indulgent and have tea as part of the experience in the associated restaurant.

Members Visit. I arranged for my wife and I to have a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament. It was very informative and the guide was great. Amazing to see such a huge part of our history for yourself. Tours are available to anyone priced £16.50 however if you e-mail your MP, they will arrange it for free.

A "must do" tour. Fabulous.. This is one of those tours that you simply must do if you get the opportunity. The history is, of course, tremendous, but so is the architecture and furnishings. Our guide was enthusiastic, knowledgeable, professional, passionate, humorous and interesting. From seeing a few other groups' reaction, I'd all the guides are good.On our London trip we had wonderful guided tours of St Paul's, the Tower of London and Buckingham Palace's State Rooms. This Houses of Parliament tour was the best. We're Australians in our late fifties and loved it!! Others in the group were from USA, Hong Kong, Sri Lanka, Canada and the Uk - they all said it was great too and with us gave our guide a nice round of spontaneous applause.

a great place to visit. great but you will be treated like a child. no sitting in the house of commons or the house of lords and don't sit here don't sit there and I will tell you when you can sit. so if you need to sit a lot don't go.

Tour of the Houses of Parliament. This was a last minute decision to take a tour of the Houses of Parliament but one we really enjoyed. Living in the UK all our lives I had never thought of doing this, or even that you could! It was very organised and the guide was extremely knowledgable and friendly. It was enlightening to see inside this wonderful building and to see where decisions involving the country are made. If you're visiting London and are going to have a couple of hours spare I would recommend you take a look.

fascinating and a must see. Book tickets in advance to visit the Houses of Parliament. The hour long or so tour was very interesting. Our guide Isabelle was very friendly and gave a thorough tour of the Houses of Parliament and the parliamentary process. It was particularly exciting because the House of Commons had just met the night before to vote on an issue. Worth the visit if you have the time!

Must see. We went to the guided tour of the Parliament. Beautiful building and many interesting things regarding the local politics and traditions. Do bear in mind that the security is tight and they search you as of airport security.

Superb experience. Booked through my MP and his assistant, this guided tour was excellent. The contrast between both Houses was incredible and the architecture was wonderful to see..... a highly recommended, must-see experience.

A very interesting 2 hours!. I had never been to the Houses of Parliament before, in fact I didn't even know you could book for a semi private tour. I thought everything needed to be done through a special agency.I was told that it is possible by a friend and since we were due to be in London, thought it would be a worthwhile trip - it was!We booked a pass through our MP which was very straightforward. On arrival, we went through airport style security, just to make sure that we weren't planning to play Guy Fawkes - quite reassuring really - and were directed to Westminster Hall where we awaited our guide. The hall itself is worth a visit, with parts dating back to the 11th Century. Once our guide arrived,we found ourselves in a group of about 15 and were taken on an informative tour of the House of Lords and House of Commons. Unfortunately,photography was not allowed which is a real shame because this must be one of the most beautiful buildings in the country. The pictures hanging on the walls and the murals were simply stunning and should be seen. Having said that, I also quite like the idea of some mystique being in place.If you are a regular shopper in the high street (I'm not) you probably won't mind the trudge, stop, trudge, stop routine of this tour but if you are like me you might find it a bit wearying on your lower back - especially as you are not allowed to sit down anywhere apart from the division room outside of the House of Commons - and then only for a minute whilst the guide gives you more information.This tour is free of charge and is one of the best I can think of in London. It is definitely worthwhile making the effort to book and go along to where your elected representatives make decisions about your life!

Fantastic age gone by. It like a step back in history and this castle which is now the houses of parliament does not disappoint. I personally love the history our great country has especially looking at the the prortraits. Went into both galleries and touched the messages boxes. I was surprised at how small the actual seats are in the commons and would not like to sit for any length of time on them. Beware though the general public are not allowed to sit on any seats in there as you are not an elected member.
Very interesting. Anyone with large or little amount of interest in politics will enjoy this experience. Would definitely recommend a visit.

Worth a Look, Busy Attraction!. A slight queue for security checking, staff helpful and friendly throughout. Tour takes you around the building and guides provide facts and history answering any questions you may have. Can be difficult to always hear guide if large group (24) and other groups are behind and in front of you. It's a busy attraction so be prepared and expected. No photography permitted inside except the main hall. But good guide book available from the shop afterwards or collect if you have a pre paid ticket from there as well. Takes in sights of Queens route for state opening from stairs to robing room. Into Lords chamber then through corridors into the different joining area's of the estate. You then enter the commons and see and hear the facts of how it all works. You cannot sit on the chairs on either chamber but the pace is fair so ample time for you. You don't have to know politics, be well educated or think things will be complicated. It's a tour for anyone with an interest in the history, the workings and worth a look. You can get free entry week days via your MP, but I wanted Saturday so had to advance pay, but for the price as things go these days it was fair.Learnt quite a few things and saw this historic site which is an eye opener and I'm no history enthusiast!Makes you think about those from hundreds of years ago who worked there and will continue to do so beyond our life times. Tradition is certainly a strong theme running through this priceless estate.So if your deciding then I would advise go for it! Approx 1.5 to 2 hours visit.

One not too miss!. We took a guided tour lasting 90 minutes. The guide was very informative. You get to see the Throne room, both Chambers, the Division Lobbies etc. lots of paintings depicting historical events with lots of battle scenes. Observe the full size statues of several past Prime Ministers and smaller busts of others. The decor is ornate and we felt privileged to be taking a peep at what goes on behind doors, which used to be closed!

Really great tour!. I wasn’t expecting to enjoy this as much as I did, I booked it for my partner who enjoys following politics and we both found it very interesting.The tour is estimated to take 75 minutes and involves a lot of standing and walking, there are very few places or times to sit during the tour and I wouldn’t recommend it for people who have difficulty standing/walking for lengths of time.Arrive at least 20 minutes before your tour as the security check to enter is airport style security and can take time.The tour starts in the oldest part of the Parliament buildings – Westminster Hall – where groups are arranged into tour groups according to their preferred language, guides are then able to conduct an entire tour in your preferred language rather than having to say things in two different languages.Our ‘Blue Badge’ guide called Liz was great! She was engaging and knowledgeable and obviously enjoys being a guide. Most of what is seen on the tour was built in the mid 19th Century following a devastating fire in 1834, but the route also incorporates Westminster Hall, begun in 1097 by William Rufus, son of William the Conqueror.The tours start by following the route taken by The Queen at the State Opening of Parliament; from The Queen’s Robing Room, through the Royal Gallery and Prince’s Chamber, into the majestic Lords Chamber. This part is very ornate with much to see and admire, these rooms look more like a royal palace than a government building and they have a lot of interesting features.Tours then move on through Central Lobby, Members’ Lobby and one of the voting lobbies before entering the Commons Chamber, scene of many lively debates.Passing through St Stephen’s Hall, the tours end in 900 year old Westminster Hall, a place where many historic trials have taken place and where Nelson Mandela and Barack Obama have addressed Parliament in more recent years. Lots of the notable events held in this area are detailed on gold plaques in the floor leading up the stairs.The Jubilee Cafe, located next to Westminster Hall, offers a selection of light meals and hot and cold drinks, the cafe was full at the time our tour finished and so we didn’t stop off for a refreshment as we’d have liked. If I were to make a suggestion it would be to have smaller tables and more of them as there were lots of single people or couples taking up tables for much larger parties and we weren’t in the mood to ask if we could share a table.The bathrooms are clean and checked hourly.The souvenir shop is located in Westminster Hall and stocks a range of goods at very reasonable prices, we were expecting to be charged much more for these items.We booked in advance and paid £16.50 per adult for the Saturday and Summer Opening tour of the Houses of Parliament – this is really great value for all that is included and the length of the tour.We’ll be recommending this tour to anybody with an interest in architecture, politics, royal palaces and/or history, the tour covers so many different topics that there is much to be learnt and it is a really good half day activity.

History Alive!. A friend of mine took there as a private tour.Both houses are amazing and I am glad to observe how British political system is functioning with traditions continued from Magna Carta. This is a must place to visit anyone coming to London.Souvenir shop is not in Westminster Hall instead of St Stephen's Hall.Please take a look at the attached photo. PM Cameron cut budget so much that loo is overdue for cleaning....

Interesting. We had a 75 minute tour arranged via our MP. Our guide was knowledgeable and made the tour very interesting. What struck me was the size of the place and the sumptuous decor in the Lords part of the palace - the commons is much more - well common. It's good to see where it all happens and to learn a bit of the history and the customs associated with Parliament. My tip would be book well in advance .

A Gothic style building. One of the iconic scenic photographs to take home along with Big Ben and the River Thames. Take a slow walk in the area and feast your eyes on the sights of the Houses of Parliment from the bridge.

Amazing. It's such an amazing experience to see it all in person! Just walking around the outside is a treat. The architecture is truly one of a kind. A must visit when in London with memorable photos.

Then and Now - Simply Stunning. I worked in the Houses of Parliament many years ago, when you could wander up, and gain access with very little fuss. It is so sad that I am now witnessing guns and spikes for protection! Still - the history is evident and it is a 'must see' if you are visiting London - obviously!
Fun and neat stairs. This was an awesome add to our London trip. Inexpensive and you get a certificate at the end. A bit crowded which made passing tricky on the staircase. A must see!

Living history. Well worth a tour, when Parliament is not sitting.
There is a strong sense of history and one can imagine Winston Churchill making one of his famous speeches.
The chamber is interesting and we were lucky to witness a live debate.

Interesting. By the time I got here my feet were aching from all the walk around site seeing so I did not go in. I just stayed out side enjoying the beauty of the architecture while taking picture of myself from different directions with the statue and structure. The site of the is very fascinating. My pictures here *re my treasure

If doing the monuments.... You definitely should see the Palace of Westminster (the UK Houses of Parliament). As a lawyer, I wanted to see them as we have such a close connection to the English legal tradition, but on another level - Parliament & Big Ben (and even the Churchill statue in the square opposite) are monuments that are quintessential London and UKWe didn't do the guided tours, but just to see it was enough for us.

Very interesting-great to see much history. Went with my 15 yr old niece. Interesting, steeped in history and some fascinating tales and stories. Loved the little Post Office in the middle of parliament-wish I'd brought something to post!

Awesome tour and very historical. We had a marvelous tour of HOP. I am so glad we decided to take a tour as it gave us such an insight into the history of the buildings and all of the historical things that occurred there. Beautiful artwork and rooms. We also got a great introduction into the parliamentary law process in England. Definitely would go again and recommend it to anyone!

Excellent Historic Location. Very easy to prebook this on the internet for a set time after we had done the Palace tour. Excellent value as for £16.50 per adult we had 1.5hrs guided tour and the children were free with two full paying adults.Our guide was very good indeed. It was all really interesting; both Commons and Lords plus the voting procedure for MPs; two MPs having missed voting the recent highly policitical Syrian vote/debate because they hadn't heard the bell. Bells are placed throughout Parliament giving MPs minutes to get to the Commons to vote. They are also placed in local hostelries and hotel lobbies (recall staying at St Ermins years ago and they have direct communication with Parliament). Very very interesting tour/few hours overall.There is bathroom facilities in Westminster Hall before the tour starts but nothing on route. Wheelchairs are provided for.

A wonderful building worth seeing. We had a very knowledgeable guide who escorted us through both houses giving an in-depth history of Parliament. It is surprising how small the chamber is in the Commons.It is very simple to arrange a visit. Simply email your Member of Parliament and ask him to arrange a tour.

MP -Verandra Sharma. Visited this historical place as a guest to MP Verandra Sharma , also meeting other guest as well. It is free entrance ,security is very tight , they give a photo id for the visitor. We had a small meeting in one of the committee room.
Watch reasonable people differ. Watching the debate and seeing how reasonable people can still discuss different opinions and accomplish things..

History lesson as well as magnificence. Been to London many times but never got around to HofP as I thought it was too much effort. However, I just went to the box office at the Jewel Tower opposite, and though there was a short queue, there were plenty of spaces on all tours as they go every 15 minutes. I got on the next one and while waiting, the time is spent in the remaining part of the old Westminster Hall. Groups are kept to 15 people, so quite intimate and lots of interesting stories related by the guides. The tour was about an hour, then you can have a break in the cafe, where I found the staff really lovely, helping with trays and finding a table for you. It wasn't really crowded so no one had to rush. You'd pay more for a coffee, but hey, afternoon tea at HofP!!

So Impressive in Person. When you walk up the steps of the Westminster tube, you can see this towering structure as you emerge from the station. I've seen pictures of this building my entire life, but seeing it in person - there aren't really any words to describe this impressive structure. Nice place to walk around.

Beautiful & interesting peek at British government. Spectacular building and a wonderful explanation on how and why certain traditions are carried out by the British government and how the Queen fits into the picture. One if my favorite tours during our visit.

Fun. And I mean that. It was enjoyable and a good take but I expected to learn something about their form of government. This is not the tour for that. Enjoyable none the less, to hear some inside stories and funny sidebars. I guess you can't become an expert in 60 minutes.... I recommend the tour but go into it knowing it won't enlighten you about the workings of the parliamentary system. Fun to see the real live place it all happens.
Excellent interior. If you are lucky enough to go inside, try and make a time for a trip. The architecture is excellent and you really feel you are walking through history!

If you can get in, it's well worth it. Parliament was not in session so were able to book tickets in advance. The guided tour was very informative and well worth the time you'd spend. How often do you get to stand in the aisles of House of Common and House of Lords? A lot of history at the Westminster Palace

Bit of History. Had an excellent guide and thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience. Took about one and a half hours and since parliament was sitting we got into the House of Lords and House of Commons.
Quite something. Now this is a place of culture and history. One can beautiful pictures from Westminster bridge. Whichever angle one looks from, the architecture is amazing.

Not giving it away but worth it. The Houses of Parliament are a must see in London and after many visits to the UK we finally organised a visit. The guides make the difference in interpreting the history, the building, the customs and some antidotes. Well worthwhile and easily mixed with other great must see and do activities in the area to make a full day out.
A bit of culture!!. If you get a chance go for the tour of The Houses of Parliament. It's interesting and informative and not at all stuffy as I thought it would be. A very well spent afternoon.

Good value I thought. Control of the tour is strict but this understandable. Its not as big as you expect and with so many tours this can be tight squeeze at some points but steeped in history, very informative guides and thought great value.

Fascinating. I took a morning tour. It was fascinating visiting the inside of this iconic group of buildings and to learn about the history. The staff were very clever in filling up empty spaces on tours, so that I was able to take a tour earlier than the one I had booked. My guide was very knowledgeable and funny.I'll have to return.

Wonderful experience. If going to London, try and get onto a guided tour of Westminster Palace or, as more commonly known, the Houses of Parliament. The tour lasts for just over an hour and half and with a very knowledgeable guide in Brigid, we had a most educational experience. To get a better understanding of the operations of Parliament and the the ancient threats against the stability of government was intriguing. The opulence of the House of Lords was also marvellous. A good tour.

Offering an alternative. My husband and I were in London for four nights, Monday through Friday. We went to Parliament on Thursday afternoon and nicely asked if we could walk in on our own. We were, of course, told no ~ Saturdays are the only time tours are permitted inside. I was disappointed and said I'd have to plan my next visit to include a Saturday. To my surprise, the guard asked if we wanted to go to the gallery and observe the House of Commons in session. YES! We had to go through security and were issued visitor tags. We were handed off from one guard to another, never being permitted to be on our own, but in the process we got to walk through Westminster Hall and learn about its history. Then we climbed many flights of stairs before handing over our bags and cameras. Then we entered the viewing gallery. There were only 15-18 members present as summer break began the next day. But this approach could work from Sept. - early July.
COOL. It was very interesting if you are into looking at things and sight seeings almost. Not too much to do but lots to look at.

Truly spectacular. From the time you see the grandeur of his most spectacular building with Big Ben you will be in awe the entire time. The architectural masterpiece is incredible. I don know way to say about this site except it is a must see while visiting London

London's Masterpiece of Power & History. I have visited this magnificent place many times, and hosted private events in the House of Lords, which is the seat of law and justice in this country. You absorb the historical significance of decades of English power throughout the grand hallways, where Winston Churchill and Maggie Thatcher ruled. Deep, rich wood, dark red velvet, hunter green and cavernous ceilings are classically distinctive, with a sense of awe and tradition. Event rooms have outdoor pavilions overlooking the Thames, with flawless service and average food. But no one comes for the eats! You must personally know a Lord to host an event, as the protocol is strict.

Impressive History. One of the must-see historical spots in London. Your trip isn't complete if you miss it. The architecture is just so amazing to experience first hand. Not to mention being able to sit in on debate sessions! Educational!

interesting. I've visited the Houses of Parliament twice. I've taken the english tour a few years back and this year the german tour. Both times it was a really excellent tour and both tour guides were really knowledgable and told interesting stories.

Impressive Historical Experience. My wife and I visited the Houses of Parliament as part of a tour group. This tour is very interesting, as you learn some history and the background of unique practices and procedures, which differ from those of the US Congress. I have a disability which does not allow me to walk long distances and they accommodated my needs with a wheel chair, which required the use of special elevators and back corridors. This was all done with the greatest care and friendliness.

Definitely Worth a Visit. We were not sure whether to visit the Houses of Parliament or not. We were so glad that we did. The building is magnificent. The guide helped us to better understand the UK's system of government and tradition. She was very knowledgeable and energetic.

Parliament & Big Ben. We went but didn't go in. Apparently when they are in session, you can only get in on Saturday. The lady at the gate told us that the tours fill up very quickly so log into the visitor website as soon as the tours dates appear.

Well worth the price!. I visited the Houses of Parliament in July, and it was a really excellent tour. You have to book it ahead, so don't just show up and expect to get in. The tour guide was really knowledgable and told interesting stories. My only quibble is that the group was kind of large. For the price, it would have been nice to have a smaller group so you could hear better. With such a large group and so many other groups in the same areas, it was hard to hear the guide at times. But overall a great experience and I'm happy I did it.
Great to see. I have to say it was nice to finally see the houses of parliament in person. Glad to see Guy fawkes failed. They are impressive and picturesque against the Thames.

My favorite building. This was my favorite building of all the many architecturally interesting sites throughout London. It's a definite must see, but one that you'll definitely come across as you see Big Ben and Westminister Abbey nearby.

Obligated visit. Just to understand the complexity of the britis, their history and their empire is difficult. Houses of parliament give you the feeling behind it all. I enjoyed my visit and have to catalog it as a must when in London

Magnificent. A truly stunning building that never fails to impress me every time I go past it. The guided tour (which I think only happens on certain days) is actually surprisingly interesting too: a fascinating glimpse into hundreds of years of British history. Plus, the architecture is just as magnificent on the inside as it is on the outside.An absolute must-see on any visit to London - if only to capture that iconic postcard image!

Show stopper. The building is beautiful. So much to see in detail and workmanship . Well worth seeing. Big Ben and West Minister Abbey is across the street . The whole area needs time to sit and take in the scene.
Best building ever. Just think this is the most amazing building ever. And Big Ben. Right on the River. Wow! Just love it and pleased old guy fawkes didn't manage to blow it up.

Awesome Experience!. I really wanted to tour the Houses of Parliament, and I scheduled my trip to London during August just so I could take this tour. My two teenagers accompanied me, and we all came away very impressed. The lady who gave the tour was well-spoken and informative, and we learned so much about the history of parliament, and the building itself, plus we heard some very humorous stories. A few months prior to this tour, we toured our own U.S. Capitol, and while the building itself was beautiful, we were not as impressed with the tour as we were with this one. If I am every in London again in August, I would take this tour a second time.

House of Lords. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting the House of Lords and being present on the floor during one of the debates. I subsequently visited again for an evening debate on the European Central Bank which was immensely interesting even if I did not agree with views expressed.! It was history - Live ! The architecture, drama and beauty of the House and the entrance to Parliament is essential for a visitor as so much of England revolves around these building allied to that the most historic clock tower in the world, Big Ben. The staff and security are always welcoming and most professional, just once you are in the house, stay quiet !Enjoy !

Excellent Architectural and Historical Buildings. Beautiful building, set across the street from the most beautiful building in London the Westminster Abbey. Breathtaking historical buildings that make ones head spin with size and scope and old-world workmanship and engineering.

Amazing... Iconic structures everywhere you look. We approached the Houses of Parliament walking past Westminster Abbey, catching a glimpse of Big Ben (I still like to call it that). The buildings are amazing, they're harsh, bold, a display of strength and power. They are best experienced up close, but best viewed and photographed from across the Thames. Whilst there a look down the river will present a contrast, with modern image of the London Eye dominant on the shoreline.

Love History. If you love history and want to see inside that fabulous building, this is one outstanding tour. Westminster Hall with details of all that's happened there was amazing. The coffee shop is a MUST at the end of your visit.

Great. While I didn't go on a tour of Parliament I still recommend a visit. The building is very interesting to look at. Parliament's location is very central within London and makes a good place to meet up or start a day out in the city.
Everything costs in London. Liked the tour, was however fairly rushed with a hefty price. Guide was interesting and gave a good show.

A real parliament. A brilliant piece of architecture. With the Thames river to give it perennial company, this House of Lords and House of Commons presents a eye catching picture of the real British legacy

House of Parliament. While walking near the Parliament house we saw a queue of people standing along side the railings in front of the parliament buildings, and on inquiring what the queue was for we were pleasantly surprised to hear that it was for a free visit to see how the parliament functions. We joined the queue and in about 30 min time were seated in a comfortable visitors gallery watching the debates taking place. After spending about an hour there, we came out and joined another queue next door at the Cathedral for evensong at 6 pm. This was most enjoyable to hear and see the choir sing .
On A Bus Tour. I love history, the tour was quiet historical , tell you this, we will be back again, with Gods help

Houses of Parliament tour. We took a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament tour with a very personable and funny guide. I didn't realize how beautiful the building is. And I learned a lot of the way the government works and it makes me appreciate how much more regimented the US government is!
Beautiful history lesson!. Very friendly and informative guide of the Parliament, learned of the history and present day workings of the English government. Allow about 2 hours for the tour.

MUST SEE - WHEN VISITING LONDON. I always go again - don't know if I expect it to change! The magnificence of this iconic site never ceases to amaze me. Imagine all the manual workers toiling away for years to createthis piece of architecture which is still very stately and inviting.
A must visit.. Even if you don't like politics go into the Houses of Parliament public gallery and see how government works from the inside. You've seen it on TV now go see it yourself.
So breaktaking. In Europe one can feel overwelmed with all the old buildings but I was truly impressed with Parliament and its beauty. It was very crowded but worth while
Houses of Parliament Britain. It was a beautiful building and the experience was great and very educational. The closing times could be extended during summer.

A must when visiting London. When entering you go through security like at an airport. I was stopped as I had a small suitcase padlock in my bag ( I didn't know it was there) I had to leave it and pick it up at the end of the tour. The tour was really interesting and the guide was very informative and knowledgeable. It wasn't just about the government and what goes on. He also talked about the history of the building. The tour was approx 75 minutes and cost £16.50 each. Worth every penny
Worth a Visit!. Interesting from a historical and political perspective. The tour we took was very informative and it was great to stand in the house of lords and in the house of commons.

Perfect guided tour. Make a reservation in advance.. We made a reservation on the internet weeks before we went to London. The reservation makes sure you get a guided tour in a language you choose and with not too many people (around 20 per guide). We had a lovely guide who made the visit very interesting and who knew a lot about the building, the people who had worked here and UK politics.

Absolutely fabulous. We only had one day in London just passing through, and we have been there before, but never on the guided tour through this beautiful building. What a fabulous tour, great guide, interesting information, and all that history, just amazing. well worth the cost of entry. There is a tesco express right across the road to grab lunch to eat in the adjacent park. For an overseas visitor just great. all English residents such take the tour if they visit London. A number one attraction.

Interesting. Always wanted to know what goes on in Parliament, really enjoyed the tour of such a great iconic building. The tour guide took us through the history of the building, architecture and designers. From the queens robing room, to the House of Lords and House of Commons, a tour not to be missed.

Fascinating. I really enjoyed my tour of the Houses of Parliament. You get to see all through both Houses, the Queens rooms and through the lobby and voting rooms. A fascinating tour with excellent guides who were always open to questions and very knowledgeable.

Must see!. This was one of the most informative and enjoyable tours on our recent trip to London. We had an excellent tour guide who provided many interesting facts both current and historical about the rooms. We were told it is only open to residents outside the UK during July & August when Parliament is on holiday. Advanced booking is necessary. The week after our return, I told my children to take notice of the news in the House of Commons where we had stood only a week before. I think that brings the experience full circle for them to have a better understanding of the significance of what takes places in those rooms. Don't just read about Parliament, visit it!

A great place to visit. Went on a guided tour here while we had a few days in London and thought it was won of the highlights of the week.The tour guide (who I think was called Geffory Mathews?) was great and was one of the best tour guides I've had in years. Well worth every penny of the entrance fee.

Fabulous and magical. When you step off the tube and you see Big Ben its just fabulous.The buildings are amazing and look fabulous, it's a very peaceful area.There is a park opposite and you can grab lunch and sit in here and admire the Houses of Parliament .I would go back and see them again

Interesting. Have no real interest in politics, however, my visit to the Houses of Parliament was fantastic, really interesting and amazing to see the grandeur of the building, particularly fascinating how old the original hall is where you start the tour (1047 if I recall!)

Amazing place and one to put on your list.. The House of Commons tour is certainly worth every penny. Our guide Clarissa was extremely informative and answered all our questions. An amazing behind the scenes tour and gives a real perspective to what you see on the news each night. A stunning building and you get to know the real history of how government is run and the historical facts behind it. We even had a wedding taking place whilst we were there! Great value and highly recommend.

Excellent visit. We were lucky enough to be invited and got to see the hidden rooms not normally on show but I wish we had done a tour as there is so much one can learn. We saw a few famous faces as there was a debate on that day. We did get into observe but did not stay long as that bit can be boring!Some foreign VIP's were there and provided a colourful interest. I guess there is always something happening there

Free tour available!. If you ask your local MP you should be able to arrange a free tour of the Houses of parliament. It's definitely somewhere to go and see what the building is like! It's a very informative tour of one of the most well known buildings in the UK.

Just old same as pictures I have been seeing.. This one makes good scene with Big ben. Can we go inside? I just watched out side passing by that, riding london eye, walking behind river. Well you should be there if you travel london because thats one of landmarks of london?

Something you must do!. We were in London this summer (2013) and we did a tour in the parliament.
It was nice to see the building, and it is something you must do!
Best regards

Guided tour and afternoon tea. The tour is good and very informative. Extremely well organised and the time of 1 and 1/4 hours is just right.However the afternoon tea is poor value. You are allocated 2 small rolls, a very small chocolate cake, mouse and just 1 scone. There is no choice. Certainly not worth the £20. There are many better deals around at the top hotels where you can have as much as you want.4 stars for the tour but only 1 for the afternoon tea.

stunning place full of history but still being used. stunning place steeped in history but still being used today, an insight into politics, we had a fantastic tour guide who made it interesting for both young and old

Awesome and very informative tour!. Did this tour yesterday as a pre-book on our first day to London. We were very tired and jetlagged but it was excellent and worthwhile to do. Our guide (Suzanna W) was knowledgeable and funny. She was full of anecdotes about the British government and historical figures involved with the Parliament. You get to walk around The House of Lords and the House of Commons, see where they sit and how the entire voting process works. Not to mention, this is my favorite building in London, it's spectacular and the Westminster Hall inside is circa 1000 years old! Most of the castle was destroyed by fire so it was rebuilt in the 1800's. A must see for any visitor of London. It is just very unfortunate that unless you're a UK citizen, you cannot visit Big Ben. It is still very cool to see and photograph from the outside.

Amazing behind the scenes with so much history.. This is a must see. Our guide had a great walking pace, so we could pack as much in as possible. She also had a wide breadth of knowledge to share with us and answered a lot of really good questions on the history of the Parliament, the building and politics. It is a simply stunning building. The afternoon tea was completely booked when we wanted to go, so if you know you're going in advance book well ahead of time. You can't take photos for various reasons - security is most certainly one of them. Be ready for walking - maybe avoid booking this if you are not comfortable going at a fast pace or have children that may find a lot of fast walking difficult. So worth the walking!

Brilliant -- Guided Tours of the Houses of Parliament. I took a Saturday morning guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, led by a fantastic gentleman named Richard. The tour starts in Westminster Hall, the oldest part of the building as it was the only room not destroyed by World War II bombings or other incidents, and follows the route taken by the Queen at the State Opening of Parliament, going through each of the primary rooms and including visits to both the Lords Chamber and the Commons Chamber. The tour was brilliant, full of interesting information and anecdotes, including both contemporary relevance, historical information, and architectural and decorative details. Essentially, it covers every topic that could be of interest to those taking the tour, without ever dragging. This site is a must-see if you're visiting London, and I highly recommend taking the tour - and go with Richard if you get a chance!

A must see!. It is definitely a must see! The guides explain a lot about the British political system and you get to go inside the House of Lords and the House of Commons... not to mention how incredible the building looks like inside. They have now an afternoon tea - a bit expensive for what is offered, but worth because it is in one of the Lords' room.

Big Ben and Little Geoff. I attended the House of Commons for an LSE alumni gala dinner on 26th. July, held in the Members' dining room. The entrance security was a bit strict, but with a demonstration takingplace outside I can understand why they were very attentive toanybody entering the Commons complex. The walk to and from the members dining room is quite awesome as one passes so much history recorded in effigies and brass plaques recording serious times in |British history. Time restricts any deep analysis but suffice to say the dinner was excellent as indeed was the selected wine. I did acquire some small souvenirs such as a House of Commons tie, teddy bear key ring, and socks which all bore the House of CVommons logotype and were in a refreshing green. Next time I will hope to have longer to read all the plaques and capture the medieal ambience coming from the great hall, and its corridors of power.

Great Tour Guide and Great Access. I've visited other national and regional Capitols, and I was pleasantly surprised to experience the up-close experience that a tour of the Houses of Parliament provided. Tour groups are allowed to go right on the floor of both the House of Lords and House of Commons.My tour guide, Pauline, was fantastic. She not only knew the building's features, she knew how Parliament runs. She also had a fun sense of humor, which made for a very engaging and very educational tour.The Palace itself was very impressive, and the Victorian architecture and artwork were fascinating.I left the tour with a lot of new knowledge and a smile on my face. Definitely a highlight of my vacation to London. Tip: Buy your ticket a day ahead of time if going during the summer opening. I bought mine late in the afternoon the day before, which allowed to me to avoid lines and assured me a spot in the next day's tour at the time I wanted.

Brilliant experience. Another one of my things to do has been achieved by visiting this historic building. The tours are taken in quite small groups with tour guides who really know their stuff. The sheer history of the place is really overpowering - had forgotten most of my history lessons that covered it all! Definitely recommend this one

I learnt so much about our own history. Joined a guided tour of the H of P. Very informative and learnt a out regal and parliamentary history and it was great to be able to be in the seats of the two houses and think about all that history. In fact we were there the day after the governments debate on Syria was lost - just shows how democracy in action is very powerful. You will need to book well ahead for when parliament is not sitting.

Fascinating. Every UK citizen ought to go, to get a feel for the place. Worth the wait to view the commons - smaller than you might think. I am really pleased I dropped in, and polotics will mean a little bit more as a result.

Everybody should do this. Went on a pre-booked tour on 27 August. These are only available when parliament is not sitting or I think on Saturdays.Very well organised. Security is clearly tight but no tighter than getting on board a flight and so not intrusive.Tour guide was very knowledgeable and you get to see all of the main areas.Took about 2 hours. Tea room at end is very good and well priced.

Fantastic experience. The entrance to this amazing building is through the medieval hall which on it's own is very interesting and steeped in history. The whole place and tour is not to be missed on a trip to London. Good value for money compared to some attractions.

Brilliant!. Fantastic value for money. Really interesting guide who was good fun but at the same time, gave lots of really interesting info. Fabulous building with lots of history. Well worth the money!! I would definitely recommend this to anyone interested in history.
Brilliant. Excellent visit. Quite short but guide was extremely informative. Really enjoyed being inside the the House of Commons and Lords

Very interesting experience. We arrived and unexpectedly found you could watch sittings. A short wait and security check later we were in the visitors section watching debate and discussions. It was very interesting

Good government. Living history. Our tour guide was a bit soft-spoken - especially difficult when we stood adjacent to another louder guide doing a different part of the tour. Her knowledge was extensive, however and she dealt with questions in an easy manner.

Great insight. This was the highlight of our recent visit to London. We all really enjoyed the chance to visit this iconic building. First class guide gave a wonderful insight to its fascinating history. I would readily recommend this tour.
Wow!. Gr8 lots of info not boring. Took my sons 14 & 11 the youngest found it a bit hard standing up for 1 hour after already beeing dragged around London. A trip well worth it.

Fantastic. This has to be one of London's greatest treasures - the whole place is steeped in history and you don't need to be interested in politics to appreciate the grandeur of the place. Definitely worth a visit

See, not just look at!. Everyone loves Big Ben over and take some pictures of it, but the parliament building itself is much more interesting and wonderful. If you can, walk to the end, take a look at Oliver Cromwell statue cast in bronze, marvel at the Victoria tower and the back of the building, and - if you can - visit the inside.

Tour of Parliament. This was the most memorable part of our vacation in London. Walking around the House of Lords and Commons was a step into British history.
Fascinating!

Magnificent. This was a very historical and enchanting visit. It was really amazing to see that this building still stands after so many years. You should definitely visit if it is your first visit to London!

Good tour guide. Tour around Houses of Commons and House of Lords took 75 mins. An excellent Tour Guide she really new her history. A lot of walking involved with few places to sit. Arrive early as you go through airport type scanners, you can sit and wait in the great hall. Visit the cafe after a bit pricey but ok for a coffee there are also toilets and an area where you can buy souvenirs.
Beautiful. This has got to be the most beautiful building in the world and it makes you so proud to be English. So pleased that Guy Fawkes failed in his attempt to blow it up. :)
Amazing Buildings. These are some amazing buildings the architecture is amazing. A must see when visitng london. Very vast not like when you see them on the television.

Great tour, perfect Victoria Sponge. Fascinating tour, even if there isn't anywhere to mill about at your leisure.If you go to the cafe after your tour get the victoria sponge. My partner and I both had it and it was the best we'd had. So good I even came here specially to write about it.

A surprising place.. Lots of history about the buildings and the political system. You
visit both houses and get some insight into how it is all supposed to work.

Really interesting tour. This tour is bookable online and I'd suggest that you arrive at least 20 minutes before the time of your tour, to allow enough time to go through security. (airport type scanners)Once through security, we gathered in Westminster Hall, which is the only area where photographs can be taken. We were then marshalled in to smaller groups of about 25 people, and taken on a 75 minute tour with our guide.The guide was very knowledgeable and I learnt a lot about the history of Parliament in this country. However, I would say that for a Brit, some of the things the guide told us were quite basic things that most people would know, but as there's an international crowd these things needed to be mentionedIt was fascinating to see the Queen's robing room, the lobby, and the Houses of Lords and Commons. I'm almost looking forward to seeing Prime Minister's Question Time on TV, now I'm been in the Commons.I'd highly recommend this tour.

Very interesting if a trifle dry.. No pictures! The history of Parliament is fascinating especially as concerns the decline of power for the royal family. The House of Lords is almost entirely encrusted in gold while the Commons is...not. It's such a different system compared to the USA. The workmanship in the building is amazing to behold.
Very interesting. Very informative and interesting but feel they could have done a lot more to include the 3 American children who were in our party

Lady Pamella waves from the window.... My imagination ran riot as I walked where statesmen and women walked and listened to a 'Reduced Parliament History' from our excellent guide.The tour and tea was a present from our daughter and was an inspired gift.The Lords opulent as expected and the Commons smaller than I thought it would be and more basic, but still all wood and leather and an air of importance. All that it means to be in a British Democracy is here and the art works, ceilings, furnishings, mosaics etc are a joy to behold. Tea in the Pugin Room with a glass of House of Commons Champagne perfected the visit. The staff were courteous and left one with the feeling that to take your seat in the Chamber after tea would be absolutely fine.

And you think our Congress is screwed up!. Another attrction that can be booked from the states (online) prior to your arrival!Tour of House of commons makes you feel like a new royal subject. Don't miss it!A few years ago, my Londoner friend got me seats in the press gallery to view the House of Lords in session. PM Tony Blair was on the floor and the critical arguement of the day dallied about when is a pint of ale not a real pint ... does the foam on the top count as full mesure or not??? Glad to see that our UK counterparts hve so many critical issues befeore them! Truly a memorable day!

Fascinating to go into the houses!. I really enjoyed this tour but my children (12 and 15) were bored at times but I think this is because there seemed to be a lot of focus on the art and architecture to start with. For me the best part was going into the Lords and Commons and seeing them first hand. This was when the tour was most interesting as the work of the houses was talked about.Possibly most interesting to adults but would recommend it. tip - If you go on weekends or in the summer you will be able to go into the debating chambers.

Great feeling when you go to the House of Lords and House of Commons. We were lucky to book a tour of the Houses of Parliament. It needs to be pre-booked-online. Open for public on Saturdays, but not all, so pl. check in advance. Its a great feeling when you enter the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The guides are very knowledgeable,

Take the tour,. I reserved and bought tickets to the Houses of Parliament tour while still in California and thought it might be iterestingWell, if any of you outside Britain ever watch BBC news and see the proceedings that occur in the House of Commons, some quite rowdy and contentious, this is your chance to stand where the speaker does and walk the halls the Lords do on the way to their chambers.Worth every farthing!

A great history lesson. Really a great tour. Tour guide was very knowledgeable and spoke very clearly (80 years old and obviously loving his job!). You get a real sense of how the English government works (at least the mechanics and personal politics) and some sense of the history of how the system evolved to what it is today. Really engaging to be in the house of lords, house of commons, the queens dressing room, and everything in between.
