Highly recommended, and we did it with our two boys in tow (who also really appreciated the tour). The great hall is amazing to see.

Iconic Photo Opportunity. No visit to London would be complete without a photo of the Houses of Parliament. My son & I always love the iconic buildings and there are tonnes of opportunities to take a snap. Go on the bridge, see it from a Thames river boat or the London Eye. Walk up from the Southbank to avoid the crowds or get off @ Westminster tube station (which will be busy). Make sure you hear Big Ben strike on the hour too- you can hear it from far away. I think you can visit inside via your MP but I haven't been that organised!

a wonderful 75 minutes of historu. This tour is very worthwhile--a must if you want to see the best of London. Get your tickets on line ahead of time. The guides are prompt, efficient and very knowledgeable. It is fascinating history in this historic place. And learning the workings of the present day Parliament was so interesting. Don't miss this!!

Enjoyable & educational experience. We traveled by National Express to London and bus from Victoria bus station. All extremely easy. We had overestimated the travelling time, and we were 1 hour too early for our booked tour. It was no problem... we were allowed join another set. There were 18 people with us. The organisation was excellent. Although there were several hundred people in various groups, they were organised so that all had plenty of time seeing the various chambers and halls etc. We were given a lot of information about the Palace of Westminster, it's history, it's workings, and anecdotes of vents over the years. Looking at familiar (to TV news etc that is) rooms was a great surprise, as I really felt that the 2 main chambers, House of Commons and House of Lords were very small. There were some small schoolchildren in our group, and I was very happy to see the guide take particular care of them and explained things to them in a way they could follow. Later we had a snack in the Coffee shop which was very good. I would highly recommend this tour to all and sundry. Very memorable indeed. Please note: Only photos allowed in outside areas and in the initial large hallway. There are free booklets, but the £7.50 for the guide afterwards was good value indeed.
Houses of Lords & Commons. Did not plan to do this tour but very glad we did - Adrienne the guide was very good and the tour was really interesting -

A brief dip into our history. After careful security screening we joined our little tour group, timed tickets, buy on line arrive 20 minutes early. Judith our guide was very informative, the tour took us through both chambers, various lobbies and corridors. I'm quite interested in the political life of our nation and very much enjoyed visiting the places where so many important events have occurred. Our grandson (10) who was with us was full of questions and interest, altogether a very worthwhile 90 minutes.This tour starts and ends in Westminster Hall, which should have a tour all on its own - Café & toilets at the end. If you have any interest in our political system or come from a country that can trace its history here then this is a must.

Facinating and Informative snap shot into the history and workings of Parliament. We had great afternoon touring around the palace of Westminster being walked around by one of the tour guides. We missed out on the afternoon tea as they had sold out so just had the tour. The guide gave a great balance of the history of the building/statues and important areas and linking this to the current protocols used today by the Queen and MP's. I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the tour includes walk through in both chambers of the house. The tour takes you past the Queens entrance to Westminster and robing rooms and into in the house of lords, past the monarchs thrown and the Lords benches seen at the state opening of parliament. Then down to the commons and past the iconic green benches/ dispatch box and speakers chair. The tour allows time to pause in each chambers while the tour guide gives a brief overview about the working of each house and customs in the chamber. Lastly finishing in Westminster hall where you start. The tour flew by and although very busy with simultaneous tours the guides are well practiced at keeping you busy until your time view areas.There were a good mixture of about 20 adults on our tour with different capabilities some with sticks, but the guide was good at accommodating tot their pace without making them feel awkward. There were a number of steps in a different places but your only ever walking for a few minutes before stopping to hear some history and its mainly on 1 level. Your mostly on your feet for an hour so with only one or 2 places to sit briefly but you don't notice.I just wish it was longer. I want to go back and climb big ben.

Great Sight!. We visited the Sight of the Parliament and Big Ben. It is very amazing to see. Everyone should take the opportunity to do so. It looks the same as when you see it from a picture. We enjoyed touring London.

Guided tour of Parliament. Excellent tour, Sarah our guide was very informative and entertaining. Fairly good access for wheelchair users although everyone very helpful and despite several tours running alongside each other it wasn't too crowded.

Loved it. Being a Legal Studies teacher in Australia I loved this. To see the birth place of our legal system!! We had booked a citizens tour as a result of my fiancé having UK citizenship as normal tours were not available during the time of our visit. Definitely worth seeing

A must see!. Nothing tells you you're in London like going to the houses of Parliament and hearing Big Ben chime the time. What a thrill to see right in front of you what you've only seen before in movies! Beautiful spot.
Brilliant Tour. Well worth the money.......book it thro Ticket Master avoid the messing about there. The only queue you will get is for security as you enter.

Excellent tour but pricey tea. We took the Houses of Parliament tour on Thursday last and we had an excellent review of the history of the place by our guide Harry.There is one flight of steps out the Great Hall, but there are handrails. It is well worth doing, but please note, officially the tour does not allow anyone to sit down, though most of us did in the Library. It should have take an hour and a quarter but we barely made it out after an hour and a half to have tea in the Pugin Room, which we had previously booked. This was an expensive addition at nearly £20 and hardly enough to fill us. The cafe showed a cream tea at £5 and I think we would take that another time. There were plenty of mementos to buy before leaving.

Both educational and enjoyable. Can't praise the tour enough. Great guide , really knew his stuff and made it fun. Learned a lot about how we founded democracy and earned the title of mother of all parliaments. Recommend book online and get there at least 20 mins before your tour time slot.It is 75 mins of walking and standing as you are not allowed to sit down in the various houses.

Brings the TV perspective to life!. Amazing history and information from the guides who are all very professional, calm and polite. Great to see where the action happens and feel the atmosphere you see on TV. Gorgeously luxuriant and so much to absorb. I've been twice and would happily go again.

THE SUPRISE HIT OF THE SUMMER. just come back today from the 2.45 tour. myself and a 15 year old. we didnt know what to expect but the £16 fee for me and son went for free was i thought very reasonable. it was well run, a lovely cafe with reasonably priced nice food and drink. Our guide was polite and knowledgeable and kept us entertained throughout. it was stunningly opulent in places, and very interesting to both myself and son who had only seen it on tv before. It lasted for 75 minutes, and be prepared to stand for 90% of the tour. I'd recommend it in a heartbeat, and it kept a 15 year old entertained as wel which was good as there arent many attractions which they are interested in.Do the tour while you can, and be prepared to be pleasantly suprised. Well run, with friendly people and it was interesting for all ages.
Awe inspiring. Brilliant tour. Get to see both parliamentary houses. Very exciting and informative. The tour guide was very knowledgable.Thanks

Great for adults, but a bit boring for kids.. 2nd time I have been through parliament, but the first time for many years, and the first time for my husband. We both really enjoyed our visit but our 12 year old was very bored. But he knew we wanted to go around, so apart from the odd bit of eye rolling, he was very well behaved LOL. So my advice is don't go with kids. That said, they go free with full paying adults, so that is a bonus.Great to see inside the Lords and Commons Chambers, the lobbies where the statues are and to learn a bit about the building and design of the place. Not too long a tour and very well guided.

An amazing palace for making laws. It was much more interesting than I thought it was going to be, our guide was very good (called a spade a shovel) and had a few amusing comments to make about some of our MP's there was a lot of walking but a few places to sit for those needing a rest. I would recommend it to anyone wishing to know how it works and what your MP gets up to. There is a little cafe at the end of your trip where you can enjoy a good Tea or Coffee + a snack and not too expensive. The guided tour was well worth the money.

Well worth a visit!. The tour takes about 80 minutes, before you go through you have to go through security, like at the airport, bags have to be scanned and you walk through a scanner yourself!!! It's a guided tour, and you can only take photos in the great hall where you congregate to start the tour!!! The guides are very informative and make it very interesting!!!! Beforehand I thought it would be boring ,no way, far from it !!! the rooms are magnificent , note the ceilings, beautiful !!! it's great to stand in the house of Lords and see the Queens throne in all its glory ,and then to the house of Commons ,much plainer in decor ,the Green chair in direct line with the throne, facing the Queen ,though quite a way apart!!!! If you have not been ,give it a try , you cannot fail to be impressed!!!!!!!!!!!

An inspirational tour with an inspirational tour guide. My husband, son, in-laws and I thoroughly enjoyed our tour round the Houses of Parliament. I learned so much about government and found it a shame I'd not been here as a child as I found it highly inspirational. I hope my nine year old remembers it all and keeps the memory with him as he grows up. The history of the building was also as interesting as some of the people who've worked in it over the years. The not content corridor, Mr and Mrs Glum and the lobby are just some of the highlights.The tour almost makes me want to become an MP and Isabelle was one of the best tour guides I have ever had!Thank you for such a memorable experience !!

Corridors of power. This visit is a must. It takes about 1,20 mins and you have to use a guide but it doesn't cost more than anywhere else. Good idea to book on line. You get the introductions about the building and then explanations of the british government law making system and strange old traditions and actually get into the seating of the commons and lords. Very well done.

A MUST for anyone visiting London. We've been to London many times in the past and done all the usual attractions so on this occasion we booked to go on the tour around parliament and what a fantastic tour it was. Well worth every penny. Our guide Robert was excellent and we were engrossed from the minute we entered the huge Westminster Hall. There was so much information and so many facts that we left feeling like experts ourselves. I can highly recommend this to anyone interested in politics, history or just having a great 90 minute tour.
worth a visit. Not a great deal to see but worth a visit whilst walking a round, we went past after walking from Buckingham Palace down the Mall on the way to Westminster.

A one of a kind experience. Visited the Houses of Parliament one afternoon in London after leaving Westminster Abbey (it is a five minute walk). A friend had let us in on what I believe to be one of London's best kept tourism secrets, so my family and I opted not to do a formal tour of the Houses of Parliament and instead sit in on one of the daily debates going on continuously in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. It was an unexpectedly entertaining experience that I would definitely recommend to anyone remotely interested in politics/government/debate, or even anyone who just wants a good chuckle, as the less formal debates in the House of Commons are quite humorous. Simply going inside the magnificent building is definitely worth the serious security, because admission is free, you can stay as long as you wish, and there is no queue!!

Great tour. We had the good fortune and getting tickets to see the Houses of Parliament and it was amazing. We had a great guide (Harry) with a good sense of humor and a wealth of information. The chambers where the Houses meet are very historical and the architecture is amazing.

book a tour. We booked a free tour through our MP's office. Once we had passed security we waited in the great hall of the palace of westminster and then we were taken on a 75 minute tour. Our tour guide was extremely knowledgeable, and it was very interesting to see the houses of lords and commons and the queens rooms and to hear about the state opening o parliament and were some of the traditions and sayings come from. Would recommend this tour to anyone.

Debates for free. It is not a very Londoner hotspot, and not many people know about it, I guess. But you can watch both Houses' debates for free. Just show up in weekdays in front of the Houses of Parliament, just behind the Westminster Abbey and ask for it. The House of Lords is really impressive.
Just Brilliant. Loved the tour. Always seen the outside but only just went in for the guided tour. Well worth the money and the guides bring the history to life also
Imposing building. A wonderful sense of history. Gorgeous building which gives you great photo shots. Near to London Eye

History and Politics - Right in Front of You. A great tour to hear about the history and to see the Parliament! We have seen this place on TV with British politicians arguing against each other; now you get to be in that place. No photos are allowed, and the tour takes about one and a quarter hours. But it is a fascinating tour. Also we were kid of luckily - the place is open in the summer during the week since Parliament is in the recess; normally during the year it would only be open for tours on Saturdays. For history buffs or any politically interested people it is a very worthwhile tour.

Very Historical. The tour was great and long enough to appreciate the history and principles behind the British Pariament. The tours are well organized and informative. The tour guide was very English which made it that much more fun. I thought this tour was better than all the Palaces and Castles in England.

Awesome. You get a guided tour with a well informed guide ,ours was very enthusiastic and was a joy to listen to.
The place is just awesome. So much pomp and ceremony and a tour of parts you would not normally see, brilliant.
grandchildren trip. Exceptionally interesting but you are not allowed to sit down and this could be quite a problem for anyone, old or young who cannot stand for 1.5 hours

If you are interested in History and tradition you may well appreciate this.. I could not help wondering what an earlier reviewer thought they were going to and why they bothered going with such attitudes towards the UK democratic system. Why upset yourself??For me this visit was steeped in history and ceremony, VERY informative thanks to our guide and the 70 minutes tour gave us a great insight to both House of Lords and House of commons.There were many Brits and overseas visitors and the tours take place on different languages to accommodate this, There is a large cafe, various mementos on sale too.
Everyone should visit. What an experience. A guided tour throughout Westminster by a great tour guide. You get to see the workings and history of the Lords and the Commons. Loved it.
Highly recommend. Great tour from Westminster hall through both the Lords and commons. Groups of about 25 with a tour guide that knows what they're talking about (I suspect that delivery varies).

Very interesting. The tour was well worth it. Our guide was very good. However, there are so many tours going on at once that it does become somewhat of an annoyance. Perhaps they should double the price and have half as many visitors.

Don't bother. Look at a postcard instead. Don't come here and be ripped off royally. An expensive city and our "democracy" is an elected dictatorship. Was a world leader once but new east European parliaments are more democratic than ours - we have no proportional representation. England is divided on class. Visit somewhere more modern
Well worth a visit. The tours are timed, well-organised and very interesting. In spite of the numbers of people, the guide was able to give all the details needed. I thoroughly recommend it.

Excellent tour of Parliament. Had an excellent tour today of the Houses of Parliament. Great tour guide, Susan, that gave us a wonderful overview of history and current government operations. She was knowledgable and entertaining. Highly recommend this tour.

A must see and book a guided tour ahead of time. We thoroughly enjoyed our tour through the Houses of Parliment. The tour guides are the best we have seen and make the visit memorable. If you come to London you must do this. By booking online you are guaranteed a spot and avoid ques.
Really interesting. Had a very informative tour around the Houses of Parliament. Really good value for money. 14 year old even found it interesting !
amazing. so much details. would love to go inside to have a look round. not sure if one day they will let the public in

Very interesting place to visit.. Enjoyed the visit, and the guide was exceptional in her knowledge of the historical background of the place. Very busy place so some queuing required. Typical airport type security on entry. Gave us an appetite to consider going into the public gallery sometime during a parliamentary session.

Most interesting History lesson. Excellent tour of the House of Lords and the Commons with a small group of people booked on line beforehand.
Easy viewing, not rushed and well worth the £15 fee.

Awesome!. We were very surprised, that it is alowded to come inside! And if not to take a tour, you can just come free of charge and visit House of Commons and House of Lords! You can listen to real discussion between parties. And this is amazing. There is a post office inside and you can send a letter with Royal logo just from the parliament!

Awesome Architecture. Could stare at this masterpiece of architecture all day. There is so much to see in the area. People watching, historical sights, and so much going on around its almost overwhelming.
Our best stop. Born in the UK but living in the USA, I must say this was the highlight of our trip. A spectacular tour. Teenage kids enjoyed the visit too.

Well worth a trip. I dragged my teenage boys to a tour of the houses of Parliament last week. I thought it was good value at £33 for 3 of us as the youngest is under 16 - he went free. We booked via ticket master, the tour took about one hour and 20 minutes. Theres a nice coffee shop when you enter, Security is airport style as you'd expect. The place is steeped in history and wonderfully old fashioned. You can't take pictures or sit down on the houses. If you live in England you really should take this tour. One of my boys found it quite interesting - the other one - not impressed, no surprise there! (I suspect in years to come - he'll still point out to a friend he's been there). There are no local eateries for fussy teenagers. We took a cab to the Hard Rock cafe afterwards.

Amazing Member's Tour - highly recommended!. After many years of saying "we should visit", I finally got around to booking our members tour of Westminster Palace and we visited today (12th August). Member's tours are free to book via your MP or a member of the House of Lords for any UK resident. There are public tours at the weekend and during the recess for the general public and overseas visitors.I can't rate the public tours, but the members tour was absolutely fantastic. Our guide was increadibly knowledgable, friendly and very engaging. He really brought to life how the UK Parliament runs and some of the history of the institution and the building.I'd highly recommend any UK resident to contact their MP to arrange a tour - its highly worth it! A big thank you to the office of Nadine Dorries for arranging.

Iconic and just like the pics. We spent plenty of time just hanging out here and watching people, taking pics and being trampled by the rest of our tourist brethren. But hey ho how can you go to London and NOT see the Houses of Parliament - almost seems a sin huh?Seriously, it is mobbed by tourist and if you find a lot of people difficult to deal with, you will find it hard to be here. You really have to be a people person to enjoy this tourist attraction. Still worth seeing.

Fascinating. We took a tour of the Houses of Parliament that includes a walk-through of both the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The tour provides a fascinating look into the history of the Parliament as well as present-day government. Factoid: Did you know that the United Kingdom did not have a Supreme Court until 2009?
Great visit. We booked this on a whim but I thoroughly enjoyed it. A great guided tour with so much to learn.A must vist and it only takes 75 mins to complete.

Packed with history; what is there not to like?. If you like history or the color of British politics, this is a must-see. A tour of Parliament offers an architectural history as well as a political history going back over 900 years. It is physically impressive and packed with excuses to tell powerfully interesting stories, if you have the right guide. (For example, do you know where the expression "toeing the line" comes from? Or how the term lobbyist" came about?) The smallest of kids may be a bit bored, but unless they'll throw a tantrum drag them through this masterpiece. They will thank you some day.

Ah-mazing!!!. Visiting the Houses of Parliament is an amazing experience and I would definitely recommend it to anyone! You get into the rooms and learn so much about the history of the building and the Parliament's day-to-day activities. Incredible! Totally worth the money! You will never forget this experience.

Well worth a visit - but glad I didn't pay. I went as part of an evening event, which involved very good catering and a tour which proved to be really informative. Well worth a visit and I certainly plan to return.

Spectacular architecture.. I have seen this building on foot and from the river and it is truly spectacular, I would love to take the two one-day but have simply never had the time, seen from the outside with the building details picked out by bright sunshine it looks incredible.

Do the tour. In summer Parliament opens for tours, and we immensely enjoyed ours. It takes just over an hour, and one gets to see both houses of parliament and learn a bit about British history. You can stop for tea at the end at the Parliament café.

Well worth doing. Booked tickets online the day before. Instructions could be a lot clearer about where to pick the tickets up. The booking office and collection point is across the road opposite Victoria Gate. We were booked onto the last tour of the day at 4.30pm and our guide Conrad was excellent. This is, without doubt, one of the best things I've ever done while in London and can highly recommend. Compared to the extortionate prices charged by most attractions, this is also very good value too.

Great visit!. I thought Id do the touristy thing with a difference and arranged lunch with Lord Allenbrooke and watched a Commons debate. I learned alot about our political system (I already have a Politics degree!). Food was inoffensive and in great company. Rule Britannia!
Breathtaking. This building is truly breathtaking in a beautiful area. It's huge compared to the footage you see on the television.

Amazing building and fairly good tour. Came here on a guided tour for the first time. Incredibly beautiful building inside and out. Tour was good but our guide was a bit officious and kept stumbling over her words. She also found it difficult to make herself heard over the various other tour guides with louder voices. A little bit rushed at times. Fascinating to see inside the main chambers, especially the House of Commons which we see so often on TV.

Experience dependant on your guide....... My daughter and I had the tour (booked the night before on Ticket Master) in August. Had no problem getting it booked but the ticket master website does not explain how to pick the tickets up. It is on site but across the road from the Houses of Parliament. Allow a good 30 minutes to pick them up beforehand. You can print them off but as we don't travel with a printer this wasn't an option for us.The tour itself is very well organised, and it is exciting to be allowed to go into the building. There is a coffee shop on your way in (not the same place they serve afternoon tea) so if you are early you can have a cuppa and a nice slice of cake, the café was good value. I would not bother with the optional afternoon tea, we walked the 15 mins to Fortnum's afterward and had a fabulous afternoon tea for not much more than the price charged on the tour (everyone we spoke to said the afternoon tea option was very poor value for money).Our tour guide was Penny and whilst she seemed quite knowledgeable, she did waffle on a lot about the architect and the tiling rather than the nitty gritty of the workings of the house and the history. I did overhear several other guides talking with gusto and really wanted to stay and listen to them instead. An example of this was the robing room, whilst we did see the main throne and the fire place she did not mention the three other thrones in the room and walked out before we could even ask what they were, a security guard ushered us out before we could even see them. Security is rife in the building (as you would expect) and one over zealous guide/guard (a middle aged woman) was almost apoplectic when one poor man leaned on a table. She also shooed us off when we stayed for a second to admire one of the portraits that we had not managed to look at when our guide was waffling about the gold leaf.I loved the House of lords and the House of Commons, although you are not allowed to sit down in either room ( I have no idea why, they are sat on every day by a bunch of charlatans and freeloaders and we pay for it!!!!!) Anyway it was nice to see where they have their daily bun fights in the name of democracy.All in all a great hour and half but as I say it is dependant on your guide.
Landmark. Didn't go in, not sure if you can, but just seeing this landmark is amazing. Great views from the London eye and from across the bridge. Seeing it at night is pretty cool as well.

Highly impressed! A must-visit!. This was my first visit to the Houses of Parliament and quite honestly, I was half expecting it to be quite boring. But I enjoyed the guided tour, through and through. The guided tour provided an informative insight on the colorful British history, and also an opportunity to see how the government is run. I was squealing with delight inside, as I walked through the Queen's Robing Room, the Lords Chamber, and the Commons Chamber! All that I've once seen on screen, was literally right in my face!!! Do not miss out on this impressive site!

An excellent and informative trip. OK, this is really going to be enjoyed by those who like their history and architecture. Not really for small children or sullen teenagers, there is also a fair bit of standing and walking and it takes about 90 minutes with no loo stops. No photos and security will take no messing. Other than that it is a very relaxed English experience, complete with queues. There is an excellent Café for a sit down and coffee afterwards.This is a pure history and high gothic architecture rush. The guides are informative and well versed in the history of the place. You get a full length tour of the best bits of the place and it has a lot to show you. They really spared no expense in its construction. Hand printed wallpaper, gold leaf and lots of pictures. You get to stand in the actual chambers of the Lords and Commons and realise how small both chambers are. The way that UK politics works is explained with humour. Westminster Hall is also a surprise, with its really old history, large size and timber roof. It is best appreciated by brushing up a bit on 19th and 20th Century UK history, but word a look anyway.

Not to miss to the first timers. Add this to your must see list! I don't want to repeat what other reviews have mentioned. It's like going to Wash DC without seeing the Washington monument or the Lincoln monument - can't do without, unless you have seen it already.

A wonderful insight of Westminster. The Houses of Parliament appeared smaller inside than you imagine from the TV reports. We had a good informative guide named David, who was very clued up on what we were seeing as we walked through the Houses of Power!!

An attraction you don't think of going INTO!!. We recently visited the Houses of Parliament, not just walking around the outside, we did a tour of the inside of the building which was really very interesting and the building itself is very remarkable!!! The building itself is not as old as we all think it is, the original building was burnt down and rebuilt during early Victorian times, but when you go inside the decoration of the walls and ceilings, the statues and paintings are quite unbelievable to behold. It is well worth the hour to hour and a half to take the tour, look at the inside and learn some of its history. After your tour you can partake of a really good cuppa at the tea rooms with a nice treat to eat before heading back out into the hustle of the crowds on the streets around this attraction. All up well worth the time, effort and few pounds admission to visit.

Great to see where it all happens!. I booked this visit well in advance and am very glad i did. Had a 3pm tour on a weekday and it was sold out! Having visited numerous other London attractions, i can truly say that this was completely different to everything else we visited. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable, although sometimes difficult to hear in the cavernous rooms when several other tours were going on nearby. It was very interesting to see the difference between the House of Lords and the House of Commons and i learned a few facts that surprised me about modern day parliament. Standing in the famous commons area seen so many times in the media, it was quite exciting. It was also nice to see so many foreign visitors on the tour.

Much better than expected!. We got to see so much more than I expected - both houses, the lobbies and the robing room. The architecture is stunning, the decor ornate and the artwork impressive. Our guide, Jo, was excellent. We got a history lesson as well as a great tour.Afterwards, we had afternoon tea in the Pugin Room overlooking the Thames which was wonderful.The only thing that let our visit down were the toilets - they looked like they hadn't been serviced for ages - broken soap dispensers, loo roll strewn across the floor, cold air hand dryers and some pretty yucky loos!All-in-all though, well worth a visit.

Interesting tour. Visited with my husband and we were both surprised by how good it was. We didn't expect to be standing in the benches in the House of Lords and House of Commons. We thought we would just be looking in the door or down from the public gallery. The guide was very good and made the tour very interesting with some humorous touches. We even had a joke with the ever vigilant policemen who were on duty.

Filled with History, if that's your thing. I loved this experience, but if you can't appreciate architecture and history, then it's not for you. Lots of walking and quiet intervals involved so wouldn't recommend small children.

More interesting than I had imagined. Go for the early times - minimises the queues at Security which as you can imagine is fairly tight. Our guide was really knowledgeable and able to give a lot of relevant and historical information of each of the areas. Really interesting to see what we often see on TV - the foyer where interviews take please / the House where the MP's sit / the door chapped by Black Rod at the Opening etc. Also get into the chambers where the Queen waits before the official opening etc, Found the whole visit very worthwhile.

Houses of Parliament. Great tour lasting 1 1/4 hours. The guide was witty and very informative. Group size was just right. The buildings we were shown are majestic and imposing, even though most of them aren't that old, apart from Westminster Hall itself. Tours are very well organised. We had lunch in the cafe afterwards and that wasn't bad either. Highly recommend a visit.
Beautiful.. One of the best place that I ever been. Majestic and beautiful. Great place to take wonderful pictures. Mainly at night.

booked on spur of moment, but good choice. very informative guide, Richard, who was full of interesting information.the chambers of parliament are really small; you don't get that impression on TV.the cafe at the end was good. We bought tickets via ticket master - beware of bought on a smartphone - they need printing, and you cannot use the email for entry. Thankfully our hotel assisted in printing out, otherwise we would have been goosed.
Houses of Parliament tour. Very good tour. Small groups. Not "a headset tour". I have a clearer understanding of English parliamentary system. We went on a Saturday. Not sure if in runs every day.

Where Big Ben lives. Good information about both Upper and Lower House, clearly showing the English Class system. House of Lords, even though unelected have by far the better class trims compared to where the 'commoners' hang out

A surprise attraction - a London must see. I must admit I wasn't particularly enthusiastic about my husband's suggestion to do the Houses of Parliament tour but I was really surprised - our tour guide [Jeffrey I think his name was] was knowledgeable and enthusiastic. The tour give incredible access including taking you to the room where the Queen puts on her robe and crown before the State Opening of Parliament, onto the floor of the House of Lords and the House of Commons too. Via some incredibly ornate rooms with lavish decor and historical painting and statues.Our guide explained how power moved from the monarchy to the government and I think I learnt more relevant British history in 1 1/2 hours than I did at my whole time at school [but that was a long time ago... so things may have changed]. It was just really interesting.We went with a 6 and an 8 year old, they just about lasted and perked up when more recognisable figures eg Henry the 8th were mentioned.At the end of the tour is a cafe serving DIVINE cakes - they looked divine and they tasted divine. I would totally recommend the caramel slice - flapjack base, layer of caramel topped with chunks of chocolate, pumpkin seeds and cranberries. It would be worth paying the entrance fee just to eat that again!Disabled Access: I did the tour on my small mobility scooter without any problems. You go through security at the beginning part of which involves having to go through a door, that closes and then the one in front opens which is a bit strange as you are momentarily in a box but so be it, there has to be security into this place! I was then taken by a guide through the accessible entrance that well known disabled political figures such as Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson, Baroness Jane Cambell and Dame Anne Begg MP go, and rejoined my tour group at the beginning of the tour. It was quite exciting going through a back way that most people don't get to see.There are accessible toilets near the cafe and all in all access isn't a problem.

Very special experience. Got an MP to take me on a behind the scenes tour of this place which is just steeped in so much history. It is the kind of thing that helps visitors to England really appreciate everything that has evolved in English government and how complicated it has been and remains. And of course then there is Braveheart!

Awe inspiring tour. Book a tour here and find out about the history of the British parliament and monarchs. It takes through the house of Commons and the house of Lords among other magnificent architectural rooms. Our guide was so knowledgeable. Its a truly awe inspiring tour, but it is best to book in advance online through their official site so you will not be disappointed as we witnessed with those who turned up on the day expecting to easily gain access.

Amazing. We had to wright to our local MP to arrange a tour.Upon arrival we had to go through an airport like arrangement.Scanning for knifes exc...It was well worth it!A guy called Nick took us around.What he didn,t know wasn't, worth knowing! He was very knoledgeable and enthusiastic.We would definitely recommend this tour.It will suprise you.

Experience of a life time. I was invited there with a colleague to a charity event, but allowed to sit in the gallery of the House of Lords with a tour group. I even met Floella Benjamin [ former presenter off Play School ] in the foyer!The building is spectacular, steeped in history and full of interesting and famous people [ we saw Martin Lewis money saving expert being interviewed! ] and Norman Tebbit in the chamber!Well worth a visit

The Houses of Parliament. Been to London many times but never visited The Houses of Parliament. Easy to get to using the Tube. Impressive building and I couldn't believe how vast it was especially Big Ben. we had booked a guided tour at 10.30 and after the lengthy but necessary security checks we did start our tour on time (try and arrive 15 mins earlier than time slot to allow for checks. Our guide Richard was extremely knowledgeable and made the tour interesting and informative with a few laughs thrown in. Really enjoyed the tour and good to see the House of Lords and Commons - just like you see on TV. worth the £32 I paid and you can see Westminster Abbey for nothing as it sits just across the road.

great experience. Did tour as part of 2 day visit to the capital. Interesting and informative. The guide made it a great experience. Quite a lot of walking which could be difficult for the elderly or infirm as you are limited as to where you are allowed to sit or rest. Lots of foreign tourists enjoy this experience. I highly 'recommend it for home grown visitors too. Eye opening!

A nice peek at question time made my day.. I enjoyed our visit to the houses of parliament even though my 2 daughters would rather have taken the speed boat tour. I have been wanting to go for a very long time . We had a very nice lady guide called Gloria who showed us around the outside building and explained the history before leading us into a main hall where a second lady took us up through Westminster building pointing out some of the statues of former Prime Ministers and finally at the top we got to see the MPs debating . No David Cameron or Ed Milliband but still a very good experience. The tours run 4 days a week and i advise going later in the day as thats when they are the quietest .

The view says it all!. Not more to say than if you are not impressed by the view of the exterior of the Houses of Parliament then you are not easily impressed. The scene is a marvel and one that everyone has to punch during a visit.Little know fact that Big Ben is the name of the bell in the clock tower not the clock itself.

A must do. Amazing building with great photo opportunities. You can spend as little or as long as you like viewing parliament and until you are stood up close, you don't appreciate how amazing this piece of architecture is.Very "proud to be British" moment

Our visit to the Houses of Parliament was the most interesting part of our visit London!. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Houses of Parliament. We took our 17 yo and 20yo kids, and it was my son's favorite site. We just walked up, no reservation, and we were able to sit in on the debates in the House of Commons and the House of Lords for as long as we liked. (the website gives you an idea of what time the Parliament will be in session on a given day). We spent 2+ hours because we found it so interesting, but even if you only have an hour it is worth a visit (leave 20+ minutes for security and waiting as they stagger visitors in). Visitors go through an extensive series of security screenings (my son's soccer ball was confiscated!), but everyone is helpful and friendly. Visitors sit in the balcony overlooking the proceedings, it is very easy to hear and follow everything going on. The debates were interesting and so entertaining, especially the House of Commons, due to the clever remarks and behavior of the various MPs. The House of Lords is more formal, which is to be expected; we spent most of our time in the House of Commons. We highly recommend this for anyone visiting London, except those with young children.

Definitely worth taking a tour. You can take a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament when Parliament is not in session. If the building is beautiful and amazing on the outside, it is incredible on the inside. Well worth taking this tour.

The highlight of my entire trip to London!. Seeing a live debate in the House of Commons was the best experience of my entire, week-long stay in London. It was amazing to be able to see the speeches given by politicians, as well as seeing the three old guys wearing their white wigs. It almost felt like I was watching a filming of a movie, but it was all real. It's really hard to explain it. You just have to go visit it. Plus, it's free!

Well worth a visit - excellent staff too!. I went on the tour of the Houses of Parliament yesterday with my husband. Our tour was booked for 12:30 but we arrived at 12 o'clock after seeing on the ticket that you should arrive 20 minutes before your tour. We were scanned and had our bags x-rayed similar to being at the airport with no queues or fuss. There was a café and toilets once inside - the toilets were clean! We then entered Westminster Hall which was beautiful. We sat on the benches and waited ten minutes before being called up for our tour. There were 24 people in our group - not too many. A lady checked our tickets before telling us that she wasn't our guide but that she would be taking us to meet him. Our guide was Will Forrester he was fantastic. He was a minute or two later after getting stuck (literally) in a toilet cubicle but came speeding along to meet us in his wheelchair. He assured all visitors that his disability would not change our tour in anyway. He was very knowledgeable and entertaining. Each of the rooms were beautiful with lots of history. Our tour lasted for 80 minutes in total. There is one part where you can sit down for 3 or 4 minutes, other than that, it is mainly walking and standing. Not a problem to us and I had seen this written by others, however, something to bear in mind for small children or people not too steady on their feet for a long time! Wonderful trip, thoroughly enjoyed it! I would definitely recommend this!

Entertaining and informative guided tour. Went on a guided tour in June 2013, visiting both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The building itself is short of spectacular, but it was our guide who made the visit so special. He told us a lot of interesting facts (as well as rumours!) about the way the parliament works in a very entertaining way (not your usual guide who simply regurgitates facts they have learnt off by heart). You are likely to learn something new whether you are a tourist or have been living in London all your life. It was great to visit the places you see so often on TV!People with mobility issues (doesn't apply to wheelchair users) should bear in mind that you should be prepared to stand throughout most of the tour as there are only a few places where you are allowed to sit down during the 75 minute visit.

impressive. Great tour with lots of interesting facts. It is an impressive building and nice to have been in both chambers as you so often see on TV.Tip : book tour online ( on website of House of Parliament ) in advance .

Listening to debate was a GREAT experience!. My brother and I actually went inside and listened to debate on a bill. It was AWESOME. It is TOTALLY FREE. You just get a pass from the guard outside, go through security, take a photo and get ushered in. It's the only way that I know of to get inside to take photos (just of interior of building but no cameras are allowed in the area where debate takes place). When the guard was explaining that only people who wanted to listen in should come and not those who only wanted pictures, people walked away. My brother and I were like, duuuuuh, just say you want to listen and STILL take pictures. haha. If you're like us though, and enjoy politics, it will be worth the pics and the debate!

Exceeded expectations. £16 entrance fee seemed quite a bargain so decided to take the tour. Very well organised and our tour stated exactly when it was supposed to. Very friendly and knowledgeable tour guide. Found out loads of info about our history. Shame that photos aren't allowed but not too much of a big deal.Some older folk struggled with walking aspect and sitting is not allowed!

Brilliant Visit on the hottest day of the year. Everyone very friendly, one of our party was offered a wheelchair which was fab because it's quite a long interesting tour and your not allowed to sit in any room. You can get a real feel of all the history and it's well worth a visit.We booked in for tea in the Pugin room and it was lovely sitting there in a fab room but the tea really wasn't worth twenty pounds a head there wasn't even one slice of bread sandwich wise, just two mouthfuls. The little fancies were very tasty but so small, minuscule. We were pleased we went it's great to see it all in the flesh so to speak, and I have a better understanding of all the jargon, like a three line whip.

Fantastic tour....tea elsewhere?. Visited with my Mum and we were both impressed by the tour. Our guide was excellent (Jacqueline) and the history and facts were fascinating. Perfect length too. My only gripe is that the afternoon tea in the Pugin Room, although novel, was a little stingy. Only 4 savoury sandwich/rolls between 2 and being only '2 bitesize' each, it was not enough. They all looked interesting too so it would have been nice to try one each. I agree with a previous reviewer too that the waiting staff were not forthcoming in topping up the tea. A few more tea choices would have been good too with Breakfast and Earl Grey being the only non fruit versions on offer. That said, the small tea room has a lovely position overlooking the river and it felt nice having tea in the houses of parliament - not an everyday venue!
Fantastic. Amazing - what more can I say.Visited last month - its always surreal to stand where so many times you have seen the place you are on TV in books etc.

Fascinating. We arranged to go to the Houses of Parliament through our MP and it was absolutely terrific. It was fascinating to see the workings of Parliament and our guide was incredibly knowledgeable and interesting. Only negative was the trip went too quickly.
charity evening. a wonderful meal set within the houses of parliament with all the pomp, glory and traditions of the seat of world democracy.
Worth a look. Didn't go inside. Walked around the outside and heard Big Ben chime worth a look at an amazing historic building

Very entertaining tour, tea a bit spartan!. We have visited the Palace of Westminster several years ago, but this year, tea in the Pugin Room was being offered, and we are suckers for tea in different places! The tour guide - Russell Grant, was hilarious; very enthusiastic, very informative and more than a little jingoistic - perfect! I seem to recall we saw more last time e.g. death warrant of Charles 1st, but this was a well executed tour and very well choreographed to allow as many people to visit in smallish groups (about 25) at a time. The acoustics of the building are not that good and you have to listen carefully to hear everything, but it is great nevertheless.The tea was booked for a while after the tour. The Pugin Room is a small enterprise just above the terrace overlooking the Thames. There are about a dozen tables seating 2-4 which can be put together for bigger groups. The linen was white and crisp, the food delicious, but, there was very little of it. There are four types of sandwiches which, as previously mentioned, are more like canapés, between two of us i.e. two very small savoury bites each. The small chocolate delice and small lemon meringue "shot" are delicious and the scone was fresh and soft, but at £19.95 each, we both felt this was a bit steep. The room is very atmospheric and quite intimate, the staff friendly, but not always attentive in topping up teacups; as there were at least 4 staff for about 24 guests, this really should not have been a problem, but was.Overall, it was a wonderful experience, but not one we would repeat unless the price drops or each person gets one of each of the four sandwiches in future.If you do not book for tea in the Pugin Room, there is a café just off the main Westminster Hall which anyone visiting can use.

Houses of Parliament. Beautiful, impressive and what an atmosphere !! Views from the bridge and close-up, great. Obviously in the centre of London and looking almost Royal, beautifully situated and certainly one of the sights of London not to be missed.

Brilliant. Brilliant tour of parliament as a guest of a friend who works there. His knowledge and enthusiasm added to the history and sense of seeing where our country has been shaped. When visiting London if you can arrange a visit make sure you do and stand where Nelson Mandela stood.

Interesting. As an adult I found our tour round the Palace of Westminster fascinating but, as I was with a school group, I have to say the children were very unimpressed. Off the record, we were told that Mr Gove had insisted that school groups were given the full history of events but our group were 13 year-old studying Modern Studies, not History, so wasn't that relevant. Also, the tour guide was asking the children questions about War of the Roses etc. and seemed surprised that our group couldn't answer his questions. We are a Scottish school and our curriculum is different from the English one but this was not taken into account at all..
Interesting tour. An interesting Saturday tour, open to all during Recess. The Commons and Lords were a bit smaller than they appear on telly. The tour guide was very informative.

UK Citizens get in tour through your MP. Get in touch with your MP and arrange a tour. Our guide was great and gave a different perspective on the tour. My teenage children were even impressed with the tour!

Herding Cats!. If you want to take a tour round the Houses of Parliament you can contact your MP and do it for free. Starting and finishing in Westminster Hall, the guides are incredibly well informed and you get to see parts you never see on TV. However, if you are taking a group of adults, you will need someone to keep the stragglers up with the main group as it is easy to get left behind. Think of them as a school group who need herding!

Striking English Gothic Palace. Like our Capitol building in Washington, DC, to many other national government buildings, the Houses of Parliament rate as a must see in London, but you should plan ahead to make sure that tours are available. I was able to take the House of Lords tour and the architecture and decoration are truly outstanding for anyone who enjoys beautiful ornate surroundings. But there were no Lords or Parliament sessions at the time we visited.
House of Lords in session. It was an amazing experience to sit in the gallery and consider how much governance has taken place in this room well in advance of the American colonization.
Makes you proud. The Houses of parliament are a stunning historical building which can be seen from the Thames at its best. You should do a Thames cruise to see all that London can offer.

Great tour. If you are at all a student of British history, law, or just life, this is a must-see. 75 min tour was excellent with very knowledgeable tour-guide who certainly seemed to love his job. It's a majestic building and it's fun to be walking around for the tour. You MUST book in advance though to get tickets---we saw so many people disappointed at the door!

Wonderful tour. Ordered tickets over the net before our trip, picked them up at the ticket office. Scheduled a 9:30 tour which was a great idea, no lines that early. They recommended being there 30 minutes early, but I'd say 15 minutes is OK if you're there for the first tour in the morning. Our tour guide was excellent (and fresh, since it was her first of the day). Tour takes about 90 minutes with almost no breaks to sit, so be prepared. The whole family enjoyed the tour, even my 14 year old found plenty to be interested in. A fine cafe is there at the end of the tour. Would strongly recommend!

Visit the home of British Democracy. Have a great 2/3 hours looking around this wonderful historic place.So may rooms, lobbies and corridors yet very intimate debating chambers.We booked well in advance and had a well balanced tour of the buildings and the history that went into creating some of the strange process's and traditions. In many ways there is much to question , and you can understand thinking this is a Westminster Bubble. Although the buildings look old, apart from Westminster Hall, the remainder is in a neo-gothic style and whilst grand in position size and overview- inside it is pretty un-inspiring and without much originality. But dont go for the architecture, go to absorb the history, the speeches the arguments and revolutions. Go to appreciate the characters who have filled these rooms, corridors and lobby areas - who have planned,persuaded,who plotted and made this country what it is today ...........and then,think and have your own thought provoked , about 'what would you do? what would you say? ' when standing in the chambers.

Taking students to Parliament!. I visited with a group of Post-16 students. An organised tour, the guide was foreign and spoke very quickly - so I found her hard to follow. Apart from that - it was wonderful to see the places where so much history has been made and witnessed, where our laws are made. I would have liked to have lingered more and been able to take in more of the surroundings, but the guided tour was rather hurried for my taste. I like to savour the sights! Well worth a visit. (even with 15 students!)

Lucky. Purchased tickets to Spanish tour, had them changed to English for family. Only slots available, and was not going to miss it. They were very kind, please book this event early. Excellent tour.

A walk through the past. You have to pay to get into this building and security is water tight, there are lots of things to take pictures off but obviously certain areas you cannot go, rumour has it they want to sell it off to a hotel chain and move to a modern building as this one is 'too small' for the work they (the politicians) do!You can arrange a private visit to Parliament if you contact your local politician, but only if you are a resident of this country.

An Awesome Visit to the Stranger's Gallery!!. We took the time to go through security and wait for an opening to go into the Stranger's Gallery and visit the House of Lords for an afternoon questioning session. It was an impressive experience to see the work of this branch of Parliament in session. Enter at the side of Parliament closest to St. Margaret's Chapel (we came at 14:10 p.m. for the opening session at 14:30 p.m.). Visitors are given a card (ours was red for the House of Lords (the House of Commons was not in session that day, but I'm guessing the card to visit them would be green). Each family gets a single card that must be carried with you until it is taken by an official. After getting your card outside, you walk to the entrance where you are let in and get your picture taken for a temporary ID that you wear on a lanyard around your neck. You then go through a metal detector just like you would at the airport. Next you to into a building that leads to the old Church Chapel. After walking through this long, open church that is still used for official receptions, you go up a flight of stairs and turn to the left. It is here that you encounter signs that advise no photography is allowed. You walk down the hall toward benches that are on the right-hand side of the ornate hall where you sit and wait to be ushered into yet another hallway where you sit on another set of benches. Once you are in the first hallway, your wait is probably 30-45 minutes more as there are only approximately 30 visitors allowed in the Stranger's Gallery at a time (you have to wait for prior visitors to leave for space to be opened up for you to be invited in). Once it is your turn to leave the leather benches in the second hallway, you go through a door (same door that we saw many of the official visitors from the government come through that day - those were the same folks we saw being questioned in the House of Lords later once we got into the Stranger's Gallery). Once you get through this door, you are ushered to another smaller hall where a room that looks and functions like a coat-check room is situated. An attendant there relieves you of all of your possessions and gives you a token with a number on it to pick up your possessions once you leave and then you are invited to walk the multiple flights of stairs to get to the Stranger's Gallery. Once you are at the entry to the Stranger's Gallery, a beautifully dressed official in coat and tails shows you in silence to your seat and you look out to see you are in the balcony overlooking the House of Lords (just like you see on CSPAN and the BBC). The gentleman in coat and tails gives each family a small brochure which explains the proceedings, who sits where, the general order of the House of Lords, and there is a monitor which tells you who is speaking. It is most impressive to see government in action and is well worth the wait! If you have any interest in politics, this is the place to visit. On the day we were there, they were discussing an education bill and foreign ownership of England's natural resources. By the way...forgot to mention, there is a sign before you go up the stairs to the Gallery that points toward the Stranger's Gallery (that's how we knew the name as no one ever said this was where we were going to be going).

An extraordinary visit!. There's so much history inside the house of parliament, I'm actually grateful that I got to see this building from the inside and be inside the house of commons. If you have time to visit this building I totally recommend.

What an interesting trip. Totally recommend this visit for all the family especially for families who like history and politics. It takes about 2 hours and is well worth the visit to one of the most famous places in London

Fantastic slice of History. We arranged a tour of the Houses of Parliament through our local MP Jo Swinson and we were not disappointed. We were met at the door and given a really interesting tour of both houses by one of her assistants. We stood at the dispatch box and walked in the footsteps of great Parliamentarians and royalty. Not to be missed.

Great tour. Very informative & complete tour. We advise purchasing tickets online before leaving for your trip. The security checkpoint took 5 minutes. Once inside you are directed to a 1000 year old "Great Hall" where you are grouped together with about 20 people and a personal guide takes your group everywhere including into both houses of parliment. We walked around both of the chambers. It is not like the US Capitol where you look down on the floor of the chamber from a balcony. Here you are actually standing next to their benches. The guides answered all questions with extensive knowledge. This was our most "British Experience" during our seven day trip to London.
Houses of Parliament. Very interesting and a real eye opener, well worth visiting especially if your interested in history.

Amazing building and experience. We visited the Houses of Parliament on a 2 p.m. Saturday tour in July 2013 and found the experience one of the best while in London. The tour guide was excellent, very knowledgeable and articulate. The overall tour itself was well-organized and timely. The building was simply magnificent. It's hard to imagine that for some people this building is their routing office space. The architecture, decour, colours, artwork, splendour, and history that surround them everyday are amazing and hard to parallel. The luxury and splendour of the House of Lords, the hallways and rooms leading to the more humble House of Commons, the paintings along the way, the traditions surrounding both Houses--all is worth this tour many times over. Security to enter the building was smooth and quick. Once inside, you wait for your tour (time) to be called in the language of your choosing. You line up and wait for the tour guide to begin. The size of the group was around 25-30 people and while it was fast-moving, we still got a lot of the experience.The tour offers a nice cafe at the end of the 1+ hour tour as well as a small gift shop.All very much worth the time and money.

vast building. Nothing to dislike...if you live in United Kingdom its a must as the centre for Government...find out how we developed our laws and see statues of men who set those laws in place as well as wonderfull views of London

Trip to Houses of Parliament. Found it all very interesting. You see the House of Commons, House of Lords and if you are lucky you see some of the M.P. walking through the lobby- lobby itself is well worth seeing

Government in action. A chance to see how British Government is run and a lot of history to learn. Amazing guides who know all there is know about htis amazing building. Time for each tour is limited but the time given is more than sufficient.

Afternoon tea in the Pugin room. Take tea at the Houses of Parliament!Some of the summer and Saturday tours of the Houses of Parliament have an option to take afternoon tea (for an additional £19.95) in the Pugin Room in the House of Commons until 24 August.
Seat of government, beautiful building. So many important decisions taken here through history. Magnificent interior, awe-inspiring architecture. Not to be missed. One of London's sight-seeing gems

ABSOLUTELY FASCINATING. For anyone who loves history or politics, this is unmissable. Our tour guide gave us more juicy bits of information than you would ever read in a history book, making the lives and experiences of people who have trodden those hallways all the more vivid and intriguing.I had heard that the Houses of Parliament were renowned for the poor quality of the food served, and that proved to be correct - don't go there hungry!
Good outing. A must see and visit for everyone showing the historical aspect of government and the superb building housing it

Super interesting and extremely well guided. The best tourist attraction in London, I think (i've lived here for 8 years), the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament is so interesting and full of history and fun facts. I hope all the guides are as good as ours (ours was an English lady who actually conducts most of the tours in Italian).

Everyone with any interest in politics should do this....... We booked online well in advance to take a tour on a Saturday afternoon when Parliament was in recess. The cost was £16.50 each. We arrived as instructed 20 minutes before our allotted time. We noted casual visitors being turned away. Entering via the Cromwell Street entrance you have your tickets checked and you then go through Airport style security. This is staffed by Metropolitan Police Officers who were the friendliest I have ever met. You then go into Westminster Hall to wait for your time. There is access to toilets and the café while you wait. Allocated to your group by time your guide then explains the layout of the tour – no photography; you go first to the far end of tour before it begins properly; no sitting down; keep together; don’t touch – which starts by going up a steep flight of steps.The tour proper starts at the Sovereign’s Entrance, then into the Robing Room ; the Princes Room and then into the Lords; then into Central Lobby, the Members Lobby and then into the Commons.Our guide, Joanne was knowledgeable – her descriptions and information was more ‘popular’ than ‘legalistic/constitutional’ – and well delivered. One thing to note is that there are several groups all following the same route at the same time – there is therefore scope for competing commentaries overlapping and delays in narrow corridors and waiting for some group members to catch up. Wheelchair visitors are well handled. Children in strollers are allowed.The tour lasts 75 minutes, all standing (with limited exceptions). Highlights – the Robing Room – huge frescos; the Commons Chamber (‘its smaller than it looks on TV’); the changing architecture of the building from old to new(ish); the unusual depictions of Kings and Queens (was Anne Boleyn really that fat!!??); the statuary (very powerful statues of Sir Winston Churchill and Baroness Thatcher). You return to Westminster Hall.

Check out Parliament in session. We entered Parliament's House of Commons while they were in session. We listened as they debated social issues and proposed laws. The clerks were in white wigs from yesteryear. The building, history, and experience were very cool. And it was free!
fascinating. Don't miss this tour, but you must book in advance online. We weren't able to visit while the House of Commons was in session which was disappointing.

Somewhere also a visiting London.. Best to book on line in advance, but an experience to see 'where our country is run from!!' Guides we encountered while knowledgable were a bit over Zealous about where to stand, sit or either. You only see a small part but interestng.

having a great Blue Badge Guide can make all the difference. It's literally filled with history; approaching it, you'll likely see the park acorss the street with statues of Churchill and Abraham Lincoln--plus a statue of Nelson Mandela(!)

Don't miss this tour. This is a very interesting tour as you get to see all the main rooms in the Palace of Westminister (as the Houses of Parliament are called) including the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Tours are conducted on Saturdays during the Summer opening and can be booked on-line. UK residents can arrange to have a free tour at specified times during the week. The tour guides are excellent.

Brilliant. Did a tour of Houses of Parliament recently and was amazed by it. Not at all what I expected. A tour guide escorts you around and gives you a history lesson which was excellent. The building is amazing with so much artwork on show. You are taken into the House of Commons and also the House of Lords, which are much smaller than they look on tv. I would thoroughly recommend this tour, you won't be disappointed .

So much History!. We had a very interesting tour ( family of 4). Have always wanted to see inside this impressive building and we were not disappointed. Our tour guide was terrific and the tour itself was well organised. What a privilege! As we are not Brits we had to visit on a Saturday.

Fantastic. If you're in a hurry, ask to visit the House of Lords. The line is so much shorter than the one for the Commons, the chamber is prettier, and the ceremony is more interesting. You will miss out on the lively debates of the Commons, but the time you save will be well worth it. If seeing the Commons is a must, consider popping in a few hours before closing time on one of the weekday evenings when they stay open late.

Excellent Tour. My husband and 23 year old son took the tour and both found it to be excellent. Highly recommend. You must book the tour in advance but it was a very interesting tour for both of them.

Tour was a bit long, but amazing place. I loved seeing Parliament, and was really happy I got to see what it was like inside. The tour got a little long for my taste, but it was still great to see such a gorgeous and iconic place.

Amazing experience. I've never visited the Palace of Westminster before and was prepared for the tour to be worthy but dull. In fact it was absolutely rivetting from start to end - the guide was excellent and of course the place itself is absolutely packed with interest. Could have spent days there - each room or chamber was worthy of a couple of hours. I highly recommend it.
Impressive. Very impressive building, another must see London Landmark. Although you can visit inside this building we didn't.

Very interesting summer tours.. You can go into the houses of parliament during the summer but you must prebook the tickets in advance you cannot turn up on the day and expect to buy tickets. Very interesting tour inside and to learn a bit of british of political history. Beutiful building inside and out a must see when visiting london.

Get in touch with your MP. We arranged a trip with our local MP and it was absolutely fantastic. I've been before but went on a larger tour but on this occasion he sent one of the aids down to give us a tour. It was much more intimate and amazing. I learnt so much history and even got to see the bars the MP use. I'd recommend it to everyone and it's free!!

Great Sightseeing Experience. After we toured the Westminster Abbey, my wife and I headed for the bridge across the River Thames. We were pleasantly surprised that our route took us passed several famous British landmarks including the Houses of Parliament. This is a very majestic complex with lots of activity buzzing around it. It was interesting to see such detail in the architecture, and as is often the case, pictures and movie clips just don’t do it justice. As we were on a fixed budget and had a short amount of time available for our London experience, we did not check into any tours. However, according to another TripAdvisor posting, you might be able to secure some free tickets just by doing some preplanning. Regardless if you decided to tour the grounds, just walking by is an incredible experience that should be a part of any London itinerary.

A great opportunity to see the houses of parliament up close. It is free to enter the houses of parliament and go into the visitors gallery from where you can see the whole house of MPs debating live in front of you and see some of the very old buildings recognised the world over. A must-see for any Brit or tourist interested in British politics & history.

Great freebie in London. We arranged this tour through our local MP, just by emailing her office. Everyone can do this.It's free, interesting, stunning, brilliant!The blue-badge guides were friendly and informative, the building just oozes history and Westminster Hall is awe-inspiring. I've lived in London all my life and love all the amazing historic buildings we have around us. This is a must see for Brits and tourists alike. Book it!
Houses of parliament. Excellent to view. Good to walk round, look at protection around the perimeter which is new over last few years and walk through the area where media chat.

Interesting. Very interesting insights on British government. I was able to be with a tour group to see both the Houses of Lords and Commons, as well as getting a view of the Queen's robing room and the Royal Galleries. What a sight to see! I spent most of the tour with my jaw to the floor!
Beautiful Architecture. Well worth the visit to see this building. Big Ben is right at the corner and Westminster Abbey across the street.
Westminster tour. My second tour. Excellent, althoughthis time we could not go to the Sovereign's Robing room as I think it was under maintenance. Love the history, esp Westminster Hall.
This is real London. Reaching this and other places in LOndon is so easy, either by bus or underground. Take your time to walk, enter and live each corner of Westminster!

This is an opportunity that is well worth your time. One can visit either the House of Commons or the House of Lords, free of charge. There is a bit of a wait for either house....with the House of Commons typically being the most popular venue. You have to go through a metal detector so do not bring too much stuff with you. You can stay as long or as little as you like. Just seeing the inside of this very old and very famous piece of architecture is worth the visit. And of course....you are right there next to Westminster Abbey, Westminster Pier.....so many things to see and do in one small area.

Great way to begin my trip!. This was the first tourist attraction upon my arrival to London. My son met me at the airport and after getting settled at our hostel and to Parliament we were late ..... Fortunately they were amazing and accommodating and it was sooo interesting - a must see for sure!! I was very excited to say the words "hey kids, Big Ben, Parliament" when walking towards the building. Chevy Chase reference if you get it lol!!
Evening Tour of House of Lords. Great tour through the House of Lords. Learned about the artwork and they history of the building. It ended with champagne in one of the rooms.

Spend a Few Minutes with History. The House of Parliament is in a grand old castle on the Thames. The large open banquet hall greets up and then you are given the opportunity to watch a session of the House in progress. It was very interesting and educational. My family really enjoyed it.

Loved Our Tour!!!!. Our friend's neighbor worked security at the Parliament Building and took us on a two hour private tour. What a beautiful and amazing building. We went through the Port Calle Security Glass entrance that opens up into a large area with restaurants,seating areas and souvenir shops.This area attaches the old Scotland Yard Building where they now have offices for their representatives. It was built as an opera building and is beautiful inside. We toured the Lords and the Commons Houses of Parliament and ended our tour at Westminster which was part of the original old Palace. We wanted to climb Big Ben, but you had to have permission from a member of Parliament. However, we saw nice views of Big Ben behind the gates and we were able to see the entrance that the Queen comes in and here special stairway. What a great day!!!

Come rested. I guess the number of visitors is so high that the guides have some pressure to keep the schedule. I felt our guide was in a bit of a hurry and did not appreciate questions. What a pity, as there was so much to see. I also felt many of the visitors had a need to sit down from time to time but thisxwas only allowed two places. So come rested and not at the end of a long day at other attractions as we dis,

A must see in London. I took a guided tour - together with my 12 years daughter. Very interesting . The explains were great and really made us feel we learned about thwarting palace. Petty we were not allowed to photo .

Parliament visit. A wonderful building this was my second visit .went with the school in 1947 it was badly bombed then and the House of Lords was used by the House of Commons. It's hardly changed but if you get a chance it's not to be missed. And have tea on the terrace

This is a must visit in London add I to your list. We will never be able to watch the news again without thinking back to the wonderful tour we had with our brilliant guide Caroline, she did keep us amused and her knowledge was outstanding. The tour is jam packed and you need to book in advance as it is only Saturdays. We were the last tour group at 4:30 pm and as such it was crowded with plenty if tour groups but was really extremely well organised that it was not a problem. You visit all the necessary rooms and the tour really let's you mind wonder back to all the discussions and debates that have gone on over hundreds of years, see where the black rod has damaged the door to the House of Commons from the other side of the House of Lords, all fascinating and well worth a visit even if its to say to all your mates when looking at a debate "I was there"

Great visit. The beauty of this vintage building along side the Thames is out standing. Right place to take a snapshot with this building as back ground. A masterpiece and must spend some time around. You visit cannot side view security reasons.

Expedited visits. The place is both beautiful and interesting but we are rushed from one room to the other with many groups colliding and guides speaking in different languages at the same time in the same room. No time to look at the many murals and other works of art.

Must see this landmark. Walk around. Fews crowds on far end away from Westminster. LOT OF PEOPLE IN THE SUMMER. News people broad cast from small green on north side, west end, check out nearby Jewel tower which is original Castle/Parliment building.

Fabulous surroundings. Great visit to see the centre of the political classes and their minions scurrying about looking important (their opinion) Beautiful surroundings but over protective arcane surroundings leave one with the impression it badly needs a modernising hand. The building though is magnificent but the facilities are very poor in my opinion

Make Your Reservations and Go!. You have to make reservations ahead of time to see Parliament, and it's well worth it! Even if you are not a history buff, you will enjoy this tour. I did! Our tour guide was an older gal who was so nice and she really did a great job with the tour, and gave us the flavor of the place. We got to see all the rooms and they are really special. The decoration, the history, the ambience of the place is just like a palace and you really get to see a lot. Take an early tour if you can, the first one is best as there are fewer groups and it is not so noisy. They are so efficient at this place as well. The lines were very organized and they had their program in good order...like the Brits always do. Well done!
Excellent Tour. Well Worth booking on the tour... learn so much about British History, fascinating. Watching it on TV does not do this beautiful building justice.

Very interesting and worthwhile. This was my 2nd visit to the Houses of Parliament.I got a free tour by contacting my local MP's Westminster Office.
