If you are from the UK and are interesting in seeing the House of Parliment, it is definitely worthwhile doing this as it saves you £30 which is the normal price of a ticket. We also managed to do this quite last minute and got put on a tour due to a cancellation.The tour took about 1.5 hours and we were shown round in a group of about 15 by a very knowledgable tour guide. She took us round the buiding and went through the history of the building itself, government and the monarchy. We weren't able to get into the House of Commons as it was in session, but when I visited in August last time we were able to get in.When the tour is finished you also get the option of going into the House of Commons viewing gallery which was very interesting. We had to wait for about 20 minutes before getting in, but once you're in you're free to stay as long or as little as you want.Worth a visit!

.... and not a politician in sight :-). The weekend tours here allow the 'great unwashed' i.e. 'Us' have a wonderfully insightful tour around the Palace of Westminster, including the Royal rooms which you never see on televised events there. The tour guides are exceptionally knowledgeable and the groups are small so everyone can feel part of the tour. So much history, so much to learn about more than just the parliament of the UK, and sooo much quieter without the rabble in the 'House' :-) I would recommend this tour to anyone with an interest in the political and broader history of the UK, its constitution andits relationship with the monarchy. Fascinating!

Long but worth it. Book before to pay a visit to the houses of parliament. It was very long and my two year old was very knackered (not to mention ourselves too). prepare yourself to walk but the guided tour was very pleasant and tour guide was extremely nice!! it was something different then what we usually choose to do on a holiday as we don't like politics!

A great tour of a very interesting building. I went on the tour of the Houses of Parliament for the second time this summer, this time with my family, and it was as great the second time as the first. Our guide told us the whole history of the Parliament from its beginning and up until today and could answer most questions we asked about the building. We really enjoyed our visit and might even go a third time!

Very worthwhile tour....don't miss it!. My husband had checked out the website prior to our trip and scheduled the tour on a Saturday morning. We're so glad he did! We arrived early as we were instructed and got through security easily. There were A LOT of tour groups-with maybe 15 to 20 people in each group. They are well orchestrated, moving throughout the Houses of Parliament. Be prepared to stand! We found the tour informative AND entertaining. Our tour guide, Isobel was wonderful! She reminded me a bit of Helen Mirren. :-D Anyway, we would put the Houses of Parliament tour as one of the top 5 things we did in London.....and that list includes Wimbledon!
Tour definitely worth-while. First time actually taking a tour and it was wonderful--very informative guide and the building is amazing. Highly recommend doing it.
Beatiful from outside, not a lot to see inside.. If you go, take the opportunity to attend a plenary session. It is possible to do so as a visitor. This can be a curious experience.

Seat of British democracy. but you can't sit down. Tour takes about 1.5 hours and expect to stand the whole time. There are stairs so call ahead if you have limited mobility, or such. Excellent tour guide, who kept the group together and controlled. Be aware there are lots of tour and during the week this is a working office (we went on a Saturday). Listen to all the don'ts, then relax and learn about the workings of parliament. Interesting tour for folks of all ages.

London's must see. You cannot visit London without seeing the house of parliament & the Big Ben. You can even attend debates and watch committees when Parliament is in session (which we did not do). You should also visit the Abbey though I find £18 a bit excessive.

special tour. We had a special member's sponsored tour, and i learned a tremendous amount and enjoyed it. I was sorry that it wasn't a bit easier to focus with the million other tours going through, but splendid to have the opportunity to get a relatively back room tour

Very interesting. A guided tour by a well-informed guide which took in both the Commons and the Lords.
A must if in London during Parliament recess but at other times you can contact your local MP to get on a tour.
Totally worth it!. So much history behind it; we were a bit disappointed at the speed of the tour which preempted any in depth looks at the paintings and statues. However, still highly recommended!

How do you rate history?. Once through the security which can be daunting but necessary (and they are polite in sharp comparison to many airports), one enters a wonderful world of ritual, history and Victorian kitsch at its most glorious. The Great Hall, the one true Medieval part is a marvel. Read those plaques for the full story.

A treat. This was the second time I have done the tour of the Houses of Parliament. It is informative, historical and entertaining. I would recommend this to anyone who is wanting to see historical London or political London.
An experience for my children. Due to the tight tour schedule, we were only be able to spend a very limited time on this site, but it was really an experience for my children.

Is this really a secret?. Having visited the Palace of Westminster on a couple of occasions I am still amazed how few people ever seem to go in! The streets outside are packed with tourists all taking photos of the building, and themselves of course. ( I'm not shy, but I never have really understood how a picture of such an impressive building is improved by having me or anyone else photographed in front of it?)In case people are unaware access to the chamber's public gallery is open to all and entirely free. Why not give it a try? Just ask one of the Police Officers and they will happily direct you.Once through some essential security checks you will find you have free access to the ancient Westminster hall scene of some of the greatest events in British History, Central Lobby, the Public Gallery and the excellent Jubilee Cafe.

An interesting day. I last went on this tour when 11 years old, now retired so I understood so much more about the building and government system as it was explained by the tour guide, she explained everything but in a way that made it interesting , I learnt a lot

Stunning building. We watched a debate in the House Of Commons. One of my best experiences in London. The historical building is awe inspiring. The staff was so friendly and helpful. Really enjoyed this opportunity to witness democracy.
Nice location. One of teh ust see place in London. just too bad that you cant take photos inside the abbey and that the staff isnt saying anyting when people make photos.

Proud and Beautiful. Some things a picture simply does not do justice for. You must stand before these magnificent buildings to fully appreciate them. At least, bare minimum... go there, look upon them in awe and dont forget your camera. As nice as any I have ever seen.

Remarkable Experience to be in House of Lords. If you are visiting London, I would highly recommend to spare an afternoon to visit the Houses of Parliament: it's free and definitely an interesting experience. The Parliament is open most days (check their website for the detailed information) and you can either choose to visit House of Commons or House of Lords. We went there about 2.30 pm. Having read that House of Lords had an architecturally more appealing design, we opted for that. It was a short 30 mins wait before we were admitted into the main room. While you wait in the hallway; glance at the brochure they give you at the door; it sure has simple yet interesting information about the building and its history. The day we were there; the bill that was being discussed was about genetically modified products and it was truly a nice experience to hear the discussions. Once in there you can stay as long as you want. We stayed about half an hour and every member of my family enjoyed the experience.

A UNIQUE EXPERIENCE. Touring the Palace of Westminster is to discover why we Brits like to think we are better than anyone else !! I know that is a bit over the top but until you have walked the walk around the various Chambers and listened to your guide explaining the strange rules which have developed over hundreds of years in our fight for 'democracy' you will not really understand why we call this The Mother of Parliaments ! (No it is NOT the oldest in the world - that achievement belongs strangely to ICELAND !) But it has set the trend for Parliaments everywhere thanks to the British Empire. Not every country adopts the same layout of course. Back in 1967 I was with some Russians touring there for the first time, one of whom asked the question 'WHAT is opposition !!!?' when we got to the House of Commons ! Do take advantage of the Souvenir shop in Westminster Hall and close by is a very good cafe serving light lunches. It helps if you can get a ticket from your MP beforehand. For visitors from overseas it is one the highlights of their trip. For the rest of us it just makes you proud to be British !! And it costs nothing...ASTROTRAVELCHELTENHAM

Living History. The imposing building can be visited only on Saturdays, but it was worth the wait. Unfortunately, due to increased security measures in the interior photography is prohibited, except in Westminster Hall. The interior of the building is impressive and dignified. I loved it. :)

This Tour is Worth Your Time. First, I would suggest you check the website to see when they are allowing public tours of the building.We were lucky enough to be in London on a Saturday when they were running them. I bought the tickets on line in advance for a 3:30 tour. They are spaced about 15 minutes apart and if you book in advance, you just pick the time most convenient for you. You can print the tickets out from home. We did it before leaving the U.S.The tickets tell you where to go to enter the building and warn you to be there 20 minutes in advance to go through security. The security was no big deal...at least not nowadays. You get a little white visitor badge to hang around your neck while on the tour.We cleared security and actually joined the next tour going, around 3:15. We had to show our tickets several times and no seemed to care that we were early. I don't think it matters to much since they just call a group of English speakers together until they have the right number and then we were off. Pretty painless with very little waiting around. The tour guide was very good, kind of a Mr. Chips type. The interior of the building is incredible. I had no idea it was so ornate. The tour is conducted as if you were there the day the Queen opens Parliament. It was fun to see the House of Commons after having seen it on TV in America so many times.There are a lot of tours going on at the same time, but they don't interfere with each other. The tour lasts about 90 minutes and there is only one brief chance to sit down...just in case someone has a problem with that.After the tour you can linger in the Great Hall as long as you like. We had a bite to eat in the café and took pictures of Big Ben from an angle that most people don't see.I highly recommend this tour.

The Houses of Parliament. Went with a group trip organised by our local MP. The Great Hall is seriously impressive, we all enjoyed the tour and sat in to listen t debates in both the Commons and Lords. We also visited the ST Marys Undercroft Chapel, which was magnificent. We dinned on the terrace area and enjoyed afternoon tea. Well worth a trip to see where our masters work on our behalf! Good value.

Visit a piece of history. Here's a tip for you. Contact the office of your local MP well in advance and ask for a tour. They will try and fit you in for a visit, even if its not the MP in person who is taking you around.

Worth the wait.. We braved the long waits to get into the House of Commons and the House of Lords. I was so glad we did. While the line was long, and while the vast majority of our time here was spent waiting to get in, what we eventually saw was great. Politics in action, and in the House of Lords, politics in action in a remarkable setting.If you can only see one, do House of Lords. If possible, see both.Try to avoid the crowds by going early or late. We went right in the afternoon and totally paid for it with at least an hour of waiting (just sitting). For all of that waiting, we stayed in each House viewing room for just 5 minutes, if that.Still, glad we did it. It was interesting and invigorating.

History ......worth a visit. House of Parliament is worth a visit if you are in London.The architecture is historic and there is so much history in this building.Be prepared for long lines if you are in London in Summer

A true feel of Britain. This was my Fourth visit the first time I had lunch with our local M.P. Geoffrey Johnson Smith.The second time was with the Institute of Directors with cocktails on the terrace. The third time I visited the House of Lords plus lunch with our M.P. Charles Hendry in a private dining room. The fourth visit I was invited to Prime Ministers Question Time. Highly recommended
Westminster is amazing. A must see in London. One of our favourite sites to visit in London. Easy to get to via the Tube. Very crowded and touristy location, but a must see!

Take your pic. Absolutely beautiful. We circled the place by bus, boat and on foot. We observed it from the eye and from the ground and at every angle it's amazing. What we did not do is go inside so I have no idea if there is a way to visit. If you are in London for any reason whatsoever, you must visit and take some pictures. FYI, Big Ben is the nickname of the bell and not the clock itself......learned that tidbit during my touring.

The tour is brilliant. If you are lucky enough to be able to do the tour do not think twice about it, it's one of the best things I have done in London. Our tour guide was very knowledgable & was considerate of kids on the tour so made it interesting for them. Seeing the House of Lords & House of Commons was a fantastic experience and also getting to learn some history of the building/our government. The tours are done in small groups , I would say 20 maximum so we were always able to hear the guide. If visiting London again would do this tour for a second time.
Huge. It was massive - it was so busy - it was just really impressive - I was wowed by it - this building is well worth seeing

Fascinating tour. This is a great tour that I would highly recommend. You are not only touring a museum and a iconic piece of history, but an actual working goverment. Our tour guide was very entertaining and informative. My wife and I also opted for "high tea" after the tour, and it was well worth the extra cost.

FASCINATING. I was unable to tour The Houses of Parliament the day I rocked up........apparently this is only possible on Saturdays or when Parliament is not sitting. However, I was able to observe the debating in the House of Commons and really enjoyed this. Maybe I'm a bit of a nerd but I stayed there for three hours and thought it was interesting.

Nice to have friends in 'high places'!. I met an old friend who is now an MP so had a lovely drink on the Terrace followed by lunch and an encounter with David Cameron. But even without all this.. just walking through the big hall and standing at the Central Lobby, etc is an amazing experience! SO much history!!

The mother of all parliaments. Only visited the outside and took pictures but that is enough to give you a sense of hiow historical it is. The big ben on one side is a definate photo op for anyone visiting London
fantastic. So nice view with big Benn and river Thames is such a wonderfull tourist atraction for all of us who traveled to London.

Very interesting tour of a fascinating building. Even though I was not feeling a 100% this was still an enjoyable experience for me. The tour guide was very knowledgable and the building was stunning. You got taken round the house of lords and the house of commons and considering it was a 75 minute tour ,it was good value for money. There is a good shop with plenty political merchandise.
majestic building. This is a majestic building , showing the greatnes og Great Britian. The most impressing is ofcourse Big Ben
Fantastic building. I went on a tour of the Parliament and found it very informative. The architecture is amazing and there was a real sense of history. Well worth a visit.

Living History. Did the standard parliamentary tour a few days ago, courtesy of our MP.We had the joy of being taken round by an extremely knowledgeable and witty guide (Kevin). Absolutely amazing being taken through such a historical building, let alone the consideration of the place that "the Mother of Parliaments" holds in the world.Very poignant looking at all of the plaques in Westminster Hall, especially the one recording Nelson Mandela's visit.We noted that Maggie's statue in the central lobby didn't have a handbag..................
Only open on Saturdays to the public. We just walked around. Go on Saturday to see the inside. We toured with Hop On Hop Off bus to learn about it.

Touring Parliament. I booked a tour to show a German friend the building. It was more comprehensive than I was expecting and everything was well-organised and timely.The security to get in is similar to going through security at an airport, but without the long delays. Once inside, we joined a queue for our tour time and were let through promptly at 11am. Our tour guide (Victoria) introduced herself and told us a bit about Westminster Hall (where the tour begins). By 11.05, we were leaving the Hall to walk down to the far end of the building where the tour starts at the Sovereign's entrance. You are shown various rooms and are able to enter the chambers of both the house of Lords and the House of commons. As I mentioned, the tour starts at entrance in the Victoria tower and progresses from the House of Lords, through the various lobbies until the House of Commons, which is the last part of the tour. The whole tour took 1 hour and 15 minutes and although it was brisk, it was in now way rushed. Your tour will take place at the same time as a number of other tour groups are happening. This means that in each room you are in, there will probably be at least 3 other groups at the same time, but the rooms are large and by crowding round your guide, you can hear clearly without being distracted by the other groups. Our tour guide was informative and peppered the talks with a mixture of facts and anecdotes. Because of the tight timetable, questions aren't taken on the tour itself, but when the tour ended back in Westminster Hall, she was happy to take any questions that our group had.The tour does not include any committee rooms or any upstairs rooms and you certainly can't wander off anywhere. Unsurprisingly, photography isn't allowed for security reasons (a guy trying to sneak a photo in another group was stopped before he'd even raised the camera) and you cannot sit down anywhere during the duration of the tour. Photos are allowed in Westminster Hall and outside the building both before and after passing security. There are toilets just off Westminster Hall and a fairly nice cafe serving a small variety of food (we had lunch there). The toilets are small and there was a queue of about 10 for the ladies, but they're clean and modern.The shop is disappointing and the quality and range of the souvenirs leaves a lot to be desired. There are a number of free leaflets about the building and the working of Parliament and some of these are available in other languages. Two other tours set off just before we did and one was a Japanese language tour and another a German tour, so these tours are also available in other languages.

A must see. The rooms in the House of Lords are spectacular. The chambers themselves are smaller than you might expect from TV, and the staff are very strict about not allowing tourist bottoms to sit on the hallowed seats (!) but this is without doubt a must see place for visitors to this country. We took my German in-laws and it was a memorable visit for them.

Excellent venue. The building is so so nice it's amazing to look at and huge, security is good and there are ques but they are professional and swift and doing. Good job of keeping us all safe. Really good signs through out the museum and toilet facilities are really clean and plentiful. If you go weekdays it's busy with school parties so can be a lot of screaming from children espically when going through the dinosaur area, which by the way is really good. The stone and gems area I really loved not normally my cup of tea but I enjoyed it. There is a cafe bit pricey I think so I took my own sandwiches I have been once in week and twice t weekends I prefer weekends. Lovely grounds to sit and have your lunch espically if it's a nice day. It's totally free go and enjoy

Classical, tasteful, and elegant. Despite the difficulty of seeing inside the Houses of Parliament, viewing the buildings from outside along Westminster Bridge or Millbank Road provides the viewer with a tremendous opportunity to indulge in the Baroque/Rococo opulence that is the Parliament complex. Ignoring the tasteless statue commemorating Mr Cromwell of historic Irish infamy, one can easily become lost in the decorative flairs and flying buttresses of the Houses. Be sure to check out Westminster Abbey and the side alleys whilst in the area.

It is a nice place. My husband and I did not enter into the Parliament, but it is very nice to see the building and the Elizabeth Tower that has the famous "Big Ben".The Parliament square is near from the Westminster Abbey and the Tames river and if it's a sunny day you can simple rest on the gardens in front of the Parliament.

Summer opening, interesting. The visit to the inside was very interesting. An amazing peek to the past and its history. The spanish guide was not really prepared and so it was a bit boring. Ill be back but in english.

Historically and architecturally magnificent. When you enter Westminter Hall at the beginning of the tour you know you are seeing something special. It was built over 800 years ago and is the biggest medieval hall in northern europe. Tour groups of 25 are just manageable and the blue badge guide was very knowledgeable. The royal chambers and the House of Lords were simply awesome. The art work was almost beyond description. The House of Commons was plainer but historically more pertinent to current affairs. The guide's ongoing description of how the parliament functions was great - it really gave you a view on how the legislature works. Excellent venue, not to be missed!

Guilding the Lilly at its best. If you have the chance to do the tour of parliament DO IT! It is a wonderful experience. Not only are the buildings out of this world, the tour was very informational, especially for those not familiar with the inner workings of the British system of government. Our guide was very knowledgable and had a wonderful sense of humor. Can't even begin to describe the buildings, carvings, frescos, stained glass, paintings, sculptures, gold leaf.. Not a space is unadorned. It is important to note that unless you are a member of the House of Lords or commons there is NO sitting on this tour.. Even though there are chairs everywhere. Also, when we arrived a 10 am, we were originally told all of the English tours were already sold out for the day...ironically there were tours in 7 other languages. We got very lucky and the "found" more tickets. Go early!
Fantastic architecture. Could not go inside but a very impressive and iconic building from the outside. Must visit place during your trip to London.

Its an experience. I got this opportunity to see the House of Parliament from the inside to attend a conference. It was a proud moment for me. Standing in the terrace by the Thames and sipping English tea was an experience. This unfortunately is not for everyone!

Tour the houses of parliament. My daughter (age 13) and I booked a Saturday morning tour of the houses of Parliament. We were very glad we did. Seeing the outside is good, but touring the inside and seeing where so many famous people have given speeches, and hearing a lot of information about the history of government in Britain was even better.The tour was very tightly scheduled - there were several other tour groups (each about 25 people) going around within a few minutes of ours - but the guide was extremely adept at keeping us to the schedule and out of the way of other groups. She was interesting, knowledgeable and sensitive to the nationalities of the people in her group. We were guided around and informed about both houses, the voting chamber and other areas of importance. There was SO much we could have seen in the house, I am almost surprised there wasn't a longer tour - but our tour was long enough for most people I imagine. So many interesting paintings and statues were placed in every hallway.At the end (and beginning) of the tour, the large older hall of the Parliament building had some souvenirs to buy, and a pretty decent cafe and WCs.Super tour, much better than just seeing the outside.
Beautiful area. Too many travellers crowding the streets. I suppose the weather was fine and it is summer after all. The steets were totally crowded and there wasnt much space to see the sights.

Toured House of Lords. Private tour after hours...focused on the art and architectural history of the building. Liked having access to the private rooms that only the Lords and the Queen occupy, hearing about the history behind some of the protocols.

Interesting. Both the interior and exterior of this building was very impressive and beautiful. Although listening to the House of Commons and Lords was sort of boring, seeing them in action was very cool. It's pretty amusing that some people still wear wigs to follow tradition. It's best to go a little before or after 5pm when it's less crowded. I've heard that the House of Commons is very crowded sometimes but when we went on Tuesday at 6pm it was pretty empty. We also walked across Westminster Bridge at night to see the Houses of Parliament and London Eye lit up and the Big Ben chiming - so breathtaking! This takes up a total of about an hour, maybe less depending on the lines and how long you decide to stay at each House. I wouldn't recommend going with babies or toddlers though - people are supposed to keep quiet while Parliament is in session.

Everyone should see it!. This imposing building is a must see if visiting London. Even if you don't go inside it is just worthwhile walking alongside it to realise the sheer size of it and to listen to Big Ben strike the hour. It is also surrounded by lots of other famous buildings such as Westminster Abbey, Whitehall, 10 Downing Street and not far from Buckingham Palace. You can also walk across the bridge to the London Eye.....so many options.

Very educational tour. This is a great tour. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and pointed out several details of the workings of the British Parliament. The building itself is huge. The tour took about an hour and a half. Well worth the time and price.
House of Lords. Lovely tour of the beautiful Parliament 2 days after the Queen made her yearly speech! very exciting.

fun to see but couldn't go in. I was disappointed that you can only go in sometimes on Saturdays. Was sad to learn that only UK citizens are allowed in the clock tower. Was great to see from the outside though and beautiful from the river at night.

See Parliament in action!. Was not difficult to into the galleries in the house of commons.This was really a highlight of the visit to London.We were able to see a debate which involved high echelon members of the conservative and opposition parties involving the Financial issues facing the UK.
Impressive building!. Loved seeing and hearing Big Ben each morning and evening. Huge building and very interesting exterior!!

Seat of democracy. Great to see both Houses of Parliament and Westminster Hall, guide was very good and made the tour amusing with little anecdotes. Would have been nice to have been able to sit on the benches in the commons, but not allowed.

Mixed Pleasure with Business. A regular attender of events and business meetings at the venue but took the time to have the tour and found it immensly interesting and well worth the time and effort to go there.
Nice to look at. You can't miss this walking around...goes hand and hand with Big Ben. Doesn't get old looking at it.

Magnificent inside as out. If you're impressed with how it looks outside, do make the effort to book yourself for a tour to see what it's like inside, and listen to the many related stories and other anecdotes as well.
History in the making. We enjoyed the very informative tour of the House of Parliament. Our guide was exceptional. Couldn't believe that the large original room was over a thousand years old.

Could have been just a little bit better. Enjoyed the experience of this tour, going through the lords and common chambers. The guide was very good but that's to be expected really.My only grumble would be the amount of people on the tour, thought 26 was a touch too many and we didn't get much time to look at the art work there and marvel at it. If anyone asked me whether its worth going then I would say yes for sure, I think you will have an enjoyable time there.
Always worth a visit. The sheer history of this palace make it a must visit every time I come through. Take a moment to sit on college green and eat a sandwich in the shadow of this great building

Very English. I marvel at the history of it all. I didn't mind the security checks, and once inside the guide shows you around and tells you all there is to know about the place. Would have liked to seat in the house of commons but you are not allowed; what a shame!!!

A highlight of our weekend. Went to London for 4 days with my husband and student son. We all chose one per arranged trip and this was our sons choice. I was not expecting it to be so good. Booked on line and our guide was excellent. Now when we see tv coverage of either house we understand the whole process much better!

Check out British government in action. We visited the Houses of Parliament on our London vacation. The houses debate into the night on Monday and Tuesday nights. The process is very painless. First you are photographed and given a paper badge, then you proceed through airport style security (you don't have to remove your shoes), and then you're in the common hall. Once there you'll be given a ticket for the House of Commons. We spent 20 minutes watching the debate before changing to the House of Lords. You have to ask one of the guards for a new ticket to visit the House of Lords, because they take your ticket. You aren't allowed to take any bags, cameras, or phones in either chamber. I prefered the House of Lords, the chamber is must more ornate and decorated. Although the debate in the House of Commons was much more lively. One final note, as you're entering (or exiting) the hall there is an awesome opportunity to have your picture made with Big Ben. Right before you enter the building, turn around. There are usually few people around and, if the light is right, it makes for a great picture.
Write to local MP and enter free. We had free tickets via local MP, so was an interesting good trip. Don't pay the £15 write to your MP and arrange free tour.

Great history tour. You have I go online to book tour tickets and its not always available. Sometimes it's fully booked 1-2 weeks in advance.Your guides are knowledgable historians and you get access to all of the main sections of parliament.For those who are unfamiliar with the UK government or history of the building it's helpful to read a bit before you tour.Highly recommend for all ages.

Must visit. Im a firm believer that we should visit the place that runs our country and have taken groups of young people to Parliament many times over the years. It is the most beautiful building full of history and tradition and even if you disagree with what goes on their its still an amazing place to visit.

Tight security but structure is jaw-dropping!. The security in this building is really tight which is understandable.. The structure is just massive and beauty is in the details of the arches and columns. Must see when you are in London.

Fantastic. I had wanted to do the tour of The Houses of Parliament for a while but had never been able to get tickets to correspond with trips to London before. About four days before our most recent visit I happened to see an article about a new opportunity to take tea in the Pugin Room (when booked with a tour of the Palace of Westminster). It had to be booked through Ticketmaster and by phone so I was doubtful of being lucky, especially as it was the first day it was available. We were successful and it was all handled really efficiently. We collected the tickets from the Ticket Office on the day, just across the road and again it was a speedy process with no waiting. The tours themselves are a little like being on a conveyor belt as they run so many during the day, and several in parallel, and there is a clear need to keep to time so groups don't back up. However, leaving that aside the actual tour was great and our guide very good. The building and its contents have a real wow factor and you really get to see all those areas we've become familiar with seeing on tv, plus lots of behind the scene rooms and corridors. The sense of history is terrific as you follow in the footsteps of Kings and Queens and Statesmen (although much of what you see is relatively recent in terms of our history having been rebuilt after a massive fire). As you pass through The Lords and The Commons you realise how much you didn't know about our heritage and parliamentary processes (plus an awful lot you did). In that sense I think overseas visitors will possibly take away a slightly different experience than a British visitor because it's so much more personal to us. As regards the afternoon tea this was perfect, after we'd been walking for around 80 minutes, so it was great just to sit down in comfy chairs. The tea was delicious and exactly as described by another reviewer, in some detail, so I won't repeat. The Pugin Room is quite small so there are limited numbers for this add-on to the formal tour but it was well worth the cost as we're unlikely to come again and a lovely way to round off a brilliant afternoon.
house of lords. took 90 minute tour of house of lords. combination of the tour guide and the architecture made this a very good tour. small group made it very enjoyable and informative.

GOOD DEBATING. Went for lunch in the Strangers' dining room with our MP. A treat bought at a charity auction.Gordon Marsden got us tickets for Foreign and Commonwealth Question Time and we were fascinated.Had a lovely (unofficial) tour of the House of Lords by ourselves and saw the Speaker's procession. If we had had more time to spare would perhaps ask for a guided tour, which can be arranged by your MP, on another visit.

Nice Place. Great place to see. Lots of history hear so make sure you go in and watch the house of commons, you do have to wait for ages but you do see the history on the walls and to think of all the heads that have walked the halls.
Limited access. I have rated this as "terrible" because although you can enjoy the outside façade there is rarely an opportunity to gain entry and the security is almost invasive.
Must see. You cant help but miss this one as it is quite near Big Ben and one of the top attractions in London. Try to get their early in the morning you never know who you might bump into.

Important part of history. The site itself is fascinating, but I think the quality of the guides may vary. Ours was fine, but I happened to overhear another one of the Guides who was frequently nearby, and heard some net resting tidbits of information from him that our guide never mentioned. Definitely do as suggested and get there at least 20 minutes ahead if time to get through security in time for your tour. No photography allowed for 95% of the tour, which was disappointing.

View from the top. I had the good fortune of being shown the roof by a friend who works in Parliament. The view from the top is amazing, a totally different way to look out on London.I must say that I found it strange that the House of Lords bar looked like a cheap cafeteria. I expected cigar smoke stained walls and torch lanterns with old oak tables and unusual nooks and crannies where the poor had previously been discussed or sold for political profit like so much chattel, instead it looked like a less colourful American Denny's restaurant, with the only thing to identify it as part of the House of Lords being the labels on the bottles of cheap wine.

Well organised tour. A guided tour round an iconic building has to be special, and mostly it was, Guide was excellent, explaining not only the features and functions of the building, but also the British parliamentary system, presumably for the foreign visitors, but some of it seemed to be new information to some of the Brits on the tour! As there were a number of tours circulating at the same time it was necessary to keep moving, but I did not feel rushed or short-changed, and all our questions were answered. Some reviewers have complained that we could not sit in either of the chambers, it would have been better if we had been told why not, for myself I presumed it was a security thing, rather than an objection to us plebs dirtying the seats. An enjoyable tour, recommended.

Outstanding visit to Parliament. Although we showed up twice to take a tour of Parliament only to find out that they do tours on the weekend,the guards suggested that we sit in the House of Commons and The House of Lords and watch their activities...Very interesting and a great learnng experience. While we were waiting to enter, information was shared with us about the facility that gave us an appreciation for the building's history by the line attendants who were very friendly. Just ask a few questions as they are very knowledgeable. The gift shop was first class and we loaded up. This was one of our best experiences while in London

Excellent Tour and Afternoon tea at the Houses of Parliament. I booked a Saturday tour of the Houses of Parliament. As a UK citizen, I could have done it for free during the week, but couldn't get time off work so chose to pay to do the tour via Ticketmaster . As I wanted to include the Afternoon Tea option in the Pugin Room at the Houses of Parliament I had to make the booking over the phone via Ticketmaster. It is still well worth the money and it's convenient to book it via Ticketmaster in advance as you pay in advance and then just collect the tickets on the day from the box office at the Houses of Parliament. I only had to queue up for approx 1 minute at the box office before I had my tickets.The Cost to do the tour and afternoon tea afterwards is £36.45. The afternoon tea is new, only recently introduced and currently you can only do the afternoon tea if you are booked onto a tour. However, one of the guys there mentioned that possibly from next year, you will be able to book afternoon tea in the Pugin room without having to do a tour first.The tour is excellent. Whichever guide you get is very informative and knowledgeable. Tour lasts an hour and a quarter and you get to see and learn a lot. You can use your camera in the Westminster Hall and the Pugin Room (where you take afternoon tea)The afternoon tea was lovely. The sandwiches were small in size (each one was slightly bigger than a canape) but they were sufficient. The sandwiches were: Ham with chilli jam; smoked salmon and cream cheese; and chicken, with peppers and avocade guacamole. The vegetarian option looked good also. The sweets consisted of sultana scones with jam and clotted cream; valrhona chocolate delice and a lemon meringue shot. You had plenty of top-ups of tea and coffee throughout the service. You could purchase champagne by the glass (or other alcoholic beverages) to accompany the afternoon tea if you so wished. Although it did not look like a lot of food, it was beautiful ly presented and actually very filling. The Pugin Room itself is stunning as are the views from the window.I would highly recommend doing the tour and afternoon tea.

Dazzling and informative - well worth it. This was by far the best of many attractions I visited on a recent trip to London.A guide takes you round in a group on a tour of the most spectacular of the Palace of Westminster's rooms. The tour was thoroughly engaging from start to finish, with a very knowledgeable guide who not only told us all about the history of the building but lots of little anecdotes about certain traditions that exist concerning law-making and state events, and painting a very vivid picture of the famous ministers and prime ministers that have walked the halls.The real highlight is visiting the House of Lords and the House of Commons and hearing about the ritual of the State Opening of Parliament, and how parliament has evolved over the centuries.It was excellent so there are only minor criticisms where there's room for improvement:- The first half of the tour is about the State Opening of Parliament, although to be honest at times it felt like the whole history of the British royal family, describing portraits one by one and giving general information about the monarch. I would have preferred, for instance, to have heard more about law-making and MPs than a backstory of Henry VIII and his six wives in one of the lobbies because their portraits were there.- The tour was great and the guide knowledgeable, however there are usually at least one or two other tours (in foreign languages) going on in the same room. It was just about bearable but a bit annoying as it was distracting.- A bit too much time was spent on the state opening of parliament, although I suppose it's because the Lords is done first. It would have been more logical to follow a bill's life through parliament and start with the Commons- For some unfathomable reason, you're not allowed to sit down on the benches in the House of Lords/Commons, despite the fact that the group stands up in front of them and is told specifically not to sit down!But all in all, an excellent tour, and I'd highly recommend it.

A day as a Minister?. Not allowed to sit on the benches in the house of lords and house of commons. Quite tiring... The guide could be more informative and he looks tired as it was his 4th tour for the day as we took the 4pm session i.e. the last tour of the day. Too big a crowd to hear the trip.

The Icon of London. The beauty of this vintage building along side the Thames is out standing. Right place to take a snapshot with this building as back ground. A masterpiece and must spend some time around. You visit cannot side view security reasons.

Excellent tour. Loved this tour! Great tour guide! Just right in length so that it did not get boring! We were treated to a special tour of the under-chapel that is not open to public touring. If you have connections to someone in the Parliament arrange for the tour of the under-chapel - very special.

Okay. Guide was very knowledgeable, but very uptight and didn't want you to stop and look at anything. You could only look at items when she stopped the group and pointed things out. Made you feel like you were missing a lot. Tour is 1hour and 15 minutes. You are not allowed to sit on any of the benches so it was difficult for some of the guests and for children. It is beautiful inside, but disappointing that you can't take any pictures. :(
history. We visited via the boat along the river thames, walking around the area of Westminster including the Houses of Parliment. It was very busy but worth seeing
Magnificent buildings. A must see when visiting London - such beautiful architecture and so historic, forms part of London skyline.

Very informative. You may think the building is beautiful from the outside, but the inside is beyond beautiful. A look back in time from the 1300s to present day plus the bonus of learning all about how the British parliament works.

Great Tour. Booked online through Ticketmaster. Really interesting tour with a great guide, the day we went was very busy but the guides work together to make sure you can hear what they are saying to their group. I also pre ordered the guide book online it was cheaper and well worth the money paid, it covers all the history and has many great pictures (making up for the fact you can't use your camera). Great tour of both houses which I would recommend to anyone visiting London.We ate in the Café afterwards the food was great and wasn't expensive.

Write to your MP. Be sure to ask your MP to sponsor you for a ticket for a tour of the Houses of Parliament for an awesome experience of the democratic process of the UK. Try and get an early tour 9.15 am and you will get into the House of Commons and the House of Lords on your tour/

Very very interesting. Very informative and interesting trip. It lasted around one and a quarter hours and we got to see the House of Lords and also the House of Commons together with the Lobby. It was very very busy but our guide was clear and conscise and definitely knew her stuff!

Seat of Democracy. The Palace of Westminster is not to be missed on a visit to London provided that you choose a time when it is open to the public, be sure to check so as not to be dismayed.Expect a long wait to get in,this can be tiring.When entering through the House of Lords you will be travelling as royalty does and will visit some amazing things on the way.The House of Commons will not be as grand but is where the day to day events happen.Westminster Hall is history itself and do not miss a souvenir before leaving this very grand building.

A London essential. The Houses of Parliament are a London icon both in and out of the UK and they won't disappoint. Photographic on the outside, but it's also worth visiting the inside too. The tour was great and I'd recommend it, but you can avoid it if you want to save money. Prepare for long queues to get in, usually between 30 minutes - 1 hour.
A must visit. Very good even if you are not into politics. The building is stunning and the history is incredible. I believe they allow the public on Saturdays, check the web site.

HoP - 75 minutes seemed like 30. The guide was well informed, and moved us around at a reasonable pace (but still time to see and take in the various rooms/chambers). Well worth a visit.Any visitors, not so familiar with British history may gain from a quick review of Wikipedia, as our guide sometimes made comments that might seem obscure e.g. pointing out the painitings as "Divorced,Beheaded, Died" without introducing Henry Viii first, e.g. talking about Prince Albert without mentioning Queen Victoria first, e.g. "suffrage" might be better explained as the "right to vote". Please note she was more than happy to take questions, but people don't always like to ask.

Everyone should come here.. Booked via local MP otherwise £15 via Ticketmaster. Cleared security swiftly and met guide - very friendly and knowledgeable. Tour started in Westminster Hall and lasted about 75mins, best part was the House of Commons where you are allowed to stand in the MP's seating area but def not allowed to sit on the MP's seats. Luckily for us a live debate was happening on a Friday in the House of Lords so no tour of that house but we could get access to the viewing areas and watch - good experience.Only allowed to take photo's in Westminster Hall. Gift shop is good, lots of House of Parliament tat. Try to send a postcard from the onsite Post Office if you can.Well worth a visit if you can and next time we will book the Big Ben tour, via MP of course.

Inside scoop. Thanks to our friend we were able to get the tour while a parliament was in session and watch from the gallery. What a delight to be there in person and listen to the debates, especially as it was the day after the Queens speech. The inside of the building is exquisite and worth the tour regardless of whether Parliament is in session.

Really Cool. I traveled to London with a friend, and she really wanted to do the tour. I was reluctant, but I am so glad we did it. It was really interesting, especially for an American who didn't know a lot about the English government. I'd recommend booking in advance, because it is a popular thing to do. Even if you're not able to get a tour, the houses are definitely worth a visit just to see the outside, and of course, Big Ben!

A Fabulous Experience. This is a "must" for any visitor to London, a fascinating insight into the democratic workings of the British government encompassed in a outstanding Victorian builiding, You've seen it on the screen see, it for real! Oh and by the way our guide was outstanding and really made the visit even more pleasurable.

Very interesting tour which provided great insight on the British government. There were problems on the tube which caused us to be late for the tour so we were worried about missing our time slot. However, everyone was very accommodating. Our tour guide was excellent. She provided the right amount of information during our 90 minute tour. The structure itself is quite impressive and contains an immense amount of history. Definitely worth the visit.

Fantastic - a tour brings the House of Commons and House of Lords to life!. Through the kind courtesy of our MP we enjoyed a tour of the Palace of Westminster on the occasion of a family birthday. Entry and security were efficiently executed and we were amazed at the number of tours that were to take place that morning. However, they were so well planned and timed that you never felt crowded. Our guide was informative and efficient, with a sense of humour too! Whereas the original Westminster Palace was the home of Kings and Queens, its present purpose is the root of our Government and the politics that encompasses. Statues and busts of past Prime Ministers are a reminder of the history of our times, with Churchill in a typical pose and Mrs Thatcher looking rather scary! The House of Commons and House of Lords, with its opulent gold thrones, brought the world of government to life for us and, along with all the processes that were fully explained by the guide with MPs going about their business in various areas of the Palace, this gave a real insight to the manner in which our country is governed. We also came away with the intention of checking that our MP is pursuing issues, and voting, in the manner his constituents desire!  This is a tour not to be missed if you have the chance. We will be applying to attend a debate and Prime Ministers Question Time in the future.Should you want to include a tour in a day of visiting other attractions in and around Westminster there is a reasonably priced car park (Q Park Westminster) virtually opposite where you can pre-book and pre-pay for a space. Then its just a 2 minute walk!

WONDERFUL!. Traveling with our two college aged children, sometimes we cannot all agree an what we want to do. My husband and son really want to do this and my daughter and I were reluctant. We decided to join the men and I am so glad we did! This was a wonderful, informative, and interesting tour. We did not want it to end! Our guide was great--unfortunately I do not remember his name. He laid out the system of government simply and quickly. We learned about politics, architecture and history and were completely entertained the entire time. Reluctant daughter LOVED it. The tours are advertised as being led by highly qualified and knowledgeable "Blue Badge" tour guides. Ours certainly was. It was worth the money.We did not have advanced tickets and I feel we were lucky to get them on the same day. We arrived at the ticket office shortly after they opened. They were sold out for morning tours so we asked for the last tour of the day and were able to do that. So, I would recommend obtaining your tickets in advance if you can. You can purchase them through Ticketmaster on the Houses of Parliament website. When I arrived to purchase tickets, there was a person standing outside of the ticket office handing out pre-purchased tickets.I don't think young children would enjoy it.
worth the visit. Took about 2 hours to do the tour and stand in line. Very interesting and guides are very knowledgable. Must stand a lot on the tour.
Worthwhile tour. The tour of Parliament is so interesting. If you are interested in understanding how this form of governing body works, you need to include this in your visit.

How can this be anything other than awesome?. The centre of Western democracy (forget Greece). The mother of all parliaments. The cradle of an Empire. The masterwork of a genius. If you can go, go. More mundanely, if you can see the Houses sitting, do (I reckon the House of Lords is better). If you can persuade a passholder to show you the chapel of St Mary Undercroft, do. But even if you just see Westminster Hall - one of the greatest mediaeval structures in the world and the original chamber of Western democracy - Central Lobby and one or other of the Chambers, it will be an hour or two excellently spent.

An amazing experience. I went to observe Prime Ministers Questions, sat in the public gallery in the House of Commons. This is currently free of charge, arranged through my MP. When you clear security, you are given a visitor pass and are able to walk around and take in the awesome architecture and history of parliament. I have an interest in politics so, for me, it was an amazing experience to be able to be there and, especially, to see MP's you usually see on TV standing only inches away from you in the central lobby. I could have stayed all day! No photography is permitted. I would have liked to take part in a guided tour but maybe that's something for the future as I will most certainly be returning in the future. Highly recommended.

Wonderful!. History is experienced when taking the wonderful tour of this incredible building. The guides really present wonderful information and are a pleasure to listen to. All the important areas of the House of Parliament are open to visitors. This tour should be on everyone's list.
majestic. its a must see.. the towering height and the beauty of the architecture is stunning, across is most beautiful cathedral. just amazing to walk down the entire avenue
excellant. well worth a visit !! wonderful guide took us round and it was better the buckingham palace (sorry your majesty)

A must for all ... experience the history and discover government. We took one of the saturday tours so it was a little quieter without MP's and others milling around and racing from one debate to another.The tour lasts approx 75 minutes, with limited places to sit it might become a struggle for some to cope with.The guide was excellent, truly giving an insight into the daily life and working of this great building, along with the grand history that is enveloped in the very fabric of the building.For us the tour was far to short, with so much history, architecture and paintings around the place we could have stayed for hours and still not learnt everything.Whilst there is a charge for the tours, anyone can request a free tour through their own MP, along with the right to sit in the galleries and watch parliamentary debates.This is the place where many of the things that affect our everyday lives are debated and decided, so I think we should all make an effort to see it and have an understanding of how it works.Due to a number of protests occuring outside parliament, engaging in the profoundly British right of 'freedom of speech', we decided to stop off at the cafe for a drink and a cake.The food and drink was excellent, very tasty and reasonably priced. The overwhelming aspect for us though was the quality of service from the staff, nothing was too much trouble and off they would scuttle to locate whetever they thought you might need even before you knew you needed it.Its a shame though when customer service like this stands out so much that you feel its worth commenting on.

A must for all ... experience the history and discover government. We took one of the saturday tours so it was a little quieter without MP's and others milling around and racing from one debate to another.The tour lasts approx 75 minutes, with limited places to sit it might become a struggle for some to cope with.The guide was excellent, truly giving an insight into the daily life and working of this great building, along with the grand history that is enveloped in the very fabric of the building.For us the tour was far to short, with so much history, architecture and paintings around the place we could have stayed for hours and still not learnt everything.Whilst there is a charge for the tours, anyone can request a free tour through their own MP, along with the right to sit in the galleries and watch parliamentary debates.This is the place where many of the things that affect our everyday lives are debated and decided, so I think we should all make an effort to see it and have an understanding of how it works.Due to a number of protests occuring outside parliament, engaging in the profoundly British right of 'freedom of speech', we decided to stop off at the cafe for a drink and a cake.The food and drink was excellent, very tasty and reasonably priced. The overwhelming aspect for us though was the quality of service from the staff, nothing was too much trouble and off they would scuttle to locate whetever they thought you might need even before you knew you needed it.Its a shame though when customer service like this stands out so much that you feel its worth commenting on.

Surprisingly interesting and what a historical gem inside and out!. Surprising because I am not into history or politics but it didn't matter. The tour guide was fantastic and interesting, just like the sights and the feel of the entire building.The architecture and decor is staggering and the art amazed me. I found I learnt a lot about British history without being bored. My only criticism is the price. I wanted to see more of the rooms off the beaten track too!Book in advance.Also, the day we arrived there were protests and lots of police outside the entrance, which might have been too busy/noisy/rowdy for some.Still, I would actually love to go again and recommend it.

Love the History behind each door.... We went to the House of Parliament as a group on guided tour. The tour is certainly highly recommended... One can see and learn so much about the british political history. The building is magnificent and the timber is just amazing inside the entrance.I've finally learn about the color on the chairs between different houses... and also where Queen normally prepares herself before the opening of the parliament. It is also very interesting where the House of the Commons reminds me of the great essence of democracy when they are there to serve the 'people' not the monarchy. It helped me to appreciate more of where we are in terms of the rights and history behind this country. Highly recommended. :)

A live museum. I did not know that one can even go inside the Parliament and it cam as a big surprise to me. The building has beautiful architecture and it is exceptionally large. It is much better to go inside this building than to visit any museum as you can see important government officials, meetings in progress and day to day work being carried on. Do visit when you are around the Big Ben area.

Interesting tour. We visited as a family and decided to take a tour round the Houses of Parliament. The interior was quite a surprise, some parts being very opulent with interesting art works. The guide really new her stuff and was interesting to listen to.Only negative was the lack of places to sit down whilst on the tour. It was 75 minutes long and so this may prove difficult for some.

Brilliant historical tour in an iconic building.. We thoroughly enjoyed our tour! The blue badge tour guides are amazing at giving a historical insite to this monumental building, & you can tell they really enjoy their job. It was really interesting learning about all the traditons for opening parliament that have come about from historical events. We were a little late for our tour but it doesn't matter as you can tag along to the next one! The statues of past priministers are inspiring and being present in the building itself is really worth it. The kids in our group seemed to enjoy it too!! You can enjoy a tour in the week Mon - Fri for free if you are a UK resident, you just need to write to your local MP to request one, I'd recommend this as it'd be nice to see the building in its working use.

Pomp & Ceremony at it's Best. The Houses of Parliament are an amazing place to visit and although the tour lasts only 75 minutes, it is amazing how much you get to see. You are ushered through the rooms by a guide who, unfortunately, does not have time to answer questions during the tour but imparts a great deal of very interesting information on the history, art work, architecture and procedures of the parliamentary chambers throughout the walk. It can be quite manic with 4 or 5 other tour groups in the same room at one time, but don't let that put you off, there's is so much for the eye to feast on, you become oblivious to anyone else around. The chambers we visited were spectacular, with their sumptuous colours and amazingly detailed carvings. It would have been wonderful to have been able to linger in each room to try to take in all there was to see. In fact if you were to visit a number of times, I'm sure you would still see & learn things you missed the first time. What initially instigated our interest was the opportunity to see the 1000+ year old Westminster Hall. We were not dissappointed, but we were equally blown away by the rest of the tour, which we did not expect. You are able to wander around Westminster Hall at your leisure once the tour concludes. We booked our tickets through British Ticketmaster before we left Australia, which was ok. The cost, £16.50, was money well spent, as I think you would be hard-pressed to find anything quite like this elsewhere in the world.
Must see. You have to see this place, if you are in London. Try to take pictures from all angles.. spend some time seeing this place.Listen to the Big Ben.

Most enjoyable lesson in English history. We took our children (both aged 14) for a guided tour around House of Parliament. Children under 15 are admitted free with fully paying adult. We were 15 minutes late due to the usual inefficiency of the Southeaster rail, but nobody complained. We were ushered through the security which was swift and fast. As we obviously missed our group, we were politely asked to wait for few minutes and then joined the next tour. Our guide was a fantastic, extremely knowledgable lady, who obviously enjoyed her job. We were taken through the whole palace, stopping in the right places, where we were given information with interest and wit and occasional and very appropriate joke. We were kindly guided through the centuries of English history with explanations for both British and non-British visitors. There was not one minute I felt bored or overwhelmed with information. I was in complete awe of this beautiful building which still has contemporary function and serves as working place for tens of thousands of people every single day. Most enjoyable day in London - if you call early in the week (Monday) to book your tour you might be able to have the afternoon tea at the HoP!
Excellent for kids. Highly recommended visit. Learnt more about politics than last 40 years from our excellent guide. I now understand all the terms used in the papers!
Postcard photo opportunity!. Great photo opportunity on the Thames. Unfortunately there were marquees and scaffolding set up when we were there so did not see everything.
Great. A great place to see and experience. Truly great and unique structures and monuments. A great way to get the feeling of how this country is governed. A must see when in London.

Majestic!. This was the first stop after arriving in London. The tube station is across the street making access quick and easy. Pictures don't do justice to the sheer size and beauty of this landmark. It was the first picture taken from the London Eye.
Great photo opportunity. If you love history you'll love this place, the architecture is incredible .Best photo opportunity is across the road at the Abbey but that's another review.

Fantastic tour. My mum and I had arranged a tour through my MP of the Houses of Parliament and it was really really great. It lasted just over an hour and our tour guide Allie was very knowledgeable with a very clear voice. She answered all the questions from other tourists well, even the abrupt ones! We got just the right amount of information without too much detail about the politics!The parliament was really amazing to visit and get a feel for the three sections as well as the Westminster Hall. The cafe was lovely and very reasonable.

great view. We went to London and did all the touristy things one of which was to see the houses of parliament stood from Westminster bridge the view of big Ben and parliament is a fantastic symbol of Britain.

The face of London. What a beutiful building, at sunset from the river the view is just amazing. We were there during the first days of August and were lucky to do the tour, it was very interesting to see how british politics work. If you are there in August do the tour.....

Inspirational! A must see.... Really really amazing place to visit if you happen to be in the great city of London! Very well organised, when we first arrived (me and my parents) we were immediately shown where we needed to go and the staff were all very friendly and passionate about their job, their enthusiasm and knowledge they had on the Houses of Parliament was incredible. The tour lasts for just over an hour so it doesn't take up the whole day and it doesn't feel like it drags, just the right amount of time! With every room we went in the tour guide (who was incredibly enthusiastic) gave a little speech about the room so it was very informative throughout. It doesn't matter if you're not really into politics, its still an enjoyable attraction to see. I have to add that it was such a bizarre, thrilling feeling running down the halls of parliament trying to catch up with the tour guide who'd already moved onto the next room! I didn't think I'd enjoy it as much as I did, but as soon as I got there it all seemed so incredible and made me very proud to be British! To be able to get a glimpse of the past, present and future of politics really was an inspirational and enjoyable thing to do. I'd definitely recommend you go and see for yourself!
Guided tour. Wonderful history and government workings tour! Bought tickets on line and had an hour tour. No pictures, of course. Security is tight. Then walk down to 10 Downing Street.

Fascinating tour!. Myself, husband and 17 year old daughter enjoyed the one & a quarter hour tour around the Houses of Parliament. Our guide was a wealth of knowledge and gave us lots of information. His knowledge of history and politics was fantastic and I'm sure this added value to our experience. If you haven't been, you must go, the artwork, buildings, furniture and fittings are all wonderful. It was so interesting, and even our daughter (typical teenager) was fascinated. Don't miss it!

We should all visit at least once in our lifetime. Historcally this is one of the most significant buildings that you could want to visit.
The tour is well structured and allows you time to see and breathe in te very special atmosphere of such a monumental experiene.
Subsequent news footage on the television will become so much more memrable and significant.
Excellent. Fantastic. Such a wonderful and memorable experience. Would highly recommend. Gives you a real insight.

German finale. Always a great place to visit, we have been there many times and it never disappoints. This Saturday there were many fans having a good time en-route to Wembley for the German football final.
Not to be missed at any cost!!. Truly the face of London. You can spend hours by simply gazing at this stunning masterpiece.A great opportunity to take some memorable pics.

love the fancy clock house. I know,It is not just the Big Ben clock buildings,but that's what the people photograph.This is an impressive piece of stonework,even the glasswork is artful.This "complex" devoted to enacting laws is a must see in London,but this is obvious.You get great pictures and video from any side.If you are able to arrange it,certain areas are accessible,and the inside is just as beautifully done as out.We always load up with pics from Westminster bridge and from the plaza opposite Westminster Abbey,often when the bells are wringing aloud,quite a scene with the old Churchill statue nearby.

Beautiful architecture..... We were not able to go inside the Houses of Parliament, but the architecture on the outside is stunning!!! All these years I did not realize that Big Ben is connected to the Houses of Parliament. You do not need to go into either to be very impressed.

The seat of power!!. We can do some pretty impressive things as a country & the Houses of Parliament are a symbol of that. Hundreds of years of history as the seat of our democracy & a magnificent building on the Thames.
Fascinating Tour. The tour last for about 75 minutes and is conducted by a blue badge guide, ours was excellent. It was terrific to see the lords and the commons and Westminster Hall is spectacular

The house of modern democracy as we know. It gives you a unique feeling when you watch the House of Parliament and the Big Ben.You feel clearly how deep in the British roots democracy goes and how much we ''Continental'' people owe to it.
at 9am. on a saturday, really long queues to get in even at that time so arrive early or pre book.magnificent architecture and at this time of the day easy to get traffic free photographs

Very Interesting Visit. My wife wanted to visit the houses on the Saturday we visited over the Holiday weekend. Glad we went. It was fascinating visit. We had a brilliant guide who was interesting to listen to and very knowledgeable. The house of Lords is a magnificent room beautifully decoratedin gold leaf whilst the commons is much more plain .

Go for the Summer Opening. I just love this building, it doesn't seem real and looks like it is made from lace. Came in December so it wasn't open for tours, but simply enjoyed walking around it and the picture from the bridge next to it are the best you can get.

Enormous!. Having seen photos, I thought I knew what to expect. But the houses of parliament blew me away with its sheer size. Its magnificent. We came out of the underground and there it was booming out chimes and towering above us. Great setting too, on the river with westminister abbey nearby and on the other side, London eye.
Fantastic sight. Westminster is an amazing building. Great on the hour to hear the chimes of big ben. To have a great view must go on london eye. But lovely

What a treat !!. Amazing and worth every penny £16.50 adult U16 free. Andrew the guide was so passionate and you actually see and hear the full history of the monarchy in a fun way, and stand in the Green pews (House of Commons) and Red pews (House of Lords)

Avoided the crowds by taking the bus not the tube. Stayed on the perimeter of the blds. Need 30 pence for restrooms!. Nothing to dislike. London's got it right now. All the improvements for hosting the 2012 Olympics shows. Love the walk along the Thames. Easy access to everything including the loo's(need 30 pence to use and they are real clean).

Interesting visit. A birthday treat for my daughter. Really interesting, but she was disappointed that no photographs could be taken inside. I no security is very important but a few photographs would not do any harm. Tour took around one and half hours but best very quickly as it was so interesting.

Worth the wait. This is more than just a parliament building...it's history. Line up and get past security and be welcomed into a very worthwhile visit. The best part is the hall, the oldest part of the building, and very inspiring. If parliament is in session it is very entertaining!

Amazing Building. My view of this is very simple, stunning building, so much detail. You can see that this building was originally made to govern the most important empire on earth (for its time).
Well worth a visit!!!!!!!

Just passing through.... We visited in the hope we would see or get to meet an MP. Fat chance! But we looked around at this magnificent building, bought a few trinkets and had tea in the cafe. Good stuff!

So good. We went for one of the tours round Westminster. It was fabulous, our guide was called Alan and he really knew his stuff. He had been working there for 20 years. The tour lasted about 1.5 hrs and there was a lot of walking to be done. Alan had a great sence of humor and made the history interesting. There is two down sides to the tour 1: you are not allowed to take photos and 2: you can not sit in the seats in the House of Lords or commons. But this is a small price to pay for such a great day.

Beautiful building. Could not go inside the building but it's beautiful architecture..... Must visit due if you want to get few clicks of your with Big Ben in the background ...... Live protests across the road add to the aura .....

Golden richness and tourist driven. She is the Mother of Parliaments - and full of eccentricities.If you are British, you can ask your local MP to make the arrangements for free, but anyone can pay to tour the buildings that date back in places to 1099.The tour takes in both Houses of Parliament (always providing the Lords and the MPs are not sitting).The building is enormous, glorious, over-the-top and fantastical, and the guides are witty.The 90 minute tour includes a visit to the Queen's rooms with two thrones - one in the House of Lords where the Queen's Speech is presented to the two Houses after the MPs have slammed the door in the face of Black Rod (her messenger) as he arrives to summon them to hear what laws will be their duty to discuss in the coming months.The House of Lords is ornate, the House of Commons mundane, yet great things (and great works of art) are consistent with the whole building.
Amazing!. The Houses of Parliament are a Gothic Revival Masterpiece. Great History and a working seat of government. Very cool.
Worth a visit. Had a tour of the facility and really enjoyed. The history of the buildings facscinating and seeing the house of coms & Lords in the flesh was a revealation.
Parliment. it was very interesting and well worth the visit. Not many places to sit so be prepared t be on your feet a lot.

Filled with History and grandeur. This is an amazing tour if you can get booked on one. I went through my local MP. I even got a visit to Big Ben, it's a separate tour but a great trip if you can get that too.

awesome exterior. we could only see the parliament from outside, in fact we mistook it for westminster abbe. we had seen the virtual tour available at the official website but since we were away at Edinburgh on Saturday, we could not book the tour...definitely regret
Out of this world. We had a magnificent morning in the houses of parliament. An interesting tour which makes you proud to be British. A must when visiting London

Overwhelming Large. This building is so unique and LARGE, it overwhelms you! There is a great spot to take pictures down by the river of Thames in front of Parliament. You have to walk away from Parliament about 1/8 of a mile. Then go down stairs to your right and you will see the picture spot I am referring to! Must see this while in London!

a great day out. the tour got off right on time with a very knowledgeable guide. It was very busy but he always seemed to find a space or quieter spot to explain the workings and history of the place.We had arranged to meet our MP who turned up and bought us a coffee. Democracy in action!!.Recommend everyone to visit, its a great morning out.

somthing new :). Me & my husband was invited to attend dinner at the Houses of Parliament its amazing place. it was new experience to us , i felt like princess in the last decades the architectures was amazing i keep wondering how they build this place thousand years ago . The security was more & we had badges when we enter . this place make me feel special ..
PMQs. If you get the chance to get tickets from your MP to visit the Prime Ministers Questions then do it! It was brilliant!

History. Just the history alone here was enough to want to see. Short walk if you are staying at the Waldorf Hilton. They had an odd ceremony going on around the corner by Sommerst House. Where the mounted guards cermonally dismounted and gave their horses a broad slap on the side of the neck. Twice. Kinda different and the horses didnt fuss to much. Plus they got an apple at the end

Beautiful architecture with a fascinating history. The architecture of parliament is amazing within and without. It isn't always evident that you are allowed to enter (for tours, etc) but you can. If you can join a tour that takes you through the various houses it is even better because you can see some amazing rooms where democracy happens.

Nice old church. Its a pretty cool building that is really old and historic. Is it worth standing in line for a couple of hours? who knows but I couldnt fathom standing in the line to see old stuff and then added stuff for tourists. I dont know if you have read any other of my reviews but this is also another site to take a picture from the outside and move on with your life.

an iconic spot of London - go inside too!. An iconic part of London that most tourists pass by to snap photos of Big Ben from the outside, but be sure to stop inside as well! On Friday, if you stop by around 3pm you'll see many representatives exit wearing ceremonial gear to make their way to the pubs - join in!
good to walk by. Didn't go in, but worth walking by. Beautiful building. Nice water walkway going to it as well. You can see the London Eye from there
Great view but thats it. It is a great view and definitely an iconic part of London. However what is there to do here? Not much of a person for politics, the history of it good and thats about it

Just the outside is spectacular. Only realised that we could enter the houses after we arrived home so a definite for the next visit to London. The buildings themselves are awe inspiring from the outside.

House of Commons in action. It was so interesting to sit in on a debate in the House of Commons. Awe-inspiring place to visit. And the tightest security we experienced during out visit to London.
