Make sure your child's pockets are clean and not full of coins, candy wrappers and rocks like my son's were--it was pretty funny/embarrassing see him taking all of that stuff out in front of the guard!

First time inside Westminster Palace & Parliament. After years of seeing nearly every attraction that London has...we finally made reservations for a tour of Parliament. Guide was great...both houses were amazing to finally see in person. Highly recommended.
London Visit. Wow, what a building - very impressive. Had a great wander around the building (as best we could) and enjoyed the history of the place.

You should go inside. Instead of just walking around the big ben, one can take a tour and go insde the Houses of Parliament. As a law graduate and have spent some time and efforts studying the constitutions..the parliament .... it is a must-go for me. There are lots to see inside... it is not just a grand architecture with beautiful paintings and scruptures, it has a lot of stories and histories.. Since it is still being used as a House of Parliament in a country with a living dynasty, and the fact that it is still a place to meet foreign gov officials, to discuss world politics and make public speeches.... It is an old yet living building, not just a lifeless museum. For that reason, I think it is much more interesting than some palace converted museums in nearby country no longer has King and Queen (I don't want to name it here), which everyone is raving about. Highly recommended.
Great!!. Now I feel that I kind of know how the Goverment works over here and how the Queen plays a part. Worth the time. Can't tour The Queens Tower though, have to be a British citizen :-(
Real English. It felt so English seeing the House of Parliment! Didn't get to visit the inside on the day we were.
Big Ben is the highlight. Interesting to see. Can't really see much from the outside but its one of those iconic London sight.

Interesting insight into the history and traditions of this British institution. I was impressed that the tour wasn't restricted - we accessed all the important sections of Parliament and were able to walk around inside the house of commons and house of lords. The commentary about the history and traditions was interesting, though not always captivating for children. Might be better to run 2 versions of the tour, one for adults and one for families.

An interesting sight. Having spent a half day here I can recommend seeing this place at least once. The scale and elegance of the place is stunning. To go inside costs but you can get close outside for free. Kids may find it boring but there is a gift shop and lots a places to eat etc. if your in London well worth a look.

Must see. If you have never been to London, or if you have been ten times, go see Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament, it is quite difficult to get a tour, but the outside is stunning, not to mention right by some other great attractions like Westminster Abbey, Buckingham Palace, the Churchill War Rooms, the South Bank, and much more.

Big Ben and the queen Elizabeth tower. Looks fantastic in bright light, not as loud as I ought it would be though. You can get a tour to look around the site and I will be doing this next time I go back as the architecture of the outside of the building is fantastic, does make you think what does it look like on the inside

The place where much of your life is determined!. This is an essential tour...I have been lucky enough to go in as a guest on the terraces and other dining areas and it is endlessly fascinating and intriguing!

Fantastic visit. We booked a tour (we found the Italian one- you can choose the language) and took my parents. It is an impressive building and entering it is amazing. The tour was very interesting and our guide was extremely prepared and interesting.
I recommend this visit!

History and heritage. It was over 40 years since I visited on a school trip, so was delighted that my MP was able to arrange a visit, and one of the research assistants took us round.It was amazing to walk through the areas where our laws are made, and to stand on the plaques commemorating so many important events in the history of our country.I would highly recommend this tour, but be sure to ask your MP many months in advance as places are in great demand.

Excellent tour. Visited the houses of Parliament and had a guided tour with Richard Edwards. He was an excellent guide bringing knowledge and humour to his presentation. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience and hope to visit again soon.

A Trip Through the Workings of English Politics. To be honest I didn't really want to go to the Houses of Parliament and did it because my husband wanted to go. I am so glad that he wanted to go. The history is amazing, the decor, the differences between the House of Lords, the House of Commons, and the Queen's room is mind boggling. The architecture is stunning, as is the woodwork on the doors, cabinets, etc. Our tour guide was so knowledgeable and was willing to answer any questions. The only reminder is don't sit on any of the chairs!

A must see, and hear, of London. The Houses of Parliament in London is one of the most fantastic sights of the city. The architecture is amazing, and the size is just breathtaking, especially from above like the London eye! If you have time I would highly suggest to make a trip to see them in action on the debating floor, which can be a little dull, but always worth it to say you did. An amazing place to see, learn, and talk about history, architecture, beauty, politics or anything on your mind really. With close proximity to other places of interest like Buckingham palace, Downing Street, westminster abbey, and London eye you can't go wrong. Make sure to show up on the hour and listen to the magnificent chime of Big Ben as well.

On the banks of the Thames river,a photgraphic must....... Awe inspiring architecture along the River Thames,a British icon that draws the crowds took look and wonder,the seat of the British Government and close to Big Ben Londons time piece.The whole area oozes history and we are told it was destroyed by fire a few times and rebuilt and dates way back in history to before the Crusades.A man called Guy Fawkes was found a few centuries ago in the cellars trying to blow up this complex and was caught and burned alive at the stake Children in England still celebrate the man and set off fireworks on nov 5th to celebrate?You have to visit.

Totally Amazing. What a totally amazing place to visit while in London. The history alone is well worth learning about, despite your political views. To sit in the house of commons and the house of lords was truly breath taking. Contact your local MP and ask him to arrange your visit as we did and its free!!!
A must see when in Westminster!. One of London's most iconic landmarks, Downing Street, Westminster Abbey, the London Eye and tube stations all in close proximity
Beautiful venue. Beatuiful old English building on the river Thames. It's the most beautiful scenes in the world . It's a place to visit when you come to London

Very informative. You need to be invited my your MP (or in our case a Cabient Member) to visit here. It is very much worth going on here just to be surrounded and informed of the History of the Britain.
Beautiful buildings. Awesome! Brill to see it in reality. Apparently the stone came from my home village, that is Anston. The weather was good so took some really decent photos

Mother of Parliaments. Lucky enough to have a private tour of the Houses of Parliament last Friday. Wonderful experienceand should you wish to have a pricate tour contact your Member of Parliament and if you wish to visit both Houses try and arrange for a Friday as sitting tend to be early part of the week. Should you not be a UK national write to the Brtish Embassy in your country of the Member of your Parliament of Senate. A free tour if you arrange through your UK MP.
Brilliant tour. The guides are superb & this is not only educational, it's fantastic value. A definite must see in London. Organisation is great & you can even have some coffee etc after.

Take a tour and learn what we take for granted. Booked a tour here on a Saturday. Cost was reasonable. A few rooms were closed in preparation for state opening. We both learnt a lot and the tour was very interesting. Even if you are not political minded, the history and art work make this a worthy trip. Would definitely do again

Impressed. I booked the tickets for the above on line. It was an extremely interesting tour but only lasted about one hour.Wish it had been alot longer We went with six other friends who all thought it was 'great'. A definite 'must' for any visitor to London. Full of history and great place to visit.It has a good gift shop and is resonably priced. Highly recommended.
Excellent site for photography. Located right beside Big Ben, this place is great for photography. Not to mention, the latest James Bond movie was filmed here!
Houses of Parliament. Beautiful Building and Suroundings. It is an important Governament Building the exelent architecture.
Great. A very beautiful building with hundreds of people enjoing it. Circulate there it's not easy. History was around it. Big Ben also.
very powerful building. thats the house of power very interesting architectural design i love the way people tale there complains and are listened to

What an experience!!. A wonderful guide for our tour of about an hour.Far too short.
To stand in the House of Commons and Lords,where so much history has been made,doesn't seem real.Worth a future visit
so much to observe,do go.

Beautiful building!. Such history. Went with my husband and two sons, Really enjoyed the tour all around the house of lords and house of commons. All so interesting. We were explained the process of how laws are made etc. Definitely will recommend.

beautiful building and so much history !!. This is a must when you visit London !
This building is so historical it is unbelievable !!
The guides are very nice and explain very well the details of the building.
I would recommend for anyone going to London

Excellent tour. Booked through our MP for a tour. Arrived early and visited the cafe. Very informative tour and beautiful elaborate building. Parliament in recess so not too busy. Good to be able to stand at the benches in the house of commons and lords. Thoroughly recommend for older children and adults.

Behind the scenes with the MP. Fascinating place, always buzzing and lots to see. Would recommend any times, best to go with your MP if possible, but the tour guides are excellent.
I have been 4 times and every time I have seen something different.

Great. Building with a clock tower. It's a great old building with a super bell tower.
The time is even right. The citizens national bank in Meyersdale Pa. Can't even get that right for weeks after day light saving time.
Old clock is super.

Very interesting. We were lucky enough to have a private tour and it was fascinating. It was great to see the parts that you see on tv all the time and to remember all the famous people who have been there

One not miss. Arranged a tour with my MP before we went and am I glad we did.
We had an excellent guide taking us through all the history of the Palace of Westminster including entry into both debating chambers, the Great hall and St Stephens hall. Well worth a visit

Busy busy busy!. It was a shame there was so much scaffolding upon it as we werent able to see it in its full glory,and the congestion on the bridge was crazy, so we detoured down by the river to escape the mayhem.

Not to miss. Beautiful building, even if you don't go on a tour the external is magnificent.
I've lived in London for a year now and still love walking to and around the Westminster area. You cannot come to London and not visit, I actually don't think it would be possible to avoid them!

Ben not so Big. The Houses of Parliament stood out as a great sight. Big Ben didn't look so big as hen on the telly but very impressed. When on the Eye, the shot of this is brilliant especially with the bridge in the forefront. My tip for this is wait for a few London Buses to cross it then it enhances the photo by 100%.
british history. a very interesting insight into british politcal history and great to be in the same rooms we see so much on tv and that are steeped in british tradition
Best day of our holiday. The guide was excellent organisation was spot on and the security, whilst very strict was unobtrusive , quick and effective.Such an enjoyable experience thankyou

Astonishing Building. Charles Barry and the Gothic manner of architecture allows for a sense of musical poetic in this wonderful palace, even if only seen and enjoyed externally. I used to walk past the buildings each day when I had work in London a number of years ago, and somehow with the Thames flowing on its way to the sea breath-taking thoughts can enter the mind! naturally about the UK and England especially - this really is the place of all attractions that attracts and not simply functionally - as the seat of Parliament. Intricacy is really the word that encapsulates the feel of this vast complex tune of a building. Monet the French Impressionist selected this feature of London perhaps for some of his most evocative paintings well worth seeing in the National Gallery a nice walk away from this tourist feature that actually deserves a good long look.

Tour of Westminster Palace. We went for one of the scheduled tours in Sept 2012. As Canadians we found it a really interesting glimpse into a Parliamentary system that our country is based on. The stories the tour guide told were great and really made the experience enjoyable! The building itself was quite beautiful.
History Talks. History Talks Houses of Parliament and the Big Ben awesome place to go .i defiantly recommend to visit Houses of Parliament and the Big Ben

Beautiful rich history. Very well worth a look though the lines were long as a result of our timing I suspect (Thatcher's body was lying in state when we were there). The views and the history of the buildings is apparent in every corner with magnificent architecture and detail in every direction. At night when it's all lit up and reflected in the river it's just an amazing sight.

Pretty neat. This is done as a tightly controlled, guided tour but our guide was animated and interesting. It was neat to see how this very old, ex-palace is used for modern government and we felt lucky to have been able to visit as I assume it isn't open for tours when parliament is sitting. As with many attractions in London, I found the fee a bit pricey but I guess that's expected in such a large city.
A must. Any visitor to London should try to do the tour, though I think you can only visit at certain times of the year.
Impressive. Very impressive. I was not able to go inside - just a quick journey - but it is truly a beautiful building.

Plan ahead but the rewards are worth it.. You need to book in advance for the saturday tours, but the effort and the price are worth it. So much history in such a small space makes for a compact touring experience. Tours are 1 1/4 hrs and well worth it. No photography is allowed inside when on tour, but you can buy books or take the free brochures.
houses of parliament. Very good tour guide very informative and knowledgeable a great slice of history could have stayed there the whole day

Perfect view of British History. You can almost feel the ghosts of famous politicians as you walk the hallowed corridors of power! The workmanship, the quality of architecture and materials take you back to a bygone age. Take the trip up Big Ben if you can.

Amazing. I thought you could only visit via your MP but tickets are easily available via their website and it's well worth the money. The guide was extremely knowledgeable and told us so much about our democratic history. Fascinating to actually see where laws are approved, debates are held and peers snooze! Much smaller than on television and definately an access all areas look behind the scenes of our parliament.
Ask you PM. Contact your MP for an exclusive look at The Palace of Westminster. Great to see up close the cogs that make the country tick.

Unexpectedly Excellent. Didn't know exactly what to expect from this tour but we both were really impressed. The tour guides are extremely knowledgeable and visitors are walked through both houses of parliament and much of the history is explained in an interesting way. Thoroughly enjoyable.

It's okay. It's not something I would go out of my way to see really, although with Big Ben being there it was the incentive to see it, but it's not really anything special and I wouldn't go out of my way to see it again really. Once was enough.

Highlight of my Weekend. We took a tour of the Houses of Parliament on Saturday 13th April and I can't recommend it highly enough. Our guide, Karen, was exceptionally knowledgeable and made the tour very interesting. Security was tight but quick and efficient and the tour took in areas I was not expecting access to. I shall be glued to the TV watching the State opening of Parliament next month, just so I can say "been there". Just a word of warning - there are few chances to sit down so be prepared to stand for the majority of the 75 minutes.

Great atmoshere and history. Worth visiting. I did go there on business so I may have managed to see more than what is normally available to tourist. However, it is a great experience just being there. The security nowadays takes quite some time to get through, but it is worth it.

Awesome and unexpected!. 75 minute guided tour started in the stunning 1000 year old Westminster Hall and took us around the main half a dozen rooms (out of 1100), including the two most important - house of lords and house of commons - which were much smaller than I imagined. I wasn't quite prepared for the enormous size, the ornate detail, the amount of gold leaf and the huge range of art ! The tour guide was very informative and shared a great range of witty banter and facts. There's not an awful lot to keep young children entertained and there are stone steps to negotiate at the start, but my children are teenagers and they were fascinated and thrilled to visit! one of the few trips i have been on that i found completely enthralling! nice little gift shop and cafe!

A must see!. I've been on this tour twice now, once when I first arrived in London and again a year later with friends who were visiting. It's such a fantastic and interesting tour, full of history but presented in a clear and easy way. It gives you a taste of history without shoving a million dates at you. The guides are easy to listen to and very friendly. There is minimum opportunities to sit down so be prepared for that but otherwise I highly recommend this. Best to pre-book too due to the popularity of it. My friends also really enjoyed it.
Worth the visit. It is great to be able to walk around the Houses of Parliament and to take some pictures from the south bank

Guided tour. Wrote to our local MP in Hereford and was invited to the Houses. A fantastic tour from a lovely Scottish Lady named Helen and afterwards invited by our MP to sit in on a commons debate. This experience made mine and my wifes trip to London even more amazing. Get in touch with your local MP and they will do the same for everyone and anyone, and as it was pointed out to me you have as much right as anyone to be there including MR Cameron and alike!

Superb and well worth the visit. In London without our young children and wanted to do something that we wouldn't have done with them. The tour was excellent with a very nice guide called Christine who was exceptionally knowledgable. Great to see in person what we only normally see on the TV and also saw a lot more besides. Excellent.

Stunning!. We are a family of four (2 x boys 7 and 11) and we booked for free through our local MP.When we arrived we fast tracked the long queue of tourists waiting to pay (which was nice as we already had tickets). Our guide though was very nice and extremely knowledgeable was a little too quietly spoken whereas some of the other guides were too loud so it was a little difficult at times to hear what he was saying.Wesminster Hall is enormous and you could easily imagine the feasts that took place there.The first thing that strikes you is how small the House of Commons is. Apparently EVERYONE says that! Although we weren't allowed to actually sit on the benches, we did stand behind them. We were given a few funny facts about the Speaker's chair.The House of Lords looks much the same but is obviously red rather than green. Then there's the central lobby where we saw all the MP's pigeon holes (Hello Mr Brake!) and there is a post office there. The central lobby separates HoC and HoL and is where you normally see news presenters doing their piece to camera.Then there's the rest of the place which is vast. We saw the Queen's changing room and other various halls and corridors displaying marble busts, paintings and other items of military or historical interest including the Magna Carta. There are heads of previous Prime Ministers and there was one empty plinth. The guide said that it would probably be used for Margaret Thatcher when she eventually passed away and by the afternoon (at the top of Big Ben) we were given the news that she had.Book this along with the Big Ben tour for a great day out.

Excellent free tour arranged by MP. Emailed my MP and she arranged this easter break tour whilst the House was in recess. Wonderful to see in real life all the places that you see in the news. Westminster Hall, the Lobby, Houses of Commons and Lords etc. Great history lesson also from the tour guide.

Lunch in churchill dining room!. i was invited to attend a short seminare then lunch in the churchill dining room, i was a little apprehensive as i thought the security and getting around the place would be a chore. I decided to take my son with me who works in London and we are both glad we attended. The whole set up is slick, fast and professional as it should be i suppose. On entering we were in the most magnificent hall, i could only imagine our kings and queens wandering around here and i felt how amazing this place is. When the seminare finished we had lunch in the churchill dining room, the service and food was amazing. We then had a guided tour of the house of lords and adjacent halls and rooms, i can only say spend the money and do it. I prefered this to wandering round the vatican and the sisteen chapel. Truely amazing and inspiring in our own country.

just seen this amazing building while sight seeing round London.. This building is stunning and famous never off tv so while sight seeing in London I had to see it. Amazing g can not be missed if you are sightseeing in London :)
Very good as expected. The tour guides were very knowledgable, but a bit stern. There are few places to rest while waiting, so be prepared to stand.

Guided tour provided insight. Interesting place, well worth the visit, if you're note rested in English History...Westminster Palace was fascinating, and the visit to the Houses of Lords and Commons worthwhile. Best to take a guided tour, to learn all the behind the scenes info.

A Real Tour History of the history of Political Britain. The Palace of Westminster is not to be missed by the visitor to London or us natives. It gives a unique insight into what exactly goes on behind those magnificent gothic walls. The arranged tours are very good and will suit all ages. They are a bit pricey but I think yo get what you pay for. Not a lot of loos in there so take the opportunity to go when you can. Just the sheer size and the magnificene of the place is quite awe-inspiring, which ever of the parties you happen to agree with. Big Ben is actually the Clock Tower and you used to be able to go up that, but I am not sure now. Wrap up well and take earplugs of you do. All in all an experience not to be missed!

Worth the queue in the freezing cold!. You need to book ahead for the tour and even then we queued for half an hour in the freezing cold. It is well worth the visit to this iconic building. The tour took in both the House of Commons and House of Lords chambers, the central lobby and our guide was very informative funny. It was a real privilege to visit this building so full of history and the site of so many pivotal events in British history.
Great outside views. Rather a jumble (security and otherwise) to try and see from within, but of course, everyone should see the building itself from across the Thames.

Great tour - learnt so much. Our tour guide was friendly and really informative about all aspects of the Houses of Parliament. We visited with our 17 and 12 year old daughters and they both thoroughly enjoyed it, which meant the tour guide managed to aim the content of the tour from adults through to a 12 year old. We managed to see the House of Lords and the House of Commons as it was during the Easter holiday along with lots of other areas of Parliament, but I understand if the Houses are sitting this is omitted from the tour.

Excellent and informative tour. We were recommended the Houses of Parliament tour by friends and family who had done this previously. The tour lasts about 90 minutes and is really interesting with a look at the House of Lords, House of Commons, Lobby and Great Hall - lots of background information and even if you have no interest in politics, there is a mass of information and it is always great seeing the bits you usually only see on the television. There was a reasonably priced café with some fantastic muffins and you have plenty of time after the tour to wander in the Great Hall and around the precincts. No photography is allowed in the main part of the tour, understandably so, and our guide was a little officious in keeping everyone together, but all the other staff were informative and ready to stop and chat, to make sure you had all the information you needed and answer any questions. Once the tour was over there was no time limit on you. Would definitely recommend to anyone who is visiting London - not ideal for very young children.

Excellent tour. Having lived in London all my life I did not realise how easy it was to arrange a visit to Parliment. As a UK resident I had to contact my local M.P who kindly arranged and posted tickets to me. Admittedly it took a bit of planning in advance, but worth it, if from abroad ticket details are available on the Houses of Parliment website.You are advised to get there early so as to get through security, once this is done you wait in Westminster hall. We were met by our tour guide and taken through the House of Lords and the Commons via the Queen's robing room and Member's lobby . The feeling of history and splendour were complimented by our informative and friendly tour guide. Normally a tour would last for approx 75 minutes, there are some opportunities to sit, but not many. There is a cafe (expensive) at the start with toilets. Our tour went considerably over time and the two young children in the tour were getting restless and a few people were struggling a bit towards the end.I was really impressed with the tour and would certainly recommend.There was a lady in our group in a wheelchair who was able to access all areas albeit via different routes sometimes to the main group, this did not present a huge problem.

Thought it would be an "OK" place to see but wrong... Superb Tour. I'd expected a "whistle stop" tour where you didn't get to see that much but in fact it was quite a leisurely walk through with an interesting guide and the chance to not only see but to be "in" the Queen's Robing Room, Lords and Commons chambers, Member's lobby and a voting lobby etc.Anyone with any interest in our historic buildings or institutions should have this site on their "to do" list. The tour is 75 minutes but with security etc you need to allow an hour and a half plus after the tour you can spend some time on your own in Westminster Hall.The ticket price, to me, seemed pricey before entering but by the end of the tour that thought had turned to "well worth the admission fee"For most of the year you can only tour the Houses of Parliament on Saturdays other than arranging a "private" view with your MP. Summer openings allow visits between Tuesday and Saturday from 9.15am - 4.30pm during the following dates: Between 31st July and 31st August and also between 17th September and 5th October.

An interesting visit to part of the UK government. had a great time. our tour guide was very informative and had a good sense of humour. lots to see, lots of interesting information about the houses and their history. i would recommend this to anyone who has the chance to stop buy and have a look!

Awesome and vey interesting. We were given a great guided your by Austin Mitchell's researcher. It was a real privilege to be shown around and see all the behind the scenes activity. A self contained large village.

A institution on the Thames. Reminds me that there will always be a England... iconic Big Ben and such.. much nicer when I was younger and before all the security nonsense and we could go in there and wander around.. Now there are so many police around it really makes it seem more a fortress, but alas, such is the world we live in now..Still worth a look, especially from across the bridge on a fine day.

Very interesting. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and organised keeping the group together. You get a real insight into the workings of Parliament. The only disappointment was that I was under the impression that the tour included the climb of "Big Ben"; be aware of this when you book tickets to avoid disappointment. I also wished the tour had been slightly longer.

A great experience. My boyfriend and I contacted our local MP and arranged a tour for last week which is free via this route. It was really interesting and the tour guide was very informative. It was great to see the chambers and the statues of former PMs. We didn't get to see any debates as the chambers were in recess for Easter but this meant that we did get to have a good look around. I would highly recommend this tour as something a bit different, even if you have no interest in politics, the architecture and art work is worth a look.
PARLIAMENT TOUR. We enjoyed a wonderfull guided tour in the Houses of Parliament by our excellent colleague from the UK. It is highly recommended to get your qualified tourist guide for this.
Worth a visit.. A really great in site into british politics and the History of Parliament. It was great to actually go into the rooms that we see on TV. Sat and Sun only.

Beautiful. This building is one of my favourites in London.. it is beautifully decorative yet quite masculine. It is so impressive from the river. if you get time cross the bridge and have a look from the other side of the river or just half way across the bridge. it is impressive having big ben attached to the side. you can go in and do tours etc but we did not get time, but it is worth just visiting the outside. You see it on TV in films and to see it up close it is amazing
Fascinating. I had the opportunity to tour Westminster Palace and Parliament. All incredibly beautiful and fascinating.

Ask for LIZ ...great tour guide. Tour of the House of Parliament. This makes Politics and Parliament real...even if you can't stand politics and claim to be totally bored by it all, I challenge you not to get something from the tour. Cheap to do ...about £12.50 less for students etc and lasts about 90 minutes. For this you'll walk through the House of Lords, yes around those red benches and then through the House of Commons...the famous green benches. You'll learn about the history of the building and some of the Queens role in the state opening of parliament. You'll see where she sits in the House of Lords amidst the gold and splendour and you'll find yourself in areas where you wouldn't ever have been expected to have been allowed ... you'll get used to security! Groups are of 25, works well, and with a very knowledgeable and enthusiast tour guide, you cant fail to find something of interest. Liz you made the visit such fun...bossy,( your words!) but really great fun. Can't thank you enough ... Looking forward to watching the state opening next month to relive the experience! Not English speaking? Website good for more information, yes your MP can take you for free but it's their work place, Tour guides give an all round non bias account. Recommend this especially for family...good history lesson, so take the kids!

Hypocrasy at its finest. Whilst this is a fascinating tour full of history and information you cannot but notice all of the polished brass and mahogany, statues, art works, tapestries and other fineries. No signs of any expenditure cuts here.All UK citizens should make this tour and see how our elected representatives look after thyemselves at our expense.

Terrific. When with Friends and did not expect much, but what a lively surprise. The guide was just so knowledgable and interesting with information on everything. After twelve years of living in London so pleased I finally got to see this amazing place.

Very enjoyable. We booked this online (although I do know if you book through your local MP ITS FREE)
Fascinating place to go and look around and with a guide you find out a lot of information.

Well worth seeing. This is "The Mother of Parliaments" The magnificent buildings, the ceremonies are not to be missed. We were fortunate to watch Prime-ministers Questions. This was arranged through our MP who booked tickets in advance for us. The drama the noise made a fascinating day.

History by the river. Awesome great guided tour of the palace and House of Parliament met Vincent Cable such a gentleman and very knowledgable .we chose to eat at the near byMichelle rue resturant it was excellent
Living history. UK voters can contact their local MP and get a FREE tour. It starts in Westminster Hall and you walk though both Houses (Commons & Lords). You can't get better value than FREE!!

history lesson. This was our second visit as our friends had'nt been and we still were amazed at the great building and the sense of history.Our guide was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic. A must to see where our government make decisions that effect us all.

Saturday tour. The Saturday guided tours are very good. They may be booked online in advance. Check in is then fairly swift. One is brought to the Robing Room, the Palace of Westminster, the Lobby and the House of Lords and the Commons. No photgraphs other than in the Palace of Westminster.

Most excellent, please GO!. Wasn't entirely sure what to expect, but it ended up being a great blend of :a) A history of the British Monarchy (and a lot of those who weren't British!)b) Religious history (or how Henry VIII took the hump with Rome)c) Art History showing Great British war victories (Yay! It annoys the French, the Germans, and the Spaniards!))d) Architectural history through the Baroque styling of the stonework, it is simply stunning.e) An overview of how the Lords and the Commons work. Be prepared to be stunned how small both these seating areas are.Don't EVER, EVER, sit down unless explicitly told to do so. (This happens only once in the lobby at the commons.) One lad of about 12 years old got the shock of his life when he was barked at quite sharply by an armed officer to "DON'T SIT DOWN!". Really funny, he needed a change of trousers!Great tour, great guides, about an hour and 15 minutes, in a group of about 25-30, about 3-4 tours going in 5 minute intervals sometimes sharing the same space, but you don't tend to hear anyone but your own guide.Highly recommended.

Amazing building, amazing tour. I have always admired the Houses of Parliament from the outside and the interior didn't disappoint. The House of Lords is stunning, like many of our palaces.Our guide was great, she was very informative, with a dry sense of homourI would definately recommend adding this attraction to your to see list when visiting London, the best £15 I've spent in a long time!

Well worth a few hours. I'm not a historian but the Houses of Parliament where amazing. From the moment you enter the great hall, history meets you I the face. We had a guided tour and Elizabeth the guide was great, answering any questions that we asked but she as asked as many people about were they came from.My wife is not into politics but she has seen the debating chamber on the TV many times and now her she was standing at the despatch box.Take time out to make this tour, well worth it.

Very impressive and imposing building. The architecture was amazing. A true icon of what makes Britain great in the creation of a "Grand Design". As you would expect there was a heavy police and security presence and you could only view from a distance.

A Must See. Fulfilling a long held desire, I finally got around to booking a tour of this fantastic building. The tour is well organised, informative and eye opening in its magnificence. You are accompanied by well-trained guides and you will see the Lords and Commons chambers and all the other places so familiar from television. The tour lasts about an hour and a quarter and you will be entranced. I’m not so sure that younger kids will enjoy it that much though so be warned. The security checks are painless and efficient and the staff friendly and helpful. When booking on line, buy the official guide, it is an excellent souvenir. You can collect it at the end of the tour. I urge you to try this tour.
Inside Tour. It's offered only on Saturdays. It was very interesting. Great Tour Guide. Wonderful art and history.
Impressive. Just walked past on the outside. Very impressive, beautiful building however. I believe you can do tours of it.

Best attraction in London. I took the tour to the Houses of Parliament in April and I think it was one of the best attractions in London. We visit the House of Commons Chamber and the House of Lords Chamber plus the Westminster Hall. I've learned a lot about the political process in England during the tour and I highly recommend it to everyone! They have tours in several languages...

top attractions. I think this is one of London's top attractions if not the first. People come here to visit the Parliament, London eye, and Big Ben (the Queen's now :)). The whole area is full of many attractions.
Stunning building. Excellent tour to all the interesting areas. Well informed, comprehensive guide who really knew his stuff. Highly recommend.
Private tour arranged via local MP. Can thoroughly recommend arranging a private tour via your local MPs office. Got to see all of the sights with just family for free.

A must do !. We had booked this tour on line just days before we travelled and I am glad we did as this was the most informative and interesting 90 minutes I spent on the weekend . The tour guide , Andy , was a wealth of information and tried to cater for all nationalities , as he asked every person in our group which country they were from and tried to throw bits of history in associated with the countries which were in the group . Moving from the houses of Lords to the Commons it gave you an appreciation of the history associated with the Houses of Parliament -An absolute must when visiting London
queues. we queued for ages then when w did get in there wasn't much to see, i had hoped we would get to see bokes in wigs and stuff, but no, just lots of corridors
Marvellous. Every time I see the Houses of Parliament my heart leaps up,I simply love this place. I was there to see the fireworks at New Year's Eve as well and it was amazing!

Try to take a tour, it was really interesting. The Parliament building are interesting/iconic to see from the outside. However, we signed up to go on the inside tour and it was fantastic!! You start in Westminster Hall, which is so historic. Just seeing the hall from the inside was great, knowing all of the history that has happened there. From there, they take you through the rooms that the Queen uses on the day that she opens Parliament. Then we visited both houses (Lords and Commons) and went into them (obviously they weren't in session). The tour was fascinating and the walk through this building was amazing. I would definitely recommend it. There is also a place to have tea before or after your tour.

afternoon tea and tour. we had tea there which was lovely and the tour was fantastic.we were also taken into the house of lords it was wonderful.the tour guides were excellent and had so much knowledge of the place.a fantastic afternoon.

Thoroughly enjoyed visiting this piece of British history. The tour takes you into the House of Lords and the House of Commons. They were not in session, so we were able to go onto the floor. The guides are also very informative on how each House functions and the seating arrangements. Saw some great statues and paintings and the wall paintings were marvelous. Standing in Westminster Hall really makes one feel the history around you. It looks so different from pictures I have seen of State functions.
Such history!. Very interesting with very knowledgable guides. Very efficient and everyone could hear well. Was amazing to see the Commons and Lords room, seems smaller than on tele though :-)
wonderful impressive buildings.. The architecture was amazing, and Big Ben was bigger than I thought. It dominates the whole streetscape, and you get so close to it. I did not choose to go inside.

Very interesting if you get lucky with right day... Very interesting if they are discussing something interesting, otherwise it could be a bit boring. I'd recommend an early visit to avoid the crowds.

Well worth a vist. Enjoyed our look around, extremely well organised, efficient and with the services of a very knowledgeable tour guide. Group size of about 25, so opportunity to ask guide questions. Both the Commons and the Lords were smaller than I expected!Very interesting visit.
Amazing!. They do not build buildings like they use to. Amazing architecture, simply stunning. You can tour parts of the building, but not all of it.

shouldn't be so expensive. Slap "iconic" on a place and charge a fortune: it just isn't right.Having said that, this is a magnificent place and there really is a lot to see. The guides seem genuinely concerned to ensure a good visit.It's well worth going in free to attend debates in each chamber for a little while: you'll see enough to get a good feel for the building. Then you can decide whether to return and pay for a proper guided tour, and to see the royal apartments, on Saturdays and in the summer.Just don't buy the souvenir leather bookmark; it's nothing special, but cost a staggering £2.90 last time I looked!
Go Now!!!!!!. Wonderful building steeped in history, next to Big Ben my favourite landmark. well worth a family visit.

so interesting!. We met our ex MP, now a Lord Jim Knight in the houses of parliament and he showed us around. The building can be pretty cold, so be sure to take a coat! So interesting the Houses are much smaller in real life than in pictures and television I think, its rather strange! We saw the broom cupboard that emiliy davidson hid in on order to get votes for women too. It was fab.

One of those things you just have to see!!. Read reviews about guides before I went and the guide for our group - Fernando Garcia - was awesome. Very polite, talked to you as a group extremely well. Other groups wasn't so lucky and had glazed looks though!! I heard some of the other guides and they wasnt good!! Think its hit and miss with guides but toured all over world and the guide we had was one of best I have ever come across at a tourist place!! Brought it to life and didn't drag it out:):):) Thank you so much!!

Must visit - amazing. I stayed in London a week and when I went to see Big Ben and Houses of Parliament, I found a queue. I bought tickets for a guided tour inside for 15£ for each adult. The place is amazing. Full of history and art. Old sculptures and paintings. They take you inside the House of Commons and House of Lords and other rooms. If you like history and appreciate art. This place is a must.

The weight of history doesn't fail to impress. What a marvellous tour this is. To see where legendary MPs and PMs have stood and given some of the most emotive speeches in our country's history. I also stood in the Great Westminster Hall, nearly 50 years after being there when Winston Churchill laid in state. The queue had begun at Blackfriars Bridge and this was before people went to great state occasions to be 'part of history' or for an amusing day out.To see the voting lobbies and the gold plated luxury of the Lord's as well as seeing where MPs are lobbied in the public area was fantastic for someone like me enthralled by the political world.Even if you are not interested in politics, go and see where some of the greatest decisions are made, you should not be disappointed. There is a canteen on site too.

wonderful. wow what a wonderful day, our tour guide Darren was brilliant, very informative and quite witty. we had a lovely tour round the commons and the house of lords i would reccommend any one to go and have a look, you must book in advance though ( and its free) just let them know a few weeks before hand. the history of it all was wonderful its just one of those things i would say "do it" just fab.
spectacular!. It was sooooo ornate! Gold leaf galore! Great to be in the House of Commons - much smaller than it looks on the telly! Nice to see AAunt Betty's throne too.

Very good value. For a london tourist style attraction this was easily one of the best value attractions I have taken part in. The tour is extensive, full of interesting information and really eye opening. For anyone, tourist or not, I would highly recommend you spend aa couple of hours on this.

A Must Place to Visit!. Had a conducted tour with a group this time-the guide was so knowledgable/interesting.We were able to ask questions etc,visit the shop + have refreshments.Would have liked a little more time to really study the wall paintings.The House Of Commons chamber is much smaller than it appears on the television.

cannot see "Big Ben". Always a wonderful sight to see HP(the sauce is named after it). One of the worlds oldest democracy buildings. The main Clock tower is often wrongly referred to as "Big Ben". Even by the British. In fact "Big Ben" is just one of the Bells within the tower.If you go to London for sightseeing this is a must.Just at the end of the bridge.

Iconic. On the river large and Iconic. See big ben and statue of Richard the lionheart. On the waterfront it looks like you can circumnavigate it but you can't as the riverbank outfront/ back ? is blocked off.
Impossible not to go here. Architecture is just ridiculously intricate for being 400 years old. Every day we seemingly made our way down to Westminster just to stare at the houses of parliament.

Everyone should visit. We were looking forward to the tour, but it exceeded all our expectations. Long delays standing in the snow waiting to pass through security, but once inside all that was forgotten. Special mention for our tour guide, who was excellent and very entertaining. In fact, all the staff were friendly and really welcoming.We are looking forward to returning for a live debate - book a ticket and go and experience for yourself.......guarantee you wont be disappointed !
Good. Was good to finally see in real life. Not too crowded, able to move about in own time. Worth a visit just to say you've been :)
GOOD FOR A FREE VISIT. This is an interesting place to visit and sit in the public gallery. Seeing the paintings and statues inside is also interesting and best of all it's free.

Not just for politicians....... I visited the Houses of Parliament with a coach party from Woking. We had pre-booked tickets, though I think it is possible to buy tickets on the day. The security is strict, much like an airport. We waited in Westminster Hall for our guide, in a small party of about 20, All tours were carefully arranged so as not to overlap or crowd one another. Our guide was exemplary, a London Blue Guide, who explained the history and business of Parliament very clearly. There was no rushing and no confusion. We saw both the House of Lords and the House of Commons, and were allowed to sit down in the lobbies. There is a small souvenir shop towards the end of the tour and a cafe to the side of Westminster Hall. The tour takes an hour and a quarter but seemed much less as it was so fascinating. I learned a lot and have felt more impressed with the process of government since. This is not a tour for children, but ideal for anyone with a real interest in British history. Altogether, a unforgettable day out.

A History Buffs Dream. We did a tour of Parliament, and it was absolutely amazing. If you are a history buff and/or political junkie, this will be a total treat. Incredibly beautiful on the inside, and history all around you. Highly recommend.

A must do for history buffs!. I loved going around parliment, it really felt special and a privilege to be there when you thought who and when and that decisions that changed all British people's lives over history had been made in these rooms. The rooms were beautiful and magnificent also.

Fascinating building...tour could be better.. Like Buckingham Palace this is opened to the public for several weeks during the summer. A guided tour will cost around fifteen pounds for adults (just ten pounds for seniors). You'll get to see both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.You will be on a guided tour listening to someone tell you things about Parliament. The acoustics of the building aren't very good and there 'll be other groups as well. If like me you may just want to see what it looks like. Both chambers of Parliament are very small. You'll get a chance to stand among the backbenches.Even if you don't take a tour, the Houses of Parliament are a must-see attraction - and within walking distance of other major sights too.

Historically fascinating. What's not to like. So much history and so well explained by the guides. Overseas visitors value this trip more than indigenous Brits who seem to take it for granted,as they do St.Paul's

Reality is so much better!. Seeing Parliament in person is something amazing. Across the River Thames is a walkway that allows you an amazing view of the entirety of Parliament and it is worth just sitting there for a little while you take it in.

Walking the corridors of power. Having lived in London for many years and admired the exterior of Westminster Palace, a family visit finally prompted me to get tickets for a saturday tour of the building. We arrived a bit late because security checks took rather long (good idea to arrive at the outside gate more than 15 minutes before tour starts!), but were rushed by a friendly helper to join our already departed group. A knowledgable and enthusiasitc guide took us around, explaining architecture, history, organization and running of the two houses of parliament and some of the idiosyncratic rituals that are still played out today. My visitors ranked the tour as a real highlight, and I found it informative and fascinating. It's great to have finally had a glimpse of the inside of this gorgeous and history-laden building.
A must see. Houses of Parliament...the center of London law and political life. The members, bursting with personality. Even if you don't care for politics, you will enjoy a visit to Parliament.

a trip through history. we arranged it through our mp which anyone can do if you live in the uk so it was free and had a very good guide so he took almost 2 hours and were able to go in house of commons and lords but alas you cannot take photos and dare not sit on the seats in the 2 houses as it against the law. but very good and cafe was very nice at the end of the tour.

Mother of Parliaments. Visiting Westminster Palace is visiting more than a majestic building, it's visiting British history in the making. I have visited the Palace twice, first with a normal Saturday guided tour, which are great, and they focus on the Royal Route the Queen does when she opens Parliament every year, plus the Commons House where of course the Queen does not have "access". They are interesting but you feel like you want to know more and the explanations are very brief.But not long ago I had the chance to visit it whit an MP as the guide, and the experience was fabulous. He knew so many secrets of the place and told us interesting and funny stories of the people who has worked and works there now. We even pretended we were MPs in the Commons chambers and we did role play the PM Question Time.This is a London must see attraction.!

Beautiful and Interesting Not to be Missed Venue. In the winter, the Houses of Parliament are only open on Saturdays so the visit requires some planning. However, the tour is absolutely fascinating and the venue is gorgeous.

Best part of the trip. Wow! To walk through a building with such history and learn so much of where it came from was absolutely incredible. Great guided tour. What a feeling to sit in the chair of the House of Lords and House of Commons. Would do it again!
Must See!. You must visit the Houses of Parliament - the history, the government, the entire experience is awe-inspiring.
must see this!. Impressive to walk on the sidewalk and feel the history; if you imagine this without all the tourists!!

WALKING THE CORRIDORS OF POWER. We contacted our local MP before we went to London and his office arranged a permit for us to join a tour of the Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament) at zero cost. We got there early and quickly passed through security so were able to spend some time in the cafe which is inside. For London the prices of the comestibles were not at all bad.There are lots of guided tours leaving the great hall every 15 mins. and we were called promptly as per schedule. The tour is comprehensive with the architecture, the furnishings, paintings, etc all worth seeing plus an insight into how it all works when MPs are in session. The real treasure though is when I see on television the Prime Minister standing at the dispatch box I can say "I stood there ?"
First Parliament in the world. Title above says everything. Be prepared and do some study, of the first parliament in the world. Architecture is outstanding and breathtaking.

Amazing in action. Did not like all of the steps to reach the gallery and then the seats were very uncomfortable for me, but loved seeing the House of Commons in action and then reading about the decision the next day.

Horribly Mangled Histories. Thanks to our MP we got a free tour. We kicked-off in the fabulous-but-freezing Westminster Hall when we met our guide who appeared almost bang-on time. Although a friendly and enthusiastic lady (with 26 years experience) she spent the first 15 of our 75 precious minutes laboriously telling us what we were about to see ... When we eventually started to explore the Lords' chambers, the severe shortcomings in her 'style' began to stick out like a duck-house on a peer's lake. I would charitably describe her technique as 'talking to 10 year-old Americans'. In the magnificent Royal Robing Room, we were given a potted history of Victoria and Albert from the perspective of those famous historians Mills and Boon. While Lord Nelson was apparently 'a very nice man', which was said in such a lovely Caribbean accent, it was hard to get annoyed. Unfortunately, my fellow 5th-graders were starting to chafe, especially the Scottish couple who were forced to educate our guide on the origins of James the First (James VI of Scotland). And I didn't know that the sovereign could re-write whole portions of The Queen's Speech according to her whim. NO!!! It took every ounce of my strength not to tell our guide just how silly that was, especially when we had just seen King Charles' death warrant - I still don't know if that was a facsimile or the original. I could go on and on ... but I wont.Magnificent surroundings but mangled history!OK, so she got us tickets to see a live debate after the Commons Chamber was unexpectedly invaded by MPs - so thanks for that. But Mr Speaker, order, order a new guide ... PLEASE!!

An informative and very interesting tour.. The tour guide was excellent and the tour fascinating.It was done in a very professional way with none of the gimicks associated with many tours these days. Anybody interested in the history of this country would enjoy this tour.We would definitely recommend.

Steeped in history and a must visit. Visiting London, you must do this tour. Loads of history at the heart of government - loads of quirky facts and stories and the guides explain how Royalty and Government have worked together (or not) down the years. Nice to see the two chambers but spoiled completely by the guide's condescending attitude and jobsworthyness on protocol. You cannot sit here, stand there, touch this, move 2 yards away from group, speak, eat , drink and breathe - you would not believe that if was not for our money (the tax payer) they wouldn't have the job!!

Interesting Tour. We went during half term which proved to be an excellent as the Houses were in recess, and we were therefore able to go into both the Commons and the Lords. I lent on the box that the MP uses during his question time, the only thing we were not allowed to do was sit on the seats or take any photos. We had an excellent guide you was able to answer all our questions. I personally could have done with another hour but it was still great. The little cafe by the great hall is very good for lunch or snacks.There was no fee for our visit because it was arranged but if you just want to go on a Saturday it will cost @ £15.

Interesting place to visit, keep your eyes peeled you don't know show you'll bump into while taking the tour. Like the Elisabeth tower (big Ben ) this is only for uk residents and is arranged through your local MP. A must do for uk residents. Lived here all my life. seen it on the tv , driven past it and now can say I've been inside. The guided tour is interesting although it could do with slightly smaller groups. None the less you get a real sense of history in here. Don't think the tv does the House of Lords any justice, it is far more grandiose than it looks on screen.This tour is free and so is Elisabeth tower so why not arrange it and come and see for yourself. One down side 'NO PHOTOGRAPHY'. However I had a great day and it will be a long time before the memory fades and if it does I'll just arrange to come again.

From history to current events. Booked a Saturday tour for Overseas visitors on March 9th. I was there 5 past 9 in the morning when my appointment was for 9:30. There were 2 groups for each time slots and one of the groups did not have enough people so I was asked if I wanted to join the 9:15 one, which I did. The tour was incredibly entertaining and educating. The only bad thing about it is that you are not allowed to take pictures aside from within the Westminster Hall. The tour guide was really knowledgeable. The tour started by following the path the Queen takes when she opens the Parliament. I think the best part of this tour is the part where you are taken inside the Houses of Lords and Commons. I never imagined being inside these rooms that I only have seen on TV. (We were not allowed to sit on the MPs' and Lords' benches, but we were standing by them while the guide was explaining stuff.)A visit to London is not complete without a visit to the Houses of Parliament.

Nice to see on the inside. First time we tried to go it was fully booked - so make sure you use the internet and book in advance. All very organised and good to walk through what is great historyOnly downside was you were made to stand in the debating areas - you didn't get to sit on the benches. Not quite sure why.....not even a quick little sit down to say you'd done it (suspect you'd have been thrown out....)
Tour of Parliament. A very interesting and fact finding tour with an excellent guide. We learnt so much and followed the route that the queen takes at the State opening of Parliament.

A great place to visit, and a unique experience !. Write to your MP and then visit - simply fabulous. The only place in the UK you'll find a statue of Thatcher to spit on. Enjoy. The day was a great success.
Impressive building. For sure very impressive building. With the big band, and london eye in the background. However, will be nothing if this is not popular tourist attraction.

Fantastic guided tour. I visited the Houses of Parliament on Monday 4th March and enjoyed a fantastic guided tour by Sarah, who is also one of the door keepers at the Palace.
One of the best attractions I have ever been to.

WHAT AN EYEFULL. I have visited the Houses of Parliament twice over the past three months for business reasons.On each occasion I have be amazed at the place.The history represented here is awe inspiring. There are information stands describing the various places on your walk round. There are places to eat and a small good quality shop.I want to return for a guided tour another day. Another good point is entrance is free.I would think this is a good tourist visit on a tour of London.I will return again when I have more time.

Well worth doing this tour. The tours of the houses of parliament are very well organised and informative. Our guide was very knowledgeable, but a little reluctant to spend much time answering questions - I think this is because the timing is very precise to fit in all the different groups touring at the same time. There is an information desk where they are very happy to chat and answer any queries.

The people's palace. Take one of the guided tours, which can be booked on line and is aslo done in a number of languages. You visit the two housess and see the magificent throne in the House of Lords.The guides are very informative.The guide book is superb and a really good souvenir. Others are on sale in the shop too.

Wasn't invited in but walked around the outside. This is always worth a visit when on a trip to London, I believe you can do a tour if you want to but I like looking around the outside and look for good photo opportunities. Its always well kept and very much an attraction especially when you come out of the tube station.

Easy to arrange. We arranged this tour through our local MP by email. It was free for us byt I don't know if there is a charge for non UK residents.The guide gave our group of about 14 a very informative talk with stops to listen all around the buildings. It takes 75 mins and we did whizz along which was fine for us but 2 elderly folk struggled to keep up.We went in at 16:00 on a Friday so no MP's around but because they had gone home we could go right inside and stand in seat area - you must not sit down on the seats!!Enjoyed the tour and learnt lots of things I didn't know about how we can access Parliament.
learn about legislative practices. Learn about legislative practices, good if you are not from a legal background. Had an opportunity watch a debate of houses of commons

Once in a lifetime experience. US travelers to London should make every effort to nab a pass to see Parliament in session. My daughter is an intern in the House of Commons and secured access to the morning Q&A period. It is definitely a fascinating way to spend an hour and something most of your friends back home will never have the opportunity to experience. Visit the website for details on requesting a visitor ticket.
Great guided tour. Our guide Andrew passionately walked us through this historical place. Visit Houses of Parliament when the weather is cold outside.
Beautiful building. The House of Parliament is such a massive building. It has great architecture and is such a beautiful building.

A well conducted tour. Tours operate through the Palace of Westminster when parliament is not in session, and our 80 minute tour visited all the main sites with a knowledgable guide. The chance of taking a more comprehensive tour tour might be appreciated as we were occasionally a little rushed, but on the whole these tours are well organised and good value.

Great to See!. Booked the tour round parliament and wasnt disappointed. Tour guide was very knowledgable and had lots of little stories. Tour lasted just over an hour and does involve quite a bit of walking but well worth it.
We went on a Friday, so we got to see everywhere as Friday isn't a working day.
Would highly recommend.

Open only a month or so per year, if you can catch them, visit them!. A must see in London, if you are lucky enough to catch them open. I was living there for a year, so I learned on time, but you can always follow the opening dates in Internet. Impressive. Must make advance reservations and be on time- although you may queue for a while under the rain and wind. But it is totally worth it! Can't take pictures unfortunately but it's just like visiting Versailles when it was actually in use.

long queues, tight security but well worth a visit. Managed to see the house of lords and commans very ore inspiring, and well worth waiting to get in. but at £15 per adult abit steep to get in I thought

Guided through history and power. Go for a guided tour of the saturday and summer openings, it is great if you are interested in architecture, history or politics. One really get to go deep inside this amazing building, and after having done this tour three times I disovered new things during every one of them.

truly a joy. We visited on Saturday 9th March having booked online, the tour started on time And although there were some 'moans & groans' about security we thought arrangements were sensible and delivered politely. THE TOURGUIDE WAS VERY WELL INFORMED AND DELIVERED INFORMATIONWITH GOOD HUMOUR, he used information about tour members nationality to make positive links about their country's links with Parliament, he was able to keep a very diverse group entertained as well as informed. The internal scenery was quite stunning and I will admit to a genuine xense of pride in our seat of government.

I never expected such opulence. We arranged a visit to the Houses of Parliament through our local MP, and were given an allocated time to fit in with climbing Elizabeth Tower to see Big Ben. Despite not being particularly interested in politics per se; I found the tour absolutely fascinating. The guide was very knowledgeable, and imparted the information in a fun way, involving everyone including the kids. It was a fairly large group, so at times it could be difficult to hear, especially as tours depart every five minutes or so, so each room can have more than one group present with two or three guides fighting for attention. The building itself was elegant and much more opulent that I expected - gilded pillars, carved furniture and painted ceilings. So much to see, I would love to go back again to pick up on the bits I missed. Security is strict, obviously, and mobile phones and cameras are not allowed to be used inside (other than in Westminster Hall), but there is a shop at the end of the tour where you can buy post cards and small pamphlets describing what you've seen.You must bring two forms of ID with you - one with a photograph and one with your address. They do check this against the list of participants. It is really worth doing, and I was pleased to see several visitors in wheelchairs - most of the building is accessible.

EXCELLENT HEARING ABOUT OUR HISTORY. What a wonderful two hours spent being given a guided tour around the Houses of Parliament. There is so much to see and to take in, you could really do with seeing it all again right afterwards. This country has so much history and tradition, it is lovely to hear all about it and with a guide, you get so much information and if you have any questions, they are so knowledgeable.Well worth the time spent.

Interesting. We have just visited the Houses of Parliament after contacting our local MP. We were given a very informative and interesting tour through Westminster Hall, Central Lobby, House of Lords etc finishing with a visit to the Public gallery of the House of Commons. Well worth a visit.

Houses of Parliament. This is probably the best free tour you will get. First you have to get in touch with your own MP at least a couple of weeks before you intend to go, and they will send you a pass and all the details you need. The tour itself was brilliant , all that history and a chance to stand where the Prime Minister answers questions , plus the building itself is stunning. I would go back tomorrow.

Pure History. Fantastic IWM Museum.The addition of the Churchill Museum has made this a top rated attraction. Entry is great value and allows the visitor to have a history lesson in the way in which the government and Chiefs of Staff conducted WW2 from a truly improvised, secret location.

Picturesque. Classic Houses of Parliament everyone has to get a picture of them. The best way to see them is by touring on a Saturday or by a cruise on the Thames. It's a staple in London and for all who visit!

It all depends on the guide. I was really looking forward to a guided tour around the Houses of Parliament but came away rather disappointed. It was all rather rushed and our guide was relatively quietly spoken to the extent that we could hear the commentary from other tours nearby. What made it worse was other guides giving out information that our guide didn't either know about/forget about or just couldn't be bothered to tell us.Fortunately it wasn't too expensive but I think your experience will hugely depend on which guide you have.
Awesome. The whole of London is awesome but the Houses of Parliament have such a dominant and imposing landmark, loved it!
Wonderful Visit. This was a well thought out and informative guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, it was a privilege to have been able to visit such an historic establishment.
Beautiful. Took some photos from the outside and its beautiful buildings. Love London.Been to Westminter Palace and Elizabeth Tower
good. Good day out exploring London. Walked around the major attractions in London including the Houses of Parliament. Amazing architecture and great weather!
Parliament Tour. Very interesting the guide was excellent. It was good to see things first hand and get an idea of the scale of the place . The architecture is stunning
well worth a visit. All the staff working at the Houses of Parliament were so helpful and informative, the building is exquisite, I could have spent hours and hours there
Beautiful building, stunning architecture. Worth visiting this magnificent building; it is simply beautiful. Located close to Big Ben and Westmister Abbey

Great way to see Britain's seat of Government. We enjoyed a great tour of the Houses of Parliament When the government is in session, you can only visit at weekends, booking in advance is a must as it gets very busy. The tour takes about 75 minutes, and costs £16.50 or so. I felt this was ok in terms of value for money. You are subject to airport type security, but you can take your bags with you. You can't take photos in the building though. You get to go through the house of commons & house of lords. Its very interesting, I'd definatily recommend it.
history or archutecture buff a must see. well worth a visit to see the traditions and just for the archutecture a must see for anyone while in and around london

London at its best. I loved the houses of parliament, from the setting to the work that must of happened to make this one of the most iconic sites in London. I visited just as the sun was going down which really served to highlight the beauty of this building in all its splendor. A must see when you are visiting London

Unexpected pleasure. I was invited to attend a reception in one of the terrace marquees. This involved being checked over airport style before I was admitted. But once inside it was really amazing, a mixture of old and new with the new additions, although very modern, were very tastefully done. The reception was great and the food amazing. If I knew that MP's dined like this I would have followed an altogether different career path !! The police presence inside was very strong and I felt more reassured rather then intimidated by them being there.You can get guided tours when parliament is not sitting and after what I have see on my rather limited 'tour', I will certainly be going back again.
Can't get better for a photographer. just make sure to be on the west side of the bridge few minutes before sunset and stay there for half an hour. I guarantee you will get great pictures
Good but not for kids. Its kind of boring for kids. If there is a debate you can watch it, its kind of cool. Its close to the center of London.
Amazing Architecture. Breathtaking building with incredibly detailed exterior. A definite must-see, especially in the sun. Great views from both land and the River Thames.

Try one of the evening events. Probably the most interesting way to visit is by attending one of the House of Commons open committee meetings or special interest group forums. Once you know where you're going and why, there is no more awesome sense of occasion than wandering through Westminster Hall and the splendid corridors to find the relevant chamber. There's usually no charge but there will be a queue to go through security, be photographed for a visitors' badge etc

Fantastic visit. We did the houses of parliament tour which was fantastic. It takes a good 2.5 hours (and even that wasn't enough to see everything properly).Our tour guide was particularly excellent. I have forgotten her name (sadly), but her knowledge of history and the way she conveyed that knowledge was extremely interesting.Would definitely recommend.

Fantastic visit. We did the houses of parliament tour which was fantastic. It takes a good 2.5 hours (and even that wasn't enough to see everything properly).
Our tour guide was particularly excellent. I have forgotten her name (sadly), but her knowledge of history and the way she conveyed that knowledge was extremely interesting.
Would definitely recommend.
Beautiful building. If u like architecture u will love the building. Unfortunately there are many "anti terrorist" things around it these days so it lost its glamour. Still worth a visit though

Interesting but police guards were needlessly rude. It was certainly a good experience to see the famed houses of parliament in the flesh. It is a beautiful buidling and full of history. I enjoyed it but thought the police guards were needlessly high handed. Mobile phones had to be switched off. I was not aware and was publicly reprimanded loudly which I thought was unneccessary. I was just a tourist. She could have said it politely without the need to humiliate me.

Amazing!. Its was amazing to visit this place! always the history its very important and this place is very important part of english history so was amazing!!!No have any place for to sit only for to walk there.If better if u go very early if not u are going to find many tourist. I went at 9:30 so was a good hour and u can take many pictures with out people behind of u!

Superb 90 minutes. Having toured other European Parliaments for free with an EU passport, was bit miffed at having to fork out £15 to tour my own. However, compared to other attractions in London that charge £15 or more, this tour is outstanding - just a pity it is limited to Saturday's only for most of the year.
Unique!. The Houses of Parliament and Big Ben say London to most people. Wonderful to hear the Westmintser chimes 'live' not just on the radio. Walk over Westminster Bridge for a different view.
Great history. Great place to visit and get an understanding of British history and politics. Make sure you see Westminster abbey at the same time

next time you see it on the tv, you can say I've been there. this was so interesting, quite a bit of walking, and not much chance to sit down, and I think we had to book in advance, but would really recommend a visit.
Meet the heart of the democracy.. This the place which you have to see when you visit London.All the area is full with history.It's vey exciting when you see the lights on inside ven in the evening.

Best tour in London. We weren't sure what to expect, but the tour was so interesting. John was obviously very knowledgeable. Beautiful building, ceilings, paintings etc. Was the best tour we did in London and it was free. Really good

History at every turn.. Guided tour arranged through our MP ( Gordon Birtwistle) Our guide was excellent throughout the tour ( thankyou Lucy ) get to see both houses and other lobby rooms. Missed out on the death warrant of Charles the first.

Great to see, make sure you book. This was a fascinating insight as our guide was extremely knowledgeable and interesting to listen to. We arrived in the morning and the next available tour was at 1.15pm, so I would advise you to book in advance if possible. The tour takes about 1 hour 15 minutes and is packed with information. You're not allowed to take any photographs though, which I love to do. When I asked why they said that it is a security issue, which I find strange as there are videos on You Tube of all the different ceremonies and, of course there is the live broadcasting from the House of Lords and the House of Commons. I think it is more about keeping the tours moving quickly. Would recommend this tour.

Parliament guided tour. A great experience, to see the Lords and Commons is breathtaking, tour guides have great knowledge, humour and abundance of history to share.Galleries, paintings & the great hall are magical.Worth every penny.
Excellent guided tour!. I recommend this tour. It is available in several languages. It is necessary to book ahead of time online. It's a very good insight of the parliament. I learnt a lot!

What a great place to see. My wife got a visitors permit from our local MPs office I thought it was going to be a dull old walk round hearing about what the MPs did and the like but when the tour started our guide John gave us all the history of the kings and queens and famous men and woman politicians that changed the country to what it is today and to see the building inside it is unbelievably beautiful a must see if your in London
Amazing tour guides. Make sure to get a ticket for the tours somehow, if you're in London for more than a few weeks. The guides are knowledgeable and funny.

London's Iconic Tower. I unfortunately didn't have time to go on a tour, but even without that experience and background I still think it's worth a trip. Big Ben, and the rest of the parliament building, well deserves its iconic status.

Brilliant tour. We went a couple of weeks ago(09/02/13) on an organised trip with Beestons which included a guided tour of the House of Parliament.We didn't know what to expect but it was a brilliant insight into the workings of parliment and an excellent experience.Well worth doing this, but make certain you go round with a guide as they were so informative

Marvellous - and free if you contact your MP!. Not many things in London are free but if you contact your MP in advance and arrange a tour this excellent visit to Westminster Hall and the Houses of Commons and Lords is!
