Every step is a step through history, from the spot where Charles I was sentenced to death to the place where Spencer Perceval was shot and where Queen Elizabeth II gets ready for the State Opening of Parliament. The guides are friendly and informative and offer loads of information and interesting snippets. We have done this tour on a couple of occasions and it is one of the best things I have ever done in London and is to be thoroughly recommended. If you are going to get in touch with your MP, and want to visit when Parliament is in session, see if he/she can get you a place in the public gallery for Prime Minister's Questions on a Wednesday - it's great fun spotting faces from above and watching the sparring!

Great architecture. Great architecture and the foundation of a civilised society. Recently visited House of Lords (next door) as a guest. Visited the terrace bar which had amazing views. Worth a visit if you can get in!

Facinating. This tour was free courtesy of our MP, if you are a UK resident you can request a tour but make sure you do well in advance. Our guide Bodo? a German gentleman put my knowledge to shame he was excellent. The tour took approximately 75 mins and included the House of Commons & the House of Lords. We knew this prior to arriving, but what I didn't realise was that we would be stood exactly were the PM and our MP's stand, and were the Lords sit. There is so much information but we highly recommend a visit. Even our daughter who is 9 thought it was the best bit of our trip which amazed us especially after seeing Shrek!

Pure history. Our tour guide was the extremely informative 'Amanda', and it was a very enjoyable 1 and and half hours or so. The guide welcomed every visitor personally, asking where we were all from etc. She also answered every question given in great detail and without any hesitation.I had visited before many years ago but I once again loved the wealth of information and fantastic interior around. The building is as impressive inside as it is outside, and I certainly recommend the houses of parliament to all. After the tour, we visited the cafe which was reasonably pricedThe next time I visit the capital, I will try and venture into the public gallery.
Fabulous. Amazing tour guides with lots of knowledge and good humour. truly stunning architecture and history.Shame about the current PM! :-)
Good to see. Really interesting and good to take the tour. Unfortunately, i felt somewhat like they rushed us through. Probably for security reasons. Well worth seeing though

A must for London visitors. I had never been in the Houses of Parliament as a child, so this was a wonderful "first" and far better than I expected. Imposing, interesting, cavernous. We had a very good guide, too. Fascinating to see the actual "corridors of power" and feel the history permeating the venerable stones.

Place to visit, would suit any tourist. We all really enjoyed walking through the Houses of Parliament. The staff there are very nice and there is heaps of information/pamphlets you can collect. We even sat in on a debate which at the time was about the horse meat scandal, something that is a huge topic here in the UK and Europe at the moment.

Interesting. I went on a visit of the House of Parliament after living in London for the last 18 years. The visit and the ticket are worth it, the visit is very interesting, good guide, make you closer to this old institution and its historical weight to today's world.
Great Day out for the Kids. Have access to the House of Commons and House of Lords. As all tours have a guide, there is a lot to learn for the children.
Fantastic Tour. First time been here, great to see the House of Lords - amazing. And the old palace of westminster. worth booking ahead to get the tour of your choice

Steeped in history. From Oliver Cromwell to Sir Winston Churchill. Steeped in history. From Oliver Cromwell to Sir Winston Churchill. From the gun powder plot to the location of the Queen's annual address. The tour takes you throughout the most iconic and reconisable building of the British Isle. Learn about the history of the Houses (House of Lords; House of Commons) and the formation of the building we see today.Learn about how the UK government operates, experience the view as a backbencher and understand the role of a 'Whip' as you explore a building befitting for one of the world's longest standing representative assemblies.I took a friend here on his visit from Texas, it gave him a grasp of the history of Britain in one fair swoop. I would highly recommend it.

Fascinating. Really fascinating to walk through Parliament, see the amazing wooden roof leading to the gallery as well as the pictures of Britain's past leaders. Then you get to the gallery and get to watch one of the great democracies in action. There is a tour through London Walks called "Westminster by Gaslight" that ends with an evening entrance to Parliament.

If you like politics, it's worth a visit. This was a must for my husband on the trip. He enjoyed it more than I did but that is because he loves politics! It's definitely worth seeing, especially for Canadians as it shows us just how much our parliament is set up in the same fashion (as well as a few differences.)
loved the infrastructure. simply loved the infrastructure and the environment around the same. Must visit for every tourist visiting london

Parliament. Amazing guided tour of this grand building. Learnt a great deal about the running of the country and finally had explanations about the whips and backbenchers of the House. Excellent guide book @ £5 is highly recommended. N.B. no photography allowed.

House of Commons Experience. There was no queue to get in so we took our chance and ended up in the public gallery in the House of Commons listening to a discussion about horse meat!Fascinating.Would recommend.Free too of course.

Great to see. I was like a little kid seeing the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben for the first time.
The architecture is just simply amazing.
A must see

Calling all Pugin lovers!. A must for lovers of gothic architecture and especially Pugin's work, but also educational and fascinating... Our guide was particularly good and really knew his history. I thought we had a good understanding of our political system and associated traditions, but we learned so more about its history and inner working. Excellent!

Opportunity to understand the Parlimentary system. Parliament provides visitors an opportunity to observe and understand the UK parliamentary process. The debates, protocol and procedures provide visitors an opportunity to both observe and enjoy another countries political environment. We were there for debates on the horse meat issue and had a great time.

What great architecture!. I was very surprised by the sheer scale of the building!
Ive seen it on tv many times, but to really see it you must see it for yourself.
The architecture is stunning.
And Big Ben is a beauty.

Enjoyed !. Loved the informative tour for about one and a half hours.
The building is a wonderful design and so interesting to learn about the English parliament.
Outstanding. A revelation! Fascinating tour of all the main chambers and rooms. Beautiful building and wonderful sense of history.

Amazing tour. If you get the chance to tour The Houses of Parliament then do it!
Very interesting and amazing architecture and history. Anne our tour guide was superb and informative. Well worth a look..

Worthwhile a visit!!. We have been many times in the houses of parliament! The architecture of the building is fantastic!! As well is worth to queue for a while to attend to 'public audience open to the public!! If you visit London you have to take a tour into the houses of parliament

Public audience open to visitors. The house of parliament is very nice but most impressive is to attend a public debate. There is a public queue for visitors outside the Cromwell Green visitor entrance and if it is a debate you can watch thru the public galleries. It can take some time to queue and you can stay the time you want and leave at any moment.

Phenomenal tour - well worth 15 pounds. You can tour Parliament on Saturdays - either buy tickets on-line or be prepared to wait if you buy on Saturdays. The tour takes 75-90 minutes and is fabulous. The building is gorgeous, and the tour covers the main sites (Robing room, House of Lords, House of Commons, etc). The guides are excellent. A great value for 15 pounds - while it is pricey compared to the US Congress tour (which is a mere 1 dollar for a reservation), the Parliament tour is much, much better than the pathetic Congress tour.

Never to be forgotten. This was an outstanding event. We booked the tour online (we usd Ticketmaster) and would suggest you do the same. The tours are divided into different languages so not too many on each one - there were 25 on ours (which seemed about the norm). You go right into the both chambers, plus the lobby rooms, the Queen's robing room....it was magnificent, fascinating and awe-inspiring. Our guide, Owen, could not have been more knowledgable, witty or friendly.Be aware that you go through full airport-style security at the beginning.Both my wife and I said we would go again with no hesitation.....it was as good a two hours as I can remember.

Must see history!. I have walked past Houses of Parliament many times during my stay in London, always in awe. It is one of my favourite buildings in England. I finally did a guided tour which cost 15 pounds. Penny was our guide and she delivered a great tour. The building is equally as impressive inside as it is outside. My highlight was the House of Commons, seeing just how close either sides of the speaker are to each other. The traditions observed within the building are interesting and unique. If one has to pick attactions in London at the expense of others, choose this one. Especially if you are interested in politics and history.

House of parliament is as beautiful from inside as it is from outside. A guided tour to parliament for 70mins. It takes you to. 12 rooms. You can only browse through the rooms can't view everything in detail as they need to cover 12 rooms in one hour. You get to see House of Commons and House of Lords.. Sad part you can't take picture inside . The rooms are huge and beautiful. The paintings and the artwork are breathtaking..15gbp.. That's slightly at higher end..
Something fantastic for free. never been before and it was fascinating to see where our famous people lie in state and to si in at the houwe of comm;ons and its free

What a real democracy looks like in action. You may have doubts about which lot is in government at the time, but this place has seen them come and go for a very long time. And the British know that the only people to blame are themselves. This place is one of the few on earth where you can feel a nation and its pride.

Landmark place in London. Not to be missed. I love Gothic architecture and this place delivers it in droves. The wooden roof is such a surprise and the whole building is really beautiful. Place you get the most amazing sense of what London is about when you walk around this area.
Excellent. Tour was brilliant , guides you through the history and their knowledge was great. The time flies in with all the things you see on tv coming to life.

Great guided tour.. This was an excellent guided tour of the Palace of Westminster which lasted 75 minutes for just £15. Our guide was excellent, very knowledgeable, and ensured the children in our group were included in the tour by asking questions and involving them throughout. The 75 minute tour flew by and there was so much to take in for one visit that we'll definitely be returning for more!I'm also looking at booking a day's holiday to go into the Lord's or Commons public gallery to watch a live debate - for free!

Really interesting and very much worth a visit. Tried to get one of the free tours through my MP but was too late in contacting him so paid £15 per head for Saturday tour and was well worth it, Liz who was our tour guide was really informative and interesting and really brought the tour to life. A magnificent building with great history and really an amazing feeling to be in stood in the opposition benches in the Lords and the Commons. Would definitely recommend this tour to anyone visiting London

Have now been there. The tour was well organised and the guide articulate and very interesting. This tour is a must for every British citizen because this is where so much history has been and still is enacted.

The Tours here are Excellent. What an amazing building, interesting tour and the chance to go around parliament. Having been based in London 8 years I would still go back to this day, an amazing time going around and recommend to all those visiting or who live here! you can even go on a day parliament is sitting if you apply correctly!

A must see at night. Very beautiful specially at night! I love the lights that Lichtenstein up the parlament and its very near to Big Ben and London eye. A must see when your on vacation here in London.

A must!. Excellent tour of the Palace of Westminster lasting 75 minutes. Informative guide (Sarah) who made the whole visit interesting even to those of us who are not that interested in politics. Security was tight - scanner machines for bags as at the airport. £15 well spent - has even encouraged us to go back on a weekday to try to get into the public gallery to watch a live debate.

House of Parliament. Fantastic history lesson up live and in person. It is amazing long history that this facility holds. The architecture is breath taking and you actually get to sit in the seats of parliament. Would recommend this for adults. May be a little long for children
Lovely London!. This is something you must see while visiting London! Great photo opportunities and beautiful buildings around the Houses of Parliament as well.

Impeccable.. This is a great visit.
Give yourself some time to get in and observe the rules for what you can and cannot bring in.

Interesting. Really enjoyed this visit, as it was a guided tour it was structured and you found out a lot about all the areas visited. Don't expect to get a sit down, you aren't allowed to sit down anywhere, but still worth a visit.
Old London. This is a must to see when you're in London. Many photo opportunities from around the facilities. You can get there by tube which is right under it.
Great tour. This tour is free if you apply through your MP - Well worth it especially if you combine it with a tour of Elizabeth Tower and 'Big Ben'. This was an absolute highlight and free!

great. on of the most interesting sights in london,famous trials were held here. on of the finest hammer beam roofs in the nation,helpfull staff and great history,free to visit in the palace of westminster
great. Visited the dock last week was soo exciting hearing these people discuss the country's future. great for an experience.

Everyone should visit Parliament. We were escorted on our visit by our MP's assistant. She was very charming, interesting and amusing. She took us on the Queen's route when she opens parliament and through to the Lords and the commons, explaining the rules as we went. PMQ's will never be the same again. We saw one or two famous faces but just to be in such an historic place was amazing.

Birth place of modern democracy. London is a city full of wonder and history. And the Houses of Parliament is definitely a place to visit when you are in town! It is the birth-place of modern democracy, and a witness of how history is shaped by the intelligence of human.
A must see!. Whenever I pass them I still marvel at the beautiful architecture and grandness. A true part if London that everyone should see x

An iconic building that says so much about London. This beautifully designed Gothic architecture is another must to see in London of course. Nobody should ever miss it. Not only is it grand and captivating, the fact that it has so much history and still is the bastion of power and politics in the UK just makes the building mesmarising. A tour inside will be really worth it if it can be arranged.
british history at its best. british history at its best.....the houses of parliament jus around thames and next to big ben u actually start feeling u r in england.
Taken grandchild to London. Didn't go inside here but walk round it got lots of photos,also in this area is the minnelluim wheel and also sealife centre.

Jaw Dropping. Though I have been to London many times, the Houses of Parliament still hold a special place in my heart. The view is spectacular and great for pictures. I will never forget the first time I looked up at the greatness of the buildings and their architecture.

Fantastic. My family and i had a Great time walking around Parliament , even seeing Big Ben is a thrill to see , and something for everyone , we enjoyed seeing the view of the Thames from the Parliament veranda well worth the trip

Be sure to get ticks to see the prime minister's questions period. The prime minister has a question/answer period with parliament Wednesdays at 11:30 --it is well worth going-fascinating to see the workings of english government at the same time being entertaining. It isn't easy to get ticks. You can get them in advance from the embassy or show up early 10am and get a pass that will allow you to get in if someone doesn't show up. If you are early enough you have a good chance
great. The Houses of parliament in London are just amazing. You walk over the bridge and get a glimpse of the HOP. You can see Big Ben and Westminster Abbey is right next to it. Also a sight to see

Learned so much about British governmental system. I arranged a tour prior to my trip to London. Non-citizens have very limited access to Parliament but there is a pre-scheduled Saturday tour. The guide instructed on the workings of Parliament at each junction throughout the tour. She provided insight into how the current process came into use, both procedural and legal, and instructed on the political history of the UK. On the tour we were able to go into chambers, stand/sit on the benches, stand at the speakers podium and much more. Not only is the architecture magnificent but the tour was very insightful.

Cant sit down. This is a great building architectural and full of secrets. We were guided around and the lady we had was very good. Please be aware it is an offence to sit down so if you are struggling with your walking then this tour is not for you.Photos are not allowed inside only on exit and in the hall.In the hall you will see many family plaques where royality have laid in state till their funeral. you are allowed to take photosThe coffee shop was not too expensiveGreat time had and worth a visit

A once in a lifetime experience. Go on Wednesday, wait for an available ticket, and watch the Prime Minister respond to spiky and sometimes uncomfortable questions from the "loyal opposition". Great live theater!!!

Amazing. Not having visited here during our last London stay 6 years ago we decided to pay a visit this time. Security is tight, as you would expect but they are not above at being friendly and having a joke or two, especially at my expense. While the outside of the Houses are ornately decorated the inside is just as spectacular. The session we attended was to do with heating and rather interesting especially the size of the budget given to this topic. Worth the visit, especially since it's free..
One of the breathtaking landmarks of London. Just the outer building itself is such a piece of art, wonderful in every season and under any light. Its magnificence takes your breath away.

Drown in history and Polictics. What a building and whah an atmosphere waliking in the steps of the great characters of the past. Worke there in the past so going back was great. Gift shop always has something new for the family.

Not to be missed. British architecture at its best! If you can get a guided tour this building is amazing approach your M.P. to see if he can arrange this for you. To stand under Big Ben at night when this is lit up always thrills me as it is just so beautiful.
Historical!. Well worth a visit. There is so much history here and it would be a shame not to visit. Nothing to dislike, lots to like.

What a great tour, every Brit should go.. I was so impressed with this tour, I'm sure a lot was down to our very engaging and knowledgeable guide, Paul, and every Brit should really go and learn about our amazing history.You get to stand in the House of Lords, the House of Commons and get a complete history of how parliament came to exist as it now. I find these things fascinating, but I was also quietly ashamed of the facts I just didn't know about my country's own history. Well worth the £15 each we paid and I would recommend anyone takes a couple of hours out of their day to do this tour.

The heart of British democracy.. If you are a UK tax payer you should contact your MP to arrange a free visit to see what your taxes pay for. The place is spectacular and the tour guides are superbly knowledgeable. The tea room is worth a visit.

Just Amazing!. Our choice to visit the Houses of Parliament was really more of an 'on the day' type thing but I have never regretted it! I am fascinated by politics which added to the experience but some people with us were less interested and yet still found the entire tour brilliant! Our to guide was Fernando who conducted his tour to an exceptional standard by providing clear and interesting information, If you go to the houses of parliament, you must ask for Fernando! To add to the brilliant tour, the vast splendour and beauty of the houses is just staggering, the House of Lords is covered with gold and even the corridors and atriums of the building are Beautiful. If you are in London, this is a place not to be missed!
Fabulous. What a building just an imposing building. I do like the way they have light up the building at night gives it more drama.
Not to be missed. Guided tour which gives you an excellent insight to the houses of parliament and the historical reasons why so much of the things we see today happen

Watch a meeting in the house of commons (Feb 2012). Go about 2pm you can usualy go into the gallery to watch..thought it would be boring but was quite interesting in the end ..glad we went Didnt go last trip and wished we had fitted it in to the stay :-(

Gorgeous Architecture. One of the more beautiful parliaments that I've seen. Right on the River Thames. Just make sure you visit at the right time to take photos as if the sun is in the wrong position it is hard to take a good photo

Well worth a visit. Try to arrange a visit through you Member of Parliament ( if UK citizen ) as it's free but even if you are paying still worth it. The building is steeped in history but unfortunately the guides can only a brief overview of the it's many features. Not to be missed !!!!
Get a person guide. I saw Parliament with a personal guide who was the former head of security. He was wonderful - full of anecdotes and a true love of history.
Beautiful at night. Just beautiful, we visited it in the evening and walked to Trocadero area afterwards. Easy to catch while in centre

Iconic landmark in London. This place is full of history. What nice craftsmanship. Bring a good camera, and walking shoes.located close to big Ben Thames river London tube, London eye. You can feed the ducks outside in the garden. This place is a functional museum.

Fascinating.. The buildings here are just superb and full of history . Seems wierd and unreal that our country is being run from such a place. Not office like from the tourists point of view. Feels more like a museum of British history-which of course it is as well as a place of government

Grand old building of democracy. Nostalgic building. However, there is vast difference between the house of Lords and Commons indicating the divide between rich and the poor which still exists now. The day I went, all the parliamentarian seats were more or less empty; MP's not interested I suppose on the days proceedings.

Living History. The guides for the Houses of Parliament are fonts of information, and they are able to describe the process of British law-making clearly and succinctly, along with fascinating facts along the way.
That one building. The place where it all happens eh, if you want to see where all those important people have their important meetings then this is the place.

Well worth the price. Very interesting tour and being able to visit both the House of Commons and House of Lords.
The only down side is that you are taken round quite quickly and don't get enough time to look at all the pictures and sculptures

Great place worth visiting.. A beautiful building with plenty of history through out the ages. The tour around the building is wonderful as is the architecture. It was enjoyable visiting and seeing the difference between the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The tour guides are extremely well informed. I would recommend a visit as there is a lot to see and learn about. The location is beautiful and being in Central London has a good buzz.

Plan ahead. If you are a UK resident you can arrange a visit through your MP. If not you need to arrange a tour. Either way it is a fascinating insight into the workings of government and the amazing, historic building where the mother of Parliaments sits. Don't miss it.

Worth a visit. At first I was a bit apprehensive about going on this tour. Sounded very boring. What a pleasant surprise! The guide was extremely knowledgeable and kept the tour informative and entertaining. Definitely a to do when you are in London

fab guide. I did this as part of a visit to up the bell tower of big ben. Our tour guide was great and explained soem of the history behind parliament. I loved walking through the formal bits and seeing the intricate details on the furniture. We even visited the room reserved for the queen when she visits parliament.

Didn't think this would be as good as it was. We popped in for something to do as a group.Although I find tours intresting normally I was worried i would find this not to my liking.Well I was wrong. It was one of the best tours I have ever done. A good insight on British politics You also go places the Queen herself isnt allowed so thats a nice buzz. The building alone is stunning to the eye.There is a lot of standing though, just keep that in mins
Excellent Guide. In the winter, tours only on Saturday so plan accordingly. So much History and tradition inside the building don't miss it.
Awesome. Seen on TV so many times but to see it in real life was an fantastic experience, the history is overwhelming

Surprise visit. My husband booked this as part of my surprise birthday trip and we were not disappointed. The man who showed us round was very interesting and informative. It was very interesting to get an insight into the history of parliament and the building itself. Worthwhile visit and different from the norm.
very interesting. we did a group tour and found it very interesting and amazing to see inside such a historic building that we are all familiar with.i would highly recommend this to anyone.
Parliament in Action. It was wonderful to be able to view Parliament in action. Check the website on when the public can enter and sit in the balcony to view the action.

Truly unique. Most visitors to London will pass and probably admire this impressive neo Gothic seat of Government, but a tour of the inside is something else.Tours are readily available, and whilst most follow broadly the same route what you see and learn will depend on the personal emphasis of the individual guide. It might be the history, art, architecture, politics or characters which predominate, but each knowledgable guide will cover all the topics to a greater or lesser extent. The length of the tour can vary a bit depending on the enthusiasm of the guide and the guided. Ours was nearly two and a half hours, with only one brief opportunity to sit down!Absolutely fascinating in all respects and some of the interiors are gloriously over the top in color and gilding. Every corner having something of historic interest.The tours are accessible, with some restrictions, to wheel chairs, but it is not a tour for those who cannot walk a long distance without resting, as ther is little opportunity to rest.Small and unique gift shop of quality items including "Mr Speaker's Whisky". Good and well priced guide book and history also available. There is a cafe available at the start and end of the tour, with toilets, and another toilet provision half way round.
Brilliant. I lucked into being there when the tours resumed after the holidays. Amazing building - very well done tours, manageable group size, knowledgable guides.
Superb tour. We did the tour of Parliament this weekend. We enjoyed it so much last July, we booked to do it again! Fabulous guides and so interesting.
Beautiful!. The Houses of Parliament were quite the sight to see. Go early in the morning before it gets too 'touristy' so you can get a good picture with Big Ben.
Perfect architecture. This building is so beautiful, I haven't been inside so can't comment what it is like inside. A perfect photo opportunity.

Worth a walk by visit. The origin of parliamentary modern system. Great photo ops! Better if visited at night, the lighting of the place is breath taking. The views around are a plus: River Thames, London Eye, Big Ben (above) & Westminster Abbey.
Worth seeing it from the outside. Even if you don't want to visit inside or take a guided tour you can't go to London without seeing this magnificent building. A must see!

So nice, I did it twice.. I live in London and took my first tour as a work related event. My wife wasn't invited so I went back again with her. Westminster Palace (The actual name of the building) was started in 1097 and so much British History has been focused on that location. I'm a Yank, but the history is still fascinating to me. The detail of the building is incredible. If you look at just the floor tiles and realize that they are not painted, they are made by hand with different colors of clay! And that is just the floor. Every inch of the walls and the ceiling are covered with intricate detail. Both of my tour guides were excellent and pointed out different points of interest and told different historical stories. Because it is a working government building, it is only open at certain limited times. Make sure you buy tickets well in advance.

Along with the Tower of London, this is England's history. an impressive building with an incredible history. If you can get a tour of the Palace of Westminster, do so. Westminster Hall, Central Lobby, both Lords and Commons Chambers - the history behind the place.....fantastic
nice to see. It has much suggestion, given the history embedded and the architecture in itself. Very interesting the view from river Thames

Beautiful building. Seen them for 60 + years not much I can say except they are a part of London and you wouldn't miss them if you were a tourist would you? Personally I have seen them zillions of times!

Well worth arranging through your MP. We aranged a private tour through our MP and his researcher spent over an hour with us. We saw all the areas we wanted to see an her knowledge was first class. We stayed on for PMQ and if you can arrange this you should as it is worth the time spent.The private tour means that you hear everything and can ask questions freely as you are not in a large group.

Fabulous guided tour. Absolutely mesmerising guide through the whole place. We had quite a few children in our group so she tailored it to keep them interested and it was excellent./ So much to see, so many sayings to discover the derivation of - toe the line, in the bag....

The Mother of Parliaments. This experience is essential for all who value democracy. You can see it in action and it is not what you expect. Clearly most of the work goes on behind the scenes as there are limited numbers in the House debating the issues of the day but that said what surprises you is the knowledge MPs have about there their subject. And if they slip up there is always someone happy to put them right! Aside from debates the buildings are delightful, Westminster Hall a treat when you look up. But for me just sitting under St Stephen's tower watching everyone rush by was great. There is no fee if you take the time to book through your MP and meet up. He or she will be delighted you are taking an interest.
Great by day... but Spectacular by night!!. Great by day... but Spectacular by night!! Try walking along the Thames from Waterloo station for a great view all the way!
Good place to visit. We walked from our hotel on euston road great location very central easy transport hub I'd book back to this hotel again

History on the walls and in all of the halls!. Did not realize that we could tour Parliament until friends who we were traveling with told that they were doing it while we were at another site!We realigned our travel plans and did it. Very glad we did.Be sure to arrive early as the que for entry can be long. Also realize that to purchase your tickets must be done at a location across the street from the line. Make sure you have them BEFORE you get on line for entry into Parliament.Bring a "zip lock bag" for your pocket items. Security is very much like an airport, except it is MORE stringent. They will also take a picture of you that you must wear while you are in the facility.Try to get a docent tour--they are also given is various languages by a very knowledgeable person who will seek answers to questions that she may not be sure of. We had one and she was SUPER!!!!The history, the explanations made a big difference. Sitting in the various rooms and learning about the portraits on the walls provided background and made it all more meaningful. My "better Half" is an English History Buff and even she was thrilled at how it all came together.Truly a memorable, wonderful experience. Very glad we learned about it and were able to go and get in when we went.

The home of democracy. Home to one of the world's earliest democratic parliaments, the Houses of Parliament are well worth the entrance price. Try and attend Prime Minister's Question Time to see how our leaders are held to account.

Great must see in London!. Just what you would expect! Lovely, and worth a visit for sure. Beautiful!! Located near all the major tourist sights especially if you are doing a "royal" tour. Check it out!

Gorgeous. I really enjoyed viewing the Houses of Parliament. The Big Ben Clock was the first site I rushed to see ,which is part of parliament. I was unable to view the inside, since it was closed for an official holiday.

A stunning sight. What an amaziing sight,this building is a very large and wonderfully sculptered spectacle standing proudly on the river thames with the Big Ben clock making it the perfect photo opportunity.

Wonderful - makes me proud to be English. To see the look on the faces of overseas visitors filled me with pride. There was nothing I disliked, just so proud of our heritage. The whole atmosphere was a fantastic feeling
Parliament in London. I haven't been inside but I suppose it is quite nice looking from the outside. You cannot miss it and you shouldn't!

A 'must do' experience...5* - I will go again. What a fantastic experience that I would recommend to all. HOWEVER take really comfortable shoes as the tour takes 1.5 hours. If you have kids and they need the loo then go on arrival in the Great HAll as there are no other loos you can use on the tour.
Tour. I went on an educational tour here. It was very informative. Tour and workshop took 2.5 hours. Took a while to get in as we all had to go through security.

Great insight into British history. Went on a tour here and could not have been more interested. Before the tour there is security screening similar to an airport. The tour starts by going through the royal areas of the Parliament where the Queen visits and prepares for the State Opening. I didn't really care about the State Opening but the history of the monarchs and how that was reflected in the building was fascinating. The best part was visiting the Houses of Lords and Commons. An extensive explanation of their role was given as well as some of the history that had occurred in there. Even if not interested in politics the building is worth a look simply from an historical and architectural perspective.
Iconic!. Take a walk along Westminster Bridge from the London Eye and cross the bridge for a good shot of Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament!
History all around you. This place is amazing. It's not really a tourist zone, just amazing British history in action. If you can get in be amazed at how all this stuff survived the Luftwaffe.
Surprising. The scale of it, the richness of the interiors... it matches the outside and more. Definitely worthy a visit.
Outside. I had the chance to pass by and took picture from outside come early in a sunny day to get good picture for the building
London Icon. We managed to go to the sessions as they didnt have tours. Some of the rooms are really very pretty!

Stunning. I have been lucky enough to attend a couple of work functions at the House of Parliment and have had drinks of the terrace over looking the Thames etc. The tours are really interesting and you get to see the house of lords etc. Brilliant - and if you get an opportunity to go - GO!
Got to see Prime Minister. We lucked out and saw the Prime Minister speaking in the House of Commons. Check on the internet before you go to see if Parliment is in session and times
Does not get more grand than this. Here we have the mother of all parliaments. It burned down the 1800's but was rebuilt. Don't miss seeing where British laws are discussed and made.

A Learning Journey. I was here in June this year but like most tourists, marvelled at the architecture of the building from the outside, only took pictures with the building behind me. This time, I decided to book the guided tour and see what it is like on the inside and was not disappointed in the least. I booked the tour over the phone the day before and it costs only 15 pounds. Was late with the picking up of the tix but was allowed to join the later one. Thought that was very accommodating of them. What was interesting about where the Houses of Parliament are located, is that they are located in a once functioning palace. Our tour was a little more than 75 minutes long and throughout I learnt about the history of how the Houses of Parliament came to be, some British history, visited the House of Lords, House of Commons, viewed the frescos and artwork that adorn the place. It was truly a wonderful learning experience and it helped that our guide, Susan, was so knowledgeable and had a wicked sense of humour. Loved how she told the jokes and kept a straight face. I arrived when there was daylight and left the building after the sun has set and was greeted by a beautiful sight of a huge lighted Christmas tree and the beautifully-lit Westminster Palace. A tour not to be missed.

Wonderful. Fascinating, historical, architecture. If you are a UK citizen, write to your MP for a free tour. The tour lasted 70 minutes and my only complaint is that I would have preferred to take more time to look at the paintings etc but as I could have spent most of the day there, I can see why we were rushed through and we learnt the basics.
Unmissable. World-famous. An unmissable destination for locals and tourists alike. One can even walk around the Commons and Lords' chambers.

History lesson. Your tour guide will explain the details of the decor, and the traditions of the two houses of the British parliament. Our tour started where the Quenn usually enters parliament for her address, the dressing room and the House of Lords. We could have spent hours just looking at the artwork that adorns the walls but we kept moving and went through the House of Commons. Interesting how the commonwealth countries have added their touch to the everyday business of lawmakers in England. Finally the tour goes through the chapel where we entered and the beginning of parliament is explained.A wonderful way to spend an hour and a half, learning about how the building came to be, who helped decorate it, and the history behind the ruling system now in place in England.

Architectural Parliament. Visited this historical attraction on rememberance day weekend, the architecture splendor of parliament is breathtaking. Try to visit as early in the day as possible due to the local attractions, Big Ben is attached to Parliament and Westminster Abbey is across the street.

annual dinner in Cholmondeley Room. Before Dinner we were invited to tour the Houses of Parliament and Westminster Hall. Robing Room being set up for the opening of Parliament, then the House of Lords, through the lobbies and corridors to the House of Commons. we finally went to the terrace for dinner. fantstic tour by one of Black Rods Officers.

Really interesting. I visited with a group and I was very pleased I did. the tour guide was amazing and funny. I found out so much history as we walked though the different areas of parliament and the inside is stunning.

Well worth a visit. Not sure what to expect when we booked this tour but it far exceeded our expectations. The guide was entertaining and enthusiastic, which made the whole tour enjoyable as well as giving us an insite as to what goes on and has gone on behind the well known exterior. The inside of the building is as stunning as the outside, so make it a stop on your tour round and you will not be dissapointed.

Actually stand in the Houses of Lords and Commons. As an avid history buff I jumped at the change to go the the Houses of Parliament. We were lucky enough to be in a group that was only about 9 people. I could not believe the history in this building (as an American the sheer number of years blows your mind). We were there during the summer break for Parliament. I could not believe we actually got to go inside both Houses. Word to the wise, don't even think about sitting down. Apparently there is an acutal law about sitting if you are not a member.

great experience. We visited the houses of Parliament on our recent trip to London, we got the tickets after contacting our MP (thank you Martin Vickers) all i can say is what an amazing experience. The building is stunning from the outside but inside WOW, makes you proud to be British, we are so lucky to have buildings like this. Our guide Peter was brilliant, and very informative and everyone in our party had a great time. If you are planning a visit to our great capital make this a must visit.

Fascinating and educational. Had a wonderful tour of Parliament by Tim Hudson. He was brilliant, patient, and incredibly knowledgeable. The visitor is treated to a behind the scenes look at British government and the magnificent buildings of Westminster. Book your Saturday tour if you will be in London on that day.

beautiful building. disliked that it was hard to get a picture without 5 million people being in it, but the earlier in the day you go, the fewer people you will have randomly standing in your photo, the building itself is amazingly beautiful, and right outside the Westminster underground station
A must for everyone. Most interesting and instructive. To actually sit in both houses and watch the country being run is quite something although you won't want to stay all day.

Great place to visit. My wife and I and 3 children visited today. It was a great experience. The inside is amazing, ornate, intricate and steeped in history.Our tour guide was fantastic as she spoke do knowledgeably about the location and all it's history.Well worth going. Would just liked to have had more time to look at everything.

A real Palace. Iconic landmark and cradles of democracy (?), whatever your view, the sight of this Palace of Westminster either from Parliament Square or the other side of the river is exquisite. The detail and gold relief adorning this gothic wonder are stirring. If you are lucky enough to go in you will find labrynthine corridors and in the old bit, Westminster Hall, the spot where Churchill's body lay, Nelson Mandela delivered an address and the only British PM shot. The sense of history is immense. If you are even lucier, tea on the Terrace is probably one of the best spots in the world (but watch out for the sea gulls!)

Interesting visit. I went with a group from our local branch o Plaid Cymru with Lord Dafydd Wiggley as our host and guide. We also had tea in the House of Lords tearoom which consisted of scones and cream and jam and sandwiches and of course plenty of tea. It was a very interesting tour of the whole building including both houses of Parliament and of the Lobby and the Westminster Hall and of the Chapel.A very historic building of course with plenty to see and to consider. We were given an insight into the work of both houses by Lord Dafydd Wiggley who was an excellent host with many stories to tell us of his work there over the years both as an MP and now in the Lords.

How it works. Tours can be arranged through your local MP. Extremely interesting to see the Palace of Westminster, See the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Guides are interesting with local anecdotes to tell.

Wellspring of Modern Democracy London's Best Visit!. Arrive by underground and get the Wow feeling when you emerge from the tube and suddenly see Big Ben towering above you.If you are sensible and are a UK citizen you have got your MP to arrange your visit,if not or in the Parliamentary recess book ahead, on spec you can just queue to see what they're up to in the House of Commons or Lords. The history is amazing from the nearly thousand year old Westminter Hall where Monarchs lie in state and where world leaders like President Obama address both Houses of Parliament and the Queen in her Diamond year did most recently. The main Palace is the rebuild following the fire of 1842 when the design competition was won by Sir Charles Barry with Augustus Pugin the champion of the Gothic revival,if you are into design this is a fascinating visit. As for the less accessible parts of the Palace the view from the Terrace is legendary but you have to get a Member to invite you to see it,and the remarkable crypt beneath Westminster Hall where the famous cupboard exists where the suffragette Emily Wilding Davison hid on The night of the census in 1901, again only with a Member. So much to see in the Palace of Westminster and there is still the Royal route, the two debating chambers the drama of Question Time.This is a place you can come so many times and learn something new every time.

Didn't have timt to go inside, still worth seeing.. I can't say that it was fantastic, but I very much liked going and seeing it. So much history has happen here. Listening to Big Ben and seeing the statues and the facade of the building are still worth it of couse if you're short on time, but doing what it takes to get inside would proably be woth it, if you have the time.
Special treat.. We were given a private tour as part of a convention and all the guides were very good and we had the opportunity to have a cocktail on the balcony on a beautiful night.
History - old and new. Magnificent buildings you need to tour to appreciate the architecture, artwork, sculptures and the political process that runs the country. Comprehensive and interesting,

Excellent day out. I was taken to the Houses of Parliament on a school trip as a child and always wanted to return as an adult.My wife and I were given a guided tour of parliament after contacting our local MP Jo Swinson. She replied to my emailed request within 15 minutes and had a member of her excellent staff arrange all the details for me. We were then met at the entrance to Portculis House by one of our MP’s staff who proceeded to give us a guided tour of the parliament buildings, into the House of Commons and Lords etc. Well worth a visit, and well worth speaking to your local MP to arrange.I would definitely return for a third visit in future.

Who govern us. Worth taking a look at the House that governs our country.Though we might not agree with the people who sit in there and the laws that leave there, you should take the guided tour which is 75 minutes and informative, interesting, and full of good facts.

A pleasant surprise. Do visit the House of Parliament. It only opens to public on Saturdays. And you can only go in with guided tour. So, do buy tickets online (you can google it). The earliest tour departs at 9:15am on Saturday morning. During November - February time, you may not need to book in advance. However, other times of the year, it's highly recommended to purchase your tickets in advance to secure your spots.
Seeing the centre of British Government for real. History of past Prime MinistersWell organised toursAccess to the Lords & CommonsGood value for money.Obviously - no photography!

Full of history. took my daughter on an invited tour of the place - stood on historic spots e.g. where King Charles 1 condemned to death, where Queen Mother's coffin lay in state etc . The security is tight but this is quite a comfort actually - still nutters out there who want to blow the place up no doubt.

Been there 3 times.. To enter such a historic building and stand where so many famous people have stood is already great but then to be able to assist at a debate in parliament is really fantastic. Whenever I go to London with friends who have never been before I always make time for a visit to Parliament, it is well worth it.

How our money is spent. A very interesting experience. The guided tour lasted about 75 minutes and the guide was very knowledgable. The whole place is a little excessive in grandeur and must cost a small fortune to upkeep.

Surprisingly good. I wasn't keen on doing this tour, but my husband was, so I agreed to go along. We purchased tickets - no queue, from the kiosk which is over the road. Although our tickets were timed for a little later, we managed to get onto an earlier tour. I don't know if this would be possible during busy times.Security checking was quick and efficient, and we were soon under the fabled arches of Westminster Hall, where so many historic events in British history have taken place. The staff were all friendly, and our guide was excellent.There is so much to see on the tour, but as others have said, not a lot of opportunities to rest tired legs and sit down. It is not possible to sit on the benches in either House. However, the grandure, history and beauty of the buildings are amazing. It is well worth a visit, though expensive.

Must See. I visited the Houses of Parliament on the last saturday of November and were lucky to get a tour guide by the name of Russell Grant. He was the most entertaining tour guide i have ever experienced. He really brought the history and politics to life. The Houses of Parliament are impressive to see both inside and out, with everything looking just that little bit smaller than on the tv. Having just taken tour of the capitol building in Washington it was interesting to see and hear about the UK home of government and with the added bonus of all the history that happened in the building it really makes this tour worth the money. Would highly recommend this to people from the UK but also any foreign visitors visting London wanting to learn about the government and the history of the UK.
Fascinating insight into British politics. We had a guided tour which was really interesting. It took 1.5 hours but we'd have liked longer to admire it.

Third Time Lucky. As this was our 3rd visit to London we were really happy to be able to visit the Houses of Parliament on their very last open day of 2012 and we were in awe of the magnificent place.The highlight of our visit was the Most Enthuisiastic Knowledgable Pleasant Volunteer Tour Guide we have ever had on ANY tour and we thank her for making this experience unforgettable
Great History Lesson. Fascinating experience to walk through the House of Commons and the House of Lords to see where British policy has been debated and discussed for generations....

Despite the restrictions, you have to ?. Hello again Folks,Please find our review of the Houses of Parliament. If it helps in anyway, please press the helpful button at the end. MANY THANKS.My Wife and I pre booked tickets with Ticketmaster prior to travel, at £15.00p each. I don’t think that you can just turn up and pay your monies, as demand is very high.We arrived at 2.30p.m on Sat 24th November,2012, so was an hour early. The lady said that we may be able to get on an earlier tour. Once in the Great Hall, we were told to visit the Café, as we were far too early.We enjoyed a coffee there and purchased reasonably priced gifts and returned to the hall just before 3.00p.m. Thankfully, the man that turned us away, remembered us and got us on the 3.00p.m tour.The tour is absolutely fantastic and everything we were hoping for and more. We both felt that the admission fee was good value for money. Alas, cameras / mobiles were allowed into the building and its tour, but sadly, you are strictly forbidden from taking any photos.The tour lasted for about one hour and this may be of concern to some, that you are also strictly prevented from sitting down anywhere, until the tour has finished and you are back in the main hall.Many ThanksGary…Improve vacation…

Visiting Houses of Parliament during Thanksgiving. Being out of the country during Thanksgiving and away from our American roots, we visited HP. It was very enjoyable to see how these institutions worked after we had seen our American counterparts do their things. We visited both houses and were able to listen to debates going on in both sides during our visit. Even our 19 year old found it interesting (although she probably wouldn't do it again). It was one of our holiday things we did for my husband.
Visited for Open Day. It's as you would imagine and have seen over the years on TV and in newpapers, a wonderful insight to a very historic building. Lots of statues of many famous policitians.

A guaranteed great trip. Fantastic. I have visited the Houses of Parliament on 3 occasions during the summer recess and every visit has been superb. The tour guides are really good. This is definitely one of the best attractions the UK has to offer. Great value.
Tour of the Palace of Westminster. So much information, a brilliant guide Russell Grant who should be on the stage A little rushed but we learned so much

Majestic. We absolutely loved this tour,the guide was very informative and we learnt some very interesting facts of history.
The paintings and the decor was amazing and the architecture was so beautiful that we could have stayed all day. Not to be missed.

My son works here!!!. Sons studing Politics so taking a year working alongside MP. Amazed at how stunning it is inside, really recommend a visit. Not my usual sort of choice, but the architecture is outstanding, really WoW factor!

Great Historical Tour. A fantastic insight into British History and Government. We booked on line to make sure we got in. I think you can only do this particular tour on a weekend and a bank holiday, so certainly worth booking in advance. We paid £15 for an adult ticket.Arrive a little ahead of your allocated time slot, as you will need to go through security, similar as if you were in an airport.We were in a tour of aprox 25 people and the person escorting us round certainly knew her stuff, very experience and made it very interesting. We took our 7 year old daughter, who found it a little long and I although the guide tried to include her, the information being given was hard for her to understand and grasp. I would say this is probably more suitable for older children and adults.Overall we found it a very interesting hour and 15 minutes and have come away with a far better understanding of what goes on within Parliment.

History revealed. I have been on several conducted tours and find it fascinating. I believe that there are some 7 miles of corridors and so it is essential to have a Guide who can lead you to the important parts and explain the historical significance of things that you would not otherwise examine.
A tremendous visit. History ancient and modern within and without. Plus Big Ben thrown in.Try and arrange a visit particularly during recess as inside is where you find the real gems.

House of Commons. Good choice on a rainy day. Westminster hall is huge and breathtaking when you walk in, it was almost empty on our visit. You walk the length of the hall and climb the stairs to the central lobby which has fantastic architecture. Onwards up many stairs to enter the viewing gallery in the House of Commons. Was very interesting for us as a Northern Ireland debate had just started when we arrived. You need to be quiet and sit down quickly or a very scary lady will shout at you :). Another free thing in London which is worth the visit.

Worth while visiting.. Our local MP, Ben Gummer arranged for a visit to the Houses of Parliament. It was well worth going as this place is amazing. The House of Lords is a fantastic place, full of history and I was shocked at how small the actual House of Commons really is, but standing at the despatch box where countless famous Prime Ministers have stood felt really strange.If you get the chance, go, it's worth it.Security is airport style, and yes you could be searched, but in this day and age you should expect that.

A good day out!. Booked this through our local MP. The arranging was done by his PA (Ella - who was excellent).Went on a Tuesday and had a tour guide who was most knowledgeable (we were down to be shown around byTom Watson but even he wouldn't have had so much knowledge at his fingertips!) Attended a talk before going in to see the "Houses" live - this is a must - excellent!I could go on and on. Well worth doing. All officials were very pleasant.Public toilets need more regular attention - floor cleaning etc.,

Go for the art. The staff are dour and you may not get an interesting session, but it's free to wander in and the artwork inside is completely unexpected and beautiful. I am going to go back and do the $30 Art Tour based on what I saw on this free entry.

A must-see for visitors to London. This is the heart of Britain. Here you have a glimpse of all the history, and all the traditions, and all the current-day settings of British government. We had a really excellent guide, and it was a memorable experience.
A must visit. Interesting to see the history and seat of power. Allow more time that advised for essential security checks similar to airports.
Parliament. We were able to visit two Houses of Parliament in action. It was wonderful to see some of the judges in their wigs and robes - in action.

Just ask your MP for a pass. It really is that simple. The MP should get you included in a tour which is well worth it - and free! The tour is on a Friday and takes about three hours. It goes from Westminster Hall through the Commons and to the Lords.

A must see!. I have visited here twice and both times have really enjoyed the experience. You are sown around by a volunteer who is very knowledgeable in all aspects. ask them anything and they know the answer. You finall.y get to understand what goes on in there, so when the opening ceremony comes on the tv you can apreciate it alot more. By the way alot of walking involved and stairs so you must be fully mobile.

Excellent tour...well worth the time. Great, informative hour tour of parliament....very knowledgeable guide, friendly, and interesting....take time to see the chambers of parliament when you are visiting from the states...good comparison of governments

Great for photos of the Thames & Big Ben. l think if u wanna a great photo of London for keeps, u must be here because this a famous London landmark against the mighty Thames river that is pure historical dating back to 18th century.Get a feel of old London that we see in movies. The scene is breathtaking.The visit can be boring but, l took great photos here too in 1997.

What a great experience. We had just visited Westminster Abbey (another don't miss) and we were taking photos of Big Ben. We saw a line of people qued up to get in to the Parliament. We approched the young man and asked him how you could obtain entry. It was a Friday just after noon. He said that the budget was just being finalized and there would be a Saturday session and if we arrrived for 9:00 a.m. we would be able to get in. After some pretty serious security checks, we were admitted to the chamber gallery. We thought we would stay for about a half hour and would up there until noon. It is so different from the way our House and Senate floors conduct business. It was straight out of "Iron Lady". The Tories tried to do an "end around" and ram a bill through containing the sale of alcohol in grocery stores without letting the opposition get a good look at the bill. Like I said, straight out of "Iron Lady". There was a whole lot of yelling, accusations, etc. It was wildly entertaining. So if you want to get a look at how things get done in the UK. Don't miss this trip and be sure to get yourself into the gallery to take in some of the dialogue! I hope it is as entertaining for you as it was for me.

wanted to rule the world!!. my friend and i had a tour of the houses of parliament,and found it very interesting.the guides explain the history and how parliament works.buetiful building,you see and walk through the house of commons and the house of lords,we enjoyed our tour very much
London. I loved the Houses of Parliament it was very long the best bit would be Big Ben but it could be more in action

A must-see. Although I was there in my professional, business, capacity, I recommend a visit to the centre of British Government. There are guided tours, but be prepared for airline style security (for obvious reasons!)

Good value and great tour guides. Book and pay the 15 pounds in advance. This well worth the visit. So much history and so many engaging stories that it really coloured the rest of my visit to London.
Amazing place. I Thought the whole experience was first class.My second visit and Ilearnt lots ofnewthings.I dont think anyone would be disappointed, and our guide was superb

Fascinating look into history & government. You may think the building is beautiful from the outside, but the inside is beyond beautiful. A look back in time from the 1300s to present day plus the bonus of learning all about how the British parliament works.
Interesting Tour. One of my favourite tourist experiences in London! I'd really recommend taking the tour as it's really informative and absolutely incredible to be in such a historic building!!!!

Take The Saturday Tour. Just returned from London. Had the chance to tour the House of Parliament on Saturday with a guide. What a great tour, brought what we see on TV into perspective.
Strongly suggest a trip to London must included this guided tour of the HoP

Monument to democracy. Stunning architecture ----pity the standard of integrity or debate matched the surroundings.If you are planning a visit it is a good idea to contact your MP first to let him/her know of your intention to visit and usually they or their PS will give you the guided tour/
Scenic yes - exciting? No. You see them all the time on the TV. Iconic, but once you've been a couple of times. Need to go inside before I could give a real rating.

worth to see once. It's an interesting place and a place where you should have been while a London visit. I would recommend it to take for it time if you've already seen some sights and learned about English history, like politics and want to see the place what you normally just watch on TV.
Amazing. We arrived in the evening, coming out of the tube station and to be humbled by Houses of Parliament and the sound of Big Ben all illuminated fab!

Great tour and a must-see!. This was my first time booking a tour. used to be you couldn't tour without special permission. It was great to visit both chambers and to get up close to it all. Particularly a must is Westminster Hall, the old medieval part where the law courts used to meet in the middle ages and also where some famous historical trials were held.

Evening visits are most amusing. Best way to visit is to get invited. In my case a Peer was hosting a reception for an industry group. This way, you can stroll throught he buildings when they are being used. Screens update on debates, trolleys of drinks groan in and out of dining rooms and you get the feel of the place where people meet and greet. This is living history. Capapes were pretty good as well.

A really interesting tour. One of my favourite tourist experiences in London! I'd really recommend taking the tour as it's really informative and absolutely incredible to be in such a historic building!!!!
A centre for London. A stunning architecture, unique to London, near the river Thames, a must when visiting London, various other attractions in the vicinity.

Interesting History. We prebooked an afternoon tour with 2 children aged 9 & 11. Our guide pitched it at the right level and it moved along at the right kind of speed. We learnt lots of interesting facts along the way. The downsides were that we weren't allowed to sit down at the various stops along the tour, despite rows of empty seats available - apparently those are reserved for MP's - (their bottoms must be superior to ours) - this was rather irksome as I thought parliament belonged to the people and I couldn't really see what harm could come of letting two tired children sit down once in a while, but apart from that it is worth doing.
Houses of Parliament. Worth a visit to see inside where the power of politics and decisions are made. amazing structure from outside and inside of building.
base of democracy. impressive building at the Thames river near big Ben and westminster abbye. go early else it will be crowded

Majestic! A sight to behold, really!. Only was able to walk around the building and admire the elegance of it all. The park beside the House was lovely, as well. Big Ben was chiming at noon, on a sunny afternoon, and this was special.

Birth Place of Parlimentary Democracy. Yesterday I was privileged to visit Parliament on behalf of my employer as part of a larger event. Security was tight as one would expect. Getting in was a bit like getting through JFK, with the exception that I got to keep my shoes on so it wasn’t all bad.I was surprised at how awestruck I was. The pageant and history liberally scattered about the place. I was reminded of how lucky we are in the UK to have a parliamentary democracy to take for granted despite all of its faults. Another four hundred years and we may crack it yet. At least we are a way down the line already.

Worth a tour.. We did this tour just before Parliment returned last month. We had a superb guide and it was a very interesting tour with the high point of the tour being the beautiful House of Lords. Highly recommended!

Attended house of lords in session. We were able to sit in on the House of Lords meeting. You do not have to make advance arrangements just ask security at the entrance when they are in session and go. Hint- check if the light at the very top of Big Ben is on at night and that usually means the gov't is in session and you can go and watch(learned this on a Old Westminister walking tour taken with the best walking tour co. In London called London Walks.

great and informative for locals & tourists- not much for kids. booked a tour of the houses after a few years of living in london. very interesting if you have an interest in history and politics. im not sure why people bought their children on the tour- there was nothing that interesting to them except the very shiny gold furniture...the art and architecture were all so stunning, definitely a great day out.

Do not leave London without visiting Parliament!. Genuinely interesting and great value attraction. A decent length guided tour, all of the necessary facts and as much history as you can feast your eyes on, not to mention getting to step inside the actual Houses of Lords and Commons. From Mandela to Charles I and various Cromwells, back to Obama and The Queen, all the big names in history get a mention here in the story of our nation and you'll be very glad you went.

Guided Tour Amazing. I will be focussing on the official guided tour of the Palace Of Westminster (the "Saturday & Summer Opening" tours) which requires the purchase of tickets and walking through the security screening. Even if you don't pay for the tour, just walking around the exterior is incredible!!Transport to/from Parliament is as difficult as taking the Tube to Westminster station; on leaving the Tube station cross the road to the Parliament building and look for the statues of Oliver Cromwell and Richard the Lionheart; they're a few metres from the tour entrance. We purchased our tickets through the Internet, and also purchased the tour guidebook that came on special with the tickets. You pick your guidebook up at the Jewel Tower ticket booth (which is about 200m and across the road from Parliament, but requires navigating some stairs to reach), which is also a good place to sit down and wait for your tour time to open (you're only admitted 30min before your scheduled tour time).When you first show your tickets at the door you will be guided through metal detectors and baggage screening; put credit cards with chips through the X-ray machine, as they will trigger the metal detectors. (It's only metal detectors and X-rays, you don't have to remove shoes, but you will have to wear a pass around your neck.) From security you find your way into Westminster Hall, which is the last point where you are permitted to take photographs and use the facilities. The tour groups are about 20-30 people each; we arrived early and there was some space in an earlier tour, so we were permitted to go with an earlier tour group.Much of the tour is done standing. There are few places where you can sit during the tour (you can't sit in the Commons or the Lords) so if you can't stand for longer than 45min bring your seat-walker or book a wheelchair (I have severely flat feet but was able to make it). The endless standing is more than worth it: the art, the architecture, the history, the rituals....All of this was beautifully explained by a friendly, approachable tour guide.The tour ends in Westminster Hall, where public facilities and a cafe are available. The food selection isn't very inspiring and the cafe is crowded, but the Cornish Pasties are very tasty and welcome after the long walk. Tables become occupied VERY quickly, so don't be afraid to share tables with another party and talk about your recent tour.
House of Parliament - so much history. Just to be able to see some place that people years ago influenced how our USA would be structured. Fantastic.

Fantastic plae to visit. We were going to London for 3 nights and contacted our local MP to arrange to visit him and the Houses of Parliament. We met his PA there at 11 and she gave us a personal guided tour of the House of Lords, House of Commons and the other parts between them. It was fantastic. We never knew how nice it was. She obtained tickets for us to go the public gallery for the 2.30 debate. We then met our MP who took us around a bit more of the building, took us for tea and cakes and told us a lot of interesting stories. It was a fantastic day out. Many thanks to our Plaid Cymru MP and his wonderful PA

Great photo opportunity. You can't go in to the houses of parliament and there are lots of police with guns and stuff but they are amazing architecturally. The area is very busy and there are lots of traffic.

Great Tour Guides. We really enjoyed this tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable, and explained to us non-Brits how the two houses in the parliament work. The building is as beautiful on the inside as it is on the outside! Full of statues, paintings and ornate finishes, it reminded me of the beautiful architecture and decoration one would find in a church or a castle. Interesting to see the Queen's Robing Room.Photos can only be taken in the main waiting room, the original Palace of Westminster. I thought the entrance fee was a bit expensive, but the tour was worthwhile. Pick up a few souvenirs in the gift shop - I don't think you will find these items anywhere else!

Unexpectedly fantastic day out. We went with a group of Rotarians to Parliament with our MP. Neither my husband or I have ever been before and we were completely unprepared for what a brilliant time we had. The decor inside is extraordinary, incredibly intricate and detailed - if a surface can be decorated/carved/gilded or embellished it is ! Seeing the House of Lords was fascinating and while the subject under discussion in the House of Commons was rather dry (something to do with Croatian relations and free school meals in academies) it was really quite fascinating to see our legislature in action. The irony that we visited the day after Bonfire night was not lost on us ! There is an excellent cafe serving sandwiches, cakes, soup etc. It's not cheap but it's fairly standard prices for London/South EastThe security takes about 10 minutes to get through and I am non-plussed at the people complaining about security screening - this is the main "senate" of the United Kingdom and often houses our most prominent and influential people. It's a high level terrorist target - what do you expect, any old Tom, Dick or Harry to be waved through ?

Exterior. We didn't have enough time to do this justice, but did view it from the London Eye and then again at ground level on our way to Westminster Abbey. The architecture is very grand. A most impressive group of buildings

An insight into both the grandeur of tradition, and the myopia of politics. A visit to the Palace of Westminster is thoroughly recommended. Not just to appreciate the extraordinary Great Hall and the House of Lords, bedecked in gold - impressive though they are.But to get a better understanding of how small the Commons chamber is, how claustrophobic and boisterous the lobbies must be when the house divides on a contentious motion, how ingrained the traditions are (the pidgeon hole system for example - or touching the foot of statues of celebrated past party politicians to give fortitude for the fray). And thus how real the issue of the confidence of the house is in the government of the country, and how bluster and bravado can triumph over judgement and common sense in the hothouse atmosphere of this tiny rather anachronistic place. Get your MP to take you round - it will open your eyes to both their wisdom - and their folly.

well worth a visit. It is well worth a visit just to soak in the atmosphere of where Britain has been governed from for hundreds of years. We were lucky enough to get the tour during the MPs massively long summer break, so got to actaully stand in both Houses. Our tour guide was absolutely brilliant with wonderful stories. Would recommend to anybody

A favorite!. What a great tour learning how the British government works. Walking thru history and seeing the similarities to my own government was a priviledge. The architecture, history and current observation of government at work was a favorite activity.
Shame about protesters and terrorists. A part of our heritage spoiled by bomb blocks and scruffy tents and war protesters.. The Queen Elizabeth Tower is tuning now it has been cleaned.

the stunning history. Westminster is steeped in history and has to be a must see when visiting London. Not sure about the statue of Oliver Cromwell being heralded as the "father of democracy" though. (I'm Irish ha!)

Quick visit. We did this as a quick visit. The nice lady on the pavement outside was drumming up business and asked us if we'd like to visit as there was a debate happening in the Hpouse of Commons. I wasn't sure as I had my 7 and 9 year old with me. Luckily they loved it - lots of security checks but that added to the excitement for them. They loved sitting in the gallery in the House of Commons and were mesmerised that they could see the lady speaking below and on the TV in front of them at the same time.

Allways worth a visit.. Not much more to say, other than excellent. Allways worth a visit to see the nations power house.Really good to see at night, the atmospheric view of big ben and the chimes of big ben at night set the sceen for me.

Fascinating. Booked through my local MP, my son and I really enjoyed this tour which lasted nearly 2 hours (over-ran slightly). A varied tour taking in all aspects of Parliament, its history and the present time. Each tour is different due to the individual guides and their personal styles. Would highly recommend and I would visit again.

Aerobics in Suits. Its not until you watch the Commons first hand, does it really come home to you how everybody gets up every time a question is answered. Its like watching yoyos...or one of those fairground games u play when a head bobs up and u hit it.Anyway hats off to Andrew Lansley, he was quite brilliant at responding to the diverse but pre-submitted questions....but somehow just airing the question doesn't seem to me to actually resolve the issue.And at a stroke .... an initive for cutting Governmental waste...... shed some of the miriad of hosts standing around all day.Nevertheless. worth seeing, interesting and educational.

Well worth the wait to get in. Parliament was at its best with David Cameron in good form. Security to gain entry was like going through airport security but sadly essential. Best to queue a good 45 min before the official entry time if you want to guarantee a place particularly if a major debate is on.

Fantastic, even without the tour.. I didn't go on the tour of Parliament, however I did go into the public gallery and watch a debate. It was really good! I thoroughly enjoyed it. No need to book in advance, just show up, go through security and you may be in the same room as the PM.
really awesome Building. it was a great place to see in London, The clock tower is beautiful and it is very nice area to walk around as well

Much smaller than you think!. Guided tour round both houses with a knowlegeable person who works there. The building is a rabbit warren but the the Commons Chamber and the Lords are smaller than I expected. Well worth visiting!

Really enjoyable. We were luck enough to be given a personal tour by our MP and we really enjoyed the visit. Everyone was lovely, from the police at the front door to everyone else we met. Beautiful building, amazing history, well worth a visit. Try to book through your MP - it's free!

Plan ahead. I booked my ticket online before I left for my vacation and printed it out at home. I highly recommend this, as the tour is very popular.The security before taking the tour is very tight. Make sure you have a photo ID with you. The tour itself is about 70 minutes long. There is limited ability to sit down while on the tour, and no picture-taking is permitted except in Westminster Hall before the tour begins or after it ends.
