Numerous tours form up at the same time in Westminster Hall and there is about three to four minute time lag between departures. Sometimes two tours can be in the same room at once, which can be distracting, but necessary given the popularity ot this tour. Just listen to your own guide to get the most of your tour.My tour guide was excellent. He explained the various rooms we visited and the significance of the design and the decoration. He also provided many antecdotes.The tour covers many of the areas that can be seen when the State Opening of Parliament is televised; but it also includes areas that I had not previously seen. I was surpised at how small both the House of Lords and the House of Commons are.I took the first tour in the morning and was able to walk to the Wellington Barracks afterwards and watch the guard form up and march to Buckingham Palace and march back after the Changing of the Guard.

Awesome. Did the tour of Parliament and sat in on PQT in the public gallery. The building is very lavish with lovely wood carvings, art work and lots of symbolic history. The crypt is lovely - don't miss the very ornate organ.
Great day out. Thhis was a lovely experience....walking around the Palace just made you realise we are so privileged in England to have so history preserved!
Arrange a tour. It can be done, look online and do it. You will never forget walking these hallways, the statues, the history, the beauty.Bring the kids, and enjoy!

Could have been great if it wasn't for our Guide.... We paid €47.00 for our 2 tickets on ticketmaster and visited here last Saturday morning at 10.30am. We had very little queing and it was interesting to see how tight the security is. We didn't really know what to expect or how much we would see but if we had had a good tour guide, I'm sure it would have been the highlight of our trip as the building is incredible. We had a guide called Noel, who could hardly be heard and was incredibly pompous and full of his own self importance. He was incredibly boring and I tried to listen in on the other groups, which seemed more interesting and animated. I can honestly say, I drifted off in his group and only learned about the '8 minute rule'. The house of Lords & Commons is much smaller than we had imagined and we didn't actually think we would be allowed to enter there. You must remember you 'cannot sit down' anywhere, as was barked at us every 5 minutes. 2 children in our group were made a spectacle of because they dared sit on a step-poor kids were tired. It is a lot of walking and standing in one place, so not ideal for everyone. Would really love to tour it again but with a different guide to appreciate it and learn about its history. This guide had a very one-sided view of english history and had a bad attitude to visitors who moved in his eye-shot. Made a great tour a disppointing experience.We did have a nice lunch in the coffee shop afterwards, which was quite well priced and the staff were friendly also.
Stunning, architectural brilliance. A great place to take the kids. They already knew all about it but seeing in real life was amazing! Very easy to get to and worth the trip

One magic experience. Once in London it will be well worth it visiting the house of commons.
It is as if you were stepping back in history

Fascinating. We visited in the summer holidays very much on the spurr of the moment. We were suitably impressed by how much you actually get to see. Inside the House of Commons and House of Lords, both seemed so much smaller than we expected ! Throughly enjoyed our time and found out so much more about the political system than we expected. Worth a visit without a doubt.

Brilliant tour, not set up to cater for the disabled.. Free tour booked through our MP. The tour guide was fabulous. She is a 'door keeper' and does the tours as well. Very knowledgeable and a good sense of humour. The history was fascinating and we really enjoyed the tour. As part of a large group (25, some were only in groups of 3 or 4), we were whizzed past a lot of art I would have loved to look at properly, but the tour took 75 minutes and it flew by. My one problem was the lack of seating available. You are expected to stand in the pews where the Commons and the Lords sit and in other rooms you stand and listen too. There were three or four places to sit throughout the tour and I have problems standing for very long so ended up sitting on the stairs in the House of Lords as I was really starting to suffer. The stairs are deep and shallow, so getting up again was an issue! A few of the light weight fold up stools you so often see in museums would be very handy as I could have taken one and sat when/where necessary without causing too many problems surely? I suggest those with mobility problems discuss this in advance when booking a tour with their MP. I am due to go again with a different friend next month and will do this myself and see if any help is available that I wasn't aware of but if so, I feel sure our guide would have mentioned it to me as I do use a stick. My comments about accessibility are to make you aware, not put you off. Do go if you can manage it, we enjoyed it far more than we expected. We could have gone to the gem tower free but I was, unfortunately, too tired to do this by the time we finished.

Living History. The free tour available made the entire visit come to life. Fascinating to learn more about the parliamentary method of governing. Made current actions more understandable. Our guide, Tim, was excellent

Breath taking. We had a brilliant guide who obviously enjoyed her job. It makes all the difference. I learned lots of things I should know but didn't. Did you know that Big Ben has no roman numeral Xs on its face they were substituted for Fs. This and a myriad other facts await you!

Iconic landmark. Amazing building a lot more detailing around the building than what you see on the TV, very busy around the area, lots of photos to take, if you are lucky you may see the MP's lining up to go in!!
Great to walk round the real thing. Very well organized and presented tours allow you to walk round the main rooms of parliament, including the Lords and the Commons.
History first hand. Definitely worth seeing where so much history made. Be sure to check schedule because only accessible certain times of year.

Outside only. This is can't-miss London, even if only for a couple of photos outside to update the Facebook profile with. I did not enter inside, but the architecture of Parliament (and Big Ben, of course) is incredible and one of the best experiences of London.
Fascinating. Such an amazing place. With a guide you soon feel a part of the history and day to day running of the seat of Government. Some pklaces much small er than you imagine when seen on TV.

Historic!. I went here because I went to see the Big Ben and it was on the same spot more or less. This is the place where history has been made and is going to be made. The building is beautiful and if you have a couple of hours over you should go there. I didn't go on the tour because I heard at my hotel that you have to be a UK citizen to do it.

HIstorical Visit. saw it years ago, but was great to see it again. very impressive that it's so old and historical and still in working condition. Warn you that the guides are of varying ages- ours was good for his life experience but his voice didn't carry that much as he was an old man.

Make this your #1 destination in London. Well, its 40 years since I last visited the Houses of Parliament as a mildly disinterested schoolboy. Coming back in 2012, I marvelled at the architecture, history and sheer gravitas of the place.We had the advantage of a most exceptional Blue badge Guide taking us around the place, which turned the tour from interesting to truly inspiring. It was one thing just to look around and stand in the steps of the great politicians of our time, but another again to have this placed into 400 years or so of context.We were taken from the Great Hall, scene of mediaeval intrigue and pronouncements of the death penalty through to modern day addresses by the likes of Clinton and Mandela. On to stories ranging from the Gunpowder Plot to WWII to the present day, culminating in the House of Lords and then the House of Commons itself.Absolurely first class couple of hours and make sure you visit the café - how a proper tea rooms should be run.
As seen on the tv. You can get right up close and see the grandure of the building itself sitting right on the thames. located close to lots of attractions so worth a visit while in the area.
It haves an Angle. Good place for photos in London :) Nothing else.The house of parliament now haves an angle so try to spot it, its funny.

Houses of Parliament. This was BRILLIANT... I couldn't believe it when I found myself sitting in the observers gallery listening to the parliamentarians debating foreign affairs, and the role of the British Government... I was very lucky in that by chance Parliament was sitting on the very afternoon I was in the vicinity.... I saw the queue forming and on enquiring found that I would be able to join it and see inside Westminster.... entry was free, but security was tight and individual ID photos were taken and bags collected for safe keeping before anyone was allowed in... once inside it was wonderful to see the paintings displayed on the walls and the architecture of the inside buildings......before the session began I was taken in a small group (about 20 people), into a side room where we were given a talk and slide show on how Parliament works, before being escorted upstairs to the gallery.... I found the whole experience fascinating and would thoroughly recommend it to anyone interested in politics or how the parliamentary system works in Britain and New Zealand where we have the same system..
House of Lords. Wait can be upto 2 hours. Would be helpful if data sheet was given about topics being discussed that day. House of Lords is more visually appealing.
wonderful. What can we say, the place speaks for itself, its what coming to London is all about. wonderful history, love it
The Mother Of All Parliaments.. Every tourist just has to put this on thier list of must visits. Take in the Mother of Parliaments with the outstanding St Stephens Tower containing Big Ben

Fascinating. Only found out by chance that you could tour the Houses Of Parliament on a Saturday. After some airport style security which the children thought very exciting we got into Westminster Hall. We took a 75 min tour taking in the House of Lords, Commons, Robing Room and Lobbies. The tour guide maybe could have brought history alive a little more (she was very Headmistressy and told people off for attempting to sit down in the HoCs) but I saw other guides who were a little more into it shall we say? Despite this it was just amazing to see behind the scenes and learn more about our parliamentary workings.

Excellent tour, special 10th Birthday treat!. As 10th Birthday treats go, this is probably one of the most unusual. Tickets for a guided tour of the House of Lords and House of Commons. £15 for an adult and £6 for a child. Tour took 90 minutes and involved standing in both Houses, right next to the Queen's throne, almost exactly where the Prime Minister stands and all the corridors and rooms in between. The guide was very knowledgeable. The treat started with the build up, walking down the St Stephens entrance, watched by all the crowds on the main road. Then, given a special pass and through a major security operation. Excellent for a wide eyed 10 year old to feel special, as he became 'a bit like James Bond'. Then, a guided tour with all ages, all nationalities. Billed as 45 minutes, we were still there 90 minutes later. Unfortunately, a lot of the talk bored the child, but that was easily overcome by taking him to one side and pointing out all the battles recorded throughout the building on statutes and big murials, making him aware of where the Prime Minister 'argues' on TV, showing him bullet holes from the war etc. Not quite the official tour notes, probably not "politically correct", but interest soared. We were then taken to the side rooms around the House of Commons and ushered through the voting doors where MPs are counted during a 'division'. We voted 'Yes' for free ice cream each day for all schoolchildren. Again, not quite the issue that the Tour guide was promoting to the rest, but certainly one that begged the question 'Can I go around and vote again?'. Bought a souvenir guide for him to take home. On the way home, imagination had been jolted and the conversation was amazing, as was the report to parents afterwards - he had absorbed much more than he let on! I would recommend this tour to anyone - it is long for children, geared for adults, but there is something very 'cool' about being a guest of the Houses of Parliament for a birthday treat!!
great place to see polations at work. it was all good inside with all its gothic and art decco wall carvings the only thing that we did not like was it was cold inside the building

Lovely monument..especially at night. You have to see this place at night...even if you dont like politics. its a must watch place at London. One can really smell history and its importance by just looking at it. A pic from the Westminister bridge is a must for all travelers.
loved it bit long. it is a very good place to go see how britian is one you get to see the historic places and the parilemnt and houses of commons which seem to cause conterversy

To see is to believe. What an experience. You see it on T/V, but in the flesh it is completely real, warts and all. This is why it is so polpular and why the overseas visitors command all the places. But we Brits need to stand our ground and demand our rights.
Beautiful building. Didn't go inside of course, but the building is stunning to look at. The surrounding area was full of tourists, I felt very proud to be English

Great views & really informative guided tour.. Went on the Houses of Parliament guided tour,it was really good to see what it's like inside,there's so many rooms you are shown,the paintings & detail is incredible.The tour lasts 1hour & 15 mins & you're on your feet all that time but it's well worth just to see behind the scenes.

Just go and say wow!. Surprisingly small debating chamber. You have to go and smell the history. I love that kind of thing and clearly anyone from a new world country HAS to come to the brith place of parliament!
A must see place. A great place to visit in London, if you are into politics or not. Well worth a visit to experience the life of those that run our country.

impressive. we were only outside. but we enjoyed the architecture. all the glamour,the endless details. it felt good to be a tourist from another country. to tell the difernce from what we have at our country

october visit. the visit was very interesting and rewarding i would recommend it to everyone be prepared for a wait to pass through security not that i objected to it more to allow yourself the necessary time everyone inside the palace is helpfull

Great fun for Brit history nerds. I missed a chance to visit Parliament two years ago and made a point of going this year. Even though I went at the end of the day when my feet were killing me, it was well worth the visit. It's been one of my favorite buildings from the outside for a while, and the inside is just as gorgeous and detailed. Being American, it's fascinating to see how the UK Parliament operates and this tour gives a crash course in Parliamentary ways. The guide started us on a fast walk from Westminster Hall to the other end of the building, then took us through the House of Lords all the way up to the House of Commons. The Lords obviously have the most opulent rooms, with fantastic decorations and historical art, including a chamber lined portraits of the whole Tudor family. The Lords' section also includes the room where the Queen gets ready to open Parliament, which was very exciting to see. The Commons' chambers are more sparse but no less historically fascinating, with lots of sculpture and paintings. Westminster Hall is very sparse, but it is the oldest surviving part of the old Palace and thus a treat to walk around. It's jarring to see the 13th century architecture in the Hall after 90 minutes of Victorian design. The whole thing is very interesting if you're at all drawn to British politics and history and want to know how the Parliamentary system has evolved over the centuries.

Everyone should go. We had a very interesting few hours here, our local MP was fantastic and met us in the main hall and then took us around the main areas (including coffee on the terrace) Sat in on a debate in the House of Commons and had a brief look around the House of Lords. Fantastic surroundings and everyone should go!

Only the outside. it's a neat place to see but as far as i found you couldn't go inside for a tour unless you had special permission and an escort; which was dissapointing but the outside was beautiful and worth the visit (even in the rain).

UNMISSABLE. IT's all been said by previous reviewers really but I would, nevertheless like to add my own recommendation for anybody visitor or London resident alike to pay the relatively modest tour price and take this absolutely essential and interesting approx 75 minute tour.Our tour guide Richard, who our best guess was a retired Forces Officer or Public School Master, was charming and very informative and was very amenable to answer whatever was asked of him.The time flew by as we were conducted around the Houses of Lords and Commons, and were able to witness at first hand what we had seen, heard or read about almost daily most of our lives. A great experience.

The country's control panel. Took my young kids and my teenager to see the PM's question time, its an absolutely fascinating experience, aside from the magic and grandeur of the building itself get a chance to see the politicians and leaders of our country doing what they do is pretty cool and it inspired one of my kids to get more politically aware and got them interested in the whole democratic process and the debating process that takes place there. It's not the dull debate you would expect and it's actually VERY lively, very rowdy and quite exciting to watch ( again definitely not what I was expecting!) I have visited a couple of time and I always find the experience quite enlightening.

Take the tour!!!. Going on a tour through the Houses of Parliament was the highlight of my 3 month stay in the UK, and I am surprised it is not more popular! I was able to go on a Saturday, but I think they are also available weekdays over summer. The interior was phenomenal, so much history, old and new, and the guide very informative. A must if interest in London's history, and how monarchies combine with democracies! Even my 14 year old sister loved it.

Ask your MP for tickets to the public gallery for PM's Question Time. This has got to be a "must" for all children.Contact your local MP and ask for tickets to Prime Minister's Question Time. That way you go straight in with no queue. Wait in Central Lobby to see the Speaker process - he no longer wears breeches and wig but still wears a black robe. Prime Minister's question time has all the main politicians attending and is always lively and humorous. Children love it and its a great way to interest them in the democracy if their country.AND ITS FREE!
BIG BEN. Iconic sights of Big Ben and Houses of Parliament. Crowded with other tourists jostling for their photo ops!

Very pretty!. You are in London, you have to see this! :)
It's very pretty and worth to see. I didn't go inside though...

Always exciting. The whole view with the Big Ben, and the river nearby.
Westminster Cathedral and all the area was thriving for the festivities for the Queen Jubilee.

Awesome history. Never have I seen such a grand and amazing building, especially one that belongs to politics. The intricate details of the architecture are so amazing, once you look beyond the crowds of tourists, pick pockets and sales people.

Incredibly Impressive. So grand it takes up multiple city blocks. Every inch is covered with detail and one can't help but be impressed. You can't really get too close, but even from outside the gates it is beautiful.

Never realised how good it is. The building and architectural content that is, very much surprised by this tour which lasted a full hour plus. After you do this tour you will have a much better understanding of the different sectors the reasons behind the make up of the parties and how the houses work. Reflect upon Prime Ministers of the past, the heroes that walked the same corridors. The chapel is a fine building with a stained glass memorial honoring the Queen's sixty year reign, see the place Nelson Mandela gave his speech from, Churchill, Atlee, Thatcher it all comes flooding past and makes you think of yester year.

Beautiful, magnificent architecture. Unfortunately, we didn't go inside, but the outside was just beautiful and awesome. When you combine it with Big Ben, it is just overwhelming.Great chance for photography, day and night!Walking across the Thames River, the Eye of London and Aquarium is on the other side. Nearby is Westminster Abbey.When we were in Edinburgh, the Scots didn't think very highly of Oliver Cromwell, whose statue is right in front on part of the House of Parliament! Just a matter of perspective and history!

A must see for tourists. No one should go to London without seeing the Houses of Parliament! Usual place for tourists to view it is from exiting Westminster Station however if you cross over the bridge you can get some great pictures of Big Ben, the Thames and Parliament, similarly staying north of the river, walk past Parliament and into the small park, you can get great views of parliament framed by all the trees and you can sit on one of the benches away from the hustle and bustle and watch the world go by.

You have to see it to believe it!. What an outstanding piece of architecture you can't help but stand and stare. We have travelled all over the world and for us this is the best. I only wish I could have seen the inside.
Beautiful. It looks great with Big Ben.Night and day excellent for pics especially from across the river towards London Eye.

Members dining at the HoP. An amazing building worth taking time to view inside as well as out. And if you can find (or make) a friend who works here, wangle an invitation for lunch in the members' dining room overlooking the Thames. I can't remember what we ate, but the whole experience was amazing - a beautiful space with stunning views and great old-style silver service.

Tour guide was not nice. This tour was very interesting as it was fantasitic to see inside this building. We were actually in the House of Lords which was amazing. The reason that I have marked it average is that our tour guide was basically a bossy boots. She treated us all like idiots and her manner really made us all want to just leave!! There was a young boy in our group who yawned. She gave him a row and told him to cover his mouth and then looked at his mother and told her that she was trying to teach him manners. However, the boy yawned 2 more times on the tour and every single time she gave him a row. In the House of Lords she was pointing to one of the tv's, not everyone looked to where she was pointing as we were so interested in everything around us. She started snapping her fingers and scolded us for not looking at the tv she was pointing to. She told us, when I point at something for you to look at, you look at it. I would however recommend this tour as it is very interesting and worthwhile. I would do it again but not with that tour guide.

Fantastic insight. Firstly, it's free! A great slice of British history that is available to everyone. Feel ashamed that I have left it so long to visit this iconic place. If you have time, book a guided tour - we didnt but still managed to learn so much. Highly recommended

political insight. loved it . real value for money, better that the tower orbuckingham palace. queue can be quite long going through security but worth the wait. nice teashop and tiolets before the tour.

Yeah but!. The trouble is the building is full of bureaucratic parasites fiddling their expenses! The building and grounds are of course quite an eyeful - for tourists it could do with more information outside about the history of the place.

great. we went here to save the 2nd batalion rrf, and i have to say the staff are so friendly and helpful. They looked after the 400 fusiliers that turned up for the march extremly well. They managed to get everyone into the public gallery. It was a very proud moment to see all the hackles on show.
Great history lesson. Great tour with knoledgable guides the Saturday worked well for us and even being history buffs our horizons were broader after a great tour nice suprise

Huge!. This building is so huge and eerily it gives me goosebumps because I've seen it so many times in TV, newspapers, etc. Took my time appreciating the architecture especially the shades of the bricks, design, etc that made this building magnificent.

Excellent Tour. I recently took this tour and for £15, I must say it was very cool. You walk around on the floor of both houses, you are just inches away from the Throne in the House of Lords. The guide gives a great overview of how the British parliamentary system works. The building is amazingly beautiful. Be prepared for security checks, no photos are allowed beyond Westminister Hall. If they allowed them, the tours would never end because of the majesty of the building.
Amazing!. Have to see it up close! It is huge and breath taking! At night it looks so beautiful. The view from the London Eye is a must, especially at night.
Nice to see. We didn't go inside but we went and walked around it. It was one of those places you have to go and just see.

A highlight of our trip. We were not even aware that there were guided tours of Parliament until we happened to walk by the ticket booth on a Saturday in October. We decided to book the next tour and were glad we did. The tours are small groups (about 20 or so people) led by guides to several areas of the building including the chambers of the House of Lords & the House of Commons as well as the Queen's Robing Room. It was exceptionally informative & interesting with a mix of history, current events, trivia & humor all mixed in. There is a small gift shop area as well at the end of the tour. You cannot take photos during this tour (except in Westminster Hall where you start & end the 75-minute tour), but you will definitely remember your visit.

Tour of the Houses of Parliament. What a fantastic tour. words cannot begin to describe the architecture , history and beauty of this building. We also had a great tour guide. Excellent value for money.

Amazing Tour! Would Highly Recommend!. I visited with two friends in October 2012 and we all loved it! The tour lasted about an hour and a half and we got to see The House of Lords and The House of Commons. Originally, we struggled to get tickets on The Houses of Parliament website but we found some on Ticketmaster, you can also buy them on the day if there is any space on the tours.

Go watch a debate!. As an Americans who formerly worked on Capitol Hill, we thoroughly enjoyed visiting Parliament to watch debates on a Thursday evening. Access was very easy (especially compared with Washington). Simply go to the visitor's checkpoint and ask to see the debates and you will go through a metal detector and then allowed to enter Westminster Hall, the incredible 13th century remnants of the medieval royal palace that mostly burned to the ground in the nineteenth century. From there you proceed through the nineteenth century portion and then ascend to the visitor's gallery. I cannot recommend this enough: even if you stay for only 15 minutes, it will be worth it! All the workers and security personnel we met were very friendly and helpful and a little amused that we were so excited about watching Parliament in action.

Lovely when it's all light up. We loved walking over the bridge to see the Houses of Parliament all light up. It's a beautiful building. Also it's easily accessible with other sites right by. Big Ben is right there, then West Minister Abby is infront of it, the London, Eye and then the Sea Life!

History and current affairs. It is great to see where all our great politicians have stood and argued their points. It is also helpful to be able to relate the tv pictures we see on the news to the physical structures.
A Must See!. Houses of parliament, the London eye and the London aquarium are all in this area so well worth a look. You cant visit London and not come here!
House of Parliament across the river. Got a great night time photo across the Thames, did not get any closer. Awesome sight. in the rain; the House beautifully lit in the dusk.
Rambling and old. Great big building which although may be considered by some as ornate - to me was quite dark and dank from the outside...never went in as no time
OLD IS GOOD but no sitting down. WoW!The old structures are still there and standing after all this time.I disliked the fact that i could not sit down through the tour cos it was not allowed.
Brill. We went on a guided tour and it was amazing, nothing like you see on the telly. Our MP arranged the visit at short notice. Everyone should go!

Intersting and informative. Went on one of the summer guided tours that they operate and must admit that i wasnot expectimg much but found it very interesting , entertaining and very informative.
You learn all about its history , hows both houses work , who does what etc and was a good education

A guided trip around the Houses of Parliament. I went onto the Houses of Parliament website and e-mailed my M.P. how to obtain tickets. He not only replied by return but arranged a visit and he escorted us around both houses, Lords and Commons, and he is such a lovely man, told us all about the history and explained how the voting system works, he spent 90 minutes with us, and we learned such a lot from him. we are very grateful for that, so it is worth checking out your M.P. on the official House of Parliament web-site so see if your M.P. can get you tickets.

An facinating building with lots of interesting parts. The Commons and the lords chambers were very interesting especially if a debate is ongoing. The old hall and the gothic corridors are wonderful, the restaurant and bar are very good provided you are invited there by an mp, and on my last visit I found the "old school" behaviours had changed to more businesslike attitudes, much more appealing and earnest

Dinner in the House of Lords. We had a great evening dining in the House of Lords. We unfortunately had to queue outside in the rain but when inside the building was really impressive with wonderful decorations. We had a tour guide who told us some of the incredible history that had taken place in the building and showed us a little of the workings of Parliament including the chambers of the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The food was excellent and catering was good for special diets. An evening to remember and savour.
Houses of parliament. Such an immense building and beautiful to look at. A popular buliding with all tourists and and a lovely location.

A highlight of my London visit. I reserved tickets to Parliament about 3 weeks before our visit. They only do tours on Saturday, so be sure to plan ahead.We visited the houses of Lords and Commons, and learned quite a bit about the history of England's legislature. They basically take you from one end of Parliament (starting with the Lords) through the long hallway that separates Lords from Commons. You don't get to sit anywhere in the Lords section, so be prepared to be on your feet for about an hour. You can sit in some parts of the Commons, however. You get to experience a little bit of what the MP's experience in the House of Commons, particularly when they're preparing for a vote. Our visit was definitely a highlight of our short trip to London.

Tour and PMQ's. The tour of the House of commons and the Lords is wonderful. The history is incredible and the stories of what happened in the great hall are great to hear. Was lucky to sit in the House of Lords and get a feel for the history (saw some well known faces too!). On a separate occasion we went to PMQ's (got tickets through local MP - anybody who is interested in attending PMQ's should write to their local MP who can arrange tickets) it is pure theatre and something everybody should see. The chamber is virtually empty then with about 10 mins to go it fills up and the atmosphere builds until the PM and opposition leader start there game of verbal tennis across the dispatch box (on this day the prime minster got an early break of serve and went on to win 6-0!)

Sorry that they weren't sitting at first, but then, wow. At first, we were sorry we wouldn't get to see some debate, but the tour was spectacular. The rooms are heavily decorated, the docent was knowledgeable and very very interesting and not only did she talk about the building, she explained how the British government worked. Do not miss this tour! If Parliament is in session, the tours are only available on Saturday, but it is so worthwhile, I would recommend you go.
Fantastic - worth every penny. Brilliant - great tour guide Wilma - really informative - you got to see every part - the history and grandeur of the building are spectacular. Woth every penny

The most stunning place I have ever seen. If there is one instance where "the picture doesn't do it justice" the Houses of Parliament would be it. And it looks pretty impressive by photograph. The Houses of Parliament, viewed by me mainly from Westminster Bridge, are quite literally breath-taking, almost too beautiful to believe. The horizontal-on-vertical gothic architectural style is an absolute marvel. The place is huge, and the thirty minutes I spent walking the exterior (in the rain, no less) was a purely magical, unforgettable experience. It's a bit more difficult to access the interior tour but undoubtedly worthwhile, and I will certainly give it a go on my next trip to London!

Awe inspiring tour of Houses of Parliament.. The tour far exceeded my expectations. Absolutely awesome! The historical importance of this building in terms of what happens within it is incredible. To be able to walk the hallways and stand at the despatch box in the House of Commons - wow!

Nick was a brilliant tour guide!!!. Despite the understandably long security process this was a great place to visit; to be able to stand on the floor of the House of Lords and the House of Commons where so many important and historical discussions and decisions have been made over the last 180+ years effecting many millions of people was both fascinating and a priviledge. Nick, our Blue Badge tour guide was extremely knowledgable and informative with a great personality. What more could you ask for at a reasonably nominal fee of £10.
Wonderful tour. This was so much better than I had expected. A really informative tour, Lindsey was an excellent guide. The buildings a lot grander than I had expected and the chambers a lot smaller.
So interesting. Very educational and it should be a great privilege to work in such wonderful buildings. The history, the grandeur and so spectacular, interesting and well worth the visit.

Well worth a visit even from just outside.. Another one to include in your city tour. Again photos do not do this building justice (Just like many in London). Unfortunately we were not able to take a tour inside during our stay. It is something that we will certainly plan for our next visit. The building is very, very impressive. Another architectural master piece.

Very educational. A guide takes you round. I had a very knowledgable guide who gave us a good history lesson and a lot of insights into the different parts of the Houses of Parliament. Great to be able to go to the House of Commons and House of Lords chambers and be able to visit what you normally see on TV. It's much smaller than what I thought!

if its open you must do this. What a wonderful building and the tour guide Victoria was very knowledgable. It is a must do what surprised us most was that in our tour of 24 we were the only British people. To actually be inside the House of Commons was surreal.
Excellent. Started with dinner in the members dining area then guided tours around the House of Commons and the House of Lords great tours great insight into how our government works great visit

Superb tour made even me want to know some history!. Absolutely brilliant.... the information given on the tour (by a guide who was superb, clearly immensely knowledgeable without being snooty!) was fascinating and mainly stuff that none of the group knew and we had a mixed group of people who knew about it from the legal or historical side. Just brilliant.

a must see while in london fascinating great insight on how their government works and beautiful as well. loved the tour and able to get inside all the rooms--they give you a pass very authentic and very thorough and filled with history and information
Impressive. We found the tour of Houses of Parliament very informative and good value. The tour guide 'Liz' was very knowledgeable and had a great sense of humour.

looked great. We hadn't been to London in years, and were surprised to see a fence around part of the Houses of Parliament - probably for security. But once we walked up on the bridge, we could take lots of pictures of Parliament. What a great sight!
Worth the Price of Admission. This is a very cool experience for a trip to London and worth the price of admission, especially if you get a good guide as we did have on this trip.

Book the guided tour!. We took the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament/Palace of Westminster and it was fabulous. The guide was full of funny and quirky facts and histories of Parliament. It's quite the contrast to how our government in the States is "run".

Excellent!. The hour and half tour was superbly organised. We had a knowledgeable, friendly guide who worked hard to make his talk relevant to a broad-background group. A great opportunity to see first hand those places so familiar from television and plenty more besides. This surpassed our expectations.
AMAZING!. we only saw it from outside but it's spectacular!!!!!!!!!!! Big ben,Temza and the bridge...everything fits perfectly

great feeling to be in the house. we were allowed to enter in the houses of parliament, went through a security check, left our bags, mobile phones and entered the visitor area on the upper level, a glass enclosure for viewing the debates in the main hall below, great feeling watching members of parliament debating.

the seat of power. We were invited for lunch by the MP.It was excellently served and tasted very good.The whole ambuence of the palace was quite extraordinary and it is difficult not to be overawed by the famous faces you see and meet.

Book before hand!!!. Book early as this is interesting to see. We had a 1 year old son with us and as we were waiting to go with our guide our son needed to have a diaper change. We were lucky to change our time of the tour in order to have his diaper changed as the security was very strict. If you do not make it on time you would miss the whole tour and believe me it is one not to be missed as it was fantastic. We managed to go around with our son yes because the tour was not only interesting for us but it was also kept short and detailed so we moved along from one room to another very quickly. They are very strict on were to sit and were not to sit so if you do not like walking or you get tiered easily I suggest you miss this one as most of the time you are standing. Would definitely re-visit
Great experience!. We loved visiting the House of Commons. The procedure to get in is organized and, although we did have to wait, it was not too long. The experience was worth the wait.
Awesome. Worth the price and the wait to get in if you are fortunate to be able to take a tour. It was so impressive particularly the original great hall.

worth a visit. This is interesting and no more so thatn when you manage to sit in the gallery for a full Commons.
The Commons and The Lords is actuallyvery small.
The best bit- Westminster Hall - marvellous.
great view. A great thing to see if you want to feel that you get in touch with the history! Unforgettable experience!
Impressive. Just walk further (from Big Ben) to see the beautiful building structure of the Houses of Parliament. Nice.

Very Interesting!. We were fortunate to get pass into this historical landmark. Loved to learn more about the House of Lords and House of Commons. Beautiful architecture and the history that has been made and created here is almost surreal. A must see if you are in London!

Pretentious guide but an unforgettable trip. I was left with the feeling that it was a privilege to be in my own Houses of Parliament. The guide, like way too many members, seem to forget that it is a peoples parliament and it's they that should be privileged to be there not us. Nevertheless it is an amazing building home to a few amazing people over the years as well as a club to many who do not deserve to grace it's hallowed halls. As a tourist attraction is a must see though just ignore the pretensions of some of the staff.

Very cool. I was able to tour when parliament was not in session. Tour is 1hr 15 mins long and is very full of history and takes you thru the details of house of lords, house of commons and all the pomp n circumstance.

Awesome to see House of Commons in action. The building itself is fantastic. I especially love the symbolism that it was once a palace for "royalty" and now serves as the heart of democracy in the UK!.
Amazing !. Just perfect ! It's really beautiful, and you can take perfect pictures with Big Ben in front of. Just go and enjoy !

The 'Must See' of London. The guide who took us around was one of the most informative I have ever met. The place really gives a sense of history and the architecture is truly amazing. With St Stephens Tower and the bell, Big Ben, along with Westminster Abbey; statues of Churchill and Cromwell; Westminster Bridge (see it at night in Autumn if possible) and St James Park nearby - you can't go wrong in this part of London. Walk along Parliament St, past the Cenotaph and Horseguards Parade toward Trafalgar Sq or see it from upstairs on a Doubledecker bus. Start your tour of London with a day in this area. It will set you up for the rest of your stay!

Yesterday and tomorrow. No matter whether you have a love of history or wish to see the world and Britain particularly, a visit to the Houses of Parliament should be on the visiting list of every British subject. Whether you wish to see the two beautiful chambers of Commons and Lords when they are most readily viewed or wish to watch the Commons in sitting from the Strangers Gallery, this is a unique experience.

Mother of Parliaments. If you are not a UK subject, it may be a little difficult getting in to tour Parliament. But it is altogether worth the effort to try, and absolutely not to be missed if at all possible. Go to the webpage to check dates and apply for admission. The 90-minute tour is packed with history--and how could it not be? To many, the Victorian Gothic interior may be a little over the top, but I believe it reflects the greatness of Parliament and the countries it represents.

My favorite.... So i went to this place three times during my 8-day stay in London. this place is rich in art and it has a nice view for taking a lot of pictures. When you stand infront of the big ben, it feels like you are just in another world. just next you have River Thames and the nice view of the London eye..you just can´t ask for more...

A thousand years of history. Brilliant building...not hard to believe it was originally a palace. So many wonderful aspects, from the flooring to the statues and ceilings.i hear that your local MP can give you a tour. Well worth the letter to him!

Touring the Houses of Parliament. We had an excellent guide to take us round about 19 Staterooms which we had never seen before. The tour was very informative and educational. Seeing the rooms where all the wheeling and dealing is done made you feel very much part of life within these walls and the wonderful ceremonies that are performed therein. It is good to know that we can demand to see our own MP should he be in house, if not he will contact us when he is free and meet us then. This was a great experience and not to be missed.

Pomp & Ceremony. From the magnificent Great Hall to the House of Commons our guide made us relive the history of the Houses of Parliament. My 49yo daughters felt they had grasped the functions of both houses by the end of the tour. As a "Colonial" it was with great effort that I did not "accidentally" sit in one of the "Hallowed" House of Lords seats. As the tour is quite long I think an issue of "shooting seats" (fold up light seats) would be an advantage.

Great information. I didn't know much about Parliament, but now I do. they handed out information pamphlets which I read. Also note that there is security check so expect to wait. Westminster Hall was beautiful and felt like lots of history takes place there. Definitely a good experience...and it was free!
Got to see parliament in sessions. we just bopped in and they were in session. A great experience! I guess it was a lucky thing, it was impressive.
Excellent tour. The tour of the Houses of Parliament was extremely educational and is highly recommended for anyone who wants a peek into the business of law-making.

Go Go Go. Steeped in true (not manufactured) history, this tour is a MUST when visiting London.
The stories come alive when you walk through these halls. Whether you are fed up with politics or not, worth the time to see where it all happens.

Perfect photo opportunity.. If you come to London, you have to see the Houses of Parliament at Westminster Palace. Here you will also see the Queen Elizabeth Tower (formally St. Stephens Tower) which houses Big Ben. It's the quintessential London postcard photograph and a must for all tourists.
London Tour 2012. Great views when visited via the bus tour, option to hop off and visit, again, great for history and just for the sheer sight seeing.

Art all around. I personally believe that the architecture of neither the US Congress nor any other Parliament in the world can be compared to the building. The art the walls, everything is just perfect. Totally amazed!
Beautiful. We didnt go in, but passed on a londong sight seeing bus, and it was amazing, such a beautiful building, and you wouldnt think it was the houses of parliament from the views it has!

"Worth a visit". Just brilliant my son had arranged this visit with our MP to stand in the great hall knowing people like Nelson Mandela stood on the steps giving a speach sent shivers down my back.We bumped into Glenda Jackson and Russel Brand who let me take his photo quite a nice man.The history in Westminster is outstanding the paintings and the statues especially of Margaret Thatcher are worth a look.The only problem is you need several visits to take it all in hense I was at the end of the group.So diffrent from what you see on tv. The throne where the queen sits is just beautiful so much gold and the speakers chair well not as grand.We were lucky enough to be taken on a tour with our MP to the outside by the thames and to have tea in Westminster which I must say was very nice. We also had a tour of the chapel just off Westminster Hall and wow is all I can say and a shame it is not open up to the public.
Everyone loves Ben. My grand daughter loves Big Ben and he did not disappoint, English heritage is unique and the best in the world, right on our door step
Fantastic tour. The tour was arranged through our local MP and was absolutely fanastic. A definite for anyone going to London. Need to book 3 months in advance to be sure of tickets.

Go and stay. In 1994 I spent the afternoon amazed by the theatre in the House of Commons. The British do government so well. They have elaborate and dramatic debates on the smallest of points. They are thorough and thoughtful and matters are well argued. I think they actually enjoy governance.

Worth a visit.. The upgraded security process means less time waiting - the tour takes about an hour and is well worth it. Avoid the cafe but take some time to visit the gift shop and the display in the Great hall after the tour.

The Intricacies of the Parliament. Would have been more interesting if they had been in session. The way they still go about things is very very slow. They resist upgrades that could be easily done. It is nothing like our congress. Ritual takes up most of the time and I am wondering if they ever get anything done.
Well worth going for an explanation
A magnificent setting. Really enjoyed the splendid architecture of this building. It's worth visiting just to take in what goes on behind the doors.

Do the tour!. Make sure to book yourself for the tour! You will not regret it but you will regret it if you don't make this stop in London! Incredibly interesting look into the "behind the scenes" of the House of Parliament. Great look at British History as well as the political system.

what a palace!. we had been to Buckingham palace the day before, but we were quite unprepared for the simly breathtaking splendour that was the houes of Lords and robing room! Words simply are not enough to describe , apart from 'WOW- AWESOME!!' The whole experience is not to be missed, together with climbing up to see Big Ben ( a separate tour arranged by contacting your local MP-it is also free!!)
James P. Excellent visit good to see what you see on TV.vist arranged by writing to MP excellent and informative staff, joined a tour guide very good not rushed well worth the effort if in London

fantastic. we went on this tour before heading off on holiday. It was brilliant! from the time we arrived we were welcomed by friendly staff and our tour guide Mark, was just so knowledgeable. It was fascinating! He really went through the history and explained what the various decoraton was. The architecture is unbelievable, the skill that has gone into this building is breathtaking. It was exciting to be stood in the house of commons and the house of lords. The history that has taken place here. It really is a must do if you visit london, we have been to so many places in london on weekend trips, and this place wins hands down, you have to go there! if you are looking at studying architecture too, this place would be fantastic to go and look at!

Hard to u der stand. A must for an American in England. Tour is very informative although the groups are too large to ask questions. The groups are back to back so it is a real cattle call. However you walk through a lot of our own history there and it is much easier to understand after you see it. A very beautiful building with curious customs. Advance tickets a must.

HISTORY AT FIRST HAND. Very informative, guided tour of Parliament's rooms and chambers. Tight security - obviously. No photography apart from Westminster Hall. Lots of facts and figures to take in from the guide. Wonderful paintings and statues to admire. Highlight was probably the Monarch's golden throne and surrounding canopy in the House of Lords. Tour takes 75 minutes. Souvenir shop pricey, but the cafe wasn't too bad. Enjoyed their tea! Recommended.

The home of the UK government. The tour lasts about 75 minutes and it can seem a bit rushed - there isn't much opportunity to stop and really look at the detail of the rooms. It can be a bit hard on the legs as there aren't many opportunities to sit - you are *especially* not allowed to sit down in either of the chambers.That said, this tour is well worth doing. There is such a lot of history about the Houses of Parliament or, more correctly, the Palace of Westminster, and the tour guides do a great job of telling that history to you.If you are a UK voter, you can go on this tour for free by contacting your MP.

Brilliant experience. really amazing experience. I was just looking at the houses of Parliament from the outside, when a friendly memeber of staff aked me if I would like to view a debate. As I had no other plans, I decided to go in. There was security checks and about 40 minutes waiting before I could actually go into the debate, but it was worth the wait. I also met a lovely man who chatted to me about how he achieved his MBE while we waited. There's no guaruntee of meeting interesting people to entertain you while you wait, but it's a great place to visit nonetheless.

Fascinating place!. What a beautiful place! We booked on a guided tour, Richard was our guide, he was just brilliant a wealth of knowledge! He told us amazing facts as we walked through this incredible building, from early Royal history where kings and queens walked with this as their palace to modern day standing where our government hold their debates in the house of commons. The artwork is amazing, I loved the room where massive paintings of previous monarchs hang right round to our present queen. I liked the bronze statues of past priministers including a very grumpy Winston Churchill and Margaret thatcher looking very dominant! An amazing building full of interesting history, go you won't be disappointed!

proably one of the most beautiful buildings in the world!. superb!a must and the westminster tube is just across the road!nice little coffee shops too!westminster abbey nearby!sweet little green park past the Queens entrance to relax in!

Excellent tour. This is a must visit if you are in London. The tour will take you through both chambers, and all of the significant rooms used in the State Opening of Parliament.Check in advance to see if parliament is sitting, as the tours are not always available.
Amazing. Absolutely amazing architecture.Shame that it is protected by barriers. Sign of the times, The small park at the side of Westminster is nice well worth a visit too.

You have to stand before you can sit!!!!!!!!. The tour of the Houses of Parliament, is as you might expect well organised. You have to go through the normal security checks on arrival and wear a 'cleared' neck tag during the tour. The tour takes well over an hour and you get to go through all the main chambers, see all the paintings and history. The tour is conducted by an official giude who we found to be very passionate about British Politics and quite amusing with it. There are lots of tours going on at the same time so it can be difficult to see everything as the head of tour guides moves you on if your guide lingers too long, and you can't take pictures!!!!Like most things there is a bit of a down side. Considering the majority of people doing the tour were of a more senior nature and had probably been trudging through London all day the staff, especially the security staff have a real stress if you sit down!!!!!!!!!!!! Considering the building has seats everywhere it seems a bit onerous not to allow the public to sit on any of them.It seems that you are only allowed to sit on a seat in Parliament if you have stood for election before hand. The rest of us are expected to suffer.So if you are a bit unsteady on your legs, can't stand up for long periods of time or have any other sort of infirmity, take a portable seat.

A part of History clearly explained. The tour of Houses of Parliament is very well run. It is a timed tour so plan ahead. You are taken through from the main hall and are able to visit the Commons and Lords(unless Parliament is sitting)The guides are excellent and explain the history and events that took place.Well worth avisit if you are interested in history.

Informative yet fun. Waiting to enter, we were a little apprehensive to find a large group of loud american students in front of us. Thankfully, they were taken aside to form their own tour group. It seems the organisers of the tours understand very well that most people want to be part of a more well behaved group. Not easy to arrange when each group contains around 25 people - yet they managed it very well as far as I can tell.The tour itself was an enjoyable blend of the familiar (entering both houses, with scenes familiar from TV broadcasts) to the novel (discovering the origins of the word "lobbying", for example) to the fascinating (learning that MPs sit in what used to be choir stalls). The guide balanced serious information with light hearted banter in a very polished style.The tour lasted a little under an hour and a half, and at 15 pounds each was money well spent.

Great experience. What a treat, this was a great experience. For only £15 each what a bargain as well. You get your own little tour with a well informed guide. It was great to see where the lords and commons have their debates. Nice to see in life what you see on the tv. We would strong recommend this outing, well worth it. Also of you write to your mp enough in advance, he can arrange this for free for you.
Wonderful Architecture. Great Must see for anyone travelling here. Didn't go inside but got to see Big Ben and took some amazing pics by the water.
Good experience. Very interesting tour. It was organised by work. There we about 25 in the our group. Tour guide was very friendly knowable.
Impressive building. Did not visit inside but was impressed with the beauty and size of the building. Gorgeous from the boat on the Thames.

A history buff's dream come true!. If you are fan of politics and know anything about British Politics you will love this tour place! The guided tour is a bit pricey but well worth it. The tour guides are incredibly knowledgeable and go into different details (building architecture, famous members of parliament, prime ministers, art work, decorations, etc). Made me want to take the tour several times to hear all their stories! The Houses of Lords and Commons are great to see, you walk right into them (as opposed to the USA House and Senate Chambers, boo!). Great treat if you're into this stuff!

Real British history. Walking around the Houses of Parliament you feel a real sense of history. The buildings are old but so well kept up. The location alongside the River Thames adds to the feeling that you are really in the home of the mother of all democracies.

Book a tour. Went on a tour through the parliament and it was great. We got to tour the Queens part, the house of Lords as well as the house of Commons. Our guide was brilliant. Make sure to book in advance.
You have to see it!!!. Great building, quite overwhelming! The guards are very nice and friendly and always glad to take picture with you=)

Free to visit the House of Commons. Just ask at the entrance and there is a good chance you can enter as a visitor and listen to a debate on the floor. You get to see some of the interior. Once inside you can wander a bit with your guidebook.

Enjoy visiting the cradle of democracy get a tour from your MP. This is a great palce to visit in London, and if you are British and a voter the tip is, if you are coming to London, write to your MP asking for a visit. It is your right as a ciytizen to have a tour of the House of Parliament. If you are lucky to have a good MP you might get a personal tour, I was given the tour by two researcher or you might get a ticket for the planned tours. But I got to see lots of things the tourists dont get to see.

Worth doing a tour. I went on a tour a few years ago. It is well worth it to get some perspective on the size if the House of Commons, getting an idea of the full scale of the buildings, see the Queen's robing room and to get a full appreciation of just what a magnificent building this is.
Houses of Parliament were interesting. They allowed us into the house of commons gallery during a debate. Fun to watch the house in action. Could stay as long as we wanted once entering.

A 'must see' in London. Truly amazing!. When one is in London it really is worth taking a tour of Parliament. It’s packed full of an astounding amount of history in an absolutely fascinating architectural setting. Be prepared for quite a bit of walking though, as it’s big…really big. The tours start from my personal favorite space in the estate, Westminster Hall. It’s the oldest part of the estate, as almost everything was destroyed in a fire back in the 1800’s. It’s also the only area where you can actually take pictures, as there is a strict no-pic policy in place in the rest of the buildings. The ceiling and woodwork in Westminster Hall is marvelous and truly something to see.I went on Saturday, September 8th, and there wasn’t anything going on in terms as Parliamentary sessions or anything, as it was a break, but nonetheless, it was well worth it as it was very interesting to learn about how the House of Lords and Commons work, and the procedures and traditions that are followed. The guides are walking encyclopedias of British history, and it’s fascinating to hear the drama and intrigue throughout the past 900 years or so. You’ll know many of the more famous characters from your early school days, but nothing to the degree that it will be presented by the guides. Every room, every hallway, every nook and cranny, is full of fascinating history. I’ve been to London more times than I can count, yet it was my first time visiting Parliament, and I now see what I’ve been missing all these years. Even if you think you’re not ‘into’ this kind of thing, I’m pretty darned sure that you’ll still enjoy this place. I’m a truly jaded New Yorker that’s pretty much unfazed by anything, but I’ve got to say that I was truly struck by the beauty and historical significance of Parliament. Just go and enjoy, and I promise you that you’ll have a great and interesting experience. Hope this helps.

Nice.... This building is the first thing you see when you got out from the Westminster underground station. Right opposite is the London Eye and behind it is the Westminster Abbey. Very great and beautiful building, especially the Big Ben. Very unforgettable trip.
Amazing. The Houses of Parliament was really impressive and we got to see so much. Such a beautiful building with rich history. Highly recommended!

A privilege. Visited the Palace of Westminster with a tour group. We entered through Westminster Hall which was built in the 11th century after undergoing extensive security checks (Airport standard). We visited St Stevens Hall - magnificent, the Central Lobby, which is seen on the BBC/Sky News practically every day, the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Both chambers are much smaller than they appear on TV. How can 650 MPs fit into such a small space? We were shown the Queen's Robing Room, the Royal Gallery, the Peer's Lobby, the Central Lobby and the Member's Lobby.Ticket prices: £15 (adults), £10 (concessions), £6 (juniors). Available: late July - early September between 09:15 - 16:30.

A must see. A thoroughly absorbing tour that fascinated us all. The building is truly magnificent and the tour guide Harry was engaging and knowledgeable. (We had no idea that the building was previously a royal palace). We booked on line and the process was quick, easy and inexpensive. You are given an allocated time to arrive. Make sure you allow 5 minutes to pick up your tickets from the box office. The tour lasts about 75 minutes, it could easily be longer. It is rather nice to applaud your guide if you feel they have done a good job. The on site cafe is reasonable and has a good range of cakes and beverages.There is a small souvenir shop selling mugs, key rings ect... I was concerned that my teenage sons (both over 18) would not enjoy this trip but they both agreed it was it was a great experience.
Spectacular architecture. Wow. I saw this site from the south bank at night, the hop on off tour and from the London Eye. Amazing from every vantage point.

not to be missed. The 75 minute guideed tour of the Houses of Parliment is excellent....you are in a group of 25...our guide was excellent....interesting and well informed about the history, the not not well known art work and the workings of the Houses and the relationship to the Crown.
unique. Where else can one find such an excellent and vast building that is too nice to be true? Big Ben of course is a nice extra :-)You can keep looking and find new details; amazing!

Inside view of the Government. A very enlightening tour that provided a better understanding of the intricacies of the British governing process plus access to historic areas of Parliament that are not readably available to the public.This inexpensive tour was conducted by knowledgable guides with access to both Chambers and the Queen's reception rooms.Tickets (about 10 BPS) are purchased across the street and must be presented to access the Parliament Building.
The seat of Democracy?. Westminster Hall and St Mary Undercroft. Security was efficient but friendly. The Chamber is impressive and so are the Speakers private rooms

History throughout. The Houses of Parliament has history every where you look and the chance to be guided through them is an opportunity to good to miss. Booking the tickets is simple, through your Local MP, and is free. The tour is a fantastic experience and you are taken through iconic rooms and past significant objects, including the House of Commons. Highly recommended.
Excellent. Fantastic tour of the place, enough information to learn with very knowledgeable tour guides, our three teenagers thought it was very interesting.

Uk Government and Westmninster. Had a great time here, took the guided tour of both houses of parliament, commons and lords lots of serious history that is good to see and some seriously nice art to look at. Not to lon a walk which is good and at a reasonable pace if you aint so nimble. Then had a ticket from my MP to go watch Cameron (UK Prime Minister) and Ed Milliband (UK Opposition leader) slug it out at Prime Ministers Questions with their respective tribes baying like school kids at each other. Deffo worth doing. Recommend this anytime

Must see twice. You must see the Houses of Parliament in the daylight and at night while all the lights are on it. Took a river cruise and the views of Parliament and all the bridges (Tower, London, Westminster, Millinium)

Beautiful Architecture. This is a great place to see when you are in London! It is beautiful and right by the water! It is amazing architecture and there is a little park nearby where you can sit and enjoy the nice weather (in the summer). The tube station is right there and the London Eye is nearby as well. It is just a short walk away from the Buckingham Palace.

pity they were not lit up when i been there!. i been on the london eye and expected them to be lit up but for some reason they were not! lots of people were disappointed. maybe because some projections of the paralympics were being shown on them? dont know!

a very interesting tour. had a half hour tour around both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. I am not particularly political nor have a great interest in politics but I found the whole tour very interesting from beginning to end. Well worth a visit.

beautiful piece of architecture. It really is. My review mainly focuses on the area. Be aware people there are no bins in that whole area, right through whitehall and further. I made the mistake of getting a macdonalds and walking along eating it. Once id finished there was nowhere to throw my rubbish. I had to carry it all the way back to my hotel. No bins for obvious reasons, with the danger of terrorism etc. very lively on an early evening. theres a lot of protesters pitched up for the foreseeable future. Go chat to them. they have some interesting stuff to say.

the house of parliament is really beautiful outside as well as inside. We took the tours it doesn't cost alot. Show up a little early to go thru security. Very beautiful inside but no photograph on the inside. The inside was very beautiful and you get to see where parliment meet to make decision. Awesome
ok to walk by. You can also visit, but I forgot to book beforehand, the visits are only with pre-booking... Anyway a very impressive building

Nice. Had a tour of the houses of parliament with a guide, and this is for sure a must visit place when in London. Would say that the history and the building itself is of more interest than the current parliament that occupys the common room, as common people. Anyway not so much on them as we all have an opinion there. The building from the outside is just out of this world visually in its design and on entering, the amazement just goes further, unreal how these buildings were ever made, shame they don't make buildings similar in today's day and age. It's history is extremely interesting and educating. Families or couples should visit, and get a tour. Well worth it.

Stunning though a little dated inside. OK we did the tour inside that you book through a local MP, I am not sure if this is available for tourist.The tour was an hour in total and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I think this trip is as good as the tour guide you get. We had a brilliant showing around and she was very detailed in her information.Oh and the Houses of commons is so small, not as big as it looks when you on TV...It is also a bit bland, the house of Lord is fabulous, lots of red and gold. Can I be a Lord please...It was just a great feeling being in the Westminster Hall and knowing some great people have been on the platform in this place.

View The Birth of Democracy. I arranged a private trip around Parliament via my local MP. It was breath taking. The history and magnificence of the various chambers, especially around the Lords were just stunning. Our guide was very knowledgeable and the 75 minute tour was a treat but hardly long enough. It's the sort of place you could spend the whole day in had you the opportunity. Buy a guide/ history book from the shop to complement your visit as photography is banned.

Brilliant Tour. Was great going into Parliament after seeing it so many times from the outside. The guide we had was brilliant. Very knowledgeable and answered all questions. You get to go into The House Of Lords and Commons. No photography allowed inside except Westminster Hall. Learnt more about the history in the 75 min tour than ever before.

The best in London!!!. The houses of parliament are by far my favourite building in London. The architecture is more than just impressive. The building is just stunning! I never get bored looking at it! The best view ever is from jubilee bridge seeing the houses of parliament and the London Eye at the same time! Love it! The must must must do in London!
Seen from outside. Looks much better than on the TV.Although we didn't go in we thought that this was a beautiful building and well worth visiting.

Imposing.... The Parliament building is just amazing ! Great architecture, imposing building ! Too bad that if you are not english, you are not allowed to vosot it from inside :(. Anyway, in one of its corners, right across the bridge, is the Big Ben, so you will shoot 2 rabitts in 1 shoot :).
Privileged. Wow!!!! This is most definitely a must go an see...it is fabulous, brings everything to life and reality and the thrill of actually standing on the same floors is exilerating

Fantastic Tour. We absolutely loved our visit to the Houses of Parliament. It was a marvellous experience to be in these hallowed halls made even better by a amazingly knowlegable guide. I actually wanted to go round again.It's a bit dam stupid that you can't sit down in the house of Lords/Commons though, especially for the older folks on our tour. They're actually worried we might wear out the leather on the benches! We paid for the leather in the first place!The carrot cake and coffee were superb too! Brilliant Brilliant Brilliant.
Out of a English movie. I liked the wigs and the suede seats. The feeling of Royalty you get when you walk in and take the stairs up. Breath taking art work every were you look.

Educational tour, more for teens and older. We were lucky to visit London at a time when tickets to tour the Houses of Parliament were available. It was a very educational tour. My husband who loves history especially enjoyed it. Our tour guide described the many rituals and traditions that the Houses still follow and honor today. My kids were a bit bored though. The tour groups tend to be somewhat large.

Stately Building in London. This is one of the places you must see while in London. It's a building that has survived a lot of troubled times. It's awe-inspiring to understand the history in the building. I would recommend this highly, especially for history buffs.

Iconic. If you're in London you have to get your picture taken on Westminster bridge with the Parliament in the background. Remember tho Big Ben is the bell in the clock tower not the clock tower itself !!
Impressive Trappings of Government. Lushly appointed and well maintained interiors were even more impressive than they appear on television or in print.

Must see. This is a must see for London, probably the most famous area of London. The architecture is beautiful, you are right downtown when you are here. I didn't go in, just had a look from the outside.

Extremely pleasant tour. We did not expect to have such a good time visiting the Houses of Parliament. First of all we only paid for 1 ticket using the National Railway Travelcard (gives one access to all means of transport within selected areas and benefits from the 2for1 website). The tour proved to be really interesting taking us through important rooms of the Parliament including House of Lords and House of Commons. It took 75 minutes and we extremely enjoyed finding out new interesting things from our guide Will. We were not allowed to take photos or sit in any of the rooms but still it was worth any minute. I will not tell more and spoil the fun....
Majestic. Wet minster Abbey is a great work of archetecture, it's worth a visit to see the Big Ben and the Abbey in its grandeur.

A very different Palace!. We arranged our tour through our MP's office, so were lucky enough to have a personally escorted tour by Sam - very entertaining, but also very knowledgeable about the history of the building and the whole political system of Britain. The building is amazing. The architecture inside and outside is fascinating. We spent over 2 hours there, longer than a normal tour, and could have stayed for longer, but we had other things to see and do.Try to do this on your visit to London - well worth an hour or two of your time.

Very Impressive Architecture. I was very impressed with the interior as well as the exterior of the Houses of Parliament. No body should miss the chance to visit them. Hundreds of years of history flashes in front of your eyes while touring the place. Beautiful paintings and other artworks are quite breath taking. Just imagine all the laws of the country are made in this masterpiece of a palace.

a wonderful tour. interesting and well done. a real feel of how parliament operates. A must during a visit to London. If possible try to get admission to parliament when in session to round out the experience, except the tour is not open when parliament in session

Very interesting. The place had a lot of history. It was even interesting how we were checked by security and given our own "badge" with photo which we kept as a momemto. We were allowed to sit in on the parlimentary debates. This process was interesting, but I have to admit, the speakers were not very interesting, perhaps it was the topic that we got.

Worth a visit to the seat of power!. Give it a go whether you follow politics or not its worth a visit! my wife, myself and the kids enjoyed the experience taking a peek at a little piece of living history.

Interesting, educational, and captivating.. We decided to do the guided tour on a whim as it started throwing it down. It cost £10 for a student and £15 for my mother, which wasn't too bad as the tour lasted 75 minutes and we were able to see a good amount of the building. Our tour guide was very good, she clearly knew her stuff and told us stories and histories of each room with humour. The internal architecture is absolutely amazing. It was so grand that it didn't look real. There were huge paintings of all the royals on the walls of almost every room. We were told all the history of the building and the government and all the traditions that are kept in place. I found it very educational and would recommend it.

a history lesson. having a private tour through one's mp's office made this tour memorable. finding the line of history to be anything but straight, we learned of the ancient lineage of a portion of the site, the royal residence for a portion of its time, the horrible fire which destroyed almost all of the building, and the relatively modern - 1830s - look of the structure. fascinating.

Educational. The tours of Parliment are only offered when Parliment is not in session so there are not many oppurtunities to tour. The guide we had was excellent providing history as well as current issues and humor into the one hour plus tour, Very educational.

Captivating. Took the tour of the houses of parliament on the spur of the moment and it was a great decision. Were led by an extremely knowledgeable and affable guide who answered all questions we could muster up. A very intimate tour as you get to see both the house of commons and the house of lords and everything in between. Some great art in there too. Well worth the entry fee.
Spectacular landmark. A must while in London, spectacular Big Ben and Houses of Parliament, steep in British history and gives you and inside of how the British Government works....
This is where politics are made!. The tour was extremely interesting. Shame that non-residents cannot listen in to sessions (when they are on). I would have repeated a visit.

Guided Tour of Houses of Parliament. This is will worth the money and even better on 2for1 offer when buying a National Rail train ticket. Very informative and definately had a wow factor, the history, paintings, decorations and an insight in to the House of Lords and Commons was really interesting, steeped in tradition. Well worth spending 75 minutes walking round. Would have liked a little longer to linger as so much to take in but security very tight inside so need to keep up with your tour guide.

Pomp and Circumstance.. From the initial entry into Westminster hall to departure, the tour is a succession of tradition and elegance all clarified by the enthusiastic and knowledgeable guides whose descriptions give life to the past and the present. The perfection of the Neo-Gothic design suggests a building far older than the bulk of it is. It is an essential visit for anyone with the slightest interest in history.

Amazing buildings and sense of history. Do not miss an opportunity to see the House of Lords and House of Commons. There is such a sense of history and buzz about the place. The rooms are amazing and there is the bonus of having lunch on the terrace overlooking the Thames
