Visits all the parts you know. An excellent value tour of an iconic landmark. Groups of about 25 are shown round by a knowledgeable guide and a good background history is given as you walk round. Both chambers of the house are visited, and the talks are given whilst you stand in the red and green benches which seem so familiar. The only place you are allowed to sit down is in the division lobby, where the voting procedure is explained before you file past the desks of the tellers which have seen so much history made. Highly recommended tour.

1000 years of history in 75 minutes. We've toured the Houses of Parliament twice (2005 and 2012). What is interesting is that each tour guide gives hi/her own perspective on the various events, so one tour may be very different from the other. Both of our guides were knowledgeable and interesting. I love British history with all of its little quirks and traditions. It is what makes Britain unique. Book ahead and avoid the lines. The only negative is that during the summer there are so many tours that often the rooms are crowded and you can't hear your tour guide (groups are sent out in stages, but often there are three or four groups of 20+ tourists in the same room at the same time). Also, if you can't stand/walk for 60+ minutes, there are no places along the route to sit.

Although the city was crowded, the tours were in smaller groups and the guide excellent.. The rooms were like a palace and the understanding we got on how British government works was very interesting.

Well worth a visit.. A tour of the Houses of Parliament is a must for anyone interested in the history of the UK. To walk in the footsteps of some of our great heros and to stand in the place where so much history has been created is a must. And if all the guides are as knowledgeable and humorous as Nigel you are in for a treat.
A fabulous experience!. thoroughly enjoyed the tour around and well worth a visit but you will probably have to wait until next summer before it opens to visitors again!

Seat of Power steeped in history. Was given a tour of the the Palace of Westminster which included a tour of the Westminster Hall, the House of Commons, the House of Lords, the Sovereigns entrance at Victoria tower, and the central lobby - posted a couple of postcards from there at the post office!

Fascinating, enjoyable, memorable - ticks all the boxes!. This really is a "must" for anyone - tourists and Brits alike. Whether or not you have an interest in British politics or not, the wealth of history in the Palace of Westminster is the attraction here. The tour guide we had was superb, and the historical facts, figures and anecdotes we heard were all mesmerising!It is fabulous to see inside both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Both look smaller "in real life", than one imagines, as does the Member's Lobby. It is fascinating standing in the latter and seeing the four statues of former Prime Ministers in each 'corner'. The highlight for me was seeing Westminster Hall, and being able to pause and admire all the amazing aspects of one of London's greatest places. Definitely worth a visit, and one you will remember!

What A Brilliant Tourist Attraction. Being a British citizen, I was thrilled to have visited the Houses of Parliament. What a wonderful insight and excellent value for money too at £15.00 per person and for probably a one time visit. The tour really was everywhere one would want to go. Beautifully decorated rooms of course. All of the famous rooms that we see on TV. I did not expect to actually get into the House Of Lords or Commons, but we did. We had a wonderful guide who also accompanied us from start to end. The brilliant Ian. Thank you for making our visit so satisfying.

Go if you can!!. We were lucky enough to get Saturday morning tickets as an after thought once we were already in London. If coming from the US look it up ahead of time and buy the tickets from TicketMaster!

Very good, and very worth the money.. I really enjoyed our tour of the Parliament buildings. Our tour guide was very enthusiastic and knowledgeable. The building is not only beautiful on the outside, but is absolutely gorgeous on the inside.
Simply stunning. Hundreds of years of history wrapped up in some of the most stunning architecture in the world - what more can I say.

What an education.. My wife and i took the tour on Saturday afternoon, our guide was wonderful knowledgeable and interesting. We would recommend the visit to anyone who has an interest in politics London or architecture you would not be disappointed. A beautiful building well explained keeps you gripped from start to finish, a Pugin masterpiece. LOVED IT!!!!The only down side is the ticket office where you have to stand out in the rain (should it be raining) not a great advert for Visit London, come on a little cover would not break the bank would it. For bargain hunters take along your Oyster card from the tube it gets you a buy on get one free.

Worth the visit. Despite many trips to London, I had never gone through parliament before. What a mistake. This was a great tour. the tourguide gave a good concise story of the history of the development of the British government and how the current system works. And the Building is stunning.
you can not imagine how big it is till you see it.. very old, fantastic details in every inch of the building. I only wished we could get inside to visit any part,

A London must see. Fascinating place to see, brought alive so well by our excellent tour guide. No audio tours here! Highly recommended for all except small kids. Reassured us that we have a truly democratic country. Check website as tours only on at certain times. Note that you need to arrive 20 mins before tour commences or 30 if collecting tickets. Enjoy it.

fascinating but busy!. Well worth going through the airport style security, the guide was interesting and well informed. However, its very busy and with three tours at a time in each room, it can be difficult to hear your guide against the other two and if there are crying babies, its very difficult!
Superb tour. We toured the Houses of Parliament and learned a lot about how business is conducted there. Very informative and entertaining. Highly recommend to anyone.

Beautifully kept building, shame about the people that work there!. Lovely building, tour was excellent and very descriptive. As walked around weren't 'allowed' to sit in House of Commons or House of Lords for whatever reason, these people forget who pay for the upkeep of these places!!!!! Not the tour guides fault I am sure, but ridiculous nevertheless!

Lucky enough to have a guided tour from our MP. Ask your MP to fix. Visit it is very interesting to see where it all goes on. We sat it the stranges gallery and watch PM's question time then a tour if the buildings.finished with tea and sandwiches overlooking the river. Very memorable.

Very enjoyable tour. Had a wonderful tour round the Houses of Parliament yesterday morning, well worth a visit and well worth the £15. Our tour guide was great, she knew her stuff! Its wonderful to see everything, all the spendour and hear all the history. The tour itsself is a good 75 minutes long

beautiful buildings. such beautiful buildings, the London which everyone see's on the tv. there is so much to do around here too - westminster abbey, a short walk to downing street and buckingham palace! so much history and definitely worth a visit.
cannot miss. The details of the architecture are amazing .. you feel inspired just standing there ..... the around it is very touristic and welcoming.

Learned so much. This tour is a wonderful learning event. The beautiful building and all of the long held traditions were great to learn about. Some of the torrid past of the parliament was included in the tour. :)

A "must visit" when in London. We booked on line before leaving home. Easy to find our entrance and going through security (as in like the airport) was efficient. Our tour leader introduced herself and we were approx 20 in number, all different nationalities but all of us understood English. The tour takes in a number of rooms and although there are up to 3 other tour parties in the same room sometimes, it didnt detract from the very knowledgeable information our leader was giving. While you are requested to keep up with your particular tour group there is still plenty of time to take in almost everything, although we do plan a return trip as we both came out with information that the other had missed! You aren't allowed to take any photos except in the Great Hall where you gather for the Tour but there is a good shop full of souvenirs should you wish.The tour takes approx an hour and a half - time definitely worth spending here.

Been there loads of times, will be back!. The Houses of Parliament is a very nice monument in London.It has been there for many many years and is one of the greatest landmarks in England.I have been there many times myself and it is always a great experience to see The Houses of Parliament.We will be back again soon to see the fabulous monument again!
August Bank Holiday Break. Obviously not able to enter however it is an extremely amaxing building. I was not aware that it was only the bell that is known as Big Ben

Fascinating Visit. It took us a long time to get round to visiting here even though we live in London. Having finaly made it we were so glad we did, Westminster Hall where we started of was awesome, what a "ceiling"! The guide tour was excellent, we learned so much, the works of art were fascinating.
Brilliant tour. Very interesting and the tour guide was very informative. Great to visit the house of lords and house of commons.

The Houses of Parliament. I visit the House of Commons at least twice a month for meetings, and was once taken on a tour of the House of Lords. Besides, in the 1970s I worked there for a member of parliament. You need t o remember that although built in the gothic style it is not as old as it looks, it burned to the ground in the 19th century and was completely rebuilt, although Westminster Hall, which is the part from which visitors exit is genuinely very old. It would take too long to write about all the parts of interest but if visiting London, it is essential to visit the Mother of Parliaments. The only drawback is the long queues and searches, for which we can thank the terrorists, when I worked there, security was much less of a nuisance.

More interesting than I thought it would be.. Was given this tour as a treat, and frankly thought it would be a bit dull.But what a fascinating place it is, much more history to it than just politics.And it is good to see that these buildings are being preserved in their original state.One of the biggest surprises was when you enter the house of commons it is much smaller than one thinks.Lords end very grand. It gives you an insight into what goes on daily when parliament is in session. Recommend this as it is a useful 'add on' to say Westminster Abbey or the london eye as it is 75 minutes long.
Vist to Houses of Parliament. Very interesting but too busy. We were ruched round and becsaue of security could not go back to look at anything. Therefore not really good value for money.

Thoroughly recommended. Brilliant tour of the Palace of Westminster. We went out of session, so were able to visit both houses of parliament along with the throning room and various others. We learnt an awful lot about the history of the palace and the country as a whole.
Excellent. A very interesting and thorough tour of the parliament buildings. A great way to spend an afternoon.

should be top of your list of sights. Great tour guide and good insights into British political life
Extremely tight security and lots of simultaneous tours
Stunning Tour. I took part in a pre-booked tour of the House of Parliament and all I can say is go go go. The buildings are simply breathtaking and the tour guide was informative, polite and fun.
lovely view. great view of old parliament - very postcard. once you have seen it you woulf not need to go back but its worth visiting once

Imprressive. Well worth a visit. Fascinating history & impressive chambers. A wonderful atmosphere with plenty of friendly welcoming staff around. Good restuarants altho the toilets need to be improved.

Do not miss this. Fantastic value we were there over 2 hours. The Lords are breathtaking made us proud to be British. Our guide was very knowledgable but fun. Entrance fee was reasonable a must see in London.

Fantastic walk through history of the UK. I've walked past this wonderful building many time and have only just visited it - and what a pleasre. An absolutely amazing historic building spanning a thousand years of history.
The tour guide was excellent explaining the working of parliamentary and the history and the relationship with the monarchy. Fantastic!

Excellent and informative. If you are interested in the mother of parliaments , then a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament is an essential Part of your education. The tour takes about 75minutes and takes in all the areas that you see so often on the TV. The guide was extremely knowledgeable and introduced lots of details .

Take the Tour. Use your Oyster card to get a discount and take this tour of the Lords and Commons. Excellent guides take you on a 75 minute tour of Parliament. Interesting, informative and thoroughly enjoyable. A must do when you visit London.

Prime Ministers Question Time. We applied in advance to our local MP for tickets to see Prime Ministers Question time - these were free and the experience was wonderful. It was when Tony Blair was PM. We felt very privileged to be taken past security into the areas not usually permitted to the throngs of tourists and seeing all the pomp and ceremony surrounding proceedings was fascinating.

Stunning and very interesting. I can highly recommend a visit if you are in London during the summer. It really is fascinating. The tour starts and finishes in the stunningly beautiful and old Westminster Hall and then you proceed through into the gallery and the Queens Robing Room and then both the Lords and Commons as well as the division lobby and the central lobby with the statues of ex- Prime Ministers that you often see on TV. It was a real revelation. My son and I were both amazed at how small both chambers are and can certainly understand now why the Commons is so noisy sometimes. Our tour guide was a lady called Enid who was a wealth of knowledge and told us loads of details about the history of the building and the contents and facts about MPs and the parliamentary process. The only thing I would say is that I don't think it would be suitable for anyone who can't stand for long periods as there is very little opportunity to sit down and the tour lasts for approx 90 minutes.It is a very strict rule that nobody is allowed to sit on the benches in the Commons or Lords!

The Mother of all Parliaments - A lesson in History. If you are coming to London during the summer and want to learn a little of our history, this is a great way to do it in a short time. You begin in the oldest part of the Palace, - the House of Parliament is in fact still a Royal palace, and then in 75 mins or so you visit the Royal Gallery, the Robing room, both the House of Lords and the House of Commons, the Lobby between the two and the 'Aye' voting lobby. Our guide Simon was very knowledgeable but also made a few jokes - we Brits are very good at making fun of ourselves and our history as we have so much of it! My 12 year old was fascinated and that is a huge endorsement! By the way the food in the cafe was great too!

the quintessential introduction to london. one mustn't go to this city without popping in to see the ministers of parliament and take a gander at big ben. a beautiful building, full of centuries of history, next to the thames, and within walking distance of many other hisotric sites...not to be missed.
Architectural gem!. What a pretty architectural landmark of London. Big Ben is beautiful. There is a nice little park in front of it and Westminster Abbey is aslo a neighbor.

Beautiful!. The best part of our stay in London. We were so lucky the parliament was on holliday so we could visit the House of Lords and the House of Commons etc. etc. We were overwhelmed by the beautiful rooms, wallpaintings an had a fantastic lady showing us around.

maybe the most evocative view of democracy. which ever angle you view the house it is humbling to see this bastion of democracy and tradition form a boat from westminster pier on the bridge or stod outside with all the other gaping tourists it is a most impressive and wnderful easily recognisable view of deocracy tradition and many colourful personalities and earth moving events see and believe!!!!

The true grandeur of the parliamentary heritage!. Absolutely glorious interiors, with incredible decor and real sense of history. Very interesting and thorough tour which explains the parliamentary history and the relationship with the monarchy. Very worthwhile and inspiring.

Outstanding tour. Great tour by a blue badge guide. We visited the Queen's room, House of Lords and House of Commons. Amazing to in the benches where Parliament sits (not just in the galleries above as at the U.S. Capital).

Fantastic Building. Standing on the banks of the River Thames is where the two Houses of the Parliament (the House of Lords, and the House of Commons) conduct their sittings. A place where laws are debated and passed. The Palace of Westminster used to be the royal home to the Queens and Kings of England, from the middle of the 11th century until 1512. What a great place to visit. Highly recommended.

Take a tour if possible. Before coming to the Houses of Parliament try to contact your MP and request a tour. We have been to several events at the Houses of Parliament and really enjoyed them - particularly taking drinks of the terrace. Lots of history, and you can sit in the gallery to see history in the making.

Sense of all That Governs. Stunning building, iconic location and well worth a visit to see the centre point of governing and commons. Located next to the square and thames, you can take the tour then wander around the area and breathe in the history.
Always great coming here. Really gives you a real Insight into our history. The architecture is awe inspiring. It's a great tour, with lots of history and snippets of info you might not have known!

Fantastic visit. SO interesting. It was great seeing the Queen's robing room and actually getting into both the House of Commons and Lords. Our guide ( all visits are guided) was interesting, knowledgeable and had plenty of anecdotes to relate. Visit was about 1hr 15 minutes and you can't wander off alone. You must stay with the guide for security reasons.

Wow. Guide was very nice and exceedingly well informed. It's amazing to see all of those rooms and understand the history, and what goes on there today. I thought I knew -- had no idea. My husband said it was the best thing we did during our month there. Great experience.
Well worth a visit!!. We had a great tour guide who made the information interesting and witty! No photos inside, lovely coffee shop,

Amazing building!. Absolutely stunning building, the immensity of it is just breathtaking! We didn't have time to do the inside tour of the house of commons or lords but we would have done, so interesting.
Excellent. During the summer you can book tours online and they are well worth it. The guides are great and the groups not too big. It is a fascinating and great experience.

Tour Guide Makes the Difference. We toured Parliament in August and our tour guide, Tony, was wonderful. He shared many anecdotes and explained how British legislation works with a dry sense of humor. You are on your feet for most of the visit and it could be a bit on the long side if you aren't interested in history or politics. I overheard some other guides on tours (which are given in 4-5 different languages) and I don't think they were as captivating as ours. Thanks Tony!

If you can manage a tour, don't miss this!. It's not always easy to get into the Houses of Parliament, but if you can swing it, be sure to take the tour. Very impressive outside, and even more so on the inside! The tour was very informative, and very interesting. I learned a lot of historical anecdotes that I'd never known before.
Gorgeous Architecture. Viewed the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben from Southbank, across Westminster Bridge over the Thames at sunset last Sun., 12 Aug.

Houses of Parliament. The Houses of Parliament are full of historic significance due to the various governments who have sat in the house past and present. Also it has Big Ben attached to it, it is close to Westminster Abbey, Whitehall and other tourist attractions, it is a long road or short bus ride away from Trafalgar Square. It is a beautiful building architecturally, there are lots of tourists as you can imagine but at various points on Westminster Bridge you can get great shots. You are able to arrange a 75 minute tour and watch debates and see a piece of British political history being made. Well worth a visit - it is advisable to plan your tour in advance.

The seat of Briitsh legislation. It's changed a lot, in terms of access and security. Because of the 1970's IRA bombs, it's hard to get in and if you are just a member of the public and queuing, you couyd be waiting for hours. If you are British, try and arrange a private invitation from your MP. Most of them put groups together and will be happy to welcome you for a guided tour.

Tour of Houses of Parliment. We had an excellent tour of both houses with the assistance of a guide and I would highly reccommend it to anyone with even the slighest of interest in History.Its open for tours in August.

Great Whirlwind of British Government. Now I know why people complain that the tour of the US Capitol building is too short. I paid 15 pounds to take a 1 hr 15 min tour of the Houses of Parliament led by a knowledgeable staff.Underlying theme to the tour: "Do Not Sit on Anything". You get to go through both the Lords and Commons areas and stand in front of the seats, though you can't sit on them. You walk through the rooms used by the reigning monarch to change into their robes prior to opening Parliament. You also get to go through one of the "Yes" and "No" halls (where you can finally sit). I'm pretty sure you're not allowed to have strollers on the tour, so not recommended for young children.The content of the tour itself is sufficient to teach you a little bit about the British government but by no means is a replacement for a textbook. There's an unspoken assumption that the people on the tour either know about how the government is structured or comes from a country that has a similar governmental structure. Luckily for me the US government is sort of built similarly so not a giant leap, but if you're coming from communist China then I'd recommend reading up on the form of government before taking the tour.Mainly adults and teenagers in my tour group. There was one 7 yr old English girl, and I could tell a lot of the content was going over her head as she constantly had a puzzled look on her face, plus she was so tired after walking around and only being able to sit once during the entire tour. Again, I don't recommend it for people with young children as the attention span just isn't there yet.A few mind boggling things for Americans: House of Lords seats aren't voted on by the public but rather are either hereditary or life-term assignments for people knighted etc by monarch. Made me stop and think "Wait, what?" for a good long time. There's no veto power or checks and balances. If Commons and Lords disagree then Commons overrules (or that's what I was led to believe). Prime Minister is not voted on by public but rather is selected from within the majority party in the House of Commons. As an example: the Dems have the Senate and Republicans the House, with Pres. Obama a democrat, but under the British system, the president would really be a republican and Pres Obama merely the opposition leader with no input from the public at all.Highly recommend this tour and worth the 15 pounds.
Fantastic!. Loved it, the history is so rich. Had a meal ther and the food was so good. I felt like I was really in a special place.

An education. We walked along the footsteps of those before. WRITE TO YOUR MP (doesnt matter if you agreed or don't) and request a visit. Everyone should go in the UK! The house of Lords just blows you away!

Legendary. Can't even describe what's like to be in front of this building. It was surprisingly beautiful and overwhelming...Awesome! Got the luck of seeing it at night with slideshows on its walls during the Olympic Games. Epic!

A slice of history. I was lucky enough to be invited here with a group of children by our local MP and giventhe grand tour. It is beautiful and fascinating, with so many interesting stories. All people we met were kind, professional and eager to talk to us. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
So much smaller than on the TV !!. Our fantastic tour guide made this a really interesting visit. The rooms look so much bigger on TV though ! Quite suprised how compact they are.

Wasn't even aware we could go in. We weren't aware that we could go in the Houses of parliament. We would have definitely wanted to check out the interior. But the outisde is amazing and you could stand there for ages looking at it and taking pictures from all angles. It is a stunning sight from every direction.

It's Right There!. If you are going to see Big Ben, you will see the Houses of Parliament. Whether you take the tour or not, it is a great sight. The architechture is amazing! A great photo op, and Westminister Abbey is across the street! You will want an entire day in this area alone when you visit London. If you have only one day...this is the area to visit!The lines were longer than I had time for when I was there, unfortunately...so make certain you work that into your plans when you decide to visit this historical area, if you want the tour.

Houses of Parliament. It's a beautiful building! I wish everyone to have the chance to see it. The view from London eye is unbelievable! I was only shocked by a message on the fence that you could be killed if you try to jump over the fence. I walk away faster as i read it. :D Even though, go and see it. You will never forget it. :)

Great Tour, Good cafe. I've done tours of the US Capitol through my congressman and now Parliament. The Parliament tour was much better. The tour was better organized with smaller groups and it was much more informative. It's not a cheap tour but about on par with other tours in London. You have to book early and tickets can be printed online. Right next door to Westminster Abby. Very easy to do both on the same day with time left over to see the Churchill War Rooms. Parliament tour isn't the greatest for small kids. My teenage daughter was bored, but at 16 she still behaved. One note...they are serious about not chewing gum and staying with the group....as you'd expect.Cafe was great for afternoon tea. Very reasonably priced. Gotta have the clotted cream with a scone.
Go on a tour with local mp. My hubby booke dme a tour with my local MP. It is excellent tour and very informative. Building is amazing and steeped in history

Beautiful building but Big Ben not so BIG!. After taking 10 photos of Big Ben there really wasn't anything more to do there and you become more interested in Westminster Abbey across the street. Nice to have in the photo album but not really the most memorable expirience you'll have in London

Must see when in London. Didn't pay to go inside but the views and photo opportunities are fantastic.Located right next to the Thames, a short walk to The London Eye, across road from Westminster Underground Station and the nearby riverboat pier.Great experience to hear Big Ben (the bell) chime on the hour.Within walking distance to Downing St and obviously Westminster Abbey.Right across road is a Tesco for snacks etc

Great experience of democracy.. Went here to lobby my MP as part of Trade Union delegation. Whilst there had a tour of the working areas of Parliament. Have been in the past as a more casula visitor and the guided tours are great and welll worth geting reservation for the public gallery for PM question time.

Go on the tour. Most people come to see the building and look at it from the outside but the tour gives you a detailed history of the place and a good explanation of how it works. The security is thorough but straightforward. The tour begins in Westminster hall and takes you through all the main rooms of the building incliding the Queen's Robing room, the House of Lords and the Commons. The guides give you lots of details about the story of the building and explains many of the statues and paintings that you see as well as throwing in plenty of quirky litle facts. The only disappointment is that you are not allowed to take photos apart from in Westminster hall. There are only certain places you are allowed to sit down (not allowed in the Lords or the Commons!) but the tour lasts about an hour so it is manageable for most people. Well worth the £15 and you need to book in advance.

Well worth it .... It was a good tour which was greatly informative. As a Brit I thoroughly enjoyed seeing inside the Houses of Parliament and needless to say the history is immensley fascinating.One negative is that you are severly restricted as to what you can do on the tour. You have to stand for pretty much the whole 1.5 hours, no photography is allowed and security officers watch on like hawks .... For me this made it less enjoyable. But it is still well worth doing and for £15 a head it is pretty good value for money!
Spectacular. Very much enjoyed this tour. The guide said they are all a little different but we were able to get right into each chamber -- how small it all is -- and the guide was most interesting.

It requires some advance planning..... Plan ahead and get tickets to tour inside Parliament. It is worth the effort to wander through the halls of history and hear the stories of British government through out the years. A must do if you can sort it out.

Outstanding if you are interested in history/politics. I came here with moderately high expectations and these were exceeded. The tour brings you into direct contact with everything-nothing behind glass cases etc..-all available to see and expereince at first hand. You can even get to stand at the dispatch box and get full access to the house of commons and lords. Our Tour guide was fantastic-informative, entertaining, not patronising and a pleasure to listen to. I get the impression she wasn't the only excellent guide and overall I'd rate this as one of the best attractions in London

The place so much history has been made. First: If you have an Oyster Card, show it when you buy your tickets because it gives you 50 per cent discount.The tour is very interesting (only guided tours are available, it's not possible to visit the place on your own). You wander around in the House of Lords and the House of Commons, see where history has been made. Unfortunately you are not allowed to take pictures and you are not allowed to sit down. A big plus is an enthousiastic guide who tells you some nice stories of things that happened. The tour lasts about an hour and 15 minutes and you will not be disappointed afterwards.

Good piece of Architecture. The building gives an excellent view from river Thames. Very well done historical monument. The attraction is futher added with Big Ben which adds more pictureque quality to grace your pictures.

A Great Guided Tour. The tour is very interesting. Our guide was well informed and set a good pace, though she was a little rude at points which seem out of place in such grand surroundings. I agree with previous reviewers about the issue with sitting down, a few chairs, now and again for the older visitors would have been more than welcome. The tour is a great insight into a great building and institution and well worth the entrance fee.
Amazing architecture. The building was so ornate and huge! It just seemed to go on and on. Would have loved to see inside!
A Westminster "must see". The whole Westminster area must be seen by any visitor. Then cross the bridge and walk down the South Bank past the London Eye. (But don't stop there!)

ABSOLUTELY GORGEOUS!!. The house of parliament and big ben are what wowed me the most as a tourist in london. The architecture of the house and big ben is amazing! Very classic and detailed and EXTREMELY breathtaking at night when the big ben is green at the top. Don't leave london without seeing this number attraction of London.
Not for kids. Daughter wanted to do this....I think she thought you saw inside big Ben( you didn't). I enjoyed it but the tour was long and boring for her ( she's 8)

Beautiful architechture. I love this neighbourhood. The Houses of Parliament are incredibly famous and absolutely beautiful. With Big Ben and Westminster Abbey right next door, what's not to love? It's fun being a tourist in London.
Huge. Although we couldn't go in, it is a phenomenal building and worth seeing. Tremendous. Also near many other points of interest.
facinating!!. i arranged a tour through my MP so it was free. this is a stunning building and you dot fully appreciate it from seeing it on TV. i would recommend this to anyone, its stunning

Well worth a visit. Have been here before on the normal small visit when you are escorted to the viewing gallery only. This visit I pre-booked on line and was during the MP's summer break and this tour was great. The security is airport style and expected, bags through scanning machine etc. but it makes me feel safer. You meet in the old Westminster Hall for the start of the tour and a great photo opportunity - although photographs are not permitted past this point, so I had to settle with buying postcards which they sell in the shop at the end of the tour. The tour guide was brilliant, lovely spoken, knowledgeable and friendly I learnt so much. It was great to visit both the House of Lords and the House of Commons (you are not allowed to sit on the seats though). I am so glad I arranged to go on this 75 minute tour so much history - would recommend it.
Amazing. Just wonderful , the tour bus offered hop on hop off and included a boat trip on the Thames , just fantatsic

Educational. The day I went i had just gotten off a 40 hour flight and had huge jet lag, that's probably why I couldn't keep my eyes open. If it wasn't for our funny tour guide and the interesting stories tough i would have fallen asleep. If you are interested in history or sitting on the same toilet that the Queen did I would try to drop by.

What a sight!. Just getting there to see the houses of parliament is a must-see. The buildings are incredible! I didn't go inside or anything, they were the last stop on the walking tour I went on (New Europe tours, free, for those interested), but there is a lot of history and stories associated wtih the houses and the architecture is awesome.
Great for photo opportunities. Great for photos and a history lesson for our young son linked into Guy Falkes. Also fab to visit so many other local attractions.
Very impressive!. Great way to spend a couple of hours.The building was very impressive with statues and artwork, that you really should make the time see.

Visit to Parliament. Although only available for booking on a Saturday if you have the opprotunity don't miss this excellent experience of visiting the Lords, Commons and the Queen's Robeing Room plus more
Great neighbourhood restaurant. Wonderful warm welcome, good humoured service, wide selection of wines and a kitchen that knows what it's doing. Well worth a visit to experience all the positives.
Stunning architecture. Wow, loved it... Britain has a lot of histroical culture/architecture to sing about about. Let's be proud of what we can offer our visitors!
Another favourite. The chance to go on the floor of both chamber was amazing. If in London this is a must. Tour guide was very knowledgeable and engaging.

More fascinating than you can imagine. First off this attraction was well worth it.You are first taken deep into the belly of the parliament and are actually in the centre of the decision makIng and leadership of the UK. I felt honoured by being given such free access throughout history.Here you'll see:Queen coronation roomThe House of CommonsThe House of LordsThe hall of Prime ministersTotal tour lasted 1.5 hours. Make sure you use the toilet before you go because there are not any opportunities to go to the bathroom once the tour has commenced.

Like a step into history. We visited on a very busy day. Parliament was in session with no tours given and the visitors gallery packed all morning because the prime minister was speaking and taking questions. The friendly usher at the visitor's entrance suggested we should return mid-afternoon. We did and had no problem receiving visitor passes. Naturally there is a good amount of security, but it didn't take too long to receive our visitor badges. We walked through the historical Westminster Hall which was both beautiful and historically significant in itself. We had to wait a short while on benches in a gorgeous corridor before being ushered up the nondescript stairs to the modern visitor's gallery. Discussion wasn't too riveting when we visited, but nevertheless, each time we see a session on the news, my son says "We were right there!" Photography is allowed in Westminster Hall and outside and there are some great picture spots. Really enjoyed our visit.
Parliament Tour. Make sure you get a tour- amazing place - you've never seen so much gold in your life!!! Very interesting historical tour

Beautiful. The chambers in the Parliament are very nice and interesting.Beautiful architecture. It feels like a step back in time. Sat in on an actual court proceeding while there. Beautiful history. The paintings and interior is also beautiful.
A piece of England. A must see if you are in London. A tourist attraction but not too busy. I suggest getting their early. Nice photos in this area.

Interesting, if not too crowded.. We visited in the late afternoon when the crowds where gone. Got through security quickly and where in the Lord's Chambers within 15 minutes. There was a long boring discussion about registering voters, so we looked around and stayed for about 10 minutes. The chambers themselves are very nice and interesting, but I would have hated to wait for a long time to see them.

A WOW. We dont have buildings like this in the states so this was a real WOW for us. BIG Ben was so cool and the tour of the parliment was excellent. We had a real "English Gent" and was very informative.
We really enjoyed this!

Very Cool. Not many tourists, but very cool to visit.
Lots of security layers before getting in, so give yourself lots of time to get in.
Nice to take a photo of. Not that exciting in my opinion, though I am a teenager. The most exciting thing was to see big ben. Overall average

Worth the money. If you like politics and history, the visit of the Houses of Parliament is worth the money. The only thing is that visits are only given on Saturday. There is always the free option of going to see the House of Commons or the Senate while they are sitting and which can be real fun depending on the subject of the day.
Iconic- I had to pinch myself. Easy to get to and well worth the trip. It felt like I was in a dream!. The weather was so kind to us- only drizzled a couple of times

Must see!. I organised this trip for my partner as he really wanted to go and I was very pleasantly surprised. The building is amazing and the guided tour is really good. It is great to see in real life what you have seen so many times on the television! The history is really interesting to learn and we really enjoyed the whole experience and would really recommend it.

very interesting. still in London whilst my wife was at a conference, and a little more time to spare, i decided to have a look at our seat of Government. these isn't much of a delay as one passes through the various security measures and once inside it is certainly and inspiring building. i decided to have a look at the actual Commons Chamber whilst it was in session and again passing through another small security check (hand over phones, cameras etc) i entered the viewing gallery. sadly, there wasn't much on at the time (just a few MP's wittering on)so i didn't stay long. however, it was well worth a visit and the staff are very helpful
What to love about London. Attracts hundreds of visitors on a daily basis. London residents should be proud of our history and beautiful buildings

Nice. It is always nice to see iconic buildings and such. My daughter doesn't remember seeing the Houses of Parliament when we brought her to London as a toddler of course. It was worth the visit just to see her face.
Pictures don't do them justice. Although we didn't go on a tour of the Houses of Parliament, they are visually stunning. Walk across the Thames over one of the bridges for the best view.
Authentically British. When you visit the Houses of Parliament, it feels like a step back in time - it really is great! The gift shop is also worth a visit for their chocolate and mints!

Amazing!. We got a private guided tour arranged through my local MP, anyone can request one. We were taken to see the House of Commons and the House of Lords tip go on a Friday when the Houses are not in session and you see even more like we did!

Great historical place to visit. Thouroughly enjoyed our tour. The guide was great knowledgable and gave us a very good historical background. Architecture is superb and the details behind the parliament procedure was very interesting. Highly recommend to visit this place.

Magnificent Architecture. Such a beautiful building with extremely gorgeous details, recommend to walk around the building from Wesminster Abbey to the other end. There is a small garden next to Thames, a perfect place to rest your tired feet.
Interesting. Learned what goes on in the houses of Parliament. Sat in on an actual court proceding while there. Do not visit 11:30 - 1:00 as this is lunch break and nothing is occuring.
Worthy of a visit if in London. Great place lots to see and informative tour, can get busy however so get there early or book a slot.
smaller than on tv,excellent experience. It was so interesting to see our roots, and watch debates. Go after 530 in the evening. We walked right in, no lines.

Beautiful History!. Loved that we could just walk in, and watch (OK, there was some security) Parliament at work. The beauty of the buildings, the history of the site, and the helpfulness of all the staff there made a short visit truly memorable.

Tour was very informative. Did an inside tour of the house of parliament. Learned so much. I can see that a lot of how the US was set up is based on the English government. The US house of representative is very similar to the house of parliament. The paintings and interior is beautiful.

Impressive!. We bought the tickets from ticketmaster for a guided tour about 2 months in advance. We of course took 1000s of pictures of the palace itself from the outside from all different angles. On the morning of the guided tour, it was raining heavily. We reached there at 10 for our 10.15 tour - had to wait in a long line and actually got in around 10.45 and the tour started around 11 am. So, once you are there the time didn't seem to matter. There were about 25 people in the group which I think is way too big a group to really engage with a tour guide. As first time visitors to UK, the information provided by the guide was interesting and fascinating although we over-heard different guides share different stories so there is probably lot more information that can be shared. However, after waiting in a long line to get in, the hour and half tour walking around seemed all that we could handle without lunch and with a young 7 year old. The palace is of course absolutely amazing and it was really interesting to hear how the Houses are formed and function. Definitely a MUST VISIT if you are going to London. We paid 15 GBP per person - totally worth it! Maybe going after lunch would help in enjoying the tour better without getting hungry and tired.

Can't fault it.. Dined here recently and if you ever get the chance, snap it up. Apart from the history, the surroundings, and the drinks on the terrace bar, the food is as good as you would expect it to be. The beef was gorgeous, just be careful of the home made horseradish - hot! Get your M P to invite you, unforgettable experience.
A must see. Any visit to London would not be complete without seeing this building. Wether close up, or if very lucky inside or even from across the river. Wonderful history.
National Treasure. Inhabited by a mixture of geniuses and blood-sucking leaches, but it's the centre of British Government and another historic must!

Houses of history. The houses of parliament are where history has been made. We lined up and went into the House of Lords while they were sitting. The discussions were boring but the atmosphere was electric to see where laws are made. You must walk through the 11thC

The Mother of all Parliaments.. I have visited both houses on different occasions as a parent helper on school trips and as a private citizen watching democracy in action. On one of the school visits wwe were escorted and guided around by a very knowledgeable chap who littered the historic stuff with anecdotes and titbits of little known history. The highlight of one visit was seeing the death warrant for Charles the First. The hairs on the back of my neck stood up.The private visit was especially memorable as we witnessed Seb (later Lord) Coe's maiden speech.Well worth a visit.

Very disappointed - building wonderful, guides inadequate. I booked this tour for my mother and we were both looking forward to it. I left the tour extremely angry at the waste of time and money. The palace and Westminster Hall in particular are wonderful but it is very poorly served by whoever it is that runs these tours.Our guide did not have sufficient knowledge: he didn't even know how many MPs there were and he was unable to identify the statues. I knew more than he did and we became very frustrated. Not only were we informed 4 times that our monarch was Queen Elizabeth II but in such a fawning manner that we cringed with embarrassment (and neither of us are anti-monarchist). I couldn't stand the patronising level of commentary and was desperate to leave. I was angry at being charged for such tripe. It seemed that the tour was heavily pitched towards non-UK visitors with a poor grasp of English. We asked to change groups because of the pitch of the guide and were basically told to put up with it. If you are a UK / Commonwealth citizen with a modicum of knowledge of our constitution decide whether the entry price is worth entry to Westminster Hall and Palace - NOT the tour. I suggest whoever runs the tours to visit the Cabinet War Rooms, the Globe Theatre or Hampton Court where they treat all their visitors with respect and intelligence.
Great for adults. Wouldn't take the kids. Loved the history and pomp. A bit long, but good value and interesting. not everyone would have the patience for it. I liked it !

Don't go on the paid tour, visit in session and watch democracy in action for free!. The Mother of Parliaments is a fantastic building to see in its own right, but if you factor in the historic events (such as where various famous people lay in state) and the art collection, it is well worth a visit even before the theatre of the House of Commons. If you go when in session, you can ask to visit the public gallery and should not have to pay. Or you can put a card in to ask to speak to your MP. S/he may not come to see you but it is your right to lobby him or her. You may find the actual debates rather staged and not very illuminating, despite The Speaker's best efforts. And the House of Lords looks like a lot of old wax work dummies - can this really be representative democracy? But the inmates add to the charm of the place.

Go inside!. My husband and I weren't sure if we could go inside Parliament, but after a certain time, you can go inside! We went in at night, after all the crowds and I think there may have been 5 of us there so it wasn't too crazy. We thought it was so neat to see a live debate- a great time.
Amazing place to visit. The architecture impress any one, and reminding us everithing we have learned in school about London history

Incredibly ornate. Fascinating tour. Great to hear all the stories and see for yourself sights you only see on the news. Absolutely beautiful building. Well worth a visit. We went at 11am on a Monday morning and hardly had to queue at all.

Integral to London Visit. Twenty five years ago when my spouse and I first went to London, we were not allowed to enter this building but when access was allowed for our trip this year, we made it a point to go. Guides were appointed to escort groups through the various rooms. Our guide explained the rooms, their individual functions/history, etc. quite adequately. Now when we see these particular places on the news stories, we will have a better understanding of what is taking place and where it's happening! This tour is perhaps not recommended for small children. There is a cafeteria with a number of offerings available if your visit falls around a mealtime--we were satisfied with our refreshments.We would see this again.
Architectural gem!. TWestminster Hall is amazing as are the rest of the building! Too bad only Westminster Hall can be phtographed.
Interesting. Enjoyable if a little rushed, to keep up the flow with the other groups, intense security be warned they dont mess about and dont like you to take photos.

Fascinating place. We booked online from Australia so we would be sure not to miss out on the Houses of Parliament Tour. We were so glad we did - the tour is extremely popular and really worth while. Get there before your tour time as there is a queue to go through security before being admitted to this magnificent building. The security personnel are very courteous and efficient.Our guide was excellent - she explained the history and the workings of the Houses eloquently and with some humour. Visitors are divided into small groups so it is easy to hear and see everything described on the tour. We saw the opening ceremony of Parliament on television a few weeks after our visit and it was great being able to identify the rooms and to understand the procedures as they had been explained to us on the tour. Possibly our favourite tour in London.
The Mother. Apart from the history - the architecture is stunning.
great architecture. a must see! you can't miss it anyway! it's huge! liked it so much my Mom is going in September.... :)

Not to be missed. As expected, we had to go through security screening to enter the main premises. The security enforcers were very courteous.Our guide was very clear and thorough in her narration and presentation of historical facts. The building is beautiful, inside and out with a very rich history to add character to the whole experience. It would have been nice to walk about a little bit more but security does not allow, understandably so. They have a nice little cafe where you can snack before or after the tour. They also have a nice gift shop. Will definitely be back!
A tick on my list!. One of the classics you must do, would recommend for older people!

Not to be missed. We are a family of five who stopped in to see parliament in action. It was an accident really as we just got into the city and popped up at Westminster to walk around. We learned that parliament would be "going late" that night and we should come back later to watch. We did just that - the building itself is really well done and watching the arguments live is just "like on BBC" which made it really fun and educational for the kids - well the older ones :) I highly recommend it!
Great Tour. We took some American friends on this tour, the guides are great and you learn a lot about our history.

Tour Parliament. We booked for a tour one Saturday and we were thoroughly impressed. Our guide was knowledgable and interesting and the place is just amazing! You get a real sense of the grandeur of the Royal State room and the House of Lords, then back to reality with the functionality of the House of Commons. Westminster Great Hall is beyond amazing, and to realise how many years it has survived!The cafe is a welcome brew stop at the end of the visit!I would recommend this tour for anyone who wants to learn a bit and admire a truely magnificent building.
Common Lords. Take the opportunity for a tour in the House of Lords/Commons - lots to see and learn about - but don't sit on the benches!

Architecturally stunning. A very impressive building with high vaulted wooden atrium. You can feel the history of what has passed in its halls. There is also a really nice little park next to it that gives you a great view of the river and surrounding buildings.
The House of Lords in action. The long wait was worth it. Seeing the magnificent Houses of Parliament and watching one of the debates in the House of Lords made for an interesting hour.
Wow!. The House of Parliament was on our tour of London. Although we did not even attempt to enter, we were able to take some awesomme pictures outside.
Fascinating!. The Saturday tours are fantastic. I thought I was reasonably good with my political history but learnt soooo much from the tour guide!
Parliament. Try and arrange a tour, its a great place to visit, historic venue of London with the well known clock "BEN"..
Interesting. Sat in the gallery behind the plexiglass for around 10 minutes to see Parliament in action. Not many senators there to listen to the others drone on.

Super Tour. Visited with a pile of children last year when the House was not in session. We took the guided tour which was both informative and amusing with the tour guide telling us lots of little anecdotes. The staff were all charming and helpful, even the security people. The children adored the experience and I would encourage anyone - not just Brits - to take this tour. Truly excellent!
Fascinating to watch how country is governed. Being able to actually see Ministers voicing their opinions and those of their constituants but also observing some who were asleep!

Great in person. Having seen so many pictures of Big Ben and the surrounding buildings, I was afraid seeing them in person would be a letdown. It wasn't. Start your London trip by looking at this building. It sets the mood for the rest of your adventures.

Great to see but not worth the lines. I went there with a group as part of a university course. My suggestion is to see the outside of it and be done. The only reason to wait in line is on Wednesdays to see if the Prime Minister is there. The House of Lords is very beautiful and there is normally not a huge wait. The House of Commons is plainer on the inside but you just have to keep your fingers crossed they are debating an interesting topic that day. Otherwise it isn't worth the queues.
beautiful. the best bit about this is the building itself it is amazing the structual work is very grand
Go inside. We witnessed a heated debate for free and with a short wait. Everyone is welcome inside. Just an impressive place inside and out. Something you can say you did.

History lesson in stone. Do the guided tour. Our guide was excellent and we were given insights that were completely new to me. You get to see both houses. We also dined in one of their halls as part of a special dinner arranged by a member of parliament. This venue was south facing and had views of the river.

This is a "must do" sightseeing venue. Often seen on television but that does not reveal the sheer size and magnificence the place. Hearing about the history of the building, the customs developed over the centuries, seeing the Lords and Commons debating chambers and much, much more was extremely interesting. Excellent tour guide.Needless to say, security is very tight.

Houses of Parliament. I saw this in September a couple years ago & enjoyed it so much. I loved the stories that the tour guide relayed to us the most. While I wasn't that interested in British Politics, It is the only way to get into the Great Hall which is the last remaining part of the Palace that used to stand there. I had to see it.

A must for any brit!!. The conducted tours are excellent and it is amazing when you are taken into various areas and have old sayings explained to you and their relevance to the House a definate must be seen attraction.
What an experience!. This is worth seeing just to say you have been there! Staff so amazingly pleasant and just well organised and such a stunning place - not saying any more - just go!
very interesting. lots of great architecture and big ben,great pics at night when buildings and big ben light up

Shockingly great. We went here with two teenagers thinking it might be a bore but it might be one of our favorite tours, extremely interesting. Our guide was Russell and he was hilarious and extremely knowledgeable. Abit aof a pain as you have to buy the tickets across the street and then go thru security but well worth it.

Fabulous visit. Went to both House of Lords, and House of Commons and watched the proceedings. Didn't realize the HoL is so much more ornate and grand than the HoC. Also the HoC has so much more security in the visitors' gallery. Sort of makes the visitor to the HoC feel more suspect.

Well worth viewing a piece of British HIstory. If you are able to obtain tickets to view the inside of the HoP, it is a must on any itinerary, it is great to see the 'seat of power' of this country and there is so much history
Who Knew?. The Houses of Parliament are BEAUTIFUL inside! You have to go and see the decor. Lovely. Awesome. Surprising.

Very old and very beautiful!. You cannot be in London without seeing the clock and buildings. We did not go on the indoor tour but we enjoyed the wonderful views along the River Thames. Another must in London!

Once in a life chance. I ended up by luck visiting this place. It was a sunny day and i strolling near and saw that it was open for visiting on that day.
Loved! it's was great to see a place were so many important decision were made and the guides were older ladies who know the history of the place really well.

very interesting. It was a very interesting visit where we learnt interesting facts and stories. The only negative was that we were rushed through the place and our tour guide couldn't finish all of his stories. Moreover the visitor groups were very close to each other and we couldn't hear the guide properly. It is only a matter of organization, the Parliament is great overall!
interesting !. for all those with a political bent of mind or interest I would highly recommend visiting the parliament while in session and watch live proceedings from the visitors gallery.

The home of modern democracy. For an ex-Tour Guide at Ausrtralia's Parliment House, it has been a wonderful experience to visit these historic buildings... I have sat in both chambers to listen to debate (on International Women's Day), and also enjoyed a fantastic tour. Well worth the time & slight inconvenience of security to take a good look.

Lovely to View. While we did not go inside for the tours, it was lovely to wander around the outside, the view along the Thames is lovely. Naturally we saw the clock tower, now known as the Elizabeth Tower. You cannot go up in the Clock Tower. Tours of Parliament are pricey, but if you are into that thing, I am certain it's worth it.
A good debate see the future forming. Good to see the tradition some of the debates are boring

The Mother of all Parliaments? Interesting to See. I went on a visit with an expert guide so we were able to hear a little about why the place is so strange and so small for the number of people who work in it. I was able to walk inside the House of Lords during my visit, as it was not sitting, but not the House of Commons as it was and a vote had just been called.VERY recommended visit but be sure not to carry anything that could be viewed as a threat as the officials are very careful of security after a few well publicised incidents over recent years.

Finally, on the 5th trip the attempt was a sucess. After trying for years, we went about 6:00pm on a overcast and rainy day. There was no line by the Cromwell statue and only a 15 minute wait to go through security below. We saw both the Houses of Commons and of Lords. The throne that the Queen sits on to open Parliment in Lords was stunning, as well as the hammerhead beams and other ornamentals and paintings in the passages. We listened to debates and found very similar dilemas to those in the U.S. being discussed. Its amazing that discussions in these rooms formed the basis for the present world order, through political sway, courage, and sheer determination of mind!
Could there be a better photo-op location? :). This place, along with Big Ben and the Tower/London Bridge, is an icon. Go there. See it. (The Abbey has a fee though)
Comedy club. PMQs is a must. The tour is fantastic the guides are excellent

Saturday openings. We were lucky to arrive on Saturday morning and get tickets for a tour starting in less than an hour. We were told to get in line a half hour before our tour start due to security. That really wasn't true because they checked your tour time when you arrived and late comers were able to go to the head of the line.The interior of the palace is as impressive as the exterior. The tour begins in a great hall which is the only part of the building where photo taking is allowed.The tour takes about 90 minutes and includes both the Houses of Commons and Lords as wll as descriptions of the voting process.We enjoyed it.

The mother of all parliaments - superb in every respect. The tours around both houses and the palace of westminster in general are superbly informative experiences. You get the background to all the important events in UK history as well as learning what goes on behind the scenes day-to-day. You can marvel at The Great Hall and stand by the despatch box in The House of Commons.Security airport-style is tight - but all the better for ...
Beautiful Architecture. Really insightful and beautiful architecture that will take your breath away

Big, beautiful and historic. It is also known as Westminster Palace, and is a really beautiful big construction. It’s also famous because of the watch tower, the famous Big Ben. Good pictures can be taken from the bridge in front of it, but try to be quick when there are no cars passing (rare situation). To get there: The nearest Underground station is Westminster.

Beautiful Building. One of the most beautiful buildings we've ever seen. Unfortunately, we did not have tickets to get inside and ran out of time. We would have loved to see the inside as well. Big Ben is amazing!

grand and historic. Our guide was a kind, informative lady. The building itself was beautiful and filled with wonderful paintings and pieces of art that I would have liked to have had the time to examine more closely, but they keep close track of everyone and hurry you along due to the numbers of other tourists.
Good Tour. The tour of Parliament takes about 90 minutes and is led by knowledgable guides. It includes tour of the House of Commons and the House of Lords

If you like to fell as a King/Queen. It is interesting to see how British Houses of Parliament work.
Wonderful tour but to bad its possible only in summer time!
Stunning architecture. Sadly, people are not allowed to enter. But Big Ben and the parliament look really amazing from outside
Beautiful.. Stunning architecture. But we couldn't get in to see it so it's difficult to tell more than the outside of the building.

My favorite building in London. Easy to get to,msitting along the Thames River, I encourage at least a stop by the famous landmark. I , unfortunately did not get there on a Saturday, the ONLY day tours to the public are offered. Still, we spent time enjoying the architecture the day we went.
Visit. Brilliant monument not to be missed. A good explanation and tour

Just brill. Lots of historical background, interesting little facts, and keeps of personality. The tour is just long enough so one doesn't loose interest. My husband, my friend, and myself really enjoyed it.Oh, and we forgot to take our pre-booked tickets with us, so had to go to the ticket office. My husband showed them the email that confirmed the tickets on his phone and they printed a new pair for us. No problem at all, very nice people.
good view!!. The big Bend of course it good to see and to hear when it start chiming. I walk around it sorrounding and enjoy the walk around the parliment area.

arrange a guided tour from your MP. Queue takes a while to get in, but once in, the tours are informative and interesting if you're into that kind of thing. You get to go into the House of Commons which is good.
Stunning Inside and Out. What a fabulous place. It is great to see where our parliament resides. This is a very atmospheric building.

An awesome Site to See.. Visit Big Ben and get a better view from one of the City River Cruises. I did not go inside for a tour but strictly took pictures and admired the amazing visual presence of the building. This is a must see in London. Parks are nearby to sit watch and hear old Big Ben throughout the hour.

Guided Tour. As visitors from the USA, we took advantage of the only Parliament tour availability our trip in June and signed up ahead of time by Internet for the Saturday Tour.
Perfect! 23 June 2012

Tour of real history. I am biased, as very interested in Parliament history. However both my kids thought the tour was sensational. The history was outstanding. I returned two days later to see parliament sitting. It could depend on the tour guide, ours was awesome.
Awsome. Amazing buildings Extremely busy as expected but well worth it
Parliament Lives. One must read up on the Houses of Parliament to make the visit even more breath taking. I couldn't stop taking pictures. Such architecture, such history. I love London!

The Palace of Westminster. Gorgeous historical building! A must see for people who are into politics, was nice to see the MP's arriving to work on the day. Even the police guarding the gates were very cooperative with the tourists as they took pictures with them. Learned a few facts as well such as it took 23 years to build and that when the Union Jack Flag is flying it means the MPs are in session and also the flag is as big as a tennis court!

Very interesting only one policeman let it down. Lots of history in this building and it was good to see our politicians working hard on our behalf. (you can sit in the public gallery and listen to the them raising issues). You do have to go through stringent security which is understandable and it does make you feel extra safe. Inside there is also a cafe where you can get a light lunch at a reasonable price.We also had the opportunity to see inside Speakers' House which was very stately where they sometimes hold state dinners. There was also a very elaborate ornate bed that was last slept in by King George Fourth and there were some lovely views of the river. Our guide was one of the men from the speakers' procession (still in his costume).The only thing that slightly spoilt the day was the rudeness of one of the policeman, just before the speakers' procession he very aggressively and loudly said "move back, move back, move back, move back" right in the face of one of my friends who was over sixty years old, I'm not sure if he was just having a bad day or he just expected her to jump. This is just the sort of attitude that gives policing a bad name, a bit of customer service would not go amiss. It would have been far nicer for him to say "I'm sorry I need you to move back as we have make room for a group of school children coming through". Or perhaps he does not realise that people cannot move as quick as when they are in their twenties.
beauty at it's finest. i could photograph the parliament every single time i see it. such a beautiful building! it was nice to see it each and every time i stepped out of our hotel.
interesting place!. Wonderful to see where it all takes place! It is reall rather grand and i am glad i went.
Must-See. The houses of parliament are beautiful...very majestic and a highlight of a visit to London.

Happy we did this tour. We had a guide and were taken through Westminster Hall, the House of Commons, the House of Lords, the Queen's robing rooms and so much more. If you can do this. Overseas visitors can book online and you need to do this well in advance. However, we had to visit it on a Saturday.

Good tour and view. The houses of Parliament are huge and gives you the impression of a castle. Umbrellas in London are must as it can rain anytime. Good planning of time will help you to cover lot of places here. Adjacent to the houses of parliament are 1: the Big Ben, 2: the Westminster Abbey, 3: London Eye, 4: London Aquarium and 5: the Thames river cruises. Be sure to cross the westminster bridge and get a panromic view of the houses of parliament and the big Ben together. If you go on the London eye, get an aries view of the same. Wear comfortable shoes as you will walk a lot and may give you cramps in high heels or formal leather shoes.
Top place. We were very lucky to be invited by a friend who is an MP, really interesting place, well worth a visit if you can.
impressive. book through your MP and it is free, very interesting, good guide.

An experience. Maybe not for a repeat performance though.. Liked: The history and the ambience. I think everyone should have an understanding of how politics works in reality. The tours of the Houses of Parliament are an education. For the architecture buffs, this is a definite on your list.

Really impressed. What a treat to see inside one of our great building and to learn the history of our goverment. Really enjoyed it. There was also free leaflets and very good books for children to understand. Our guide around the houses was Carol, a lovely, well informed and clear speaking lady. DOWNSIDE... your couldn't sit down in many places and didn't get the chance to look at painting etc atyour own pace, you have to stay with your group.
avoid the food stalls. a nice view, bring an umbrella just in case! Great to see it all tho, would the walk. Only bad thing is the westminster tube station is like (what feels like) half a mile away.
Worth seeing!. Very interesting tour learning about how the British Government works. We saw Iron Lady, the movie, before we went and it helped to understand what we saw.

Great free attraction. We applied for the free tickets via our local MP, who was really helpful.We arrived a bit eary and took refuge in westminster hall from the rain! The tour guide was very interesting, but tried not to make it too intense. It's a shame you can't take pictures, as we saw so many amazing things.I was allowed to lean on the box in front of Cameron in the house of commons, which was a great experience. Overall a great free day out for people interested in history/politics.

Amazing Architecture. A seriously impressive building. Find out a little about it's history before you go. The detail in the stonework is incredible and puts modern architecture in it's place. I'd rather look at this building everyday than the Shard.
marvellous. Truly captivating.. a beautiful old building especially when you look at it from the bridge set as a backdrop against the Thames. A must on any sightseeing tour to London.

What a great day out. We really enjoyed our vist. Security was smart but not over bearing and they were swift but efficient Once inside my eyes were everywhere. i need to go back and have another look. So much to see!

Fascinating!. Very interesting close-up look at the British government. Our guide was very knowledgeable and serves as a doorkeeper when parliament is in session. It was intriguing to learn that anyone can come to the central lobby to speak with their elected official - if the official is available, they will speak to their constituents without an appointment!

Not normally my thing - but definitely interesting. We went when my parents visited us in London from Australia. We went on an official tour that lasted approximately 2 hours and was amazed at how much we could see. You could wander through most of the rooms and go into the House of Commons and House of Lords. Not really my thing normally - but definitely worth the visit if you're looking for something to do.

Book this through your MP for free. I wrote to our MP requesting a free tour and we were offered a selection of dates and times. The tour was free, and I guess because we had a timed tour, it wasn't too busy. Security is very thorough, but only took about 10 mins.There was plent of time to get a coffee and use the facilities before our tour - you do not stop during the tour. Then we were introduced to Sarah, our guide, who is one of the special security guards in the House of Commons. Sarah was very informative - with lots of real life stories, she told us about the history of parliament, how politics works, plus some insight into the stange workings of parliament. The whole tour lasted about 1 1/2 hours but it went so fast. Really informative.We decided to give the cafe a miss for lunch. It is a bit ordinary and over priced - but fine for a quick coffee.

Incredible Palace, Excellent Tour. Booked tickets to tour Parliament through the Parliament website. Went through security with no line and were placed in an English speaking group immediately. Took 1.5hrs to tour. Excellent and informative guide. Beautiful Palace, especially the House of Lords. Worth doing. Can't take pictures inside...like many of London's top attractions.

More impressive inside than outside. The outside of the Houses of Parliament have always just looked very grey to me! However, when I visited the inside of them a few years ago, it did feel quite surreal to be walking around inside a building in which so much history had been made. It is well worth visiting the inside if you get an opportunity.

Go at Night for best Views. Big Ben is one of those things you need to see to understand its reputation. It's a clock tower from another time. The Building itself is pretty big and impressive. My advise is to go at night time and view it from the South Bank. Try and go on the hour so you get to hear the clocks 'bongs' There leave the building lit up until about 12.05am, so you can go there and film the clock at midnight. 5 Mins later the building is plunged into darkness and its time to go home!

A must see for history buffs!. We were fortunate enough to have a private tour with Black Rod going into places most people never get to see and hearing the amazing history of Britain. A visit to the private pub downstairs brings you into the location where many discussions occur on matters of state.

Must see!. Many visitors may think visiting a government building would be boring but nothing could be further from the truth about the House of Parliament. It is in a palace and the rooms you tour are so beautiful and you learn so much about the customs and traditions of Britain's government. Trust me, this is well worth your time!
House of Parliament. A fabulous historic building, used for many State occasions, as well as the seat of government. Don't miss it if you are visiting London.

Must not miss attraction. It is easy to find at Westminster and on the Thames embankment. There is no need to go inside and you may need to pre-arrange this anyway. The views outside are spectacular and there is ample opportunities for photographs. Big Ben is right there too and all part of the seat of government. by walking on to Westminster Bridge you can get great views of all the buildings plus views up and down the river. It's all free and never seems too crowded.

History and Politics. We found an official website offering tours of the Houses of Parliament very cheaply. The tour lasted 11/2 hours and was fascinating. Now whenever there is TV report from the lobby, or the chamber, we remember our visit and the interesting facts we were told.

Like walking thru a history lesson. Ticket process and security were easy, guided tour very interesting. No photos allowed but guide did a great job explaining how Parliament works. So glad we added this to our itinerary.
Don't miss the tour. English history in 75 minutes. Tours are in Saturday only if the Parliament is in session. One of the highlights of a visit to London.

Proud to be British! Worth every Penny!. On Saturday June 16th, we joined the tour of the Houses of Parliament. I booked this through Ticketmaster. I remember at the time thinking that this seemed very reasonable for what was potentially on offer - but it surpassed all expectation.The whole thing went like clockwork. We arrived in the morning and I parked my car in the Car Park in Abingdon Road, just nearby. Two minute walking distance from the Houses of Parliament. I had a picnic in the car which we collected later and ate "for free" in St. Jame's Park.Everything was beautifully organised. I enjoyed "asking a Policeman" where the Cromwell Entrance was. I am sure I could have found it - but I just wanted to do it. They were wonderfully helpful!No queue, and you are ushered in at your allocated time. Expect a thorough search - well, I think it's sensible.Barry was our guide. He was good! Not too much information all the way round that your mind drifts off with overload, but just enough to be interesting. Thanks so much. The groups are fairly small, so plenty of time to ask questions. There are other groups going around at the same time, but it is so well organised, that you never feel squashed or hassled.The rooms in the building that you are taken to see are quite breathtaking.They cover the Queen's Robing Room, through to the House of Lords and Commons.Magnificent and Interesting.I would recommend this to anyone, children included. The whole thing takes about an hour and a half. I think it was about £15. I never knew you could do this tour - and it was quite wonderful.Why not tie it in with a visit to Westminster Abbey? If you go to a service, it costs nothing and you are treated to some of the best choral singing in stunning surroundings. Very good for the inner soul. This made me feel so proud to be British and we were lucky enough to coincide with the Trooping of the Colour - so we popped round the corner to the Mall and waived to the Queen and all her family and experienced the pomp and ceremoney of the guncarriages and most of the British Army in all its Splendour.£15 a head for an incredible day out!

Take the tour!!!. The Houses of Parliament offer guided tours by very knowledgeable guides. The building and the history are SPECTACULAR!!!
