You get to visit the House of Commons, House of Lords, the Robing Room among other parts of the "Palace of Westminster."The only drawback is that you may only take photos in the room where the tour begins and ends. (but it's a pretty remarkable room on its own!)
The Corridors of Power. Very interesting as wella sbeing a beautiful building.

Fascinating architecture, guide could have been more engaging.... We applied through our MP for a visit and managed to combine this with the tour of the Clock Tower (see my other review - very much worth it!)The architecture is fascinating and the history behind the buildings make it a very interesting place to visit, however, our guide was not particularly engaged, didn't join in the banter of the group, didn't share interesting bits of information, like "first past the post" etc that my Wife had been told about on a previous visit, and also made some errors in her historical facts which were corrected by other members of the group!I'd still recommend anyone to visit, as it's still an amazing place to see, maybe go prepared with your tour guide!

Enjoyable but expect to wait. If you're interested in seeing Parliament in action it's a simple matter of waiting. Plan for an hour or so before entering as security screening and the wait for entry into either/both Houses can take a while. We enjoyed the chance to see Westminster Palace and the House of Lords & the Commons in action. Must admit we stumbled into two interesting arguments on the floors with the Commons debating a new defamation law and the Lords debating student financial aid funding. Both timely and topical here at home! We wouldn't recommend this visit for young children as the wait time is just too boring and you must be quiet (and sign an agreement document to "not disturb" either House will visiting. There are more entertaining things to see in London but a great chance for those interested in governance to see the British version.
Superb building, an icon!. Didn't go inside during this visit, but a trip to london wouldn't really be complete without seeing this icon!
House of Lords. The river view from the terrace is great but, unfortunately, it took a long time to get through security even though the visit was pre arranged.

A lesson in history, civics, and art. The houses of Parliament are simply stunning. For an American touring London this should not be missed. The similarities and contrasts between the American and British legislatures are simply fascinating. Add on top of the civics lesson 900 years of history plus some of the most interesting Victorian art in London and this is a trip well-worth the price. Tickets: Tickets can be bought across the street from the tallest tower (not Big Ben) at Parliament. However, I found it most convenient to simply buy the tickets online the night before (through ticketmaster) to ensure I would have a spot in the tour.Photo Op: Pictures are only allowed inside Westminster Hall (the medieval part of the building) however, after the tour on the ramp out of the building there is a fantastic view of Big Ben unobstructed by fences and tourists.

Magnificent!!!!. We applied to our local MP for a visitors pass two months before our trip,and everything worked out perfectly. The Houses of Parliament is without doubt trhe most fascinating building we have ever visited. Every corner turned revealed yet another architectural marvel,with layer upon layer of historicalfact, and a little fiction,explained to us by the highly informed and entertaining tour guide. This really is a must see London attraction,and the fact that it is a dynamic functioning environment,and not a museum,makes it all the more fascinating. Every British citizen really should make the effort to see parliament,you will be blown away,and it's free!

Well worth a visit. I have visited the Houses of Parliament several times over the years, sometimes with my MP, at other times as part of a function, as recently. It is difficult not to be fascinated and impressed by the sheer amount of history in the buildings. Many are surprised at the relatively small size of the House of Commons and House of Lords. Well worth a visit.

Wonderful history. I was lucky enough to be able to go inside on a tour of the House of Commons learning and seeing how the day to day debates happen. Well worth it if you can go inside even the outside building achitecture is a wonder to behold.
Plan ahead for tour. We took a saturday tour - it was the best and most interesting thing we did in London. We worth you time and money. Plan early to get tickets, since it is routinely sold out

Sitting in Question Time. I missed my guided tour (summer openings), but that did not get me down. I waited in line and went in for question time: amazing experience. Got to see various MPs grilling the Minister of Defense. Themes that routinely came up were: Scottish independence, Inheriting a bad budget, and maintaining regional identities (Welsh, Scottish) in the military. It is very interesting how MPs stand, moan, and laugh during the course of the session: quite a contrast from Congress. If you are early in line, there is a talk from the Information Office, where an explanation is given of what session you are sitting followed by a brief overview of how parliament works (helpful for foreign visitors).Overall highly recommended. Highlight of my 2nd trip to London.
Really Interesting. Really interesting guided tour. Shame you can't take photographs inside, but still a really interesting tour conducted by very knowledgable guides. Great value for money.

Controlled Pandemonium!. The Houses (Commons and Lords) are not only beautiful to see but you are allowed to watch debates on legislation. Gift shop has all sorts of interesting items, from House of Lords Scotch to bookmarks.
Historic. This is historic, lovely location so much to see and do and very beautiful.
Lighting. I used to walk past this place on the way to work and there are always tours taking people around. In the evenings this place lights up and a good photo can always be taken

grandiose. Pretty much like our DC area in washington..we didn't get to go in the parliament buildings because they were closed for the jubilee, but apparently you can go in on saturdays for a free tour
Fabulous. Just beautiful to see. We didn't try to go in, but the outside is so stunning that it is worth going over there to see just that.

Very interesting tour. I really enjoyed our tour. You go from "the Queen's bits", through the House of Lords, and on into the House of Commons. The tour ends in Westminster Hall where you are left by the guide and are free to explore. Our guide was very informative and friendly. I'd consider doing the tour again one day. And I'm sure everyone says so, but it looks SO much bigger on TV! The Commons is tiny!
Fascinating. Used our London Pass to get right into parliament. Very short line. Saw both House of Lords and Commons. Different setup from US Congress, but the issues being discussed were the same.
Wonderful!!. My family and I visited this incredible building last May in a lovely sunny day. We will never forget it.
Impressive. Very interesting and impressive,the outside area and gardens are very well kept

Very educational. The guide was very knowledgable about the history as well as current issues. It was brilliant to be able to see the the building up close. The tour is 70 mins and you really are seeing something new the whole time you are there. There is cafe and wash room area. Get there 30 mins before your tour.
A Must. Everybody should visit this venue. We are so lucky to have such history in this country, other countries must be so envious given the amount of tourists milling around.

Very pleasantly suprised. Touring the houses of parilament was so interesting! Before I went I didn't think I would enjoy it at all but there is so much to look at and things to learn. Generally speaking I get a bit of history after a while but I could have sent a whole day here!

fantastic tour...........a must when in london.. had to wait in a queue about 10 minutes to get through security but it was not bad. we first went into westminster hall which was full of history and you were allowed to take photo's there but no where else while on the tour. then you get your tour guide allocated and set off into westminster palace which was absolutely beautiful and very very grand it is so steeped in history.then we went into the house of lords and then the house of common's. where you are reminded not to seat on the seat's but it is very tempting. the tour guide was very informative and knew her stuff. the tour is quite tiring as there is so much to take in and you cannot really sit down and they seem to be on a tight schedule time wise. there is a cafe there although expensive but it was ok. a souvenir shop and an area where you can get free leaflets and information about parliament in all languages. overall a great tour getting an insight into what goes on!!!

Best seen from across the river. Very impressive, it seems to dominate the landscape!Best views are from the other side of the Thames across. Westminster Bridge. Big Ben went off- not as loud as I thought it would be lol
Wonderful site. They are an amazing sight, especially form London Eye
Impressive. Beautiful building, grounds are immaculate. Was struck by the size and shape of the trees (!).

Worth the 2 hour wait in the rain!!!. I absolutely loved my tour through the Houses of Parliament, and waiting in the rain for hours to get in didn't detract from it at all. It was extremely interesting to learn more about government in England, especially as an Australian whose own system it is modelled after. It's really a step back in time as you walk through this gothic architechure building and hear about all the historic events that have taken place here over the years. I recommend a visit here to those who are interested in history and want a little more than the typical touristy visit to London.

An iconic building. A iconic building, known throughout the world. Best seen from across the other side of the river, just walk across Westminster Bridge. Listen out for Big Ben, the name of the bell not the tower. The bell cracked whilst being made, which gives it unique sound.

Steeped in History. If you love English History, ou cant beat the houses of commons. if only the walls coluld talk, it's such an amazing building with it's massive rooms and corridoors, you can imagine all sorts of deals being negotiated in there. Fabulous lead windows and architecture to see. Well worth taking the guided tour.

Good historic visit. I was lucky enough to latch onto a women's group to attend the Houses of Parliament for a tour. It is so very interesting and wonderful to go into this former castle and see where the British hold their government. The difference between the House of Lords and the House of Commons is remarkable and quite entertaining with a good guide. some of the customs that remain are most interesting as well. I learned quite a bit of history on that tour, some of which I knew but had forgotten, but also quite a bit of interesting behind the scenes type of stuff which is always fun to know. a good tour for anyone.
they rule us. what a great place to walk and if your lucky you may see our parliament in action.

Good from the outside!. Wasnt able to go in as they didnt have any tickets until sat. Location is easy to get to by tube and there is other attractions in the same area which you can easy make a day out of it. Good attraction.

Very interesting tour. My husband and I really enjoyed this tour. Having visited London a number of times and been to a lot of attractions, we were looking for something new. There was a lot of security and queuing, but the tour itself was fast paced. I would have liked a more leisurely pace, to really look and read, but understand why this is not possible. As an Australian, I understand the Westminster parliamentary system, but still learnt a number of new things. It's good to know that Australian wool is inside the huge boosters (?). I was also surprised to learn that most of the buildings are not so old, because of a fire in the 19th century, but were rebuilt to replicate the original. It's not cheap, but worthwhile. My husband got a seniors' discount, and I most probably could too, but am too law abiding.
Wow!. Lunch was perfect, wine flowing, and the queen and royal family came too!

I worked in the Palace of Westminster and it is THE place to visit in London. The Palace of Westminster has everything for history lovers. It is a working establishment and it can be fun sitting in central lobby MP spotting!! The various facets of the Palace are very diverse and a booked tour of The Lords is a must. Visit Westminster Hall as well as the Commons. If you are able to obtain tickets to sit in the Strangers Gallery, you can watch debates or Prime Ministers Questions.

A grand old building. We did a pre-booked tour on a Saturday and thoroughly enjoyed it. The tour guide was engaging and informative and it was absolutely fascinating. You are taken through the two houses and ante rooms, with history, recent and ancient, laid out before you.I have always thought it the greatest building exterior in the UK and now I am also convinced it has the most stunning interior.The tour takes about an hour and a quarter and is never less than amazing. I would recommend it to anyone.
SEE PARLIAMENT AT WORK.. A visit to the Strangers' Gallery to listen to proceedings, whilst the House of Commons is sitting, gives a great insight into Government at work. Highly recommended.
MP trip. do get a trip organised by your MP. Well worth the visit and so full of history. A talking point for years to come - very down to earth guide too who enagaged our son well (aged 9)
My favourite tour. The tour guide was really informative, some MP's could do with taking the tour to remind them why they are there.

palace vs parliament. Many people are attracted to Westminster Palace to see the House of Commons and House of Lords. Politicians require security and thus make viewing the actual palace more complicated. In addition, politicos wish to rub elbows with their own constituents, therefore the building is restricted from "overseas visitors" except on Saturdays and in August-September, when Parliament is not in session. Tourists CAN schedule visits for the purpose of watching debates, by queuing up on St Margaret Street. The House of Lords' line is usually shorter; once you are in you may go to either.Westminster Palace has existed since the 11th century and did not become home to Parliament until the 13th century. Two fires, in 1520 and 1834, caused extensive renovation. The latter rebuild, by architect Charles Barry, incorporated the medieval buildings into the current "perpendicular gothic" style we see today. The palace was also retouched after a bomb struck during WWII, and more lately has been cleaned of grime from air pollution. The building is now divided into the Old and the New. Surviving all the above are the original gems: Westminster Hall, the Cloisters of St Stephen's, the Chapel of St Mary Undercroft and the Jewel Tower. Even some of the New rooms are lovely, such as the Queen's robing room, complete with throne.The Clock Tower, of course, holds the 13-ton bell named Big Ben. But the only way to tour that tower is to marry a British citizen. Be sure to notice the statue of Richard the Lionheart, plus Rodin's Burghers of Callais. Blue badge guides run 1 1/2 hour tours continuously in summer.
Beautiful. The architecture is detailed magnificent, You can take a look up close or from across the bridge. It all just take some time to sink it.

a must see for visitors. This was certainly one of the highlights of our touring around London and we had a wonderful guide called Hillary who was so knowledgeable about the Palace of Westminster and the British Parliamentary traditions
Parliament was in session. Beautiful buildings but you cannot go inside when they are in session.

unsurpassed building. Another unsurpassed building in London, glimmer goldenly at night time. Unfortunately, the chill windy weather which around three degree really put me off to cross over the South Bank to snap total buildings photo

Wow. Defintely a must see when in London, amazing architecture and right in the middle of old London. Seen from the street, boat or bridge, you cannot help but get a really good view of it. I really wish we could have gone inside but we didn't have the time - next visit!

Shockingly Great. If you have any interest in politics you will love this site. Watch a debate for free. I just happened to walk past the Houses of Parliament when debates were in session and saw people waiting in line to get inside so I inquired the staff standing outside the gate. I got in line and waited about a half hour before going through security. After going through security you go back outside, where you get a good view of the Clock Tower without the crowd and can take pictures. You then enter Westminster Hall where you can read a little bit of history of the hall and pick up a visitor guide and map. You are also able to take photos in the hall but from there your camera is off limits. From Westminster Hall you are guided to either the House of Commons or House of Lords. Since both had debates going on and it wasn't that crowded I went from the House of Commons to the House of the Lords after inquiring with staff.This is a hidden London secret gem. Best of all it's free! No advance tickets are needed, just walk up to the entrance on St. Margaret Street when there is a debate in session. It was interesting to see the debates live and in action, and if I was a UK resident I bet I would have even found it more interesting!

Surrounded by history and tradition. We reserved our Saturday morning tour of the Houses of Parliament by reserving on their website. We gathered to meet our guide in Westminster Hall, the oldest part of the complex.We had an excellent guide. She showed us the Queen's Robing Room, the Queen's throne in the House of Lords, and much more. We learned about Opening Day traditions, including the background of Guy Fawkes' Gunpowder Plot. We learned how the Commons' members vote by walking through the Yea or Nay lobby. We learned about the damage done to the House of Commons in World War II and Winston Churchill's decision to rebuild it as it originally was. The tour was a beautiful history lesson. We're very glad we took the tour!

This escorted visit to 'both' houses, as well as the older parts of the building such as Westminster Hall was nothing but fascinating. The guide was excellent throughout. Being shown as much as one can be shown in this 1100 room, 800 foot long building includes the upper and lower house (Lords and Commons) as well as the division spaces of the commons and other rooms one never sees on the TV.. It puts reality into those television shots - for example, showing how small the House of Lords really is in reality.With a history such as this just waiting to be discovered, this is a must for anyone looking for somewhere to visit while in London.

Fascinating. We booked the tickets just two days in advance, couldn't print out the tickets because we didnt have those facilities but we were greeted at the gate by a friendly guy showing us where to go to pick up our tix. two minutes walk away we had our tix handed to us in an envelope all ready for us went back to the entrance, waited in a queue till our time was called, through security efficiently and quickly and we were shown to our tourguides spot.Liz introduced herself, explained some rules (like dont take photographs though of course someone tried. There's always one) and off we went. Liz was incredibly knowledgable, friendly and looked after us carefully. Not surprisingly you can't touch paintings or furniture so you do have to be careful. But wow. the architecture and interiors of the palace of westminster are quite incredible. the details, the painstaking craftmanship - blow you away. I bet MP's and staff who work there take it for granted but they shouldn't. How lucky they are to work in such a building. We will be back to climb Big Ben one day (you have to organise that in advance via your own MP - UK residents only)I highly highly recommend visiting the Houses of Parliament if you visit London. (only little comment for suggested improvement would be to upgrade the visitor toilets. Soon.)

Incredible experience. I have been to both house of commons and house of lords --- i was there with the guided tour and it was absolutely brilliant. History behind the place -- of course interesting. When you see well-polished Mr Churchill's right foot (or shoe) or sweat-damaged corner of 'box' where prime minister put their hands on during 'question' time in the parliament -- then you will realised that house of parliament is 'live' and the place is 'real'. All the history and tradition in there is just so interesting to know.
History and politics!. Beautiful buildings, the hub of decision making and the Abbey close by. Big Ben chiming, a delight!

My taxes could be better spent. Despite bombproof glass across the visitor's gallery, security insisted on keeping the area less than half full, presumably for safety reasons. This lead to over an hour's queue, for no real reason. Officious security staff would have felt at home in many of the worst US airports. They need to remember the people they are ordering around are the ones paying their wages.
Very Gothic. A super piece of Gothic architecture, view it from the river to get the best impression.
The mother of Parliaments. The tours are fun. But even more fun is going to meetings there. It's a sad thing that the security is now very heavy handed.
AMAZING ARCHITECTURE. Worth seeing we walked down the street after leaving the London Eye. The sun was just setting over the big ben as it rang. One of those Ahha moments.

Parliament - one of the best things of our trip. Visited in April- we are big history buffs & Anglophiles are were very excited to go. Took the tube to the Westminster stop - got off & at the top of the tube exit you're right under Big Ben --- great way to start the adventure. Then go around the corner to start Parliament adventure. NOTE: TICKETS aren't in the Parliament/ Westminster Hall building - they are across the street about halfway down the "block" on the outside of a little white building - cross the street, go down some stairs and you should see the line. Get your tickets, then cross the street again and go through a few ticket "checkers" to stand in queue. In queue - they count you off and give you a lariat for around your neck that will eventually hold your ticket/ pass with your photo on it. then through to an airport - type security system - metal detectors, bags on conveyor belt for x ray, etc. (There are armed guards too) Then your ID on your lariat and into the ground area. From there you can take in some of the amazing outside architecture (wow!) and we were a bit overwhelmed at the amount of detail in the small part of the outside we saw. Gargoyles, grotesques, royal symbols, statuary and more. Then you can go into the main hall - Westminster Hall. Here is where Kings & Queens were annointed and laid to rest; here is where the trials of Guy Fawkes and William Wallace were held. Feel the history! Amazing wood beamed ceiling ( I think from the 1200's? ) and statuary. TIP: look for the plaques in the floor - these note various trials, burials, etc. Great piece of history. This is where you can queue up for the tour - there are lines for all the major languages in case English is not your mother tongue. We only waited about 5 minutes before our tour - groups are a maximum of 25 so that you can easily get around & hear the guide. There is no eating or drinking or cell phones during the tour. **NOTE: except for Westminster Hall there is NO photography allowed - so put the cameras away. Tour starts and you go into Parliament Hall - I can begin to do justice to all that you see. But you get to go into and stand IN the House of Lords and the House of Commons. The voting halls for Commons, the "press" areas, the amazing hallways with giant paintings depicting key moments in history. Amazing busts and statuary of key Parliament members; people in the arts & sciences and more. GREAT tour guide who gives fun and educational insight and learned a LOT. Learned how Churchill kept Commons small after the war, nothing is electronic or "remote" - all done by hand, in person. Learned the Queen cannot go in the House of Commons (listen for the fun story!) and much much more. You come back out after the tour into Westminster Hall again - perfect for more picture taking and there is a small gift shop just inside Parliament hall (start of official tour area) as well. Take time on way out to look at other parts of the hall, Big Ben, etc. Took us about 1.5 hours for the "official" part of the tour but at least another hour before & after for picture taking and being in awe. Highly recommended - although kids may not be so interested or entertained. I would put this as perhaps a "15 and up" attraction.

Blend of the past and present. I tried twice on the same day to enter the Houses of Parliament and each time there was at least an hour wait to enter. I returned the next day and was invited to view the House of Commons in action. After a security check and a 45-minute wait, our group were ushered into the Public Gallery. I have little knowledge of UK politics but I found this very interesting.

Stately and magnificent. We didn't go in for a tour, but we walked all around and viewed the buildings from every angle for plenty of photos. The architecture is magnificent and compelling. There is history galore here, so read your guide books or the internet sites about it. The Houses are one of the most recognizable tourist sites in London, along with the Great Clock of Westminster (more commonly called Big Ben, which actually names the huge bell inside the clock).
Very nice view. TIP: Go across the bridge to the south side of London and view it in the evening, just stunning

Very interesting and not too touristy. Really great to be able to go inside one of the most iconic buildings in London. Lots of history and the guides make it very interesting. A different touristy thing to do.

Interesting tour. We had an excellent guide, who was knowledgeable and enthusiastic. Great architecture and beautiful interiors. Gives a good insight into Bristol politics and history. Well worth doing. Allow time for security checks - it took us about15 minutes. Once through the security checks, there are toilets and a cafe next to Westminster Hall (where tour starts and ends).

Great Experience. On a recent trip to London, we visited the House of Commons for the first time. It was a great experience to see how their government does business. It is so different from what I expected. The security workers were helpful and were able to tell us all about the different areas of parliament.

A must for visitors.. Good to see what goes on behind the scenes and gives insight into how are parliament works. An excellent guide gave the tour.
Disliked unable to linger longer to look at the wonderful paintings.
See for yourself. A chance to go behind the scenes. There are various types of tours. After takling the general one, avail yourself of the specialised ones.
Outstanding. Brilliant guided tour. The history of the place told brilliantly by our guide was amzing.

exciting!. So exciting! though as a bit of a political science nerd, it may be a little bias. However, we were just walking past having a look and one of the police officers invited us in, we had no idea that you could just go in. No charge, we had a great walk around and learnt a lot, and then to make my day we got to go and watch the sitting of parliament. fabulous, the staff were great and accommodating, everything was fabulous
Impressive building.. Anybody interested in architexture, would love this. Take a walk next to the river and inclide the surroundings for a nice walk.

Heritage site, if you can take a tour inside. What can someone say about this great buildings. Most people know the building before the set site in London. Its vast history and the frequency of appearance makes it one of the most photograph sites on earth. The Palace of Westminster as it is known, was built in 1600's if I remember well and you can still visit the throne room, the great lobby where above the alcoves you can see the 4 Saints, protectors of the 4 Countries that make United Kingdom. The great hall where the Great Queen Mother was kept in her coffin while the guards were rehearsing the ceremony is also interesting for its size. Finally, I enjoyed a cup of tea and scones together with some sandwiches on the terrace next to river Thames. Unforgettable experience.

great to see where all the decisions are made... nice surrounding area, walked along the water, great views and lot's to do around this area - Big Ben, Thames river cruises, London Eye all within walking distance.

Fascinating trip. After getting through the arduous (but necessary) security checks, you get to go into the beautiful, modern, airy Portcullis House. From there, the stunning Westminster Hall is fantastic, steeped in history, and has informative and helpful information boards in a variety of languages. If you're very lucky, you might be able to get into the crypt, which is mind-blowingly lavish and beautiful. Next, visit central lobby, and be amazed again at the opulent decor. If you can, try to get onto the terrace to experience unrivalled views of the river and the London eye. We were lucky enough to be accompanied by our MP's researcher, who gave us an in-depth guided tour, before taking us to eat in one of the many restaurants there. Apparently, you can also write to your MP and ask for tickets to Prime Minister's question time, which must also be fascinating.Fun fact: there is a hairdresser hidden in the depths of the Houses of Parliament!
Interesting. Was a nice sunny day which made all the difference. The food and the souvenirs were expensive on the stalls

Democracy Rules OK!. It is amazing architecture and fascinating as the seat of government. The tour is excellent and if you can also get tickets for Question Time in either the Lords or the Commons it is an even better experience. The Lords is stunning, the Commons less so - but you know it's more powerful.Definitely one for those able to vote.

An icon like no other. If this is your first trip to London, there' no way you should miss this!!! I dont think this building needs further introduction on why it's a must-see, it's significance and history.One tip: Walk to the other side of the river (across Westminster Bridge) to the south side, to view the building at night, when it's lighted up - that's the BEST VIEW!!!
breathtaking. look at the architecture on the different parts of the building. This building tells a story!

So interesting... loved it!. For anyone interested in politics this is a must-see place! Went on a tour of it with the politics society at my uni and did not regret it.. despite leaving at 4am! Sadly not everyone in the group was able to get tickets for PMQs (me included) but the tour was good regardless. If you do go, try asking your MP for tickets.
Great place. Was lucky enough to get a tour round from an MP so got to see extra bits and even got to go to the MP'S bar.Really worth a visit

Special Day Out. If you are lucky enough to have a MP(Member of Parliament) sponsor your group, it is worth the extra effort to get the VIP treatment. This was the second time i had been to Houses of Parliament and having a different guide gives one a slightly different perspective. The oldest section is the 900 year old Westminster Hall, please marvel at the magnificence of it's roof and splendor of the large stained glass window as you sense the grand events that happened there. The tour includes the House of Lords and House of Commons and if you are lucky you will see the Members of Parliament going about their daily work to make the United Kingdon the great country it is.

Great tour. For years, I tried to get in to have a tour or a look-around. Since I am not a Brit, I had no MP to secure a ticket for me. Starting a few years ago, they now have Saturday tours. It's well worth the time and effort, a great time! Allow yourself time to go thru airport-like security; the tour lasts about 1 1/2 hours,.
Amazing structure!. Great to view on land and by a ride on the Thames.

Beautiful complex, friendly staff. Be prepared to wait in queues, but know that it is well worth it. Once you pass through security, etc., you are allowed to walk through Westminster Hall, and eventually travel up to the Public Gallery. It was incredible to see parliament in action!

History and Politics in one place. I've been there 3 times already and can visit the place again! The house of Commons; the benches; Voting lanes; the House of Lords.... you can 'smell' and witness the history in the building
a must visit. very good to visit,very informative trip,its where they make all the rules and laws
Beautiful on a sunny day. An iconic place to visit, and worth it to see "Big Ben" in the flesh.
Brilliant. Go to the public galleries of the House of Lords, much funnier than the House of Commons one!

Highly Recommended. We had booked through our MP and were supposed to be part of another group of 20 people. But we arrived early and ended up having a private tour with one of the door keepers. It was very interesting and helped bring back schooldays history lessons to life!
Worth every penny. I have been on the tour twice now. It is brilliant!!
Worth a visit. If your into history then worth a visit. Nice to see the place thats been on TV so much.
Stunning. Totally stunning in every way, the architecture is magnificent and the history is fascinating.

Brilliant tour. Small group escorted tour around this facinating place - you get to walk through the 13th century great hall, the lobby ( often seen on TV when MPs are being interviewed ) the State Robing Room, House of Lords and House of Commons.
Pre-book or get there early

Houses of Parliament. This was an extremely interesting visit - especially if you are British as it probably means more to you. To see Parliament in the "flesh" instead of just on the television was fascinating. We even got to stand (not allowed to sit) on the benches. Booking is a must.
worth seeing. took about 20 mins walk from hotel was a nice walk at night time

History in the making!. We happened to be walking by Parliament and noticed a short line. I asked if we could go in and within minutes we were in the House of Commons watching a debate! We then went to the House of Lords which was also debtaing and got to see the throne where Queen Elizabeth sits when addressing Parliament. It was a terrific opportunity and experience.

Just walked around this in April . . .. . . . but the Palace of Westminster is always impressive whether you're close up or taking the long view and there are some lovely gardens to visit at the end beyond the Sovereign's Entrance. If anyone offers you a tour inside, go! I did it twenty years ago and still have the memories.
Politician's Parlour. Lovely to see knowing that Australia's government is based on the same system.Impressive.An iconic building and piece of history.
Good to go and see if you're in London. Definitely worth going to see if you;re in London, lovely place.

Well worth the early start.. We booked in through our local MP and was very little hastle...jsut a couple of emails. Really glad I got up at 6am to get there, a really interesting hour or so guided tour.
WOW. It was a magnificent building in all its glamour. Simply amazing

What an experience.. I arranged a tour with my MP, went to Portcullis House where we were met by a Researcher and went under Westminster Bridge to the Houses of Parliament. We went into the Great Hall where Henry VIII used to play tennis, saw where William Wallace stood when sentenced to death, where Royalty lie In State, we went into both Chambers and went up into the Public Gallery to watch a live Debate.
Houses of Parliament. Interesting to see where the Politicians hang out, the guides are very knowledgable.
Timeless. This is one of the must see places in London. It has history, character and above all it represents everything which is British.
nice place to visit. It's just so beautiful. The architecture is so breathtakingly beautiful. I don't really know what else to say. It's one of those places that you have to see for yourself.
Its iconic. Visit here, if you are a uk resident you can get your MP to take you on a tour

Fabulous tour of westminster palace - such history. just back from a 2 night stay in london and had a tour round the houses of parliament over easter. The tour was so interesting, so much history and we were amazed you were able to go into House of Lords and House of commons. The tour was completely Free, we could not believe this tour was free, all I had to do was email my MP prior to the visit and ask him, his secretary then emailed me back sending me a permit through the post. How simple was that!! a real must do thing to do in London, for free!!!!We even had the most knowledgable lady taking us round, she was passionate about Westminster palace and houses of parliament, as she had worked as a secretary to a MP before retiring. She was a brilliant tour guide, and made the tour so interesting, I would recommend anyone to do this tour, a remarkable insight into our history and law, and decision making, brilliant
House of Lords. I am priviledged to attend a cocktail reception each year at the House of Lords, and look forward to it with great anticipation.
Nice building.. Historical site for my foreign guess to see. Areas around there make great photographs for long lasting memory
Educational and Historic. I enjoyed learning about the history of the law and the inside is beautiful

Exceeded my expectations.. We booked a private tour via our MP for our visit over the Easter break. Not only was it free but the place was very quiet. A fabulous building and it was really interesting to have a look round inside. Highly recommended.
tour on Sat. I have seen the outside many times, but this time we did a tour lead by blue badge guide inside, house of commons etc.Very informative and well worth the tix price
Impressive. Wasn't inside, but just to walk around it is an experience
Fantastic. Don't pay for this - you can apply to your MP for tickets but you nay have to wait. However, well worth it.

You've seen it on the television.... Having seen it on the television I was quite amazed at the size of the place. We went on a tour organised via our MP, which was free. There are also tours not arranged by MPs, for which you pay. The tour tells the history of the building etc, and you get to visit the Queen's robing room and both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. Both are quite amazing places. Members of the public are not allowed to sit on any of the benches within either House, but you can attend sessions in the public gallery.If you go when Parliament is not on recess, you may well see familiar faces - either MPs or Members of the House of Lords. (Julian Fellowes and Brian Rix were both spotted on our visit.)Well worth a visit - contact your MP and see if you can arrange it, or go on a 'public' tour.
Been Inside. Having been inside it's nothing special although the outter building is fantastic
tour houses of parliament. Very nice tour with detailed explanations of daily life in British parliament and it's history. Very interesting.
Impressive Building. So impressive and an icon of London. Beautifully lit up at night and a gorgeous view of the south side of it from the Royal Victoria Park.

Excellent. Worth the visit, really small in places compared to the TV view. House of Commons surprisingly small but quaint. House of Lords funny. Westminster Hall spooky but really fantastic to look at the floor for the plaques. Worth a visit.

Very Interesting. We recently went on a guided tour of the Palace of Westminster (UK Parliament). It cost £15 each for tickets but was well worth it. We saw the Queen's robing Room and walked along the corridors to see both the House of Lords and then on to the House of Commons. It was very interesting to see all the places shown on TV and to actually be there. Security was thorough and you weren't allowed to wander on your own but the guide was informative and friendly. There were several tours going at once but wherever possible groups were arranged by the language spoken (ie all Spanish speakers were grouped together etc) and staff were very helpful in directing people to the correct tour for them. Tours last about 1.5 hours. It was a really good and slightly unusual way to spend a Saturday in London and I would recommend it not only for foreign visitors but for Brits too.

Historic. Although I haven't been inside the Houses of Parliament it is an absolute gem of a building. The best part is that, although partly destroyed by fire, it was rebuilt and preserved for future generations.
just like the movies. to look inside dramatic such a great history such a great culture worth seeing
When in London.... Stunning architecture and a very interesting history. I recommend taking the guided tour they offer on Saturdays.
Great Britain at its best. This was the best place we have visited in a number of trips to London. The history and charachter are awesome.

Beautiful!. Obviously, I've only seen Parliament in pictures, but when I saw it in person, it was a ton bigger than I expected! It was huge! Very bold and aged architecture. The sound of Big Ben ringing just made my visit to London complete. Unfortunately, I didn't get a chance to sit in on parliament deliberating.
Iconic!. If you visit London and not take time to see at least Big Ben then you should be ashamed of yourself!
This is the business. Pugin's architecture, Big Ben, the House of Commons, House of Lords...here it all is, wonderful. Do the inside tour if you can. This is where it all happens.

The seat of Democracy. I particulary liked the statue of Sir Winston Churchill looking onto the house from Parliment Square..I wonder what he would have made of the demonstrators encamped around him during 2010 / 2011. For all of that it proved that we in this country have a democracy second to none !!
Awesome tour..... Extremely interesting...worth the time! Very knowledgable guide and interesting history
Iconic. I couldnt stop looking up at the wonderful celings. If only we could have looked at more of the rooms and the chapel that is by appointment only.
It was a building. What can I say, I saw it. Wasn't that impressed. I can appreciate the history and all that transpires there currently, but it wasn't my thing.

Really interesting visit. The history oozes out of this place - makes you proud to be British when you realise how many people have given their lifes work for democracy. Long may it continue and I hope the current incumbents understand how important it is for them to be 'Honourable' as they stand on the shoulders of others.

Loved the HOP tour. I went on the HOP tour with my 17 year old daughter last Saturday. I would highly recommend it. It was educational and the tour guide was excellent. It was one of the highlights to our trip to London.
Fascinating tour. Well worth going on this tour, brilliant to see the places I've seen so many times on TV.So much of our history and tradition is here.
so cool. I loved it and it was so cool there is only a little bit that they can show you but all that we saw was enough it was really fun and educational.
awesome. the discipline n manner in which the things were conducted.besides i liked the tight security through which v had to pass.
The Grand Big Ben and Parliaments. A must see on your trip to London. It over looks the Thames and is next to Westminster Abbey.

Amazing historic site. Loved the paintings, the history, the building.. everything about it. The flow of visitors was great...you got a scheduled time slot at time of ticket purchase which helped for planning. Too bad it was only open on Saturdays - a lot of people didn't get a chance to tour the building.

Parliament - not just for politicians. Visiting The Houses of Parliament is a splendid opportunity to appreciate the outward signs of a parliamentary democracy. Visitors can be seen, at times, meeting their local Member. The buildings are worth a visit and also can be viewed from he Thames.
Worth a visit. Expect queues but really worth a visit if you have time, try and learn a little about the history it holds so many secrets of englands past

A visit every UK citizen should make. I last visited the Palace of Westminster in a school party, more than 50 years ago! If you are a UK citizen it is easy to arrange a visit through your local MP.Tours are escorted by very knowledgeable guides and take about 75 to 90 minutes. Providing there is no sitting taking place at the time of your tour, you get inside both the Commons and the Lords chambers which are remarkable places. The rest of the Palace is also beautiful, and beautifully kept, considering that it is a place of work for hundreds of people.Westminster Hall, where your tour begins and ends is also pretty spectacular with the hammer-beam roof being the largest medieval timber roof in Northern Europe.
There's so much to the Houses of Parliament. Beautiful buildings and statues. A real tourist attraction so very busy.
Very Awesome from the Road. Loved the views and would have liked to see the inside.

Very Interesting!. We did this on a Saturday as it is the only day they allow actual guided tours. It was very intertesting and glad we did it once.
Tip: Tours get sold out so book in advance.
The terrace is gorgeous. We went with friends who work there and it was a very swift visit with drinks on the terrace but very interesting, I would love to go back for a full tour :)
the house. every time this is seen it still makes me pround to be a londoner must be the most photographed and visited but totaly understandable
The Big Ben. Don't miss this attraction...The Big Ben and The house of Parliment on the river..you will like it...in front of it you will find the London Eye and the Aquarium
A fantastic site, makes you proud to be British. What a fantastic building, so beautiful and well kept. A must to see for all visitors to London.

A very special building, the seat of power. I felt very priviledged to be able to visit this historic seat of power.It is a very impressive building full of history. I would rate it one of the UK's top attactions and to sit in on a session is very special.

Very interesting and worth the money. While in London for a weekend break, I found out you could visit the houses of Parliament.The cost was reasonable at £15 and I thought I would give it a try.The tour is guided and lasts about an hr. it is extremely informative and very interesting. You do get to visit areas I didn't think you would.Definitely worth a visit

Book a Tour. After many visits to London we decided to book a tour of the Houses of Parliament. The admission price is reasonable and you should arrive in time to get through the thorough security process.The tour guide was excellent and the places you get to see are wonderful - the Queen's Dressing Room, Parliament, Senate, hallways with portraits and statues. We especially enjoyed seeing Churchill and Thatcher!
Great Experience!. Managed to get tickets, via our local MP, to visit the Houses of Parliament and Prime Ministers Questions.Great Experience. Great Theatre and well worth the visit.

Great look at how our democracy works.. Another eye opener. You just don't realise how very small the two chambers are. Our guide was intersting, informative and entertaining, and another attraction where you wanted to see more of what was there, the tour only touches on the tip of the iceberg.
Calling eachother names in a democracy. Visit this when the House of Commons is in session and you get a show no theatre can give you.
Good guided tour. Very informative guide giving interesting facts in a pleasant manner.
The national treasure. Went to see Prime Minister's Questions and have lunch. What a fantastic experience. It really is one of the best places in this fabulous city.

Disappointing. We organised this trip several moths ago through our MP but we had very limited access due to the Queens visit the following day and the various security measures taking place. We were only there for half an hour and did not even get to see the House of Commons. The visit was only half an hour long and is usually 2 hours or so.
If u are visiting london then u have to see it. Very characteristic landmark of london,u have to go and see it!an if the day ia nice u can take some wonderful photos

Excellent guided tour. The tour took about one and half hours and took us from Westminster Hall through to the House of Lords and finally the House of Commons.The whole place is steeped in history and we found the tour very interestingHowever please note you cannot sit down any where - unless you are an elected member of parliament - and therefore can be quite tiringIf you take a camera you are only allowed to take pictues in Westminster Hall, for obvious reasons security is very tight
A constitutional history lesson!. It is a fascinating place, full of history. The decoration is stunning and the guide was excellent.
Great spot!. Excellent journey to the heart of British democracy! Book in advance!
Excellent - a tour is a must. Just the right amount of time & very informative. Make sure you book in advance - all well organised.

Very Beautiful and Historical. Totally worth going. It shouldn't be missed if you have the opportunity. The building is beautiful and the history is really interesting. The guide was very informative and funny.
It is amazing how detailed artwork is on it!. Just walk around and get amazed and terrified on how old this place is and still standing looking sooo great! It will be there when we'll be gone.

**THIS IS JUST AN INCREDIBLE PROJECT**. Then to know it also can house about 200 families of that parliament is such a great achievement and all the history with this great building. We both felt a great awe with this view.
Houses of Parliament. Houses of Parliament Free to go in no waiting To walk were others have
mother of Parliaments is worth a visit. the scale and grandeur make it an impressive day out

Listen to democracy in action. We went to the houses of parliament when they were in session. Sitting in the gallery even for a few minutes is a thrill. The etiquette and tradition that the staff as well as the legislators follow is amazing. The building in it's own right is gorgeous.
Pretty. It is very ornate...beautifully photgraphed. Big Ben is attached and plenty of great shopping all around

Great tour. We went on one of the guided tours available on a Saturday. Very well organised and our blue badge guide was great, funny and informative. Quite an experience to stand in the hall where Guy Fawkes, William Wallace and Charles I were sentenced.
very interesting tour. a long wait to get in but worth it. the lobby was great as was the statue of lady thatcher.

Incredible architecture. I was impressed by the architecture of the building. I'm not a fan of the Gothic style in general but when I saw it really loved it...!!!
It's one of the London's symbols so you shouldn't miss it.
Historical. So much history bound up in this place and it dominates the skyline along the river at Westminster
Fantastic!. Have been there twice, and would gladly go again. The guides are brilliant - and definitely love their job!
Must see. HoP is a must see for first time visitors. Great place with Big Ben and London Eye very close.
Only saw from the outside. It wasn't open for visitors, but the outside was impressive.

You just feel "I'm in London". The whole area of Westminster is an icon in London, and the first time you see the Houses of Parliament you just feel that you are in London. The building is huge and with a beatiful architecture. If you are visiting I suggest that you see it from the other side of the river, and at night if possible =). The only problem with it (in my opinion) is that you can't visit on the inside

The House of Commons is as boring as the House of Representatives. The parts of the Houses of Parliament that you are allowed to see are quite beautiful. The view from Westminster Bridge is the classic picture we all see. If the House of Commons is in session, it is possible to sit in the gallery and listen to what is happening. I was there on a very boring day! You aren't allowed into most of the building, so the outside view is all you will really get to enjoy.
A treat... I didnt think i'd have much interest in this but it was an excellent tour and visit - full of interesting history, facts, seeing house of commons/lords.. well worth the money

Just the architecture. You can spend ages just looking at the complexity of the architecture, and the tower of Big Ben. Try to get into the Underground to see the amazing industrial architecture of the Jubilee Line interchange.

Political centre. Very informative tour; entering both the House of Commons and the House of Lords, both steeped with history ... and the high security on entry served to enhance the whole experience. Amazing architecture - both the neo Gothic of the main buildings, and the stunning roof and space of Westminster Hall
Briilliant. Brilliant place to vist would go again well worth a vist good day out
Pocket modern history of Britain. Only Britain treasures it's history above political efficacy - if only the politicians were as interesting.

Geltside Two. Absolutely amazing!! Loved every minute! It makes you feel very
proud to be British.
Great Building. This was a awesome place. I would like stayed more !! (but it was raining)

Excellent. The Houses of Parliament tour is extremely informative and interesting. I liked the fact that groups were divided into different languages and taken by extremely knowledgeable and professional guides

Historical Site - must see. The building is huge and be prepared to go through security. We bought the tour that took us through the building and it was great to hear about the history and significance as well as the structure of the British Parliament. It's a great place to start a London experience.

Living History. I toured in Sept. 2008. It's great to know that these halls had been here for centuries and have been so much a part of history. Unfortunaely, it was too dark in the gathering entrance for pictures which weren't allowed elsewhere.
An essential. Being part of Big Ben, you cannot miss this. Look for the windows. They are tiny
Beautiful building. Beautiful building. A real London landmark. I didnt go inside but I had a wander around outside and took a lot of photos of the architecture.

Gorgeous Buildings. AS London Bridge I just Love the Houses or Parliament. The architecture is so gorgeous I could sit and look at it all day. When lit up in the evening it is breathtaking. You just have to see it for yourself. One of my favourite buildings in London.

Toured Parliment. Tours of Parliament are offered on the weekend. Even in February I had to buy my ticket in advance. The guide did a great job giving a tour of the place and explaining how Parliament works.
great. we had a french speaking guide and it was great visiting it marbellous
average!. not much to do but was good to see all of the landmark sights!
HP do not miss it!. When seeing this monument you feel like a small ant:) so many details, so many people, so much traffic but we feel overwhelmed by its history and greatness...really wonderful!
Absoute must see. You cannot go the London and miss a Parliament tour. It just that simple.

Where were the Brits?. This was a very interesting tour. The tour guide was enthusiastic and clearly very knowledgeable, which really added to our enjoyment. Being able to go into the House of Commons, Lords and to see the places we are so familiar with on TV was fascinating. Surprised so few of the visitors were British! Are we not interested in our political heritage or is the tour under publicised?

Steeped in history. Make sure to book a tour of the Houses of Parliament if you are on a trip to London. You start off in the great hall, where people like Thomas Moore were tried, and Nelson Mandela gave a speech. You have to go on a guided tour, but the tour guides are all great. There is plenty to see and you certainly will not get bored.

Getting Close to Lords & Commoners. London is steeped in wonderful and sometimes alarming history, with government and royalty nearly always at the center of it all. The Houses of Parliament is a great place to experience it all. Tours are offered on Saturdays, and include not just a history of the building and government, but also insights into how Parliament operates today. The tour is a full 75 minutes and well worth the 15 pounds.

Fantastic place to visit. I wasn't sure if I would enjoy this but it was great,really interesting . The history is amazing. The only down side is constantly being watched by security throughout the tour, I know they have to be very security conscience but it does make you feel a little uneasy,but it is worth it.

So much history in one building. This visit really exceeded my expectations. It was exciting to see the chambers of the Commons and Lords - we were able to stand at the dispatch boxes and even saw a couple of recognisable MPs in the Members' Lobby. Now I understand where the term 'lobbying your MP' comes from! Some of the rooms are spectacularly beautiful - particularly the Prince's Chamber, the Royal Gallery and the Queen's Robing Room. Westminster Hall is the oldest remaining part of the palace and is really breath-taking. One can imagine King Henry VIII holding court in there.We didn't get to go up Big Ben - these tours are booked months in advance, but even so, this was a really great visit.

A thousand years of history, sense it, feel it,. As a family of four, we did the members tour. Through our local MP we requested passes which were duly approved, signed and fowarded within the official envelope.....from the House of Commons!The members guided tour is...thought inspiring, fascinating, steeped in history, and a greater sense of presence I would suggest you may not feel in buildings of such historical meaning. The Palace of Westminster is the heart of democracy, commissioned in 1097 and built in 1099. It has survived many things, including more recently (1600's) the great fire of London, and the blitz in the 2nd World War and so much more!Top Tip would be...write and ask your MP for passes. This could take up to 6 months...but plan ahead, a milestone moment.

Makes you proud to be British.. A truly outstanding piece of our heritage on display for the world to see. An absolute stunning building even our American friends were in awe of the place. nearly one thousand years of British and parliamentary history. Then there's Big Ben up there with any of the most iconic images in the world. A day in London would not be complete without a visit. 10/10

Definately worth a look!. It was fascinating to see such an historic building. Guide was knowledgeable. The tour deals mostly with the modern uses of the building rather than its history. Personally, I would have liked more history yet still a highlight of my london visit.

Please go and experience. We went into see the House of Lords as Commons had a huge queque ( Only downside ) and I thoroughly enjoyed itSo interesting, such beautiful buildings and surroundings and it has no admission feeOne of the highlights of our London tripPublic Can visit from 1430 onwards
Great Building. Fantastic building, very impressive. The tour gives you a real sense of how we came to have our modern system of government, very interesting and informative.
Everyone should go. Had a great tour guide that brought us back in time throught the House of Parliment. It reminded us of the time we visited the Capitol building in D.C.

Palace of Westminster. Situated on the north bank of the River Thames. The sky is abit cloudy when we arrived there. But when the nightfall, the view was very beautiful with the lights all being light up. Loved the Gothic architecture and style. Of course, "Big Ben" is here too. Certainly a must-visit attraction in London, UK. An an iconic landmark!!!
Just fascinating. Walking round here at the seat of Government is one of the most interesting things I did on my day up in London
A must see. A must see but not really very "interactive" I would combine it with a boat trip from Westminster Pier up to the Tower of London
Majestic building.. Not able to see much nof it. views of the river excellent.

A history lesson. Not only are the Houses of Parliament beautiful edifices that sit on prime real estate on the northern banks of the Thames River in downtown London - the very center as it were - but they are also steeped in history. Knowledgable guides give you the background and the history on tours which are well worth taking. There is so much to see and learn - this is a real insight into the multi-faceted history of England

Great experience. Great tourguide, and fascinating tour. Downside is that we were rushed through this expensive tour because we were the absolute last for the day. Long line, and not able to take pictues...even of statues, etc.
A must for a history junkie. Twice I've been on guided tours and the guides are brilliant. It's an amazing building with so much history. No two visits are the same.
Houses of Parliament. Well worth a visit, rooms appear much larger on T.V.  Tour is quite interesting, building has much more history to offer  other  than the workings of Parliament
Houses of Parliament. Well worth taking a tour. I especially liked it when we were shown the outdoor riverside cafe/bar where the MPs partake in a little refreshment or two.
Landmark. Spectacular architecture, such an iconic landmark in London.

see democracy in action. we were in Westminster and decided to visit the coffee shop for lunch, we found our way into Westminster Hall (awesome) and then joined the queue to enter the public gallery of the House of Commons - the queueing system is a bit weird, but persevere, we entered as the Prime Minister was making a 'statement to the commons' on terrorism - how cool is that, a spur of the moment decision on where to have coffee and we end up in the Mother of parliaments, witnessing democracy in action - not to be missed!!!
law of the land. great architectural design. wish i can see more. just seen it from outside

So much history. Really interesting tour with the right guide but you have no control over who takes you around. I just swapped tours when I heard someone speaking who had spent his working life there and obviously loved the place.
Big Ben. If you are visiting London you must visit the iconic Big Ben and the houses of parliment which is the centre piece of London

A wonderful opportunity to see open government at work. I had been invited to a reception in one of the rooms in the House of Lords that open onto the terrace overlooking the river. The views through the floor to ceiling windows were magnificent but it was too cold to enjoy the terrace.After a very pleasant reception, it was around 5.00pm and I couldn't resist having a look into the two chambers where debates were going on.Security is obviously tight and you do have to get your pass when they take a photo and it appears on your pass. The checks are just like the airports but everyone is checked as they pass into the building. Once inside you are free to watch the debates from the visitors galleries or as they call it in the House of Lords, the 'Strangers Gallery'A very worthwhile visit for anyone whether a UK resident or overseas visitor.Don't leave it out of your itinerary. Its our British Government working.

Behind the scenes of parliament. Did the guided tour with my 15 year old daughter. It was really well organised and the guide was very knowledgeable and interesting. The inside of the building is fantastic and it is nice to see inside both the House of Commons and Lords - though don't sit down -or else!!

What a wonderful place. The tour was extremely enjoyable- didn't realise how beautiful the rooms were. We stayed on for Member's Question Time. I did think I might get bored but it was very interesting. We only left when we did because we had a train to catch.

guided tours only. Get your MP to book you on to a tour, but give plenty of notice. Otherwise tickets are sold in summer recess. Lots of stairs and steps and little disabled access. Fascinating tours, so worth the wait but they are booked up months in advance.

Fascinating. What can you not say about this architectural marvel. A wonderful example of colonial splendour, the Palace of Westminster is fascinating both outside and inside. Take the tour but be prepared to wait a while as the demand is high. The only drawback is the location in the middle of a busy junction. so photographs can be difficult. However it is well worth the visit

Wonderful to see democracy in action. Wonderful to see democracy in action. You can lobby your MP and sit in the gallery. Great photos from outside as well and very near to Westminster bridge which is great to stand and stare
The Saturday Tour. This tour with a blue badge guide was the highlight of out week in London. A wonderful opportunity to see everything in both chambers so closely and fully.

Incredible tour of an amazing monument. Having made a reservation before and printed off my ticket, I got to skip the queue to enter Parliament, which was brilliant. The place was packed but the tour guides did a fabulous job of spacing each other out, speaking loudly, and caring for each person in the group. (We had an elderly person in our group and the guide made sure she always got a seat when available, which wasn't often, but it was very sweet of him.) The actual site was incredible. There's really no where that tourists cannot go within the houses and palace. The House of Commons, House of Lords, etc are all viewable. I would highly reccommend this tour to anyone interesed in British History and politics.

School Visit. Went there on a school trip and got to go inside the houses of parliament, got to stand and touch the box where the speaker stands. It has a beautiful interior as i would ecpect from an old englis building.

What can I say. A famous London landmark full of history.Inside it's beautifully kept and wonderful resturants to which only MPs or Lords can go with their guests . Used for business functions so tr to get invited as worth the visit
Not as old as it looks. ...but still it's impressive enough from the outside. The inside is a cornucopia of decoration and history and literally overwhelming.

Grand Tour!. Managed to get tickets on the day, but probably best to book in advance to be sure!Fabulous organised tour lasting around 75 minutes in a small group- our guide was very knowledgeable, yet delivered all the facts in a relaxed and sometimes humerous way. It was brilliant to see all the famous places that you only usually see on tv such as House of Lords and House of Commons, and to learn such a lot about the our political system- don't know why it took me so long to visit!! Worth every penny of the £15 entrance fee- just do it!!
Parliament visit. Excellent we really enjoyed this tour, costs £15 ea.... Heavy on security to be expected, 75 min tour, excellent guides, cafe on site

A place in Visitors Gallery, followed by lunch on the Terrace.. Ask any MP for a ticket, preferably for 12.00 noon, on a Wednesday, when Parliament is in full Session--to hear 'Questions to the Prime Minister'. Greatest Theatre on Earth.
Houses of parliament. Really interesting and well worth a visit. If you can go round with a guide as this is much better.

Wow. I cant believe it has taken me until I am 50 to visit the Houses of Parliament. Al I will say is WOW. We were lucky enough to have a private escort and were taken behind the scenes as it were. The whole experience was superb and I highly recommend a visit to one and all. You WILL not be disappointed. Trust me and book today.

Amazing!. This was the very best sight we saw in all of London. Get tickets for Saturday tours from Ticketmaster. The experience was completely amazing and I am very glad I did not miss this opportunity.

Good tour. You can do an excellent tour of the parliamentary buildings... showing you some secrets, and allowing you to hear some fantastic stories. You may be lucky enough to bump into an MP en route as they go about their business (I was) and if you plan your visit at the right time, you'll catch a glimpse of a television debate too. If politics or British history is your thing, then you should do the tour. If it's not... it's still a spectacular building from the outside.

Unbelievably brilliant. We went with a 19 year old, who is studying Government and Politics, he and us thouroughly enjoyed the tour which lasted just over an hour, which was just about right. We didnt even know that you could do such a tour until we stumbled on the tickets on ticketmaster.
very interesting.looks like it is seen on tv. You feel history surrounding you.. lseating etc does not look worn but very fresh and new.
Awesome. The History of the place, the sense of occasion, the traditions and the sheer professionalism of the guides and the people who welcome you there. Its what makes Britain GREAT
Houses Of Parliament. looks great, Big ben is local and worth a visit. Shame about the laws that are passed!
The Mother. Great from the outside; better from the inside. Prepare by watching Prime minister's QUestin Time on TV

Unique. The Houses of Parliament are unique and just drip history. They are very photogenic from most sides and you can take tours inside. You can also watch news crews filming on the grass and enjoy the antics of protestors trying to get "into shot". You may even see the odd politician or celebrity in the vicinity.
Nice to say I've been but what a wait. Tried to be in the public gallery during a debate but was not successful. Wish there was more opportunity for guided tours.
Spot your MP. Politics aside this beautiful building is worth seeing. Pity its no longer a royal palace.
A great monument. A very important part of London! Maybe most people don't like politicians but the Houses of Parliament are something really unique!
Houses of Parliament Tour. It was a fabulous tour - so interesting. Definitely worth a trip - and the guide was excellent - about 1 hour and 20 minutes and just brilliant.
Go inside. Another wonderful building where the inside is as beautiful as the outside. Take a wonder inside and sit in on a session - but try not to laugh too loud at the debates....
Fascinating history. Our local MP guided us round this wonderful building - we even ate in the Churchill rooms

Make sure you get the best guide. The houses of parliment is like a story book, with many different aspects of history contained within. A really good guide can make it not only interesting but fun with many things no one would even guess about the place. Get a bad guide and you will mearly get the historic version. The artworks are outstanding, the views amazing, the architecture and interior holds some surprising gems of history. I just love the place.

Loved the History. We reserved our tickets in advance over the internet so there was no waiting. Our guide was excellent. Not only did we see the famous rooms including the Commons, but we were given a history and review of what we were seeing. I wish we hadn't put it off for so long.
interesting tour. and you can sit/stand in front of the famous red and green seats

Fab tour by local MP. We had a fab informative tour by our local MP. Westminster Hall is breathtaking and so many interesting facts on the way round. Saw Michael Hesletine, Sir Douglas Hurd and Theresa May on way round! Go on a weekday, it has a real buzz about it!
One of the oldest parliaments. The building has a lot of history but if your are looking for achitecture it visiting St. Pauls would be more advisable.

Loved the organised trip I went on.. We enjoyed an organised trip with a local company, and it was great. From the Queen's entrance, through the Lords chambers, The House of Lords, the long corridor via visitors lobby, to the entrance of the House of Commons, right past the library with Hansards to the MP counting counter when the division bell rings. Then we entered the Commons via Speakers chair, and stood in the governments benches, but a stern police officer prevented you from sitting on them! We had a great day, escorted by a very good guide who was an Usher of the House. We also bumped into a few Lords and MPs as well, which made the day. A final look in the old House of Westminster, where Charles 1 was tried, then home, very tired and knowing we had seen all there was. I recommend a trip like this, it will open your eyes.

Big Ben is a Bell. Often mistakenly taken to be the clock and its tower, Big Ben, that sits on the corner of the Houses, is in fact the name of the bell which chimes the hours. The Houses are the seats of the lower (Commons) and upper (Lords) chambers of parliament. You can queue to go in to hear them debating, but there is not much else to do.
Tour was great. Found the tour very interesting. Are brought through the whole building including the house of loards and commons with the full history along the way. Really worth it.

Best value for money guided tour ever. You have to go through rigorous security before you even get inside the place but by gosh it is worth it. The building is a fairy palace and a scene from a gothic novel all in one. The guide was so knowledgeable, clever, funny and a great story teller we never wanted it to end. I learned more about government, British history, politics and law in 2 hours than I did from a higher diploma course in public admin! and it was way more fun. Even our young teenagers thoroughly enjoyed it and didn't get bored. It was quite reasonably priced for a family ticket. Best money I've ever spent on a guided tour.
Private Visit. Was very impressed with the whole thing. We had a meal in the Terrace Restaurant. was a thoroughly enjoyable day and I will remember it forever.
Great hour and a quarter. very impressed with tour guide, and info given, dont get there too early as it is really cold in the the hall area, before the tour.

Fantastic tour. This was a fantastic and engaging tour. The only thing that was difficult was that the tour ran over and there was no where to sit down. However, the tour guide was great and learned lots about the process of the UK Parliament.
Really Good Tour. I when't there last october and wasn't disappointed security was a bit heavy but you kinda expect that, all and all a very good place to go see.

Houses of Parliament. Go and watch a debate in the gallery. You may see some well known politicians and it can get quite lively. Children are allowed which is good. You have to queue for security but it is quite fascinating. The building is interesting too and can be combined with a visit to the nearby Westminster Abbey which should not be missed

Well worth visiting - fascinating insight to the government of England. This trip is only available on a Saturday as the Houses of Parliament are occupied with government matters from Monday to Friday. The building itself is very grand and historic and of would attract those who are interested in architecture and the british monarchy, the two chambers are also very interesting and the guide on the tour explains the seating arrangements and various rituals perfomed such as the Queen's visits and state opening of parliament with 'Black Rod' etc. There are also some interesting paintings and frescos which depict Kings and Queens and famous battles from history, together with statues and busts of previous Prime Ministers. The guide also gives you an insight into the voting process and explains some of the terms used and the procedures gone through to approve a bill in the two houses outlining the differences between the two. Well worth taking the tour and a good insight into how the government of England works.

Tyremarxx. One of the most famous buildings in the world; famous for being called the wrong name. The clock tower is just that; the clock is also just the clock. Big Ben is the name of the largest bell. The Houses of Parliament are in beautiful scale; it is not until you stand there that you realise how big and imposing they are. London is just a great city.

Worth queuing up for. If you can get in to the Houses of Parliament, you will see wonderful architecture and paintings. The building is something we should be prond of. You can also buy "House of Commons" gifts (chocolates, mugs, pens, etc), which you won't find anywhere else!

Best value part of London!. Taken on tour by some experienced people who really know their stuff. An amazing tour that all visitors to London should see, such a great piece of history and current life in London.

Better than a history book. This was my 3rd trip to London, but I had never gone inside the Houses of Parliament. My mistake. This time, I planned to go and see Parliament in session. Can you imagine going to Washington DC and just looking at the Capitol from the outside? Go in and see history - and history in the making. I was lucky to the see the ceremony of the Speaker of the House of Commons walking though the hallway before opening the morning session. Neat. Visited both Commons and Lords houses. Even if Parliament is not in session, go and experience for yourself. The guides and visitors' staff gave good background info and were very friendly and educational. Hear, hear!
Power. Hate the security aspects but totally appreciate why they are needed. The entrance vibrates with historical happenings.

Don;t go for PMQ. Wonderful building - visitors should see the Chamber if only to be shocked at how small it is. Don't go for PMQ - it is a pantomime. Altjhough I would like to see the Lords abolished the level of debate is much higher here
Impressive Building. Impressive building... worth seeing, even just from the roadside!

a must visit. We visited through our MP Gary Streeter , Via his staff with our children aged 10,6 and 1 we were welcomed by very friendly police and had a tour , you see it so often on the tv , but in real life it just ooze's history.

Fascinating. Booked guided tour through ticket master. 2nd time I've done this but wanted to take my teenage son. Tour takes about 1.5 hours and includes the Lords and Commons. The guide was witty and well informed.

Interesting historic field trip. House of Parliament is only open for public on Saturdays. You are obliged to buy your tickets across the street and then undergo a whole security check, like checking into an airport. You can not walk around without a guide BUT the many stories we heard and statues, paintings and rooms we saw made up for all the practical inconveniences. Tours take long (about an hour) and you are not allowed to sit only when explicitly mentioned but for me it was all worth it.
