If you visit London and want to taste the great their great political heritage or understand better current policies, I would surely recommend the houses of parliament.

Great visit ONLY saturdays. Brillant. We loved the fact that we were just walking past and had not organised this before hand bought tickets and enjoyed every minute of seeing the House of Lords and standing where the prime minister stands.recommended

Great place to see the Democracy in Action. Went on a RBL organised visit, and was hosted by our MP. The fully guided tour was very informative and followed by a trip on the Thames made a wonderful day.
a real insite into the working of the country. what a great building to visit and the guides a well informed and keen to share all the history and infomation with you.

Very Impressed. Our visit to the Houses of Parliament definitely came up to expectations. It was a very interesting experience.Our tour guide was very good and had a great sense of humour. We booked on-line and were pleased we had done so because there were lots and lots of visitors. Nothing to dislike.
Very very interesting. What a privilege to visit this historic building. Opulent, historic, interesting. Very well organised tours packed full of information. You will stand where history was made.
Very nice building. I did the tour inside of the Houses of Parliament which was very interesting. Went on a bit too long and was a little boring at times but none the less, it was great to see.
weekend. Lovely building memorable experience highly recommend
HISTORIC. just amazing.So much to see in such little time. You will never forget going there. Brilliant

The Seat of Power. Well in London you must see the seat of power The houses of Parliment, and see all the chambers etc and all the offices for the cabinet and all the Mps etc all the countries have seats of power, but not one with some much interesting History Paul and Joan Bennett
Great tour of Parliament. Our guide, Owen, was excellent. He explained the history and how their system of government works, while showing us the House of Lords and the House of Commons.
Awesome. The arcitecture and woodwork in this building is incredible , too good to be wasted on Politicans !
Amazing. Was lucky enough to be invited to the house of parliament for a university function, this place is amazing, so much history, fascinating tour guide, hope I can go back one day.
Great architecture. I think the building is worth a tour around (not necessarily a ticket to get inside). It beautifully attached to "Big Ben" or may be actually "Big Ben" is part of it.

A history lesson and museum tour in one!. I can't recommend this tour highly enough! I remembered loving it the first time I took it as a teen, but enjoyed it even more this time around as a mother. The rooms are gorgeous - so richly & densely decorated, and the style contrast between the House of Lords and the House of Commons is striking. But it's the history you learn on the tour, the traditions and stories, that are fascinating. It's hard to beat the Brits when it comes to their royal lineage of drama and romance.We went on many great tours, and visited many interesting/beautiful sites in London. But hands down, this was my entire family's top pick for best attraction.

Enlightening. Very informative and excellent guide. It was wonderful to go into the Queens robing room,House of Lords, House of Commons and other rooms. The great hall gave a wonderful feeling of history
fantastic tour. we arranged a tour here through our MP and it was well worth it, next time we go we will try and get into the public gallery to see the House of Commons in action
Icon of London. It was just think I thought it would be. With Big Ben it is an icon for London. Looks great at night, all lite up.
Fab place to go great. Great to see this at night as fab lit up along with houses of parliment and london eye

Feel the Power. It oozes history and feeling you're at the centre of Britain. If the walls could talk etc etc etc. The tour is well worth the time, the Commons is a very odd feeling after seeing it on TV, if you have arranged a ticket for PMQs then its the best show in town.
Enjoy.

Don't forget to stop here!. Tour groups are small, which is nice, and they move you through pretty quickly. Be sure to check the schedule, tour availability can be hit or miss depending on the time of year. Glad we chose to squeeze this into a busy few days in London.
The home of the free world. A must see on any tour of London.It is a wonderfull building and Home of the Goverment and opposision of England.

Excellent afternoon visit. The tour was extremely interesting. I learned so much about Parliament and British history. By walking through the various houses you can understand how they are linked and the work of government is carried out. The Guide who took us round was very knowledgable and had a real passion despite ours being his fourth of the day!

A centre of today's world power.... A great tour - as is usual for British historic tours, these buildings hold all sorts of old stories. In this tour, I got to be right inside (like, right between the benches!), down on the parliamentarian's floor, (but not allowed to sit on the bench behind by rear end since I was not an elected peer...), right there where I saw David Cameron speaking to the house on my local news program the week before!I recommend it - but buy your tickets on line before you go.

Excellent. Visited last Saturday. Booked on line through Ticketmaster and printed tickets. £15 each for adults and £10 for Seniors. When booking select the language you wish to hear on your tour.Huge cue waiting for entry to Parliament and airport type check-in, so give yourself plenty of time for this before your scheduled tour.After entry there are toilets and a decent cafe.The tour starts in the huge hall where the Queen Mother lay in state after her death and numerous trials have taken place in the distant past, such as, Guy Fawkes, etc.Our guide was brilliant and made the visit really enjoyable and informative.BEWARE - If you are the type of person who needs to sit down occasionaly. You are informed that you can only sit down when invited to do so and this was only once towards the end of the tour. The tour commences up quite a lot of steps and there are steps in the Commons and Lords to negotiate. Seats have stickers on saying you cannot sit down.The tour took about 75 minutes, maybe a little longer.
Very interesting tour. If you can manage to get a guided visit you will not be disappointed

Charming and fascinating.. One of the most beautiful places in London! You can admire the entire complex through a beautiful walk along the banks of the Thames. Surrounded by other famous touristic attractions such as Westminster Abbey, Big Ben, London Eye. You can't go to London without visiting the Parliament. A long sail down the Thames is perfect at sunset.

A must. From the outside the building is impressive. You can get inside to follow the debates when parliament is in session. If you are interested in politics you really should do that - the debates are lively and the MPs are very outspoken. There are tours around the building when the parliament's not in session which is worth taking. You can also sometimes climb Big Ben, and see the clock work and the dial from inside.
Always impressive. Always worth a look - best views are from the south bank of the river.
Excellent walk around. Just had a walk around and from here to Buckingham Palace. Great experience
Houses of Parliament. Inside and outside, this is an impressive edifice. Take the time to visit as much of it as you can.
Landmark of London. Defintely worth a visit. Just seeing the building from the outside is worth your time. Can be difficult to arrange a tour inside.

Breathtaking trip to the Houses of Parliament. Fortunately I visited the Houses of Parliament as part of an organised business trip so I had the added pleasure of attending Prime Ministers Questions and go to see a little more 'behind the scenes' than I would had I been travelling alone / as a tourist. It's a cliche but a visit to the Houses of Parliament is a 'must see' for anyone visiting London.

Book a ticket and go. Book a ticket for one of the Saturday showings and you won't regret it. Very informative. Everything is both completely used but also fantastic condition. Not too long either - 1 hour and 15 minutes. Make sure you buy your tickets online and print at home if you can. Avoid trying to get on the day if you can.
So much more impressive than on TV. The sun shone when we were there and the whole building looked like gold!!!

Beautiful Views. Coming out of the Westminster Underground Station Big Ben is staring you right in the face. It's beautiful and you don't realise just how big it is until you get there. Parliament goes all the way around. I did not have time to you inside, but the outside and gardens are lovely. You can see so much from the location. Walk along the bridge right by Big Ben and you can see the famous London Skyline with the Thames River, London Eye, London Bridge, Big Ben, and Parliament.

Regular visitor. I regularly visit the Palace of Westminster as I belong to a Parliamentary Group. The building never fails to thrill, as its walls sing of its history and the momentous events that have taken place there. The Committee Rooms are just as beautifully decorated as the grander public areas, and the Members' Chapel is exquisite. Occasionally if I have time after our meeting finishes, I go up into the Strangers' Gallery and watch the debates in the House of Commons. This is a privilege that is open to every UK citizen and overseas visitor, and something of which we can be justifiably proud. The Members' Dining Room serves an impressive level of cuisine, and if you are also lucky enough to be treated to tea on the Terrace on a sunny summer day, this view from the banks of the Thames is breathtaking.

Well worth a visit. London has many attractions and it is impossible to choose which one is the best tovisit and which one gives you value for money, so my husband and I decided to visit the Houses Of Parliment. We booked in advance on the internet, very easy to do. I must saywhat a lovely experience, we had a guided tour which lasted 1 & 1/2 hours and the timeflew by. We both learned more about the kings & Queens of England and all parlimentmembers through history than one could ever learn through reading books or watchingtelevision programmes. You have to go through a security proccess much like airports, which one can understand. The tour guide was lovely and very knowledgable and youcould ask any questions you wish. There is a coffee shop and obviously toilet facilities. The Houses Of Parliment is very easy to get to by underground, and the sight of Big Ben greeting you is magnificent. I would certainly recommend visiting the House Of Parliment .
The seat of British government and oozing with history. Interesting, absorbing and hard on the feet if you dont wear comfortable shoes.

If you can get an 'insider' to show you around, so much the better!. So much to see and do - and you'll be amazed at just how big the place is, and how small the two 'Houses' are - certainly not as big as they look on television.
A must see. Didnt even know they did tours till we passedLoved every second of it and will be returning for a mid week debate viewing

Fascinating tour. Brilliant - went on a tour of the house of Commons and House of lords a few years ago and couldn't  believe how  interesting it was - and how tradition has been passed down through the centuries

Fascinating history. It is well worth taking a tour of the Houses of Parliament. All the guides' tours are different because they each research their own information. It means no two guided tours are the same. A great way to spend some time in London
Very good for photographers. Beautiful detail on its arcitecture! and lovely surroundings.

terrible place. think it should be turned into an hotel or waterpark, really has nothing to do with the here and now - a big part of the reason politicians misbehave and we don't get representation. let's build a new building fit for the information age and consign this punch and judy show to history

beautiful. Houses of Parliament are stunning, and when approached from the right angle, breathtaking. The wonderful thing about London is all the most iconic landmarks are within walking distance of each other - Buckingham Palace and Downing St are only blocks from Houses of Parliament and Big Ben, Wesminster Abbey is just down the road, and London Eye and Tower of London are just across the Thames.
Awesome!. This is a must see when visiting London. Beautiful building with long history.

A MUST VISIT place, when in London.. Heritage, heritage, heritage.... A wonderful building. The seat of power for Great Britain.
It is a marvelous place to visit. OK, you might have to stand in line, and wait to get in to see the place, but it is worth it. GO THERE!

Step back in history. You really do feel like you're stepping back in history; fabulous architecture and it's just a great overall experience - and totally free! Try and visit the House of Commons chamber when there's an important debate scheduled - although there will probably be queues for the public gallery. And don't miss the House of Lords. Excellent.

Houses of Parliament. It has to be seen, just to say it has been.
Look for the police with H&K machine guns!
CLASSICALLY SPECTACULAR. Beautiful architecture, the building is very well maintained. Spectacular view of it from the Westminster Bridge.

One of the nicest monuments in London. I have done this tour several times with different clients and also with friends visiting London. I would say that this is probably my favorite monument in town, although the experience really varies depending on the guide you have (you must have a guide for doing the tour for security reasons). I've done the tour with Marc Belben (one of the guides) and it was superb! Marc is very professional and charming and I just loved listening to him. The rest of the times I have had different guides and some of them were boring to death! Anyway I think is worthy taking the risk because if you are lucky enough to have one of the good guides the experience is simply unforgettable!
nice. It was interesting to see where the english politicians work and play

Amazing history. if you live in the UK your local MP can arrange a tour for you - regardless of Party allegiances. I would say DO IT! Even if you're not into politics, the pomp and history surrounding this building cannot fail to make an impression. I am sure that they do tourist visits too so it's worth looking into if you are a foreign visitor to London.

A Great Art Museum.. When I visited the Houses of Parliment and the Westminster Palace I was amazed seeing all this work of art both the architecture and all the great paintings. Entering the only surviving part of the old Palace of Westminster gives you a strange feeling specially if you know the history and what events took place there through the centuries. The Houses of Parlament are one big tresure of nearly everything but sadly not well known to public.
Emblematic. Going to London and not going to the Houses of Parliament is like going to Vatican and not going to see the Pope. One of the most emblematic attractions in London!

An iconic symbol of an iconic City. A majestic palace that houses the British Partliament, Westminister is perhaps the most well known iconic image of the City. A visit to this place is a must while touring London. Beautiful building and superb maintenance makes this one of the finest attractions in London.

Unexpected views... U feel like a bit in museum... they have inside great collection of arts,, nice views from windows if u lucky.. nice coffe and gift shop.Rough to get there and all security takes time but obvious,, if u like history then is really enjojable .. ( havent been on big ben tower:() excluded for visitors in that time as i was... recomended on rainy day.

Almost more breath taking than the Abbey. The night we arrived in London we went for a walk around town and when we passed the parliament and big ben and to be honest, we weren't that impressed. We even made a joke about how they should just start calling it Ben. Then we went in the day and HOLY, I was speechless. The whole building shines in gold and the detail and carvings that cover the whole Parliament are absolutely stunning. What's more amazing is it's so old that everything's been done by hand. There is more detail here than on the Westminster Abbey. It's worth a walk over to see, especially in the daylight. You won't be disappointed. If you head over to the Westminster Abbey you can see the original burial spot of Oliver Cromwell (the statue in front of the Parliament), and hear how that ended. You have to be a Brit to be able to go in the Parliament so don't get your hopes up.
Take the tour. Tours are only on Saturdays but really excellent. Lots of history, amazing building. Well organized.
Touristy things to do. One of the places to tick you have been too but only outside not inside

awesome. This place is absolutely awesome, from the royal robe room to the houses themselves it is all facinating and worth a visit, I think you can go for free if you contact your MP but we paid £15 each for a tour on a Saturday when the houses are empty.This shows the pomp and ceremony of the british parliament in its full glory, as you can imagine security is tight and cameras not allowed but is really worth a visit

Best free day out I've ever had.. If you write to your MP they have to arrange a date for you to visit. Michael Gove's office and his PA Karen were just brilliant. We had a great tour, it was interesting, fun and very informative. I got a chance to stand at the dispatch box in the commons and the House of Lords. Being able to touch history really brings it alive. Seeing and touching the marks on the table were Churchill’s ring bashed into it during his War time speeches was my highlight. The building and the architecture is amazing, truly inspiring. My only downside is the sadness that we’re never going to build such architectural master pieces again. Worth a letter to your MP without a doubt.
Fascinating!. You have to experience a tour of parliament! An event not to be missed!

The mother of all visits. How can you not be impressed by standing the despatch box used by the likes of Gladstone, Churchill and Thatcher.Guides were knowledgable and displayed a great sense of humour. The tour nicely paced and appropriate duration.Great tour

Brilliant Tour. The tour was fantastic, The lady that showed us around was very good and her knowledge was spot on ! Big Ben tour would have been good but is now closed to public tours.Not recommended if you have walking difficulties as the tour is long with only a couple of sit down spots.

5-star attraction. This is a must-see if you are interested in history and/or architecture. The downside, after airport security screening, is being herded around and treated like children - don't sit there, don't stand there, but our guide was interesting and gave an excellent potted history, and the parts of the building where the monarch goes are spectacular. Some reviews mention photos: as of January 2012 photos are allowed only in the medieval Hall, strictly no cameras after that point. A flight of stairs to begin the tour. Book in advance at http://www.parliament.uk/visiting/

Essential. There tend to be mixed feelings when considering a visit to the palace of Westminster. Politics, surely, is dull, and there must be limitations as to what you can see due to security considerations. Not a bit of it. Whatever your feelings about politics this is an awe-inspiring, intimate journey into the heart of national power. Spending time in both the House of Lords and the House of Commons, accompanied by a knowledgeable and passionate guide, this is essential viewing for all. The palace itself is spectacular and drips with opulence. The history could not be more significant. Whatever your preconceptions, take this tour. Aim for a weekday morning to ensure you can get into every part of the tour, then stay around for a debate in the afternoon. This is a glimpse of the history of yesterday, set in the living, beating heart of the history of tomorrow

Love it!!. This is a very good experience! You can see live the people that you see on TV and understand how does it work. Additionally the bulding is fantastic and they make the visit a really nice experience for democracy

You can go inside. If you queue up in the morning you can go and watch parliament in action. If you are not familiar with the UK parliament I'd recommend you opt to visit the House of Lords because it is the older and the most beautiful of the two debating chambers.

one of the most important places in the whole world. one of the most important places in the whole world due to its long history of decisions made there, which were crucial for most of the know world in the past. Buildings are lovely and their climate is amazing. you have to see it
Sign up for the Tour. The guided tour is the best way to go. If you are not a UK resident, the tours are only available on Saturdays and extended days during the summer.

Amazingly interesting Tour by Tim at Houses of Parliment. Excellent tour by a very knowledgeable guide! The security is a little bit scary but apart from that, a world class experience! The tour guide took us through the history of the monarchy and the establishment of the palace of Westminster, the various fires and phases of rebuilding, the art movements in relation to the architecture, materials and methods used in the interior detailing. He also explained various historical dramas that happened in the Palace of Westminster and the development of the modern political system we have today. I learnt so much about the history of our political system and how it works now, was great to stand in the house of lords and commons! Well worth a visit!
great. great views dont forget your camera! Nice site which makes the long journey worth it.
A Must See. Excellent don't miss it! The area around the parliament is amazing with sea world across the bridge. Great place for pictures and food. We had great Belgian waffles beside sea world.
great experience. loved the whole tour so interesting would love to go again
Big Government. I loved the shape of the building and seeing it from the London Eyeat night.
Interesting but dragged on.. had a tour here on a school trip. was very interesting but dragged on a bit...

Power House. From a dark dirty and gothic horror, this place has cleaned up to a place that on a sunny day looks like a Golden Palace. The interiors are as spectacular as the exterior. If you get invited there, go! If you don't get invited, go on a tour. If you can't afford that, visit the Strangers Gallery for free - but remember, you have to behave yourself up there much better than the 'powers that be' are behaving themselves down in the chamber!! Order, Order!!

Spirit of Glory. This is my fifth visit to London and I always go to see the Houses of Parliament on the day of arrival. I physically feel the tension and spirit of the place. To understand Great Britain, you have to be there!
Get to know what goes on. The guided tour was very interesting and good value. The tour went from one end of the building to the other with the guide explaining everything that goes on
Iconic!. Stay on the opposite side and get the pictures for the whole view in the photo> you will remember it for ever.
Lovely walk along the river. It's great to visit, just to see these magnificent buildings, great photo opportunities and there is usually something going on the green in front.

The House of Parliament; Democracy in Action. A highlight of our trip to London was our visit to Westminster Palace to watch British government in action. When Parliament is in session they often work on Monday nights as late as 10:00 pm. We went through security and were given badges to wear on lanyards. We first went toward the House of Commons and were told to expect a wait of up to an hour. But our timing was perfect. We walked right in and found seats in the balcony where we could both watch the members on the floor or for close-ups watch the TV monitors placed around the balcony.The debate that night appeared to be about an amendment from the Opposition party that would have allowed unemployed to receive stipends from the government even if they had up to £50,000 in savings. The attendance during the debate was quite sparse but when the vote was finally taken members poured in to vote. First an oral vote was taken and the decision of the presiding officer was that the amendment was defeated. But then a second vote was taken on the question and this time the officer cried in a loud voice for a ‘Division of the House’. This time members walked through one door to vote yes and another door to vote no. After a time the presiding officer yelled out ‘to lock the doors’ and voting was finished. Shortly thereafter he announced the voting results.Having watched both a debate and vote in the House of Commons we then left and made our way to what was now a waiting line to get into the House of Lords. The wait was not too long and we soon were able to sit in the balcony overlooking the much more ornate House of Lords. We watched for a while but left before any vote occurred. The subject of the debate appeared to be over a trade issue with the Common Market and whether a government should be able to veto a contract that did not favor a domestic industry. One of the debaters was a Lord wearing bright red socks. The Lords did not look as sophisticated as I expected that they might.Parliament in action is worth watching wherever you are from but for Americans it was wonderful seeing the more intimate atmosphere of the British Parliament.
Public Gallery. I wrote to our MP for tickets to the public gallery and we weren't disappointed, it was great to see what actually happens, and we even recognised some faces.

Absolute must see!. Fantastic tour by staff who know what they're talking about and have a passion for Parliament. The history and stories came alive through a brillant tour guide who adapted to her group's various backgrounds.We are not UK nationals so we booked ourselves onto a Saturday tour. We've been to a few similar tours around the world (US Capitol Hill, NZ Parliament) and this was one of the best.Walked through the House of Commons and House of Lords, saw the Queen's Robe Room and the corridors throughout.
A mist see for any tourist. Old English history and the seat of power. Check out the clock, Big Ben is the name of the bell inside
Awesome from the outside. Great views from all sides, stunning architecture.
Iconic. Such an iconic land mark, a must see in London and great on Photos

beautiful architecture, great learning experience. I felt that a trip to London was not complete without visiting one of the most famous British institutions. I was not disappointed. You need to buy tickets to get in unless you are British and generally only Saturday is possible. We bought ours online at ticketmaster and picked them up at a booth a short distance from the entrance which faces Westminster abbey. There is heavy security and a tour guide is required. Our guide was excellent.

Excellent photos!. Obviously a well known landmark and a great photo opportunity and easily accessed from Westminster underground station. This is a tourist haven and plenty of outlets selling London related presents to take back home with you. Plenty of other tourist places to visit around the area and this is one to put on your list of things to do. We also caught the river cruis from Westminster pier which again offers great photos of the building from the river.

Houses of PARLIAMENT. Worth a visit, tours last 75 minutes and the guides are excellent, both knowledgeable and with a smattering of humour thrown in. Well worth the tour price, though there are ticket agencies outside the building offering slightly discounted prices on those published.
Amazing living history. A must visit. Long queues but the most amazing Pugin building.
Looks great at night with the lights. loved thsi at night time sitting in a cafe over looking the river and these
The mother of all democracies!. A wonderful testament to political freedom! Remember - Big Ben is the bell; not the bell tower!

Amazing insight into British Democracy. The building designed & built by Pugin quite reasonably drove him mad! Never seen such an ornate and insanely theatrical place. A strange mixture of village and public school, the two chambers and many corridors make this an odd place to conduct daily business in the modern world. The medaeval hall is the most impressive strangely. The worst thing about it is the toadying behaviour of the lower 'ranks' of staff who fawn and tug their forelocks whenever confronted by an MP. No wonder British democracy is a bit of a travesty! It's like a theme park!
had to take a look. one of those buildings that actually looked more impressive from TV screen rather than in the flesh

Finally saw this place - graet. We have been to London many times and have tried to get into the houses of Parliment, finally found a site which offers a guided tour for around 10 pound. Great tour and great place to visit, well worth the money - dont miss thistour.
I could just stand there and look at them all day. They are just brilliant. I love the look of them and to know the history behind them is great.
Must visit. No reviews can justify the actual visit. A trip in the past which is well worth the effort, in the to appreciate its cultural and political impact in world history.

tours!. Went here on a tour with my study abroad program. Who knew that you could just take a tour any given day. You can even sit in on Parliament in this pseudo "sky box" looking area. Many people don't know that you can just do that. Security is tight, but also expected and its kind of a neat aspect of it going through security and getting a badge just to enter. It was also a privilege to learn so much about British Government. I ever outsmarted my London boss by being to places he has never been before. This is a great treat to anyone interested in law.
Tours are amazing!. Great tour guide, beautiful parliament...great stories...totally reccommend!
Always a must see. Take the train and very quickly and easily see all the major attractions, starting with the Parliment building.
Red carpet treatment. Led by a very knowledheable guide, it was like walking through history.
Magnificent buildings .... ... both at night and in the day time. Walked along the Thames and saw them from across the river when they were lit up. With Big Ben's clockfaces shining brightly as well.
Nice for pictures. Great for holiday snaps. Can see many other sites in the area
Commanding presence. Interesting place to visit, particularly if you get a chance to see the various chambers. Pity you can't take pictures of this fascinating glimpse into the halls of power...

see democracy ... or such. Well worth the visit (go late in the day, no line-ups). Well organized, knowleadgeable staff, ready to answer any questions and engage in discussions. Interesting to see the sleeping peers of the realm and the debates falling on the deaf ears across the aisle. It is an impressive place well worth going.
Impressive Building. How such a impressive building can be built like this i do not know. Attached to Big Ben this is worth a visit
Just like Australia. The size of the place, condition and heritage. One can see where Australian system comes from.
My best view form the city of my dreams. The most beautyful view from London, particularly up to the London Eye.
The history is great. Guides are really good and the building is fantastic.

Best part of our trip!. We loved the tour of Parliament. The tour guides were very knowledgeable, the tour size was small enough so that we could ask questions and the history of the palce is amazing.
Nice place to roam around in central london. Nice place to roam around in central london just close to Big ben. If you want to spend some quality time just roam around river thames

Great guided tour!. Booked guided tour on the phone. Really worth going to see....good explanations, very well organized and fun to sit in an MP´s seat. Loved all the gossipy titbits which make History so interesting.
Classic English History. Great way to get a feel of how and why England once ruled the world and how the UK's political system helped shape many of the countries aound the globe

Wonderful to walk in the footsteps of the Great and Powerful. Thoroughly recommended. We booked ahead on ticketmaster
I'm a political junkie and enjoyed every minute of this marvellous experience.
So iconic!. Beautiful architecture! It was amazing to finally see this building that I had always seen in pictures and on TV. Go both during the day and night--two completely different scenes.

Interesting look into our Governance. We prebooked this online and attended with our teenage sons. You have to go through security to begin with but this doesn't take long and you soon enter the Westminster Great Hall to begin your tour. We all found this tour really interesting, the art work on the walls was stunning and we were all surprised how small both the Houses of Commons and Lords really are.Would really recommend this tour.

Always wanted to see it. We didn't plan and book for a visit inside the parliament. Yet we strolled around the place took good pictures from both side of the River. We saw the building from various places . Its a beautiful building. A must visit for one who studied political science .
Parliament. Did not get to go inside. That has to be pre arranged months in advance. Plus many historical landmarks were closed because of the holiday.

Amazing Architecture. The Houses of Parliament are a must see on your walk through London. The architecture is amazing (as with most of the historical buildings in London. It's such a sight to see at night time when it's all lit up!

Incredible access inside a historic building. As a Londoner I was amazed to be able to walk inside such a historic building and see the rooms actually used by government for real. Incredible feeling to be sat on the green leather of the house of commons straight out of PMQs. A must when it is open.
Worth a visit. Went here at the end of the day when the queues were gone. Great to see this place from the inside and worth the trip.
Political views. Wonderful photo opportunities from either side of the river

London "Must Do". The tour is excellent value and gives a fantastic glimpse inside the workings of Westminster.It is only available during Parliament's Summer recess though- so plan your visit accordingly.
Excellent tour. Tour exceeded my expectations. Would recommend that everyone goes.

A Must See View at Night. See Parliment at night!
You can't go in, but just seeing the building with its gorgeous lights along The Thames, next to Big Ben is enough for that tourist attraction check mark.
Take a stroll along The Thames but make sure to cross Westminster Bridge for the view across the river.
outside only. we visited the site as you are unable to enter but is a very impressive building to been seen from all sides by various methods ie walking, hop on hop off bus and the london eye
STUNNING. Beautiful building, can't miss it so don't worry about not being able to find it!!
Worth a visit. On a guided tour of the Houses of Parliament you get to enter both the Commons and Lords and learn about some of the history of the place, much of which you might be surprised by!

not to be missed. Its about history, the magna carta, the independence of parliament from the crown, its seeing and feeling where the debates take place at the dispatch box, and if your lucky to go to the shop to buy some very exclusive gift items. Brilliant tour take as little as you can with you as you will go thru a stringent security check and have to leave phone behind in safe keeping

A very pleasant suprise. I went to this not expecting to enjoy it at all (dragged along!) but once in I loved the tour. Educational in a fun and funny way. Our guide Adam was a real hoot, bringing the history alive and truly making the whole thing wonderful.Not boring at all, but for the politics lover it's a must. But not for kids- a lot of standing.Be prepared for a full security check!A must in London

Very interesting. We did an official "tour" of the Houses of Parliament a couple of summers ago. It was very interesting to hear about the mechanics of Parliament. The Commons is much smaller when you see it than you expect it to be, in fact there is not really enough seats if every MP turned up as happens for "Three Line Whips". The tour takes on the same route the Queen does when she opens Parliament. At the end you can visit the old Westminster Hall, remaining part of the old Westminster Palace, which is very historical seeing trials such as Thomas More and more recently the laying in state of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother. I did wonder if the tour might be boring but it was anything but. I would recommend it.

Great to look at. Walking passed and taking photos is one of the options. I didn't take a tour throughout but merely admired from a close distance. Well worth to have a look at the Parliament as there is a lot of history.
Interesting. Really interesting tour with a very knowledgeable guide. Probably the only time I will enter the House of Lords!
Sit in the house of commons. You can actually sit on th visitors bench and see the live debate going on. This will give you a truly realistic impression of british politics!
Sat in on a live debate. we were able to see in on a debate in the house of Lords. it was really interesting and an exciting this to do. They were debating about healthcare..

Everyone should go. The tour is excellent! It is well paced and very good value for money. The Houses of Parliament tour gives you the history of the building as well as taking you into the Commons and House of Lords. If you have ever watched it on television then go and see it yourself. I was actually surprised at how much smaller it is than it seems on tv.

The one and only. Worth the queue and the security. Working time capsule from another age. It is possible as a UK citizen/voter to access the building, simply asking to see your MP to whom a message will be pasased if they are in the House at the time. Many visitors probably regard it as more of a museum than a functioning place of work so if access seems difficult and limited I guess remember that security restrictions apply to this and all public buildings in this age. Allow lots of time in the summer.Also worth visiting is the Parliamentary bookshop on a stand-alone site on the corner of Whitehall/Bridge Street (near where everyone stands to get a picture with Ben Ben clock/St Stephen's tower in the back ground. In the immediate area check out the underground architecture of Westminster tube station - 120ft below the ground and the River Thames.

Really worth a stop to see the history of England. Brillaint place to visit. The historical perspectives and amazing rooms and art work are worth the time. A completely different feel from other spots.

History at its Finest. As a student, I interned in the House of Commons, it was an incredible place to work--everyday walking into the building was like stepping back in time. I've kept in touch with friends who work here and my old boss, and knew when I took my husband for his first visit that we would undoubtably take a tour. If you are a UK resident, you can sign up for a tour for free, if you are a non-resident, there is a fee, but this 75 minute tour is absolutely incredible and worthwhile. You only need to do it once in your life and you will remember it for a lifetime. Not suitable tour for kids under 8 as it is a lot of walking and a longer tour.

the most interesting tour. We have all seen on news reports every night of term but to take a tour of Westminister is memorable. We had a great guide and were able to walk by the seats in the House of commons and the Red seats of the Lords. The sense of History is palpable. Top attraction for me in London
Great for sightseeing. Although we didn't go into the houses of parliament, the views were absolutely phenomenal!
Majestic building. This is one of the most characteristic buildings of London. You can't miss this place, specially for the Big Ben!
London Must-see. Take your pics and go. Nothing really else to see other than the buildings from the outside. Getting inside not worth the effort.
Interesting. We were lucky enough to get a behind the scenes visit courtesy of our local MP, very interesting
Closed. Closed on a Friday when i went. But just walking around it was nice.

A building full of history - well worth the visit. I booked a private tour of Parliament through my MP (anyone can request this through their mp, but do it well in advance of a trip as they are usually booked up quite a bit beforehand). The tour starts with airport style security checks at the entrance before entering the Palace of Westminster (Westminster Hall). This is where your private guide will meet you and advise you of the history of the hall, its various purposes (you can see the plaques where various kings, queens and former PM's lay in state). The guide will then take you into the main building and allowed us access into the restricted areas of parliament such as the Royal Chambers, the houses of lords and the house of commons. It was great to see these rooms I had seen on TV so many times and stand in the spot where the Prime Minsiters of this country have put forward the laws that have created the Britain we know today, it was also brilliant to see the history and hear about the traditions that encompass the building that controls out country.This was my second tour of Parliament and both times the guides had been very knowledgable, but on this occasion the guide recognising we were Scottish customized with a scottish them which was much appreciated. From this tour you are free afterwards to meet with your mp, visit the public areas such as the galleries or the restaurant and just take in the crowds in the center of the building infront of the post office.This tour is free to all british citizens and is well worth doing. I also got to purchase some House of Commons Scotch Whisky from the tourist shop - A nice 10yo malt from Speyside which I have yet to sample but have added to my collection.
wonderful lesson. everyone living in a democracy must visit the mother of Parliaments

Threadbare Seat of Power !. A great place to visit for my birthday and see the then Pimeminister, James Callaghan, snoring through a 'Tenants Land Rights' bill !It looks fantastic and quite imposing from a River boat too.
Democracy in action!. This trip I was able to see the hearings conducted by Parliament about "phone hacking and invasion of privacy" by some of the media - great!

It's not authentic...it's the real one. The Halls of Parliament are actually functioning government. you can queue in at various hours, but if you come at a slack tourist time, you can sit, quietly, and watch the Lords or Commons in session. The walk in brings you through history, and the passersby are likely the faces you saw on the news this morning. Skip the Wax Museum, this is reality TV before they invented TV.

Awesome. We walked right in with no waiting. Security was easy to get through. We were able to sit, quietly, and observe both the House of Lords and House of Commons. As a student of American Government, it was particularly interesting for me.
The Best River Side Bar In Town. Make friends with your MP. It is worth it to sip a beverage on this amazing terrace. Got to be the Best Thames-side view in London.
DEC 2011. Unable to go inside but the just the architecture is mind blowing
Awesome. and very beautiful, as most of london. Liked it very much
Felt like going back in time. I hadn't realised what an amazing place this was. You could sense the history. Made me proud to be British
Loved it. This is history and I love older buidings. Quite impressive

History feast!. Just incredible to stand at the Despatch box in the House of Commons and imagine you are the PM! The history in this place is incredible and the guides help bring it to life with anecdotes, historical events and current events too. Thoroughly enjoyed it - took about 1 hour 20 mins. Be warned - it wasn't the warmest - maybe the heat is turned down at the weekends!
Old but Wonderful. Architecture that lasts and lasts. Use the Hop-On Hop- Off bus to get around and save money.

Excellent!. Needs to be pre-booked via your MP but very interesting and worthwhile. We were lucky with Eric, our tour guide, as he was witty, informative and had an excellent way with people. Some other guides (groups follow in quick successsion) seemed to bark and bray at their groups -very distracting. The buildings were magnificent and well worth seeing.
Running the country!!. All lit up at night and looked wonderful. Very impressive to look at and makes you wonder how the running of the counrty was going!! Big Ben looked fab!!

Totally magnificient. Visiting the Houses of Parliment and seeing Westminster hall, Commons and Lords chambers, Division lobbies, central hall was truly amazing. Saw a procession as the Speaker walked to the chamber. Visiting Big Ben after climbing 337 steps and lisitening to the chimes at midday was another treat.
Worth a visit!. Went for the visitor tour. Great tour of House of Commons and House of Lords. Amazing history in the building, great guide who was very knowledgable. Well worth a visit!
A very exiting experience. A very exiting experience. Remember to order tickets before you arrive
You've just got too!. If in London this is a must. fantastic tour giving loads of info about the history of the Parliament. Beautiful building and very atmospheric

A little bit of history in the making. Didn't manage the tour round, but enjoyed seeing up close these grand old buildings that we're so used to seeing in the media. Very friendly policemen around that we had a good chat with.
fabulous. Went into the house of lords to hear a debate on a human trafficing bill-big ben was beautiful

An extremely interesting visit. Seeing that the Houses of Parliament is now open for tours on Saturdays, we decided to pay a visit and were rewarded with an extremely interesting hour and a half tour of the building. The building itself is full of history and our well informed guide provided us with a fact filled tour that keep us enertained for the whole visit. We turned up on the off chance and had to wait for less than 30 minutes before we started the guided tour. The history of the building before becoming the home of Parliament was interesting and is home to some excellent artefacts.
Crazy cool!. We walked out of the tube and right into the base of the Big Ben clock tower! Amazing building.

House of Parliamnet - Great Architecture. We enjoyed the viewing the building and Big Ben from the bridge, the riverfront pedestrian walk, and various other locations - both during the day and night. Excellent!
Neat building. We did not go inside but it was worth walking by. Great photo spot.

You don't eat here for the food, it's the setting and the company.... Unless you're a member you have to be invited. Once through security you can sense how relaxed it is. The food is fine - something between a 'posh' hotel and the very best school dinner you can imagine. The setting is awesome, with views over the Thames and a genuine sense of being in the bosom of the Mother of all Parliaments. Don't ogle but if you look about you there will be faces that you recognise from the news and a good chance that you'll be sitting close to one of your political heroes - from either the UK or abroad.
andrewinlondon2011. fantastic buildings to visit, Need to book in advance but is well worth it. Fantastic and informative guide. Wonderful interiors
Got a behind the scenes tour and it was AMAZING. the House of Commons and House of Lords is great, plus you can feel the history from Westminster Hall.

The tour makes history come alive!. You are led off in groups of about 20 with very interesting guides who know not only the basic history of the place but all sorts of little stories and nuances that they are happy to share. Seeing the places where so much took place was amazing. The House of Lords and the House of Commons are different places in decor, majesty, etc. You cannot sit in any of the chambers so be prepared to stand for the tour which takes less than an hour. Seeing St. Stephen's Hall with it's own history and grace is also a treat. Be sure to take a look around the property as you are entering after buying your ticket and as you exit. There can be timing issues as the tours don't take place while the Houses are in session so be sure to check before you go.

Impressive - without the MPs!. Lovely buildings, steeped in history and well worth visiting. Quite easy access & friendly security.Need a guide to appreciate the experience and, if you are lucky, you will enjoy their expertise & the opportunity to ask questions.Allow over an hour and don't expect to be able to sit down on any green or red leather benches!Not sure our current MPs deserve their lovely HQ.
A window on democracy. Entrance to the Houses of Parliament including the public galleries of the House of Commons and House of Lords is free.
A must see. One of the attractions in all the pictures of London, definitely worth seeing in order to complete your trip to this city!
Well worth a look. What beautiful buildings - lovely. If you are in London go and have 2 looks - one in the day and one at night!

An interesting historical visit. It is worth a visit once at least. The art and architecture of Parliament is interesting, there is a tremendous sense of history and scandal about the place, the guides are very knowledgable and passionate about there subject. Paintings, rugs, tapestries, and of course the chambers; The Lords and the famous green benches, which you can't sit on! The ceiling in the debating hall worth a glare, post a card for a parliament postage mark, statutes of bygone Prime Misiters. We took our children, who enjoyed it. Give a couple of hours for the visit.
The Picture. The View is like a god made heaven of building on land. if you like history you are gonna love this master piece,

Great Place To Visit, No Debate.. Brilliant. An eye opening introduction to what always seemed (on TV) as a somewhat dry and dusty place. Not so, the guide bought the place to life and we were able to see the this wonderfull establishment. It will never seem the same on TV again.Worth booking on line. the timed tours were on time so no waiting around.
Pure traditional London. It is worth a walk around the area, including the small garden by the river, to get a taste of London.
pomp and regalia. took 20 people. was amazed with the inside of this buildng. stunning and had an excellent guide who was quite hilarious.
Worth A Visit. Enjoyed the architecture and history of it and to some extent the political machinations

MP's Parliament Tour. Any British Citizen can book one of these tours through their MP. It was 75 mins long and so interesting. Our Guide was brilliant, surprisingly from the US but she made everything come to life and certainly knew her history. We were allowed in both houses; such a privilege! Fascinating and highly recommended.

The Fulfillment of a Dream. Feel the atmosphere of ages. See where laws of the greatest empire were written. And imagine it has been the same for centuries! Very nice that you can make your own pictures inside...
Truly amazing. What a fantastic building. It looks even better when standing in front of it and is much bigger than it looks on the television

1000 + Years of a Glorious History. The Houses of Parliament tour is truly one of the finest historical and cultural experiences one can encounter when in London. The Parliament docents provide both informative and entertaining insights that will provide patrons of all ages a memorable encounter with history.
Great View. The Houses of Parliament look great at night and day in London. A brilliant landmark.

A must for everyone. A 75 minute guided tour of the Houses of Parliament which is both entertaining and informative. The UK has an amazing history and much of it has been played out in this fantastic building. The guides (we have been twice in 2011) are very knowledgeable.
awe inspiring. First time here and would certainly visit again very well organised and very friendly towards to visitors , satff could not be better. What a place!
Brilliant.. The Mother of all Parliaments finally restored so the scaffolding has gone and it can be seen in all its neo-gothic glory.

I stood where the PM stands for PMQ's. For anyone with any kind of love of history this is a must do activity. Virtually every step has a story. Guide was informative and mildly funny and I stood at the despatch box in the House of Commons where the Prime Minister stands and is held to account by MP's....
beautiful building.... Well, I guess one of the most beautiful buildings in London. Huge and impressive. It's a shame you normally can't visit it as you go (as far as I know)...
Great.. Loved the old architecture and history. This place is beautiful in real life.

Excellent. We had a great time in here. Got some good souveniers and had a nice light lunch and cream tea after. So much history. Try to go on a group without teenage foriegn students.
Didnt really spoil it for us but could have as they really were not interested.

Well worth a guided tour. We went as part of a private party but the visit included a guided tour which was very enjoyable and informative, including both chambers. Our tour took around 45 minutes. Security was tight but very good-humoured and our guide was excellent. Not sure about arrangements for general public to visit but worth it if you get the chance.

Superbly done. We went on one of the Saturday opening tours. The guide was superb and gave us a wonderful insight into the Houses of Parliment and their history. You get to visit both chambers (sitting on the benches is strictly forbidden) and see behind the scenes. There were plenty of anecdotes and a lot of unexpected details that got people laughing. The tour does involve quite a lot of walking (including one quite long set of steps) and going through some tight security and is not recommended for people of limited mobility, but it is well worth doing. Tours are also offered in various languages apart from English. You have timed entry, with a group of 20 entering every 15 minutes. For anyone with a love of history, politics or architecture it is a must. Photography is strictly forbidden once the tour has started, but is permitted in St. Stephens Hall and you can, for example, photograph yourself standing by the plaque marking the spot from which Nelson Mandela addressed the two Houses on the steps of the Hall.

Houses of Parliament. Remember to plan in advance as this tour only takes place on saturdays and is heavily booked. I had to wait 3 trips before I managed to get an entry.Loads of history, some splendid architecture and interesting facts on politics and the monarchy.The guides are great.

History, Politics & Architecture...What's Not to Love?. Touring the Houses of Parliament was one of the highlights of my trip. Although it wasn't overly crowded, the tour groups were being whipped through at an impressive rate. The voice of our (female) guide was often times drowned out by the nearby male guides and I did wish there was more space between groups. Anyone who loves current civic events and history will thoroughly enjoy this tour and it's well worth carving out a couple of hours during your trip and booking ahead.

very majestic on the waterfront. definitely a sprawling landmark that symbolizes London, along with the famous Big Ben. I wish we could have tour inside, but don't believe we're allowed unless you're a UK citizen. In any case, it's very picturesque, you can take a photo and not expend additional time here ...

Beautiful Palace. But could be avoided if you are running out of time. The palace is outstanding, but you aren't allowed to take much photos. If I hadn't much time in London, I would totally avoid this place.
Eat with your MP. Excellent meal with smooth service. Expensive but worthwhile.

Wonderful guided tour of pillar of democracy. My son organized our tour of the Houses of Parliament. It was extremely interesting. The guide was well-versed in the history of the building and its institutions and amusing, too. It is one of the oldest elected democratic bodies and both chambers are well worth visiting. The House o Lords is incredibly beautiful, as are all the rooms we visited.

Worth it!. This was an amazing experience, if you love politics, this is your place! There was a wait to get in but it was well worth it. Seeing from up above what goes on in Parliament was memorable. It'll be the first thing I'll do if I go back again!

First rate tour. Brilliant tour guide and we came away with so much knowledge that we didnt have before. The tour was free, having arranged it through our MP, but we would have gladly paid the admission cost for such a wonderful experience

History of a building, of democracy and of a nation. If only history was as interesting when I was at school.The tour of the House of Parliament tells not only the story of the building, demonstrates how democracy evolved and embodies the story of this great nation, it also takes you into the chambers and halls where the business of Parliament still takes place.Fascinating, I would encourage everyone to go!
Awesome. An awesome place to see and take pictures, do not miss seeing it from the London Eye!

fabulous attraction in London. This place is really a must see in London. One may skip it only if have very little time in London and have no time for tour. However if you only have 1 day in London, i really recommend the tour. 1.5 hours - very comprehensive, you learn a lot about how British legislative system and government works. Also based on the wood carved interior, this is really one of the most unique and beautiful parliament buildings i have seen in the world. I enjoyed the tour and highly recommend it in line with other London top sights - Buckingham palace and changing of guard, Tower, Tower Bridge.

We loved visiting the Houses of Parliament!. We were fortunate enough to be taken through the Houses of Parliament by a young man who was previously a page. The ancient banquet hall where William Wallace (Braveheart) was killed was the first part of this tour. We also saw groups of uniformed school children waiting for their tour when we were there. They looked like they had just stepped out of a Harry Potter casting. There was a central hallway between the House of Commons and the House of Lords with separate niches holding huge statues of the patron saints of each of the countries that comprise the United Kingdom. It was fascinating to see all this in person and I highly recommend it to everyone!
parliament visit. Excellent tour-had a very informative guide who kept it interesting.

Beautiful!. This is a beautiful and giant building! The big ben tower makes it noticieable from distance...you can take lovely snaps from other side of the river thames...keeping this building in backdrop. While seeing the building make sure yuo do not stand on the road or crossover roads ignoring the traffic!

Very interesting trip!. It was extremely interesting and i would definitely recommend going on a tour around the site if you are interested in the history of parliament and how everything works there.
Impressive.. Had not realised, from just looking at photos, how big and beautiful these buildings are. Big Ben is colossal.

well worth a visit. Very well organised tour Guide Andrew was brilliant he certainly knows his stuff. The tour takes you through the parts of the building you would never normally get to see. Be early for your booked tour though due to security checks.

One of the must-see objectives in London. A walk on Thames side will give you opportunity to see the major objectives in London.
The architectural masterpiece is one of the major objectives you should not miss.

Beautiful. We only seen Houses of Parliament from outside but still it made a huge impression !!!The building itself is amazing and magnificent !!!!! It looks the best from the London's Eye and I would recommend it to everyone !!!!

Great building. I only saw the exterior as it was a Sunday afternoon when I visited but learned a great deal about Big Ben and the tower on other tours (River Thames tour). Hearing the noon toll is a treat and walking the outskirts of the buildings was enough for me.
Must see govt in action. I wanted to see the Commons but settled for Lords. Sat for a 1/2 hour of an amendment to the education bill. Just to be there was great! We all grew from here

Top history. A superb visit externally.
If you want to go inside check with one of the police as for the best time.
Wednesday midday is Prime Minister's questions and busiest!
You will enjoy this visit!!

A Must See in London. We toured the Houses of Parliament on a Saturday, the only day non-UK citizens are allowed access to the building. Tours are by groups, which in our case only had 25 people. Our guide was knowledgable and interesting. We didn't feel crowded as the tours were arranged so they did not interfere with each other. Of special interest was the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Having watched Prime Minister's question time it was great to be there and see the room.

A must to visit. This was facinating. The tour goes from Westminster Hall through the House of Lords and then House of Commons.The guides a very knowledgeable and make the tour very interesing experiance.To my suprise, when in the Houses of Lords and Commons, we were not mearly standing behind velvet rope looking in. We were allowed to stand between the benches where MPs sit. The tour lasted about 1 hour and if you don't do anything else in London then this is the trip to do.

Even the teenager thought it was fantastic. We were visiting London for the first time in a long time, and had not pre-planned what attractions we were going to visit. We wandered past Westminster in awe of the building and decided to do a tour of the houses of parliament. We were lucky as it was only when we were doing this tour that we realised that it only runs on a Saturday. The guide was top notch, very informative and keeping us moving through the various rooms and chambers.The tour gave perspective to the operation of government and in walking past the front bench a dispatch boxes you are reminded of the famous leaders who had stood there making great speaches and decisions. The historical context from the Tudors and Stuarts to the modern era are all around you, and my teenage son thought it the highlight of the weekend. The guide was first class, and I would recommend that you include this visit in any plans you have. Cafe facilities on site are pretty good.

History in action. You will have to queue to gain access but the main hall is spectacular and being able to watch parliament in progress is worth the wait. Even if the debate is boring, just watching the MP's come & go, discuss & whisper is fascinating

A beautiful majestic building...... I took a disabled gentleman for a daytrip here and amenities were good (although a little 'antique') and the staff were very helpful. A specific guide was there to enable disabled peoiple to get to each floor in time for the speaking guide to continue with his tour promptly.
Interesting. It is interesting to watch parliament in action. Although the lines can be very long during the day, going at night had no line at all.

MPs call for Hillsborough papers release. If you want to witness history or part of the history making. Go to see any debates even late at night. I believed the debates are between 2pm to 10pm. If you are visiting the area, just drop by to see. It may surprise you.It was the night I would never forget. Being a Liverpool oversea supporter finally able to visit Liverpool was a great experience. I was able to attend the debate for Hillsborough papers release (see link below) was even greater. It was a historic night for Liverpool supports and many affected person on that tragic day. There was no line going into the parliament when it was after 8:30pm. The room was full of supporters. Everyone was happy!http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/house_of_commons/newsid_9614000/9614508.stm
Houses of Parliament. Magnificent building! The lady guide was the best one in UK!
Spectacular Building. Situated along the banks of the Thames with Big Ben along side this is a sight to behold. A beautiful Gothic building.
Fascinating. Booked this tour through our local MP, David Willets. Should of done this tour years ago. Loved it.
Very interesting tour. This was a wonderful tour with a wonderful guide. Get your tickets on Ticketmaster and do not miss!!

several long cues,. have seen a live debate in the evening. Took some time, because a lot of people were waiting. Outside the building a cue, and inside the building cues. Total waiting time 1 hour. still a unique experience.

Always Fascinating. At any time of the day, with the big bang, is a great place to take a picture. Around the area there are some roman ruins as well (not many ppl would know) and while you are there you can also visit Westminister Abbey.. Book a visit INSIDE if you have time

Breath taking!!!!. London is full of many glorious structures, but the Houses of Parliament is simply awe inspiring. You get a particularly good view of this from the London Eye. There are also tours of the inside of certain areas, so if interested check for times. This is a must see, highly recommended!!
Breathtaking. Big Ben was fantastic. And the Houses of Parliament looked majestic. So much better than when you see them on TV. So familiar!
Classic. Brilliant architecture as always extremely busy but must be done

Great day out!. Went with a group and were showed round by a guide. Long at the start, but soon gets interested in the chambers and committee rooms! Best to ask MP's for pass' as it means you can meet with them and access some different areas. Food on site also good, although slightly expensive, but; it is Parliament!

Totally blown away - fab destination!. This was absolutely brilliant. Had a private tour with our MP's PA. Would highly recommend this history filled destination that is so current and visually in the news everyday!
Amazing to see in real life. see where history is made, decisions are debated - and how small the actual rooms are..
Not to be missed. We got a free guided tour courtesy of our MP. It lasted almost 2 hours and was fantastic - house of commons , house of lords, robing room and the rest. Our guide was great as well.
mp's. went past houses of parliment I wish that they would guided tours so you get to see more of where the goverment sepnd most of there time
History at its best. A really interesting tour with very knowledgeable guides. Also the cheapest bar in town!!
Grandiose. Simply wow!!! The face of London and a sight to behold.

Ding Dong!. We enjoyed a fabulous tour of the Houses of Parliament. A very well informed guide was able to explain the history of the place and its traditions. Not sure if these tours are by invitation of your MP only.
Very interesting. Loved hearing the history behind this palace and seeing the scenes from TV

Free if you ask your MP. If you are a UK citizen you are entitled to free entry to the HoP, you just need to contact the constituency office and book a spare time.For this you get a 90 minute tour before the masses arrive, seeing both Houses, and bits you would recognise when you see Parliament on the TV. saw a few noted politicians on the walk around, really intersting and amazing interiors.
Incredible architecture. One of the most spectacular buildings I have ever seen - breathtaking!

A very worthwhile visit. I was lucky enough to be in London on a Saturday which is the only day that guided tours can be booked. There is so much to learn about this building and Andrew was a friendly and knowledgeable guide. He made everyone in the group feel involved and was so patient. The tour is well organised and good value for money. I hope I get the opportunity to visit during question time to complement this visit.

Amazing. Appointed the visit through ticketmaster.com, with some weeks in advance. No problem at all. Spanish guided tour. It started on time and the guide was really good. He explained lots of details on English parliamentary history. It's really amazing to notice the austerity in both the Lord's and Commons Chambers, something you don't expect. 1 hour and a half of a very complete tour. Highly recommendable,

Very plesantly surprised. We really only took the tour as our teenage daughter was studying Legal studies in Australia, so we thought it would be good for her....It was a very informative, enjoyable tour. Gave a great overview of how the system works. Loved hearing about how the Queen opens Parliament and also seeing the House of Commons and LordsWell worth it!!!

The Most Polite Insults and Impassioned Speeches I've Ever Experienced. We certainly enjoyed the architecture and design of the building and the tie-in with Big Ben; however, the best attraction for us was attending a session of the House of Commons (HOC), while they were discussing/debating controls over general policing, as an outcome of the riots that happened in August. It was a fascinating display of oratory, sarcasm and polite, orderly insulting that we should consider adopting in our own legislative processes! The MP's were really getting into the discussions with the representatives from 'the government', but always maintained a high level of parliamentary procedure to gain control of the floor and have their say. Brilliant!The House of Lords (HOL)...well...let's just say this: after watching the brilliant discourse in the HOC for well over 2 hours, watching 15 minutes of the HOL was like watching a display of rigor mortis. We'd love to go back to the HOC sometime when the PM is presenting!

Beautiful Building - Horrible host. The house of Parliment is absolutely fantastic - and all the gothic architecture breath-taking. You don't need a ticket to go in and listen to the statesmen speak - just name, address and phone number on an index card and you can sit in the gallery above the House of Commons or Lords. If you want to see the robing room, side areas and main building - then you must take the tour (for non-UK citizens).HOWEVER i had the awful misfortune of getting the worst tour guide (red, pink, orange haired, woman in her 60s - Eidon?), paired with being the only American (native English speaker) in a group of English as a second language tourists, including two Russian ladies that nearly got the whole group put in handcuffs.The tour was horrible !! as every few mins the guide was off tracking down the stragglers -- we lost a lot of the explanations and descriptions because by the time she got everyone in the right place, the next group was already pushing through. Luckily while we waited for the others - there was usually one or two other guide groups we could eaves drop on the other guide's descriptions of legal process or the architecture.Tour is about 90 mins, but make sure you arrive about 15mins before the tour start time as you have to go through a very lengthy security building, several ramps and cues.

Not to be missed.. At the age of 60+ I finally made a visit on a Saturday morning with an overseas visitor to the Palace of Westminster House of Parliament and House of Lords.Should have gone years ago! This place that we habitually see on TV is just amazing.I suggest to book tour on the internet to avoid queuing or disappointment and book the earleiest tour possible before it gets too busy. Study the website for opening days & times. If not prebooked the ticket office is across the road near Westminster Abbey.Security to get in is pretty daunting so the less you are carrying the better.Our guide was superb and clearly loved his job and took a pride in showing people around and somehow managed to remain non political.At first you collect for the tour in the great hall where there are toilets,gift shop & cafe.The tour commences with the House of Lords area and ends at the House of Parliament.What you will experience is pretty stunning. No photography except in great hall.Nearest metro is Westminster. There are good photo opportunities outside the building,To sum up just go ! Check open dates very carefully.

My Vote for a Top 3 London Attraction!. The guided tour of the Houses of Parliament was surprising very good. Overall I would rank it in the top 3 tourist attractions I have visited in London!I booked tickets ahead of time online, and it was well worth it. I waited in no lines, went right through security, waited about 5 minutes for the tour to begin.You get a great overview of how the British system works (as an American I had no clue) and get to see all the rooms seen on TV. The tour begins by following the Queens path through the opening of Parliament, and through that story you go through some of the less famous rooms - the story makes it very entertaining. You then go through both chambers (Lords and Commons) and get a great understanding at how Parliament works. I found it very educational.The guide was first-rate and really knew what he was talking about. I found him entertaining and engaging. There were many tours going on at once, but it was very well organized and you could hear the guide at all times.I also ate lunch at their cafe, and found the food to be very good and reasonablly priced. They also have very nice and free toliets, a rare find in London!Overall, I very highly recommend this tour. Be sure to book ahead of time, and beware of the opening times (summer opening and certain weekends...not open when in session).

Go During Summer Recess. We were fortunate to visit during the summer recess. We went on a group tour in the mid morning time frame. After finding the ticket office which is located across the street and down some steps we had a very short wait until out tour started. We had one of the best tour guides ever. She was very knowledgeable and answered all of our questions. I highly recommend visiting while the government is not in session. We were able to walk through the House of Lords and Commons. Our tour guide was able to give a good understanding of roles and responsibilities of both houses. Seeing both Houses from the floor was even more dramatic. As with any tour it is the tour guide that makes or break the tour and ours was top notch. Personally for me this was the most interesting tour during our trip to London.

Really enjoyed this. Because I am Canadian, it was interesting to see how British parliament is similiar to ours and how it is different. We booked our times before we landed in London, helped us organize our time. This is right next to Westminster Abbey.

Absolutely stunning. I just don't know why we haven't been before! It was a superb journey through history. The Houses of Parliament are stunning and the knowledgable guide added to the experience. At £10 per head, this has got to be amoungst the best value attractions in London.

Fascinating history of parliament. The tour of the houses of parliament and the lords is really fascinating if you want to learn about the history of our government and the palace as it was until Henry VIII. Westminster Hall and it's history is a real treat, where Guy Fawkes and Charles I stood trial. Highly recommended tour, full of facts and information.

Really really interesting. We took the kids on the Houses of Parliament and we all found it to be fascinating. Our tour guide was great and kept it interesting for everybody which was tricky given that some in the group broadly understood our political system while others were from overseas and did not know anything about it.In the hour and a quarter the guide covered architecture, art, politics, history, constitution, tradition and also squeezed in some very interesting stories.Excellent tour which has something for everyone

Dull, dull, dull. We had a private tour following a wonderful lunch at a nearby hotel and were really looking forward to thisbut I would not recommend this it was very dull. You don't get to see that much and the rules about where you can go are very strict. Our tour guide was bossy, officious and very, very boring. Made me feel like a naughty kid on a school trip, but there was no bunking off or being let out early, you have to stay with your guide at all times. There are no toilet stops and not many sit downs if you are the sort of person who might need these on a 1.5 to 2 hour trip. Such a shame as this is a place steeped in history and there must be many an amusing tale to tell. Going through the efficient airport style security was the highlight of the visit! It was nice to look at though! There is a toilet, small shop and cafe at the end. Save your money and go on a river trip instead.

The public galleries were free, but dull.. We did not do a guided tour, but rather attended a debate in the public galleries (house of commons). This was free, but going through security screaning, leaving your bags (even your purse), and waiting in line took about 40 minutes. Once we were seated in the gallery, we only stayed about 10-15 minutes, as we found it quite dull. So, if you are pressed for time, I would say this hour would be spent better elsewhere. In addition, you could only take photos in the first holding/waiting area.

Very interesting! and excellent value. Excellent! The tour of the Houses of Parliament lasted just over an hour in a group of about 20. The tour guide was a young man who got the balance just right between being informative whilst not waffling on. One thing we were surpised at is that the tour only takes you to certain parts of the houses of parliament (house of commons, Lords, Queens robbing room) - large amounts of the building are not visited. You are instructed to stay with your group at all times during the tour and you will always notice that the security guards and police officers within the building are ensuring that you do this!This was a bit of a shame as we would have liked to have spent longer in certain rooms and 'taking it all in' but it is understable that for security reasons this isn't going to happen.There is a nice cafe right by where the tours begin and end which was very reasonably priced.When booking our tour we had noted that you were not allowed to bring anything more than a small bag with you but we saw people in there with many large shopping bags and overnight bag (we had paid to store our luggage at Waterloo station so that we would not have to bring it in with us).
