We turned up a bit early for our booked tour time but the staff allowed us to join the next tour that was going which was great, saved us waiting around.A fantastic tour, excellent value, highly recommend (even interesting for people like me who aren't really all that intersted in politics but who would just like to have a nose around!)

Beautiful and picturesque. The Houses of Parliament, along with the iconic Big Ben, make up an amazing scene on the banks of the Thames River. The Houses are big - much larger than I had imagined. The views from the eastern side of the Thames is particularly good.

A wonderful experience with a guided , informative tour!. We booked a 9:15 tour one day and were guided with a group of 19 through the buildings.Our guide was witty, gave clear explanations and we both learned a lot. It's a wonderful way to learn more about their system of government and traditions.

Great to see because of the history...but. Outside of the building, not much to see unless there are protesters accross the street with a bull horn saying "follow the worms..." ok it was about budget cuts, but the irony was still there!

Once in a lifetime. The historic Houses of Parliament, or Westminster Palace, are only open during the summer recess, or perhaps on Saturdays throughout the year. If you're in London at any of those times then it's well worth a visit. Be prepared for surprises though as the we went on a Thursday morning when it was supposed to be open but there was some emergency MPs meeting so we had to go back the next day. £15 for adults so it's not cheap, but it's a once in a lifetime experience so go for it. There are of course concessions for students, OAPs etc. Get the tickets from the ticket office which is the white building further along from the entrance, over the road. Tours have established times and you have to get your tickets 20 mins before, as it will take you some time to get through security which is understandably tough. They also do foreign language tours, although these are less regular so check in advance if you want French or Italian etc.You get to see all the main parts - Westminster Hall (departure and arrival - thoe only place you can takes photos), the robing room which is used once a year when the monarch opens Parliament, House of Lords and House of Commons plus connecting rooms, corridors etc. Lords is of course much more ornate and interesting from an artistic point of view, but there's so much history attached to everything that in the end it's all interesting. Bad point: "modern" staue of M. Thatcher! We had a very good guide (Ian) - a history teacher type but very good at explaining everything and answering questions. It's pot luck, but I imagine they are all up to the same standard. Groups are of around 20 people and the tour takes about 75 mins. Warning: not much 'sitting down' time or even possibilities (do *not* sit on the Commons' benches!) - OK but some may find it tiring. Toilets and caffetteria acessible from Westminster Hall. Not cheap, but you're in the heart of London. Free souvenir badges and pencils!All in all a very interesting experience and vital for anyone whos interested in British history or indeed the beginnings of democracy in the modern sense.

Worth building into your schedule. This experience was amazing! The organisation from beginning to end was faultless. The tour Guides are obviously highly trained and knowledgable; one slight criticism would be that when my husband asked a question about Members wearing top hats, the guide was dismissive and made him feel uncomfortable. She was obviously not listening during this part of her course, as we subsequently received a very nice email from Westminster giving us the information we had asked for. Note to Guide: "Oh I am not too sure about that," would have been fine! Apart from that and sometimes that is all it takes to take the edge off an experience, the tour was well worth the money. It was fascinating seeing things normally seen only on tv, close at hand. Look for the dent caused by Black Rod's stick!

Not to be missed. Anyone visiting London and remotely interested in history would be a fool to miss this tour. Well worth the money, well organised and very imformative. We were advised to do this trip by friends who had visited London in August and said how interesting their guide had made the tour. This was certainly the case , as we passed other groups you certainly got the idea all the guides knew their stuff. Our guide Russell, however topped the lot, as well as all the historical facts and dates he made the tour extra enjoyable with funny lines he threw in from time to time. He did a tremendous job. The building itself is spectacular and now hearing parlimentary news makes more sense . I have certainly recomended family and friends do this tour on their next trip to London.

WOW. The House of Parliament tour (HoP) should be on everyones agenda if they have the opportunity to visit during the summer recess. Tickets can be purchased from an office nearby but we got ours through Ticketmaster the morning we decided to go. Glad we did as they had sold out on our arrival in London. No difference in price.Airport type security to get in so allow an extra 15 minutes before your allocated time. Groups of 25. You are taken through rooms that are absolutely beautiful and full of history. Amazing building. You hear about some of the history as well as how Parliament works. Was truly 'wowed' by the beauty of the building. Depending on your guide I guess depends on what you are told.Small cafe and toilet facilities are available just before you start/end your tour.

English History Brought to Life. We took the guided tour years ago, and were excited to return with our young son (8 years) this time. It was as great as we remembered, and our entire family was fascinated. The tour provides insight to not only the British government system, but art, architecture and a great history lesson as well. The Albert and Victoria stamp on the decoration in the newer parts of the complex is evident, and this is a great stop before you visit the Albert and Victoria Museum (also highly recommended). Our guide was extremely knowledgeable, and tours are offered in various languages. Don't miss it!
Very Interesting tour. If you get the chance definitely do the tour of the houses of parliament. 75 minutes and full of interesting facts. I'd recommend fully

Something everyone should do. My partner booked this up as a birthday gift. There's so much history wrapped up in this place that the whole visit is fascinating - our group size was just about okay (a mixture of Brits and tourists from overseas) - our guide was very knowledgeable and encouraged questions - of course we had to buy a bottle of "House of Commons Claret" from the shop which we're reliably informed is very good.Well worth a visit .

Went with mum in wheelchair - could not have been more helpful. This is my second tour of The Houses of Parliament but this time I took my mother who has to be in a wheelchair for any lengthy standing or walking about. The staff were very courteous and professional at all times. We had to take a different route from the main party on a couple of occasions but we missed nothing. The guide was informative and amusing and checked regularly with us to make sure my mother could see and hear everything. All in all a very enjoyable tour for all concerned.

Interesting tour, though the guide was stuffy and didn't answer questions. Coming from the USA, we are unfortunately not well educated on the workings of the Parliamentary government of our British cousins, thus we were really hoping to get a first hand lesson on the inner workings of Britain's parliament with this tour.Unfortunately, our guide was a bit stuffy, and was unwilling to answer many questions, particularly it seemed from the few American's in the group including ourselves. I'm not saying we didn't learn anything about the workings of Parliament, we certainly did, however, when we tried to supplement what the guide stated with some direct questions we were blown off.The chambers and buildings themselves, however, were beautiful and well worth seeing. If the guide would have been a bit friendlier I would have been given the tour 5 stars.

Not to be missed!. This was fantastic. A beautiful building with amazing works of art, including floor to ceiling groups of paintings, beautiful statues, marble columns, lots of gold plating, and of course, the atmosphere of the parliamentary houses, etc. The guide gave us accounts of the operations of the British parliament and what the various sections of the building are used for. The only suggestion I would make to improve the tour is to make it a bit longer and include more information regarding the architectural history. By the way you can't take photos here but there are books and postcards etc that you can purchase.

Just like you see it on TV. You have to book this in advance, and you'll still have to wait in line, but it's all very interesting, even for a non-Brit. We had a great tour guide who talked in detail about the antiquated means for passing laws in England. A week later, we toured the Parliament in Edinburgh which is light years ahead in technology, but the London Parliament is full of tradition and the yelling and rudeness you see on the telly is easy to imagine when you're standing in the chambers.

A wonderful, educational tour!. My friend and I actually toured Parliament in August of 2010. It was the last tour of the last day they did it for overseas visitors in the summer. Our tour guide was a lot of fun, and did a very good job of explaining the fascinating history of Parliament. Everything in that big building has a story! From the candlesticks, to the ceiling. It is too bad that you can't take pictures though. I wanted to photograph everything! I cannot recommend this tour higher!

very interesting. we visited the hoouses of parliment on the saturday morning pre booked on line to avoid the waiting. The guide was brilliant not rushed and gave lots of opportunities to ask questions.Spectacular inside the house of lords just a pity you are not allowed to take pictures apart from the entrance hall, house of commons a lot smaller than seems on tv.very interesting dont realise the full rules and guidelines that ahve to be met for the people who work within this fasinating building well worth a visit we would like to return so we can can go up big ben must be organised through local MP well inadvance of visit
Wow. I cannot praise this highly enough, the sense of history, the spectacular decoration of the building and the details pointed out by the guides make this unmissable!

Brilliant - can you do this in any other country?. Only booked the evening before and availability seemed good even then; but pre-booking of some sort is probably essential and I think tours are only available during parliamentary recess. Good value and thoroughly enjoyable. Tour lasts an hour although you need to arrive 15 minutes before start time and should allow 2 hours overall from arrival to departure. Takes you onto the floor of both houses and through many other interesting rooms. Guides extremely knowledgeable. A very upbeat and informative experience. You don't need to be a political or history buff - just interested in what makes the world tick.

This is one of the Greats. We pre-booked our tour online and walked straight in without queuing after first going through an airport style security check. As we were a little early we waited in Wesminster Hall and read the information on this amazingly old building. An official then approached us and invited us to go on a slightly earlier tour and our group of about a dozen or so listened while our tour guide, a pleasant and well spoken lady, introduced herself and the building. We then followed her through to each area where she got us into a tight group and gave us lots of information pertaining to that particular place. As well as the robing Room, we also visited the House of Commons and House of Lords and all the interesting and relevant features were pointed out to us. We saw all the well know and some of the not so well known areas in this tour lasting about 75 minutes, and even shook hands with one of the Lords who happened to be there and came over and introduced himself. Finally, our guide took us back to Westminster Hall where she wished us well and said we could go back to the shop if we wished. This is a hugely interesting and informative tour for an extremely reasonable price. Don't miss it.

Outstanding. This is a must-see. So exciting to get into the debating chambers and hear so many pieces of info from the excellent guide. Our tour was slightly marred by the presence of several precocious children who had evidently been enouraged to ask questions: unfortunately these questions were rarely relevant and only disrupted the guide's flow. However, she handled this well and the experience was well worth the £15. Also there is a cafe which has excellent cake! Excellent afternoon out: compelling stuff.

Absolute Must when in London! Nearly Perfect.. Pros:1. Tour guides are exceedingly knowledgeable2. The history of the building is almost staggering. You can stand on the spot that Thomas More was condemned, or when Queen Elizabeth received her jubilees.3. The guides teach you how Parliament works, which is very interesting. They even include the little details, like why their is a small damaged sport on the door to the House of Commons.4. 90 minutes, which is the perfect length for a walking tour, allowing you to take advantage of the other nearby attractions.Cons:1. The pros outweigh the cons, hence the 5 stars, but if you are American, you will notice the con even more. Americans are used to their public buildings have free tours (The Capitol Building for example). The Houses of Parliament cost a staggering 15 GBP (approximately $25), which is expensive. However, because of the extreme high quality of the tour, this con does not take away the fifth star.

Unexpectedly enjoyable. Well worth doing.. I booked the houses of parliament summer tour to fill a couple of hours in London prior to a theatre trip and enjoyed it more than the play !The whole thing took about an hour and a quarter and the knowledgeable guide was working the whole time. Highlights were the Tudor and Stuart portraits , the over the top opulance of the robing room, statues of former alpha prime ministers and of course the house of Lords and commons.It doesn't come cheap at £15 each and it can sometimes grate that it's a tour and you can't just wander about at will but overall I thought it was great value for money and well worth doing. If you are at all interested in government or history you'll love this-oh and there were a few snippets of gossip too.

Walking Through History with a Guide. We hadn't planned on going through the Houses of Parliament. It just happened to be open for tours when we walked by and we took the opportunity to see it. It was fabulous. The guide was telling us who and when and the kings and queens, prime ministers, and so many stories about the great halls, the actual place where Parliament meets (we were not allowed to sit down!). It was really a great tour. Took about an hour and was something I won't forget soon. Only open on Saturday's the sign said. Well worth the pounds sterling to see it.

Surpassed All Expectations. This really is a must see for anyone visiting London. My wife is no fan of politics however she really enjoyed this tour. Parliament is surprising very beautiful inside with some exquisite rooms and works of art that will delight you. The House of Commons is much small than it looks on TV and it's no wonder that it's standing room only some times. Our guide was very entertaining and the hour or so that we were there went very quickly. Worth every penny.

WOW. Do MPs have the priviledge to walk through these gorgeous chambers every day just to go to work? Amazing.. I was really impressed by the beauty of some of the rooms. The grandiosity of the paintings and structures is really stunning.. And house of commons is so much smaller than what it appears on TV!!!I learnt a few more things than what I already knew about the parliament from our guide, however I would say that the tour was too rushed as well as been disturbed by all the other groups moving around us. The tours could be much better organised, I think. Also, if you book the tickets online, you could find it hard to understand where to collect and where to go to enter the Parliament itself. There are not many indications. Remarkable visit, but the overall organisation needs quite a lot of improving.

Brilliant pice of our history. Booked the tour over the internet and so walked straight in even though we went on a busy Saturday afternoon, we did this 75 minute tour last weekend and had Caroline as our guide, both the tour and Caroline were great and very informative.Both the houses - Lords and Commons - are beautiful but far smaller than they appear on television.I would rate this as by far the most interesting tour that we have done - do not miss the chance to go when you are in London.

Intresting but long. The guide inside are very long.it takes 1.5 hour to go throgh all the place and you can't seat every where you want to (only on the green chairs and not all of them)also its much more intresting for people who live not in a democratic country, since the parliaments around the world are a bit the same.

Very interesting tour. Wow, this was the biggest surprise out of all the attractions we visited in London. Well worth the £15.00 fee!!All very organised, no waiting around. After the strictest security ever, which included having your photo taken, we made in our in way into Westminster hall, the oldest part of the palace. Amazing setting! So full of history. Like something from Hogwarts.Our guide was a guy called Noel - who was 84(!) but he didn't look it. He made the whole experience. Very funny, engaging and told us stories about what happens in each room and when he met Churchill.The whole thing lasts about 1 1/2 hours but seemed to go much quicker. On the whole a fantastic experience - but amazingly we were the only English people there, in out our parliment! Crazy. More english people need to visit.

worth the wait. I was doubtful about the tour when I saw the queue. However, the groups were broken down to about 25 people and the wait was about half an hour. The setting, exterior and interior are incredible and so are the stories. It gave me a much better understanding of all the UK and everything I saw afterwards. Our tour included one visitor in a wheelchair and , although he had to take alternate routes, they were prepared for this and it was do-able.

A MUST! - Very Interesting!!. Well worth the £15 entrance fee! Advise you book your visit time before you arrive to save time.I would recommend this place to anyone. It's a lottery who your guide is, but unfortunately for us we had quite a soft spoken woman who was drowned out at times by other guides standing close by. At these times it was hard not to concentrate on our guide and let your attention travel to the other guides.It's very much a 'whistle stop tour' and the guides are against the clock as there are loads of tours also happening at the same time as your guide.

Just to say you've been there.... It is one of those places you go to in order to say you've been there. The next time you see the House of Commons debating, you'll see the chairs you stood by. Kind of cool to know that. The guides really know their history. Also interesting to learn differences between House of Commons and Lords, if you didn't know. House of Lords membership can be passed down by vs. Commons. Also, learn about process during voting, debates, and when the queen is there.The place is massive, you get a sense from walking through the sections they take you through. Not sure if kids would like it, epsecially little ones.After buying your tickets, give yourself 1/2 hour to get through security. Seemed to me that you have timed tickets, but when you get in they just put you on first line till it fills up to about 25 people and they take you all up. So if you are running late or stuck in security, you should be OK as it doesn't seem like they are sticklers. But to get on time you planned on, best to do the 1/2 hour advance. When I bought ticket they said 15 minutes but it took me over 20 to get in.Also, no photos inside except for very first hall they take you in. You can't sit for a lot of the tour. Occassionaly there are spots where you can sit, they will tell you.

Absolutely brilliant!. This is one of the best tours I have done in London. The tour guide is extremely knowledgable and explains everything in great detail. It is well organised and executed, Well worth a visit and I have recommended to many people. I particularly liked the ante-chamber with the statues of past Primeministers in cluding a fearsome statue of Maggie Thatcher - complete with handbag!

Fantastic history - but you can't sit down for over an Hour!. We had great guide. Brought the history of the place to life. Very interesting. Explained lots of the traditions of the place.The tour lasted over an hour and some of the group were old and frail. You were not allowed to sit where the MP's or Lords sit.Given the "expenses scandals" you would think these low down bums would let you bum go low! Canteen was reasonably priced and good quality stuff. The gift shop had limited goods but was reasonably priced.Book your ticket over the internet to save disappointment.

Totally stunning surroundings!. We went here after reading the excellent reviews from this site and I must say I agree it is a place not to be missed.We went to the booking office for about 10.30am got tickets went straight in, was searched for security reasons then sent straight through to the magnificent Westminster Hall whereupon we met our Guide and set off once we had twenty people in the group.The guide was very informative and clearly loved the job.The tour lasted 75 minutes, we weren't allowed to sit on certain seats but there were some opportunities to sit down for a few minutes. We paid £15.00 each to get in but it was worth it!

Great day out and very informative. Worth booking in advance as it was quite busy also arrive at least 30 mins before tour time as The Great Hall where the tour begins has lots to see and read, look out for the plaques on the floor.

Definately a must. Pre-purchased tickets for our visit here on a late Thursday afternoon. Entry was no problem and there were no queues. The quoted tour provided was quite extensive and lots of great information and stories was provided. The palace is a beautiful building and well worth a visit in itself even if you aren't interested in parliament. Being able to enter both the lords and the commons was a great experience.

Pretty easy to get into. Came on a late afternoon and it was in session. After clearing security, I got a badge to go into House of Lords, opposite the House of Commons. Pretty neat building. Sadly you can't take pictures inside the chamber, it's quite beautiful. They seem much more orderly than the House of Commons, especially when the Prime Minister comes in to answer questions. Nice and free and you get to see how the British government works.

Beautiful place - full of history. Went on a work related trip but had plenty of time to observe some cermony & tradition with the black rod. Went to the Members restaurant which was fantastic - worth a visit to say you have been there - but no great desire to go back -

I loved it, not so much my teen. Having worked at the US Senate and toured the Israeli Knesset, I was fascinated with the similarities and differences at the UK Parliament. So ornate, and formal! Really interesting, particularly as we then tuned in a few days later and recognized the chamber. Tremendous for a history buff like me. Good guide, but we were the last tour of the day, so were a bit rushed. One caveat: my 15 yo daughter, however, was not nearly as impressed as her father and I were. When asked later what she liked least about our whole 2.5 week trip, this was it!
Worth a long wait to observe the houses of Lords or Commons. The wait and security are bothersome, but once you get into the chamber, it is worth it.

A lection of history and democracy. If you are traveling to London you shouldn't miss a visit to the Houses of Parliament. There are only guided tours and there are several security check points as this building is still used to house parliament debates but it is worth the time and money. We had a very funny guide, packed with interesting information about history and up to date facts in the British legislative body. We have learned a lot about the architecture and history of this building and also about the way things actually work in the House of Lords and the House of Commons.

Outstanding tour!. My daughter and I booked a tour of the Houses of Parliament through the ticketmaster link on their web site. It was pouring down rain the day of our tour. We stood outside for around 45 minutes for a tour that was suppose to start at 12 noon but it took quite a while to get into the building and through security. We finally got inside at 12:30. We were there for of course the English tour and we didn't wait long once inside. I have to say that it was so worth waiting in the rain. It is absolutely gorgeous on the inside. It was so interesting to hear about the workings of their government and the history behind it. My 18 year old daughter found this tour so fascinating and this was our 8th day in London and had visited so many places. I highly recommend this tour!

Excellent tour. I booked this tour because of tips on the TALF forum, and I wasn't dissapointed. As I'm not from the UK I went on saturday, and on ticketmaster I selected the 09.15 tour. As mentioned on the ticket I arrived about 20 minutes early and I waited in line to go through security, my bag was checked, I went through one of those airport type gates and I also had my picture taken which I had to hang on a lanyard.After that onto the great hall for the start of the tour, and since I was solo I was able to join a group nearly starting. I had missed the introduction though and as we walked swiftly through a lot of beautifully decorated rooms I wondered why we didn't stop, but we just walked to the end and started there.What a wonderful tour through some amazing rooms, where I wondered where there was a centimeter of room left that wasn't decorated. We learned about the houses themselves, how the Queen goes about the opening of parliament every year, how the house of lords/commons works(I particually loved the voting), and why there are curtains about knee high in the public gallery in the house of lords....Added to that I loved that we where in the rooms that you've seen on tv so many times(even though we weren't allowed to sit down). It seemed very busy, often there where 4 groups in one room but our guide was excellent and it was never hard to hear him.Overall excellent experience and I would throuroughly recommend.

Free Tour. I recently took my parents here who were visiting from New Zealand. If you are a uk citizen this tour is free, all you have to do is write a letter to your MP addressed to the Houses of Parliament requesting what dates you require. I had a phone call confirming the visit within 2 days of sending my letter with the official invite arriving by post shortly after. A quick search on the internet will find your MP and his parliamentary address.

Very interesting and informative. The tour was very informative, and as a Canadian I found it really interesting to think about the similarities between our parliamentary system and that of Britain. The buildings are beautiful both inside and out, and are absolutely worth a trip. The only downside I can think of is the price - 10 pounds for a student ticket is a bit much. I see that some other reviewers were frustrated with having to go through security, but this is Parliament, after all, and security is to be expected. It's worth it to go through a few minutes of hassle to have a couple of hours inside these amazing buildings.

Security was irritating.. We visited the Houses of Parliament in early June. This wasn't scheduled in advance, it was just something extra to cram in on our last day in London. We got to watch a few speakers in the House of Lords, which wasn't very interesting as there wasn't much attendance on a Friday afternoon. Security to get in was irritating, and seeing this place wasn't worth the hassle. It was airport-type security, but in addition to the usual procedures I was also patted down, which I am getting sick of while traveling. Not only that, but to enter the viewing gallery we had to hand over all our possessions, including my handbag, which had all our money in it plus our passports and digital camera and new cell phone. No lockers were provided with secure padlocks; our belongings were stored in open shelves with dividers, and we were handed a number to retrieve our belongings when leaving. I didn't like this at all and it made me very nervous that our money and other items could be stolen, so we didn't watch the speakers in the House very long as I don't like my personal belongings being left with strangers. When we went to retrieve our things, there was no one at the desk and it took a while for someone to get back there to hand us our things. Anyone could have walked up and stolen our items and the belongings of others. So be warned, since no one else on the first page of reviews has mentioned it, that they will demand everything you are carrying, no matter how personal. If I had known that beforehand, I would have made preparations for it, or skipped this place altogether.

Absolutely schedule this tour if you can- very informative. Take one of the scheduled, reserved tours of Parliament (usually Saturday) if at all possible! You need to arrive 20-30 mins before your appointment to go through security, then you are put in relatively small groups (20 or so) for a tour that takes you on the parade route the queen takes for the opening day of parliament, through the Houses of Lords and Commons, and ends in the very old very beautiful Westminster Hall. All the buildings are just gorgeous, and lots of historic frescoes and paintings. You won't see this part by just sitting in on a debate.Our guide was an older man who was well-spoken, humorous, and gave us a very good overview of the British Parliamentary System, what is lobbying, how the vote works, etc. This was one of the highlights of our trip.

Great Building, Great Tour. I highly recommnend this 75 min. tour of the Houses of Parliament. Our tour guide was great, mixing in the political aspects of the building alond with its history, architecture and traditions. The artwork in many of the rooms is amazing! Included are the Queen's dressing room (where she readies herself prior to the first seesion of the year), the House of Lords and House of Commons. The tour groups are fairly samll, maybe 20 or so people so it is not difficult to hear the tour guide. Even our teenage daughter and her friend enjoyed this tour.

Really interesting. being a taxpayer I was a bit miffed at having to pay for a tour round my own seat of Government but after this very interesting tour I can say it was worth every penny, The guide was very informative and answered all questions and I learned a lot about how my government works.i would recommend this tour to anyone interested in history or politics,

Humbling. Blue Badge guides do an incredible job touring groups through the Houses of Parliament. They probably give the tour 6 times a day, but our guide was informative, friendly and interested in the topic. I appreciated that our tour was a nice mix of information - a bit architectural, a bit on the ritual, a bit on the legislative, a bit of behind-the-scenes stories, and a bit on current affairs. Our lesson learned was that if you have an early tour time (ours was 9:15), don't plan on grabbing breakfast/coffee close-by before your tour. By luck we ended up finding a cafeteria in a Methodist church across from Westminster Abbey. Or, there's a cafeteria once you're in past security.

My favorite thing in London. The houses of parliament are not only beautiful on the outside but the inside is spectacular as well. I highly recommend taking one of the guided tours they have every Saturday. The tour guide was knowledgeable and touched on this history of the building site and buildings, how the government functions there and some of the inside decoration.. I purchased my ticket online on ticketmaster but you can also purchase tickets that day!

Unforgettable experience - to stand where history happens everyday. Even in America, we see TV shots of the lords and MPs debating, so to actually walk around in the rooms where these debates take place was thrilling! Our tour guide based her tour on the annual opening of Parliament when the Queen visits and led us from the robing room through the various chambers, describing the events and the history behind them. It was fascinating. Being from overseas, we were limited to a Saturday visit, and we booked well in advance.

Not to be missed. Open Saturdays all year round plus daily in summer, a tour of The Palace of Westminster is essential. There's no self-touring on here; the ticket price includes a walking tour and it's worth every penny. A thousand years of history brought alive by knowledgeable guides. Stand right among the benches in both chambers and come within inches of the Throne. Many, many fascinating facts and objects. Not to be missed.

A beautiful building - well worth a visit!. The tour of the Houses of Parliament was the highlight of my London visit. Each room is sumptious and full of splendour. The excellent guide gave us a real insight into the running of the establishment and a wealth of information about its history. Do book a tour - you won't be disappointed!

Hot late night action - at Parliament. Monday night in London is kind of a bore-- the good theaters are dark, there are no shops open and the bars are... full of the kind of folks who hang out in bars on Monday nights. But the lights are on at Westminster Palace--and that's not just for making it look pretty at night. The MPs are putting on an after hours show in there, and though their debate isn't exactly mud wrestling, they're still slinging barbs across the room at the opposing party. The seating gallery in the House of Commons is an architectural wonder by itself, fashioning a fascinating fishbowl out one of the world's most recognizable meeting rooms by slicing right through the wood paneling and green leather benches with a glass wall. On the other hand, visiting the House of Lords is almost quaint and kitschy-- modernism completely missed the "Strangers Gallery," but in place of glass and steel, you get gold lea, heraldry and statuary everywhere. It's surreal just how much it is just what was in your imagination-- but even more so. But more impressive is how late the MPs and Lords go-- at least till 10 pm. By then, you still have time to go see what happens in the bars.

Amazing!!. This was the highlight of our trip! It was so non-touristy and it was fasinating to see the inner works of the parliament! Locals were there moreso then tourists and we had great seats to watch from above! Highly recommendable!!

Brilliant.Exceeded expectations. Having read the mostly enthusiastic reviews on this site I was really looking forward to visiting the Houses of Parliament but it exceeded all expectations and I can't recommend it highly enough. We hardly waited (with prebooked tickets) and saw far more than I expected. The guide was interesting and informative with just the right amount of information. It's definitely a must see.

Tours all year. Until recently, tours of Parliament were offered only in the summer. Now they're available in the off-season, on Saturday. Make time to join one, they run throughout the day. Skip the overrated Ripper-industry tours -- "Jack" was Francis Tumulty, an American sexual psychopath. This tour has it all: history, majestic beauty, grand architecture, an opportunity to explore the rooms and corridors from which Britain once held sway over vast swaths of the earth's surface. I took the tour in January; it lasted about 75 minutes. The guide was very knowledgeable and quite happy to answer questions. The regular adult admission fee was 15 pounds; as a 65+ senior I paid 10. There is a small gift shop available at the end of the tour, selling mementos at generally reasonable prices.

British history. I wanted to visit Hourses of Parliament for long time but didn't have opportunity. So during my trip to London I decide to go and see this famous histrical site. I bought tickets online at ticketmaster. I like an tour very much, House of Lords, House of Commons, Westminster Hall everything is very impressive and intersting. And especially is atmosphere.

thoroughly enjoyable. Having been to London numerous times and never visiting the Houses of Parliament, this was an exciting new experience in London for me. I was with a big group of friends and someone had already prearranged the tickets for us. I really enjoyed myself and seeing what you see on the TV and being able to sit there too was an experience in itself.There is a lot of security to get through but it is definately worth it!

Well Worth £14 and 70 Minutes of Your Time!. My wife was less than delighted when I told her I had booked a tour of the Houses of Parliament during our city break to London. However, she was pleasantly surpised and thoroughly enjoyed it - the tour included : eloquent & well informed tour guide (only 12 of us in the party), walking through the corridors of power, standing in the Queen's dressing room, walking through the House of Lords' debating chamber, standing next to the P.M.s lectern etc.

A Must See. I had always wanted to do a tour of the Houses of Parliament but I was never there during summer opening. I bought and printed my ticket on Ticketmaster for £14.00 (no booking fee). I went on the 9.30am tour and it was less crowded then. I had to go though security before I got to Westminster Hall where the tour commenced. Westminster Hall is very impressive and this is where heads of state and the royal family lie in state after they have died. They have brass plaques on the ground identifying where they lay. This hall also survived the Great Fire of London. This is the only room that you are permitted to take photographs in. Our guide was Harri and I really enjoyed his tour – the tour was 75 minutes but it never felt rushed and you could ask as many questions as you liked. We were brought to the room where the Queen prepares to open government sessions each November and shown the route she takes to the House of Lords. The House of Lord is impressive also with its red leather seats and paintings. We were not allowed to sit down in here – apparently only elected or invited representatives are permitted to sit down here! We were brought to Central Lobby and then onto the House of Commons with it’s green leather seats and it was explained to us how voting takes place and told where the leaders sit. It’s amazing to think the amount of history that has passed through this building. A lot of the stained glass windows are not the original ones – they were blown out during World War 2. All in all I really enjoyed the tour. It was very interesting and informative. The interior is just as spectacular as the exterior and I would definitely do this tour again. It’s a must see for anyone visiting London.

Brilliant visit. The visit takes in the Commons and the Lords chambers and the guide, Leonie, was excellent with her knowledge, humour and clarity. Allow about 2 hours for queueing (with prepaid ticket) and the tour. There are toilets available before and after the tour but not during.

A superb tour, a must see palce.. We have always watched the proceedings inside the house on TV and wanted to see inside the palace for ourselves, so we booked our tickets through the house of commons website and then made it part of our weekend break. It is absolutely fantastic. We had a great guide and the ornate decoration has to be seen to be believed. The highlight for me though was being in the house of commons chamber with its famous green leather benches. A must for anybody interested in history and pollitics.
One of the best things to visit. We had a great time! Besides the Opera House that we went to, this was the best attraction. The building is full of history. We had a great time on the tour.

Give it a go. If you are ever in London you should definately take the time and visit the Houses of Parliament. It's even better if there are some good talks going on. You may feel a bit bored and want to fall asleep but even if you can do just half an hour that's good enough to see how British law and politics is conducted.

Not worth as much time as it can take. I'm clearly in the minority here, but I'd advise most travelers against a visit to the Houses of Parliament, unless they can get in without waiting.Yes, the Palace of Westminster ranks among the world's most iconic buildings, but the outside is far cooler than the inside. (The House of Lords looks elegant enough, but the House of Commons actually borders on shabby.)Watching Parliament in action seems like it should be fascinating, but unless you can score a seat at Prime Minister's Question (and you can't) the proceedings are dull as dishwater.You'll get into the Commons, steeped in veneration for this cradle of democracy, and rather than seeing a full chamber in full throated debate over something cool, you see five guys reading speeches about parking meters in York onto the record. This quickly grows tiresome.That said, it's worth a look if you can get in without waiting, which is very possible at off hours. I've strolled right into evening sessions in the winter months. But it's certainly not worth standing in line for many hours to witness. Do you really care about those parking meters in York?

Gorgeous and definitely worth the visit!. I didn't plan on taking a tour of the Houses of Parliament, and it was a sort of spur-of-the-moment decision that I made upon actually seeing the beautiful facade of the building, and I am extremely glad that I took the tour! I can't say my tour guide was very informative - I managed to pick up a few scrambled facts about the building and the parliament - but I might chalk that up to the fact that it was a large tour and it was hard to hear with a few screaming toddlers in our herd. It might also have been the whole British accent thing. It was still very cool to be able to an important governmental building and be able to sit in the same chairs that representatives sit in, etc. The building itself is absolutely grand. I honestly thought it was much older than 19th century, perhaps medieval, but that just shows what I know about London history I guess! :)I grew up in St. Petersburg, which has a lot of impressive palaces with gilded walls and tons of sparkliness, but I honestly loved the Parliament house more. It has a very refined interior - Victoria's husband sure did know how to decorate. The food in their cafeteria isn't half bad either!

Learn about British history, government and current affairs. The guided tour helped pull together historical aspects we gathered from several other tours in London. This was a great history lesson! The tour follows the path used by the Queen when she opens Parliament each November.

certainly worth a visit. The guides are enthusiastic and interesting. There are a lot of tours all going at the same time however this was not a issue. Be prepared to be on your feet for 2 to 3 hours to take in the interesting history these awesome buildings hold. Security is high,however this is only to be expected. You will take a journey through the history of monarchs and politicians, the tour at times is extremely amusing of stories of pomp and ceremony of centuries past!!! I could not help but touch the stone walls as you can feel the history within them.The gift shop at the end of the tour (the English do this so well!!!!!) has some interesting items to purchase , well worth a nose around.I would not recommend this attraction for children under the age of 12. They would just not get the history.

Take a step into history.... If you are in London in August or September, be sure to put the Houses of Parliament on your list of things to see. There is a lot of security to get through-we had our ticket checked 6 times- and were also given a security pass to wear. If you like history and learning about the government it is a must see. The Houses of Parliament used to be a castle and some of the rooms are gorgeous- pay attention to the Queens Robing Room.

Excellent Value. The tour is extremely well organized and guided. There are many tours going at once. We had a great guide and the stories, history and traditions are well worth the price of admission. People with young children should not go on the tour. We had a two year old that was very disruptive. It can be hard to hear because of the multiple tour groups.

Impressive building but..... The building won't disappoint. However, maybe it's to do with trying to herd a group of people around a high security building but some blue badges (official guides) can be a bit officious. Makes it a bit like a school tour......"oh do keep up Jenkins!"....you know what I mean.

A walk through history worth taking a second tour. Early last summer, I met a gal I'd only known online to take a tour of the Houses. She was more than interested as she was British. Even as an American, I loved it because I enjoy English history.Yes, security is heavy and no picture taking, so possibly plan on leaving your camera with the guard and any other electronic items. Or better yet, leave them in your room. Check the websites. But it's worth it. I bought my ticket online before I left and walked over from my hotel. And took my picture outside after I got my camera back. The other pictures of the Parliament buildings were taken in May 2005 when I walked in the area following a river cruise.Our guide was very knowledgeable and also acquainted us with the rules of the tour, what to expect - such as little to no sitting with certain exceptions. As one of the reviewers said,the first tour of the morning or the first in the afternoon is a good time. I also had tickets for the Royal Mews and the State Rooms. I learned later, it's necessary to schedule the royal tours on the same day and the tour of the Houses separately.I would like to take the tour again. And after reading some of the reviews, I know I would enjoy sitting in the galleries to hear the live action.Summer tours are only possible when the Houses are not in session and the Queen is in Scotland. Usually a period within August to September. As every reviewer has commented, it's a great experience for older children.It's one of those things you must do at least once.

Well Worth the Time!!. I really enjoyed my short visit to Parliament. I have a huge interest in history, so that probably explains my excitment about visiting the Houses of Parliament. I would recommend taking the guided tour, it was very interesting. I posted a photo and some more details on my visit on my travel blog if you're interested to read more at: http://adams-travel-blog.blogspot.com/2009/07/london-3.html

Great Cultural Experience. We were able to watch MP's debate some interesting issues during our visit. If you have an interest in international politics, this is a great place to visit. It is also an affordable way to rest your feet while getting a great cultural experience. You can stay for as long or as little as you want which is pretty cool since you can make it fit your own schedule. I went in January so there wasn't a wait. Not sure what it would be like at other times of year.

A definite must-see!. As a Canadian, I'm not new to Parliament buildings. But the British Parliament buildings are a sight to behold. While buying a tour pass is not exactly inexpensive, it is definitely worth your money and time. The tour guides give great tours and the buildings are beautiful both inside and outside. Security is very tight, but that's understandable these days. Definitely a must-see!

Well worth a visit. I was able to access Parliament during a Monday night session as part of a "London Walks" tour of the surrounding area. Our small group sat in on a session of the House of Lords while they debated an obscure welfare bill. (Everyone fell asleep just like in American politics;) We were allowed to stay as long as we wanted and politely ushered in and out at our request.I would strongly suggest access via this evening tour for anyone interested in politics or world events. We were also given an explanation of the buliding of the Houses of Parliament in full view from across the river; an iconic London sight if there ever was one.

Worth a visit!. We arranged passes thorough our MP before we travelled. Our tour was slightly shorter than usual due to Prime Minister's Question Time and we could not enter the Commons, but the tour was interesting and the guide was very knowledgeable. The architecture was fabulous - particularly the House of Lords. We were able to access the public gallery and listen to the debate after PM Q's. Tea/coffee is reasonably priced in the Jubilee Cafe.Thoroughly enjoyable even for those in our party not particularly interested in politics.

Great Tour if You're able to see during Summer Break. Toured in September, 2008. Since I'm not from the UK, to see Parliament I needed to go on the group tour and I'm glad I did because it was excellent. You get tickets from the Jewel Tower building (I believe that's its name) located across the street from Parliament(on Westminster Abbey side). There's a Parliament sign. There is a small fee (not included in a London pass card if you have). I believe these tours are only open to international visitors in the months of August and September.Parliament is located on the Thames River and is a huge gothic styled complex of buildings and the base of the British legislative body. The tour of Parliament was about 90 minutes long. You see rooms affiliated with the House of Lords as well as the House of Commons. The British Parliament is divided into these two houses with a third being that of the British Monarch who still plays a significant role. The House of Commons is elected by the people while the House of Lords retains British history somewhat by being made up of British religious leaders and appointments due to the heredity of British titles. Our tour guide (Hugh) was very good and had a great sense of humor about British history, politics and royalty. We were not allowed to take photos inside Parliament except for the Westminster Hall which is all that is remaining from the original Parliament building which was devastated by the London fire. The Hall has an incredible wood roof that is the largest in northern Europe. This is also the Hall where most heads of state and royalty lie after their passing. Parliament was also hit during World War II and extensive renovations had to be conducted as a result but Westminster Hall remained somewhat untouched overall. During the tour, we saw the rooms were the Queen prepares to open each session. She has a ceremonial role in opening sessions and no bill becomes law without her signature. However, it is purely a ceremonial role at this point of history. This is explained on the tour. We also saw the small rooms where the House of Commons and the House of Lords meet. If you’ve ever watched PBS, you will know what I’m talking about. Those rooms where they are crammed in on top of each other arguing and debating. The Brits like it to be close because they feel it leads to better interaction and debate. There are also viewing platforms located above the rooms for the general public if they want to watch the debate live. Our tour was one dazzling room after another with the Lords side being a bit more royal looking with painted and guilded ceilings and the Commons side being a bit more “plain” with heavy use of wood paneling and single color ceilings. Both very pretty but in completely different ways. The House of Lords side is heavy in the color of red while the Commons side is heavy in the use of green. Both have their own meeting rooms. The Lords side meeting room has a number of portraits of former British kings and queens while the Commons side has statues of Winston Churchill, Margaret Thatcher, etc. You can see pictures (that I couldn’t take) at: http://www.parliament.uk/about/images/interior.cfmParliament is also home of the famous Big Ben. It also has some nice grounds which are open to the public and run along the Thames River. It was a very informative tour and I’m so glad I was able to do.

Stunning Place. Just back from a weekend away in London and have to say that one of the highlights was a visit to the house of Parliament.To arrange a visit you contact your local MP who will set it up for you. You received a permit throught the post allowing you entry which is free.After going though security you are allocated a tour guide who takes you around the various rooms. Once inside the building can only be described as stunning. Our tour guide was brilliant, very funny and had lots of history to tell us about the place. You are also taken into the houses of commons and Lords which was amazing to see. The tour takes around an hour and afterwards there is a little shop to buy merchandise and a well priced cafe.If your going to London do yourself a favour and arrange this trip in advance. It is well worth it. Even better if you go on a wednesday and can get into see Prime ministers questions.

I like politics, world issues, democracy & accidentally bumping into free stuff. ... so the HP was great.The main hall is an architecturally interesting building with a number of brass plaques noting historically significant events.We arrived early enough to witness the entry of the Speaker to the Commons which had some drama. The session was questions on notice to the Ministers responsible for Defence related Departments and covered some topical.A great afternoon. Well worth your effort.
